Well known by its background in the film, Tomb Raider, thus temple shows how the force of nature will always win.Structures have survived yet encompassed by the various sponge trees.Take in this place. Go early to avoid disappointment and beat the crowds (especially the coach loads from China a d Thailand.)Take a closer look at the Chambers here and see why there are holes in certain stones; jewels were adorned in the central chamber to mark Royalty and to mark the centre of this magnificent temple.
Breathtaking!. The most popular place for taking the photos, really magical. The best time is to go in the morning because of the temperature and crowds.

Trees growing through temples, magocal. Another great temple left us speechless. The fact that you can get so close and climb around is wonderful if psychologically I struggled with the longer term effects.A few vendors outside selling usual merchandise.
You have to see it . The legendary tomb raider temple !The tree are just completely crazy !!Don't forget to bring water and a good guide with you !Enjoy ;)

Sightseeing I'm the temples. Beautiful place. So we'll preserved With a lot of history and beauty to be seen by all.Our tour guide ( Hann) knew a lot of the history that temple had. Hann was an great guy as a tour guide and person Me, my husband and my teen daughter enjoyed hiking in the temples and see the work that was preserved for so, so, many years. I really that a lot of things they did back in there years are still happening today just not so cruel.

Amazing. A real gem in the temple area. The trees have grown into building and tells the story of an abandoned city. To walk among the ruins and see how nature has formed this temple area is a unique experience!
Tomb rider in real life. Simple review. You must go here, buy yourself a day pass and check out all the temples. Be warned that there are several tourist and maybe hard to get a selfie

Eerie and amazing. Ta Prohm (Tomb Raider Temple) was one of my favorite stops on our tour of temples around Siem Reap, Cambodia. It's one of the temples that has been overgrown by the jungle, giving it an haunting, but at the same time beautiful, feel. Very, very cool...

My fav. This is what I like to see, when Mother Nature claims back what's hers. I couldn't get enough of this temple and all the trees roots, some of them looked like they had melted over the top and down the sides of the walls. Amazing indeed! I will be back with my fiancé to spend more time here.

Far and away the best photo spot in the Angkor Wat temple complex. We saved this one for last, and our guid, Da Mao, took us around the temple and showed us all the very best spots for pictures. It really paid off- of all my Angkor Wat photos, the most astonishing and dramatic ones are definitely the ones from Ta Prohm. There's just something about the trees.These trees have been here for ages, creeping and growing up and over the ancient temples. It's an amazing looking area- giant trees looming over tall buildings, as if the jungle has crept in and is eating up the temple. We were told that many of the Angkor temples used to look basically like this, and that the trees and plants were cleared out and buildings restored over many decades. Ta Prohm is one of the few left of the major temple areas which still has many strangler figs and other invasive trees that prominently cover many areas of the temple, walls, buildings, gates, and stonework.At this point, taking them down would destabilize many of the buildings on which they grow, so the policy of the people who run the temples is to leave them for now- and in some cases even to prop them up. Then, once they do ultimately collapse, the dead tree will be taken away and the rocks will be restored in the area where the tree was. You can see this in one or two places around Ta Prohm, which my guide pointed out to us.The ancient carvings are interesting, too. They aren't as detailed and well-preserved as the ones at Banteay Srei, and they weren't as monumental in most cases as the heads at Bayan, but there were some beautiful ones here, too.Overall, it's a fantastic place to visit. We were advised to try to see it in the early morning, but the rain at about 7 am that day made our guide decide to reschedule it for mid-afternoon. By about 2 or 3 pm, the buses of tourists may have diminished a bit, and it won't be quite so crowded. Even so, it was definitely one of the busiest temples we saw. Easy to see why, though- the aching beauty and destructive power of the clinging trees is just so creepy and so otherworldly, and yet at the same time, lovely. It's a unique sight to see. I've never seen anything quite like it anywhere else in all the world.Do NOT MISS Ta Prohm if you are anywhere near the Angkor Wat area. Stop and see it even if you have to choose between this and the main Angkor Wat temple, which is huge and wonderful, too, but maybe not quite as unique.

Very interesting old place - huge tree. This is the temple that is older than the Angkor Wat and one of the most visited attractions in the Angkor Archeological Park primarily famous for the reason that the movie Tomb Raider was shot there. But well worth a visit to see how the roots of the old tree have grown. Generally done as a tour of the trio that is Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm. VIsit this place in the morning when tour groups are at Angkor Wat. You can see this place in about 1 hour as as usual wear good footwear
WOW. I can see why Tomb Raider chose this for their location, it is a fascinating place, simply majestic :)

The Tomb Rider's Tomb, yet not that adventurous! . Was told that this is the Tomb Rider's cave due to the movie was shoot here, and to be amazed with it, the trees are so huge!!!!!!! I've never seen such huge trees before, and when you think the tree ia just normal tree, no it isnt, the tree grew on top of the tomb! That makes this area so special.But due to the weight of the tree on top of the tomb, some of the area is closed. If you doesnt have a tour guide, please follow those with group or else you will lost your way out.

You're Kidding, Right? Of Course You Should Go!. C'mon. This is the Tomb Raider temple. Why would you even wonder if you should visit it? This was the last temple I visited on my 1-day tour of Angkor. It. Was. GREAT! To see the trees growing through the stonework of the temple is really a visual treat. My tour guide and I arrived in the early afternoon (around 2 pm) and it had just started to rain. So we grabbed large umbrellas and trekked to the temple through the rain. Who wants to hang out in the car because of rain when there's an ancient temple RIGHT THERE?? Of course, because of its popularity, this particular temple was overrun with tourists but it wasn't as bad as it could have been, because of the rain. There has been a lot of conservation work done on the temple but a lot of it is in ruins and even those parts are beautiful to see. So go. Go. GO!

Amazing! . By far this is my favorite temple in the Angkor Wat Archeological Park! Peaceful, surreal and amazing! We went before 12 PM, before the mad tourist crowd and heat! The earlier, the better. Take your time. We hired a tuk-tuk driver through our hotel and it was worth it! The driver was able to take us closer to the temples that tour buses and cars can't. We passed by people walking. And the cool breeze from the ride was refreshing. Different take on our experience

Famous for shooting the movie 'Tomb Raider'. Unimaginable scene of large thick trees engulfing old temples and structures. Many attractive structures have been damaged already and now could see piles of dumped blocks around. It let me ponder for a while and go back to hundreds of years back to imagine how the scene would have bee then.

Amazing. Nature meets ancient history. Seeing how the trees and plants have grown over this building allows you to visualise how the other temples will have looked before the restoration work began. Some amazing sights and photo opportunities.

Temple in the jungle. After Angkor Wat which is still in activity, it's very interesting to see a temple that is in the middle of the jungle and still needs lots of work. This is a diamond in the rough that is also worth visiting when you're in Siem Reap. One advice for a good visit (beside the water and mosquito repellent), take good shoes as sandals or flip-flops won't do with the very uneven stones.

Didn't see Lara Croft.. Under renovation when we went. Tonnes and tonnes of people were there and we couldn't move as they all decided to take stupid pictures in the most inappropriate spots. For goodness sake people; do yourself and everyone else a favour and leave your camera at home. You're never going to look at your crappy photos again!Overall average experience.

Wow. This place was absolutely superb, we visited every temple and this was by far my favourite. It's really atmospheric with the trees and ruins. The fact it's where indiana jones was filmed made it all that bit more special.
My personal favourite. My favourite of all the temples! It was just amazing. Smaller than Ankor Wat. Very peacful and easy to get around. Its a must dont miss it!

Incredible!. Amazing to see nature taking over this ancient temple. Such a special place - could have spent more time here for sure. Get your local guide to show you the face surrounded by vines - quite eerie!

A temple well integrated into wild. I visited with my wife in the early morning. Recommended to be the first temple as it will be less crowded and morning sunlight is much more softer for good photos.
Amazing place. This temple is the most neglected but probably because it doesn't need anything else to be incredible.
majestic. A must see temple when you visit Angkor. The giant trees wrap around the temple is exotic and beautiful
Ta Prohm. Another very nice temple with lots of giant trees that became part of the attraction. The temple is more than 900 yrs. old and the giant trees are more 400 yrs. old. A must to see.

Amazing what nature can do. The temple made famous from the Tomb Raider movie has so much more to offer than the spot shot in the movie. Trees that are hundreds of years old have overgrown the temple and made for an amazing temple to explore. Lots of places for amazing pictures and to just stare in awe of the power of nature. Unlike Angkor Wat and Bayon Temple, you are a bit more restricted on where you can go at Ta Prohm as ropes somewhat guide you through the temple. Try to sneak ahead of the large tour groups as it will be tough to get by. Also please respect the area and don't venture off to areas that are roped off!

Where film "Tomb Raiders" were shot. The trees over the ruins were so huge and have not seen anything like it elsewhere .Nevertheless because it was a famous site for film shooting of "tomb raiders" ....it does connects

Amazing - my favourite. This site was wonderful. Fascinating that the trees dominated some of the buildings. Lots to explore - see the bats, hear the echoes in the tower, look at all the carvings - wonderful. This was used for the film Tomb Raider - you have to see it to believe it. Number 1!
Best temple. Fantastic for 5 year olds to explore. Lots of cool walk ways. Its cooler in this temple. Great time had by all.
Fab. We went here early in the morning and I would recommend that to avoid the crowds! We had a fantastic time here and it's a must see to all in the area

Tomb Raider Temple. The film Tomb Raider by Angelina Jolie was filmed here back in 2000. Lots of damages can be seen here. However they are doing some rebuilding and restoration at the moment. It was a great place to visit

I love it, I love it, I love it!. This is just soooooo amazing! The trees together with the temple ruins! Out of this world! You feel like the 'Tomb Raider', which was filmed here. Wear sensible shoes and go with a guide!

Tomb raider lol. Of course you have to see this temple riddled with fig tree roots. Tomb raider? Unfortunate thing was the Chinese from China were there and they were not keeping to the rules so it was ver disconcerting to see!!
Deb . Best temple of them all. A must to visit when in Cambodia. The trees growing through the buildings are amazing. The Tomb Raider Temple

Definitely very unique compared to the other temples. Such a great experience. Excellent temple to view with how the Tree's have grown through the structure. I felt privileged to experience this place and its people.

Great place for picture taking. The infamous Tomb Raider tree is found here. Amazing to see huge tree roots grow all over the ruins. Entrance fee covered with the Angkor Wat ticket purchased. We took probably 70 mins to cover the place and picture taking. Tour guides available if you would like to know more about the story behind the place and each section. Not sure how do they charge for a guided tour though as we decided to walk around on our own.

Beautiful temple. I traveled twice to Cambodia to visit the temples and Ta Phrom is worth the time. Maybe not as impressive as Bayon or Angkor Wat, it has its own personality and charm. You should not miss it.

Stunning, Huanting - A must see. It has everything a temple should have. Its eerie and has an almost mystical feel about it. the only thing that ruined it were hoardes of loud tourists. If I went again I would go for the sunrise or sunset option with less people.

Overgrown Trees in Temples. An overgrown paradise of trees and temples. The trees swamp and cover the temples. Amazing how the trees have grown and the temples were left undiscovered for hundreds of years.

The images you associate with Siem Reap and Cambodia. Ta Prohm is marvelous and picturesque, a fusion of nature and human construction. The entire temple complex in Siem Reap is really amazing and will takes many hours of your time to completely be absorbed. The only problem, ironically, are tourists. It may be difficult to get "clean" photos of an artifact without seeing other people in the background. Perhaps consider going at times where there is less traffic.It probably goes without saying, but remember to bring your camera and some extra batteries. Also make sure you have plenty of water with you and sun lotion. It can get very hot and humid.

Impressive Trees, Mother Nature. Indeed an intriguing place as if the trees growned by magic, on the most unlikelly places of the temple, giants of the forest, support the walls of the temple, which probably without them, it no longer would be standing. Trully a must see, very beatifull site!

Amazing temple. These temple is famous for tomb raider but i think it also inspired temple run game. You need to walk a lot to see all the temples inside. Temples architecture differs from one to another so be sure to take many pictures along the way. Definitely a must see tourist attraction in Siem Reap.

Treasures under the roots. I am really amazed with the structures and somewhat wondering how the ancient people made this very important treasure of Siem Reap. If you are here bring umbrella, hat, and water to prevent from dehydrations coz it requires a lot of walking :-)

Lots to explore. This temple was really beautiful. The trees growing out of the walls show a mixture of man made and natural beauty. From the temple you can look into the jungle which is stunning. It's not surprising this temple has been used as a filming location for several big films including Tomb Raider. There are lots of tunnels to explore and it would be quite easy to find areas where there is nobody else so you can take time to reflect on its beauty.

Must do alongside Angkor Wat. While cant compare with the scale of Angkor Wat, I really liked the natural setting in the jungle and the crazy trees growing over the ruins. A true Indiana Jones experience!
Great!. This is a tourist favorite, where the lines for having someone take your photo with a tree are long! Be sure to carry an umbrella if it is a sunny day!

Jungle Temple. The people of the 12 century were amazing at how they constucted these amazing buidlings. The restoration work is on going, but the jungle has its own ideas, this is a wonderful place to visit.

The jungle temple. This temple is noted for the many trees that seem to be taking over the remains of the structures. It is simply astonishing how these giant trees have grown up and around the structures, their roots seemingly grasping onto the stones and embracing (or choking?), their massive trunks towering over these once majestic, now humble structures.

How time and nature take their toll.. Wonderfull to see nature combining with the craftsmanship of the Khmer people. It is an excellent location to see true beauty. It's also where Tomb Raider was filmed. Also great for hide and seek! Try not to get lost!
Such intriguing tree work!. It was absolutely amazing to see what the trees have done to these ruins.. the trees are massive and really old. Must visit just to see the trees..
A gem for a reason. It will be crowded, but if you go in recognizing that, and just walk slow, you'll be okay! The trees are truly spectacular and there's a reason why they filmed a movie there!
A must-see. As I write this, I can't think of any way to describe this place but magnificent. Rich in history, abundant in beauty. This is an ancient city overrun by nature, bold in size and detail.
Very cool. Probably the most interesting temple we've seen. It's all overgrown with trees it feels like you're really exploring here.

Amazing!!!. I woke up very early morning to meet my TukTuk driver at the hotel lobby. We started the day at 4:45am. A couple hundreds people got up early and raced to get the best spot for sunrise photos at Khmer Wat. Our next place was Ta Prohm. The TukTuk ride took about 20mins so it was still quite early when we arrived. The place was smaller than I thought but I enjoyed very much and spent more time than my original plan. Ta Prohm is my most favorite place in Siem Reap. We left around 10:30am when saw many group tours started filling in and the place was getting too noisy.

Lives up to the hype. Known more as the "tomb raider" temple these days, but is amazing to see. Was a bit crowded in places at certain photo points, but was well worth the visit. Our tour guide knew some good photo locations away from the crowds too, so going with a good tour guide in a small group paid off

one of my places on the bucket list. Ratana was awesome in letting us know the history of this temple.awesome awesome awesome.And we went to the other 2 temples 1st b4 visiting here. the ambience is soothing. amidst the other tour guides giving narration, u could hear the serenity of the forest.

Tomb Raider moment. If you have felt in love with place shown in Tomb Raider, you should come and see this place. It is pristine and beautiful. The way trees are coming out of compound walls and how roots are running all over the place, it makes this place really beautiful.
Trees & Temple mixing together. Must go here before it gets totally disintegrated. Massive trees all over the temple, makes you wonder how they grew in the first place.

this temple is being funded for restoration by. the indian government is funding the restoration of this temple. though a laborious task the renovation will preserve the temple for generations to come.

Beyond words!. The trees were absolutely amazing – unlike anything I've ever seen before. It is a majestic place and it feels so magical. I wasn't expecting it to be as amazing as it is. Absolutely loved!!!

TREES GONE WILD. If you're touring the temples in the Angkor Wat area you must not miss this one. It is more famous for having wonderful trees growing out of the very walls themselves. Look at the photos to make sure you visit here. The original builders must have had no intention that trees should colonise their buildings and it's just a measure of neglect over hundreds of years that have produced these amazing structures.There is one problem. You want to photograph the tree roots winding themselves around the man made structures and you would like to do that without simpering tourists insisting in standing to have their photos taken in front of the trees and walls. You may have to wait for 5 to 10 minutes before you can frame a human free view.And why do certain tourists always make a V For victory sign when they're having their photos taken? Thinking of the historical perspective, it makes you deeply suspicious.That aside, do visit Ta Prohm. It's spectacular.

Don't Miss It !!!. You're not going to see anything like this anywhere else. I havent been to South America but I doubt if any of the Inca marvels beat Angkor Wat and its various temples , Ta Prohm being one of the best.
Awesome Ta Prohm. It was a very humid day but seeing the marvels of this ancient tempel one forgets all the discomfort.

Must See. If there is just one other temple, I would recommend Ta Prohm. The trees going through and around the building is incredible to see. I went with a guide as well, who was able to give me a brief history. I went in the afternoon, when the crowds weren't so large. Must see if you are here!

A symbol of the fight between the nature and civilization.. This is a temple,monastery and university complex built by the king Jayavarman the 7th to honor his mother in 1186. Once upon a time around 12500 people used to live here. After the fall of Khmer empire in the 17th century, this temple was abandoned and nature took it over. Now one can see huge fig and silk cotton tree trunks and roots are embracing the temple like a gigantic snake. The Hollywood films Tomb Raider and Indiana Jones and Temple of Doom were shot here.

Impressive but overcrowded . Like All the major temples in the complex, this is as popular as Bayon and Angkor Wat due to its "tomb raider tree". We came after visiting Angkor Thom complex and unfortunately it's flooded with tour groups. Could be nicer if there were less people but seems impossible. If you want to get away from the crowd, visiting during lunch hour is recommended as tour groups usually go for lunch. We did enjoy more private space at Angkor Thom during our lunch hour visit there.

Beautiful temple left to the jungle. This is my favourite temple as it has not been restored and has been left just as it was found. You can see where large trees are growing out of the walls which gives a feeling of the jungle taking over. Definitely a must see.

Serenity. I didn't watch Tomb Raider but this temple still impressed me with the beautiful tree roots. We were the FIRST ONES to step into this temple in the early morning so I enjoyed the peace and quiet of it all. This temple could be done within an hour or an hour and a half.
awesome. another fantastic temple and was used in tomb raider once again the pictures does not do it any justice needs to be seen with your own eyes to appreciate its full beauty

BEST TIME TO VISIT. It's an amazing place to visit, however the best time to see is around 4:00pm as there are much less people. There are guards around the sight so ask where the famous spots are, otherwise you might miss some.
Amazing roots. A big portion of it is currently under renovation. But it's worth the walk. Tomb Raider inspired. you'll see a lot of big roots everywhere.

The tomb rider . Love it with the great tree with the great temples.Built by the king Jaya to his mother which was damaged during the war between Thailand but was rebuild some of the part by the French.

Amazing. Wow - this place is awesome. You feel as though you have been transported into another world. You can see why this place has been popular for making movies including Tomb Raider. My friend and I had our own personal guide which was great so we learned so much about the history of the place and we beat all the crowds as this is a very popular place. This is a must see and was my favourite place that I visited in Siem Reap.
Absolutely stunning Temple. This was probably my favourite temple. It was magical. The trees are so stunning it almost appears unreal.
Amazing. Ta Prohm was amazing temple .a lot big tree stand covering on the temple .Very lovely that can see this temple .

An exquisite sight . This temple encompasses the true beauty of the Cambodian history and its natural state, the jungle! The building remains are wrapped with streams of roots stabilising the trees that grow metres above the temple roof itself, a spectacular sight. Definitely worth a visit, one of my favourite and was quite memorable to say the least.
Be a raider!!. The temple has some amazing structures, huge trees and is extremely beautiful. Definitely a must do!

Very impressive, not to be missed. Although this is a relatively small temple, it is one of the most impressive in the temple complex.
It is amazing to see how the huge trees are "crawling and hugging" the temple stone structure.
Make sure to visit this temple...

Very nice complex with beautiful trees. The entrance to this complex is a 400 meter walk over a well maintained path through the jungle. The first thing you notice are the humongous 400+ year old trees growing over the structure. The shape from the roots are just incredibly and the shade makes the temperature acceptable. Many tempels have been (partly) restored. The route through the complex is like a labyrinth so it is also fun for the kids.For me the beauty of the temples in combination with the trees made this a perfect visit.
the best!. This was by far my favourite temple along the small circuit. you are able to really feel like you are a part of the culture. The temple is amazing, especially the tree temple!

This is amazing. Known for obvious reasons as the jungle temple, it is overgrown with magnificent trees and unrestored. The tree roots drape over the walls and wrap around columns. It is magical. It's quite small and gets very busy with tour groups. You have to be patient to get a good photograph. Wear good shoes.
Just mind blowing. Lives up to all expectations, was truly stunning scenery, stopped the wife in her tracks & reduced to to silence - what more could you want!

Very impressive how nature takes back. Along with many tiny hopping frogs you go from the East Gate to the remains of the temple and very big trees! It is impressive how the trees are clinging themselves around the walls and towers.
A HUNGRY JUNGLE. As you explore this temple area it is so obvious that the jungle is literally consuming the structures. Photos galore, is crowded later in the morning.

Truly memorable . This is a popular temple (the tomb raider film saw to that) and a must see. The way nature has reclaimed her site and literally grown into the temple is a memory I will cherish. It's everything I had hoped it would be.It will be busy (go in the aft noon when the tour buses are elsewhere, it will be hot (take water), it is worth the trip

Top and the best. Ta Prohm has a very well laid out walking path with both decking and soft ground both in and outside and through the archeological site. Lots of pictures here as the tree roots cover the temple is the most amazing way looking like large anaconda snake draping over temple walls and roofs. My favorite with the aspara carvings and the walk through the site. Nice signage on the temple showing how it was archaeologically put back together. But many loose parts exist and you can understand how it's beauty and mystery attracted movie making -
Worth to visit. don't missed this wonderful monument whenever you have got a chance to visit Siem reap. go for it and explore the historical story ahead.
Woooowwww. You feel like in a movie.You will never see something like this.Take lots of pictures, it is a place worth of long lasting memory.Go, go, go!
Amazing. Really amazing to see the trees taking over the buildings. I loved this temple. So much nature and not as busy as some of the other temples. This is a 'must see'
Amazing. Oh my god this place is just amazing it was more than we could imagine it to be. It was beautiful you need to see it to believe it. You really need to put this on your to see list.

Be patient and queue for the perfect photo.. A smaller temple, so only need to allow 1 hour to visit this one. made famous by Tomb Raiders, tourist crowd around the specific movie scene areas. If you be patient and wait, will can get perfect memorable photo. no climbing at this temple.

Amazing Tree Roots. Is a dynamic interaction between nature and man-made art. I felt like Lara Croft from the Angelina Jolie ‘Tomb Raider’, which was filmed here. Most of this haunting beauty is enveloped by tree roots and has been left in pretty much the same condition it was found in.

My favourite of Siem Reap's temples. Even if you have seen more temples than you have ever seen in your lifetime, you MUST SEE Ta Prohm.Words can't adequately describe this complex so pack up your best camera and head to this temple - You will definitely be glad you did.
Like nothing I have ever seen before. Fascinating place. The trees growing through the temples are something else. Fantastic photo opportunities.
Awe inspiring. Ta Prohm is where nature and man meet in creating an awe inspiring sacred setting. You feel like you are instantly transported to another time, dare i say another life time.

Good place to reveal!. I watched the movie of Tomb Raider, but this is more than that with its special attraction of being quiet, peaceful and amazing scenic views,
Highly recommended,

A great mixture of well preserved ancient monument with some restoration. If you are looking for the true Indian Jones or Tomb Raider experience, this certainly delivers. Go with a good guide who can explain the significance of the various aspects of the monument.
The Jewel. We could have spent all the day at Ta Prohm as there is so much to see and do, we have many pictures to look back on.
Love it. Our kids took lots of photos and they certainly love the site, it looks like in the movie when the tree covers the ancient rock statues, especially the faces.

Majestic display of nature's power. Stunning and mesmerising...the ruins are overpowered with silk cotton and fig trees. The sight leaves you spellbound as you wonder at the resilience of these structures and beauty of trees.

Highly recommended to visit!. This place is beautiful! Located pretty near Angkor Wat, you'll find huge tree roots growing over and covering the walls of the temple built 900 years ago. Also one of the filming sites of Tomb Raider.

Must visit once in a life time. This place was on my bucket list since the very beginning. After watching the movie "Tom Raider", you would surely like to visit this place. It is basically an old temple made up of stones where you can see trees coming inside of the building. This place is a must visit place.
Purely Spiritual. Ta Prohm is a mysterious temple. It's covering by the jungle which make it even more fascinating. I totally love it.

Not to be missed.. Even if you only have one day to visit the temples, don't miss Ta Prom. The atmosphere is wonderful and some great photo opportunities providing you go whenthere are not too many tourists.

A crowded must. Ta Prohm is a must when visiting the Angkor area, but don't let this stop you from visiting other similar temples. It's crowded and the new walking system might be a bit of a hassle, but it is a must see.

Trees growing over the ruins were quite impressive. We expected the trees growing on top of the buildings to be creepy - but it wasn't. The stunning view of this temple went beyond so far from my expectation. Go there soon...especially if you are a photographer!

Big trees in the big temple . The trees look like important than the temple because they have a classic trees around.
Please take your picture with the trees it's important of this place.

Used to be my favorite temple--Now its Disneyland. This is the temple that was the set for the original Tomb Raider movie. The first time I visited Siem Reap ten years ago, this was my favorite temple. It was a wild natural ruin at that time. Exploring it meant climbing rocks and squeezing through small openings in the collapsed structure.I was disappointed to discover they had built wood sidewalks and stairways throughout 75% of the ruins--and 90% of the best areas. You want a photo? They've built a wooden deck for you in exactly the right spot. They're catering to the hoards of package tourists that don't want to get their shoes dirty. If you want to see what this temple looked like in the "old days" you'd better get here quick before they turn the other 25% into Disneyland. Don't get me wrong. Ta Phrom is still amazing. But you don't really get that authentic feel with the sidewalks and directional signage everywhere. Sad.
Of course 5-star. Amazing place...the trees alone are worth it...great pics. Worth all the challenges of traveling to this area.

Ta Prohm aka Tomb Rider. The infamous tree is here. This temple is a bit greener and calmer compare to the smiling budhha due to the tree covering the ground. You might get lost looking for this tree or a way out but fret not, there is a guard everywhere that is willing to help. Pretty sight and pretty photo everywhere just make sure you have enough battery throughout the day!

The trees that have grown to encompass the temple are awesome. The temple that had become famous after "Tomb Raider" is another amazing place to visit in Siem Reap. Some parts have been restored and are definitely worth a visit.

Tombraider temple!. Not as must see as the other temples in the complex, but of interest due to Angelina Jolie's Tombraider being filmed here. With the big old trees and their roots starting to naturally demolish the place, it is still worth viewing. Local hawkers were the worst I've seen so far on this trip though.

Very interesting place. If you have not much time to stay in SR I recommend you to get a small tour from Tuk Tuk taxi for 15$ and they will take you to the Angkor thom area that included Angkor wat, Bayon and Ta Prohm. And the Ta Prohm is one of the highligh how amazing the tree tower above Ta Prohm, for me it was very impression
It's Amazing . This place was so beautiful and amazing. Walking to get there was a paid off. ... don't forget to bring water if you're visiting this temple.
See it soon. Have visited twice eight years apart. As they do it up it is losing some of its mystique. However still very cool.

Loved this place. Sprawling ruin that feels like it has been taken over by the jungle. Amazing carvings and despite lots of people, we were able to find quiet spots to sit and soak up the place. Easier to get about than other main temples due to no stairs. My favourite temple in Siem Reap
Beautiful. That's amazing temple with incredible tree & well worth a world heritage site. I cannot image how it done, but i loved it's histories. Don't miss it!
Must see. The Temple from the movies, nature is trying to reclaim the building with the most awesome effects, tree roots making there own sculptures.

Nature's Wonders. Though this place is famous for Tomb Raider movie scenes, it's worthy of being notable for much more. The walk around the temple is filled with trees reclaiming their jungle. Rubble of the temple is everywhere, but you can still walk through many of its halls. Moss surrounds much of the stone with just a hint of the majestic building one can only imagine it must've been. It isn't any wonder that it inspired art on the big screen.

Fro tree lover. This place is amazingly mysterious, you feel the gate of time just opened and you wend through, the mist, the great huge trees that eats the walls, the green fungus. It is a MUST TO VISIT, after Angor Wat.
Transformers :D. Part of the transformers sequel were shot right here! Amazing natural wonders towering the historical temples make sure you drink enough water
Ta Prohm. Along with Angkor Wat and Bayon Temple Ta Prohm is a must see. A truly amazing stone temple overtaken by the Cambodian jungle.We absolutely loved it!!!
Tomb Raider or Indiana Jones. Incredible to see from the entry gate to the building itself. Ta Prohm is amazing to see and one relic I'd advise seeing amongst all in Angkor.
Stunning!!!!. We visited at the end of the day and although still busy it was more than doable. Beautiful place. Loved the sounds of the jungle from the surrounding forrest.

Too much hype. Seriously there is too much hype about this place, almost all of it comes from the Tomb Raider movie where it plays a very very small part in the movie. Some people think you will be entering a tomb or a cave like structure. Instead its an open air structure of ruins. After seeing Angkor Wat this place will only add to your trip overhead in time and cost and will not give anything more than a structure that has an overgrown tree on it. Oh and by the way Angelina Jolie wont be there either

my favourite temple. temple has been left as nature intended and the trees growing through the temples really enhances the history. There is a lot of detailed carvings and having a guide would be beneficial. This was my first temple on the grand circuit and my personal favourite

good place. Construction on Ta Prohm began in 1186 AD. Originally known as Rajavihara (Monastery of the King), Ta Prohm was a Buddhist temple dedicated to the mother of King Jayavarman VII.A rare inscription at Ta Prohm provides statistics on the temple's workers. Allowing for some exaggeration to honor the king, the inscription's report of around 80,000 workers, including 2700 officials and 615 dancers, is still astounding.Sadly, Ta Prohm was looted quite heavily in recent years due to its relative isolation, and many of its ancient stone reliquaries have been lost.

Best temple from all the ones seen. This was a very unique and different from all the temples visit. It is amazing to see how nature takes back control of the environment. This is a must visit and I will recommend hiring a tour guide.
Amazing!. You should never miss this site aside from Angkor Wat. I really like its structure. This is where we shot our temple run photos haha...

My favorite. We went with a guide, entering from the North Gate. You'll have a hard time finding it, but if you do, its worth it. The main gates are riddled with people selling things. But the temple itself? Amazing.

So busy!. This was definitely the most busy of all the sites I visited at Angkor. It seems everyone wants a photo of themselves in the Tomb Raider temple.Pro-tip... take a day and visit Koh Ker and/or Beng Mealea... both offer a Ta Prohm type experience, but devoid of the crowds.

Loved the trees coming out. I'm at awe at what nature and time can do. I really enjoyed visiting here and since visiting watched Tomb Raider again! Better come early to make clear photo shoot otherwise you can see people's heads everywhere.
Best temple!. This temple is amazing. So many interesting and great places in the temple to see how the jungle has reclaimed pieces of the temple. Really every turn is a new unique photo opportunity.

A pride of humanity. Really an impressive temple. You could immerse yourself and be there for a couple of hours and still find things that would surprise you. Have been here twice in the last six years and will be coming back again
Amazing - wet season beauty. Spiritual, breathtaking majesty in the middle of the Forrest, gradually. Ring reclaimed. Y the trees. Our favourite templ.

Spectacular. Visited with our guide who explained the history of the site including the pop quiz fact that Tomb Raider was filmed here briefly. Spectacular ruinous site which has been overgrown with massive trees. They have extended their root-like fingers through the walls and roof of the structure giving the site an eerie ethereal look. Part of the incredible Angkor Archealogical site it was built by the ancient king to house his grandmothers ashes(long since removed). Interestingly, our guide pointed out many of the Buddhist wall carvings that had been carved over when the temple was taken over by the Hindus. Get a guide. It's worth it.

Absolutly amazing. Seeing the trees growing up through the structures was fantastic. I am glad this temple was left in this natural state. If you've seen the Tomb Raider movie, you'll recognize it. This is a place you need to visit if you're in the area. And, for those of you into geocaching, there's a geocache hidden here.

Nice temple, but crowded. As any Ankor temple, it was crowded with tourists. Generally, for me this isn't really a problem. However, where trees grew over the temple, there were queues of tourists who wanted to make a picture of them in front of the tree. That was a bit too much for us. Nevertheless, a great temple that you should visit when you are in the Ankor area.

Loved this place. As with Angkor Wat, we went with a tour guide and so glad we did.Although this was the low/off season it was still quite busy. Apparently it gets even busier later in the day as folks move on from Angkor Wat, and Bayon to Ta Prohm.Well soya visit.

Famous temple from the Tomb Raider movie. Well worth the tour as part of a wider tour seeing Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm. Try and find the face in the roots in one of the inner walk ways. This was definitely a worthwhile visit.

Ta Prohm. Angkor wat is overrated but cool, Ta prohm is gorgeous, Bayon is incredible, don't miss Angkor Thom, and banteay srei is pretty neat though it would not be the temple to see after you’ve seen a bunch of them.

Watched Tomb Raider again after visiting. Loved the trees coming out, growing threw and growing on the temples. I really enjoyed visiting here and since visiting watched Tomb Raider again and saying I was standing right there. This was one of my favourites.

Lots of Giant Trees ~ Feel Sacred. We were so exciting here...lots of giant trees which make it feel old and sacred...well it is sacred. Better come early to make clear photo shoot otherwise you can see people's heads everywhere.
Ta Prohm was great. Wonderful temple ,Ta prohm was amazing temple had the big tree cover on the top of temple .and this temple was tohm rider one the big movie .
interesting. well worth the visit they are doing a lot of work to it but it will not effect your visit. you will need about an hour and take a guide as there is many interesting facts

Feel the power of the trees. Apart from the historical value of this site, it also makes you experience the power of nature. It is as if one is face to face with the raw power of nature. Although it looks nice in the photos this is a place one MUST visit to feel the presence and the power of nature.

Interesting.. This place I found very interesting but was a little disappointed to find one tree had no roots protruding as the had been removed , did see other areas with large roots and was delighted.

My personal favorite!. My personal favorite in the Angkor complex! The giants tree roots mixed with those ancient monuments are an amazing site. More and more tourist mixed with a weird/random local control could mean... Well, pretty much anything, depending on what happens next...
Nature and architacture inter-twine. Another amazing structure. Some have merged with trees that are actually hollow. Its like everything just froze in time ...amazing.

Back to the Root of Faith. Big trees taken over the thousand years old Buddhist temples. Looks so amazingly eerie. The co-existence of the trees & the temple ruins are mesmerizing. You must visit this place alone .... you can feel the pulse of the temple & visualise the history.

Must see
when you are in Siem👿Reap. Very fascinating with huge tree rootingaround the perimeters of the walls andcolumns.It was dizzling when we reach there making the way difficult to walk around. Wear walking shoes. Proper decentdressing is required to allow entry in thenear future. Best time to visit Siem Reap is from December to April where the climate is milder and no rain. Huge smiling statues. Angkor means city

"Tomb Raider Temple". Its fantastic, we were astonished with it. You can spend the whole day getting lost in it. Buy a guide, you can get a very good one (see the picture) for 6$ if you negotiate (you can offer a bit more if you want to help these good people) and enjoy every detail.

Mother nature taking over. Unlike most of the temples of Angkor, Ta Prohm has been largely left to the clutches of the living jungle.Ta Prohm is extensively ruined, but you can still explore numerous towers, close courtyards and narrow corridors, discovering hidden gems of stone reliefs beneath the encroaching foliage. Many of the corridors are impassible, thanks to the jumbled piles of carved stone blocks that clog their interiors.There are 39 towers at Ta Prohm, which are connected by numerous galleries. Visitors are no longer permitted to climb onto the crumbling galleries, due to the potential damage to both temple and visitor. The carvings are amazing including a little carving of an unexplained dinosaur.

History, architecture defeated by nature. By far the favourite of the temples. Left to the mercy of nature the massive silk-cotton and strangler fig trees took root in the loosened stones of the temple. Go early to try avoid the crowds and heat.
Very nice, beautifully covered by jungle. A little ruined, but lovely covered by trees, jungle. Great combination of human and nature power. Have to see, but not because of Tomb Rider
Strange merge of ruins and jungle. Classic images of trees growing atop of and between century old ruins I'd captivating. Most enjoyable and great photo opportunities.

Lara crofts temple. The ruins are famous for its feature in the Tomb Raider film, on a gloomy day the site can actually look quite out of a horror movie, but if you look around across the Angkor archaeological park, there are a couple of other places also which look quite similar to this--- at first glance its like is it a temple growing in side a tree or is it a tree growing on the temple. This is being restored by our very own Archaeology Survey of India and they seem to do a better job out side the country than in India :)
Astonishing. This picture made already the tour of the world several times but when you are in fron of it you say Yes it's true and so beautiful

Great in the early morning. This temple is understandably very popular with tourists, so we prefer to go in right as it opens (7:30) to avoid the crowds and get great shots of the trees reclaiming the temple.

Lots of big trees. I was whimsically expecting this temple to be deadly quiet, but it was quite busy. We took many photos of the big trees clambering on top of the ruins. That's the best thing here.It's not as well preserved as other temples, many of the fallen stones are in piles.But definitely, come here. Find a seat, take a breath and soak it all in.
Tomb Raider. This is just like a Steven Speilberg setting..... amazing how the Trees have like outgrown the monuments over time and collapsed a part of the temple. Must visit

Ta Prohm The Temple Covered by the roots of Trees. Ta Prohm is a temple near the Angkor Wat that is very well known since Angelina Jolie used this temple for her film 'Tomb Rider'. This temple is very unique caused by many roots of trees covered the walls of the temple. While you are in Siem Reap, this temple is a must place to visit. The views are very interesting.

Cool place to hang out!. This was our favourite temple. It was much more authentic - trees growing over ancient building - felt like we had stumbled across it in a forest. There were also not as many tourists here.

A temple being reclaimed by the jungle. One of my favorite temples ,it has fallen into disrepair. The jungle is growing up through and around the walls and literally reclaiming the entire structure. I visited here many years ago and have photos of areas that are now completely collapsed and overgrown with creeping fig trees.There was a restoration project going on a few years ago but it appears to have stalled. See it before it disappears forever.

Stunning. An amazing place... walking through is like stepping back hundreds of years. You can feel the history and rates up there with the the other temples. Just to see the power of nature over many years is breathtaking. Hire a guide if it's in your budget, to get a better understanding, but if not just walking through is mind blowing enough!!!!

This was my favourite temple. As we left Angkor Wat the rain came down but we decided to go to Ta Prohm anyway and I'm so glad we didn't miss it. It was amazing how nature has claimed parts of the temple with massive trees and tree roots growing over parts of the temple. It was really wonderful to see.

Power of nature at its best . Ta Prohm//the Tombraider temple was our favourite of all we saw in Angkor. It was magical to explore, covered in huge trees wrapped around the surviving buildings. It feels surreal to walk around. Go early in the morning when there is less people. Also, by the way, the typical Tomb Raider image you imagine is really difficult to find and we're not if we actually managed it..
Ancient treasures almost forgotten. This ancient temple had been swallowed by time and natural forests. Great that it was discovered and shared to the public with little fee.

Awesome! . This is a greatness to behold just like the angkor wat. A must see and must treasured heritage. Explore and witness the history and culture every intricate details the structures and ruins represent.
My favorite. It's hard to compare the great choice of temples in Siem Reap, but the beauty and uniqueness of Ta Prohm crown it the champion in my book. Stunning!

Eerie, Magnificent. This was, by far, the most interesting for us. All of the ancient temples are fascinating, but something about these tree roots snaking around, through, between the structures was eerie but compulsive viewing. On one hand, it was such a shame to see the destruction the roots have caused over the centuries but on the other hand, the magnificence of it was truly awe-inspiring. Incredible. Adjectives really cannot describe it. This is a must-see in Siem Reap
The best temple of them all. Truly amazing a must see for tree lovers and temples lovers alike. I was in awe of the size of the trees.

Wonderful Nature of Mother Earth!. I shows long time ago ... WOW how this place abandon for so long. The great forest that no one else discover. What is the history of this place? Any how it was very attractive place to visit to know what is the story behind this ancient place. Cambodian historian can say some more about this tourist spot that boom.

Get your free steak knives here!!. If u didn't get enuf of Angkor watt get over to Ta prohm. You get more excellent carvings and some ripper statues and the sort. But that's not all, it's a photographers dream with some speccy trees rooting up all over the joint. Don't forget the vertical panoramas of the trees with you in front which will be hanging from your wall in a frame in a couple of weeks!! Have fun!
Surreal. Difficult to tell where the trees stop and the temple begins. Quite a unique site and a must see alongside Angkor Wat

Our favourite of all the temples. My husband and I lived Ta Prom. The integration of the surrounding jungle creates a gorgeous setting to appreciate the architecture and respect the impermanence of something that was once so grand. Our little one like exploring the temple but did find some areas harder to traverse than Angkor Wat.
Amazing place. Amazing to look at and walk around, plenty of stuff to take photo's of. It's like Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom in real life, haha
Amazing! . Ta Prohm lived up to its hype. The temple is truly magnificent and a photographers paradise! It does get busy and quite hot so be prepared to have your patience tested.
Surreal!. The century old trees made the experience memorable. This place is the Angelina Jolie place that, of course, the actress made more popular because of her movie was shot here.
Move over Lara Croft!. I really liked this temple and it was far less physically demanding than Angkor Wat. Great photo opportunities round every corner.

Spectacular, photographer's dream!. Ta Prohm was a great place to visit in the middle of the day when it was very hot because of the shade afforded by the trees. However, there were a number of other visitors at this time so it may be better in the early morning. The site was unique because it gave insights into the restoration efforts for the temples. Entry is included in the general ticket price for the Angkor Wat archeological Park.
The best?. Maybe the most beautiful and amazing temple of Angkor. It's huge, like a maze but the stones are now mixed with the trees, it gives a wonderful atmosphere, really intense and unique.

Wow!. This was my favourite temple of the four I visited. I thoroughly enjoyed visiting Ta Prohm and had a great time taking photos and timing it right so that no-one else was in shot :)Make sure to go earlier in the day or risk getting caught in heavy rain

Tomb raider made famous. This is the must see as it is the famous temple for all the trees growing through. It will be the busiest due to this but.you can do all the close temples in one day at $20. Just tuk tuk them all for about $16 and wonder alone. Guides available if you want.
Our favourite temple. The overgrowth must be seen to be believed. Trust me, the pictures do not do it justice. Go with a guide to appreciate all aspects of the Temple.

The tomb raider temple . Was hoping it was lusher but it is still a must see I think. The place looks small but not so. There's nooks and crannies to explore, loved how all the figs cover the temple. Strangely, because you really hoped it's as isolated as tomb raider portrayed it to be the crowd gets to me. Everyone taking photo infront of roots !!!

Beautiful tree's.... The tree's growing through this temple are amazing to see, although sadly the temple is in disrepair.I've never seen Tomb Raider so that isn't why I visited Ta Prohm. But there's alot of visitors. One local took our photo and that was it for myself and friend, he wouldn't leave us alone and when we gave him money too take more photo's he wanted more...left a bitter taste in my mouth. So be aware of the 'photographer'!

Spectacular temple well worth seeing.. This is one of the temples in the complex that is a must to see, seeing the temple on any medium is nice but walking through the temple you get to experience it on a different level. You can still see how truly magnificent it still is.

Great temple to let the kids exolore. Wonderful temple to spend some time exploring with children. More shade than most of the other top temples and large enough to find a quieter corner to explore and play with younger kids.
Gate alone means greatness. Entering the area.the "heads" alone gives you that grandiose feeling of what is waiting inside.must see.

Everyone wants to be Tomb Raider!. The mystique of the Ta Prohm temple is lost to the droves of tourist here. They come here with one intention only... that is to take a snapshot under the "Tomb Raider" tree, made famous by none other than Angelina Jolie. To avoid the droves of tourist, the worst being tour groups, go early in the morning, or save it for the lunch time. There is no way to enjoy this temple with the constant barrage of tourist inching closer behind you to keep moving to the next level.The appeal of Ta Prohm is the nature in which the forrest has reclaimed this temple. Most elements are still intact, and the intermingling of nature and the ancient building cannot be captured better than it is. The temple has not been completely restored, with areas of rockfall still blocking the passage to some areas. So you have to keep to the trail and follow the signage. Take a look at the map of the temple before venturing in as you are bound to get your orientation mangled up once you're inside.Another must visit in Siem Reap.

Cycle away. I think the best experience I've had is cycling to each of this temples the exhilaration, the power, the wind urging you on and don't even forget the temples themselves. Best way to get your body working & enjoying the views
Have to see it to believe it!. Something about this place is magical, it was used for filming tomb raider and i can see why. The jungle has taken over the temples and it looks amazing,
Be a tomb raider!!. So amazing to see the jungle consuming the temples. Was also cool to see where Tomb Raider was filmed! 5-star picture!

Early Winter. Wonderful to see these heritage monuments and how nature has grown all around it. The Ta Prohm and Bayon temples are almost taken over by nature and the towering giant trees.
Lots of walking to be done-- it is hot and humid so you have to be ready for that-- cotton clothes and head scarves help

Worth a Visit. Ta-Prohm I felt was a bit exaggerated. This may be because of the movie "Tomb Raider". It has a beauty of its own, but cant match the carvings and architecture of the other temples of Angkor
Nice and me quiet . We liked this temple because it was more quiet and less crowded. It's also very impressive to see how the trees has destroyed but also grown in to the temple

lonf Story here. Ta Prohm's popularity has soared in recent years along with the rest of the Angkor complex, but especially because of its appearance in the movie "Lara Croft: Tomb Raider." Be sure to check out the controversial "Dinosaur of Ta Prohm"
Once you visit onetemple, you want to see all!. Part of the temples and a must see.It can be overwhelmed see all the temples in one day, but worth the experience.

Simply one of the must see's. This temple has almost been devoured by the jungle giving a very unique look compared to the rest of the temples in Angkor Wat park. We spend an hour and a half walking all the small paths in this temple to get the whole of it. Can only recommend to take you time here.

After Angkor Wat - the best Khmer temple. Just loved the very beautiful and artistic trees intertwined with the historical temple. We spent a lot of time in this temple compared to the other temples (besides Angkor Wat, ofcourse) as the scale, architecture, courtyards, prayer rooms are all intriguing. The trees and their roots add so much charm and mystery to this complex, you cannot help but be mesmerised. And of course one cant forget Angelina Jolie's slick scenes from Lara Croft in this temple - they add to the glory of this place. It rained towards the end of our visit in this temple and that just made the place so much more beautiful to be in.
amazing !!. what an unusual place to see...all entangled and entwined yet so beautifully preserved by nature ...a super place for photography and admiring architecture !
Big tree interesting . Ta Prohm is amazing temple .it tohm ridea movie one .have big tree covering on the temple .if visiting at morning it batter time no tourish .

Great Temple that shows nature at its finest. Beautiful Temple that makes you truly appreciate the relationship between man and nature. The temple is currently undergoing some reconstruction, so you cant see the main attraction of the Tombraider door covered by the tree. However, the restoration should be done soon and its still a great site to see.

The best temple. My favorite temple in Siem Reap! All the temples you visit are awe inspiring but this one in particular is something special with all the trees over growing and intertwining with the ancient structure. Well worth a visit

Amazing experiencr. I almost don't want to rate it so high because I'm afraid it will get crowded, but it was seriously one of the most beautiful places I've ever been. I went the first day, and then went back the 2nd and last day I was there just so I could wander around and get lost again. Highly recommend.
Amazing! This is Cambodia as we remember it.. Not as many tourists and not quite as many hawkers here. Could imagine this as it was hundreds and hundreds of years ago - same trees!
Tomb Raider. Of all the Angkor ruins, Ta Prohm was my favorite. It was my favorite because of the trees and unique stone decor. I totally understand why this site was used in the movie "Tomb Raider".

Classic example of nature reclaiming mans domain. Everybody who hasn't been here will know this complex from the "Tomb Raider" film. Again pictures don't do it justice, and the atmosphere needs to be appreciated. So try and find a vantage point and be mindful for a few moments. See nature and the way it has reclaimed what man has built. Some trees were cut down/removed and there is a lot of collapse, but later trees have been cut down though leaving a good few dozen feet of trunk to support buildings. Open areas have been left to jungle.

Tomb Raider Temple. This ruined temple did not disappoint, incredible atmosphere despite the number of people. We arrived here mid morning and this was the busiest site so far. We had arrived for sunrise at 5am... Tree roots 'hold' parts of the temple structure together and are simply massive. Easy to get lost in the maze of ruined rooms and courtyards, the temple is not massive in height but the trees sure are!

Seeing how nature has grown into it was just amazing. Amazing temple with huge ancient trees, no words to describe this place. The tree roots which have forced their way into Ta Prohm really give it character and add to its beauty.

A refreshing change of temple visit. This temple has a charm that others cannot offer, the way in which the jungle has taken over the site makes it quite a different experience from the others in Angkor. For the film buffs it also featured in Tomb Raider. It was nice to be able to explore the ruins in the shade with a refreshing breeze. Would definitely recommend a visit.
Ta Prohm. Enjoyed the sights and the calmness of the area. The music by the local musicians were very soothing. Visited the place the movie tomb raiders were shirt.
Wow. This is my favourite temple from the visit. Theres something about Ta Prohm that makes it fasinating.

Must see temple. As you see temples in Siem Reap, you may have the feeling that you are seeing the same thing over and over. This temple had character.strong history to it but also had a mystical feel. Do not miss this place.

Amazing temple. My personal favourite of all the temples. Stunning carvings with tree's growing amongst the temple. Brilliant opportunities for photos (if you can avoid the crowd) and an easy place to get lost in for hours!

Great photo op to take pictures. The highlight of Ta Prohm is definitely the tree growing through the temple. Huge roots from tall trees have taken over parts of the temple and caused other parts of it to collapse.

Even more spectacular than in the Tomb Raider movie. Its very thought provoking to understand how the trees can grow such in huge size over centuries aroud this temple. Don't forget to look for several statues almost hidden in the tree roots.
Adventure. This temple screams adventure and mystery. We felt as though we had stepped onto an ancient mythical location.
So much more than Tomb Raider. Amazing that the temples are still standing with the incredible tree roots embedded! Enjoyed exploring the nooks and crannies here.

Tomb Raider Territory. Everyone kept mentioning Angelina and tomb raider here! We did this temple on our 2nd day of temples. It had a lot more people, or perhaps just more noticeable due to the more compact nature of the site compared with Angkor Wat. Very different due to the destruction wrought by the trees. This makes it fascinating to look at and of course photograph. Keep away from the tour group selfies and find some of the quitter spots to take photos.
Amazing. It is hard to describe it because it is absolutely amazing. . Don´t forget to wear long skirts or you cannot enter the temple. The trees growing inside the temples are fantastic

Amazing Ruin meets Nature. Wow just amazing!! I've never seen anything like it. Spectacular to see this work of Wonder consumed by these hundreds or thousands years old trees. I'm not sure which one I'm in awe with, the temple or the force of nature. When you have both intertwined together, it makes for a jaw dropping sight! What a delight to be able to witness this amazing Wonder. So many people, hard to capture photos without people in the way. I was there during the low season, June, still there were large crowd. I can't imagine how crowded it would be during the high season.

In need of restoration . After a breathtaking visit around Angkor wat and then the bayon temples the temple of tomb radar was sadly disappointing . It's in the process of being renovated so is currently a pile of rubble. My advice is spend the most time at Angkor wat and definatly invest in the tour guide there as it sets you up for all the temples

Beautiful in the rain. The tomb raider temple is more beautiful when standing amongst it. We headed here after Angkor Wat so it would have to be something impressive to beat that. In the early afternoon, the rain had started to fall and we learnt how the rain freshens up the moss turning the stones an almost mystical green hue. If it wasn't for all the travellers (myself included!) trying to capture every possible angle on our cameras, you could mistakenly think you were in a fantasy land. Go and escape to another land.

Another Amazing Site - Tomb Raider. Yes as the name suggests, the movie was inspired here. Lovely amazing place as to how the tree roots have grown so high and over the structures of the Temple - just so unique. A must visit, very few steps but lots of walking- can be done in an hour. Start at West and end at the east side or vice-verse. We enjoyed it very much. Nature is so so beautiful here.
Wonderful power of nature . Amazing sight!! Sadly we got lost and missed some of the most memorable trees, but it was a very beautiful sight. Definitely worth going to
Absolutely stunning. An ancient temple overrun by the jungle. Voted 'most photogenic temple' by our family :)I felt like I had fallen into the set of the Jungle Book!
Very cool, with trees growing into the temple. Spung trees grow within the temple, knitting together the ancient blocks. Supporting the temple and destroying it at the same time.
Fascinating place to visit.. I fell in love with the symbiosis of the trees and buildings. They are so beautiful and amazing. I would be back to visit with my family.

the guardian of the temples. These majestic trees are the heroes of this temple. Every single tree rises up into the sky with the earth holding it strong. These giants stand tall guarding its children.
another temple. another temple so spread it over a few days or you may loose the value..exciting structures oozing with history,,,
Beautiful but can be crowded. The trees that are have grown through the temple is really a sight to see. This destination is very popular for tourists and can be very crowded at times.

Photographers dream . Although this temple has suffered serious damage over the past 500 years or so I think it is the most interesting temple of all in this region. Better carvings snd structures and the photo opportunities or great. Very interesting with various angles, doorways, carvings and tree roots taking over some areas. Pick a day with good sunlight and take a good camera.

Another beautiful part of the complex.. This part of the larger Angkor temple complex is beautiful and well traveled. The iconic tree sits right in the middle growing out of the temple showing the strength of Mother Nature over time. A must visit.

Love the trees!. We have to thank Angelina Jolie for bringing the excitement to our teens after watching Tomb's Raider! Definitely made it more interesting for them. For the adults, it's magical without all that. The trees wrapping around the structure truly is beautiful.

Beautiful but busy. This was probably the attraction I was most excited to see and the temple and surrounding area is absolutely stunning. However it was absolutely crammed with tourists, many of them massive groups following a leader with a big flag. It was hard to enjoy the scenery at times with all of the noise and traffic. A lot of the place is carved out by little paths and these paths became super full. I heard a man in front of me say that it was like salmon trying to swim upstream. Even so, this is a spectacular area that 100% can not be missed. The mixture of man made and nature here is just incredible.
Trees are Awesome. Lara Croft Tomb Raider was filmed here. Somehow the tree roots brings out the character of this temple. I can't describe it. You should go and see so you will understand.

beatiful but decimated. keep your angkor wat tickets. they work and are checked everywhere. the site is the most ruined among the angkor wat temples. i am proud that the indian govt. is co-funding to restore the temple. there were huge..i mean really huge trees at the site, with the highlight being the 400 year old tree which has grown on top of a structure with its roots entwined around the structure. the site is being resuscitated stone by stone but it might not happen in my lifetime.
the best temple. i think it was the most beautiful temple, because you can see how trees grow on the old temples. amazing!

Magnificent.. Probably my most favorite out of the big 3 temples. You have to go early (right after Angkor sunrise) when it's not crowded by tour people in order to properly appreciate the power struggle between man and nature. This is also one of the places where Tomb Raider was shot (the other one a nearby temple called Banteay Kdei).Take lots of pictures! The place is just so photogenic I'm certain you'd have stunning photographs even if you're not a pro.

Truly memorable experien. To Prohm temple allows the visitor to experience what the explorers found when they found the temples engulfed by the jungle...trees are as much the star of this temple as the stone and carving. Walking through crumbling doorways held together by massive tree roots is s truly memorable experience and a great contrast to the justly famous Angkor Wat nearby.

Trees growing out of temples and walls. Ta Phrom is among the most visited temples in Angkor. The enchanting sights which captivate the visitors are the giant trees growing out of the temples and the roots wrapping the ruins. This temple received added worldwide recognition as a location set for the movie Tomb Raiders starring Angelina Jolie in 2001. Even platforms are built in a couple of places for visitors to get the best angle for the most memorable photos.Certainly a must visit in the Angkor itinerary.
See it to believe it..... Ta Prohm, probably the very best proof of how old these temples are, knowing how many years a tree needs to grow as thick as you will find them in Ta Prohm. Stunning!

see it before it crumbles apart. people would go to siem reap only for the angkor vat, bayon temple and ta prohm. this is in a very dilapidated condition. see it before it crumbles down. restoration work is in progress so some parts are inaccessible or where you need to be careful walking through. sure you carry a huge amount of drinking water. can be very dehydrating. also best to take a licensed guide

Hauntingly mesmerizing. Ta Prohm amidst tall vegetation is hauntingly mesmerizing - the only problem you might have is to find a moment to have it to yourself while you try to capture its beauty with a camera (without another person in the picture). To beat the crowds, go early when everyone is at Angkor Wat waiting for sunrise.
Temples. I enjoyed an hour here walking around exploring the temples with the tree roots growing out of them,good photos.

A must go and see before it crumbles. You feel very little surrounded by these huge roots of trees embracing the old ruins of the historical site. Many huge trees are still strangling the man made temples, dwarfing the magnificent doorways and balustrades with their mighty roots and trunks.

Trees + Temple = Wow!. Ta Prohm is indeed very unique in the way that the old trees blend in perfectly with the temple itself. The whole scenery is just amazing. No need to say, bring a good camera with you.
Rain out but loved it. Tight spaces and lots of tourists, so not many photo opportunities, but great history and beautiful nonetheless. Certainly worth exploring.

Temple with unusual vegetation. This temple has lots of great vegetation growing thru it but care needed when walking thru a lot is just being held in place by the tree roots. Great place for unusual pictures

I think ... my most favourite temple visit!. The fact that is was not a towering formidable temple like the others - but still managed to have an amazing 'presence' and energy to it! We had our fabulous and informative guide sharing history and facts, and even joined us in sitting quietly in one of the gardens when we were lucky enough to be alone ... and meditated! It was an awesome experience ... very grounding.

Great walk around iconic Angkor location. The "Tomb Raider" temple was very enjoyable to walk around with the growth of trees in and through the remains. Worth reading up on these main sites (+ Bayon, Angkor Wat etc.) to learn more about rather than just walk through, which will add a lot more to the experience.

Loved out. Visited this temple in pouring rain so went back next morning for proper look. I loved it ... The way the ruins have been left with the amazing trees growing over and around is wonderful to see. Beautiful almost gold trees. Definitely worth visiting.
Nature taking back. A dream coming true visiting the Ta Prohm temple. Nature is taking back with roots looking like enormous octopus arms. Amazing.

Nature eventually claims everything!. This is a beautiful temple, which has become one with nature! The peace that you feel here is probably not because it is/was a place of worship, but because it blended so beautifully with the surroundings...

Very atmospheric and interesting place. Ta Prohm is a smaller site than many of the others in the area but so appealing with the trees growing around the ruins. Take time though, don't rush around with the crowds and do not forget to make sure your camera is working

Pretend You Are Indianna Jones. Absolutely loved this temple. While it is disappointing that the growing trees are starting to break up the temple, it is awesome to be able to see the trees growing over the stone work. Lovely colours, and nice and shady (a great relief from the heat), this temple, is definitely one of the must-visits.
amazing attraction. another site to visit was a nice experience to visits this location a lovely hot day go prepared for a lot of walking

Ruins. This probably the most ruined of the major temples, but this makes it perhaps the most mysterious of the temples. Lara Croft Tomb raider was filmed here and to see towering trees literally swallowing up the temple us awesome. Where to start on preserving and conserving such a spectacular place is the question.

Ta Prohm. Never miss this the cotton trees grown on stone structures is something to see......
All other temples are good but this on is a classic...amazing
Tohm ridea . Ta prohm temple in tohm ridea very nice with the big tree cover .it stay in small tour around can see after angkor thom .

Another beautiful temple! . Ta Prohm was really beautiful - all aspects of this temple were so different and there was so much to see wherever you looked!
It was really interesting to see the trees growing through the ruins.
The grounds of this temple are very spacious with fewer tourists around as well.

Crowded but it is possible to escape!. It does get very busy, but it is one of the best temples to visit and is worth braving the crowds. Most of the tourist groups, families and older visitors will stick to the main route on the wooden walk way. For the more agile, it's possible to walk through the temple ruins and find lots of quiet viewing spots away from the crowds.

Like being in a movie set. When I was young I watched Angelina Jolie's Tomb Raider and was amazed at the temple where it was set. Later I found out that some scenes were set in Ta Prohm.When I finally got the chance to visit the temple, it was truly impressive.Ta Prohm is only temple in the complex that has the unique tree growing around it.You really do feel like you are in a movie set as it is just seemed so surreal that something like this is nature made not man made.Combination of the trees, it's quiet location within a lush forest and the fact that it is not as crowded as Angkor Wat itself made Ta Prohm my favourite temples in the Angkor Wat complex.

Not just because of Angelina. Worth to see. Driver told us that tourists didn't know this place before Tomm Raider movie was released. I suspected the place is just Hollywood reference. We were positively impressed with temple.It is big and has many objects inside to explore. Thing that makes it special is TREES growing inside and around old buildings with huge magic roots. Very impressive!

Overtaken by nature. Located in same area as Angkor Wat. Few minutes away by tuk-tuk. Very impressive to see how the roots of the tropical trees strangle the temple. Even in the low season (june) rather crowded with tons of Chinese running rudely in front of your camera without any respect.
Mystifying. This is a truly majestic place that transports you back in time. The trees growing in everywhere are fascinating, and the carvings are truly beautiful. We recommend it!
Exciting. Very nice location for this attraction. You are going to see this place if you are on tour to see the rest. I can't say enough that everyone must visit Cambodia just to see all this.

Amazing!. Amazing how the trees have grown in and around everything! It's hard to imagine what it must have been like to live in the time that these temples were built. I was incredibly humbled to travel throughout this country for it is the most spiritual place I have ever been.

The "Tomb Raider" temple. This temple has been partially reclaimed by the jungle, adding a sense of mystery and beauty that typified the "Tomb Raider" movies. It's also a faster and easier site to see than the primary Angor Wat temple.
Favourite!. This had to be one of our favourite temples, so much so we visited here twice at different times of the day to get good photos. This temple is very popular so expect some crowds.
Incredible. The history of this area is incredible. A guided tour helps to put the enormity of this into perspective.

Man + Nature = Awesomeness. This temple is so cool because it has become so much a part of the nature around it. The trees are one reason that this temple is still standing. It's a symbiotic relationship and freakin amazing!

One word: AMAZING!. This must not be missed. Apart from its fame from the film Lara Croft: Tomb Raider (2001) starring Angelina Jolie, the ruins and roots bowled me over. I had to keep my mouth from gaping and because we went there when it was raining, everything is glistening. It's a special place.

Looking for Lara Croft. This one was featured in the movie! All the ruins at Ankor are unique in there own way. They are all worth a look. Wear comfortable walking shoes. Wear sunblock & a hat. Even bring a sun umbrella.
Engulfed by trees. You can not avoid being trapped in centuries ago, imaging the daily life here. If you are in Siem Reap you have to be here, feeling the essence of the Kmher empire

Awesome historical sites. The ruined temples (actually it's a university) was an awe to visit. We went there after the rain in the afternoon, so it's a bit muddy and flood at certain areas of the temple. Overall, it's a place where you can take spectacular photos.
