Very different feel of a Wat. The overgrown Sprung tree roots in this temple location makes for a very different temple feel from the rest of the Angkor visits. This is a small temple so again visit either really early at 7-8am or late afternoon 4-5pm when there are less hoards of mainland Chinese tourists. Because they come in multiple large tour buses, you will end up seeing mini China if you visit at about 9-10am ~ noon in June and July. Line cutting, hoarding artifacts for picture taking instead of appreciation makes for a miserable experience if you visit the temple when they are there.

Majestic. This is a must visit. We had a personal guide to take us around who had alot of knowledge which was very interesting, would of missed a lot of the little intricate details and interesting facts if we hadn't. It was the same place that tomb raider was filmed. He also doubled as our personal camera man. Again lots of walking and suggest taking water with you.
Oh my gosh.... Loved seeing major trees grow on the ruins. . This must be one of my favorite places ever. The history, the large trees growing on top of ruins... Worth a visit.

Favourite temple. This temple was easily my favorite of the ones I saw. You walk through a leafy track to get in where there is a victim of landmines band playing traditional music. This sets up well for the temples which is a maze of conserved walls, trees growing out of buildings and some ruins.They have done an excellent job with the conservation of this place but its a little difficult to navigate...although getting lost in this temple is by no means a bad thing
Amazing. So much beauty. You have to take your time and you can see so much in and around the temples. I took so many pictures and bought post cards. Experience of a lifetime
Mystical. Truly mystical atmosphere, there is a sense of the temple being swallowed by the jungle over time, well worth the short tuk tuk ride from Ankor Wat

Very Unique & Beautiful, Movie"Tomb Raiders" shot here.. It is a very Unique temple from others as it has Massive Trees growing on its stone walls. It is big needs atleast 1-2 hrs, bring Umbrella as you will be walking a lot & plenty of water to drink.

Alot under construction.. We went here after Angkor Wat and although the trees and things looked amazing growing out of the buildings the whole area was quite damaged and parts were under construction. We went in June at the hottest part of the day, loads of tourists and there was just nowhere to escape the heat, worth a look but wouldn't make a special trip
stunning. Its amazing how nature takes back the temples...the tree roots are awesome, stunning and scary at the same time. It was an experience we wont forget. A must go when in Siem Reap...

Tomb Raider!. My favourite temple out of my 3 day visit. This temple appeared in the blockbuster ‘Lara Croft Tomb Raider’ movie. Built during the 12th-13th century by Jayavarman VII this temple consists of concentric galleries accompanied by stone towers and gopuras. This site is a traditional ruin that you can expect to enjoy for at least 1-2 hours.

Its breathtaking and the view is marvelous. This was quite special and must be added to anyone's itinerary. Massive trees snake through the walls and their power has destroyed parts of this temple. After Bayon, this is probably my favorite temple.

Favourite temple. Awesome experience seeing all the temples but Ta Prohm was my favourite. The trees growing over and through the buildings was amazing to see, I could have spent hours there. When you go be prepared to take lots of photos.

Tomb Rider movie! yeee!. i really surprise that i come to see a Hollywood temple, really Amazing that you can't forget it. the tree had grow on the temples. and the temples look like a mystery place. Like it

The famous trees with the great roots are here. Speechless. Stunning place covered with jungle. As we walked through we were blown away by the power and size of the trees growing over these ancient walls.
Excellent temple - must see!. This is even better than Angkor Wat (although you have to see that too). It's a lot more compact than Angkor Wat and is certainly a must see. Highly recommended.

My favourite temple of them all :). The old tree roots coming out of the floor into the temple are a sight to see!!!
Little details make all the difference

Pretend you're Indiana Jones. While Angkor Wat has been meticulously kept up and cleared, Ta Prohm is pretty much in its original state, with tumbled walls and trees growing through the ruins. It's a beautiful site and has fewer tourists than the Angkor complex.

great place. Ta Prom temple is really nice place, the temple is famous from film Tomb Rider, and most of the time is full of tourists. Everybody want to visit Angkor and be ready and prepare yourself for fight with many tourist to take nice pictures withou people. Temple is amazing and ignore tourists and try to enjoy it.

Temple and its gigantic trees are amazing; Tomb Raider is just an addition.. Aside from the fact that the Movie Tomb Raider of Angelina Jolie made an additional impact for the tourists, the temple and its gigantic trees are amazing already. Foot-walks are available so tourist doesn't need much effort while exploring. Restoration is still on going.

Take 2 days and split the day. The best way to see all the temples is split your day into early morning and late afternoon - see 2 of the smaller temples in morning and 1of larger ones in the afternoon- because it's Hot and humid and I live where it's the same weather and was beat every afternoonUse a guide if you can and you will get more out of it.

Ruins - A tree eating the temple. It is a long walk before reaching this temple. I almost passed out. I enjoyed looking the the trees. They look scary. I asked the tuktuk guy if I can bribe him to take me all the way almost to the temple but he said it is not allowed. The young boy was selling me postcards and told me it is a very short walk and he must be running if it only took him 15 minutes. Bring a hat, lots of water and take lots of rest in between. Be careful of dehydration especially if you travel in June.
Absolutely worth a visit. It's amazing to see how the forest and the temple have grown together. So many great pictures to take! Go see it!

Amazing nature . Ta Prohm is a temple which is well worth a look. It is a fight between ancient buildings and the jungle. The Spung trees are trying their best to reclaim the temple. The are unfortunately slowly destroying the temple but they are amazing to see all the same. The biggest problem with this and all the other temples is the locals trying to sell thier cheap souvenirs and they will not take no for an answer and make getting in and getting out a problem. The best part is that they appear to have been banned from entering and hassling the tourists inside.
Tomb rider temple. Amazing place. All the complex is unforgettable adventure. You cannot miss it out. Comfortable clothing, shoes and camera is all you need!

tomb raider. yes this is the place and it doesn't disappoint - so much to it with the living trees growing through the masonry. Some excellent restoration work has gone on and continues. A must see, simple as that.

Lara Croft Tomb Raider. You must go see this temple. Fantastic ruin of disarray. Stand in the center temple at what is left of the altar where the prince once prayed. Realize the walls were once covered in precious stones, rubies, emeralds, sapphires, and diamonds when the kingdom existed.
Best must to see . It amazing temple on the the wold have big stand on the roof of temple it was tohm rider movie .but had a lot people in there hard to take photo .

Stuning. We visited this magical place and the kids loved exploring the hidden hallways and mysterious courtyards. The trees were fascinating and the kids really came to life with their imagination. It's one of those places you can only imagine until you see it in person. We had a guide that could tell us some info but unlike Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, I think you could experience it on your own and not miss anything.

Definitely go if you are visiting Cambodia. Amazing temple in the clutches of the forest. Come and see for yourself the amazing force of nature and you will be left in awe. Don't miss the opportunity to visit this temple while you can. It is truly an amazing experience.

Tomb raider temple. Ta Prohm is famous as it was used by the film Tomb Raider with Angelina Jolie. The temple is partly overtaken by huge trees which give it kind of atmosphere. Besides the Bayon temple andthe fmous Angkor Wat is one of the main attractions of the city and place to visit.

Loved it but time it right. Easy to get around and see everything. Lots to see and its amazing how far the trees roots go. There are some areas that are not accessible but when you look inside you can clearly see why.The best way to get photos is to walk through the temple between the waves of visitors.If there is a tour group in front of you either skip ahead a little or stay back for 5 minutes. Then you can get great shots without lots of tourists in your photos.

Great historical site. One of the must-sees if you are in Siem Reap for sure. A beautiful temple, and its location in the jungle made it very cool. It was however the only temple in our Angkor trip where we were ambushed by young children hawking souvenirs outside, so watch out for that.A great destination overall.

Wowzers! A stunning part of history.. As we were on our honeymoon we didn't want to spend days on the tourist trail, yet we didn't want to travel to Cambodia and not experience the temples in all their glory.We settled on one day, embarking on our trip quite early in the morning, to take in the amazing sights of Angkor Wat, Bayon, Ta Keo and Ta Prohm. I've never seen Tomb Raider, so that reference didn't impress me, however, I was drawn to the imagery of the temple being swallowed by the jungle and imagined this is how the whole of Angkor would have been when the explorers first stumbled across it. I wasn't disappointed! Ta Prohm is impressive, to say the very least. It is so unique and very commanding. You can see and feel the power of the jungle that enveloped it. And yet, it has a overwhelming ethereal quality about it, graceful and beautiful. Yes, it is hot and yes, it is dusty and YES, it does get busy! However, it is worth it. I seesawed between wanting to run around and have adventures amid the closed courtyards, narrow corridors, tangled roots and the jumbled piles of carved stones to gently walking along and immersing myself in this spectacular history.
Nature meets temple. If you've seen the movie tomb raider then you'll probably be familiar with this location. It's a magnificent temple which is surrounded by nature.

Tomb Raider Temple. Really amazing how the trees grow from the ancient stones. Lovely photo opportunities but be prepared to queue in order to await your turn to get the photo you want. Many tour parties from Asia who will think nothing of taking 8 shots each whilst everyone waits. I do not know how this would play out in the height of the season but just about bearable now.Worth seeing though it is a beautiful temple

Lara Croft Tombraider May Have Killed This Site. The Cambodian government chose not to renovate this site, using it as an example of how the temples were seen in the past. There is a large tree, made famous by the Syfy movie, growing in and around the temple but its not as picturesque as one might expect and the roots and crumbled rocks make it somewhat unstable to walk.

Tomb raider - but morning is better!. Nothing more to review that others haven't cover, but GO IN THE MORNING during rainy season.The sunrise at Angkor Wat is probably cloudy and you won't get to enjoy that experience now days. The reason why you want to go early is that 1) It's much more cooler2) less tourists at key spots3) LESS TOURISTS AT KEY SPOTSI visited in the afternoon, and not only was it hot, but there must have been thousands of Chinese tourists invading the place. Ta Phohm is famous for its jungle like trees consuming the temple, but you have to actually wait in line to take a photo of the nicer places. Not something you want to do in the jungle.Seriously, go in the morning.
Majestic. One of the best temples in the area, with a lot of unique grandeur on display, with trees mingling with stones to give an eerie aura to this place.
great temple. I would recommend to visit this at noon time as there was less tourists.as there were several covered trees around.

Tomb raider temple. Tomb raider temple is an example of something very beautiful which was lost for a long period of time and then found again. Can see the effects of nature. Great work by the India archaeologists in fixing it up.

Get ready for a lot of dusty walking. Place is stifling hot in the afternoon, and there's no way but to walk through the heat. Bring lots of water and sunblock. They allow hats and sunglasses, and you won't ever need to remove your shoes :)The temple is beautiful, but some places are really ruins so be wary of the signs/lines. We entered through the West Gate -- that will take you inside the temple. If you wish to exit through the East Gate, you have to get out of the temple, and go around it, but still within the outer wall. Seems confusing, but there should be a sign there indicating that you can go around the temple, inside the wall bounds. You can buy cheap souvenirs right outside the gate. I made the mistake of buying small tokens in Angkor Wat, when it was way cheaper in Ta Prohm. They accept PHP, aside from USD.

Very scenic temple!. Really enjoyed my trip to Ta Phohm, it was so beautiful wandering around with all the trees snaking down the temple walls. Can see why it was used in the Indiana Jones and Lara Croft films as its so picturesque & couldn't stop taking photos! Would definatly recommend seeing Ta Prohm temple when in the Siem Reap area.

A must visit in Siem Reap!. One of a kind temples in the Angkor Wat tour! The roots surrounding the temples and the history about the temple gives a very ancient feel.. reminds me of tomb raider. Do not miss this out. Best time to visit will be in the early afternoon - late afternoon.

So Cool. We saw the pictures from the kids and travel broshures and loved to walk through the remains of the building. Restoration work is under way to preserve some of the building. lots of the blocks have fallen due the tree roots knocking them over.
Tomb raiders site!. Amazingly beautiful temple with trees snaking throughout the walls. Watch the movie before and after your. Is it not to be missed!
Amazing. Such an interesting place. Beautiful and full of history. The way the trees have taken back the land is amazing to see

Beautiful . This is the most amazing place I have ever visited, it's completely surreal, no one could be disappointed.
I have no more to say because some things just don't need babble , but the minimum word limit requires I go on before it adds the review

By far the best. I will take this place in my heart where it will hold a special place for the rest of my life. Unlike other temples it was in ruins but so very very beautiful. It was nice to wander around unspoilt ruins where nature has taken over
Incredible and atmospheric. Absolutely worth the visit. To see the spung and strangler figs that have overrun this place up close is amazing. Go now before nature finishes it off.

My favorite temple, I felt in other times!. In this temple I had the feeling of something big, of a world full of history and amazing things that can not be explained with words only contemplated with the eyes and felt in the heart; Its truly amazing the overgrown fig and trees interwining with the ruins, I can only wonder how how how they builded this at that time; how much will and inspiration had this civilization in the 12 cent! Come on I want such inspiration! This Buddhist monastry is very impressive!

All it's made out to be.. Do note that for Tourist, the entrance Fee to the Heritage Site of the Ancient Temples is US$20.00 for a Day.Our Guide took us first to The Main Attraction which is of course Angkor Wat. After we had walked and seen the various interesting sections we then departed this Temple via another 'Gate' and proceeded out to the area where our Tuk-Tuk was awaiting us. Exiting here we cross the other section of the Moat and after a refreshment pit stop we proceeded to Ta Prohm which is some distance away.  There we stop at the entrance Gate and there is a l-o-n-g walk to the Temple. The 'path' is quite level and wide and is of compressed earth. At the end of the walk you arrive at Ta Prohm. What catches your eye immediately is the scene that has been depicted on countless of Post Cards, Photos, Paintings etc. i.e. the huge Tree that has grown over the ruins. This is nature claiming back . The tour of this Temple will show that there are a few more areas where Nature has claimed it's roots ... so to speak. Restoration work is slowly in progress as evident by cranes and blocked off areas. The section where there was a Chamber built for the King's Mother incorporating gems that supposedly caught the sunlight and illuminated the Chamber was fascinating but alas, all the Gems have been lost to robbers !!! and what is left behind are the holes where these Gems were once embedded in. A dream place for the avid photographer. Be patient for the crowds to clear so you can get the photo you want. Then, be prepared for that long walk back. However, do note that there are a few enterprising chaps who would offer a pillion ride on their scooters to the Gate for a small fee in US $ of course. Even the very young children selling souvenirs ... magnets , books etc. will trade in US dollars and mind you they will very cheekily ask for clean decent notes !!!! All in all, be prepared to walk and walk. Another item from our 'bucket list' that has been ticked off.

A must see amongst the temples. By the time I got to this temple I was fed up with the heat and walking around in the shade was really refreshing. It wasn't as busy as the other main sights but there still a few people milling about. It's scary and fascinating how nature reclaims everything around it, I dare say this temple looks better as a ruin overtaken by nature than in its once full splendor.
Worth a visit!. Again, visit before 10am when hordes of Chinese tourists arrive. This temple was amazing and dont forget to try the small echo room!

15/6/2016. Amazing Giants trees. Very good spot for taking photos but u need to wanders around to look for them . There a a little Buddha face embedded into one of the giant tree. Ask one of the many park ranger "where is the tree with the small face" immediately she knows what I was referring to and took me to see the face

spacious ruins where tomb raider shot. went there early in the early morning to avoid the big crowds. there are two gates on two ends so please remember to tell the driver which gate to wait for you - otherwise it will be quiet a walk to the other end. love this place!
See my comments on Angkor Wat. See my comments on Angkor Wat. Don't forget, some areas within these temples are still places of worship and so dress modestly and behave respectfully.
Add it to your list to see while at Angkor. 'Tomb raider temple' yep add to your list. Recognisable and really interesting. You do need transport from Angkor Wat.

Magical nature takes over . Was not dissapointed with this sight! Nature truy shows its power! Spent most time here and took loads of pics! Can see why they shot tb raider here! Looks like a hollywood set

Ta Prohm is all that's written on the tin and more!. After seeing the photos of Ta Prohm it was the temple I was most looking forward to and it did not disappoint. I expected to be sharing the place with the crowds but was pleasantly surprised to be able to enjoy relative solitude (and my photos certainly benefited from this). I think a lot of people will do this temple second or third in a day, so perhaps we had the advantage by heading straight here first thing. Ta Prohm has a certain tranquility that even some of the more unrestored temples didn't quite achieve. You can really imagine yourself as someone who simply stumbled upon this wondrous place whilst on a wee stroll in the jungle. Also - if you are in love with Ta Prohm, make sure you tack on Preah Khan and (if time allows) Boeng Mealea to your itinerary as they are also beautifully unrestored and have a similar feel.
Marvellous. The first temple we visited and we marvelled at the good condition of of the buildings. A must see to respect times gone by.

Great photos to be had . Another popular temple made famous by the movie very busy around the tree everyone is familiar with from the movie may have to hope in line for that pic but apart from that it's a big temple and the crowds thin out after this point.
Worth it. The trees are very impressive. The crowds of self-entitled tourists blocking traffic is annoying and the bad smell is unfortunate. I would still recommend seeing it though.

amazing views - just like the Tomb Raider movie. Great temple and the ruins are amazing the way the trees have overtaken them and caused much damage to the structure. Lots of great photo opportunities here. OK to visit later in the day when hot as plenty of spots for shade and relief from the sun.

Step into History . Listening to the guide's stories on the history of the khmer empire and it's conquests throughout much of Southeast Asia, it leaves one to imagine the scale and magnificence of the buildings that were built in the 11th century thereabouts that housed it's people, livestock, animals like horses elephants oxen. Although Ta Prohm gained further prominence from it being part of a scene in the movie tomb raider, a visit to Siem Reap is incomplete without walking through the silent compound of Ta Prohm and it's buildings, stopping to marvel at huge and old trees sitting atop the aged stones from yester-years. A must see.

Expect unexpected....woooowww!!!. I've never thought there are places on earth like this....jungle-architecture...visit when there are not so many visitors...since I was in Angkor several times, rainy season makes difference :)

Like something straight out of jungle book!. Keeper of the temple is so old you're just not quite sure how long hers been there. Incredible to wander through. Really is like another world. You can't go to Cambodia without going here, it's criminal.

Favorite Temple near Siem Reap!. We visited Angkor Wat, Bayon and Ta Prohm while in Siem Reap. Ta Prohm was probably the least known of the three, but we found it the most interesting. Of the three it was the most in disrepair and the least restored, but this significantly added to its charm. The jungle foliage had taken over much of the exterior which created some amazing views of trees, roots and vines growing what looked like straight from the rock to extend in every direction. It was also the least crowded of the 3 which was another bonus.
The most amazing place. What an amazing place to visit, it looks mystical in the early morning with mist still hanging in the air, makes a great photo
Go at sunrise . Go at sunrise and you'll have the place to yourself! Wait one hour and you'll be fighting for space! Really beautiful, favorite temple

Eery. This temple gives you a real sense for what the years of war and neglect have done to these edifices. Much is still in ruins. The tree roots are huge and resemble the cobras commonly depicted with their gods.
Amazing display of nature at work. This is my favorite by far, it is amazing to see these giant trees and how they have interacted with this temple. Nature at it's at finest.
The best. We toured Angkor Wat and Bayon on the same day, and for my entire family, Ta Prohm was our favorite. The trees and ancient temple are just amazing. I cannot say enough - you must go.

Nature at it's best. Wow nature sure is showing us it's in control. The tourists were taking so long taking selfies I couldn't get a quick snap of the tree I wanted to but I still got heaps of other great photos.

Enigmatic temple left to the jungle . The trees among the ruins make this temple exude its unique appeal. I walked about 30 minutes from the West entrance to get to this point where some of Angelina Jolie's scenes were taken in the Tomb Raider movie as Lara Croft. I also found a face tower in the temple similar to Bayon. Large figs are everywhere strangling the temple ruins! So many hidden corners with attractive wall sculptures.

Breathtaking. I admit it - the only reason for choosing this out of all the amazing places to see in Angkor Park was Tomb Raider. Yep, this is where Angelina did her thing as Lara Croft! It was a great move. I'd read other reviews that this temple is always packed (because of Tomb Raider), but it wasn't so. I was able to walk around the entire place at my leisure, and although there were other people, there were no real crowds. The landscape and architecture is spellbinding.

Another tick off my Bucket list. This is a place that has always fascinated me, now that I have visited it I have not been dissapointed. It is certainly a must see if visiting Siem Reap. Its amazing how the tree roots have shaped the surroundings.

Famous from the movie Tomb Raider. This temple is famous from the tomb raider movie. It has beautiful colours and the combination with the vegetation is really great. A must see. This temple is on bicycle distance of the entrance.

Magical. I remember walking into this temple down a long road of falling leaves. You knew it was going to be magical. The tree roots breaking through the temple are massive and glorious, but the walkways have been repaired and stabilized so you don't have to worry about it being unsafe for kids. This was also the coolest (temperature) temple of them all as it's in the forest. We didn't think our guide was necessary for this one as there were so many tour groups all walking around the small interior, so you could listen to any one of them to get a better understanding of the history.
Strong tree. It is amazing to witness how the roots grew over the temple and its means to survive for 400 years before its been discovered.
great atmosphere. maybe this was my favourite temple in angkor wat. It is quite in ruin, but its decay adds to its charm
Enjoy my trip to Ta Prohm Temple!!. This temple is like inside a forest. Trees grow everywhere at the temple. Many good spots of photo taking and must queue for photo taking. Really visit this temple

This place was amazing. I liked this place even more than Angkor Wat. The trees growing out of the walls/roofs etc was really amazing, you can see how the roots grow out from them into the structures. The trees were also massive, some of them might have been too big because they were cut down a bit at the top. Locals outside at the entrance jumped on me to buy things which was annoying, but overall that place is a must see.
Family trip. Beautiful. One of the most amazing place i have ever been. Hope they will maintain the place as it is. Will definitely be back.

The Final Leg of our Trip to the Temples. We visited Angkor Wat, the Bayon Temple and finished at Ta Prohm. The day was very hot bot fortunately Ta Prohm is very compact and despite its obvious celebrity appeal it was very interesting and easy to move around. I didn't know much about Lara Croft but am a lot wiser now
Interesting Trees. Is an interesting temple for of old" tress growing on top of the temple. Go during none peak season. If not you will only enjoyed the "people" instead of the temple

Wow. Lara Croft was here.....
Loved the trees that has grown over and on top of the buildings. It's almost like it's time for nature to reclaim the land!
Great to see other nation contributing t the restoration of the great piece of architecture and the amazing temple.
Loved it and can't wait till they finish restoring the whole place.
OMG!. You can't stop begin amazed in every temple in Angkor. This is of course one of the most magical ones. You won't believe it can be in the same world you have always lived.

Mesmerizing!. This one was arguably my favourite temple here in Siem Reap! Most certainly one of it's kind anywhere in the world. I understand that it's even more beautiful during the wet season when moss grows on the stone, which changes the colour and ambiance around the temple.
jungle temple. ITS a temple that cover by the natural tree. it just restore finish in years 2016.. i would say must visit temple in siem reap.

Untouched . I read reviews that this is a great temple to see in the morning to beat the crowds. I went at noon and it wasn't nearly as crowded as Angkor Wat or Bayon were hours before. Those two are where you should go first. It is cool to venture to Ta Prohm later in the day and see the immediate juxtaposition between the restored sites versus the untouched Ta Prohm.
Your own version of Tomb Raider. It was great to see the temples built and have been taking over by these humongous trees.. Your own version of Lara Croft..

Great Temple - fascinating. I enjoyed this visit very much. There is a lot of conservation going on but essentially it is a picturesque ruin in the jungle. Some of Tomb Raider was filmed here.Of particular interest are the massive trees growing through the middle of the temple. Really interesting - don't miss it!

Trees, roots, and rocks together!. If you can only visit one temple besides Angkor Wat, make it this one. Because of the large, beautiful shade trees, we were able to sit and enjoy this temple. The roots have destroyed the temple in some parts and keep it together in other parts. It is fascinating! The green cast from the coupled with the trees and roots separates this temple from the others. It is very peaceful, and a beautiful place to shoot panoramas! It is a bit of a walk in but so well worth it especially with all of the shade!
Best experience. Angelina Jolie was here... our tuk tuk driver was telling bout this temple it seem nature curse on this land I don't how true.is it but it's a life time experience

An extremely special temple, guards should be able to better manage large groups of tourists to improve the experience. Having visited Cambodia as a change from going all the way to Europe I didn't really take too much time to research Siem Reap. The temples looked interesting and I had not been there before so hey why not! Wow, the temples of the Angkor Wat complex were breath taking and just remarkable as to how they were formed and the history associated with them is amazing. Sunset at Angkor Wat is definately something for the bucket list. It was very hot and tiring exploring the temples but such an amazing place in the world. The way the trees encapsulate this amazing temple is remarkable and beautiful. Pity about the huge numbers of Chinese tourists that embarked on the place with no respect of others. Whilst I did my best to block them out, it did detract from the experience.

Miracle of Nature. This part of Angkor Wat, is worldwide indentified due to strong presentation in several magazines and travellers.
A miracle of Nature, that covered and protect the temple from the visibility
of contemporary distroyers.

Tombraider temple... . Personally i Find this Temple way more beautifull then Angkor Wat. In this Temple nature took back the place and all the Stones are covered with Trees and plants. Only to bad that there is a big yellow Construction Crane in the Temple. This is the Temple that was been used in the Tombraider movie....well to bad that Lara Croft was not there anymore.

Old Temple in Angkor . This is one of the older temples in the Jungle and is being restored. It has many trees growing through it and is very interesting. The restoration work is well done and there is a lot to see.
It was AMAZING 👏. This is the place where Angelina Jolie's film TOMB RAIDER was filmed. It is sometimes called the Tree-Eaten Temple. One of the best temples in Siem Reap. <3
great place. this is one place you need to go when you come here. you can get any taxi , it is easy, some good food places near here also

Magical place. Nature is such a lovely thing. It's such a magical place to visit. The way the trees grew around the temple, such as the archways, the statues. It's like they knew that one day, people will come to see the greatness that can happen when nature and man's creation can work with each other. Loved every minute of exploring this Ta Prohm

The Jungle Reclaims.... Inspite of the Tomb Raider reference here, this is a must see just for the amazing architecture being reclaimed by the surrounding forest. I can't really do it justice with words, but if you can only see a few temples, do not miss this one.

What an amazing place. All the temples areamazing but this one shows the force of nature. Our excellent tour guide's historical information helped form a picture of a truly staggering city that existed so manycenturies ago.

A most wonderful, intriguing relic from the past. This is easily one of the best temples. Not only is it impressive with its size and lay-out, but it is preserved in the state it was found in - with trees growing along its walls and tumbled down stones kept where they were. I also noticed that regardless of the state of practical semi-destruction, everything was safe - the paths were well laid out, steel bars support the beams, etc. Despite these, you would think you yourself were discovering the temple was it was in its dilapidated state. Mysterious, interesting, intriguing - one wonders about the life that used to teem here. Easily one of my favourite temples in Siem Reap!
Beautiful. . Another beautiful temple within this amazing temple complex! So much beauty in one place. Really enjoyed these temples.

A beautiful example of the power of nature.. Also known as "The Tomb-Raider Temple" thanks to the film featuring Angelina Jolie, this stunning piece of Angkorian engineering has been part swallowed by the jungle, giving it a unique example of how fragile even one of the most sophisticated ancient civilisations was.
An absolute must see on your tours of the beautiful temples of Angkor.

Exquisite temple. This was was my favourite temple as it was in a more natural setting with lots of tree roots through many parts of the temple. This allowed for fabulous photographs. Many parts of the temple has collapsed however they are trying to preserve it. At this time of the year there is not many tourist however it is very hot. We only had to line up for only 5 to 10 minutes for the famous tomb raider shot. Spent about 1 & 1/2 hours at this temple. One not be be missed.

A highlight for me. This temple and the trees and roots are amazing, I felt a real sense of peace at this temple so surreal, wasn't busy so got lots of time to ponder and wander, this was my favourite of the three big temples
Another small temple with great trees. the trees are over 600 years old .... not sure if it is true but seems like it. The way the roots grab around the temple! Magnificent work of mother nature
The Indiana Jones in you. This is a Temple that has left "un-restaured". Giant trees are devouring the ruins. It speaks to the Indiana Jones in you,
One of a Kind.. This temple is fantastic, one of the kind. Urgent need of funds for restoration and preservation of the temple.

The temple that retains part of the jungle which had been hiding the entire city of Angkor Wat.. This particular temple is left with the jungle trees that had previously covered the entire Angkor Wat city and it gives you a good idea of how nature interacts with man made structures.

Don't Miss This Iconic Site. If you have only one day at Angkor make sure you this this unbelievable site. It takes you back centuries and is so stirring you can imagine yourself living during the height of the Khmer civilization.

Come experience the sheer power of the mammoth roots that have entwined themselves.. Breathtaking sights. Hats of to the team that worked hard in restoring every inch of what we see. Keep an hour for this temple. The roots are all over. you need to experience this and see it first hand.

A must see. This place is everything the guide books says it is. It is an absolute must see in Siemens Reap. It is just breath taking to see such an ancient structure being reclaimed by the forest. You don't need to be a pro to take amazing photos in this place.

Tomb Raider location. . Everyone knows this temple from the movie and it's interesting to see a place that looks like it was developed on a sound stage, but it's the real deal.
It's popular because of the movie, but it's a must see.

Not very impressed . It is a great place to observe how large trees have grown through the walls of the temple.Western travellers visit it mostly out of fascination for Lara Croft's Tomb Raider. However, I did not find it very impressive. Having said this, ask your guide for the story of the King mother and the 8000. That is a good story attached to the temple.
Beautiful Trees. The ancient structures and trees are something to see. So well preserved after so many centuries.It was just extremely hot. Take a lot of water.
Best temple. Was favorite one that very nice temple in siem reap ,Had a lot big tree covering on the roof of temple .
magical. it was In my opinion the best temple I saw in Angkor, it was everything I had been dreaming of. should be on everybodys bucket list travelling to Cambodia

Temple overtaken by nature! A must for tomb raider enthusiasts!. We visited this temple at sunrise to miss the crowds and there was me, my husband and 3 other tourists so we virtually had the entire temple to ourselves. Our guide told us the queue to take a photo of the tomb raider door can span past an hour in busy periods. Sunrise was a wonderful time to visit because we could take photos to our hearts content. This temple is different from most temples because the trees have taken over but this adds to the charm of the place. Unfortunately, some parts of the temple have fallen prey to the trees and have completely collapsed but sympathetic renovation work is ongoing to rebuild them but it will take years to do this. I loved this temple and the way nature has taken over. I would recommend it along with bantreay srei and the bayon temple.
very beautiful. Ta Prohm was amazing one had the big tree and tohm rider one but so many people to see in there .if you come to temple don't forget this temple
Adventure! . This amazing temple coexists with huge old trees and vegitation has taken over! It's really an amazing sight and should not miss by any means!

tree temple. famous from tomb raider scene. big tree holding up the structure.however the direction signs inside the temple is confusing. i had to circle the temple twice before i can find the other way out.

it is a time travel..... This temple is also called the tree temple.. one of the temples that is most damaged and you can see countries like India is helping to restore the site but lot of damage... but this site will take you back in time as the big tree will give you the time of tis temple.. the trees are so tall that you cannot believe how old the temple was there before.... not sure ow long these temple will survive but very very good place to get another history lesson and the power of nature,..

You gotta see it. After the majesty of Angkor Wat and the vastness of Angkor Thom , Ta Prohm was not as impressive as I was expecting. That may have been because it was getting to the end of our first day or because it was more run down than the rest. However you have to get the famous photo and pretend you with Lara Croft. There are many temples in the area with trees growing through them but this one is impressive. It is worth seeing the famous trees.

My favourite temple in Siem Reap. I came here at 7AM before their official opening time at 7.30AM and secretely sneaked into the temple. The entire temple was emty and at first it seemed like I was the only human being inside the temple which made it even more exciting and almost a bit scary to explore it. Sudenly I heared voices and realized it was a two cleaners sweeping the floors of the temple. Phew so i wasn't completely alone. But I loved the emptiness at the time i visited so i could take pictures of spots without having any tourists photobombing my pictures. It was also a very peaceful walk which I quite enjoyed and found a lot of interesting spots inside the maze like Ta Prohm. Highly recommend this tourist attraction but come early so you can avoid the crowds

Tomb Raider. It is a must to visit as Tomb Raider was filmed there. Took so many photos of trees with big roots. Do go into Echo Chamber - if you pound on your heart it echos but no echo if you talk loud. Fascinating.

My favourite in Siem Reap. Ta Prohm was my favourite as the jungle was left to grow around the temples. It truly felt like you were entering antiquity. It had a more intimate feel. Go see it before they put up more barriers to it.

Where the trees rule. This temple is now almost as famous as Angkor Wat. Whether it's from the filming of "Tomb Raider", honeymoon spot for Eva Longoria or simply just "that temple swallowed up by the forest", this place is likely on many hit lists.It's amazing to see nature trying to reclaim teritory, roots pushing aside huge lumps or simply smothering them like some giant wooden octopus. Take your time and get those perfect photos. This is a temple worth soaking in for a while, a truly ancient feeling.

My favorite temple at Angkor Wat. I loved the combination of nature and man in this temple. All the temples are wonderful but I found something so beautiful about the ruins and the power of nature. The strangler figs are impressive!
Famous Place for "Tomb Raider tree". There are great trees tower above Ta Prohm. It is surprised that the trees are very large with long leaves and roots.This is famous place for "Tomb Raider tree"
Nature and mankind together. This temple shows you how nature and mankind can be together. Trees between the rocks are impressive!

One of the must visit places in Siem Reap. Interesting combo of nature and man-made. It's a jumble of trees, fallen temple walls, carvings. Something new at every turn. e had some amazing photo opportunities and the guide explained everything in detail.

Truly not to be missed!. Amazing temple, do not miss out on this one if you visit Angkor complex. There are great photo opportunities here and the way the trees have taken over the temple will leave you with an unforgettable experience!
Amazing. What a sight with trees and roots everywhere. wonderful that restoration work is happening to preserve this site.

Holiday . This is the temple where Tomb Raider was shot.
Unbelievable... A definite must see.
A tour guide helps you understand the history behind these temples.

Wow! . I visted Ta Prohm and would highly recommend it to other visitors. Such an iconic sight with these huge trees growing up from the temple. It is amazing to see the restoration work that has been done and is continuing in an attempt to return this temple to what it once was.

Tomb Raider Temple. All of the Siem Reap temples were great but Ta Prohm was more interesting due to it being in ruin with strangler fig and other trees growing through the temple structure.
Early June week day was great and not too crowded but was very hot- 40 degrees.

Captivating!. Did the Tree or the wall come first? This was the one venue that we stayed at the most. It is like something out of a dream where the roots over stretch to cover these ancient ruins and just plain amazing to behold. Other than Ankhor Wat this was my favorite place in Siem Reap other than my Hotel. Must see!

Fascinating. Ta Prohm is the temple with the tree routes and trees growing out of the ruins. When we went in February it was so crowded with people in such a small area. The photo opportunities are endless if you can shoot the photos around the people.

Classic Image. A perfect spot to understand how nature had covered the temple complex of Angkor. Its corridors have not collapsed (as is the case of most temples) so walking around gives a feeling of their past glory. This is a Buddhist temple, pay attention to the synchretism and the presence of Hindu elements.

Stunning . This is an obvious choice for the temples so make sure you don't miss it. Just a small word of caution the street vendors in front of the temple where by far the most pushy we experienced in Cambodia.

One of my favourite temples in the region. Ta Prohm is one of my favourties in this region. All the temples are amazing and beautiful but this one stands out for me. I visited here last year and then again this year and really noticed a change in the short period of time between visits. A lot of this site has fallen down but I was happy to see they have a restoration project in progress. I think I love this site because it is so wild. Nature is doing her best to reclaim and the trees and root systems are amazing here. The temple is beautiful and I am pleased they are working to save it as it would be a huge shame to let it go. Well and truly worth a visit. I will always visit this particular temple each time I visit the area. I just love it. Don't forget,this was the temple that some of Tomb Raider was filmed in.
Amazing temple. This temple is amazing and was definitely one of our favorites. This needs to be on the list when you visit Siem Reap!
Like an Indiana Jones movie. My favorite place, could have taken photos all day, the light was great, you should read about it ahead of time

So Amazing. Seeing is believing. We were told by our guide that this particular temple was being reclaimed by the jungle around it but, having already seen Angkor and The Bayon, we couldn't imagine that Ta Promh would be more impressive. However, it was! The power of nature is something to behold! Do not visit Angkor watt without seeing this.

Beautiful . This place is so pretty you feel like you're on a movie set. It's beginning of the rainy season in June but only rains in the afternoon. Get yourself out there early morning and you could be done by 1 o'clock which is plenty of time to see the temple and perhaps another one too.

Ta Prohm at number 3. Well worth the effort to get here. The vast site that is the Angkor Archaeological Park is a treat to behold. My personal favourites were:1/ Angkor Wat - for its sheer vastness and impressive feel. Yet so much of the structure is covered by intricate carvings.2/ Preah Khan - because I love the way nature and specifically the jungle over powers the temples. As Preah Khan is on the 'grand circuit' it isn't visited as much as the more busy temples on the 'small circuit'. And those fewer people add a richer feel to your experience. 3/ Ta Promhmis the best example of nature and temple fighting fluidly in stone. More beautiful than Preah Kahn, but way more crowded too

Amazing and best temple of all. Known as the Lara Croft Temple this has been returned to nature and is so much the better for it. Amazing trees are reclaiming the area and it has an almost mythical feel to the place. Well worth a visit

A M A Z I N G!!!!. What a difference lunch and an adjustment of perspective can make!After spending the morning at Angkor Wat then indulging in another delicious meal we were ready to take on Ta Prohm or as the tour guides seem to prefer the Lara Croft Temple.Our driver dropped us off at the East gate and told us to walk through the temple complex to the West gate and he would meet us there. Great we thought and set off down the wide dusty path towards the temples. We were surrounded by lush forest and could hear lots of birds along with music. We discovered about halfway to the Temple the music was from a group of land mine survivors playing a range of traditional Cambodian instruments. As we got closer to the temples we started to see piles of rubble and partially collapsed buildings, many with trees growing through them. We also reached the ticket inspectors at which point we discovered that one of our group had lost her ticket. Most likely it had fallen out of her pocket at Angkor Wat. We explained this to the ticket inspectors and showed them a photo of the ticket on her phone, yes she had taken a photo and luckily so we all thought but NO. No paper ticket equals no entry. No amount of discussion or request to be reasonable or compassionate would move the inspectors to allow her entry. So unfortunately she and her partner had to return to the East gate and get a tuk tuk around to the West gate whilst the rest of us continued on.It was absolutely amazing to see how the banyan trees had taken over whole sections of the temples. There are so many WOW, OMG, LOOK AT THAT moments it takes your breath away. There is just so much to look at and some many amazing photo opportunities to be had.Ta Prohm is a MUST SEE for anyone who visits Siem Reap. My meagre writing skills can not do justice to the spectacular, impressive, simply amazing sight of these massive trees growing out of the temples. For me the visit to Ta Prohm was the highlight of our trip! I would love to see it during a massive thunder storm. I feel that it would be a sensational experience!

Beautiful but filled with grumpy tour groups.. Long lines for photos at every pile of roots, hoards or Chinese tourists getting angry at you because you walked in front of their camera. I'm all for respecting people's photos but it gets a bit much when you can't walk at all because people push past you and get angry for walking in front of their photos. Beautiful place but far too crowded, couldn't really move. Well worth a visit if you can put up with crowds though!!

Ancient undisturbed by natures invasion.. This temple is an ancient ruin which has been invaded by tree roots and has been left undisturbed by man for years. One feels a little sad to see the temple almost on the verge of collapse. Beautiful ancient carvings can be seen. Here too one needs the same temple pass.

for movie buffs.. and lost in time feel... go here!. Roots overgrown walls, tourists everywhere.. this is probably the most romantic temple I have been to yet.. and its simply amazing.. to see how nature reclaims what once was hers...

A Must. Seen Tomb Raider? Well either have I, but I am familiar with this site being in that movie. It's pretty amazing to see, trees are growing everywhere, even right on top. Was there a couple weeks ago, when we went it got crowded. Crowded beyond belief, so plan accordingly before visiting.

My Favorite Temple!. Ta Prohm was the first temple we visited in Siem Reap and it knocked my socks off! It set the bar for all the temples to come and it turned out to be my favorite.We visited it first thing in the morning (recommended) so it wasn't too busy yet. It was astonishing how the trees all grew around and through it. They really added to the spectacular nature of this temple. What amazed me about Ta Prohm (and all the temples at Siem Reap) was how accessible they are to visitors. There are no barriers around them (except where they might be working on some restorations). Visitors can walk through them, climb on them, touch them, trace the carvings. They are huge and jaw dropping. Each is different from the next. At Ta Prohm, I entered through a doorway and found a monk sitting quietly. I gave her $2 for a donation and she gave me a yarn bracelet along with a blessing for good health. I learned that I needed to keep the bracelet on for at least a week unless it fell off first. I ended up cutting it off after a week. I don't think it would ever have come off on its own - LOL! Anyway, I had a lovely moment with the woman and felt blessed my entire trip.Beware of all the vendors outside the temple. Unless you want to buy their merchandise, keep walking. Once you stop to see something (I did), they will all descend upon you. Especially if they see you take out your wallet. I did end up buying a beautiful cotton top. But had to fight my way back to the car afterwards. ;-)
falling apart. Unfortunately, this temple, also called as 'tomb raider', is already falling apart. Go inside at your own risk or just observe from outside.

More than just the 'Tomb Raider'. The way I see it, you should appreciate this temple not just because of the Tomb Raider film. Better look at how it is still standing today and how the conservation efforts are taking in to restore this heritage.
The trees are amazing. My favourite temple because the trees were surreal!! Couldn't get enough of them! Had to watch the Movie Tomb Raider afterwards to see them again.
Jungle temple. This temple is stunning. Nature really has taken over. It has lots of intricate detailing and lots of rubble to explore. Quite popular as it is on the main route but a must see.

Great Temple. Ta Prohm was made famous by none other than the Tomb Radier films and probably the main reason why its also one of the more popular temples. Hollywood asides it is without a doubt one of the more atmospheric temples in the Angkor complex, its surrounded by the jungle and has (of course) the trees growing around and within the temple itself; this is what makes Ta Phrom distinct in its own right. So before you rush to take the "mandatory" pictures of the tree roots made famous by Hollywood, take your time around Ta Prohm and its immediate surroundings and get a good feel of the temple. It's got its own unique ambiance which for me makes it stand out above most of the other temples around the Angkor complex.

Good Visit. This temple took less time to tour but was still worth the visit. We bought some interesting souvenirs here that when framed look great in our home. This was one of the hottest days of our visit and the temple was 106 F in the afternoon. Water and an Air conditioned bus were critical.
Incredible!. The most beautiful proof of the strength of a tree...The ruins themselves are spectacular but then add in the trees growing through and under and over- its simply stunning.

Wonderful place!!. Ta Prohm is a gem of Siem Reap! Magnificent human and nature creation!! A feeling like we're in an stone era is really an extra ordinary experience. I think this place is the champion among Siem Reap's places to visit.We are a group of 4 travellers. We went there just by booking a tuktuk driver from the old market. Compared to the distance and routes we had, I think hiring a tuktuk is quite a big benefit for us.

The ever famous Tomb Raider location. Having to be there totally made it such a fantasy alike. I was thinking of Lara Croft the whole time and how the movie was shot and all. I did not like the fact that there was an old crane left standing there which was a huge eye sore. Not sure it was left there by the production team, somebody needs to get that thing OFF the sight! It ruined the whole ambiance !There were few deep rooting trees as shown in the cover photo, and there were just so unbelievable, you can't help but wonder, how long have these trees lived?Are they real? Are they alive? This is a MUST!

Tomb raider filmed here!. Just before we step into the temple grounds, there were young kids (4-6 yrs old) coming to us to sell us souvenirs. Just be aware of your belongings. It was raining when we were there so besides getting wet, our shoes were all muddy and umbrella is just too tedious. The best is if you have your raincoat on. The temple is just amazing. Some areas are rather dark so just have to be careful and watch your steps.

Another must-see place!. I wanted to go to this place because i watched tomb raider:lara croft. This place shows the beauty of the tree which causes a destruction of the temple. Around 20-30 min walk.

Beautiful ♡♡♡. So serene!!It's almost like stepping into another world! Do yourself a favor and wear sturdy sneakers. We saw a few girls wearing silly deess shoes or heels. This is an old temple that is now over grown with beautiful big trees that are 400 and 500 years old. If you can i would recommend you go on a tour so your guide can give you some history info about this place. Beautiful and worth the few extra $$ so that you can learn about the rich culture and history ♡♡
My favorite. This temple was my favorite. You could get into it and explore on your own more than the other temples that are more strict. Also monkeys across the street you can play with.

A must see in Siem Reap. One of the busier temples we visited but an absolute must see. It's a photographers paradise if you can get a picture without the huge crowds. Our children found it facinating too!

Amazing Tree Temple. Amazing temple! Our group of 8 people visited Ta Prohm in March 2016 and all loved it. Seeing the crumbling temple with the beautiful trees taking over was fantastic. So exciting to walk through and over! The day we visited the temples was the hottest on our trip to Southeast Asia and there was a lot of walking during our visit. Be sure to bring a lot of water with you- even more than you think you will need!We had a fantastic guide who helped us avoid the crowds and tour groups. It felt like the places he took us we were the only ones there!A definite must see and a highlight of my trip!

Surreal. Human creation and nature in one place. This place is another marvel in Angkor. The trees are so surreal. You would get the effect of actually being in some kind of a movie here.. in general in all places in siem reap, I'd suggest carrying a guide book (lonely planet/whichever u prefer) to go about looking the places. I am not too sure if u would enjoy it the same way if u went with guides. I am not saying they r bad, but it's even more interesting to explore the places on ur own if u have the time n patience.

Beautiful . I love that this temple has been left to become overgrown and the trees have now become entangled with the ruins. Its a beautiful site.Not much restoration has been done on this site, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. It's a shame that the new caretaker of the site opted to cut down some of the really old trees though. That was disappointing.

Fascinating and magical . This is like something from a fairy tail or as many people say Indiana Jones. Amazing to see the trees and stone intertwined. In some respects the trees are keeping the temple standing but also at the same time ripping it apart. Well worth a visit.

Be prepared for long walks!. Here are some tips for all the temples if you are going to visit alot of them,prepare a day or two to visit them all and make sure to pack alot of water! 1.First what we did was buy ticket in a goverment controlled establishment (you a have a choice of a 1day 2day or 3day pass for all the temples included) we got the 1day pass for $20 and visited 6 temples.If you are not that into walking i would suggest to just visit bayon and angkor or just split the temples in different days for there will be alot of walking! 2.SLEEVLESS,SHORTS,SLIPPERS,SHADES AND SCARFS ARE NOT ALLOWED although sandals may be considered.but most importantly make sure to be comfortable to enjoy ur visit. 3.Just to be sure dont forget to check the weather,temples dont have roofs and there are only few convered area so if it is gonna rain i suggest you bring you rain coats or umbrella.Ps. Guides are available in temples if you are into history and culture i suggests you get one as of now they are not the rip off kind of guys that will try to fool you they are nice and knowledgable guys that can share real great stories as you stroll in the temples,and they also know secret sculptures and images that you might pass by.

A must see if you like giant trees.. Awesome views of trees and buildings fused together. It was raining when I visited, so bring a raincoat and soak proof footwear. Places were generally dim due to the gloomy weather, handy phones with torchlight function was very useful. Our temple guide was well versed in hand phone cameras and took for us very good panoramic pictures. I wore an anti-mossie patch but my friend who didn't ended up with several insect bites on his legs.
Surreal!. The trees here are absolutely stunning, Seeing nature intertwined with the man made is so surreal. Be prepared with a camera because this site is absolutely gorgeous!

A Jungle Delight . We visited in May before the rains had started.It was an easier temple complex to cover than some of the larger temples we allowed 1-11/2 hours moving slowly and taking lots of photos.The low season meant there were few people but would recommend later in the afternoon ie after 2.30 ,as when we traveled it was often over 39°C.

Force of nature!. Top 5 temple of Angkor!After a few days of traipsing around temples for as long as the heat would allow, many of the sites start to blend together and look the same. Ta Prohm, however, differentiates itself by the colossal trees growing up, around, and through the ancient walls. That alone is worth the visit.

Awesome. Has to be one of my favourite places in the world. No I hadn't seen Lara Croft, but this temple was just jaw dropping. Visited earlyIn the morning when there were very few visitors, almost unlimited access and words cannot describe how unbelievably stunning this temple is. Please visit!

totally unexpected!!. many wonders to visit in Siem Riap, but I never expected to see something such amazing. Our visit was in end April, not people around, just few couples, and probably that´s why I enjoyed a lot!, such pretty place, to see how the nature mix with the buildings like they grown together... is a must to see!

The tree temple. What a place this is, as much as I was blown away by the scale of angkor Wat this temple took my breath away the magnificent trees intertwining with the temple is very beautiful and gives you an idea of the slow creeping power of nature. One bit of advice is to go over the tour path and explore there are a few wee corners that offer stunning views and tranquil settings away from the noise of the mass tour groups. For me this place is a must.

Another staggering attraction. Another staggering attraction along with the other attractions around Angkor and Siem Reap. The amazing trees, with huge routes almost like sculptures intermingled with the ruins is beautiful.
must see. this temple is the main reason i came to sieam reap my wifr very enjoy seeing this temple. the big tree is very wonderful to look at.
Seeing is believing. You just have to spend some time here! It's like HOW did that happen, and what the hell are these Alien trees? Spectacular and my favourite of all the temples in Angkor.

Must visit. The most interesting and photogenic of the Angkor temples. The place is not so big but everywhere you look, you see lots of beautiful sights that you just want to photograph. Seeing the buildings overrun by trees and the jungle seemed surreal but true! Best to go early morning before the hordes of tourist buses arrive to enjoy the place in peace and quiet. Do not miss the view at the back of the temple, quite different but equally beautiful.

Amazing site to visit, it is fantastic. Just amazing how the trees and buildings have merged together. The most incredible part of Angkor and the most amazing temple we've ever seen. Every way you turn there is a great picture.

Tree Roots Temple. This temple is much more than the fame brought to it by Lara Croft. and the tree roots surrounding it. It is actually a big complex with many galleries and carvings of dancers (Apsara) still in good condition. Do not miss the face of a dancer on the lowest part of a tree root inside one gallery.

Amazing. I consider this the most interesting of the temples. The trees growing on/over/in the temples are really interesting and huge and the only remaining buddha statue hidden in the roots of one of the trees is one of the highlights.

Not to be missed. Breathtaking site that will leave you in awe. Remarkable ruins with growth of trees seeming like they are growing out of the ancient stones. It is an architectural marvel in seeing the stones cut perfectly to fit onto each other

Fantastic!. It might be a popular tourist spot but it is not difficult to see why. The archaeology is interesting in itself but with the trees, it becomes almost mystical. The site itself is not massive but so impressive. Another one worth getting up early for. Also take plenty to drink. It was very hot and humid.

A real beauty. Absolutely stunning, although much smaller than Angkor wat I preferred this temple. There are trees growing there, the roots winding over and around the stonework which is very unusual and attractive. It has an almost eery quality to it because of this. This is the temple used in the tomb raider movie so many will recognise it from that also. Bring lots of water and make sure to cover shoulders and legs to below the knees out of respect.
Amazing Cambodia. Took a tour of the temples with Angkor Tour Guides. Temples are amazing! Definitely worth the heat! See them before they are too touristy!

Another photographers' dream. We left our hotel at 5:15am and arrived at the temple just at dawn was breaking. Massive trees growing on top of temple ruins... very photogenic. Roots have crumbled some portions of the site, but in some ways that only makes it more beautiful.

Visit at off times to avoid the crowds. We visited this temple around lunch time when all the tour groups are visiting the restaurants nearby. It was a great choice. Still crowded, but not as bad. If you are seeing temples in Angkor Wat, you need to stop here
Must see. Make sure you visit if doing the temples, well worth spending the time to see, we did the main ones in a day but some were spending two or three days touring them.

Amazing. This place is one of the "must see" in the world. It is impossible to describe in words the overwhelming impression the coexistence of nature and man creates. A visit in May is hot and humid but the advantage is that there are few tourists at this time of the year.

Great place to visit and be awed by the power of nature. The Tomb Raider affiliations aside, this is a must if at Angkor. The power of nature is humbling seeing enormous trees growing through these ancient structures. Would advise to get there early so not too crowded and not too hot.

Looked like a movie set. We went to Ankor Wat first and then asked the tuk tuk driver to take us straight to Ta Prohm. As we had left our hotel early there were very few tourists at this temple and I could get lovely photos with no one else in them. As we are older and it was hovering around 40c I don't think we would have lasted on an all day temple tour so we were very happy with our choice.

Avoid the big crowds by.... Ta Prohm is an amazing temple. I've been there many times and I never get tired of it. The trees and ruins combine to create a memorable, extraordinary landscape that feels straight out of a movie set. The only weakness about Ta Prohm is that some of the corridors are tight, and when massive tour buses arrive, and hordes of tourists suddenly flood into one of these tight spaces, you can find yourself surrounded by scores of selfie-stick wielding adventurers. Some of the most special places in Ta Prohm are in somewhat confined quarters, and thus, they can get overrun by tourists at certain times of the day. Typically (though not always) tour groups start out from Siem Reap and work their way out from the city, stopping at Angkor Wat, Bayon, etc., before arriving at Ta Prohm. So, one solution to the overcrowding is to do the temples in the opposite order. Start at Ta Prohm and then work your way back toward Angkor Wat, back toward Siem Reap. In this way, you'll experience less crowds than if you follow the standard route.Even if you arrive at Ta Prohm at a busy time, there are wonderful parts of the complex that most groups don't see. So, ask your guide to take you to places where most tour groups don't go.It's an extraordinary temple. But it's even better if you can avoid the crowds. -- John Shors, bestselling author of Temple of a Thousand Faces: A Novel of Angkor Wat
"Tomb Raider Temple". Nature and mans creation coexisting for many centuries. Part of the "Raiders" movie was shot here. Go back in time.

Visit this temple first before the others. With the overwhelming trees you have a view how the other where also (as Angkor Wat before to be restored). It is an excellent idea that this stays in the actual situation, so people realize how Angkor was discovered! The views are indeed amazing!

Feel the Tomb Raider Movie Setting. Well-known as Tomb Raider Movie Setting, Ta Prohm also called The Jungle Temple. Many Fig Trees strangled on some of the buildings and one of them was used as Tomb Raider Movie Setting where Angelina Jolie picked the jasmine and fell down in to the earth.I started my tour from the East Gate where I faced more or less 300 meters path way before you get into The Hall of The Dancers. This hall has its own balustrade.Follow the path to see this temple and mind your step. There are a lot of stone on the ground that you might slip on

Interesting p. This temple is amazing - seeing the trees that have grown into and around the structures is fascinating. The restoration project and photos of that were also interesting and education. However, it is extremely busy. We found that Beng Mealea (obviously not accessible to everyone because it is far from the main complex) had very similar features of nature reclaiming the structures, but without the huge crowds.

One of the highlights in Siem Reap!. All around the venue has the feeling of 'magic'! Felt like we were lost in a myth while we were enjoying ourselves taking photos with the wizardly-looking trees and climbers. I spotted BIG BIG beehives up on the big trees in the middle of the temple! OMG they are the biggest beehives ever in my life!
Wonderful. Like a movie set only authentic. An eerie combination of nature and man's artistry. A spectacular temple

A must visit. This place is always top destination for tourists from the movie "Tomb riders". Always got crowded with tour group in particular spots so if you are not with tour group, no need to squeeze yourselves with the tour group to take pictures, etc. Wait a bit until big group(s) gone, then you could enjoy a minute silence with these amazing ruins.

Lovely. . We did a full day of temple visits and this was my favourite. I strongly suggest hiring a guide to take you around. Ours explained all the carvings, history, restorations and general info about the area. We learnt a lot. The guides also know when the best time of day is to visit each temple so you are there with less people. Always a win!
Pictures do not do it justice. The trees appear to strangle the temples and are truly amazing to see. One feels a bit like you are in an Indiana Jones movie.
Beautiful, beautiful site. Hard to believe at first sight. You have to soak in the pictures of trees growing on top of stones. Seems unreal at times.
the "Tomb Raider" Temple. want to see giant tree roots devouring a 1000-year old stone temple? This is the place to go. Instantly recognizable by anyone who has seen the movie "Tomb Raider"

Temple highlight. . We went with our own guide who was so knowledgable. The reconstruction process is on going, and was supported by the movie people to the tune of 3 million U$. In some areas the trees are actually supporting the temple. The re construction of the gallery is impressive and you can see the challenges they must have had to build the temple in the first place. The second gallery is yet to be restored but is apparently planned. The shaded areas were cooler despite 38 degree temperature in May. Though we came about 11 am, there were quite a few other tourists but not so as to spoil the magic. An hour would be good but up to two to really explore all the back walks, courtyards and side alleys. The teens were most impressed here of all the (8) temples we visited. I would have to agree though maybe a tie with Angkor wat

tomb raider in real life!. I didnt really know much about this small kingdom of Siem Reap but after my trip for a couple weeks to Siem Reap, I cant imagine of finding a place to visit amazing like this. So amazing mate!!!
Best temple in Angkor. Go go go go to this temple and go on the morning or afternoon when all the annoying Chinese tourist are not there. It is beautiful and magnificent

from another planet. the place is amazing ....another planet .......it is difficult to write about... angkor wat is a amazing building and a amazing construction ....here the temple it is more mystical -...if you are around dont miss it

Amazing one. I prefer this one to angko wat because it had less tourists. I feel my peace here with people' creation with the rocks. It takes short walk to be here under the big tree. They have sellers both sides to sell you stuff. They are nice though. Would recommend everyone

Don't miss this: nature reclaiming!. This is a photographers dream - a photo opportunity at every corner or root! Although very difficult to just get the trees, and the buildings they are consuming, without getting the masses of tourists in the pic too!! Maybe make them the subject :) A real education on how nature takes back - if allowed :0
Nice look into the history. was fun walking & watching Lara Croft set come alive. It was fun but please go whenn the sun is low.
Very nice. Lovely to see all the amazing tree roots claiming back the ruined buildings. It's all roped off so you can't quite get as close as you might think but it's still a must see.

Gorgeous, felt like Lara Croft for a few hours. Its exactly like it looks in the movies if not better. Its a massive complex. I got lost inside, despite signage in English. Every turn is a photo opportunity. yes the massive tree roots do look like its supporting the entire complex to stand upright, at least whats left of it.
view of big tree. the tree on the top of temple is the place that we can take photo and enjoy big tree and quite place and song of the bird and very amazing of khmer his story.
Must visit in temple tour. Awesome .the roots of the trees and the trees grown on the temples are sooo huge. Don't miss. Plenty of photo shoot points.

Fascinating. A Fascinating attraction which is unique from the others temple.The temple is almost swallowed by the forest and trees are growing on the temples.The huge roots of the trees grew over the walls around the temple and onto the temple structure, some have even went through the roof and invaded into the interior of the temples.Angkor Wat Temples pass is required to enter the temple.The 'Tomb Raider' Temple is in the deepest part of the temple compoundThe walkway is uneven and sandy, advised to wear sport shoes, for all the temple.Spent about an hour in Ta Prohm.
swallowed by nature. Also must see place, you can see how the nature takes back everything if there is enough time , and because of this element this makes this temple look really great,

Stunning. Amazing temple, trees growing out of the temple make the place seem surreal.We visited first thing in the morning, and would definitely recommend showing up before it opens to be the first ones in, as we had the place to ourselves before the rest of the tourists arrived, so all our pictures only had us, or no one in them. A must see in Siem reap!

Am I the only person who hasn't seen Tomb Raider. Ta Prohm is now forever inextricably linked with Lara Croft, but even for those of us who have never seen the movie, but have seen countless photos of trees sprouting out of temples, it is well worth a visit. I was another solo visitor who happened across an eager security guard who was happy to tag along, find photo opportunities, take photographs etc, and who I was happy to tip for his services. Cambodia is a country where the people are very poor, even in Govt jobs, so it is not uncommon for enterprising souls to try to find ways to supplement their income, no matter what we as visitors might think of the concept. It is a fact of life in Cambodia.

Wow. Unrealjust loved the trees around the temples really lovely , little walk up to it so make sure you go out the right way you came back in. in that heat it can be effort to go back through this happened to us.you will really like these temples so special.

amazing place. Amazing place beautiful Brahma temple but here nature tells us that only nature is the most power full among all,the way roots of giant trees crushing the temple under it ....this is the place wher Tomb raider movie shot so just enjoy..............
wonderful trees. There are some wonderful trees above the temples.. really awesome. Easy to see around as they provide staffs in every corners of the temple

Stunning. i couldn't believe that i was walking where this had been built so long ago i loved it the guides i saw walking around were great but i ventured in alone and took my own path. It was fantastic i cant wait to go back and see this again and see if there's any change over the next couple of years.
Tomb Raider.... Absolutely amazing to see what can happen in a thousand years. The history and nature combined forms such a brilliant spectacle.

Amazing example of nature meets ancient ruins. The huge tree roots over the stones was spectacular. One of the reasons to visit Siem Reap. Impressive to see and experience. The experience of going and seeing this place is mind blowing.

Awesome shots. Went in the afternoon again around 2 pm. There was not alot of tourists compare to Angkor Wat when we went at 6 am. A bit scary for me and my boyfriend since there were dark sections and there werent alot of people walking around. Other than that, this temple was out of this world again!
Beautiful. Very nice temple, interesting to see how nature has mixed with the temple's structure over years. Definitely a "must see" in Siem Reap.

Tomb Rader. This place is wonderful. Be careful with the guy who will offer to get photos of you then he will ask you to come with him and then he will ask $10 at the end. Good thing he knows how to take beautiful photos.

Beautiful temple to see.. Amazing temple with huge ficus trees growing around,over, under and through the stone buildings. Recommend visiting the Ankgor Museum first before going to the temples for a better understanding of the temple complex.
Great place. The temple has a great atmosphere and is a absolute must see in the park! It's kind of a maze and there are so many hidden corners to explore. So take your time and enjoy!

A walk into History of Cambodia. This is the most interesting temple of the Angkor. Giant centuries old trees grew out of the ruins of the temple. I was amazed to see a tree has its roots grown like an octopus's tentacles dug onto the temple wall. The surrounding jungle makes Ta Prohm quiet with only birds chirping, flying here and there, serenade. A Budhha's face is almost covered up by the roots of a tree. Gave me a sad feeling, prayed for more conservation and restoration of this temple, so more generations have chances to discover its History.
Beautiful - amazing nature . Our favorite temple. The nature rediscovered this area and the trees growing over the temple are stunning. We loved it!

Tomb raiders feel. Restoration of Ta Prohm is still running. When i first came here 10 years ago and still coming back every year. This place always gives me goosebumps. I like the ancient and "magical" trees here. The place is really beautiful in pictures as well as in real
