Some of the Tomb Raider scenes were filmed here.A significant temple in the ancient history so worth having a guide, as the history is probably more interesting than the present!

Overgrown Trees Give it Character. A must see but very busy - too busy. Go here at the beginning or end of day so it is no too busy. Each photo spot was packed with people, pushing and shoving to get the perfect picture. This kinda takes away from the experience - or adds to it depending on your point of view.

Wow . Amazing place!! ..at the entrance there is some food and drink stalls you can stack up before you walk in grab a fresh coconut "heaven " to cool you down!!..great place for photos ..ps keep a look out for the hiding face in amongst the trees,it's pretty cool!! .

Impressive Jungle Temple. Ta Prohm is impressive to say the least, and of course this particular temple near Angkor Wat was make even more famous by the Lara Croft: Tomb Raider movie. While not my favorite temple by a long-shot, this is a must see if you visit Angkor Wat in Siem Reap, Cambodia. The juxtaposition of the encroaching, overpowering trees against the seemingly immovable stone is quite stunning. Plan to spend a good amount of time here. There is a lot to see. I would recommend hiring a driver and going on your own. I don't do tours, as they kind of suck and you are always on a time schedule set by somebody else. You will want to add a visit to Ta Prohm to your adventure bucket list. This is a must see.

Very wvocarive. A half day visit starting early and finishing by lunchtime is perfect for this temple. Remote and still derelict in places you can really see what nature can do when left to its own devices. Well worth the trip
Better than Angkor Wat!. Was very quiet wasn't plagued with tourists and was overall peaceful and calm. Amazing trees with roots reaching down from the roof.
Absolutely brilliant!. This was definitely the highlight out of 3 days in Siem Reap and well worth the heat and crowds. Visit early.
In the end the Jungle wins. Great experience to see the picture you have seen for real. Watch your step and take wayer and a hat. In the end the jungle wins.
Temple. This place is great if you want to look at the history of Cambodia it is incredible. This is full of interesting things and is fantastic for a family trip

Fabulous!. This was one of our favorite temple visits while in Siem Reap. We used a tour guide through Angkor Wat Sam's, and our tour guide was awesome. I recommend you ask for Hiek Han if you book a guide. He took us to any temple we wanted and was full of great knowledge with fabulous English. To see how nature has taken over the ruins was awesome, and Hiek Han's knowledge made it that much better.

Lara Croft Movie Site. This site is where the trees having taken over the site with their roots in some cases destroying some areas of the temple. This site is where Lara Croft Tomb Raider was filmed. It s fascinating to see what the trees have done. Well worth the visit.
Temple in the jungle. Still overgrown with huge tree roots that have become a part of the temple. Don't miss it especially if there is no tour group there at the time

Impressive place to be sure. We were disappointed that there were so many noisy tour groups and hundreds of people taking selfies everywhere you turn, but they are all there for a reason - the sight is magnificent and the trees rooted in the temple ruins are incredible. Suggestion - while it's hotter, midday will mean fewer crowds.

Tomb Raider. This is where Tomb Raider was shot. A good visit - lots of clear paths, imagine what it must have been like before so many galleries fell down. Go early and beat the heat and crowds. Don't stray off the path otherwise they come looking for you - I got down a tunnel - chamber and was eventually called back. Awesome photos. Take a guide. You must have the mandatory park entry pass US$20 to get into any temple in the areas. One pass for one day does all, other day passes can be bought - but how many days do you really want to do.....

eerie atmosphere!. The place of some scenes of the Tomb Raider movie, in places where you can avoid the tourist crowds the atmosphere is quiet and and the jungle is invading sections in ever slowly never ending progress.

Wow!. Amazing example of the jungle taking over a temple. Makes you realise why the temples lay undiscovered for so long. Stunning place but be careful as health & safety not on top of priority list here! It really is stunning to see. Take plenty of water, a fan and an umbrella for portable shade. This one is this most stunning but they really need to do something to preserve it as you can virtually clamber anywhere you want. As much as we loved this I just know that future generations might miss out when it finally all collapses or someone is seriously hurt. We had an excellent guide which is do worth it otherwise you're wandering about aimlessly. Definite must see on your temple visits here.
historic location. excellent place to visit and see where tomb raider was filmed - and to see where nature has taken over the temples. Best of the temples in Siem Reap by far.

Our favorite temple. This was our favorite of all the sites around Siem Reap. It had the untouched wild nature attacking the temple feel. The roots working their way through the blocks and lushness was breathtaking. We were lucky as there was almost nobody there when we went and it felt almost as if you were the first to discover it.awesome!

Ta Prohm Temple and the Magical Tree Roots. Banyan, fig and large kapok trees spread their enormous roots over the stones, walls and terraces, as their branches and leaves twine to form a roof over some of the structures. There is an inescapable charm as you walk around the grounds, like no other place on earth.

From another world . The intertwining of nature and architecture here is just amazing.
This us a must see. The trees grow on the temples then go in search of water. Just amazing

too crowded. We attempted a first visit in the middle of the day. It was awful, no mean to see and enjoy anything. We decided to come the next day at the first hour in the morning while other people were at the sunset in Angkor wat. Good point! Few people, good light and many places that we didn't saw the day before. But, there are other temples that look like Ta Prohm and that are more relaxing at any time of the day…
Temple and Trees. Its more about the trees than the temple, but the trees are well worth the visit. Wonderful photo opportunities and not very crowded early.
Amazing. . Take water. Wear comfortable shoes. Take a guide with an air conditioned bus. If you have kids under 12, bring passport because they are free. Enjoy!
Huge land but limited attractions. The only thing I like about this is the huge tree next to a temple structure. I like Angkor Waypt and Bayon temples better.
the best of all. this is a must see place of magic. choose an afternoon time and avoid the crowds so you have the place to yourself
amazing temple. loved to see the trees growing over the old temples,again we were there during a drought, so it wasn't as lush as I had imagined.

Surreal temple!. This was the last temple we toured for the day. If you have more than one day to tour temples, I would do this one in the morning. By the afternoon, it was crowded and extremely hot (spoken by a Texan!). The trees growing into the temple are so magnificent and the place feels magical. I would love to visit when it was less crowded!

Ignore going for Tomb Raider reasons, it's so much more!. Tomb raider this, Lara croft that... in some ways I found it annoying that such a wonderful and unique place rich is history is talked about with regards to a c grade Hollywood film. It's just so much more. For starters the fact that it sat in the jungle so long that massive trees grew on the roof... surely thats enough? So do take the time to go. Ask your guide not to distract you from experiencing it by pointing out where this and that happened in the film. I mean really - it was a crap film and it adds nothing, rather it detracts from the experience of exploring and learning about this place.

Magnificient. You just got to walk and explore deeper. Unfortunately I was very very down with the weather. I felt 'awe' and recalling Lara Croft movie.
Could not walk any longer but least one of my bucketlist is checked.
The trees were all humongous. Sadly, due to the growth of those trees that made the temple toppled.

Lara Croft. I adored this place - took so so many photos - apart from the fact that Tomb Raider was filmed here (my boys were so excited!) the place was stunning - the way the trees had grown and made their mark - every phot told a story!
Fascinating. The temples are really interesting and best done with a. Guide. The trees growing over the temple are amazing.
How did it became like that?. Large trees mixing all together with those very huge rocks, making a great chemistry and form, how lucky Cambodia to have this kinds of ruins.. Thanks !

Best "over-grown" temple. Really beautiful temple grounds. Huge trees with the roots climbing through the structure, felt very authentic. It's pretty cool to say you've been in a place Angelina Jolie has been! This temple had some pretty awesome carvings on its walls too and the restoration work done by the Indian government was awesome because some of the temple was back to its original glory. Overall a 10/10 would see again!
A lot of renovations going in. A lot of the structures have fallen so there is a lot of renovations going on which detracts from the impressive place it really is.
Amazing. Great place, would recommend visiting but I am sure if it was in the UK health and safety wouldn't let it be open to the public.

Tomb Raider - amazing! . The temple was visited with a guide Mr Sophanna (Miker) outlining the amazing aspects of the temple which was the tree roots having the ability to have grown through the temple foundations or on the roof displaying enormous roots holding the temple structure together. This temple has the tree roots wrapped around Buddhas head which has been one of the most common photos associated with Cambodia. We visited just prior to Song Kran which is the Buddhist New Year and a festival atmosphere was evident during the visit. Well worth visiting.

Days of the yore . You can almost feel the Khmer kings walking in the temple compound. Made famous by the Tomb Raider movie, the temple right now is getting crushed under the weight of the enormous trees in the area. Although repair work is in full swing.

Nothing like it!Best ruin for an extra hot sunny day.. Though it is a little sad in some ways that the Tomb Raider movie draws some fame to this amazing site, it was fun with our 4 year to watch the applicable Tomb Raider on Netflix to build some excitement to visit the site. There is nothing like it in the world, as it is where amazing nature meets amazing man-made ruins, literally. There is more shade at this site than the others, so it is a good option to plan for an extra hot sunny day (which there are many this time of year).
Tomb Raider... Made famous by Tomb Raider, it was the busiest of all the temples we visited, very impressive that they have chosen to leave it as the Jungle Temple!

the one not to be missed. one of the must see temples in seam reap
its impressive and it give you an idea how the found the temples years ago
Amazing. Fantastic temple with some great photo opportunities. I would recommend an evening visit. We arrived about 4 and left before 6 and crowds were minimal.

Beautiful ruins. Ta Prohm is still much as it was found after being lost to the jungle for many years. It is fascinating to see the forces of nature intricately entwined in the ancient stone walls and buildings of this interesting temple. Some renovation work has been done and there are story boards showing photos of before and after restoration. It would be a very difficult puzzle to piece together the large carved blocks of stone, and there are many areas that are still in original condition that make you aware of how decimated this temple was from the surrounding forest. This is a must see when in Siem Reap.
dont miss this. this place is really spectacular - dont miss it - its was amazing to see the tree coming out its a must see

Prepare camera to make some new ce shoots. One of my 2 favorite tamples in Siem Reap and absolutely must see. Beautiful and different from others. Felt strong energetic as soon as went into that lost in jungle and half ruined place.Would recommend to plan a visit for second part of the day if interested in taking nice pictures without random people on a background.

The Tomb Raider temple. This was the one I was most excited for since seeing the first Tomb Raider movie. It was awesome but super crowded. It was extremely difficult to get any pictures of the jungle taking over the temple with all the people there. This was our second stop after lunch. It was hot and humid but our guide had ice cold water and an air conditioned car for us.

Better than in the movies!. The ruins of Ta Prohm are just phenomenal because of the trees supporting them from the inside out!Everything you've seen in "Tomb Raider" and more - truly magnificent & majestic trees helping to preserve this beautiful temple in such an amazing way. There are countless photo opportunities, and although the hordes of tourists can seem overwhelming at times, the tour buses seem to be on a pretty tight schedule, so if it's very busy when you're there, just hang back and let the people from the tour buses run through, and then you'll have much more room to move (and nobody in your photos!!). Also, the further into the site you get, the more spread out the crowd becomes. You can find stunning examples of trees & their roots without all the loud pushy tourists in your way. We found the vendors outside Ta Prohm to be by far the most 'intense' vendors we came across during our trip to Siem Reap and the various Angkor sites, so beware!

The power of the jungle and the people. You have to see it to really appreciate it. The power of nature never cease to amaze me. This temple is one of the best known temples and as such one of the busiest but definitely worth it. Even if you have to stand and wait for 15 minutes for everyone to clear so you can take the perfect photo.

Huge tree roots enveloping the old temple.. This temple is the least crowded and the 4 to 500 year old tree's with massive roots snaking through the ruins make it very interesting. Definitely put this temple on your list. Different from the other temples because it's more of an original "ruin" and still in the natural state of being taken over by the jungle.

Tree Temples. Because of the famous trees growing thru out this complex, it is a good late morning place to visit. The crowds are not heavy at this time. It can be very confusing to walk thru and the guards stationed around the compound cannot be counted on to tell you the way out, if you are not with a tour. At the entrance, there are very nice bathrooms, which are free if you show them your park ticket.There will be a couple of Buddhist Nuns in the interior of the Wat, who will bless you for $1USD and tie the red and yellow (long life and happiness) strings around your wrist.

Amazing Ta Prohm. This is an amazing temple because of the trees growing through the ruins. The temples are a wonderful testament to the ingenuity of the people of the day. Really hope they can be preserved for many generations to experience in the future.

Ta Prom, the Temple from another world. Early Morning in one of the finest temples of Angkor - there are only a few left with roots and fig trees, some where broken allready after 600 years - but stil mystical.I remeber my first visit in 1992, a solider with a Kalashnikow guarded the entrance.He was to heads smaller than me, I asked myself, will he protect me if a Khmer Rouge is on the site? - that time Khmer Rouge were in the area! Jayavarman VII build the monastery in honour for his parents - good son! It's maybe 5km from Angkor Thom, and not so much crowded. March 2016, not the peak travel period. Maybe not all tour groups visit Ta Prom. It's my favourite from the big Three: Bayon, Angkor Wat and Ta Prom. Go very early it's open from sunrise . Now you are not allowed to climb to the galleries, 1992 my guide allowed me to step very carefully it was amazing and some of the best in my archelogical travel in my life. Don't do it today. The structures are so fragile due to broken roots and cut trees due to weather damages they had to cut some, but it's still the mystical ambiance, Henri Mouhot describes in his book Travel in Indochina (1867)

Raiders of Lost Ark. We really loved this temple as it had all these trees that had roots encasing the place. It made it look creepy but most unusual. Naturally knowing it was a film set made it a 'must see' . It's much smaller than Angkor Wat but more accessible.

stunning. What can I say about this place that hasn't been said before? My favourite temple, my poor Nikon was at burning point. Absolutely a must whilst in Cambodia and a reason in itself to visit this wonderful country

A little disappointing. I was looking forward to seeing this temple as it had been identified as the location of the Tomb Raider movie, and has been described in a number of guide books as being the temple that can give you the feeling that you have stumbled upon an undiscovered ancient tomb. However, I found that the complex has been sanitised with viewing platforms for photographs, with lines of people waiting their turn. It also appears that many of the trees have been cut back ( for preservation reasons). I still enjoyed the overall temple visit, and would highly recommend the full tour ( certainly one of the wonders of the world).

Lara Croft made it famous!!!!. Known mainly for the Tomb raider films, this sight is phenominal! What for me was more poignant was just passed the entrance, there are a group of musicians, who have all been made disabled by the land mines planted during the war torn years of this country's history! They busk to raise money to support their families as they are unable to work. They are so grateful of even a dollar! tear jerking and emotional stuff!

Absorbing, eerie and absolutely stunning.. As essential viewing as Angkor Wat, this temple is absolutely stunning and leaves you wanting to explore the whole area on your own, Lara Croft style! Unfortunately, the bus loads of tourists tend to spoil the spiritual vibe however, it's possible to find a quiet spot if you're very patient and let them all go in front of you.
The famous tree. You must visit Ta Prohm well at Angkor Wat. This is the famous tree you have seen in movies. It's so amazing howall these trees have grown in the rocks.
Decor for great films. Fascinating,very Tomb Raider or Indiana Jones!Certainly some of the best photos you'll ever take!Enjoy it!
Stunning. It was a busy day when we visited, but that did not take away from the breathtaking and remarkable trees in places holding this temple together.

Great for Photography. I have been to the Angkor Wat before, but not Ta Prohm. This temple was the one I wanted visit on this trip. Not disappointed at all. Great for photography. They are at a stage of renovating the parts of the temple.
Your Tomb Raider Experience. Smaller temple but more character. Trees grow into the walls Have to jostle for vantage points to be able to get photos
Best part!. The ruins of the Ta Prohm temples are among the most beautiful of Angkor Wat. Plan some time for the visit, its worth it!

A must see . We loved this temple. It is one of the more popular ones so will be busy especially around the tree rooted areas.
When hot take an umbrella there is limited/no shade in the temples.

The tomb raider temple. Will forever be known by this moniker because of the film which is a shame as this monument should keep its ancient name. The gigantic tree roots which have woven themselves into the fabric of the buildings look artificial until you look closely. Another fantastic place..

Atmospheric & Photogenic. This temple has been left as it was discovered with lots of trees growing out of its ruins amidst jungle surroundings. It is one of the most popular with visitors, the movie "Tomb Raider" was filmed here. This temple puts into perspective the amount of restoration work that continues today at the other sites.
Big rooted trees. very famous by the tomb raider movie and it certainly looks more awesome in person than in the pictures
Incredible Ruins. You see wonderful pictures of this temple in magazines but seeing is believing, what a great experience.
Mesmerizing!. It is amazing that something like this actually exists, like out of a fairytale book, not to be missed!
Amazing. To me this was the most wonderful place. So atmospheric. The sounds of the jungle in the background and all the tree roots. Truly amazing.
Start early. This was one of my absolute favourite places in Angkor. We got there when it opened (07.30) and had the place virtually to ourselves. Such an amazing experience.

Cool. Jungle temples is great. Beware the crowds of people waiting in line near the large trees covering temple entrances. There seemed to be a lot of pushing and lack of personal space.
Otherwise really neat temple.

The Tomb Raider Temple. Apparently they filmed the tomb raider movie here. Everyone told us this about 30 times. Regardless, it is spectacular. The trees overgrown into the buildings and structures is just a sight to see.
Do not miss visiting here!

Overgrown & Fascinating. I loved walking through this temple, it is reminiscent of how long ago this temple was built and how it has stood the test of time. Overgrown with trees and nature, this temple is certainly different from most of the temples you'll see in Cambodia. Absolutely don't miss this!
WOW. Great photo op.. The power of nature and how it takes over can be seen at this temple. Truly amazing site to see. Hot day, take lots of water and wear comfortable shoes.

My favourite temple. This is most definitely worth a look. It was amazing to see a temple that was covered over by trees and rediscovered and is in process of being restored. By far my favourite temple.

The most beautiful yet busy wat.. This wat was particularly stunning and a must on your list. However be prepared for crowds at all times of the day. If you want a picture with the infamous tree be prepared to queue.

My favourite of all the temples. This is the Tomb Raider temple - although I have not seen the movie! It has trees growing through the ruins and I thought it was majestically. It was my favourite of all the temples and I highly recommend you go!

More Spectacular than Angkor Wat. While it is not as huge as the Angkor Wat, this temple is so much more spectacular. The giant trees that grew within the structure gave you an idea of how old the temple was.There are restored building structures with a board of before-after comparison photos, added up to the attractiveness of this temple.Angkor Wat was the temple you must not miss due to its popularity and the size, but Ta Prohm is the temple that you must not miss because of its spectacular scenery.

Nice day trip. We had a nice trip to Ta Prohm.
Some really nice photo shots with all the amazing trees growing over the temple ruins. Quite amazing place.

Better than the movie. This was our favorite Temple visited in Siem Reap due to the dramatic vista created by the invasion of the forest on the Temple and the easy access to view all aspects of the temple being on one level and well board walked. We spent 2 hours at the Site as part of a private tour - highly recommend utilisation of a private guide so as to understand the history and the importance of the site to the local community. Simply awe struck by this Temple & would return for a furture visit.

Must see. Again stunning, with nature clinging to the buildings. The huge trees with massive roots like a giant snake coiling to the dusty ground in search of water.The crowds are almost nothing here and you can enjoy it in peace.
Great adventure. This is a temple where Tomb Rider was filmed and also many computer games are made based on those ruins. Amazing view and pictures!

Otherworldly. Ta Prohm is perhaps the most surreal of the Angkor temples. It has a mystical and otherworldly quality. Trees grow in and through the temple structures creating a merger of human and natural elements that required centuries to achieve.
Great temple, enjoyed it a lot . Very interesting how the tree has weaved it's way through. Fascinating. Highly recommend to anyone. All the temples are truly magical

Oh wow!. This is one of the most fantastic places to go. The way the trees are taking back what is theirs is fantastic. The preservation of this temple has been beautifully managed so that you see the temple and the fantastic way the trees are interwoven with the walls and roofs. We went in the afternoon which was baking hot but the shade from the trees and going into the temple makes it bearable.This is a place you absolutely must put on your bucket list.

Massive Tree Trunks are more interesting than the temple it self. This is a large area, but the temple part is pretty much just ruins. By the time you get to this temple, you probably will be templed out already. The most interesting part of this temple for me is the large tree trunks that grow into the sandstone and ultimate cause the demise of the structure.
Magical cum Mystical. This place gives visitor a magical and mystical feel esp. with the overgrown roots of trees partially covering the ancient buildings. Definitely worth a visit.

Temple totally swallowed by the nature. The architecture of the temple is not big to appreciate but the extent of nature's invasion makes it big. Huge trees and their roots swallowing the entire temple is unbelievable. This temple needs more resurrection and attention. The work done by Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) is to be appreciated, yet there is lot to do.

Ta Prohm. Ta Prohm is another awesome Angkor temple. Ta Prohm was also used as the setting in the Tomb Raider movie and a great place to look around.
The temple has been partly taken over by the jungle and many tree roots are now a part of the structure.
Definitely go to visit Ta Prohm if you are in Siem Reap.

One of the best temples to visit... On the planet. The synonymous "Tomb Raider" temple did not disappoint. I visited at 4pm and avoided the crowds. Great temple but if you like this, you'll also like Ta Som and Preah Khan.

Atmospheric Temple. After watching Indiana Jones movies it was really good to visit this temple which was once lost to the jungle. The restoration has helped to open up the temple and show its real beauty. We went in the latter part of the afternoon in April when it was less hot. Very atmospheric and nice to see as the sun was lower in the sky.
Got lost inside. Its like a maze trying to figure how to get out. There are 2 gates west abd east. By 9am it hmgets hot. Bring hat. Sun block your umbrella.

On The "Must See" List. Most tours go here, but don't miss it if you have a choice. It has elements of many of the other temples so you get a good feel for the entire complex in one place, and since it was famous in a movie, you do sorta have to see that! We arrived when it first opened and found very few other tourists, so we could wander around and take our time, and get photos without other people in them. Be sure to wear sturdy shoes and bring water, no matter how early you go!

Nature Invated. They have allowed this place to remain largely as it was when it was rediscovered. It is semi shrouded by the jungle that surrounds. This makes it very photogenic with the roots of iant trees growing around and through the stonework.

Incredible temple . Incredible temple in the jungle . Left partially excavated , certainly more picturesque than any other site at Ankor Thom. My photos of temple entwined with giant trees still take my breath away .
Coolest temple in the area. This was the coolest temple in the whole of Angkor Wat-area. The pathway to inside the area is also really nice!
Really fascinating. We really liked walking around these ruins with our guide. I strongly recommend going with someoneWho understands what is there.

Our favourite temple. We visited Ta Prohmafter watching the sunrise over Angkor Wat so it was relatively early in the morning. This made for a quiet, relaxing yet almost eerie visit around some spectacular ruins.Selling it's self as the 'tomb raider' temple, is something of an understatement. We found its spider like trees growing between the cracked and crumbling ruins and intricate and mysterious (there appears to be a stegosaurus) carvings to be more than just a setting for 10 seconds of a Hollywood movie. Easily our favourite of the temples we visited in and around Angkor.

Movie Set use Overstated. Another great historical site within the Angkor complex however the more recent use as a movie set is getting a lot of emphasis. Great example of how nature is trying to reclaim the area.

Amazing Place, Must Go. I enjoy this place so much. It was amazing. Could have spent more time wondering around and taking pictures. A must see. Even at a hot time of day there are so many trees it makes it manageable.
All inclusive trip. This is in my 8 hours day trip. Ruins after ruins. Other impressive architecture! Very hot and dry. Remember bring more water, fellow travelers!

Do not miss this attraction. This is the temple not to miss. By far the best. We arrived late in the afternoon avoiding the bus tours. We were able to walk around by ourselves without anyone else around. It was increasable

Nature showing reclamation. When left alone, nature reclaims everything
An interesting site to visit.
But it is just another temple ruin, with some interesting views

Jewel of Angkor!. Tons of people and tourists crowd here, mostly known as the "Angelina Jolie Temple" or tomb raider temple. Be sure to explore this temple complex, one of the few that you can walk around the actual unrestored ruins.
Well worth the visit. To see how the trees have reclaimed back to the jungle is fantastic. Some parts have now been "rebuilt" there is still plenty to do if you are good at jigsaws.

Scene from a movie. This is from Tomb Raider.
Place is full of big, ancient tress, maze like area,a bit hot but worth seeing.

Magical!!!!. This is probably one of the most popular if not the most popular because of Tomb Raider. Very very magical and enchanting temples. Those old trees are amazing beyond anything I have seen. I hope they keep this wonderful place of history as it is. Simply wonderful!

Absolute must. Ta Prohm is an absolute 'must see' when visiting Angkor Wat and Siem Reap. Hot, tiring and don't forget the water!! Very busy am and you won't feel properly dressed without a selfie stick!!!
Amazing to see!. This temple is unlike any other! It is a must see. Absolutely beautiful and the trees are amazing. Make sure u stop at this one!

Best temple of my visit. I loved this temple more than the big one of Angkor Wat. There's a mystique about it with all the trees and roots growing out of the ruins themselves. Tomb Raider was partially shot here. Lots of restoration work is currently taking place, which is great to see. We had a tuk tuk for the day (USD 15) who took us to Angkor Wat, Bayon another temple and Ta Prohm. He even had an esky with lots of bottles of water on ice!An excellent day:)
The one to see!. This Wat is just like what you saw in Indiana Jones. It was not cleared of jungle but left as is for us to enjoy. Don't miss this one.

Spectacular. The iconic imagery here is that of enormous trees rooted in temple ruins, with the gigantic root systems snaking in and around the huge blocks of stone. Photographers could spend a whole day here- but good luck trying to get a shot without people in it-at least during high season.

Transported Back in Time. Ta Prom was one of our favorite, if not our favorite, temple in the Angkor Wat complex. The forest and temple coexist in a way that the border between the two is completely blurred - trees grow on top of and in the temple, eroding the walls of the once grand temple. There are arrows that generally guide you through the myriad of rooms but it's great fun to detour and explore a bit on your own. This temple is quite a bit different from the other temples in the broad Angkor Wat site and cannot be missed.

Stunning place to see. We viewed Ta Prohm later in the afternoon and it was quiet then, if you go earlier there are many many tourists arriving in coaches. It is well worth a visit and to see trees taking over buildings in this way is spectacular
Wow, wow. Just thrilling to see the tree roots growing through the temple stones. Your imagination ruins wide here.
Magical!. This was the most amazing temple of all! It is a temple not to be missed. It was magical, almost unreal!!!
Our favourite temple complex. Despite the hordes, it was a still very atmospheric, particularly if you moved away from the famous trees. Lovely and shady, and very well preserved bas reliefs.
so many lovely old trees with so many forms ;-). i love this temple. so many old trees with so many forms. even the silvery colors under the sun was so magnificent..you can't miss this temple!!!
Amazing. I rode an elephant around the circumference of the temple and saw many of the Hindu and Buddhist influences on the history of Angkor city. It was an amazing place to see.

Lost its' historical integrity. I was excited to see the temple featured in the Tomb Raider movie but with hundreds of tourists doing the same arriving by the bus load and reconstruction meaning that most of it was held up by scaffolding, it lost its' historical integrity.

Great experience. Actual temple was smaller than I thought it would be but is such an amazing place to wonder round and experience. There is a general set of signs to semi guide you through but it's very relaxed so you feel like you can explore lots of passage ways and mini courtyards. Size of trees were amazing and color of the stones beautiful.

Amazing blend of ruins and nature. Wow, sometimes temples are even more spectacular when nature intrudes and becomes part of them. This was our favorite. While renovation work is constantly underway (somewhat controversial and an effort to accurately reconstruct using original stones or materials) this is a fantastic place. Again, go early, dress for the heat and take water.

Get here before the crowds. This is another wonderful place to visit. This was my first visit, but my husband's second. He was quite surprised with how much it had changed in 4 years.It is now well and truly on the tourist route.

Tomb Raider. This site is truly magical, nature taking back and co-existing with temples, lots of walking, can be a little cramped if your 6'3" like i am at times so watch your head, but still the bumps are worth it! Amazing place, truly stunning!!

Amazing setting, evocative and the real thing. TA Prohm was the real thing. Better then anything Disney could dream up. Ruins of old temple grounds only partly restored, filled with trees, vegetation and piles of fallen rock. Strangely serene, despite the crowds and the decay.
Excellent. This monument is very big and great. i ve Watch this building on tv and in real it's same like my book.

Old trees around even older temples. The photo opportunities at this site are awesome. You have to work your way around the crowds though. Had a guard point out some really great photo areas not spotted by all the tourists. Loved the place.

Amazing Must See. Best temple in the Angkor Wat area. Go as early as possible to avoid the crowds and get photos of the trees, roots, and temples without tons of other tourists in them. We went to Angkor Wat for sunrise, and then immediately to Ta Prohm (I think we got there around 8am). I am so glad that we did. It was wonderful walking through Ta Prohm in the early morning. You could sit and enjoy the peace and tranquility, or take people-free pictures like a madman, whatever you like. I did a little of both. We spent about 2 hours there, and that felt comfortable to explore everything, but if you want to sit for longer, 3 hours might be good.

Stunningly beautiful. These are one of the many temples within the Angkor district. It is beautiful to observe, but it felt like the guides and temples were just being used a movie buffs tribute site - because the film Tomb Raider was shot here - rather than for its intricate attachment with nature.

Mystical temple entwined by tree roots. Amazing to see how the trees have entwined themselves through the temple. Compared to the other temples it is somewhat "unrestored" yet still beautiful and amazing architecture and definitely worth visiting.

The tree roots make this place, it is not the fallen down stones that do it.. When you visit this place then forget the film 'Tomb Raider' which thankfully I never saw and have no wish to.......
Just remember that it was Mother Nature that the Tree Roots grew with the help of and then you can appreciate her power instead!

Wow-amazing!. It's awesome to see how the trees have taken over everything. Loads of great photo opportunities but very crowded at times. Had to queue for a photo at the Tomb Raider tree but well worth it
ABSOLUTE favorite temple in all of Angkor Wat. This is a stunning temple with all of the trees growing up and over the temple. A very peaceful place if you can get it to yourself. Very special!

Fascinating history . This temple provided a fascinating look into Siem Reaps history. Beautiful trees grow in and out of the stone temple and one is able to get up close by walking through many old walkways.
A very enjoyable trip and highly recommended.

Amazing. Amazing to see what mother nature does. Restoration work has started and many trees have been identified for cutting down. I wonder if it will have the same effect once it is restored? But seeing those trees around the temple buildings is simply amazing

Worth the trip. Worth the trip despite the sometimes oppressive heat and crowd. All of these sites are impressive complexes. Each with their own unique history. If you have the time try and see Angkor Thom as well. Expect a small queue for your tomb raider pic.

Right out of the movies. This is the one from Tomb Raiders. Trees wrapped around and actually holding together the walls. Good shoes are imperative at all these temples. Go with a good guide. Makes all the difference.
Wonder. With private tour guide, it's must visit the grandiose power of nature, the kids were very amazed how the trees can grow through the stones and rock over the years
Still untouch. I think of all the temples I visited this is still the most raw still very few areas have been remade.

Tomb Raider temple. Our tour guide Mr. Teav Kimsan helped us enjoy this special place. It's not to be missed. Good walking shoes and modest clothes that keep you cool are musts. Our tuk tuk driver was awesome So phal Kong 098337558.

Ta Phrom. It is beautiful to see how the trees have taken over the buildings. You can see that a lot of work is being done so that the temple doesn't become more ruined. Our guide said that fifteen years ago the temple was mainly ruins and that a lot of work has been done. We could see signs that people had been trying to piece stonework together. It is great climbing over the rubble. It is a beautiful place. Try to go when there are not lots of tour buses.

Amazing what nature can do. The history of Ta Prohm is riveting, as is nature's overtaking of the structure. Hopefully both the structure and nature's encroaching can be kept without too much more damage. Well worth the visit and a great backdrop for photographs.

Temple engulfed by Trees. This is a temple dedicated to the mother of king Jayverman VIIHonestly the trees are holding this place together. There is quite a bit of restoration done, and its a site worth a visit. Beware of bus loads of loud Chinese tourists who will walk all over you. A beautiful place when not crowded.
Wonderfully enthralling!. Definitely worth a trip to this temple site - the trees look so eerie and yet extremely beautiful at the same time.
Highly recommended!. Ta Prohm is definitely one of the temples not to be missed.. truly unique and beautiful :) Don't leave it for the end because you might be tired and there is a lot to see inside!
Too much tourism. The temple by itself is beautiful but not too much different from other temples. But as it was the location of a movie, everyone want to see it, and and is full of people.

See For Yourself what Featured in the Movie. The temple grounds are extensive with an excellent example of the power of nature to reclaim even the mightiest of human constructions. Fortunately the temple and its trees and vines are being preserved. Visitors walk through the entry gate along a forested walk to the temple and then through the temple with many examples of what trees and vines can do. You may have seen this in the movies but it is even more spectacular in person!

Tomb raider temple. Fascinating to see the damage caused by the Spung trees and the restauration work that attempts to reconcile the architecture and the trees. Our guide was more interested in telling us about a well-known film star than the temple - get a guide book!

Ta Prohm. This is also know as the Tomb Raider temple after the movie Tomb Raider that was shot at this site. The trees at thiz site is as impresive as the stone buildings itself although there isnt much buildings left intact. A good stop for some photo opprotunities, marvel at the massive trees growing on the ruines, and find the spots that apear in the movie to recreate the scenes :D
Amazing atmosphere. Fantastic climate just after dawn, before big tourist groups. Visited several times already, and still like to discover more and more.
Just like in the movie!. This is another great temple and just as you expect the roots are all over the stonework. Care should be taken on some of the walkways and climbing over stones.

My personal Favourite temple, love the trees . Location for Lara Craft's tomb raider. My Favourite, love the trees wrapped around the Temples. Our guide Lucky explained that the seeds were droppings from parrots

Nature takes over. Tree lovers will gush over this temple. The way the trees have taken over the ruins is stunning. This might have been my favorite temple (tied with Smiling Faces Temple/Bayon Temple). A must see.

More a ruin than temple. I find one of the most incredibly temples in Angkor. Sooner or later you will see this ruin either you have a one or three day pass. It's amazing to see a tree grows through a temple. With it's natural beauty history, the temple of Ta Prohm has been left in the lap of nature. The temple that the general public is particularly known for the hit movie Tomb Raider with Angelina Jolie. It is one of my favourite most beautiful temples in the Angkor area. Ta Prohm has been left mainly various other temples as they saw it in the discovery fully grown with large trees. It is a temple where nature grown. A few parts of the temple have been restored and further the jungle has not destroyed the temple. This contrast a temple as good as the soil is leveled by nature

Review. I was particularly interested at visiting this temple after it was featured in the film tomb raider. I was surprised and interested in how the trees roots had grown through the temples ruins and had become part of the temple itself. I found the temple beautiful and I really liked all the temples carvings and how it had become one with nature. It felt very serene here, despite other tourists it was peaceful. I loved the trees intertwining with the ruins and felt amazed at its beauty and character.

The best of the top 3. Even if Angkor Wat tops the list of the sites I liked this temple the most among in the area close to SR. The only one that beats it is Beng Mealea. Much less people (late afternoon) and you get some perspective when seeing all the trees growing on the walls.Don't miss it!
One of the best sights of the complex. Although there are many incredible sights around the area, Ta Prohm is an amazing jumble of building and tree, quite fantastic and atmospheric.
WOW.... so impressive.. Thoroughly enjoyed this temple. The famous view is obviously worth it, but so are the many other little corners of this complex.
history tour. As this was second on the day tour we had organised it was different to the others and the information posted along the way

Exotic scenery with ruins intermingled with vegetation. It really was so unique to see the ruins not yet restored, which made them even more interesting and exotic.... tree roots intertwining the ruins (nature reclaiming the land)

Excellent Ruins. Given its age this temple is in good condition. It is famous for being the Tombraider Temple and is part of the great Angkor Wat site. The way that the trees have grown through the ruins gives it a unique quality and provides a memorable experience.
Tomb Raider Temple. Loved it! Go early it gets really crowded, we went at 7:30am and we were able to take our time and get awesome photos.

This temple not restored, allowing the return of the jungle to slowly devour the stones.. Tomb raider fans will find delight in the authenticity of the gradual takeover by nature of the creations of man.

Awesome. This made me feel like I was in an Indiana Jones film. Probably my favourite of the temples, although in worse condition than others. I had always wanted to go to Angkor wat and had not appreciated the number and variety of other temples. It is an amazing site and can only be fully appreciated in person. We had a private guide who we had through booking our holiday with TrailFinders, but there are plenty of official guides you could book with over there and it does add a lot to the tour, so is worth doing. We did all of the main sites in 1 day, but you could easily spread this across 2 or 3 days if you wanted to take it a bit slower and wander around some of the smaller sites. This is one day that will stay with me for a long time.
intriguing but hot!. Not as many tourists as angkor wat. Peaceful in general but lots of walking if you go from one end to the other. bring an umbrella/parasol and gatorade!

Tomb Raider. Way less crowdy then Angkhor Wat and in my personal opinion even prettier! Its temples are proof of the architectural geniosity of the Cambodian people, while the plants and trees show that nature conquers all over time.

Ta Prohm - Tomb Raider territory. Apparently used as a location for one of he Tomb Raider movies, TP was different again to the visit to AW.Trees growing out of the walls of the temples gives the whole place a feel that the jungle is ever encroaching, ready to swallow the whole place.....
The Second Most Popular Area in Siem Reap because of Tomb Raider. I didn't like the platforms they put there so tourists can have their photo taken. For me it ruined the beauty of the place.
Rustic Temple in the Jungle. Interesting to see where The Tomb Raider movie was partially filmed. It would appear that there's no stopping the jungle from taking over again. Good photo opportunities.
Best attraction in Angkor area. Tempel is interesting and a good example of how the jungle has taken over the area. Best attraction in addition to sunrise at Angkor Wat.

Far Too Crowded to enjoy properly. Far too many tourists to make my visit peaceful and pleasurable. I'd been out to Kok Ker where one can see temples taken over by trees only and concluded that Ta Prohm to be the wonderful place it is needs to control access somehow. There are photographs to be had but great patience is needed to get any without a few tourists blocking out some of the scene you want. This is not a place for the less sure of foot; indeed most temples aren't. Wooden stairs up and down, uneven tunnel and paths and piles and piles of fallen blocks add hurdle after hurdle.I can see why it is rated highly as the tree roots are extraordinary, the few carved stones and arches that are left standing are in good condition, and despite everything there are some spots that one can find where the coach loads are not led.Tip: go at lunch when others are at the trough.

Wonderfull temple. Ta Prohm temple is the most wonderfull temple of Cambodia. This temple have big tree grow on temple. When you come to visit Cambodia please do not miss this wonderfull place. Thank you.

Tomb Raider Temple. Excellent place to visit. Site where Tomb Raider was filmed. What is special are the spung trees growing on the roofs of the temple and causing the scenery to be really spectacular. Real Ancient ruins feel!

Romantic ruins. Compared with our 2004 visit, this temple is less impressive because of the conservation / reconstruction going on; and inevitably, because of the greater crowds, since Angelina made a film here. The trees that adorn and are destroying it remain the main attraction -- pity it can't be frozen in time, because either the trees or the re-constructors are inevitably going to put an end to its romantic charm.

My favourite. This is definitely my favourite of the Temples we visited. We were very lucky that our personal tour guide knew the best places for photos where I could also avoid other tourists in my shots. Quite spectacular and a 'must do'.

Mythical, grand, beauty, tomb rauder. This incredible old temple is best known through its appearance in Tomb raider. The Racine, the roots and incredible trunks growing in the already beautiful temple is an unbelievable sight! Must see

Yes, this is the one that EVERYBODY knows....and there's a reason for it!. Yes, this is the "Tomb Raider" temple, and is the reason that many people even come to Angkor. It can be very crowded with tour groups (and that can be annoying).....but of course, with ANY crowded and popular tourist site, there's a reason for it. It's beautiful, mystical and other worldly. I HIGHLY suggest that you go first thing in the morning! Be there at the gate by 7:20, so that when they open the gate at 7:30am, you're the first to get in and are AHEAD of any groups, and get to walk through this magical place, just hearing birds and crickets chirping, with morning sunlight filtering through the trees!I promise it will be a VERY different experience than going any other time of the day, slowly making your way through while sandwiched between Chinese tour groups.

Get your Lara Croft:Tomb Raider on. This was such a good start to seeing the Angkor Temples! It was packed full of people but we still managed to get some photos so that it looked like we were the only ones! Photos will never do a place like this justice, and it should definitely be on your list of places to go! The temple tells stories of all those who used it in the past, and has been very well looked after and maintained.

Nature v temple. Fantastic site where trees and their roots as well as time have invaded the temple structures. Absolutely magnificient. I think it would be extra stunning in the wet season when green moss also adds to the scene

Nice trees behind the tourists. When we think of Angkor we have these images of all these huge trees taking over the ruins and that where it is the most impressive... But you'll have to get through the tourist sea first !

Massive trees! Not to be missed!. This temple is a must see while in Siem Reap. It is where the Angelina Jolie filmed Tomb Raider. Eggs makes this place so special are the massive trees that have grown within the temple. The roots are so large that they look like huge snakes.

Be there before 8am. Very impressive and mysterious place. Just make sure you arrive before 8am. It opens at 7.30am
The huge trees with its roots are stunning. Tomb Raider has a scene shot here.

Majestic. Ruins, big old trees, old temples, stones.................all are there to give you the majestic view. The full area is history of mankind....standing in front of us. Be there to relive the past...

Truly unique. This was the third temple we visited on a spectacularly hot day, and whilst I had nearly reached my limit for the day, this temple was truly magnificent. Clearly our guide had saved the best temple till last. The way the trees have become one with the structure and the lengths gone to to maintain both the structure and the trees is impressive. Well worth the visit!

amazing. Angkor Wat in Cambodia gets all the publicity, and it is incredible, but Ta Prohm should be first on your list of sights to see in Cambodia, if not the world. I have never seen an abandoned temple complex being taken over by nature.Tree roots and branches are everywhere-on rooftops,inside rooms on fences and walkways.

Photogenic and atmosperic. Ta Prohm is largely unrestored, with trees growing throughout the complex, frequently in visually stunning ways. It gets fairly high visitor traffic both because it was featured in the "Lara Croft Tomb Raider" movie, but also because its unrestored nature offers interesting contrast to the other temples. If you only have time for a couple of temples, Ta Prohm offers a nice bookend to Angkor Wat.

Look out for indiana Jones.... Similar architecture to the other main temples, but rather more atmospheric because of the large trees which were left during the restoration and whose roots snake over the stonework. Very busy though, so gettig a people-free photo can be quite a challenge.

Cant say enought about all the temples we saw.. This is an amazing experience and place. Please visit! We took 3000 pics not including videos. This is a must see amazing country. Its hot. Bring water, and extra battery for camera.

Impressive. Ta Prohm was one of the three temples that we visited around Angkor Wat. With this temple one can step back in time into the history This temple is also known as the Tomb Raider temple, made famous by the 2001 movie of Lara Croft: Tomb Raider The massive trees have overgrown on the roof of temples with roots shrouding the walls. The renovation work is being carry out by Archaeology Survey of India and they are doing the nice job. The restored portion is amazing. Carry water with you to avoid dehydration as one is required to walk a lot to catch the glimpses of the temple

True Cambodia. If you seen Cambodia in films or pictures in books this is where they comes from. It is fascinating and very big, although busy there is room and space to explore, if you can't do much of the area make sure this is one you do visit.

Made famous by Tomb Raider. This temple is like a maze. I got lost while looking for the tree in tomb raider. Up until now Im not sure which one is it really is. The temple is like a merger of temples and trees. Most of the temples were already ruined by the trees. Yet it is still a beautiful disaster..

Best of the Best Angkorian Temples!. This is my personal favorite. Tah Prohm provides visitors with a genuine experience of adventure as well as a feeling of imperturbable tranquility while losing oneself in the undisturbed and atmospheric surroundings of the temple complex. The temple is especially tranquil in the morning, as crowds often flock to Angkor Wat and other more prominent temples as their first attraction of choice. When walking around Ta Prohm, be sure to follow the signs, or risk getting lost or missing out on places of interest within the monument. While some areas have been closed to the public, there are hindden scenery that can be found by going off the beaten track. Make your way through the narrow and dark passages, for some interesting finds.Ta Prohm is ‘the’ photographer’s playground. It is a haven for those who love taking photos or revering the aesthetic. Traversing the through the ruins of the temple does not require strenous climbing. It is thus, suitable for childred and the elderly.
Interesting. Personally I will rank this behind Angkor wat and Bayon. The highlights are of course those big trees that grab the temple walls. Interesting.

Love the hugh trees growing on the top of the temple. People who love nature will definitely like this place. Tree roots are found everywhere. There are many giant trees inside and outside the temple.

Beautiful mix of nature and architecture. Ta Prohm is a stunning sight to see with trees growing around the temple structures. Made more famous by the TombRaider movie, this is a temple you shouldn't miss in Siem Reap.
Amazing Temple. A woundeful temple and many things to see in area and i it short time by Tuk Tuk to go there. i really love it.
Nature's Majesty!. Mother Nature has invited this temple, with tree root so reading the most amazing living sculptures. Don't miss this temple while you're in Siem Reap.

Out of the forest. This is one of the most photographed and shows how the forest took over most of these temples. Many of the strangler fig are left as they are actually holding part of the temple together
The trees are winning. Everyone may recognise this as the temple in Tomb Raider. It is brilliant but can get very busy with lots of photo taking . Well worth the trip

Don't miss an opportunity to visit. Jaw dropping experience, just don't expect to get good memories on camera, there will be a Chinese person puckering up for a selfie on every shot! Fascinating place, you must go

We went at sunrise - Amazing Experience. Against all advice we returned to Ta Prohm at sunrise to beat the crowds. Its true you can't actually see the sunrise but you do get the place to yourself and experience the sunlight filtering through the trees - its magical . For me a much more memorable experience then watching the over-crowded sunrise at Angkor Wat

Lara Croft in real live. Unfortunately Ta Prohm has been too famous as a scene out of Tomb Raider when its own history is even more mysterious and enchanting. Again, pictures speak a thousand words.The magical trees that dwarf the temple is called Spung tree (pronounced as "Sperng") and as dead as they look, the trees are very much alive.Its really humid and hot during March. Not recommended for cycling though many tours promote that - the bikes end up being trolleyed back as its just too hot. Along the way, there is a group of musicians made up of landmine survivors, do support them.
wow. Sooo goood to be there and discover ancient temples which are so amazing. This one is really worth seeing.

Ruin emerging from the forest.. This is the temple that everyone said I had to see - a temple that has emerged after being taken over by the forest. Prominently mentioned is the connection to the movie Tomb Raider. The temple did not disappoint. Even so, if you have time to visit other important sites, and wish to see trees growing out of buildings, consider Ta Som and Banteay Kdei.

5*, nothing less!. We visited this temple first in our bike tour with Grasshopper. (It was actually our second temple of the day after seeing the sunset at Angkor). We were amazed by all the wear of time on this temple, but the efforts to keep it in great shape are worth noticing. This temple is not as big as the other two we saw afterwards, but it is nonetheless incredible because of the trees growing over it. It is simply magnificient! Everybody should see this! As for the other temples visited today, we could have stayed much longer to study all the details on the walls...

Amazing. I went here right after visiting Angkor Wat and I liked it better. It was much less crowded and seems to be in better repair (at least the stone does not appear to be as blackened). It is set up more like a park than Angkor Wat and there is a lot of jungle foliage including trees whose roots seem to melt over the temples. It's mighty hot and humid there so dress accordingly and bring water.

Fantasy or Reality?. This temple is buried deep in the jungle and will activate anyone's wildest imagination. It is overgrown and rooted into the jungle, and forms are intertwined in a mysterious way.
Stunning. Lives up to expectations, just remember you may not get the photos you would like due to the number of Chinese tourists wanting to take selfie at every inch of the way.

beautiful!. I am not particularly interested in seeing every single museum, temple and church in the world, but i definitely recommend seeing this temple. All the locals seem to be super proud of this temple because Angelina Jolie filmed Lara Croft here, but besides all the hype, this temple is definitely the most picturesque and most interesting out of the few I decided to go to. It also wasn't as crowded as the others I went to. More spacious and a great place for photos. Definitely a must see!
Wow. This is just so cool, the trees has really gone rough on this temple. Take a bike and enjoy the temples. It's easy and gives you all the freedom you need.

Favourite temple to visit. The temple us very atmospheric with huge tree roots twisting in odd directions they look almost alice. The temple is old and walls are tree damaged as its in the jungle. It is so imoressive to see what they built so many years ago.Famous for parts of the tomb raider film but it's so much more. If you like an old athentic temple with some movie connection it's worth a visit.

Indiana Jones Worthy. Ta Prohm is a must see on every visitor's list of places to experience in Siem Reap. Famous for being the location for Angelina Jolie's first Lara Croft movie, it is easy to see why this is a favourite among moviemakers and tourists. Stone reliefs being strangled by massive vines and roots, stone rubbles, labyrinthine passages, and moss covered stones make for an unforgettable experience amidst the forest.
Wonder of Man and Nature. Must see to appreciate. This one's a no brainer. Be sure to note the enormous bee hives in some of the trees. Really amazing place.
worth the visit. The temple entry is included in the other temple 20 usd. Long work from the gate to temple. Restoration going on. We enjoyed it but noot as much as Angkor.

Tour with Sothoun Ok. Went on a tour with Suthoun Ok visiting 3 sites in one day organised through the Sofitel hotel. Travelling in the air conditioned vehicle with cool towels and bottles of cold water was a blessing on the extremely hot day. Suthourn is an excellent guide who knew where to visit and when to avoid the other tourists. He also knew the best places to take photos and took amazing photos of us both. His knowledge of the various sites was great and we learned a lot about the history and saw many highlights on our tour

Interesting for different reasons. This temple, as depicted in the many photos you come across, is in ruins. Nature and man have destroyed a lot of it, and this sets it apart from Angkor and Ta Prohm. This gives it a much different feel, more ancient and real almost. Very few remaining carvings unlike Bayon where the carvings are tremendous.It is also much smaller and set on one level, so very accessible. Great photo ops. On reflection If you have concerns about your capacity to visit all three in one day due to heat or fitness issues. I would do this temple first, Bayon second and use any remaining energy reserves for Angkor.

Amazing!. This is of course one of the must see temples whilst in Siem Reap, featured in several films and it's understandable why! Absolutely amazing how the tree's just grow through the structure, very interesting.

A living temple.. This was my favorit temple. The fact that the jungle and the tree roots grew over the temple walls and ruins was neat I had seen some of the area in the Indiana Jones movie which was partially filmed at this temple. It was also interesting that India researchers were helping to restore the temple.

The power of nature. You will be impressed with the tall and huge at Ta Prohm. They've been here for thousand years.
If you come to Angkor, even for only one day, please pay Ta Prohm a visit.

Looking for Lara Croft. The third temple you are going to see, if you have a driver, they prefer to drive you to Ta Prohm right after Angkor and Bayon and then you probably very tired from walking and climbing you are going back to your hotel. That's what I did.
Family visit of Angkors. Wow what a temple! It is surounded by a big trees I have ever seen. How did the people build this temple and how the trees can grow between the rocks.
Over grown. Very interesting to see how it was when it was discovered, with trees roots growing all over. Restoration work still in progress.

Mysterious temole. This is the TombRaider temple. Beautiful example of how these amazing temples were lost in the rainforest. It is hard to imagine how that can happen until you visit here and see for yourself!

Picturisque. Ta Prohm is the picture you always see on Post Cards, on travel magazines.
it is nice to visit them early morning for a good capture otherwise when Chinese tour groups are coming, you will never get to have a good view shot.

Ta Prohm temple very amazing . I visited the small tour that have many temples but I want to visit Ta Prohm temple. I'm very suprice when I saw thise tample is very very amazing with the root of amazing trees on the temple, some tourist called temple Thom rider I'm very happy to saw this temple with my friend.

My favorite of the temples of Siem Reap. its the "Tomb Raider" temple, but its amazing and a proper strategy helps see.. I am going to use the same review sturcture i used for angkor wat. There are a couple of things to understand about the temples in general in Siem Reap. If you want to read about Ta Prohm only then jump to #8This is one of those sites that delivers through all of the built up anticipation. Like many other wonders of the world, there are hundreds of sites, tours, guides, and ancillary services that are offered adjunct to exploring the ruins themselves. Understand that Angkor Wat is one ruin in a whole network of ruins over miles and miles of area. The most important part of a visit here is to simply educate yourself, get a good guide or driver and see the right things at the right time. First thing to consider is time of year. I went over the new years time and there are hundreds of thousands of people with the same idea. Its high season with a capital H, so if you are planning on taking photographs without people in them, either forget it, or you better be really good at photoshop. If you are coming specifically to photograph, i would recommend a time of year that is less popular. Then there is the next part...WHAT should i do? How do i start planning this? There are a million sites that all say they are the right way... 1. Start with your budget. Budget depending, chose your hotel.The choice of hotel might determine your options for guide services. For example if you stay at the Shinta Mani hotel..(even if you don't...you should visit since its the #1 hotel by TA. and its amazing) they will get your tour together for you. If you are on more of a budget, get your self your own guide / driver. The difference between a guide and a driver is that a guide can give you the history of each of the locations and a driver can only take you between the locations. Sometimes they can be both in one. I went with a tour guide / driver who was amazing and is on trip advisor. He name is Da Mao. He is one of the main tuk tuk drivers of the shinta mani hotelHe has a tuk tuk which is one of the best ways to get around. If you are sensitive to heat, you may want to opt for an air conditioned car. 2. Plan the temples and the time of day you want to hit them. Sunrise is a popular time because you can take spectacular photographs. Angkor wat is the most famous of all of the ruins and therefor one of the most popular at sunrise. I recommend getting up around 4:00 am and heading out around 4:30 - 5:00 am. (in december) 3. You will need to buy entrance tickets. They are around 20$ for one day and 40$ for 3 days. The lines are HUGE during christmas time. I opted for the 3 day even though i only planned one day simply because there was a shorter line. However you can put the 3 days to use if you buy the pass anyway. 4. When you get to angkor wat, i would recommend going directly inside the complex and to the small "lake" all of the photographers wait there to get the "post card" shot of Angkor Wat with the sun rising and reflecting in the "lake". I want to reiterate the lake on the inside (not the moat on the outside. It is best to go straight there are ALL pro photographers are trying to get to that same spot. So you will have to vie for position.5. Bring some food with you so you can eat a little something while inside. It is a HUGE temple and takes quite a while to see in its entirety. 6. Keep in mind that it is an ACTIVE functional temple so discrete clothing is REQUIRED and should be respected. This means that the ladies need to cover their shoulders and have skirts that go below the knee. You will some some tacky tourists in hotpants due to the heat, but it REALLY looks tacky and disrespectful and they may flat out refuse to let you in.7. Once you have seen enough of this temple and grounds its time to head off to the other temples like Ta Prohm (tomb raider temple) and Bayon (smiling face temple). Due to the timing of seeing the sun rise at angkor wat you will be hitting bayon closer to mid day. As a photographer all of the temples are less visually interesting in the high sun, but it is still great fun to explore. Bayon is really cool and kind of a labyrinth and requires much more vertical climbing up stairs compared to angkor wat. Enjoy it. 8. Ta Promh is the one i hit last in my tuk tuk trifecta. This was my favorite. This temple cant be explained with words. All i can say is go. It is COMPLETELY surreal. It is straight out of a dream or movie or some other incomprehensible scenario. It is the perfect example of a temple swallowed by the jungle almost perfectly. If you tried to make this on purpose i dont think it could have ever been possible to man make something to look like this. JUST GO....and if you have it in you take the "long" walk inside. There is a long and a short walk,...but why short change this experience.There are children selling ALL SORTS OF EVERYTHING...as cute as they may be...DONT buy maps or ANYTHING from them. You are actually keeping them out of school by perpetuating a living that avoids education by glamorized begging. there are plenty of non profits that you can donate to. I know its hard but its really important to help the local children become educated.I hope this was helpful and if you got a few things out of this....respect the clothing in the temples...dont buy from children and dont miss sunrise, and bring a wide angle and telephoto.
Do not forget to visit this temple.. the most beautiful one after visit Angkor Wat, loved and recommend to all tourists don't forget to visit this temple.
Very different. This is a good example what damage trees can do and how much power the roots have. It was so interesting to see this temple from other temples where all the trees had been removed.

Wonderful! Wonderful! Wonderful!. Don;t miss this one, unbelievable atmospheric, we saw it at sunset but any time oif day must be fascinating, though I would avoid the heat of midday if possible Take a wet cloth in a plastic bag to keep you cool --- or cooling snakes from the Cancer Council.

Second Place we visited. This is a very popular place due to Tomb Raider. I love these big trees, it was amazing how they took over the structures. We went to this place right after sunrise at angkor wat to beat the crowd. We had our breakfast inside the van. It was worth visiting early in the morning because we only shared the place with 2 other small groups and was able to take photos of the place to our hearts content.

Tomb Raider Temple, beautiful!. Also known as Tomb Raider, this place is amazing, the mix between it's astounding architecture plus the nature growing in the temples is unique. This place seems out of storybook, it will amaze you.

Magical. Certainly more beautiful than the more famous angkor wat. When he the ruins see beautiful, I wish I had seen this temple in its glory days.. Quite liked it. Absolute must when you visit Siem reao
A definite must see. Amazing to see how nature is trying to reclaim these temples and the trees and the structure are now inseparable. Definitely worth the visit. Take your time and a lot of water.

Amazing Place - late afternoon . Well worth visiting. Lots of shade along the walk in and again when wandering around the temple which is handy in the very hot weather.Late afternoon was great for coolness but also gives great long late afternoon shadows for photos.

The 'Lara Croft' Temple. Used in the Lara Croft Tomb raider film and subsequently it gets busy. But it is very interesting and also very beautiful. As with a lot of these temples, there is ongoing restoration work and rightly so as they are too special to neglect.

Surprising . I was very excited to visit this place since this is popular from a movie starred by Angelina Jolie and BTW I am a fan sorry. Hehehe... But this temples offers such an ordinary and exemplary designs of faces and the history behind it is actually remarkable. This Temple will surely offer you a marvelous experience in touring around because due to its wide location you might be lost in here but don't worry it's safe and you will have an amazing experience here.

Nature against old civilizations. Yes, this is the Tomb Raider place. Famous for the movie, but mostly have to visit because it's interesting to see nature making its way into these big temples and buildings, with trees that are hundreds of years old, on top of even older structures.
wildly beautiful. almost demolished, but being re-constructed by ASI. it has a raw beauty with eucalyptus trees growing over the walls of the temple.

Fascinating demonstration of preservation and decay . For us this temple was more a demonstration of the impact of the invasion by the jungle of the temple complex than about the original temple itself.It would have been lovely to see more pictures and learn more about regaining these sites from the jungle and rediscovering their beauty...Such well preserved and significant architecture. Our adult family group visited in a van with a driver on the short tour from Siem Reap. Could have spent days there but enjoyed a representative sample of the three temples. Very humbling to have been able to experience such an amazing place

Unbelievable . A fascinating place, with the trees taking over the landscape & taking everything back to nature. The guide was also able to show us were the tomb raider film was shot and pointed out the various locations they used for filming.
Stunning. The way the trees intermix with the Buildings is incredile, some of the sights are mind-blowing. It was very busy when we were there

Though Angkor Wat is the biggest and most impressive, to me, Ta Prohm was the jewel in the crown.. Yes, one MUST visit Angkor Wat while there.....the earlier in the day the better so as to hopefully have less fellow tourists and a bit cooler weather, but to me the FOR SURE stop while touring the various structures scattered throughout this extensive complex is Ta Prohym...it is the one with the Silk Cotton trees growing out of the stone ....perhaps the one captured most in photographs and film. All of them, if standing alone, far away from the others, would be mind-boggling impressive and well worth visiting. However, since there are so many great structures on the property, it gets a bit overwhelming, and one tends to get "templed out"......if you have the get up and go to see them all, go for it....but if you only have a day or so, be SURE to visit Ta Prohm after visiting Angkor Wat. Incredible.

Eerily Beautiful Temple. This temple has not been restored and that has its own beauty. From the crumbling walls and tumbled down stone blocks to the trees grown out of the same, it all provides a beautiful place to explore. It's a about a half-mile walk from where the tuk-tuk drops people off to the actual temple structures. And then there are many steps to negotiate while exploring the temple. It can be done on crutches, as I did. One just has to be careful.

A temple being overtaken by the jungle. The sight of gnarled old trees wrapped around the centuries old temple was awe inspiring. The whole temple sites are like nowhere else on earth. So glad I did go while I could.

Nature vs Man. This ancient palace complex (featured in the Lara Croft Tombraider film) has become overgrown with gigantic tree roots. There is ongoing archeology at the site. It is a beautiful site due both to the amazing stonework and the force of nature.

Overly crowded and better in the movies. Been there, done this. Prefer to visit other temples for the banyan trees and roots in the temples (Beng Mealea and Ta Nei). Try and get here early before the crowds.
An other Temple? NO!. Jungle meets Temple. Best place to see the harmonie...A further temple, but different to the others. You can see the different epoch of the Khmer culture.

Awe inspiring . I hired a guide for the day, but one can easily go without, however wear sturdy shoes and lots of sunscreen. Drink lots of water as the sun is intense. Much of the stonework is crumbling and undergoing restoration, and with the insight of my guide I had a deeper appreciation of the history of the temple and people.
Trees everywhere. I did not expect trees everywhere what a beautiful surprise. The tour is winding but well worth the visit. A must see while in Siam Reap.
Tomb Raider Location. We loved taking pictures at this site--the trees looks like icing pouring down over the buildings...bring your camera!

Crowded but a must visit.. This location was made more famous by Tomb Raider. You do get to walk through just about the whole complex and it is really impressive to discover how the trees have overgrown the complex. Don't forget to look at the craftsmanship that went into each stone...this sometimes gets lost in the mammoth size of the ruins and trees.

Enchanting. Ta Prohm was one of the temples that we visited in our 3 day trip around Angkor Wat. I couldn't hep but be awed by the magnitude of the trees that have grown on top of this temple. This place is a perfect example of stepping back in time. Just make sure to be completely protected from the heat but make sure that you are also comfortable because you will do a lot of walking around. It helps to pay attention to your tour guide if you are doing a private tour.

Not like it used to be. When I visited here 12 years ago this was my favorite temple, but this time it was my least favorite. This particular temple was so busy and regimented as to make the visit stressful
Amazing and special place. Would recommend going without a guide and having a relaxed walk around, can be very busy at peak times but did not take away from this spectacular place.

Tons of Photo Opportunities. I love to take pictures and for me Ta Prohm offered more great snap shot opportunities than any of the other five temples visited during my private tour. Maybe it was the massive trees that had become one with the temple, the interplay of light and shadows caused by their canopies, or the beautiful carvings that were still intact albeit hidden by the tree roots, whatever it was, I was enchanted by the place and took more pictures here than anyplace else. Yes, this temple is also known as the Tomb Raider temple, made famous by the 2001 movie Lara Croft: Tomb Raider.
