But if your expecting to find an inner chamber with a four faced statue guarded by monkey gods and lion-dogs then you will be disappointed, because that was all done in a movie studio somewhere. As you can see from some of the photos I took, parts of the temple have tumbled to the ground and other parts are under renovation. The renovated parts are so well done it is almost imperceptible. There was a huge crane on site when we went but it did not detract at all from the overall beauty of this temple. I would strongly suggest that this temple be on your short list of things to see on anyone's Angkor Wat tour.

Where trees and building co-exist. The Ta Prohm temple is truly remarkable. The huge trees overgrowing the temple ruins seem to make the place come alive. My favourite finds at the place were the hidden face of a smiling Buddha and the carving of an animal which resembled a dinosaur (cute). Words cannot do justice to this amazing site. You have to visit the Ta Prohm to see it for yourself.
In the mood for love!!. Come and bury your secrets into the cracking holes in this mystic temple, as Wang Kai Wai instructed you!!!

Overwhelming. We only went to Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm. Even though Angkor Wat is the most known of the temples, I would say that Ta Prohm was the most overwhelming. The trees are living their own lives, and it is just incredible to see the powers of nature take over the ruins

Amazing temple in the clutches of the forest. Ta Prohm is one of the real highlights of the Siem Reap area. It's huge and looks like something straight out of Indiana Jones - maybe it is at is was certainly used in Tomb Raider, and I think Congo. The trees growing around and in some cases through the temple buildings are amazing.The only downside is the number of tourists is quite off-putting. We came here twice, once very late in the day, when it was much more pleasant.

Must-see!. Really impressive how the jungle strikes back... the huge trees overgrowing the ruins create a very special atmosphere and provide some shade. Look up to spot some squirrels! ;) Opens at 7:30, and in the first hours there weren't many people around.
Wonderful temple. We really like this temple lots specially all big trees so beautiful and our took us right time we almost avoid crowds bus tourists.

Amazing. Wow, this place was just breathtaking. To see how the roots of the trees were intertwined with the building was so special. You almost think that you are dreaming and that this can't be real but it is. This was our last temple of the day and I'm so happy we ended with this one as it was very unique and special.

Incredible Place. The temple is very interesting to see how they have restored some areas from what appears to be just a bunch of rubble. Amazing. The trees growing out of the structure is very interesting.

"Tomb Raider" temple.. Just one of the many temples in the area, but made much more interesting by the jungle growth that is gradually taking over the temple. Tree roots seem to be able to grow into all the cracks in the rock and it is a facinating glimpse of the constant battle between nature and man. Well worth the visit.

Most crowded temple. This also must see temple is the most crowded temple of the complex due to the presence of the banyan tree roots strangling the stones.It was very crowded, but probably due to the restricted boardwalk along which the tourists are directed. As everyone also wants to have their photo taken with the roots in the background, passage can be slow.

Wonderful temple but so many people. More people than spung trees at this temple. Ta Prohm is really impressive and if you are limited on time I would say it is a must see amongst the many temples at Angkor, but pick your time to avoid serious crowds. Apparently hottest part of the day, midday to 2pm is quietest. Fair warning: Lots of sellers in the car parks who come to the cars and some knock on the windows.

Great historical value and great photo ops. Of course we had to see this temple because of the movie connections. Get the photo, then get the movie reference out of your system then relax and walk around and enjoy the architecture and history. And then look for the awesome tree root photo oppurtunities. Great place

Looking for Lara. I didn't find her but it was great seeing the sites used in Tomb Raider. The down side is the mass of humanity waking through a limited area; next time I would try and get there first thing in the morming

highlight of my visit to Seam Reap. Ta Prohm was my favorite in Seam Reap, one has to visit to get the wonderful feeling this site gives you, amazing structures with tree roots growing over the buildings, the history is mind blowing, highly reccommend to put on your bucket list. Can be crowded, but every thing seams to flow. Can understand why it was used in Angelina Jolie's movie tomb raider.There are places to buy water, but do make sure you have adequate with you as it gets very hot.

Not just a Temple but great people helping themselves and others. There is little more to be said 'touristically' about this wonder of architecture and nature entwined not already set down here. However, during my two visits over two days (in 44C heat!), I had the opportunity to meet, talk to and enjoy the music of the War and Land-Mine disabled musicians found near the East and West gates. If every tourist who raises a camera or iPad gave a few dollars to these guys, their lives and those of the 100 plus family members they support would be really improved. They are really doing something amazing, plus keeping the traditions of Kmer Mahori music alive in their villages. They also put aside a portion of donations to help other local war-disabled unable to earn even a meagre living - we owe it to them as they add to our pleasure of this magical place.The next time a young person at home uses the term 'Awesome', I'll tell them that awesome is a place like Ta Prohm and the people of the Angkor villages round about.

Amazing. The whole 10 miles square site is absolutely out of this world. Water, compass and tuk tuk to travel between temples is a must as they are literally kilometres apart and you will not be able to walk in between them in 40-50 degree heat.

Love this temple ,the story on the wall are great ,there are many photos oppurtunities. Prepare for long walking under the heat ,walking shoe is needed.Make sure your camera battery are fulled charged .The walking tour would take you about 2 hours .If you planed to visit the top level make sure you dressed properly .

Another favourite.... Liked the crumbled nature of this temple and all the trees growing over it. We saw this after another couple of temples and were hot and tired by this point - we should have waited until the next morning when we were more fresh as definitely on of the highlights.

Awe-inspiring. I will keep this review short and sweet for Ta Prohm is to be seen to be believed- there are no words to justify this ancient temple sufficiently which is a remarkable example of a fusion between man and nature to create what appears to all like a genuine Hollywood set ( Ta Prohm has famously been featured in Tomb raider). Over the last few hundred years since Ta Prohm was abandoned birds have been dropping seeds in the crevices and cracks of the rocks that make up this beautiful temple. The result is that trees have slowly grown and separated the rocks and in places appear to have fused and become part of the structure. Having visited a number of temples in Anghor this is probably our favourite due to this ( for fear of repeating myself) amazing relationship between man and nature. Definitely get a guide as they can show you the quickest and most rewarding route through the temple as the crowds of tourists could spoil your enjoyment of this wonder. I would like to put a special mention in for our guide who was with us for 4 days and guided us through a number of temples with not only professionalism and humour but a genuine love and respect for the architecture, skill and people that built these amazing structures. His name is:Mr Ngeth Samol and if anyone wants his e-mail address please contact me
Fantastic!. Ruins are in very poor shape. Interesting how the Spung trees have been growing right through the rocks!

Nature is stronger. This place was made a household name by Ms. Jolie by getting sequences of tomb raider shot here. There is a unique beauty in this place when compared to the other temples courtesy the roots which have reclaimed parts of the temple. It is a must go if u going visiting and is included in the fees u pay for Angkor Wat.

Siem Reap. We spent the best part of the morning here, wandering through the temple ruins, some dating back to the 12th century and were amazed at the beauty of the overgrowth of trees and other plants intermingled with the structures. For the historical value this is well worth visiting and meandering through the ruins.

Wow, what a tree!!!. This place is very interesting, to see how much tree and root can grow over any structure over time. It refreshed memory from Tomb Raider. It a must see place. We went in the afternoon avoiding all big Chinese tour groups in the morning and glad wasn't crowded.

Stunning.. This is the temple to see the dramatic interaction between the archeology and the jungle with huge trees engulfing the buildings. When we went it wasn't too busy and there was a good discipline between everyone at the good photo spots. One not to miss.

Wow - so nice. This is one of the best if not the best temple in Angkor Wat temple complex.Due to popularity, this place can be very busy. Be patient and take your time to enjoy the place. Make sure you camera has lodes of memory space as you are likely to take many photos.Try to avoid big tourists group if you can.
Amazing! . Differently worth a look - this would be one of my favorite temples. The trees are huge and the roots have grown over the old temple leave a dramatic effect of nature and man made.

the interessting temple in this inviroment. to see, how trees grow opon the tempel-walls is spectacular. this is a must in the temple fields of Anchor. dont miss it. Choose a tuk tuk Driver, for 1 , 2, or three days..
Nature at work. Awe-inspiring to see what nature does ... Nothing comes in- between nature when it decides on its course.Lots of restoration going on and I hope hey continue to preserve this place.
one of a kind. this is a must to visit its beautiful nothing like it.Must hire a private tour if you like to know more in detail about this place

AMAZING - one of my dreams fullfilled!. This is for sure one of the most amazing and stunning sites on the archeological temple site of Angkor Wat. I spent a lot of time here, to see all those incredibly big trees literally becoming one with the temple architecture, is beautiful. Definitely my favorite!!! My tip: go watch the Sunrise at Angkor Wat, but don't stay. Leave right after the sunrise and come right away to Ta Prohm as this is one of the busiest temples and it gets very crowded and annoying. I came here early and it was already busy but absolutely ok.

One of my favorites, a top tier place to visit, Temple of the Tomb Raiders!. Really interesting temple to visit on many levels. It has the history of being a site for a movie and it is just a really cool place to see and take pics. Ta Prohm is on of many temples that have vegetation and trees growing among and around them .. Our guide said that bird dropping with seeds are the cause for the vegetation and tree growth in and around the temples. Sounds feasible to me. There is also one very curious carving on the walls of Ta Prohm. It is a carving of what looks like a stegosaurus, a dinosaur that predates this temple by about 155 million years. An alternate story is that it is a mythological Hindu beast. I posted the pic, you decide! :)

Dramatic Trees. Felt amazing to finally be standing in front of the temple famous for the huge Spung tree roots growing over and around it. There are a number of other areas of the temple with other amazing roots growing around the site and is amazing to witness this!

Incredable Temple!!!. Sourounded jungles made this beautiful temple more wonderful. Don't miss it if you visit Siem Reap. You should hire tour guide with you if you want to know more about its history.
Amazing!. All temples have distinct differences, however, this one truly is incredible. It has a different feel to it than other temples.

Just how I had imagined the Angkor temples. Good to see the temple in the original ruined condition. Personally I preferred this to the restored Angkor Wat. Access is restricted and it is a fair walk to the temple site.

Many photo opportunities. The site was made famous by Tomb Raider. Can find many locations for photo opportunities. But also because of that, many tourists swarm around the iconic fig trees that enveloped the walls. Need some patience to capture "people free" shots. The place to go to see how nature challenges man made structures to gain an upper hand

The Tomb raider temple - Ta Prohm. Most of the guide will called it as Tomb Raider temple, it is not as grand as you seen on the screen so don't have too high expectation on that. ( The movie also not firm there ) This temple is smaller than Angkor Wat but the bird singing and the tree growing make you feel very calm there.There are many local and kids selling the guide book and local music instrument at the entrance, just be nice to them if you are not going to buy.It's a short walk from the entrance to the main building the path is smaller beware of the old China tourist and Korean tourist that will block your way and not behave well.

The jungle devouring the temples. This temple was a lovely inclusion to our Angkor tour, as it really brings home the fact that these temples were being surrounded and absorbed into the jungle before they were rediscovered. Most other temples in the complex have large cleared areas around them, where the encroaching jungle was pushed back, but here the jungle and temple share the same space, with huge trees simultaneously tearing down and re-enforcing the crumbling walls.

Very atmospheric. We arrived very early having watched the beautiful sunrise over a nearby lake and were very disappointed to hear that the temple did not open until 7.30 rather than the 6.30 we were told it has previously done. This is a shame as being an early riser we hoped to beat the rush and large parties. If anyone from the local tourist board is reading this please note that as Cambodia is a very hot place is is better for us tourists to get to the temple early before it gets too hot. The temple was fascinating and the famous roots in the temple building looks great. Saw the famous tree from Tomerader film. If you don't have time to see all temples this is not one to miss out.

Worth a visit. We visited Ta Prohm after a long day at Angkor Wat and although we were tired and running on low....it was worth a visit. It was a stunning place like nowhere else I've ever been. I only wish we would've gone the next day and spent more time there.

Magical site. This place took me to my childhood dreams of a perfect magical forest.Of course that’s only achievable if you can abstract yourself from the hundreds of tourists. If you do that, the place is sublime.

Temple with over run roots all over templeruin from giantitic tree. The over ground tree with the root systems penetrating the temple ruins and distorting the temple stone block were purposely left intact .There were still many trees remaining inside the temple compound with roots system penetrating the stone blocks.

A Temple under Restoration. This is a temple good for taking pictures because you can see temple wall being engulfed by Huge tree roots. However this temple is under restoration and many sections good for picture taking shown on internet were closed and inaccessible to visitors. I had a chance to visit this temple 5 years ago and was still able to see many sections. The present condition is bad.

Tomb Raider. Yes all the locals kept reminding us that this is the film site of tomb raider. Too many people by the time we got there. After visiting the park, I have decided that when I return, I will do it in reverse. Instead of heading to Angkor first, we will bypass the crowds and head here first then go back against the crowd.
To be visited after Angkor and Bayon temples. Angkor, Bayon and Ta Phrom are included into the same day pass. It is impressive to see how the vegetation has taken all these old stones.

Sort of interesting.. I know that I should have been more impressed with the famous ancient tree and the fact that Tomb Raider was filmed here - but it was just okay. I'm sure I was overwhelmed with the heat by the time I got here. There is some much needed restoration going on around the temple and it was interesting to see how much detail (stone carvings) is still apparent after nearly eight centuries. Just get your picture taken by the tree and then read about it later so you can appreciate it more.
Amazing. Just for the trees (can't remember the names) growing on top of the temple complex and the roots creeping towards the ground. Great experience.

Beautiful with tree on temple. I love this temple lots specially all big tree crowed on temple it made temple get more beautiful. The most we want to see spot of movie Tom Rider even we never seen movie but we must come here to see the spot. hahaaha

Best temple out of 3 big ones!. Much better than the most famous Angkor Wat. Here you can feel the history oozing out of every picture frame! Less touristy and awe inspiring. Get there late afternoon to beat the crowds & please avoid the tourist pucture trap spots & venture to more secluded areas where you can immerse yourself in the beauty of nature vs man-made wonder! Just unforgettable! You dont need a guide. Just read the history of this temple before you visit it & then discover it on your own terms and in your own time. Guides are for brainless lazy tourists!

Amazing Temple. Well worth a visit but to obtain photo opportunities is near impossible. Restoration work is progressing slowly but the stone work , carving and intertwined tree roots provide the backdrop for a fascinating experience.
Nature taking over impressively!. Here you'll see the massive trees seeking their way to water, and weaving a root-web over the ancient temple. Of all the temples this was my favorite.

The most amazing temple in Siem Reap. The Ta Prohm temple is one of the most photographed locations in Cambodia as it is the site of the Tomb Raider movie, and the location where the trees overgrow the temple walls. First approaching the temple you would not know it was something special but on entering you see the famous big tree over the wall and great restoration painstakingly underway.The temple is huge and the carvings in stone and construction are an incredible feat given the age of the temple. Pictures cannot describe what you need to see.Since the temple gets crowded quickly, a visit when the temple opens in the morning will ensure a great visit.
Nature reclaims with beauty. This is a wonderful tranquil place where beautiful ancient architecture yields to the strength of nature. Breathtaking

Great temple and views. Can get busy. This was part of our day trip. You get some nice shots of the temples and the tree roots. Bear in mind that it can be very very busy, and the best shots (by the tree roots) can have queues of people wanting to get their own personal shots. You will just have to be a little patient to get yours. Unfortunately we went on the hottest day of the week and the temperature was over 100 degrees so make sure you have some water with you.

Nice temple in the jungle. The temple is very nice and famous after the movie tomb raider. It is not very different from the other temples except from the fact that gigantic trees are on the roof of some towers/edifices. There many trees in the site. According to our guide one must be careful and not steer from the paths because under the stones sometime sleep poisonous snakes (they are active in the night, but you never know).

Loved it - but get a guide it will be worth it.. Nuff said - get a guide - they know the "sweet-spots" and are worth it. If you don't' you may miss some of the things you would probably like to have seen.
One of the best temples. This was definitely one of the best temples to see as it was a bit different to the others due to the tree roots
Anither. Amazing visit at the Siem Reap temples...growth of trees is amazing to see. Beware groups lining up by the tree made famous by AJ.

Ta Prohm. Wonderful temples. Took for the little details as well as the big stuff. Trees are painstakingly preserved along with much restoration by "The Indians". It was fun to see the parts that I've seen in films like Laura Croft Tomb raider. I recommend a private guide. It is really in expensive and they add so much more depth to the experience. If you don't have a guide try to eves drop or watch where they direct their group to stand or look.

Truly stunning. We visited this the same day as Ankor Wat and wished we had seen it with fresh eyes - early or later in the day when there would be less tourists and with fresh eyes. It is amazing how the jungle has green through the temple and there is still a lot to see and walk through. It is very peaceful here and I can imagine it being very spiritual and eerie at dawn or dusk. a must

Trees and Temple. This amazing structure will make your jaw drop. There is this particular temple where there were holes on the wall and accdg to the guide, it used to be filled with Gems. So when the sunshines on them can you imagine how beautiful the room would be?? very nice work of art.
Very nice temple!. I would recommend to visit this temple after Angkor Wat and Bayon. you will see the temple and big tree are in one.

Amazing. This is where they shot Tomb Raider with Angelina Jolie and the whole area is a must see if you're going to Siem Reap. There's nothing like this anywhere else in the world. Our guide did an amazing job and was so proud of his country.

Visit to Ta Prohm. Initial feeling was that it is only ruins but the effort in restoration finally reflected at number of places. Trees have been supported on walls which destroyed it too. Needs still lot of restoration work to make it more memorable.

A must!. Beautiful architecture and ancient trees... It's out of this world. not a coincidence that it's used in so many high profile movies. Make sure you leave enough time to do it justice and also, do visit some of smaller lesser known temples that are after it (we found them less crowded and yet more interesting)

My favourite in Siem reap. This is truly like no other place in the world.
It's amazing
My favourite in Siem reap as it has the ancient buildings but also the tree roots growing over the structure
Nothing else like it

Nothing too exciting except for the tree roots!. Trip to Ta Phrom was shorter than expected as there isnt much to see other than how the trees have taken over the temple. If you want to take picture at the famous 'tomb rider' location, take the short route through the temple. We took the long route and had to turn back for a shot at this spot!
Indianna Jones comes to life.. Trees now intertwine the temple giving a surreal effect. Used in Indianna Jones movies, has an amazing atmosphere
See trhis one if nothing else. Very interesting tree root growtth through the buildings. Lots of Chiunese tourist though that make it very crowded.
Outstanding site.. One of my favorites, the huge trees slowly destroy the buildings while simultaneously holding them up. Go early to beat the crowds and the heat.

The temple of trees. After finishing up Angkor Wat and dinner we came here next. Our driver dropped us at the East gate and told us he would be waiting at the West gate.The exterior was not much to look at. Crumbling walls and entry ways. We walked a few minutes and made it to the entry to the main temple. Along the walk, we had trees on either side proving some shade to protect us from the sun. There was also a band that played music. This group was raising money for landmine victims and some of the musicians appeared to be those same victims.The interior is the main temple which is still in various states of repair and decay. What makes this temple so special is the manner in which the trees have grown into the structure. While this growth gives the temple it's unique atmosphere, it is also slowly destroying this temple. The moat that used to surround it was dried up.The images inside are unforgettable. I have not seen anything like this in all my travels around the world. The temple was less crowded but you would still need to queue to get the good photos. Once of the most unique photo opportunities was of the Buddha face peeking out from between tree roots.This temple provides much more shade opportunities than the others. Again, dress smart. Wear comfortable shoes. Some parts of this temple are in a state of disrepair and wearing shoes like heels of any kind would be a really bad idea.Ta Prohm is definitely one of the "must-see" temples that provides a unique experience worth the time spent.

Stunning. This is a bit of a no brainier but this is an absolutely stunning temple. Visually amazing. The drive up in the tuk tuk was fun, and walking up the road to the temple keeps you in suspense. Take plenty of water as it's very hot once you're out of the shade.
a piece of serenity. one of the most beautiful sites of angkor war..if u buy ticket for one day ,don't miss it...so mystical and full of peace.

Must see!. Incredible temple - our favourite of the trip. Take your time around the edges where you can get a good look of the trees engulfing the temple as the centre gets absolutely packed with people all wanting their photo with the 'famous' tree. Well worth a trip though, unlike anything I've ever seen.

Yes, that 'Raider Photo Op' is here. If you do not want to stand in line to get your snap of the Angelina Jolie site, there are MANY trees growing in + out of walls (or maybe holding them up). An amazing interplay of man + nature.

A dream come true. Cannot be missed. Yes, it is a lot of repetition, but here you see how the jungle encroached, a "purer" image of what these temples looked like before the 19th and 20th century intrusions.

Great. As Angkor Wat. Worth a visit. And highly recomended.
Minimum a full day (sunrise-sunset) for the whole temple area (all temples). Two days are better...

Tomb Raider Temple. Much of Ta Prohm looks like it was just recovered from the jungle, due to the trees that have claimed parts of the buildings. For this reason, it is probably high on the list of most people's favourite temples. Many will also remember it from the Tomb Raider movie.Unfortunately, its population means it is often crowded and there are long queues to get your photograph standing next to the tree-covered parts of the temple. It is still well worth a visit.And look out for the bas-relief carving of a dinosaur on one of the walls!
Tomb Raider revisited. The famous trees with the great roots are here. They have quiet a few. One of the most visited temples at the Angkor archaeological parks.

Stunning visit, very atmospheric. We made this the first visit of the day as our guide advised everyone else would go to AW first and the light was better for photos. You enter at the West gate and eventually leave via the east gate. Ta Prohm really gives you an idea of how the temples must have been when they were discovered. The visit is unspoiled, i.e. no facilities, or guides/ signs on site, you have to arrange this before you arrive. I would recommend you use a guide so that you don't miss some of the special carvings, the site is huge and it would be easy to miss something, or even get lost!One point worth knowing is that you can buy the entrance tickets the night before and the site opens at 7.30. despite asking for an early visit we got there at 8.30 when the ticketing area was very busy. We took the whole morning on Angkor Thom and Bayon, you will need to get out of the heat by 12. We saw AW in the late afternoon, and our guide was right the light was just right for photos.

One of the place to go in Siem Reap. Ta Prohm temple is where they shot a film Tomb rider. This place is amazing you can see the very big tree grow on top of the temple and sometime the blend with the temple.

Stunning. A lot smaller than Angkor Wat but never the less just as stunning, the giant trees have taken over in parts and the photo opportunities are fantastic. Gets crowded but it's not to be missed.

Really awesome temple, but it can get crowded.. Ta Prohm is one of, if not the coolest looking and most photogenic temple. That said, it gets busy-- really busy. So get here early or go on shoulder season... busy season mid day this is just a crowded mess.

Nature over mankind. This place depicts how nature can have its way and absorb any creation by mankind. The entire temple has been engulfed by tree growth over the years. Be careful while visiting and follow the suggested path only as temple walls and ceilings are still fragile and prone to collapsing. People with small kids should avoid. Suggested visit length : 2 hours

Siem Reap Photography tour visit. We were taken to Ta Prohm as part of our Siem Reap Photography tour with our guide Ota.. Fantastic,we arrived without the crowds and the photo opportunities were great

A stunning experience.!. With the exception of jungle and path clearance, the construction of steps and walkways , with not a huge amount of time given over to Health and Safety.(!!!), this Temple has been left much as it was when it was rediscovered back in the late 19th Century. It's the most bizarre experience, which if not for the crowds, would be downright spooky.!! Massive, and I mean massive, tree roots, make for the classic Tomb Raider scenario photo, which unfortunately is probably why a good percentage of tourists head here...Thanks Hollywood.! But for me, it was just a sensational experience to see a rambling, part-collapsed, temple complex, in the middle of jungle that over time has been completely engulfed by nature. NOT the kind of place to be abandoned, alone, at night, with all the jungle noises...but then again,,!!!Sensible, comfortable footwear ESSENTIAL for this one.!Enjoy the absolute surrealism of the place, and all it's crumbling, disorganised beauty...and chaos.!!!
Amazing. Speechless. This is truly stunning. You have to go to see how special this place is. It does get very crowded so patience is needed.

First time to Tomb Raiders significant place. This temple is also known as "Jungle Temple", a must to visit after Angkor Wat and Bayon temple. The specialty of this temple is a lot of huge trees which might aged more than 400years old are grown surrounded the temple. The exact spot of Lara Croft in Tomb Raider scene is the most famous spot for photography as there would be long line during peak season. According to our tour guide, this temple is built for the mother of King Jayavarman VII. Really feel like in the middle of jungle as surrounded by many huge trees.

Earie trees. The highlight of this temple are the huge trees that have cut through rocks to make for an eerie yet spectacular sight. Made famous by Angelina Jolie's move, The Tombraider, this place should definitely be on the sightseeing list in this area

Temple Ruins worth a visit. When we visit this temple, we are puzzled, whether the temple is holding the trees or other way round. It is very surprising to see how a good portion of temple is still intact due to gigantic trees growing around it. A large portion of temple is ruined and government is working on restoration. Well marked directions to go around safely. However one should be extra careful on a rainy day. This temple has been pictured in Hollywood movie Tomb Raider.

Tomb Raiders — Feeling . When you arrive you'll be enthralled by the recapture by nature of such mighty buildings but that's what happens when the gardeners taking years of holidays.Apart from the Tomb Raiders spot loads of other magical places.A guide will show you great places n be there to take your couples photos !
Trees make a difference!. Great place for photos of trees taking over buildings. Gives you an idea what Washington, D.C. Will look like in a few years.

Hallmark of Cambodian ruins. The Ta Prohm is a hallmark of the Cambodian ruins.One would be amazed to see the tree roots and how they have merged with the temple structure. Has gained popularity from the Tomb Raider movie. The Archaelogical Survey of India is working with the Government of Cambodia to restore this beauty of a place.

Mystical and magical. Ta Prohm is probably my favourite temple. It is hauntingly beautiful, sad to see the decay but it's beautiful at the same time. The nature is incredible with the massive trees and roots hanging in surreal places. Do t miss this Temple.

My favorite temple. Although Ta Phrom is not the biggest temple, it's definitely my most favorite. And the reason for this is not because it been made "more" famous by Angelina Joli from Tomb Raider but because one can actively see the restoration process in action. These are one of the few temples that will be mostly "left" as discovered and only a portion will be restored to give the tourist an idea what it looked like centuries ago. This is also one of the few temples where one can still climb or walk free off the beaten track. The roots of the trees that had taken over is truly amaizing.

Mind blowing Trees !!. Now this place is just amazing the trees are over 600 years old. Hard to get ya head around how these places were built so long ago with just the use of hand made tools and of course Elephants. Truely an amazing experience.

A Cambodian Oddity. This is a bit of a Ripley's Believe It or Not sort of attraction: Enormous trees growing on, through, and around the temple with great, knobby roots digging through the stone. How do they do that? Most visitors seemed to like it because it had been in the movies.
Tomb raider . The trees growing over, through and around the stone temples is just beautiful, it is a very photogenic temple and it enjoyable to walk around, you can hear the birds sing in the trees.
Amazing. To me this was more fascinating than Ankor Wat itself. To see how nature reclaim the buildings and surrounding areas is amazing.

IMHO - the Best !!!. Angkor Wat is the King but Ta Prohm is my absolute standout. It is crumbling and for the most part in ruins but this just adds to its romantic (??) appeal. Not all areas accessible like Angkor Wat -this just has the X factor !!! A bit of a walk from the very touristy entrance but very, very worthwhile !!
Amazing trees!. The temple is great but the trees are the highlight. Should definitely visit this site. A great example of the jungle reclaiming its land.

Angkor Wat. An amazing place but also very interesting to see what it was like before the renovations. It is probably best to visit here early or late in the day as the heat and humidity is intense during March.
Its a must. You and hundreds of tourist agrees. This is the best temples inside Angkor. Its destroyed and nature is taking place so its getting more beautiful.

Amazing. A visit to Ta Prohm is a must see. The temple is not as well preserved as some of the other temples. The root system of the trees is amazing and fascinating. You can see and hear the parrots in the trees. We arrived at 7.30 am, when it was a little cooler and not so crowded which I would recommend. So you can take photos with ease.

Amazing temple!. You have to go see this one. It's a little further away so there are less tourists. This ruin is untouched in comparison to the others. Large trees are growing up through and on its structures! Very cool, don't think twice, just go see it!

Highlight of my time in Siem Reap. This is a must see if you are in Siem Reap. While Angkor Wat is iconic in its own regard, you cannot miss seeing Ta Prohm. The ruins mixed with the gorgeous giant trees is truly remarkable. Simply stunning, it hardly felt real. Bring a camera for sure, and take your time. This is not a place to rush through. On your way out enjoy the beautiful music performed by the locals who have lost limbs to landmines. Then get in your transportation as quick as you can before the vendors at the gate overwhelm you.
Got to see this. It is in the 1 day tour - and well worth the visit to see how the place has been invaded by the flora and fauna and disrupted the buldings
Amazing out of the way spot. The temple ruins and nature melded into a fantastic symbiosis of art. It's important to show up early to avoid crowds and there are refreshments at the site.

Nature VS architecture = amazing. Truly amazing, thanks to how nature is overtaking the man-made structures. Absolutely something not to miss and one of the most unique things we've seen in SE Asia to date. Loved it!

Ta Prohm the tomb raider temple. What we enjoyed about this particular temple was seeing part that were covered by jungles and giant trees/roots. It's something you normally only see in photos/films, so we considered it a 'not to be missed'.

Ta Prohm. After visiting Angkor Wat, this is the next "must visit". Can get crowded in the afternoon, so get there as early as possible in the day. Take plenty of water and covering from the heat. Not to be missed.

Witness the power of Mother Nature!. Ta Prohm is a must see when in Seim Reap. The temple itself has been overtaken by Mother Nature’s strangler figs and trees and the beauty of this is breathtaking. Though much smaller than other temples such as Bayon and Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm was my favorite. A very cool and unique temple.
Fantastic. This is a really amazing place to visit, a combination of history and nature. This is the "Indiana Jones" one if that is what you are looking for.
Tree lover. Yes the temple was ancient and historical, but it was the trees taking back where they use to grow! Really amazing root system!

Humbling. Things are no longer like they used to be - absolutely awesome sight that is a must see sight.
However choose your timing well to maximise the experience - visit in December, dry season but not stupidly hot like it is right now.

More impressive than the movie!!. Unbelievable that this temple complex is still standing after all that nature has done to try and break it apart. The fig trees have been down huge, invasive roots over the walls and through the stone building blocks. And yet it still stands.This place is even more impressive than the photos in National Geographic and other magazines. And you can just picture "Tomb Raider" as you walk through.This is a MUST SEE.

A temple to enjoy in or after the wet season. Ta Prohm, better known as the jungle temple, is best seen during or after the wet season. Came to this conclusion after a recent visit as the lack of colour from moss and lichen that we saw on a September visit in the past detracted from this otherwise beautiful temple.

Tomb Raider Temple. It is very nice temple with amazing huge trees, This is the top three of nice temples in Siem Reap should be visited. You should turn around this site so you are able to site the all site...
Tomb Raider!!!. The tree's in this temple make this temple so amazing and unique... Seeing it in the flesh was an amazing sight to see.

A triumph of nature over empires. After savouring Angkor wats magnificent work of human hands, you will marvel at God's creation among the gigantic roots of trees that are 300-500 years old according to our tour guide. It made me reflect on my roots - my family, my God.. OU rtour guide shared that the trees grew beyond measure when the mother of the King left Ta Phrom temple. Nature took over.
Tomb Raider maxed out experience!. In my opinion the best temple in whole Angkor Wat, because of the nature, remaining building and the ambience, mixed all together!

Home of the tomb raider!. We came here particularly because tomb raider was filmed here (probably why many other tourists came here too) and it did not disappoint. Stunning tree roots around the temple. After seeing the other temples reconstructed over the years, this is a nice place to see how the temples would have looked when it was first rediscovered. Make sure you find pictures of the tomb raider scenes before hand so you know the best angle to take the pictures of the famous trees!

Tomb Raider. One of the places where 'Tomb Raider' was filmed. Without the film it is still a wonder of the world. A great place to wander around and take in the sights. Can get crowded and a long walk in. Entrance is included in the original ticket purchase.

Loved it. I really liked this temple also known as Indiana Jones Temple.
It is different from some of the other temples in terms of design.
The ruins are made complete with the trees thatin my mind are the real stars of the temple.
Definitely visit, as it is interesting in design
Early visit for less crowds. One of our fav temples with Beng Melea, by arriving early we avoided the large crowds, not much to add except it is a must see

"SPECTACULAR". one of the reasons we visited Ta Prohm was because Tomb Raider movie was filmed. Loved the roots growing over the buildings. Lot of construction work and because of that a little bit of magic was lost. But it is an experience not to miss
Fearytal Magic!. By far the most exotic and and magical place to wonder around, if only to try reliving this faraway past... only hic, the constant tourists selfying everywhere all the time!

Go early!!!. The temple opens at 7:30am and I would suggest that you get there for the opening. Most tour bus arrive around 8:30 it gives you one hour of quiet time to enjoy this beautiful peaceful scenery!
Loved it. Even if not a Tomb Raider fan I couldnt help but wonder at the majesty of this place and the integration with Mother Nature

Nice!. We visited around 3pm in the afternoon but it wasn't too hot. Probably because there are a lot of trees. The temples were take over by nature; hence, you see some ruins devoured by roots of the trees and it looks really nice and interesting. Just be careful because not all areas have wood platforms you can walk in.
Astounding!. This was the set for the movie Tom Raider. It's like being "Angelina Jolie" for one day. I was able to see the huge roots of the "Tom Raider trees" and it was such an awesome experience.

Jungle Temple. beautiful temple and one that noone should miss when visiting angkor. As with all the key temples, best done early in the morning to avoid the crowds that can bottle neck here. Recent restoration works are going well and the temple is looking great

Favorite Siem Reap Experience. We visited Ta Prohm in early morning before the crowds built up, and appreciated the ease with which we could walk around and enjoy this magical ruin. Take plenty of photos -- when you get back home you'll want to re-visit here over and over using your photos.
Magical. The complex defies description, with trees and tree roots which both invade but protect the stones of the complex. An unforgettable experience.

Very nice temple with a giant tree!. The trees growing out of the ruins are perhaps the most distinctive feature of Ta Prohm. I been in this temple very surprise when i saw this Giant tree like a giant smake.
Another great Temple. We visited early in the day. It was peaceful and quiet. Some great photo opportunities. Very atmospheric. Yet another one not to miss!!

Nice temple. There are better temple ruins.. It's beautiful just like other temple ruins in the area. But this one is ruined by the restoration. Too many decks and ramps in the way. Let face it most of us want to take photos and none of us want to see a wooden railing in the photo....just takes away from the beauty. This temple gets insanely busy because of the "Tomb Raider" effect. I saw a bus load of Korean Tourists arrive at 7am. It should take you about 2hrs to see this.

Beauty created from nature's destruction. Made famous by Hollywood but more importantly, created by the Khmers and given uniqueness by nature's determination to reclaim its ruins. The large spung trees growing over the decaying temple structures are beautiful and awe inspiring. Avoid the crowds but put this on your must see list. The wy the trees are covering it and pushing walls over, it won't be around for ever.

Interesting . Tomb raider was filmed here. Partly restored. Some climbing stairs and lots of walking. Recommend combining as a tour with other sites and early morning is a lot cooler as it can get hot! Interesting, probably recommend hiring a local guide through a tour company in Siem Reap or from your hotel.

My favorite temple.. It is the busiest temple I felt and you might get claustrophobia upon the entrance but I still preferred this of Angkor Wat (not much though). I think the best time to see this one, is early in the morning right when they open - so it wont as crowded. And make sure to know from which gate (east or west) you are entering - you dont want to walk twice to find your tuk tuk driver, trust me.

Mothernature. Ta Prom has been colonized by nature so you can see the strength of all the roots that have found a way between the walls! Very impressive!Please respect the Temples, too many people are bad behaving just for a picture. Don't touch, don't litter and don't climb.
Mind blowing. As I said in the Angkor Wat section, you can expect to find hundreds of tourist. But besides that, what we saw here we've never seen it before. It's mind blowing!

Prehistoric temple merged with nature. Remains of the temple still intact with grown trees.. The pathways are indicated but could hardly go to the centre of the temple where the SIVA lingga is located..Could not trace the location of the SIVA lingga.. Was a set back and disappointment for me.

This place will amaze you. Ta Prohm aka Tomb Raider temple is a Buddhist turned Hindu temple and truly is a gem in Siem Reap. Before it was turned into a temple, it is also an educational institute. This place turned famous after Lara Croft: Tomb Raider was shot here back in the early 2000s. Compared to Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm is smaller but tells a completely different story. So many events took place in this temple through out the course of history. To understand better, I suggest a guided tour. Also, please be sure to bring a camera as I personally feel that this place is definitely good for photos. However, be sure to be fit to go into this place as there are some parts narrow and stuffy. During our visit, we were told that one tourist fainted as the place was not ventilated.
Exellent. It is an magnificent adventure to go to Ta Prohm and experience ancient sites. We had a wonderful time and will hopefully come again.
Awesome!. You can make it in the same dayTake your time going around Read about itTake water it is very hot and humid in this month

Our favorite of the 3 temples we specifically chose to see. This is our favorite, choosing from this, Angkor Wat, and Bayon. Humble in size compared to the Angkor Wat, but not disappointing due to how unique it is, the Ta Prohm temple was one of the shoot locations for the Tomb Raider movie. Seeing massive trees growing over and enveloping parts of the temple were truly unique and overwhelming. A must visit!

Great adventure location. . This location will have you feeling like Indiana Jones as you are transported back into Raiders movies. Large trees with exposed roots spill over the temple and make for dramatic images. The site can be self guided or as part of a tour. It can get very crowded so images without tourists can be hard to get. Incredible workmanship for a time when machinery did not exist.

Our favourite of the temples. This was our favourite temple on our visit to Angkor. It has been left in the state it was discovered in and not restored like some of the other temples. Nature has taken over; there are great trees intertwined around, in and on the ruins, which is quite spectacular. Busy but well worth a visit.

amazing. Very hot, there are two entrances so make certain you organise with your driver where to be picked up. Can become very crowded at times (through narrow walkways) with groups going through stopping for photos. Try and get past them. One of the more popular and spectacular temples. A must see.

Just like a movie. Known as the tomb raider temple, Ta Prohm really looks out of this world.It is amazing to see how nature took over the structure in such a way that it looks part of it.It feels like it is alive.Loved this temple!!!For sure one my favorites in the all complex.

Great Temple. It's odd that the three great temples were built close to one another. Of course in the olden days people travelled by foot and it would have taken them days to travel from one place to the other. The more I looked at these temples, the more I was intrigued by the mystery of the place. The more one hungers for historical details and hoped that more information would unravel the VISION of the monks and rulers. Hope the government would start restoring the place for the sake of preserving it and continuing the legacy of their ancestors.

This Temple is very different - I urge you to see it.. This is a much smaller temple that Angkor Wat and far less preserved. Famous for being in several films, it is kept very much as it was found with trees growing over it and very little has been restored. I love this place and there are very interesting quirks of nature with the tree growing over the ruins. Great photo opportunities here and a fascinating temple to see. I think the right approach has been taken with this temple and to restore it would take a lot away I believe. Beware of Japanese and Chinese “selfie” photographers and posers. They hog the points of interest and their social protocols are less sensitive than the West so “push in”. That said, I highly recommend a visit here but you will need a guide to get the best out of this.
Amazing... Tree's through buildings. One of my faves, in the whole day. Awesome!! Nature and stone as one. Really old, and one of the more easier ones to walk around

Very atmospheric . The lovely Ta Prohm , looks like it is growing out of the forest. It has been left as it was originally found, with trees and creepers everywhere, they add to the mystery of the place . Don't miss it !

A Memorable Sight. It was our last day in Siem Reap, and we were feeling a bit “templed out”, but our tuk-tuk driver suggested that we ought to see the Ta Prohm temple. We were glad that we followed his advice, as we really enjoyed our visit.The thing that set this temple apart from others is that there are very large trees seemingly growing out of the stone walls and ruins. The roots seem to snake over the ruins before eventually disappearing into the ground. It somehow seemed to give the temple a completely different character to other temples we had visited.The locals sometimes refer to this temple as “Tree Temple”, or more often as “Tomb Raider Temple” as it was one of the settings for the Angelina Jolie film.We would certainly recommend others to visit Ta Prohm.
Beautiful temples. My favorite temples in the whole complex. Took about 45 minutes to see it all. Just beautiful - lots of photo opportunities..

A Reflection of Non-Performance in Life.. Amazing to see the facts that trees had taken over the deserted buildings, the scenario led me to a lesson: "In life, you pay a price for being stagnant and non progressive."

Channel your inner Lara Croft & Tomb Raider. Even more spectacular than in the Tomb Raider movie, this temple is covered in huge 700 year old trees that have grown on top of the temples, winding their roots around & into the buildings. Nature vs Architecture !
Science Fiction Location. Images that you will only see in science fiction movies. its very thought provoking to understand how the trees can grow such in huge size over centuries aroud this temple.

Can't miss it!. if you go to the Angkor complex and don't see this temple, you are missing out. It's different in that it's been taken over by nature and makes it so unique. We spent about 7 hours in the complex and concluded with this one. All the other temples start to look the same, but we are glad we saw this one last. It gets crowded here, so photos without people are hard to take. And it's also easy to get lost in this one. Our group split up while some us wanted a Lara Croft TombRaider video (we're such dorks), and even though we had a clear meeting place, it still took us 30 minutes to find each other.

Awesome Angkor Temple. Most famous for its strangler fig vines encompassing the ancient stone works, Ta Prohm is one of the more inspiring of the Angkor Temples. Well worth the time in exploration, though not for those with access or walking issues.
Unbelievable. To stand next to the giant weirdly shaped trees....you feel tiny. Great roots...used in many movies.

Best Temple Ever. This temple was not disappointing. It was so neat. I could have wandered around it for days and days. The trees were so neat. I couldn't take any pictures to really justify this place.

Mineral and vegetable. Although not the finest temple, this one attracts huge crowds for the giant trees forcing their way through and around the stonework. The links with movies like Tomb Raider make it a huge draw for the selfie takers. No peace to be had here during peak season!

Famous images. This is one of the temples that you have seen photographs of long before you get here. We liked it in the late afternoon light. It was not too terribly crowded, but for some reason it was a loud bunch with way to many selfie sticks, so it did not end up being one of our favorites. Absolutely worth it, but if you like the tumble down/big tree temples the Preah Khan, Ta Nei and Being Mealea should also be on your list, especially if you have the time.

Definitely my favourite temple!. The carvings and buildings are breathtaking. We went after the sunrise at Angkor Wat and so didn't have many other tourists around the place. The huge trees sprouting from walls and in rocks. Plenty of photo opportunities. Spetacular!

Magical Temple. This temple is very unique with its trees that grow over the temple's buildings. The forms are beautiful and if you are lucky to have few tourists it is magical. Take time to sit down in there.

Mystical feel. Along with Angkor Wat, and Bayon, Ta Prohm is one of the most popular to have a photo taken....there's a platform in front of this ....and often a queue of several people waiting also to take a photo standing in front, due to Angelina Jolie's 'Tomb Raider' film; as well as the sight of the tree roots devouring the temple structures. Incredible how the roots of the trees have invaded the stone buildings....to the extent, if the roots were to be removed/destroyed, the stone structures would apparently collapse. Definitely worth visiting!

No 1 Temple. our visit to Ta Prohm was one of the highlights of our visit to Siem Reap... one of the most extraordinary locations you will ever come across... with beautiful design and architecture overgrown by the local silk-cotton trees... this was best seen early morning when the sunlight highlights the various textures of building and nature together

Ancient building in forest . Very much enjoyed Ta Prohm as it is a large complex that nature has started to claim back. There are initiatives in place to restore it but it will be a long and difficult process. The surrounding forest is enjoyable to walk through albeit rather dusty which is true of all the attractions within the Angkor Wat area.

Reclaimed by nature!!!. This temple portrays the power of nature. Nature can take back whatever it wants. The entire complex has been invaded by massive trees. Roots of the trees have penetrated several feet thick stone walls as well.It is advisable to get to the temple in early hours(opens at 0730 hrs) to avoid the rush. Else you will find long queues for taking pictures.There is nothing much to describe in the temple. But the rampage of nature on this temple is treat to the eyes.Dress light. A hat and bottle of water is a must for the visit.
Amazing. Really memorable trip at sunset ... The tree roots just growing in and around the temple - Apparently it was lost for 100s of years and the trees grew from bird droppings !

Group Tour of the Temple of Doom . As part of our bike tour of Cambodia with World Expeditions, we biked from Angkor Thom to Ta Prom (aka the Temple of Doom) before we biked to Angkor Wat. This temple was unique in that it has significantly fewer stairs than the other two so if you have mobility issues or small children it is easier to deal with. Having a tour guide was very informative and entertaining as there were things we tried that we wouldn't have known about otherwise. For instance in one of the prayer rooms, if you leaned up against the wall and slapped your chest, the sound reverberated through the stone itself. Tres cool!

A temple overrun by nature. Definitely my favourite temple at Angkor Wat. The blend of nature and building is amazing. The trees have been growing on/through the temple for centuries and the mix of deterioration and growth is moving. It's like nature is taking back what was once hers. The carvings and buildings are breathtaking. We went early in the morning (after the sunrise at Angkor Wat) and so didn't have many other tourists around the place, which I think made it so much more serene and special. It's also where part of the Tomb Raider movie was filmed.

Check it out. Worth the trip if you are in the area. The site is not as well preserved as others, but still great to see. The huge trees sprouting from walls and in rocks is a cool site.Some shaded areas, so you can be out of the sun.
Amazing. Very busy site but well worth it, plenty of photo opportunities, morning visits are cooler, some drink stalls outside
The awesome Tree Temple !. Get there early before the rush (7.30 opening) or you will end up with queuing for photo opportunities with hordes of others....

Beautiful silver Giants. This area is so amazing ... Ta Prohm was a temple that was built by the King to commemorate his mother ... The trees are so tall & they have the most beautiful silver bark & the tree roots are amazing ...they go about 100 meters down under the ground to sustain their long life ... I can highly recommend a trip to this temple

Amazing . This is where tomb raider filmed several scenes. All though I have never seen this movie I can picture it and as soon as we stepped in it felt like we were in another world. I feel this is even better then Angkor watt. I could have spent even more time here but unfortunately we were part of a tour group and were rushed. It's hard to review such an amazing place. The pictures don't do it justice as these trees are massive and so old it's amazing to climb around the temple and touch the trees.

Good but very crowded. This temple is worth visiting but try to come first thing in the morning, make sure you're already there maybe few minutes before it opens. We had a hard time taking photos without the other tourists. Explore the inside of the temple first and take photos quickly, then explore outside later once you had good photos already. The place can get very crowded easily.
very beautifull jungle temple. go early in the morning to visit Ta Prohm. Then it's more calm tan the rest of the day. A must to explore this tample, so many beautifull places

Eerily beautiful. Ta Prohm is the temple that provided background for much of the film Tomb Raider. We managed to get in between crowds. It is one of the low built or "flat" temples rather than a pyramid. Fascinating to see how the trees grow around and through the ancient structures. Try to see it at off hours - the stillness and silence adds to the haunted feeling the place gives off.
Tomb Rider Tracking. I went here for following the Tomb Rider movie which Angelina Jolie who be an actress. Three were many giant roots which cover sculptures.
Ruins and temples. many birds ,parrots, nature, go early, stay late, hire a driver, wear loose comfy clothes and runners, take your own water etc,

In the footsteps of Lara Croft. Probably our favorite one, along with Ta Som which also has a nice mysterious touch. The third one this mysterious our be Being Mealea further away. Great temple that can be visited during the day as lots of shade.

Stunning. Definitely one of the most beautiful temples in Angkor, which makes it very crowded. If you want a little chance of actually enjoying the visit, go there very early in the morning (we did so and it wasn't too busy).
Many good photo opportunities, including the 'Tomb Raider' door (if you're into that kind of stuff)
Loved the creepy trees. Fascinating to see the tress growing everywhere, on top of rooves in walls, amazing! well worth the visit.

Spend a lot of time watching trees roots. Famous for being Tombs Raiders stage, I think the tree they show in the movie is the best one! And there is a line to take a picture over there. However, if u move a little you can find more interesting trees and places to discover. The aire is more fresh here so u can enjoy even at midday.

Beautiful - but crowded . We were looking forward to this amazing temple as one of our highest priorities on this trip, going there on our second day in Angkor Wat. Excited as we were, we took off to the temple, and surely, it is amazing! We even managed to get lost in the large area of just this one temple. Despite its overwhelming beauty, the quality of our experience was greatly lowered by the enormous ammount of tourists. They arrive in large groups and block the paths - part of the reason we got lost. If not for the crowds, the temple would have gotten five stars!

Not quite like the movie. The temple is in very poor condition with most of structure being piles of rubble, where trees have pulled down the temple as they fell or the tree has completely split the wall and it has fallen. If you go in February you are hard pressed to imagine lush jungle. It is a giant dust bowl with large stones - much like a quarry or abandoned open mine. There are about 4 trees with sections of temple attached where you can see how it used to look and a few Sections where you can go inside. See it if you want to have a photo where scenes of the Tomb Raider movie were filmed but if you are short of time there are other temples in better condition from the same era. Not many stairs in this one.

Amazing tour...amazing place. Loved the roots growing over the buildings...a trip back in time and well worth doing.. It is an experience one does not miss...I went by motor bike, walked over the bridge and into the temple alone...walking everywhere and seeing everything.It is so magnificent..
Amazing!. This was one of my favorite temples in the area! I absolutely loved the amazing big trees, an experience not to miss! :)

Kind of over rated . It might be the high temperatures or the fact that this temple was the last thing between us and our lunch break, we failed to spot what was so special about it - except that the Tomb Rider movie has been shot here. There is a "secret" rear way to the temple that helps you avoid the queues, so if you have a guide ask him to show you that one. If you are moving without a guide the "secret" entrance would be exactly at the opposite site of the main one - and you can recognize the path to it by the guy checking entry tickets on the road.

Very ancient and unique buidling. This building is very ancient and unique having large trees embedded as a part of the building. The crafted stones with meaningful characters are spiritual and sensational

One of the worth seeing place at Angkor. There are a lot of exotic old trees, old building and cool. Do not forget to bring mineral water while exploring angkor wat complex. At Ta Prohm, there are 2 gates (enter gate / exit gate) (if not mistake). If you go by tuk tuk, please ask your tuk tuk's driver where he can wait you / meet you (or contact him if network available) due to far distance from the first gate to another gate, otherwise you will get lost and tired while finding yr tuk tuk's driver.
Time and Nature. The will for these giant trees to survive with their roots growing around these spectacular structures is awe inspiring.
Tomb Raider Temple. I think this is where the film Indiana Jones and the Tomb Raider was made. The tree growing over and through the Temple was amazing, just like a giant snake taking over.

power of nature. This temple has retained some of the feel of how it was "taken over" by nature. But the fact that the edifices retain their stature despite roots of trees winding their way through cracks demonstrates the power of those who built this.

Unique sight. Tree roots crawl around ancient stone structures. Nothing like it! While you walk around seeing the artful fallen structured you will be amazed at how nature has integrated into the stones.

Lara Croft fan.. This one was a must on our itinerary so we could see the temple with the trees overgrown all around it. There are sections being restored but they have left some of the beautiful vines in place.

Tomb raider temple a spectacular sight. We visited this temple in the afternoon of day one of our two days of temple touring in Siem Reap. Although we were getting hot and tired by this stage, the temple was still a very worthwhile one to visit. The way that nature has taken over with the big trees growing up through the temples is spectacular. I was surprised that no enterprising Cambodians have set up a stall selling copies of the Tomb raider DVDs, but maybe I missed that bit!

Absolutely surreal!. You can not miss this place if you are visiting Cambodia and if you do please make a return trip for this is a place absolutely worth visiting! Giant trees with massive roots wind their way through the masonry and give an out of the world feeling. Indeed the landscape looks quite alien and you can even spot a dinosaur carved on one of the walls! Fun place for photography and observing how nature reclaims what man had taken away from it!
Indian Jones. Have been here a number of times and never get tired of seeing the huge trees grow thru the temples. So real I was looking for Angilie Jolie or Indian Jones to come by. I will be back.
Lots of Fun. This is truly an adventure and a must do if in Siem Reap. These trees eating away at the temple are amazing. Find the faces between the roots.

Very nice temple . A bit further, but still ok to cycle to and back even on the worst bikes for 1$. There's a Siem Reap river crossing at the middle between the Angkor Wat and the Prasat Kravan temple where one can have a refreshing swimm with the locals if you're not afraid to jump into the river with them ;) it's right next to the bridge, there is a big water wheel pump on your left hand side if you're going Angkor - > Prasat Kravan direction. It's really refreshing after a whole day cycling into this Cambodian dry season weather! I was there every time we were passing it.

A nice contrast to Angkor Wat. I guess the claim to fame for this temple is a short scene in the movie Tomb Raider, but even if you're not a fan of that film, this place is a must-see. The jungle has been taking the temple over for centuries, although work has been done to reduce the damage. Still, it's in a much rawer form than Angkors Wat and Thom, so it gives you something different to take in. It's smaller, too, so it takes less time to see it. There's more shade as well, so it's a good place to visit on a hot afternoon after a morning at Angkor Wat or Thom.

Amazing. Tips.... Go first thing in the morning and take a water bottle. Read about the temples before. Buy the Angkor guidebook for much less than your hotel when you buy the tickets.. This place is really fascinating with all those big trees taking over the ruins. If you are shopping for tshirts at the end make sure you get a larger size....they really shrink!
Great history. The local vendors can get a little out of hand, but non aggressive. Start your prices at about half of what they are asking.

Jungle temple. Probably our favourite temple. We loved all the large trees growing among the ruins and the hanging vines.A very popular temple as it appeared in the Tomb Raider films, and so can get very busy in places (usually the places Lara Croft had been).However, there are plenty of quiet parts of the temple away from the crowds and exploring all the narrow corridors and little courtyards is fun.
Must visit you have to touch the anglie jolie tree. Excellent you must go. Go in between lunch time less crowds. Take some water, but market very close by.
So different!. After sunrise at Angkor Wat we came here and again quiet!So different but worth seeing. The trees have grown into the walls And ruins.

History still alive. Our tour guide is a friend and he knew when to go and we were happy with his guidance in this because it quickly filled up. Pictures of the roots and temples is a cool experience. Life is hard to picture this far back!

Ta Prohm is one of the temples to visit. Ta Prohm is one of the interesting temples to visit during your visit to Angkor Wat. So do not just stick to the most famous two (Bayonne and Angkor Thom) but you'll find Ta Prohm like going back in time.

Trees are incredible!. Amazing how these trees have grown through the structure, worth visiting just to see that...a very peaceful place, best to pick and choose which temples you want to see as you could spend week seeing them all!!

Better then on every image. This is a must seen thing in cambodia, its absolutly amazing. Important, do it early in the morning, not that many tourists and not as hot as it could get.There are many "secret" place where you have an amazing view, there for its good to have a guide, not only for good shoots as well for the history behind it. I can highly recommend Zhen.
Imagine the trees. taking over the temples. Go in the afternoon , to avoid the masses.We really enjoyed the quietness in the p.m.

Incredibly Beautiful!. The most incredible part of Angkor and the most amazing temple we've ever seen.I can't begin to describe the beauty of Ta Prohm and won't even try because it is a must see in order to understand.The way it is mostly left as it was found adds to the beauty and we really hope they don't change that aspect.We only had a day pass and therefor left here while wanting to stay longer. We both could have spent a half to full day in and around Ta Prohm itself.It is a must while in Cambodia and we wouldn't go there again without visiting Ta Prohm. We definitely recommend it!

Ta Prohm. his is a gold crown that has just found recently in Ta Prohm temple during excavation for the reconstruction of the 'Dance Hall'. it is worth the Khmer treasure from the Angkor period. We used to hear by people us about the property made out of value metal such as gold silver copper bronze gems rubies etc., now it really comes true. ​This crown was found in March 2012.

Visit to Ta Prohm Feb 2016. Very interesting and eerie at the same time. It is easy to see why this is the perfect location for a movie. Love all the overgrown trees which certainly gave it mystery. I wish there was more educational information while touring the temple.

Famous ruins, but actually worth seeing. I like the ruined nature of this temple. Seems some renovation happened and possibly more planned, but they should be careful to keep the ruined feeling, making it different to the other temples and still worth seeing. Incredible to see the size of the trees that are wrapped around the walls etc.Our guide took us in through an almost unused side track, and was great to approach this way, down sandy path, through a ruined gateway and through the jungle.Glad we did this.
Worth the Visit. Aside from the cool ruins, the spectacular trees make this temple a must visit on your trip to Siem Reap.

Interesting . Interesting to see this old temple with giant tree roots growing almost everywhere. This is my 2nd visit and the last one was 3 years ago. There are a lot more tourist than before. I have not seen much of a difference in terms of its restoration. It's pretty much left the way it was(3yrs ago)but with a slightly more safety structures around to stabilised the rocks.

Lovely contrast to other temples but overcrowded. Lovely to see a temple overcome by nature but a bit of a shame that so many of the visitors appeared to only be interested due to its history as a film set. Impossible to move in some places. Even so - very glad we went

My Favourite Angkor Temple!. Ta Prahm is almost indescribable, my favourite of the three Angkor temples we visited recently (also Angkor Wat and Bayon). I found such beauty in its delapidation, the piles of "rubble" among the structures that have withstood the ravages of time. I loved the wonky stone wall surrounding this ancient city, the bulk of which is till miraculously standing after centuries, and the encroachment - or rather co-existence- of nature among the ancient architecture.Having said all that, I am glad there are internationally-funded restoration works afoot.Tip: It is a one way circuit once you're in and the tour groups speaking myriad languages descend, and the guides get a bit shirty if you try to go against the tide, so take your time or perhaps at a later, quieter time...and take reliable mobile phones if you don't want to lose anyone if you become separated like we did. So glad we took spare phones and invested in local SIM cards!

or - Tomb Raider Temple as it is also known. Ta Prohm may edge out Angkor Wat in many peoples books for the wow factor. Although smaller, it is perhaps more spectacular in the way the jungle has attempted to reclaim what man has built.Being able to get right in and among the ruins is a truly remarkable experience.DO NOT MISS

Better than the other temples. Beautiful with all the tress growing over the built structures.. lots of tourists though and no signs to tell you anything about the history of the place. Only the reconstructions that jave taken place in the late 2000s.

Cambodia is great. The temples were amazing and whether by car or tuk tuk, we did both, the people are friendly and accomodating. This temple was so beautiful with enormous trees growing to cover walls and fences. Make sure to bargain and have a laugh with the traders. Cambodians prefer to use American dollars so take lots of small notes.
Tomb raider. There is a certain mystery to this place as it is covered by giant tress, of course, if you watched Tomb Raider you would recognized this.
Best temple ever. After visiting Angkor Wat i thought that was great, but Ta Prohm beats it. The trees growing through and on top of ruins is amazing. I must have took 50 photo. It is a must visit

A must see in Siem Reap. Very amazing, it's really worth a visit, you'll be surprised. When visiting Siem Reap, only take two mornings to know all the temples, the city is very hot, and you'll enjoy more spliting your tour

Hollywood film set. Loved this temple the most of all the ones we saw in Siem Reap. The sheer beauty of the sight with the roots growing through the ruins, the parrots in the trees above all contrived to make it the most evocative temple in the complex.
unique place. Ta Prohm temple is very unique as the whole complex is full of parasitic trees -some of which are very old and grow on, in and around the temples and walls. must see..

Ruined ruins. Packed in amongst tour groups and their dozens of cameras this was such a disappointment.
There's a difference between protecting heritage and actively ruining it with reconstructive surgery. Billed as the most natural temple, it is far from this. As an archaeologist I was really disappointed to see such a lack of care for the ruins.

Awesome temple. This is really a awesome temple which is full of exotic but strange growing trees and beautiful broken ruins. Really amazing that the rustic greenish tone caused by the moss can spread out so evenly on all the walls, and blended well with the colour of the stone. A must go place if you visit Cambodia
Unique. This is the last temple we visited. It's unique compare to other temple and it's smaller. Make sure u take the long path when visiting this place. You can see a lot more.

Tombraider Temple. This temple has the added attraction of being featured in the Tomb Raider film. If it hadn't been I believe it would not get half the amount of attention it does. There are large trees growing out of it and it is being refurbished but there are much more interesting temples to visit in Angkor. And it is very very busy.....

Very cool to see nature take over temple ruins. It's very interesting to see trees growing on top of the ancient temple ruins. It gives the place an eerie, but magical feel. Additionally, check out the chambers where beating your chest causes a resounding echo (and only beating your chest; no other sound, curiously, causes an echo). It's quite something.

Interesting combo of nature and manmade. Relatively small temple, and yes there are trees growing through the stones. Lovely (easy) walk to the temple, and the trees are marked with signs, as in a botanical garden. For those tired of climbing, this temple is a bit of a break.

Great, but not as great as other temples. I enjoyed exploring this temple, although I didn't enjoy the thousands of other people who were there as well. It was impossible to get a single shot of anything without someone standing in the way.TIP - Go in the morning as everyone is at Angkor Wat for sunrise, you'll avoid the crowds this way.
Beautiful but crowded. The beautiful trees growing out of ruins is worth the visit if you can avoid the hordes of tourists, perhaps at after noon when everyone leaves to escape the heat.

Tomb Raider temple is great!. This temple is swallowed up by sprung trees and is fascinating. It looks very much like it does in the movie. There are countless great picture opportunities. Try to go to this one in the early morning and let everyone else go to Angkor Wat first. A guide is very helpful.

Channeled my inner Lara Croft. This is my favourite temple site....used for the "Tomb Raider" film. Nature is slowly taking back the land so you will see stunning tree roots climbing over and through the temple buildings.I will return to see this again, a definate must see

Nature at its best. Unbelievable 400+ year old trees taking over what humans have built, this temple is proof that nature wins! Try and go early hours so you dont end up with loads of pictures of other tourists hahah!

Beautiful. Each temple in Angkor and beyond is unique in some way! All are grand and hold a strong energy of peace. Considering their age and exposure, their preservation varies, but is miraculous. The trees which have become part of the structure are fascinating!

Tomb raider/ Ta Prohm - when big trees and temple fused together. The star of this temple is the overgrown big trees on the roof or wall of the temple and the crushed walls. This place reminds me much of the yemple run game. You will see interesting tree growths which resembles legs and human bodies.

Tomb raider. One of the must visit temples in Angkor. This temple is again different among the others. A lot of nature, it's just amazing how the trees are grow on top of those stones. Crowded place but it's worth it.
