Ta Prohm is another amazing temple. Ta Prohm is another amazing temple especially with the massive trees breaking through the walls and slowly taking over.
Another Angkor Watt attraction.. Definitely worth seeing, splendid ruins, occasional monkeys and tropical birds, a feeling of timelessness.

Tomb Raider. One of the many attractions available while visiting Siem Reap. This temple is best known from the movie Tomb Raider. It is not essential you have a guide as there are many locals inside who will guide you around and give you the historical facts. They will also show you where to look for the Buddha face encased by the tree roots. This temple has lots of areas that are wholly held together by the giant roots of the trees. This temple I found was also the busiest after Angkor Wat, as we had arrived around mid day on a four site tour, I would not recommend visiting much later. A lot of great photo shots here.
If you need a meditation . This is the place to stay. Even the tourists cannot spoil it. You can always find a corner just to sit and feel the greatness of nature...

We went twice, plenty of giant trees growing around and crushing the temple walls . You'll find plenty of amazing sights of trees seemingly crushing the temple walls. Also look out for the tiny face smiling between tree roots.

Nature is the star of this temple. Ta Prohm is probably better known as the Tomb Raider temple due to the movie being shot there. It's not hard to see why they chose to shoot there as trees are growing up through the stone of the temple, giving it a look that eventually it will be swallowed back up by nature.Our guide took us in through a little known or used back entrance which allowed us a more intimate moment with the temple before we joined up with the crowds inside. And it is crowded so be prepared.

Tomb raider Temple magic. great place to see nature has run riot here with tree roots embracing crumbling towers and walls, ancient trees towering overhead create dappled shadows gives this place a magical feel, we loved walking around had a fantastic day
Next Best Thing to Angkor. Probably the second best temple in the complex - you can almost see Harrison Ford running through the ruins!

Fab. Another amazing temple which was a lot quieter than Angkor Wot or Thom and it is where Tomb Raider was filmed. Lots of interesting areas to explore and wander around. Lots of sadly collapsed areas that are too far gone and costly to rebuild. Photo opportunities by the door way where Lara Croft entered and exited. Loads of trees growing in the stone work

Proof of the force of nature. Actually nothing more to add to all the others. "The Tomb Raider Temple" is also one of the must-visit temples in this huge area. If you're planning to see temples the whole day or three days you might just remembre few of them and this is one of those. See it and feel it

A perfect mix of art and nature. Known as the Tomb Raider temple, as the movie featured this temple, it's a clear favourite for many people due to the way that nature has embraced this temple. Gorgeous, enormous trees appear to be hugging the temple and the effect is artistic and beautiful. Of the temples in this area, this one was my favourite.

Stunning temple. Also known as the tomb raider temple apparently. There are many interesting aspects to this space. Initially when you walk toward the temple to,the right is a building called a library but our guide informed us it would have housed a significant statue originally, behind that would have been a bathing pool. To the left are stones which are ordered and hopefully will be used to be put back. In front of the temple is a stone floor which would have been a dance floor and would have had a roof. The engraved imagery on the walls and carvings have interesting tales to tell. The trees that have sprouted out of the building and downward are of course fascinating. If you look closely you can see tiny plants starting the same process. It is a must when doing the temple tours to have a guide on at least one of the days you get a lot more out of the experience.

Tomb Raider. This temple is made special by the trees that insist on dragging it back into the jungle. The authorities have some hard choices here...the trees or the temple, as the trees will ultimately win this fight with their roots taking a good grip.
Unusual temple covered by tree roots. A fascinating temple to visit after watching the sun rise at Angkor Wat. This temple is famous for its tree roots which have enveloped the buildings.

A true jewel. Ta Prohm is one of the main temples in Angkor and for me the most beautiful. The image of the nature transforming and sometimes destroying the buildings is just breathtaking. Really worth visiting once in a lifetime.
Magical Ta Prohm. MUST visit...while famous as "The Tomb Raider" location, its a sight that evokes immediate awe & wonder on how nature can take over a monument neglected for a few hundred years

Tomb Raider country. Lara Croft visited Ta Promh in Tomb Raider. Massive trees snake through the walls and their power has destroyed parts of this temple dedicated to Prajabaramita (the King Mother). But the trees add to the mystique of the place and lots of good opportunities for photography.

The temple is all in ruins!. Full of ruins and lot of restoration work is going on. If you really cant walk, avoid this. But if you can - please see it along with Ang Kor Wat and Bayon temples. This temple has many banyan trees and the roots are all over the temple. The place where Tomb Raider was shot!

Awesome you won't believe what your seeing. The temple has trees growing out of the walls all over the place at some parts its scary to think how strong the roots are as those tree are big and tall , not to be missed . Take your camera, comfortable shoes as walking on uneven ground and climbing steps is a must then snap away , this was the highlight of our trip to Angkor.

Was really looking forward to this.... In a way it's a shame how famous Ta Prohm is, as the sheer amount of people somewhat spoils it. It was really difficult to walk around some parts when we visited, as we were held up by tour groups. I would love to go back but perhaps in late afternoon when less people are around.

Mesmerising. With roots covering the entire temple complex, it is a very interesting sight. The entire complex (almost) had collapsed due to the roots and now the archeological surgery of India is helping in restoring the entire ta prom site. It's quite a good effort dinner so far and is definitely worth a visit. U ll also see the spot where the tomb raiders was shot and all the movie buffs can take pictures there. Note: most temples do not allow sleeveless tops and shorts for women so make sure u are fully covered! ;)

Tomb raider temple. Each temple is very different this one has left growing all over it. Same trees and root systems have exist with this famous temple. The map and the front entrance was hard to work out. Guide could not assist as English was not good.

Amazing temple . A smaller but very well reconstructed temple where the restoration group has tried to balance both the restoration of the temple with the needs of the large trees that have overgrown this temple. The juxtaposition of man and nature is highlighted in the way nature tried to reclaim what was hers.....This along with Angkor Wat are probably the two busiest temples however if you take your time you will be able to find some great picture perfect spots that aren't over run with tourists....There is so much more to this temple than Lara Croft tomb raider!

Large trees growing through the buildings.. The whole aspect is over whelming as there are several large trees growing through this very old temple. Walking around it can be a bit of a challenge if you are not very steady on your feet!

Oscar for impresion. We have visited Ta Prohm between 8.30-09.30 and it was not the best time because we got there in the same time with at least 200 other tourists. So we walked faster to get in front of them but seeing Ta Prohm on hurry is not what we wanted. It is one of the best temples in Angkor Wat area and it worths spending more time here. The trees embracing the walls of the temples are simply stunning.

Was so looking forward to seeing this temple 2016. Siem Reap feel it is a very calm and friendly place but do not let your guard down have had amazing time here for the last week but was (bag) Ipad )pickpocket at Ta Prohm Temple while in crowded area to enter the temple and while checking up on police report talked to another tourist and same phone at Angkor Wat taken so be aware . With that said amazing place the temples are just awesome and the workmanship is incredible love the place .

The star attraction..... Ta prohm is one of the most popular temple of the Angkor.
The movie "Tomb rider" make this more famous then other temple. U can find Large trees tangled with the temple in many places.
Also very photogenic.

In the top 3 temples. If you only have 1 day in Siem Reap, I would make this temple a must see. This is the temple made famous in the movie "Tomb Raider". It is in the process of being restored so you can see what the jungle has done to the temples that were lost for so many years.

Due to the trees it looks creepy. Of course despite all the history let's be honest ... Lara Croft is the reason alot of people will be going there! There's only a few places where the roots grow over the bricks but the effects are pretty scary.
However if you are into architecture some parts of the building, especially a long corridor is truly amazing.

Mightily Impressive. The temple is amazing. The way nature has reclaimed this one has left some breath-taking scenery. Its super crowded and widely known that the Tomb Raider crew filmed here so there is never a quiet time to visit. But saying that if you venture out of the beaten track a bit you can quite easily find your own part of Ta Prohm to explore on your own

Tomb Raider visit. The place where they shoot the movie Tomb Raider. Such a beautiful temple. The tree where Angie filmed was great, big, huge and unbelievable. The people were friendly but it is quite far from Angkor wat

Trees have overtaken several of the temple structures. I would image much of the area looked like this prior to people clearing the trees. This was one of the last temples I saw for the day and was fairly crowded, but worth a visit. I would call it one of the top 3 that I saw. There is the signature Laura Croft "Tomb Raider" shot and tree as well as several other amazing ones. Unfortunately a couple large tour groups where going through while i was there so it always makes for a bit of a different experience but was still good. I started on one side and made my way to the other to meet my driver, it gets a little confusing in the middle, trying to find your way around and out but you eventually run out of options and make your way through.
This is the Tomb Raider Temple. This temple is one of the must see attractions of Siem Reap. It has trees that seem to be engulfing the temple itself. That was an amazing natural wonder

Love to see what Nature Can Do. This is an amazing place in that it was uncovered from underneath the overgrowth and graphically shows both how humans can construct extraordinary edifices and nature, in the form of giant trees and roots can take it down.Looking at the enormous roots and unreal results of a huge tree overtaking a building is simply amazing.
Tomb Raider. Yes the some of the fillm was shot here. Possibly the most fascinating of the temples we visited in seeing how nature will try to recover the land from man.
My Favorite Temple in Siem Reap. Honestly, my favorite temple - it just feels very run down and true to its spirit, no wonder they Tomb Raider over there. Great experience.

Ancient temple reclaimed by nature. One of the more interesting Wats of Siem Reap. Many are very similar but this one is particularly stunning because of how the trees have literally grown through the temple. It makes for gorgeous photos and the impression of stepping into an action adventure archaeology movie.

Very unique temple among the 100 or so temples in the Angkor area. Easily my favor temple that we visited as not only is it an incredible temple but to add the unique way that nature is reclaiming it is incredible. This should be at the top of anyone's list when they visit Siem Reap and make sure you spend some time exploring all the areas as there are some hidden areas that we found completely empty.Words cannot accurately describe this amazing place, just go and see it.

'Indiana Jones' temple. We did visit the ruins, captured by the jungle. This place is very chaotic indeed and hard to get the real impression of the original idea building the temple/mausoleum/royal building for the mother of the king. But it is a sight with a sort of 'touch of destiny' , very hot too and not a breeze. You have to walk 10 minutes on a dusty forrest pathway. Not suitable for children, but noticed some trying to do it anyway. Remember some water if you stay some time there.
Magnificient. Not to be missed. Very much in same state as found.Easy access throughout.Late in the day is best to avoid the usual large crowds.

Left with trees uncleared as it was found. My personal favourite Angkor complex temple. This is the one where part of the first Tombraider film with Angelina Jolie was filmed. Make sure you have lots of spare camera batteries and digital photo cards!

Our favourite temple. We had 3 days in Siem Reap and Ta Prohm exceeded our expectations. It was Tomb Raider and Raiders of the Lost Arc all rolled into one. Beautiful buildings with gravity defying trees growing right through the middle of them.

GOT "COVERED" with "ROOTS" of TOURISTS!. As a SOLO traveler, I felt being "covered" by "roots" of tourists, all angling for best photo shoots at this temple. I just practiced "Patience", waited until the group moved on before making my visit and taking pictures. Key feature of this temple are the big roots of the trees invading the various sections of the temples. Happy visit!
One of the best temples at Angkor. Its an amazing experience to see how the jungle took over the temples. Very atmospheric. Wish it were not a one-way route through the complex, though.

What nature can do to the historical temples to create something magical and surreal.. Ta Prohm temple is not like any other temple. Beside being made famous by Angelina Jolie in the movie tomb raider. The fact is seeing in real life at how the trees had captured the temple with their roots is a very magical and surreal experience.

What trees!!!. Its a MUST MUST visit! The trees are something else. You are left wondering how did these old trees gobble up the temple structures. You have to see it to believe it. We got some lovely shots here - thanks to our guide.

Beautiful mostly unrestored temple and made famous by "Tomb Raider". This temple was built in the Bayon style in the late 12th and early 13th centuries What I love about Ta Prohm is that it has been left in much the same condition in which it was found with a combination of trees growing out of the ruins and the jungle. The trees growing out of the ruins are perhaps the most distinctive feature of Ta Prohm. These start with just a seed dropped on the roof by say a bird for the tree to grow.UNESCO listed Ta Prohm on the World Heritage List in 1992.The temple of Ta Prohm was made famous and used as a location in the film Tomb Raider.One that must be included in your temple tours.

AMAZING. I should have been tired when we got to Ta Prohm and what the locals call the Tomb Raider Temple but man. The ruins and the trees growing out of, within the, on the temples and soaring their branches up to the sky is. just. so. amazing. Yes, it's just a tree growing from a crumbling temple except that I was standing under blue Cambodia sky and the temple is hundreds of years old and you can feel the history of the place.

Experience Hampered by 2 Busloads of Tourist. I was literally caught in a people traffic jam at this temple. It was hard to move around or get any good pictures. This is not an authentic ancient artifact, i was recently rebuilt.
A paradise for photogarpher. So nice place to photograph. I saw wonderful places with my photography tour and I am sure I have seen a part of it. ready to come back in a few months/years...

Rise of the Tomb Raider. Photos that you see on the internet can never do justice to the awe you feel standing beneath the trees that are literally overgrowing the Ta Prohm temples. We arrived in time before busloads of tourists so took some epic photos of this site. Highly recommended.

Magic. No wonder they filmed Tomb Raider here. It is not real. An amazing mix of architecture, nature and history. You have to see the impact of the trees on the temple to believe it. Best part or our trip to Siem Reap.

Excellent temple. This was one of our favourite temples. With its overgrown trees and spacious grounds, it really captures the imagination and you always feet like you have enough room to hourself. Most definitely a must-visit temple!

Review of Ta Prohm Temple. This is a large temple partly taken over by very large trees damaging some portions of the temple. The Dance Hall has been restored by the Indian Archeological Society and more work is under way. The new stones fitted in place of the damaged pieces could be clearly seen. This temple is located roughly in the center of Angkor Thom.

Very touristy, but it is a must see!. The so-called "Tomb Raider" temple, because it was featured in the movie before.The temple is gorgeous, and the tree growth that are going through the stones looks quite mystical in a sense.There are two entrances. One on the south (which will enter from the east of the temple if I recall), and one on the west. There is a path where people are urged to follow. Otherwise, you may be prompted by the official to double-back through the same path (The path is Counter-Clockwise)

Ambrosial air. I felt the energy radiationg from old temple and tree. I think this is the best place in Angkor Wat. I've never been to this kind of ambrosial place.But it is little bit crowded in some points.
Atmospheric, just too many people. Great little temple where nature has taken a bit of a hold. The only problem is that everyone knows it and the crowds flock here.
Breathtaking. I've always seen pictures of this incredible temple and now I can check it off my bucket list! Absolutely amazing!!!

Most interesting of the temples. I would highly recommend this temple for a walk around as it is truly amazing in many ways. The ruins themselves are so interesting and not moved or disturbed as many are. The huge trees have overtaken a lot of the buildings and seeing the power of the trees and roots mixed in with the buildings and ruins is definitely worth a trip to see. Movies have been filmed here and I can see why - amazing place.

Great experience. All the photos do not lie, this is an amazing place to visit. Blue skies mean one thing, high temperatures, but as the Temple is a long walk down a dusty track you do get shelter, but it is a long dusty track, having run the gauntlet of the children and mothers attempting to part you from your US$. We had visited quite a number of temples, and Ta Prohm was at the end of a day which had started at 04.45, so we weary, hot and tired, but the views even among the hoards of other visitors, was really worthwhile, I loved it.
Overwhelming trees. It is worth going to this temple, just to see how nature has tried to reclaim the land, and to realise how much jungle has been removed to allow us to visit.

The great wisdom of ancient Cambodians. My inspiration of visiting this place was the "Tomb Raider" film starring Angelina Jolie. It is very sacred, serene and hidden in the forest. The intelligence of the ancient Cambodian people was reflected in the details of the construction. The Banyan trees here are the biggest ones that I have ever seen. The attraction I like most is a chamber that can produce resonance inside when I beat my heart with my fist.

Incredible. Definitely stop here, the trees among the ruins are unforgettable. Remember unlike most other spots with this temple you go in the front and leave in the back, don't come back out in the front. Tuk tuk drivers drive around and meet you on the other end.

Great to see temple in partially restored state. We enjoyed seeing the only partially restored temple. It gave a good idea of what restoration had accomplished in other temples. Well worth a visit, even if not as monumental as Ankor Wat.
Trees. This was my favourite temple, I just loved the wonderful old trees growing within the temple. We managed to get there as it opened at 7:30am which was before it got too busy.
The best of all the Sites. This Wat is the best from a historical point of view it displays the impact of nature over time and the efforts to preserve history
fast ride. nice view of trees that destroyed buildings by theirs roots, very hot and hard to explore, and very big and tasty coco r sold nearby entrance

Not as good as before. Rating it average as the place has lost its atmosphere since last time I was here 10 years ago. They have cleared a lot of the trees and put pathways, losing the charm what made this place special and different. it still has main symbolic trees growing in the temple.
The best of all... Amazing! Must be seen to be believed! Real tomb raider stuff. Highly recommended for a few hours ****

oh what a place!. Seeing Angkor Wat and Angor Thom was fantastic but this place blew me away. The strange way the trees grow out of the walls and winding the way through the ruins - even came across a bride and groom having a photo shoot. The sunset was amaizing as we came out.

Haunting and Beautiful. This temple nearly disappeared into the jungle. It's overgrown, exotic, haunting. We had already visited Angkor Wat and Bayon, and I wasn't expecting to be so awed by this one - but I was!

Temple of Doom. As the restoration work of the Ta Prohm Temple is just on its way, funded by the governments of India and Cambodia, the temple can still be seen as it was after centuries of neglect. Shrubs and even large trees have found their place in between the stone walls and building of the temple. This makes a visit to the Ta Prohm very interesting and result in many impressions and atmosphere pictures. It was told that in the Ta Prohm Temple scenes were shot of the movie "Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom". In view of the observations you can make in this temple and the atmosphere, this might just be true. See my pictures. Ta Prohm temple must be on your short list of the Siem Reap attractions. A five point review.
Different temple. Worth doing the three in one day. Use a guide to maximise effort, avoid crowds & get info. Quite different to Angkor Wat - this has smiling faces

Jungle power is awesome. The destruction of the buildings by the jungle re-taking possession of the site is a display of the energy of the trees and their gigantic roots. The hundreds of years that passed that allowed this to happen is living history. A definite must-see!
Spung infestation. This temple will show you really what had happened to most of Cambodia due to the quick growing huge SPUNG tree

Wait to take the 'perfect' photo, well worth it!. I was in 'aww'...it was so interesting to see Ta Prohm in real. Before the trip, I knew about this place, but when seeing it in person, you easily get mesmerize. Just be patient for your turn to take the 'perfect' photo, well worth it!

Impressive. It's not that big as the Angkor Wat, but in my opinion it's more beautiful. Arrived there in the morning so the place was not very crowded. It's in the forest so there is lot of shade to cover from the burning sun. It takes about two hours to visit, and it's simply beathtaking. The trees grew inside the temple in a controlled manner, and it seems like the jungle wants to get in more and more, you can't really tell if the tree roots are holding the temple walls in their place or viceversa.Simply amazing!! Best place I have ever visited!

Simply stunning!!. This temple is truly stunning. When walking to it through the east gate it is like walking into the jungle. We were here early in the morning and the birds were in full song as well as all the other animal noises. The atmosphere in my opinion is better than Angkor Wat. Seeing the trees growing out of the temple is amazing.

Old and nice temples. The best part of all the temples in Angkor Wat is this one Ta Prohm temples Is better to go in the afternoon because in the morning is to crowed.You need to walk more than in other temples, but it's still awesome

Most astonishing temple of the area. This was my favorite temple. The way it merged with nature over time looks amazing. It is very huge and it'll take you a while to see all its parts. Furthermore you can challenge your friends for a beer: who can find the description that looks like a Stegosaurus first? (Google it first to know how it looka like)So this temple is absolutely 'must see'. Have fun there. Regards.

Another tempo to explore. We trekked across the site from one side to the other. There was entertainment along the way which transcended to another time and culture. The ruins were interesting as the vegetation takes root. It's a dusty large site. Bring water and a hat. It didn't take long to get my fill here. The mokar driver was waiting on the far side.

It's all about the trees!. Ta prohm is refreshingly different to the other temples. This one is cool and shady, great to visit in the heat of the middle of the day. The trees, although destroying the temple, are now a spectacular part of its structure. A wonderful look at natures awesome force. Very serene and relaxing.The tomb raider tree/doorway is a bit of fun too

Incredible site in the middle of the jungle. Must see when in Cambodia. Defies description. Incredible architecture and an amazing history.Must do'stake a guide - makes a huge differencewear sensible walking shoesTake a camera!

Ta Prohm (Tomb Raider) Temple Siam Reap. Spending a day wandering the temples of Bayon and Angkor Wat wouldn't be complete without visiting the Ta Prohm temple made famous in the Tomb Raider film with Angelina Jolie.Its amazing structure has been enveloped by the surrounding forest where by it and nature co-exist to produce this amazing place. Giant roots emerge from small cracks and spread high into the leafy canopy above.Its a magical out of this world place to be and a photographers dream.A must see.

Amazing "Jungle Temple". A few sites around Siem Reap are loosely referred to as the "jungle temple", but this one really lives up to the name. There are numerous places where amazingly determined trees have taken root in and around the ruins. Being one of the more famous temples it gets very crowded, so arrive early if possible. Firsthand tip: if you walk a bit north of the temple (there are trails) you can find an original gate with faces similar to Bayon temple; I've attached a photo. It's very cool and chances are you'll be the only one there!

Nature Meets Man. Famous for its role in Tomb Raider, this temple is the ultimate cross between man's innovative creations and nature's unforgiving capacity to grow and envelope anything it wants. The imagination is on overdrive when visiting Ta Prohm. Highlight of the Angkor visit

Very dated and run down but should visit. I was extremely happy to see my country's National Flag (The Indian Tricolour) and the board saying that this site was being renovated by the Archaeological Survey of India. This made the visit even more interesting. The site of the huge tree roots having engulfed an entire building was just so amazing- showing that no matter what a man does, nature is always all powerful. Currently under repair, lot of sections are inaccessible but still a good visit
Dinosaur. Went to see the dinosaur etching and I was disappointed because the rumor was that the carving was done by a film crew but overall it is a must see temple

The jungle take th back. Excellent temple complex with vast jungle growth still attached and not removed. Go first thing in the morning to have temple to yourself without people in your photos and the ruins to yourself before the throngs arrive.

Ta Prohm. Definitely not to be missed as part of your temple tour around the Angkor complex. This is an imposing temple left in its natural state with jungle overgrowths. Of course this is probably the most famous of the series of temple having been captured in the famous Lara Croft Tomb Raiders movie. Can't beat the choice of movie location for this movie . It certainly leaves a sense of awe and amazement of these huge trees and vines that have rooted itself onto the temple ruins. While there has been extensive restoration at this site, the jungle overgrowth have been tamed somewhat but the trees affixed to the ruins remained since this complex was rediscovered. The jungle overgrowth is a distinct feature of Ta Prom and adds an air of forbiddance as you wander through the complex. Many corridors have collapsed but it is still a beautiful temple to explore.

Straight out of Tomb Raider. This temple is very impressive and the way the trees have claimed it just make it all the more alluring. It's well worth a visit, really spend some time here if you can - and don't forget the all important photo with the Tomb Raider tree!

Amazing merging of jungle and ancient temple. IMHO, this is one of the most amazing and and photogenic temple in Siem Reap. This is due mostly to the fact that the jungle has been allowed to flourish, in a controlled manner, in the temple complex. The results are such that the root systems of the mature strangler fig and the silk-cotton trees become parts of the stonework. Sometimes it's difficult to see if the roots are holding up the temples or the other way around! I was impressed in Ayutthaya, Thailand when I first saw the roots of a tree completely, over the centuries, engulfed the fallen head of a Buddha. That pales in comparison with what you'll see at Ta Phrom, both in scale and in complexity! For being featured in the Tomb Raiders, it's quite accessible and relatively free from crowds! I suppose that most tourists have only so much energy and the expend it at the "major site" of Angkor Wat so that by the time they get to Ta Phrom, they're exhausted and don't spend as much time exploring this beautiful place. However, to make sure you don't have to share the temple with too many people, you should come at opening hours or the hours before closing. Also, don't skip it just because it's raining - that's when the crowd is thinner and the photo ops are even better! Your multi-day ticket is good jere!

great temple!!. no need for too much words. if you are visiting angkor you must see ta phrom. but most of the tours start be here at noon and end the day with angkor before sunset photo madness.as a result bayon and other temples in small tour are crowded in the morning and noon.a small tip; if you spare more than one day (you must) angkor area; bayon, ta phrom etc will be less busy after 15:00 pm.
Wonderful!. One of the best parts of Angkor Wat. beautiful connections of nature and architecture with trees growing into ruins.

cool place.. be aware of workers there. very cool place. I was a single traveler. A park police office started talking to me and showed me places to take pictures and took pictures for me. But dumb me.... he wanted a tip when done. I offered a few dollars, but he said that was not enough. Wanted $20 I said I did not have it with me. I said I would come back the next day so I could get out of there. I should have known.. so beware when you think someone is just being nice.

Simply stunning. I visited Ta Prohm at the end of my last day touring Angkor. I don't think I could have timed it better. Right at sunset the temple started emptying out and my tour mate and I got tons of great pictures of this temple at sunset with no one else around. Absolutely breathtaking shots of the trees growing through these ancient structures with the glow of the sun's last light painting the scene.

Something from another world. The trees and the temples here are truly something special! Be sure the arrive early, as tour groups take up most of the space at this temple. I would suggest seeing Ta Prohm first over Angkor Wat, as this temple has so much to see.

Huge trees growing on a stunning temple complex . At Ta Prohm you will see huge trees growing on a stunning temple complex. The massive trees have grown on top of the walls and buildings themselves. The roots extend down the rock work and into the ground making for some picturesque scenery. The stone carvings are very detailed and just stunning. I would definitely recommend a visit to Ta Prohm!
A Dream Realized. Having wanted to see Ta Prohm for so long, we were not disappointed. The trees have to be seen to be believed. It's a remarkable place worth the trip to Siem Reap on it's own.

"Tomb Raider" temple with beautiful trees; great for nature lover. The temple is famous for its trees over ruins, memorialized in the movie Tomb Raider. I think Ta Prohm is one of the most interesting temples - huge, ancient trees and their roots draped over the ruins, giving you a sense of time travel and unreality. If your phone camera has the panoramic function, you can use it here and capture the entirety of jungle life + history. Highly recommend.

Ta Prohm. This is probably my second favourite temple after Angkor Wat. This area was apparently where they shot the movie Tomb Raider with Angelina Jolie. The trees wrapping around the stonework give this temple an extra special look.The only downside to the temple are the hawkers, we only pulled up to the temple car park and we were surrounded with sellers, I couldn't get out of the Tuk Tuk for them... Its the worst of all the temples definitely!
A perfect combination of nature and history. While some places are always busy with photo queues, the majority of the complex still provides a great atmosphere combining nature and temples.

Incredible!. Our favourite temple of the Angkor Wat complex. The way nature has taken back, and then added to the beauty of the temple is simply stunning. It's very difficult to find a quiet place in this area,mainly due to many Chinese tourists pushing to get a photo opportunity, but persevere and just take in the peace and quiet before another horde arrives!

Probably the best temple of all. We visited Angkor Wat before this & really enjoyed it but Ta Prohm surpassed Angkor Wat as far as we were concerned. The jungle encroaching with all the trees growing out of the temple made it quite magical. Definitely one not to be missed but it does get very busy. We got there as it opened but by the time we left there were a lot of people.

Best temple by far, but I didn't see Lara Croft!. I was very keen to visit this temple and I saved it until later in the day because I wanted to build up to it! Amazing to see nature reclaiming these structures. I wasn't disappointed and I was surprised how few tourists there were. We must have been lucky visiting on a Sunday and this place in my opinion is better than Angkor Wat

Embraced by the Jungle. Our day 2 of our 4 day trip if Siem Reap, we sat by Srah Srang, a reservoir in Siem Reap to watch the sun rise. There were few people at Srah Srang and the views are also incredible. From there, we explored an incredible Angkor temple that brought out the inner Lara Croft in me! It was raw, mysterious and wild thereby transporting us into another world and time.The temple of Ta Prohm was neglected and swallowed by the jungle of Cambodia for almost four centuries.I didn’t notice any sign that Tomb Raider was ever filmed here. But with so much of it in a collapsed state, it’s hard to believe that this place had once been the filming location of a big hollywood movie.A whole tree growing on the roof, with roots cradling the temple before finally reaching the ground is indeed a sight to remember.How long would it last before the temple collapses under the weight of that massive tree? It serves as a grim reminder that we can only borrow from the earth for so long. Eventually, everything returns to earth.Archaeological Survey of India is carrying out restoration works within the temple.Suggestion to go there early to get good photographs.

Visit Ta Prohm before Nature Conquers it. Uniquely embraced by forest, this temple has unique character. Unfortunately, the trees also weaken the temple structure as the Historians race to restore it. This is the filming site for Tomb Raiders and a must-go for movie buffs

Wonderful ruins draped in trees.. Take one look at Ta Prohm and the instant impression is of some place where time has stood still.The ruins are as they were when people walked away for the last time, but the giant trees and their roots snaking over everything provide a sort of “sleeping beauty” atmosphere.It is as if the trees and the jungle are keeping the place safe which is far from the truth since their incursions have tumbled many a building and left restorers with a serious task.The site is most recently famous for being used as a location to shoot some scenes for the Tomb Raider film with Angelina Jolie.Entry as with all temple sites in this area is via a one day pass for $20 or a three-day pass for $40. The pass has an electronic photo of you which is taken at issue and it should be carried at all times as guards and officials regularly check visitors.When I toured the site my guide and I were there fairly early before the big tour groups start to arrive, so we often had sections of the site to ourselves or with only a few other people in sight, by far the best way to experience the ruins.I clambered about with my attention drawn to this giant stone face or that carving, my guide really earning his $35 a day fee by ensuring I saw things and places I would never have discovered on my own.Many sections of the ruins are too dangerous to go in to, fractured by tree roots or the passage of time to a point where they are unstable, but there are many other sections where you can wander freely in awe at what you see. Good trainers or boots are essential as terrain is rugged and very uneven as you’d expect among ruins.There are wonderful carvings everywhere you go, hidden doorways leading to small rooms, ceilings created by stepped stones, the remains of statuary and some slightly grimmer sights of damaged stonework where the Khymer Rouge or others looted artefacts to sell.You need to keep your wits about you and have a good guide who knows the site because some points of interest are tiny and hidden away, notably a small stone face which peeps shyly through a gap between two large tree roots which have grown over its niche.Everywhere you go are fresh wonders, startling tree root formations or unusual carvings. One actually gives a hint as to how the temples were built, showing men at work on construction.You can spend hours just wandering around and the need for toilets and food may be an issue. Both are available close by and I enjoyed a traditional dish of Amok chicken served to me inside a coconut with a very welcome glass of iced tea in a small jungle restaurant.Don’t miss a visit to this spectacular temple but get there early or late to avoid the crush.

Don't miss this one!. Whilst everyone comes to see Anghor Wat it's Ta Prohm that gives you the feeling of what it must have been like for the first people to discover the temples in the jungle. Massive trees grow up and around the walls and strangler figs have almost succeeded in living up to their name.
Time Stands Still. Amazing temple. The trees which have grown over the temples - hard to describe. Temple is beautiful and worth the visit.
Fascinating. There just one word for it – Fascinating. And not too crowded when we were there. It takes you and hour to walk around the area.

Excellent carvings and tree-covered gate. This temple has a very nice entrance and proceeds through a long sort of corridor complex of gates, the last one spectacularly covered by a tree. There are a variety of vendors selling T-shirts and prints, etc,, on the way which can be a bit of a "pain"!

Really nice but too touristic. That's a shame! This place is so beautifull but they should limites the access to a certain number of tourist per hour! I would like too be rich and book this place only for me and only for an hour. Because of tourist, it ruins my visit there :(

Nature always win. This place was one of the busiest sites we went to visit. I suspect it was all the Tomb Raider hype, Tomb Raider was the least impressive thing about this temple - this really shows you what nature is truly capable of. If you want to make the most of your visit, recommend paying a bit of money and getting yourself a guide (it's not too pricey and worth it) - they know the sites and really does make a big difference in how you experience the complex.

Great temple. Search for the less seen parts of the temple and don't spend time only in the front and the central part of it. It has a magic flair. Certainly worth seeing and I'm not the only one to state it
atmospheric. Fascinating ruins left in discovered state with massive trees growing through. out of town but well worth thet rip
The most beautiful one. In a city full of beautiful temples, this was my favourite. The mixture of architectura and nature, makes it a unique place in the world

Small temple. There's only one reason to go to Ta Prohm: the tree-covered gate at the very end of this temple. It's a must seen, so no way to get around it. Late afternoon is a good time to see the temple (good sunlight, less visitors)

Temple visit. This was part of the small circle tour. This was my favorite temple. This temple has not been reconstructed. Beautiful to see. Watch which entrance you take as it can be a lot of walking if you leave at the wrong exit.
A step back in time.. A relatively undisturbed temple which has been left mainly as the French explorers first found it in the early 20th Century. Wear good footwear.
wonder of nature. this place is so different from other temple . wow the roots of the trees almost enclave the whole temple. If i am an actor i wouyld like to have my movies shot here.

The Jungle Reclaims. This temple complex has been left more or less as the jungle had reclaimed it. It is amazing to see how strangler figs have spread their root system in which ever way to smother and enfold the temple buildings. This is a small temple complex and visitors here can be fierce, frustrating and infuriating. Still, an amazing place and another tick on the bucket list.

Make this your first temple. I read from a post from someone on the internet to make Ta Prohm your first temple to visit because you would remember y o ur first impression most. Well, that was certainly true of Ta Prohm. We arrived around 7:30 and there were just a few other tourists there. Good for pi tures as the light was good too at that time. The most startling thing about Ta Prohm was the trees and vines growing through the ruins. It was eerie and mystical. The craftsmanship was impressive and the ruins were easy to negotiate. Make this one your first and you won't be disappointed. Sharp contrast to the crowds at Anghor Wat and Bayon.

Extremely photogenic, showing what the jungle is capable of..!!. Ta Prohm is one of those places everyone who's seen or heard of Tomb Raider just has to visit. It's spectacular for the way it demonstrates how the jungle takes over and destroys a building. However, restoration is ongoing and as our third visit, we saw how a building can be destroyed and rebuilt over a five year period.

The one with Tomb Raider 😜. As our guide told us, the official name of this temple is Ta Prohm but after Tomb Raider was released everyone calls this the Tomb Raider temple.The way that nature has made its presence felt in the temple is beautiful but also slightly terrifying. The trees growing over the buildings and temple structures creates this surreal feeling of being enclosed with nature. This temple was less crowded than Angkor Wat or Bayon Temple in Angkor Thom, but there are still plenty of people and surprisingly there was a pretty long line to take pictures with the roots of the trees. Be careful walking around as tree roots are everywhere and in unexpected places. Highly recommend to wear proper shoes instead of flip flops or sandals as it is also a bit sandy.

It was more interesting a few years back!. They started by cutting the trees, then scaffolding everything, then putting half of the site "off limit"... May be in a few years, you will visit it in a plastic "reconstitution" or a "virtual reality model".... Most important, try to avoind going there during the Chinese New Year... Hundred of millions of Chinese will surround you!

A testament to the transience of man's creations. Made famous by the Tomb Raider movie, this is the 12th century temple complex where the indigenous trees have been left to engulf and entwine the creation of man. The conservationist decided to leave a great deal of this complex au naturale, so expect to find many roped-off sections where the blocks have fallen and are sitting in piles. Nonetheless, this is an amazing site. Go in the early morning to avoid the streams of tourists that buzz through.

Worth a Visit. Who doesn't want to be able to say that they have been to the Tomb Raider Temple, truthfully though, this was our third temple of the day and I was done in probably 15mins. It was actually a good insight in to how the temples really have held up over the years, as this place has had very little reconstruction/conservation work done to it, unlike the other temples, it has instead been more preserved as it was when re-discovered. If you are visiting the other temples, then you'd have to come here for a look, but if you are considering only visiting one temple, I wouldn't make it this one.

Magnificent atmosphere . This was by far our favourite temple of the whole lot that we saw in two days. It probably helped quite a bit that we were there late afternoon, the light adding much to the atmosphere. Pretty temple, amazing roots, super place.

While you're in area.... Almost anyone knows about Angkor Wat and, justifiably, wants to visit if/when they are in the area. However, few could name any of the other significant archeological sites in the same general area.Bayon Temple, Angkor Thom, and Ta Prohm are just three of many and, like Angkor Wat could be considered "must-see", too.(Ta Prohm is also known as the Jungle Temple, and was location for many of the scenes in Laura Croft Tomb Raider.)They are all located in the Angkor Archeological Park and, although sharing similarities, have significant historical and/or architectural differences. A US $40.00 pass gives unlimited entry to all the sites in the park for a 1 week period.
Nice but less impressive than the big temples. After having seen Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, this is less memorable but still very interesting due to the vegetation and restoration works.

Nature and history together. It is amazing to see how the nature overcome the stone. Its is like a fusion of nature and man made temples. The roots grow over the walls. The nature just find its way. The best of the complex by far

A must see!. This temple was one of our favorite from the classical "temples loop" of Angkor. It is unfortunately popular amongst tourists but really worth the visit as it is one of the rare temples where Nature has overtaken its rights with the trees blending into the stones!
Otherworldly. This is an amazing religious complex and the way the trees have fused with the buildings is a marvel in itself.Yes, this is where the Lara Croft movies were filmed.

Everything is impermanent. That the jungle took over this magnificent complex ought not to surprise us as everything is impermanent. We appreciated this complex for its own merits not not because of some film. It created within us a sense of reverence and awe at how things change and how fragile human endeavour, however worthwhile, is.

An amazing example of man versus nature.. These ruins are being taken back by the jungle. It is amazing to see. Our Tuk Tuk driver took us here first thing in the morning so there were not too many people. You have to see it to believe it.

Film Star!. Star of Tomb Raider and amazing place. The buildings are slowly being taken over by tree roots which is fascinating to see. Some reconstruction work is taking place and a display explains this very well.
Our favorite. Well worth spending hours here. There were a lot of maintenance ongoing when we visited. But neither less it was an excellent experience.

Unforgettable. This was the first of 3 temples we went to with our teenage sons - also Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm. We chose this as they had seen it in movies and other shows. It was a magical place for us all. We spent about an hour here wandering through the ruins and soaking up the atmosphere.

Feeling of Adventure. This Temple has a special feeling of adventure. The temple must have been very beautiful when it was in use. Now the nature and the big trees have taken a step in to to the ruins and the place has a special charm.

Reclaiming frorm the Jungle. The jungle has had 700 years to grow and reclaim this former temple and city. It is being restored and to try to rebuild the collapsed structures will be a monumental job. The trees have rooted themselves around the building stones and it is a beautiful mingling of man and nature. It is a long walk in and out, be aware. The city walls are a kilometre a side and you walk into the temple in the centre. Definitely take the long walk around the temple, it is nicer than the shorter walk. One recommendation, most people will choose to go to Angkor Wat first, so this will probably be later in the day and there are vendors everywhere outside these temples, buy a cold coconut for a refreshing drink and enjoy it in your TukTuk on the way. Nice and refreshing.
best part of my trip. i loved seen this trees on top of the temples something amazing, only issue is that it gets too full of tourist and hard to take pictures.
Tomb raider!!. When my tuk tuk driver drove past this I couldn't believe it. Great condition, but can get very busy so patience is a must. It was great fun to be able to see where the movie was shot.

High on the list. It's easy to get "templed out" in Siem Reap, but we place Ta Prohm high on the list, after admiring the carvings at Angkor Wat. The massive trees are reclaiming this ruin, and may eventually win. Early is better as Ta Prohm is popular.

Roots tear apart and hold together. We got a driver and guide which made exploration efficient. The site was very crowded, having a guide allowed us to see the main views from spots from which to get a good photo. The site is most interesting to see how the trees grew around the structure at times supporting the structure and st times causing the structure to break apart. The sounds of parrots add to a " jungle " feel. There were many young people visiting by bike and hiking with guide book in hand. They were enjoying exploring the site. Given we are 65+ having a guide made the visit very easy. The pavement is similar to other sites, not difficult to navigate for someone of a certain age. We enjoyed this site very much and would recommend a visit for all ages.
Temple in forrest. The Giant trees are amazing. This is a must visit in Siem Reap. A unique ancient temple that I will remember.
Nature and History!. Beautiful to see how mother nature has woven its way through the stone in the temples. Its breathtaking.

Forget Angkor Wat - this is the best. This was the highlight of our visits to the temples in Siem Reap. The complex is huge. Ta Prohm is a mixture of towers, courtyards and corridors all filtered from the direct sunlight by the encroaching jungle. The carvings on the temples are extremely ornate in places.

Spectacular. This site is one of my favourite ones in Angkor. The atmosphere is just magic: fabulous temple ruins in the middle of vegetation. I really hope conservation works will give it a second (and more!) lives. Go there it is a must see!

Lots of people. While this is a must see it was a little crowded. There are board walks and signs to direct you around this temple but really you just have to follow the crowds. It is difficult to get photo without other people in them but with patience and a little ingenuity it is possible.

Very touristy but lovely. You will have hard time walking around because of all the other people but it's lovely and beautiful covered with banyan tree branches. Worth to visit even if you might end up standing behind other people for some time.
Almost as nice as Lara herself :-). In my opinion, this is not as nice as Angkor Wat or Bayon, but it is very impressive nonetheless. In particular, nature lovers will really enjoy this

And there it was. I pictured myself standing here and seeing this place. And then there it was right in front of me and it was more of an experience than I could have imagined. As with all temples in the areas above Siem Reap the scale in impressive. I got lost in wonder as I strolled around the incredible ruins, bewildered by the number of giant trees sitting on top of the structures. This place is so accessible. You need to come here.
Can't miss it. Set in a location with huge trees, we love this palace. Even with a great amount of Chinese tourists during the Chinese New Year holiday, I still think it was worth it.
Amazing sight!. This temple is covered in banyan tree branches. Lovely sight as you walk through the old temple and find fallen stones, nature and art all mixing together. Magical place.

A bit too touristy! . This is a beautiful temple. Main feature is the trees growing out of the temple ruins. It is a big complex and can get tiring with the large group of tourist. Go around 12pm. Yes sun is hot! BUT less tourists n you can enjoy the temple a bit more
Ta Prohm. I would recommend to go in the evening. I got beautiful sunset picture. Long walk into the temple. Another unique temple that i will remember.

'Absolutely fascinating!. Very nice old temple & ruins,
also good spot for early morning visit!
An absolute MUST on a trip to Siem Reap!
Hollywood . Busy Temple due to Hollywood connection but well worth a visit. Seeing trees and ruins interesting. Lots of windows to take interesting pictures.
Nature wins over manmade temple. Temple was left over to the Nature in the past years and nature took over in stunning ways which is clearly visible on many areas around and in the Temple.

Lost landscape staff for over two hundred years. Again, you must have an Angkor Wat ticket for entry. This place is another must see in addition to Angkor and Bayon Temple. Not the easiest to get around with low level arches and parts being bombed out by the Pol Pot people.
Tomb Raider. There, I said it. Recommend taking a guide (or earwigging on a another tour group). As with all of the temples in this area it is truly an eigth wonder of the world.
Tomb raider !!. its the most beautiful but most crowded of all the temples lots of loose rocks so make sure your not in thongs
The tomb raider. This is the one with all the huge tree roots for the good photos nice and easy to walk around in one of the must visit temples

Jungle crowd. Beautiful amazing and...very crowded. Being smaller and more confined the crowds were much more noticeable than at the larger sites but it's still a really cool place and would probably be the best temple to visit if you could hit it at a quieter time.

Just like in the Movie !!!. The temple is well laid out, the tree is still growing strong surrounding the temple - there is a walkway in front of the temple so unlike the movie you can't climb out of the temple!! However, it is very warm, bring hat and water. The temple appears to busiest in the later part of the morning so - go early!!! Also this is just a small part of a very large temple complex - there are lots of beautiful spots for photos.

Great outside of peak times. I loved Ta Prohm. The crowds, not so much. Being the famed Tomb Raider temple means it's best to visit in the early morning or later in the day. It's definitely one of the most visually stunning and I really enjoyed walking around it and taking it all in. I even purchased a prayer bracelet from a lady there, who told me I'll be very lucky ;-)

Memorable visit. Visually stunning, historically confusing but well worth the visit. Take the effort to get here, ignore the crowds and find a quite spot to soak the visual impact of the place in. Three hundred year old trees framing even older stone architecture. Use your three day pass spread over the full week to get the best value and impact.

One of the most interesting temples. Because this temple has been left essentially untouched with nature, trees etc growing through the buildings it is one of the most visually striking and interesting of temples
Such a neat place. Be sure to visit this temple when exploring Angkor temple complex. The trees overtaking the temple are pretty amazing.
A Movie Site. It's another amazing wonder amongst the temple series in siem reap. Imagine yourself in 'Tomb Raider'. Lots of conservation work is being carried out.

amazing experience. it's quite an experience. not sure if it lived up to the "faked up expectations of the movie that was set there"; but that's a personal mind-set. It's incredible to visit and I think visitors must be grateful that there's access given to these amazing temples to be experienced. Well worth the trip and hugely impressive.

Nature always wins. Left mostly untouched by archeologists it shows that the forest has a remarkable grip on man's contructions. Best seen in the early morning. A torch is handy to have inside this temple.

No longer as unspoilt as before. I fully blame the Tomb Raider movie for spoiling what was originally a very beautiful and deliberately under-restored temple. I remember being able to access the famous tree-root without artificial impedimenta, but this time when i visited, the authorities had built a viewing/photo taking platform with a queue of tourists waiting to take their turn to pose in front of it. It really spoilt the entire experience for me. I dont blame the Angkor authorities, i blame the fact that it has now become so famous that It seems impossible to see it the way it really is anymore. A real pity

Lovely for pictures - if you like to queue!. Very busy, if not the busiest temple in the circuit. Well worth going t o see but id recommend maybe another dawn start for this if you dont want to queue for pictures and liek to explore in peace. A few hawkers around on the walk up to it but still wouldnt have missed it.

Forest verses temple. . The forest has nearly taken back these temples. But it's very good to see all the massive trees growing out of the temple ruins. Its another very popular temple due to Lara Croft movie that was filmed there. Definitely worth paying this popular temple a visit.
Incredible. Awesome, Incredible, Wild, Great, Wonderful, Beautiful, Amazing, Indescribable, Adventurous... and much much much more...

Number 3 attraction in Angkor. I have numbered my attraction in Angkor , but actually the top 3 Angkor Wat , bayon Temple and Ta Phrom all these 3 attraction should be on minimalistic list for visiting Angkor. This temple is more famous for featuring in the Hollywood movie "Tomb Raider" and is also sometimes called as "Tomb Raider Temple"

A must see!!. I was blown away by these temples!
I am sure some people may disagree with me, but I enjoyed this temple much more than Angkor Wat. My kids couldn't believe what they were seeing and I was amazed to see the age of these trees! My favorite!!!

Do not miss this place!. This was among the highlight in my Siem Reap trip.. To see nature and man made buildings combine together is magnificent. The temple is just a short walk from the drop off point and very shady.. This is a stark contrast from Angkor Wat. So you can spend more time here. Do take a lot of pictures and take the longer trail to see everything. Absolutely breathtaking

Walking among Giants. Walking through this ancient site was truly amazing. Giant trees growing among the ruins gives visitors a true sense how old this site is ! Great stop amoung the many temples in the Angor Wat complex.

Amazing. A great site to visit. It is extremely popular which makes it a bit busy. Can go off to the the sides though and no need to be so obsessed with a particular view just because it was in a film. Pretty impressive. I thought Preah Khan was just as impressive but with far fewer visitors. You have to see this one too though!

Hauntingly beautiful. There's a lot of repair work being undertaken here, which does detract from the existing temple structures. There's some beautiful temples here which are covered with trees; some growing through the temples.There are some artists here who sell their paint and charcoal works of art - some of them are incredibly talented and worth buying.

Amazing place. Although, navigating through the temple is difficult with the crowds this temple with the Fig trees joining with the rock that was laid over 1000 years ago, it is a sight to behold. I found it to be amazing to see and was thinking how advanced the Khmer people, must have been to build such structures. You will enjoy this and the other temples of Angkor Watt should you go. This was my second time to Cambodia and second time to Angkor Watt and this temple. I am still in awe of it all.

Nature Triumphs Once Again. We were told that this was the temple where Laura Croft, Tomb Raider was filmed. We were amazed how the trees and roots had enveloped the site and made the temples almost living entities. Much of it is crumbling and falling down but it is an impressive site.

It's not like the movies. This is a temple that nature has taken over. It is worth the visit. Go with a guide so you can get the full history and not just that Angelina made it famous via Hollywood. Recent changes to the landscape have altered the temple because trees have been removed to prevent further destruction to the temple walls. Beautiful site.

What an interesting place!!. Folks who just visit Angkor Wat and do not go to see Ta Prohm really miss out because to me this temple complex was very interesting. To see how the jungle has taken over and to learn the importance of the trees, fascinating. Don't miss this!!

Mesmerising.. Looking at the wonders of nature blending itself with the architecture of the human race. One can see gigantic roots hugging onto the ancient walls. Plenty of spots for photography so please bring along enough storage and batteries. I myself shot around five thousand shots. Will share some of the good photographs once I have uploaded them onto my computer.

"Tomb Raider" tag doesn't do it justice. There are in excess of 1000 temples within the Angkor complex, with Ta Prohm being one of the "Big 3" that people visitThis temple is also known as the "Tomb Raider Temple" as it was here that a big chunk of the film was set. This temple has been reclaimed by the jungle where Strangler Figs and Kapok Trees have entwined themselves around the ruins. It is an incredibly atmospheric ruin made up of several towers, closed courtyards and narrow corridors to explore round the site. This temple is undergoing a lot of restoration funded by the Indian government at the time of writing, but still it is very much open and is one of the key places people visit. The huge trees that have taken over the site are the ones you usually see in pictures of the complex, with one particular large tree featuring as the Tree of Life" in Tomb Raider. It is a must see if you visit the site, but it does get busy and the amount of tourists with selfie sticks really does start to grate...

My 2nd favourite in Angkor archeological area. Very beautiful temple. The trees that are wrapped around the temple strucktures are just amazing. Personally my 2nd favourite of the Angkor area temples!

my favourite temple. It's difficult to describe this temple, with the huge trees and roots growing around the ruins. It was my favourite temple in the area. Again, the number of tourists is huge, you'll never be alone.
Temples. This is where Temple of Doom and Tomb Raider was filmed. My kids absolutely loved climbing all over this amazing temple and woukd highly recommend it

More temples to see, on the grand tour. This was dedicated to the sister, not as ornate as Bayon or main Angkor Wat temple but still good. Some nice pictures of the trees growing over/into the structure, unfortunately destroyed no the temples slowly.
Famous place with magnificiant trees. A famous film which was shot here was Lara Croft, you can almost recognize the trees immediately. This is a must do when in Cambodia.
Amazing. I loved this temple seeing how nature has grown into it was just amazing. Lots of climbing and best to go early in day before it is too hot
Atmospheric. Very atmospheric and interesting place. Again our guide was able to help us avoid the queues and gave us some interesting information on these temples.

sexiest temple in Angkor Park area. possibly give you chance to visit this temple more than once. very much visited it's sometimes so crowded you miss its real beauty. when it's quite it is so easy n rewarding discover the MAGIC affecting every single stone/step/tree

The Ruined Ruin. I've lived in Siem Reap for a little while, and for most of the time Ta Prohm took pride of place as my favourite temple (I was able to overlook the boardwalks and stations erected for large group photos). It was bliss if you skipped Angkor Wat and went there early in the morning. Alas, Apsara Authority in their infinite wisdom decided it would be a good idea to restrict the opening hours. Now when you show up for the new 7.30am opening time, a formidable queue has already begun to form, and it takes a mere half an hour before the temple is beyond-enjoyable busy. Well done Apsara, you've ruined the best ruin!
Ooh wow!. A must go and see before it crumbles. Amazing temple with huge ancient trees. The ruins and carvings are just awesome. I think this is more ooh wow than Angkor Wat.
Nature wrapped around ruins. This is a smaller site than many of the others in the area but so appealing with the trees growing around the ruins. It was my favourite .
Wonder of nature. Amazing. No words to describe this place. You feel very little surrounded by these huge roots of trees embracing the old ruins of the historical site. this is a most!
Extraordinary. A spectacular temple. The way the tree roots envelope the temple building is mesmerising. Well worth a visit.

Too Cool to Miss. This place really affects you. As you walk around all the tree roots growing among the ancient ruins you imagine all the time that the temple sat untouched in the jungle. Some of the scenes are unreal and it's no wonder they shoot movies here.

A Must !!!. It is difficult to find the correct words to describe this temple.It must be visited to see how wonderful nature can be.Take time though, don't rush around with the crowds and do not forget to make sure your camera is working!!Enjoy

Be a tomb raider and explore!. This is the most fun of the Temples so be sure yu do not leave it for last. Wander through the trunks and trees, the boulders and out cropping and see what you will find. it is so easy to get lost and pretend you are in another world!

Different from the other temples. Located a few kilometres from Angkar Wat, this temple is unique compared to the others as the large sponge trees have taken over some of the temple. Rather dilapidated but still very interesting. Minimal carvings.

Beautiful but very busy. This was my personal favourite of the temples, the architecture is simply stunning and the tree roots which have forced their way into Ta Prohm really give it character and add to its beauty. By the time we got to Ta Prohm, it was about 10am and was already very, very busy! Large tour groups piled in from every pathway, but this was obviously to be expected. It's quite easy to get a bit lost so a map would be helpful, such as those in the lonely planet guide.
Laura Croft Tomb Raider. A most unusual temple in that it has been left with the trees growing on it. This is the must have tourist pic of the Laura Croft Tomb Raider place.

The Mystical temple. If you wanted visit only 3 temples in Angkor, Angkor Wat, Bayon and Ta Phrom would be it. This is the 3 most visited temples, especially Ta Phrom that gained it fame from Tomb Raider. The temple is very much mystical, in what seem like a perfect assimilation of Nature and man made structure. You could spent hours and hours here and exploring every corner and niche of the temple. The trees and roots are overgrown just like in such a way the complement the temple and make it even more beautiful. We went here a little late, and boy, the crowd was crazy. but if youu keep exploring, once in a while you while find a corner where there is no one else except you.

Amazing, but oddly not the shrine to Angelina Jolie that it will be portrayed to you as..... Absolute don't miss. You'll be told that this is one of the few ruins left untouched, unchanged. Untrue. But it was left more intact than not. Despite the fact that it is a fantastically amazing ancient remnant of an incredibly beautiful and impressive place of worship, every tour guide leading hoards of Korean, Chinese, & French tourists through the temple will instead be boasting of the fact that a famous actress was filmed swinging on a vine here once. Plug your ears to them and savor at least an hour of astonishing wonder at this gem of history.
Famous for being in Tomb Raiders movie; that's it. Yes, the trees growing over the temple look cool, and the queue to take a photo in front isn't too long. Not much else though.

Very interesting site. It's interesting to see what the jungle can do to man made structures and here is a perfect example. This temple is being devoured by the trees. Every temple my husband and I went in to made us feel the walls and roofs would collapse. This one really did. Many of these temples are being renovated by foreign archeological associations. This one by India. It is slow going for them. This temple's main attraction is the trees. And it is the site of a scene from one of the Raider's of movies. Great pictures can be taken of the trees and their long snake like roots.

Amazing nature. Love the other-world-look of this temple with it's stone buildings half digested by the jungle where it hid for so long. Great to see that some restoration work is taking place on the site and if you only have one day to look around, we think Ta Prohm should feature as one of your top 3 (with Angkor Wat and Bayon).

Atmospheric . Great to see the old temple with the trees growing around and over the structures. Thrilled to see the conservation work going on to help restore some of the parts. Toilets near the entrance were also very clean.

Our Favorite Temple. This temple is a highlight of our Cambodian trip and of our entire year. A truly amazing space, the interplay of the building with the slow destructive might of nature is truly an awesome sight. Ta Prohm should not be overshadowed by Angkor Wat and should not be missed. Hire a guide for the day, well worth it and you will discover many small details of the temples you might otherwise miss.

A must. When you visit Angkor Wat for the first time you may be surprised by the sheer size of the park. As a consequence, you may be tempted to skip one or two of its sights. This is frequently at the end of a tour but DO NOT SKIP THIS ONE. For a great number of visitors, it's the favourite. Will leave it to the reader to witness why.

Mysterious and beautiful in the middle of the jungle!. A true jungle temple where nature has been given free reign for many years. The temple, Lady Croft visited. To avoid people and crowds, it is best to be there between 06:00 and 10:00 am. The sooner the better!
wonderful. The trees which are slowly engulfing the temples is just jaw dropping. It really makes you look a lil bit longer and be in awe.
Number three tourist attraction. More amazing architecture with interesting tree formations throughout the temple. Crowded but worth the time to fully explore and photograph/video.

Wonderful. Any film buff will, of course, recognise Ta Prohm. It is a magnificent decayed ruin with trees growing into buildings and has a wonderful atmosphere. Tip - go here early, rather than to Angkor Wat first, to experience it when it is less crowded.

Loved it!. Ta Prohm is one of our favorite temples. The iconic trees growing from the ancient architecture is just incredible! A little tip - not everything is at Ta Prohm's main site, there is also a "little Ta Prohm" not far away, that has more trees and less people. Make sure to ask your Tuk-Tuk driver about it. Don't miss it out if you can help it. An unexpected gem!

My favorite. Get a guide and you will not be sorry. So many interesting things and i loved the way the trees grow over the ancient temple. This place was so special and had so many stories. Exceptional!

Awesome and fascinating. Ta Prohn, otherwise known globally as the site of Angelie Jolie's Tomb Raider is truly a site to behold! Thankfully UNESCO and possibly the movie production has resurrected many of this centuries old crimbling Hindu / Buddhist temple. "The jungle is taking back the Khmer culture" with trees both strangulating but also keeping erect the mystical homes of the Cambodian gods. Walking around and through the sandstone worn architecture with 1000's of celestial maidens and stories yet left on the walls added to the adventure of more intact temples such as Angkor Wat and Bayom. Don't miss each of the main structures as they evoke a different story based on the challenges placed on the times of their kings and families. I recommend a guided tour to best appreciate so many of the intricasies lost to an otherwise wandering eye!

One of the best templest in Angkor Wat temple area. I like the athmosphere in this temple because of the huge trees, the overlaying roots and the rotten stones eyerywhere. you can breathe history here. Huge restaurations take place at the Moment.

Amazing. You could crawl around in dangerous places at this temple! It was refreshing, because everything is walled off elsewhere. There are cool echo chambers here -- look for a small tall chamber with a candle inside and ask a local what to do (stand on the stone inside and thumb your hand hard against your chest).
Tomb rider movie place. Very nice place. Angeline Joulie filmed the scenes for "Tomb Rider" movie there. Impressive historical place! Nice, no dislikes.

Worth fighting the crowds. This temple was very crowded, and you depend on the cooperation of other visitors to give you a chance to take the 'canonical photographs' without people and their selfie-sticks in the way. Still, it's worth it, both because the temple and the trees growing in it are beautiful, and because if you've seen photos from Angkor (including "Tomb Raider") you've seen images of this location.
Superb.. Like temple run. The subject says it all. Absolutely superb.. There are 2 exits, so in a group decide meeting points to avoid getting lost

Unbelievable. This temple was neglected in between for more than a century.Then it collapsed due to natural disaster. Thereafter, trees grew on top of buildings and stones. To see large roots of trees all around like Pythons is a treat to eyes.

Amazing!. Ta Prohm was probably the busiest temple we went to. All the big tours wanted to see the "Tomb Raider tree" and had a line to take pictures with. Aside from it being busy, I enjoyed this tour so much! Just angle your camera up to make it look like there aren't anyone on the temple lol.The temple is very old, built by hand and so detailed! What a sight to see!
Inside an exotic photo. While not the best preserved of the temples, Ta Prohm has the most exotic and unique feel because of the remaining trees. There are photo opportunities at every turn!

Eerie ruins overgrown by large tree roots. Large trees have taken root over the stone walls at a half-dozen spots in this mostly-collapsed monastery. It's very picturesque. Don't miss the carved image of what looks like a Stegosaurus dinosaur (near the end of the route through the ruin).

Favourite!!. Please do not miss seeing this! Pictures do not do it justice. Ruins + trees all entangled really makes you feel like you've stepped in a time machine. By far my favourite temple in Cambodia.

This was our favourite temple. More atmospheric as it has been deliberately left as it was discovered back in the early 20th century. Nature taking over gives this obviously historic building an extra bit of glamour.

Ta Prohm temple. Be careful everyone, it may be difficult there were lots of rocks to climb and a stone may fall on your head thanks to the silver tree roots.Too bad it collaped now you'll have to climb over the rocks. I had trouble and my tour guide helped me.After all i was only a child of 10 two years ago.
Amazing!. I felt like Ta Prohm was by far the most interesting temple, that I could have probably spent by full day here so might be worth getting a 3 day ticket to Angkor Wat

lots of tourists. This is smaller than I expected, but great for photos, but try to go early morning or evening. The photos would be better regarding light and hopefully less tourists cramped in together trying to get the same shot. But if you end up as we did when it was busy, it is still a once in a life time. I went with Grasshopper bike tours and the guide was excellent!

The famous site of the Tomb Raider film.. This is one of the more photogenic temples and ruins in the entire Angkor complex. It is far more run down than some of the other sites but this makes it very special especially with the roots of all the Spung trees which grow in the area spreading among the ruins and into the walls.Full of loads and loads of photo opportunities.

One of my Favorites. Ta Prohm is one of my favorite places in the whole Angkor area. Nature has taken over, and the very dramatic sprung trees wrap themselves over and around everything man has built. We went in the late afternoon, when it was quieter and the golden sun made for fantastic pictures. You really feel like you are back in the 11th century when it was built.

More interesting than Angkor Wat?. While Angkor Wat (one of the Wonders of the World) is the star attraction in Siem Reap, it is realistically just a bigger and better preserved site than some other temples.Wat Prom, however, only a short distance away,is totally unique and mind-blowing. We have never seen anything like it. This site (where the Angelina Jolie movie Lara Croft, Tomb Raider was partly filmed) has large trees growing on top of, out of, and around the ancient stone temple complex. It is incredible to see what mother nature has done here.

This is quite an intriguing place with the trees growing through the buildings.. It is a smaller building so at times there can be a lot of people in more confined spaces. Beware of children trying to sell you things. It is not encouraged because they need to be in school.
