Words can't really describe their timeless beauty. These temples are amazing. To think how they were built over 1000 yrs ago with the minimal technology...incredible!

Beautiful but hundreds of people . If you go there early in the morning, there might be less people, but acceptti see lots of tourist, as this is the busiest temple in the Angkor park. It got famous because of the Tomb Raider movie, and the amazing trees coming out of the walls and roofs.You can access it from the Banteay Kdei west entrance.

our favorite temple. Ta Prohm is a stunner, w/ all the detailed carvings and oxidized greens and reds found elsewhere plus dense jungle growth throughout, giving it a spooky-yet-majestic feeling overall. We highly recommend getting here right at 7:30 AM when it opens, especially if you want photos. There will be others there at that time but it won't be crowded until the tour buses start rolling in after 8:30 AM and photos become impossible.Best of luck!
Amazing Trees. This was the most unusual temple we visited and loved it. As it's a smaller site it did get a bit congested at times but well worth seeing

Tomb Raider Temple. This is the temple where Angelina Jolie filmed Tomb Raider and they like to make everyone aware of this claim to fame. It is known for the over grown tree roots which make it interesting for photo taking. Again, it is crawling with tourists but still worth seeing.

Stunning Temple. Absolutely don't miss this temple when you visit the Angkor Archaeological Park! Angkor Wat gets a lot of the pictures and mention, but I believe Angkor Thom is even more stunning than Angkor Wat. The temple is huge and trees have overgrown it making it absolutely spectacular. They have a lot of spectacular spots for the photography lovers.It was the site for the movie Tomb Raider. The place could do a bit better job of managing tourists to make sure they don't destroy this temple as it is basically free reign of the place. Angkor Wat is huge, Bayon has a different design with the faces, but the jungle and nature revolving around this temple makes it my personal favorite. I've been to Angkor Archaeological Park three times now and it remains my favorite every time!

Fascinating ruins.. Ta Prohm is a great example of the symbiosis of jungle and man made objects. They are beautiful together. We had a policeman who showed us around and gave us insight into what we were seeing. Lot of fun and he practiced his English. Highly recommend.
Unmissable in late afternoon when less crowded. More intimate than the other sites. Closes at 5:30 but go as late as possible to get more atmosphere. Fantastic for photos but of course busy.
Incredible. There is nothing like this anywhere else, I am sure. You cannot believe what you are seeing--the majesty of the whole thing is spiritual
Famous for it's Tomb Raider movie backdrop but it's more.... This is the only temple with trees. Actually the roots overtake some parts of the temple. It is a sight to be seen and not missed.

Jungle Takeover!. It was so interesting to see how the jungle takes over abandoned structures. There is a tree growing over and across a wall that has been visually documented for years in varying stages, but there is newer growth and growth they are in the process of removing with heavy equipment.Time constraints did not afford much to be spent here. There was probably more to see, though it is not a large temple.

Absolutely stunning.. An absolutely fantastic place. The enormous tree roots intertwined with the ancient building remind us that nothing can stop the all-powerful force of nature. Certainly a highlight even in this extraordinary complex of wonderful buildings. Not to be missed

Amazing. We spent 3 days visiting as many temples as we could, this is one of the prettiest so don't miss it! Once again, having a private guide and an air conditioned van, made it easier to move around, stop wherever we wanted, and enjoy the place.

Excellent. This place is exactly how you imagine a lost temple to be, wonderful. We visited it a second time but earlier in the morning on the second day. Our first visit was slammed by three Japanese and Chinese tour parties all arriving at once! dear Lord Save me....hell on earth. We went back a couple of days later before the dreaded midday arrival time and it was great. The Temple opens at 7.30am, we were the first in there and it was great.

Jungle location and peace made this my favourite temple in Siem Reap. Having seen several of the most popular temples in the Siem Reap area, this was my favourite, I loved the way you could just wander round and explore in solitude without bumping into people or queuing to go up steps like in some of the busier places. You could just lose yourself in the passageways and tumbledown nature of the place whilst admiring the battle between jungle and stone as the trees reclaim their place with their massive roots. A wonderful location to ponder time, the universe and deep stuff. A must see for anyone!
dream wat. what a amazing, wonderful and unbelieveable place. U cant believe that is it real. trees are coming from wonderland

Very very beautiful. Extremely picturesque. Full of places to take beautiful pictures. The architecture here is amazing! So much history and so much art. Also really awesome that it this place was in tomb raider. Also kind of reminds me of the original Jungle Book. Must visit together with Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat

Amazing strangling fig trees. Interesting tree roots around a lot of the buildings. The site had been hidden amongst trees until discovered by a French naturalist in 1860. Hard to imagine 70,000 people living in the confines of the monastery.

Amazing a must see.... Went to Ta Prohm middle of day two of our two day temple tour. Left Ta Prohm and Angkor Wat until thE end. We were not disappointed. Such a different temple with trees growing in amongst the towers. Just amazing and definitely worth a visit. Very busy especially where the famous tomb raider tree is...everyone lining up for photos. Suggest avoiding that piece if a photo in front of the tree is not your thing!
Amazing. First thing i want to say "How". The temple is beautiful. i wonder how people can built it. the most interesting is the tree grow very big on the temple.

LET NATURE TAKE ITS COURSE!. Extremely cool piece of history! Ta Prohm offers visuals of nature taking over an attraction to great extents! Easy to get to via tuk tuk. A great place for a photo opp if you can handle annoying inconsiderate visitors walking in front of you at any time and place. Patience will pay off. Seeing these tree roots explode through the rock is a sight in itself. A place to just take the visuals in ... nothing like you may have seen before. Definite visit on the temple tour in Siem Reap!

Angelina Jolie is the reason why people come.. The place is huge and difficult for elder people to move around. It's crumpling and resemble very little the grand scene in "Tomb Raider" if that was the reason you come ( was the reason I came!).
Brilliant and different. Another totally impressive temple, a little different this time because of the extra dimension added by natures interaction with the artists incredible creation.

Surreal. Ta Prohm is a truly surreal fairytale place where the nature shows us its power. The gigantic ancient fig trees are intertwined with the thousand year old walls of the Wat eventually destroying it with a slowest possible speed but strongest ever force! A must see place!
Very wonder of the temple. its one of the world heritage, only in Cambodia, and also in Tomb raider, now its just a suite heritage of the world,
Unique. Tomb Raiders was filmed here and so it is very well known. The tree roots engulfing the temple reminds us that Mother Nature is in control...always.

Thom Rider Temple. Ta Prohm temple is one of the best temple in Siem Reap. Angkor Wat and Bayond temple are fabulous too. I can't wait to recommend this temple to my friends and family when i am back home.

One of the Top 3 Sights in Angkor Wat. This temple was build in the 12th century and abandoned. It has gained recent fame due to the "Tom Raider" movie. I did not see Angelina Jolie though. Instead you see a magnificent temple left to nature. It has intentionally not been restored and you can see how powerful the trees are. ( I am now concerned about my driveway at home. ) Fantastic atmosphere and great photography scenes. Get there early before the tourist groups come as space is limited. About 45 minutes from Angkor Wat. While there, visit the Phreah Khan Temple which is not that far from here.

Untouched!. This temple felt like no one had visited in hundreds of years, the trees growing into the ruines made the place feel very ancient. We had an excellent time exploring the dead ends and it felt like a maze. A must visit if you are in Siem reap.

Incredible! . The trees are growing through the temple. It just shows you the power of nature and the sheer beauty. We loved this temple as you just get lost in looking. It is hot and crowded so go early and take water
More Temples to See!. Ta Prohm was our third or fourth cant remember the order in which we did the tour but nevertheless the temples tells you the stories of tje past.

Too touristy with not enough space to move around. It was hot, busy and loud tourists everywhere all wanting photos with the Angelina tree!Did not find it a pleasure at all. Way better to visit Beng Melea to get a feel for a "tree temple". Unfortunately many visitors forget it is a temple and behave appallingly. But it is architecturally beautiful -

Jaw dropping!. This was one of my favourites to visit. I went there early which was nice. Not all the tour groups had arrived yet. It was amazing to see how the big, tall trees were still living as their roots were all over the place.
Wow. Ta Prohm is an amazing temple with trees growing in and around the temple. Apparently, a part of the Tomb Raider movie was also filmed here.

Ta Phrom. An amazing place,but I was there in the early 90's and so I hear that it has opened up a lot.The temples ae awesome,although when I was there you had to look out for de-mining there.Cheap marijuana$5 per kilo.An awesome place for photography,but I didn't like the food-very poor quality.Getting there was dangerous too,as I was with a group of friends and held at gun-point for a bribe.

Incredible Site. Once you tour this place you know why it was chosen for the "Tomb Raiders". You are amazed at every turn to see the jungle entombing the temple. Incredible, awesome, spectacular are appropriate descriptors. A must see on your tour of Angkor!

amazing and beautiful. This site is worth more time than you think. It has a strange serenity to it, that is also a bit spooky. Seeing how the trees have intruded on the buildings creates such unique images, lots of climbing on and over stuff, so watch your step.

Excellent experience!. If you like Tomb Raider you're sure to love this place.This was our first stop on our visit to Angkor temples. We didn't use a tour guide but I see how it could be useful with so much to see. There are plenty of other reviews to let you know what to see specifically when you go here. We walked around by ourselves and were amazed by everything, especially the massive trees. Lots of photo opportunities.I really enjoyed this place and suggest it to anyone visiting the Angkor temples.

Simply Amazing with nature and archaeology. First we were on an organized tour and the second was on a photo tour with Angkor Wat Photography. Afternoon and early morning to see the difference from the sun light. Simply amazing to see the giant trees and the roots growing among the temple. One needs to be patient and take your time to truly see and enjoy the beauty of this temple.
Tempel in the jungle. Ta Prohm gives an overwelming impression of how the nature can grow over the works of mankind. The roots of the giant trees that kling to the tempels are really breathtaking.

Amazing!. This is the temple where Tomb Raider was filmed, the trees are growing on the temple as you see in the pictures. It is an amazing temple they are restoring! It is smaller than the movie makes out but beautiful none the less!Many tours offer to see this amazing place and I would recommend to see.

Mother Nature gets her way around this temple:). Ta Prohm is definitely one of the temples you should visit. It is medium sized, 2 hour visit should be sufficient. Unlike elsewhere, trees growing into the temple structure have been left intact, to some astonishing effect. The intertwined temple ruins and tree roots form a unique labyrinth, with a bit of creepy feeling to it - especially with little crowd around (should also work well on a cloudy day). The trees are majestic and simply overwhelming. Don't miss it, and don't forget your camera!

Natural and architectural beauty!. Ta Prohm is easily one of my favourite Angkor temples! The ruins are beautiful. The massive roots add to its marvel and uniqueness. We went towards the closing time - the weather was great and the place was quieter, perfect to enjoy the sunset time.
Amazing. I keep saying the same thing for all the Angkor temples. They are all special and fit I to a puzzle of history. Xxxxxxxxx

This place is just superb!. One of the absolute highlights of the area! It's just so different to the other places here, and the trees growing through the ruins are incredible. It's awesome just getting off the main track, and climbing around the ruins for different views. This is one of the top three attractions in the Angkor Park.

Beautiful Temple Covered by Giant Tree Roots. This temple, one of several in the vicinity of Siem Reap, is known for the giant trees growing over the temples. (In other temples, the trees have been cut back.) The roots are fabulous; the older ones are white like the stone of the temples and look like stone, too. We walked west through the site into the setting sun and turned around frequently to see the sun on the temple walls. It was very magical. When we visited, the temple grounds were relatively crowded. In case you didn’t get this from other reviews, this temple is featured in Lara Croft: Tomb Raider. But you don’t need that claim-to-fame to visit this wonderful site.
Jungle Temple. Ta Prohm is a beautiful temple, bound by massive roots. Amazing area to explore, a must see if you are in the area!
Very cool and calming. It was busy but the area felt very calm and of course there are the trees growing all over the buildings and rocks, which is the paramount of nature taking over!

Atmospheric. I have to say that I think the wooden photo stands that have been erected detract a little from the overall atmosphere of the place but I guess they serve a purpose. I recommend going a little later in the day as its quieter I'm told. This is my favourite of the temples I've seen so far.

It was ok. It was much better than Angkor, we can walk more calmly and see more things. Trees are Awesome. Some are very high with other roots that turned stone and blend the architecture of the place.

This is the beat attraction in Siem Reap. After visiting Banteay Srey Temple, Pre Rup Temple, Angkor Wat, Taprohm temple and Bayon temple. I like this the best. Somehow the tree roots brings out the character of this temple. Since this is where the film - Tomb Raider was film, it brings back memory of this film.

Tomb Raider Temple. The last stop on our temple tour that was self-guided. Again, there were a lot of tourists, but no complaints from me :) seeing how large the trees inside the temple were pretty cool. You have to be able to walk a lot, though.
An absolute must visit. One if our favorite places to visit - picture perfect. Go early as it gets hot and spend time exploring.
The one they all come to see. A must see , if not just for the way the trees grow of which I have never seen any where in world like it...

Spectacular. This site is pretty spectacular. It was fascinating to see how the tree roots were entwined with the buildings. Lara Croft Tomb Raider was filmed here. It was quite busy when I was there and there were lots of people near the fenced off area by the entrance used in the film. Lots of ruins and just a fascinating place to visit.

Go early before the crowds hit. I went for the sunrise and was there by myself (with my guide) for about an hour. You can't see the sun come up here but it is worth it to be there by yourself. It was easy for me to imagine stumbling upon an ancient site because Ta Prohm is kept mostly as it was found. They have put up some barriers and walkways to protect the site but overall it is worth it to see the Spung trees growing all over the buildings. I highly recommend this site if you are in Siem Reap

Exclusive experience. That's a must! Even if you go from somewhere to se only this temple you will be happy.I saw pictures before but the life experience is so much better. I can't describe it. You should go and see so you will understand.
amazing. Each temple is amazing - and to see the trees grow out of this one is spectacular - again - you have to visit this
Great interesting and amazing. What an amazing site to see all the trees growing amongst the temple. Some of the trees are destroying the temples. The famous tomb raider tree was good to see.

Visually stunning. This was my favourite temple as it was so unusual. The trees growing through the temple are huge. Do not miss if you come to Angkor. It it busy but can't avoid that. Our guide was brilliant at avoiding crowds.

Brilliant. This was my favourite out of all the temples and ruins. It was a bit busy with coach loads of tourists, and very hot but worth every second. I especially liked looking at the tree roots growing through the stone walls. Don't miss this one out on your tour

Love this place. Ta Prohm is an atmospheric amazing set of buildings with the jungle trying to reclaim its prize. There are wooden walkways everywhere now to preserve the place and signs, that are often ignored, to not climb on the ruins. Look for bee swarms in the tree canopy.

Site from Tomb Raider. This was really fun to see because the massive overgrowth of vegetation and trees have not been removed. Shows the power of nature and engineering of ancient man. Fun to wander around and take pictures in the remarkable area.

Crowded. Access is getting more limited and tour groups dominate. For that abandoned look better to go to Ta Prom (quieter) or Beng Mealea (more accessibility and more spectacular). Even better, skip the lot and go to Koh Ker.
Must See. One of the best temples to explore. Everything is open and it's like the claws of tree trunks reach from the sky to grab the walls. This and Preah Khan are my favorite temples.

WOW- Love the Starngler Figs!!!!. This place is iconic as I'm sure you've seen photos of it, but they don't prepare you for the scope and sheer majesty of this temple. In top 3 f must do's in Angkor. Go early morning for the best light and to avoid the inevitable tour buses that start to show up around 10:30

You will feel like Indiana Jones or Lara Croft!. If you want to feel like Indiana Jones or Lara Croft, this is your place! I loved it, it's just amazing to see huge trees taking back their original kingdom, embracing like snakes the ancient temples. It's mysterious, adventurous, a place you can't believe it's true until you see it... Much better than in books or pictures. Just one tip: try to go in the morning if you want to dodge the crowds.
OUT OF THIS WORLD....AMAZING !. WOW ! What a place...up there with Chichen Itza, Pompeii and Ephesus. Tnis place is a MUST when visiting Siem Reap. Pleae use a guide as you will enjoy it even more.
Amazing. Trees that are 2 meters in diameter grow on top of the rock walls of the temple. A most beautiful and amazing place. Don't miss it.

"Tomb Raiders" temple. If you are a Lara Croft fan this is a must. Otherwise the trees weirdly growing into, over and around this temple are unique and kind of spooky in an alien sort of way. Worth a stop for sure.

Ta Prohm. I think After the pictures of Angkor Wat this Temple area with the tree roots is the most pictured when we think of this area. It was fascinating to Walk through and See how the trees had tanken over the temple. There were also some good engravings but i think most people were more interested in the tree roots. It was fascinating and a joy to Photograph. This is a MUST to visit, we did it with a tuctucs Big fün!

Really crowded, pretty cool. If your reason for visiting the temples is to see the Tomb Raider tree, then you have to come here. If you just want to see some big trees growing out of the temples, you can find a different temples that is less crowded. This place was packed full when we went around 9am.

Eerie combination of ancient ruin and massive trees. With limited time we visited Angkor Wat for the sunrise (along with a thousand others), when back to the hotel for breakfast and a rest, and returned to Ta Prohm to see the stunning scenes used in movies as well as to search out the lesser known carving of an animal that resembles a stegosaurus. Perhaps they didn't die out 150 million years ago after all. Afterwards we drove around the small circuit. The many other temples along the way are overwhelming in their number, size, and reasonable state of repair. The crumbling castles that I grew up near in the UK are pitiful in comparison with these ancient structures for architecture, size, an ornate carvings. The ancient Khmer could teach us much about building with stone.

Magical. I loved this temple so much that I came 2 times in my trip. The trees ae incredible over the temples. It is very crowded all day, I went in the morning and the next day in the afternoon, and there were a lot of people both days. So be prepared to wait for the perfect photo. Anyways, is a must see.

Visit first thing in morning. This place is definitely a must visit. But if you don't want crowds I would highly suggest to get here by 7-7:30am. As by 8:30am busloads of Asian tourists were swarming everywhere! Would not have been fun to wonder around with hundreds of other people here.
Mysteriously amazing. This is probably one of the most mysterious temples in Angkor Thom, you will be able to see how nature will always claim its place! And also... It was Tomb Raider's movie set!

The movie didn't do it justice. This temple is surrounded by huge trees some of whose roots have woven through the walls and floors of this unique temple. Located 30 minutes or so away from Angkor Wat this is an also must visit temple. Built centuries ago and rediscovered recently, this temple is also huge in scope and breadth. The carvings into the stone walls and ceilings are amazing and detailed. A truly fantastic sight to behold.

Amazing temple. I like Ta Prohm very much, i never see it before in my life.I like the tree on top of the stone. Ta Prohm temple is on the north of Siem Reap, it stay around small tour. My Favorite Temple. I will come back to see it again in future.

Ta Prohm or so called Tomb Raider temple at Angkor Wat. After all temples we visit at Angkor Wat the Ta Prohm temple was the most spectacluar with the big trees and their roots which are climbing over and thrue the stones. Not easy to take pictues but we catch all with our eyes.....superb

Stunning. My favourite of all the temples. A must see. Strolling around gives you a feeling of how life was there nearly 1000 years ago. It was the only temple that appeared not be as preserved as the others.We arrived about 4pm which was a perfect time. The hordes of tour groups had left, and we had the pleasure of being able to freely walk around.Tip: if you find yourself here around in the evening before sunset, go view the sunset from the lake. It's about 1km away.
Amazing. This differentiates itself from the other nearby temples by the extraordinary banyan trees growing in/on/through the stones.

Spectacular - my favorite temple!. By far Ta Prohm was my favorite temple. I even scoured the markets to find paintings of it. It is a beautiful combination of green, pink, and black stones. More excitingly, it was overrun by the most incredible trees I’ve ever seen. It’s amazing that the temples were built to protect them from their enemies but it could not protect them from time and nature.

The best temple!!. This was my favourite temple here, It is smaller and cooler as it had more shade. This was the Tomb Raiders temple,with trees growing twisted amongst the ruins-very photogenic!Buy a three day pass [$us40] instead of the $20 day pass, get a guide for the first visit, then come back to see it more leisurely.Go to the toilet before you go in, because there are no toilets inside the temples! Take a face mask or scarf as you are walking on very fine sand, it the wind blows it will go in your mouth and eyes.Take water, hat, sunglasses, and spray agianst insects before you go.
magic has gone!!. too many people. too many works have been done on the site. in my mind, you can skipp this temple. .

Ta Prohm Siem Reap. Ta Prohm Siem Reap.This is the temple built around heaps of trees. Is 1 of the top 5 temples to visit.Great temple to visit, takes approx 2 hours to really get through. Once you pay the $20 USD it doesn't matter which temple you go to.Tip - Must visit the national museum prior to going out to Angkor archeological park

Come to Ta Prohm right after sunrise. We visited Angkor Wat for sunrise, and while other people still busy exploring Angkor Wat after sunrise or still having breakfast in Angkor Wat, we headed up to Ta Prohm. Not like Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm have one way to get around and the track already been set up, you can't go back once you pass the big iconic tree on Tomb Rider movie, you have to keep on going and go around then get out from the right side of the entrance. So if you like taking picture without many people around, come early. We get there around 7.30 am after watching sunrise in Angkor Wat. No guide will tell you information, you will walk and just looking on the ruins. There's only one big information board right after the entrance. So, if you're interested in Ta Prohm history, google it before you visit it. On the entrance, you will be welcomed by kids selling souvenirs or coconut and they were pretty annoying forcing you to buy their stuff. Just keep on walking and say thanks, when you stop they will all come offer you stuff. All at once!When you're leaving, you will exit from the same gate, they will do the same thing too. Good luck
one of the highlights. this is one of the highlights and needs to be on any trip - it is busy so if you can try picking your time.

Another great temple. The classic Tomb Raider temple - worth a look but the famous tree now has restricted access so a bit disappointing. This can be busy at times but early or late and there are not many people around. There are better temples in my opinion but this is a must see regardless.
An Indiana Jones-like temple experience. Trees and root systems growing up thmrough crevices, stones, over walls. One of my favorite temples.

Truly stunning!. I have been to hundreds of temples and ruins around the world. Angkor Wat was impressive, but this one really dazzled me!! This is also the "Tomb Raider" temple. Definitely go see it!!

Amazing place that has not been altered very much. This was a wonderful sight with the ruins being torn apart by the tree roots. It was featured in Tomb Raiders but, there are many trees growing on top of the ruins. There are still detailed carvings on the buildings. They did limited changes here to keep it as natural as possible. A must see.

Magnificent!. If you want to enjoy the magnificent views at the Ta Prohm, arrive early in the morning before the large groups and immerse yourself in history and the views of trees overtaking the temple. Simply beautiful..

Nature vs Man. Can you believe all these temples were hidden in the jungle? It is incredible what nature can do. You will be stunned in front of this marvelous temple, reclaimed by nature step by step. Make sure you see it until it's not too late! :) Spung trees are slowly growing under or over it!

My favourite temple!. The temple opens at 7.30 am, we came early waited a little and were the first ones to enter. Waking up early totally worth it. We are pleased with our experience and great pictures!

Man and Nature in Harmony. Another beautiful temple within the jungle. You could close your eyes and believe you too were looking for jewels as was Lara Croft. The wind, the trees and the birds calling in the sky made it all more mystical. But keep your eyes open as there are 100's of tourists looking to photograph the temple made famous by the movie. If you haven't seen the movie you will still be in awe of how the trees have wound themselves around the structure of the temple virtually holding it in place.

Truly spectacular. Magical temple with incredible trees growing around, over and through the ruins. I liked this much better than Angkor Wat. Crowded by a not to be missed experience. The most photogenic place you are ever likely to see.
So Exotic it Feels Unreal. You must see this one, however it's a bit of a walk. Be prepared to take your time and lots of photos.

Best temple of all. The most ruined temple we saw, but it was definitely my personal favorite of them all.There's a certain energy and vibe to the place that you cannot find anywhere else. it's crowded with tourists, so if you can spare an early morning or late evening visit it will be totally worth it. Relax and enjoy the beauty of this place. It's tranquil, grand and amazing all around.
Amazing jungle temple. I liked Ta Prohm the best of all the temples around Siem Reap. The melding of the jungle with the brick work was amazing. Definitely a very peaceful place.

excellent trip to Siem Reap Cambodia, very well explained and visited by all tourists. excellent trip to Siem Reap Cambodia, all the sites of attrations are very well explained and visited by all tourists

Magical. When we visited the beautiful Ta Prohm it was very crowded. It's very popular so my recommendation is try to get there as early as possible in the morning to catch it before the crowds. It will be worth your while. The huge trees taking over the temple are truly a scene out of a movie.

Preserve by nature,. Very unusual help of the Jungle to preserve a Temple, a marriage of human creation and forest to hold and preserve what could have been erased by time...By the way we didn't see Angelina Jolie around, !!!!!!!..
My favorite temple to visit in Siem Reap. Filming site of the movie Tomb Raider, you can see the trees growing out off the temple ruins, many photo opportunities.

Like a Laracroft. It felt like Laracroft embodied me for a while as we explored this place. It is interesting especially learning about how old the trees there already.Outside, the locals are very eager to sell you their goods and souvenirs, so you have to be patient because they will try to persuade you to buy.

Great place, worth a visit. Tomb Raider.Everybody knows about this place. It is really good and absolutely worth a visit. I recommend taking a guide, who can explain everything (the set up, the carvings, the stories etc.)

Crowded but necessary. Yes, it is crowded but at 1200-1300 there are less people around so it is a good time to visit. Most tourists stick to the wooden path where the main sights also are, but it is very well worth leaving the track for short exploring in the other corridors. This is an easy way to find solitude even in the most hectic tourist hours and you’ll find other strangler trees almost just as good as the ones tour groups are herded past. But don’t forget to go the wooden path as well. The main sights ARE worth seeing! AS for alternatives to Ta Prohm – yes there are similar temples but still – there is a special feeling around Ta Prohm that shouldn’t be skipped.

Smaller interesting temple. This is a famous temple because it featured in the Tomb Raider movie and was quite busy when we were there despite it being early morning. It is spectacular to see the way the trees grow on top of the structures. We were there in the dry season so most of the trees had lost their leaves and with it the 'jungle' feeling. It was still awesome. This temple has been badly damaged by nature and man in the past and parts are under restoration. We visited Ta Prohm as part of a Grasshopper cycles tour and our guide Som was so knowledgeable, it was quite a bonus to have him explaining things to us.
Awesomeness!. Simply marvelled at the age and beauty of this temple. It was absolutely stunning and great for photography. Do arrive early before the crowds of tourists for photo taking.

Fabulous . Take a tuk tuk for the day to see more it's worth the money. Go early to avoid the crowds as lunchtime onwards you get coach loads of people and end up queuing. They charge for everything so take your own drinks as it works out expensive. Wear flats.

Great but busy! . If you can get over the sheer amount of people then you can see the gorgeously manicured temple in all of its glory. If you are only looking to see trees growing out of temples you can find much of the same at Preah Khan and Banteay Kdei with far less people.

Tomb Raiders in Cambodia. This was the set for Angelina Jolie's movie Tomb Raider's and it's even better. It's Hollywood and achelology put together and the trees and temple has actually grown into each other.The locals call it the Tree Temple and almost every shot is of a tree and temple locked into each other in a century old embrace.

Impressive, highly recommended. More than the other temples, this one really shows the ravages of time and nature. Very striking, especially to see the trees (and the snake-like tree roots, growing over, and out of, the temple ruins. The attempts to stabilise the ruins are impressive, but look somewhat insignificant against the power of nature.
Feeling like Tomb Raider. This place is very nice. Huge trees, nice spots for your pictures..Just read their rules before going there. Dress conservatively and pose appropriately ☺

Worth Seeing for the Jungle Trees. We visited Ta Prohm in conjunction with a visit to the other nearby temples. The most impressive part of this visit was seeing all the jungle trees (banyans and other types) growing intertwined through parts of the temple complex. Definitely worth seeing.

Magical. This was one of my favourite temples. Trees and their huge roots zigzag between the temple and its stone work, its unlike anything i have ever seen. If you are visiting the temples make this one a priority.

Not as impressive anymore. I visited this temple 8 years ago, but could barely recognize it anymore. It seems like a lot of Buildings have collapsed, and there were not that many evidences of nature taking over anymore.

Take your time, it can be HOT. Amazing place, interesting how international companies are assisting Cambodia with preservation. I found a paper fan for $1 at the pottery school and nearly wore it out on our temple tours - it was very hot. Be respective and dress according to local requirements.

breathless. Breathless is the correct word to describe it, I love Angkor Wat, but this place..is even better, the nature living inside the temple...is..amazing! human and nature power melt together, stunning!!

This is the one!. All the pictures that you've seen, and the reviews you read, will not prepare you for actually seeing and experiencing this temple. Awesome! An absolute must when you visit Siem Reap.

Veggie temple. When the nature get its way back on what the men built it gives a unique sight you can find in Ta Prohm. This temple is beautiful mainly because of the nature which decided to put its touch into the temple.

Gnarled roots grow around the temples. This was probably the busiest temple at Angkor Wat, but also one of the best. There are trees growing out of the temples and enormous gnarled roots that wrap around them. Lots of buildings to explore.
Impressive and intriguing. Massive temples overgrown by trees. The "rooms" enclose a range of different sculpture. An interesting mix -well worth seeing.

more than a movie location. Many people visit Ta Phrom because Angelina Jolie was there. In fact, it is a famtastic temple site, with the buildings and exquisite carvings enhanced by the tree roots often sjating their space. Give yourself plenty of time takeitall in.

absolutely, positively a Must See in Siem Reap!. These jungle, tree root temples are amazing. Of the hundreds of temples in Siem Reap this was my favorite. Bring an extra battery for your camera, some water and be amazed by the tree roots engulfing and toppling these heavy stones that weigh tons. I took hundreds of pictures and could have stayed all day. Luckily they pair this one with Bayon, the smiling face temple and sunrise at Angkor Wat. That is by far the best tour to take.

Try to go early in the morning. This temple gets incredibly overcrowded with tourists and poking umbrellas, so I tend to avoid it when my friends come to visit. It is gorgeous though, so try to go first thing in the morning to beat the crowds.

Eerily exquisite. Of all the temples in or near Siem Riep, this one was fascinating. Abandoned in the 15th century, nature has taken its course created an eerily spiritual place where nature conquers human attempts at immortality. Beautiful.

Amazing temple!. This temple was the most spectacular one in my oppinion! I would recommend our amazing guide Brem Sopheap. He is smart and He is enthusiastic knowledgeable friendly and hospitable. He will always do what he can to add to your experience and has plenty of interesting things to share with you about his country.

My top favorite . Impressive with this temple.. All temples are amazing but ta Promh is my favorite one.. I used to see only in the movie but it is true incredible. Next year i will definitely come again.

INCREDIBLE!. No wonder Ta Prohm was chosen as a location setting for the movie Lara Croft Tomb Raider! With the roots of trees seemingly intent on swallowing the temple, it adds dramatic character to this eerie place. It's totally awesome!!! Being here, my husband said he felt like Indiana Jones with less hair and a bigger belly:)))
Worth a visit . Don't miss when temple hopping. Ta Prohm underwent some impressive renovation work - great to see the difference.

Perhaps the most spectacular Temple. Because this has been left essentially as it was "discovered" in recent times with huge trees growing in and through the temple structures it is perhaps the most interesting site of all. Huge trees, especially the strangler figs have formed a lace work of roots that intersect and at times hold together the very blocks of stone from which the temple is built.

Memory for life. Remember to take with you a good camera. There will be lot of motives. Even if you do not have any intrest in the amasing history of Ta Prohm, you will be busy with your camera. Get there early or late in the day and spend 2-3 hour. Take time. Be patien in spite of all the tourist.
Time and nature. Yes this is it the famous tomb raider temple , displaying the the beautiful forces of nature , trees taking over what man has built.

Historical!. Though I didn't have a photo of the big tree standing on the part of the temple it was still a pretty view without me getting a picture of myself with the tree. It was a peak season for tourists so I rather go and check every corner of it.

Trees took over the Temples. The amazing sight of the numerous tree that basically took over the historic temples. The root of the silk-cotton trees wrap around the temple structure so tightly that it strangled the breathe out of it. Few other Angkor Temples may have the same feature however Ta Prohm is totally covered with the jungle of trees taking our the temples. The movie Tomb Raiders does promoted the temple popularity but seeing the real thing is more exciting than the movie. Recommend time for this temple is as much time allow but not less than an hour. Go with someone to take your picture. Selfie has its limitation somehow in this place.

Must see if in Angkor Wan. There is no other place on earth where architecture blends with nature as in Ta Prohm. It is like a fairytale, the jungle book and everything we dream as a child in one place.

Lara Croft territory!. I have seen pictures of this ancient site and the tree roots! At last, I had the chance. It was incredible! Going through, I can't stop but imagining what Lara Croft did at where....I have to watch the movie again!

Different than the rest. If you are doing a trip through the Angkor park- this is a temple not to be missed as it is different than all the others. Seeing the trees growing over the buildings and the ability to wander and explore are unique experiences.

Personal no2. Iconic with its trees and a must do
I would even suggest coming here before you do Angkor Way as this is one temple that gets highly visited and as a relatively small one with the key images close to the ground, it can be hard to get photos without others on them
Tombrider temple . So wonderful and beautiful temple with big tree on the temple. So unbelievable to see this kind of fabulous. Don't miss this temple of you come down to Siem Reap
Amazing trees. The Jolie Temple as its called here in these parts, due to tomb Raider being shot here. What trees cropping up from everywhere, inc the temple top
Great!. I visited this temple midday. It was so hot and crowds are everywhere. Truly this become the most favorite spot of tourists - a tomb raider temple

Best temple of the lot. If you could only visit one temple at Siem Reap, Ta Prohm would certainly rival Ankor Wat. It is quite different in that this temple is amazingly overgrown, which creates an amazing scene for many photos and memories you won't forget. Beware of large tour groups overcrowding certain sections of the ruins!

It's amazing and beautiful. Every temple has its own uniqueness though it may look quite similar from the outside. This one has lots of big and old trees and it seems the trees are taking over some of the buildings or rather they are dependant of each other to survive.Visitors are made compulsory to wear attires that cover at least till the knees and also the arm as the temples are considered sacred place. Please wear comfortable walking shoes and hats when you visit here. By noon it is very hot and you need to keep yourself well hydrated.

By far my favourite ruin in the complex. This atmospheric structure has an air of mystery. The twisted root growth of these amazing trees are just like it is depicted in Lara Croft. Fascinating and much shadier and quieter than other areas.

Pretty much the best ruins in Siem Reap. the best temple/ruins we saw. make sure you go super early, I think the grounds open up at 7AM, but its best to beat the crowd so people aren't fighting over picture spots. this is literally one of the best things we saw. amazing.

This was our fave temple. Photogenic. . Great photo opportunities with the trees growing in and through the buildings. Crumbling piles of sculptues and building blocks. Quite spread out and less congested than some of the other temples which makes it more peaceful. Look out for the trapdoor spiders to the left. Fascinating.
As always the amenties are distant.
Ancient Overgrown temple. Be prepared to walk alot. Hugh build up. Very old and falling structure being propped up. Some of the path are not even. A lot of steps. Wear comfortable shoes.
Worth the trip. The whole Angkor complex is amazing, and well worth the price of admission and the price of getting a tuk-tuk driver to take you everywhere.

Loved Ta Prohm .. maybe even more than Angkor Wat .... Beautiful temple. There are a few trees growing into the walls left and right which gives it that awesome Tomb Raider feeling. All of these temples have been restored in various degrees (except for a few of them on the jungle route). Weirdly enough "less restored" actually looks and feels better - more real. Or just leaves more to the imagination. The plus is also that Ta Prohm has maybe slightly less visitors or maybe we just went at a better time than the bigger and better known Angkor Wat and Bayon.

Awesome place for photos . Got some great photos. Every temple is unique and all are worth a look. We went without a guide. You can buy a guide book at the temple but make sure you haggle as the sales people put horrendous markup on items.

Magical place. Ta Prohm has a tranquil atmosphere and is cooler than the other Ankor temples due to tree cover. There is good signage and ropes to show the best way to walk. It is removed from the roads and hawkers and is a less hectic experience. I was able to sit quietly and absorb the atmosphere and took some excellent pictures. An inspiring and unique place.

My Favourite of all Ankor. I think because it's in the jungle a bit and therefore there are more trees and shade this place tops the list for me in Ankor. The atmosphere is gentle and calm if you can find a spot out of the crowds ! (Tip: Take the "long walk" )Obviously memories of Tomb Raider are everywhere but there are no obvious commercial links which is nice. There's not much left but the overall effect is beautiful and will stay with you for a long time.Our tuk tuk driver dropped us at the West Gate and we wandered over to the East Gate to meet up with him
tomb raider!. its amazing! ya might have to queue up to get a clean foto but it is of course worth it. the trees growing around the temple are amazing!

Miss Kroft was not there~~~. Ta Prohm was the first temple we visited in Siem Reap area and was incredible and all that we had expected. The site is large and covered with walls, towers, statues and plants. The strangler fig trees certainly do live up to advertisement and are taking over. Beautiful carvings and relief scenes everywhere!! Not wheel chair accessible and you need some decent shoes for walking among the rocks, etc. A beautiful example of an ancient site!!

A tree lovers paradise. This temple is all about the approach. Hopefully your tour guide is as good as mine and takes you the long way...through the woods, enter the temple through a crack in the wall and there it is, the lost temple. The way the environment has taken back this temple is symbiotic in nature given it makes this place one of the coolest I've ever visited. I highly recommend a visit.
One of the wonders of the world. One of the must visit place besides Angkor Wat. The iconic tree growing atop the roof is exactly like the pictures depict.

fascinating. This complex is famous for the Tomb Raider movie and the whole settling is pretty awesome. The trees that have grown through the temple structure are amazing. Be prepared to wait patiently for photo opportunities as there were 1000's of people there doing the same. Well worth the wait and the visit. Take lots of water with you.
incredible. at visit of angkor wat dont miss ta prohm for me it's one of the most impotant one of the siteenjoy your visit
Unbelievable. This place was used for several movies, notably Tomb Raider. Hardly surprising. It is an amazing place, almost as if from another planet.Enchanting and see inspiring.
Wondeful temple.. We are every liked this temple than other temples we saw due we travel in siem reap.We like lots and lots don't forget ask driver and tour guide to bring you visit this temple.

Absolutely stunning. After having visited a few temples in Siem Reap with two young kids, I wasn't really looking forward to another temple. But Ta Prohm is different, the way the forest has grown into the temple structure, it's almost spiritual. I only wished it was less crowded. Definitely my favourite temple in Siem Reap.

Lacked ambiance - follow the tour keader. I had heard and read about this temple and I had expected it to be atmospheric and 'lost' in the jungle.Certainly the trees invading the temple are there but I felt like I was being marched around a circuit which was roped off and board walked. Lost its appeal to me and I just didn't feel it at this temple.Probably my biggest disappointment of the temples in Siem Reap. High expectations which just were not met for me.Hoards of tour bus tourists in quite a small place.

The most wonderful place on the Angkor Tour. This is the temple that we enjoied the most. The Wonders of the history and the Magic of the trees that have been growing for several hundreds of years on the temple-walls.Except for the amount of visitors we had a great experience to look trough this Place. We even met some munks With their Iphones! Hillariuous.
Majestic. One of the temples that you must visit while you are in Siem Reap. I spent nearly as much time here as I did at Angkor Wat. Fascinating how nature intervenes.
Awesome trees. This was the most crowded spot due to it's fame from the movie Tomb Raider so it was hard to get a picture with no humans but it was really beautiful to see. Highly recommend.
amazing roots on temples. The roots growing on the temple complex make for very interesting photos and sights. The temple itself also has many places for beautiful photo opportunities.

Untouched Beauty. Ta Prohm temple, also known as the Tomb Raider temple was mysterious and breathtaking. It has been left untouched by archaeologists except for the clearing of a paths for visitors and some structural support. Everywhere the eye travels there are fig, banyan and kapok trees, their roots, trunks and branches twist through pillars, grow on top of walls, and have intertwined themselves wherever they can.

Stunning. One of our favourite temples - truly amazing the way in which the jungle moved in on the temple. To avoid the crowds do the visit backwards - adds an extra walk but worth it for the peace. Also remember which entrance you came in - both look the same after a hot exploration of the temple and we unfortunately exited the wrong oneOne definitely not to be missed

Beautiful temple. My favourite of the temples that i saw. The tree growing through it is just amazing. aside from all the tourists there with you, you do feel like you are exploring as its mixed within the jungle. its a shame there are a few barrier areas, but you can understand why they are there- to protect the temple. well worth a visit

A remarkable place to visit. Of all the temples, I thought this was the most unique. The ravages of time and neglect have shown that without humans, nature will take over once again. Go early, or the crowds are a bit hard to navigate. A definite must see!
The Tombe Raider temple. Stunning! Amazing how all the trees are now part of the temple. Can get really busy with the tourists so arrive early if you want good photos

Ta Prohm - a highlight of our trip. Must have a Guide - so much to learn about the Temple that a Guide can share. A wonderful experience not spoiled by the crowds of self-absorbed selfie stick owners and people doing poses in any doorway or in front of every tree growing on or near the temple.
The most impressive temple. In my opinion Ta Prohm was the most impresive themple of all the temples I visited. I like it how it was a bit different and more mysterious than other temples.
Amazing temple definitely a favourite. You have to visit this temple to see how nature is claiming it back slowly. It pays to get there early before the crowds arrive. It is stunning

The most photographed Tree in the world.. One of the most interesting site. A must see! However, be prepared to be swarmed by other tourists. We went in the late morning, there were many tourists already. If you want to take a good picture. You probable have to be there early to beat the crowd.
Incredible!. Ta Prohm demonstrates the power of nature. I highly recommend exploring this amazing temple in Angkor Wat.
Ta Prohm my favorite temple. If yobou want to discover the temples is nice to visit first Ta Prohm ... you can see how they where built. The nature is taking back its place ...

Great Photography Spot, For Nature Lovers!. There's something quite mystical and romantic about Ta Prohm besides the fact that it is where the Tomb Raider movie was filmed. The best time to get to Ta Prohm is in the AM before 8.30am if possible. This is to avoid all the crowd later in the day. As it is a temple hidden in the jungle, there's just something quite stunning about the way mother nature and man-made structure intertwine. Not for urban travellers.

It is the image of Angkor I had in my mind. Absolutely wonderful.. Spend more time in the back areas of the temple for some great views and photo opportunities where the crowds and big groups are much smaller and spread out instead of burning out waiting for good shots near the entry. The very far back corners have some elevated places that give you great views of the entire complex and that area has more of the tree roots swallowing the temple with far fewer people trying to get photos.
Temples. One of the more interesting temples to me in Cambodia! I liked the mysterious root growing around the structures, this place is great for photography.

Triphid trees!. Awesome sight - the sight of the trees encroaching on the temple is both scary and awesome... take a good look inside every nook and cranny. You will be surprised at the carvings you find.
Fascinating. Just a great place to see with the trees growing in and through the ruins. This is not an overly large place so it is quite easy to get around and into for some fabulous pictures.

Tomb Raider Temple. Made famous by the movie Tomb Raider, this Temple is spectacular = almost swallowed by the jungle before being rediscovered, the amazing tree roots embrace the temple allowing for some amazing photographs. Would recommend you visit this Temple early in the morning as it can become very crowded. We went back for a second time.

A man-made and natural wonder combined!. I was initially a little skeptical about putting this temple on our shortlist of ruins to visit, as I thought it may be overhyped as the Tomb Raider temple, however really glad our tour guide recommended we include it. The temple itself is in a very poor state of repair, compared to Angkor Wat or Bayon, however what is amazing is the way the trees and their roots are intertwined with the ruins. It is quite spectacular and definitely worth a visit.
Amazing temples and trees!. From all the temples this was my favorite spot for sure. The trees look stunning, its really impressive.

The temple where the movie The Tomb Raider was shot. One of the must see sites during a tourist trip to Siem Reap. It is an old temple complex, where old banyan trees have literally swallowed the temple buildings,

Really cool ruins. As you would know this is one of the sites where the Tomb Raider movie was filmed. The ruins are truly spectacular and it's quite surprising how they got entangled with the tree roots as they have. Another must visit if you are in Cambodia.

WOW!!!!!!!!!!!!. Even thoough it is not a historically important temple, it is a very amazing attraction mostly because of the "nature's revenge" on the building. Trees actually grow in the building walls. Pictures cannot show the real thing. You must see it with your own eyes.

Magnificent. What an awesome experience! I almost felt like Laura Croft in Tomb Raiders! To see the jungle and trees melded with this once- glorious temple was truly a sight to behold. Don't miss this one if you are in the Angkor area!

Must see temple. This temple is quite different in that it has these huge silk cotton trees growing all through the ruins and they have enormous roots that just have to be seen to be believed . It is easy to see why it was chosen to feature in the Tomb Raider film as they are really spectacular and quite spooky .

atmospheric. This particular temple in the Khmer temple complex was made famous as a location in the film Tomb Raider. Roots of banyan trees growing through the stones is something to behold and quite magical.
Temple with old trees. It is amazing to see how nature battles against man-made structures. And the trees win this battle. What gorgeous sights.
More of the same. Maybe I am just templed out but it was lime more of the same. I enjoyed taking pictures of chinese taking pictures more than the temple itself
Visit visit visit. Amazing place I loved every minute discovering this temple. It tends to get very hot so early visit would help but this is a suggestion for all temples really

The trees make this worthwhile. Another site undone by crowds. But the way some of the older trees have gobbled up the ruins is very cool. It was a nice day for a walk and the company was enjoyable. If going to Angkor Wat, tack this temple on to your tour.

My favorite temple. This temple is all about "When Nature Takes Over" because that's exactly what happened here. A tree growing on the top of a temple?!?! Yes! The guide said that the bird dropped a seed and sure enough, a tree grew! What's even more miraculous, are these temples are still standing with these gigantic trees on top! Here was also where a Monarch butterfly landed on me, quite a few times. It was rather majestic and beautiful. There's something to be said about Kingdom of Wonder, it's just miraculous!

The BEST ruins in Cambodia. I would recommend getting here very early. We first experienced Ta Prohm mid day on a guided tour and the place is so crowded that you can't truly enjoy it or get any good pictures. We came back the next day on our own and were among the first to arrive. WOW what a difference! You can truly appreciate the beauty and envision what this place once was. We were able to take pictures of everything possible with no people getting in the way. The more you can get through before 8am the better, as that is when tour groups start coming!
Man v nature. This was one of my favourites in the area, this place shows nature taking back what man has created. So lovely to see! Beautiful!

Tomb Raider. While you are visiting other temples, stop by to see this one. Of course, it is famous for Tomb Raider, and be ready to hear about the movie. However, it is astounding to see these overgrown trees finding their way into the temple.

Fascinating sight. The guide seemed quite hyped about this one. Although we were intrigued by the tree vines and roots intertwined with the temple ruins, the other temples were just as good. The photographic opportunities abound, but be wary of professional photographers and aspiring photographers who may take 10+ shots before you get a turn.
The Tomb Raider Temple - exquisite!. A must see for Lara Croft fans! Beautiful and really tall trees, superb stone carvings, beautiful and mystical.

A favorite. On our tour of SE Asia this was a truly unique temple and we saw a lot of them. The beauty is the jungle reclaiming the temple buildings. The trees actually grow on the temple tops creating an unusual site. Curiously there is a dinosaur carving in one of the walls. There is more shade in this temple area making it more bearable.

Lots of beauty despite the crowds. It was quite a walk there in the hot mid-day sun from Banteay Kdei. Think Ta Prohm is too popular now after that Tomb Raider movie.The crowds were horrendous and made it quite difficult to take photos at certain spots. At one point, I just looked up and took pics of the lovely trees and sky. The rebuilding of the gallery from its ruins is quite amazing. If you have time, look for the head/face in the tree roots and the stegosaurus dinosaur carving :-)

Best Atmosphere!!. I highly recommend this ancient ruin as the iconic trees growing on the rubble and buildings is very photogenic and also creates a mystical atmosphere.There are slight crowds by midday but the atmosphere of Ta Prohm is too good to miss!

Bussing around Cambodia. I've visited most of the temples at Siem Reap during my three visits and this one is my favorite. They're all different but all are amazing. Hired a tuk tuk from and back to the hotel for $15. They're a great way to take in the atmosphere here in Siem Reap.
Temple in roots. A temple that was taken over by the forest and if has been a fight to reclaim it. Wonderful mix of human endeavour and nature's assimilation.

Wow!. This of course is a must- see place. Catch the early morning sun for the best light. Walk away from the crowds to see some stunning sights. You can also walk around the outside walls if not on a tour. That will give you even more chances to see some really amazing history. To me, this is the best place to see. The trees growing over the temples are 300-400 years old, and so huge, pictures do not do them justice.  The sun is really hot in this part of Asia, so be prepared, especially after 10 am. Toilet facilities are in-between the big temple complexes, so plan accordingly, and western styles are available. Foods and drinks can be had outside more temple areas, usually everything is one USD. I did not need to buy local money for 4 days here. Everyone wanted USD. Tickets for all the temples are bought just outside of Siem Reap on the main road to Angkor Wat. $20 for one day or $40 for three days. Children under I think 12 had a discount.

Incredibly atmospheric. My favourite of the temples visited in the Angkor area, seeing the trees growing over the walls, in the mostly unrepaired state is so much better than the repairs going on at the other temples in the area. Be warned it doesn't open until 7:30 in the morning at the moment so you cannot experience sunrise over the temple but it is not far from Srah Srang,a former bathing pool where you can watch the sunrise without the hordes that you get at Angkor Wat

Very fun . Travelers: My family of 6. My husband and I with 4 boys. 17, 14, 12 and 9.We were there on the 20th. The kids enjoyed it. Very pretty. We had already visited Angkor Wat and the Bayon temple the day before.The weather was hot but not unbearable.Lots of people to try to go around to take pictures. But all in all very enjoyable.Very nice.
My favorite temple!!. My favorite temple in siem reamp as I had time to observe and digest the beauty without the rush in angkor want.,

The absolute top. Over run by the jungle and never recovered like Angkor Wat. On several levels this site is a testimony to the expertise of 12th century Cambodians. This must be experienced in the early morning before the sun rises. The sight of the massive banyan trees reclaiming their site and as the sun rises to hear the jungle wake up. The birds, the monkeys and who knows what other animals. And at that time no other tourists. Perfect !
My favourite temple in Ankor Wat. This ancient, historical temple is fascinating and beautiful. Its is where Tomb raider was filmed and is amazing how the trees have grown around the ruins.
My favorite tample. Ta prohm is my favorite tample. There is some inscrutability. Тhere are many areas without people. It`s possible to make nice pictures.

Really worth seeing. Marvelled at the age and beauty of this temple. Would highly recommend visiting this temple and enjoying the atmosphere. Warning: gets hot and there's loads of tourists (me being one of them)

Gorgeous. This temple is gorgeous and is great for photography. It's pretty much unrestored and the roots of trees going around the structure....It's absolutely stunning and incredible. Be ready to climb some steps for this one :)

The trees are amazing, beautiful temple.. What captures me in this place are the trees. Opening hours is at 7.30am if you reach earlier you have to wait outside. Get here as early as possible otherwise it will get crowded with tourist and you won't be able to capture any photos and it gets so crowded it's difficult to move around. The huge white trees around the temple are beautiful and magnificent. If you get a guide they can tell you more about the place, just outside the temple grounds the local people stay nearby and even fish at the ponds in the temple ground.
Doesn't disappoint!. One of my favorite temples here. It's magical!!!! My dream would be to have access to the temple with fewer tourists around to take better photos.

Amazing and strange.. The ways the Fig Trees have entangled themselves in, around and on top of this temple is quite amazing. A must see. It shows how nature is trying to take back the jungle. Take your camera.

Tomb Raider & Temple of doom. . This was awesome. A little bit more left to nature.... So adds to the mystique. A lot of restoration going on.... a good thing. Have your camera and cell ph charged. So many photo opportunities! Wear your joggers. This was one of my fave's apart from Angkor Wat

Simply stunning. If you loved Tomb Raider you will love this temple as it the one they used in the movie. It's more than a movie location though. It's beautiful. It's where nature has decided to take over the temple. It's just a special place to visit. You don't need to be religious to appreciate how special this place is. I recommend to just sit in the temple and take in everything in.Hot Tip: after seeing the sunrise at Angkor Wat drive straight here. (See Angkor Wat another day or in the afternoon) If you do you will have the place to yourself as the bus loads of tourists will arrive as you leave.

So This is the Law of the Jungle. Wow! I have seen nothing like this before – nature taking over man-made grandeur. So this is the Law of the Jungle: clear, strong, ferocious! Seeing all these ancient trees growing out of ancient temples, from all directions and around concrete structures, is like watching the force of nature unleash its power before your very eyes! Amazing! A must-see!

Must Visit. If you visit Angkor Wat, this is a must visit place. I'm impressed by the nature of the trees covering the temples. Came to know from our tour guide Jimmy that is became very popular after the tomb raider movie shoot here. I manage to take lots of nice photographs of this place.

unique experience. Our guide saw to it that we arrived early in the morning, after a gorgeous sunrise at Srah Srang, and we pretty much had Ta Prohm to ourselves. We'd never seen anything like it - tree roots growing on the temple everywhere. We were told that anything dead is removed, but active growth isn't cut. We suggest having an air-conditioned car and driver rather than a tuk tuk or bicycle to get there, unless you have lots of time and don't mind sweating in the heat all day long. We probably overpaid, we didn't bargain, but an air-conditioned Lexus with English speaking driver and professional guide, all to ourselves, was $80 plus entrance fees for the day with hotel pickup and drop-off and worth every penny. Everything in Siem Reap is paid for in dollars, so don't bother getting any Cambodian money. We used tuk tuks in town, $1-2 a trip. The temples are not to be missed, and the more time you have to explore with a guide the better.

For an Indiana Jones experience, Ta Prohm is an essential visit at Angkor Wat. Be patient for the best photography.. Popular for a reason, it can be a challenge to capture views of this temple area. A "sacrifice" temple, letting the jungle grow over the ruins may delight viewers, but the strangler fig trees can rapidly destroy the archaeology of this lovely temple.

Eerie, but natural. My favourite place at Angkor because the overgrown trees give a very surreal atmosphere to the place. Although the drive from Siem Reap can take up to an hour, it is well worth it.

Seeing is believing. I had read about this site & also watched it on National Geographic
It is breathtaking to see how the jungle had taken over the buildings. Huge roots appear to strangle the building. Several spots for great pictures.
Tomb Raider. Along with Ankor Wat another must see. Not as impressive as far as scale or the structures but the trees that are growing out of them

excellent - just missing Angelina Jolie jumping out !. even if we didnt see Angelina Jolie... or Lara Croft here... the temple here was just amazing... the whole complex and tree roots and more, there is a very special atmosphere here... was there one busy am, so returned the following pm before closing time and it was the best time of the day, sun was setting, hardly anyone there and he sounds of the insects extreme !!

Awesome temple. Go at lunch time to avoid large crowds! Beautiful temple! Its easy to get tired of visiting temples in Angkor Wat- Ta Prohm is very different to the others and is a must see when in Angkor Wat!

WOW !. This temple is just amazing the way the jungle has tried to take it back. Early morning is a good time to visit before the rest of us tourists get there. We were almost the only ones there and later it is packed. As in "Tomb Raiders" a must see.
best visited first thing in the morning. gates open at 7.30am. there might be groups at this time but not as many as later. The most atmospheric place in Angkor, imo.

The Jungle Book. This was the most amazing experience of visiting. When we were choosing our route, we decided to go counter-clock-wise of all other streams of tourists and we managed to get to Ta Prohm in the morning when there was no one. That was a real Jungle Book experience. An ancient city lost in jungle and surrounded by giant trees and silence, there were only birds and us... That was amazing.
Stunning temple. There is a lot to see at this beautiful temple! You can spend hours wondering round discovering all he details and just taking in the atmosphere
Amazing. This is a must see, if you are in Siem Reap. It take about one - two hour to see the most importent.
beautiful but too crowded. beautiful, well, basically cos it's where they film tomb rider. tons of people, loud and noisy. but otherwise, pretty

Ta Prohm, our favorite temple in Siem Reap. Ta Prohm was beautiful and very different from any of the other temples in the area. We loved the trees growing out of the rocks and found the whole temple to be very memorable.

WHAT AN AMAZING PLACE!!!!!!!. This is one of the top temples that i truly love...The tree architecture as i call it, is amazing, truly spectacular.....Mother nature really showed off her stuff in this temple, nothing like this anywhere else in the world. Their are stone faces that have grown in the trees....The temple itself is a masterpiece but under a lot of construction jacks becuse of the weight of the tree limbs over the roofs. Unfortunately time will only tell how long these beauties will last.......Highly Recommended.......

My favorite. I actually found eerie Ta Prohm better for photography than the main Angkor Wat complex. The temple was used in the film Tomb Raider and the scenes really did bring out its actual appearance.
Perfect!. I feel like I'm already in the movie, Tomb Raider hahah just kidding! The place and knowing the history of it is already enough for me to be impressed on how amazing these temples are!

Exploring fun. The view from outside was amazing until we got inside! The way the trees have cloaked and become part of the structure are breathtaking. There are so many little passages to explore I could have spent many more hours there.

Our fav temple . After exploring a few of the temples this one became a fast favorite. The structure and the fact that the trees are embedded into the building makes it really original. It's a nice walk around admiring the stone work and plenty of interesting places for photos .

This was our first temple visit. This was the first temple we visited and we were in awe of the wonderment of this amazing structure. We could not believe how intricate the carvings were and the trees over growing the temple were something else. The sheer size and structure of this temple is just incredible.

Pretty cool!. Fascinating! All though this place is made famous because of the movie, really the only crowded area is the main doorway pictured. You can explore the rest of the place with ease. It really is amazing what nature can do.

NATURE AND WONDER. Loved loved loved this temple. The way the trees grow over the stonework of this temple is incredible. This temple is definitely much more than just a location from the film Tomb Raider. If I ever go to Cambodia again I will definitely be returning to this temple. My favourite (Bayon coming a close second). Travelled July 2012 (but won't let me select that date).
Amazing. Great temple with lots to see. Enjoyed seeing the mix of nature and ruins. It was fun to explore all the buildings and felt very Indian jones.

Beautiful temple with growing trees. This is the temple where all the tourists visit. Famous from the Tomb Raider movie amongst other movies.
Visit early in the morning to avoid tourists and hurry as the temple is deteriorating with the trees dying also.
Enjoy!

A unique experience. This was one of the more religious feeling temple. It was amazing to see the falling bricks perfectly arranged as if we were the first person seeing it after 1,000 years. This is a definitely must when seeing Angkor Wat.

More than just Tomb Raider!. We visited first thing in the morning and had the temple with just a few other people for the first 30-40 minutes. It was spectacular. Although we had seen all the photos, it was more beautiful and mysterious than we imagined. We revisited Ta Prohm a few days later in the afternoon, and it was packed with tour buses and simply was not nearly the same experience. GO EARLY, when others are still at Angkor Wat.

My absolute favourite. This is a true place for being blown away. A ruin cant get better than this. Blown away but the history and simply the current being of itself. Nature is taken over and claims its territory back. Loved it.
One of our favourites!. Beautiful to see the ancient ruins being dominated by these mammoth trees. Very authentic and shows its age! Recommended- GREAT photos

Ive never seen tomb raider. Didnt have any expectations going to see this temple, I often dont google things I prefer to discover in person. I havent seen the movie and our driver just told us 'temple in the forest'. WOW. This temple was so beautiful and its sad but amazing that nature is slowly destroying it. Such an amazing sight to see and my favourite. Shame about the crane I wanted to get closer to some spectacular carvings but oh well. We went late morning and it wasnt crazy busy. But I would reccomend early morning if you can.

The name bigger than the temple. Ta Prohm is a very famous temple, probably more because of the movie rather than the temple itself. It has got a lot of old trees. But it has not got the scale like Beng Mealea or Preak Khan. Hence, I was kind of disappointed about this temple.

Awe inspiring strangler fig riddled ancient marvel.. Never tire of visiting this temple. Morning and evening offers the best light for the best photographic hues. Over the past 5 years, you can walk on less of it, but I guess that's good for preservation huh? Never fail to remember Angelina Jolie strutted those magnificent thighs of hers here while filming Lara Croft. Oh yes baby!

Out of this world. Ta Prohm is easily the best temple in the Angkor Archaeological Park. If you don't have much time, you may just see the exterior of other temples and skip, but for this one going inside is a must! It will be better if you visit this place when there are few visitors, so that you can feel the mystical aura.

Must see!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!. I really love tomb raider film that's why I come to see this temple but it's even more beautiful to see with your own eye then in the film you must see this temple even you not in to tomb raider.
Tree temple. This was a fun place as it has not been cleaned up and the trees are still in place. It was in the movie "Tomb Raider" and very recognizable. Not as many visitors too.

Simply Amazing. one of the must visit temple if you come to the Angkor complex. Its so different with the other Angkor, it feels magical inside the Ta Phrom. You wont regret it to come here. But it also confusing to find a way out if you come from the west side and wanted to go out at the east side

Best spot at Angkor. Cool with the trees eating the temples. Recomend renting mountainbikes. We did that for 3 days which was perfect for seeing both the small circut and the big circut. 40 dollars each. Popular spot so many, many tourists. Make sure you have some spare money for the mucisians that suffered from mine injuries. The only way for them to make money and dont have to beg.

Atmospheric 'Indiana Jones' type temple a must see. This is the temple half strangled by huge trees growing over and around the walls and shouldn't be missed. Time your visit for early or late in the day as the temple interior is tiny and can be unbearably filled with large tour groups shuffling along and taking interminable selfies so that it's difficult to take any photos of the actual temple!
Temple in the jungle . Another stunning temple to visit...here is where tomb raider was made...very impressive...the nature takes over the uman creation!

Favourite temple. Really loved this temple, the trees, the walk to the temple , it really is a special place with a special feeling about it. If you have young kids say 4 and up and only wanted to do one temple with them I would choose this one.
wonderful. most people go here because of the tomb raider films , but even if you are not into tomb raider it still is a must to see

Do look at the temple carvings too!. This popular site has also been nicknamed The Tomb Raider Temple, after the eponymous Lara Croft film was set there. It is impressive, although it was odd that visitors seemed more interested in the banyan trees growing out of the walls rather than the impressive masonry. Admittedly, it is very atmospheric. It is also interesting to learn that the French, who first began conservation efforts, decided to leave the trees to run rampant when they are clearly still damaging the structure. So visit while there is still the opportunity!

Indiana Jones. This temple was different from the other temples we have seen. The temple has not been completely cleared for trees and other growing plants. Indiana Jones must have recorded some movies at this place, I guess.You'll have to see this one! The sight of the temple constructure with climbing trees are unbelievable.Highly recommended.Look for more reviews by MulleEllum.

Best views of trees strangling the temples!. Must-see if you want to be saddened but fascinated by the way three different species of trees are destroying the exquisite temples of the Angkor area. This is the "Tomb Raiders" Temple, and the temple itself is not the reason to visit. It's the trees, which have literally lifted stones out of the ground.

Very crowded and a maze. Unlike a lot of other temples where you are just allowed to wander the temples on this one you have to follow the path which we found to be a maze. You enter on one side and go through to the other which we didn't think was the easiest until we had some help. It is amazing how the trees have grown up and taken over the temples over hundreds of years after the temples were abandoned. One of the fabled temples that is often photographed.
Nature Interacting with Man's Creations. The "Trees" Temple gives a good idea of how nature takes back what humans leave. Like something out of Disney's "The Jungle Book", only real.

Busy!. Visited Ta Promh a few years ago and the change in tourist numbers is staggering. Nothing to do about this of course and good to see tourism is growing but certainly takes away from any sense of mystique.
