Having said that, the teenagers we were travelling with still thought all the tree roots growing over it were pretty cool.

This is the Angkor of your imagination. This is "the" temple of the complex, the one you have always had in your impression of Angkor. Spookily overgrown with vegetation and trees, calls of parrots in the trees etc. This is a Raiders of the Lost Ark set if ever there was one!

Amazing architecture overgrown with tree roots - very atmospheric. Ta Prohm, the setting for Lara craft Tomb Raider movie is an awe inspiring place. The sense of ancient civilisations and the march of time is powerful. We made two visits, one in the middle of the day which was crowded and difficult to photograph because of the number of visitors. The other was very early in the morning specifically for photography and this enabled us to take photos from good angles. The north gate of Ta Prohm is not visited as much as the main body but there are good sights to be seen here of carvings.

Loved this temple .... How amazing is this temple, it was the second most impressive temple after Angkor Wat. It has an atmosphere about it that the others simply do not have, with the amazing trees, bird life and location of this temple.
Amazing. Amazing Site! It is famous because of the movie Tomb Raider and definetly the most crowded site in the Angkor area. Nonetheless, don't miss it!

Easily the most crowded site at angkor. Of all the temples at the Angkor site, Ta prohm, or the ‘tomb raider temple’, is probably the site where the tourists are most densely packed. At almost all the temples you are free to just wander around whatever way you want, but at Ta prohm, even if you are not part of a tour group, there is a definite flow pattern to the tourists and deviating from it is not easy. Most visitors head to the right as they approach the main building (following the ‘way of visit’ signs) and then enter the main temple by deviating left again. After traversing the main building you then exit at the back. By turning right as you exit at the back, you can then walk around the side of the temple and this is where the famous ‘Ta prohm tree’ is located. Nowadays, there is a line of people waiting to be photographed in front of the tree. The line is on an elevated boardwalk, and when you finally get to the front of the line you cannot get right up to the tree itself. When we visited (mid afternoon) the line was about 40 people long. Note: if you don’t want to wait: there is an equally impressive tree at Preah Kahn that you don’t need to line up to be photographed with, and you can get right up to it. We went against this flow of traffic by not entering the main building at the front, and walking around to right, going immediately to ‘the tree’, and around to the back of the building intending to go into the back door. BUT this was a mistake because there was a guy at the back door stopping people entering the ‘wrong way’. Because most people go through the main building, or to the right side (as you approach it from the main entrance), the left side is relatively peaceful and much less crowded, and here you get a real feel for how nature has reclaimed the temple over the last 500 years. It is extremely atmospheric in places on this side, and I imagine if you get a time in the day when there are fewer visitors it would be the same all over. In some places the view was distinctly marred by the presence of an enormous yellow crane. For me it was the least enjoyable of the temples we went to.

Architecture meets jungle. Since the movie Tomb Raider came out I've had a fascination with this jungle reclamation of this famous temple. It is truly stunning to visit and over the course of 4 trips to Cambodia over the last 3 years I have always made sure to revisit this temple - and view the restorations that have been taking place but without modernising the character of the original temple.

The best. This is the most authentic and atmospheric part of the ankor wat experience. Not to be missed.It has the rather superficial distinction of having been featured in a hollywood movie, but it is the sense of passing time and the spirituality that grabs you despite the thousands of people there with you. For me it is the heart and soul of those lost times.

worth it!. If you are short on time, the 3 temples you must visit should be Angkor Wat, Bayon and Ta Prohm,It is amazing to see the trees interwined with the stones.Was proud to see Indian Archaeological Society help in the restoration of this monument.Our guide explained how there was a debate whether to keep or clear the trees, which may fall on the temple structure.Lot of places to take the picture featured in the Tomb Raider moview

Picturesque. Absolutely stunning. A place to let the imagine run wild on what it used to be and how amazing it was. Be prepared, sadly, for the selfish tourist who has to have 20 shots in the one spot.

The famous Ta Phrom - Angelina Julie's Tomb Raider shot. One cannot miss where Angelina Julie made a shot at the entrance of this temple. Very evident and set from the other temple is the big fig tree growing on its entrance.

FAVORITE TEMPLE. Yes, I even liked it more than Angkor Wat. It was interesting to explore, fun and Indiana-Jones-like, and the trees are amazing. I would highly recommend going with a guide to get more information, and also so he can show you interesting things not on the main route.

Better known as the tomb raider temple. This is another one of the impressive temples in the area. It is the one that was featured in the tomb raider film. It is very interesting how the trees have grown through many parts of the temple. Definitely worth a visit.

Raider's of the lost ark. If you love the movie...this one's for you. It is rather small compared to most complexes and very very crowded. You'll find it difficult to take a photo without other people in it.

Just like in the movies. Pity about the harassment from hawkers.. Ta Prohm can't be missed when visiting Siem Reap. It was my husbands favourite temple. Once I died the temple you feel at ease and there is a mystical presence. Unfortunately we had to run the gauntlet when we arrived as surrounded by hawkers. This was particularly confronting for our children.
Tomb Raider. The tree that made it famous by Tomb Raider was about 400 years old. A breathtaking location with lots of over growing trees that overtaking the temple.
Fantastic - a highlight!. Amazing temple! We visited twice during our trip - the second time at 5:30am which was magical! This a temple NOT to be missed on your visit to Siem Reap.

Holy trees!. This temple must be in the top 5 of your list of temples to visit. It is beautiful, peaceful, and the trees are amazing. It's amazing to see how the trees have grown through the stones. Having a tour guide is VERY helpful. We were able to get there before a lot of the crowds, which made this experience more enjoyable.

One of the best view on earth. This temple looks pretty old but it's still beautiful by its beauty ! It's surrounding by the jungle and u will see a big big tree ...! Imagine like you were walking in the jungle then u see a temple with nautre and a big tree on the temple , it's so tall and big ..!

Beautiful place. As with the other temples take lots of water and comfy shoes. This was my favourite of the Siem Reap temples. Nature and man made buildings intertwined. Go with a guide who will explain the carvings and tell you the history behind this remarkable place.

Amazing temple and trees. One of the must-see temples. Truly amazing to see the way the trees have enveloped the ancient temples and ruins. Nice to see some investment going into the reconstruction of some parts.

Mysterious. Although it's only trees and broken building and rocks around. This place is beautiful like heaven. Amazed by the super tall tress and the roots tied around the walls are such adorable nature sight seeing. Unfortunately most of the buildings are collapsing and maintainance are needed. I'm not sure if Ta Prohm can be maintained well like now. Quickly go and visit this place before the building collapsed.
A glimpse into nature controlling mankind.. This beautiful temple built 1000 years ago has been over run by the jungle. Huge trees attach themselves and grow out of the stone structure.

Great ruins. Definatley worth while visiting as the temple is unique with the tree roots over growing. To get to it from the entrance is a 5-8 minute flat walk on a sandy dirt base. Markets are near the car park area and very cheap if you are good at bargaining. Same items that can be bought in Siem Reap itself but I found it cheaper at the temple.

Fabulous. Last if 4temples visited in a day, but by no means the least, obviously made famous by Tomb Raiders film, but the way the trees grow out if the stone work is amazing, was quite quiet when we visited at the end of the day which made for better photos
One of the best. Absolutely fascinating temple with giant trees and roots growing everywhere. There were queues of tourists waiting for their photo to be taken by the famous doorway.

Mystical. The ruins overgrown with trees and tree roots give this place a distinctly mystical feeling. I could have spent a couple of hours wandering and finding places for cool photos. However, our tuk tuk driver gave us 1 hour, so that's how much time we spent wandering through this temple (we had several temples on the itinerary for the day). The prime photo spots are very popular for photos, so be prepared to stand in line with the crowds.

Our favorite temple. We found this temple to be the most interesting and enchanting. The trees make it surreal. We went late in the afternoon when the sun was shining in such a beautiful way with the birds chirping ever so hauntingly between the enormous trees that have taken over the temple walls. Definitely don't miss this one!

Must see, don't miss at any cost. I strongly suggest a good screen lotion and good shoes.
I live in Brazil, and never seen such amazing trees.
Hope you can survive the crowds... get there as early as you can.
Probably you can avoid the local guides, but read a little about it.

This is the best part!. I know AngKor Wat is the famous temple... but I think we enjoyed this location much better. The overgrown trees are very interesting and best part... it is shady so we are not baked under the sun!

A lifelong dream!. It was stunning, better than I ever could have imagined. We spent a late afternoon here which is stunning for the light and the dappled shadows of the trees, but it was still quite a busy time. Be prepared to q up for a picture with the 'famous' trees. I would recommend bypassing these if they are busy and exploring the quieter areas, often a big tour will rush through getting the snap that they want and then their are peaceful interludes to enjoy the nature. We also went their just after sunrise and that was bliss, it was so peaceful, so quiet, chances for some great photography, to enjoy the light and the power of nature taking back. At about 11 it proceeded to get absolutely crazy with large tours pushing and shoving to get a 'selfie' with the fig tree, at which point we left!
Lost in time. Stunning temple buildings lost for centuries. Strange remarkable growths of trees over buildings. Outaide the vendors children sold everything for a dollar, to start with.
NATURE VS ARCHITECTURE. The temple is the one where they did not removed the trees from the ruins. It is impressive indeed how the nature takes over!

Entering a different kind of world. The first thing my friends told me bout this place is yup, Tomb Rider scene. lol. Actually it is more than that. The area was mesmerizing. Architectural design, the scenery, are awesome.

Film location . As were staying in Seim Resp it was good to see the location of the film Raiders of the Lost Arc and too see the ruins of the temples and the ginormous trees growing in and around the ruins
Original Angkor Wat. A Must go, so you can see what it is like before this ancient city had been discovered 400 years ago.
The power of nature. This was a truly amazing temple to visit, where you see the power and majesty of nature intertwined literally with the fabulous temple ruins. A must visit when in Cambodia

Ta Prohm is a unique temple. adorned with stone elephants, Ta Prohm is unique in the massive stretch of ruins left behind by the Khmer Empire. You can climb virtually to the top, but be careful about it and if you don't like the original stone stairs, there's a new easier staircase on the right hand side
Simply stunning. Jaw dropping scenery straight from Indiana Jones, best visited early to see this incredible place in the soft morning light,
Tomb Raiders. This was the temple featured in Angelina Jolie's movie, Lara Croft. The trees' roots even made the temple more unique.

My Favorite Temple Ruins out of the All of the Temples in Angkor Archaeological Park. This temple ruin was the place where Lara Croft: Tomb Raider movie was filmed. It is definitely the most eye catching temple ruins in the entire Angkor Archaeological Park!! Imagine seeing huge 500 over years old trees growing out of the temple ruins! Unfortunately, when I was there...escavation works are already in progress to remove all these beautiful trees. This project will be completed within 2 years. So when you go to Ta Prohm in 2018, you will no longer see these Sprung trees growing out of the Ta Prohm Temples :-( I don't know whether this is good or bad...but the uniqueness of this place will be gone. I mean - most people remember Ta Prohm as the place where there are tall Sprung trees growing out of the temple ruins right? I was here from 8am to 9am. This temple ruins is not very large. And with a private guide and car, you can visit the important parts of the temples and skip the uninteresting parts.Important Reminder:Be prepared to walk and walk...and walk! Thankfully with the private car/driver, I didn't have to walk that much ;-) My driver drove all the way inside the complex to pick me up when I told my private guide my legs hurt. P.S. Check out one of the pics I posted regarding the dress code when visiting the temples.

You must see it, if you are Lara Croft's fun. Well, the title says but this site fascinating from view of trees and roots growing from walls of the temple. Go there in early morning and you will have a chance to snap photo without someone photobombing it...

A must-see in the entire archaeological park. Sure, everyone knows Angkor Wat, but this has to be the most famous as the setting of Lara Croft: Tomb Raider. And it is quite a sight to behold. The temple seems as though it is being consumed by the trees in the area and I sure hope that they are able to preserve it for future generations.

Busy. It's famous for being famous - trees growing over the ancient buildings. It's heaving with tourists at all times and actually one of the more difficult to orientate around. Go very first thing when it opens.....
Fascinating. The set of tombraider comes to life when you visit here. The trees seem to balance precariously within the temple walls. Quite a sight.

Trees take over the temple. From what I gather, this is one of the most popular temples, although we did not have time to see more than the top three (Ta a Prohm, bayon wat, and Angkor Wat) and I can see why.The trees that dominate this temple give it an eerie feeling. It is a beautiful representation of the amount of time these temples were abandoned for and the power of nature.Prepare yourself for crowds. We started calling this the Photobomb Temple, because it was happening all the time.
It was left as when it was discovered. This one is special because it was left in thr original state it was found to prove the power of nature. Unique special place.

It is more than just the Tomb Raider Tree. There are a number of examples of the tree roots in the temple. Thei impact on the structure is interesting. It is one of the few temples you can visit that you can explore the temple rumble and imagine what it was like to find a temple that was not maintained.
Huge trees. When you visit here, you will see many huge trees. I would say they are the hugest trees I have seen. Wonderful!

Beautiful!. Had never seen the movie, but still wanted to see this temple. The majestic trees attempting to take over are awe inspiring. Beyond the trees there are many great things to experience including the room that echoes, the detailed carvings, and the mysterious feel it has in general. If you go during a busy time, wait a few minutes for the crowd to pass, as most tours do not stay very long. There are many opportunities to take pics in front of trees and many unique lighting experiences for the avid photographer.
Our favorite in the Angkor group. Overgrown, with trees growing through and around ruined sections Ta Prohm temple has a warm, even sacred feeling we did not find in other temples.

Marvelous. Don't miss. Amazing combination of the huge trees and the temple. Extra ordinary built together this temple gives you the feeling you are the first to discover it under the jungle trees. We came an hour before sunset which added to the magical feeling. Unforgettable.

Must must. Try to go early in the morning around 7-8am to avoid crowds.. normal tours will arrive after visiting angkor wat and it will be impossible! the temple is beautiful and with the trees "invading" the effect is great!
Unusal Temple and Tree Tangled Together. We got to Ta Prohm early in the morning after sunrise to avoid the crowd. It is a very beautiful place and different from other temple in Angkor Wat.
Great ruins. Enjoyed very much. Would recommend going early or late, lots of tourists. Make sure you find the hidden buddha face in the tree roots

The popular "tomb raider" temple. I guess its a must visit temple due to the movie. The distinctive trees make every photo shoot photogenic and atmospheric.I love the history behind each and every temple.

Ta Prohm. Tour guide calls it the Angelina Jolie Jungle, from the movie Lara Croft. A very unique site with trees extended down to the ground. Lots of tourist, but if you get a chance to take a picture with those trees, try the iPhone panoramic vertically - a trick our tour guide took some great pictures.

One of the several highlight of Siem Reip!. Don't miss your walk through this amazing and ancient site, and wonder at how the 'jungle' has taken it over. it's essentially a ruin, in process of being saved, and made famous by Angela Jolie's Tomb Raider movie. Fabulous!!
Love. Love love love . This is a must see when doing the temple visit . The only problems I found was that there not enough information around the temples describing built dates etc....
Go early . We got there as the grounds opened and it was beautiful. With the peacefulness pre tour groups you get really experience this unique place. A must visit in Siem Reap
Amazing. Loved the way nature overwhelmed the stones. The trees are the main attraction. The 'Jungle Temple' should be on must do list when arriving at Siem Reap.

My favorite temple. Ta Prohm was my favorite temple in the mini circuit. Yes, it's known as the temple that Angelina filmed Tomb Raider in. BUT, if your tuk tuk driver does the tour correctly, he should take you here first thing in the morning, when it is not crowded. My bf and I went right after the sun rose over angkor wat, and we basically had the entire ruins to ourselves. This made for such a relaxing experience and great photos. Bring sunblock and wear appropriate clothing please!
Quite Extraordinary. A temple taken over by the Trees...you couldn't make it up. Stunningly beautiful, haunting and great memories from a bygone civilisation.
Beautiful place. Beautiful place but very crowded. Even in winter is very hot so better is to plan a visit not for noonday...............

Interesting to see nature and the temple in an arm wrestle. This one is much more decrepit but that is also part of it's appeal. The trees growing though the temple walls look straight out of a Hollywood adventure film. There was a que to take a photo at the base of the main tree, but I found the photos really good from slightly further onwards, further along the platform (more perspective).
Fall still and take in nature. We got to Ta Prohm early in the morning, whilst still dark. To sit quietly and see how the temple and trees come alive as the sun rises is an experience of a life time.

Jolie Good. Forget all the references to Tomb Raider, this sight would amazing even if it hadn't been used for the movie. To see the tree roots which have been left to take over the temple is simply stunning. Try to avoid the crowds, go early and take plenty of photos.

Mysterious & Magical - Not to be Missed - Especially at Dawn. While thousands of tourists made a beeline for Angkor Wat before sunrise, I asked my tuk-tuk driver to drop me off at Ta Prom at 5:00 am.Mind you, I had arrived in Siem Reap the evening before and had no idea what lay ahead in the Angkor Archeological Park. I learned that morning at those early hours, it was pitch black and I had no flashlight on me. Luckily a few sunrise worshippers arrived at the same time so I followed their light to the front of Ta Prom. What a way to start my visit to Angkor.As the sky lightened, Ta Prohm slowly appeared like magic. The giant tree roots that grow over the temple added to the mysterious surrounding. As I walked deeper into the ruins, I was enchanted by the carvings and the structures. Before the visit, I had thought there was only one tree that grew over the ruins, but the number was endless.It was the best way to start my visit to Angkor. Tips: Try to get there before sunrise and explore the ruins before hords of tourists arrive.
The Jungle Book LIVE. Amazing, spectacular but too many tourists at the same time.... It ruins the experience unfortunatly but the site remains a sheer beauty and wonder of the world!A must see

My favourite. After visiting all of the restored parts of the Angkor complex I found this temple the most interesting. Because it is fairly untouched it is easier to imagine how incredible the find must have been all those years ago, and of course shows the power of nature to reclaimed the jungle despite humanity's efforts. The giant trees are stunningly beautiful.From a practical side - its the same as all the Angkor complex - the morning has more people but less heat and the afternoon has less people but more heat. Your choice.
Best temple . By far the best temple next to Bayon, which I saw at sunrise. I visited this twice and one more just sat there for hours, soaking up the scenery and journaling. A must see in Siem Reap!

Mesmerising. Known as the Angelina Jolie tomb raider temple. Can totally understand why the movie was shot here. The temple is now being restored in cooperation with the Indian government, a long process already underway for 11 years. A must do.

Tree temple one of the best. Trees are taking over this temple and it makes for an eerie, but fantastic experience. Much of the interior is in ruin, but there is apath marked out to follow and the huge trees that have grown from within the walls to send their roots out in all directions are quite wonderful to see. One of my favourite temples and well worth a visit.
One of the highlights of the trip to Cambodia. Ta Prohm does not disapoint - it is full of mystery and magic - just a fabulous place to visit and immerse yourself in history

Tomb Raider. Made famous by the Angelina Jolie Movie, this is the most famous temple in Angkor Wat- apart from Angkor Wat itself. There are some areas which have been restored using the original stonework, pretty amazing considering a lot of it was just piles of random rocks! The only downside of its fame are the huge number of tour groups, a lot of them from china and very very loud !

Temple jungle. You can't avoid the masses of tourists here and it will be hard to take a picture without strangers, but I still found it worthwhile to visit this temple. It's really spectacular to watch how jungle tries to take over these ancient temples - even if you don't like Indiana Jones.

tomb raider temple. lots of people know this as the tomb raider temple - hence the large number of tourists. Its tough to get pictures of the temples with the trees/roots etc and just yourself and no pesky tourist in the middle - a lot of patience and strategic positioning is needed. Its worth visiting just to see how nature ran amok with these temples once they were semi- abandonded

Amazing mother nature. All temples do look alike but this place is about nature vs man made structures. Its an awe how the great trees and their roots has invaded this ancient structure and how they co-exist now. The greenery on the concrete is amazing when you snap a good shot on camera. But yet again, you will not capture the tranquility of the space with those noisy groups of tourist from you know where...! My wife and I tried to get a shot on camera with the help of another kind guide. But they came some elderly women and shove us out of our frame and they were trying to get a picture on my camera. Weird!
Early morning favorite. We went to this temple in the early morning of our second day, just after sunrise, and it was just Magical! Best temple in our 3-day visit

Overwhelming number of people. I was most excited to go to Ta Prohm but it was just too overrun with people. It's a smaller temple so with the amount of visitors there, it was impossible to get any decent photos (most were unwilling to wait 5 seconds for others to snap a shot). It was beautiful but a lot of stuff is blocked off and you aren't free to roam around like at most of the other temples (though I'm sure this is what will happen at all of the others to prevent more damage to the temples). Definitely go check it out but keep your expectations low.

Beautiful temple from Tomb Raider movie.... This temple was beautiful...lots of amazing trees and the loudest cicadas I have ever heard! It was wild, we thought it was a siren. Had a great time taking pictures here and exploring the temple ruins.

Wonderous nature. Ta Prohm was wonderful. The walk from the drop off point to the temple was beautiful with evidence of nature winning the fight with structure. This temple should be on your definite list and one our party enjoyed the most.

Time took over. The beauty of this temple is the time who took over.Rajavihara, was the real name. Unlike most of the temples, Ta Prohm was left in "nature" condition, the way they found it. Photographic atmosphere with the trees growing out of the ruins plus the jungle arround, make it popular with visitors, but the "take my photo in front" is creepy for me. People forget, this is a temple, still... I enjoyed more the respect in my visit 15 years ago.

Worth a look, good for when it's hot. You can see it all in about an hour. Shaded by beautiful old trees which are taking over and slowly destroying the temple. Wear good closed shoes as it's very sandy.

Jungle Takes Back . Loved Ta Prohm the most out of all the temples. So distinctive with the buttress roots forcing their way through the ancient site. It's an amazing scene to see the temple & forest meeting & witness the destruction of the temple with it's invasive roots. Efforts are made to slow this down & restore the progress of the forest but not sure who is winning. Very crowded & you do have to keep reminding yourself to be patient if you wish to take photos. Queuing traffic of people waiting to get photos in front of the famous Tomb Raider sites but be patient & all is worth it.

The iconic tree! . The trees here are all very large, dating back hundreds of years easily. It is a lit bit of a walk back from the road compared to the temples in the area. But the amount of trees and sheer size is worth it!
simple beautiful and crowd. the nature and the buildings are simple amazing, but it`s so crowd of tourists that is almost impossible take a picture without someone else

Do this first to beat the crowds. A friend said to do the three main temples in "reverse" order e.g Ta Prohm, Bayon and Angkor Wat last. We didn't as I wanted to see sunrise and I wish I had. Photo opportunities were not great as the temple is intricate and narrow and full of tour parties so maybe heed the advice of my friend! It's beautiful and would be worth it

Amazing Place. The trees growing on the temples are something else. We had a great guide 'Peng' who took us at the quietest time and snuck us through doors and pathways to avoid other visitors and get some special snaps.

Trees are claiming the temple site!. We visited Ta Prohm as part of our 2 day visit to the Angkor Wat Archeological site. This temple complex was built in dense jungle which is reclaiming the site since it was abandoned hundreds of years ago. This is the only temple which has numerous huge trees actually growing over the ruins of the complex. You will recognize it from popular movies like Tomb Raider. The trees are slowly destroying the temple with roots separating the stones which comprise the temple. As with the other parts of the Angkor Wat park, expect huge crowds and hot and humid weather -- even in the winter. Bring water and a hat -- but don't miss this site!

Every Site Is Much Interesting If You Read And Have Knowledge. It is simply a site with hugh tree rooted to the rocks. That's it. If that is enough to caught your fancy and awe, good. But if you add aome more info, read a page or two about the site, the more you will become engrossed and in love with it.Tip: as a primer, visit the Angkor Natl Museum first before touring around temples. The museum is comprehensive yet presented in a way that is easy to follow and would not consume long hours (or tons of pages). There are also peddlers selling books, you can haggle for $5. Or if you prefer a tour guide, you can also do so.I chose to visit the museum and got a copy of the book. It saves me time considering my visit is short and have to squeeze in all possible destinations. I do reading before or after each site. Sometimes, i visit the book when at the hotel resting. :)

Battle of man v nature. Loved this temple. Man built, nature destroyed, man is rebuilding!Some great photo opportunities, the trees are spectacular.Make sure you know which gate your tuktuk will be waiting at!
Giant roots and ancient structures. I was in for a surprise when I saw giant roots imposing its way on structures. Great views and powerful images from man and nature!

Go early, early, early. Our guide wanted us to head out early for our tour. The tour usually starts at 8:30 and had us start at 6:30. We had gotten in late the night before and agreed since this was booked after we got in at 10:30 pm. We didn't argue since at least we got a tour booked.We're we ever glad we did. There was no one at the ticket counter and within 10 minutes we were touring this temple ( the site of the movie Tomb Raider).We were practically alone there, got great pics, were able to take our time.We visited 2 sites that morning and headed back for a 3 hrs break at 9:30 because our guide told us the rest would be too busy till 12:30.On the road out we saw how right she was. It was jammed pack at the ticket counter, bumper to bumper taffic going in.Guide was booked with Indochina tours and our guides name was Mom Traypich ( she freelances) She is an avid photographer, knows her stuff and spoke excellent English, but does choose her customers. If you would do a 6:30 am tour you will have priority with her.

Nature and Man - Wow!. Likely the most photographed structures in all of the greater Siem Reap area, Ta Prohm is a sight to behold. I have been captivated by the trees devouring the buildings since I was a child and then seeing them finally for real was amazing! The Spung tree owns the buildings upon which it stands, but without the buildings, they would have no support. While the building is not organic, I saw the relationship as more symbiotic and not parasitic. Of course you will visit Ta Prohm, right? I mean, hellllooo? You will love it when you go despite the crowds that throng the place.

Must, must, must!. It is one the place in the whole world that really thrilled me. It is like visiting a secret ghost town, and frankly - it is nothing to do with Tomb Raider. is a remarkable place itself. Just plane a long visit to enjoy.

Enjoyed visiting Ta Prohm. After visiting a few other temples, we came here over lunch time. It was quieter to walk round and seeing the jungle reclaiming the land was impressive. Spent an hour or so walking round and taking photos without the crowds. Probably one of our favourite temples!
Nice . Amazing Temple with all the trees. It is a pity that it is so full of people. Second populair temple in the area.

Simply AMAZING !!. No words can describe the feeling you will get when you see this temple complex. This temple in 10 mins walk from main entrance, it is located in once supposed to be a dense forest still have a spooky feel to it. I cant explain the feeling I got when I saw banyan trees equivalent to 10 storied building growing over temple buildings. DO visit this place as it is one of the untouched ruins you can find in the world. Take water bottle and cap as by the time you will visit after seeing other temples it would be day time and sun heat might take a toll on you.
Move over Lara Croft. Another amazing part of the Angkor Wat complex. Make sure you visit this site to see the fabulous architecture and the way in which nature has retaken the environment.
Tomb Raider. If you have seen the movie, a scene was done under one the trees here. There are even nicer trees than the one in the movie!

A Khmer King really loved his mother!. Fascinating to read why this was built. And also interesting is to see how the jungle attempted to reclaim the site after it was abandoned about 600 years ago. A visit could be combined with Angkor Thom.

An absolute myst. Yes go and see this site! Try for early morning before the crowds come. We spent 2 solid hours walking around and enjoying this lush, overgrown ruin. Evokes memories of Hollywood movies, but an absolute must do on the temple circuit.
Temple of Movie/. Very beautiful temple with big tree. cold and nice to walk around and taking great picture of this temple.

Certainly one of the "must see" temples in Siem Reap. Ta Prohm can get horrendously crowded, so a good time to visit is early morning to beat the crowds. While everyone is at Angkor Wat watching the sunrise, visiting Ta Prohm then will ensure you miss the crowds. You won't see the sunrise here as it's surrounded by dense jungle, but the filtered light through the trees spotlighting the temple is just magical.Plan to arrive well before 7am, or do a quick scoot around after 4.30pm in the afternoon when everyone leaves to watch the sunset at Angkor Wat.

Tomb raider. Didn't see Angelina here but I could see where she had been! A great spot to visit before the jungle returns this temple back to nature completely. Look out for the dinosaur carving made by a cheeky restoration worker.

Temple revealed at dawn tour. As dawn broke the parrots began to wake and the temple was slowly revealed in the jungle. Amazing how the balsa type trees have reclaimed the temple, growing high and strong above the walls. A lot of climbing through ruins, bur interesting.

Go Early or Late. Made famous in the Tomb Raider movie, everyone wants to see Ta Prohm, and I mean EVERYONE.It is undeniably interesting and charming, but it is relatively small, so it gets crowded with tourists quickly.Consider Preah Khan as an alternative. It is larger, equally interesting and has the same cotton trees growing over segments as well. Fewer tourists over a larger site = better experience.
The tomb raider temple. This was just great ...not as busy as the main two, and it was Fantastic our tuk tuk driver teddy from funky was excellent

Really nice temple. Nice temple, bad points because the paths are so narrow and tourists behave there like idiots. Thinking they are the only ones there and blocking the way of hundreds of tourists.Without these kind of idiots it would be amazing temple

Famous temple as seen in Lara Croft: Tomb Raider.... Well preserved and steeped in history with it's famous ancient fig trees which have integrated with the buildings structure from when the jungle retook the temple. To miss the crowds I would recommend visiting either in the early morning or late afternoon where you can explore the temple more freely, but I would also recommend a guide to supply further details about the history of this temple. I would recommend bringing a water, sun screen, a hat and a camera to capture some great pictures of this truly picturesque site. You can also enjoy traditional Cambodian music on the walk to the site which is nice.
Beautiful ruins.. It felt hauntingly beautiful with huge tree roots entrenched in the temple and nature has overtaken the structure.
Must see in Siem Reap. Loved this temple. The trees are really cool to see. It was crowded, but still worth the trip to see it.

The Signature Ta Prohm. A must see but not my top 3 favorite. The jungle and trees entangled in the structure is amazing and you must see it but I simple liked others a bit more. It is popularized by Tomb Raider and highly accessible, so see it and enjoy it like all of Siem Reap and Angkor

A piece of history uncovered in the jungle!. This was as unique an experience as Angkor Wat. You could see how the jungle overtook the temple ruins which makes the restoration seem even more amazing. Definitely worth the visit.

One of the coolest. And I mean coolest in multiple ways - an AMAZING super neat temple, but it's also shaded and has some hallways/indoor bits so it feels literally cooler than, say, the direct baking sun of many others. Incredibly atmospheric and beautiful, especially if you get there early, as many tours schedule it later in the day and it can become a bit crowded due to the whole Tomb Raider connection. We made it our first stop of the day at about 7am and saw almost no one. For sure a favorite.

Tomb Raider temple... and more!. in addition to the Tomb Raider connection, i was pleasantly surprised to know the Indian govt. is participating in it's restoration!the iconic roots of the tree and the whole aura of this place is a bit different (and slightly eerie too).go with an entertaining guide to hear all the tales!

Tomb raider and strangler figs. Tomb raider has made this temple even more famous, but it is the gigantic strangler fig trees which adorn various parts of the temple. With how famous it is, you should get there early if you want to take pictures without tourists. Even on New Year's day, we got there around 6am, and other visitors began around the same time.If you are a keen photographer, and want to take photos of the entire strangler fig tree, then you will need something as wide as a 20mm lens (on full frame). 28mm just isn't wide enough.Another neat trick is to take pictures of these awesome trees and ruins using the panoramic shot within your phone. Start from the top and scan downwards!A nice cool place to explore, I found it more interesting to view the trees and ruins as opposed to the carvings in this temple. But maybe that's just me.

Amazing fig trees growing on the temples. Must do after Angkor and Bayon in my opinion. The trees are really magnificent. Besides the ones on the roofs and walls, there is one like a dragon that goes horizontally. Amazing sight.

Ok temple, but very busy. I have seen both tomb raider movies and cant remember seeing the temples feature. I went to Ta Prom in the early afternoon and it was uber packed. Most of the other temples have trees going out of them, so Ta Prom offers nothing unique.There are quieter temples that are far more atmospheric.
Best Temple!. One of the most interesting temples to visit with young children. They can touch everything and have fun exploring and climbing over the ancient ruinings.

Fascinating site. This one's a cliche because of the Tomb Raider connection, but that doesnt make it any less worthwhile visiting.In fact, we found it just as (if not more) interesting than Angkor Wat. Seeing how the trees and vegetation have grown through the stoneworks was just awesome.Also - dont forget to put the camera aside and just take it all in for a while. It's a truly special place.
Most fascinating temple!!!. This was my favorite temple. Seeing the trees infused in the temple walls was fascinating!!! Photographer's heaven! I got some wonderful photos.

Such an experience.... :). Amazing.....small (comparing to others) but the most misterious....and beautiful. The trees have an important part in this...you should go and see for yourself. Unfortunatelly there were a lot of tourists, but that's normal... Really amazing...you can seat in one of the roots or in a stone, relax and appreciate... :)

Tomb Raider Site. We took a tuk tuk to the temples of Angkor. Our guide asked," You know Angelina Jolie?" "I take you now to site of Tomb Raider!" This movie improved the economy of this area. They are very proud of their heritage and take pride in sharing it. Ta Prohm is a lovely site.

My Favourite temple . My favourite temple. I simply love it. I enjoy hearing the traditional Cambodian music on the walk to the temple played sadly by landmine victims. Please give a donation to support them.
Nice and big. This is where tomb raider was shot so it's very popular. The structure is like a maze and very nice. It's very big inside, worth a visit.

Tomb Raider. Ta Prohm is a fine example of nature taking back human creation. The tree roots are mighty impressive and grow quickly to overtake the structures, in some cases helping the stone buildings stay intact. If you get a chance to travel about an hour away to Beng Mealea to what tour guides call "Indiana Jones", it's worth the trip just to go through the dark tunnel.

As interesting as the pictures. It is a a surreal temple with trees going out randomly... lovely, and small not to feel overwhelmed. Still requires a lot of restoration work, but definitely one of the favourites from all the temples seen.

Make sure you visit this temple!. One of our favourite temples, during our visit in Angkor's ruins.Make sure you visit this temple! Especially during Cambodia's winter it is an easy trek with perfect temperature and weather.
Trees and temples. A very busy venue. Long walk to main set of temples. Trees and temples everywhere. Very flat but lots of fallen pieces of walls.
Fascinating temple. Loved Ta Prohm, gives you a sense of how nature thrives over man made structures and the beauty of nature and ancient structures together.

The Photographer's Temple!. Ta Prom is the temple you're looking for - the trees tangled in the walls and fallen blocks make for the mystical shots you've seen in any article on Cambodia. The downside is that the number of hawkers around the perimeter are in plague proportions. Another important tip is to be wary of (yes, got caught out!) Is the location of the gates. I intended to do a loop and exit through the East gate. Instead I performed a double loop half gainer and ended up out the West gate. This, apparently, was alarming for my family but routine for our tuktuk driver, so, we all survived. Shooting in the temple - I found the Nikon+ 14-24 & Fujifilm X30 worked out well. Tripods & monopods are frowned upon, which is a shame, but stopping down, shifting WB to shady and being flexible with EV gives excellent results.
FILM SET TEMPLE. Used for one of the Raiders films, this temple has been left fairly untouched. The trees still grow over the stones with enthusiasm.

Man and Nature come together !. The first time I came here, nearly 14 years ago, I was somewhat horrified at the lack of control over where the tourists went. I was therefore quite pleased to see this time that at least there was an attempt to keep the tourists of the actual ruins ! This really is an incredible historical spot, which needs to be preserved for future generations. The trees are slowly but surely damaging this temple but better nature than man !

Spectacular,. It is a fascinating place, but in spite of an excellent tour guide who tried his best to guide us around and tell us about Ta Prohm, our visit there was not a pleasant one given the throngs of people. I wish they would prohibit the use of selfie sticks in the temple ruins; most people who use them seem to be oblivious of their surroundings, and can pose danger to others around them.

loved the fact that nature had taken back this temple. It is the Tomb raider temple, not that you'd know if you visited, but I loved the feel of it, abandoned for 500 years and overtaken by nature (and now hundreds of tourists) but there is a lovely feel about the site and you can still lose yourself in the nooks and crannies, and plus great for a few photos.the site has an echo chamber, you stand against the wall and beat your chest and you hear the echo... it's meant to be cleansing so my guide told me :) but it was a much greater echo than you'd expect.I hope they dont over restore this temple but I'm sure people climbing all over it isn't going to help it's maintenance, i was torn loved getting to feel history quite literally ... but the britishness in me said shouldnt really be touching all this stuff...great place for a couple of hours.
Like in the film. Very nice to be there, the place of the movie tomb raider . Take your time and moment , because it was very crowdy
Unique Temple . I felt the romantic and unique air during the visit in Tampa prohm. The temple and the roots like blended together since they were made :)

Soooo cool. This was too me almost more impressing than Angkor Wat, as this is in the middle of the Jungle, and with trees growing all over the temple you get the feel of being in the middle of a Tomb Raider movie (and yes it was actually filmed here, so no wonder) .

Iconic. Really fantastic and I credible to see the trees reclaiming the temples. Very atmospheric.
Only one word of warning; try to avoid arriving at the same time as the selfie crazed Chinese tourists wielding their selfie sticks with no consideration of others.
Another must do.
Best Temple! . So gorgeous, awe inspiring and the best of the large temples. This was our last one on our large temple tour and it blew us away.

Out of this world. To see the might of the trees which would once have been in the forest reclaiming the buildings was amazing. Huge majestic trees
Great architecture and photo opportunities abit of an easier walk than some of the other attractions with less climbing. Great way to spend at least 3 hours
Don't miss this one. Obviously not in the same condition as Angkor Wat, but seeing the way the trees have taken over, growing through the rocky terrain was awesome

Extremely photogenic temple in a jungle with trees growing out of and over the ruins. The trees are the undoubted stars of this temple where the jungle is slowly winning its fight to reclaim the site. Huge root systems sprawl over buildings and mean that parts of the temple have to be reinforced to cope with the weight. The bas reliefs aren't as nice as the Angkor temples, but you won't notice that as you'll be staring up at the canopies which almost seem to be clambering over this temple to get to the light. Truly beautiful.If you have a guide, they'll show you the carved face poking out through some roots (see pic) and the roots that looks like a derriere!

tomb raider attraction is a must!!. this place is the only temple which has not been restored. is incredible to see the effect it has after the many years. its quite sad too. the place is a beauty overall. there is not much too see compared to angkor wat which is nice as if you want to do both temple in one day, you can still walk. beautiful temple. the trees which are hundreds of years old are incredible.

What can nature do. Visiting primarily Angor wat in one day I had few hours to burn and prolonged to Ta Prohm. Well, this temple speaks volumes for itself. Grown over by huge trees it trul looks amazing. Part of it was restored from pile of blocks and debris although I still dont know how they managed to shape it back to original state of architecture?

Amazing!. Also know as the Tomb Raider Temple - so it's naturally one of the more popular temples and can be really busy. It's well worth it though - the trees amongst the ruins are so beautiful. When we visited a portion of it was closed for restoration works - but we were able to see most of it. Highly recommend.

Make sure you know which gates you enter. There are not a few people that cannot remember which gates they enter. There are the east and west entrances. The entrance into the temple proper is a distance away from where the tuk tuks are parked.
This monument can get very crowded as the passages are narrow.

Laura Croft and Indiana Jones made this place famous for Americans!. What an awesome place to visit, to see the progression of tree growth over the temple area, to walk by the walls of reliefs! We took the 'long' way around it and really enjoyed seeing how nature and man-made buildings coexist in eternity here! Take the opportunity to visit this temple if you can and really feel like you're transported back in time!

Very different Temple. This temple is well worth visiting as it is very different from many of the others which are available. It is a very popular temple which means there can be lots of people, although this is always going to be the case. The tree roots which have taken over the structure are often more exciting than the temple itself and you will be sure to hear the word 'Lara Croft' regularly! Try and see as much as you can when you're in Siem Reap- you won't regret it- and make sure this one is one your list.
Amazing first thing in the morning. The history and the trees give this temple an amazing feeling. Our kids kept saying how much they loved the trees and how they have seen this in movies. A must.

Not to be missed. We arrived after 2.30pm and walking through the west entrance with our guide, were amazed at every breath-taking view. The atmosphere was a lot more sedate than Angkor Wat, and it felt like a deeper connection to the surrounds. Definitely a must-see on the temple circuit.

A must see. We did the tour of the temples all in one day, starting with the sunrise at Angkor, then the terrace of elephants and leppers, followed by Bayon and Thom, and finished here. It was rather busy by the time we headed here at 1130, so definitely ensure you get there early to avoid the crowds....

If you only have one temple to see, it's this one. Go early!. We went at sunrise, so the temple was empty. Simply mesmerizing, definitely the best temple in Angkor Wat. Once we saw this one, all the others were pale in comparison, even the main one. Most of the other temples look the same, so this one, with nature all over it, is by far the nicest. Go early to avoid crowds, otherwise you will not be able to take a single picture without a tourist in it.

Go directly after sunrise to avoid crowds. This is a one time experience and we loved it. We were visiting the bayon temple during sunset (you can't see the sunset, but you are on our own with the sites) and came here straight after. By that time there were already guided groups here, which made it feel like disneyland for a couple of seconds until we walked away from the group.

Unbelievable. If Hollywood special effects department built it, you would say 'never on this Earth'!. Unfortunately tarnished with its Jolie/Lara Croft rap, it is just one of those visual examples of the power of Man vs. Nature that is riveting. Make sure you have your wide angle lenses and/or panoramic mode ready to go. Amazing that it was neglected for so long to become as devastated as it is when others were maintained properly. Most special visit.

Favourite part of the complex. The complex is stunning, straight out of tomb raider. The repaired bits of temple are intricate but I hope they don't go overboard as the really cool bits are the gnarled trees which grow out of the ruins.

Go Early to Avoid Crowds. If you visit this location early in the morning, you will avoid the multitudes of people wanting to see this very unique place. Some of the passages can be so crowded that you cannot move through them comfortably, and creating photographs is more than challenging.

Temples tours. Probably the best temple in both the two circuits... Rather small compared to others but you can still feel the jungle...too bad tom raider made it one of the biggest/busiest attraction of the area....

My fav in Angkor area. Ta Prohm was definitely my favourite temple in Angkor area. It's a magic place where nature and human works are intertwined in an inextricable way. One can't survive without the other now. Walking around you have the impression of being in a surreal place, with the strong light of the sun only filtering from the branches and the ruins covered in green musk. Don't miss it!!
Incredible how nature took over. This temple is the best! The trees taking back their spot, the light, condition of the temple... Just stunning

My favorite temple in Siem Reap. We viewed 4 temples as part of our tour and this was my favorite of all. I enjoyed the peace and tranquility of the canopied tree lined walk to the temple, with the dappled sunlight and bird song, then the spectacular reveal of that magnificent tree twisting through the temple. It is a smaller complex so can be covered in an hour, but I could have easily sat and enjoyed the serenity in the gardens. I would recommend getting there between 7.30 and 8, both to beat the heat and the crowds.
Great place to visit . This has got to be on your Temple Tour. The setting is unique and the views are amazing. Can get crowed, but take your time and enjoy all the view and take a tour guide.
Indiana Jones in real life. Incredible temple, in the midst of being swallowed by hundreds years-old trees. Like stepping back in time. Beautiful and haunting.

Absolutely worth it!. The temple is almost surreal. It is beyond spectacular and a must see if you're visiting Siem Reap. Some parts of the temple are falling apart but this only adds to the charm of the place. Photos really don't do this temple justice. You have to see it to believe it.

Tomb Raider. Played this game about 20 years ago on PlayStation. Kind of weird to have life imitating art, imitating life so to speak. Great visit nature regaining control adds perspective - wonderful setting and great area to visit with the Angkor 3 day pass.

Incredible Visual. This is the site of the Tomb Raider movie. It is amazing to see and touch in person. I still can't get my head around these trees roots growing around the temple vs. underground. Another wonder and a must see. Put this on your list. Yes, you will have to wait your turn to take pics in front of tree roots, but it is worth it. Pack patience, after all you are on vacation/holiday.
Amazing Combination of Stones and Root. I was speechless when I saw how the root covers the temple.it was really amazing! I finally can see it by myself not only in Lara Croft Movie!
Rad. Totally awsome with the trees wrapping around the temple it was incredible to see and many great photos taken here.i believe it's been in the movie tomb raider

Simply stunning. We visited in December and arrived at 7.30am on advice of others who had suggests we see this Sam.ler site before heading to Angkor Wat. It was good advice and I would suggest going half an hour earlier so you can take pictures that aren't filled with people.The sheer magnitude of these trees often make it difficult to capture it in a photo. This truly is an example of nature reclaiming its environment, which is seldom seen these days.This is a truly magnifient sight to behold.

The movie site.. You will recognize this from your movie memories or just realize it is like being on a movie set. A fantastical setting full of trees growing out of the old site, dark corridors and a great canopy of trees and wildlife. Take your time here and try to wait out any waves of crowds so that you can have your private moments.

Interesting juxtaposition of man and nature.. This is a stunning place to visit! It was incredible to see the ancient temple grounds with the giant trees growing everyone. This was an interesting juxtaposition of the progress of man and power of nature.

Beautiful temple in its natural state. Ta Prohm is breathtaking. The only temple that has been kept in it's exact natural state with trees growing in and around the temple. The walk up towards the temple is also beautiful on a summer day, with trees canopying around you and the birds chirping away.

Once in a lifetime experience... truly amazing. Made famous by Angelina Jolie's movie. Even so, it is incredible with the tree roots that adorn so much of it and have interwined themselves with the buildings. Very interesting and spectacular to visit

Other-worldly trees. All the photos you have seen of this Tomb raider temple pale in comparison to the sight the confronts you when you behold these gargantuan, almost-parasitic trees with your own eye. It is worth braving the selfie-crazy crowd!
Must see!. This is a must see temple at Siem Reap area. Absolutely stunning and worthwhile the trip. Not to miss!
Ta phrom. A must see. Breath taking views. Be prepared for steep climbs & jostling with tourist crowds. Amazing views of buttress roots which morphed into the temples.

Better than the movies!. My teenage daughters insisted this place be on our list and it was well worth it. If you have enjoyed the tomb raider or Indiana jones type movies this place makes you feel like you are in the thick of it. Hot and humid and amazing

Love this place. The trick with this temple is to do it early in the morning before the crowds get here. We left our hotel at 6am. When you get to Ta prohm, the light is good for photos, there are few people there so you can get good shots of the people and not people, the temperature is good and then you can make it back to your hotel for breakfast.

The movie set temple. This is the one that most people have seen or heard of in that it has been made famous by Angelina Jolie's movie. Even so, it is incredible with the tree roots that adorn so much of it and have intertwined themselves with the buildings. Very interesting and spectacular to visit
Best temple. Not so busy, great for exploring and tons to see, great for a picnic. Great for kids and so relaxed and lush compared to other temples. Best in the morning I think

Nature overruns Mankind. To enter Ta Prohm, which dates back about 1000 years, is walking into a time machine which encompass many centuries. I entered the temple grounds and found that once mankind had, literally and effectively, departed from the site centuries ago, nature had reclaimed the land. Trees grow through, around and out of these imposing temples – and the ambience is awesome. Nature has taken over Man’s efforts. The structures are large but the trees engulf them. Some bas reliefs do exist but they are not as stunning as at other temples.I had returned after nearly 20 years – and the provision of steps and gentle roped-off guide paths were welcome. Nevertheless, half an hour is time to be spent here, with little rest, as there is so much more to walk through. Fresh coconut water is refreshing after a few of the sites are visited!
Favorite temple!!. My favorite of the temples! Just love the tree growth around the structure; it gives it such a fan imaging unique look. It's a bit crowded but loved it nonetheless.

Trees taking over. We visited twice. During the first visit we somehow lost half of the temple but fortunately we returned to see it all. Somehow we had made a shortcut inside the temple..It is amazing to see this temple to see the power of the nature. Without the trees this temple would be just another one in the list. Now it is one of the best. Pity that the trees will destroy the temple but maybe that increases the attraction.
Unbelievable. A lots of trees grew on the temple rock. It looks fascinated for a visitor. All visitors never skip Ta Prohm temple because it is the top 10 temple in Siem Reap.

Tomb Raider temple!. After Bayon, this is probably my favorite temple. Uncrowded early, lots of great photo opportunities, the candle wax melting trees slowly ripping my face off by the awesome that is nature slowly taking back from the centuries.My only gripe was the large Korean tour group standing on the roots of one of the trees all having their picture taken, That can't be good for the tree, it was outside of the back gate, it just seemed a little disrespectful of the tree. It was kind of a hike from the temple to the back gate. There were some big water buffalo by the entrance that were leashed up, they might have been cows, my eyes were still recovering from all of the awesome. A very spiritual place with great energy.

Best of the Angkor Temples. Really loved the Ta Prohm temple. We were fortunate to arrive there late in the day (4 pm) and the light was beautiful. This and the fact there were few people made the experience better than anything we had amongst the crowds at Angkor Wat or Angkor Thom. The detail of the carving at Ta Prohm was really impressive and the unrestored nature of the site really made it seem you were could be just discovering it yourself.
Temple from the Tomb Raider Movie. It's famous from the scene in tomb RaiderWatch as nature over takes the temples wiith huge tree and their cascading roots through the structuresNot a long stop
Another reason your in Angkor. This is another must on trip to Angkor, it's one of a group of temples that stand side by side and only a short tuk tuk ride from Angkor Wat

my favorite temple. + shady+ big trees+ when I am going there = I feel peace- too much tourist = noisy* try to avoid big group time schedule = you can ask your tour guide / tuk tuk driver = they know what time this temple is a little bit less tourists

Nature and Architecture intertwined. this is a unique temple where the trees grow on the temples itself. Its really exotic and mysterious in its own way. This is probably my favourite temple along with the bayon temple. When you visit the place, then you will realize why Tomb Raider movie choose this place for their scene. I felt like an archeologist for a day....Must do: a) Find the spot where tomb raider was filmed to take a pictureb) Find the place where you can beat your chest and hear the loud echo from the wallsc) take a paranoma picture from bottom of the tree to top of the tree
Very nice temple. very nice temple with a lot of big tree and nice temple that Tom raider has been take placed to film here by Angelina Jolie.

Trees v's man made. Trees win!. This temple site is more interesting for its trees than the actual temple itself. It's easy to see natures power here where very large trees have taken over some parts of the man made structures. There are tress straddling walls, sitting on buildings and almost covering other parts like a giant spider web. You've most likely sees these trees in some movies but they even more impressive in real life.

Love this place!. This temple is the reason I really wanted to come visit Angkor Wat/Angkor Thom! The trees growing from the temple walls just fascinated me! And seeing it in person did not disappoint! Wow just wow!Just a tip - either get here super early (we didn't) or try coming during lunch time (we did) and you'll get this place in relative peace. One of the things I didn't like about visiting the area was how crowded the main sites could be. But with the right timing you will have a great time!

To see nature coming through the buildings is amazing. This temple has been used as a film set and you can see why. Nature has reclaimed buildings but the atmosphere is amazing . You have to visit to get the full experience. book as part of the mini tour and keep a Tuk Tuk on call for the day.

The best temple in the park - deserves a second visit even!. This temple featured in the tomb raider movie(s). Have not seen the movie nor played the game I did not really know what to expect. What a surprise! This is the only temple containing the "lost in the forest" appearance, with conservation work aimed at preserving its 19th century "as found" appearance. Visit first thing in the morning for a truly exquisite site.

Trees are taking over. This by far was my favorite as I never expected trees to grow over the ancient temple. There are many placed to see within the temple make sure you the the APSANA covered with trees.

If u r nearby, please go there. Amongst the Temple in this area I strongly Suggest visiting this gem. Real djungle feeling here Maybe behause it is so.
Awesome trees integrated in the structure.
Restaurated and really beautiful.

Seen tries growing over buildings?. The temple of Ta Prohm is all in ruins, with massive trees growing over the temples, the roots protruding into the pathways, tree trunks overshadowing doorways. It is the site where the film “Tomb Raider” was filmed, and you can see why. Be prepared to walk some miles as you explore these fascinating temples. It was interesting to hear that the Indian Archeological authorities have chipped in to help restore this site for posterity! Well done!!
Mind the roots!. The biggest trees ive ever seen! they are part of the temples already which makes the whole place exotic in a way that the trees compliments with temple ruins!

Unique experience. This is probably the second most famous Wat in the Siem Reap area. It has been little restored and the faunal overgrowth gives it a special character although eventually nature will potential destroy the building that remain. A visit to observe sunrise proved a good idea as there were only 6 tourists present to enjoy a slightly eery and surreal experience in peace and tranquility. Travellers soon flock to this location and by 08.00am it was pretty busy. It is a good photo opportunity and well worth including in your itinerary as it is not far from Angkor Wat.

Tomb raider. We did not meet Lara Croft - but felt almost like adventureres. Beautiful and untouched and "wilder" than nearby Angkor Wat. It easily gets crowded so arrive early or get there around lunch when everyone else has a lunch break
Beautiful and haunting.. Well worth the visit! Beautiful structures being reclaimed by nature. Easy access for families with older children. Once in a lifetime experience!!
Amazing. Gotta see this amazing temple covered with trees. Don't miss it. The surroundings are surreal and you wonder about how this trees could still be living.

Interesting, but falling apart.. Unlike Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm is falling apart. There are many areas you cannot access due to fallen stones. However, this is still a beautiful temple set in a wonderful forest. The strangler figs growing throughout the temple make for some great photo opportunities. I would rate this as my second favourite temple in Siem Reap. Be prepared to deal with large crowds!
Interesting and like a maze. It is definitely worth seeing the trees splitting rocks. Once you are inside, you might feel you were in a maze. Everything looks similar but everything is different.

Fab attraction for sunset. We went at sunset and it was worth the wait. One of the only temples that hasn't been touched too much. We went at 5 and there were only a few people here. It's a few minutes walk from the car park to the temple.
Movie Buff. I love my adventure movies and thanks to Tomb Raider had wanted to see this for ages. It certainly was worth the wait. Loved it.

Temple in the trees. The beautiful ruins of this Buddhist temple are intertwined with the ancient trees. They support each other but eventually the massive trees will destroy much of the ruins without human intervention. Very atmospheric. Like being on the set of an Indiana Jones movie!

Beside Tomb Raiders. Know for the mivie Tomb Raiders, but there is much more than the movie, the tree roots all creeping and penetration the stone buildings... creating a contract of co existence and harmony...
Amazing. This is the most beautiful and spectacular place. Took my breath away an absolute must see. Fabulous !

Must see, but over it in five minutes. It's certainly cool and unique. I only needed 10 minutes to cruise through and take some pics. If you're not into the whole history of it, don't get a guide and just walk through. It's massive and certainly different than most temples. I thought it was the most worth it if all three we went to.

Get there early!. If you have the opportunity to go early before the crowds it would definitely be worth it for this temple. In peak times you're shoulder to shoulder with other tourists queuing to see each section of the temple and it's near impossible to get a shot without someone in it.While it was amazing to see the power of nature over time, we preferred Beng Mealea temple outside of Siem Reap because it hasn't been restored yet and is even more swallowed up by the jungle.

Tomb Raider, everyone will tell you its in the movie !!. All part of your Angkor Wat trip. Not too be missed. One of the many temples in the area dating from the 12th Century This was one of my favourites as you can see how nature is trying to reclaim it

Didn't see Angelina.... This is the "Tomb Raider" Temple. I think the big attraction of this temple is the tree that has grown over another tree and the temple ruins. It is an amazing site. Again, it's just another temple but I think it's definitely worth visiting.

AMAZING. Of all the temples We seen I was by far most impressed by Ta Prohm. The giant trees growing up through the temples are a sight to behold. It's far quieter than the larger temples so much easier to explore & get the best pictures.

Temple taken back by nature. This is a great temple to explore, it may not be as lofty as the other temples but the fact that nature is taking it back gives it an amazing look and should be visited! Also the site where Tomb raider was filmed although don't get too caught up in that fact as there is not too much recognisable from it. Will need to buy entrance ticket from the ticket office.

The beauty of Man vs Nature. You have to visit these temples multiple times because each temple has their own distinct characteristics that blow ones mind with every visit. The beauty of Ta Prohm is the obvious haunting tree roots that engulf the structure. It never gets old. It's places like this that will continue to inspire artists for generations. One look at Ta Prohm and you'll see HR Gieger all over it. Love it.
Nice place. Must go! This is a very nice place for photo taking. And this is a special temple, since lots of tree root was combined in the temple, not so many temple like that

the "Tomb Raider Temple". this is a great temple to visit not only because of the famous movie that included it but because a lot of it is under cover of the jungle which in turn sheltered you and made it a lot cooler . I really enjoyed seeing this temple as it was a lot different to all the others that i had seen . The only down side on the day was 2 japanese tourist who thought it might be good to carve their names in a tree in the temple . I would come back here again as I did not see all of it and parts of the temple were being repaired and restored

A maze of Kapok. Wandering in the maze of Kapok, the trees are on the structure of Ta Phrom Temples estimated about 300 years, in Khmer called "Spong Tree", the English is silk and cotton tree. We are impressed by those giant tree and the spectacular scenery!

Unique place not to be missed. Makes you feel like you're in a tomb raider movie. Never thought that trees could grow like this. It's a very unique place that also very touristy. Take your time to explore the ruins. I like it most of all the places in Angkor.

Temple and nature. Ta Prohm is a wonderful mix of temple buildings and floruishing trees. Unlike other temples made entirely of stones or sandstones, Ta Prohm has many trees growing in, above and on the temple buildings, giving it quite a mysterious and unique feeling. This is possibly one of the reasons why the place was chosen for the film "The Tomb Raider".
I've always wanted to see the tree roots here. This was, for me, the jewel in the crown of my visit to Angkor Wat and the associated temples. It was simply awesome.
Lara Croft . Kids excited about finaly visiting this place. Trees are amazing the way they wrap and grow around the temple
Trees in Building. The second best and memorable place to visit , lots of great photos , exciting vibrant place to wonder around

Just amazing how nature gets a grip. For me being a biologist, it was awe inspiring to see how the trees embrace the temple ruins - all started by seeds being deposited in temple cracks from bird droppings many hundreds of years ago. The silk-cotton trees and strangler figs have certainly got a grip these days. Congratulations to the 19th century archaeologists who decided to leave Ta Prohm more or less as discovered. Many tourists were visiting at the same time and I found progress rather slow due to congestion. Watch your step as the paths and terraces are uneven. Spot the carved face surrounded by a strangler fig and the butt (or bum) tree as described by my jovial guide.

The charm from the past is gone. Have been at Ta Prohm first time 15 years ago. There were no wooden walk ways with free access to all the great trees overgrowing the Ta Prohm. Understand that it's all about to conserve and protect the place but unfortunately the former spirit of Ta Prohm is gone.
Fabulous. The ruins are absolutely stunning. A highlight of the Angkor Wat site. Well worth the trip to Siem Riep.

Unmissable - the Iconic temple a la Laura Croft. Compelling ruins, even with the huge number of (overheated) visitors. There were a few times when progress through the temples came to a standstill due to the crowds in confined, unrestored ruins, and dark corridors that need a careful path.Ta Prohm has a real "Laura Croft" feel about it due to the closeness of the jungle and the intentional policy of not cutting back the vigorious vegetation, and particularly, leaving invasive trees inside (often quite literally) the walls of the temple as well as inside. The power of nature, shown in the tree invading, and the moving centuries old walls of this unique site. This policy of non interferance sits heavily on Ta Prohm, giving it that almost mystical feel, and advance of the vegetation and numerous trees growing within the temple is both a cause for celebration (of Natures power), and future food for thought.Unmissable.
Plenty of photo opportunities. Amazed that this special place is not more protected from the elements. We have seen so many photos and TV programs about this place we probably expected a bit more.

Fascinating temple . Ta prohm, jungle temple or the tomb raider temple is best visited in the early morning, as this is the time the temple is quite and not filled with tourists. The temple is best viewed when it's quite as it gives you an opportunity to truly observe how nature has tried to take back this temple. Restoration of the temple has really paid off as this temple is a sight to behold! The temple seems to be the favourite for most people due to the way the trees curve around, in and through the crumbling temple.
Best out of all the temples!. Glad we went because this was the best temple - not to be missed! Whizz round after watching the sunrise and it will be so quiet!
BEST OF THE BEST. Beautiful, Rich its history, very Interesting and Quiet (I guess thank to AngkorVisit for making this happen).
Come before the crowds arrive. Arrive between 8-10 Am while most of the crowd is in the bigger temples. Nice place to take photos of the big tree taking over the temple without the throngs of people.

Become one with nature!. Huge and ancient trees coming together with the temples! It's remarkable to see the power of nature that has always won the battle versus men! A large temple where you need to take a few hours just to walk around in it. Many beautiful spots to take pictures and a lot of shades so it doesn't get that warm in all places. There's one inner chamber which is supposedly said to still contain some gold relics from the past. They did not open this chamber due to fear of making it collapse altogether.
Filming of Laura Croft:Tomb Raider. There are many temples in Angkor, this is only one, but filled with history. Be sure to see as many as you can
Just beautiful. The architecture is interlaced with the vegetation which is scintillating. You will love your visit here.
The movie "Tumb Raider" was on the same shot.. Never seen the natural habitat of a tree can grow like that! The power of nature. Your got to see it to believe it.

A Good Promenade thru Ta Prohm is a Good Pastime. The site has a quick route and a longer route - do the longer route as you will see and experience more. Take your time. Crowds can be disruptive but enjoy the peace and beauty. Viewing the natural essence of Nature as she has tried to reclaim the site - humungous root systems (almost "alien" in nature) - vie for modern man's attempt to show off the site. Note the detail engravings but don't get lost in the passage ways - there are many. But fear not, there are staff personnel watching everywhere.
Got to see it. An incredible structure and a must see for any Tomb Raider fan. The whole Ta Prohm complex is spectacular and the trees growing on top with their routes is quite a sight to behold!
Great temple. This is the amazing temple in the world. If you can't visit one time in life that will be sad. I wish everyone feel the same to me. Have your great time.

Brilliantly atmospheric. We visited at dusk and this was the highlight of our holiday. The cicadas , birds and monkey's noise was unbelievable and most tourists had gone home. The blending of ruins and amazing roots and trees has to be seen to be believed. The only down side was the crowd of persistent traders and children who seemed to be allowed inunchecked despite our tourist passes being scrutinised frequently.
if you watch Tomb raider, you need to come here. this is a place of attraction with lots of Old tree stick with the building. I like it a lot.it's one of the temple worth for visit.
Tranquility. Unique and special place with beautiful spong trees on the ancient temples, amazed by the tranquil and serene sight :)

Nature at its best. The main attraction here are the huge trees with long roots that "climb" the remains of the temple. My kids enjoyed this more than Angkor Watt. There's not much walking or climbing at the site, so convenient. It's recommended to visit at the afternoon where there aren't many people.

One of my favourites!. Love this place a lot. We took the long walk to explore the whole place. Really enjoyed the scenery there. Lotsa of pictures taken. One of the most popular site is the tree grown on top of the building but they have restricted access near the tree, so you can just take photo at the side which is good enough. Also look out for the Buddha face in a tree root. Really amazing. The whole place is stunning. One hour is not enough! Make sure you give urself enuff time to explore to the max!

tomb raiders. Buy the ticket, see all the temples you want for one price. I enjoyed sitting in this quiet temple. It was in the movie, and some folks want to see it for that reason.
