I didn't see the movie, but I've seen the temple! Very nice buildings, old, historic. Don't buy all your souvenirs from the first child. Buy small, as all his/her friends will line up for the next sale. I enjoyed the children very much. But they are relentless.

The most amazing temple. I personally find this site more amazing than Angkor Wat.The most amazing force is really nature. Come and see for yourself the amazing force of nature & u will be left in awe.Do put on proper footwear as the extensive tree roots within the temple and the ruins from the collapsed roofs make moving around not easy.

This has to be on your bucket list. The entire Ankor area is a must for adventure travel. 100 square miles of ancient temples and structures. Welcome to the real life temple of doom. Ankor Wat, Bayon, Ta Prohm, it's all fabulous. You need at a minimum of 3 days to do justice in visiting this area. Before you go spend an afternoon at the museum in Siem Reap for the history of the area. Oh, going through customs after flying into the Siem Reap airport felt like being in a Marx Brothers movie.

Amazing . We spend 9 days in Siem Reap and enjoyed all Temples and activities here. Ta Prohm is very impressive. The combination of ancient temple and jungle make it look amazing. It does not have the most detailed carvings and is not the oldest but has a special atmosphere.If you go in the early morning, you can prevent running into big tourist groups. We arrived around 6am. There were maybe 6 other tourist on location. Especially if you like taking pictures without tourists on it, go early. We also like the feel in most of the locations here in Siem Reap, much more real - not this typical tourist attractions with hundreds of tourist signs, barricades or arrows to follow. It does not feel like they try to squeeze cattle through as quickly as possible.A real highlight!

Fun. Now I must say my 6 yr old was expecting something much more like Tomb Raider (tunnels) so he was a bit disappointed. But it is worth seeing. Very interesting and fun to see how the forest can take over.

Beautiful temple hidden beneath giant trees!. Hidden beneath the roots of giant trees, this temple is unlike any other you would see around! The fine architecture and the interesting history behind it (Jayavarman VII built this grand structure for his mother as the Khmers had matriarchal families) makes this a must-do destination while at Siem Reap!

Modern Day Tomb Raiders. This was by far our favorite temple to visit. The trees and the overall view is just amazing. We were very sad and shocked to see many tourists carving their names in the trees!! Like what?? This is a world heritage site people! We said something to the tourists that we saw, but they looked at us with dumbfounded faces and continued to carve. I hope this place is still around for us to visit again!

Favorite Spot in Siem Reap. This temple was propably my favorite one. I don't know why, but I was deeply impressed more than at Angkor Wat. I didn't want to leave this place, because for some reason I couldn't take my eyes of this beautiful and strong nature which has this amazing connection to the surviving ruins. I think I left a tiny bit of my heart here..

Romantic and deffinetly highlight!. At the end of long day we visited this so-called Tomb Rider- Jungle temple. It is really exciting to see these huge trees climbing on these temple walls. Very photogenic place.

Visually the best of the temples. The 'tomb raider' temple is absolutely stunning, certainly something I will carry with me for many years to come. Give yourself an hour and a half at least to walk around it, though you'll likely be swept up by the crowds and ushered round by snap happy tourists. A must see after angkor wat.
Monster treees!. I love trees and nature and anything green. Equally as interesting as angkor. The trees are alive!! Amazing.
My second favorite temple. I loved this place so much. Was my favorite aside angor wat. The nature and ruins exist together and it's incredibly beautiful. Highly recommend not to miss this one

Felt like Indiana Jones!. If you are into taking photographs, you will go crazy at these places. Really awesome! My family and I went early in the morning to catch up the best time to wonder around with the crowds. Left at 6am and back in town at noon, perfect for lunch time. The entrance fee is one for all the archeological sites. If you want to take your time to walk around all of them you could purchase a 3 day ticket. My two boys 7 and 5 could not handle all the walking so, they made it short 3/4 of the time. It gets a bit hot and humid (we visit mid decemeber). Totally a place to visit.
Fascinating temple. One of the best temple in Angkor Park with many photo opportunity and fascinating view. Really peaceful, also

Outstanding temple; its the one from the Tomb Raider movie.... I loved visiting this temple and I think it was made better because our tour guide (Sun Same) took us here early in the morning before the hordes of tourists made their way around. He said that the large groups go to Angkor Wat in the morning and then head to Ta Prohm next so we went to Ta Prohm first and were almost the only people inside. It made for amazing photos and the quiet ominous feel of the place. I loved it and would put this temple in the top three of Cambodia.

Erie in the early morning hours. This temple has been given back to nature and it makes it special and very different from the other temples. It has its own ancient history but also modern history being the site where movies have been filmed - Temple of Doom I think. Anyway, we approached right before dawn and it gave an erie feel. Wonderful!

Spellbinding atmosphere. Great atmosphere as many of the big trees that have overgrown the ruins were left in place, otherwise removing the tree roots will have destroyed the ruins themselves. The entire complex is large with narrow passageways, so its almost like a maze and possible to get lost. There are many spots for great atmospheric photo shoots. Our guide took us to one of the small prang towers where if you lean back against the wall and thump your chest, it will echo all around you.
Cool Roots. The tree roots are amazing and so cool how they wrap on top of the buildings. There are some stops to take photos, but over crowded with tourist and "bus-groups".
Interesting. Loved how the jungle grew around the temples and the ancient ambience it creates. One of the best place to visit in Cambodia.

Must Visit place. A must visit place before it collapse
- the temple is surrounded by huge trees
- many refurbished structure.
- unique place that you can see trees surrounding the structure
- it is like a small maze where the buildings are almost similar

Must see after Angkor wat. This temple is magnificent. There is a tree growing through it- hence why its second name is jungle temple. For all the movie buffs, it is also the location where some of tomb raider was filmed. Very pretty temple
Fascinating!. This is really a highlight among the temples in the Angkor complex. A bit crowded, as are many of the sites, but still definitely worth a visit

Atmosphere galore.. You dont need an introduction to Ta Phrom Temple. Just go, its well worth the 20 bucks site admission on its own let alone Angkor Wat and Bayon. Thoughts of Tomb Raider spring to mind all the way around the crumbling tree infested grounds. Atmosphere galore and you dont need a guide to enjoy the site but i am sure a guide would be appreciated by some who want to know a little more. Combine with Angkor or Bayon for a great temple touring day in very pleasant surroundings.

Best Temple in Siem Reap. The images from this temple are already so famous but it really does have a tremendous amount of charm. There has obviously been some restoration work but any future restoration should be handled with care otherwise it will be 'Disneyfied'. There are many photo opportunities with the trees growing out of the temples but patience is required as the site was really busy during our visit.

Interesting. It is part of the scene in movie Tombs rider! It is a place for those who like to see the ruins. Tree growing on top of the structures. It is hot there. Make sure to bring mosquitoes repellents. It is pretty deserted and complicated entrance & exit. I lost the landmark with the driver but luckily the security officer took me back to the hotel for 7$ for just one way ride!

Busy but beautiful . If you can catch Ta Prohm early in the morning before the hordes of selfie stick carrying tourist arrive, it is magically. One of the more decaying temple with the most amazing trees growing out of the ruins. Less busy around the outside edge of the buildings you can still see great views.

Like walking on the movie set of Lara Croft. Awesome how the trees are simply holding this place together. The restoration works that have been completed to date when you look at the before and after photos on the story boards on site are amazing. I have no idea how they work out how these piles of stones go back together. Its like a million piece jigsaw puzzle with no edges and corners to get you started. Take plenty of water as it get very hot and humid when walking around and look for the shots that made the movie Lara Croft and Angelina Jolie famous..don't forget to give a few dollars to the beggars that have been injured by the landmines that still litter this war torn country. To them a few dollars are a couple of days of food and to you its only a dollar or two..

Favorite of three "Angkor" sites. Intimate and other-worldly. Crowded of course. When too many humans are all scampering trying to capture the "perfect" picture, one can feel jaded. The tree roots growing around the building is memorable.

Tomb Raider. Great part of Angkor Wat , well known from the opening sequences of the original Tomb Raider. This area although also very busy seems to be quitter and more tranquil than the rest of Angkor. Looking forward to going back

A tad underwhelmed. This is the ruins of an erstwhile Buddhist monastery but it seems to be most famous for being the location where Lara Croft Tomb Raiser was shot. Couple of good spots but not all that awesome. I would have liked to spend more time at Angkor Thom
A bit too crowded. Beautiful place full of history and beauty. Just a bit too crowded with tourists everywhere and it became almost impossible to take pictures without others in it.

A temple time forgot. As with most of the temples around Angkor, Ta Prohm had been covered with foliage. But rather than clear everything out, it was decided to leave it unrestored, in it's semi natural state. The outcome is there are amazing trees that seem to be eating the walls and structures. There is a mystery to the place that can only be understood by visiting. And if you do go, try and go when it is not so crowded. We went in September and visited the site in the morning. Hardly anyone there. We had free reign of the place and did not want to leave.

Morning visit. Try to get here early in the morning (say before 7:30) before the crowds arrive. This one was my favorite temple - in the middle of the jungle, morning freshness, birds, and very few people. An experience not to be missed.

Tomb Raiding. Always associated with the film and Angelina Jolie. Visited here more times than I can remember. Rebuilding in progress all the time so always something new there. Try to remember that you enter temple at east gate and exit west gate ( or vice versa) so your driver will have driven to the other side and you shall have to locate him when you leave. A good driver will be watching for you but some like a mid day nap so make sure you can identify it. Take its number.

Busy and under construction but still very cool. This site had construction work dotted throughout which spoiled a few of the photos. Try to get here at the less touristy times if possible unless you like photographing the back of people's heads.

Fabulous mysterious tree temple . A wonderful, magical place where the trees have grown over the huge stones. Lots of unreal shapes from the extended tree roots. This is where some of Tomb Raider was filmed. You need 90 minutes at least to appreciate this temple. Go here first in the day when crowds go to other temples first.

Unbelievable trees. To be there And witness how these trees have taken over the temple is just nature at its best. The movie tomb raider doesn't even. Gives justice to the beauty of it. You just have to see it to believe it

Lara Croft Notoriety but ...... This is my second visit here and obviously could not help make comparisons to my last visit ,10 years ago.During my last visit there was an amazing old tree sited at the vicinity of the back court. Obviously NATURE and time has made their mark and that beautiful is no more. I believe for the purpose of conservation and safety that same said tree is no more. As a consequence the respective area was cast in bright light. Naturally this does not pose a problem, however the sense of mysteriousness about the place due to the altered shadowiness of the surrounding was not the same as before.

huge, worth a visit. More a collection of small buildings in different courtyards than a massive temple. A bit more in disrepair than some of the other temples, but certainly worth a visit after Angkor Wat and Bayon.

Great! But... . This is very popular spot as "Tomb Raider" was shot here (with Angelina Jolie) but if you get stuck behind a school of Korean tourists though, you are screwed. lol. Tight one-way corridors had me feeling like I was in a conga line! Make sure to avoid the crowds and maybe show up early morning - not mid afternoon.

No sign of Angelina!. It was brilliant to tour this temple and see the place for real after watching Tomb Raider in the past. Quite a busy temple but fascinating to wander round and see the mighty trees growing above the walls of the temple. A must visit temple if you have to make a choice.

Tomb Raider Temple. Must see! If you saw the Tomb Raider movie or not you must visit this temple. By far my favorite. The ruins are incredible and the natural foliage growth astounding. We were also serenaded by the natural insect sounds that live in the area. I really felt like I stepped on a movie set. Down side, it gets really busy as it is one of the most popular attractions. I wish they would limit the number of people allowed in at a time. Oh well, just get there early and enjoy.

Very nice and very crowded!. If you have ever heard about the temple in Siem Reap where Tomb Raider was recorded, well you've heard about Ta Prohm! In my opinion it is on the highlights and surely a must see in Angkor Wat complex but very crowded because its popularity. It has lots of trees with its roots spread all around the temple's walls making it a nice place for good shots (if you are lucky enough to not have tons of tourists there seeing it too). Once you are in there is a path to be followed but you can explore basically everywhere inside the temple! If I am not mistaken this temple is included in the small tour package and of course you need the Angkor Wat temple's pass to get inside too (US$20 for 1 day and US$40 for 3 day passes). :)
Tomb Rader!. Locals call this temple Tomb Rader as angelina jolie filmed there. The roots of these trees are amazing. They are so thick and creepy looking and seem to be growing out of stone.

Welcome to the Jungle.... Ta Prohm is one of the most amazing ruins at Angkor. It's been mainly unrestored, which makes you feel like you're on the Tomb Raider set. The way the jungle has grown in and around the ruins is incredible. If you can, try and get here early, as it can get fairly busy ...some awesome photo ops!
My 2nd best temple after Angkor Wat. The main reason I had to come here was to see the dinosaur carving, you might need help from one of the locals to find it, I tipped him one dollar.

So beautiful but so crowded!. People flock to this temple because of Lara Croft Tomb Raider. Try and visit during 'off times'. Also, take your time and explore, as you will be able to find good places to photograph the trees encroaching upon the buildings. It's a wondrous sight to see. Nature encroaching on man made buildings is really something. I'd recommend visiting to anyone, just prepare for the crowds.

Amazing.. We arrived here later in the day at 5pm and it was almost empty. Very ideal time to go. The sounds of the jungle including the monkeys, birds and crickets were an experience and wonderful to hear. The trees growing in the temple walls were incredible. The temple was also amazing but naturally falling down so dont let little ones climb on the walls etc. A definate must to go and visit.
Photographer's paradise. Breathtaking, a must see and an absolute dream to photograph! Try to get there early enough to beat the crowds.
Tomb Rider!. Yes, this is the place where movie was made ;) They didn't clean it from jungles, so you will see how time and jungles can eat everything around. Amazing atmosphere inside!

Breathtaking Place. We visited here early on our first day visit to the temples, we had just been to see the sunrise at Angkor Wat so by the time we got here it was only around 7 am and relatively quiet, our guide Rany was great as he knew it would be a quiet time to visit and he was right, he advised us to bring mosquito repellent due to the jungle type environment.This was our favourite part of our visit to the temples, a great photo opportunity at every turn, having Rany as our guide meant we got to see everything and also he took some memorable photos of us together.There is some work going on around this area but in no way did it take away from our visit.It is everything and more we could have hoped for, definitely well worth having a guide so you get the full experience.

Tomb Raider (Angkor Tree?). Usually the last of the three temple that the guide will take you to. If you are up for it there are a few other, do your home work before handAmazing site, much small than Wat or Thom but famous for the trees growing on buildingGo see, take photos

Favourite of the tour. This temple was my favourite. Got some pretty cool pictures here. I do recommend going early in the morning because it can get very crowded and temperatures can get pretty hot as well.
awesome place. its a great place to go not just for the history but also for the opportunity to get clicked at the same spot where a few scenes of Tomb Raider was filmed.
Great place to visit. Raiders of the Lost Ark fame. Well worth a visit but include also Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat as all compliment one a nother

Beautiful. And currently under reconstruction.. Ta Prohm is breathtaking. I loved it to pieces and wish I got more time there. It is currently under reconstruction (December, 2015) so there's cranes and other maintenance equipment about, so I'm not sure how it will look when it's completed its overhaul. Hopefully not too dissimilar. I really like the crumbly aspect of Ta Prohm. I also noticed that there are now platforms and barricades preventing you from walking right up to the walls and trees. I'm guessing it's because of the influx of tourists (Cambodia estimates it will get an increase of 2 million tourists within the next couple of years, so I recommend going soon). It's a shame that hoards of people visit this temple for the sole reason of "Tomb Raider was filmed here" as it's a magnificent beauty in its own right and doesn't need a movie to advertise it. It also made it's harder to enjoy the natural, crumbling, mossy beauty of the place when you have tons of people clamouring to get a photo in front of the 'Tomb Raider tree's. Do not let that you stop you though because it's an exquisite site. I'm so happy I got to visit it. There are victims of land mines playing musical instruments on the path up to the temple, so if you have some extra change, please donate.

Nature taking over. One of the most popular sites in the Angkor Park, Ta Prohm stands out with its jungle environment. The trees and roots engulfing the temple make it a remarkable scene. Some parts of the temple were left in ruins. I prefer it to be left in that way. Everyone links Ta Prohm to Tomb Raider and you would see why. Along with the fact that a scene was shot there, the place does feel mysterious. However, it can get very crowded which makes taking pictures rather difficult, but all the visitors were nice enough to line up and take pictures in turns. One of the trees now has a boardwalk built around it so you can no longer take the same picture as seen on postcards. I've been to Beng Mealea and I recommend going to both. They are very different but equally impressive. But if you only have so little time, pick Ta Prohm cos it's closer and more famous and a trip to Angkor Park isn't complete without a visit to Ta Prohm.

This is where Tomb Raider was filmed - magnificent!!. I was in awe at how the trees have Placed themselves all over this temple. I thought it was one of the most amazing things I've ever seen. Nature seems to have taken over this temple in the most creative ways. Wish I had spent more time in here. Truly magnificent.A MUST see trip.Date visited: 1 Dec 2015Make sure this is one of the

Temples being swallowed by nature. These strangler figs that are growing on top of parts of the temple are incredible, it really does give it a 'other world' type of feeling. I loved the unkempt nature of this temple, but again being one of the most popular temples expect lots of tourists. It's nice to pick a spot away from other to just sit and take it all in and really appreciate where you are and try to image being a fly on the wall.
Mystical. It is all about the trees. And the cicadas that sound like bells, and just the air of this place is awesome. There is a reason they save this one for last when you take a temple day tour.
My favorite part of Angkor Wat. The temples are all similar in Angkor Wat but in Ta Prohm the trees covering the temple makes it special

Nice Jungle Temple but not so amazing as on photos and folder. I expected a larger scale seizure of temples through the jungle. There is a lot of people all the time. Temple is renovated and rebuilt - that's good job.
Reminds you Tomb Raider. This is a representative attraction of the whole Angkor Wat. The roots of trees aged hundreds or even thousands of years wrapping the temples are fascinating.

Don't be Indiana Jones. Known for appearing in the Indiana Jones movie - this temple again is magnificent and how strange to see nature regaining control over this temple - makes for some stunning natural / man made creations! Do take some time to "take stock" and embrace and enjoy this temple - it's not all about running through Siem Reap with a camera! A country with an amazing and sometimes fraught history that can create something like this - spiritual!

Movie backdrop. Good backdrop and prop for exotic adventure movies or cartoons. Otherwise not outstanding compared to Angkor Wat itself. Octopus-like tree roots and trunks that extend into or wrap around part of the stone buildings. The site itself is not that big.

Just like other temples in Siem Reap but this one is mainly attract coz of the tree trunk/root crawling to top . It is famous coz of tree trunk and root is crawling towards top of the temple and some has making the stone of the temples dropped to the ground. But some kind of organization/group of people is doing some preservation works currently.

To Prohm Temple. This temple was unique in that it had not been restored and the massive tropical plants had overgrown many sections. It was fascinating to visit and totally different from the other temples in the area. A definite must to visit

How can this temple still stand. You have seen this amazing historic temple in the movies, however it is still hard to believe that it is real. Myers, it is ver real. Not only the complex of root systems are difficult to take in, but the temple itself is beautiful. Even with the large number of tourist posing for photos, it is peaceful and a joy to visit.

My favorite in all the temples in Siem Reap. Loved it!!! You feel like you are back in time in the middle of the jungle. This is my favorite of all the temples in Siem Reap. If I had one to visit, I would go to this one. Hiring a guide was also very useful (we hired one form our hotel, Golden Temple Hotel and were very satisfied).

History against the jungle. This was very interesting to see how the jungle entwined around the ruins. this particular temple was why I almost wanted to see the entire complex, it did not disappoint. . Note: the jungle is constantly trimmed to keep this rustic look without the jungle re claiming the ruins..
Fascinating. Next to Anghor WT this is, in my opinion, the next best temple to visit. Amazing to see how the trees have grown around the buildings over the years
Quaint and exotic. Lovely temple, much smaller than Angkor Wat but still nice. If you're doing a 'temple day' in Siem Reap, I certainly recommend to include this one in your list.

Go early!. Crowds at Ta Prohm in the middle of the day made our experience pretty frustrating. We walked by all the crowded spots (the best photo spots) because we could barely get by the big tour groups and decided to come back to see what we had missed. We went from 7:00am-8:00am and I'd suggest going even earlier to have more quiet. There were still enough people that you might have to wait a few minutes to get the photo you want, but everyone was at least pretty respectful and quiet at that time of morning. It's also significantly cooler so more enjoyable. Go early to truly enjoy the beauty and wonder at Ta Prohm! Don't let the big crowds steal the experience of being in this awesome place.

The 'Tomb Raider' Temple. Place was super popular due to the Tomb Raider movie but this temple definitely has more than that!!! Beautiful trees that are gigantic growing above buildings, simply amazing!!! Must visit!!!

Get up really early and you will love it! . We headed here very early in the morning and beat the crowds of tours. The place is beautiful with buildings over grown with trees and wildlife. We loved it but I bet it's very different with the crowds of tour companies. Be prepared for fake guides that charge you, sellers calling you to buy things and book sellers. But that's at every popular attraction. Please don't give money to the children they are working for someone the money won't go to them and they will go out and do the same thing the next day. Remember to promote good tourism in the country.

Stunning place covred with jungle. We visited it early in the morning to avoid crowds. There are multiple places to stop and take pictures so expect groups to stop by and form lines. There are lots of trees so it would be good if you have little time and plan to do something in lunchtime.

Tomb Raider but slightly less Hollywood glitter - see it for what it is. Famous temple from the Tomb Raider movie but loses the glitter from the Hollywood 'add on' in the movie. I would recommend moderating your expectations. Having said that, the trees growing on the stones are impressive and the temple is a work of art. It is important to see the temple for what it is and not lose sight of its importance to the world

Fantastic network of roots and famous for Tomb Raider. Great place to visit and very popular with tourists due to Tomb Raider. Try and find the face in the roots in one of the inner walk ways. Amazing place.
awesome temple. please try to go early to avoid the crowd. You should try to get there around 8 am before the crowd, it is a very small temple.it is also much cooler earlier in the morning
Amazing. Breathtaking. Many tourists, but what do you expect. Well worth the tour as part of a wider tour seeing Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm. The trees in this place are amazing.

Nature does it again. After spending the morning amazed at the creation of man, it was neat to tour this temple which juxtaposes the beauty and power of nature with the creation of man. As we walked through we were blown away by the power and size of the trees growing over these ancient walls.
This was definitely a worthwhile visit.

Restoration challenge. Ta Prohm, the "Tomb Raider" temple is amazing because of the way the trees and jungle work with the ruins to create the feel of a temple lost in the jungle. The temple is currently undergoing "restoration" to stabilize it from the ravages of both the jungle and tourists, without destroying its unique charm. Walking through yesterday the temple was amazing, but there is a real risk that further "improvements" will make Ta Prohm feel like a Disney attraction.
Siem Reap adventure. i was most disappointed in this temple. So much have been destroyed. Rocks all over the place. Except for the famous tree in Tomb Raider, there's really nothing much here.

The highlight of our trip. We (3 girls) came here twice. The first day it was overcast and it rained torrentially so we actually seeked cover for a while inside a temple, just staring out at the ruins and the rain. It was magical. There were less people here this day as it was later in the afternoon. Our second visit was also good, but not as nice as it was overcrowded, sunny and hot. Nonetheless, these ruins are absolutely sensational, and the trees that grow between them are incredible to see. They entwine as though they have become one with the temples. I suggest going on a day that is overcast instead of sunny, and go later in the day (maybe 3pm), to avoid the crowds.

"Raiders" of the Tomb.. Looking at how huge tree roots that just penetrate through what was once stone walls that provided shelter. I'm at awe at what nature and time can do. A definite must on the Ang Kor Day tour.

A Magical place. What a magical place this is! Absolutely stunned by the giant trees making their way through the temples. Visiting this place threw me a 1000 years back in time. Must visit! WOW! WOW! WOW!

Beautiful trees and incredible routes . Must be seen as words cant describe the beauty of this site. The huge magnificent trees with there incredible routes are just so unbelievably old and beautiful. Take your time and don't rush through the site like most visitors. Pictures you can download but the moment will stay with you if you take the time to be present.
Tomb raider temple. Second day temple tour after Angkar Wat. Amazing how the trees grow in the temple structure. Lotsa of trees which make the walk and tour less humid and hot. Nice place !
Wonderful but erie feeling of another day. Seeing the vast trees overtaking the magnificent Temple reminds us all of what can happen over time without human intervention. A photographers paradise
Sight seeing. More needs to be done on the conservation and restoration. Nonetheless, was impressive. Definitely baby carrier if you have small kids. Stroller not advisable.

Excellent Guide for all of Angkor: Mr. Mey Try. Mr. Try took us to this ruined temple site on our first of 3 days with him. First, he is one of the best guides I have ever been with. He brought everything alive. He is knowledgable, personable and fun to be with. Ta Prohm is the ruin you see in photos with all the tree roots over the temples. The archaeologists left them there for various reasons. It is dedicated to a ruler's mother as I recall. Ask Mr. Try: mentry_58@yahoo.com
Amazing Visit!. This is the temple featured in Tomb Raider located in the Angkor Wat complex. Definitely a must see! Amazing how the trees there just grow out of the stone temples.
My favorite te,ple. This is an amazing temple with trees growing right out of the top of it. Wear comfortable walking shoes and it is a lot of walking. Take water its hot but well worth a visit.

Favourite temple experience in Siem Reap. Don't miss visiting this temple if you're in Siem Reap. The huge tree roots entwined through the stone walls are amazing and like nothing you will see anywhere else. Scenes from Tomb Raider were filmed here

Temple overgrown with huge trees. Ta Prohm was a temple that was still under restoration. The distinctive feature of this site was the huge trees that grown out of the ruins with gigantic roots exposed to the air. The roots were widely spread over the ground surface and coiled round their support. Though conservation and restoration were on-going, the site was intentionally kept to be the same as when it was discovered.
Temples . We personally thought ta prohm is better than Angkor Wat, Angkor Wat is very over rated and the market sellers do nothing but ruin your visit
Crumbling but wow. A very complex structure.ASI of India has done a superb job of restoratiom.Kudos.Some parts under renovation.

very very busy Temple.. the third temple of our excursion day was during the late afternoon and was very crowded with mostly Japanese tourists in very large groups.The knowledge of our guide proved invaluable in being able to avoid the crush of people by taking a counter direction of their tours using passages and paths that seemed to be known only to him. The value of growing up in this area. The only time we could not avoid the crush was at"The Tomb Raider Tree" which would appear to be the "Must Have Photo Op" for most travellers. Long queues of pushing and shoving people wanting to get up close and personal by the tree. Oh well, just one crush is acceptable to see, feel, and enjoy the scope of this amazing place.

The coolest temple you'll see. Sure, Angkor Wat is massive, but Ta Phrom is the most memorable for me. The way the trees have made themselves at home is just amazing. It's large enough for you to spend hours in, and it's in the middle of a jungle area too and that just adds to the spectacle. I've been there twice now, and could absolutely go again. I've got more info at jimmysworldtour.wordpress.com if you want the whole story.

Feeling So Surreal. It has such a Surreal feel. For the most part you can follow a path through the ruins with Platforms built to guide you through and small ropes to prevent any damage to what is this amazing temple. The French government it jointly funding a project for furthering restoration on this site.There was a crane on site ,how ever we did not see any workers the day we visited. Well Marked with names of the trees. Really Incredible site of Man Vs Nature.

Love the towering trees!. One of the best things about Ta Prohm is the amazing trees that tower over the ruins. We went early in the day in the hopes of finding lower numbers of people there, since so many people start out at Angkor Wat in the morning. This plan turned out well, & we really enjoyed the atmosphere of the ruins at Ta Prohm.

Amazing!. This was my favorite stop of the Angkor Wat complex, so much so that I went back another day. The tree roots encompassing the Temple were just amazing, a great show of how nature eventually overtakes mans creations. A beautiful temple even without the trees however much more so with the roots, looking like melted candles, dripping down the sides.
Favorite temple of them all. Really cool to see the battle between nature, ancient man and modern day. Well worth it. Don't follow a tour, discover it for yourself.

Beautiful. An excellent juxtaposition against Angkor Wat. Angkor Wat is refined like an English castle and Ta Prohm is a beautiful dance between time, jungle and temple. As amazing as the temple is the size and power of the jungle to infiltrate the walls and roofs of the temple is awe inspiring.Only recommendation would be when the sign says "long way around" on the guided walking path, take that route. Ta Prohm is invaded not just by jungle but also with large, noisy and honestly rude tour groups; but the tour groups are also lazy and so they take the short routes. The little walk you get alone with the other respectful independent travellers makes the experience worth while.

Forget Tomb Raider just enjoy how fabulous it is!. The number one thing people say is that this is the Tomb Raider temple, but actually it is just beautiful in its own right. It is fascinating how the trees have decided to take back their land and grow through the building. It's sad it is being destroyed but beautiful all the same. Get there quick or there won't be much left!!!!

Beautiful but ruined by crowds. We visited this temple yesterday morning around 10am after seeing Angkor Wat at sunrise and a few other temples. Ta Prohm was the one place I've wanted to see since I was 10 years old and as stunning as it is, you have to deal with hundreds and hundreds of tourists queuing to get that perfect photo, and they stop at nothing, or for no one, to get it. It's overcrowded and combined with the insane heat and having to follow a planned route around the temple, as beautiful and amazing as it is to see, it's being ruined by too many people all crammed in at once. If you can manage to get here and miss the tour buses, this is a must see. It's a stunning place to visit.

Can get quite crowded "Tomb Raider" temple. Beautiful temple where the strangler fig trees make a commanding appearance to the temple. Capturing the beauty of this temple takes a whole day, as there are many interesting corners and corridors. The relief found throughout the temple are prominent and well-preserved. Some parts of the temple have collapsed but restoration works are also in progress. Surrounded by towering trees this temple fits the name "temple in the jungle" well.

Power of Nature. This temple overgrown by roots of beautiful high trees is sure my favorite.The trees are so magnificent and the strong roots moving the whole building are most impressive. This is always a must for me and is very different to all the other temples in various stages of restoration.

The so called 'tomb raider temple'. This temple is absolutely magnificent and if you are ever going to Angkor wat you must visit. It is amazing to walk through the temple and see the nature literally be in the process of taking it back. The only downside is how it is always referred to as the tomb raider temple (I know I mentioned it in tagline). This temple has had hundreds of years worth of history and shouldn't be defined by some terrible Hollywood movie.
Amazing temple!!!. I went to this temple in the morning. The trees and the temples live and support together. Some temples are collasped. But too much tourists here.

Amazing trees!. Ta Prohm is a must see on any visit to the temples. While Angkor Wat is understandably the most popular Ta Prohm takes you somewhere else. Here you will find the amazing trees growing round the ruins and a small place of peaceful retreat. One not to miss

Beautiful temple . Apart from angkor Wat and angkor Tom this is the other most beautiful temple. Amazing tree roots grown into the temple. It is also where tomb raider was filmed if you are interested in film

Stunning Beautiful Temple of Angkor Wat Temple Complex. For me, this temple is even more beautiful than the Angkor Wat itself. I would not waste my time with the other temples. What is further heartening is that India is playing an important role in its restoration.

amazing temple- but too many tour groups moving slowly through it. This really is like something from a movie, well, it is a movie set. However, our visit was a little hampered by large Chinese tour groups who don't seem to realise other people don't want to trudge through as a group. In fact we couldn't get photos of any of the cool bits as they were all over it. Maybe visit off-peak? there are very clean bathrooms at the start of the site. You do get hassled by kids selling stuff more here than at the other temples we visited. Still, it is well worth the visit.

Tomb Raider!. AS the location where the movie Tomb Raider was filmed, there were more tourists interested in figuring out exactly where the shots were filmed than in understanding the site's cultural significance. It's a lovely spot, and gives a good idea what the Angkor complex looked like before building were restored, but it was the least interesting of the Angkor locations we visited.
stunning. we loved this part of the area as well... every time you turned your head..more stunning than the last..

Beautiful but Crowded. This is a must-see temple, after Angkor Wat and Bayon. But be prepared for the crowds and be patient waiting your turn to take photographs beside the many trees that grow out of this temple.
Ta Promh. The location where the Tomb Raider movie was shot. It was a unique experience, lots of temples and tall tress with thick stem

The beauty of nature. It was pretty hot when we went here, so i didn't really enjoy my time there that much, if the weather was a little cooler i'd definitely enjoy my visit more, but well, i guess we were really unlucky, the trees were pretty cool. I advise you to wear a hat and bring an umbrella or a fan to keep you cool if ever you're gonna go to Ta Phrom.

Beautiful. One of our favourite temples at Angkor!
You can still get a rough feeling of what other temples must have looked like when being discovered because of the beautiful combination of the temple structure and the trees that grow in between and around the stones.
Definitely a highlight and must-not-miss!

Overgrown. Love the temples with trees growing over and holding them together, it is so quiet and peaceful around the temples except of course for the ever present tourists, but if you can manage to get away from everyone it is quite serene. Never ceases to amaze how the people of these times built these magnificent temples. One of the best.

site of the movie Lara Croft: Tomb Raider. being the site of the movie above-mentioned... i got curious in an instant... and i was really at awe when i saw the humongous roots of trees covering the temple. just be careful touring inside the temple... you can easily get lost... there is something eerie feeling inside... a bit dark but all in all i enjoyed my tour here.
Truely Amazing. How does it feels to stand by the history of hundreds years of old? Which was destroyed by time and rebuild again to its old shape by keeping mammoth trees raised inside.

amazing trees in Ta Prohm. Apart from the temple itself which is a great historical construction, the trees in the temple are amazing. You have to spend time to explore the inside of the temple as well as to stroll the outskirt of the temple where you can see many spectacular big trees. It is easily the best temple in the Angkor Wat area. I prefer the ruins to the restored temples which many often are not done well showing the modern touches. A must see temple when you are in Siem Reap.
When Nature Takes Over. It is truly fascinating to see what happens when nature takes over. Go early! If not, you’ll see what happens when the TOUR BUSES take over.
Tomb Raider Temple (Ta Prohm). This is one of the best temples at the angkor complex.. You will see the big trees and their roots growing on the stones of the temple.. Its a nice view for pictures.
The best place of angkor wat complex. This is the place of tomb raider movie, this place amazing, with so many ruins of temple covered by old tree, around this place is scenic panorama

Amazing and Spiritual Place. Must see with a professional guide to give you a guide tour in your native language to understand its history. Probably, the highlight of all of the Wat/Temples in Siem Reap.
My favorite. A perfect mix between organic and mineral It's my favourite temple so far ! On the map Ta Prohm is on the big tour but easy to include it in the small one. Unmissable !!

The most photographed temple . This was probably the most impressive to me as it was like being in another time and place. Breathtaking the way nature has reclaimed it but smaller than I expected although still large. Take plenty of water and bug spray
Lara Croft moment :). Been dreaming of visiting this place for the longest time. It exceeded my expectation. Love the place.

Trees. Big trees are bad for the temples, their roots are breaking apart the temple. However it is truly marvellous and a wonderful experience.
Definitely go if in the area

Fabulous Place. This place such a place that you couldn't compare anywhere in the world. Temples which involved by tree roots will hypnotise you. It is not easy describable place so strongly recommend to visit if you are in Siem Reap. I am sure you will take more than 100 photos in this place.
Temple meets nature. The natural destruction is fascinating. Even in the last 12 months things have changed. These temples are a reminder of the power of nature

So Exotic. Such an exotic experience to come here. The other Wats are restored, but here you can see how nature takes over a location pretty quickly. The birds are abundant and it is surrounded by trees. So, as you walk, you hear the different birds, the humidity is a presence, you feel the trees surrounding you (and encroaching on the temple) and many of the stones are surrounding the temple, making it feel and look so old. All of this combined feels so romantic and exotic. Not only was this place beautiful, but it was also an experience.

Tomb Raiders Here We Come. You could film a movie here...maybe they did! Not for the handicaped as it is up and down and around stairs unless you can walk a bit. If you can get here, I would highly recommend this site. A small bit of rain made things a bit slippery. However, it was well worth being careful just to see it!
Raid the tomb!. Such a cool place to hang out with your mates. Beautiful. The trees must be tamed before they tear the place apart.
Incredible. It's better than Angkor Wat in my opinion. If you're debating whether or not to go - GO. It's ruined state makes it more interesting and has so much character. Honestly unmissable.
Amazing place. Do not miss out. One of the must sees of Siem Reap. Beautiful scenery with amazing colours. Perfect for shooting with a camera showing different angles and colours.

Ta Prohm. This was originally called Rajavihara in Khmer style. The uniqueness of this temple is that it is left in the same condition where trees are wrapped around in the temple. Restoration work is going on this temple. There are a lot of gum trees around this place.

An Other-worldly, Breathtaking Ancient Temple. I hired a local personal guide and air conditioned car for our 3 days in Siem Reap. Tha Prohm is a must-see--made famous by Angelina Jolie, who filmed scenes of TOMB RAIDER there. This was my 2nd trip to Siem Reap, and took 2 guests this trip. We visited IKKT Silk Factory, a temple and enjoyed an Apsara performance/dinner our first day. On day 2, we toured Angor Wat & Angor Thom, and attended the Phare Circus that evening, day 3 - Tha Phrom, Bantea Srei, and the Landmine Museum, with sunset on a nearby temple pagoda.
The Roots Temple. One of the three important temples of Sieam Reap. A long walk in and out of the temple but a very interesting visit.
Love how to natural big tree grow. This is where Tomb Raider was shot. I love to see how the big tree wraps around the temple.. it's beautiful and lovely energy too

Magical temple. It was lovely seeing how the trees have grown over, around and through the temples. The roots were intriguing and so many photo opportunities. Loved the moss growing on and around the temples as well.
Feels like a fantasy world. I felt like indiana tomb raider. Not to be missed and somewhat less crowded than nearby Angkor wat. Just go.

breathtaking. This temple is almost better than Angkor Wat! Visit early in the morning and see the sun come up! It is a fabulous experience to witness the sheer presence of the jungle taking over and covering up this beautiful temple. A never to be forgotten experience. If you are in the area don't miss it!
Sightseeing. what a stunning place unbelievable how the trees are growing amazing to see them and take photographs one of the highlights of the tour.
Mutual support. The trees and the ruins mutually support each other. Fascinating site which no one should miss if they are in the area.

Best of Angkor Thom. Of all the temples we saw, this was my favourite one. It is just so mind boggling to see these ruins and how the massive trees have wrapped themselves around the stones. It is amazing to see the juxtaposition of the power of nature and the craftsmanship behind the temple itself. Truly awe-inspiring. Thanks to Angelina Jolie for putting this on the map through her movies. Our driver dropped us on one end and met us on the other side so we wouldn't have to walk up and down unnecessarily. Makes sense.

Our favorite stop in Siem Reap.. We really enjoyed this temple and not because of the movie. The way the trees have grown in the temple and become part of the foundation is really neat to see. It makes for a lot of fun and unique photo opportunities.

Great film set, great temple – Tomb Raider the best. Loved this place. Not of course the best in terms of the size, and the scale. But for sheer uniqueness this place was fantastic. Tree routes everywhere, tumbled down tunnels, weird animal noises from the forest. Also massive respect for the group of musicians, maimed by landmines. They played local music and just got on with living. Stop and give them a dollar or two as they so deserve it.

The most spiritual place I once knew. When I walked into Ta Prohm 2 years ago I was blown away at how tranquil and spiritual the place was. I am not an overly spiritual person but you could almost feel the temple and trees resonating with mystical energies of love and calmness. When I came is year, it seemed that part of the magic that Ta Prohm had once held was gone. Due to erosion and a few architectural problems, tourists are now not permitted to venture wherever they wish and have to be cattle herded in one direction...and with the amount of tourists that still visit this site you really do feel claustrophobic in the sea of bodies. I wanted Ta Prohm to always be my special place of visitation but now it holds no meaning for me. Oh, I would still suggest you go, if nothing else to feel like Lara Croft, but the tourist trap that it has become does nothing for me. I hope people's experience can outweigh mine for the better.

Go first thing in the morning. Go first thing in the morning to beat the crowds and for the best light. Amazing. Don't forget to look for several statues almost hidden in the tree roots. And buy a little bracelet from the little girl.

Tomb raider temple. This one was unreal... The trees and all of there roots are out of a movie ! In fact they were in a move ! Tomb Raider with Angelina Jolie. As we explored we go-pro video taped it as well, it's really out of this world !

Surreal experience. This was my favorite of all the ruins in the area. You'll feel like Indiana Jones or Lara Croft as you walk through the structures which have been completely overtaken by the enormous banyan trees. Some pictures I've seen labeled as Ankor Wat are really Ta Prohm.
nice. WNice templets absolutely worth visiting. Can recommend, try this you self. Much to see and discuss afterwards
most known temple, very crowded. one of the best known temples due to movies, nevertheless fascinating place. A good guide is a great idea to get more info when you visit.
when nature takes over. another great place to visit and just walk around discovering beauty of nature that took over the temple, take water as it gets very hot
Ruins at its best. Of all the temples in the archeological park . Nature has caused most destruction in Ta Prohm . However this man made temple almost devoured by nature is a vision.

A dream come true . We visited Ta Prohm in a small group of 8 people. With our tour leader we usually walked apart from the big groups but unfortunately we sometimes had to cross them... Nevertheless it was a dream come true... The temple has a beautiful scenery... The trees and the buildings seem to have become one. Unfortunately a few trees have been destroyed through heavy storm and have to be chopped down. But the atmosphere is still there. Some part are being rebuilt at the moment. I would count 1,5 hours to visit this place.

Like a Maze. This temple is a do not miss, but it can be a bit annoying with the amount of people for the photo shots.. Beware to try to remember your path inside. It is mostly ruins and you can get a bit lost of your direction, so allow some extra time to get out..haha

Fairytale Temple. This was the best temple. More enjoyable the Angkor Wat or Angkor Thom. It was not crowded and the trees intertwining with the building it majestical. There is an outside way to go around and see more trees (some you can even stand in) and come back in and explore some more. It is an amazing experience and reminds me of a fairytale.

Atmosphereic ruined temple. Our local All Points East guide was amazing at taking us to the jungle clad temples by the most interesting route. We availed the tourist entrance and walked up though the jungle to the incredible gateway with the smiling Buddha heads. We climbed and scrambled over 2 vast dry moats and outer walls until we arrived in the inner temple to marvel at the invasive tree routes. At dusk the temple takes on a really magical feeling.

A must see!. Trace the steps of Lara Croft in this amazing temple overtaken by nature. A monument of human civilization that was completely overpowered by amazing trees should be your first stop after visiting the main Angkor Wat temple in the complex. We spent 2 hours simply marveling at the power of nature and found much needed peace and quiet at this tourist-ridden hotspot. Make sure you take extra batteries for your camera and plenty of water!

Tombrider Movie was shot here. This temple was amazing..the trees grew within. Many fallen stones but restoration is being taken place. Its an amazing creation! There will be a loud sound of insect sounds like the cricket but do ask your tourguide what animal it is. I saw one and it looks like a cross between a fly and a roach. Eeee! I suggest to wear flats or a pair of snickers. The trail is amazing...
Nature at its best. This was an amazing site with the trees growing around and over the temple. It was quite the site to see how nature has taken hold of the temple

Witnessing the awesome force of nature. It never fails to awe me that inspite of the grandeur of the structure, nature is able to take over. This was the place that Angelina Jolie filmed at for the first Tomb Raider movie. The trees literally burst out of the walls of this ancient architecture. You will be in awe.

Simply Stunning. You can't help but be amazed by this place. It's simply stunning! As you walk around the site it's hard not to imagine what it would be like 800 years ago! My only negative was the mass crowds of tourists. I too was a tourist but I like to think I was more considerate that most and tried not to photo bomb other peoples photos or push in line for a mass selfie at certain points. It's still a beautiful place and a must see!

I give this place the most mysterious and beautiful temple of all the temples in Angkor Wat.. You will see the big ancient trees in the movie scene of Tomb Raider here. So marvelous. Looks sacred in a way. If you have much time you can rent a bike here. All the temples are very near to one another accept Phnom Bakeng.

Out skirts of the temple are quiet and beautiful.. We went here and actually walked the wrong way around (yes there are arrows haha).. But that being said were we went was very quiet and very few people. Loved this place and yes the tree over the arch is impressive... Getting a good photo is always hard as there are usually so many people here but we were lucky.I must say that the 3 main temples are always busy.. If you really want a tranquil experience, get a driver to take you to a lesson known temple early in the morning.. These are usually deserted at that time as everyone starts at the big 3... We had one place all to ourself.. it was hauntingly beautiful...

Amazing. Seeing how the forest has enveloped the temple buildings is amazing. It is great to see an unrestored temple but frightening to see how nature can destroy and overtake a building. Our 2nd best after Angor Wat.
My favourite temple. This is the Tomb Raider temple, the one where the jungle has taken hold. Very atmospheric but too many annoying groups.

Majestic Trees. We visited this temple first after watching the Sunrise at Angkor Wat. It was quiet, peaceful and cool at that time of the day. Its nice to just walk around and take in the amazing things that nature has done here.

Amazing. OF course watching Tomb Raider expectation was really high. It is amazing how the jungle took over this temple over the years. The size of the trees are amazing and the strength of the temple in withstanding the force of roots is amazing.
crowded. tried to get photos without other tourists in them but couldn't manage. very crowded and quite overrated

The "Tomb Raider" Temple. This is the place where Angelina Jolie appeared in her Tomb Raider film---a temple overgrown with large trees whose roots cover major portions of buildings. It is am amazing place, and I recommend going early in the morning to avoid the crowds. It is a small temple and would be hard to see with several busloads of tourists running around trying to see it at the same time. It is my favorite place in Angkor, and one that should not be missed!

She's a beauty but loads of tourists there . I love this temple but it was difficult with my elderly Mum. Nooks and crannies twists and turns and crowds to navigate. This is the temple Jayavarman VII built for his mother's mortuary cult. A less popular option is the one he built for his father known as Prea Khan. I think just as pretty and not as difficult.

Go really early. Seriously, don't bother going after 8 Am, you will be disappointed. Make this the first stop of the day and you will really enjoy it. Make sure to go outside the temple and walk the perimeter, it is amazing.

Magical place . Ta Prohm was magic from the start. The first thing you see is a small ruin of a building with a tree coming straight out of it. The tree and the building are one now, after centuries of growth. As you pass by this first building you see how expansive the temple complex is. Ruins and trees growing up through and around them. Absolutely stunning.
HUGE trees have eaten the ruins. These are the ruins from the Angelina Jolie movie, "Tomb Raider". Very eerie. Trees are so large, it wasn't possible to get an entire one in a picture.

Study. It is recommendable to hire a local guide. Several companies offer their service. It means, that you are free of queing up at the entrance and will get answers of very many questions - in a way we liked.Visit Ta Prohm early in the morning, before the busses arrive and you will enjoy the mysteries and beauti of this temple.The almost hidden women is a nice little extra.Find a quiet place in a corner and you will enjoy the temple - and the people visiting and taking photos, while standing in very peculiar way.

Breath taking. My top temple in Angkor Wat. I visited it ealry in the morning and was there almost on my own. I could walk around in silence, take pictures without having too many people. The temple itself is wow! I will tell no more - must see.

Jolly interesting. Make sure you have something to tell you of the history of this place. It is enchanting. Be prepared for lots of tourists taking photos, which can detract from the overall experience. Still well worth a visit though.
Amazing sights. Very interesting, and lots of photo opportunities. Feels really ancient. Restoration loses it a bit of charm.
amazing place to visit. the way the jungle has started to reclaim the temple it a sight to behold and a true one in a lifetime opportunity to see.

A amazing place to be early in the morning!. If really u wonna feel that magic place of khmer history...than go there early in the morning. my tuktuk-driver Sam brougth me there early in the morning (9 am) after visiting Angkor Wat first. take time and drink a coffee in a small restaurant near the Road and feel the people working around there 4 their old culture... . If u are early there u enjoy that special place - u need quiet, u Need Time to observe and discover that magic place. l nötig wonder why Angelina la belle..choose that place too 4 her film. If u are late nötig to be surprised by the tsunami of tourist groups.. especially chinese....verry loud an unfriendly way with less respec 4 other visitors! Ni hao ma? Take someone water with u there in the case to be thursty...take time after your visit to enjoy a Khmer yellow noodle soup in a small restaurant there and invite your tuktuk driver too - to Thank him 4 the good job he did/do 4 you. To visit Ta Phrom u need a official visit card one day 20$ - to get first at the Central Gate. My driver Sam Tel 092 945 331 will be a real help in your discovering action. Tell him my name Paul.. You will enjoy a good save relaxed trip into Khmer Culture!

Lines are long. The line to see the famous tree of Angelina Jolie is long. You have to fall in line to get your picture taken. However, some people want you out of the picture because it ruins the view of the tree.

My favorite temple in Siem Reap. This was my favorite temple in Siem Reap. We were able to climb on some of the rocks and trees and the landscape made it the most unique temple my group visited. Our tour guide kept calling this the "Tomb Raider" temple, because the movie had scenes from here.

Ta Prohm Temple (originally called Rajavihara). Within this 12th Century temple is the famous shot from the movie Tomb Raider. This is a jungle temple what with how the trees have entangled around the temple structures. It truly is a photographers dream. It is wonderful to see the amount of reconstruction going on with this temple.

Atmospheric. There are a couple of iconic views based on the trees that have wrapped themselves around parts of this temple, but there is much more to see here than just the well-known views. A must-see during a visit to Angkor Wat.

Tomb Raider!. Only problem here is that everyone visits and, because of the more fragile nature of the temple (due to the trees growing through) the route through is more laid out and regimented than elsewhere.However, this is a truly amazing place - you won't get the photos of a deserted temple, and you may have to wait to take your photo at the key places, but it's all worth the effort.

Do yourslf a favour. These are the most incredible ruin to visit you almost expect to see a troop of wild monkeys rush out of the ruin. Be warned it is hot and very humid at the site so plenty of water and good comfortable walking shoes are a must as for all the Angkor temples

Spooky and beautiful (but take your time). Ta Prohm is simply surreal. The enormous trees growing over the ruins are simply awe inspiring and stunning. It's a got a very spooky atmosphere (if you can block out the crowds) but really explore. It's much bigger than you think. We went a second time and discovered a whole section we didn't see the first time, and there were hardly anyone else there. The 'Tomb Raider' tree is spectacular but there are many other bits that are equally impressive.

Wonderful. The moment I liked the most during this visit was the pause in front of the tree grown up in the wall.I find it more interesting than Angkor Wat even if it is in ruins.It has nice sculpted motifs on the wall that were nicely preserved.

Interesting how the trees are growing. This temple, while still in the midst of reconstruction is very interesting to see how the trees have grown throughout the temple. Many within the rock walls of the buildings. While it is exciting to know that a movie was filmed here, the experience itself is very nice and beautiful.

aka "The Tomb Raider Temple". Almost as iconic as Angkor Wat itself, seeing the massive strangler figs slowly consuming this temple is a wonderful contrast to the restored temples that surround it. Come early or late for the most atmosphere/fewest other tourists

TA PROHM. Amazing-different- Too bad it rained all afternoon, but still got a lot out of it. The roots are far above the ground. Remember which end you entered so as not to get lost when you are done exploring.

Looking for Tomb Raiders. Kept my eye out for dodgy looking characters...didn't see any...however did see a window into the past.. a past that to this day intrigues me. what did they do here, how did they build it, why did they leave?A great monument & a great experience.

Amazing Place. This is one of the most amazing places I have ever been. You can see how nature and ruins are fusion in one. The buildings are amazing, the full site is something you may not see in any other plaes. All Siam Rep archiological sites are unique and for me one of the must amazing places on earth all Khmer Empire, including this site, Ankor Wat and Bayon.

Lara Croft Tomb raider. Filmed at Ta Prohm. Waterfall and crocodile tree are a beautiful view on and over the temple. One of many temples with trees growing over and on, but unfortunately also destroying walls and temple buildings due weight and roots pushing walls to fall or collaps.
Even better than Ta Prohm is Beng Mealea! !!!!!!
Awesome jungle temple. This temple is overgrown with huge trees! When you are there, you understand immediately why they recorded several takes of the Tomb Raider movie over here!

Like a move set. We went there Jan 2014. Although similar this is somewhat different type of ruins. You'll see how nature can overcome works of man. They were doing some renovations/reconstructions on some areas when we were there so some areas were off limits. Maybe next time we can visit it again

Start you temples visit here. A superb relic with the highlights for me being the way the forest is reclaiming the temple. The spiders web tree is worth the entrance alone. Be prepared for the manic marketing from the locals when you exit the gates and visit the toilets. It's a hard sell, but all part of the wonderful experience of Cambodia. Also check out the dinosaur on the stone carvings, unbelievable!!!

This amazing place will knock your socks off!. Tomb Raider fans would love this incredible temple. Beautiful artwork, great atmosphere and so photogenic. I was lucky enough to visit it on damp morning when only a few tourists were there.. It's a romantic place and to me, one of the best sites to visit in the area. Can't wait to see it again.

Go early (5.30am) and you will have a peaceful visit. Wel worth getting up pearly for a very different experience to Angkor Wat. This temple will eventually be destroyed by the trees that are growing through it but not anytime soon. It mght be a different story in 10 years time
Shows wat nature can do if left alone. To see the way the trees have taken over is simply amazing. Quite incredible to see tree roots that have moved large walls and gone between the stonework

Bring your Tomb Raider poses. This place needs to be seen. If come in the afternoon is quieter so can get pictures alone easier. The trees growing around the temple is beautiful and as you walk round each turn has another picture in waiting. One of our favourite temples.
They call it the Movie Temple. A temple where Tomb rider was once shot. As for historical or religious interest it can't be even close compared with Angkor Wat

Tomb raider scenes!. We visited 3 temples in the are and Ta Prohm is the one I remember mostly for the amazing trees that grows on top of the buildings. Some scenes if Tomb Raider was filmed here and you will recognize some trees from the film. Amazing pictures can be taken here.
Tomb Raider!. A part of the Tomb Raider film was filmed here because of its earie beauty; the jungle reclaiming the earth from the construct of humans. Very cool

Ta Prohm. Great site. Lots of people go there. Try to get to the sites early. Best to go to the temples early in the morning. This temple though has more protection from the sun. Lots of pictures to take.
Eiree and one of the very best experiences. It is difficult to comprehend how this could have occurred. The Indian Government are very involved. The restoration work continues.
Jewell in the crown. So very interesting to walk around this temple and listen to the history, a once in a life time for most visitors to Cambodia and not to be missed.

My favourite of them all!. At every turn there are crumbling temples that have been taken over by nature. The huge tree roots that have embedded themselves into the temples are a breathtaking sight. This is definitely a photographers haven. Every corner there is a new amazing sight to be seen! A must see and my favourite of all the temples in the Angkor Wat complex!

Destroyed by Nature. The cooler temples really have to have something that distinguishes them over others. For Ta Prohm, it's the melding of nature and temple. The trees are slowly tearing this one apart and it's pretty awesome.

Dramatic. Ta Phrom takes your breath away. The elaborate ruins , the gorgeous trees embracing the ruins give such a dramatic feel to the place .The trees are gigantic soaring into the sky with roots which are huge and snake around the temple in fascinating shapes. A must see place and great photo ops :)

Still One of the Favorites. From all the temples I've visited, this is still one of my favorites. Go on an off peak time so that you can enjoy the serenity of the place and watch the tall trees from below. It's just amazing to see how the tree roots have intertwined with the temple ruins itself. It's just sad because if you go on a peak time where loads of tourists are around, it is not the same ambiance you experience.

Mesmerising!. Out of all temples I was left mesmerised by this place. When u think about HOW it is possible, you think about Mother Nature and start appreciating every second of your present. I would advise you to embrace one of the trees and charge yourself with a new and powerful energy for a few minutes, you will feel it straight after.
Must see. I did a small circle and liked this one the most. Breath taking and very photogenic, definitely worth to spend some time there.
Tomb Raider Temple. the temple is very unique, where tree plant on the temple. it have mystically beautiful. the best to visit at noon time.

Great environment with huge trees. The Temple is in very ruined state. The conservation work is going on with the initiative of Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) the temple is attraction for tourist due to Tomb rider Angelina Jolie also. But it is a very attractive temple complex.
The power of the Jungle. An awesome sight to see the beauty as well as the destructive nature of the Jungle on this ancient temple
Finally. This place is one of my dream place to go when i was in college days too much worth it to see this awesome place.when i was here im too much amaze every details how to create this place.

RAJAVIHARA @ TA PROHM beautiful carvings with trees growing out of the ruins . We were there on 13th November 2015 .If you are going 2-4 people better take 1 TUK TUK . It will be cheap and saving trip with different experience travel journey . We rent a van as we when 2 family with Kids . Ta Prohm is a wonders I can say , numerous beautiful carvings . Ta Prohm is the modern name of the temple at Angkor. Originally called Rajavihara . The trees growing out of the ruins are perhaps the most distinctive feature of Ta Prohm .The temple of Ta Prohm was used as a location in the film Tomb RaiderOverall observation says that the trees growing out of the ruins and the jungle surroundings have made it one of the most popular temples for tourist to visit and take an amazing shoots. Good place to bring Kids , our children explore many things specially carving mixed with mother nature make them feel their so lucky to be there at their age.
ow the tree roots.. Like being in a secret garden. I loved the tree roots covering buildings, must be so difficult to manage

Better early in the morning . This temple is the one i liked best in angkor. The problem is that it is included at the end of what they call small tour, so by the time you get to ta prohm it is really hot, you are exhausted after walking all morning, and it is really crowded. My advice is to visit this temple early in the morning, first thing if you didn't go to see sunrise, or right after sunrise in angkor wat if you did.You 'll love it
unbielivable sight. Trees growing out of buildings ??? this is a sight not to miss, even in a torrential rainstorm as we had.

Giant tree . The tree is breathtaking and is totally different from other templs around. The Cambodian government started restoration for Ta Prohm and the view was still breathtaking. Ta Prohm is more than a giant tree as it has several sides to capture nice photos.

Unfortunately most of the roots have been removed.. They are still doing construction and have removed the roots instead of reinforcing. I would have preferred to see the natural beauty of nature taking back its land.

Lara Croft - Tomb Raider. Used during the filming of Tomb Raider, these ruins are a case of the temple being swallowed up by the jungle, albeit somewhat trimmed back. The trees must be hundreds of years old and the visible root structures are amazing. As with most of the Angkor temples, the site is undergoing restoration and are there numerous piles of stones etc. That said, there is plenty to look at and some great photo opportunities.

Never seen a better example of nature reclaiming. If you are going there, chances are you have already seen it from the movie Tomb Raider. It has a very high sense of mysticism because of the gigantic tree roots eating their way into the buildings. There will be lots of picture opportunities there but you might have to queue a bit. Also, they built a wooden platform right in front of it's most famous bit, for pictures of course, but it kind of spoils the natural feeling of the place. I hope they get rid of that abomination soon.

The bomb!. LOVED this ruin! Could spend a whole day here!! Lots of beautiful carvings, detail, and the lore behind it is mind blowing!The wall alone around the outside goes up 20+ feet and is so thick, 2-3 elephants could walk on the top side by side! There are monkeys in front you can feed, super cute!

breathtaking. Ta prom is amazing..that's all I can say, a mix of temple e twined with the jungle.I went one day at 1pm, it was busy and difficult to take pictures and get a true ambience so I went back the following day immediately after sunrise, 6.30 is I pretty much had the place to myself and it was beautiful. Ask your tuk tuk driver to wait for you immediately after sunset and take you to the east gate of ta prom (the walk to the temple is not as long fro here and then ask him to pick you up at the west gate. It will make sense when you do it. No long sleeves needed here.

Bizarre. Must-see experience.. There's nothing quite like Ta Phohn. We visited in the rain, which made it even more atmospheric. It's a jumble of trees, fallen temple walls, carvings. Something new at every turn. The things that's hilarious though are all the tourists that pose in that Laura Croft stance. The power of Hollywood truly is worldwide!

Vegetation in splendor growth amongst the ruins.. Almost as if Bonsai practiced amongst the crumbling ruins of a glorious past. Enjoyable visit in spite of the heat and humidity. Yes Mother Nature triumphs!
Who thought trees were cool!. Honestly so impressed by the sheer size of the trees here' never seen anything like it in my life!! Really impressive as they wind round the temples.
Stunning. This was another breathtaking experience that offers you the chance to see superb detailed carvings mixed with mother nature. Not until you see it can you appreciate it.

Outstanding. Just wow!!!! For us, among all, this was the best one. Temple, nature and sounds of nature around - outstanding. And it is not because of Tomb Raider movie. Temple is located about 1km east of Angkor Thom. We found out that Ta Prohm has been left in much the same condition in which it was found, known by its trees growing out of the ruins. Temple is on the UNESCO World Heritage List since 1992.

Ta Prohm - Well Worth Seeing!. We visited Ta Prohm on a recent visit to Siem Reap. This temple was made famous in the Angelina Jolie movie and we were anxious to see it. Trees have overgrown the temple and it feels like they are holding it all together. It has a mysterious feel to it and we certainly enjoyed being there. We were expertly guided by Sim Sophath and had been brought to the site by John Sochheat, our tour guide/driver.This temple is very popular with visitors and once you get there, it is easy to see why. A very enjoyable visit.Lyn and David, Brisbane, Australia.

One of my favourite places in Angkor!. This spot is popular because it was featured in the 'Tomb Raider' movie starring Angelina Jolie. It felt really cool to be in the same spot they shot those scenes. While the architecture and carvings are beautiful, the most stand-out features of this location is the surreal-looking trees and how nature is reclaiming the temple within it's huge twisted roots. This is definitely a must-see location when visiting Siem Reap and Angkor.

Too many tourists, guides, selfie stick!. The place is no longer a good spot to appreciate history and nature. There were simply too many large crowd of tourists with their guides as well as selfie stick. There were designated path for us to walk on and you could not pace yourself to enjoy the nature. You were simply being pushed to walk further. There were tourists competing to take the perfect pictures and waiting in lines at certain infamous spot.I even saw one tourist sprinkling her loved ones ash at the tree while her partner took her photo doing that with many tourists queuing behind them to wait for their turns to take photos. If you must go, go early. Go before large crowd of tourists arrived.

Awesome Ta Prohm. I love the seemingly untouched ruins of the centuries-old temple evidenced by big roots of trees growing over stone walls and pillars. Except for the presence of throngs of tourists, it gives an eerie feeling of the ancient times.

Really interesting. Loved this Temple. It really was something out of a movie. I expected lara Croft or someone from raiders of the lost arc to come out from behind the huge trees. Very interesting and a place your imagination could run riot!

Don't miss this while in Siem Reap. Liked the experience of walking around Ta Prohm more than Angkor Wat.It might have been the comfort of the trees surrounding this area - somewhat special I would say.But the complex was in a dilapidated condition. And it was nice to know that the Indian government is helping the restoration of Ta Prohm. I could see some restoration work going on around at that time.Also, there were a group of musicians on the way from one of the entrances. Listened to them for quite some time.

Amazing trees. It's not so much about the trees when you think about This visit but you what you see are Alien like roots and trunks of trees growing out of these ancient temples - this was also a monastery by the way!Great photo opportunity.By the way do buy the book Ancient Angkor from one of the hawkers in the coach park on the way in- it's a great guide. Don't pay more than $6. Very informative.We had a guide. But, we were in awe of the detailed carvings and the atmospher is addictive.Don't miss this one.
