Tombraider Temple. Our favorite, the trees took over this site around 400 years ago and dominate the architecture, a must to visit

Ta Prohm visit. Late 12th Century jaw dropping and stunning site where nature (rainforest) took over. It has been maintained in such natural state which gives it a magical aura. The trees appear to embrace and melt into the structure. Awesome.

Atmospheric and so interesting. Listed as number 4 on the 'Temples to See' list - I would put it at number 2. It is in an incredible state of dis-repair and doesn't offer the same volume of friezes, carvings and statues but in my opinion is just a fantastic area to see. A jungle temple being absorbed by nature and her Strangling Fig trees.

Harmony between nature and culture. We didnt watch Tomb Raider, but we spent more time in Ta Prohm than the others, as it was really fascinating. A very interesting place for nature lovers and photo takers. The architecture was amazing, the trees are breathtaking, the experience was exceptional. The temple is quite big so you may get lost of directions, but you can always ask around as the locals are helpful. Do not climb on top of the temples, as it is a very disrespectful act.

Or as they now call it Temple of the Trees, Tomb Raider Temple. This is so much more than the movie Tomb Raider could ever show..but since the movie they now call it Temple of the Trees. Beautiful ancient Banyan trees which go on and are wrapped around the temple. It's absolutely beautiful and no movie could ever give it justice it's a must see in person. Make sure you get the 3 day $40.00 pass as you will want to see many of the temples..and all these temples aren't just temples..they are breathtaking and absolutely wonders of the world.
Great Place. I loved visiting the complex, it was immense but it was a bit hot although I went in November. There's a bit of walking involved but the site is worth seeing most definitely!
Tomb Raider Temple. It's incredible how these huge trees are growing through and atop these temple ruins. Don't miss this one!

The Bane of Tomb Raider. The "Tomb Raider Tree" delegation ruined this place. It is now the most crowded most littered temple in all of the Angkor region, with lineups to take photos in front of the Tree on a precisely-placed wooden photo box. It's hard to get lost here because there are people at every turn. And the authorities refused to restore it because the tourists like the "lost city" vibe too much.Admittedly, my bias comes from being an archaeologist in the region, but there are plenty better temples at Angkor to visit. If you want the same vibe, less tourists, and less clout, go to Preah Khan, Banteay Kdei, or Ta Som. All of them are Jayavarman VII-era temples outside the traditional "small circuit" of Angkorian tourism, but are most definitely worth the trek.

Fascinating. I enjoyed this temple complex even more than Angkor Wat. The temples are all still mostly unrestored in the jungle and the trees and vegetation is growing in through the temples. It is where the Tomb Raider movies were filmed and as we came across more and more amazing sights I kept thinking I was in an artificially created theme park . We arrived at 7.30 am and we had the place mostly to ourselves until about 9.00 when the crowds started to flood in and it was starting to heat up so I would recommend going as early as you can.
more than tomb rader. must see place! down & sunset time are both worth to visit. Hope to have some rest there in the near future.

Go early for a peaceful visit. Be prepared to have your breath taken away. You can't even fathom how amazing the trees are that are trying to reclaim this beautiful temple. Go early to ensure great lighting for photography - and to avoid lots of tourists. Be patient, also. Some people aren't aware of anyone but themselves, so you may need to shoot several shots of the same spot - because people walk right into your field of view.
fascinating temple with incredible trees. this was our first temple that we visited -- home of the movies -- and now we know why. this is as impressive as it comes

Where was Lara Croft?. Really, she was the only thing missing from this incredible wonder of the world. The way that the jungle is slowly taking this place over and tying it tot he landscape is visually stunning and spooky. Well worth the visit!

Very unusual. This is a joy and spookily different from any other ruin I have visitedRenovation has not progressed far as yet but the trees growing out from and around the ruins makes a marvellous spectacleDefinitely worth a visit.

Peaceful if you go at the right time. . Ta Prohm was one of my favourite temples. We went there twice. The first time was late morning and we could not fully enjoy it because of the crowds of people. Luckily our tour guide showed us a quieter corner where we could sit and observe the blend of nature and history. We decided to go again at 7am without our tour guide. At times we felt like the only ones there and could explore without getting jostled around. The bird calls were amazing at this time and we could sit and listen without any interuptions.

Even better than Angkor Wat. These temple ruins are fascinating and take the time to explore the site. Often called the tomb raider or Angelina Jolie temple as this is where the film was shot. Huge Spung trees have rooted themselves in numerous places over the ruins engulfing them in giant squid like tentacles.
Amazing.. All the temples were very interesting. We saw some as part of a tour and then hired a tuk tuk for the remaining days to revisit.

Nature takes over. This is where a part of Angelina Jolie's movie 'Lara Croft - Tomb Raiders' was shot. It's extremely crowded, so might be better to visit early in the morning. The views again are absolutely stunning.
Great photo Op. Great photo op to take pictures. Carvings inscribed into the walls records the evolved history of Cambodian people.
Wonderful. If you visit Angkor Wat, please don't miss Ta Prohm. It's the one I like most. Very beautiful and amazing.

Where Nature and Culture Meet. This was our 2nd stop for our Tuktuk tour in Angkor Wat. Ta Prohm has less open fields than other temples, as you can reach a stage-like structure a few meters from the outer wall. What makes it different though, was the presence of plants, and how most of the trees have 'eaten' their way through some of the walls and blocked some passages. You can see how strong these structures are

Worth a visit. The highlight of Ta Prohm is definitely the tree growing through the temple. Lots of interesting stonework and great photo ops if you can navigate the hordes of tourist groups that manipulate locations. Lovely walk to the temple, not so nice when you walk back and are set about by hawkers. Overall still worth a visit.

Exotic Temple. Ta Prom or as sometimes called; The Jungle Temple may be the picture that many people have of Angkor Wat, trees have overgrown the temple and are growing out of the walls. This is spectacular to see and much easier to walk through than Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. My wife had a knee replacement a few years ago and she had problems climbing through the other temples, but this temple was relatively easy to explore. To date, there has been minimal reconstruction, however, India is currently undertaking a major reconstruction. I hope that they don't do anything to remove the fig trees.
Crowded. I think that the Tomb Raider hype has hurt this temple. Way too many people stopping for too many pictures.

Amazing place too many people . While this is an absolutely amazing place the sheer number of visitors at the time we were there really diminished our enjoyment, the tour groups were loud and pushy - no zen here!

Well worth the visit. We arrived early in the morning before too crowded. It was so peaceful walking through this amazing attraction and having the time to admire the wonder of nature.We loved it all. The force of nature is certainly at work here in a most tranquil way. We were taken by a car, but could easily have done this with a tuk tuk.
A Step Back in Time. The trees and tranquil setting make this temple worth the extra time it takes to get here. Right before sunset is best.

Guided tour visit was too rushed. The temple is really worth seeing but we went on a guided tour and it was really too rushed to allow for a proper examination and appreciation of the carvings etc. You will probably get better value out of a self arranged visit by tuk tuk with an illustrated guide book or, alternatively, hire a guide for the day.
Breathtaking . Go early and avoid the crowds. A wonderful experience to see nature taking over the ruins. My favourite of all the temples I saw in Cambodia.
See this. Again if you are staying in Siem Reap then this is another must see attraction, smaller than the others but just to see how the trees have grown into the buildings is amazing
Wow and wow!. I thought that visiting another temple after having seen Angkor Wat would be disappointing but Ta Prohm is amazing. Well worth the drive from Siem Reap.

Must see! Especially for Tomb Raider / Lara Croft fans. While Angkor Wat in general is amazing, this place will appeal to those with some gaming background. Walking around in Ta Prohm feels like being in Tomb Raider 3. Wondering around the trees growing out from the ruins and listening to the exotic birds, I felt the same excitement as I did back when I was a kid and played Tomb Raider...Gaming put aside, it wonderful to see how nature reclaimed this territory and took over the ruins. Of course she has been pushed back again by the tourism industry, but still you'll get the feel of the struggle between nature and man.Wonderful atmosphere, I suggest to arrive early and spend a couple of hours.
The highlight of our temple tour day!. This was the reason I wanted to visit Cambodia...and was worth the trip! Very beautiful and well preserved. There are many tourists but not too bad.
Fantastic. This is a really fantastic site, so big and ancient, just lovely to be there. it was not overcrowded either for such and important site.
Trees are the main thing. Very interesting temple with lots of giant trees integrating with the temple parts. If you are a fan of Tomb Rider, then it is a must visit.

Tomb Raider!. One of the more famous ancient ruins that gained its fame through the Tomb Raider movie by Angelina Jolie. An untouched temple ruin that dates back to the 1200. Spectacular with plenty of photo opportunities. Ensure good shoes and prepare for a long walk.

The power of nature. Ta Prohm is evidence of how powerful nature is. The seasons have taken their toll on the temples and mother nature has taken back what is rightfully hers. The trees growing from the temples are a sight to behold.

Nature reclaiming the ruins of this ancient temple. Great tour of some ancient ruins of this 12th Century Buddhist temple - only a little bit spoiled by the clamouring begging children trying to sell postcards and magnets at the entrance to the grounds. Awesome sights - one part in particular was used in the movie Lara Croft, Tomb Raider.
Amazing. Amazing place. We did a half day tour of the temples and sites around Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm and Bayon were the best. Going here for sunset is apparently phenomenal.

A really interesting couple of hours. I enjoyed the time spent at this temple with the ruins being reclaimed by the jungle. The tree roots entwined with the bricks was very picturesque. I managed to get a bit lost in this one.

My Favourite Temple. This is my favourite temple among all I visited in Camnbodia. The photogenic and atmospheric combination of trees growing out of the ruins and the jungle surroundings have made it a very nice scene. I always feel amazing when I see some part of the temple actually hide under the root. A MUST visit temple in Siem Reap.

Cambodian History. Very enjoyable we spent 2 hours there and as usual was overwhelmed by the history. One local man was here and he sort of took us to some little places inside the temple. It was actually very helpful and I gave him a tip at the end and he was happy. Highly recommend this trip.
Absolutely Amazing!!!. Hidden gems of Cambodia it's a must to see and do in Seim Reap. I never saw anything like this in my life, unbelievable.

The trees and roots look big in the pictures - but they are gargantuan when you see them live!. Do not miss this location - made popular by the Tomb Raider movie, but it is a testament to how nature is still holding and at the same time ripping apart a man made tribute to nature (sort of). The size of the trees is about 3 - 5 stories high and the roots are all over. Remember to ask your guide to show you the stegosaurus? carving.
Lara Croft eat your heart out!. One of many amazing temples obviously made famous by the Tomb Raider films. It is amazing in its own right and it's staggering how the trees have grown over the walls.
Wonderful, but overcrowded. Too much tourists, very difficult to see some objects and make a gooD photo. Select proper time to visit this place
Impressive. However the scaffolding isnt great and it spoiled a lot of photographs for me. However the temples have to be preserved. This along with most other temples gets extremely crowded.
Amazing. The way the roots of trees over the years have grown through the walls and brick work is Amazing. Not as large as Angkoe Wat but still as spectacular
our favourite. temple in the forest many of plants what what growing around the stonewall fresh place for go away from the hot zones

Tomb Raider. Mysteries, eerie and down right beautiful. My favourite of the temple complexes still semi untouched adding to the character of the place. Monsoon during my visit and I personally believe it made it better and added to the atmosphere of the place!
Tomb Raider. Particularly enjoyed this spot as I am a Tomb Raider fan and seeing it up close brought back memories of the movie.

Interesting and Photogenic. Quieter and smaller than the overcrowded Angkor Wat. Pleasant morning stroll around the shaded temple grounds. Overgrowth of large tree roots make for interesting scenery. Currently undergoing a long term archeological renovation. Fallen stones have been studied and marked for putting the puzzle back together. One small building has been completed in the 10 years of the project so it may be another 50-100 years to reconstruct it. Worth an visit.

If you like "Indiana Jones" you'll like Ta Prohm. . . .. Smaller, yet mysterious and fascinating in its own right, Ta Prohm is worth a visit. I saw it in a tropical downpour, which made it all the more eerie in some ways, with the huge trees growing up and out of the various buildings. By all means see it.

Perfect at Sunrise!. Being tourists, my friends and I wanted to experience sunrise in Angkor Park. But as we pulled up in front of Angkor Wat at 5am to see the swarms of people flooding the entrance, we got back in our tuk tuk and kept going. We pulled up outside Ta Prohm before the guard checking tickets had finished his breakfast and were thrilled to find that we were the only people. While everyone else huddled together near the lake at Angkor, my friends and I freely explored this beautiful temple. It was the perfect, isolated way to start the day, and I will do it again the next time I return to Angkor Park.

A 'Must See' Temple. This is an amazing temple to visit, but allow enough time to soak in the whole atmosphere. We saw it at the end of our temple viewing day and both had the feeling we would like to return and spend more time at this magical place. It is amazing to see the way the roots of the trees have wrapped themselves around the temple, very much in a nature vs civilisation way. It is great to be able to wander around and experience walking through the temple rather than view it from a distance as is quite often the case in ancient sites.

I think I saw it somewhere.... Ta Phnom is a temple very famous since the movie "Tomb Raider". You can feel like Lara Croft trying to find the hidden treasure, with giant trees trying to crash the construction with their giant roots. A necessary stop and visit when you are at Angkor!
Amazing scenery. Remove the other tourists and you are transported back a 1000 years what a great experience can recommend this tied in with Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom in one day trip
Beautiful. Of all the temples, this is most intriguing. Trees have grown into the complex.......both hurting and helping the structure. Really neat to see.
Most interesting. This was our favourite as you can see all the tree roots growing through the buildings. Indiana Jones featured a bit of this temple.
out of this world. Speechless, you have to be there to believe. I never saw anything like this in my life, unbelievable.

The site of the Lara Croft movie, but amazing to see. Full of international tourists! However, it was simply incredible to see the ruins and the vegetation and enormous trees that have grown on the temples

Jungle/Tomb Raider Temple - my favourite in Angkor!. This temple is amazing, it looms out of the jungle and is a magical sight! It's being taken over by tree roots and vines, which adds to its charm. It has been left the way it was found and it feels amazing just walking around. This temple is incredible photogenic and there are so many photo opportunities just wandering around. I was lucky, the group I was with got there early, just before a large tour group arrived and so we got to take plenty of photos with no one else around.This temple was my favourite and I can recommend everybody in the Siem Reap area to see it!

Wow. It is a ruin ... but additionally to being a world famous ruin the temple is really dpacisl with the many trees groing inside and over the temple walls. I think it gives a great impression whate the French fiubd when they dug their way through the jungle to find Angkor. So take time to visit!
Just like the game 'Temple Run'. The place reminded me of the IOS game 'Temple Run' which is really awesome. Trees growing through the temple gives it a different feel to the others in the area.

Nature shows its power. The "tomb raider" temple is definitely a place you must go. The amazing scenes of nature finding its way, climbing on the walls and on the temple, make this one of the most interesting temples to see. Do both the "short walk" and "long walk" because it is worth it.
Amazing temple. I had not heard of this temple the trees growing through the temple are amazing . Do not miss this temple
Beautiful Yet Sad. Seeing this beauty being damaged by growing trees and roots was the most saddening experience. Wish it was possible to preserve nature and History simultaneously.

The ruins are beautiful. Loved visiting Ta Prohm. Did no homework on this temple before I arrived and took a guide with me. When I got there it felt like I stepped back in time, into the Lost World where ancient civilizations once lived, in the jungle. The sounds of birds and monkeys took me into scenes from the Indiana Jones and Tomb Raider. It was eerie and it was beautoful. The moss covered wats were sight to behold and the perfect symmetry of their arches were just amazing.This should not be missed. And yes, all the trees and tree roots growing over and solidifying over some of the buildings were just amazing.

Photo Place. Lovely place showing the trees literally eating up the temple ruins. Good for photos. Need to be careful where you step on in case of caving in. Need to bring water and snacks if you are intending to stay long. Best to go morning, evening or meal times to avoid crowds.

Like being on a film set. I can see why the producers chose this site for the "Tomb Raider" movie, it lends itself brilliantly to a fantastical, mystical location. Around every corner is another "wow" moment. I prefer this temple to those of Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom in as much as you feel as though it has just been stumbled upon and that you are the archaeologist finding it. Many of the stones on the floor are numbered in the hope that the temple will be put back together someday. I rather hope they leave it as it is - it's quite enchanting. Look out for the little Stegosaurus carving by the west gate entrance. Keep a lookout for the large black ants while you're walking around - they bite!

My favorite temple. This was my favorite temple that we visited on our trip to Cambodia. It was our first stop of the morning, so we got there around 8am, and there were only a few other tourists around. I definitely recommend getting an early start and seeing this place in the quiet (and cool!) early morning. This is the "tree temple" or "Indiana Jones temple" or "that one where they shot 'Tomb Raider'". The trees have taken over, and it creates a really interesting mix of man-made and natural beauty. Whenever you go, bring a LOT of water. Like a comical amount of water. And please cover your knees and shoulders, don't be that person who thinks the rules don't apply to them.
Tomb Raider !!. Magnificent !! How wonderful on human made "mixing" with the nature product !! :)"The Tree" is in the middle of the place, so try to look for it before you go.

Got to be done Tomb Raider!. This place is truly unique, you cannot quite believe how the trees which are so huge have grown for hundreds of years and underneath the stone temples that were there way before the trees! a must see when you visit Siem Reap!

As Seen in Tomb Raider. While my guide was very emphatic on mentioning the Angelina Jolie connection to this temple, Ta Prohm - with all its over grown trees - does not require any famous names to be impressive (though after my visit I do want to watch the move again' its been a while)
Amazing Place. I would recommend as part of your trip around all of the Angkor Temples, hire a private guide to take you around the more interesting off the beaten track parts of this amazing temple.

Sadly we didn't see Angeline Jolie haha. Words can't begin to describe, and none of my photos will do it justice. This is one of those things that needs to be seen with your own eyes. We did a Grasshopper pushbike tour and thoroughly enjoyed it as it covered a few different temples and riding the wall of one temple. If you get a good guide they'll explain the history of the temples which is amazing to hear - especially for an Aussie when we come from such a comparatively young country. We'd heard Angeline Jolie was back in Siem Reap visiting temples for an up and coming movie, so we were hoping to see her again but sadly we didn't.Of all the temples this one was in the worst state, so if you're considering a trip to see the temples best to go sooner rather than later. Eventually there will be so much movement among the trees and structures that I imagine it would become too dangerous to get close to, and that will be an incredible shame.

Splendid but disappointing. We were really looking forward to visitig this and although Ta Prohm is a great temple to visit, recent restoration has taken away it's 'swallowed by jungle' atmosphere as the surrounding area has been cut back and kind of manicured. The famous tomb raider 'Crocodile' tree remains in place and this in itself is great to see. It is a temple of towers with closed courtyards and narrow corridors. There are lots of tall trees shading the area which provides great relief from the sun. A nice visit but a lot of visitors made progress slow - next time I will arrive at this one earlier as I don't like slow moving crowds.

The jungle temple was our favorite of all. We've heard how the jungle covered up the wonders of Angkor Wat and surrounding temples for hundreds of years: now see how the temples and trees blend together here. Good examples of preservation and reconstruction (painstaking) with some areas put back in excellent (1100AD) condition. So worth it; make sure this is part of your tour.
A must in Siem Reap. What can I say, the temple was in a Tomb Raiders movie so a must visit. And the trees growing within the temple are something that you have to see first hand.
mystifying must see. Spectacular site for viewing the unusual aspects of this earth.Caution to wear appropriate clothing as day time sun and humidity are high.
Big tree is amazing. In here you will meet amazing tree which is "part" of the temple. Besides it, the wole temple is worth visiting.

Guidad tur Ta Prohm. Beautiful tempel! We are so thankful that we had our fantastic guide, otherwise we´d never seen all the detaljs and know about their history. Our good and safe driver took us all day long between the tempels.I can really recommed both of them. If you are going there, you should go with them.Driver: mr Sarath, phone +855 70 636232 Pick up is free. Small tour: Ankor Wat + Ta Prohm Temle + Taprom 12 US dollarHe also have a lot of more tours, give him a call.Guide: mr Seanin Chean, English speakting tour guide with certification. Really good guide och easy to understund.Really help guide and driver.Took us to nice dinnerplace and stopped on market when we wanted a stop. I can really rekommend this two! Have a nice trip :)/Maria Åslin

I'm in LOVE!!!. Those giant figs reclaiming the ruins are breathtaking. Around every corner your eyes need a moment to adjust to such wonder and your brain just whispers 'stay here please'. Visited multiple times, I think I will return to Cambodia again for more, yes definitely

Lives up to expectation. This temple really does look like the photos. Unfortunately that means that is is full of tourists trying to take their own photos, not all very tolerant of each other due to the heat so patience is needed to prevent international incidents. The tree roots are huge and it is amazing to see how nature can so easily destroy the wonders that man can create.

Best temple we saw!. Lots of interesting things to see with the trees going round the temples. It is really amazing to see, and there are lots of brilliant photos to be taken. Film buffs will also like it with the links to the Tomb Raider film.

Ta prohm. This is the most amazing temple,as well as the temple it has these amazing trees that the roots have grown right down and covered the temple wonderful to see.but grew around the face of the budah sho it's screed for that absolutely amazing place a must see I tge temple journey.
Again loads of water.

Not just Lara Croft. This is an amazing place. We were lucky enough to go when it was quite quiet, early in the day on the advice of our guide. At almost every turn there is a sign of nature taking a firm hold on the site, both holding it together and prising it apart. Its wonderful.
Spectacular. Truly a wonder of the world. You cannot visit Cambodia without coming here. Well worth the trip fee 20.00 dollars per person

jungle temple. seeing the trees growing on top of the temple structures was spectacular and gave an insight into how all of the temples must have been when rediscovered in the 1860s after 400 hundred years of abandonment.

Exactly what you envisioned!. This place is exactly what you pictured these temples to look like... where nature takes back what was hers!minus the hundreds of tourists that is.. but if you get there at a good time where less tourists are roaming about you can get in some good shots. (we were fortunate that it was a fairly rainy day and the bus tours didnt want to roam as much or perhaps were afraid of getting wet?) This is the place... you saw in Tomb Raider! and it upholds its charm thanks to the jungle trying to recover it.

Ta Prohm - Great place but not for old people. This is a great temple with lots of old and big trees dominating the temple. But, this is definitely not a temple for old people to explore as from the entrance to exit of temple is very very far. My mother hurt her feet when came out from the temple.
amazng. There is nothing I can add others haven't said. Just make sure you have time to explore it all and don't try to pack too much in.
Great. This is my second time here and it was great with the tree growing on the building structure. A good place for photography. Could hardly find any shed, the weather is hot all year round.

Surprisingly, loved it. Yes, this is the "Tomb Raider" temple but there is more to it than being linked to an Angelina Jolie movie. The juxtaposition of nature and man made structures is beautiful to see in person. As the other reviewers, it seems like nature is trying to take back what is theirs as the stones used to construct this temple is able to retain water and thus justifies the roots growing over the buildings. As with most in the Siem Reap temples, pictures do not do this temple justice. We were in awe of its different kind of beauty.

A Mysterious Place. What an unusual and fascinating place this is. I can imagine Indiana Jones searching for hidden treasures here, but Lara Croft beat him to it - this was the location where the Cambodian part of Tomb Raider was filmed. It's mystical the way trees grow out of and around the temple. I found this to be the most interesting and intriguing site in the Angkor complex.

The most photogenicof temples..... Hired a guide here as well. Would have missed a few of the best areas without his advice.The approach is in the shade due to the amount of trees in the area, so it felt a bit cooler here than Angkor Wat.The only thing needed to get the most out of a trip to Ta Prohm is a lot of patience.It is not overcrowded in general but the spots from which to take a good photograph were much sought after at the time of our visit. Plus quite a lot of other tourists take a mind boggling amount of "selfies", go figure.Some of the temple staff were helpful enough to take a few of our group pics and assist folk to take panorama shot, nice one.Your patience will be rewarded however and this temple should be very high on your list if time is short in Siem Reap.Take a look at our travel map, we joined TA late in life and only review the places we have been to since joining. You may wish to trust our judgement on this masterclass of old temple versus the jungle.
The trees taking over the buildings. Fascinating place, with the trees trying to reclaim their space. Again, lovely to see the restoration in progress.
Brilliant tour. We are so pleased we visited Ta Prohm. Incredibly beautiful and somehow very moving and yet a restful place to be, even surrounded by many tourists
MUST visit!!. We were so impressed by the roots climbing up, in, out, down, making all kinds of shapes! Huge - must experience to see this! Beautiful, absolutely close to nature!
Beauty of nature. Beauty of nature over the rocks. The nature gets its place again and you will feel like Lara Croft walking through the passages.
Must see!. This is such a beautiful Temple. The Beauty of nature and human craft together creates a lasting visual impact! It carries you to another world

Interesting and must see. This is the often talked about site in the movie Tomb Raider, it is excellent due to the untouched trees that are huge and over grown with roots breaking the ruins. Well laid out and easy to explore, watch out for the mosquitos here, there are many more than Angkor Wat.
Amazing!. This is a must do! You cannot take a bad photo here. The walk to it is cooler than the other places because of the tall trees.

Go early morning to truly enjoy this amazing temple. All the negative reviews relate to crowds. So go early to get the best photos and enjoy the incredible atmosphere. We did sunrise at Srah Srang, the Banteay Kdei before coming here for 7:30/8 and it was really empty. Just a handful of other people at that time so could take our time exploring and taking pics. It's truly incredible to see the trees slowly reclaiming the temple, and a beautiful irony that those arboreal destroyers now keep the temple standing. A must see!

Most interesting temple!. Ta Prohm, you hear so much about it especially since it was featured in the famous Tomb Raider movie, but seeing it was another story. It was amazing to see the Banyan trees growing so large within the ruins. I highly recommend this temple.
Truely Amazing. I ;personally found this temple the most fascinating with the trees growing in and over the ruins of the old temple.

Beautiful, and sad...but worth going to see!. I was really looking forward to seeing this temple at Angkor Wat. I've read about it, seen pictures, and on the big screen (It's in Tomb Raider). Literally every nook, cranny and corner you turn there is another epic picture! The grounds are being over taken by the jungle, giant banyans climbing their way super high in the sky, taking down the historic structures below it. There were restoration efforts being taken while we were there. A giant crane, bamboo scaffolding, and before/after posters of what it will all look like when complete. It's truly amazing to see what they are doing to bring back the original look and architecture of the place. What is not amazing is how when you're dropped off at the gates to walk into Ta Prohm, you are instantly bombarded by little kids trying to sell you on cheap magnets, figurines, tshirts, etc. Local people are calling you out from every angle for the first 50 steps into the gates. There are even huge signs/billboards directly in front of the entrance that tell you "don't support locals begging for money" and so on. So why don't they beef up security and kick these people out? I know they are trying to make a buck, but this is a national world heritage and historic place. Thousands of people don't travel thousands of miles to walk among the temples to be hounded by cheap tricks and scams. Take these stalls out and put them at the front of the park, so people can enjoy what they came to see. If you can keep a blind eye and deaf ear to all the sad craziness going on around you, and just enjoy the majestic wonder of it all, like we had to do, you'll be in good shape.

Watch those crowds. This temple was not as suitable for dealing with the hordes of visitor. I also found it the hottest probably because of so many people. But don't miss it,it has the most wonderful trees.

A must see "before you die" category.. A trip to Siem Reap is enhanced with a visit to this complex. It shows a stunning temple complex in it's fight with the surrounding Jungle. You will marvel at the work of building this complex many centuries ago mixed with the forces of nature as massive trees and vines grow in, around and over these magnificent man made structures. in my opinion a much more rewarding experience than the sprawling Angor Wat complex.
Memorizing. Hidden gems of Cambodia it's a must to see and do in Seim Reap good walking shoes early in the mornings water and hat a must.

The temple of 3 "WOWS!". I can't add anything to what previous writers have said....read just a few and you'll get the idea that Hollywood knows how to pick otherworldly spots. The French need to be thanked for rescuing these sites from the jungle. Hard to believe that this place still exists after the jungle owned it for so many years.

Nature and history. Whilte this temple isn't as historically significant or large as Angkor Wat, it's worth a visit. It's fascinating to see where the jungle has taken over the buildings, merging with the stones and bricks in may areas. Like the other temples in the area, the engeineering and building skills are unbelievable.

Interesting Cambodian Temple. Famous to some of us because of the Angelina Jolie movie that was filmed there, we found it to be so fascinating. Many twists and turns here and all are mesmerizing. A must see in Siem Reap.
Tree temple. You have to see this place to believe...A true harmony between architecture and nature..Tip:Carry water and Umbrella it can get very hot and humid

go for the atmosphere. This temple is unusual because it is still in the posession of the trees and their roots - all this adds up to the misterious and at dusk gloomy atmosphere. Went there twice to catch the moments of being alone in this jungle devoured temple.

Stunning - ruins, trees and Tomb Raiders too!. Not sure which bit was the most impressive out of the trees and the buildings! Every corner turned gave us yet another 'must do' photo shot - hopefully there will eventually be more funding for putting more of the jigsaw of stones and carvings back together - that's if the incredible trees don't take over completely! We visited the museum the day before to get a better insight into what the temples were about, what to look out for etc (which, although expensive was worthwhile)..... We also purchased our ticket ($20 for one day) at 5pm the previous day and used it to go for a sunset visit (to Angkor Wat) and saved the early morning queue before a full day of temples.....

Character and charm. Thinking of the ancient civilisations whom lived and worked here. Now slowly being consumed by nature. A visit will not disappoint. Is some regards of the 6 or 7 temples I have visited during my stay. I preferred this one the most. Less busy early in the morning after sunrise. I tried to spread my temple visits over several days before the humidity takes holed of the day. More comfortable and leisurely. I also booked private tours for this reason.. Starting can be when you want it to be because you pay more..for the one on one service.

I felt like Tomb Raider.. This is the temple that was almost taken over by the jungle, and was only discovered this century. Its is the temple made famous in the Tomb Raider Movie. Huge roots from tall trees have taken over parts of the temple and caused other parts of it to collaspe.
Awe inspiring!. An amazing temple to visit! You are standing in the middle of Nature and architecture intertwining! Amazing to see! You feel taken back in time!

Trees and trees. Of course Ta Prohm doesnt need any introduction as this was where Tomb Raiders was shot. However I have never seen the movie. Its a lovely walk to the temple and the trees lining up prepares you for what is to come. The 1st thing that captured my eye was the tree literally growing out of the temple. There were trees and trees everywhere and huge tree roots sprawling all around.Go early as its less crowded and you have more time to get good shots.

Magical jungle temple. This was the first temple we visited at Angkor and it will stay in the memory forever. The way the jungle trees have sought to reclaim the site is almost unique. We let one of the security guards show us around, as a consequence I have a lot of photos to share when I get back.

Amazing architecture. Tomb Raiders couldn't have chosen a better venue.This Temple site had a mystical feel to it with the trees growing out of the temples, it created a unique experience and had you wondering what would it be in its hey days.

Make Believe. Ankor Wat is an absolutely amazing place to visit... We spent 3 days taking it all in, but this was probably my favorite location... I could wax lyrical about the Architecture, atmosphere or the fact that you don't know if the tree or the building are holding each other up... but I like to just think that Angelina Jolie was there! mmm

Amazing temple.. This temple is in my top 3 of Cambodian temples. Is incredible how the trees grow up through the temple. It is a must seeing in Cambodia. Another interesting thing is that temple is the temple of tomb rider movie.

My Top List. This place is my Number 1 place in Seam Reap.
100 faces always look at you all the step in this place.
You can go there by tuktuk. Its very easy.
Very cool!. One of my favorite temple in Siem Reap! It hasn't been rebuilt, but still is very much intact. The trees growing over the walls and partially collapsed areas make it surreal!

the temple was in the way! . I could see why it is one of the top temples in siem reap. the trees were tall, grand and mysterious and made the temple looked like it was in the way of the trees instead of the trees being in the wrong. definitely worth a visit if you only have a day pass and as with all popular temples, go early to avoid the crowd!

Giant Trees. A worth visit to this temple. Felt pity for the sight of a ruin temple in its rubble but was amazed by the sight of giant trees grown and draped over it. One down side, it could get really slow moving and crowded to the centre area.

Looking for the famous tree?. My friend and I were looking for the huge tree that Ta Prohm is known for and it is located near the entrance - I can't remember which now but if you don't see the huge tree right upon entering, then keep going because you will not be disappointed!!!

Angelina Jolie. lol thats the first thing about this place tourists would think of since tomb rider was shot here. This is the building covers by hundred years old trees. It is unique in its way. Crowded though while i was there.

Fantastic Temple to explore after Angkor Wat. This is another temple best explored after Angkor Wat. This temple has become famous for it's role in TOMB RAIDERS and is truly mesmerizing. I did feel I was in an ancient film myself as I wandered around this temple.

Trees and varied restorations. Of the temples we visited, my favorite. I really interesting mix of restored, under restoration, and unrestored area with really big trees perched on top. However, the central area can be really crowded.

amazing. So glad that this temple has been left in its "overgrown" state - not only is it supremely cool to see how the trees are "draped" over the buildings, but it's also neat to imagine the French explorers in the 19th century happening upon other temples like this.
Fantastic temple. Definitely worth a visit. We visited on a weekday avoiding the weekend rush. Would recommend getting a two day temple pass which provides access for 3 days.

Must place to see, Nature at its best!!. Before heading there I was aware it was famous by the Tomb Raider movie but this place doesn't need a movie to be the star of the show. The immense sponge trees which have stamped there mark on the temple gives it that extra character.. Best to try and go early to reduce the crowd levels.

Just like the film!. All the amazing photos of trees growing out of the buildings - seemingly - . Has to be seen to be believed. Again carry copious amounts of water, wear a hat, and take your camera!

Highlight of all the temples. I was totally intriged with this temple, the tree roots is beautiful and this old temple is full of character. All the tourists is annoying but I guess I was one of them.

Reminiscence of the past . Another masterpiece of ruins of the past. The temple is almost overtaken by bodhi trees all around! They have overgrown the temple walks even destroying the walls. Despite reconstruction, they stay in rumbles. Another good place to visit and ponder over our past!

A must if you go to Angkor Wat. This is a highlight of any trip, the ancient ruins with trees growing at will from out of the structures are amazing. Tons of pictures to take and a great way to end the day of walking around the vast area.

Beautiful and horrifying at the same time. It's true, like others say here, that the trees make Ta Prohm special. Don't just walk the obvious path here, be sure to take every twisty turn you can. There is an amazing view at every turn. But the trees create not just a beautiful and exotic view, they create a horrifying tangle that workers must contend with to protect both the temple and tourists. Be careful walking through here, but enjoy the amazing views.

Beautiful Area. We loved the way the jungle seems to want to claim back the territory lost to the Khmer kings. The natural vegetation provided the area some sense of mystery and spirituality that was missing in Angkor Wat.
The highlight of my trip. This temple in my opinion was the best of the places we visited in Angkor. It was more interesting and beautiful than the mighty Angkor Wat.
Just Beautiful. Even trudging through the rain to get there wasn't a bother. This is definietly a once in a lifetime experience. I loved it!

Nature fighting back at Ta Promh. Ta Prohm was one of three Mahayana Buddhist temples supported by monks whose cells can still be founding the grip of great silk-cotton trees that UNESCO decided to leave in place while renovating. Other temples in the Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom complexes are distinctly Hindu. Fans of Harrison Ford movies will recognise some interiors. An unadvertised gem is a small echo room that will echo beating your hand over your heart but nothing else. Take plenty of water. Include with Angkor Wat and as part of Angkor Thom (great moated city). Tuk-tuk and guide advised. Search Prim.

Do sunrise here if you have a 3 day pass!. We didn't actually have a 3 day pass just the one but we chose to do Ta Prohm at sunrise! It was so peaceful and beautiful here. No one but us there we had the whole place to ourselves for over an hour! It was amazing just being there watching it uncover as it got lighter.
A very special place.
Another great temple to see. Combine with Angor Wat and Bayon and be sure to get a guide - that way you understand / learn more about what you are seeing.

Man and nature. We just loved the way the trees have 'improved' Ta Prohm, giving it an extra dimension from the other temples. The root flow down the ancient walls like mercury. Certain areas were popular for photos as they feature in Laura Croft Tomb Raider, quite amusing to see these Chinese ladies fancying themselves as Angelina Joilie!!!! The harmony between nature and man is so evident here, there are currently some restoration works going on. Unusually a lot of the tree on the approach are named.

Jungle temple - most interesting visit. We liked this temple best of all, as it a good mix between ruin and reconstruction with the stunning roots growing through parts of it. We visited at lunch time when it was quieter - the tour groups go off to their restaurants - but it is a hotter time to visit. It is near Angkor Wat so is easy to access, whereas some of the other ruined temples such as Beng Melea are a longer journey out of town, and although interesting may not be worth the effort if you are time limited.

Jungle Temple. The site made even more famous by the Tomb Raider movie is in its own right a marvel. Witness the immense trees which have fused with this ancient temple to create a unique experience. Best to try and catch early on as it is a busy and claustrophobic temple when the crowds descend.

Alone for sunrise. Forgoing the typical sunrise at Angkor Wat, my boyfriend and I decided to escape the crowds and try our luck at Ta Prohm. We were not disappointed. We had this entire temple complex (of Tomb Raider fame) to ourselves for over an hour, wandering the abandoned ruins overgrown with roots. It was a truly magical experience, and definitely off the beaten path for a sunrise experience we won't forget.
Magic. A must when visiting Siem Reap and Angkor Wat. A magical place! Like a yin-yang of nature and human achievement!
My favourite temple in Siem reap. This is for me the best temple since it has been eaten by the forest so it is a mix between man-made and nature.

A must see when in Cambodia. Wonderful and amazing trees. A must see when in Cambodia. Wonderful trees amid ruins in a more natural state than other sites in the area. A tree lovers paradise. Go early to avoid the crowds. Everything is amazing and breathtaking. Leave plenty of time to explore, we were here for about 4-5 hours and it still wasn't enough. Must pay and have a tick to enter but this site is included with the Angkor Wat tickets.

Holiday . Another crazy place, trees on, over in stone structures. You might be lucky & one of the security men might show you the best places to get pictures don't shue them away accept their knowledge & give a small tip after.

You have to go!. Another tick on our travel wish list with our visit here. Such an awesome sight with the tree roots climbing through the temple. Unfortunate that it is damaging.
Had a Lara Croft moment! A must do!
Temples in siam reap rock!!!. loved this place to bits. not as busy as the other temples and still included in your day pass. still scratching my head how the trees ate up the building

Amazing combination of nature and ancient architecture. Stunning in every corner you turn to. A must visit place if you ever be in Siem Reap. Sunscreen and cap are recommended. Local guides are also available.
The temple of your dreams. This is the real life Indiana Jones temple. Buried in the jungle and left as is to this day. Simply a visually stunning attack on the senses.
Really liked the tomb raider temple.. Beautiful and fragile, amazing to see how nature has taken over this temple. Constant maintenance is required or the whole place will be destroyed over time.
Angelina Jolies claim to fame. Though nice views are available, it seems that this venue's claim to fame is the picture by Angelina Jolie

Trees rule. If this tells us anything it's really is about how nature given the chance will reclaim its territory, this temple is famous for a film I have never seen and if that encourages people to visit these fantastic places then that's fine by me. Great place to get some photos

Cool, but lost some of the natural greatnss. We all remember what in looked like in Tomb Raider. For better the tree has been cut, but still an amazing place. Visit early to miss the crowds. Do it straight after sunrise at Angkor after before the buses arrive.

Tomb Raiders. That's what every tourists will comment when they arrive and busy queuing up taking pictures! Nice but again to me it is nothing special. Of course, you get to see the tree with roots growing above ground! These sites just makes one feel - once you see one you see all. A full day of temples hoping is enough!
Fusion of Temple and Trees. The great temple exhibits unique natural fusion of trees with temple architecture. Massive trees have overtaken walls and boundaries of all the temples on this site.

Fascinating!. This small temple is memorable due to the tree roots that have taken over the complex. Together with the moss and the pink sandstone in certain parts, it paints a lovely picture. One of the smaller attractions in the complex, but worth a visit.

It was okay. It's a very popular temple thanks to Tomb Raider. A lot of tourists any hour of the day. This is not the best temple to go to if you're visiting the temples for its serenity and mystique.
The power of nature. Such a lovely place and a photographer's paradise. The size of the trees and roots can only be believed when seen.
tomb raiders. tomb raider in h.d.☺ finally get to see ine of the more famous places and scenes in the movie...very enchanting and serene place.

The tomb raider temple. It is famously known as the tomb raider temple after it was featured on the Lara crofts tomb raider movie. It is special for its creeping tree roots which have become one of the binding factors of the temple, removing which might cause the temple to collapse.
Nature vs temple. Loved this temple, incredible to se how the nature is taking over.. Looks very autentic and old, jugle-atmosphere.

Temple visit: one day cycle tour. We visited the temple as part of our final stop of our cycling tour.It was used in the Tomb Raider films and it was quite exciting to see parts of the temple that had been used during filming.It's one of the only temples that has been taken over with vegetation. Another must if you are only going to see a few of the temples and have limited time.

Surreal. More difficult to access than Bayon or Ankhor Wat but well worth it. A bit of a walk to the temple from the road but you see groups of men playing instruments with limbs missing from mines. The giant roots holding up the temple are so strange and you can get lost wandering in the complex.
There aren't words to describe this site.... Amazing, fantastic, excellent, awe-inspiring... so many words describe Ta Prohm. Pictures don't do this place justice. It's a must see location!

Ta Prohm at a quiet time. Most people will tell you this is a site where there are just too many tourists for it to be fun. I have visited during the on-season and its is just frustrating. If you want to take photos don't bother going in the on-season instead brave the heat and travel in June July, you many get rain and hot days but at least there are hardly any people there. My daughter and I traveled in June July and found Angkor and Ta Prohm almost empty. If you want a go get a good tuktuk or car driver try Mr Pahna he is the best in the business. Phone him on +855 1286 45 81 or 855 975085708 e.mail and facebook panhachhouk@yahoo.com and arrange him to pick you up from the airport. If you do manage get him as your driver ask him to take you to the real local market for a tour, well worth a look . On your way into Cambodia you are unlikely to have your full quota of kgs of luggage. Most airlines offer 30kgs but most people take nearly empty suitcases into the country and fill them while they are there. Don’t take a half empty suitcase into Cambodia, fill it up with children’s books, educational toys (no battery operated toys), toothbrushes, soap, shoes, technology items and other useful things. The items don’t need to be new, just in good working condition. Please don’t take lollies or sugary stuff and don’t offer religious items, Cambodians have a diversity of religions available to them, let them choose. You can ask your hotel to distribute the items or take them to the Children’s Sanctuary

Early start. This temple was amazing. We did a huge mistake in visiting at noon.The temple was packed by large groups of noisy, inconsiderate tourists. It was impossible to take photos of this temple without people giving finger gestures etc. We strongly reommend you make this your first temple of the day, as early as 0700 in the morning in order to enjoy it's beauty. Then visit Angkor Wat and the other temples after. Also generally it gets very hot in the afternoon, recommend early start for all temples. We bought a 3 day pass valid for a 7 day period, just perfect, and you get 3 days for the cost of 2 this way. Enjoy

Very unique. This was our favourite, not sure why other than the amazing trees and their roots, there aren't as many structures to see but a must see all the same. The drive out there is quite attractive also and many other photo opportunities

Ta Prohm. Ta Prohm was the first on my list , and my favourite out of all the temples. We went there first on our first day to avoid the crowds at Angkor Wat. Our guide was fantastic and knew all the best spots to get photos so we wernt wasting time. Tomb raiders definitely put Ta Prohm and Angkor Wat on the world best travel spots.
Trees!!!!. The temple structure by itself is interesting but the way the trees have entwined themselves into the temple really make this a special place to visit . Beware of the main photo shot .
Felt like Indian Jones. Magical place. Preferred it to Angkor Wat. Take your time and discover this place. Go early to avoid the heat.

Go before it's too late. It's fantastic. Go before you can't walk in it around it or through it, This is a treasure that can't be missed. It's an awesome sight, very surreal and a visual treat. You really can't believe what you are seeing, photos do not picture the beauty of this wonderful site.

My favourite temple!. Ta Prohm was my favourite of all the temples we visited at Angkor.We visited at 3.30pm and there was hardly any tourists there so we could wander freely and felt like true explorers!It's more atmospheric than some of the other temples and the conservation work they have done is amazing.We went back again later in the week as we enjoyed it so much.

One useful tip for fall 2015. Must-see in Angkor. A recent (Sept '15) restauration of ruins in the centre of Ta Prohm finally gives a fair overview of the buildings.Make sure that your driver meets you on the OTHER side of the temple. Because of works in progress, it is a one-way visit. Or you may end up like us walking 2 km back on the road. That was pleasant but unforeseen ;-)

Tomb Raider . There's a reason Tomb Raider was filed here. The ruins look great and it's amazing the way that the trees have taken over a lot of the structures. Go early (before 7) if you want to avoid the crowds.

Guides famous filmed about monument. Went along afterward to see the Ta Prohm movie. It was very good and one cal almost not believe that the film was directed here for such a short time! But this is the most famous Monument for the guides to happily point out. A real must see
Real ruin. Its old-age and conditions make it a good site to see how it was when westerners first discovered it centuries ago.

Incredible. My favourite of the temples we visited. It really shows how difficult it must have been to reclaim the other temples from the jungle. Compared to Angkor Wat with it's clean lines, it's a mess but the greenery everywhere, the enormous trees and the peace it exudes is just lovely and oh so picturesque. Absolutely loved it.

Simply amazing.. This an amazing temple located in the heard of the temple sites of Angkor Wat. It is really incredible how the jungle just swallows up the ruins. This temple is on the short 1/2 day circuit of temples as well as the full day. One of the true gems of the whole area.

Amazing. This temple is everything that you dreamt it would be and so much more! We decided to go right as the sun was rising - which we highly recommend after you've done Angkor Wat at least once for sunrise. It is so beautiful in the early morning and barely any tourists are around at that time... magic!

Adventures of Tomb Raider. When you arrived here, the atmosphere of ancient Khmer temple will make you feel like in the adventures of Angelina Jolie/Indiana Jones. The trees sprouting out in surrounding area made this location one of most popular temple in Angkor complex. Since this complex is huge enough (and hot), prepare some water as you gonna take a long walk.
Facinating Ancient Ruins. Another must see - in Siem Reap. Take your camera. See the power of nature in full force. Go to the museum first. Then it all makes sense.
Amazing. I loved Ta Prohm. It was so beautiful walking around and seeing the ruins and how the jungle has taken over. This place should be on everyone's to do list.

beautiful. Very vert beautiful. I could never ask for more. Went there alone. In the morning. It was amazing.
It brings u back to centuries ago.

Must see - our favorite. This site is not fully excavated and is partially overgrown by the jungle. Gives on a sense of an Indiana Jones movie, although Tomb Raiders was filmed here. It is magnificent. We went early in the day and caught the sun awakening the temples and vegetation. We liked this site more than Angkor Wat.

A lost civilizattion. Judging by the ruins and the grandness of the buildings, this site must be a bustling place many thousands years ago. There were engineering greatness like the drainage, structural and architecture to show how one great civilizattion existed. What happened to them? How did the civilizattion ended? There is so much mystery surrounding the area.

Take your time. Ta Prohm temple is the iconic temple of broken, moss-covered stones, mysterious engravings and the jungle reclaiming its space. I went to see it as part of a five attraction tour. While I'm not sorry I did it this way, and our guide was wonderful, I really regret not going back and taking the time to view it more slowly.This is great for artists and photographers, even writers will be inspired by its charm.

Very intimate. We visited after 3pm and had the place mainly to ourselves. The walk from the car park through the forest brings you to a peaceful glade and the majesty of this Temple hidden in the trees is never forgotten. I liked this Temple it is atmospheric and peaceful. The 400-500 year old trees blend and become part of the stone work. Amazing
Amazing how the nature goes with the history. You will be impressed by how the nature goes well with the historic buildings. Definitely should not skip this.

Atmospheric temple site.. This was my favourite temple of the three main temples my brother and I visited as it has been left in its original state. The huge tree roots crawling all over the buildings create an almost unworldly atmosphere.
GREAT PLACE. I went two times to Siem Reap and every time you find new pictures and situations. Great, Iconic. This photo is the most iconic pictures of cambodia.

The famous temple. Ta Prohm became famous after being used as setting for the recording of Lara Croft starring Angelina Jolie. The temple is beautiful, however it is pretty busy and the line to take a picture at the famous spot can be pretty long.

A real treat!. We stayed in Siem Reap for 4 nights and hired a tuk-tuk driver for 3 days. He took us to all the obvious temples and some others including this one besides. Well worth the visit and probably missed by the vast majority of tourists who will go to Angkor Wat and think they've covered Siem Reap.

wow. A must see if you are visting Siem Reap, Cambodia. We could have easily spent the day here just wandering through the mesmoizing sights. A phenominal place to allow your imagination to wander the stuff fairy tales are based on. the trees and how they have grown around the old structures are amazing. Do have a local guide.

Fantastic place to be. What an amazing experience, its like stepping back into a world gone by. The jungle really has taken hold of this spectacular temple. Its smaller then some of the other temples in the area but 100% worth a visit. Get there early to avoid the crowds and take your time admiring the architecture the way the natural world meets man made.

Just go there!. This is sublime - the writhing tree-roots look like huge snakes trying to devour the stones of the temple. The overall feeling is of the forest trying to take over and the restoration work is heroic

The Tree special!!!!. Ta Prohm - The tree is on the temple.
Very special.
Many tourist will take photo at here. Ta prohm is on re-renovation because the temple is old.

Tomb Raider Temple...Very postcard worthy. The place is popularly dubbed as "Tomb Raider Temple" The scenery is amazing and it is as if you stepped into another place and time. A lot of the temples have big overgrown roots of trees crawling in and out. Aside from this, parts of it make you want to jump from one spot to another Tomb Raider style!

The Power Of nature. More atmospheric than the other temples as you walk through dense jungle to get to it. It is a great lesson in how man conquered nature, but then nature fought back and is slowly reclaiming the temple, knocking down huge walls and stones in its path. Of course everyone with a Wesrern face refers to it as the Tomb Raider tomb, but other than that there is absolutely no mention of the film anywhere which amazes me for the potential tourism trap.
best time to go is early in the morning. we went at 7am in the morning and had the temple to ourselves! No need to worry about getting crowds out of your photos.visited on: Sept 2015

Tomb Raider,yes. We went in Dec 2009. Fantastic weather. My friend and I took a tuktuk from our hostel and spent the day touring all of the temples. We saw everything and the day was not enough. Ensure you have a wide angle lens 14mm. You can park or cycle or walk. We hired a tuktuk for the day very inexpensive. He was an unemployed teacher and was a fantastic tour guide. Wear sensible shoes bring water perhaps a snack and be respectful. There is an one time entry fee, you get a pass with your photo on it.

Step back into another time. This is such a special place where the old temples are being taken over by tree roots. It is much smaller than other temple areas in the area but very interesting. A must see while you are in Siem Reap. There are lots of children in the area begging. We stopped with our guide,We found out that these children have no one that takes care of them and have very little to eat. They are older than they look. So sad. The whole country is so poor.

Beautiful. We enjoyed every aspect of this place. There are negativity like baggers and such. But i wouldn't let those things get in the way of one of the worlds wonders. The person who commented below obviously highlighted the negativity. If you do notice all the bad things it will over shadow the good, like the scenery, and every place you go you will never enjoy it!

Tomb raider . This was absolutely spectacular. The routes that have grown around and above the temple make you feel so small. This place is a must visit and only one of many many sites and temples to be seen. I felt like Laura Croft in tomb raider.
I love the trees. This was the place to admire those gigantic trees and the old temple struck together. For this reason alone, it's worth visiting.

My Favorite Historical Site. I've always enjoyed visiting Ta Prohm. It's so much cooler than Angkor Wat & Angkor Thom. You get to see many giant trees...amazing how their roots can penetrate through stones. Green shades everywhere.

My Favourite of all the temples. This is the classic temple that Tomb Raider was modelled on. The most amazing array of ruins, intricacy and trees growing everywhere with roots literally strangling the building. Amazing.
Indiana Jones. Imagine yourself as Indiana Jones when he discover temples. All the family is delighted to discover how a temple look like when first found. Even better than Angkor

An aging pile of rubble left to the beggars. Ta Phrom was the most disappointing of the Angor Wat Complex. After braving the sea of aggressive beggars, we walked down a large corridor of mainly boring trees and came upon the wonders of a pile of rubble with a yellow crane towering above it. It was good for about 5 minutes of fun to wander in between the broken corridors only to be met by beggars or stalked by a shady looking character asking us if we wanted Marijuana or would give him a dollar.

Just like on TV. Very impressive site, a little smaller than I expected. I would suggest visiting early in the day - before say lunchtime, to avoid the sun, bugs and humidity. Make sure you take plenty of water.

Amazing!. Its an ancient large temple in ruins with big trees spreading their trunks and roots over the structures! Seen nothing like it ever! Must see along with Angkor Wat and Bayon Temple (Angkor Thom) in Siem Reap.

Trees. I really love this temple is amazing trees actually growing out of the Temple them selves I think they made the movie tomb raider here amazing photos you need about 45 minutes to see it all i'm happening I think is very hot here now and take a tuk tuk so you don't have to walk to far
Truly amazing. The hype about this ruin does not overshadow its incredible presence. The trees make this site feel almost alien. Truly amazing!
Beautiful. There's something about the trees and how they've wrapped themselves around the ruins that's surreal. Hopefully someone can finance this place so it can continue being restored.

Amazing. Amazing structure and architecture. Every wall has a detailed carvings as well as the rock is soft that's why the roots and moss are getting its way to the stones. This is where the Tomb raider had their shooting.

You have to go to this temple as its very different to the others. Here you can see what the other temples would be like if they were not so well kept but don't think that Ta Prohm is left to nature. A regular team ensures that weeds and trees do not totally take over yet they have managed to keep the amazing trees that grow on the ruins intact by careful lopping. Ta Prohm is a must to see. Much cooler due to the shade than the other temples but do wear mozzie spray!
Nick & Angela . The show was an intense, electric ,high energy,fun and entertaining circus of acrobatics, definitely a must see ..
giant root. It must have taken hundred of years for these trees and its roots to get so big. It is unique to Cambodia, I think.

Became famous because it was the site that Tomb Raider film was shot. This was the 2nd Temple that we visited because it was known for being famous because of the Tomb Raider film by Angelina Jolie. Amazing trees preserved at site.There are some parts of this temple that are muddy as when we went there we were caught by the rain. There is also a crane inside that is a nuisance for taking the picture of the site. There are temple guides around that can assist you and can take some of your photos but there's this one guide who asked for tip after they tour you around/take photos.

Everything You've Heard. is correct. Beautiful wreckage of an ancient civilization. Worth getting a guide but choose one in a uniform. Lots of people wanting to sell you stuff. The book on the temples is probably worthwhile if you don't have a guide.

A must-visit ancient temple. Got the chance to visit this famous temple. It was once used as one of the shooting place for movie Tomb Raider. The signature trademark of this temple would be the huge tree that has fully grown alongside the temple

Amazing place . Nature taking over the temples. We visited the temple at 2 pm and it was not busy at all so could take pictures without having to queue. Nice to be in the setting of Tomb Rider. Worth visiting .
Amazing Cultural Site, Must See. Seen this many times on television, but is amazing in person! A definate must see if your in Cambodia.
My top favorite. Don't come here because you expect to see Tomb in the movie Tomb raider. Come here for amazing temple in the minddle of jungle TA PHROM.

Yes there are trees growing on this old temple.. Yes there are trees growing on this old temple.It kind of feels like nature is taking over. The corridors are small, tourists are in their thousands.Maybe I missed the point, but not sure what was unique about this temple from the others in the area.

Fabulous. On a substantially smaller scale than Angkor, this Wat is possibly more interesting. The trees have attempted to take over several walls and buildings and provide a wonderful aspect for photographers. Be careful where you walk as there are multiple trip hazards. Not really suitable for disabled access.

amazing trees. Is the largest temple in land size but not building .It took 20-30 minutes walk from south entrance to north.Bring yourself a bottle of water.Try to appreciate the power of trees and don't miss the shooting scene of " Tomb Raider "

How jungle takes over. This used to be my favorite temple in Angkor before I visited Pheah Khan. This is pretty much similar, but a bit more compact so if you are in a hurry this is a good alternative to Preah Khan. This temple is a good example of how the jungle and vegetation can gradually take over.

on my opinion - The VERY best of the temples. I wanted to see nature taking over temples and this totally delivered. The trees have taken over this temple and provide an amazing experience completely worth seeing!

Top Rater. This is the temple complex that we enjoyed the most. The whole area is amazing but this one is the temple that stood out the best for us. The battle between man and nature is striking here. The king number 7 built this for his mother so you know it has to be good !

The power of nature. Amazing strangler figs grow out of buildings and walls, It is pleasing to see the restoration progress over the last 2 years.
A must see.

Where nature entwines with history.. Very attractive scenery, wonderful old architecture intermingled with the jungle, combining to make a special place.
Made famous by a scene in the movie "Tomb Raider".

Beautiful tree lined walk to the temple. Dear travellerThis temple is especially wonderful as it has an architectural texture of trees woven into the texture of its temple. Most of the trees are several hundred years old and the temple itself is built in the 11th century. Mostly used as a place of worship and evidently built by the kings to pay their respects to the gods. The element of Hinduism and Buddhism that is depicted in its stone reliefs. This temple achieved world fame when it was used in Angelina Jolie's Tomb Raider. The walk towards the temple is tree lined and sculpted with the ecological history of the place. The temple itself is extremely peaceful and made for the best temple visit.

Jungle book come to life . This temple has all sorts of amazing tree roots coming up through the temple. Kids can run, climb, and explore without having the sun beating down on them like Angkor Wat. Just watch out for mosquitoes and I think it would be really slippery when wet, but it was beautiful and definitely worth visiting.

Amazing!!!. The whole region is amazing.To actually be there and see the way the trees have over grown over 100s of years was unrealThe bird life was the only site that I have seen in South East Asia that I have been through for the last 5 weeks from Ho Chi Minh city through Loung Prabang and SurinIt good to see and experience the forest the way it is and the natural bird life in an protected an areaTo be there to see the site and hear the sound of different kind of birds noises it was wounderfull.

Wow.. No words could describe this place well enough. It just blew us away. The combination of man made beauty and 400 years of natural beauty whilst it was left undiscovered is just outstanding . I was speechless . And believe me. I am not normally( my wife will vouch for that) .

Amazing!. You feel very insignificant standing in this temple seeing how powerful nature has been in its taking over. The roots of the trees are fascinating and often bee swarms can be seen high up. There is always work being done on these temples so be prepared for sections that are shut off to the public. Platforms have been placed in front of the most impressive trees which spoils the look but is at least protecting the area. You can join all the others having their photos taken and think of Angelina.
Amazing, but a bit difficult to finid. This is the magnificent "Tomb Raider" Temple where Angelina Jolie did the movie. You will enjoy the great architecture and nature of the trees intertwined.

Extremely beautiful/as in Tomb Raider. If only able to visit for a day I suggest going to Angkor Wat and definitely trying to make it to Ta Prohm as its the temple used in the Tomb Raider movie with Angelina Jolie. The structure of the roots and vines from the trees into the temple walls and foundation is absolutely stunning. They are trying to restore the temple so you may come across construction sites. I would suggest going early in the morning rather than later especially if you're a photographer buff and prefer to have pictures without a lot of tourists them. If you have two to three days to visit the temples, I definitely suggest doing this temple in line with the circuit recommendations, see the attached picture map. Both Angkor Wat and Ta prom where my two favorites, and we actually spread them out over the course of two days so that we could enjoy both of them in all of they're glory instead of trying to cram it all into one day.Note1: Take a bike! They're $1usd and most come with locks, not that you really need them. Some routes/circuits are 10-12km, but you obviously don't have to follow the recommended three day tours. Biking allowed us to observe daily life in the rural areas outside the temples as well as Siem Reap as a whole.Note 2: do not go ticketless! They will fine you. Grab tickets en route to the temple roads, on your right approx. 3km before arriving at a fork in the road. Angkor is to the left of the fork. Note 3: Money is changed in USD, Cambodia uses the reil as change, like cents. Note4: snack stands and beverages available near Angkor Wat - restaurants too, and vendors line up near other temples. Prices slightly elevated but it's not ridiculous inflation.

Tomb Raider Temple. This is the temple that you see in the Tomb Raider movies. I liked the temple but not the hype. They talk it up so much as the famous temple, that a lot of people only care about that and forget about the absolute serene beauty of it. Really could just sit back and stare in amazement. Please leave enough time to really enjoy it.
Inspiring. Traffic level wasn't too bad when we visited this sight. You have to find the quite spots, but when you do it's incredible!

Nature Clashes with 1000 Year Old "Tomb Raider" Temple. This temple, while under construction, is still visually stunning. It's incredible to see how something built by man, almost a thousand years ago, is still standing. This temple is definitely not to miss on your Siem Reap visit.

Surreal. It's beautiful but little over crowded due to being famed tomb raider temple. Do check the bas reliefs. Loved the place and the surreal surrounding. Morning probably is good time to visit as most of the tourist are brought here after the sun rise sighting at Angkor wat so afternoon was pretty crowded.

Great place for photos. Ta Prohm is a great location to take some photos for great memories of the Angkor complex of temples. Only problem is as the day goes on it gets extremely crowded and somewhat annoying to dodge throngs of tourists. also be sure to keep a hat/cap, wear light coloured clothing and carry sunnies as it get EXTREMELY HOT even in the winter months.

This is a must-see. When you see photos of huge trees with their roots growing down the sides of the temple, chances are it's Ta Prohm. The temple itself is undergoing reconstruction, and is impressive in its own right. But what I found most impressive are the silk cottonwood trees that are enormous and grow on top of buildings and temple walls. There are scenes in one of the Tomb Raider movies that were filmed in Ta Prohm. If you plan to visit the temples of Angkor, you should not miss this one.

Got me worried about about my garden back home!. Impressive and iconic but really busy. There too many staged areas for tourists to stop for photographs which causes great disruption in ability to move around the site.

Best of all the temples. This temples is amazing because of all the trees growing out of it. Get here early in the morning before the crowds and it's downright magical. This was my favorite temple! This is also the temple where tomb raider was filmed -- it's no wonder they chose to film here.

A must visit when in SIEM Reap. Incredible how this temple has survived for hundreds of years.. The trees in many places have destroyed part of the temple, but in other areas , the trees are wrapped around the temple structure..
Incredible. Visit early in the morning to beat the heat and crowds. We went twice the second time early in the morning and had it to ourselves. Very worthwhile making the effort.

Peaceful and cool.. Loved this attraction. Pleasantly suprised to find that the use of it in LC, Tomb Raider has not turned it into an Angelina Jolie memorial. Lovely to see that there really are blue butterflies!!!

Spookily fabulous. We travelled with Audley (uk).... Slightly perturbed at the 5am pitch dark start but smug as cats with the cream when we left 2 hours later as the hordes arrived, with photos to die for and not another tourist in sight....

Where nature has taken over. We visited the 'tomb raider' temple from the wets entrance and it is a bit of a walk from the car park. but when you get there it is with it to see the Spong trees growing over the temples. Plenty of photo opps, especially the angelina / lara tree where there was a small que for pictures. Well worth a visit

More than just a movie set!.
