Although perhaps best know from scenes in the movie Lara Croft: Tomb Raider, Ta Prohm offers so much more than a film set.It's my favorite of all the Temples around Siem Reap with an atmosphere steeped in history and mystery. You could wander around this temple for hours constantly discovering something new around every corner.

Not a tomb raider in sight. We got here tired after 5 hours of temple touring. The walk in is beautiful. Be prepared to be hassled by the sales team before you go in tho! This is my favorite temple. It's where art, history and nature combine in such a wonderfully ornate way. We are going back again - but first thing in the morning.

Original jungle temple exploring!. Very different than the other temples as the trees have been allowed to grow through the temples here, which means you get a much more ruined temple in a jungle, with roots weaving through carved ancient walls and the sounds of parrots overhead. Butterflies lazily flit through the ruins. The shade of this temple is very welcome in the heat so a good option for the middle of the day.Only downside can be that since the temple is largely ruined there are limited routes to walk. When we were there there were large groups of Chinese tourists being quite loud,which lessened the experience somewhat.
Amazing. Its the tomb raider temple and the Bayon tree its one of the most iconic images of Cambodia how nature ha taken over the temples is incredible

theses trees are so hardy they do not require soil as far as i could see.. The movies may have made this place know to many BUT you really need to see it in person. These trees have grown everywhere. The temples hold them up a wonderful symbiotic relationship.
Tomb Raider!. It is a truly amazing site and to see how the trees have taken hold is quite something. Also very interesting for anyone who has seen the film!
Surreal. One of the iconic temples that are a must see on any visit to the Angkor Archaeological Park. Quite easy to get around but allow some time in peak seasons as it can become quite crowded

angelina. I love my picture in this place the roots everywhere
it remembers me the movie of Angelina
very nice temple my favorite in Cambodia

What a unique place. Seeing how nature is engulfing man made buildings, reclaming back what was once oly green and trees is magical.
This is maybe one of the most iconic places where you can take a picture in Angkor complex.
But beware that you'll have to wait in queue for that picture.
Unmissable!!

Temple eaten by the jungle. If you are travelling with kids, this temple is a must as it featured in the movie tomb raider with Angelina Jolie. It is a great example of how nature can take charge of even the most robust manmade structures. Quite impressive

Unique Temple Swallowed by the Jungle.. Ta Phrom was the absolute highlight of my visit to the Angkor Wat Temples. At the first sight of this temple entangled in tree roots I just stopped and gazed....it was amazing and unbelievable. Walking thru the narrow ailes in the temple I found refliefs showing the Bhuddist mythology. Everything quaint and stunning.

Nature taking over. Despite the many tourists (like myself!!!) it was wonderful to take in the beauty of nature wrapping itself around these ancient temples. It's worth going, just make sure you have lots of space in your camera.

Indiana Jones meets Tomb Raider. Out of all the temples, this was by far my favourite. There is a mystical feeling in the way nature has taken over much of this temple, yet also holds it together. Despite the fact that it's busy with tourists, don't skip out on this one, even if you are exhausted from trekking around all day. It is also quite shady, so a good temple to visit during lunch time or early afternoon.

A MUST SEE!!!!!!. The whole complex is huge and absolutely amazing. This is probably the most popular place as it was used for the tomb raider movie, so expect a lot of people there. A little tricky though if you want to get (like me) shots without tourists in them, but if you pick your time and your spot you can just about manage it. OK you like us may need to stand in line for your turn in front of the temple doorway, but got my wife to stand there and I took a shot, then as she moved away it gave me as clear a shot as you are going to get! If you get off the tourist track a little and explore there are other wonderful (other) tree root covered walls to be found. Magical!!!For infoThe three day pass is $40 but this was in our package as were all the trips we did.

Tomb Raider Movie Set. The Tomb Movie Raider was filmed here and even with all the tourists attending, it was very easy to imagine the films characters in this site. The trees growing amongst the ruins contributed to the uniqueness of this temple.
A famous Tom Rider Temple. A must see temple when visiting Siem Reap, Cambodia. A big tree grow up on the top of the temple, made by nature. Come and take a look.

Tomb raider temple. This is amazing, to see how the jungle has tried to reclaim the temple and the work that is underway to try and reconstruct the parts that are in ruin. It is like the world's biggest 3D jigsaw puzzle. Looking at the restoration process is very interesting.

Also called "Tomb Raider Temple" BEAUTIFUL. After Angkor Wat, this is the best temple to visit in Siem Reap, amazing great trees growing through the temple, there a re some ancient lovely not refurbished parts that you will enjoy...

Unreal experience!. Don't fall for the scams when people offer to tour you around inside. You can access everywhere without them and it's better to just wander around, take loads of photos, and move on at your convenience. These places are like playgrounds for adults, so be prepared to take silly photos, climb around to get a good shot, and make unforgettable memories!

Unbelievable tree growth through the centuries.. Not to be missed site in Cambodia. Tourist will have to be prepared for hot and humid weather. Good shoes and very light clothing necessary. Cambodia cotton shirts and pants are available for sale everywhere. Perfect outfit not to be devoured by mosquitos that may be lurking specially at dust and dawn.
Amazing site. I loved visiting this place because it has a unique feel. Weather was quite warm during January but good sunscreen and hat can save the day.
Siem Reap sightseeing. The place was magical. The hyped-up Tomb Raider shoot location will not disappoint any traveler who are apt for culture and ancient architecture.
Interesting. As with other reviews, this is part of the one day temple tour l did. All so interesting, and amazing to think they are as old as they are, well worth a visit.

Great temple restoartion work!. Hats off to Archeological Survey of India who has taken up the responsibility of the restoration work here. It's a massive temple, but mostly damaged due to overgrowth of the tropical jungle of huge fig trees. India has done a great job, restoring many parts of this temple that people can visit today. This also exhibits how the entire archeological park used to look a century ago, when this entire city was forgotten and reclaimed by the nature.

Best of the Temples. This is the most amazing place. A must see. Make sure you have plenty of space on your memory cards.
There was only 1 down side and that was coming out at the end. Pesky sellers wanting you to buy stuff, very very persistant.

Amazing, relaxing and still so wild. . It was a perfect morning. Early start from the west gate. Early the better to avoid group in the narrow passage. Majestic trees and ancient ruins together. Back in time. Easy to walk due to wooden floor for the children. Do not miss the side of the temple. Wall carving also amazing and covered in green. What a perfect start of the day. For us, the best temple to see. Enjoy.

Magical Place. Went there early in the morning,before the tourist busses arrive.Most magical and tranquil atmosphere,and you can hear the sound of the birds.Just make sure you be the first visitor of the day.

One of the best. Despite its notoriety if I only visited one temple it would be this one as its so overgrown and covered in the familiar green moss. Despite the fact that its so popular there are still plenty of good places to get those special photos as all the rabble only go to the main spots so look carefully and you will find those magical photos away from the crowd.
photo ops with the roots!. Since the movie tomb raider was shot here, there was a long line for photo ops and september is a hot month to be doing this! But nice pics for sure :)

Tomb Raider Temple!. This temple is absorbed by jungle. It is I the condition that Temples like Angor Wat were in before being archaeologically restored. It is intensely beautiful nested in nature. I almost wish the other temples had been left the same way. In Egypt they dig from the sand to expose history. Here from the jungle. This site was used to film scenes from the movie Tomb Raider with Angelina Jolie. Who is somewhat off hero to the Cambodian people. A must see. Don't ignore the spirit house on the outside right before you enter.

Tomb Raider temple. It's a site to see mother nature taking over these temples. I visited early in the morning and although there were people there, it wasn't crowded. So if you want to avoid the crowds, visit first thing in the morning.

Crowds of tourists keen to be photographed in Lara Croft poses!. Celebrated perhaps for the wrong reasons as the setting for the Tomb Raider film. Atmospheric and decaying with the enormous banyan tree roots invading everything.
My fav temple. Great to see the clash of old (temple) vs new (tree). So interesting the way they are preserving both - with supports for the temple and the tree! Great photos.

Awesome experience. The trees and the green mossy stone was definitely an awesome sight to see. My husband and I took a private tour over two days to visit the temples and while they all have something unique and special to offer, this was one of my favorites.

Had our family in awe. Well, had 14yo, 16yo and Mum and Dad in awe. 5yo was interested enough in the maze of mossy, shadowy walkways that were somewhere between rainforest trail and temple footpaths, and had overall had a great time. But the rest of us felt a mixed reverence for the people who had built this place and for the power of the jungle that is slowly taking it back. Our favorite of all the temples around Angkor, we included it on our US$15 day trip (and awesome driver - see my Angkor Wat review) by tuk tuk from our Siem Reap hotel. Forgot to mention there is a hefty charge of around US$20pp/day to get into the Angkor temples (I forget the exact amount but its less for children under 12 and adds up quickly for a family of 5. Once paid it does cover entry to all temples).
Tomb raider. Amazed at how mother nature rules here. Awesome ruins and photos to be taken here. Feels like Angelina Jolie.. haha
Ta Prohm - A "Live" Temple. The best site in Siem Reap. The trees behave like leaving octopus. Amazing. Took enormous amount of photos!!

Nice trees, but slightly overrated compared to other ruined temples. great spot, go in the morning before the crowds. if you really want to see the 'ruined' versions of the temples there are other ones nearby that are better. this one is just more touristy, and has more photogenic trees
Nice place. Not the best, but still intersting seeing the big trees and roots over the ruines , Indiana Jones style, don't forget unberalla

Cherish Your Tomb Raider Moment. Watching them trees spread across all over the temple will make you wonder how this man made structure survived all these years. A moment of proud for us Indians as Indian government is helping to maintain the temple complex. You would surely notice and see some pieces of the temple in bushes, broken statues or carved, covered in dust and moss figurines. The place is one of the best things to see in Angkor Wat.
Great place to visit.. Brill, exactly.what I thought Cambodia would be like. The temple was being repaired which is a feat in it's self.

Ta Prohm - or 'Jungle Temple". World Heritage Site, and also where the movie, Lara Croft, Tomb Raider was filmed. It's amazing the way trees are growing through buildings, and something definitely not to be missed.

The Temple with Tree. This temple is one of the must go places in Siem reap. Amazing display of nature. Giant trees have taken over many parts of the ruins. This is a photographer's paradise. The trees make this temple very unique. Don't miss.

Amazing!. Absolutely loved this nature V man temple, with nature winning. This is the Tomb Raider temple with massive tree roots growing in, around, through & over the enormous sandstone blocks which make up this temple. One of the not to be missed in Siem Reap!

Thought I'd be awed by this....not disappointed!. Absolutely took our breath away! Was there before 8am, and was the first and only people for about 30 minutes. ..incredibly moving to see nature take back this Temple. ..Highly recommend.

Hidden: Maze; Mystery; Like Giant Optopus!!. Must visit this temple!!The mystery, maze, the trees that have grown interwined among the ruins just like giant optopus hold on to so tightly; the presence of a mother's love to the children with soul. This temple was built for rememberance of King's mother. Every corner there is a fundamental feature of its own and there are stories of agitated so touching.

Best Temple. Loved this temple - probably one of our favourites and a must see. While Angkor Wat is amazing this smaller temple allows you to take in the atmosphere and see how man and nature have combined to create a truly magnificant structure.

Very beautiful! Awestruck by this place!. The Tomb Raider temple, as famously called by the locals.. This was undoubtedly the best place in Siem Reap. Ta Prohm mesmerizes you from all sides. This is the most beautiful and photogenic temple I have seen till date. The co-existence of nature makes it really beautiful. This place is a photographer's paradise. Ensure to come early during the day as it gets very crowded.Kudos to the Government of India for participating in restoring this temple. Restoring this temple to it's original state would be a near impossible thing as the roots of the trees go very deep down and poses a hazard to the monument. Hence, restoring it partially to ease visitor access and make the temple stable has made the temple very unique. A visit to Siem Reap is incomplete without visiting Ta Prohm aka The Tomb Raider Temple. Highly recommended visit with a duration of 2-3 hours (or more for photo enthusiasts!!)
Back to nature temple.. Enjoyed this temple because it has been left somewhat natural. Really gives you an idea of what the temples looked like before they were restored.

Nature reclaimed the temple and made it even more mystical. Yes, it was made famous by Angelina Jolie, but its beauty predates her and hopefully will remain long after hers fade. Visit soon, though. Nature is doing her best to reclaim her province. The temple grounds are made more unique and awe-inspiring because of the interplay between man's monuments and nature.
Breathtaking.. There is no way you can ever successfully photograph this place or see by way of visual media properly.You have to go there yourself and see it in its entirety.
Mysterious. Not to be missed.The approach through the jungle adds to the intrigue of this unforgettable complex..The trees flow over temples and walls as though they were liquid.
Big trees grow on the temples. Cambodia is wonderful and its my own country. Ta Proum is one of my favorite Temple is one of the most beautiful Temples in Kingdom of wonder Siem Reap City.

Eerily Beautiful. While Ta Prohm does not offer visually stunning photos from afar, it does offer something else very unique. The structure is crumbling and the ruins have not been kept up or restored like a few of the others. However, this was my favorite temple I visited. I actually enjoyed the moss and the eerie feeling this temple had. The sheer natural beauty that exists here is so captivating and fun for shutterbugs. The downside for photo lovers is that there are often annoying signs or fencing that prevent you from taking a pure, natural picture (...well, those other tourists, don't help either).

Nature takes over again.. An unbelievable site where nature has taken back over. Nature is demolishing the buildings and covering the ruins with tree roots which look as though there have been poured over, fantastic!
Awesome. We visited in the rain, but that did not dampen our awe of the ruins being taken over by the Spong trees. Creepy ... quite literally!

early in the morning. Go to this place very early in the morning before the tourist come, otherwise too crowded in this small but fantastic temple. Be there before 7h30 am, then you have time and place to enjoy the atmosphere and take photos

Photo shoots worthy of Tomb Raider. Cooler than most other temple spots, with very good angles, colours and monuments to take pictures with. The mix of the huge trees and roots with the crumbling stone structures is very unique, but expect to squeeze with several other tourists for the good spots

Excellent ruined temple of Bramha. Part of Angkorwat temple complex, Ta Prom mesmerizes you from all angles. How do you describe a brahma temple surrounded by a huge set of rings of roots of a tree. Must visit while in Angkorwat temple complex.

A Temple and Jungle, merged together.. This is the most beautiful and photogenic temple I have ever seen, simply because of the existence of the nature. Unfortunately, it is the most crowded too. The temple was surrounded by jungle and after it was left abandoned for centuries, the nature took it over, growing out of the ruins. Most of the area inside the temple are off limit, so you cannot roam freely inside the temple, which is why it feels crowded at times.If you are coming from the east gate, just after the gate, you can choose to use the long way (right) or the short way (left). Always choose the short way because it is nearer to the entrance to the temple so you can beat the crowd and see the famous tree first. You can cover the long way area later.I love the fact that the govt decided to keep this temple as it is, with only minor restoration just to make sure the temple is in a stable condition and to ease visitors access. It would make the temple more "original" and stunningly unique.

Get here before they totally rebuild it.. One of the more memorable temples to visit. We arrived here around 8.45am and there were around six people in total wandering around. By 9.30 am the Temple grounds filled up fast and we were glad of the opportunity we had to take photos earlier. An easy drive from town and well worth the effort to get there before the tours do. It is easy to access and wander around for people with mobility issues. I had a crook knee but managed a good 2-3 hours of wandering around as there were few steps or gradients to wear it out.Seeing it in its current state of disrepair is surreal and I hope the efforts to restore it do not detract from the emotions this place evokes
Beautiful!. Very interesting to see the trees coming out of old structures. Unbelievably beautiful and great experience!

The famous Tomb Raider temple. Aka the 'Tomb Raider' temple, it is very popular, hence almost impossible to see it without having to brave the hordes of tourists. An early start is best to avoid the crowds.
Mr Shane. Out standing place to visitLost in time. Must see amazing .you will have a better time with a guide
Cambodia's USP. The place is definitely Cambodia's USP. Not to make it sound spooky, but the roots actually speak to you. Please do pay attention to the dress code.
Incredible. This is the one you want to visit above all others. Not as majestic but laced with ruins and rich history.

Mezmorizing. Ta Prohm wasn't as busy as the other temples we visited. It was the third visit of the day and we were there around 10:30 AM. We spent less time here than the other temples, but it is simply stunning.
Mystic temple. Different from other temples, Ta prohm stands in the mystic forests, so you can feel a nice breeze.

Thomb rider movie seen. Angelina jolie participated on a movie that was taken there, "Thomb Rider".
But even so, the place is amaizing with all the trees that growing out of the walls.
Another must see.

Amazing. We have been to Ta Prohm on 3 of our 6 visits to Cambodia. It is a must see sight and each time we find more amazing things to look at.It is a photographers dream and the characters of the tree roots can provide many amazing photos and also when the sun shines through the trees.Good time to visit between October and February.

Tomb Raider Temple. Didn't know what to expect when I heard about this one. The trees that are growing out from the structures here are very large. The pictures I was hoping to get are different than in the movie, Hollywood actually combined Ta Prohm and Bayon to bring their film to life. Still worthy of a visit, when I was there part of the structure was under renovation , but the live monkeys living in the area made up for any misconceptions I had visiting Ta Prohm.

Indiana Jones feeling. This temple is awesome. With all the old huge trees growing over the ruins it looks like out of an adventure movie.The famous gate out of the tomb raider movie is well visited and if want to take a picture with you or your family you have to que for a moment.Definitive worth a visit and you shouldn't miss it!

Amazing temple complex. I would recommend spending at least an hour at this temple exploring the grounds and the temple itself. This temple sends you back into the jungle where you can see trees that have grow around or within the temple ruins. The detail of the carvings is also a highlight of this temple. When exploring this temple do not follow the crowds. It is best to get to this temple early to beat the crowds.
Astonishing trees!. Next to angkor wat the most recommendable temple in my Opinion. Especially the trees are astonishing. They make for amazing pictures!

My favorite. This was my favorite of the 5 temples we visited. A chance to see what time does to these ancient wonders. It really makes you realize how small we all are when compared to these fabulous historical sites.

More Cambodian History. This temple has fig, banyan and kapok trees growing through it, dislodging stones, but all of this adds to the sense of how it must have been to discover these temples in the Cambodian jungle. It really is a fantastic atmosphere here and good to know that it has been stabilised to preserve it in its current state. If you only have a short time in Siem Reap, Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm and Angkor Thom are quite easily reached by tuk-tuk and can be a half-day tour.
Must go !. Like every other temple in Siem Reap is definitely worth a visit, the trees in this place are something that never seen before

The Power of Nature. Very interesting photo opportunities if you have the patience to avoid all the barriers they have put up for renovation. And wait for the people to pass before you have the perfect click.

Best place in Angkor complex. This was the best place we have visited in the Angkor complex. We were able to get there pretty early and there was not so many people. It was possible because we did choose the small circle and run the other way round leaving Angkor Wat as the last to see. Best choice we have ever did.

Fantastic to see how nature has taken over the temples. This was an amazing temple to see, all the overgrown tree roots taking over the temples, took some great pictures, well worth a visit , you will be sorry to miss it
Thanks for keeping it natural. Best example of letting it lie without disturbing nature. trees grow all round the structure - lend it a natural setting. Must see to go back 800 years

Amazing. The melting of history and nature is amazing at this place. We liked it very much and would highly recommend to visit this temple too, although it is a little bit further in the woods. The scenery is unbelievable.

UNBELIEVBLE RUINS. Nature at its best, giant trees have taken over many parts of these ruins, Amazing photos can show the strength & height of the foliage at this World Heritage Site.Lara Croft & Tomb Raider were filmed here.Worth having guide to explain the history & point out the DINOSAUR CARVING - myth or legend???

The trees!. This is nature at it's most awesome-really shows how small we are in relation to nature! The growth of the trees over the temples took centuries and it is a must see. I never saw Tomb Raider but this is where they filmed part of it.
My favorite place!!!!!!!. Big Tree and green roof. Walk through to find Apsara in the tree and find dinosaur also be Lara Croft with that background.
Weird & fascinating !!!. Just part of Angkor Archaeological Park. Costs approx US$20 per day.I'd suggest a 2 or 3 day pass, instead of trying to do it all at once , much too big.

Too crowded on weekends. This temple has attracted many tourists to visit as Tomb Rider movie scene was taken it there. I was there on Sunday and it was super crowded. Try to avoid going on weekends as it was quite cramp. You can't really walk freely in the temple due to limited space. Anyhow, looking how the old trees grow on top of the roof were quite magnificent.
Memorable. While everyone wants to see this temple, it is still very much work the experience and the visit! This stands out for sure!

Ta Prohm. Tomb Raider.. Excellent. One of my favorites out of the temples. The ancient trees are stunning as t hey have grown over, through and around the temple walls. A 'guide'( one of the locals) spotted little, solo me and latched on, showing me the way, walking alongside me and talking about Angelina Jolie and Tombraider. When I gave him a dollar for his 5 minutes' tour' he moaned and said it was 'small.' Nevertheless, a fantastic site to visit.

My favourite . The Tomb Raider Temple as its now known due to the movie. Although it is in the worst condition and under some renovation it is by far the most stunning, surprisingly the dilapidated condition seems to add to the beauty and age of it.

Khmer Architecture for all. We all saw it in tomb Raider with Angelina Jolie. To see it in reality it is like most of the great ancient architecture of BCE although this is not. Being built in the CE is not to be missed by those wishing to see the buildings of the Khmer Empire.
Awe inspiring. An amazing display of nature and beautiful architecture fused by time. Angkor is fabulous but this is spectacular and we all felt this was our favourite site.

Another nice attraction in the archeological park.. Apparently this was the place where Tomb Raiders was filmed. Ancient buildings with huge trees growing through them. Definitely need a guided tour to get the most out of this place.

Ta Prohm. This is a unique attraction that blends architecture with nature's power. The great human creation of Ta Prohm Temple has turned into another amazing scene that combines human's art and god's power. You will have mix feelings seeing these beautiful tree trunks and roots embracing the old historical structures but at the same time has distorted and caused damages to it.

A Must-See!. A must see. Great to explore and fun for kids to climb over. This is the Lara Croft temple with trees growing in and over the temple walls. Truly gives a sense of how the forest hid the temples for centuries.
best at sunrise. To get the amazing photos you dream of go for sunrise to avoid the crowds and people getting in your pictures.

A scenic place. I love it! So amazed to see this sand stone castle covered by gigantic trees. Everyone know it was a location of Tomb Raider movie but, that was not the only reason to see Ta Phrom. The Sand Castle itself has a unique charm and really gave me a private feeling as I went there in late afternoon; and really felt in love with the ambiance.

simply spectacular. An age old battle between this once glorious temple and mother nature, a magical setting out of any children's adventure novel, This is an amazing place to spend the day exploring always finding something extraordinary to photograph, Be sure to bring an extra memory card and batteries for your camera, you'll need it, Also a good idea to bring water and wear a hat, it can get quite warm

Feel the Aura. This is a magical place but TombRaiders has turned it into a novelty so sometimes the aura of the place is lost. Try to avoid the crowds and dis-repectful tourist some of whom think it's an amusement park.

A must!. Of all the well known sites in the Agkor complex, Ta Prohm must be considered one of the best. Don't go expecting tomb raider, but enjoy the peace, spiritual and sereneness of the place. Less hype than Angkor Wat, Bayon Angkor Thom, but definitely the place to see. Trees, roots and less touristy, it will be the place your friends will want to see the photos from.

Photogenic temple in the jungle. This is one of my favorite temples in the Ankor area. We were lucky to see it during the slow season and to hit a time (late afternoon) with not too many other visitors.Mystical air with the temple and nature in a constant wrestle.

A must. This is a must visit in the Angkor Archaeological Park. So much atmosphere here with the jungle reclaiming the ruins. When you arrive there is a sign that points to either a short walk or a long walk. Do the long. It's not hard going and it is not actually that long.

There is a reason why the site was chosen for Tomb Raider. The jungle like atmosphere of Ta Prohm makes it very unique to the other sites in Siem Reap. Could not stop being amazed at this site. definitely worth a visit.

Very cool place. Ta Prohm shouldn't be missed on your trip to Angkor Wat. Make sure you drinks loads of water before, during, and after. I also recommend getting a tuk tuk ($15-18USD) to take you around!
Visit the Tomb Raiders temple!. Very exotic temple, with trees covering the ruins. This is where the Tom Raider movie with Angelina Jolie was filmed. Really beautiful!
Amazing . Famous in tomb raider! Eaten by huge trees,like tentacles it's beautiful but busy. Hard to get a photo without anyone in the background. Great atmosphere

Look for the "dinosaur" carving ;). According to our guide, this is the temple surrounded by "foot trees" (/sp^ng/) that did not usually grow in the area, but suddenly overtook everything after a few centuries. This temple was the one featured in Tomb Raider; but really, just seeing it is awe-inspiring. The roots of those trees crushing those temples to ruin just shows how much more powerful nature is compared to anything man-made.

Get in touch with your inner Lara Croft or Indiana Jones!. This temple is where parts of the movie ‘Tomb Raider’ were filmed. Don’t miss visiting this exquisite temple. Ta Prohm is only partially cleared of jungle and only partially restored. Large piles of tumbled building blocks still remain in situ, many covered in lush green moss. The greenness of this temple is part of its allurement. Many trees are still in place growing on, over, or through the temple itself.

The most iconic of Angkor's jungle temples - plan carefully.. Thanks (or not thanks) to the movie Tomb Raider this is one the most popular temples in the Park which is partly devoured by the jungle. Too avoid the crowds (particularly Chinese / Korean tour groups) I would recommend arriving between 6.30-8.30am.

Loved this place!. This site was made famous by being in a scene of a movie. Although the trees are probably destroying the site, they add to it...nature reclaiming the land. Another fascinating temple in the area.

Very nice roots. Must go to see the tree roots and where Angelina Jolie filed Tomb Raiders at!! Try going with a private tour guide so you know what each of the roots meant and how it affected the temples.
Nice jungle temple place for video shoot. LOCATION: located on the inner circle and can be done through bicycleGENERAL COMMENTS: really good place, with nice trees almost eating up the temples

Trees vers ruins. Interesting array of tree growing through the ruins Amazing the effort that would have been needed to build this and the other templesgood to view after bayon on the way to Ankor Wat
great. This was my favourite as I loved how the nature has mixed with the temple ; kids liked it too and it was not so hot as lots of trees.

Lara Croft's Tomb Raider experience. If you're a fan of the movie, definitely this is a must see, even not . Amazingly the roots of the big trees gives the majestic feel in the area. Though they say that those actually damaging the old structures, when you look at it as if the actually supporting the temples.Because of the Tomb Raider the movie,the place is mostly visited but there are some parts being closed for renovation.If you happen to visit, bring hat and water as the place will drain you. Be ready for walking and a little bit of climbing. But definitely stike a tomb raider pose
Siem Teap - TaProhm Temple. Another amazing temple sighting - Siem Reap in Cambodia is one of our favourite places on our travels in Asia and Malaysia!

Lara Croft has been there!. its very funny to walk through this awesome place knowing that Lara Croft had her adventure there. its unbelievable how nature took over this place. look for the buddha face between the tree roots ;)

don't miss it. After visiting this temple you will never plant a tree to close to your house. Those pesky trees have completely ruined a nice temple, creating tripping hazards and damaging rock walls, in some places completely smothering architectural treasures with winding roots. But fear not, the temple is nicely maintained and a safe destination to visit, strangely it has become a highlight of a visit to Angkor.... Don't miss it

A must see attraction. It takes your breath away when you see the size of the trees and the way they have magically entwined themselves over years with the temple ruins. Go with an guide so that they can give you the full experience. We went with Mr Sok from SOK Foundation. After your visit watch the Tomb Raider movie and you will see the ruins come to life.

Temple visit. Of the four temples we visited (Bayon, Ta Prohm, Angkor Wat, Banteay Srei), this was our favourite. The tree roots coming through the temple are fascinating and even the teenagers seemed to enjoy it more than the other temples.
One if the best temples. This temple together with Angkor Thom were my favourite. The athmosphere that the trees among the temple is really beautiful. Also for the fans of Tomb Raider.

Must see Ta Prohm.. This is my favorite temple in Siem Reap, It was so amazing and really nice sculptures, just wonder how could they built this temple is really incredible that the biggest giant trees climbed up the rocks is just magnificent, some trees are 800 years old and had grown over the temple ever since and became a part of it.

Blown away . Wow.. What an amazing experience in Cambodia. Incredible how the nature has taken over this part of the park.. Great to be able to get access to these areas.. Had and sunscreen required as it gets hot in the sunTotal must see when in Cambodia.

yet another amazing temple in land of temples. Take a guided tour when you visit this place. We went with the odyssey tours and they did a very good job. I was mesmerized with the enormous temples and the fact that they have stood strong for 1000 years is amazing. This was my favorite after angkor wotThis is where tomb raider was shot.Would totally reccommend people to go visit it.

Worry about the Structure Stability of Ta Prohm Temple. My 1st Visit (travel alone)to Ta Prohm is at Year 2004. 2nd Visit (detour from Vietnam) is in Year 2006, 3rd Visit (with Family) in Year 2009. This is my 4th Visit (with Muslim friend). Noticed the structure of the temple was support by steel propping and shoring system. I'm bit worry about this ...hope to see this temple in good condition and remain its charm and mysterious ..

Must Se. Better than expected. This temple was much larger than we imagined and had many areas to explore. It was busy but easy to find a quiet spot. More than one tree growing through walls. Due to restoration work access was limited but definitely a must see.

Grandeur and Mystery. We might have seen the countless images of tree strangled ruins and Angelina Jolie in Tomb Raider, but nothing really prepares you for the sheer grandeur and mystery of this site only partially reclaimed from the grip of majestic trees surrounding the area of the temples.
Loved Ta Prohm. My favorite temple. It was amazing to see how the jungle has taken over the temples. This is a busy and crowded temple, but so worth it!
Best temple by far!. This was my favourite temple in Ankor Watt. It seems the jungle wants to claim it back and ward off any intruders. Definitely worth a visit!
Recommended. This is nice place to see. Fantastic. Big gigantic tree with huge roots grown thousands of years ago. A lot of ruins left from before n still there to see. A picturesque a.

500 years old trees. Another great stop in the tour of Angkor and an amazing one, the tree temple (tomb rider temple) is incredible and the way the trees climbed up the rocks is just magnificent, some trees are 500 years old and had grown over the temple ever since and became a part of it.

Wonderful. Along with Angkor Wat, the main reason for visits, a must see is Ta Prom, a wonderful smaller temple, completely different, and so unbelievably gorgeous! Here they filmed Lara Croft Tomb Rider, by the way....! Try to avoid the rainy season, maybe november is a better time..

My favorite!. Ok, we were already amazed by the whole Angkor Complex, but when we saw this, it was another level. Abandoned through the years, you can see how nature has done it's work in regaining its territory. This was definitely my favorite, as it is still under re-construction, you can see that every piece, even if it is on the floor, has particular details that you cannot miss. It is not very big, so it won't take long. Maybe 3 hours if you want to see everything slowly.

Amazing place with such a lovely presence of nature. Ta prohm was one of my favorite places of the Angkor archeological site, such a presence of the power of nature, the trees that devoure the old constructions are so imposing!!! This place is quite famous because of Tomb raider, but I have read about it a long time ago, so it was an honour and a surreal experience to see it.The place is very touristy and attract large crowds, when I went there were some parts under restoration. I understand some people claim it is not that great because of tourism, that it is a shame the place has walkways, that it is not anymore as 10 yars ago....... Well yes certainy it's a shame the place has to cater for so many people (some tourists are indeed not very considered), and probably many years ago it was majestuous when it was off the beaten track, but things change and greater capital for maintenance and restoration is attracted for the whole archeological site, and it helps to keep the beauty of the place while bringing people. So I don't agree with the "purists" travellers that say that the beauty is gone

Amazing trees!. It was fascinating to visit Ta Prohm where Tomb Raider was shot for a die hard fan of the movie like me. I was also deeply humbled looking at the wonders of nature. The roots were so thick and surrounded the ruins twisting their way through crevices and walls. It was a beautiful symbiotic existence as if the trees were to be removed the ruins will crumble and fall. It was heartening to hear that some countries like India, China, Japan have taken up restoration works for each temple. Ta Prohm is under the Archeological Department of India. Lovely place and lots of pictures to click.

Tomb raider temple. Amazing experience in the middle of the jungle, where you can enjoy nature like:old trees devouring the temples.You really feel like your in the video game of tomb raider.It's really fantastic walking among the historical buildings and you can enjoy the wonderful panoramic nature around you.Do not miss it!

A "must include" stop while touring the Angkor complex!. A must do while visiting around the Angkor Wat complex. My favorite spot all around, with beautiful surprises around every corner. Much smaller compared to other nearby landmarks, but the tree roots and the architecture is incredible! If you take in sunrise at Angkor Wat, go here immediately following while it's still early!
Amazing history. Part of a day tour to Angkor. Huge fig and cotton trees entwined around the ruins. Our guide from Buffalo Tours took us to all the best spots to take memorable photographs.
Tomb Raider Temple - Ta Prohm. One of the must visit temple when visiting Siem Reap. Unique with it's trees root covering taking over the temple. Looks really great on photos.
Realtor nice . If you visit temples please do not forget go to taprum , cut it is nice. And the big tree is amazing .

Majesty meets magnificence. If you had only sufficient time to visit one of Siem Reaps ancient wonders, this should be it. It is a wonderful combination of the magnificence of architecture and the majestic graces of the forest. Each corner you pass brings another gasp or a 'wow'. Tip - go early and make this your first stop.

The most impressive temple around. A must-see!. Simply the most impressive temple among so many others around. The way in which the tropical forest seems to merge with man-made architecture here took my breath away when I saw it the first time. And I keep coming back every few months just to sit and watch. A truely magical place. Photopraphers: bring a second Memory-Card with you!

Most impressive one of the three day tour. This Temple was my personal favorite of our 3 day tour through the park, the trees still groing are simply awesome.No way you must miss this one in your visit !

Indiana Jones :). When you visit Ta Prohm you feel like Indiana Jones or Lara Croft from Tomb Rider. In spite of direct sunlight, there is always shade here because of the canopy of the trees. The place is mysterious, looks like it has been forgotten and abandoned. The trees have been destroying these bulidings by squeezing their roots between bricks making them fall apart, which gives the temple this fantastic atmosphere. You can go around the bulidings and see some pieces of the temple in bushes, broken statues or carved, covered in dust and moss figurines. The place is one of the best things to see in Angkor Wat.

A harmony of nature and religious culture. Siem Reap is no short of impressive temples. Ta Prohm temple sets itself apart from the rest with its enchanting tranquility and perfect harmony with nature. Once abandoned, the temple withstood the trials of time but without a price. Huge centuries old trees flourish within the temple grounds, trunks overgrown and roots entertwined with the temple facades, adding a tinge of nature's charm to the temple.
Thumb rider. Very impressive temple because of trees growing through the ancient walls. You see nature reclaiming what once was powerful civilization.

Stunning beauty!!!. Ta Prohm is just amazing. A mixture of man made beauty combined with the Wild of nature. Although now well controlled, it is still beautiful the way the roots move between the temple walls and trees have grown through and on to top of buildings. We went just after lunch and there was barely anyone here. Which was fabulous as there are so many good photo spots. Totally worth a visit,
Ta Prom - Wow!. Unbelievable... I'm so glad I can tick this off my bucket list! What an amazing place... A walk back in time!

Thumbs Up!. This area got it's media attention after Angelina Jolie filmed her Lara Croft movie here. With that said, the overgrown trees on the ancient ruins are still a sight to behold. However, through the course of time, the trees have outgrown some, if not all, of the old ruins and destroyed them. If time is not an issue then I would highly recommend a stopover for some great photos and 'Kodak' moments. It's not recommended for the physically disabled.
One of the must sees in Cambodia. Best to include this tour at the same time as visiting Angkor Wat. Can get day pass to include a number of temples. Cooler than others due to some shaded walkways.

Ta Prohm - simply awesome (at the right time of day). My favourite place at Angkor, by quite a margin. We went twice; first, as part of a day trip around the main temples. Ta Prohm was SOOO busy we could hardly move freely. We were often in long, snaking queues of tourists shuffling forward, hardly having time to look at the temple/trees, let alone take a photo.So we rose at 5 the next morning, got a 5.15 tuk-tuk from our hotel, and were the first to arrive at about 5.40 am. It was a wonderful experience - so emotive first thing in the morning, with birds calling, the sun rising - probably my single best memory from Cambodia.
Awseome. this place will take your breathe away,we had an awesome time here.just be prepared for the young kids trying to sell you stuff and they are persistant.Stay calm and be strong,hahahaha
Amazing. Can't believe that giant tree cover on the temples, It was really empressived and I was lucky that not so many people in that time and I took a lot of photoes.
Unbelieveable!!. U must visit this temple.Its a miracle and beautiful scenery.Wear a proper shoes and bring an umbrealla or a hat.Weather was hot and later in the evening it rains.

Nature overpowering man - Do not miss!. This is truly an example of the mighty powers of nature overpowering man's handwork. Reminds of Indie Jones and Lara Croft experiences, awakening the explorer in each one of us. The silk-cotton and fig trees which have captured the sites with their roots, add to the mysticism.
Beautiful, serene. An amazing example of nature meets ancient ruins. Tomb raider fans will recognise this beautiful spot. This is why we came to Siem Reap and it didn't disappoint.

Tomb Raider. After Angkor Wat this is the best temple. Good atmosphere and dramatic with the trees growing over and through the temple. And of course scenes from the movie "Tomb Raider" were filmed here.

A really special place. Visited this spot as part of my day trip to Ankor Wat. This was the last area I visited and although I was exhausted by this stage, Ta Prohm still took my breath away. It is such a magical place.

Ancient tree that ruined the temple enhanced the beauty of this place. You might have seen the place in the sequel of Angelina Jolie's Lara Croft - Tomb Raided movie. It is the place where Jolie met little girl at the ruined temple. In this site, nature shows what it's capable of, the trees might ruining the temple but what we see is true beauty, man made temple and nature become one. A must see site while you're in Angkor Wat Complex.
Stunning!. Amazing, incredible, stunning! Absolutely overawed by Ta Prohm. Highly recommended. Amazing how the trees grow out of the temples!

Magnificent, a must see. I visited Ta Prohm with my partner and travelled to and from byTuk Tuk easily, it was a beautiful drive just getting there. Entry to the temple was $20US each (but this enables you a day pass to visit multiple temples). It was absolutely stunning. I would highly reccommend anyone to visit this temple as I have seen no other like it. The trees growing over and through this temple were epically beautiful. Of course it was hot and humid but that's to be expected. Despite signage advising no shorts or singlets can be worn, this was not upheld. Modest shorts and singlets are acceptable. This was by far my favourite attraction in Cambodia. Don't miss it.

Loved this temple. This is the well known temple of the movie Tomb Raiders fame. The features include trees growing on top of the ruins which give it an even more alluring character. Definitely worth visiting.
Atmospheric. Interestng and atmospheric (though very wet when we were there!)Bit of "running the gauntlet" at the entrance.

Very busy. The temple itself was breathtaking and the huge tree roots over the stones was spectacular. However even though we were visiting during the "off-season" Ta Prohm was still packed with tourists and walking through the Central Tower at times we couldn't move because of all the people. However, definitely still would go to see it even if just for a short while because the sight of the trees reclaiming the temple is quite magnificent.

Ta Prohm Visit. Ta Prohm was also one of the best attractions I have ever seen. I love jungles and places like this! Just imagine that tree being "one" with that structural building. Now that's cool! The scene is just amazing and I love the way they maintain it. It's clean and easy for tourists to roam around the area. People can just take Photos all day!

Like being on a movie set!. Absolutely stunning location. Definitely worth a visit. It is a popular tourist destination though so expect crowds. This was my favourite of all temples - they have done an incredible job restoring it.

very busy but still great. The temple was breathtaking and definitely worth seeing. It was just a shame that there was such a ridiculous amount of people, even for off-peak season. Almost impossible to get photos but if you're patient you can wait in a line.

so many trees growing on the temple, amazing. this was the easiest temple in the area to walk, due to the large number of trees. it also provided for some really cool pictures. most of the place is in ruin, but the overgrown trees here are what you are going to want to picture, not the temple itself.
A must see. A must see - if you visit nothing else, this is the temple you must visit. Phenomenal setting, easy to get to, but quite popular, so expect people.

Breathtaking!!. This was probably my favorite temple. It was so beautiful and truly amazing. Plus, it is famous for being used when filming Tomb Raider. Definitely recommend taking the time to go check it out!

A Magical Place. its Truly a magical place. just loved the tress that grow out of the temple feel like u in a different world. love the green shade of the temple. a very unique color to it also a out of the box place to go during the noon to beat the heat.

Taken over by the Nature. Feeling amazed on how well the nature and mankind creation blend together. At the same time feeling sad to see how mankind's greed ruined this place.You can enter from the west gate and exit at east gate. It took me about 1 hour and 30 minutes to walk from west to east. You can ask your tuk tuk driver to wait at the east gate so that you don't need to make 1 big round to return to the same entrance.Great place for nature lover. Be sure to bring additional battery to last for more photos. Most of the nice sceneries are located at the central.

Watch where you plant seeds. This tree is about 900 years old, way back that time someone must have planted the seed and not knowing how huge the tree would grow up to.And when the building of the temple they must have seen it as a small sapling so they left it, but then over the many years it started to grow more larger then the roots started to take over the corner of the building, it was too late to take it out as part of the building would collapse so it still stands as it was hundreds of years ago now joined to the building.
The best templo in Angkor. If you, like me, like nature, this is the place to visit. It is by far the best templo in Angkor, and a must see on the place. Have to go
Great place. Pictures, pictures, pictures. Don't pass this site up. Good place and great people. Super history and ruins. best time of year is December and January.
Out of a movie. The concept of time is made more realistic when one views the growth and age of these trees entwined throughout this historical work of art

It made my day. Although the temples in Siem reap are fabulously fantastic but Ta prohm makes our day so memorable. The trees grew over the temple created a stunning view, which is hard to forget. People would love to Return to Siem Reap, probably, because of this amazing temple. ;)
Tomb raider. Tomb raider site. Amazing evidence of natures strength. The tree roots have worked their way through literally destroying the temple.

The very very best of Angkor - a magical place.. A totally unbelievable place to visit. You can't visit Siem Reap without coming to this temple complex. We visited late afternoon when the crowds had died down so you could really enjoy the ambiance without getting elbowed out of the way. Part of Tomb Raider was filmed here.
Ta Prohm . Never seen anything like it. Trees growing out of the ruins 9 centuries old in the heart of the ancient Khmer empire.
Ta Proh. This place was made famous by Angelina Joli. The trees and the roots that grew in the temple were spectacular. Such a wonder of nature. I oved every bit of it.

5* just for Indian Jones. We cant give anything but 5* just for the scenery of Indian Jones. Take a guide who can recommend the best places to click pictures. Those pics come out like a movie set. It actually made me wonder if this was the place that I took the picture. The place has a special spirit that makes pictures come out extra special. Dont miss the special ceremony where you clap hands and do an ancient ritual. I prayed there and it was a special moment to be in silence thanking god for this wonderful trip. Just outside we had another special moment where our entire family of 15 posed by standing under the roots of a tree for a final picture

A little gem. We were tired by the time got here having done two large temples already. However, it was good to have done it and seen the trees growing out of these ancient temples. Looked for Lara but.could.not see her

Huge massive trees. It has got huge massive collections of the trees which I have never witnessed in my life.The place is quite big and have to walk a bit to see the depth and the size of the trees which seeing at first sight makes you feel wonder a lot.
Amazed. Was so amazed at how those trees could grow so huge and architecture of the building are well kept and clean

monsoon at Ta Prohom. Stunning! Great experience to see 'ruins' ie a temple that has been only partially renovated. Rather romantic. It was last of the day, we were tired, hot and bothered and got caught in a monsoon downpour and it was just great! Loved the band (?) Playing halfway down the track. More walkways protecting us and the ruins than some of the other temples so a bit of queuing for photos but very worth while. Well worth the effort.

Amazing. This temple was amazing. To see how nature has fought back and is trying to take control. some of the best photos were taken here. It rained the day we were here and it really didn't matter. So good was this temple that we went back the next day. The walks around the outside are as good as inside

The iconic tree trunk known the world over!. My wife and I journeyed here from Bangkok using the cheap train from Bangkok to Aranyaprathet and then via tuk tuk to the border town of Poipet.It was totally worth the journey.This tree must be one of the most famous trees in the world. To enter the derelict temple and stand near the roots was an amazing and surreal experience. Although there are many such temples in the general area it was the tree and its fame that made this the stand-out temple to visit.
Must see. Incredible to see how the trees have supported, yet helped destroy this temple. Under reconstruction by an Indian team part is done and part in progress so it's good to see how it's done.

My favorite. This was my favorite of the places we visited. Once inside, we were mostly covered from the sun, and it was fun to walk through all the tunnels. Only one thing, make sure your Tuk-tuk driver is waiting on the other side of the temple! If not, you will have to walk all the way back or hire another Tuk-tuk just to take you back to the other side

Lara Croft - The Tomb Raider temple. This is actually what inspired me to go to Angkor Wat. Angelina Jolie , famous Tomb Raider was shot here. The Temple is covered with gigantic trees which in a way are supporting the structures and the other way around too. Actually the trees and their gigantic roots , barks growing in this way, have made this more of an attraction I believe. Many of the trees have though now been removed for the resurrection so its better to visit the place now before everything is gone.

A definite must see in your life tome. Wow wow wow! We just loved the way nature had decided to claim back what is hers. It is so fascinating to see the way the trees have started to grow over the buildings. So dominant yet gentle in the way the man made structures of yesteryear are being supported by nature's scaffolding. You can feel the earth's energy. There is a calm symbiotic coexistence that can be felt. Take a moment to feel the trees. Explore the whole grounds with your children. You'll remember it forever. And don't forget to get creative with your photography.

Ho Hum Ta Prohm. Aside from the fact Lara Croft Tomb Raider was filmed at this location, and there are some awesome trees growing out of the ruins, this is just an okay stop on the temple tour. Compared to Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, it was lacklustre for me.

Definite must see - Watch out for unsuspecting 'guide'. This temple site immediately invoked feelings of mystery and intrigue and amazement. From the unbelievable giant tree roots enveloping a once majestic stone structure to the beautiful intricate carvings on Stone blocks. Countless corridors and walls play with the natural light. Watch out for guides who approach you and start to talk to you about the site. It may have been an isolated incident but this chap ended up asking us for money. But don't let this put you off visiting.

My favorite Angkor temple. I would describe Ta Phrom in three words: eerie, time-honored and majestic. Just seeing the roots of the tree "harmonizing" with the temple is just mind-blowing. The kind of architecture you won't find anywhere else in the world. Definitely, my favorite Angkor temple. I came here during low season, so there weren't much people in the temples. I had time to explore it on my own.
nature always win. Seeing how nature has taken back this place. Trees growing around what was once would have been a grand sight. fascinating place to visit.

So very Lara Croft tomb raider!. These temples have the feel of the Mayan ruins in Coba, Mexico: a mix of excavation and jungle. The century old trees covering much of the exterior wall are truly breathtaking. Very crowded the day we were there, but that's to be expected. Spring for a guide; you'll be glad you did.

An intimate encounter with the past. When walking towards the temple, take your time and admire the huge perfectly straight trees and their beautiful symmetrical shapes, some of them are one of a kindto be found today in South East Asia. Once you get closer to the temple stop at various places for a while and contemplate the majesty of the structure, yet at the same timeenjoy its many corners and intimate places.Best in the late afternoon towards closing time ( 5 p.m. ) as the light is perfect for some amazing photo opportunities and yes one does not want the noise from the crowds but enjoy this meeting with the past in a very personal and quiet way.Fabulous temple and certainly a highlight!Spend time!Cheers,BMW
Holiday. Was a great experience and enjoyed being able to share the history of this country a must-do while visiting Cambodia
The magnificent amazing sight. The magnitude of the trees and temples are just spectacular, splendid and awesomely impressive nature at its best.

Photographers dream. I think this ends up being everyones favourite temple, its truely magnificent with the tree roots invading the historical ruins. It had been 5 years since i had visited and the erosion was more way more noticeable which is a shame.Fantastic for photos

An amazing film set and you can be the star!. Ta Prohm is not always the busiest of the Angkor Wat experiences, but when it is...or if it is raining...then there is a problem....everyone wants the same photo! One of the smaller sites, this is one to see in isolation if at all possible...the impact of nature on the built environment is spooky. it is a great photo opportunity...ruined of course if your visit coincides with a coach party. So, either start or end with a visit here, you will not regret it and you could have some incredible photos with dappled shade or dazzling light. I don't know anywhere else in the world like it...it is a film set in itself.It is the "Tomb Raider" site, so there is that additional dimension but above all try to get some photo angles on the incredible formations and shapes created by the massive roots and limbs of the trees intertwining with the stones and pillars of the monument. This site is also a bit tricky in the wet...and the central area floods quite easily, so ....maybe one to take care with...Enjoy it though, we certainly did.

Must visit. Unlike Bayon and Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm has been taken over by nature and has not been restored. It's truly magnificent and well worth the time. Try to visit it early as it will be overrun by tourists by late morning, and taking nice pictures would be really difficult.

Temple of ancient trees. It's amazing how the tree roots intertwined to form snake like, octopus and other shapes. This site is no longer an active place of worship. Peaceful and serene surroundings outside the temple is good for nature lovers and photographers. There are different shades of green. The history of the temple is interesting. Do read up to appreciate it. There were books being sold for about USD5.

Ta Prohm. Best visited late afternoon when the crowds have thinned. This is an interesting display of the futility of trying to control nature. The roots of the Sprung trees drip over the walls of the temple and it shows the fragile nature of these man made structures.

Ancient temple surrounded by jungle. Ancient temples brought to life again in Tomb Raider movie. Surrounded by trees you suddenly emerge into a maze of rooms, courtyards and terraces. Allow plenty of time to look at the many carvings. Can you find the one that looks looks a triceratops?

Please visit. Amazing temple, with tree roots creating such splendour . It is a lovely drive out to the temple whether by car, tuk tuk or even bike if you are fit. Interesting brick fence right around temple.
Ta Prohm. The Ta Prohm jungle temple is one of the area’s most beautiful temples. Ta Prohm has been relatively untouched since it was discovered and retains much of its mystery.

We took a lot of pictures in this area. There are blind musicians along the way, children selling key chains and souvenir items. As compared to other temples, most of the Ta Prohm are with large trees. The trees are so strong that they can displace the ruins.

Beautiful trees surrounding the temple!. The vibe in this temple is pretty different from the rest as it had many trees surrounding it which were over a hundred years old. Really liked the "Hidden Mickey" in the temple which is a goddess hidden amongst the roots of the trees.
Excellent!!. Truly spectacular! My favourite of all the temples! The battle between nature and man made structures is truly astounding to see here. Would return back there again if I could!

Beautiful. Well, we have seen so much of this temple in the internet, but when you are there, you will be impressed. You need to walk a short distance (about 5 to 10 mins) from the entrance, to reach the temple. Comparatively, it is not too tiring because there is not much of climbing up and down the steep stairs here. And the uneven walkways (some stones are broken) are now laid with wooden platforms, making it easier for visitors. There are many trees here, shading us from the scorching sun. Many trees are perfect for photography, provided if you are patient to wait for your turn for a good angle/ good shot. We find it beautiful and the children had fun walking through the temple buildings. You will need time and drinks for the hot days.
Ta Prohm. What an amazing place this is and so sad that the buildings have been let go so far with trees climbing allover them and in them. Wonderful the work they have done to restore them.

Tomb Raider Central. Could spend days in here taking photos, the root formations are incredible. Our kids (12,9 and 4) loved Ta Prohm, were convinced they could find hidden treasure if they looked hard enough, really captured their imaginations!

literally ruined!. its a beautiful temple complex but terribly spoilt by the coach loads of Asian tourists all in a hurry to video themselves and so wrapped up in taking selfies on their selfie sticks that it was annoying to anyone who wanted to just absorb the magnifisence of the history and grandeur it has to offer.. the trees and tumbledown walls really are like the jungle has tried to smother it! stunning but ruined by ignorant tourists. there is a one way system in operation so you cant just roam around either...
Amazing Place. My favourite of the whole SiemReap experience, great for photographs and usually quieter in the morning than Angkor Wat.

Tomb raider temple not to be missed. This is the temple from Tomb raider and it's well worth visiting as it is an small extra charge to the main temple areas. The trees growing through and around the temples are huge, another must see.

Yes.. Definitely one of the more interesting temples. It's overgrown with life giving it a mysterious charm. Because it isn't one of the main temples it is a bit less touristy - fewer people visiting, this adds to the serene mystery and makes for one of my favourite temple experiences. I highly recommend seeing it.
Another off the Bucket List. Just WOW. This place didn't disappoint. I have seen the Tomb Raider movie so wanted to come and see this place for myself. It is astounding how the
Amazing!!!. Have to see - just beyond amazing and an amazing energy - take your time and see all the small things...

Thickness of the trunks, unreal. I really enjoyed the place but extremely touristy. If you are unfortunate to arrive after a coach load of tourists, you will just have to wait for the photo everyone else who is there wants. Kids trying to sell after the exit can be pushy....
Amazing!. The Architecture & the Banyan trees are amazing, worth the visit!We did a tour which included Angkor wat, Ta prohm, elephant terraces.
Really amazing. Didn't expect that it's so breathtaking, some areas closed due to renovation - but that doesn't influence your impression, you must see!
An old wonder. I have been here three times, and its constantly changing due to both renovations and sections being closed off due to being unsafe. Its a must see if its your first time in Siem Reap

Renovations but well worth a visit. First visited in 2006 without any restrictions on access. It was good to see the work being done but it could be difficult to move around if it was busy. Most people know it from the movie..the jungle templewith trees growing over and out of the stones.
Good for photography partiularly am for the light
Tomb raider. One of the name grabbing sites. The trees here are truly amazing and add a lot of interest. Take the time to enjoy it .

Worthwhile visiting despite some Issues. Fortunately, we went there before sunrise, around 5.15am. We pretty much had the temple for ourselves until 6.30am. When we left at 7am, there were a couple of buses arriving already. Unfortunately the sky was overcast on the day; it is still very atmospheric and definitely worth a visit. There is some renovation going on and some heavy machinery/crane on the area. This does not exactly look cool, neither in reality nor on your pictures.My advice: go there early if you want to beat the selfie-crowd.

Almost surreal!. Ta Prohm is one temple in Angkor truly different from all the others. The giant trees growing right through the temple architecture simply have to be seen to be believed. Made famous as the temple where the Angeline Jolie Tomb raider movie was shot, this one is a must see.

The nature is coming. The different buildings are beautiful. More and more are rebuilt. And that is just perfecjt. Here in this area you can see how the nature takes over when humans leave.Beautiful trees. Seems like water running down the walls. Beautiful.
Interesting. Out of all the temples, this was the most interesting to me. I'm glad I saw it. The trees growing over the ruins were quite impressive.
Beautiful and Historical.. I have to admit that I have not see Tomb Raiders, so did not go to this temple because of that movie. I found it beautiful and so glad we had it on our itinerary.

amazing sight - don't miss this. This was an amazing experience. We expected the trees growing on top of the buildings to be creepy - but it wasn't. Somehow it all assed to the peace of the area, which was busy in August but not overcrowded. This is a must visit if you are going to the Angkor Wat complex

Make Time to See This!. If you're anywhere in Cambodia, make the time to see this temple. It's crazy amazing, aside from the fact it's been in all kinds of movies. I enjoyed climbing on some of the ruins. Just be careful you're not climbing in areas that are blocked off by cones.

would be better after renovation. The stunning view of this temple went beyond so far from my expectation. However, this Tomb Raider temple is now ruined by the construction. However, I believe it would be much better after completely finished renovation. <3 AMAZING

Best to see. Though Angkor Wat is the most famous place to see, I really do prefer Ta Prohm, which became famous by the 2002 movie "Tomb Raider" with Angelina Jolie. - It's more mystic and be aware that the Spung Trees will be removed to save the temple. - Go there soon...especially if you are a photographer!

another must see in Angkor. Angkor complex is filled with places, where You could spend the whle day just taking it all in and taking hundrets of photos. Ta Promh is one of those.
Here, trees grow out of and over ancient ruins, while people work to preserve them and it's almost magical.

Creepy, fascinating and intriguing!. A mystical place, one feels like Stanley and Livingston walking among ruins in the deep dark jungle and not knowing what lies ahead of you. You can see how the jungle has woven itself into the once standing structures that are now remnants of a past civilization. At once, creepy, fascinating and intriguing! Try to visit in the cooler months, not in August when it is so oppressively hot and humid.
Awesome place worth visiting. Cost included in Angkor pass. Should visit this place. Can easily spend 3 hrs here... This is one temple you cannot miss in sieam reap.

The "Tomb Raider" jungle temple. This is a special place, not to be missed in a visit to Siem Reap. Under gradual restoration hampered by the tree roots that are partly destroying and partly holding together the structure. Wonderful atmosphere.

Low set compared to Angkor Wat and very different, amazing tree roots engulfing the temple. Wow what an amazing sight this was, we spent a long time, as much as one could bare in the intense heat crawling around this place. Just pay particular attention to where you come in, if you have to exit the same way, we came out completely lost, and had to hire another tuck tuck driver to ride us around, to find ours stretched out asleep waiting.
Beautiful. For me it was a unique experience, I was so happy to see all this arqueológica area, just remember take water with you and good shoes for walk

Must go. Ta Prohm is must go. It is kept more like how it looked when it had found out. So people get the feeling of past and how it really look when it get abandoned in the jungles. You can see trees with giant roots growing out of the ruins and that make it attractive and good photography location to click the ruins. This is where Angelina Julie's Lara Croft: Tomb Raider has been filmed. You can see some photos of our visit herehttps://www.flickr.com/photos/29065913@N04/albums/72157653826321654

Better Than You Imagined. I dreamed of coming here for many years and it was everything I expected and more. It was fascinating and you can spend hours walking around admiring the beauty here. Worth the trip.
Lots of atmosphere and beauty. One of my favourite temples. Go very early to avoid the bus loads of loud tourists and the kids trying to get you to buy things. Definitely worth the time.

Nature taking over. Excellent. Has been kept slightly unrestored. Started with the minor temples on the first day before moving th Ta Promh on the second and the most famous ones on day 3 ( as per Lonely Planet's recommendation)

Amazing Temple. Ta Prohm which is located at the north east corner it is a beautiful temple, bound by massive roots of huge trees. When in late nineteenth century Ta Prohm was discovered by French
Originally known as Rajavihara (Monastery of the King), Ta Prohm was a Buddhist temple dedicated to the mother of King Jayavarman VII.
stunning. Must see with a guide to get the useful back ground information about the history of the Angkor wat temple complex!

An A-Maze-ing Place. MY FAVOURITE Place to visit!Ta Prohm doesn't disappoint, it's so peaceful, lovely and so big to explore! It has 39 towers standing, so be careful you could get lost here. But there's a map here and there, so you can refer where you are. Surrounded by forests, this place is not to be missed. Find a spot where you can just sit and rest for a bit, and you'll drown out the noise (even when there are tourists just on the other side of the wall). It's such a peaceful place to be in. Here, you can also see gigantic trees resting on the temples, the efforts to upkeep this place is commendable.A not to be missed stop in Siem Reap! <3

My personal Favourite temple. Ta Phrom is personally my most faves temple among others in Angkor Archaeology Park. It's atmospheric combination of trees growing out from the ruins and the jungle surroundings the temple fascinates me so much

Visit the tree temple to see what nature can do. This temple is being restored by the Indian govt. through an archeological exchange. Fascinating to see the trees growing over the old temple structures. Also to see before and after pictures of parts of the temple that have been restored by the Indian team over the past few years.

Tomb Raider Temple!. It was really neat seeing this temple, as it was the location where the movie Tomb Raider was shot. We loved seeing all the intricate carvings on the walls, and the way the strangling trees grew around the temple with the roots growing in between the bricks of the temple. I'd suggest trying your best to not go with tour groups, or else you'd be waiting a long time to take photos.

It's magnificent. Looks like very old. . It is a definitely one of the bucket list when you go to Angkor wat. Nonetheless the Tomb rider really blow the popularity of this temple. But it is indeed very magnificent. The roots looks very old and the temple which is now looks really like a ruins full of treasures. The thing is. The place was really full when i came. It's packed with tourist fron all over the world. And it is concentrated on the most famous spot at Ta Phrom which is the center bayan tree pictured in the Tomb rider movie. Though it's a very long walk to the inside. I really like the temple compared to Angkor wat

saved for last, most beautiful of all. We had a long day exploring Angkor Wat and our guide saved this one for last. The most beautiful if all! The temple is in it's natural state with ancient trees growing right out of it and forming part of it. Lots of walking and climbing, but well worth it. This was stuff from the movies in real life

Tomb Rider. As what I expected. Too bad there were construction on my visit. In addition, there was a barricade in front of the tree, so I cannot take a photo sitting on it like the others who came before me. But sure, once you're in Angkor Wat this cannot be missed
Amazing . This temple is truly amazing the trees overtaking it all is breathtaking. Some advice bring loads of film, batteries, and storage space. You will be taking a lot of photos.

Awesome experience. Came here with my friends and we did not have a guide. But one of the security guard came to us and started to take us around the ruin area and showing us all the places that were great for pictures. He even took pictures for us when we were at the spot where Tomb Raider movie was filmed. He was very nice and spoke some English but mainly he spoke Cambodian. He was like a guide for us and when we were done, we tipped him. He didn't ask for anything but we felt like tipping him to show our gratitude. Thanks to him, we were able to go around and experience all the areas that a guide would have taken us. I do not suggest doing this when you are there but if there is a chance that you needed someone to guide you, you can try to look for our security guy. The ruins was grand. All the trees that grew roots around the structures were reaching up to the sky was amazing seemed so far away. A must visit if you are in Siem Reap.

Amazing!. Apart from the hollywood fame, this site is historically significant, as well. While I would have loved to see Lara Croft running around, the crumbling ruins, covered in moss are so beautiful. This truly was a once-in-a-lifetime visit.

Best temple in siem reap. This was such a cool temple. You can see why they chose it to film Tomb Raider. The trees were amazing - they are huge and roots are embedded within the stone of the temple and grown upwards intwined within the temple walls. Nice photo shot.

Amazing!. Incredible! I loved exploring this temple. It's a decent sized complex with lots to explore. Get there first thing in the morning or around 4:30pm to avoid the crowds. It's very peaceful and enjoyable when it's quiet without the tourists.
Amazing ruins. The trees are huge and the roots grow into the temples just like what you see in the pictures. Worth a visit.

Stunning trees rival the breathtaking architecture. Here nature and humanity combine to take your breath away. The trees with their naturally sculptured root structures which defy gravity rival the centuries old temple architecture. it's a wonder of the world - it's accessible when you buy the $40 ticket which allows you three visits over seven days. The temples are accessible. "Guides" will engage you in conversation and many are worth the tip as they will bring you into the "nooks and crannies" of this living history. It is breathtaking and well run. You definitely need a tuk tuk / about $15 for the short trip or negotiate a rate if you want to travel to the temple around 60km away - all well worth a once in a lifetime trip - bring lots of disc space on your camera - it's breathtaking and an umbrella to shade you from the heat or rain. Eating is at "tourist traps" on site but there is no other choice and they are adequate / drink lots of water and bring good walking shoes as there are lots of steps to negotiate. A bucket list trip - hard to find its equal worldwide.

Beauty in disrepair. Ta Prohm is a little different from the other temples in the sense that it's covered in lush greenaries. It felt serene and calm to be here. Go for the longer route.
