As most tours follow the same route, most will be tired by the time the reach Ta Prohm, hence, they're more likely to go towards the 'highlight' route. Going on the longer route almost guarantees silence, as the path is around the temple enclosure instead of just through the temple. One thing I love about Ta Prohm is that even in disrepair, it still feels calm and regal. It's beauty in it's own way. It's my favourite, right after Bayon.

Temple of Trees. Ta Prohm was so unique temple that has been slowly taken over by the jungle over the years, but is being restored through a joint venture of the Cambodian and Indian governments. Famed for the trees that seemingly grow through, around, over and within the temple, it is a very wonderful temple to visit and spend time. It can be tricky at times though due to the popularity of visitation by tourists as this temple was in the movie Tomb Raider, which seems to draw large crowds.
Ta Prohm Raider. Basking in the glory of Tomb Raider movie. Loved it. Seriously though, beautiful temple with lots of interesting carvings and icons.

Amazing Temples!!. This is the most beautiful temple ever!!!We do love this temple because of the trees are unique, the roots of the trees example, with the remarkable scenery and spectacular animation trees as well as location. The best way to explore this temple should be at 6am in the morning and 12 in the afternoon due to avoid from crowded. Whenever you enter this temple, make you feel like the heaven, with romantic parrots singing, ever branch of trees fully of bees and some trees more than 8 bees in every branch. I could not even more describe what the immaculate temple is.

Amazing temple. It is a jungle surrounding temple, really beautiful, and also famous temple. It took 25 minutes to reach there by car or Tuk Tuk. This is one of the attracting temples among the main temples in small circle explore tour. I have been there two times, but still want to see it again.

For Historic Lover's. I got to know about this temple that it's more than 1000 year old. Once you enter traditional music will welcome you. It's the place you must visit . Try some butter Kulfi outside too..haha
Must see place in siem reap tour.. Must see place in siem reap tour.size of the tree roots are resembling Anacoda.wonder is how nearly 900 years old temples are carring these trees.

Just amazing, but you better be quick!!. This is one of the most beautiful temples in the world!! The attraction of course is the trees which have spread the roots around the temple itself. Our guide however told us that the Government and UNESCO have decided to TAKE OUT ALL THE TREES in this temple so they can rebuild what the temple would have looked like originally. What a shame, the whole attraction and beauty of this place is the incredible trees that are between 400 - 500 years old!! Visit as soon as you can - we were here 4 years ago and can already see the huge difference with work already starting to cut back the trees.

Hidden secrets around every corner. . A calm and cool location. Fascinating seeing mother nature reclaiming her turf. Spotting a stegasaurus, a triceratops in the carvings was trippy. And the young girls face peering from the roots a delight.
The beauty of nature!. WOW!! Something everyone must witness, the beauty of this temple being overgrown in ginormous trees!

Tomb raider movie set!. I was here with my girlfriend and our tour guide Mr. Lonh! This was our first stop for our 3-day so we were very excited as we entered this temple! This sight is where they shot Tomb Raider so my girlfriend was so excited about that. We had heaps of good photos from this temple too! A really beautiful place that you shouldn't miss!

romantic and interesting. the temple was the most beautiful place i saw! interesting with all the trees all over the old structures and very romantic! obviously, all tourists wanted the photo next to the tree from jolie's movie shoot there, but that just gave it a bit of a western charm. you can always skip this part of the temple and enjoy the rest to the full :)
great experience. magnificent trees that are hundreds of years old... a pity the structures are falling apart..some reconstruction going on
Beatiful place,recommended!!!. Very beautiful and amazing place. Unbelievable,can't imagine how the ancient make it!! A lot of big and beautiful trees.

Precious. Great temple to visit and see. It is very interesting to watch how nature has decided to take over the temple. This is probably one of the most intriguing temple for pictures, where you will have many opportunities to take various pictures at various locations

Don't miss this one. Even though lots of it are broken.. this temple has its own uniqueness. Particularly the gigantic tree that has grown on it for years. Outside the complex there was a group of handicapped musician which plays traditional music beautifully. If you can only visit a few temples, this one shouldn't be missed

Tomb raider at Ta Prohm - fab visit. Ta Prohm is known as the tomb raider temple. The banyan trees are still growing over the ruins, and they are still ruins! I liked that they were not restored, unlike Angkor Wat and the temples in Angkor Thom which are mostly restored. Fortunately no crass signs and people politely waited to get photos in front of the famous tomb raider tree. There are several of these trees growing in the temple complex. It lies just outside Angkor Thom, but you need a Tuktuk to get there as this is still kilometres away from the main Angkor Thom temples.

Man V Nature - nature always wins.... Funny how this world works. Man destroys nature. Man builds temple. Man destroys temple. Nature reclaims Temple. In this case tourist destroys experience. Tour buses with loud blaring music, VIP's with sirens blaring and minions clambering around them with umbrellas destroy all sense of place and serenity. If there is one piece of advice I can offer the lovely Cambodian people - claim back your temples. Have more tourist police enforce a no stupidity rule by having people talk quietly and respectfully. Ban the selfie stick. We visited in low season and out all the sacred sites we have visited (and there are quite a few) the ones in Siem Reap tested our patience the most.

Surreal Walk. Walking in the set of Tomb Raider was so surreal, not because it was a movie set but because this was actually a thriving and glorious place years ago. Walking through the halls of Ta Prohm just sent chills down my spine.
Make sure Ta Prohm is in your itinerary. Ta Prohm is definitely special. The way the magnificent trees have taken over the construction is poetic and it definitely is something you cannot miss.
The best place. Very Very special place. there have the good natural. You should not believe whom if you still not go there which see by yourself.

Nature and temple entwined in one - stunning!. Found this part of the Angkor Tom site had a lot of pesky beggars who bug you continuously whilst approaching and leaving this site - which is a shame but something you have to ignore or deal with in whatever you choose.Tomb Raider was filmed here you can understand why when you approach and enter this site. This temple has a very different feel to it than the others on the site. You really do feel like you're in the jungle, with all the massive Sprung trees everywhere reclaiming back their territory. It's truly a sight to see these huge roots wrapping themselves around the temple. It's a wonderful place to roam around. It's extremely hot in here as not my breeze, in fact none! So take plenty of water to drink. My hair was soaked by the time we left, very sticky and hot but worth it.Part of this site - when we entered was under reconstruction which was a shame as it did spoil the beauty and ambience of the site when you first enter but you soon move past this area and soon feel like you are back in time in the jungle glimpsing the past and imagining how majestic this place must of looked back in it's glory days. Fantastic photos to be taken in this site - and one very cheeky funny pic, see my pictures and I bet you smile. Do not miss the temple - it's a sight not to be missed.

Amazing must see Temple. This is one of the other temples that is a must for visitors to Siem Reap. It is my favourite. We have visited this at least 5 times. The magnificence of the trees growing through the ruins is well worth a look.
Excellent day out.. Worth a visit, especially the part used in the filming of Tomb Raider. Lots of little areas to explore and great for those budding Photographers.

Better than Angkor Wat. Just about everybody I have spoken to including myself enjoy Ta Prohm more than Angkor Wat. There are less tourist. The designed of the temple makes it seem that you are only one of a few tourist there. That is because there are a lot of walls and corners so you can't see the entire grounds in any single view and all the tourist. Also, besides the Tomb Raider fame of the place, the temple looks old and ancient. It is not 100% perfect and that it what I expect when I see old temples. Definitely go to this temple.

A must see. In hindsight I would choose to go here above all other temples. It is enchanting! I'm not usually in favour of guides but unlike the other temples, it is difficult to find all the amazing nooks and crannies without one e.g. we never would have understood the echo chamber, which is fascinating. Go early before the heat overwhelms you.

Ta Prohm - our favorite. We nearly didnt go. Reviews on TripAdvisor about the beggers. In the end I really wanted to go - so I talked to my kids ahead of time about politely saying no and moving on. We were instantly besieged when our tuk-tuk pulled up in from of Ta Prohm, but we simply said no and went inside. Once inside - no issues at all. Its spectacular - GO!
overgrowth galore. overgrown similar to Angkor Thom, but a different atmosphere and well worth the visit--probably better when the sun is high we went late and it was a little dark
A different temple. It´s very different from the other temples but at the same time such a wonderful place! Tomb raider was film there!

Truly awe inspiring. I had wanted to see this for years. This topped my list of Wats in Siem Reap. The fact that so much of it is swallowed by maddive trees and do much of it is in ruins gives you a sense of the power during that period.
It's a beauty!. Fantastic! Every Temple had its own story so this one was a beauty to boot. This green temple was best visit before the sun rises and it was awesome!

Just like the postcards . All the temples in the Angkor area have distinct characteristics. Ta Prohm is famous for trees overrunning the temple ruins. These trees are majestic. Unlike other trees, the roots are the highlight than the tops and leaves. Wrapping themselves around and imprisoning the ancient stone blocks, these towering flora create an impression of nature reclaiming what is rightfully hers, displacing the no doubt immense effort taken by man to erect these tributes to their gods a millennia ago. Look out especially for a small stone face looking out from a crevice, almost entire enclosed by roots.

More than movie location. the temple with the trees interwoven within are really impressive. Property had more tourist density than Angkor Wat but getting out into the forested part of the site really let you get away from the crowds.
Part of the Grand Tour. As part of the Grand Tour, we visited Ta Prohm or the Tomb Raider Temple. We saw the temple swallowed by the roots of the big trees.
Simply amazing!. A must visit in Cambodia. Very beautiful place, but a bit too humid, really hard to breathe there. Walk around and enjoy the beauty of the union of nature and human cruft.

Overcrowded/Too much maintenance/Buddha Face tree chopped off. Was a little disappointed when I found out that the infamous Buddha Face tree was being chopped off as the tree's growth was disrupting the nature of the temple ruins. Purposely paid an extra 5dollars for a visit to Ta Phrom bcz the Grand Circuit does not cover here.Still looks magical as compared to other temples in Angkor but it is definitely losing its charm to overceeding and several disrespectful tourists.Please consider a more advanced alternative of restoration of the temple than chopping off something that is significant to the temple. (Considering the high entrance fee = daily traffic flow + country collaboration project)

Temple in the Trees. Like most of the popular temples in Angkor, this is very busy. The main pull here are the trees growing above the ruins and this does make it different from the other temples near by. That said, much of the complex has been cleared and some restoration work is ongoing. Definitely worth seeing.

Interesting Temple for Tomb Raider film. The location is one kilometre east of Angkor Thom and on the southern edge of the East Baray, The temple of Ta Prohm was used as a location in the film Tomb Raider. Although the film took visual liberties with other Angkorian temples, its scenes of Ta Prohm were quite faithful to the temple's actual appearance, and made use of its eerie qualities.In 1186 A.D Jayavarman VII constructed Rajavihara in honour of his family. The temple's main image, representing Prajnaparamita, the personification of wisdom, was modelled on the king's mother.
Tree of Lifr. was so amazed to see old tall trees.... you could even see the huge roots... the old temple ruins are also amazing... must visit this place guys

Overgrowth Bliss. The natural storyline of life played out through the infamous dinosaur carving, the once great building/ civilization, and the land being taken back once again by nature. You're inner child/ explorer will not be disappointed.

Trees and temples. My favorite. The trees are amazing and you feel like you just discovered this temple in the jungle. While a lot of the jungle has been removed enough remains to make it interesting. Other temples have been cleared and do not have the adventure feel of this one.

Wonders of nature. It is really a wonder of nature with the trees growing in the interior of the temple.The formation of the trees on the temple replicas is really amazing and one wonders how nature can make it look really great. It is a good place for photography too.

Spectacular site. The tomb raider feels was great on this popular site. Although there were restoration works in process when we came, the long walk was all worth it and we enjoyed exploring this place. Everyone wants to take a picture with the tree from the Tomb Raider movie so make sure you come around mid day (lunch time) to avoid the crowd. But it can be humid so drink lots of water and protect yourself with scarves, hats or umbrellas.

Rest in peace. I have stayed 5 days at cambodia and spent my all days at angkor temples. That was one the most enjoyable and peaceful times of my life. Everyday hire Bicycle and take my slackline. You can visit magneficient temples - from wat to bayon and ta prhom. - when I feel tired , lay on grass , play with monkey and play with my slackline. The only important thing you should definitely take some water and hat with you. Otherwise sun can be dangerous. But you will leave from cambodia by full of happines , peace and fantastic memories.... :)

Nature taking back. just nature taking back their place. It`s amazing how these estructures stand tall between these enormous trees. Be sure to bring enough water and some snacks, and umbrella it`s a good idea too.

trees growing on top of temples??? really ?? you bet. some of these amazing temples are out of this world,Ta Prohm has all of that and more , beautifull carving and trees growing in the walls of the temple,its easy with a 20 dollar angkor wat ticket .and a tuk tuk for 15 dollars for the day to travel around all these places and your tuk tuk is waiting for you when you finish to take you to the next one ACE

Better than the movie. Movie set stuff BUT real,,,,,this place was totally awesome and the fact it was a movie set fades into significance as you walk thru the site discovering amazing structures invaded by nature

Tomb Raider. It's busy but it's worth it. And tourists will ruin every photo you try to take. It's like another world and it's magical. There are loads of nooks and crannies so you can escape the madness and just enjoy what nature is doing. Take time to chill out and watch.

The reason you must return. Ensure your camera is fully charge and you will spend about an hour minimum to wonder around this temple, definitely tour guide is recommended to understand a little bit more about the architecture.
Tomb Raider . Well...I was speechless..its really big and so beautiful....its was the highlight of our tripp. .i will go back again.,,,,
Trees and temple. This temple is unique. You will see how nature and trees love the temple.Absolutely one of The most wonderful place. Can't wait to visit again !

The trees have quiet, regal character. They will astound you.. Ta Prom outshined all other temples for me because of the grandeur of Mother Nature and her magnificent trees. It's a lesson for all of us in patience.
Ta Prohm, Ruins In The Jungle. Incredible place! We visited twice while we were there. My recommendation is to go early in the morning (around sunrise) before the crowds pick up.
Passage of Time with Nature. How has nature enjoyed the passage of time to entwine with the ruins is excitined to see but also a wonder of how the temples were built a definite must see

My Favorite "Tomb Raider". I just ever saw that in the movie but in reality it is much more wonderful than what i saw ;) . This temple takes a big part of inspiring us to choose Siem reap province for our honeymoon destination.

Amazing . One of the highlights of the day. The way the trees seem to be growing out of the temples is a great sight and bonus it was very quiet the day we went, barely a line up for the famous 'tomb raider' shots.
Recommend going in the afternoon as the sun is in a much better position for awesome photos!
A special place. Amazing, no wonder it's world heretige listed and one of the top tourist attractions in the world. Tomb Raider movie was shot here. Incredible trees erupting from the ruins.
magical. the place is good even if restorations are being done...its magical...the trees still standing tall even if hundreds years already...

Wow. This temple is a must-see. The movie "Tomb Raider" is not.
This temple is included in your $20 USD ticket when you enter the park.

Nature takes over. This is a great temple to see what nature can do if left on her own. The temple is full of tree roots and large trees. There are a lot of people walking this temple and I was about to leave due to the busloads of tourists when a young man approached me and suggested I take a photo from a particular angle. He led me and my camera around the backside of the temple through areas that no other tourists were. He was an unauthorized tour guide, and I was ok with that. He got some money out of me in the end and I got some shots that I wouldn't have taken otherwise. This is definitely a temple to see.
Beautiful. Nature has been allowed to run its course which is part of the beauty. You will walk away questioning "why" hasn't a scientist intervened.
Tomb Raider Temple. Just stunning with trees and roots entwined in the structure, used as a location in the movie Tomb Raider. A must see. Great photo opportunities.
Beautiful by nature. Falling in love with the nature surrounding the temple, absolutely a wonderful place. Can't wait to visit again !

Fantastic!. A lot has been said about this temple, most notably that it was used in Tomb Raider. I say it's more than those things but definitely the best superlatives you could come up with. How those trees engulfed such imposing temple adds up to the mystery. This is a must visit site!

Amazing place. Amazing to see all of the roots and trees that have claimed their place in the temple trough many years !
Very fascinating place, and it's amazing to see so much history almost burried in roots..

Beside Angkor wat this is what people are looking for. It is my favorite temples among all temples in SIem reap. I feel immediately like in the middle of jungle once i step into this temple. The feeling that is indescribable. Besides Angkor Wat, This is what i believe all visitors come to Cambodia for.
Unreal! A must see.. This temple was fascinating. The trees over the years are slowly taking over the temple for a surreal atmosphere. It's like nothing I've seen before.

"Tomb Raider Temple" but much more than that.... This temple has the iconic photo opportunities and is a mixture of light and shadows. It is a photographers challenge, getting the light just right. The history, the dappled light, the moss and lichen smothering the sandstone blocks, all add to the atmosphere in the temple. It is a very popular temple, so there are always a lot of tourists in it.
Nice temple. Great temple. Magnificent trees and roots in on and around the temple. In the forest so a little bit cooler.
The trees are nice. if not for the trees growing in and out of the temples, not a lot to see here - but still very enjoyable. Mostly everything is on one level so not many steps/stairs to navigate.

Atmospheric, don't miss. Not to be missed! If time is tight, drive around Angkor Wat and take the obligatory photo, then proceed to Bayon Temple. After all the steps, then take in Ta Prohm for two very contrasting experiences.
What a Beautiful place. Such an amazing place but recommend getting there as early as you can to beat all the crowds well worth spending some time exploring

My favourite temple . Loved it!! Favourite one in the Angkor complex. Go with a guide. Very spiritual temple. We received blessings with a bracelet to keep evil away, and lit incense. There's also a really cool chamber where you can beat your chest and the sound echoes. Legend has it that the sound of your heart echoes up to the heavens and the gods come down to bring you good luck.
Jungle- Temple. I love how they have managed to retain the temple in the jungle feeling. Big roots of trees seem to let people know that these trees now own the temple and its walls. Magical place.

One of the most scenic temples in the area, iconic tree roots growing throughout the walls.. Our tour guide took us the 'scenic route' to Ta Prohm, in order to enter through the forest and a remote gate. (There are main entry routes but none nearly as interesting.) Best known as a location for the Tomb Raider film, this temple has so much more to offer, including the iconic trees roots growing throughout the temple walls. Definitely worth a visit to wander through and admire the crumbling beauty of the site.

Our favorite temple. This was our family's favorite temple. It's much more 'jungle-y' than the others. Also a bit cooler because of the shade from the trees. Our 7 year old loved it! Lots of things to climb on and explore.

Brings out your inner Lara Croft - the best temple in Siem Reap. This was the temple I was most excited for and it did not disappoint. I only wish we had come here first as it did get quite crowded as the morning went on. The trees that crush the temple and twist around it are phenomenal - I don't understand how they grew there or how the temple still stands but the contrast between the beautiful, crumbling old building and the strength of the living trees is breathtaking. I could have stayed here all day just wandering around.
Surreal experince. Once In a lifetime experince. It looks almost surreal with the trees having taken over the the old temples.

Famous and haunting.. To see nature and detailed stonework melded is spectacular. The famous tree is here so it is one of the most visited temples, but it's vast enough that once doesn't feel cramped like at Bayon (though it's my fave). I appreciate that Ta Prohm has been kept almost intact as it was found with the trees and overgrowth untouched - give a few areas where structural support has been added. This is a photographer's (novice or expert) paradise.

Beautiful. This was one of the most beautiful temples that we visited; although if you want to make the most out of your visit it would be best to try and get there earlier in the day, as by about 4pm people were literally queuing to take a picture with the big tree growing from the roof.

Why does everyone keep raving about Tomb Raider?. These ruins are awesome, Tomb Raider or not. I remember coming here in the early 2000s, shortly after the film was made, and no one kept talking about the damn film. Granted, the film was good. But these ruins are kickass, Tomb Raider or not! There is an overwhelming sense of overgrown jungleness as you see trees whose roots have knocked so much rock down that it needs metal shafts to support it. The big trees appeal to a macro guy like me, but if you like the intricacies of the carvings, there is also a huge amount for you to see. Not an overly lenthgy venue too, and with plenty of shade (trees, see I keep going on about them), you'll find this is one of the less burning experiences if you come in the summer times.

mysterious and most beautiful temple of the Angkor Wat complex. We went to Angkor Wat for two days with our driver. The first day we visited Angkor Tom and afterwards Ta Prohm. Yes, it is touristic, but once you are there, you won't notice it. The temples and nature have made an evolution together. So magical to see!! I am so glad I visited it. But be aware that you have to follow the signs, because the entrance and exit are at two different places.

Dramatic! Tree roots over or destroy temples. It is a must-see spot. Huge tree roots crawl over temple or insert into the temples. Spectacular! The power of destruction is strong. In some cases, temples became debris /ruins. If you pay attention, you will see a face behind a enormous tree. Check out the URL below and you will have a better visual.http://hkindependent-traveller-croatia.blogspot.hk/2014/12/ta-prohm.html

Ta Prohm...must do. Even if you're not a Lara Croft fan you must visit this temple. The jungle has made this temple a home & has made it breathtaking for all to see. We managed to get to the site around noon & found the jungle location a great reprieve from the afternoon heat. Take lots of water & photos.
Must visit. Surely one of the busier places in Angkor area but don't let yourself bring down by the masses going through this nice temple
Tomb Raider Angkorian temples. Trees at Ta Prohm most popular in angkor complex, long walk but satisfy after fantastic views and tall trees around the area

Go early or late. Hands down the BEST and most atmospheric of Angkor temples. Ta Prohm is on another level of its own. Despite going during the busiest part of the day, we still managed to find quiet and surreal corners to just stand and marvel at this ancient ruin. It was so nice we arranged to come back on another day. We went early to avoid the crowds and were rewarded with the best experience of our trip.
Must see before its too late. Awesome with the centuries old humongous trees perching on the architecture.Seeing is believing, but sad with the crumpling of the walls at site.
Truly Amazing. This is amazing when I saw the trees grow on top of the building and there's trees growing on trees. The roots were so strong and it grew out and along the building!!
Tree covered temple. Very beautiful temples covered in trees. Famous from the Tomb Raider movie. Unfortunately, also way too crowded and many people walking around this temple complex all day long.

Loving how nature has taken over these ruins. I am impressed by this place because nature particularly the trees have taken root over the ruins oblivious of the human conflict and character of the surroundings. I can only say to all visitors to never miss this place.
Amazing temple. Ta Prohm is where the nature is so impressive! The best time to visit is during early morning when it's not too crowded.

I got lost. lol.. I went here alone because my driver wasn't allowed to go inside. I lost my way and ended up in circles a few times. Bad sense of direction that day. But I enjoyed every minute of it! The trees, yes, the trees, speaks so much of how historical and magnificent this temple is. Good that they are trying to preserve it. Can't wait to visit Siem Reap again! :)

A temple in the trees (or vice versa). A temple in the trees (or vice versa).By late afternoon, after the visits of "the waves", a chance to taste a little silence with the sound of nature (and some "insensitive humans"...).An ongoing restoration of the most remarkable, exceptional space when we want well asseaoir and imagine what it would be ... the XIIth century reconstruction galleries is really successful (even if it is still running for years), false doors are also a discovery (after you get used; it was my first visit of a Temple in Angkor...), the sculptures are usually well preserved (see some pictures) and I like the lion, a guard who look mean (without perhaps what is asked) ... Made the turn and examine the different perspectives, you'll enjoy it.

Would recommend it but.... An amazing temple half absorbed back into the forrest in places. If our timing had been better this would have unquestionably been 5 stars but we timed this wrong (mid morning) and the site was swarming with large tour groups. I'd recommend this temple early to avoid the clouds to savour this atmospheric wonder.

Ta Prohm. Ta Prohm is one of the favorite temples . It is unique and among the most popular with tourists temples. The temple was truly engulfed by vegetation and it seems, visiting for the first time, Visitors will have the ability to put themselves in the shoes of the first explorers who discovered these remains.and look at what they are facing.. You could see the huge fig tree with gigantic roots drooping down from the roof structure of the temple and continued to spread across the groundTa Prohm was used repeatedly decor in the film Lara Croft Tomb Raider movies and other jungle's movies too Favour the beginning or end of the day to enjoy the place in relative tranquilityCurrently large renovation works are being so impossible to visit some parts

Bewitching and marvelous!. Make sure you visit this place in the early morning and catch the light after sunrise. This is the best time to see and you will meet less tourists. You have to buy a ticket in advance and you will explore a hidden treasure in the jungle where nature conquers back was once belonged to it.

The tree will be removed.. This is my favorite spot in Siem Reap. I just loved revisiting this temple. I heard from the guide that the authority has decided to remove the tree because the temple building wouldn't be able to stand it any more. So go see the temple before the tree is removed.

Like being in the Jungle Book.. The most overgrown of the temples, but also the most restricted as to visitor access. Also by far the busiest we visited - lots of noisy, vocal tourist which spoilt the atmosphere somewhat.

Incredible. Also known as the Tomb Raider temple, this temple is insane. The trees twisting and growing through the ruinous remains is spectacular. It's a good idea to get here before 9am as I think I saw coaches arriving as we were leaving. We had the place almost to ourselves in places.

An absolutely inspiring, breathtaking and humbling jungle experience.. This jungle temple is extensive and entirely unforgettable. If you're visiting in the dry season be sure to pack lots of water and wear comfortable shoes (preferably runners to safely navigate the tricky terrain).

Amazing - only thing missing was Lara Croft. Definitely very unique compared to the other temples in the area. Would recommend to go either early in the morning or at sunset to miss some of the crowds.

Visit to the jungle temple. This is the most rooted and overgrown of them all not far from Angkor Wat. The sad thing is that many of the huge trees with the buttress roots that have grown over the temple are dying. Ever wonder what will happen to the temple and popularity then. The entrance staff that check the tickets are very rude and do not let people reenter the next day. All the admissions 20 to 60 dollars for 1 to 7 day passes go right in the pockets of the corrupt officials and not into the upkeep and restoration work. That is being donated by many different countries. I visited there back in 1995 and again in 2000 and August last year not September.
Amazing! . Such a great experience. I thought there would only be a few trees penetrating the stonework but there are loads with a myriad of photo opportunities! Such a mystical place!!
Worth Seeing. Excellent temple to view with how the Tree's have grown through the structure. Much smaller in size to the other temples and also still under restoration but a must see.

Ancient wonder of the world. A wonder of the ancient world. This place was so captivating with its ancient trees intertwined with ancient walls. The sense of timelessness and reverence quietened the spirit and opened you up to true wonder. I felt privileged to experience this place and its people.
Great. Thank god these temples were discovered... they are fascinating and a must go to place in angkor....
Stunning. I visited many temples in Cambodia and this is by far my favourite one, the trees growing on the temples and the sharp light through holes in the ceiling and doorways make amazing pictures

Exquisite Picturesque Abandon!. Though not possessing the extensive Khmer temple size, scale and scope of Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, this "King's Temple" though is made even more impressive and imposing by the 'battle scene' being witnessed, between Mankind's architectural prowess and Nature's inexorable strength. The incredible picturesque structure (deliberately left natural and largely unspoiled) feature giant silk cotton or as Cambodians call them "Sprung" trees, with their enormous exposed root masses that drape majestically over Ta Prohm's building superstructures. The trees roots seem to pour out from the main trunk like organic molten lava and clutch possessively at Ta Prohm's intricately adorned facades.You get a feeling of nature's relentless strength and majesty all in one, as you gaze in stunned awe at the imposing spectacle that is Ta Prohm.One of the best viewing times is late afternoon (about 4pm) before the attraction closes and when the heavy tourist traffic has subsided. Charge your camera and make sure your memory card has enough space. You will want to remember this.

Go.. Anyone going to Angkor Wat will almost certainly visit Ta Prohm as well. It's part-and-parcel with the experience. We had a wonderful time there, and the photo ops are fantastic. They have done some restoration to this temple, while choosing to leave some of the more imposing trees that have taken over.
BEST of the lot. Our 3rd stop on our day tour and was definitely the best. Lovely and weird sights. The roots growing on buildings - just out of this world.
A MUST SEE. We loved this... so eerie but special at the same time.... the main tree is cordoned off now but didnt take away from the experience
An amazing temple. This is an amazing temple, best suited for photography lovers. There are many trees around the temples. One should go there early morning to enjoy the nature.
Very Special. There is something very special about Ta Prohm. There are lots of ruined buildings but you still get a feel of what Ta Prohm used to be. Magnificent!
Great photo opportunity. Loved this temple, amazing to see the tree growing over the building but a pity because of the damage it is causing. Makes for great photos

Go early to avoid the crowds and this temple will likely be empty. You will have it all to yourself.. This is the Tomb Raider screening location. While it might be cheesy to some it was a truly beautiful place. It was really peaceful when you go there in the morning once they open and quite. It was almost magical like it was portrayed in the movie.
Fusion. Love the way nature both takes back and helps to preserve at the same time. Some great restoration work in progress.

Tomb raiding. Its a pity half of these buildings have fallen down but they are surrounded by trees. Some even have trees growing on the roof! I felt like lara croft minus the lips.
Awesome photos and a magical place.
The way the tree roots cover the buildings is like nothing you can see anywhere else.

The jungle temple. This is a great temple for photographers. Try and get there early to avoid the crowds and you will have some fantastic opportunities to photograph it in dappled light from the tres.

This temple is amazing. Of all the temples int he area, this was our favorite. The trees are growing on, in and around the ancient structure. Amazing photo ops. If you are a photographer this is a must shoot.

My favorite. Our family rated this temple at the top of the list with Bayon. It is simply stunning. I do not have a trick to be able to see it quietly. It was very packed when we were there... You just have to be patient and manouevre around the big tourist groups. If only the could behave and admire...
COOL!. THIS IS SO AWESOME!! :) Imagine a tree merged with a temple.. What a beautiful site to see. I really want to come back here.

Don't skip it in Angkor Temple visits!. Maybe the most impressive among the Angkor Temples... You can see how nature rules within time! If you have only one day for temple visits go for Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm...

Early Birds. As early as 6.a.m., we left our hotel and had a ride with a tuk-tuk which took us to the jungle-covered temple of Ta Phrom. It was extremely fascinating to see how powerful nature can be. Within centuries, the temple had been overtaken by the jungle with its majestic trees. It makes you feel small ....

one of the three temples to visit. Travelling w 3 young kids aged 3,6&7, we knew we had no chance of visiting more than 3 and w had read that visiting the following 3 temples was a good alternative: Angkor Wat, Ta Promh and Angkor Thom. The tuk tuk leaves you some 10-15 minutes walk away from the temple itself (depending on how tired the little feet are) .... It's a dusty path and not easy to drag kids along but the first sight of the temple with this huge banian like tree growing almost on top of it and here and there tree roots wrapped around the temple took our breath away. We took some funky and funny shots w the kids monkeying around the temple and its roots!! Add on this the fact that Angelina Jolie's Lara Croft was filmed there and you got yourself a sure winner!!
A Temple being renovated under Indian Archaeology. Another Temple full of telling you about Hinduism prevailed in that ear in Cambodia, another attraction a huge tree

Stunning!. This temple is like it jumped out from a fairytale. Left for centuries untouched, mother nature tried to dominate and believe me she has done a very good job. The restoration team decided to leave the larger part of the temple as it was found in the jungle so you have the chance to admire the temple almost untouched.It used to be a monastery and university in the 12th and 13th century and it was built a few years later than Angor Wat.Personally I liked it more than Angor Wat temple.

Tomb raider!. Inspired from the movie tomb raider.. beautiful place.. but it can be overcrowded.. If you want a guide, please get a proper guide from your hotel or the ones with uniform. There are a few local men trying to hit on lone travellers and guide them along the temple and asking for tips.

Indiana Jones I presume. If you want to see where Angelina Jolie emerged in the Raiders films, heres the place. Plenty to see, imagine the beauty of when it was built (you can see where the gems were placed in the ceilings), imagine when it was rediscovered. See with disbelief the restorations that were done and completely botched by well meaning foreign governments
Great!. Another awesome temple in Siem Reap. Not as crowded as Angkor Wat. Worth a visit. Also the location of where they shot Tomb Raider.
What more can I say?????. You enter a different world, you can see the ongoing fight between man-made buildings and mother nature. The architectual details are over the top! ABOLUTELY STUNNING!!!!!!!

My favorite temple. I have to Angkor temples several times, I am interested in Ta Prohm, that is one of the Buddist temples built in 12th century, I love it's natural state of ruins that partly collapsed overgrown by the giant figure trees and Banian trees. It is good to see this temple at about 6or 7 am before the crowd.
Best temple!. We used to see the photos before coming to Cambodia and now we really admire the people who made it and the nature added more value on it. It looks amzing. Have to see!!

Ta Prohm - just beautiful. A great temple to visit in the heat of the day as the trees give great shade.
The temple is mainly in ruins and the beauty is in the way nature has entwined with it.

Tomb raider template.... ...or at least that's what I was told. Nevertheless, it was an oddly beautiful place. Massive trees growning on the top of buildings, lots of little hidden rooms, beautifully carved stones make this worth the visit. It was being restored when I visited. I would suggest visiting Bantey srei and Bayon temple as part of your visit. Also as there is soooo much to see in Ankor it would be best to get a 3 day pass, you won't regret it.
The Lorax loves Ta Prohm. This place is worth visiting just for the incredible trees! Temple itself not as interesting as some of the others

Tomb Raider temple... You have to see!. Whatever you do in Siem Reap please try and spare an hour at Ta Prohm. Made famous by the tomb raider movie it is much quieter than Angkor Wat and Byon but so worth seeing. It's peaceful setting with the trees both destroying and holding together the temples needs to be seen to be truly appreciated. Don't rush and don't miss this.one out on your visit.

TOMB RAIDER! MUST VISIT!!!!. i love how the tree into the temple, recommend to bring comfort shoes because their alot of walking in these temples. bring sunscreen wear a hat, because it can get very hot in temples.

Gob smackingly awesome. Felt lost in another ancient world - this temple by far was the best one we visited . I would definitely recommend never ever to miss this. It gets hot and humid by the end of all this temple hopping carry plenty of water and have your tuk tuk driver on call just in case you faint from heat exhaustion - do not visit temples in the afternoon try for early morning visits when it is less hot.Definitely wear a hat !

Otherwordly. The massive strangler figs trees among the ruins provide the ruins with an other-worldy feel. Visit this place shortly after sunrise or near evening to leverage on the shadows and silhouettes for photographs.
Tomb Raider!. Never have I seen vegetation being so incorporated into the building of a historical place such as this! This is where Tomb Raider was filmed which unites the past with the present!

Another must see on the Anglor Tour. Allong with the incredible beauty of the architecture, it was amazing to see how nature had taken over this incredible space and added to the mythical character of the space.

Not my favorite of the temples I visited, still an amazing thing to see! Tomb Raider is the claim to fame. While Tomb Raider may bring most to Ta Prohm, the magestic nature surely keeps you winding and wandering (frequently getting lost) through this Temple. It's currently under renovation/repair. As a result it really does appear to be in shambles, and many parts are closed off. This was the last stop of the day for me on my multi temple sightseeing tour, I'm glad that I went!Be mindful, I found the vendors and children selling things to be very aggressive here, follow you around, get in your way if you say no.

must do. try it early to benefit from the light
the trees are indeed super spectaculier
take your time!
nature and history coming together

Those trees. For me this is atop of my favourite list. I felt the most on this one of how this could have been a lost city prior to discovery. The mingle of jungle and temple is amazing and honestly, what awed me the most about Angkor was the impressive vegetation. And in this temple you really get the feel of how vegetation and massive trees can live around our own constructions. The temple is beautiful in itself as well and the restoration work has been amazing. But those trees. Wow. Like every other major temple we visited, we were there by 6 am and had the complex almost to ourselves. My bet is, if you go 5 to seven days, check one big temple per early morning and leave the time from 9 am to 11 am to visit a few other small ones, than just relax at the hotel. This is what we did and it worked amazing.
Must see. Its a must see in this area for sure.....worth the money....so just go there and have a look you will like it

A bit meh. Went here as part of a day tour. After visiting Beng Mealea and other temples with lots of trees growing out of ruins, Ta Prohm did not have the wow factor I was expecting, but our son loved the association with Tomb Raider!
Awsome place.. Ta Prohm met all our expectations, it is not a huge site but you really have to take your time. There are so many nooks and doorways to discover. It really has the "WOW" factor.
A surprise. Now best known for its Angelina Jolie movie connection, this temple merits spending more time than I did.

Must see temple. The environment inside the temple is very different. There are many big trees are "eating" the temple's wall, which make us feel very old and pitty, why this beatiful temple has to be abandoned for hundreds of years.Not so many visitors compares to Angkor Wat.

Ta Prohm (Tomb Raider temple). Lots of old trees to see with all the long roots lying all over. Went with a good guide who showed us lots of good spots for photography, like inside the huge tree trunks etc. It is interesting to see how the trees were grown naturally, intertwined with the building.

Awesome!. It was one of the major temples of King jayavarman VII. In fact it was a temple-monastery.Today it is known for the trees that have grown intertwined among the ruins, showing us, how most of Angkor looked on its discovery in the 19th century! This was an inspires decision and today Ta Prohm inspires a lot of authors and filmmakers! ( Lara Croft - Tomb Raider)...Actually my favorite place in Angkor Wat. A must see!
The Best. This is Tomb Raider territory, I loved it, this is where you see all the trees with roots crawling over temple remains - has to be seen to be believed - loved it.
Amazing!!. This is probably the most amazing site in this area as it makes one realise just how the jungle takes over after man has gone. Some of the sights are quite unbelievable!!

My favorite. I used to see this temple only in game Tomb raider. It was so beautiful in the game, but believe me it is much more beautiful to see in reality. Feel like i was in the middle of jungle when i step into this temple.

A dream. I always dream to go there!!!!! And i did !!! What are you waiting for????
Is like staying in a film! You cant loose

Makes you feel like a tomb raider or someone very tiny!. Some of the places that you need to walk around without support definitely make you feel like an action hero! Luckily, they aren't oo difficult or scary!
The trees there are huuuuge! Take a few pictures standing next to them and ask your friends to spot you in them!!

Temple and the giant trees. Unbelievable and amazing. The way the trees have grown around and out of the temple is something unbelievable.It's good that the world's archeologists assist with this World Heritage Site.One of the distinguishing characteristics of this site is the numerous strangler figs and Banyan trees whose roots complete cover some of the structures. Many can't be removed because the roots actually support some of the stonework.

Worth a visit. Amazing photos but not much to see inside (the Tombraider films use the outside but not the inside of this building). But definitely worth taking in as part of your temple tour because it isn't far.

Nature and Ruins live in Harmony. The atmospheric combination of trees growing out of the ruins makes this an enchanted place. You will walk along wooden gangways as many of the corridors are impassable, filled with piles, of delicately carved stone blocks dislodged by the roots of trees. There are plenty of photo opportunities, but be prepared to queue if you want to take a snap of the famous Laura Croft (Tomb Raider) tree.
Amazing!. Don't miss this temple! It is not very big so doesn't take too long to walk around, but it is amazing how the trees have grown around and through the temples. Absolutely spectacular!

Worth a visit if you are in the Angkor park. This temples is worth a visit if you are already in the Angkor recreational park area. It was beautiful and not as crowded as Angkor Wat. Take a guide for more insight that you would get otherwise.

Reclaimed from the Jungle. Ta Prohm is another of those immense temple and monastery complexes from the twelfth century that was abandoned and completely overgrown by jungle. Partly reclaimed in the 19th century by French archeologists, the site is completely uncovered today. One of the distinguishing characteristics of this site is the numerous strangler figs and Banyan trees whose roots complete cover some of the structures. Many can't be removed because the roots actually support some of the stonework. It's all part of the enchantment of this ruin.You've all seen the famous doorway from Lara Croft: Tomb Raider? Well, you'll probably get a better look at it if you screen the movie. On site, hundreds of tourists attempt to get a good shot of themselves in front of the doorway. Fat chance at taking a photo without people in it. Giggle.On the way from the car park to Ta Prohm there is a fine group of musicians along the path. They are victims of land mines left from the recent troubles. They sell CD's of their music. I'm still kicking myself for not taking a minute to support them. Their music was pretty wonderful.It's evident that the restoration here is ongoing. Walls are being re-assembled and the Hall of the Dancers is under restoration at this time. It's good that the world's archeologists assist with this World Heritage Site. Enjoy.
temples and trees. The way the trees have grown around and out of the temple is something to behold. Lots to see and the path way well marked out one not to be missed.
My favorite.... What an amazing place... just simply my perfect temple... Perfect in everyway. Loved this place e and the views. Hope it last..... (it is hot... humid and full of turists)

Enchanting Ruin. If ruins can enchant you then this is the place! Its a simple wonder how this totally ruined structure is still standing and giuves you an eerie feelings when you enter the temple. Huge trees in all shpes and sructures have totally engulfed the temple but it has also enhanced the ebauty of the whole place! The enormously huge trees have got themselves totally synthesised with the twmple structure to make an wonderful effect in totality. Its simply charming and enchanting.Its like a poetry with nature and man made thing embracing each other in total harmony.
Very cool place.. Amazing trees. The roots have completely taken over this temple. Was a great place to wonder around for 20-30 and see. Make sure you do it.
Temple serenity. Loved it and we were so pleased to have chosen this one to view. The trees and root formations, the cool setting and serenity. Would highly recommend.

A walk thru. All you do here is walk right thru to get to Anglo Wat. It was a long 30 minutes walk though. We started at Bayonne Temple, then Angkor Thom, ThenTa Prohm, Then Angkor Wat. Others started the tour in reverse.

Tomb Raiders. Amazing! walking around all the tree roots grew out , through the foundations, roofs and imagined Angelina Jolie is lurking around the temples...so adventurous...love every minute of it!
Amazing. Great day. Never thought trees could grow on rocks.when we were there they were doing a lot of renivations to the rocks. Great to see.

Love it¡¡. Have you seen Jungle book (walt disney)? If you saw it you can understand where WD take the inspiration... It´s incredible to see the conjunction between nature and the architecture, if you love movie films.. some scenes of Tomb Raider was recorded here so you can take a look, inside of this beautiful and amazing temple you can feel a lot of energy... make a big breath¡¡

Just Grand. We beat the crowd as it happened that lunched earlier that day and arrived at Ta Prohm at noon when everybody was leaving for lunch. It just had a fantastic atmosphere. It was so big that we could easily avoid the crowd when they were back after lunchtime. I would not add more about other aspects that some reviewers already provided and that I agree with, like better with a guide - but to my opinion not too talkative a guide ;-) because this place is inspiring and invites to enjoy the calmness. Also agree it is a testimony of the forces of nature. The beauty and grandeur just left me speechless.

Busy but beautiful . Because of the mooie with Lara Croft, this temple is being visited by many tourists . Don't let that withhold you from going to see the trees growing info the temple. It is beautiful

Stunning!. We visited this temple in early morning before all the crowds got there and all I can say is that it is simply stunning! Situated in a jungle area, the trees have taken over in some areas and are growing over and through the temple walls. It is a photographers dream and round every corner you will find another photographic opportunity.There is some work being done to rebuild parts of the temple, but this does not detract from its beauty and serenity.

Tomb Raider. After renovation in 2010/2011, wonderful walkways throughout the temple to see the many trees coming up through -- take your time to look around, and there are many amazing sights to see.
Errie how the tree's entwine within the structures. Interesting to see how the trees are actually holding most of the structure together. Again another fascinating temple as a must see.
Tomb Raider bring fame to this place. This is the place where Angelina Jolie shoot the film Tomb Raider. It was outside Angkor Thom. All the trees you found there are huge.

Zen and the art of temples!. Immerse yourself in history (and a film set)! One of my favourite temples. Get there early in the day to avoid the tourist throng, and spend some time being idle and listening to the jungle around you. One of the most peaceful places I have ever been to. Stick to the paths and don't be tempted to cross over the roped area for your next FaceBook profile photo like some people do.
Worth the trip and does not take long. Worth the trip, it does not take long to see this sight, but it is amazing if you take your time to really look at this site

Step Back In Time. You really feel like you've stepped back in time... Or time has stood still. The trees reclaiming the land give and understanding of how old this temple is. Lots of tourists but I still managed to get some cool photos with no one in them. A must see.

Ta Prohm, a msut to visit while in Siem Reap !. Impossible to go to Siem reap and not to go to Ta Prohm...not only because it was the site where Angelina Jolie was Lara Croft in tomb raider but because it is really impressive to see this temple and how the forest has invaded it!

The famous one. Famous for its film appearance. Though kind of think it worth more than just that. Gives a good taste of what the MANY temples in Cambodia look like when the jungle gets a hold of them. YEs there is renovation work going on but that's so it doesn't fall down!

Where is Angie?. The temple was awesome but I thought Angelina Jolie was supposed to be there.We enjoyed searching through the remaining carvings for prophecies about her, but were unable to find them.If you go in the morning, you will miss the Angkor Wat sunrise, but also miss the crowds. Ta Prohm is quite peaceful at sunrise, watching the rays sneak through the canopy. This is an excellent time to make an offering to Angie and pray for an appearance.

Super cool. Another must see temple in Angkor. Best time is afternoon but it does get overrun with tourists at that time so if you want to avoid that perhaps visit for sunrise or sunset when people crowd the more popular spots
getting overrated. The growing artificial structures erected to help preserve Ta Prohm from the ever growing tourists are spoiling Ta Prohm's unique look of huge trees wrapping around the temple.
Amazing!. This was the third temple we visited. The way that nature perseveres is incredible. Massive trees have grown out of the ruins creating amazing sights. Well worth a visit
Tomb raider experience. The invasion of trees is amazing. You are guided without much possibilities to wander away from the path. If you want less crowd and more liberty visit Banteay Krey.
Great temple.. Our favourite temple by far. Very atmospheric and you get the feeling of being an explorer discovering the temple in the jungle.

Stunning temple absolutely marvelous.. Ta Prohm is a huge temple that is amazing. Every place in the temple is photogenic and marvelous. The different types of trees growing on doors and pathways make for an excellent sight. A certain MUST SEE not to be missed indeed.
Must seen.. TO crowded with Chinese people. The made some picture moments where you can make te famous pictures. Go for the highlights try to avoid the Chinese crowd...

Very interesting architecture and history. Large tempel area with leads of tourists, but very well worth à visit, more meaningfull with a good guide than without. Very hot, bring sunscreen, lost of water and good walking shoes
Exquisite temple!. A beautiful temple with unique characteristics thanks to the natural environment. Overgrown with moss, trees and their associated elaborate root systems this temple is a must see.

Mesmerizing!!!. Simply mesmerizing. The place looked like it is covered by a magical spell. The only problem is some of the temples are starting to collapse because of the huge roots. Restoration in some affected areas are in progress. I hope they could still preserve this beauty.

Nature versus history. Fascinating perspective, where nature has 'invaded' the temple and effectively recovered the walls as distinct from seeing wars and other battles cause destruction. Nature rules!

If there is only one to see - it's this one.. If you are not into templing - this is the one to see. Together with the Angor Wat you can do it in 3 hours. Have a breakfast go there on tuk tuk, enjoy the two temples (not more) get back to the Haven restaurant for lunch and enjoy the rest of the day in a pool! :).

Well worth the walk to get into Ta Prohm. They were doing a lot of renovation while we were here, so many areas were closed off - but still - you have to see the trees growing through the building - it truly is amazing.

Batteries of both cameras finished.!. .... although I got there at the 100% mark for both of them! We left this temple last to visit during our stay in Angkor. It was a sweet conclusion of our trip!. They are doing a great job preserving the place, while at the same time not altering the effect of nature on the temple. Where 'nature', change for jungle!

Not to be missed.. Everything in this area is fascinating. I was just amazed by it all. Every time you turned around it was a wow moment. We came across an old man giving blessing here. A small donation, you get blessed and string tied around your wrist and you take a photo, what more can you ask for, just another great experience.
Amazing Temple. Such a lovely temple and it is sad that over a periodof time trees have grown over the temple endangering the temple. Glad the government and Unesco are taking careof the temples.

Adored this place. This is one of the best in my opinion. There is something very cool about the trees growing through the walls and buildings that makes one realise that these places were once covered by the jungle. So glad that it was rediscovered.
A surreal experience . Be a tomb raider in a city forgotten by time and nature. See it before the jungle swallows it. Walking through the jungle ruins was surreal.

Good but not great. We were looking forward to seeing this temple the most due to the jungle that has grown on and around it. We were disappointed however and found that it was worth the trip up to Beng Melea which was far prettier and you are allowed to climb on and around the temple which made it much more of an adventure.

Gotta Getta Glimpse. The management at my hotel suggested that I start with this temple very early in the morning, and I'm glad I did. So, I pass the recommendation on to you. Get here as early as possible--the park and temples open at 5 a.m.--and be undisturbed except for the ambient noises of a jungle waking up. This temple is second only to Preah Khan and perhaps Banteay Srei.
Amousing. You can't understand how the powerfull its the nature untill you visit this. So elegant! You can think that the temple its better with the treed around it.
Trees for days... Very surreal to see these kind of places! Way cool to see the trees and how things grew around and how they are still standing today. Check it out!

Amazing. A must see while in Siem Reap. There are some even more amazing sites to see if you are willing to travel to NW of Cambodia along the Thai border. While in Siem Reap this is certainly worth a visit

The tomb raider temple. That's how Ta Prohm was introduced to us So many giant trees, its fascinating.It's a beautiful complex, but a lot of it was under restoration when we went, so its a good idea to check beforehand and go. It's an amazing place but the constant sound of building equipment acts as spoilsport.

Where time stands still. This temple is pure heaven. Amazing trees climb over the buildings and walls. It has been largely left as it was when rediscovered. It has a peace I find difficult to describe even with all the visitors. I have been twice and will go back again soon. Don't just see the main Angkor Wat site, please please visit this and the other small temples as well. The effort will be well rewarded with wonderful memories

One of the big 3 while visiting Siem Reap. Recently visited this amazing site which consisted of a temple called ta prohm. It is a typical flat Khmer temple as opposed to a temple pyramid style. The trees growing out of the ruins are perhaps the most distinctive feature of this site, the forest looks as if it is reclaiming the land it was built on. Fans of Angelina Jolie will recognize the site for her part in Tomb Raider.A must see and very easy to walk around and get close to the features. Great photo opportunities. Bring your own food,water,insect repellant and camera. (If you find this review helpful please tick the box tks )

Stunning!. Much smaller than Angkor Wat but more impact as you can walk through the ruins and see the amazing trees whose roots have emerged from the stones over the centuries. Being smaller, it is easier to completely cover and the photo opportunities are around every corner. It is also not so popular as the big temples and it is even better if you can get there early in the morning. So, Angkor for the dawn then TaProhm for the intimate walk-around.

Stunning. Our tour to Angkor Wat did not originally include Ta Promh as it is not of such great archeaological significance as the other Angkor temples, however it is not to be missed purely for the mind blowing tree formations (If you have seen the film Tomb Raider you may have seen this before). It is true that as a temple it is nothing special but for the unique phenomenon of the trees that have grown on top of the temples it is not to be missed. It is one of the wierdest and most beautiful things I have ever seen. Also note the carving of what looks like a stegosaurus in one area - how could the people at that time have envisaged such a thing? Quite fascinating.

Knitted Nanna's of Templedom. Walking amidst these fully owned and redeemed temples, where the trees and forests have relinquished enough of the forgotten realms yet still are sentinels of life here in Siem Reap, you can become beguiled by the cool air within and around these shrines, when the cloaking humidity above seeks to own you. Grandma Temple is Divine!

Temple of Trees. As you enter the gate a nice road leads upto temple. On the left side you can find some souvenir shops and a local band playing nice tune .When the other prominent temples had height Ta Prohm doesn`t . Its a huge ruins . Original shape of the temple no more exist ,everywhere stone blocks ,some of the corridor has been blocked for safety .Center of attraction here is to see huge trees grown in the ruins.

Better in the late afternoon. An amazing temple but usually so overrun with tourists that it is very difficult to enjoy. It may be better to visit late in the afternoon when the bulk of travelers have gone home for the day. I went several years ago so was able to really appreciate it but on our last visit there was a lot of restoration work going on so it was not easy to have a good look around.

Loved these ancient ruins.. These temples are definitely worth the visit. The details and carvings are not as intricate as in the other temples as it was not as historically important, but it is a wonderful experience to imagine them emerging from the jungle centuries ago. Now being engulfed by the jungle these temples are a sight to see.

Fantastic. There were ongoing renovation works for the temple but still very attractive place. Also known as 'Tomb Raider Temple' and very popular spot for tourist. Best to visit in early morning before many crowds in. The trees are just amazing and simply reflect the rise and fall of a Khmer Kingdom.
Quick stop that shouldn't be missed. Admire the beauty created when nature and civilization collide to form breathtaking sights. A short visit, but well worth it

Just Facinating!. On a once in a lifetime trip to Cambodia this temple is a must see! I particularly love the massive trees and roots everywhere!They are doing a massive restore as there is a lots of destruction from a previous earthquake long ago!A tour guide makes visiting here even more special as they explain details and history of each site!

Must Do. It's incredible to see how the ancient ruins are being enveloped by growing trees. It takes only about half an hour to visit. The restoration work is being done by India and Cambodia. It's a beautiful place to be.

Best times to go / Escape the crowds / Best Angkor guide. Amazing temple to explore! Defiantly my favourite of the Angkor temples. Best to do straight after a sunrise explore of Angkor Watt. 9 - 10am is best to avoid the crowds, as Ta Prohm one of the must see temples. It really begins to get busy around 11 am. Worth going around the sides of the temple as everyone just goes straight though the middle, the sides are deserted. We sat down amongst the ancient ruins for 10 minutes, incredibly peaceful, breezy and cool compared to the hot touristy hustle and bustle of the middle section. If you've bought a packed lunch it would be a lovely place to sit and reflect.Need a guide? I know THE guy! Charmony - ph 092820529 amazing knowledge of Khmer and temple history as well as Buddhist and Hindu mythology. He will take you places you'd never find by yourself (I tried without a guide the day before I hired him, the difference is night and day!) Kind and friendly with Good English and also he's a great photographer that knows where and how to take the best photos (even with professional cameras)!

Amazing but infested by tourists!. The temple itself is impressing and definitely a must-see but our experience was a little bit wasted by all the buses of chinese tourists arriving at the same time. There are so many other great temples to see far away from the crowd!

amazing to see mans creations and nature in conflict and harmony. This gives an insight into what Angkor Wat may have looked like on discovery. over run with trees and roots but that gives it a spooky charm. We saw it after a heavy rain storm which somehow made it feel more appropriate.

Wow. Better known as the "tomb raider temple" the forest has taken over some of the temple structures given it a truly ancient and undiscovered feel. Amazing site and not to be missed if you're in the area.

Enchanting. It's my personal favorite, better than Angkor Wat. The ruined temple was surrounded by gigantic trees that leves me in awe. I went their on the last week of July, apparently their rainy season, but I personally loved the timing as the lush greens and moss added charm to it's captivating beauty. Plus it was just drizzling intermitently, not bad at all compared to the scorching heat! It even added value to me when I learned about its history. The temple was abandoned when Siem lost against the Thais, at least that's what I heard from evesdropping fron the other group's tour guide .

Busy. Better temples in Beng Melea. this is the famous 'Tomb Raider' temple and being so popular it was inundated with tourists wanting to get their pictures here. There are similar temples outlying Angkor which are more spectacular these this one and completely deserted.

Fantasy temple... this was a great visit. The trees have intertwined with the temple and look amazing. Many little hiding places and good photo opportunities, aside from the usual. Saw a face (carving) wrapped up in tree roots. Doing great job of restoration (though clearly this will take some time). Nice that there was before and after pics so u could see what was being done. Beautiful and kind of magic looking.

Wonderful, mesmerising Ta Prohm. Ta Prohm took me by surprise. I was sort of ready for the wonder of Angkor Wat, but hadn't really heard much about it's smaller "partner" before. Despite the condition of the temple it is an amazing place. The trees that have taken over the ruins need to be seen to be believed and in some cases will leave you in awe. When we went there was a lot less footfall than Angkor Wat and it gave us time to take in the place. Maybe this is why I enjoyed it more than Angkor Wat as we could spend some quality time browsing at our leisure.This is a must see attraction.
Best temple yet!. Tombraider was filmed here as every knows! Was my fave temple as it was quieter and the roots on the temples are amazing. hard to believe the temples haven't collapsed!

Most memorable temple near Siem Reap. The sheer charisma of the place is astounding! As you walk in your realize you have arrived somewhere special - but try to avoid the busy times (check the carpark for coaches!)
Ta Prohm. This is where Lara Croft Tombraider was filmed. The vegetation growing in, around and on the temples is amazing. Some great photo opportunities to be had.
Awesome. It was such an amazing temple, it seemed very spiritual and I would definitely recommend it to anybody visiting Siem Reap.

Go Early!. This is of course, the "Tomb Raider" temple. It is certainly a sight to behold, the unique ways the trees have grown everywhere is something I have not seen before, it is incredibly interesting. My best advice is to go early. While everyone is lining up to get into Angkor Wat in the early morning, we went the opposite way, going to Ta Prohm first, and Angkor Wat last. We got here at about 8AM and finished about 9AM, on advice of our tour guide provided by the Sofitel, and literally had the place all to ourselves. No crowds whatsoever, allowing us to get the best pictures and take our time looking at everything. So get there early for your best chances to have an ideal experience. Out of interest check out the "dinosaur" carving towards the back wall of the temple, something we found interesting and that not many others we spoke to had heard of.

Nature takes Charge. Went to see this as the last stop on our temple tour. While the entire structure is currently under construction there were still some beautiful moments and photo opportunities. At this temple, the ruins are indicative of the true strength if nature as trees are sprouting right through the building in several areas of the temple. It was truly beautiful. Within the area of the temple, several markets were set up and vendors would play music as you walked through the paths. While they were looking for money, it did make the progression enjoyable.

Witness nature taking over!!! Ethereal!!. We had hired a mountain bike to go around the angkor temple complex! The ride was nothing short of awesome and as we approached Ta Phrom, I could really see what the fuss was all about. Had been there after 2 days of temple touring and quite frankly, I wanted to give it a miss. How foolish it would have been of me! You would not want to miss it for the world. Realised how puny we are in front of the nature and was awestruck by the humongous trees (Spung, if i am not wrong). Seemed to me that an endless conflict between human enroachment and the nature's fight back for its territory has been going on for years. Instilled some hope back into me. Trees are here to stay! Pls dont miss it....The best temple in all of Siem reap in my view, where the deity is Mother Nature herself. Sad to know that people visit the place to see where the Lara croft movie starring angelina jolie was shot. Nature invictus!!!

Incredible interplay of nature and stone. Definitely worth a visit. Other than being known as the "Tomb Raider" temple, these ruins are uniquely spectacular for its interplay with nature. All around the temple, massive stone walls intertwine with gnarled, monstrous trees in a fantastical and awe-inspiring way. Definitely put this on your list. A good way to see this is to hire a guide for a day to drive you around - it's relatively affordable, too.

The most genuine temple as discovered by the explorers. When you think Angkor and you you this picture, just bear in mind that Ta Prohm is the last temple in the Angkor Tom complex that is still shown with the trees who grew in it since the temple complex was abandoned at the end of the Khmer dynasty. A must see.

This is what we come here for........ Just as we envisaged these ruins would look like... Indiana Jones stuff!!.. Mystic and ancient; all the other shrines pale into insignificance, when compared to this experience. Your camera will get a real workout here , as it is impossible to stop clicking away, cause every corner of the place reveals new surprises. If you miss this one on your visit to Siem Reap, you will regret it.

Ever wondered where Giger got the inspiration for Alien from??. Of all the temples in the Angkor zone this is the most gob-smacking. Ancient trees intertwined with rock walls and stone temples that seem to rise from the jungle everywhere. When it offers a long or a short tour option, take the long. You will not regret.

Top Temple. By far the most popular temple other than Angkor Wat namely because the film Tomb Raider was mostly shot here and also features the carving of a stegosaurus made famous on the History Channel series Ancient Aliens. Still, not everyone notices the dinosaur unless you're looking for it so keep your eye out when you walk into the courtyard where the 'famous tree' grows. It is on the pillar on the opposite side. The old massive trees here are amazing so remember to say 'hi' to them..

amazing; can't-miss on a visit to Siem Reap. This is one of the three main sites around Siem Reap, along with Angkor Wat and Bayon, which is essentially part of the larger Angkor Thom complex. Many of the other temples are worth a visit too but one should budget time to allow for spending a little more at these three places. I wouldn't even consider spending less than two days on all the temples in the general area, and three days is actually more than a lot of people would need, although for others a week would be better. All of the temples have that lost-in-the-jungle feel to them but none in the same way this one does; the jungle really grew back around it, as is obvious in the pictures. Angkor Wat is huge, so it takes time just to walk around it, and Bayon is small, so it goes fast, with Ta Prohm in the middle.

Awe inspiring !!. Amazing to see a combination of manmade history taken over by the nature. It is awesome and you never the forces of nature after seeing this. Your own life will seem insignificant when you see this in totality
scammers. scammers here too. refuse when a local tries to talk history. they will show you a piece of paper afterwards that you need to pay them $20 - $100 for the "tour" that they gave.
A must see.. Another must see of the Angkor Complex. Amazing seeing the trees intertwined into the Temple - makes for fun photos and fun exploring.

Tomb raider!. Simply a magical place. Almost spirituel. It's quite heavy on tourists now a days, so get here early. I wouldn't say that exactly this place is the most amazing place, but Ta Prohm must be experienced as part of visiting Angkor.
I just want to go back. Would love to go back here one day this place is far too amazing again too many people for my liking but you get that with a place as beautiful as this

Amazing Trees. Loved this one in particular! The trees are just incredible! Definately worth going, the walk down to this temple has some painting stalls. Just keep walking if you wish not to buy anything, because as soon as they catch up your eye, you've just brought a painting,

Really cool, but crowded. If you think you're getting off the beaten track by coming here, I would disagree. This temple is almost as crowded as Angkor Wat, though much smaller. It's astonishing to see nature reclaim such a massive and beautiful landmark, but it can be a struggle to appreciate the temple with any sense of serenity.

Takes your breath away. An amazing accumulation of temples with trees growning right out of and through the temples. A must see, worth enduring the heat and the walking to view these ancient ruins...a la Tomb Raider.

Soon will be better. I know this temple as tomb raider. I cherish this temple's atmosphere the most. However, there are many places in this temple renovated. It gonna be the most beautiful temple among all after renovating.

Will not disappoint. When you visit Cambodia you know you are going to see a lot of temples. What is unique about Ta Prohm is nature has taken hold of the walls of the temple and there is no stopping it. Therein lies the beauty and power of nature. Plenty of opportunity for unique photography.

Nature fights back. The atmosphere at Ta Prohm is extraordinary - I have never seen anything like it before. The temples are in ruins and the trees have just grown up through, on and around the stone walls. We met a local who showed us a place where a little buddha is peeping out between the tree roots. A very special place. We bought 'First they Killed my Father' by Loung Ung there. Heartbreaking story

Beautifully dilapidated example of nature intertwined with mankind.... Absolutely moving experience, I found Ta Prohm one of the more interesting temples. In particular, the very well known tree roots were spectacular! There was a huge queue to take a photo in the area at the time, due to a tour bus group. Worth waiting as it's one of my favourite photographs of Ta Prohm.
