One of the more interesting temples. This was one of the more interesting temples in terms of architecture, history and the amazing trees. I enjoyed my visit here.
Favourite of the Siem Reap sites. Easily my favourite of the temples we saw. There is something to be said for the takeover of nature combined with the beauty of the initial construction.

Amazing place!!!. Wow! What else can I say! This is a must see place- I've been around the world and this is definately a place to be seen- it's majestic and unreal! Lost in the jungle for years , you can really feel that vibe!!! Go!

Ta Prohm - Tomb. Ta Prohm is also known by tourists as the temple in the movie " Tomb Raider". Unlike many other temples in the area, Ta Prohm has not been cleared of encroaching jungle. In fact it's charm is largely that the stone temples are intertwined with huge trees that have twisted themselves around the temples over the centuries since it was built. You may have heard rumour that there is a carving of a dinosaur on the walls of this centuries old temple. It's true, it looks clearly like a stegosaurus, and yet the carving was done in a time where the dinosaurs were already extinct, but science had yet to discover dinosaur skeletons. How can it be? An ancient mystery to debate among ourselves. Take a guide if you want to find the dinosaur carving, it's small and could be hard to find on your own.

Amazing tree roots!. The temple itself is amazing, but what makes this one really attractive are all the old trees that grew inside and on top of the temple. You will find really old trees covering the walls and the gates of the temple.As this is one of the most attractive temples at Angkor, please arrive early; otherwise it will be crowded of tourists.

So Unique. This place is just superb - one of the absolute highlights of the area. It's just so different to the other places here, and the trees growing through the ruins are incredible. It's awesome just getting off the main track, and climbing around the ruins for different views. This is one of the top three attractions in the area.
Incredible nature. It is a beautiful temple. Great location for pictures of nature and history coming together. They are renovating part of the temple since it is falling apart.
fantastic. This is one of the best temples in Angkor. Try to visit early or late in the day as most tours tend to arrive there mid morning/lunch time

Right up there with the colosses to me. The structure certainly isn't of the magnitude of the Roman colosseum, but you throw in those amazing stranger figs, and the giant trees with the buttress roots and I was in complete amazement.definitely the high point of our trip to Cambodia.

The jungle wins here. It's incredible how the jungle here totally prevails over man.All temples in Siem Reap would look like this one without maintenance and heavy gardening.It's very fascinating, although probably the least spiritual temple given its conditions..Everywhere piles or big rocks simply eradicated by roots and trunks.The temple the kids will like the most.

My Favorite Temple!. Yes we did the sunrise over Angkor Wat, but Ta Prohm was the most magical. Do NOT skip the smaller temples as to me they were the most amazing (and typically less crowded). Make sure you have a good guide who can give you the background of each. We saw so many people wandering about without the insight, and for the time it took to go to Cambodia from the US, the small amount of money spent on a guide was absolutely worth it!

Totally Amazing. The ancient buildings provide a strong place for the amazing trees that grow at Ta Prom. I found the looks of the buildings fascinating and was really stunned when I saw the huge tree roots (?) / trunks (?) climbing over the tops of the ancient buildings. We were allowed to go into a building or two but very carefully. Actually, amazement is too small a word for these trees and their "props." I am sitting here staring at the photograph of these huge trunks (or roots?) remembering a great desire to go into the building while I was in Siem Reap.
gorgeous. One of the most beautiful temples in Angkor. Lovely location for pictures, a bit quieter than slme of the othet main temples.

Lots of renovation & refurbish in place. A lot of area have been blocked and there are alot of refurbishment in place which is quite disappointing currently. Also there is a lot of place which is demolish and broken which is not a very good sights
A bygone era. One place you cannot leave out from your itinerary. The trees growing there does not only reflect a lost generation but awesome trees growing wherever they take root

Wow!! Will not be forgotten!!. This temple was built from the love of a son for his mother. It has some incredibly wonderful features including the 350 year old trees and their roots that have taken a hold of the buildings. In a couple of places the trees have had to be supported in order to stay safely in place. We went early, just after sunrise and had the entire temple to our small group for at least the first two hours before all the other tourists started arriving. It is easy to spend time here, taking in the beauty, being in awe of the wonder of it all and just re-energizing with the incredible peace from the temple. This is a must see!!
Tomb Raider. Famous for that little sequence from that movie the place is incredible. Many of those trees which grow up through the buildings for those photo opportunities.Can be very busy.
Excellent place. This is well worth the visit but make sure you have plenty of time as it can take some time to get around depending on whether it is the busy season or not.

Simply the best for realising your Indiana Jones fantasy. Currently undergoing some much needed restoration, this is by far my favourite temple. It's a decent size (without being crazy big like Angkor Wat). The tree growing out the side and the general wildness of the site makes it the perfect place for grownups to pretend their in an Indiana Jones or Tomb raider flick.
Amazing. Temple versus mother nature. It is a site to see. You can see first hand how a jungle can take over abandoned sites. The work to restore continues. Don't miss it.

The Magnificent Ta Prohm. One of my fav temple. Love the spung covering part of the temple..It's a perfect postcard picture. While I was there, they are still restoring some parts of the temple, however there are some parts of temple that you'll still able to visit and take some good pictures.
Office outing in Seam Reap. Ancient wreck temple or castle . The wreck and the old architect are still real and reserved. Not too many tour group and crowed people so we can explore the place closely

Spectacular. The ruins seem to be struggling to emerge from the jungle. Some buildings have /ist the fight, others seem supported by the tree roots, and others look like giant snakes or elephant trunks entwined in the buildings. This is a must see when you are visiting the region. Spectacular.

Our Favorite. Of all the temples and ruins around Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm was our favorite. While much smaller in circumference than Angkor Wat, it took our group longer to get through because of all the fabulous photo ops. The invasive vegetation overrunning to temples made for some spectacular photos. This attraction can't be missed!
So atmospheric. This is the temple featured in Tomb Raider. Here the jungle has over taken the temple with huge trees looking like Octopus as they wrap themselves around the building. Just amazing.

Outstanding honor to be able to visit here. Ta Prohm is incredible.... to look over the area and explore within the various temples here is a step back in time... be sure to stop for a bit and take the time to allow yourself to soak it all in and mentally transport yourself back to the former days of glory of these temples, imagining what they used to be and hold. The trees encapsulate the temples like a mother holding a baby, it's just so amazing to see and beyond.

Living the legend. Ta Prohm ranks third in my list of favorite sites in the Angkor Wat complex behind Angkor itself and the Bayon, but that's an awful even competition.Bring comfortable shoes and a couple of bottles of water -- there is a bit of hiking involved in getting around the temple -- but it is worth it. The encroaching trees serve as a reminder of the condition of most of the temples.No, Lara Croft won't come swinging through the trees but the complex certainly gives you the feeling of being in the middle of an adventure. I have to confess that on one visit, while alone inside of one of the internal towers, I took out my phone and played the ringtone -- the theme from "Raiders of the Lost Ark" and it felt good.Not to be missed.
Added Dimension - Trees!. Loved the way at every turn as we scoured the passages huge tree roots had wedged themselves between rocks, over doorways. Gave a different adornment in a class of its own!

Step back in time. From a photographers standpoint, much of the temple area was unavailable as restoration work continues. Additionally, wooden walkways and platforms are now built throughout many areas that protect the fragile remains, but also add obstructions to negotiate while composing photos. But, the mix of ruins and nature, and the jungle canopy provide for stunning photo ops esp. after a rain.That being said, I went in the early morning to avoid the crowds, and I was not disappointed. This was one of my favorite temples in Siem Reap. It is not as large or ornate as other temples. But, I was completely fascinated by the way in which nature enveloped this man-made complex. The roots of trees from the encroaching jungle flow over and around the ruins as if to both support and preserve them. The moss and other plants growing on the tops and sides of structures add color and life to these long abandoned ruins. The intertwining of nature and man was awe inspiring and a definite must see even with the on-going restoration work.

Restoration at the Tomb Raider temple. TA Prohm is a beautiful place. It was the Tomb Raider temple since the movie was shot here per our tour guide. There were too many things happening at the time of visit due to the restoration. It was awesome seeing trees' roots within and around the temple as if they are one. Worth the visit!
Wow. We had the most amazing time here. It was under restaurant ion during our visit but couldn't fault the experience. Seeing the amazing tree routes tangled around the ruins is a must see.

Spectacular.. Spectacular. This has got to be my favourite temple in the entire complex with its huge overgrown trees. A pity a portion of Ta Prohm appeared to be under some restoration work when I was there though.
Temple visit. Beautiful place! Even in pouring torrential rain, this was a temple well worth visiting. The trees growing around the temples were awe inspiring! Havent seen anything like this before.

Restoration Works. Was really looking forward to seeing trees growing over the structure but unfortunately all the center part of the temple was closed off for restoration work and we didn’t get to see much of it. Would have been a spectacular sight

Sprung Trees rule here. Huge trees grow from the roof tops of temple structures , making the huge roots part of the temple. It's hollow within the trunk. The tree roots make this temple beautiful & unique yet destructive.

Nature taking over!. Loved this temple, it was the high light of our trip! Nature is taking over this temple and you can see how the tree roots are tangle in some of the walls, really great for photo opportunities!

Tom raiders fame. It helps when there is a Hollywood movie linked to it. The trees that grew of them were stunning. It made the temple look gothic. Again its one of the 3 temples if you have to pick. This with Angkhoer wat and Angkhor Thom.It can be covered in 1 hour. Prepare for the heat and humidity inJuly.Clothes, shoes and water are key. Not for strollers or for too young kids as there is a lot walking and uneven floor.
Great place to get lost in time. It's my favourite place in the whole Angkor Wat. Would have been even better if there weren't so many tourists.

One of a number of temples in Angkor wat. Angkor Wat and all the other temples on this site gives one the sense of both tremendous power and peace, as in past the Khmer kings rule stretched from Bay of Bengal, China and Vietnam.Was a religious site and even now people of south East Asia regard it as a pilgrimage destinationThere are supposedly 100 plus stone temples - of course we did not go to all as it would be exhausting - but we managed to see at least 6 before the heat got to us. This mystical "city" of the Khmer gods is awesome in every sense of the word - largest religious monument in worldTa Prohm like other temples has sculptural decorations on stone. Documenting the Cambodian history and culture - particularly liked the Aspara dancers, elephants, and the huge stone heads leading to the Bayon Temple,gods - Siva, Rama, Krisna all carved into the stone - Hindu and Buddhist Can't remember which temple - but very impressive carving of the Hindu epic of Mahabharata battle sceneRestoration work being done when we visited this temple which visibly has been taken over by rain forest. Walls seem to be held in a stranglehold of huge serpentine tree roots. Nature and the gods locked in embrace. - just beautiful, and peaceful even with the thousands other visitors

Big trees, big roots, big crowd.. This is a temple dwarfs by the big trees and their buttress roots eating into the temple.Comparatively easy to walk around. Popular throughout the world due to the movie scenes. Can be very crowded. Need to wait for your turns to take photos with the buttress roots ! A sight not to be missed.

Overcrowded By Tourists. Angelna Jolie's filmed her Tomb Rider in this Ta Phrom, this place is pack with tourists all over the world. Root are covering the entire temple this place need to restore & rebuilt to make it a better place. Worth a visit.
Fascinating temple. This is also a must to visit temple, this is the infamous "Tomb Rider" temple. The amazing roots between the temples are fascinating,...totally different from any other temples.

Neat but overcrowded. This temple was neat because of all the trees growing through it, but it was very crowded because it was featured in Angelina Jolie's Tomb Raider movie. It was certainly cool, but other temples were better and less touristy.
Amazing!. I completely understand why they used this temple for Tomb Raider-- it is incredible, and one of the most beautiful sights in the Siem Reap area.

Lara Croft. everyone raves about this and I watched Tomb Raider night before I left...truth is there are LOTS of these type trees overflowing onto temples and the 'actual' one now has a walkway around it....but found it still exciting...
Nature Taking it's course. You can really see how old the trees were as they have grown so big that the roots are covering part of the temple.
best temple ruin in Angkor Wat coverd with the roots of a tree. this is one of the most famous temple ruins where the jungle tree took back his area so that the big roots are climbing over the temple

The best temple in angkor wat.. Like many famous places, there's nothing like the others. The tress growing around the temples are massive and the way they grow through the compound is one hell of a sight. Many photo spots but you have to queue which is not a problem. Just make sure you bring enough water and wear a breathable clothing because the air is really humid here and there's a lot of walking.
Nice Place, would have been nicer without the crowd. A great place but I suggest you visit the place when there are not a lot of tourists. It is definitely more enjoyable.

Temple of Trees. If you are a huge nature lover then you will enjoy seeing how nature has taken over this temple. Trees are growing throughout and on top of the temple structure. Parts of the temple are non accessible due to collapsed stones but there is much to see in the areas available. Restoration of the temple was taking place during our visit. A trip back might lead to more amazing sights. Lots of walking and not as much stair climbing as other surrounding temples. The big attraction inside the temple walls is the tree growing over another tree.
rain made for a quick visit. If you are a Tomb Raider fan, then Ta Prohm is a must see. It bucketed down rain when we arrived, so our visit was very rushed, but it was still a beautiful experience.

Ta Prohm is another magnificent temple in Seam Reap. Visiting this temple makes you feel as a explorer of a lost city. Fascinated to see the temple in which part of tomb raider was shot at. Much has been written about it, Jayavarman VII built this temple to honor his mother. This is a wonderful temple for pictures.
Temple of doom. Indiana Jones made this site popular, but the vines and gigantic trees that have engulfed the temples are a sight to see. Absolutely amazing and out of this world.

Ta Prohm is Impressive . Our personal guide Kim took us here because it is such a contrast to Angkor Wat. Here the temples have been enveloped by the jungle for over 100 years and this really highlights the way nature can reclaim back human endeavor. Restoration work here has been carefully undertaken but not so as to diminish the impact of the encroaching trees. A must see.

Great Khmer temple in the Siem Reap area. While most of the attention goes to the temple of Angkor Wat itself, there are plenty other temples in the greater Siem Reap region and several of them are also 'must see' imho. Ta Prohm is one of those! Our guide brought us there at a time of day when there were still only a few people around, allowing us to enjoy the temple largely by ourselves ... just great. For families with children, this temple does provide you with the 'Indiana Jones' feeling.

Nature's victory. commonly known as the Tomb Raider temple (where the movie was shot), it is a striking reminder of how insignificant we can be when it comes to nature. The temple is over run by giant trees and their roots are now the supporting structures of the temple. It is currently being painstakingly restored, but the trees creates an awe inspiring sight, couples with the ancient remains it is a must visit, and excellent for photos. One of the top temples to see.
Review of Ta Prohm. Unique and mesmerising place. A must see place in Siem Reap. Good to take a guide as they will share the history of this beautiful and enchanting place.

Awesome to see nature reclaiming the temple. You really feel like an explorer when you visit this place. The roots of giant trees spill over ancient ruins. It's been reinforced, so it's very safe to explore. Took our 4 small children there (ages 2, 4, 6, & 8), and they had a ball climbing all over the fallen stones. It is relatively small (in comparison to other temples), so an hour is the most you would need. To avoid the crowds (as this place we the set for Tomb Raider), go just an hour before it closes. It's not too hot, and you'll have the place mostly to yourself.

A magical view!. It my 4th time I visit the temples in Siem Reap and Ta Phrom is still my favorite.Unbelievable what time did with the roots from these huge trees.Definitely worth a 1 to 2 hours visit.

Mystical. Our favorite Wat by far. We arrived very early in the morning and had the place to ourselves for well over an hour. Excellent sun angle for great photos. Some renovations going on however there are still plenty of areas to explore that are in their natural state. Don' t miss this one!

Your tuktuk driver can also double up as your guide. The ruins of Ta Prohm, with huge trees branching out of its ancient walls, make for a photographer's delight! Although restoration work is slow, & a lot of areas need improvement, it is definitely a nice place to visit on your own. You don't need a guide if u buy a book on Ancient Angkor or get yourself a map of Angkor from your hotel. Then you'd know which all places to go.

100 times better than that movie which was set here. Ta Prohm is one of my favorite temples hands down, or roots down if you prefer. The blend of powerful civilization with unsurpassed powerful nature is stunning. This place is a playground of ancient beauty and gigantic, overgrowing nature. If you'd like to view this amazing temple without throngs of people, then you best get a good guide. One who knows the best time and entrance (and photo spots) is Narin. Check out his website: www.angkorbesttourguide.com and contact him at: narinviptours@gmail.com.You won't regret it.

View the place that time has forgotten!. This is 1 of the 3 temples of Angkor Wat that are a must see. The scale of this temple alone is breathtaking, but highlight to this place is how the trees have overgrown some portions of the site, giving it a surreal view at times. If you go here or Bayon, get there early, more and more tourists are visiting and making it more difficult to visit.

Fabulous. This was my favourite temple but would have liked some kind of guide, preferably audio to explain the temple. They are doing some work on parts but there is still lots to see and it does it detract from the experience. Be prepared for the sales people, including many children outside the temple.

The call of the native. All the temples are very inviting in Cambodia - the hefty entrance fee charged for the three days to view these temples surly takes the priority to visit this temple . this is second spot in the attraction after the main Ankor Vat . This temple is a reminder of The forgotten kingdom of past era and it' s glory of the rulers and their love for the religion .

The tomb raider temple. This temple is sited perfectly amidst green trees unlike Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom which have been cleared. The huge trees that grow on the roofs of the temple, made famous by the Tomb Raider movie, were even more amazing in real life!
Must Visit!. Loved this place. This is a famous picture spot :-) easily takes hours to explore this place. Must visit

Nature vs Human Creation . This is a unique temple. It is also made famous by the movie Tomb Raider. For me, it's a demonstration of nature vs man make architecture. You can see how the trees grow around the structures. Some even actually affect the structure integrity. Putting that aside, I'm amazed with the tree that grows for like 600 years or so. Definitely something to see when you're at Angkor!

Tomb Raider. To see sunrise at the temple made famous by the film, we had the opportunity to experience the surrounding jungle transformaing from night to day as well as the peace of the temple - not eerieness, as dawn broke. Fantastic.

Even Better Than Angkor Wat. Despite the heat it is a fascinating temple. Our guide was very informative and on the day we went few visitors. That may also have been due to the timing ... many large groups go to lunch in the middle if the day. I enjoyed Angkor Thom Na Angkor Wat but so glad we also visited this temple.

Worth visiting. Must visit place to see how the temple got taken over by mother nature when left unmaintained.
I loved the way tree shaped and covered the most of the temple with its branches.
Do bring walking shoes, towel, water, camera. Guide is recommended to have a good understand of the place.
It's a short 1hr visit.

Incredible and so glad we went !. Highlight of our trip among our group of seven! We all loved Ta Prohm and were fortunate to have a great guide. We were there just after rain so it was misty and not too crowded. Don't miss this if you are in Siem Reap. Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom were great but Ta Prohm was excellent !!

Nice place, sometimes a bit crowded. Another place really worth a visit. The tree is a very popular spot for people to take a picture so if youre there in the high season...prepare to wait in line to get a good picture

Made famous by the movie Tomb Raider but worth a visit. There are so many funny, beautiful and remarkable things about this temple that it is a not to miss stop on your tour of Angkor.
It still needs a lot of renovation to once again see all the glory that is there it has many attractive elements well worth seeing.
Beautiful temple. Of all the temples that we've visited, this is one of my favourite. It is worth coming at the heat of the day around 2pm when a lot of the tourist are resting.
Tomb Raider Temple!. Ta Prohm temple or was later on named as Tomb Raider Temple! Love the giant roots that grew over the ruins. One of the best temple we have seen. Do not miss!

Tree Temple. This temple has had little restoration at this time but that gives it it's charm. Ta Prohm is known for the trees that out and around the temple but these trees are also the thing destroying them. They are trying to restore this temple but I think there will be parts that they can not so I would see this one while you can.

Commendable Restoration. The temple is extensively damaged and the restoration work done by Archaelogical Survey of India is commendable. The restoration is still in progress. The temple is noted for the trees inside the structure - possibly some of them the cause of destruction or the result of destruction. Enter via one of the gates East or West and exit via the other gate to ensure that you don't miss to see the whole temple.

Magical place - especially early morning. This is a magical place, yet the experience can be totally spoilt by the mass of tourists. If one manages to get there early before the large tour busses, it is still possible to experience the quiet magic that surrounds this temple. A definite must see.

Unmissable, preserved but as found by the archaeologists. Iconic temple overgrown by the roots of silk cotton trees.an unmissable highlight of the 2 day visit to Angkor way complex. Lucky was I to get my driver to fit this in on the morning before my plane left at 12 to get back to Thailand where my main holiday awaited. Cambodia was the highlight of the holiday

Marvelous temple!. I found this temple, complex and varied but I have to say that we truly enjoyed walking through all the interiors. We were thankful that we had advanced info about this that's why we allotted ample time for our visit. Another unique temple experience for us ! Am not very much into architecture but just the same, I could not help but be amazed at how these structures were designed and built.

Amazing temples. Best one for kids.. We went to Siem Reap for 5 nights, This temple was the most interesting for our kids aged 11 and 8. Keep this in mind as its hot in Cambodia and kids get hot and bothered in the heat. If you have time, go alone without the kids for a longer trip and then take them for a quicker tour another day. My husband and I did this. I went in the morning and he went in the afternoon while the kids played in the pool all day. The next day I took my son and the following day my husband took my daughter. You can just get a tuk tuk there and take as long or short as you like.
Tree Temple. This is the place where man made and natural heritage are in harmony. The magnificent trees make you spell bound with mystique in the surrounding monument.

Truly a wild temple!. They say since this temple has been discovered it has been untouched. The place is wild with trees taking over the premises. It is amazing how these large roots go in between the crevices and establish themselves. These trees make the temple truly unique. There is some restoration going on. I do not think they will ever remove those trees. But, it seems like the big roots can make the structure unstable in places and make it dangerous to be under. Some places are marked "unsafe".A must see in Siem Reap!
My favoutite temple. This is my favourite temple in Angkor. I wish i spend there more time just to sit and admire the uniqu atmosphere.

Smaller and therefore more crowded than some but with tree roots galore a sight and site to behold.. I am not going to say "made famous by Lara Croft tomb raider" as that is an horrific injustice to an ancient civilisation and architectural feat - but if you do want to see where it was filmed, this is the temple for you. Known for the trees which began growing on the roof moss and gradually wove their roots through the temples and became part of the structure. Great photo opportunities but as it is small, and under construction, it does tend to get quite crowded so go early, or late, or hope that lunchtime is quieter, and be patient!
Intersting. This one is a lot of people's favourite because of the trees that have grown through the ruins. Also where Tomb Raider was filmed.

Nature reclaiming man made structure. Magnificent view. Nature has reclaimed this temple structure. Nothing much about architecture but the way that the trees have blended into the temple structure can never be done manually or seen in any other places. Must try the Chest Echo Towers - lean your back on the wall and talk, echo will be heard. A must see in Siem Reap.

The wild temple. Yet another must amongst the temples. Not only scenery of "Tomb Raider" but also a breathtaking temple. Trees are growing all over the temple and you can just get lost inside ...Great place to take amazing photos and worth a trip. Not as crowded as Ankor Wat but as worthy to visit.

Larger than life, mesmerizing... You feel you have got stuck in time. The shear size and magnitude of this place gives life a whole new perspective.Its a must see - may sure you have the right gear - preferably good walking shoes and a light jacket in case it rains. the place can get quite damn and wet / slippery after it rains. Watch your step - there are many places where you are likely to trip and fall over. The thing is, you get so consumed in looking around and you may trip and fall.I was lucky to have a driver who doubled up as a guide, otherwise you may want to have some local guidance on going around.Ta Prohm is a square property with a build up wall on all four sides. It takes a good 2-3 hours if you wish to look into all the monuments and take good pictures. (You can also do it quickly in 15 mins if you are short of time, but I wouldn't recommend that).Typically one gets in from the West side and walk through the property and exits from the rear gate. Make sure you have co-ordinated with your driver / guide on where they will pick you up. Its a long long walk back if you need to go back all the way.Tips - keep water handy. there aren't many local stalls around.

Ruined Temple With Ingrown Trees. Ta Phrom is one of the most famous temples in Siem Reap. Many tourists flocked to see the huge trees growing on the temple blocks and it is impressive to see the roots eating into the old ruins. A lot to explore with many photo opportunities.

Beautiful temple, do it justice, do this place before Angkor. This temple was amazing and I wish I had of seen it before all the other temples, as it looks like the most ancient and untouched. it is well shaded, so a good place to do at the hot part of day. the sellers are quite pushy, more so than any other temple.

Tomb raider!. Apart from the hustle and bustle of tourists - yes, you would expect that - the temples were amazing. With spung trees growing out of the ruins and images poking inbetween the roots, it makes for a magical visit. Our visit was in the rain and I would not have had it any other way. The rain gave it a very mysterious feel.
The Jungle takes over. An amazing temple that has been overgrown by the natural jungle. Huge tree roots cascade down the face of the ancient walls and trees tower overhead.
Like from another planet . After angkor wat you must and visit this one. Its amazing and you should walk all around it and enjoy it. The amazing trees that over grew stones are magnificent.

This you gotta see!. We came to Cambodia to see Angkor Wat, but also went to see the lesser known temples, including Ta Prohm. A couple people in our group wanted to skip Ta Prohm, because of "seen one temple, seen them all" attitude. Ta Prohm really is different from the other temples, and I loved it here. It was fun to see the trees growing through and around the temple stones. Be sure to see this one.
Amazing. The tree that live above the temple was very amazing. It shows like the nature taken over the temple... Stunning

Dont miss out on this.... A must see place!! The lush green trees with the trees growing throughout the ruins of this amazing temple.NOTE:this Temple is one of the most touristic temples out of this entire area also, due to this reason there are a lot more roped off areas in this complex and you cant explore as much compared to other temples - still worth going to! dont miss it

Of trees, ruins and Tomb Raider. This ruin holds many secrets, just like what you see in Tomb Raider. Be adventurous and go into the nooks and crannies to find yourself emerging at an unknown location with views that will make you go gaga.

the best temple ever. I really love this temple so much, this temple is always in my heart with big big tree stand in front of me, so amazing place that i seen before i would like to recommend all the the traveler who come to visit siem reap dont miss this temple !!!!!!!!!!!

cool. I think this was maybe the best temple there, definitely worth a visit. We were hoping there might be guides there we could hire but there were none, they only hang out at angkor watt it seems so if you want a guide you'll need to pre-book through an agency or your hotel...

Has to be seen to be beleived. If you only went to see one temple in Siem Reap it would have to be Ta Prohm. Lost in the middle of the jungle, Ta Prohm is the absolute hidden treasure. Overgrown by the most amazing trees, there are roots strewn through the Temple - this is where nature reclaims it as it's own!
AMAZING TREE TEMPLE. This is the temple where i am looking for years... finally i realize it is much more than my expectation
Forest Growing on the Temples. Massive trees growing on top of temple ruins. Very interesting. Very photogenic. Was one of the scenes of the movie "Lara Croft: Tombraider" stariing Angelina Jolie.
Amazing place. I've traveled to over 35 countries... And this place is the place that will always be in my heart...

Feeling like in another world!. This temple was amazing with the trees. It makes you feel as if you are in another world completely. I took so many pictures that I cannot say which is my best or which I like more, but all are amazing. It is the symbiosis of nature and architecture that makes this place truly special. So far my favorite temple. We went early in the morning to come when it is not so crowded and cooler.

Fascinating. A must even if its just to sit and stare how the trees have grown into the rockwork. I know the tree roots are gradually destroying the temple but it is just fascinating. They look like the legs of some giant alien creature.

awesome sight. amazing sight to see those old giant tree roots growing over the temple. Would advise good walking shoes and a hat. The temple floors are stone blocks and quite uneven and the sun can be relentlessly hot on a clear day. Also bring bottles of water....
Love those naughty trees. Fascinating site and one of our favorites. Make sure your camera battery is charged. It is truly amazing to see the damage that has occurred via Mother Nature at this site.

How to photograph Ta Prohm, even when it is too crowded.. I have visited Ta Prohm many times and yes it was easier and less hassle ten years ago, but it is still by far one of the most overwhelming experiences in the temples of Angkor. The trick for me (as a photographer) is to sit down in a spot I want to photograph and just wait. Once you stop moving along with the crowds, everything changes around you, you start to see details, colours, patterns, the crowds stop being in the way (well in some places anyway). Always an incredibly awesome experience.

Breathtaking beauty. Absolutely amazing. Bring a sun hat, a shoulder bag to carry water and maybe a snack and be prepared for lots and lots of walking. There are some areas that are inaccessible to wheelchairs or those needing physical assistance with stairs or uneven terrain. This is Cambodia....it's hot and humid and you need to go slow and just appreciate the beauty as well as the cultural differences. We spent almost an entire day just wandering around and sitting under the trees to people watch. (And monkey watch)

Worth the visit . Temple itself is mostly in ruins but it's still nice to walk around as nowhere is of limits.Walking around you do get an adventure like experience and certainly the most popular area is the part with the tree roots growing around part of temple, a great photo to be had.Go early if you can as gets really busy come lunch time.

Awesome temple!. It's so different to the other temples. There are so many trees that kept growing over, underneath and on top of the temple structure. It looks awesome and it's a great picture spot. Unfortunately these leads to that a lot of the structures are destroyed. But lickily there is a lot of work going on to rebuild the structures that fall apart and to fix the ones that are still intact. You cannot go to all the areas because of that work, but there is more than enough to see that keeps you busy for one hour and more

Temple vs nature. The mix of old temple and nature taking control makes this an inhteresting site to visiT. Difficult to see how the temple will be preserved given the amount of trees growing amongst the stones, which is part of the charm.

The tree roots are amazing!. This is one of the more interesting temples (not that the others aren't!), with a wonderful integration with nature by way of the tree roots intertwining the building work.
Stunning trees. A must see temple for the trees that are growing out of it. Worth having a guide that will take you though the temple and explain what the trees are and all other history.

A Must-temple to Visit in Siem Reap. As recently, the beautiful temple was recommended by world-famous football player, Mr. David Beckham, to all visitors must visit when he came to visit there. So, you can come to check out more!

Amazing Temple!. It is located in Angkor Archaeological park and it is a kind of jungle temple. It is a great temple that exist even though there is a big tree on the top of the temple. Very nice view!

Our Top Ranked Siem Reap Temple. Ta Prohm was our group's consensus favorite temple in the greater Siem Reap area. It was followed by Bayon, Angkor Wat and Beng Mealea in our ranking. We went in the morning and it was not very crowded. Incredible meshing of nature with an ancient magnificent structure. Clearly a can't miss.

Must go!. Truly amazed with the creation of our mother nature. You can see tree trunks outgrown from the temples, breaking themselves free from the sandstone. Bayon temple was the third temple I visited in one day after Angkot wat and Bayon Temple. I was so exhausted that time and really need a charge before i can go on with the day tour. Found a place to sit, I close my eyes to rest my body for a while, the tranquility in the temple make me feel so peaceful and warm even with some tourists walking around. Must visit here!
Beautiful setting. Interesting nature around the temple. Impressive trees growing out of the temples after being forgotten for centuries in the middle of the jungle. Worth the visit.
Special place. Really nice place. Look out for the dinosaur carving, it's worth asking a guide where it is and doing some research on it

Disappointing visit due to the temple condition and ongoing renovations. Huge crowd arrive here due to Angelina Jolie and the Tomb Raider fame. But in actual practice temple is in pretty bad shape. Matters are made worse by the cordoning off of large portions due to construction work. Hopefully it would be better once restored.

Welcome to tomb raider country. This is Lara Croft country , wonderfully impressive temple with giant fig trees growing out of the roofs of some buildings and smothering walls Temple entrances run east west , the easy route with all the Lara sops can be frustrating as another group posses for the iPhone pictureWell worth wandering outside the inner compound , on my second visit it had just rained , place was flooded( make sure you are in sanders or flip flops ) then great place to wonder Around , there are far more strangler fig pictures than the standard tomb raider ones

Amazingly Creepy. when the trees eats the tomb,,make sure to bring some water and spare clothing because is very hot ..this place is very amazing and its hard to explain how nature and tombs almost combined.. it just pretty cool

My favourite of the temples!. I did a full circuit tour starting early in the morning to catch the sunrise at Angkor Wat (like everyone else in Siem Reap) ending at Ta Prohm. Most were pretty good, however Ta Prohm ended up being my favourite. It might have been the time of the day where there were less people around, but the ability to find peace and quiet while exploring the temple was fantastic. The trees are awe inspiring and make you realise how small we really are in the world. Man vs Nature. Nature wins every time.

Beautiful, but packed with tourists.. Had fun pretending to be Angelina Jolie for next 45 minutes, but atmosphere was kinda ruined by the areas being roped off. Good for preservation but loses a tad of its charm. Went about 11 a.m. was packed with tourists.

Surreal and sublime. Ta Prohm temple is widely known as the Tomb Raider temple due to Angelina Jolie's movie flick.I have to say this one is my favorite of all the temples even more so than the great Angkor Wat.What makes it special are the silk cotton and strangling fig trees that hug the temple roofs. Those giant trees make the place more charming in an ancient kind of way. We also loved the many bas reliefs of the devadas. There are also other curiosities on the walls like the devada peeking through a tree, a carving of what looks like a dinosaur with spikes on its back, the relief known as the departure of the buddha. My son also enjoyed looking for small creatures like salamanders, milipedes, butterflies and big ants. What a serene beautiful place!

Fantastic!. This was my second favourite after The Bayon. Couldn't believe the size of the roots on the trees. Wear comfortable shoes, hat and sunscreen and bring water. Note their are no toilets inside any of the temples and it's a long walk to get out so use them before you go in!

Magical. This place is very different from the others, but it is also very beautiful. Currently there is alot of restoration going on so make sure you follow the route. Even better just take a guide. They can point out some very interesting things that you would never notice or understand such as a carving of a dinosaur!!! How cool is that!? The trees growing all over look so amazing, it's hard to explain. I went with Angkor Travelers Choice for the tour and it was fantastic.

Ta Pow. Despite being quite crowded with Tomb Raider Fans, quiet areas of the temple could be found. It's amazing to see the temple stones in piles, while other areas restored or untouched. Definitely worth seeing.

Ta Prohn was breathtaking!!! A must do while in Siem Reap. Plan on getting hot and sweaty...Going back in time and seeing the trees overtaking the Temples is incrediable. The way these temples are built is just crazy how exact these builders were. Be sure to have a great guide to bring everything to life for you.

Structure fascinating and well worth a visit. We had a nice time here exploring and the tree formations within the block work was mind blowing.a good 2 hours and we had seen pretty much everything at a good pace.Take plenty of water and a fan as get very hot.
wow. Tomb Raider, we have all seen the movie, this is where part of it was film, trees growing out and over the temple ruins give it a different feel from the others

A good place to visit.. This is the place where we can found the historical tree which we can all over the internet. One more thing made us more excited about this place is India is helping financially to reconstruct the ruins at this place. Very well recommended place and can spend 3-4 hrs at this palce.

Lost in time! My favorite!. Of all the temples, this was my favorite. I love how nature has taken over the temple! The trees are amazing and continue to both tear up the structure and at the same time hold it together with their roots. It's a must see.

Tomb Raider Live!. It's easy to feel like an ant amongst these towering gigantic trees that have once taken over the temples. Siem reap has done well in reconstructing a lot of the temples so we can appreciate them better.

To be admired. This is without doubt one of the more stunning structures on the Angkor site. The giant tree roots that have encapsulated the ancient stone walls is stunning. With an experienced guide you will probably find they will take you here or the Bayon first while the bulk of the tourists head off to Angkor Wat. This is a good idea as it gives you a chance to take photos and enjoy some of the tranquility this place offers.
Tomb raider!. Most of the appeal of this place for me had to do with the movie, but I also talked to people that hadn't seen the movie that still thought it was cool. Worth a visit and a photo!

To ditch the crowd: go between 10 and 12. And take the long road (there's a sign right in front of the main temple). You'll be almost alone to marvel at the trees that have engulfed whole parts of the outer wall, or split smaller buildings apart. The long road really isn't that long anyway, maybe 15 minutes.

Well worth the visit. Well worth the visit, such amazing history, well kept and easily accessible, those with any step difficulties may find this temple difficult to access as there are many stairs. Was quiet this time of year so nice and quiet.

Mother nature vs manmade structures at its best.. Once you are passed the enormous amount of children and adults trying to sell you things, it is an amazing place that is being taken over by the sheer force of tree root systems and man is trying to return it to its former glory. Every area holds another opportunity for a unquie photo. Hot day pace yourself take plenty of water and patience.
my favorite temple. Ta Prohm is the favorite temple at Angkor Wat because of the century old trees intertwined among the ruins.

My favorite next to Bayon Temple!!!. This is what I will absolutely take with me for the rest of my life. I can sit here and just close my eyes and remember my visit here from beginning to end.From being in the crazy Siem Reap heat this is what we needed after visiting the other temples. I didn't expect this at all...but after we parked we just started walking down this path, a path filled with trees one each side, the trees alone brought shade and a beautiful breeze. That heat you were thinking about and dreading completely goes away. As we were walking we heard traditional khmer music in the far distance as weakest walking down the path we finally saw that there was a group of older people playing instruments who we later found out were farmers that had suffered from the khmer rouge reign. They were disabled but play as the tourists pass by and you can make a donation. Which I did, if you do get a guide when in Siem Reap you'll understand the khmer rouge did a lot of damage to the country. Aside from that sad part of history my point is the path leading to the temple, that walk with the music playing is just pure bliss, a sort of serenity. And what topped it all off was there were butterflies flying everywhere, every size, every color. Just so peaceful.As you approach the temple you are just amazed, walking through it amazed, from beginning to end, AMAZED. How did these overgrown trees grow the way they did, it's just crazy!The walk back to the car was just as i explained as the walk in.I just loved this place, also there was a local at the temple painting paintings he was selling. Such a talented young man, I bought one and have it framed in my home now. Support the local artists!

Beautiful and more than that. We followed the tip of our local friend in Siem Reap and we visited Ta Prohm before anyone else. We enjoyed our visit without tourist and it was one of the most amazing experiences that we have in Cambodia

Big Trees!. Big trees with huge roots were everywhere in this temple. If you're amazed that these buildings have stood for many years, think of the tree roots that managed to work their way through the buildings and make a stand for themselves(literally)!

Just wow. The temple is almost ruined by mother nature. Some buildings Seem like they will collapse anytime. But what is amazing is despite the forces and harshness from the nature, the temple is still surviving. A mixed of temples and huge trees make up a beautiful sight, almost magical. The place can be crowded with ridiculously large group of tourists. But if you avoid the crowd and take a different path, you can enjoy some peaceful time on your own.

Go before it's gone. Nice place to visit. And this is one of the must visit places in Siem Reap. So just make a go at it and take some photos. However, no need to spend too much time there, as it all looks similar.

Mesmerizing (but under reconstruction). If you're in this forum or Trip Advisor review, you already know why Ta Prohm is so popular and worth a visit. Unfortunately (now, written July 2, 2015) there is lots of construction happening in the main complex, which includes that famous spot with the thick roots enveloping doorways and temple walls. After the construction finishes, I am sure it will be 100x awesome, but for now there are areas closed off and lots of noice and dust. Nonetheless, it is still a jaw-dropping site and many areas to meander at your own pace.
You'll be in awe!. This was SO cool. It's an incredible site to see these amazing walls just being consumed by trees. You'll never see this anywhere else in the world.
Amazing attraction. This temple was just amazing with the sculptured tree roots working their way into the ruins, well worth a visit

Beauty in ruins. It was really fascinating to see the structure as it lies now and try to imagine what it must have been like, when it was just built (in all its glory). In fact, that would have been a sight to see - all temples in tact.Most peculiar though was the stone carving that looked liked a dinosaur (a Stegosaurus maybe?) and the massive Spung tree that has its roots on the structure and stands tall on the structure. Dedicated to the king's mother - this is one of the temples you get to see that hasn't been restored (the other one being Preah Khan, built by the king for his father).

Nice place to visit. if you imagine to Tom Rider what you think about the place. It's more than your imagine, I do love a big tree there and you can spend more time to absorb history and nature. Nice to take photo with the big tree here too.

Awsome:). My favorite temple around Angkor Wat.It looks awsome with all the trees and roots growing over the ruins of Ta Prohm.The only plave where a lot of people where cueing for a selfie was in the front of the door which was in the tomb raider movie. That's no problem as there a plenty of similar places in the ruins.
Impressive. The temple is really impressive as the jungle with this huge trees seems to fight with the temple to take it back from the humans.

Well-rooted in history!. We visited Ta Prohm towards the end of the day when it was more quiet, less hot and when the lighting was subtle enough for some good shots. This is a place not to be missed for the sheer fact that here grows some of the oldest trees in the world; well-rooted trees that have encroached the ancient walls and conquered them. Some of the roots look like giant serpents and it is really an engulfing experience. Built as a monastery and university in the late 12th and early 13th centuries, Ta Prohm has been left in pretty much the same condition in which it was found although there is currently a conservation and restoration project in place. It was inscribed in UNESCO's World Heritage List in 1992. Do visit Ta Prohm while it is still standing and witness first-hand a ruined past ruled by the tree kings.

Tomb Raider Temple. We saw Ta Prohm early in the morning. This was a great time to go as there were only about 6 other people there. Also it was cooler at that time of day and the early morning light afforded great photo opportunities. With very few people around you didn't have to wait for people to get out of the way while you were taking photos. There was a guide onsite who was available to point out features of the temple.
Simply worth the trip. This was my pick as the high point of my entire Cambodia trip. This temple is amazing, a must see. Site of the original Tomb Raider movie.
The king who smiled. Quite a different temple to ankor wat with its benevolent smiling king seen from every angle. Lovely entrance with gods and demo son bridge over river.

Magical. There is a lot of preservation and restoration work going on so parts of this site is closed off. Nonetheless, it remains a magical place to see. You can see the battle between the ancient stones and the trees and how difficult the restoration and preservation efforts must be as they struggle to find the balance between the two. We headed straight here after the sunrise at Angkor Wat at about 7.45am and it was still wonderfully empty.

It's cooler than the movie.. Stepping into this site makes you feel like you're "in the other part" of the world, feels so ancient and strangely odd to be at the ruined temple where the trees is overtaking it.
It's definitely one of the must visit temple in Angkor wat.
Glimpse of the past.... Great effort to conserve this place despite the number of visitors everyday. :) I would love to visit again in the near future..
Amazing world we live in!!. An amazing experience to see history combined with nature and wonder how life was at that time. Well worth the visit and I thoroughly recommend it.
Uniquely Ta Prohm. The place is amazing and well-preserved. Its historical value is worth knowing. Its a beautiful place for those who love to take photography
The Trees!. Ta Prohm should be a part of every tour to Siem Reap. It helps to have an expert guide like Phany take you to the iconic places. Loved this, took the pictures too.
Magical. This temple is just magical. A lot of people know it from the tomb raider movies, but it so so cool to visit. The trees coming in and out of the building are just beautiful.

This is it. This is what you expect from the temples. It's the one from the Tomb Raider movie, and it is astounding. They left parts of the temple in the original decayed condition, to make sure you know what that looks like. The temple becomes pretty disorienting due to this, but its kind of good thing because you can just wander around sort of exploring the place. If you can manage, go here early in the morning or late in the afternoon, as the place looks best when the sun is not directly overhead. The tall trees around make for a very special lighting situation that way.
Gift of the past to modern humans, a place worth visiting!. Gift of the past to modern humans, a place worth visiting!The place that takes your breath away, the lost city in the middle of the jungle

Crown´s jelewer. The finest craft to be seen in the area Like not a giant temple but a tini one with amazin craft work in every wallGuide is recomended instead of the not big temple to get all details and not missing histry of the place

Tomb Raider. Conservation work is ongoing and there is currently scaffolding and a crane on site, however the magic is not lost. If it's that iconic tree picture you race after, I strongly suggest visiting Ta Som, I thing the fig tree swallowing the East Entrance is even more impressive.
Incredible. Very impressive not just the falling down bits but also the jungle and all those beautiful butterflies. Take your time and just stroll.

Ta Prohm. Amazing Ta Prohm Temple in Siem Reap Cambodia .
Very wonderful historical very beautiful natural trees .
I love Cambodia and I love Cambodian

Nice setting, more trees. Nice setting, loved the trees, makes it all seem like more of an adventure. Different feel from the Bayon or Angkor Wat. If you want to go one step further on the "wildeness" of the temples, go to Beng Mealea

The greatest temple in the world.. Ta Prohm is one of the wonderful temples in Siem Reap, Cambodia and all tourists never miss this one when they arrived here.
Everyone could explore here during morning or afternoon time but all time are the best.
I would happy to go there again during my free time.
Amazing structure. Part of the one day tour of Angkor Wat. Worth your while with many sites for photos. If you hire a guide, you will enjoy the history.
My second time for Siem Reap. This my second in Siem Reap i still love Ta Promh temple because of this temple is my temple i liked than other temple.

Tomb raider untouched. We had time for 2 temples and chose Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm.
This was smaller and the jungle seems to want it back. This one went from being Buddish to Hindu and Angkor wat was the reverse. Fascinating.

Ta Prohm-Out of this world. I have never seen a temple like this in the world. Not in Egypt, Peru, Mexico, or Europe. Ta Prohm is a unique temple where trees have grown on top of the temples, and this is a unique spectacle in the world. Since Banteai temple is really close to Ta Prohm, go in the morning and visit Banteai and then Ta Prohm.

Amazing!. Definitely a must-see! The huge trees and their huge roots are like no other. The trees are both holding the temple together and causing it to break as well, which to me was fascinating. You will also appreciate the intricate carvings on the stones, just like the other angkor temples.
i was in tree heaven. great to see the trees enveloping the ruins, really interesting to see. took loads of photos to show everyone at home.

Astonish!! Very unique! . Great place to visit and it's actually a must to visit if you are in Siem reap. The trees there are huge with their giant roots and trunks. The temple is amazing too.
Great place to take lots of beautiful photos.
My fav temple!. Was more restored than I had imagined it would be, but I guess that's to make it safer. Very cool photo opportunities here. My favourite temple we visited in SE Asia.

Amazing mix of Nature of History. I guess you MUST be daft to go all the way to Cambodia and NOT visit this place. Get good cameras ready and immerse yourself in the awesome atmosphere of such a historical sight. Bring lots of water though. Sun's hot and you CAN be really thirsty.
My fav. I visited 14 temples on my trip to Siem reap. This was one of my favourites. Something about not being the least restored and in ruins with nature taking over. Luved it!

Anaconda Tree!!. Yes, this is another temple where alive tree grown up on top of temple and surrounding of temple..people. Will easily get lost! Without tour guide.Those going alone without tour guide, please dont afraid if you lost, you might end up on same place n seeing same tree al over again n again..Be bravo and enjoy the nature with advanture.. You will find way out!!

Sightseeing. Ta Prohm temple is simply mind blowing! While walking around you are amazed by the nature taking over the ruins. There is some maintenance going on over here but that doesn't stop anyone from seeing the most important parts of the temple. It's a must see. Ruins, trees, piles of rocks... Great, dramatic pics guaranteed!

Bit of temple raiding. This was really great to get my own photos at this very famous temple. The trees are beautiful and I love the renovation work they are doing without taking out all the trees. Feel very lucky to have made it to this and all the other temples on my first trip to Cambodia. All, I can say is, just go and experience it for yourself!

Temple full of Roots . Ta Prohm is one of the must see temple in Siem Reap, it's roots over the temple is the uniqueness. This temple was built by King Jayavarman VII in honour of his mother. The carving on each side of the wall really impress me. Only in this temple, I didn't feel the heat. It's because of tree shade. Further more, the movie TOMB RIDER was shoot in this temple. Please bring your camera to capture the moments.

Outstanding architecture. The architecture at Ta Prohm is one with nature and while the restoration work might put you off a bit, it is an amazing place to visit to see how nature and man made wonders can co exist. And yes, locals call it the Tomb Raider temple after the popular Hollywood movie

Unearthly and mesmerising . Ta Phrom was the last temple on the 1 day Angkor tour my girlfriend and I took. This is the most mysterious of the three and is comprised of several towers and other structures. Most of this complex seems to be choking in the powerful embraces of tree roots. Visit the temple with a guide; our Seven Candles guide knew exactly which courtyards and other areas were deserted.Bizarre, fantastical, atmospheric but - understandably - under renovation. An important choice must be made: preserve the temple and remove the trees and roots and with them the haunting atmosphere, or keep the trees and roots and let them consume and destroy the temple. Visit Ta Phrom now and catch a glimpse of its mysteries before the roots have been cleared...

History right there. A fascinating piece of Cambodian history that we experienced first hand. Gives you 'goosebumps' when you think how old it is.
Even managed to take photos without 'hordes' of tourists in the picture!!

Must see!. This one is one of my favorite temples in the entire complex. It is simply fascinating to see way the banyan trees drape lazily over and around the ancient structures. I saw it mid-afternoon, and it wasn't too crowded at that time. It's definitely worth it to take your time here.

good sight. Popularly known for movie: lara croft- tomb raider,
The trees here are huge, with temples located in between the roots. The roots are spread over a wide area, and have flattened shape. Amazing sight.
go early. went 730-830. very few tourists. Came back at 1300 to see something i missed. It was packed. You need to hit this tight temple up early morning if possible.
Worth the visit. Even though its incredibly famous and you think it won't live up to the hype, it does! Just amazing how the trees and buildings have merged together.

avoid the crowd. the best time to visit this beautiful temple is late afternoon/ evening to avoid tour bus crowd and the queue to take pictures with the trees. Ta Prohm is a nature beautiful and most atmospheric ruin temple, bounded by massive roots of huge trees.

Out of this world . One of the most interesting and beautiful temples in the Angkor complex.
You can truly see the course of time as the jungle reclaims its place though the walls of what's left of this ancient place.
A must see for all who visit Cambodia
Can't wait to visit again. Amazing place , can't wait to go back, wear sensible shoes and take plenty of water to drink. Remember to be respectful and do not take photos of monks

Amazing temple. A great temple that is being reclaimed by the jungle ,absolutely beautiful must see .
Amazing to be where there is so much old history and craftsmanship within the delicate walls
Brilliant experience. One of life's must does, totally unbelievable place, I seen the major sites around the world but this place wins hands down for beauty and nature!

Tomb Raider Temple. Wow, waiting for Angelina Jolie to pop out of the roof and swing on the trees. Amazing place !!
dress comfortably proper shoes
Hidden Temple in Angkor Jungle. I booked a Guided Bike Tour on February for a day in Angkor. It was really funny to discover this amazing Temple by Bike!

A Must See. This is a very interesting place. The evidence of the power of jungle vegetation on the handicrafts of humans is predominantly evident. See it in the early morning or late afternoon. If you are a photographer both times are great for capturing the magic and mystery of this place.
Interesting. Another fascinating and interesting temple. The trees that grows in between and the nature surrounding it. Look so glorious, magnificent and beautiful.

Nature 4 Man 2. First time we went here it was torrential rain, so didn't even make it to the entrance; sheltered and then turned back around as it was just too much! That was an experience in itself though.Returned the next day and it was well worth it. One can really appreciate the strength and magnificence of nature here and I'm glad that the renovations incorporate the trees as it makes this temple seem unique.Be prepared for lots of children hawking items outside, I really wanted to help a few of them, but just didn't know how. A sad situation, particular when I saw them all drenched in the rain.My one gripe was the attempted Westernisation by referring to this Temple as "Tombraider Temple" - it's Ta Prohm and the locals should be proud of it and it's name!

You found the right place for an adventure movie temple Angelina!. Ta Prohm became famous internationally because of the movie Tomb Raider with Angelina Jolie. In this movie, she enters the temple ruins of Ta Prohm, and is beset upon by stone fighter statues and stone lions come to life. We did not encounter any living stone statues, but were very impressed by how impressive this temple was, with trees and plants growing everywhere

Dinosaur Carving. I have been to many spectacular places around the world, and the best way to convey this one is that Angkor is one of the few that are more awesome than the publicity photos and descriptions.This is a two day adventure, at a minimum, just to see the "main" ruins. Be prepared to walk, climb, and be amazed. The first day we went with a guide and driver to see the "inner loop" ruins ($70). The second day we went via Tuk Tuk and traveled the "outer loop" at our own pace. This worked well for us.Musts: loose clothing, hat, walking shoes, sunglasses, bug spray, sunscreen,

Mother Nature Taking Over. This temple was a former monastery, so the preservation of culture, combined with giant trees growing in, around, and on top of it, made this temple stand out. Guide made it better, other tourists made it a little annoying (if I pause from walking to let you take a picture or wait on your massive group to take 20 individual shots in front of the "tomb raider" tree, is it too much to wish you'd do the same?). But it was awesome to see.

Ghostly impression. What impressed us at first sight was giant roots of huge trees which cover the moss stone walls or grow out of ruinous towers, which makes the temple more myterious and fascinated; there are some roots look like lizards or white snake rolling around the ancient temple. Over time, the inner flagstones were eroded, some corners of the temple were destroyed and in current restoration. This Ta Prohm is actually a ruin because most of it collapsed. However, the temple was well-known since Hollywood chose it as a background in the film “Tomb Raider”. I think it 's a nice place you should visit at least once in a lifetime

Simply amazing. We've seen the movie. But to actually see the temple, well, that's another thing. Once we walked in, we kept wondering how the temple had not collapsed. This is one of the three more well known temples in Siem Reap. It's well worth the visit.

Must-see but prepare for the crowds. This temple is amazing and you can't leave Siem Reap without getting a glimpse of its famous temple trees. Be prepared to wait a bit for the staged photo points, as, even in low-season, it is fairly crowded.
Iconic. Probably the most crowded temple with vistors. Understandable as it offers some of the best 'tree in temple photo opportunity in Angkor.
Ancient temple growing back into jungle. This ancient Buddhist temple is falling into disrepair due to growth of the jungle however it is still amazing to see.
Tomb Raider. Yes, this is the temple from the film Tomb Raider. Beautiful temple with overgrown trees. It's always under restoration but worth a visit.
Beautiful temple. Fantastic temple and well worth a visit. This was the highlight of my trip to Siem Reap. A must see.

Great archeological work. One of the must visit places in Siem Reap and it is a fantasy of those who are interested in architecture. India - Cambodia joint project where they are resurrecting the whole temple from grounded stones. A great piece of ancient architecture and also a great way to demonstrate how nature (with those hundreds of years old trees) and human creation (building) can co-exist.
Awestruck. Unbelievable beautiful and well maintained. We had some amazing photo opportunities and the guideexplained everything in detail.

A mix of stones and trees, incredible. Famous for the trees growing in and around the temple structure, this is one of the few places that a trip to Siem Reap cannot be completed without. There are many spots for taking wondrous photographs. I have never seen anything else like this.
Awesome Pictures. You get some really awesome pictures taken here. The way the spung roots invade the Ta Prohm temple accentuates the grandeur of the entire architecture.
Nature is so cool. Amazing to look at the trees here and how they just grew in and around the temples. I was more in awe with the trees than anything else.

Just wow...... Make sure your camera batteries are charged! This is one of the most amazing places to visit - our guide was brilliant helping us with all the information we could possibly need. Morning was a good time to visit before it gets too hot!
Must see!. Beautiful temple, visit in early morning or late in the afternoon to have some quietness and best light for pictures.
Amazing place. Usually a crowded tourist attraction. Take your time to enjoy this place. Must visit when in Cambodia. Try to visit early morning to beat the crowd.

Travel Back in time. Ta Prohm was initially named Rajavihara (Royal Temple) commemorating mother of King Jayavarman, this amazing Khmer master piece was taken over by Nature and now slowly emerging from forest however it is left untouched mostly which itself is a beauty, seeing trees growing on top of temples A scenic sight. This temple is less crowded than Angor wat. It is a photographers paradise.

Awe Inspiring!. Ta Prohm has left me speechless! The way these magnificent trees have grown all around the ancient buildings is absolutely incredible! However they are crushing the buildings which in itself so sad. I'm so so glad I've seen it though & if I came back to Siem Reap I would spend more time there! It would be better if you didn't have to share it all with other tourists, but that's not possible. Our guide suggested we have an early lunch & go when most others were eating which is what we did, so it wasn't too crowded. Don't miss this place, you will be very impressed! It's currently being restored with a lot of work going on but ignore that & just enjoy the beauty of it all...!

ANOTHER PLACE NOT TO BE MISSED. Ta Prohm is one of the more popular sites to visit and I have been there many time. However, it is usually very crowded with people trying to take photos of themselves by the tree growing over the wall. The best time to visit is early morning before the tourist buses arrive.
Wow. Take your time here, the crowds rush through, so it's difficult at time to stop and take it all in, amazing place to see!
Excellent. Wanted to see this, Tomb Rider site, alot of the roots have been removed as they were crushing the buildings.You can still see how the jungle took over, amazing place.

Under construction. This will be amazing once the work us complete and it's so nice to see they are restoring them. I think the opening hours should be longer in the evening so when it cools down you can explore longer.These Temples would be an experience at night !!!
Actual view is the same as what I saw in the magazine. Very nice. I was amazed seeing these big roots. It's actually the same as what it is in the featured travel magazines. Good spot for photo ops.

An overabundance of tourists makes an early visit here a must!. I love the ambience of this ancient place with its tumble down stones and strangler figs taking a firm grip on the remnants of temples. I believe the Cambodians have deliberately left this site in disrepair although there was a lot of work going on with cranes and scaffolding when we visited. I'm sure this must be from a safety viewpoint. It is a great vision of an authentic ruin, however, and not a Disney substitute!I recommend you go early because the bus loads of Chinese and Korean tourists (in particular) make it difficult to move around as they tend to stand around taking photographs and talking with their guides with little regard for the egress of others!
Angkor wat was amazing. My dream trip and even better I went there with my princess she's only 9 but good insight for her to travel to this trip. Definitely out of her box!
great temple. This is the temple I would definitely say you have to see because the very big trees grow on the temple that no whereelse left.
Favourite one!!. Loved this temple it was a proper ruin. Obvious attraction of the tomb Raider film and it looks the same felt like i was exploring myself!
WOW. I been in my dream Temple . was Truly inspired when the Tomb Raider made here. Local Souvenirs available outside the temple.

Iconic. One of the highlights, the best part is tucked round the back. Some restoration work going on but its doesnt spoil the experience. Some beggars but a couple of firm No Thank yous and they leave you alone.
Must do. Even if you only see one or only a couple of temples, this is a must see. Amazing to see how the jungle has fought back at the building. Impressive restoration works continue.

Absolutely magical. I found Ta Prohm absolutely magical, much more than Angkor Wat. Seeing the ruins being overtaken by nature is beautiful. I visited during monsoon and the slight rain made for an even more memorable experience. Truly recommended.

It was simply beautiful. This was my favourite temple of all the temples I visited. To see the way the trees grow out of this temple in many locations was great to see. Some great structures are also in this temple. Not to be missed.

Good and Bad of Restoration. Ten years ago when my wife and I first visited Ta Prohm, more popularly known as "The Temple of Doom" no restoration work had been done. We climbed unrestricted over giant heaps of fallen stones, squeezing between gaps in the walls, and marveling at how the jungle had overtaken this once proud temple, with giant fig trees perched atop stone masonry and with roots grimly burrowing deep between the crevices to maintain a hold. Fragments of Buddha images and other religiously icons lay on the ground.Now a great deal of restoration work has been undertaken and much of a visit to Ta Prohm is on wooden walkways, with other areas roped off as unsafe.I guess it had to happen for safety's sake, but somehow the magic of that first visit has gone forever.

Let's Imagine. I love this temple, it's so much to see, so much to imagine, so interesting when trees roots almost taking over, the temple and its area. One part of the temple that you can hit your chest and hear the reflect pounding.
Worth vieitng. This site is worth visiting, as I visited after Angkor Wat for sunrise and there was a lot less tourists. It is also very unique, different to Angkor Watt

The Tomb Raider temple. The temple is where parts of The Tomb Raider was filmed and you can see the massive trees and their root structures engulfing the ruins of the temple. Great photo spots but such unique vegetation! Loved this temple. Look for the carving of a stegasaurus on one wall on way out. Our guide pointed it out.
Amazing. This temple is difficult to take on board.... It is so amazing, built in the jungle with the huge fig trees growing up through it. Would I recommend a visit. YES YES YES.

Breathtaking!. The tuktuk ride to Ta Prohm was hot and dusty. The place was rundown. A few of the facade has already crumbled down. However, the place is under restoration and rehabilitation. There were lots of tourists having their pictures taken with the magnificent trees that has grown amongst the walls of the temple. This temple is famous for it. There were beehives on some trees. Be careful on possibilities of falling debris when inside the temple. *read about the Philippines at joylenesdayout.blogspot.com
Amazing site. A must see when in Cambodia. The forest reclaiming the site is wonderful. Some of Tomb raider was filmed here.

An atmospheric jungle adventure.. The atmospheric ruin of Ta Prohm is high on the hit list of every tourist. Once swallowed by the jungle only the larger trees are now left in place. Ta Prohm is a temple of towers, closed courtyards and narrow corridors many of which are impassable, clogged with jumbled piles of carved stone blocks. A touch of Indiana Jones as you wander around and of course the iconic and most photographed spot where Lara Craft entered on her search as tomb raider. If you have the energy Ta Prohm is most impressive at dawn before the crowds arrive but like us late afternoon with afternoon shadows is just as good.
Lost in Ta Prohm. Exploring Ta Prohm is so fun, even getting lost in it. Felt like Tomb Raider for awhile. Amazing place to see! Must do on a small circuit.
Return visit. Disappointed as mostly roped off for major renovation. And there are simply too many tourists at this site - see Preah Khan instead.

somewhat undistirbed. Seeing the trees towering above the ruins and the roots interwined with the rocks is wonderful. Knowing that it was built so long ago is amazing. similar but different from Angkor Wat--worth a visit.
Do not miss !. Stunning and well worth the time. There are thousands of picture opportunities here but it does get hot - take water or buy at one of the cafes outside the main gate

Amazing. We arrived in the low season, (June), really, really hot but the plus was there were not very many people climbing over the ruins which gave you time to take photos of this amazing place. Take plenty of water as you really need it.

Huge trees and roots. This is a lovely place and so unique. The way that the jungle has over run the temple is unbelievable. I couldn't figure out what these trees are? They called them "fig" but I am not sure.

My favourite. To think that this has been standing for 2000 years is beyond belief. The area is so serene an peaceful and is the only Wat where there were Monks blessing you and tying prayer bracelets on your wrist (all donations grateful)
Worth seeing. Apart from the Tomb Raider point of interest this temple was a little different... It also has shady spots which are welcome by the time you have done a few other temples

Tomb Raider. Tomb Raider, Indian Jones. Yep you feel like an explorer.
Simply amazing. Don't forget your camera.
Very atmospheric, even calming.
A must visit and one of the coolest places I have ever visited.
Picturesque. Another in a litany of amazing ruins, to view and wander around. The photo ops are amazing. Definitely one temple to not miss.

An amazing site.. If you are visiting Angkor Archaeological Park and you have limited time you must ensure this temple is on your list.
