This is the sight that those that remember the "Tomb Raider" film will recognise. There is a bit of restoration going on but this doesn't impact on the view. You get a real sense of how powerful nature is and it's easy to see how the jungle can soon overpower deserted buildings.You can make your own way there but it is worth hiring a tuk tuk driver (we did this through our hotel), for your time here as they can be really helpful in identifying the best bits to see. We would also advise reading up on the place before you go as this helps bring it to life. We went in May and it is very hot at this time of the year; you shouldn't let this put you off unless you have problems with heat. The plus side of this time of year is that the crowds are much smaller.

What a special place. Loved the setting and the fine examples of nature taking over this wonderful temple. Good to see some restoration work underway, although the heavily scafffolded structure and the noise of the dozens working did detract from the quiet ambience of Te Prohm on arrival, but there's plenty to explore out of ear and eye shot of the restoration work, and one has a real appreciation of the importance of restoration and preservation when viewing an area which has been successfully completed.
Go to Angkor wat but don't forget Ta Prohm. For me, it is the most interesting temple in Angkor area. Vegetation mixed with these stones charged of history, give a incredible and amazing feeling

Nature vs Man. I find this temple so romantic in a human way. It was man winning over nature, and eventually nature taking over this man-made temple. It is interesting to know that there should be a delicate balance on how to conserve this temple. This temple is known for its giant trees, that is slowly swallow up the temple itself. You'd have to be there to believe it.

Just call me Lara Croft - Tomb Raider. What a beautiful place. While I know it is necessary, they are restoring this temple so the scaffolding I saw in May 2015 took away from the beauty, although only slightly .
Like in the movie. Exceptional scenery of temples in the jungle. Despite the humidity and very hot temperatures, you forget about this discomfort and deep dive 1000 years in the past.

So cool. Seeing the temple they used in Lara Croft Very cool to see the different type of temples and to see how if built with lava stone the trees grow through them The history to each temple is amazing
Go at midday. Less crowds at midday and because much of this temple is in the forrest, there is some shade to keep you out of the sun. Less crowds outweighs the little bit of heat in my book.

Lots of Construction. This temple is really beautiful, but because it was the off season they were doing a lot of construction so about a third of it was not useful for photographs. It took away from the experience a bit and just wasn't as grand as the photos made it look. Still a cool thing to see, but if you have limited time I think Bayan and of course Angkor Wat are more worth the trip:)

Amazing. Tomb raider makes this place famous but it should be famous without the film as it is gorgeous. Nature and humanity intertwined. Cannot get better than this. Angkor Wat is the only place that rivals this temple.

More restrictions. Many parts are sealed off for the benefit for everyone. Collapsed tunnels, part of the site or walls unstable are closed down with ropes on stands. For the convenience of visitors there are wooden walkways built at some places. The patio where the tree overgrowing the building is having a pedestal with ropes hindering anyone attempting to clime up. Good! But the surface of the surroundings also have wooden walkways built around since my last visit 6 years ago.

Tomb Raider. I guess this is what it's become known for but outside of that there is alot to see here. I loved the sound of the works going on, and there is still a lot that is in ruins so a good chance for photo's, if ever i return i think i will go back and compare to see what has been changed

Tombraider. The conservation work is going on but still a very nice place to walk around, and honestly i liked the sound of the people working just listening to the hammers and stuff, felt like that may have been how it sounded when it was originally being built

The Tomb Raider Temple. This temple was abandoned for centuries. It is very interesting to this how the jungle has taken over its structures. Constructed in 1186 A.D. this temple alone used to be home to over 12,500 persons.You can visit it all day, because you can be in shaded areas. We were very lucky since an older men started pointing out to us the great photo opportunities…so I asked him to guide us, gave him $4US at the end. I know it was far too much, but our daughters thought it would make a huge difference for him and none in our lives.
awesome experience. Like all the temples in the area some are more unique than others. I suggest getting the 3 day pass and visit during the day when its cooler, sunrise and sunset

Beautiful, a must-see. The "Tomb Raider" temple is worth all the hype! Even with ongoing restoration, it's stunning. I went at 4PM and while there were still some people there it was not at all crowded and I was able to avoid the big tourist groups.

A must see. When I thought of what the temples of Angkor would be like this temple is what I expected. Although this temple is in pretty rough shape it has the growth intertwined with the structures that is both tearing them apart and in some cases holding them together. They've done a great job making the temple accessible. Beware, there will be a lot of tourists that seem to have a lot of trouble taking a picture and you will spend some time waiting to move along through the attraction.

Out of this world. Mystical, absolutely amazing temple - a must see on your visit to Angkor and definitely plan more time for this one. It's big and you would want to spend time around those trees covering the ruins, growing in between, on and around them... I felt like I was in a fairy tale, on another planet or in a dream! Could spend there the whole day to be honest, what an atmosphere! My number one favourite from our visit to Angkor!

On the trail of the Tomb Raider. Walking into Ta Prohm, I experienced something really surreal. These are the type of places that you see only in adventure movies and in fact Ta Prohm was the site of Angelina Jolie’s Tomb Raider. Being here for myself was really interesting as it felt exactly how it would in the movies. Mystical, surreal, a hint of danger even. But today, Ta Prohm is a major attraction on the Angkorian archielogical site.The temple felt like its wrapped in time. In ruins, trees and jungle have grown around it and the temple has somewhat merged with the jungle. Some of these trees are hundreds of years old and its roots and trunks wrapped around the temple structures, destroying them in slow-motion in the process.Located east of Angkor Thom (and not within Angkor Thom itself), the temple is incredibly popular due to the attention it received from the movie. Therefore, its best to plan your trip there earlier during the day or much later when crowd thins. Whatever you choose, don’t miss this temple. It’s incredibly beautiful and offers plenty of amazing Instagram opportunities! I’m glad I managed to see Ta Prohm in my time. There’s a massive conservation effort happening now to protect and rebuild Ta Prohm since Angkor is now a UNESCO Heritage Site. However, that would mean that the trees that are now part and parcel of this ancient ruin will be removed in order to protect the temple. Ta Prohm of course would be restored to its former glory, but the allure of being an ancient lost city would also disappear.I don’t know. To me, part of the allure of Ta Prohm are these trees. Giant roots holding giant statue heads was the quintessential imagery of Angkor. It’s no longer there, and soon all the roots will be removed as well. That’s why I think more than ever, you should go see Ta Prohm now.

Wonderful. There is nothing to dislike here. Originally and deliberately abandoned when other temples were undergoing preservation work, there is now some conservation underway. A good thing, as this place has it all, and is especially famous for its trees. Please visit, preferably early or late, as this is one of the most popular sites, and will feature on the itinerary of those with limited time.

Ignore the rennovation and make sure you see the restored area. Be prepared to see a lot of reconstruction when visiting the temple. It is still a beautiful temple with several trees roots entwining the stones. There will be crowds and try to avoid the weekends as busloads of Thai's visit. Parts of the temple have been restored and surprisingly few people seem to visit or their guide does not take them there. It is to your right if you are coming out of the temple or on your far left when entering. The Indian government helped restore this part of the temple. There is of course the mandatory Lara Croft tomb raiders picture stop where people patiently wait there turn to take a photo. Lots of spots to stop and just admire the stone carvings. Well worth a visit and try to go early or late afternoon when it is cooler.If you found the review useful I always appreciate a helpful vote.
Box-Office Worthy. The tree roots are literally taking over the ruins. Pictures will not capture the wonder of this temple. Its even more impressive than it appeared in the movie, Tomb Raider.

Loved it!. I have never seen so many faces on a temple in my life. It was cool to see the trees actually growing inside the temples and to see their gigantic roots. It was also cool to know that Tomb Raider was filmed here as well. A must see!

A rare temple partially covered with roots and the branches of a Giant Tree. I have visited many places having temples,but this one gets into my vision,and it keeps me seeing the view continuously.I understand that the temple remained unattended for few hundred years,and,lo,it made the Look ,a must watch and see.It looks next to impossible yo separate the Tree part from temple,has spread At many places as a huge creature.Great visit.must include in the itinerary.
Don't miss. An essential part of the Angkor 'brand.' You're already there, don't miss this fascinating temple. A magical place.

Great temple with a huge tree. Great temple with a huge trees. I really like this temple. I wonder the way that the trees have grown over the temple which I think that it could not help the weight of the trees.
Amazing. Very busy but it is a must to see maybe try to go in the morning as by the afternoon it is so busy and crowded .Do not need a guide very easy to walk around by yourself .

Another part of the tour Anker Wat . As is with the Rest of the tour another great temple with the trees growing in and over the walls these are all similar temples but all worth a visit as they are Fantastic
Magical and mystical. Made famous by the movie Tomb Raider, it was fascinating to wander through this temple. The trees have a life of their own and make everything look more mysterious.
Go early..... Avoid the crowds and start with this one. Lots of photo ops. To see this huge temple overtaken by ancient trees is a great reminder of the glory of Angkor and its history.

Best very very early. I went to Ta Prohm twice. Once in late morning or early afternoon. It was fairly crowded and there is so much construction going on, plus wooded "photo op" structures that it was difficult to enjoy and difficult to get good photos. I returned in early morning and it was much more pleasant, but not as thrilling as it was a few years ago.

Go early!. Very gorgeous as you can see how amazing nature is, it is a very mysterious and gorgeous temple. Make sure you go early! I would have had a much better experience if I was not there with all the crowd. Makes it difficult to navigate as it is a small area, I lost my friends multiple times.
Must See!. Beautiful! Make sure you go inside the temple to see the tree growing through the middle. This was one of my favorite temples!
Lovely but construction spoils visit. Saw the tree featured in movies but was roped off. Enjoyed visit but enjoyed other temples more as less crowded.

One not just for Angelina Jolie fans!. A weird and wonderful temple on the Ankor schedule. A little smaller but how they have let the fig trees grow around the walls makes it a very different experience

Way to many people!. Beautiful but, to many people almost Disney like!
Things are starting to get ruined here.Ive been coming for 7 yrs now.
So very fascinating!. The history of this place is amazing. Bring your camera and a sense of wonder. Also, visit in the afternoon or morning to avoid the heat of midday.

Nature can create new surroundings. Impressive the power of nature throughout the centuries. One feels so small in such surroundings and congratulations to the Siem Reap conservation team for what they have done after the dark years of the Khmer Rouge.
Highly suggest you take time to learn about the Khmer Rouge and their atrocities.

The Lara Croft connect is not the coolest thing about it!. Ta Prohm gives you the feel of walking into ancient ruins. A little more slept in than the rest almost? you can really imagine the splendor that was. overgrown trees and large rocks being left as they were adds to the appeal. some restoration work is underway and that seems a dampener. Go really early because the crowds love this one!

Interesting trees and temples. This temple was very different from the rest. What makes it unique is the way the roots of the big trees seem to engulf the entire temple such that they become part of the architecture. The trees provide shade and reprive from the sun so that's a plus point. Simply gorgeous!
Great for Sunset. Avoiding the crowds at most other temples, this is wonderful for viewing the sunset. Not much else to say (but have to fill the 100 character minimum)
Amazing. Loved how the roots have taken over over the ruins of the temple. This was definitely the highlight of my trip to Siem Reap and the temples.

Mysterious temple. This is one of the most interesting site besides Angkor Wat & Bayon Temple. I love the feeling standing alone among the ruins and seeing how great the nature did with the temples. The trees are even more stunning than what I saw in brochure or Internet.
Ta Prohm. Loved the trees and the way they have infiltrated the buildings. The size of some of the roots were amazing. Had a guide to talk about the history.

Amazing!. More than the structure and the architecture, what amazed me here is the fact that the temple got lost under jungle. Its just amazing to see how nature can hides something in its abode... it was a thought provoking, amazing experience!

Amazing. How the forest as over taken this smaller temple tress growing round it and inside abit couldn't take my eyes off it I was that impressed but by this time I had to leave as was getting Into mid afternoon in april and bin on the go since 5.30am 3rd and final temple of the day still thinking about how them tress have grown round the temple just mesmerising
Must See Temple. This is a must see Temple in the Siem Reap complex! Worth the walk with many good picture taking opportunities...

Short route. Select short route instead of the long route if you want to see this tree attached to the wall. Though the long route has structures the one has to see. So why not pass through both routes, not a tiring, long walk if you do both.

Ta Prohm temple. one of the most exciting parts of the temple toursliked the way the temple has not been restored and less people visiting itdo not go to Siem Reap without taking time to visit this site
A unique temple. A unique mix of how trees have taken over a what was a proud temple left alone for 500 years - nowhere else in the world would I expect to see such a sight!
Ta prohm walking. Overgrown and not many people there. Best temple we visited as shaded. We took bicycles which was hot but a good idea

Astonishing proof that however great man-made things, the mother nature will always reclaim it. Ta Prohm is one of the most famous sites after Angkor and Bayon in Angkor and it has the reason to be that famous. At Ta Prohm, you will witness the greatness of nature vs the achievement of once a greatest civilization in history. The place can be a bit crowded with many tourists but still you can't miss this place when you are there in Angkor. More about visiting Angkor temples, you can check out @ http://www.heypt.com/#!Visiting-Siem-Reap-Angkor-Wat-Other-Temples-in-Angkor-Region/c1kiu/55688e3d0cf2adc1ad677703
Nature strikes. Just amazing to see the trees encroaching the temple. Gives a completely different feeling unlike other architectures.

Trees!!!. The best part of this temple is the trees that have grown up into and around the walls, gives it a distinct look that its in the jungle. I had a tour guide while there and it was great hearing all about what was being fixed and by which countries. I didn't care about the Tomb Raider stuff but he told us about that too.great stop on the list of great places here.

The most photogenic of the Angkor sites. This is the place most of us have seen in many pictures - and it doesn't disappoint. In truth, this place feels more Indiana Jones than Tomb Raider , quietly hidden in the jungle. Our guide took ushere very early after it opened, claiming that most tour groups visited later in the day so it would be quieter. This certainly proved to be the case and the site was beginning to become crowded as we were leaving.. A magical place, definitely one to tick off the bucket list !

Awesome. Of all the temples this was my favourite. Left in the state it was discovered in apart from some safety measures, gives you a true understanding of how the whole park must have looked when it was discovered. Absolutelty fascinating. Try to latch on to anguiide for more facts and titbits, or take your own guide to get the most out of it. Interior can get crowded mid day so go early if you can.

The nature comes back. The templeitself is not more impressive than many others in the area. What makes this temple so special is thestrenght of the vegetation that is coming back and taking possession of the carved stones.

Too many conservation works. The conservation works did close most of the temple area. I'm a bit dissapointed. But surely next time i will be there again. Eventhough most of the areas are closed, you can still enjoy the ruins. The tree form are stunning.

Awesome. I am sure that for may, the first introduction to the treasures of Angkor seem to be the most impressive and live longest in the memory. For us, our guide took us first to Ta Prohm and, even after you have seen the pictures in the holiday brochures or seen them in the film Tomb Raider, this place was awesome and our best memory of the entire site. The old trees that were allowed to wind their trunks and roots around the temple buildings lend the whole place a romantic and 'hidden garden' aura. If you can stretch to it, go with a personal guide - they are full of knowledge about each of the sites and, equally, important know when is the best time of day to go to avoid the heat and the crowds. And give yourself time at each of the sites - it is more rewarding and less of a blur thatn if you try to do everything in one long day's trip. Fabulous.

The Strangling Fig Trees. You cannot but be over-awed by the way the tree roots have grown in and out, over and around structures as well as between the sandstone slabs. It gives the sense of another world, or indeed, another planet! An amount of conservation projects have/and are taking place to persevere these treasures. An amazing experience!

Romantic. Te encroaching trees here could have been cut down to create a vision of ruins similar to the other great Angkor monuments. The French archeologists, though, liked the romantic feel they evoked and so they've stayed. The site is one of the most easily identifiable because of its role in "Tomb Raider."
big site but not much to see. big temple complex but not much to see except for the bas reliefs. it does get repetitive once you go through the whole site starting from Angkor Wat etc.
Fabulous. It just goes deep in you you feel engulfed by the whole atmosphere ! It is just awesome.and moving.m

The best inside the way. This place is inside Angkor Watt, those threes grown up over the buildings, including that you can get on the house trough the roots. I friend of mine went there, but didn't see this "checkpoint"... don't forget it!!

mistery in the jungle. This place looks like Indiana Jones' movie set with big roots that entangle the ruins of the temple. And there is a surprise: on a wall there is the picture of a stegosaurus, an incredible oopart!
Tombraider set. This is as it is,,,, its like you have just found it, a wonderful photo experience although it can become crowded

Tomb Raider Experience. Its was a different kind of experience to see the huge white trees that I think was already there for centuries. Be ready with your comfortable shoes because you need to walk for i think a mile because the location of the tomb raider was on the farthest side of the Ta Prohm.

Very nice. Not too far from Angkor Thom, It's very nice, you should go there.
I think It's one of best ruin in over the world.

Very Atmospheric. Ta Phohm is indeed a very nice temple to visit. Most of the buildings have crumbled and are in ruins, but this is what gave the temple it's beauty. It was built by Jayavarman VII for his mother, and that adds on to my interest in this templeI was most taken by the huge Kapok trees that have taken over some parts of the temple wall and buildings, The tree roots are so huge, and the purge on the walls, as if saying that nature still triumphs over time. The trees are witnesses to what the temple was like in it's hey days, as well as the years after. Another must see, amongst the temples.

Not like what it used to be due to insane amount of tourist & conversation work. I came here in 2005 to visit Ta Prohm and it was probably one of the most breathtaking experience of my life, finding the place mostly untouched and left to live on its own, even at the cost of letting some trees crush the stones & even fall. There were only a few tourists back then, and the main gardian of the temple was an old man who swiped the floors and alleys of the place and was on the cover of Lonely Planet's Cambodia guidebook.10 years later, Ta Prohm has become one of the 3 major temples to visit in the area, and as such it is pack full of tourists, and conservation works are seen everywhere to keep it safe & keep it as much as it used to be. Needless to say it doesn't look quite as genuine and untouched as 10 years ago, and the tour felt less impressive. Go to Preah Khan if you want to see what Ta Prohm felt like when there weren't nearly as many tourists & conservation work (added wood beams, wood stairs, etc).

Fantastic. This was definitely our favourite ruins site - it has such a wonderful atmosphere. I suggest going later in the day as it enhances the atmosphere. There are some great photo opportunities but unfortunately there was a lot of restoration work going on when we visited - hopefully this is just to prevent further decay rather than to change anything structural

Simply Amazing. Hint for here is go after 10 am by then some of the crowds are starting to move on. But you must spent time and if possible talk to the locals who are happy to talk. Watch out for the young kids trying to sell postcards who be "trying".

Get there early. On our trip of a bazillion temples that we did while in Cambodia this was one that we couldn't miss. Because = Hollywood obviously. (Although someone in our tour thought it was the Indiana Jones temple which would have been even more amazing. Anyway) This temple is incredible and to see the way nature has immersed itself in and around a manmade structure is incredible.Saying that - if you want to pose near the iconic tree that is features in the film expect to queue. We waited there for fifteen minutes which isn't long at all but we were in the low travel season so prepare to line up during peak times.

Go before it's too late.. This place is stunning. By far the most beautiful site I've seen in Siem Reap, it pushes your imagination and adventurer's spirit. But, unfortunately it wont be this way for long. Trees are now being removed by the Cambodian government to "sturdy" the structures; haphazardly. Go before it's too late.

Unbelievable. Omg it was just like you see in a book, movie or catalogue !! Blown away, I was so excited to go and wasn't let down. We went at 8am before there was too many tourist and got great photos with no one in them .

WAHT AN ARCHITECUTE. Pl. do not miss this wat as you will find lots of architectural beauty .This wat was built when civil engineering science was in primitive stage .
Visit and ENJOY

Angelina Chose a great movie for her temple. This temple is close to Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. The 3 of them can easily be done in one day. The temple is pretty nice, it was used in the movie Tomb Raider. It has large trees growing attached to the temple buildings. You should not miss it.

Incredible !!. You truly get absorbed by Ta Prohm.
It is easy to see why it was used for Tomb Raider.
You can wander around for ages.
As always getting there early is better. It gets busy fast.

Stunning place.... Wow!!! what a unique temple the tree roots that are growing through the stone temple are just amazing... you feel like your in a different world... definitely don't miss this one... Enjoy my friends :-)

Best temple in Angkor I've seen. I liked this temple better than all the other ones. Because of the vegetation all over the place, this place feels a bit mysterious. If you're going to visit some temples, make sure you don't skip this one!

Absolutely Amazing. Pictures don't do justice as to how amazing it is to see how these huge trees have grown in and around the ruins of Ta Prohm. It shows the power of nature and how amazing nature can be. Totally worth seeing.
Lara Croft Temple!. interesting but in more more disarray than the other temples visited. Good to see the 'famous' tree roots intertwined around the stones.

Ta Prohm's state of ruin is a state of beauty. Ta Prohm's state of ruin is a state of beauty, which is investigated with delight and left with regret.
Ta Prohm is locating southwest of the East Mebon and east of Angkor Thom. Its outer enclosure is near the corner of Banteay Kdei. It can be accessed by enter the monument from the west and leave from the east entrance.

Phenomenal. Ta Prohm gets a lot of visitors based on the Tomb Raider movie... So keep that in mind. Trees are growing through the architecture of this temple, and it's beautiful. Definitely a must see while in the area touring! Take a guide so he can show you the face hidden in the tree roots!

The Tomb Raider Temple. Beside the Bayon Ta Prohm is definitely the nicest temple in the Angkor Park. Ta Prohm is kept in a more "natural" state than most temples. On my first visit in 2011 it was overgrown with silk cotton trees. Although many trees were removed now to reduce damage to the site there are still some very impressive ones left. The two most picturesque ones could be also admired in the film Tomb Raider with Angelina Jolie. However you must be very lucky to get a decent picture there because they are crowded with people taking selfles. Ta Prohm was originally a monastery and is surrounded by a square wall. It has two gates, a west and east gate. From the gates to the temple/monastery you still have a walk of roughly 300 meters through dense forest. Tip for photographers: Visit either very early in the morning or lat afternoon. With a bit of "patience" you can manage to take pictures without thousands of tourists in it.

Our favourite temple at Angkor. We visited Ta Prohm very early morning and had the whole site to ourselves. It was before the heat of the day really hit and it definitely made for a true 'Indiana Jones' experience. Nature has truly taken parts of this temple back in a beautiful display of power. The size of some of the trees growing through the ruins needs to be seen to be believed. Some of the roots are so huge they now require scaffolding.There are numerous piles of rubble and doorways leading here, there and everywhere. No health and safety! A wonderful and authentic experience without the hordes tourists at Angkor Wat (because we were there not long after dawn.)Not only is the temple the famous 'Tomb Raider' temple, where Angelina Jolie filmed for three months, this temple is also the site for the famous 'dinosaur' carving. It looks like a stegosaurus, but obviously at that time, no one would of known about dinosaurs, or what stegosaurus' particularly looked like. Enough to send chills when you see it! There are many theories that the animal is a hippo or a rhino and the plates behind are decoration, however you need to see it for yourself. There are websites that help you find its exact location, but luckily a local asked us if we needed help and we asked about it. He was happy to help and also pointed out a few other places of interest on the way, as it was only round the corner from where we were. We gave him 2 dollars for his time and he was over the moon.A must if visiting Angkor!

Kingdom of tree temple. The beauty of this temple is big trees crowning the temple. The greenery add more beauty to Ta Prom. Love this place. It is great to visit after lunch cos there plenty of shadow. Not too hot for you!

Nature in Architecture. The Sung trees are phenomenal and the way nature is entwined with the temples makes this very atmospheric. However, it is always busy even in dry season but I guess that is the power of Tomb Raider (and Hollywood)....

Witness the power of nature. Ta Prohm, the Tomb Raider temple with the trees growing out of it, was my favourite temple at Angkor. It’s a great illustration of the power of nature and what would happen to a lot of buildings if left untouched by mankind. A lot of the temple has been reduced to piles of rubble and visitors are generally allowed to roam all over it.

A fascinating experience. I loved seeing all of the temples in and around Angkor Wat. It is an unbelievable experience that everyone should see at least once in their life. The heat can really get to you so if possible, try and go at a time of the year that it is not so hot. This will slow you down!

Bit noisy, but awesome. The day before we went there was a massive storm which knocked over some trees, unfortunately one was in this temple. This meant that the whole time we were there we could hear a chainsaw cutting up wood, which ruined it a little bit. But besides that it was awesome. Definitely worth a visit to this jungle temple.
Very impressive temple area. Ta Prohm is an impressive temple area and very different from the other ones because of the roots. Definitely worth a visit.

Easily one of the more distinguishable temples in the park. The huge tree roots hugging the temples are perhaps the main draw of Ta Prohm, especially the one which appears in the Tomb Raider movie. There are lots of picturesque areas as well. This temple is easily very distinguishable from the other temples. If you have a short time only, try to visit this and the surrounding Angkor Thom area.

Overcrowded but beautiful. Do not go here mid morning. We got there at about 10am just after Angkor Wat and the place was teaming with bus loads of Chinese tourists. These kinds of tourists are absolutely horrendous, very loud and rude, (and disgusting at times, spitting right in front of us) and they all want a photo of just themselves at each tree. We managed to miss these tourists everywhere else but here unfortunately.Chinese tourists aside, ta prohm is very picturesque and would be awesome without the hordes. I hear late afternoon is a good time as everyone flocks for a view of Angkor Wat at sunset.

Hollywood. Affectionately called 'The Tomb Raider Temple'. Suffice to say that it is self-explanatory. But the magnificence of the ruins and trees that have majestically grown around them is a sight to witness. Currently a part of the temple is under restoration.

Do not miss this one either!. Loved this temple! Great photo ops! The trees over all the walls were neat to see. Not as good for carving photos but get photos of habitat and the nature taking over. Definitely see this one too!
All Watted Out. After visiting Wat Thom and Angkor Wat this was just to much to take in on a weeks stay in Siem Reap. Good if you are really into temples.

Very atmospheric. This was also a highlight of the temples, although it was so crowded it still seemed to have the most serene atmosphere. Those massive overgrown tree roots growing atop the temples are so beautiful.

Do this temple late afternoon. Visit this temple late afternoon and you will have way less people giving you a better opportunity to take exceptional photos. Put this temple on your list..you will not be disappointed

Why visit Ta Prohm. We visited Ta Prohm on the same day we visited Angkor Wat. It is a very unique place, with these amazing trees that are now part of the temples. I definitely think its good to do BUT: there are usually lots of tourists and (assuming you are with a guide) you will be running around in the sequence of visitors that fills the temple. This takes something out of the experience. Also be advised that during busy season, it can be VERY bad and try to find times to avoid crowds (ask your guide on advice). Siem Riep is getting very touristic and unless you visit when the weather is very hot, you need to be smart regarding your visits.

Nature over man. Ta prohm is an excellent example of nature getting back at man. Many parts of the temple are covered with large soft wood trees whose roots have outgrown the temple walls and towers. It is said that Ta Prohm was build by the king for his mother as a sanctuary. Many parts of the temple were in dilapidated condition. Now, Govt. of India and Cambodia are collaborating to restore the temple to its original glory.Tomb Raider movie was shot in this temple and there are lot of spots where you can take amazing photos.Must visit for all Angelina Jolie fans!
Amazingly beautiful. Literally the best temple of all in Siem Reap.Huge trees surrounding the temple and they were so mind blowing! A must visit place

Tomb Raider. This is where it was filmed. Excellent site and it has these amazing trees that are growing around the ruins. It is quite mysterious and amazing. The history is fascinating and you are standing in ruins that date back hundreds and hundreds of years. Well worth the visit.

Experience not to be missed. A place must visit when in Siem Reap. It is probably the only place in the world, you can see a whole big tree growing in the temple where the roots are protecting the temple from the outside. It's an experience not to be missed.

Straight out of Tomb Raider. This temple has been left in the undergrowth for centuries and now it is reclaimed you can see how the trees have grown over and on top of the temple area. It is a fascinating place with crumbling walls and nooks and crannies that you have to explore.It can get very hot and humid there so bear that in mind when you go.

Trees growing on the temple roof!. Another remarkable temple in the Angkor area. Famed for the trees on the roofs of the temple, the roots cascade down to ground level. There are several of these trees, anything up to 300 years old. Another mixture of Hindu and Buddhist religions, the temple has had some renovations done - initially by the French colonialists - but all in all, there are a number of very unstable areas. Go into the Echo Chamber, thump your chest, and listen for the echo! Erie, to say the least! Apparently the Echo Chamber was built to relieve stress!Our guide informed us the trees, most very tall, are 'Spung' trees, although we were also informed that the trees are strangler figs. There are also the famed banyan trees in the temple.Certainly an excellent temple to visit. Beware: there are masses of visitors, so there's plenty of folk getting in the way of photographs!.
Took me back to the Lara Croft days. Excellent site. Although the trees that are slowly ruining the site appears to have increased it still has its charm and mysteriousness.

Lara Croft: Tomb Raider Tempel :). The way how trees are intersecting and growing over the monuments is amazing and first time ever to see such place! There is a sense of mysterious and majestic atmosphere in this temple.

Historical Wonder. Known by many of the locals as Tomb Raider (as it was used for shooting scenes from the movie), the site has an incredible feel to it. Even though you may have many tourists around you, it fells completely serene & peaceful. Find a spot and just sit and soak in the history.

Looking for Lara Craft!. In my opinion, the best temple in Cambodia! A lot of interesting structures and great views. And, of course, the place where you can feel like you are in the Tomb Rider movie.
Magical. This place is amazing, go before sunrise and you might be lucky enough to be the only people there, much more atmospheric.

Go Early!. We visited once around 11AM and it was packed, I was literally being pushed around by other tourists at times. We went back this morning and were there by 5AM and we had the whole place to ourselves, there was not a single other person there. In fact, we beat the guards there. We got the most beautiful photos and saw things we completely missed the first time around.If you don't have a guide, I recommend taking a book about the temples with you, it can get really boring if you don't know what you're looking at. I used The Treasures of Angkor by Marilia Albanese, but people sell guidebooks everywhere you look for $1-3.

Fantastic place.. Fantastic place to see. This old temple has lots of ancient character and was used in the Tomb Raider films and then the penny dropped as to why the films main star has an interest in cambodia and has adopted from here, der and dribble. But all good to see. We went with out great guide Tep Nat $35 for the day, tep_nat_2007@yahoo.com, would recommend. In high season, he gets booked out. In low season you should have the pick of days like we did, we went in May2015. This temple was the 2nd temple of the day itinerary Tep had for us. See my Angkor Wat review for more info and tips. Good to see this, glad I did, do it.
Incredible experience. Not only an amazing temple - but the trees! Probably my favorite temple of a 30 day trip through SE Asia.

Lost in another world. Definitely the highlight of Siem Reap! We just loved Ta Prohm as it offers countless photographic opportunities shared equally by local activities and the stunning structures. A photographer's dream! What an amazing place to visit! No wonder they have used this area for the Tomb Raider movie. While we were there, it started to rain and the weather gave the ruins an eerie atmosphere. That first glance of a giant tree root growing over the ruins, doors and buildings creates an incomprehensible sense of lost time world and the insignificance of us mortals. Absolutely surreal! Some ruins have been forced apart and are still in the process of getting dismantled. One can only imagine what it must have looked like when first rediscovered by outsiders. Mother nature emphasized here that time is a human concept. Ta Prohm was our favourite attraction and we were so fortunate to be part of "The Lost City".

Nature taking over. One of the best places to see nature reclaiming its land. Its a beautiful temple. Beaware there are places that can be mildly unsteady with plenty of rocks n stones from the temple. There is restoration work occuring atm so you wont be able to visit parts

Special. . Loved this temple. Work was actively going on to reconstruct areas of the temple so I was unable to see all of it. What I did see was good. The trees growing through are incredible. Usually work would put me off however they had evidence of it before and after. What they have done is nicer than piles of stones scattered around the floor.

i loved it, found it better than angkhor wat. Well, this was definitely the highlight of the temple excursions we ventured when in siem reap. the place was literally empty when we went there, giving it a spooky quality. looking at nature ravage a temple was eerie at best. that said there was a hauntingly beautiful quality to it.
I liked it. This were my favourite of the day - naturally it felt very videogame like, hence why is was used in Laura Croft! Lovely how nature has started to reclaim it

Super Crowded. They say this is the Laura Croft - Tomb Raider movie temple ruins. Based on the huge crowds, it must be the most popular ruin.It is worth the visit because it has many large trees growing in the walls and they are very picturesque, even if the tree roots are destroying everything.This temple has restrooms but almost all of them require a payment. I recall it is 1,000 of the currency which is about $0.12. So we almost never had bills that small and they never give change. It became quite annoying.

Beautiful but.... I loved this place. We were lucky that it was not too crowded until we neared the end of our visit. But sadly certain tourists who arrive by the coach load really do need to learn some respect for these amazing places. We saw countless incidents of them climbing over barriers and ignoring signs and the noise that accompanied them drowned out the jungle. I think the thing that annoyed me the most was the thousands of little sweet wrappers, again the majority from a certain country all over the floor and the little Cambodian children calling for you to give them sweets. Why on earth would you bring sweets to give to small children who have no access to dental care. Please just think a bit before doing this. Our guide told us cavaties in youngsters are of epidemic proportions because of this habit.

My favourite temple here.. This is by far the most interesting temple in this place I think. It is all on one level and is being taken over by the jungle slowly. There are a lot of trees growing out of the middle of the ruins which makes for some really picturesque views, it is beautiful. This temple was also the place for some of the scenes from the movie Tomb Raider, so you might recognize some of the locations. Restoration work was going on at the time, so there was a crane on site which ruins a bit of the atmosphere, but you can't really blame them for that.I would easily go back here. I Recommend getting a three day ticket for 40$ so can see most of the stuff.

By far our favourite. This temple, used as a setting in the Tomb Raider movie was absolutely spectacular. It has been overtaken by the Spung Tree creating a magical combination of the temple and trees. Highly recommended for a visit!

Tomb Raider - Under Construction. Lots of the site is under construction and not viewable. They've built wood pathways and decks around the famous sites which I think takes away from the "exotic" or wildness you expect to experience.
With that said.. it's still amazing, and must see if you're visiting Angkor!
Lots of restoration going on. But don't let that put you off, it's well worth the visit, take your time look around read the information
Just amazing. Jungle Temple with the fig tree branches and roots intertwined to form a roof over the structure. I would recommend this trip as it is just so amazing and worth the walk.

Best temple in siem reap. Just wow, don't look at the photos just come here its incredible, we went twice for 2 and 3 hours each time.
The tree everyone wants to see is on the right hand side from the main entrance, it took us a while to find it.
Love it

Fantastic - A must see. I very much enjoyed the visit to Ta Prohm, I visited in the evening just before the sun went down and it had a magical feel to it with the trees growing over the ruins and the combination of the light and shade. It's a shame that the restoration is not keeping up with the decay of the place. Some of the fallen stones are awesome and it would be nice to see them back in place. Its a much smaller site than Angkor Thom but it has an appeal all of its own.

So Wonderful Temples. Ta Prohm temple is very green and attractive. Big, big trees add up the beauty of the temple. You can visit here just before or after lunch time as there are plenty of shadow.I love this place very much. It is one of the most beautiful temple. A must visit temple if you are in Angkor, Cambodia!
Wow... If you've never been to Cambodia and only watched tomb raider as a reference, Ta Prohm is perfect for you! To be seen of course!

My favourite temple. This one was my favourite, by far! The history signposts and how far the conservation work has come is amazing, seeing trees vs stone! If you can only see two, see this and Angkor wat
natural power in this temple. In Ta Prohm , you will see giant trees growing all around the temple. This is an amazing place ,nothing more to say .Come to there to feel it.

Ta Phrom or aka-Tomb Raider Temple. This is a beautiful temple to visit as it indicates how nature/jungle has tried to reclaim the temples that have been forgotten in time.Without to much description Ta Phrom is a must visit as is many temples in Siem Reap.A organised tour with a guide is a MUST we used we had a excellent & best english (American accent) guide- Vannak (vannakguide@gmail.com), extremely knowledged.This tour was organised thru (the best) Odyssey Indochina Tours with a air conditioned car driver and guide.

Mesmerizing. Wondering how the tree got roots and how the temple was built.
Simply amazing experience. Also, was excited to see the movie shooting spot :D Tomb Raider.

Amazing. Just like a post card. The views were breathtaking. The trees growing on top of the ruins were just as we had pictured. Hard to believe that the were built centuries ago and the carvings were amazing. To marine a stoa son doing that kind of work defies belief.
My favorite. We went here first and loved it. It was so cool, and wasn't nearly so hot as the other temples because it was shaded.

A must see. I really enjoyed this temple and it's really worth seeingEasy to get around and we spent around 2 hours which was sufficientThe guide helped us out by starting at the front and when we were done getting the driver to collect us from the back entrance. Saved lots of time and got us out of the heat quicker which was terrific. By leaving. The back way we were able to go through the back of Angkor thom and stop and see the terrace of the elephants as well in the one tripMake the effort you will enjoy it

My favourite!. Skip seeing Angkor Wat at sunrise and go straight to Ta Prohm. This way you will get it without all the visitors that are there for the rest of the day, since this is one of the major attractions. Seeing it in the morning with the mist makes it magical and mysterious!

Stunning. It was amazing, i loved walking around the temple and seeing how nature has claimed back temple, but you can also see at the restoration work talking place, but in keeping with its surrounding. Loved walking around, found it peaceful, even with all the tour groups.

the tomb raider temple. walk along the wall on the jungle path( do not stray off the path due to land mines!) and enter through the North gate and proceed through the trees growing through the buildings for the obligatory tomb raider shot. an amazing place.
Tomb Raider Fun!. Incredible photo opportunities - make two visits. One to take it all in and another to get creative with your camera. It's totally worth it.

Fantastic. Enjoyed very much. To see the trees envelope the temple is amazing. I went after see Amgkor Wat and the sunrise. It was crowded. My advice is after sun rise go here first. It will be less crowded. Then do AngkorThom followed by Angkor Watt. You going against the tour crowd.

Last one to be seen on day one. Sadly it was very very busy , think it'd be magic earlier or later in the day when less people around .Thankfully the guide helps to make the most of it . Amazing how the jungle is striking back and the huge trees are taking over

The tree!. I will not forget this temple because this is where I first saw a huge tree that grew on top of a portion of the temple. If i remember right, this is also one of the places where Tomb Raider was filmed. Beautiful tree!! people took turns taking pictures with it.
A ride back in time. Those huge trees that obducted Ta Prohm are an instant ride back in time and...fairy tales. Beside losing the time perspective we lost a little bit the orientation in space?!

Nice but crowed. We went there around10am, and that was crowd!!! If could respect a bit of calm and silence it would have been so better... But even guides are screaming and talking loud so not good example...
Anyway inside is beautiful when trees meet stone and buildings!!!
Woaho!!

Back in Time. We really enjoyed Ta Prohm, which stands out a bit more from the other temples because so many of the buildings have been "reclaimed" by the trees. I truly felt we were in a different world. It also reminded me a bit of the Disney movie Junglebook, where the Orangutangs live (but I believe that is sri lanka). We went with a guide which I would recommend, as you get more information and stories than you might if you just "read up" on the area. It is incredible to me that these structures are still standing, completely exposed and with a healthy tourism business, when we cant get buildings that last 50 years these days.

Temple in Ruins, but being repaired. Even while workers are putting this temple back to it's original state (block by block) visiters are still able to walk through it. Workers in thongs or bare foot work beside you, supports hold the temple together over the top of you as you walk into every part of the construction. The giant figs are part of the beauty which hold the temple together.
Amazing. This place is truly Fantastic and should be on everybodys bucket list. Again get a registered tour guide to give you all the history behind it..

Beautiful and breathtaking, the trees are magical, the carvings. magnificient. This place is well worth a visit, quiet, cool and peaceful. You must see it to understand the beauty and energy of the trees, original carvings and sense of stepping back into time.

Wow!. Went in May , very hot & crowded. Loved seeing all the humongous roots everywhere! The buildings with its cravings were amazing . Take your time and get different angles for your pics and views . One negative drawback are the vendors waiting to pounce on your at every turn. Also not recommend for kids under 7 .
Amazingly beautiful. Amazing how nature is taking back from the temples, the jungle is growing on and between the walls of the temples. This is quiet unbelievable and a challenge for photographers.
Stunning!!. This is the best attraction at Angkor Wat. The way the forest has grown over the structures is eerie. Don't miss it.

Original one. This one is the most original one and for that it's the most outworn. But you can still see the natural beauty of the trees growing in the stone and for that reason is the one that i liked the most in Angkor.
Serenity. This is a must see before Angkor Wat. The faces on the towers is unbelievable. This place is not nearly as crowded as Angkor Wat.

ANGELINA Jolie was here....so was I. When I went, there were lots of ruins on the ground. Some restoration is underway. Great experience to see the merger between great ancient architecture and nature at its extreme. This place is a highly recommended visit if you are in Siem Reap. Give yourself 1-1.5h to explore the site. There will be lots of walking, so be sure to wear comfortable shoes and if you are here in May which is a very hot month, be sure to wear light clothing and put on a hat.
Another great temple!. The trees are very impressive. And if you do the long walk, you can avoide the crowds and enjoy the peace and quietness!

Love the huge tree. This place have a lot of huge tree dominating the ruins. It is recommended that you go here in low season since too many tourist around this site can screw up the magical and mystical feeling of this site.

An amazing temple overgrown by a more amazing tree!. If you want to see what nature can do after some time this is a great temple. To see such a large tree and how it has come up through the temple is like nothing I had seen anywhere else. This temple does get crowded so plan your visit at an earlier time. There are lots of steps and turns so you must be able to walk. We were told this was where Tomb Raider was filmed.

Very fascinating place. If you are into A. Jolie and her famous "Tomb Raider" movie, then this place is a must as some of the film was made here. Pretty neat! We liked the root systems of century old trees , wrapping around the ancient ruins. Awesome and unique. This place is very close to ANGKOR WAT And must be included. A three day package for USD$ 40 per person will allow for visits to many temples in the area. It is well worth it. We suggest to hire a private car and guide----- not very expensive. The guide is very helpful in walking around the temples, especially for older couples.

I expected to see lara croft. As with all of the Ankor temples i was pretty amazed. This site is so huge. While europe was struggling to emerge from the dark ages ankor and its associated temples was a city of a million people.The roots from strangler figs made this temple look like the set that was used in the lara croft tomb raider movie. It's a must see if you want to prioritise which of the nearly 600 documented temples you want to visit.A must see.
Special. This temple had a unique charm due to the way in which, over the centuries, the buildings have become entwined with various trees.

One of the most visited temples in area with magnificent trees taking over the buildings. if you want to avoid crowds of people near the building where Lara Croft was filmed - walk around and will see even more beautiful and impressive trees, quite tranquil and peaceful places around.All in all - would definitely recommend going there!

Awesome temple. Crowded during peak season but you could still find a quieter corner. Yes, touristy due to Tomb Raider but still a must see made more atmospheric by the roots growing through the temple.

One of the most memorable temples we visited. Yes it can be a bit crowded at times, but don't let that spoil your visit. This is a beautiful temple, where the man-made meets mother nature. Definitely go and visit this very individual temple!

Incredible big trees are around this place. Some buildings are covered by very big roots. Sure, you will enjoy those trees and ruins which have to remind yourself that there are many places waiting your visit.

Ta Prohm. They are in the middle of renovations to this temple, which at the front makes it seem like a construction site. But at the back is the most glorious buildings, carvings and trees. This to me, with Bayon and Angkor Wat are the 3 temples not to miss.

James Bun. Remember Indiana Jones and the wonderful tropical jungles of the film set? Get a real experience of this in the Tahrom territory. Over many years birds planted seeds among the ancient stones of the temples and worked with nature to swallow up the work of man. Many huge trees are still strangling the man made temples, dwarfing the magnificent doorways and balustrades with their mighty roots and trunks. Walking through the jungle to this ruin made us feel like the first explorers to visit the Angkor temples complex which have lay I disturbed for a few hundred years! We did love the Sounds of the birds singing and the quiet atmosphere !

Could be magical. We visited at sunrise to avoid the crowds. It was great to have the place totally to ourselves and hear the birds. There is a lot of reservation going on so some areas are basically a building site at the moment. Such a shame as they have also cut down some of the beautiful giant trees. I can understand the need for preservation but its spoiling the magic. Having a se unity guard walking around with his radio blaring pop music spoiled the atmosphere somewhat. Listening only to the birds would have been preferable. I found it disrespectful. Go and enjoy it before they spoil it too much.
The strenght of nature!!!!. It's magic! How powerful are those roots...human being is so insignificant when you compare with nature. If you want a picture without tourists go early.

Highlight of our visit to Siem Reap. This magical temple looks as though the jungle is closing in. An amazing place and, in our view, far more spectacular than Ankor Wat.But you need to be there very early, at daybreak, to see the temple at its surreal best and to avoid the crowds. This was the highlight of our visit to Siem Reap.

Tomb raider temple. Very popular considering that it's not very big and has had poor reconstruction and not in as good shape tje majority of the other temples. Mainly a bit of a tourist trap due to the tomb raider film. Awesome foliage and obviously the trees growing around the temple. There are no toilets here, but there are drinks available.

Return of Tomb Raider. This was the third Temple my wife, daughter Emma, her boyfriend and I visited during our stay in Siem Reap, Cambodia. It was great to get up close near the many areas of the Temple famous for its part in the Movie 'The Tomb Raider', remembering the action from the movie seeing the many ancient trees now overrunning the building making it a very amazing spectacle. Glad to have visited and got some great photos.

The jungle temple. A much beloved-and-visited temple by the tourists.It is left in a seemingly neglected, unrestored state, but believe me, behind this look is a lot of very carefully executed restoration of the Indians and Cambodians. I have to put down my hat before them, since you still have the feeling (minus crowd, wooden platforms and ropes), that you’re an explorer, finding this unknown temple in the middle of the jungle.When I’m thinking what can I advice you not to miss, I’m quite puzzled.Every single stone, bas-reliefs and overgrown tree were dear to me.Maybe watch for the tympanum above the northeast entrance , where is an image of goddess Prajnaparamita modelled on the king's mother. Don’t expect an image as good as the Buddha faces in Bayon and other temples.They mostly left the trees and their roots seemingly untouched, and the effect is striking. Good example is the strangulating root formation inside at the easternmost gopura (entrance pavilion)It is pointless to mention all of this symbiosis of vegetation and old temples, because you can find plenty of them, no one of them is more striking than the other one. We walked around the north satelite temple ,dedicated to Jayakirtideva, the elder brother of Jayavarman VII, who obviously was a good family man. It is a bit out of the main stream, but worth to see, since it is very charming.Unfortunately a lot of corridors are impassible because piled up carved stones are blocking your way. Still if you try to have a peek, you can find hidden or half hidden gems, just take your time.There are plenty of places, where you can’t get close to your aim, so you have to adore them from a distance. They are surrounded by ropes, and you can see them from a wooden platform- as I mentioned it above- but it is very understandable, that they have to be protected from further damages due to the huge and not always well behaved tourist inflow.Only what I can say as a recommendation, that I plan to go back, and spend at least half a day in Ta Prohm.

Magical. If you can manage to get here before it becomes flooded with people this place can be absolutely wonderful. We managed this and swiftly went in a different direction to anyone else. There are still some areas where you can truly feel like you are exploring by clambering over large boulders or up walls, ensuring not to venture into any of the areas that have signs indicating you shouldn't. I thoroughly enjoyed our visit here and would recommend it to everyone. The combination of man in nature is truly something that makes you think about our place in the world.

Um......finally lost to popularity.. Well I guess it had to happen. That temple made so famous from the Tomb Raider movies, is now a horribly overcrowded and spoiled shadow of it's former majestic self. This place was unbelievable when I first visited in 1999, and on subsequent visits over the years, but now, sadly is, well, unpleasant to put it politely. All of the classic photo views have been destroyed by board walks, rope barriers, signs and crowds. You will be literally jostled by hundreds of tour group visitors from one end of the temple to the exit. I'm so glad that I was able to visit here in the early years when you could often have the place to yourself. Now, the atmosphere and appeal of this temple has been completely destroyed. Don't even bother.

Trees-Growing Temple. This temple has been known since it was also the same location shot in Lara Croft: Tomb Raider which was starred by Angelina Jolie. Ta Prohm has this photogenic and atmospheric effect with combination of trees growing out of the ruins and the jungle surroundings making it one of the most famous Angkor temples visited by tourists. Too sad, it has been neglected and needed much restoration. But so far, it was also an amazing place to wander since the air was cool and there were a lot of trees to find shades from the glaring sun.
Tomb raider. Dawn visit to Ta Prohm was a real experience with no people and the only noise was squirrels! Glad to see international governments supporting renovation works.

Global travel and tours. We have returned from a tour of Cambodia which was arranged by Mr Ann of global travel and tours. all the hotels were excellent and the program was well planned with time for us to look around the places we visited by ourselves.the guides were also of a high calibre with great knowledge of the history the country. We can highly recommend global travel and tours and Mr Ann if you are planning to visit this area of the world.

Beautiful but overcrowded . A lot of charm for this very nice temple but during our visit, we suffered from big groups, very loudy, who behave like in the metro, pushing you to get the best picture. Pretty incredible. It is really key to avoid peak hours but i am not sure if this is really possible

Yes I got the same picture as everyone else!. As people say on here you have to see it. But that is it. The temple is in the middle of a straight walk. You get dropped off one end and walk through to get to driver again. And yes seeing it in the flesh is amazing but just been somewhere today even better if trees growing through the ruins is your thing, Beng Mealea. Now this place is Lara Croft as when visit you actually climb up and down and walk on the sides of this temple. See my other review on the gem

Tomb Raider. This temple is where some of the the Lara Croft Tomb Raider film was shot. That automatically means that it will be busy as it's on everyone's list as a 'must see'. It is a must see! The forest is reclaiming its land and has been allowed to do so. Tree roots breaking through the temples is an amazing thing to see.

My favourite temple area. I actually think I preferred this to the main Angkor wat area. It has a really cool ancient jungle vibe to it. I love how the buildings and trees have become one. Don't miss it!

Magical. Very beatutiful! Not too busy when we went at noon. When you stand near the tree roots you get a real idea of their scale. There are certain places that you have to line up to take photos, like the famous tree from Tomb Rider, but it takes a few minutes. It is one of the main temples and is worth the visit.

Tomb Raider Temple. Our hotel had a DVD of Tomb Raider, which we had seen years ago, so we watched the relevant part prior to our visit to Ta Prohm. Easy to see why they picked it as a location as it is very atmospheric. Not as impressive as Ankor Wat or Bayon, both of which have been extensively restored, it does give you a good sense of what these temples looked like when they were rediscovered in the 1920s by the French, and what they would all look like again but for the continual upkeep now.
Loved this place. The trees gave the temple a very different feel. It is well worth going even if you're feeling 'templed out' as it is quite something else.

Ta Prohm or "the Tree Temple" - A place to visit early in the morning. We visited early in the morning before sunrise and had the same experience as some reviewers below,- a quiet place amongst the large trees and just a few other visitors.We really enjoyed to slowly walk around and in the various buildings.There are lots of stones scattered around but the place is still under extensive conservation and restoration.This place is well worth a visit

Nothing stops nature. Deep in the forest you will find the ancient temple of Ta Prohm. The atmosphere is mystical, you can almost feel the spirit of higher power all around. Go early in the morning; less crowd and the light for photos are perfect.

Another unique temple!. This temple is famous for a fairly modern reason – it’s where Tomb Raider was filmed and the locals are quite proud of that. It’s a very impressive temple with that mix of man and nature as the trees are slowly taking over the temple. The trees are not being touched and won’t be removed unless they die. The roots are all over the side of the temple and in some cases, making their way through the walls.

Cooler side of Angkor. This is one of our favorite temples as it has a cooler atmosphere with massive trees that sprung and cloaked the temple and it's ruins. It's like being one with the jungle. You also get to thoroughly enjoy the temple as it is not that crowded.

OUR FAVOURITE!!!! at Dawn. After the previous days trip to Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat we were collected at 5.30am to visit Ta Prohm before sun up! There was NO-ONE there but us and we explored at leisure with great photos in differing light. I'm sure you know that Tomb Raider was filmed here.We had a small packed breakfast watching the sun come up, jaw dropping memories not to be missed!

Tomb Raider feeling. The photogenic and atmospheric combination of trees growing out of the ruins and the jungle surroundings have made it one of Angkor's most popular temples with visitors = expect a lot of tourist looking for Lara Croft feeling.

Interesting. Most interesting because of the way that trees have been preserved as they intertwine with the temple, gives a real idea of the powerful forces of nature at work and provides some stunning views

So different!. Different to the other temples we visited as it has been left in a semi jungle like state. Fascinating to see how nature took back the land. It is amazing to see how the trees have grown around and within the temple. A definite must do.

Fantastic huge tree temple!. Went there this week with my friend, in my opinion it is the best temple is Angkor Complex actually. I went to take the some photo for my part time work, the things that make me impressed are the huge trees growing on the walls of the temple, it's look absolutely amazing. Regarding the location it is not so far from Siem Reap city approximately 12km and spend around 15 minutes to go there by motor bike. Highly recommended to visit this amazing temple. Wonderful temple unquestioned!

A temple strucutre within tree roots. Another stunning place to be visited besides Angkor Wat and Bayon temple. The giant roots that penetrate the rocks are simply amazing. Best to go there with a tour guide for better understanding on the structures.

Tomb Raider stuff!!. Ta Prohm temple, originally called Rajavihara was built in 1186 AD by King Jayavarman VII, and is known by the trees growing freely among the ruins and blending with the rock. The place where the scene for Tomb Raider was shot is usually teeming with tourists holding cameras, but if you are patient and get lucky enough, you can have a couple of minutes for yourself and your entourage. (Note: hydrate!!)
My fave place in siam reap! . This is the best site out of the ang kor wat! And bayon too! Ang kor wat itself is less attractive than both Ta prohm and Bayon!.

Wonderful site . Ta Prohm in my opinion is the best temple in the Siemens Reap area under restoration A lot of the work has been completed and with each area they show the before and after The trees that have grown through the temple have been left and are amazing It is the best looked after siteI would recommend this before other sites in the same area

One of our favorites. Top 3 in Siem Reap, together with Bayon and Preah Khan. Not too big, but interesting details on unexpected places. Just dive in and have a look. At the moment (march 2015) a construction work is taking place at the entrance. Remember where you got in so you can find your way back!
Go here first! . Really enjoyed this temple. Great to see the tress growing around the ruins. This one was our favourite and enjoyed it more than Angkor Wat! A must see!

A tree within the ruins. Better known as the Tomb Raider Temple, it really is a cool stop to check out at Angkor Thom. A few of the trees have grown within the temple and it's such a cool site. It's not as big as Angkor Wat but definitely a must see. Unlike a few of the other temples, it offers the most shade so it's doable during the afternoon when the sun is at its worst.

Roots and ruins. Would have loved to be the fly on the wall or turn back time for a taste of the historical site. The ruins and devastation of the site by the roots and over time is just massive..where do one starts for restoration work for a nation swamped by hunger!?

Totally amazing. Absolutely amazing temple at Angkor that is an absolute bucket list must do. The temple has been overgrown by the jungle and some really massive trees and was used in the set of Tomb Raider and I can see why. Just do it.

Another Excellent Stop in Siem Reap. Once there, i felt like Indiana Jones... Old complex, being "eaten" by the jungle. Totally worth the visit, got amazing shots. Be careful, although some places seem "not too loose to walk" you may find a surprise.

Memorable and Exciting. Exciting you ask?? Yes this is where the 3 foot snake fell out of a tree,,, looked really angry, so glad it did not land on anybody but was on the outer perimeter of the temple and rare to see I was told, don't worry, it's all part of the adventure and no snakes or rodents in the temples,,, trust me…But another beautiful Temple to explore,,, each has such a different story about life in a ancient time… Highly Recommend...

Beautiful Temple. Beautiful to walk through, giant trees everywhere! There were a lot less tourists compared to what we heard about Angkor Wat. What isn't great is the children trying to sell souvenirs at the temples. Do not buy from them, it only fuels the cycle of keeping them out of school.

Guide suggested visit later in day.. Our favorite temple.  Our guide for two days did a great job: He said the two most visited and popular sites with the largest crowds are Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm. Some large tour groups only spend one day in Siem Reap and these are the two most popular sites visited. Our guide suggested we visit Ta Prohm the following day a couple hours before closing. When the large tours are starting to leave. It was a good plan, when we got there, several large groups were leaving. Ta Prohm has a smaller area to walk around and it would have been all must impossible to take pictures during the super crowded time. Here is a web site that might help you. WWW.Canbypublications.com

Simply Amazing & Lovely. Our family & I visited Ta Prohm, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, as part of our guided tour of Siem Reap. We understand the temple was built in the Bayon style during the late 12th and early 13th centuries. Ta Prohm was left in much the same condition since discovered, unlike most Angkorian temples. It is amazing to see huge lovely trees overgrowing from the the temple ruins. Good photo opportunities so do not forget to bring your camera. Highly recommended & must-see in Siem Reap.
Shades of movie scenes. This temple has been left with several huge trees growing through or over the large stones. Very worthwhile visiting.

A different world. Well known for its use in Lara Croft - Tomb Raider, the beauty of this place and the uniqueness of the temples and trees make it very special for those who witness it. Went with Happy Angkor Tour - Private car with tour guide "Mr Em". Fantastic person!

Undergoing restoration. In the past year this temple has had a large restoration project started. It no longer has quite the same thick 'jungle' surrounding it and it appears that some of the larger trees have been poisoned due to sudden cracking of sections of the temple (you can see all the measurement gauges that have been recently placed). Some sections that were previously open to visitors have been closed off due to safety issues and the work site but most of it is still available to view. It's immensely popular so try and get there early to avoid the hordes that descent in busloads. It's still a really lovely temple.
Our Favourite - Fascinating Place. So much to see in a compact area. Loved the whole beautiful and mysterious setting. Appreciated less talking and more to look at.

Nature versus Culture. Ta Prohm is amazing! Not because of Tombraider but how nature can take over and integrate with culture. In the late afternoon you can spend quiet moments and it gives you goosebumps!

More than a movie set. With roots and branches entwined with the temple's stone structure, Ta Prohm is magical. You wonder at how this temple lay hidden for so long, how archaeologists cleared the land to reveal its beauty. Ta Prohm is a wonder of both man and nature.
Photogenic ruins. Got some great shots of the decaying ruins, it was busy on the day of our visit, but overall a good experience

Unbelievable!. We went to Ta Phrom with relatively low expectations as we expected painful crowds even though we’d planned to get there just after 7am. Even though there were quite a few people around the gates and entrance, once inside the temple, we were pleasantly surprised that we didn’t have any issues taking many ‘people free’ photo’s. We’d visited this temple 10 years prior and, as expected, there were many notable changes in that there are boardwalks and many roped off area’s now whereas there was nothing like that before. On our previous visit, I remember climbing over rocks to see several sights that we simply walked up to this time. What we really were surprised about was how breathtaking this place is – even though we’d been there before. Photo’s, and memories, really pale in comparison to actually seeing this place with your own eyes.

Make sure your camera is fully charged. There are so many great sights here make sure your camera/phone is fully charged. Every where you look there are fascinating structures, carvings and of course trees. The before and after photos of the restoration work are interesting to see. It must be like putting together the worlds hardest jigsaw puzzle.

Different to the other temples. After having visited all the other temples, Ta Prohm first seems like from another world. Beautifully overgrown by strangler figs and moss this temple has its own kind of charm. The downpoint about this temple is that afterall it's a big tourist attraction and the wooden walkways/platforms and chinese tourgroups take away a lot of the charm and peacefulness and just make it to another tourist overrun temple in Angkor. It's worth seeing though, especially if you can get there before the guided tours come!

unique. I was told this silk cotton tree species (not sure if I remember its name correctly) was found growing only on the walls of this particular temple, and nowhere else in siem reap. for this reason alone, you should go.
Nature Wins!!!. You can't visit the national park without stopping here. It is truly a unique experience unlike any other I've seen.

Spectacular. Everything here is bigger than you expect". THe trees that have overgrown onto the site are amazing. Deferently take the camera. Need to wear sensible shoes as can be hazardous to walk around but this is a must. Can get very hot and very busy, but not as busy as angor wat

Fabulous experience. We just got back from a visit to South East Asia and this was one of the highlights....try to go early in the morning to beat the heat and the hoards of screaming Chinese tourists. Be careful on the steps, they can be loose or slippery. The site is quite eerie with all the roots of the plane trees which have taken over the temple....the jungle will always win.

Where Nature Takes It All Back!!. In our opinion, this Temple was the most exiting sight in the Angkor area we saw. You can visit it quite quickly, but most giving would be to return the next day with more time - and more water bottles!
A MUST. One of the most attractive sights we have ever seen. It is recommended to go there very early in the morning because it can be very hot during the day.

The tomb raider temple. Easily our favourite Temple on the tour, less crowded than Angkor Wat but with some fascinating and very unusual features such as the beautiful Banyan trees with their incredible roots growing over, under and through the stonework of the remains of the temples.This was the Temple that made me want to come to Siem Reap as it featured in the Tomb Raider film although I was mildly disappointed that we didn’t have to trek through miles of overgrown and dense jungle to reach it (or bumping into Lara Croft).We went round this temple nearing the end of a long, tiring day touring temples on bicycles with a truly appalling and boring guide. But despite this when we arrived and started wandering round it all seemed worth it. After a while of doing the temples tour I was starting to feel that they were all blurring together but Ta Prohm really stood out. There seemed to be more interesting things to see here than a lot of the other temples and surprisingly it was less busy than the other temples.We spent two days cycling and trekking around the temples but to be honest if I had just seen here and Angkor Wat I wouldn’t have felt that I missed out not seeing the rest of them.

Nature vs Man.... See it now while the work of both are complementary. A thoroughly unique and mystical experience which together with Angkor Wat and Banteay Srei make for a varied and rich experience.

The tomb raider temple. We wanted to come here to see Angelina Jolie... Kidding- but the film has given this temple its reputation!The beautiful photos you see of ancient trees literally growing out of temples is here. And there's lots of these old trees here.This is one of the best temples for this man versus nature experience.As with all temples, the earlier you go the better - before the coach load of tourists swamp the place.
Tomb raider. Perhaps one of my favorites. The overgrown trees, breathtaking. Go early to avoid the crowds.This is definitely A Must See when coming to Siem Reap.
