Ta Prohm is best before 8am. If you want to get good photos with ruins covered by huge tress, try to get there before 8am. Once the tour groups flood in with crowds and noise, you won't get the magic and impressive feelings from this place.

Greetings from Tomb Raider. The temple is one of, if not the highlight in Angkor. Famous because it was featured in scenes of the first Tomb Raider movie. The mixture of ancient temple and the overgrowing/huge trees is so beautiful and has a very misterious feeling. Must do! Again, come early. E.g. the door through which Lara Croft came in one scene has people lining up 10 deep for a shot.

Not as restored as Angkor Wat.. Ta Prohm is famous these days for its association with the "Tomb Raider" film, but there's so much more. It hasn't been restored as much as Angkor Wat, but the stonework being strangled by giant tree routes is quite a sight. It's definitely needs to go on the "must see" list.
What a Place!. This place blew us away. We weren't expecting our kids to enjoy this tour but to our surprise, they were more into it than we were. This place is a must visit.

A Must See On The Temple Tour. This was the first temple of the three in the small circuit that we visited. We arrived just after sunset and practically went the whole viewing time without seeing another group.I would definitely recommend visiting early as it can be frustrating trying to get photos without other groups in them.Ta Prohm was our second favourite out of the three that we visited. The incredible silk-cotton and fig trees growing on and wrapping around this temple creates a magical feeling that is unlike any of the other temples in the circuit.A must see if you are visiting Siem Reap!
Amazing Trees and Tomb Raider. Most people remember this area from the movie Tomb Raider and I must say, this area is amzing seeing old ruins reclaimed by nature

"The Tomb Raider Temple". I loved Tomb Raider, so when my guide for the day described this temple as THE Tomb Raider temple I knew I had to see it. I don't have much of a memory for movie sets, but I immediately fell in love with this temple! I love how nature is taking over the man made creations built so long ago.

so sad !. I first visited Ta Prohm in 2008, and it was great, like discribed in guides, you could enjoyed a very picturesque temple, where you could feel the strength of nature and the beauty of trees intertwined with human constructions covered with moss ...The charm has all gone!It has been my only and so strong disapointment in early 2015 re-visit of Angkor.The site is now protected from massive (mostly asian) tourist hordes with lots of fences. You cannot walk freely anymore in the temple, you have to follow the continuous flow of people left at one side of the site from a big bus and kept at the other side back.The temple is small so, it cannot welcome all these people. Thats a pitty. No way to make any nice picture now here.Only advise: go to other temples that are as nice as this one, but with no one!!

Absolutely Brilliant. Ta Prohm Temple is much more intimate than Angkor Wat and most of the temple has remained relatively unchanged as it was when it was refound after 400 odd years.Some beautiful big trees have covered parts of the temple and makes for great photography.

Picturesque tree temples. This is one of the most picturesque tree temples in the Angkor complex. This was built by King Jayavarman VII in honour of Prajnaparamita (the goddess of wisdom of Mahayana Buddhism). He dedicated this temple to his mother. Very old and long trees are in this complex. Renovation work is going on.
Stunning. A must go! It is really beautiful and unique. I loved this more than Angkor Wat. Go earl yin the morning to enjoy fresher temperature and less crowd.

One for the bucket list. Ta Prohm is a small but popular temple. It lay swallowed by the jungle for centuries, and has been left largely in the same condition as it was found. Giant trees snake their roots over its walls, slowly tearing on the ancient structures. There is some restoration work going on, but don't let that get in your way. There are also hoards of tourists. Still, it is possible to find small secluded spots where you can find amazing photo opportunities. So strap on some combat boots and pretend you are Lara Croft for a half hour or so. You'll be glad you went. It's a mesmerizing place.

Temple becoming one with Nature. Amazing site where nature has long since begun to reclaim the temple. The site itself has some fascinating areas. Much of it is in ruins, and there are massive trees that have taken over. An excellent site for pictures. When coming here, you can say either the Temple's name or simply "Tomb Raider" as the site has gained considerable fame after appearing in different films. When entering, you'll see signs to take the "Long Walk" or the "Short Walk". There isn't a difference other than the long walk takes you all the way around the site and then back into where the short walk patrons are exiting. The Short Walk is better. There isn't really too much of interest to see on the Long Walk. Both take you by the areas where trees have taken over, but the Long Walk makes it longer than necessary. Note, site is not friendly to wheelchairs or strollers. Bring water, sunscreen, hat, etc.. Better to wear tennis shoes/hiking shoes instead of sandals as the direct/soil will turn your feet a different color. Once you're past the ticket checkers, there are no bathroom facilities or refreshments available until you exit the site. Bathroom facilities and refreshments are only available prior to the entrance/after exiting on either side of the site.

Most beautiful temple!. It is the most amazing temple and must see. Please wear long pants and shirts with sleeves to visit. They sometimes don't allow to enter if baring skin. They do have scarves and pants selling shop outside but they are highly priced. And walking shoes are the must.

Don't forget you Indiana Jones hat!. Very interesting – a lot of renovation going on – quite an enclosed space so unfortunate of you get caught up with a group of tourists taking pics of each other in front of trees growing through the stonework (yawn) – definitely worth a visit

Temple buried in the jungle. This temple is well known for its rather overgrown character - huge trees have invaded the ruins, this lending a special exotic eery feel to the place. But please note that in March 2015 this place was undergoing some major kind of restoration project and there was a fair amount of scaffolding around and a few cranes. Still we were very glad we saw it.

A great temple, just a bit crowded. This complex was also a great place to explore, and larger than I expected. Sadly, though, the Tomb Raider film has made it very popular, and it was the most crowded of the complexes we went to.

Magic. I find it amazing that you can read the reviews of a place that has 95% excellent reviews and there is always 5% that had a terrible experience. I read the terrible reviews for Ta Prohm and they all had one thing in common, crowds. I totally agree that large crowds ruin most experiences so we avoid them. We arrived at Ta Prohm at sun rise and there was no one there. We took all the pictures of what we wanted with no one in our way. It was completely quiet except for the birds in the jungle singing to us. The shadows as the sun rose and the sounds of the jungle gave us a magic experience, and of all the temples we visited while in Siem Reap this was our favorite. Don't give a terrible review to a place because it was busy, instead go when it isn't and see places before or after the tour buses have gone.
Amazing!. By far one of the best temples we visited, great architecture and very detailed carvings. Makes sure the camera is charged, you get loads of great snaps.

Incredibly Captivating!. A must visit even if you have only an hour to spare or 2 hours if you enjoy the detailed work of the carvings which unfortunately some have eroded anyway. There are many carving depicting Devatas- female goddess,some carving from the Buddhist mythology ( 12th century and others are Hidus. The ground can be dusty during hot season and muddy in the rainy days so plan what you wear accordingly. You will be stepping among the ruin in some area and some on the trailing giant roots. Near the West Entrance or most of us : Exit- along the stretch walkway- there were some trees which at this time of the year spread many tiny brown bits about 2.5-3 mm long that if they get to your skin can be quite itchy even painful. I had the misfortune to catch one inside my sport shoes then another inside my eye!It is a humbling experience to witness such great work of human and nature and how it is at present and wonder what would happen in the future...

Amazing. We had seen photos of this temple complex covered with banyan and kapok tree roots before we visited Siem Reap and found it fascinating. However, to actually see up close how the massive tree roots have virtually 'smothered' parts of the structure was amazing. If you are visiting Angkor, this is definitely not to be missed

Go early. This was touted as the site of filming for the movie Tomb Raider. Aside from that, it was interesting to see a site that has been left pretty much as it was rediscovered. The trees have taken over the stonework and some of them are huge.
Like a Disney world? or Hayao Miyazaki world. You should see this work nature made certainly. You feel like plunging into the world of an animation of Disney or Hayao Miyazaki at all.

The jungle temple. Rather the Jungli temple.. The huge trees grown over the temples of this complex is something of a marvel and the neglect that these creations have suffered over the ages. The Archiological Survey of India have taken the task of restoring some of these temples.The trees look like dynosours crowling over the temples.
Jungle temple overrun with tourists. Ta Prohm, my favorite temple in the city, was significantly more touristy than the last time I visited in 2001!

The reason for my trip to Cambodia. I wanted more than anything to visit Ta Prohm but as I mentioned in my review of Angkor Wat that I thought I would be visiting Ta Prohm when we got there. I loved both but this temple is truly a visual wonder. The Balsa trees are huge and they have taken over the temple and that is what makes it worth the visit. They were doing some work there and I hope they don't try to restore the temple.
Jungle Temple. this temple has not been restored and has been left to its ruins. The jungle and nature surrounding this temple make it particularly special.

Tomb Raider's temple. Yeap, it's just the most amazing place in Angkor : according to me, it's amazing to see these trees groing up on the ruines,...But like everywhere in Angkor, there is a lot a tourist,..

Unusual temple with roots crawling all over. The temple was stunning however what makes it unusual is the roots of the trees. It gives the temple a twist of difference and with lots of ruins and debris to discover. It is undergoing a restoration at the meantime while I was visiting.
my favorite temple!!!. It isn't as big as Bayon or Angkor Wat.....but it was my personal favorite. The majestic trees and it's location really gave it a magical feel.........

Best by far!!!. On our recent visit to Siem Reap we did a 2 day tour of the temples of the area. It was extremely hot and humid which is what the weather is like in April. Ta Prohm temple is amazing it was the most fascinating of all the temples we visited. It really is like you are on the set of tomb raider, we couldn't believe how amazing it looked with all the trees reclaiming it. Overall this temple is a must when visiting Siem Reap, if you only have a short time in Siem Reap Angkor Wat and this one are your two best options.

tomb raider. it was in a way like a film set must see to believe the trees are massive winding through the ruins it reminded me of the film this site is also included in the entrance fee for Angkor Wat the fee lasts a week and covers many sites it is $40 at moment

Fabulous!. Beautiful ancient ruins in the jungle. However, we were surprised to see a crane in the middle of the complex. Restoration work is being carried out/ Expect to see a mini construction site there!

Arrive early. Leaving our hotel at 6am allowed us to avoid the big tour groups. The temperature is cooler and light through the trees beautiful. Highly recommended for teenagers who may struggle with the more formal Angkor Wat. Creative way to keep boys engaged is also to have them create a story using the ruins.

Tomb Raider Temple. Loved this. Loved that it was being conserved but really loved to see parts that had tumbled down too as you could totally still imagine how it had been. Go early here as it gets so hot and we left too soon as a result. Lovely wooded area and walk.

Feels more "ancient" than Angkor Wat. Because of all the big trees and roots that are growing out of the ruins, it has a more ancient feel to it. However, there are ropes and metal support on some areas so these areas are not "photo" worthy. This is the last temple we visited (after Angkor Wat and Bayon Temple) so it was nearing noon when we got here. It was really hot and the sun was already beating down on us. I suggest you visit this temple in the afternoon when its cooler and for better lighting when taking photographs.

Great temple to visit go early morning before it's too hot.. We had a 3 day pass and on day 2 went to ta prohm the temple from tomb raider and Indiana Jones. The trees are part of the temple and have made it a truly magical place. We spent several hours looking around no guide needed although we did have a guide book. We had a tuktuk for the day and left hotel at 07:15 am we were back at hotel just after lunch having seen 5 temples and beat the heat of the day well worth early start.

Famous for Tomb Raider. This is probably the second most popular temple in Siem Reap (to Angkor Wat) and is well worth a visit. Made famous in the Tomb Raider film, it is extremely popular with tourists. I got there early at 8:55 am but it was still very crowded. You have to wait your turn to get a photo taken next to some of the famous parts of the temple with the tree growing out of the walls.The crowds rather mar the experience (as it is quite a beautiful temple but the hordes of tourists getting selfies dims the overall enjoyment somewhat).

Stole the show at Angkor for me. Went here on our second day at Angkor after visiting Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom on day one. Ya Prohm tops them all in my opinion. Angkor what is deservedly the main attraction in Siem Reap but the collision of temples and Jungles at Ta Prohm is breath taking. It really feels like you're in an Indiana Jones movie or stepping into another world. Don't think that seeing Angkor Wat is enough, do not miss this place

Movie location. This has got to be one of those places like Petra, Jordan, where you expect to meet Harrison Ford around the corner. There are massive trees growing out of the ruins from before they reclaimed this temple from the jungle. Its a photographer's dream. You can hear cicadas in the background and expect giant pythons at the end of the next door.

series of smaller temple. We went to Ta Prohm after we went to Angko Wat. So maybe I was a bit underwhelm. It is a series of smaller temple, with steep climbs but beautiful nonetheless. Pay attention to the carvings on the walls. They tell a story. Breathe in the air and experience history. Good thing that it is a less crowded here.

Magic - Mother Nature wins again!. Jungle Temple - nature has turned this into a magical place- perhaps even more sacred now. Massive trees lend your imagination an aura of Magic - it is just fun. Charge your camera batteries and bring water so you can spend the time you want. We had an excellent guide which always deepens the experience! He clearly loved this temple.
Great great great. I love something ancient so this is really a great place for me. I took a guided tour so i didnt have enough time to discover the complex.

An Amazing, Out of this World Place. We had a driver drop us off at entrance and walked through the temple grounds on our own. No guides. I believe we must've arrived in between large tour groups as it was relatively quiet. There were a good amount of visitors, just not quite crazy.Surely, having a guide may have given us some more insight into the temple, but it was actually also quite nice to just walk through and marvel at the sight on our own. Indeed, there is a certain appeal in knowing they filmed Tomb Raider here.. but it in and of itlsef a thrill to see the site for its own mythical beauty. The real kicker is how up close you can get to temple. We were able to climb up on stones and peek into all sorts of nooks and crannies. Its a once in a lifetime experience!I also recommend going in the afternoon, 4:30 ish. We found it a little cooler than earlier in the day... and the light, for photos, is amazing!

Favourite Angkor temple. This is definitely my favourite one - every turn brings a surprise, something different to see. The way the growing trees have eaten up the temple makes it so interesting.Because it is below the trees this also makes it a more comfortable visit in the shade. The temple is pretty big so it also feels less crowded than the other main ones.

Lara Croft's place. And that is why it has now become one of the more popular Rs in the Angkor complex. It can get very busy, so it is worth getting a guide who can take you in the back way, where'd you avoid many of the crowds. Well worth a visit to see how the jungle's power re asserts itself over man's creations.

Reclaimed by nature . It's not just the one 'tomb raider' tree - the whole temple was reclaimed by jungle. It's an incredible temple to visit and wander through. Still being recovered too as relatively 'new' to the project. Must visit. And go around 1 pm to beat the crowds.

Another great temple. Very interesting visit, unfortunately our visit coincided with bus loads ofChinese tourists who were a bit pushy to get photos of this famous site. Still, we enjoyed our time there.

Best temple for atmosphere. Visit early before the crowds. Ta Prohm, the jungle temple is an amazing temple with the roots from the spung trees both holding the temple together and destroying them at the same time. The roots growing over and through the stones is an incredible sight. This was our favourite temple and it it well worth visiting early morning before the crowds and coach tours arrive. We were there about 8.15 and shared the temple with probably less than 50 people so we have lovely photos.
One of my favourites!. Probably one of my favourites! Loved seeing those big tree trunks on the rocks. This is also the Tomb Raider temple. Pretty nice! Everyone should visit this.

Magical, but get in before it's too late. A truly magical place. The crumbling buildings and the amazing trees and roots. I guess the tourists come because it is exactly what it is so it was deeply disturbing to find it is being "renovated"There were generators blasting out and a whole section has been rebuilt and it looked awful. Ponds have been drained and trees cut. Let nature have it all back and if that means it will all be gone in 100 years so be it. Just enjoy the unique feeling this place has before the "improvements" destroy this place for ever.

A must see in its own right.. Famous for Tomb Raider, but has an incredible history of its own, & is very atmospheric. It is a bit of a conundrum in that the huge ficus trees are holding most of the temple together, but equally, they are destroying the temple as they grow. As with the other temples, much of the statues, & all of the gems were looted or 'rehoused' in various museums long ago. You will struggle to see this temple without huge crowds, but go soonish - the trees will continue to damage the structure as they grow & much is already held together by metal bands etc.

Nature taking Over. A temple built the forgotten in olden times is now getting crawled on over by huge roots of banyan trees which have crawled over the terraces. Huge complex now under restoration surrounded by dense greenery.

One of many great temples in Siem Reap.. Ta Prohm was well worth the visit & offers some great photo opportunites, it isn't too far from Angkor Wat & is easily accessible. We hired a tuk-tuk driver for $15US & he took us from town out to Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm & back.

Cool temple being overrun by the jungle. Make sure you visit Ta Prohm when you're in Cambodia. They left the temple as they found it and trees and growing all over the temple which makes for some really cool pictures. All they talk about is how Lara Croft Tomb Raider was filmed here...so there'll be LOTS of tourists taking photos by the doorway that was featured in the movie.This is one of the most visited temples in this area - so be prepared for thousands of tourists - especially Chinese and Korean tour groups that'll overun the temple and you if you're not careful!Even with all the tourists - it's still worth it to visit Ta Prohm.

The Power of Nature is making Ta Prohm the Temple of Doom. Ta Prohm Temple leaves a lasting impression of the incredible power of nature. The jungle was the main destructive force to the temples and Ta Prohm is a lasting example of the temples trying to compete with the power of the jungle. The force of the roots of the trees are growing through the stone and temple walls are crumbling down as the huge roots crash through the ground. The forces of nature is making Ta Prohm the Temple of Doom. Everyone knows this was the set for the Tomb Raider movie starring Angelina Jolie. It is a stunning locale and easy to see why they chose this spot to film. It was surreal walking in the footsteps of my movie star idol and it truly is worth a short wait to get a photo under the huge fig tree seen in the movie. The roots just seem so powerful. Hollywood glitz and glamour cannot overshadow the forces of nature casts an ominous tone at this temple. A must see during your visit to Siem Reap.Temple Tour Tip: Limit your water intake, limited restroom facilities at all temples. We loved having an air conditioned private car. Watch your step. It is east to trip over the roots or stone.

Tombraider temple - so cool - workmanship on this temple.. A lot of restoration work taking place. Be aware there are not many toilets at all in the temple areas. Lots of steps and not good for anyone that has a disability or cannot walk long distances, over uneven ground., If youre going to Angkor Wat , then this is a must see, take a look at these other temples. Amazing workmanship on this temple too.

Tomb Raider & Crowds. This was by far the busiest site I visited. Extremely crowded. Everyone want to feel as though they are in Tomb Raider. The amazing tree structures growing from rooftops and everywhere else they can germinate. The main tree which is magnificent is notably very busy. My best advice is go to this site an hour before sunset to see it and experience the sunset at the same time. Great site, well preserved, just a little crowded.
Worth to take a look. If youre going to Angkor Wat you should go and take a look at these other temples too.Amazing workmanship on this temple too.

Not reallt "a temple in the jungle", but still very cool!. This is the place were they filmed Tomb raider and going here it's easy to understand why. The ruins are very cool with heaps of trees growing inside and over them. We hired a tuk tuk driver for the day who took us from the hotel to Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm and back for $15. I recommend doing so as the distance between the temples are long, the areas to explore big and the sun extremely hot. Be aware of people, especially children, trying to sell you junk for ONE DOOLLAAARR and friendly strangers wanting to "tell you the stories of the temple" as they will (over)charge you. This country is nicknamed "Scambodia" for a reason, so be prepared. We told our driver to start with the temples furthers away, this one, and then work our way back towards Angkor Wat. This way you won't have to fight the crowds as much and you save the coolest thing for last!

Good Visit. This is the tombraider temple and is the one where the trees have not been taken out so it is as near as it should be to "original" A lot of restoration work taking place. Be aware there are no toilets at all in the temple areas. Lots of steps and not good for any walking disability.

Smaller temple. Ta Prohm is one of the smaller temples in Siem Reap. I find this temple more interesting and fascinating because of the big roots that coiled and crawled through the cracks and crannies of the walls. The roots gave the temple a unique character. It is a perfect place for photo enthusiasts.
beautiful.... if you want a clear view of the tree that have outgrown the structure, just be patient.. for sure you will have your desired solo moment :)
Trees emerging from Ancient Roof Tops. Ta Prohm trees emerging over the top of ancient ruins. A comfortable stroll through the ancients buildings.
must go. The place was very beautiful. The best one out of all the sites I visited. You need a guide taking you there at the right time to avoid the crowds.

Remarkable. This was our first temple in Siem Reap and we were deeply impressed. If you haven't read or studied about what to see, I would recommend this book (our tuk-tuk driver shared his copy with us, but if you have it, it will be a great resource). Focusing on the Angkor Temples: The Guidebook (3rd Edition)
Tomb Rider Temple. The temple was invaded by trees that turned this amazing place. I recommend going to this temple in the evening, because at lunch is very full.
too crowdy. everyone is following Angelina Joile as Tomb Raider, I think the busiest place in whole Angkor. Wonderful and worth visiting, but you have to share hunderds

One of the coolest temples in Angkor Wat. This temple, as seen in Tomb Raider, is one of the coolest temples to visit in Angkor Wat. Enormous trees growing over old structures and fantastic small tunnels made from the vegetation. It's a must see!

Beautiful tree meets architecture wonder.... What a mind blowing experience. Please watch any uTube coverage you can find before going, you will enjoy and get so much more out of your visit. DO NOT go with Siem Reap Shuttle Tours, that was our big mistake. The group started with eight by the end of the day it was only my husband and I. It started off quite well with the guide telling us a lot about himself! But after we had refused to buy the very expensive over priced lunch the whole thing went rapidly down hill. The guide practically ignored us and made it very clear we were some kind of nuisance in his life! he would drop us off at sites and say where and when to be collected with no other information about the amazing sites we were about to see. We have now watched many programmes since and we could have discovered so much more than we did. Highly recommend this place for a once in a life time must do....we will certainly be going back.

The trees are wilting. ta Phrom is famous for many things, one being the set of the 2000 movie tomb raider, but the very features that attracted the Hollywood movie makers to use it a going. I have been to Ta Phrom for the last three years in a row and it is not the same as it was. Restoration works, as important as it is, is actually detracting from it appeal as the trees are removed. See it while you can, it will be a very different temple soon.
Amazing . An amazing temple with trees growing right over the ruins like nothing I've ever seen before, crowded yes but worth it!!! Any where worth seeing is going to have crowds,

breathtaking. A breathtaking experience! This was the best place to visit for me in relation with all the other tombs. We did the small tour and did it in the opposite direction when you follow the numbers in the eyewitness travel or capitool. It was quiet calm when we vised the place. When you plan to visit this place at the end of march make sure that you bring enough water (or arrange this with you tuktuk driver) because the temperature is really high at that time of year.

amazing but busy. how nature can take back something over time is so impressive maybe no more so than at Ta Prohm , it gets very busy here but don't let that ruin your experience take it all in even if that means 2 or 3 times around it just doesn't get boring.

Best of them all!. fascinating place to walk around. There is restoration work going on but i hope that they dont restore it so much that it looks pristine as that will detract from the character of the place. And why on earth this association with Lara Croft? Nuts, the place can stand on its own merits!
Fascinating. The Angkor Wat temples go on and on whilst imparting a sense of lost mystery. One frequently hears visitors humming the Indiana Jones theme here.

Ta Prohm is marvellous. We decided to revisit Ta Prohm again this year. There is is much new reclamation occurring there and this is good. The interaction between nature and the ruins is stunning.
It is our favorite Cambodian temple. Eerie and phenominal are two adjective that jump out.

Nature and civilization intertwined. For me the most impressive temple in Angkor park. The trees are 400 years old, holding the temple in their long 'tentacles' .... at the same time keeping the rocks together and also slowly destroying some parts. The roots stretch for 15 meters under pile of rocks to then reappear again, they rip open some walls and make the temple just magical.I'll reccomend a guide for this one, as there are some hidden jems you can't find by yourself (room that was covered in rubies / Hidden face of a statue inside the roots / A wild boar carving that looks like a dinosaur / And the most stunning room in Ta Prohm - Echo room (there's only another one at Angkor Wat).Ta Prohm was built for the king's mother. She had a school there for apsara dancers.

Nature made and man made. What a combination!. Explored Ta Prohm during a very good trip with Gate 1 Travel through Vietnam, Cambodia and Bangkok. The Siem Reap temple complex provided many hours of unique sights and we had only one very full day to see it. It will deserve a return trip. While my favorite location might be the Bayon Temple, the trees overcoming man's temple in Ta Prohm were very special and reminds us that while human creations may endure the centuries, nature is not particularly impressed with us.

Amazing, but undergoing conservation. This place is amazing, but be aware it is currently (and hopefully on an ongoing basis) undergoing conservation, so there is 'building work' going on while you are there. This was a bit of a disappointment for me as I had hoped it would be quieter, but nontheless an incredible place to visit.
Nature fights back. Amazing to see how trees won the battle to reconquer their territory ! make sure Ta Prohm is in your visit list, its really worth it !

Go early for best photos.. This was our main temple target, and we really wanted to get good photos from here. So we went to Ta Prohm at 6 am in the morning, and there were only few people there, so timing was excellent. Place was just amazing, really impressive! We spent there few hours, and got all the pictures we wanted, except from the part which was closed for renovation. When we left, crowds were pouring in. So if you really want to experience this wonderful temple, go early!
Tomb raider!! Amazing day. Every turn every tree every carving more awesome than the last! Do not miss this temple! It's absolutely breathtaking!
Movie scene - literally ;-). Fascinating symbiosis between the temple and mother nature. It looks like a fantasy movie scene. We went in the afternoon, which was not too bad with tourists.
Fantastic temple. The temple is very nice and great to see. A lot of tree on the top of temple. I am really enjoyed with our trip. Good temple and too many temple in Siem reap.
Tomb Raider. Make sure your camera is fully charged, the trees that are swallowing these temples are really beautiful. Parts of this site are being renovated but does not spoil your tour
Nature takes it back. Over a period of time, creations of wonderful architecture is reclaimed by the nature. However, restoration efforts by modern technologies will make it last longer.
Amazing. Wonderful temple overgrown with huge roots of Banyan type trees,best to visit in the afternoon when not so busy.Very spectacular and definitely worth a visit if in Siem Reap.

SEEING IS BELIEVING. Even though this temple featured in Tomb Raider and people around the world saw the weird and wonderful images of giant trees blending with the temple walls, the spectacle is even more amazing in the flesh. It is a relatively compact site and the film has greatly boosted visitor numbers but it is still possible to wander around without encountering the crowds. The entrance to the main hall gets a little congested but nothing too bad.In addition to the visual impact of the trees, there are some very nice base reliefs.

Highly recommended. The most atmospheric of the temples at Siem Reap. We visited in late afternoon when there were few other visitors and with an excellent local guide.This was one of the highlights of our holiday. Highly recommended.
The Trees. Everyone comes to this temple as it has had very little restoration and, hence, has the classic 'trees growing through the temple' look.Come early to avoid the crowds, a must see.

'AWE' and serene. Appreciated the uniqueness of the temple with the trees occupying the place. You will be at awe just observing the size and character of the trees! Combined this with 12th century ruin, it's totally breath taking. The place might be packed by tourist, it's worth to take your stroll all the way to the back of the temple. There is an open area where you could sit down, rest, reflect and just absorb the beauty it has to offer. Do pay attention to details and peek through the window and ruins, you might be surprise with nice art works. Highly recommended!!

The forces of nature. Like all the temples get there early, if you bypass the sunrise at Ankhor Wat and get there before the crowds its breathtaking. the battle between the temples and nature is fascinating and makes you realise how fragile the human race is, buildings are no match for the forces of nature. A must see

Trees seem alive !!!. another temple on our list of "you must see places". To see the trees and nature fighting to take over the stone temple again, weird and grotesque shaped trees and roots intertwining the temple - it was almost as if they were liquid and took on a spooky haunted house look. this would be great to see at night by moonlight. There is some restoration work on site but there is minimal disruption to viewing.

A must see.. See this temple with all the tree roots growing through was awesome. They have left this temple as is, not like the others where they have restored them. A must see as all the temples are.

WOW this is a must to see. Definitely recommend seeing this one in the late afternoon, as it is very very busy in the morning, we went at 4pm and there were not so many people and we managed to get many photo's with jusdt us and no one else. I think this is the BEST temple of them all.

Amazing to see!. To see giant trees slowly but surely crushing the magnificent structures of Ta Phrom was just amazing!
A must to visit temple, but please be advised that this particular temple can be very crowded with tourists.
Tree temple. this is the famous temple in pictures with huge tree roots grown over the temple structure. it wasn't as awesome as in the pictures, but a must visit
A must see. Its a great temple you have to see while you are in this area. There are a lot of tourist but that`s ok if you go early in the morning. A must see
Amazing. I climbed as high as I could go. This is up there with Angkor Wat. Well worth the effort and the climb.

Fantastic. Feel like you are in the movie Tomb Raider. We absolutely loved this temple with the broken giant slabs of masonry lying in disrepair,. It gave a real sense of age and you felt like you were part of the movie set Tomb Raider. The setting is so magical, with the roads bordered by jungle on your approach. Huge trees with gnarly knotted roots grow from parts of this ancient structure. It is breathtakingly beautiful and a delight for photographers. The bas reliefs are delicate and you feel like an explorer finding a magical kingdom. Lots of climbing through this temple complex that has been partially reclaimed over the centuries by a wild and strong jungle. Absolutely awesome to see this. It is in a way a natural wonder as well as an architectural wonder. Favorite temple.

Ancient tree roots among the ruins. I loved the tree-covered walk towards the temple, so welcome on a hot day. When we reached the buildings we were delighted at the amazing encroachment of tree roots supporting - or perhaps supported by - the stone structures of the temple. Fantastic photo opportunit at every turn. Then we heard traditional music played by a group of victims of land mines. People were sitting on a bench listening, so my husband and I got up and danced a waltz to the music, on the ground, in front of the band and the crowd. Everyone was surprised and I think it made the musicians' day. Thanks to the musicians for making our day! Thanks also to our wonderfully patient guide, Mr. Chong San, who so generously shared his knowledge and love of country with us.

Where nature rules. This temple makes everyone a photographic genius -- the photogenic tree roots growing on top, in and through the temple make a marvelous contrast against the buildings, and switching to black and white and simply playing with the contrast creates evocative memories.

Astonishing. Go see this place just before the sunset when the colours are most beautiful. In this place it's easy to walk because there are wooden platforms covering many of the the paths. Remember to have mosquito repellent with you.

The Power of Nature!. Too many tourist and still cannot stop me to find out the interesting part of Ta Phrom temple. The sad part is some of the attraction area is under restoration project. Overall is fantastic

must see. not to be miss;maybe the prettiest of the temples; well worth the visit, a bit different in a good way from the others, the eerie qualities take you back in time! photographic delight-at every turning.
Amazing. Jungle meets art...astounding that you can climb around and explore. Go early to avoid crowds and tour buses.
sunrise at Ta Prohm. Quiet at sunrise, nobody else around, history comes alive as you wander around.. a favourite place to visit

Magical and atmospheric. Probably the most atmospheric of the Angkor sites especially at dawn and a must see along with Angkor Wat, Ankgor Thom and Banteay Srei. This temple has been left pretty much as it was discovered after having been abandoned for 600 years. It is engulfed by giant trees whose roots trail over the crumbling buildings. Can get busy and noisy with tourists wanting to take photos of the areas featured in the Lara Croft tomb raider movie but with a bit of patience you will find some quiet space. Enter by west gate early to avoid the crowds and exit by more popular east. Unlike some of the other Angkor sites you don’t need a guide. Can be visited separately or as part of the Angkor Archaeological site one, three or seven day ticket.

As famous as Angkor Wat. This was the first temple we went to see on our tour and we managed to get ahead of the crowds. In many ways this temple is as well known as Angkor Wat itself because of the amazing trees and their roots which are entwined in the structure. There are some great photo opportunities. It was interesting to see the extent of restoration work that was going on as well. A unique site and possibly my favourite...
Movie Set. There are so many amazing temples in Cambodia. This one is a must. It's like being on a movie set and everywhere you turn you are completely amazed at the scenery. Such an amazing place!

Ta Prohm. Visit this at the end of the visit to the Angkor complex and you will appreciate what nature can do to what man has built and what the other temples must have been like when they were originally rediscovered

My favourite!!. Of all the sites, this was my favourite - the vegetation which has been carefully maintained is so beautiful- you get a very good sense of where the evolution of this site over centuries has come. There are a few famous sites such as the extensive roots that grow over the ancient buildings- it is over the top. You must not miss this site!!!

Full of tourists but worth it. This place is a tourist nightmare but if you can out up with that then it's an amazing temple. Engulfed by the Jungle yet being painstakingly rebuilt you feel like your in the middle of an excavation dig.

One of the most impressive tempels near Angkor Wat. Ta Prohm is part of the Angkor Wat tempel complex. In fact it lies just next to the Angkor Wat temple. The interesting part of this temple is that it is overgrown by very ancient trees. Thistemple can easily be combined in a one day trip with Angkor Wat, and Bayon (temple with the laughing faces)we collected our one day ticket for the temples the day before. When you do this after 5 PM then you have free entrance for the rest of that day plus the next day. At that moment there a no big queues at the ticket office. The late afternoon entry allows you to see the temples during sunset. Sun rises above the Angkor Wat temple walls at around 07:00 AM, but it is advised to arrive at around 05:45 AM so that you have a front row seat near the temple lake.

Magical man and magical nature.. Truly stunning evidence of the way nature will adapt to growth opportunities. The way the tree roots have grown over the crumbling temple structures is amazing and creates a unique sight. Our guide took us at dawn which was even more magical with the sound of birdsong and even a squawking gecko. We will not forget this marvellous temple.

Ta Prohm.. Like the book of the jungle with Mogley... Amazong! Must see early in the morning before millions and millions of tourists arrive! Around 8.30 AM is a good time. The trees over the monuments is unbelievable!

Jungle Temple from the Movie. This is the famous Tomb Raider temple that was featured in the first movie. The temple is absolutely amazing. Giant trees have come to dominate this temple since its abandonment over 600 years ago.

Fun . This temple is fun with the trees growing out of it. Much more interesting with a tour guide though. This temple also needs a lot of restoration work. Great if you've seen the movie Tomb Raider!
Nice. Great to see the restoration work being done.Lots of people, but still able to have photos taken.The tree roots hugging the stone blocks is absolutely amazing to see.A must see in Siemens Reap

Tomb Raider. One of the few temples that you can walk/climb around in and pretend you're Angelina Jolie or Indiana Jones! Pretty fun as our guide was cool and took our party through unused routes and backdoors that made it feel all the more like an adventure. Temple itself is mostly ruins with the trademark "Strangling plant" prominent throughout the temple. Worth visiting at least once if you have a 3 day pass.

Fantastic. Would highly recomend a visit to Ta Prohm just seeing the trees and how there roots have grown over the temples is amazing ,the whole tour was great.I would highly recomend one day private tour of Angkor Wat.

Temple in the jungle. One of these places you feel you've been to in a previous existence, yet totally incredible. The walk through the jungle to the sound of music performed by ex-soldiers hardly prepares you for the stonework strangled beneath the trees - a totally magical, mysterious place. Only quibble was with insensitive tourists having their photos taken, lingeringly, in the key spots - fairly spoils it for anyone wanting to take a photo sans human interest.

Don't miss this temple. I have never watched the tomb raider film and am ashamed to say I did not realise the connection until we visited this temple. However it blew me away, it's completely fascinating to see how the tress are taking it over. I now need to watch the film when I have finished my holiday!

Simply amazing!. Arrive after 4pm and you'll miss the crowds and see this amazing place bathed in a subtle light which gives a mysterious effect. The size of the trees and their roots are unforgettable. This is a must visit place, you'll never forget.

Magical. just a great place to see, mystique. Took my daughter back after the crowds around 4.30pm it was virtually empty and we were the last to leave, much quieter than the mornings for our experience. Your guide will walk you around in an hour and thats fine but well worth more time - next time :)

Uncomparable Ta Prohm. The scenery here is uncomparable and was my favorite temple out of all. You will see the massive trees and roots growing out of the sandstone and the ruins of the buildings. It was mysterious and weird but fantastic. It is best if you can go there very very early (6am) to avoid both the heat and the crowd. We went around noon and it was heat but not crowd.

A must, if here.. We did it on a day ticket short tour, 3 sites, leaving at 6.30am when cool. Best time. Site is fab, so glad we went, as we nearly declined as it was too hot. But do go, take water, and a camera. Brilliant half day out.
Man-made against nature. A nice place for taking great pictures. In contrast with the ruin of the temple gigantic trees are seen growing healthily withstanding the test of time.

magical. This is the temple which has featured in films I have never seen! However regardless of that, it is an amazing site to visit with the temple buildings having been partially reclaimed by the jungle. It is a photographers heaven. The sight of massive trees growing out of sandstone buildings is fascinating and I for one hope that it is maintained in this way rather than over restored.

An unspoilt ruin of the past glory. Ta Phrom temple is about 3km east of the main Angkok Wat temple complex It has a separate entry fee of 20us$. You have to enter from the west ant get out at the east gate.Be prepared to walk about 1 km while entering and again going out leaving apart the vast area of the temple complex ruins.When we went after visiting the main temple complex of Angkor Wat.,it was already well past noon and though it was February,Sun god was merciless and it was very tiresome to cover the long terrain.So,keep enough stock of water and of course a wide brimmed hat.Whn we went, it was teeming with tourists as it has become a very hot tourist attraction after ANGELINA jOLIE took shots here for her film so much so that the temple has now popularly called tomb raider temple after the name of the movie I would suggest you not to make the mistake of visiting this temple after Angkor Wat as much of the unspoilt beauty of this temple can be enjoyed and realized in the morning or in the afternnon. This temple built in 13th century has been intentionally left untouched by the archeologists so that one can cherish the actual condition in which it was discovered in18th century by French explores. However, some structural supports and strengthening are being done by the experts of Archeological Survey Of India to arrest further decay and collapse. the sight of the huge tree branches and roots of huge Banyan trees twining and entrapping the age old decayed structures give a haunted look especiall with the big dense jungles surrounding the area.The area has not been cleared of the jungles and only a narrow pathway has been cleared for the tourists.o, it is ver easy to get lost unless you are having a guide with you as it happened in my case and I had to ask other guides for the right path to go out . Actually, it is very confusing to move on your own taking photographs and suddenly finding you are lost!!.It is or rather was the largest temple complex with residences, univ ersitity, other buildings details of which are found in a stone inscription written in Sanskrit which gives facts and figures the splendor and vastness of this once prosperous city.Visiting this temple complex in dusk or dawn gives an eerie feeling as if you are in a lost world full of ruins and jungles By the tIme I was coming out, the Sun was setting and the feeling was really surrealistic!!

Worth the visit. worth the visit if you have time, but if it's a long hot day with children, either a quick visit or plan another day. We've spread the temples over three days to make it easier as a family.

Just as the Movies. Actually better. Get there early or later (when people tend to go towards Angkor Wat for sunset). You get a feeling of the jungle encroaching quite well here - huge trees. Quite easy to walk around and as has been said - photogenic. A certain don't miss site.

Expected much more. I was a bit disappointed by this temple as it was the one I had been most excited to see. I was expecting stone walls covered in lush green jungle, and instead there were just a few trees that had grown around some areas of the temple. Great photo opportunities, but overrated.

My favorite Temple. This is one of the most amazing temples and was definitely my favorite temple out of all. A must see. We went around noon when most of the other tourists were at lunch-- it was less crowded and we got better pictures.

Wow!. Anyone who has seen the movie Tomb Raider has knows Ta Pham, maybe not by name but this site is hard to forget. What you see in the movies is good but only a small part of this incredible site where the trees and roots have grown over the ruins of Ta Pham. This is the beauty of when nature, time and man-made come together. (Funny that a lot of the guides refer to Ta Pham as "Tomb Raider" now)Your $20 temple pass will get allow entrance for all of these fantastic sites.
Wow. Another beautiful temple that is just as you imagine it only better! Easy to walk around but get there early to beat the crowds.

This has some mighty trees growing out of it. There are many areas in Ta Prohm Temple where the roots of trees have taken over this beautiful old Buddhist Temple, yet it still stands! It's amazing to see this surreal, eery place with the symbiotic relationship between nature and structure. 10 out of 10 for photographs too.

Tranquility in the jungle. Best visited before the crowds descend this temple is set a short distance in the forest. While it is still currently undergoing renovation this activity did not prevent enjoyement of the ruins. Fascinating ruin overrun by trees and nature. This is much of its charm. In our opinion the best in the Angkor complex.

tomb raider. anothr not to be missed temple, went to this one after Bayon, in the early stages of restoration but that adds to the experience, it's where parts of tomb raider was filmed, very hot in the afternoon, also very popular so expect lots of tourists, if you have a few days go to the temples in the mornings , one of the best, not to be missed

Our favorite!. The force of nature is rarely more apparent than in this temple overgrown by trees. Restoration is an ongoing project and it is interesting to see how much has been accomplished. At the more popular photo op sites you will likely have to wait for a turn, but most people are friendly.
Great. Hire a guide.There is so much history they can advise you on. Absolutely amazing structures throughout the park.

Another wow.. We recently returned from our trip to southeast Asia and the time spent at these sites were so worth it. I think that to get them most out of this you need to erase anything that seems touristy in your mind and go with the emotion of the place. It is truly a place that time forgot. The parasite type trees that took over the other tree looks like the glue that in some ways may have held it intact during times of quake's or other mother nature activities.

Spectacular site !!. Ta Prom is another must see in Siem Reap. This Temple has been a little overrun by the Jungle over the years and this has made for a spectacular show of buildings with trees literally growing out of the stone. The large trees growing from the walls, and roofs make for an amazing site. The damaged they have caused is obvious but there presence makes this site unique. Again plenty of walking and steps but keep looking at the temple and you will hardly notice
Ta Prohm- Tomb Raider scene. I found Ta Prohm overrated. Of course it is worth to see and has a lots of details, but there are many more impressive temples and structures in Angkor area.

Must see; go early!. Our guide insisted we arrive at dawn both the beat the crowds and to see this temple at its best. It was just beginning to get light when we arrived; I'd brought a tripod with me but cranking up the ASA to 3200 meant I didn't need to use it and I got a series of excellent people-free photos of this place of mystery during various stages of sun rise. You don't get long shots of a flaming ball rising above the temple; but with trees growing through the ancient ruins and serpentine root structures twined everywhere the light at this time of day is perfect. And it was soooo peaceful. If you've found this review useful please click 'Helpful' below.
A mystical lesser visited temple. This was my favourite of all the temples. If you need to be selective regarding the number of temples you visit, be sure not to miss this one.
The power of nature!. Truly a reminder that nature is more powerful than we can ever imagine, reclaiming whatever was there before the intervention of human beings. An exceptional site to visit!

Too much Tomb Raider hype. It's a curiosity due to the fact that this temple appeared in a movie, but Ta Som has an impressive tree strangling the entrance way and Preah Khan has many trees and is a bigger, quieter complex with more to see.

My favourite place in siem reap. Among the three most important locations... Ta prohm is by far my favourite.. The tree and the ruins are simply magical... prepare yourself for one of the best walks in Asia

Fantastic Temple. Ta Prom is another must see in Siem Reap. This Temple has been a little overrun by the Jungle over the years and this has made for a spectacular show of buildings with trees literally growing out of the stone. The large trees growing from the walls, and roofs make for an amazing site. The damaged they have caused is obvious but there presence makes this site unique. Again plenty of walking and steps but keep looking at the temple and you will hardly notice
Touristy. The trees and the queues of tourists waiting for photos made this my least favourite angkor temple. Im sure I would have gads a different view had it been quieter.

Atmospheric but gets quite busy. Ta Prohm arguable is the most atmospheric of the Angkor temples since it is to a larger extend left in the state it was found in the jungle. Especially the Spung trees growing over the ruins give it that Tomb Raider feeling. It does get quite busy however especially towards noon so taking an undisturbed picture is already a challenge, people take turns. The temple is currently being restored in an India-Cambodia co-operation project, clearly some activity going on there.

Not to be missed. We visited early morning while it was still cool and really enjoyed our time. There is a great sense of the past as you wander through the ruins. Bring a camera there is alot of opportunity for rare photos

Ancient temple complex overrun with tourists - note my TIPS!. We visited this ancient and famous temple on the same day that we visited Angkor Wat and The Bayon.It is an incredible place thanks to the amazing trees growing throughout the temple complex. Be warned that it is really overrun with tourists regardless of what time you go visit it. At one part of the site, we thought that we were going to be pushed aside by the crush of tourists flowing through.We went early afternoon after first visiting Angkor Wat, eating lunch and visiting the Bayon. We spent about an hour strolling through the ruins. I would love to give this place a 5, but there are simply too many people there to enjoy the true magnificence of this ancient temple complex. TIPS:Visit Ta Prohm as part of a visit to the overall Angkor complex.We went in the East entrance and out the West entrance (or was it the other way around?) but be prepared to get disorientated in the complex. We overheard multiple tourists trying to get their bearings. Car and driver for the day is around USD 30. It's useful hiring a car/driver as it gets very hot and the air-conditioned car is a welcome place to rest in between temple visits. One day entrance fees to the Angkor complex is USD 20 per person. Multi-day passes are also available. Don't clamber over the temple ruins - stay on the paths. This is a temple under restoration. No need to take shoes off at the temple.Take water - it gets really hot.

Ta Prohm - tomb raider temple. Amazing. While this is a well visited temple remain patient and you will get an opportunity to get the photo shots that you don't want other people in. An amazing example of the forest taking back its own while being able to experience the architecture still remaining.

Tree "sculptures" makes this different from the other temples. Ta Prohm, made famous froth setting of the Tomb raider film, suffers like many of the temples at Siem reap in that there are crowds of visitors. What makes this one different is the incredible "sculptures" created from the huge roots of trees that have invaded the site. As such it is well worth a visit but like many of these sites, go early in the morning to be able to take photos without a backdrop of crowds of people.

Amazing site. This is an amazing site and one can see why it was chosen for the movie site for the Tomb Raider. Huge trees growing on the temple walls and holding the stones together. Well worth a visit. The Apsara dance hall is being preserved and reconstructed so will be interesting to see if this blends in with the ancient structures.
Pushing and shoving. Come here at lunch time at the opposite direction for the perfect opportunity to avoid the bus hordes

Ta Prohm -photographers delight. My favourite temple. Rundown, tree roots growing through the buildings. We went in a back way with our guide. Felt like we had just discovered it. Lots of work going on. Lots of walkways which I found annoying for photography. Quiet in the mornings at 6 am ish. Not to miss this one, great for photography.
Tomb Raider experience. This historic site must not be missed on your visit to Cambodia just to see how the trees intertwine with the ruins as seen on the film Tomb Raider.
Nature and architecture as one beauty. Pictures don't do it justice. The century old stones and the trees engulfment of the temple shows power of nature and the beautiful history hand in hand!

Must visit for Angkor visitors. Like most temples in the Angkor complex, a visitor walks through the Ta Prohm from one end to the other. This particular temple draws more attention than many others on account of some of its parts being overgrown by enormous tree roots, an aspect of the place that gave it a place in the Angelina Jolie-starrer Tomb Raider. The extra attention implies a much higher number of visitors in peak season, but most people are considerate about taking turns to click pictures. It is a must-see for visitors to the Angkor complex.
Tomb raider - definitely worth a visit!!. You can't miss this on your temple tours. There are a lot of visitors but you can find some quiet spots and it's amazing to see a temple as it was found.

A must for Tomb Raider Fan. One of the reasons I got so excited to see the temple up close and personal is the fact that I wanted to remember some scene from the film Tomb Raider: Cradle to Life. The ruins were so amazing. And yes the spots where Angelina Jolie climb mesmerized me. Some parts were reconstructed but we enjoyed it much!

A must see. Beautiful location on the standard tours that guides will offer you. Once you have seen it you will understand why. The temple looks like how your imagination would picture discovering a temple forgotten in the jungle for years (partly because this is the picture used by publicists for the purpose) so do take the time to see it for yourself. It is busy and the inevitable Angelina Jolie comments will happen but enjoy it. You will see how nature has combined trees and vines to grow through or around the temple and it is stunning. Reconstruction work is taking place and only time will show whether the archaeological theory eliminates the atmosphere, hopefully it will show sympathy to the traveller's impression by retaining some of the jungle's intrusion.

Great photo opportunity. This is a very popular temple and well worth a visit. You will have the opportunity for the classic photo alongside the massive roots that grow through the structure. We found the other tourists generally pretty reasonable at taking turns to allow each other to go up for a photo, without hordes climbing over it simultaneously.
Ta Prohm WOW!!. The pictures tell the story of this amazing place where nature has reclaimed its old temples as part of its own....Imagine being the discoverer of this place all those years ago!!

Tomb raider temple. You need to buy a pass that lasts for 3 days that way you can spend day one in the temples, the second day relax, take a boat on Tonle Sep, and then go back to the temples on day 3. This way you really enjoy the experience especially at this time of year when it's really hot and tiring, The site is amazing and there is so much to see. Good toilet facilities.

Kapok Trees, Roots and Marvellous Ruins. This is a famous site among the several in Ankgor Wat. This is the one with the roots of massive Kapok trees (used during WWII to make life jacket filler) encompass many of the walls of the temple. It is a challenge for preservationists as the tree roots ever so relentlessly pry walls apart. We enjoyed this site even more than the major Ankgor Wat Temple ruin--perhaps because it was shady.

Walk-through temple in reconstruction. Forgot any hope on good photo, this place is for more years under reconstruction, but it is the main photographed place there in Angkor Thom ancient city. All romantical photos with monks and treess inside destroyed buidilngs were from here, but! So there is an stage for photographers and sometimes you can wait for your "romantical" photo till to 20 minutes because the herd of visitors will do the photo of life one by one! Go there at evening or in the morning or after the rain. Be careful before pickpockets!!
Amazing. All of these sites are amazing. If you go to Siem Reap take them all in. Buy the multi-day pass and go to the surrounding temples too.

Not Just Where "Tomb Raider" Was Filmed. Ta Prohm gained notoriety for being the location for "Tomb Raider" but it's so much more than that. The temple provides an amazing view of the intertwining of nature and architecture with the huge tree roots and the crumbling temple structure.

Tomb raider. This temple is where they filmed Tomb Raider. As we had not seen the film it meant nothing to us but the temple is also known as the jungle temple as it has been reclaimed by nature. It is a 13 century Buddhist temple with many ornate carvings discribing a war that was fought at that time & also the feasting afterwardsWe were there in the middle of the morning so the temperature was climbing. Also my blood pressure as at this time of day there are loads of Chinese & Koreans tours who take every opportunity to take photographs, they also seem to have an official tour photographer who takes photographs of the tour taking photos of the temples. It was therefore difficult to take photos with all the people about.Be aware if you are in Cambodia around Chinese New Year, there will be a lot if Chinese & Koreans there as it is an official holiday.
Unreal. Everything close by was amazing the history and the ruins, made you take stock of the modern world, it was hard to imagine hundreds of years ago people lived and prayed here.

the best temple. This is the best temple where the trees grow out of the rocks. It is best if you can go there very very early (6am) to avoid both the heat and the crowd. This is my favorite temple, it really gives you the indian jones feel.

Simply Fascinating. This temple was a must stop on our trip of Angkor. About an hour in the temple is sufficient and gives you an idea of the havoc nature played with these temples, and why they are truly called ruins. This has a lot of rocks lying out of place, so I would recommend being careful with young children.

Best to go with a guide. There are many interesting factoids about this place but during the first bit of the tour we were by ourselves. A helpful local guide gave us an impromptu history of some of the hidden charms we would have otherwise missed.

A truly magical place. A truly magical place. The majestic trees helped over shadowed the hordes of tourists while the temple ruins themselves seem to gain a life of their own as they engaged in their millennium long tangled dance with the roots.If you ignore the bits of construction, and avoid the main tourist paths, and open up your imagination, you can still find a glimpse of what might have been there in an era long past.

Get there early!. We went there just after sunrise so there weren't many people around. This enabled us to experience the site at its best - slightly eerie and awe-inspiring. Make sure you get there early!
Best temple. If you see this place your mouth stays open!!!! Absolutely fantastic !!!! We loved this place, all the other temples are nice but this is the cake .

Ta Prohm. I believe nature has its own way. This temple is really awesome. Those people who are yet to see such a beautiful creation must visit this site. i pray these trees will stay strong and be there for the next 500 years.... amazing.
Probably our favourite temple. The trees are a thing of wonder, the ruins amazing and the work that has been done to reconstruct the fallen temples is fantastic.Peaceful and thought provoking.

Very intriguing place, don't miss it.. If you are in Siem Reap you should visit all the temples like Ta Prohm. The magnificent tree roots that have merged with the temple remains over the centuries; giving the feeling of a forgotten and mysterious place. The UNESCO should not allow to film movies there like Tomb Raider. Don't miss to see the fantastic carvings all over the place, sometimes overwhelmed by the giant roots.
Must see this one.. There are many many temples but this one is particularly interesting with all the trees growing through it.

Temple taking over by trees. Ta Prohm is a amazing temple with the trees reclaiming the land . Just when you think you are wat 'ed out you come to Ta Prohm it's amazing and so tranquil and not as busy as some of the other temples . Like a few of the other temples there is construction going on , but it does not spoil this amazing place . It's nice that there is plenty of shade to avoid the heat .its a must see while you are in Siem Reap . Enjoy !

Laura Croft nowhere to be seen!. We had this temple virtually to ourselves - it was stunning and well worth a visit to see the contorted tree taking back the land that this temple sits on. Quite surreal.
Avoid during the middle of the day!. Too many tour groups ruin the experience, otherwise fascinating temple. Temple ruins dominated by the surrounding jungle.

Tomb Raider ruined this temple.. This is a smaller Temple complex, but because of the popularity of Tomb Raider is WAY to crowded. There are a couple other temples that have trees and growth...go to those and skip this. The buses of tourists and everyone taking selfies of themselves there was obnoxious and gross.

Do this one at dawn. Best temple by far, with huge trees poking through and hanging overhead. This is Angelina's temple (from Tomb Raider) and so much reconstruction remains that you will get a sense of what the first explorers found. We went at dawn and had it all to ourselves. A top memory of our Asia trip.

Temple of Roots. This Buddhist temple is located in a very dense jungle invaded by tall banyan,fig and kapok trees.Over centuries the roots of these trees had engulfed the very structure of the temple.Ta Prohm ( ancestor Brahma ) was built in dedication for the king's mother at that time.This temple was left in ruins and the authencity of the place is still maintained.It is breathtaking to see how the enormous roots had intertwined in the structure of the buildings.It is a sure sight not to be missed by tourists,especially photographers.There are ample shades to relax around the temple.

Stunning . While walking around the grounds you can imagine what a beautiful place this once was. It's a pity that the trees have destroyed such a beautiful temple but then again it's what makes it so special and unique today. You can see the wonderful restoration work been carried out by the Cambodian archeology team with the help of India. I can imagine that in 10 years time this magical place will be even more beautiful.

A dream come true, but.... I would give Ta Prohm 5 stars because it is amazing. No doubts about that. An absolute beauty in the jungle.But I cannot. And I am quite sad about it, but still - I cannot. Letting such hordes of tourists in (and I won't mention the nationality, but I guess all Angkor visitors know what I mean) and letting them behave in such despicable manner is outrageous. This beautiful, mysterious temple has been transformed into some sort of movie set / ancient Disneyland: one path to follow, basically breathing on other tourists' neck, in a really substantial crowds, listening to guides and package tourists shouting... No mystery at all. No peace, no quiet. On top of it all, restoration is being done, and from what I saw, it's not good... I guess, it's not perfect now, but still - visit it before it turns to concrete. Because it will, soon.I know it's a bit hypocritical to complain about the crowds while being a part of one, but the whole point here is not that it's lots of people - it's how they behave. It's an absolute circus, and I am quite surprised to see the guards doing nothing about that. Funny enough, they found it necessary to approach and scold my boyfriend who was wearing a hat (solely as sun protection), but were ignoring the bus-loads of tourists who were shouting, throwing rubbish around, and generally disrespecting the place altogether.Such a shame, this place deserves better.
Tree temple. This was a most interesting temple very old and different with the tree roots in the buildingsOnly dislike was it was very busy

Bring out your inner Indiana Jones at this site!. If you're a fan of ancient architecture and mysterious structures, you've come to the right place. The walls are full of carvings, you can spend an entire exploring and taking it all in but of course there are so many temples to get to.

Historical!. One of the most impressive temples that you can find. There are trees that are thousand years old, most parts in this place has been crumbled down, but I can see that the people are trying to restore the place.

restaurations. Ta Prohm was my favorite of all temples in the Angkor Wat area. Unfortunately they had to start restaurating or in another 100 years the jungle would have totally taken over. This means that the most beautiful views are obstructed by work people, machines and all kinds of support systems to keep the lot from falling down. Absolutely necessary, but a little bit disappointing still. Thankfully I'd seen it before they started this renovations, so I still have unspoiled pictures!

Beautiful!. To see the trees growing out of this structure is just amazing! We had no problem with tourists. Everyone seemed to be spaced out even though it was Chinese New Year. An unforgettable temple and they have done a great job propping it up so visitors can come and see. What a fabulous place it must have been once upon a time. You can still see the beauty of what it once was. Definitely worth a visit!
Awesome - but busy. One of the main temples to go to at Angkor Wat but thanks to Angelina Jolie and Tomb Raider its very busy - try and get there early. Well worth it though.

Amazing sunrise?. You should go there very early, before sunrise, to watch the first sun rays ingnite this special temple in golden color. Unfortunately it was a little cloudy/hazy and no gold color was observed. But the power of nature, with the trees entangles within the bricks and stone towers is very unusual and has its own charm. Great restoration and preservation works are in process and the temple is fantastic. Do not miss it.

Stunning: jungle-covered temples - a merger of nature and man-made structures. Unbelievable sight - I thought you only see these in the movies - where the jungle was left untouched to wrap around temples and structures. I could spend the whole day here and marvel at nature combining with man's intricate handiwork. While it is apparent that this site has been neglected and abandoned in the past, it is still amazing to see trees growing out of the ruins. There are 2 gates: East and West and because of the collapsed state of many buildings, visitors often have to go around in circles and can easily get lost among the buildings. My wife and I got separated from our group and it took awhile to find and rejoin the group.

Small, but worth it. I generally preferred the smaller ancient structures around Siem Reap. This one was no exception. Although not as well restored as some of the larger areas, the intimate feeling, the way nature has taken over and started to take it all back is fascinating. I recommend this one once you come all this way. As I have said regarding other smaller Wats you can visit, I think you do not need a guide, although that may just be a matter of personal preference. Try to get to the smaller ones when most tour buses are at Thom and Ankor Wat (just my experience, but people seem to come to these after they visit one of the larger ones at the beginning of their day).
The place, lovely. The place where they shot tomb raider if you don't know! Its a lovely place filled with history and culture, apart from the angkor wat and the bayon temple of course.

Ta Prohm of Tomb Raider fame. Awesome!!! Nature overtaking stone..its really something. Giant trees and roots submerging parts of an ancient temple...one has to cross slightly precarious bridges and fallen stones, to get to it, but its totally worth it. Yes there are a lot of tourists, but , it does not detract from the experience. There is a statue of one of the Apsaras ,divine angels, within the confines of thick Roots, much like a hollow in which an owl would sit..and further on one can be photographed between the roots of a tree which are almost as big as a partition between rooms .

Amazing place. All the tree roots climbing through the stones of this temple are really amazing. A pity about all the tourists though! We were there in the afternoon and you could hardly move. Very difficult to get any photos. Worth trying to see something of it though.

Go early in the morning. Try to get here early 8:30, before the tour buses arrive. There is now a fixed walkway to get around the temple complex without climbing on the stonework itself. Very atmospheric when not crowded. The trees still embedded in the structure are great for photographs, but they are still damaging the infrastructure more and more each year

Incredible. I've never seen any place like it. It's amazing to see all the trees grow out of the temple that was once abandoned. I love to look at different shape of trees which are very unique as they try to grow from the most unusual place. I went there about lunch time so there were not as many tourists as the other temples.

Lakwatsera sa Cambodia. Ta Prohm really nice there.. Amazing place to go in CAMBODIA. Lots of temple there. I really enjoy most the called tomb raider. Angkor watt. Beautiful along sunshine. Buts... I have BIG COMMENT about over all The City. Itself...Honestly speaking I won't go back again to this country. Most of them are liar even the travel agency. We been there with my friends last December only to be disappointed about their tourism. People are Crap! Some of them or most of them but there's a bit consideration with the other Cambodian people.when we are there. From the border they will take you ride a bus for free going to the next area which the taxi or service car will transfer to City of CAMBODIA to find hotel. Beware if the taxi stop over in the area which a lot of TUKTUK service. It's ok to ride TUKTUK going to the hotel you like. Or better told them from the beginning that you have already hotel to stay. Your friend is waiting for you there. So that they don't have any chance to chase you. Because Somebody will ask you if you have tour JUST SAY YES you already have. Don't entertain them they will follow you to the hotel. But ask them politely that you already have tour and say Thank You. Some people there are not contented with the TIP.. I wonder how's the difference between the same amount of RIEL = US$ They don't want their money. Advice: Better to have a package with your agency rather than getting package when you're there. It's worts! In consideration with Food it's great, the night market you can buy items with cheaper price. They have also their own version of Shabu shabu. It s yummy and affordable. I just hope Cambodian tourism could penalized those tour guide and agency who violate the rights of Tourist.

Tomb Raiders Territory!. This is where the trees are intertwined among the ruins. We really enjoyed seeing nature reclaiming this temple. This was the temple chosen to be left in its natural state, and they have done much work to prop up the ruins while letting the tree roots show their strength. Strangler figs and silk-cotton trees are wedging roots into the masonry of the temple. We had hoped to have photos without hordes of tourists, but this is difficult to do. Of course, it's a little silly to complain about the tourists when we are also part of the overwhelming amount of people. I don't thinkk you can hold the popularity of this place against Ta Prohm!

Better than angkor wat. In my opinion this is the jewel in the crown. An amazing place with all kinds do of wild and weird tree roots. When we got here 8.30 ish it was just starting to get busy so my advice would be to maybe go here first,to get some truly awesome photos.
Smaller temple, great trees. I loved the trees in this temple and seeing the restoration work that has been done and is still in progress. I plan to watch Tomb Raider when I get home.

Fascinating. If you are going here, you musst have a guide and plenty of water to drink. This is a fascinating temple where the large trees grow out of the temple. You will need to buy a day or multi day pass to visit the area

Love the temple, don't love the crowds. There is a ancient and mysterious feel to this temple complex. With over grown vines and roots gripping the stone structures, and enormous trees shading the courtyards, this really is a sight to behold. The bricks are crumbling, and corridors have collapsed, and the entire temple is in danger of one day falling to the ground.
