Having said that, it is a shame that tour companies converge on this place and allow their clients to blatantly disrespect the signs that say "Do not climb on this site", "Do not touch". If so many thousands are allowed to behave without respect at this site, everyday, we will one day lose it.

Amazing trees. This is where Tomb Raiders was filmed and seeing this in person was just amazing. Ta Prohm has been left in much the same condition in which it was found: the photogenic and atmospheric combination of trees growing out of the ruins and the jungle surroundings have made it one of Angkor's most popular temples with visitors.

Amazing. This was our favourite of the Angkor temples. As you approach it you feel you are stepping back in time. It is incredible how nature is reclaiming this building for its own. Very atmospheric. A must see!

no longer the icon that it was in the 1990s. The temple is still a sight to behold, but it is now overrun by tourists. The restoration project is arguably one of the bigger controversies in Siem Reap, but it is happening and there's not much the anti-restoration camp can do about it.

One word can't describe how good is this Temple (Wat). Not far from Siem Reap, is this absolutely stunning temple of Ta Prohm. The movie Lara Croft Tomb Raider was filmed here many years ago, but it didn't show off all the brilliant features of this Wat. Nature is slowly taking back this place after humans made the building, many years ago. The trees and their roots intermingling through the Wat walls are breath taking and make great photo shots. This place is a must to visit and please do not rush in and out. Stunning
Temples Exploration. Loved it! Most amazing temple in Cambodia. Nature taking over is just fantastic to see. A lot of tourists so get there early!

A real Indiana Jones experience. This is the temple we had most wanted to visit, and to see it early in the morning just after dawn and before the crowds assembled we were not disappointed. A great opportunity for photos and video where you can capture the squawking green parrots in the background. This is where trees grow out of the stonework and is the most natural site in the area as the temple is being stabilised rather than renovated.

the wonderworld. Early in the morning I have found Ta Prohm in a a good condition to visit and admire the photogenic atmosphee of the trees growing out of the ruins and the jungle surroundings. It's an unforgettable experience and makes me wonder how such advanced civilisation in a such a primitive era has dissapeard ...
Unique experience. The way the trees have taken over and covered the buildings just has to be seen. A unique experience.

Tomb Raiders remembered. The Laura Croft movie made this site a legend and it certainly is a wonderful place to visit and get a sense of the Khmer Architecture. Loved it and the grounds around. Just note which direction you enter from as there are two parking lots to find your bus or Tuk Tuk.

Tomb Rider scenery. The biggest archaeological puzzle in the world being solved little by little every day. I was here two years ago and when I came back now there was a new temple standing where there were just big stone blocks! Not to mention the tree roots "hugging" the temples and our hearts.

More then just the Tomb Raider temple!. Must see temple in Siem Reap! It is a popular temple for tourists as a scene from Tomb Raider was filmed here however this temple has so much more to offer. It is a truly beautiful place to visit. I took some of my favourite temple photos at Ta Prohm!

my husbands favourite. went there at 0600 so missed the crowds and had sunlights first rays on the stone.
Loved the bird and animal noises of the dawn chorus made the whole experience fantastic, amazing temple.
Only problem was the very aggressive tarantula on the walkway rearing up as you got close!

Famous for the tree. Like our guide put it, Ta Prohm got famous because of "Tomb Rider" and I agreed after the visit. The temple was not that impressed and the visitors were queuing before the giant tree just to get a shot. A good rest after Angkor Wat.

Very cool place to see. The trees growing in and about the temples were amazing. We went on a Saturday and it was just too crowded to enjoy. Couldn't get any good pictures without a bunch of people. Imwouldms commend not going on the weekend and going early or perhaps later in the afternoon when everyone else is going back to their hotels

Packed!. Very cool, but unlike Angkor Thom/Angkor Wat, the passageways are too narrow for the crowds- this one gets packed and difficult to navigate in many locations. See it for the overgrowth, but take your sense of humor and patience.
fantastic. Wonderful place with big tree. It must see. The whole place is mystic and magic. Here was Tomb Raider story.
My fav temple. This temple is so cool! It feels like you are in the Tomb Raider movie. I loved exploring this temple! Lots of fun!

The most unique. Everyone knows about Angkor Wat. That's a crowded but good place to go. The Bayon was my favorite.But this was a close second. The TaProhm temple was the most unique and interesting as we saw lots of trees and vegetation taking over and growing through each stone of the temple. It's a very cool experience to see man and nature fighting. (Spoiler alert - nature is winning). Bring your camera - bring your bottled water and hike it out. It's less crowded than the other places. About 40minutes from town by TukTuk.
Good. Not too far to get to, enough things inside to keep you interested, not too crowded. A bit of restoration construction happening

take your time. visited here with private guide, so pace was at out timetable not a group one! the setting and the atmosphere with the trees growing out and over the complex is stunning, visited late morning, but as the trees give shade and light streams through highlighting the walls and carvings, if visiting, do try to find the hidden statue that is framed by some roots, the image and carving are almost pristine due to the way the roots have framed it and are now sheltering it from the rain, again take your time to explore and relax don't jut fly through or your wasting your time even going, might as well stay in the bar!

Amazing but get there early.. Have to say out of all the temples in the archaeological park this was my favourite. It has quite an eerie feel to it until the bus loads of chinese arrive with their unconventional poses :p That added to the entertainment for me. Restoration work is currently going on and it's great to see some of the work that has been done so far. The colour of the bricks, the carving's & the huge tree's strangling the temple make it very special and unique. Even if you are visiting Siem Reap for a few days and struggle for time to fit it in I recommend finding an hour or so. Breathtaking!
A tourist sight. Nice but full of people taking pictures and selfies. Why do people prefer to look at themselves rather than at the place? They could do that at home and leave Ta Prohm to the rest.

Tomb Raider Temple. This feels like you are in the middle of that movie.The trees are winding around the temple, it is a bit overcrowded from chinese visitors, but if you make you way through you will find your personal photo spot at that area.We had a guide and that helped, if you go on your own you should read about it beforeyou visit.

Amazing. Another fantastic temple, and very interesting history, I highly recommend having a guide. The trees growing amongst the ruins are amazing, as is the restoration that is taking place...an amazing jigsaw puzzle to be solved.
Wounderful Temple. I like the view and natural around that area. Wish to come again, I recommend that all visitor of Siem Reap do not miss this place

The Tomb Raider temple.. This temple stands out for it's overgrowth with old trees, which made it a perfect setting for a brief 1 - 2 minutes in the first Tomb Raider movie (if you want to check in the movie, about 2 minutes in), you can find the gnarly roots which are in several Angelina Jolie screen caps from that film. There is also a unique 'echo chamber' in the middle. This temples seems to be a favorite among visitors, maybe because it is shadier, smaller ... and has this really cool Indiana Jones vibe.

The best of them all...... The temples and palaces around Angkor Wat are superb....but this location is the top. The Spong ( spong ....I am told ...is correct) Trees have created a mystical atmosphere with roots growing in and around the building creating a scene well known to many from the Tomb Raider film. But don't go there just because of its Hollywood claims. Marvel at the dilemma between saving the stone or protecting nature and her trees. A visual (and photographic) delight

Incredible. Huge roots lay in these incredible ruins. This is a fantastic temple and a must see in Siem Reap.It does get quite busy though so be prepared for big crowds and queues to get photos with the trees. Worth it though.Definitely check it out.

A must see. Ta Prohm was used as a set for the Tomb Raider film and it is obvious why. I have been wanting to see this up close for a long time and it was all I expected and more. Nature is well on the way to reclaiming the temple and the resulting effect is awesome. A personal favourite. Like all the temples it is always crowded but be patient and you can get wonderful photos with out another tourist in the frame. Sadly some damage was done by the scaffolding used by the film crew. Our guide was concerned that this did not happen again.
Must go here!. My favorite temple do bisit this one a little out of the way but worth it. I love that it has been taken back by nature

Wild. Ta Prohm was probably my favourite temple on my recent trip to Cambodia. It may lack the grandeur of Angkor Wat, but it's slightly less hectic, and I also enjoyed the shade provided by those trees. There are so many photo opportunities, and it's truly amazing to see the battle between nature and the man-made structure. Highly recommended.

Amazing. From the West entrance, you will have to walk all the way to the temple and there are shops just outside the temple where they will force you to buy books, paintings or other souvenir items. They are doing some restoration on some parts of the temple. This is where they shot the movie Tomb Raider, the intricate carvings in the temple is really amazing. The main attraction of Ta Prohm is the big trees that cast their roots on parts of the temple.
So peaceful!. We were lucky in we went to this temple and missed the crowds (we were there around 4:30). It was peaceful and gorgeous. We didn't want to leave!

Get there early. Ta Promh, it's the Tomb Raider set and the great big tree roots slowly wrecking these great stone structures makes for some very atmospheric ruins. A personal favourite on the temple route.

Allocate about two hours for this one. Initially I was put off by the volume of tourists but I soon realised that two thirds of people do not go far into the temple. We went through to the middle and back areas where there were very few people, quiet and peaceful and a great place to relax and enjoy the moment.

Trees, growing out of ruins. Ta Prohm, pronuonced as Ta Proh, is the modern name of the temple in Angkor. At the entrance, what touched us most was , a physically challenged group of men, rendering soulful, melodious music with instruments. This was originally called Rajavihara, built in the late 12th century. It was founded by King Jayavarman as the Buddhist Monastery and University. The trees are very very old, the big roots of the banyan trees themselves look like trees. At some places, the roots have formed shapes like pyramid. People stand and pose infront of these tree like roots and click photographs.This is one of the most distinctive features of Ta Prohm, that the trees are growing out of ruins. Unesco has inscribed Ta Prohm on the World Heritage list. It is one of the temple complexes, visited by tourists from all over the world. There are entrance gopurams at each of the cardinal points, but we can access it only through the east and west entrances. An excellent place, which draws so much crowd!!!

Awesome!. This is in my opinion the best of the ruins in Siem Reap. It hasn't been restored much, other then making it safe for tourist. The photo-ops are endless, and it just looks fantastisc!easily combined with a trip to Bayon and Ankor Wat

We enjoyed this more than the famous Angkor Wat. We find Ta Prohm more interesting than the famous Angkor Wat for it's uniqueness not only because of its ancient history but for the nature that surrounds it. The huge trees and roots that hugging the old temples are amazing. If you are not claustrophobic walk inside the ruined and explore, you'll be surprise of the beauty of tree roots taking over of the ruined. Ta Prohm is now called Angelina Jolie's temple because of her movie Tomb Raider. To get a good photo you have to be patient as it gets crowded specially during mid day. At the entrance, lots of vendors even young kids trying to sell you souvenirs, ignore them if you are not interested to buy.

Ta Prohm Temple. Wow, what an amazing and mysterious place!This Temple should be on your 'to see' list. You won't believe the size of the trees and their roots over and in through the ruins until you see it for yourself. This Temple was filmed in the movie 'Tomb Raider'.

Worth it. We visited Ta Prohm after Bayon and Angkor Wat... And it was definitely my favorite. The jungle setting is so much more intimate than the open grasses of Angkor Wat. Tomb Raider or not, it shows the power that nature and time has over anything man-made...

you can chose between Ta Phrom and Preah Khan. We are a family of 3 (2 adults and a 10 year old kid). We got an overall of 5 days in the Angkor Archeological Part.First of all, be ready for a very warm and humid weather and second be ready for many steps up and down.Like many others we got to visit Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom with all the temples within: Bayon, Baphoun, and the Elephant and Leper King Terraces. In the second day we left the Angkor complex behind and we visit the Khbal Speam, Preah Khan and Bantey Srei and finally Ta Phrom and Beng Mealea in the day 3.I would say Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom are must do! Ta Phrom and Preah Khan share the same feeling with gigantic threes growing in the temple. And Finally Beng Mealea where the work for restoration is still on very initial stages so I wonder you can see something “closer” on what the explores found here 100 years ago.The ticket costs USD 20 for a single day or USD 40 for 3 days.Regarding time, you can spend easily from 2 hours to half-day.

difficult to avoid the tourists but very beautiful. This is a wonderful space - the massive trees growing on top of beautiful temples - buildings in states of disrepair. It has a special beauty. Ask your guide when the least touristy time will be. The spaces are small and narrow. Often filled with tourists trying to look like tomb raider - which seemed a bit uncouth. The many patways and ruins take a bit to get through but it is worth seeing the many spaces.
Magical. We got there at sunrise; very few other people there; well worth the extra effort for magical experience.

Lara Croft. It's setback a bit from the road, and would probably be a bit creepy leading up to it but for all the people.Inside is really interesting. The tree roots are literally coming up wherever they can, and piercing and growing over the structure.For those not in the know, Tomb Raider was also filmed here.

My favourite of all the wats. we went by Tuk Tuk from the hotel to the Angkor site. We saw this temple on the short route. Maybe it's because of the movies made there, not sure, but the roots and trees growing over and out of the temples was mesmerizing. I couldn't wait to see more and take more pictures. Definitely do not miss this one! It's hot, hot, hot out there so take water, hat,etc. and be warned everything is sandy/dusty. No will have very dirty feet at the end of the day. But worth it. We got the 3 day pass, which is same price as 2 day pass. Be sure you have your pass with you, they do check frequently.
Also a must-see temple. Even though at first sceptic because of movie decor, but we all felt a feeling of serenity when entering this temple. The intertwining of the trees with the ruins are amazing.

Huge trees. The place is huge. A lot of restoration work is in progress when we visited in February 2015, with cables, supporting the trees, foundation, construction workers working on site. We were amazed at how the trees grew onto the temple buildings.

Nature power. It is not just a movie set, our tuk tuk driver refers Ta Prohm as the Angelina Jolie temple due to its site as a movie set for Tomb Raider. The whole place is just amazing with trees growing out of the temple and both man made structure and nature co-exist with each other. The whole area is just amazing with huge trees and ruined temple buildings that has to give way to nature.It is a long and dusty walk to the temple so bring along water, caps and hats. You will have to be patient enough to take good pictures as the crowd is overwhelming in this site. There will be locals trying to swarm you with all sorts of souvenirs from the main gate, so decline as polite as possible if you are not interested.

Somewhat Creepy. This is a fun place, somewhat creepy with trees embedded into the structure. They are working on some repairs but it's slow going. This is definitely worth a visit but it's hard to walk around.
A great part of the Angkor experience. This is not as crowded as the other temples and well worth the visit as each temple is differant than any of the others.

The power of nature. The temple is a live evidence for nature's power. First man concurred the place and built a temple. When the Kemers had to retreat to Phnom Penn, nature send his arms in the shape of a jungle and concurred the ground back. See the huge trees emerge from the ruins of temple and know who won.

Nature at its best!! Just an Awsome place to visit!. This is one of the most amazing sites in the park! To see the trees take over the place and the size of them is simply amazing! If you like to take pictures...this is the place to be!Only "small" downfall. The popularity of the site makes it very hard to get pictures without tourists in them! Just need to be patient and the shot will come. To be on your Temple list!!
Man versus nature. This site gives an overwhelvingly demonstration that in the end nature will be the winner in the struggle of man versus nature

More than a movie set.. While it's difficult to avoid Angie while you're here, it can be done, even though many of the folks around you are here for that reason. While it's stunning in it's own rite, it's also great for getting a feeling for the international effort that's being expended to restore all of these sites. Were it not for the efforts of the UN, we wouldn't have the opportunity to experience them. O.K. it's pretty cool as a movie set too.

A stunning temple. A beautiful & fascinating temple almost as famous for the extraordinary & enormous tree roots wrapping themselves around the buildings as it is for the buildings themselves. A very worthwhile visit.

One of the must sees, but go early to avoid selfie stick crowd!. An amazing place to visit, full of mystery and intrigue, with the tree roots battling against the stone walls! Top tip would be to go early before tourist buses arrive with the selfie stick crowds, as you wont get any decent pictures once they do, as it seems every one of them want a picture in the same place!
Highly over rated. This temple became famous after the movie- but some of the other temples in the Angkor complex are much better

Natural beauty. Having seen photos of the site I don't think I realised how tall and old and majestic some of the trees are. Most of the restoration work here has been very sympathetically done but as so much of the site was quite unstable I and sure in places they had very little choice. A lovely contrast to the other 2 main sites.
Must visit when in Siem Reap. A very interesting place to visit. A must while in Siem Reap. You will be doing a lot of walking over dusty soil on uneven surfaces.

Come early morning. While this site doesn't offer the grand sunrise views like Angkor Wat, I would recommend spending one of your sunrises here. This place is absolutely magical in the early morning here without the crowds. The crowds will get here around 7:30am though, but that should give you a good hour, hour and half to explore the place almost on your own, with a few other intrepid travelers. Ta Prohm with the crowds is a very mediocre site to visit. The area is just too small, and too many people will jockey for the famous photograph spots.
Amazing temple. This temple is fantastic, incredible to see huge roots of massive trees wrap themselves around the walls of the temple. Quite eerie and best seen near dusk as it becomes quite scary.

Beautiful. Love this place. You can wander off the beaten track and see no one. Get plenty of drinks. Don't worry about needing the loo. You'll be so dehydrated that won't matter. It's just like tomb raider only better because it's real. Love it, you should go.

One not to miss!. Spend a bit of time there, look for the little lady hidden between the tree roots, take as many picture as you can, it is less crowded in the early afternoon.
The place is magical, might be worth an evening trip...
One of the best ruins. This temple is a must visit. See the trees clawing back their land, the amazing restoration work on one of the buildings. To me this was the best temple.

Better than your Imagination. Seeing is believing!
The only thing you need is MORE time to take it all in!
Spectacular place we will come back one day for sure!

Worth a visit. This temple is worth a visit purely because it is different. Also if you have seen Tomb Raider you will relate to it. Has many tourists so beware it does get busy!
Charge your cameras, you can get some great photos here!

The pick of the temples. Cambodia and Siem Reap are noted for Angkor Wat temple and quite rightly so. But Ta Prohm has something mysterious about it that makes it an even more enjoyable visit than Angkor Wat itself.That said, do both (at the very least)!!!!!As with all temples, this is not a place for people who are unable to do a little bit of basic climbing over rocks.

A history in itself long before Lara Croft. What you see in Lara Croft film by Angelina Jolie does not do this place any justice. Read the history and you will be amazed by the artistic touches by the ancient Khmers. Ta Phrom and the entire ancient city of Angkor are the oriental version of infamous Maya sites of Central America. A must-visit if you're in Siem Reap for a couple of days. In dry season, the weather gets really hot from noon till sundown so bring plenty of water. Also, the entire Angkor complex can get very dusty due to the dry south-westerly wind so ensure to put on your anti-dust mask when you go out. Dusty air and hot climate during the period of dry season from November to April could cause one to end up with throat-related illnesses if you're too exposed to the elements. I prefer to visit Angkor at the beginning or the end of wet season as the air is always fresh and dust is pretty much washed down by the monsoon rain. It does not rain all day during wet season though. There's still some dry spell and one can be lucky to not encounter any rain for one or two days throughout the trip.
Impressive!. Ta Prohm's state of ruin is a state of beauty. Cool shade of the trees and the temple's hallways protect one from the sun's heat.

Ta Prohm was my favourite Angkorian Temple. We started out at Ta Prohm, made notably famous more recently as the ‘Tomb Raider’ temple. The fascinating highlights from Ta Prohm, are the huge trees that seem to have taken over the entire temple. Some trees have stretched out their roots to take over walls and it’s something that you really have to see to believe. A lot of the structure is also in ruins and while we visited there was some restoration work going on. We were amazed at the age at which the temples stood. Ta Prohm was built as a Buddhist temple, dedicated to the mother of King Jayavarman VII in 1186. It was a temple that really caught my imagination and for me, it was the best temple of Angkor. What we adored about the temples was the rustic and atmospheric feel, the intricate details of the carvings and the rich history of the Angkorian temples. The stones are placed at such precision and complex interlocking shapes, that it is impossible to fit even a single piece of paper between them. Whether you have one week or one day in Siem Reap, I would definitely recommend coming to Angkor Wat and seeing the famous Angkorian temples. Unlike other modern temples in Thailand and other parts of Cambodia, these aged temples offer more dramatic and atmospheric views. Would definitely recommend going around midday when most people are having their lunch if you want a quieter experience - we did and was worth it. Many people told us we would need a minimum of three days for the temples which would cost $60 (per person) and around $60 (for a Tuk-Tuk driver for three days). We were able to see most of the large temples, stop off at the smaller ones and even had time for ice cream and lunch before the sun set over the temples in just one day. The day ticket is only $20 (per person) and if you arrive around 7:00am, you will have more than enough time to visit the temples including Angkor Wat. There are absolutely loads of temples though, so if these are your thing then a multi-pass deal might be for you.If arriving to Siem Reap by bus, avoid at all costs the locals who almost pounce on you at the bus station. Their prices are extortionate compared to the services your hotel will offer. One local tried selling to us, thinking I didn’t understand the exchange rate. When calculating this in my head I told him no and he got very aggressive and shouted something in Khmer as we left the station. Their selling tactics are very hard sell – they don’t give you time to think and before you know it you’re reaching for your wallet. Speaking to many travellers on our journey we have heard many similar stories.

Unbelievably fascinating. We went there in the late afternoon when the sun was hitting the trees just right. Gave the place more of an air of mystery. I kept thinking Indiana Jones would show up. It was just so impressive with the trees intertwined with the ruins. One of the highlights of my trip. Am thinking about going back!

This is what happens if you don't tend to your garden a few centuries. Trolls would like it here. It is a mystical place with its overgrown, massive trees that have partially devoured the temple and shattered its walls. This makes this site stand apart from the other temples on the tourist circuit. Another interesting feature is the remarkable reconstruction work that has been carried out for decades.

One of my favorite places on earth. If you love history, archaeology, photography, or very old dramatic trees, this is going to be one of your favorite places too! A cool break from the other temples of Angker as it is forested. It has become a lot busier over the past few years, but, is still a lot quiter than the main temple area.

BEAUTIFUL PLACE. Such a beautiful place, with the trees grown up on the top of the buildings. This is impressive. A good guide would help yo understand the place and historical facts. We would have missed a ot without the person we hired (tourist center)

Overrated. Ta Prohm has been made famous by the scene in Lara Croft Tomb Raider the movie. It is quite small inside this temple and the crowds make it almost impossible to move through the site. While the overgrowth of the jungle and trees surrounding the stones is cool to see, prefer Beng Mealea (~1 hour drive to Siem Reap). This temple is less popular but has the same effect and less crowds.

Worth to visit. This temple has huge trees and roots growing throuhg the temple. There are many great spot for photos. However, it quite busy temple because Tomb Raider used it for shooting location, so visit in the morning to avoide the crowd.

Must see temple - Ta Prohm. We were lucky enough to watch sunrise at Ta Prohm - even though it was an early pick up, it was worth it! There were only 2 couples & our guides as most of the tourist visit Angkor Wat for sunrise! So we had the whole temple yo ourselves........ Which was great! I believe it gets very busy From 8am onwards.

Trees and Temples!. Wonderful temples with an array of trees and roots growing through them. A most surreal sight but makes for wonderful photos! Would recommend this Temple to anyone and put on a list of must see things in Seam Reap!Very interesting!

Ta Prohm should not be missed. One of the must see temples of Cambodia, very easy to view as part of a temple tour. Alongside Angkor Thom and the Bayon, Ta Prohm is a must see. If it were anywhere else, the temple would be world famous. Here, it lives in the shadows of the better known Angkor Wat, but that does not mean it can be ignored.
Ta Prohm. This is a very busy temple thanks to Lara Croft. Our guide helped navigate us to the best photo spots at non peak times. The trees are amazing and well worth seeing.

Banyan Trees Invasion. It's a fairly interesting temple given the banyan trees have invaded the original Ta Prohm temple. It's a good break from the rest of the temples near Siem Reap as the trees give it a little twist. Lots of interesting photo spots here as well. If you have time, definitely check it out. Most people visit here because of the trees and how they took over the original temple's architecture more than the history itself. And if you're a Tomb Raider fan, you have to pay a visit! The temple pass will cover this one.
Great if ruins are your thing. Overgrown temple with big trees growing on walls. Part of Angkor Wat tour and one of the better ones. Large parts are restored and it gets crowded.

Unique experience. Visited both Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom which are both magnificent edificies, but I preferred the Ta Prohm temple in the same vicinity. Best time to go is lunchtime. With not so many people there you can appreciate how eerie it is. The gigantic roots of the silk cotton trees growing over the walls and temple make it quite a surreal and unique experience never to be forgotten.
Ta Prohm. Ta Prohm, a temple with a big three grow up and very beautiful temple in Angkor Wat area. You can see in Siem Reap Cambodia.

Excellent yet very very crowded. Ta Prohm or what many refer to as the Lara Croft Temple was a sight to behold. While the tree made famous by the Hollywood movie was a great sight to see it was difficult to see anything substantial as it was so crowded you had to move with the crowd. After entering you are sucked into a vortex of people and the heat rises due to close contact. A quick glimpse of the tree and your spat out at the exit, where you can take your first breath of freedom. It was a great experience to see however not something you would plan a day around nor plan to solely see. Go if seeing the surrounding temples.
Overgrown forest. One of the temples which could not be fully restored. The over grown trees encroach on the structure to form an amazing site.
the best. Amazing brilliant stunning.I think that describes it.A must in everyone's experiences.Go early to avoid the crowds

The jungle has reclaimed the Temple. Ta Prohm has been left untouched rather than being restored. the jungle has reclaimed the temple, with huge tree trunks and vines snaking around the centuries old stonework.Here you get the feel of how the explorers would have found the ruins.Construction began in 1186 and was known as Rajaviharathe (Monastery of the King ) it was dedicated to the mother of King Jayavarman.It's an amazing site to see where the power of the vines have split stones in two. The roots are strangling the temple.There are 39 towers at Ta Prohm , all inaccessible as a danger to visitors and to preserve the ruins.Some corridors are blocked off with fallen stone blocks and this all adds to a fascinating experience.As ever, sensible shoes, hat, water and camera !!

Photogenic temple, cannot be missed. Ta Prohm Temple shot to fame because movie Tomb Raider was filmed here. It has been conserved in much better condition than most temples in Angkor area. The photogenic and atmospheric combination of trees growing out of the ruins and the jungle surroundings have made it one of Angkor's most popular temples to visit. A little hard to walk. Need a pair of good walking shoes.

better than any pictures. Just retuned from visiting Angkor Wat Archeological Park, actually covering an area of 200 square kilometres. So much more than expected. Ta Prohm.....stand back Tomb Raider, here we come. Pictures or words can't describe!! Such an amazing destination.

Mother Nature a Pervasive Power. We loved the large trees taking over the ruins. Towering trunks and thick root tentacles draping and piercing the stonework. This is something different from other temples.
ta prohm. Bit hard to walk in places, but so unique worth the effort, make sure to wear shoes not thongs.go early in day as gets busy and hot

Very interesting and slightly less crowded and touristy than the Angkor Wat. The temple is well worth a visit if time permits. Not as big and awesome as the Angkor Wat, it is interesting in its own way, you will find many ancient old trees sprout out in the middle of the complex. It is also not so physically challenging to explore this temple compared to some other ones.
Ta Prohm. This is fascinating place to walk through. To see the way the huge trees have grown threw the rock and temples over the years is amazing. Well worth the trip to see them.

Interesting place but too crowded. To reach the temple tourist has to walk quite far and not many tut tut available. The temple has interesting architecture & history but too many people around that it is difficult to walk around
The temple in tomb raider. Great temple to go see, if you're a movie buff and love seeing where some movies get filmed. Also very beautiful seeing all the trees growing out and on the temples.

This was one of the most interesting Temples. As you probs know the Lara Croft movies were filmed here but forget about that and look at the amazing Temple with it windy old trees and strange, odd massive tree holding the main part of the Temple up.It is just stunning, that is of course if you can get near it with the amount of people from China shouting and taking pictures of anything that moves, hahaa.No they were fin I face we had fun with a few of then, we all laughed about posing in front of the Temple.I really thought this was a great experience and well worth the effort.

Outstanding. One of the most iconic sights in Cambodia and well worth visiting with the temples and the roots of the trees in the brickwork and the trees at one with the temples. Good luck trying to avoid the crowds.

The Jungle Temple.. This is the amazing temple where the enormous jungle trees have been allowed to stay, demonstrating how the jungle slowly enveloped the temples/ Huge tree roots twist round and through the temple buildings. Apparently this has been used as a set for the movie "Tomb Raider"

Amazing!. This was one of the amazing Temples we visited in Siem Reap, the trees growing through the cracks in the temple are huge, some of the roots are so heavy they have been supported by props. They are still alive but because we were there in February (winter time in Cambodia) there wasn't any greenery.

Looks bigger in the movie, but much prettier in real life!. The tuk-tuk driver's will indicate this temple as the "Tomb Rider" temple. Just walk inside and you will understand why this place was chosen for Angelina's movie - it's BEAUTIFUL! Some nice artwork and lovely examples of nature's strenght. The big fig trees that grow among the rocks are impressive.If you wanna see pretty carving, look for the red-stone walls. They are harder than the grey ones, so the stonework is better preserved.
Under rated when called Tomb Raider Temple. The site is fenomenal, breathtaking, simply speechless. It is like nature took a hold of the ancient ruins to become their guardian.

A beautiful little temple & well worth a visit. Each temple in the Siem Reap area hos its own charm and appeal and the temple is a great place to get some really iconic photos of the temples, there is also a good few spots around the outskirts of the hotel that make great photos and allows you to get away from the spots where every tourist and their grandmother is taking a photo.

love it. If you want to see how nature can overcome human structure, this is really the place to visit. Simply awesome to see huge, monster-like trees crushing thousand year old huge stones. Have to be there to experience the wonder.

must see temple. This is a must see temple. I had a private tour because I wanted to avoid the crowds. If you take a group tour, they all follow the same route and will be tons of people. After sunrise at angkor I went straight to Ta Prohm and I'm glad I did. Enjoyed the temple with about 5 people. As I was leaving, here came the cattle trucks of people.
My favourite place in Cambodia. I absolutely loved Ta prohm. Its truly amazing how trees have grown through the building and they are still standing.

1 of 3 definite must see Temples in Cambodia. At first this temple appears to be similar to others around it, however upon entering it you quick discover it is very different. Trees growing out of the walls, with their incredible root system draped over the walls is amazing. I will need to see Tomb Raider again to proudly declare 'Ha, I've been there!'
Gorgeous place!. Like all the temples of Cambodia, this one too is gorgeous. It is not to be missed. One gets to see the art of man, but also the overwhelming power of nature there.

even better than Angor Wat. I have two knee replacements and dont manage stairs all that well. However I managed to get around quite easily in this temple. It is being restored and I hope it doesnt get 'too' restored. We got up at 4 am to see the sunrise over the Angor Wat and then went to this temple. Amazing.

True National Geo Moment. Ta Prohm is the area that has been left as it was found with all the trees and vines in place. It looks like another world and was featured in the movie that made Angelina Jolie famous.

Amazing tree and architecture!. A must see place when you are in Siem Reap! The temple's architecture just simply amazing. It is as if you are stepping into history itself. The temple was under going restoration at some parts. The gigantic trees are super awesome!
Awesome beauty. Plan to see this wonderful site earlier in the day before the hordes of tourists arrive. There are lots of nooks and places to explore. A feast for the eyes.

Tomb Raider Temple. It is truly an experience to see this temple and how nature has become one with the massive structure. Famously featured in the movie "Tomb Raider," it was everything I imagined and more. Very little restoration has been done, so visitors are able to see the beauty of the temple mixed with the beauty of nature. Due to the narrow direction of human traffic it was extremely crowded and slow to get around, so try to avoid all the tourist bus loads of people and get there early.

Beautiful !. Ta Prohm was our favourite of the temples we visited. Much smaller and quieter than Angkor Wat making the visit calm and serene. Be sure to make a donation at one of the buddha statues and receive a bracelet and blessing from one of the monks.
The tomb raider temple. This is one of the most beautiful temples if only for the fact that the jungle is re-claiming it. A must see of the hundreds of temples in the area.

Beyond Our Expectations!. 6am is an ideal time to arrive, before many other tourists. Silence, except for birds singing. Green parakeets. And then it appears - huge stones that were once part of an enormous temple, with trees growing out of them. Eerie yet peaceful. A ghost of a temple. Photogenic. If at all possible, get there!

A must see. This was a highlight of all the temples we visited. As its in dense wooded area / jungle area - its cooler than other more exposed temples. The trees that form part of the temples are just amazing. Be prepared for crowds and the children selling things by teh front entrance. Like running a gauntlet just to get in but once you do - you will feel like you are in another world.

A 12th century temple left mostly as found, overgrown. The Temple has been largely left overgrown by the jungle. there is an archeological group from India currently completing a 10 year project of restoration in a small part. It is amazing to see the roots of big trees strangling the construction.

Fascinating but footing can be tricky. Ta Prohm is another of the amazing temples in Siem Reap. It's fascinating, beautiful, ethereal,wonderful -- especially if you are as nimble as an antelope. We were hit by a mini monsoon while there and water quickly pooled. Some confusion about where the tour fellow was, some of our group went one way, others another way. There aren't directional signs, there aren't steps, there are some routes that don't go far, there are some deepish drop-offs. We learned to watch very carefully as we didn't want to tumble -- walking sticks aren't a bad idea. So, stop and enjoy a sight and take a photo, and while you move on to the other photo moment, watch your step all the way..

Wonderful. Amazing to see nature fused with temples; as human abandon religious buildings nature works slowly to sustain and take ownership. Magical and mysterious place. The tour itself was somewhat crowded. I would suggest visiting early in the morning.

Tomb Raider temple. Wonder of nature with Spung trees growing out of rocks in the temple. It was made famous by Angelina Jolie's shot in the movie Tomb Raider where she jumps thru the hole in temple floor holding the tree branches & aerial roots.

Better than Angkor Wat. It was my second time at this temple and I found it as dazzling as I did a few years ago. There is something so magical about nature retaking it--I think it is more breathtaking than Angkor Wat. If you can get in before the heat and the crowds, better yet.

Great historical site. This site is amazing with the overgrowth of old trees. The restoration that has been done and continuing is impressive. It is a step back into history. Would recommend a visit to this site.

Tomb Raider Temple.. One of the best temples to explore in the whole complex. Make sure if you are getting a Tuk Tuk here the driver gives you enough time to explore. You need about 2 hours here. It is included within the price of the Angkor Wat ticket.
Amazing Ta Prohm. Amazing root tree almost in every where winding the small temple in Ta Prohm which are still untouch with renovation.

Magical. We went just before sun rise and it was worth the very early start as we had the place to ourselves. The place is truly magical with a mixture of restored areas and areas taken over by nature with tree roots growing through walls and towers. This is where parts of Tomb Raider was filmed. For me this was the best temple, much better than any of the others. But go for sun rise before the place gets busy, it may mean rising at 05.00 but just do it.
Temple wonder- small and beautiful. MAde famous by Tomb Raider and Angelina Jolie, the quieter but nicer place in Siem reap temple tour.
Nice temple. It was really interesting and we liked it a lot. We passed it on our biketour. Do not miss it, when you visit the area.
Loving everybits of Cambodia. Simply amazing place with amazing people. Love the ancient architectural and structures. Very photographic. I would definetely return for the 3rd time.

Best of the Best in Siem Reap. From east to its west door it takes about 20 minutes long peaceful walk. Altogether Ta Prohm would require 1 hour of your life. The huge restoration project of the temple was underway when we visited after the Angkor Wat and there were at least 20 people in the outdoor carving a stone, hammering a marble and doing sorts of delicate work very patiently. Ta Prohm has a character, It does not bore you, instead it enlightens you with the balance between the persistence of nature and human creativity. Trees are part of the temples, they themselves became a temple. Apparently the Indian government is sponsoring this ongoing project and perhaps by 2020 it will look very different from today. At the moment at least, this stone/ tree world heritage is unspoiled. TIP: At Angkow Wat you can purchase daily, 3 day or weekly tickets to visit all temples with one ticket.

Big and unique temple in the world. We love love and love this temple so much. Huge temple with great born with trees on this. We hope the conservator could have been taking this temple long forever. Fantastic !!!

Another Temple of the day tour.. Ta Prohm was where Tombraider was filmed. Another fantastic temple of the temple tour. The tress growing through the buildings are amazing. There was some work going on, which was great to see. Large areas of the temple were being conserved and I cannot wait to go back to see it when its finished.
One of the Temples to visit. We last visited 10 years ago and there seem to be a few more platforms around now, but still very unusual and worth a second visit.

Surreal surrounding. The temple grounds looks like it is fabricated for a fiction movie. In fact it was once used as a set in a Hollywood movie.It's amazing how the tree roots can grow on top and in between the temple without causing a lot of damage. A must visit. Perfect photography spot that cannot be found elsewhere

Whole lotta people!. What makes this place unique are the huge tree roots growing in on and around the temple. The temple itself is pretty beat up because of this but people like to stand in front of the tree roots and pose with them. Kind of ironic :-P It is an interesting place but it was full of people getting in the way of my groovy pictures which is why I gave it a 4.

My favorite among all temples. Real Tomb Raider experience!. Loved this temple and felt like an explorer between the thousand years old tree trunks indiana jones-like entrances. Definitely worth seeing but avoid peak times like the afternoon. I would suggest going anytime early morning.
totally tomb raider. Amazing place, just like you would imagine! Would highly recommend you make sure this is on your list of things to see at Angkor!

Just like Tomb Raider!. Wow, nature has really taken over this site with a vengeance. The mix of man made temple and complex tree root structures is as impressive as its reputation suggests. Yet another must see in this area.
Must see temple. This temple is a must. The tree roots growing over and around the temple make for a spectacular site. Amazing photo opportunities abound.

wow... Fascinating, wonderful...heres where you,ll see the incredible vegetation that wind there huge roots over the ruins..be careful walking around, if this was europe or north america health and safety would have blocked access...

Expected to see Indiana Jones!. Wow - a genuine wonder of the world. Such an amazing site with the trees growing in, out and on the temple walls. Has a very Dali-esque to the place as the roots seem to pour themselves over the ruins. Look out for the statue peeping out from between the roots - worth hunting it out. If you are in SE Asia it would be a crime to miss the Angkor Wat complex.

Another hour another temple!. This was one of many temples we visited during pour guided trip. It was fine, and like many temples was a mixed state of dilapidation
and repair. Worth a visit.

Can you find the dinosaur?. Besides the obvious attraction to this temple (the breathtaking view of the jungle taking over), my husband and I wanted to find the dinosaur carving. We were so overwhelmed with the beauty of this temple we totally forgot to look for the dinosaur carving! Let me know if you find it.
had to be our favorite. lovely wonderful place. go at the recommended times. can be very busy with crazy tourist groups. plan accordingly to get the best light and peace

Jungle taking back. Wonderful and famous because of movies like Lara Craft- Tomb Raiders. Nature taking back when man goes away. The King who made this built, could never image how big the Bussines would be so many years after. This comparable to Tikal in Guatemala, Machu Pichu in Peru , New Grandge in Ireland or even the Pyramids around the globe. Come and take a look yourself.

Another beautiful temple!. I visited Ta Phrom with my sister in August 2014 as part of our bucket list trip to Siem Reap.This temple is obviously on everyone's list, given that it was made famous by the movie Tomb Raider, and is apparently the most visited temple besides Angkor Wat. Ta Phrom was built by the amazing Jayarvarman VII who dedicated it to his mother. Like the other Angkor temples, is very beautiful and dignified. The temple is crumbling and overgrown with incredible strangler fig trees but these only add to its beauty.There are some amazing carvings to be seen and if you look carefully you'll find the Buddha face that has a tree growing around it, which is just beautiful.Take your time to explore and be patient to get the perfect photo as others will be trying to catch the same shot - especially in front of the "Tomb Raider tree".Things to remember when visiting the temples:-* Be sure to book a private guide so you can move at your own pace. Make sure you get one that really knows their stuff as hearing the stories and legends around each temple was far more interesting than just hearing the facts. (If you need a guide then feel free to PM me - I'm more than happy to give you a recommendation!)* Wear sunblock and a hat. It is HOT.* Be sure to take the time to drink it all in. No matter how many other people are in the complex you'll be able to enjoy it all if you're patient and take your time.* Don't climb up on the temple walls, or let your children do it either. This is so disrespectful to both the temple and to the Cambodian people.* Please remember to dress respectfully. Yes, you're on holiday and yes, it's hot but this is a temple.Enjoy! :)

Amazing !!!. My favorite temple , There are platforms erected here and there to make walking easier but at the same time, this also makes it less authentic. This is where Preah Khan, another temple with overgrown trees and less visited, has a plus point.Nevertheless, it is still a must see, go later , after 4pm , than it's not so crowded anymore.

Jungle-covered ruins. Visiting this temple felt like being an explorer and it seemed to be much like it was when it was first discovered. The kapok trees growing up, over and through the ruins are immense. Really enjoyed this temple. A must see in my opinion.

Temples and Banyan Trees. Love this spot. Make sure you stop here on your Angkor complex tour. This is the 3rd or 4th stop on the Half Marathon Tour. The temple and the over grown trees are really impressive.

The most beautiful temple within the Angkor park. You can see here roots of old trees grown on the walls of the temple structure - marvelous scene. Nice walking through the jungle before and after the temple - take your time, don't hurry. Best to start with this temple in the morning - beat the crowds !

The early bird catches the tranquility. An early morning tour is recommended before the masses descend. Quite breathtaking......make sure you get a good guide.....some, like ours, just make it so dull and yet the history is vibrant!
Oneof the best. One of the best spots at Angkor! Definitely nice because are not rebuilt yet, and you can remember Lara Croft stile there!

Man versus Nature. Go early, or you will be so busy picking you way from between tourist groups that you will neither get good pictures nor see the place in all its glory. This is where man and Nature meet, and the great trees that hold the temple structures in their grasp, literally, are as awe inspiring as what man has made.There is much restoration work here, and it is wonderous to see how from piles of stumbled stones the restorers are managing to rebuild the temple as it originally must have been. There is not much by way of carvings but it remains a must see.The musicians, land mine victims, who make sweet music en route you walk to and from the ruins are worth lauding.Can see too, why film makers found this a perfect location for their climax scenes! I wonder what brave person will dare spend a night alone here!

The one and only "temple in the jungle" - incredible. Ta Prohm is the real "temple in the jungle", where nature slowly reclaimed this Khmer site until it was rediscovered. Now it is the archetypal ruined temple where man and nature kind of co-exist. It truly is an incredible sight to behold.This was our number one temple to see in Siem Reap and it was truly amazing. All the others - Angkor Wat included - as spectacular as they are, did not amaze us quite as much as Ta Prohm.The site it large enough to explore over a couple of hours, though being in the jungle we found it easier than other temples where you were more in the sun. Regardless, make sure you have your water, sunscreen, hats, etc.So much has been said about Ta Prohm before, and it really does live up to expectations in our opinion. An unmissable part of any trip to Siem Reap. Top recommendation.
Tr Prohm. Another wonderful example of temples in Siem Reip. Try to get to this one if you ahve the time well worth a visit

Enchanting. I visited the temple at 5:00 AM so there were no tourists yet. This is definitely one of the nicest temples in Angkor. Some parts just get flooded especially after heavy rains. It was also hard to get out ( it took me 30 minutes) because the exit signs were a bit confusing.

Must see in Siem Reap. After a long walk from the visitor center, you enter through one of original gates near old traveler stops. Temple is under reconstruction but walkways are well marked. If you go early in the day, beware of the large tour groups, some with annoying "clappy" hands noise makers to lead their tours. Everyone wants the same Tomb Raider photo so difficult to get near if large group present (some bringing their own professional photographer). The view of nature reclaiming its own is amazing. The rapping roots make great photo ops. Again, persistent sellers (mostly children)will have to be negotiated back to visitor center. Large number of shops circle the parking area.
Loved it!. Definitely one of the temples to stop at and spend some time exploring. I took a TON of photos and could have spent more time there if I was able to.

Soooo Crowded. Ta Prohm is truly stunning, but unfortunately the huge tour groups that are let in by the masses ruin the ability even get a picture. Definitely still GO, but get the inside advice from your hotel/tuk tuk about what time of day to go so that you can actually explore, enjoy, marvel, and maybe even get a picture. We were there around 4pm and it was so thick with Chinese tour groups that we finally gave up in some sites and just kept moving. Maybe the ticket agency will start to limit how many visitors can go a day because in such a cool site that is so compact (small walkways between doors, doorways, and falling rock/trees) it really does ruin it when you can't even get a look or a picture without someone's head in it.

The best. This was probably my favourite of all the temples. Loved the vegetation and the tree trunks growing through the temple just made the experience. It is in the process of being restored but I hope they leave some of it in as is so people can see it for what it is. This is where some of the movie Tomb Raiders was filmed, which bought a lot of people to the temple, but I just loved the feeling of the place for what it is.
Wonderful. This is an incredible place, made all the more so as when we were there, so few other people. If you go to SR, then you're sure to come here!

The jungle reclaims. The temple is famous for the trees that have then back what was rightfully theirs, and they are stunning. Access is level with only a few, well supported, steps to negotiate. Lots of interesting nooks and crannies to explore.
Tomb Raider experience. Awe inspiring how the strangler figs have wound themselves in and through this temple. A must to see
great place. great place to visit. should be in everyone's bucket list. worth every penny & time. great tour guide.
Ruins look beautiful. Even though in ruins looks stunningly beautiful.Amazing ,the sheer size and enormity makes it a behemoth to visualise

NATURE WINS. An amazing place that shows, nature left to its own devices takes its over any man made structure. The trees are magnificent. We noticed huge restoration, I hope the trees are left in there rightful place and not replaced by more man made stone.
one of 3 to visit!. This one of 3 that are a must see for temples. Great location and very cool to visit. Our guide was amazing and showed us through without too many tourists around!

Amazing, a must see when in Siem Reap. This site really is amazing. There were too many people when we got there just after lunch, I guess an early morning or late afternoon timing would have been better. I guess everyone wants to go and see where Lara Croft was shot.......... I honesty think it would have been better if they did not shoot the movie here :)

A Different Perspective on Ruins. What makes Ta Prohm distinctive is the many large trees and roots that have taken over its temple structures. Though many other archaeological sites in the area are better maintained, we actually really enjoyed the different perspective Ta Prohm offered. As a temple that has not been restored on much, it gave you a much clearer idea of what these ruins would look like today if they were left in a more natural state. The contrast with other temples like Angkor Wat and Bayon was interesting to see.
Go early or don't go!. Go early before Ankor Wat otherwise you just are climbing over people. Then go back for sunset at Ankor Wat and miss the crowds.
Just amazing!. The "Jungle-temple". A dynamic interaction between nature and man-made art. A must-see! Try to come realy early or at lunch to avoid the long queues.
Temples in the forest. This is perhaps the most photographed site where the large trees have taken over the temples. Popular tourist site. Large crowds make photographers frustrated.

I'm 60, but felt like 14!. This is just the most amazing place I have ever been. When you get to the main buildings and see the size of the trees growing through them, you can't fail to be excited. They are currently restoring the main palace with such commitment and eye to originality and detail. If you only have the time to see a part of the huge area surrounding Angkor Wat, you must not miss this.
Hyped. Unfortunately visited ta prohm after Angkor wat and thom and therefore felt this place underwhelmed. Known more for being part of a Hollywood movie than anything else

Fascinating place. While not as well maintained as Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm is a great place to visit to see the many faced Buddah. You can still climb around on some of the temples, so it's not as restrictive as Angkor Wat.
Ta Prohm and the ruins are fantastic. Awesome structure of the temple and trees. Do not go there without a camera... The trees grown awesomely in the temple. Nice place for photography.

The Best. This is my Favourite of all the temples at Ankor Wat. So many interesting facts and differences, it is best to book a guide for the temples, lots of interesting stories get missed if your just wandering through on your own.love the trees how they have grown, the lovely walk into this temple and usually passing Land Mine victims as they play traditional music. Lots of sellers trying to get you to buy their goods at either entrance, show the slightest interest and you 'll have 20 people swamping you with their products. A great experience.

Was a Amazing temple. Ta Prohm with its trees growing thru the stone temple is amazing . I have visited this temple many times since 2010 and all I can say is that the tourists are really destroying the feeling of the place, All the major sights of the temple are now covered in wooden platforms for the chinese and Korean tourists to take photos of themselves in front of. A real pity cos it was a really magical place once upon a time.

Amazing Phrom. OMGoodnes never did I imagine the amazing structure of Ta Phrom. It is nature at it's best with many large strangler trees and silk-cotton trees hugging the amazing ruins. Many amazing photos opportunities.

Proud to be an indian. Imagine seeing the mahabharata and ramayan depicted beautifully in stone so many centuries ago. Its an amazing feeling.The sheer magnitude of the temples is astounding. Technology used back then also is an eye opener eg. An apsara carving is on different stones in pieces but you can make out only if you look very closely. Its known as the tomb raider temple - how imaginative.Its very hot so take caps sunglasses and maybe a sun umbrella. There are excellent displays of restoration work done by indian, french governments.A photo is taken when buying the tickets and you have to wear the photo id at all times.

Excellent. Greatly enjoyed this site. Takes time. You need a good guide to get enough of the history. Has been restored but appears to be left as it was found with the trees growing out of the buildings.

This was a truly spectacular day. What an amazing situation where trees grow up into a temple and then become part of the temple.
I had to go and watch tomb raider after visiting this temple as it features!!

Scaffolding?. I liked Ta Prohm better than Angkor Wat, I'm more interested in nature than the temples themselves. The walkways are fairly narrow and there are some dead-ends that cause bottle-necks. There was scaffolding over certain parts, I'm not really sure why, but it ruined the atmosphere a bit. Still a cool place though
A must see. This temple is my favorite. Come as early in the morning as possible, before the crowds arrive. The forest around is also beautiful with big dipterocarps.
Amazing. Amazing temple, the most famous Tomb Raider. This place, have big tree is grown on the Ta Prohm Temple, this is my first time to met amazing like this

Amazing temple site, see it early!. This temple is popular for being known in Tomb Raider, however its more than that. Go early (right after the sunrise at Angkor Wat is a great time). We were almost completely alone in the temples. Amazing pictures and lots of cool sites at this temple. Very worth the trip. A tour guide can show you the ins and outs and is highly recommended in my view. The local guide was amazing to talk to about everything that is Cambodia. Ask for #8 driver Raya at your hotel he was great stayed with us all day very friendly person.

Amazing ancient architecture site. We was amzing to see such beautiful temple wraps in a deep jungle. Sadly some part of the temple were broken down and some were left unattended. There was a restoration going on at the site which is a good thing.
Amazing. Very unusual with Mother Nature taking back the temples! Worth a visit to see this spectacle. Pick your time to visit as there are always a large number of people.

Famous because of Tomb Raider. LIKE : There is yes, the special tree/treesBut perhaps my expectations were high, I was not too impressed by this temple. It is still worth a visit, but I didn't think it outshone the rest of the temples, with my favourite remaining to be Bayon.DISLIKE : Construction going on at the site

Can be crowded..... We bought the seven day pass and stayed in Siem Reap for 8 days and nights in January 2015. Hire a tuk-tuk driver in Siem Reap anywhere near the pub street or market and keep your wits about you. A tuk-tuk driver will drive you to the furthest wats from Siem Reap, wait for an hour or so, and then drive you to another wat or back to town for about 8 bucks. If your hotel calls the tuk-tuk, expect to pay $20 or $15. If you flag a Tuk-tuk at the market, expect to be asked for $15 and settle for $8 or $10. If you show up at the same time as a bunch of tour buses from Korea, just tell the driver to head for another nearby wat and come back later. If you see a gaggle of middle-aged women dressed like multi-coloured incarnations of Sailor Moon, run, don't walk.

Ancient Walls, Roots and Trees. Nature has partly reclaimed this temple and surrounding walls with beautiful effect - trees growing out of walls, tree roots overhanging temple structures, large sandstone blocks pierced, broken, destroyed by the irresistabe power of nature.

Just beautiful. We really loved this temple; the trees are quite impressive.Go with a guide on a day tour to see Angko Wat and Bayon at the same time.You can also go by bike if you are fit and up for the challenge. We went in January and was very hot. We got a driver and a guide for the day and highly recommend.
Beautiful. You have to see this one, with the trees growing out of the temple. Great photos! One not to miss! Going round these temples by bike is fun.
Great nature temple. The favourite, we like the ruin and the nature together feeling great atmosphere at this temple. We prefer to stay whole day at this temple but we have not enough time to do so.
My favourite temple. Amazing and well worth the visit. I saw it ten years ago and still very much enjoyed it this visit. Go early in morning before it gets too busy in the afternoon.

An iconic site. Ta Prohm is well known from the movie Tomb Raider. This was probably my favourite temple although not as extensive as Angkor Wat, the gnarly trees and roots give it so much character. Allow enough time to explore and if possible have a guide to maximize your experience.

OUT OF THIS WORLD!!!!. You've seen this temple in Tomb Raider - on blogs and internet sites, but being there in person will simply take your breath away!! Centuries-old giants towering over ruins, their roots weaving in and out of intricately carved stone...another magical space to discover around every corner, and all with the humming energy of something much deeper and older than anyone could imagine. This is truly a once in a lifetime visit, and not to be missed

Start with this one. Not the most impressive so do start with this one. Of course, amazing trees growing in the middle of the ruins. Can be visited in the middle of the day thanks to the shade of the forest.
The tree that is "magic". This is not a very significant sight but when I saw it I was really into it. There is something mysterious about this "tree temple" :)

Amazing. Its really an amazing temple, sooo fantastic that you cant believe it,you can just wonder how this place looked for about 800 years ago,, my second time here but still amazing,i personally like this more than Angor wat

A MAJOR TEMPLE , ROMANTIC AND AWESOME. One of the major temple, next to Angkor vat is quite romantic with many hidden corners, a lovely place to explore , now in ruins with silk cotton trees entwined among ruins.A monastery known as RAJA VIHARA built in late 12-13c is worth visithing, NOT TO BE MISSED to appreciate its Architectural excellence, which is AWE SOME. Under the India cambodia co operation project renovation of this heritage monument is under progress.

Another "unbelievable". It´s difficult to believe what you see, and to imagine that this was a jungle a long time ago. Amazing to see the roots of the trees growing inside the buildings. Please do go when you visit
Cambodia. Including more temples of Angkor Wat it is such an amazing place.

A must see in Cambodia. This is one of two of our favourite temples from our recent visit to Cambodia. While Angkor Wat is the "headliner" temple it can become overcrowded with tourists. A more serene experience can be had at either Bayon or Ta Prohm temples. We hired bicycles for our week's holiday and cycled to many temples at our own pace, which we recommend, especially as you will have lots of tuk tuk drivers haggling with you for a price to take you out to the temples. Cycling helps you to appreciate the scenery along the journey and is in fact not that far from Siem Reap town. Traffic is accommodating to cyclists and the roads are generally straight and in good condition.Ta Prohm is a beautiful temple which, as many reviewers have said, is gradually being reclaimed by nature. The trees growing through the stones make for amazing photo moments. We sensed a very calm vibe in this temple (compared to others which felt like mausoleums) and recommend that you visit early in the day to avoid the crowds.Tip: Wear long sleeves and knee length pants to protect from the intense sun and also in keeping with respect for the Khmer culture and people, especially if climbing up the steps.

Unique Temple With Amazing Trees!. This temple is quite unique with some amazing very old temples being swallowed up by some very old trees.There are some terrific photo opportunities but the whole of Angkor is so popular it can get very overcrowded throughout the day.Try & push out to the exterior walls of the complex away from the main thoroughfare as this is where the large groups of Chinese & Korean tourists are taken.I would suggest going as early as possible because as well as the large crowds it does get very hot as the day progresses.A full day trip organised by the hotel cost us $US15 which took you to the main sites stopping off for lunch was cost us US$20 in a nice restaurant.I would imagine you could get the transport costs down to about $US10 if you bargained hard away from the hotel.A definite visit but go early to avoid the crowds!
Great. Less crowded than the "big boy" and is a sight to behold. Loved wandering around being astounded by the ingenuity of the architecture.
Incredible!. It was amazing to see the trees taking over the temple, so beautiful and incredible. A fantastic temple and a must to put on the visit list.

Jungle Temple. Super cool to see this temple after having seen pictures for years. Unbelievable how the jungle is taking over. When we were there, they were doing maintenance so was really dusty but managed to get a few shots before we had to get out of the area. Highly recommend!

Prohm Temple. I had seen a lot of pictures of these roots growing on the walls of Angkor Wat trmples. In fact the tourism department used to advertise with these pictures.It is not just one tree, but lots and lots of them. This is a Temple in the jungle and it is a pleasure to watch these trees. One should not miss this.

Atmospheric. Our excellent personal guide took us there at 5.30am....to see the sunrise and to be the only people there.... until 6.30 when all of another 6 arrived. Beautiful sculptures of stone and nature to enjoy. DO NOT miss this one... and yes, it is worth getting up early to go.

Where's Lara Croft. The well known 'Jungle Temple' with its giant fig trees is just as awesome as any photos suggest. The conflict between man's great creations and Nature's forces taking it back is at the centre of the experience. To me this is the heart of the Angkor experience. Get here early in the morning before the bus groups and your imagination will be set free. A satisfying almost overwhelming spiritual moment. truly AWESOME!

Work with a guide to avoid the crowd here and get a great photo. After seeing Angkor Wat this was the next most famous temple. Also known as the Tombraider temple it is cool to see the trees growing around the stone. It is like nothing else I had ever seen. Very cool photo op so try to avoid the crowds to get a picture by yourself.

WOW. Incredible. The trees are such a treat to eyes. It gets spooky after a while with all those peculiar jungle voices (step in and you would know what I am talking about) Its fun to roam around. Unbelievably amazing and picture perfect. For me it was a star attraction after the The Ankor and Bantey Kedi. A must must visit

Awesome . With some restoration work done & a long way to go the indian government is doing a fabulous job . This temple is dedicated to brahma & to the king jayavarman ancestors, his mother . You can see how the temple was completely in the clutches of the jungle . The massive roots of the trees can be seen all around it . Worth the visit .
Forget Tomb Raider. This place, more than many I have been, reminds you that man is so very small and nature so very powerful. She always wins.
Ta Prohm. Once again a totally amazing place to visit. the history behind all of these places in Cambodia is incredible. Sit back and enjoy.
The best of them all. We were lucky as the place was not too crowded when we vistited the temple in the afternoon. Very evocative and beautiful place with great photo opportunities.
Tree on the stone. the very old one, probably the most ruined temple and it still remains the strength and the history. The beauty and the forest.

"Tomb Raider" temple. I never saw this movie, but this is an awesome place for shutterbugs, huge trees overgrowing into the temple provide unique shots. It does get VERY crowded by late morning, so go early or late. It must have been "free" Japanese tourist day when I visited.

awesome. This is the famous Tomb Raider temple, and even more awe-inspiring in real life than on film. It is fascinating to wander through ruins from which grow large trees. It is picturesque and sobering at the same time. This is an ancient place of worship, co-existing with elements of nature. Definitely my favourite of the temples.

Beautiful. We went early. Right after sunrise at Angkor Wat our tour guide took is straight here. Unless you're a wiz with history take a tour guide (helps the locals out with work and you get a lot of local knowledge). The place is nearly empty, which is quiet a strange feeling. There is restoration work going on to preserve the place. The size of the tree roots that have taken over is amazing. It is such a beautiful place. Dress respectfully - knees and shoulders covered or you may not be allowed in!

Stunning. Maybe my favorite temple/ruin in the Angkor Archaeological Park. All the trees left in the ruins provide some nice shade as well, so its a nice to visit when it's a hotter part of the day. You could easily spend 3 hours at this site.

A scene from indiana Jones. This was our favourite site. It is amazing. It's buried by the jungle with huge trees spanning buildings and walls.The walls have so much colour in them and there are lots of parakeets in the trees. All the areas have monkeys, but please don't feed them or they can become a nuisance.

A Magnificent Blend of Nature and Architecture. There's a reason for Ta Prohm's tourist-driven nicknames, "Indiana Jones temple" or "Tomb Raider temple" ... walking through these ruins you feel transported to a wilderness, a wonderland, seen only in movies (Tomb Raider did film some exterior scenes here.) This is the temple that archeologists left (partially) in the grasp of the jungle. (Other temples were cleared completely by the French to maintain the structures.) But seeing the amazingly tall trees with their python-like roots wrapped around lintels and doorways, overwhelming buildings, is quite a unique and eerie experience. We went at the end of the day... when the shadows were long and Ta Prohm was at its moodiest. Truly one of the travel highlights of my life. Don't miss it!

Worth going to just to see the size of the trees and roots. Not too busy when we went and again very impressive place. You have to stand next to the tree roots to get an appreciation for the scale of them.Need patience when taking photos as everyone wants photos by the famous tree from Tomb Raider. Another enjoyable visit and great explanation of the history by our guide.

Live History. Ta Prohm is a must.Just to see the huge trees growing through the temples is amazing. some have hadto be cut down as they were destroying the ancient temples. They have now put up safety rails to protect both which is a good thing.Along the way you will pass a Cambodian traditional playing group who have all beeninjured by the past. Please be kind and donate to their well being.A Tuk Tuk will take your there and wait.
Remarkable. Go visit at dawn to avoid biggest crowds and to appreciate the sun coming up over this remarkable place

Pretty but packed. I visited this temple a few days ago. The temple itself is quite impressive, with huge trees growing on the ruins. Because of the Tomb Raider movie (according to my guide), it is know packed with many tourists that want to visit the "Angelina Jolie" temple... Had a feeling of a "Mona Lisa" effect... people queeing to take pictures and selfies at a spot that appears in the movie. A bit sad actually, but if it can bring more visitors to the temples complex, I guess it's not that bad...

The Best of Angkor!. Went to see the actual sunrise here around 7am, and there were no crowds, just a couple of other tourists enjoying the quiet time here. There is a lot of reconstruction going on, so just be aware. The temples and the snake trees are the most incredible we've seen so far!!! LOVED IT and definitely recommend!

Most awesome temple of all. We visited this temple early in the morning before any other tourists visited, making it the most serene of all temples for us. It is called the King of Trees because it is in pristine untouched condition, covered with crumbling stones and over powering trees. This was a very large temple, almost as large as Angkor Wat, and has not been repaired at all. The only thing done to this magnificent temple has been to build wooden stairs around the temple, as well as stairs climbing up to the top and down to the depths of this most sacred place. We were blown away by its majesty and loved seeing it in its natural state of dis-repair. do not miss this temple, try to see it as early as you can for the most perceptual impact.
Amazing!. The lush vegetation is slowly swallowing up Ta Prohm so come and see it while it still exists! Made us watch the Tomb Raider movie just to see bits of Ta Prohm again!

Top 3 pick in Siem Reap area. Ta Prohm is one of my top 3 temples in the Siem Reap area. I love the temple's condition being in balance and harmony with nature. I love those Spung Trees, which are both destoyers and preservers of the temple--their roots initially breaking apart the stone, but now that their roots are massive and encompass many structures, they are holding the temple stones together. Some people may not like temples with too many wooden platforms to guide the tourist's path. However, without the platforms and walkways, the millions of tourists climbing and walking over the temple stones would further erode and damage them. In my rankings, I do not factor in the tourist crowds. All the temples that are worthwhile and which do not have a high risk or land mines left over from all the wars, will have too many tourists. The number of tourists visiting is growing each year, so the sooner you visit, the better.

So beautiful, especially when not crowded. I like the walk back and forth- it's so quiet and peaceful. The temple itself is beautiful and if you go when there are not a lot of people there you will get excellent photos.
