The trees made the spectacle. Temples in Cambodja should be seen taking into account each characteristics. In this one, the most amazing thing is the Interaction between the buildings and nature's work through the trees. There is one particular species that is responsible for the main effect a(spong, I believe this was the name); a tree which has very strong roots that entered in the walls of the temple and will surprise you coming out here and there. So at this temple, what's to see is not the building itself, not the apsara's or the engraving, but the sites created by the roots coming through walls and towers.There are splendid spots in which you'll take marvelous photos. It is a little tricky to walk through, exactly due to fallen rocks here and there. It was packed when I visited - people wanna see the site in which Tomb Rider was filmed.So prepare your camera, and be patient with the herds of tourists (just like you) that you'll find in the place.
Awesome!. This one can't be missed either, it's so cool. It's almost magical and mystical how the trees have grown into the ruins of the temple.

Temple with roots growing on it. Very interesting temple. A must see for Siem Reap. This site was used for Indiana Jones and Tomb Raider movies. Fascinating seeing the trees growing through the temple structure.

Man v. Nature. Super crowded, I imagine that it would be incredibly peaceful if you weren't there with hundreds of others.It is however an incredibly beautiful temple with the man v. nature theme going on.

Must go. A really fascinating temple where huge trees are taking over its walls and grounds. Restoration works are under way at the moment with parts of the grounds out of bounds to visitors. Nevertheless, walkways have been built around those parts and you can still get a good view of the structures. There are only 2 entrances - the east gate and the west gate. As the grounds are quite confusing, it's easy to get lost. Our guide was stopped at least 3 times by people who were lost. If you don't have a guide and only got a driver to drop you off, it's a good idea to ask your driver whether he's picking you up at the east or west gate, so that if you get lost, a guide on the grounds could point you in the right direction.As most of these temples are still used by the locals as places of worship, it would be respectful to dress appropriately. You may have seen pictures of people wearing shorts and tank tops while visiting the temples but do note that there is a dresscode. Knees and shoulders should be covered. Instead of wearing pants for example, I saw a few women wearing dresses and skirts. Ta Prohm doesn't have steep stairs to climb and so dresses and skirts that fall below the knee are alright. However, if you are also visiting other temples on the same day like Angkor Wat and Bayon, it's best to remember that some of the stairs there can be quite steep. Not only could dresses and skirts hinder your climbing, they could also leave little to the imagination for those climbing behind you.

The Jungle Always Wins. This is one of those temple complexes they decided to leave the riotous tree roots everywhere growing out of the roof tops of buildings, tearing up the foundations, tumbling the giant stones, just to remind you the jungle always wins. Lara Croft Tomb Raider was filmed here. You can have your Indiana Jones moment.

Go Early - Very Quiet!!. We chose to go to Ta Prohm early - it opens at 5:30am, but we got a tuk tuk from our hotel at 6am to make it to Ta Prohm by 6:30am. Sunrise was about 6:15am. When we got there, it was VERY quiet - there were hardly any other people around, and it was slightly misty, which made the site seem even more eerie and impressive. We were easily able to explore at our own pace, and take lots of photos without other tourists in them. As we left, more and more buses were arriving - if you go, make sure you go early!!

Amazing Temple. Amazing temple that had big tree is grown on this Ta Prohm Temple, my first time met this temple.The best temple in Siem Reap. We'd beat the crowds by being ant Angkor Wat for sunrise and leaving before the upper levels opened. We were three of around fifteen people at the site and it was amazing. Really quiet, relaxed and calm. I felt very peaceful. The trees growing out of the architecture make for a unique sight. Upon exiting we passed a number of ant columns and some termites. Really interesting watching them all up close. You'd be amazed how well an iPhone can tackle macro shots.

Beautiful. The most famous area of it was under construction when I visited. It restricted people to cue-up taking turns to get a good pic with that gigantic root growing over the doorway. The root of the trees here are so big that it can cause the structures to shift or be unstable over time. Because of the gigantic roots growing on the structures- I can't help but wonder if they got buried or something. If you love the Forest or Jungle.. you'll like this place the best and in addition... you'll be welcomed by the sound of birds all around.
Too Crowded. Tomb Raider's tree / well known as the Hollywood tree, and too many people there. Hardly take a perfect shots.

A classic site. You certainly won't be disappointed if you visit here. I would follow most common advice and visit either first thing in the morning or around lunchtime as it's quite a small temple compared with some of the others and therefore it can get easily get overcrowded by tourists at certain times of the day
Lot's of People!. Get Sun to bring you there because he knows all the awesome spot to take great pictures and if you are planning to get some professional shoot, get Sun to bring you those nice spot.

Nature and Temples become ONE. What an amazing sight the trees have overgrown the temples and have become part of the monument words cannot describe what this actually looks like and even photos are not up to par with reality

Wild, Mysterious, Special. We were told the Ta Prohm Temple was built in dedication to the king's mother and took approximately 6 years to construct. The temple is often referred to as the Jungle Temple or the Tomb Raider Temple as segments of the Tomb Raider movie was filmed at this temple. Once we returned home from our trip, we re-watched the Tomb Raider movie. It wasn't all that great, but, we enjoyed the temple scenes and thought how amazing it must have been for the actors to visit the temple without the obscene mass of tourists.It didn't take us long to realize the appropriateness of the nickname, the "Jungle Temple." Unlike many Angkorian Temples, the Ta Prohm Temple is unique because much of the jungle has not been cleared and it resembles how the temple would have appeared when the European explorers first stumbled across this treasure, which provides travelers with a unique flavor of how the temples appeared prior to the commencement of renovations. It was absolutely remarkable and mysterious, and, at brief moments, when we managed to block out the tourists, felt like we were living in a fairy tale.Roots were usurping the temple structure and tree branches were gripping all parts of the temple indiscriminately. Large stones that fell over long ago blocked pathways. The majority of the trees growing out and around the stones of the temple are Spung trees. The age of the spung trees ranged from 200 to 500 years old. The trees were massive and it was quite extraordinary the way the trees maneuvered between the stones. The jungle atmosphere was wild and highlighted the destructive power of mother nature.

You have never seen anything like this. The destruction of the temples made by the roots of the forest trees are the particularity of this wonderful temple. It is impressive and the machine and mental pictures you will take with you back home are unforgettable! Do not hesitate and get a pass for more than 3 temples and you will not regret. It is worth the money since these are unique temples in the world.

A must see temple. If you don't have much time in Siem Reap see this temple. It is partially collapsed, and over run by huge creepers and roots. And itfeatures in the Tomb Raider movie. Beware some of the rooms because the fallen roof stones have not been cleared - though that makes the place all the more romantic in my opinion.

Beautiful. I went in the morning. It was full but still manageable. I had a good time and a good chat with my guide who knew so much about it.It is a powerful place to get a deeper understanding of the past and you can also buy a few things for your friends around as there is a market.I really enjoyed my visit

Surprisingly Good. This is where you see the trees being embedded to the temples. When we got there, restorations were on the way still i can see how beautiful it was. This is where you get to be Tombraider as this is where Lara Croft (Jolie) shot this film.

As advertised. The Tomb Raider temple is neither a tomb nor raided. It is well preserved in the state it was supposedly found, with strangler fig trees hugging the stones -- in order to give visitors a flavor of what the temples at Angkor were like before they were renovated. Ta Prohm, however, is very crowded. Korean and Chinese tour groups come by the buses, and they come all year long no matter what the season is. Russians too.You feel like you are in an Indiana Jones adventure, then the next group piles on in, and you feel like you're in a Tokyo subway.
Temples in the Jungle. It's like the LOST WORLD. The trees that grow over the temples form amazing architecture. It's the most mysterious of all the temples we saw.

Fairytale trees!. Very beautiful! You can only walk around the outside of the temple (not in the central walkway) due to restoration. The trees on the temple make it look like a fairytale, however a lot of the pathways are blocked due to some of the stones having fell. As it is one of the main temples it has a lot tourists at all hours of the day. Highly recommend visiting this temple!

Fabulous, but very, very busy. This was my favourite of the temples - you get a real sense of the age of it. It looks amazing with the tree roots usurping everywhere. The only downside is that everyone else thinks it's amazing too so it is HEAVING. Expect to shuffle along as though on a crowded subway and to queue to get photos. Maybe it would be better in the early morning when everyone else is at Angkor Wat.

Stunning, Awe inspiring. There is something special about this place. It may be packed with visitors and at first glance you may think you will never get a photo of the special sights. But with a little patients you will. Find your spot and sit quietly as the crowds work their way around. Then suddenly a lull will give you that perfect picture moment. Whether it be the Tomb Raider window or the crocodile tree. Im still amazed by how many people miss the dinosaur carving near the back of the temple, something to ponder about there. A truly inspiring location.

Unmissable. The huge trees that still grip parts of the temple are truly extraordinary and really have to be seen. The crowds have necessitated more barriers and ropes than at many less well known temples, which detracts a little from the feel of the place, but it is still remarkable and an essential stop on any visit to Angkor.

Wow!. Words cannot describe how amazing Ta Prohm is, a must visit for sure. We only visited three temples here (first Ankor Wat, second Ankor Thom, and thirs Ta Prohm). Viewing them in this order, in our opinion, was one being better than the next, thus ending with the best one. Visit the park for a day or week. Up to you. Lot's to explore but after a while you will be "templed out", so pace yourself. Rent a private car as well. Distances between temples is too far to walk in the heat (and the air con is very nice). The dirt roads also make it a little challenging (dusty or mud depending on season).

The best temple in Angkor. Having been overtaken by the jungle, this temple mixes nature with architecture in a stunning way. So stunning it would be a shame to restore it to its original glory. Definitely worth a visit. My photos do not do it just but a google search will show you its true wonder. We were lucky to see it surrounded by so few tourists. Go at the break of dawn or the very end of the day (at dusk) to get it in its fully glory.

example of destructive power of nature.. Here one can see the immense destructive power of nature. How a small seedling of cotton- silk tree can send its roots between the huge stones and ultimately topple the mighty structure. Force of Nature!

Beautiful but too busy. Ta Prohm was the second temple we visited during the day but by the time we got there is was crazy busy and hard to take photos without getting hoards of tourists in them by 12pm the areas cleared as all the bus groups went off for lunch. As this is a shady temple miday is ok heat not too intense otherwise maybe first thing would be ok.
Amazing!. Spectacular! Large trees growing over the ruins! Very magical and lovely! Easy access to the temple via a straight path.

Jungle magic. I visited with my family, and after a short walk through the jungle we came across this magical place that seems as if the trees have taken over the temple.
Spectacular and well worth a visit. Tomb Raider fans will no doubt recognise it.
It can be very busy, and there are many hawkers trying to sell you stuff outside.

Better than Anchor. I loved Ta Prohm so much, in fact more than Anchor. The trees taking over the temples displayed a struggle between what man has built and nature. I can see why Hollywood fell in love with this place.
AMAZING!

Maybe the perfect sunrise temple. While many visiting the temples at Angkor choose to watch the sunrise at the Angkor Wat we took the advice of friends to avoid the crowds and experience a sunrise by ourselves in this marvelous location amongst the trees that have grown over and through this temple. It was a great decision. We were alone and treated to a cacophony of bird songs as the sun brightened the area of this magical temple. We did not see the sun rising on the horizon but we did see it illuminate the jungle that is integral to this structure.
Stunning. Wow! Wow! Wow! I wish I had a time machine to travel back and see this Royal Monastery in all its glory. The sheer scale of the temple and stone carving detail was mind blowing

Wow!. I have seen the many photos - but being there to see it for myself is different. Wonderful. Seeing the roots of the trees growing around and into the temple was really beautiful.Go during the hottest time of the day - that way, you avoid the crowds. But even then, we had to queue up to take photos at the popular areas.

Lara Croft wannabees must visit. Ta Prohm is the most photographed and recognizable of the Cambodian temples. The strangler fig trees are enormous and they do strangle the temple literally and figuratively.
Unforgettable. An unforgettable part of the Angkor experience. A marvellous area full of history and you'd need to be hard-hearted indeed not to love the Cambodians!

What it must have been like years ago?. I do not have a vocabulary extensive enough to add anything to former reviewers.It is a MUST SEE destination hence whenever I mentioned "so many tourists", my better half replied "darling WE ARE ALSO tourists".Be prepared for dust, queues and heat but...it will be worth it!
Come here early. A local gave us the hint to come here straight after sunrise at Angkor Wat because you'll get great photos with the early morning light & beat the crowds. It was beautiful.

The architecture is fascinating. Ta Prohm is the temple you see in movies and photos with the kapok trees forcing the stones apart and embracing them at the same time. It is worthwhile to read up about the various temples beforehand or buy the guidebook so you can fully appreciate the intricacies of the relief carvings.

Where architecture is taken over by nature. Brilliant brilliant brilliant!This is the "tomb raider" temple, made famous by photographs of monks sitting on the roots of trees, and although it seems like it is forever undergoing restoration work, it still feels like you get to experience this temple fully. This is best visited at ease- don't rush through this one, its special! You may get lost a little within the temple but its well worth it.

Very good temple in siem reap. Ta Prohm (Khmer: ប្រាសាទតាព្រហ្ម, pronunciation: brasaeattaproh) is the modern name of the temple at Angkor, Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, built in the Bayon style largely in the late 12th and early 13th centuries and originally called Rajavihara (in Khmer: រាជវិហារ). Located approximately one kilometre east of Angkor Thom and on the southern edge of the East Baray, it was founded by the Khmer King Jayavarman VII as a Mahayana Buddhist monastery and university. Unlike most Angkorian temples, Ta Prohm has been left in much the same condition in which it was found: the photogenic and atmospheric combination of trees growing out of the ruins and the jungle surroundings have made it one of Angkor's most popular temples with visitors. UNESCO inscribed Ta Prohm on the World Heritage List in 1992. Today, it is one of the most visited complexes in Cambodia’s Angkor region. The conservation and restoration of Ta Prohm is a partnership project of the Archaeological Survey of India and the APSARA (Authority for the Protection and Management of Angkor and the Region of Siem Reap).

The must see in the temple area. In my opinion one day is enough in the temple area of Angkor due to all the tourists, and if you visit the temple area Ta Phrom is a must see!Watch out for the bats in the ruins haha!

Indiana Jones site!. This is the site to see and photograph the famous trees growing in, over and through ruins. Only partially restored which we found more romantic and interesting. A must see but does not handle crowds well as smaller and too many people hog the best photo sites for too long. Try early morning for better experience.

Yikes. You can look at all the pictures on all the websites and none can due justice to seeing the real thing in the flesh. It's like something out of a cheezey Roger Corman sci-fi flick. When nature goes wild, look out!

Pretty, but go in the heat of the day. If you have a full day of tempe tours planned, do this in the hottest part. The trees provide shade. It is very pretty and I recommend going here. The trees are amazing.

Breathtaking.. Angkor Wat and especially Ta Prohm are one of the most amazingly beautiful places I've ever seen - and that I probably will ever see. This is a must-see if you're anywhere close to Cambodia. I suggest waking up as early as possible to avoid the crowds.

favorite temple. A Must See!!!. one of the Coolest temple I've ever seen. this is a must see. its different than the others. Be careful I sprained my ankle at this temple, there are mini ditches that are hidden by the leaves. so be careful walking around but other than that it is a really cool temple!

Sepectacular. This place sure is a must! We all know those trees and those roots growing over and under buildings bit seeing it in nature sure makes a difference. If you choose the right time there are not that many tourists (very early morning or late afternoon).
This is the most atmospheric site in the area. Visit early - gets very busy for a the nature of the site, but fantastic trees growing amidst the ruins. Don't miss!

One of a kind!. Loved this beautiful temple and tried to look for Angelina Jolie :). It was walking into a different time and dimension altogether. The beautiful tree roots holding some parts of the temple were amazing. This is my favorite temple.

Love the trees. This is one of the temples with trees that have taken over. Sadly, I think they've had to cut some of them down, but there are still a few remaining and they are amazing. We went at sunrise while the crowds were at Angkor Wat and it was empty. I think there were maybe five other people there?

Wauw, wow, whoa. Yup, this is as good as it gets. We were there around twelve, but because of the leafy jungle it was bearable. And stunning. You can imagine when you see this that there are some 50 temples still uncovered, their simply eaten by the bush. So impressive, especially when you just tilt your head a little, so you don't see all the crowds. Crowds or not, its worth it and probably our favorite.

Classic building super staff. Perhaps best location in town! Riverside, near old market and Pub St. but quiet. Interior entirely hard wood and immaculate. Staff friendly and attentive. Colonial charm, a slice of Indochine.

Beautiful. The cicadas are very very noisy here. The sight is amazing, worth the visit, go in the morning though it's cooler. You might want to consider a guide as its a maze. Very beautiful and very busy.
Awesome. Another awesome temple i was glad to have my english tour guide. wear walking shoes and walk on some of the rocks, get a pic that other people havent managed to get if even possible.

Favorit temple for young ones. Perhaps affected by the Tomb Raider movie, but to see the temple with huge trees on top of it gives a very different impression. just wonder whether the archeologists will remove those giant trees to save the temple?
Stunning. We went to this amazing place at sunrise. It was eerie and very special and one of our favourite places

Tombraider. Yes, this is the tombraider temple. A lot of this temple has not been cleaned up since it has become one with the surrounding jungle. A unique one! Don't forget to go see Banteay Srei and Bayon too.

Absolutely Amazing!. A truly amazing temple, widely used as a film set (but don't let that put you off!) A lot of the buildings are completely entwined by massive tree roots; if the trees were removed, or fell down, the buildings would collapse, hence the trees are carefully managed. A lot of reconstruction is still taking place - there are a huge number of stone blocks, each labelled, waiting to be put back together in a gigantic three dimensional jigsaw puzzle. Some reviewers have criticised this - all credit to the Cambodians for taking such pride in such an amazing atmospheric place. You will not visit anywhere with so many 'Kodak moments!'
A favourite. This has to be a favourite amongst the Angkor complex. The way the trees have grown in and around the temple is incredible and somehow makes it all the more appealing.

Favourite Temple. Am hoping this temple will be saved from mass tourism. It's the temple where they filmed parts of the Tomb Raider movie. Areas roped off for renovation but the job doesn't look great. People clambering all over the place. Hard to see how it can withstand the numbers. Go early for sunrise, take a torch. It's best to view before the crowds get there. Lovely shaded walks around this temple.
Unbelievable Sight. It's "Tomb Raider" temple..With huge cotton silk tree roots growing out of the ruins & amazing nature..
best temple to see hands down. Very mystical temple--over grown trees have taken over the temple which in turn have made it such a landmark to visit and photograph. By far my favorite temple.

Wonderful Experience. All these temple structures are part of the 600 years of Hindu/Buddhist rulers creations. Each structure, carving, sculpture is a masterpiece.Unfortunately now available as ruins only!

Amazing. Go before 8am to ensure minimal tourist interference. Very interesting with the trees and roots growing through the temple, and was the set of some Tomb Raider scenes. Make sure you cover your shoulders and knees to guarantee entry.

Scaffolding. This is just as amazing as Angkor Wat, but currently (jan 2015) there's a lot of scaffolding as restoration works take place. However, if you can look past that, and realise why it's being done, you cannot fail to be touched by the place - it's really beautiful.

"Tomb Raider" temple. This site has silk cotton trees overgrowing the walls and becoming one with the complex walls. You'll need to stand in line to take your picture at the Tomb Raider tree but people are courteous.

Loved it. A small group of us did Ta Prohm on the first afternoon of our 3 day pass. It took us approx 2 1/2 hours to walk around this one temple. We didn't have a guide but had read up on it before going. Would highly recommend this temple.
Interesting. This was our first temple and it was very interesting. The large trees growing on top of the temples are unbelievable.
Interesting. This was our first temple and it was very interesting. The large trees growing on top of the temples are unbelievable.
Inspiring. This place is so different from Angkor Wat and Bayon, with the trees and roots seeming to hold it in place. Also the colours in the stone walls were a real feature. Loved it.

The piece de resistance... :-). The top visited site after Angkor Wat is Ta Prohm (“Ancestor of Brahma”)- made (more) famous by the movie Tomb Raider (not that we could care one hoot about that). This temple is unique in that the Cambodian archaeological authorities chose to cut back only part of the jungle letting the roots of huge banyon, kapok and strangler fig trees, the jungle and undergrowth swallow up the temple. It was truly stunning (so long as you can time your visit towards the end of the day when the tour buses have hit the road). We found areas of total peace and tranquility from where we could contemplate the power and scale of nature and its ability to re-take what belonged to it in the first place as it consumed these amazing stone buildings, covered in bas-relief carvings and intricate decoration.In it’s day the temple would have controlled over 3000 villages... unbelievable really.Definitely a must do! :-)

Seeing is believing. When I first look at the photos I thought these must be photoshopped. But I saw the temple and the massive silk cotton trees roots hugging each other and it was eerie and at the same time very beautiful.A must visit but do take care when going through blocks of stones, low ceilings and walking on sides of wall

Tomb Raider Temple. This was even better 7 years ago before the barricades and renovations (which I understand) but it is still amazing. If you have only a small time make this a must see. The trees are probably more amazing than the temple. Don't miss this one.
Romantic and surreal. This large monastic complex is still overgrown with some huge trees. Since it is the "Tomb Raider" temple, it's packed with tourists. Get there at sunrise.

Indiana Jones' Temple. This is the temple with the fig tree roots growing all over the stones. If they remove them, the buildings will fall down!!They do now stop further growth of trees in the ruins and are doing a good job of bringing the place back to life. However, I'm sure the roots are here to stay for a long time yet.A must see when in Siem Reap

Again beautiful. Again this is a beautiful temple but there are 'photo spots' that are crowded because of the movie. This was my husbands favorite temple. It has not been restored and the trees growing on the wall are amazing.

My favourite temple of all!. This is set in an overgrown jungle area, it is not a let down it is stunning! Unfortunately its always very busy with tourists so you just have to grin and bear it. A truly amazing temple that is a must see. Part of it was being restored when we were there, it was amazing to see the skill at making it look so authentic to the original parts. Just beautiful.

A must see. This temple was amazing with all the tree routes growing into the structure of the old temple. Never seen anything like it was the sheer size of the tree routes was impressive. I enjoyed this temple the best.

Amazing Tree on the Wall. I don't know how these trees balance on the wall.Most of the roots were on the wall.Everybody taking picture with this amazing tree.But mostly there are few temples with Buddha image.For us Buddhists we would like to pray at these ancient temple.Some temple they have Buddha image without head.We feel sad about it.

Best temple in Siem Reap. Ta Prohm is my favourite temple in Siem Reap. It is the famous Tomb Raider temple with the trees growing on top of the stone temple structures. Its a great blend of nature and ancient man made structure. As expected it is quite crowded and there is a lot of reconstruction going on. Still bring your wide angle lens and you will not be disappointed.

Indie Was Right!. This is the Indiana Jones temple, I think he picked the right one. The trees growing from the ruins make for great photos, and we were glad to see the restoration work going on. Ta Prohm really has a mystical feel about it, we thoroughly enjoyed our visit.

Another Temple?!. Having visited Angkor Wat it was difficult to see how 'another temple' could be interesting. But interesting it was, for lot of reasons. The entrance to the grounds is just amazing. Glorious huge tumble-down stones greet you to this extraordinary place. You can see why they used it for a film set! A good walk to the temple itself - time to enjoy the peaceful trees and surroundings. It was good to see the artisans rebuilding this amazing 'building'!. I do not think it is a job they will finish very quickly! It is like putting a huge, and rather heavy, jigsaw together! There is lots to see and you get a feeling of the cataclysmic slow death of the temple. The trees and their wonderful roots having caused havoc - and still there to see. Amazing photo opportunity. Definitely worth a visit.

Rooted in ancient history.....literally!. After being blown away at the magnificent Ankor Wat, we came here to see the amazing site of huge fig trees growing through, & on these ancient ruins, with root structures that look like serpents.This place can get very busy & photo opportunities need to be taken with some assertiveness!We were with our private guide who managed to steer us skillfully guided us away from the noisy tour groups, which definately added to the magic of the place.
Amazing. It's just amazing to see old trees and branches embracing the temples.It was also heartening to know great work by Indians in restoring the temples. Hats off to the restoring team.

lives up to its fame! Here is the reason I wanted to visit Siem Reap!. We made to different visits to Ta Prohm during our 4 days in Siem Reap. The first time, we visited it during afternoon around 3:30pm. It was PACKED with people. Big tour groups and long lines for pictures. We still enjoyed our visit, was it wasn't very magical. We went back on our last day, just after sunrise at Angkor Wat at around 7:30am. There were still some people, but no tour groups. We were able to take shots with no one in the background but our family. Took time to try taking photos from different angles and just strolling leisurely. By the time we leave close to 9am, many people are heading into the door. I would say if you want this to be magical, go early in the morning!

Takes on other-worldly hues at sundown. The site, possibly because of its association with Tombraiders, attracts large crowds, but after you have been here, you realise that it is because of Ta Prohm that Tombraiders is a hit, not the other way around. The bell-ringing sound of cicada insects welcomes you and reminds you that it is a temple you are visiting. The giant Spung trees that grow out of, and surround sections of the temple make for a photogenic setting, with the Gopuras peeping out between trees at places. At sundown, these gopuras take on a golden hue that seems to completely transform the place. Apart from the tree roots and branches, the charm of the place is also due to some fine carvings all around. Some sections were closed when we visited because of the restoration efforts being on, but what we could see made the visit well worthwhile.

Amazing giant trees. My fav temple , stunning with so many giant trees on the temples . Ya ,it's tourist attraction so no doubt there are over crowded there. Can not take a nice pic but feeling so amazing .

Step back in time. This is an amazing temple that you can see workers rebuilding, slowly. Don't miss the photo board of before and after shots of the reconstruction...and there are so many blocks to re set....the baryon tree roots having grown over the stones, and just massive and unimaginable how it happened. Very crowded and walkways much narrower than the spacious Angkor Wat. Great photo op!

Pretty Amazing. This was undoubtedly one of our favorite temples & a must see! I must agree with another reviewer about the crickets, the noise they make is unreal & truly adds to the experience ( & it lessens the noise of screeching, shrieking Koreans )& the atmosphere, which itself is pretty eery.The magnificent fig trees aren't just big, they are truly gargantuan, what an amazing site! The roots of some are so huge they are having to be supported, some are supporting the ancient ruin, whilst others you can see are destroying it. However you can see work underway to preserve both trees & buildings. Inside one of the narrow buildings, make sure you look for the "hidden face", absolutely amazing!!!One thing to watch for here is the hawkers as you enter the walk to this temple, they got very upset when didn't purchase the wooden Buddha we'd been admiring for ... $200!!! We got the same one later for $25!!!

Rooted in Ruins. The way to Ta Prohm from the Angkor Thom is a the most portal-like gateway I have ever seen. It is an other world place. The tree roots that are cracking hundreds of years of history make it both tragic and humbling at the same time. Not to be missed. Avoid crowds to soak in the place.

Other-worldly. When you enter the complex, one of the first things you see is the silk-cotton tree whose massive roots are spectacularly draped over a temple gallery. This is a wow-moment, and a great photo opportunity-- if only there weren't so many people crowding around. But fear not, there is another silk-cotton tree farther in, whose roots, reminiscent of an alien species, have spread indolently across the roof. Keep an eye out for the location where Tomb Raider Lara Croft aka Angelina Jolie leapt from the roof as it has a strangler fig tree whose roots are quite impressive too, in a different way.

Larger than Expected!. We went to Angkor Wat for the sunrise and then immediately came here to beat the crowds and have good photo opportunities and this worked out perfectly. We spent about one hour here, and just as we were leaving there were throngs of tourists appearing. The temple is very large and majestic, and it is where the tomb raider movie was shot. Impressive!

Awesome. This is where nature meets history. It is amazing to see the giant fig trees engulfing the temple, in some places it appears to be destroying it, in others it is almost as though the trees are holding the temple together.If you come to Siem Reap you must visit this temple.

Get There At Dawn To Avoid The Crowds. This and Bayon were our favorite temples. We got there before sunrise with our guide (highly recommended) and the crickets sounded like a high pitched alarm. Amazing! At sunrise, we shared the temple with only 3-4 other small groups. Left just before 9am, just as all the massive tour busses were descending on the parking lot.
Top 3 in Siem Reap. My bucket list: when I first watched Lara the tomb raider with Angelina Jolie. Finally, I am here. Feel like a teenage again.

One of the top few temples.. We booked a tour guide who suggested to visit this straight right after brunch. Around 11:30 am, we left the restaurant to this temple. That was when most visitors were leaving the temple for lunch. There was still a lot of people but certainly not overcrowded. The trees needed the temple and the temple needed the tress to keep its structure. The intertwining of the roots and the temple structure was special. Tomb Raider, Angelina Jolie was filmed here according to our guide.
Another stunning themple... Once again this place doesn't fail to impress, everywhere you go in this area there is temple after temple they are all stunning

The best at Siem Reap!. The trees and massive tree roots at Ta Prohm are an unbelievable sight! It is truly an example of man vs. nature.Restoration efforts are in full scale and the progress is superb!Overall, my favourite of all temples in Siem Reap - you will need a minimum of 3 hours to walk all around this temple and the galleries.
Incredible but a Busy Building Site too. Visit but don't linger. Indian Govt are working away and the much talked about atmosphere of 15 years ago has gone.

Go to the Prohm. Looked forward to visiting here to take in the scenery of Tomb Raiders. Walking along the cleared jungle path set the tone of our adventure, then it appeared. The trees that have taken over the temple are amazing and certainly sets it apart from the rest of Angkor Wat. There was even a woman sitting peacefully doing embroidery in one dark corner. Truly a magical place. It's my turn to say "Ta" to the Prohm!!

Trees and stone. Another great site in the Siem Reap area. Crowds were a bit more of an issue here as access to this site has to be limited due to the condition. Get a guide as there are lots of stories to be told and interesting angles for amateur photographers.
Go to Ta Prohm! Just do it. Get lost in it's maze of paths and passages. See how nature is taking over the temple complex. By far my favourite attraction in Siem Reap; it's just beautiful.

A single visit not enough!. It is #1 on TA for a reason...breathtaking, a single visit not enough, visit multiple times and different times of day as the light changes so much in the jungle. This is the most crowded as the temple is busy and it is smaller with less moving space.
Ta Prohm. Wear comfortable shoes and enjoy the trek! The trees are enchanting! I highly recommend including this in your visit to Siem Reap.

Amazing view. But too many people!. The temple itself is a sight to be reckoned with. But unfortunately between my friends who were already tired, and the amount of crowd that is gathered around there, it's just too hard to appreciate the architecture to the fullest. Word of advice: Try to visit the temples in the early mornings as there are less people to deal with!
An amazing place!. The fig trees that have overgrown the buildings and surrounding walls etc are amazing and met our expectations that we gained from the tour guides. Well worth a visit!

Tomb Raider Temple. There is a mystical feel to this temple complex. It's amazing to see how the trees have taken over the temple and you feel as if the pillars and beams of the temple are acquiescing to the wishes of the trees. Most of the tourists we came across were clearly there for having a bit of fun and not to learn or savour the history. Groups of people were squeezing into door frames and archways for pictures and selfies !! Make sure they show you the temple chamber which echoes when you thump your chest but doesn't echo when you speak. If you've seen the Tomb Raider movie a lot of this will look familiar to you.

Get there early--we were given this advice by our guides at Angkor Jasmine Package and they were spot on. The site was n. Wow and more wow! Work to preserve Ta Promh is going on constantly but it's obvious they take care to keep the archeological work and preservation to be as unobtursive to visitors as possible.

Avoid the Minions!!!!. This temple would be the most beautiful of all....but also the most crowded. I don't even know when to suggest the best time to go as it seems to be crowded all the time (thanks to its Tomb Raider fame) I just compromised by taking most of my photos up high, over the heads of the hundreds of Korean tour groups (all wearing colour-coded t-shirts) Just don't get in the way when they are called to regroup. I was shoved off the path numerous times, slammed into walls and once nearly into a pond.That aside, the temple is well worth braving the crowds as it truly is lovely. The huge strangler figs invade the stones with sinuous determination. The roots delve into the temples secrets with ruthless purpose until they dominate the whole structure and become part of it. Its is a beautiful sight indeed.Its quite a wondrous place if you can escape the noise and pushiness of the tourist hoardes. Its a definite must-do in the Angkor complex. Don't miss it.

Still Worth Seeing Despite Popularity. This can be one of the more crowded temple sites around Siem Reap, don't let that discourage you from checking it out. If possible, try to get there early in the morning, you will have a better chance of not being around throngs of other tourist and still be able to get some great photo's.

Best yet. Huge huge trees take over an entire temple complex!!!It's definitely awe inspiring & exactly what you'd want to see in Siemreap. We were here after Angkor watt & with a relatively less crowd, we had an awesome time.
So famous and too busy. It's a beautiful tempel to see, but at the high season to crowded. No fun to take pictures. But worth to pay a visit.

touristy friendly but lost its rustic feel. visited this place 3 times (2006, 2009 and recent 2014), it is now more tourist friendly with all the wooden paths but somehow have lost its rustic feel. Found it best during the 2006 and 2009 visit where really had to climb over roots and stuff.

Best Alternative. Once you have seen the Ankgor Wat complex, take the opportunity to visit this site. Great photo opps plus a chance to see how the jungle has taken back so many temples. Thousands lay in ruins or hidden away by the jungle growth and this site shows the great beauty in this process.

lots of huge trees, good labeling... You will be amazed with all type of huge trees along the walkway and also inside the temple. Don't waste too much time queue for picture at the beginning because further inside have better spot for picture taking and less people.
Super crowded !!!. This is one of the super crowded temple but worth to visit because it is really amazing, awesome and beautiful !!! A must visit temple in Siem Reap.
Nice, but crazy busy. Really beautiful spot but the crowds were crazy, especially around the 'money shot' of the spot from Tomb Raider
Stunning - don't miss it. One of the most beautiful temples we visited - don't miss it. Can get very busy so would suggest going with a guide who will take you at the least busy time.

When you go make a world of difference. I went to this site twice as the first time I went tourists literally FIGHTING over who is next to stand in front of a photo spot. You can't see the sights from the people. Do yourself a favor a go there 6 or 7 AM and you could have the whole place to yourself. in Dec/2014 a lot of the site is closed for tourist access as the reconstruction is in full force. If you still want to see and have access to a temple site with grown in gum trees, do yourself a favor and go to Being Maelea.

Speical but Just Bad to be too Famous!. Quite interesting and unique temple, no one will miss it. But full of crazy crowd of tourists! You may want to find a time that is less busy to visit this temple, while travel to the less crowded ones (e.g. Banteay Samre, Banteay Kdei) on rush hours

Amazing, breathtaking!!!. Ta Prohm is part of the Angkor Wat compound, or as the locals call it the "Tomb Raider Angelina Jollie temple"... it is absolutely amazing and a difference to the other temples nature has taken matters into its own hands... the tree roots resembles hands invading and crushing walls and crawling through windows.. its very cool to watch...the whole thing is picture perfect... a Tuk tuk taxi can take you from your hotel wait for you and bring you back for only 10$, the entrance to the Angkor Wat park is 20$...To see the whole Angkor Wat temples....will take you about the 3 days, so choose the best to visit.. Ta Prohm being the best in my opinion for how cool it looks.....the tuk tuk will drop you off on one gate, and he will pick you up on the other side...we started from the east gate....coming out the West gate... on the west gate you have little souvenirs shops and refreshments As you are walking in you will see a group of musicians that are land mine victims all missing limps... they play the typical Kmer music, a CD for 10$ worth buying and its very emotionally moving. If you end up in Angkor Wat (the main temple) watch for one great coffee shop attached to an official gift shop, its Air-conditioned (It gets very hot) and the wash rooms are clean, and smell clean !!!!!! also food is pretty good.
Beautiful ruins. Ta Prohm has an romantic aura with the huge trees and the greens surrounding the ruins. best visited in the early morning.

Overated but still worth visiting for its unique trees and interesting landscape.. Unique trees and landscaping there should be the order of the day. Temple there is average at the most, but the way the trees grow on the temple makes it unique and interesting.

Endless photo opportunities. Fantastic day out. This was my favourite place while visiting Angkor Wat. It is very rustic and natural it has amazing photo opportunities. We visited around 1pm and it wasn't crowded.

unbelievable. Just imagine trekking through the jungle and coming upon a long-forgotten temple that has been ravaged by the jungle. That's Ta Prohm. Words cannot fully describe the grandeur and mystery of this temple. If you want to see only 1 temple that has been lost to the jungle, this is it.

The BEST among the Best. Breathtaking, awesome, wonderful, simply the best of all temples in Siem Reap. Huge trees hugging the ruins is so majestic. If you have limited time Ta Phrom should be on top of your list.

Our favourite temple! . We went around 7am, and there wasn't much of a crowd which made it very easy for us to really take our time to explore the temple carefully. We didn't have a guide, and that would have been helpful to explain the whole story of the place but we were more than happy to just enjoy the ruins, the trees conquering them, and seeing the restoration work. This temple could get quite crowded around 9am (most tour buses come back during that time), so our advice is to either go early or during lunch time.
Unlike no place else. I had seen these in the movies and visiting the place for real was a lot of fun. this temple is unique and the hollow trees and the roots are one of their kinds

Brilliant!. a second-to-none architecture in the world! built by the great King Jayavarman VII as a worship to his mother. this temple has the most unique design contributed by not just human but also mother nature with the houses penetrated by the giant ancient trees. a must-visit place absolutely.

UNESCO world heritage site, please be respectful.. This was a highlight amongst the many temples we saw in Cambodia. But it upset me greatly that so many tourists seem to have no regard for what they were seeing, and having no regard for other people taking photos. And I saw a couple of tourists, just walking all over the place as if it was their own, and then being loud and displaying public displays of affection at this place. I felt like saying to that couple 'get a bloody room' and it's socially faux pas in Cambodia to display affection publicly, so it was even more embarassing that they were english speaking. Protip - don't lose your tour guide, because you'll learn stuff about this place, that you wouldn't know unless a cambodian tour guide is with you. There is a spirituality in this place, that can't be described. Take your time to walk around here, and in parts it's quite cool. Three things though 1 - make sure you go to the toilet across the street before you enter the site otherwise it's a long walk back to go 2 - take a hat to protect you from the piercing sun 3 - take fluids because the heat will get to you 4 - take respect for the history of this placeIt was amazing, but I just wish that UNESCO, the cambodian government, cambodian tourism would do more the protect the areas and the buildings, and had more areas cordoned off to tourists.

Busy but beautiful! . This was one of the most crowded of the temples we visited in Angkor but it was worth it as it is so beautiful! Huge tree buttresses coming out of the stones- and it's the tomb raider temple- so definitely a must see!

Worth seeing but queue for photos shoots. We went during the peak christmas week so had to queue for the best photo shoots which were picturesque overgrown tree roots into the temple. This is where "Indiana Jones Raiders of the lost ark" was shot. Definitely must go!

Best temple at Angkor. Often called the 'tomb raider temple' this was the best of the temples to us - really amazing and a great atmosphere. Try to get there as early as possible (I would say skip the sunrise at the main temple and be there at first light) to have the place to yourself. Unfortunately in December 2014 there was ongoing construction, but there are still plenty of parts of the temple that make you feel like you're in the jungle!

Worth going. The temple is in ruined and covered trees and vegetation but that is what makes it interesting. I went during mid day and there were a lot of tourists and taking photos can be a bit frustrating. Nevertheless, it is one of the most-go temples in Ankgor.

An amazing temple. This was my favorite out of all of the temples I visited during my stay in Siem Reap. You should visit it early morning, before 8.30 to avoid the crowd. It was an amazing experience to walk around the temple without the disruption of tourist crowds. Highly recommended

Awe-inspiring. Absolutely wonderful to see a battle between man and nature, one that nature has obviously own. Huge roots are wound around the rocks, some so much so that metal pillars are needed to prevent the temple from completely collapsing under the weight of the trees. This is a must go, and there is a lot of shade from the trees so it isn't too hot to visit.

A Must See. The temple has been taken over by the jungle and it is amazing to see nature reclaim a structure like that. Eventually the trees will have to be cut down so that they do not break the rocks. I would recommend going before then! Remember your sunscreen, deet insect repellent, and good walking shoes.

Roots and Ruins - both amazing!. Definitely worth a visit, not just because of its " Angelina Jolie-Tomb Raider" fame, but to see the dynamic way nature has worked on the ruins of the temple! Massive roots of hundreds of years old trees gnawing through/around/over the temple walls is a sight to see. Not to mention big "holes" and roots of the trees for photo ops :)

A little crowded but not to be missed. Beautiful trees hundreds of years old that have grown and taken over the ruins, very popular from the tomb raider movie so like some of the other temples a little over crowded with tour buses but still worth the visit. You have the locals trying to sell you things on the walk up to and out of ta prohm but with any of the locals just say no thank you and they seem to get the hint.
most feel of 'Oringinal and untouched'. If I only have 2 hours in siem reap, i will see just this one,its most original, and make you feel different compared to other Wats.

Unique experience. The Ta Prohm temple ruins are unique in the fact that you have tall trees which have grown over the temple buildings and continue to grow despite stone structures in their roots! Apparently the Tomb Raider movie was also shot here!!

Wonder after wars. It's one of Angkor Wat complex but it is very impressive by big trees cover the temples and architecture of Temples. It is ruined by war and natural trees.I stayed there a long time and listen to our local tour guide about history and activities in this temples. It is very interesting and honor these strong dynasty who had created this wonders.Hope to be back and explore new things in Siem Reap.Tony

The Search for Enlightenment Part 4. Ta Prohm. In order to associate the name of this temple with something familiar, remember Ta Prohm as the Tomb Raider temple. Huge trees dominate the rock structures. Some roots have become so huge that steel structures now support the trees in order for prop them up and prevent them from falling into the ruins.Truly amazing. The photogenic and atmospheric combination of trees growing out of the ruins and the jungle surroundings have made it one of Angkor's most popular temples with visitors. Outside the temple, ruins are left as they were found. It could get a bit tricky because of the crowded walkways inside and the very humid Cambodian climate.
Just wonderful. Simply go there. Not worth questioning if you should make the time to include this temple. You'll love it. Take water!
Huge temple relic. Ta Prohm temple is King Jayavarman VII's legacy to the Cambodian nation. Striking huge cotton-silk tree roots grow out of the ruins, providing memorable images to all tourists

Ta Prohm - aka Dripping Trees. It has been almost a year since I was in Angkor Wat, and this was one of its true highlights. Beautiful atmosphere with its ancient temples overgrown with what I refer to as dripping trees. Worth adding to your itinerary for its unique ambience...

Wait a year if you can. Ta Phrom is the temple made famous in the Tomb Raider movie. It is possibly the least restored temple in the main Angkor Wat area.A year and a half ago the trees encroaching on the center of the temple were wonderful photo ops. Right now there is major renovation of the central part of the temple. There are still areas in the temple complex that give you that wild abandoned feeling, but isn't more always better? Wait a year or two for the reconstruction to get finished. If you can't wait, go as early in the morning as possible. The light is better for your photographs and your fellow guests just might be getting that second plate at the all you can eat breakfast buffet at their hotel.Also if you can't remember the name of this temple, just ask for the Tomb Raider temple. Everyone know which one you are talking about. If you want to round out your Tomb Raider movie tour, be sure to see the East Gate of Angkor Thom (not the one with the paved road - the one a bit further south). This is where Lara Croft pulled the temple down, though no temples were hury in the filming of the movie.
Tomb raider location. Not a bad place to visit. However, it can be quite crowded with fellow tourist that makes taking photos difficult.

Wonderful. To bad its so ruined by the spung trees, but it's highly recommend to visit. Wish the guide had spoken more about the temple itself. He mostly told us about the trees and the restoration. So the temple gets a 5, and the guide a 3 :P
The Jungle Temple. Breathtaking views of an ancient temple, which is taken back by the jungle (as seen in the movie "Lara Croft - Tomb Raider)
Not to be missed. You think you are on a film set. Unless you see it you can't explain what it's like, though if this was in the uk it would be shut down as a health and safety concern.

Nature and ruins intertwined.. A really impressive thing to see the way the trees have over hundreds of years intertwined themselves with the ruins. I haven't seen Tomb Raider and didn't know about any connection here so don't worry about that being a factor in your enjoyment.It was the busiest site we visited during our day, but we went at lunchtime which seemed to ease things a little.
Crowded. It seems to be popular for the Lara Croft movie, which is not a bad thing. We did this temple in the afternoon so we were a bit tempted out too.
Crowded. It seems to be popular for the Lara Croft movie, which is not a bad thing. We did this temple in the afternoon so we were a bit tempted out too.
Power of Nature taking back. Like: amazing treesDislike: DustyLots of trees claiming back their land, not just one. Save some space on your camera for this place.

A must see. The atmosphere around Ta Prohm is very warm and traditional. It is a great place to let the kids run around and explore the ruins. You could easily spend the whole day exploring around the temples which, Indiana Jones was :) I would recommend to visit when it is not to hot and not to busy.

Another surreal siem reap experience . Unfortunately this place is known as the tomb raider ruins, which is how a lot of people even advertised for it. Walking through it though was incredible though. The beauty of it all was quite overwhelming and I'd certainly recommend it to any visitors thinking of going.
Amazing temple ruins. This was one of our favourite temples (we did both the small & grand tours of the Angkor Park). Partial ruins with trees taking over sections.

The Tomb Raider Temple. Very popular with tour coaches so either get there super early or around midday when some return to hotels for lunch. UNfortunately, crowds are inevitable and so are working children and unofficial tour guides who are actually scammers.
Amazing. The match of old stone buildings and wild trees is just amazing. I loved being there. I walked a lot to see around, but never got tired.
loved the jungle feeling. I love the trees growing in and out of the ruins it has a great atmosphere quite croweded though. there are some renovations underway which were fun to watch

Magestic. Probably the most beautiful place I've ever been in Siem Reap. Magestic for its gigantic trees growing above the ruins of the temple. It was a bit small and a long walk from the entrance but the view left me jaw dropping. If you want a scene away from earth, visit Ta Prohm and do the Lara Croft way. Beware of kids selling you anything. Our Tour Guide told us "if you don't want to buy, say no thank you. if you want to buy, bargain' Actually, I bought my ref magnets here to a kid who bargained from 2 for 3 dollars to 6 for 2 dollars! Cheaper than the markets!! And Enjoy!

Worth a visit. Located between Angkor Thom and Srah Srang. Visited early in the morning, even then had some visitors. Was told it gets crowded. Photogenic in parts; not much restoration seems to have been done, having said that restoration works were on (visited late Nov 2014) in some parts.Angkor Pass required.

Tomb Raider. My favourite. Stunning and a must on any temple tour. Make sure you take a guide their local knowledge and insight is a must. This is one of the smaller Temples and can get a bit crowded time it well. Having said that tourism is clearly down as I went in high season and not that many people. Ask a guide to show you the carving of the Dinosaur.

Mysterious and Atmospheric. Loved this temple out of all of the Angkor complex. We visited early (arrived around 7am) which was the best time to go as it was very quiet - really added to the atmosphere. Great to see in person after seeing so many photos of this temple - even better in person!

Iconic Temple. The most iconic place to visit aside from Bayon and Angkor Wat due to Tomb Raider. The temple however had a lot of vendors at the entrance and tourist have to learn to politely brush them away.

A must do. As everyone else has said, this has got to be on your bucket list.My advice, invest in a local accredited guide, preferably one recommended from your hotel, (if you have a reputable hotel). The cost of the guide for a day will more than repay itself in local knowledge, the best photos and all the little tips they have to offer on what means what and where to look.

Nature Wins. Ta Prohm is a fun one to visit to see the awesome power of nature to ignore the efforts of man to build something that will last. The place is being torn apart by giant trees that are apparently unconcerned by the massive blocks used to build the temple. There are quite a few places in this temple where you are not allowed to go because it is unsafe, but there is still plenty of exploring. Biggest drawback is that there is a pretty specific path that is jam packed with other tourists, and if you want to pause, they don't want you to, and if you want to walk, you're invariably going to be running into someone else who has decided to pause.

Visited along with Phnom Chisor. If you visit Phnom Chisor definitely stop by here...it is not far and a nice temple to see without many tourists around. The temple is minimally maintained so you can get the real feel for something that had sustained 900 years of natural decay. The lakeside is walking distance from here as well so if you can have lunch at one of the huts along the lakeside.
A must!. it was truly mind blowing! the architecture and history behind it is astounding i found it more impressive than the main structure, all the temples surrounding ankor are insane!
Beautiful temple with Amazing Nature. Probalbly one of the best temple to visit in Siem Reap . Beautiful temple with Amazing Nature . They call it as well Tomb Raider after the movie .
Amazing temple. One of the most popular temple in Sean reap .There are a spung tree running a long the gallery make it amazing.

Fantastic!. The best of all we did in Siem Reap. Impressive to see how nature can win! Even though it is a touch noisy because of restauration work we did enjoy it a lot. Something not to miss if you're around!
Nature & culture. The tomb raider tree made famous by the movie is very stunning. It's also interesting to see how nature swallowed the temple centuries ago.

Great place to get lost!. You are probably aware that this is the 'Tomb Raider' temple and the locals appear very proud of this as everyone you bump into mentions it! Restoration of this temple is perfect, just enough to make it reasonably safe (one hopes) but it still makes you feel like an explorer. We spent at least an hour here and I still have no idea of layout. Collapsed doorways means that there appears to be no symmetry, unlike other temples, and there are loads of dead-end courtyards. Throw in the trees growing over and through everything and your have one amazing experience. Possibly not my favourite (Bayon?) but definitely top three.

Jewel in the crown. This is obviously the crowning jewel of the the Angkor Wat complex. Its the most photographed, and even though it hasnt yet been fully restored, it easily meets expectation. As with all of Angkor Wat, make sure you have comfy shoes, suncream, hat and hydration to ensure this visit doesnt become tiresome. Overall, definately worth the venture.

Temple visits. It's historic and also something you should do. When in this area, visiting Temples is actually a MUST. You just take a tuktuk or you can rent a bi-cycle and ride out to the Temple areas. Enjoy the special PEACE
Amazing. Ta Prohm is a beautiful and amazing temple, bound by massive roots of huge trees, very impressive. If you go to Cambodia you have to see and visit this temple.

I found the dinosaur!. A great place to explore closely - I read a story about a dinosaur (stegosaurus) amongst the ancient carvings - it is there but you need to think outside the square - its actually in a circle and don't for get to find the little face hiding in the roots of a tree....

Great temple. This place is a must if you visit Siem Reap. It's quite different from the neighboring temple such as Angkor Wat or Bayon. There's a huge tree growing inside which looks amazing. Some area are still under construction.

World of Difference. I enjoyed my visit to Ta Prom. Particularly interesting was the way in which they are going about restoring the temple/s to their original glory. The work involved in this must be amazing and staggering, but it's interesting to compare the pre/ post temple reconstruction.

Great Attraction. Highly recommend visiting this place with Hour Sokkung tour Guide hoursokkung@gmail.com. Book directly with the tour guide and avoid all the agencies commission etc. These tour guides make less money as is and this way it would really help them take care of their families

Top 3 in Siem Reap. While this wasn't my favorite temple (Baphuon in Angkor Thom), this was a beauty. So you get to see and hear about how people plunder and destroy temples but to see the exact opposite - nature and how if left to it's own purposes could eat up an entire place was very interesting. Loads of tourists taking pictures everywhere so forget about having a chance to get meditative here though.

Arrive before the tour buses. We took a chance and arrived around 7:30am, which gave us ample time to explore this marvelous site at our own pace. The combination of trees intertwined with the buildings. Many great photo ops.

Tree roots growing on Temples. Incredibly photogenic and a delight to see and explore. It is one of the temples that has trees growing on top of the ancient temples and the roots are growing around the stones and doors. Our tour provided by Beyond Unique Escapes got us there before the crowds making it possible to get a lot photographs with no people in them.

Superb place. I was there on the second day at Siem Riep, after visiting Angkor. This was the most exciting visit to a place that i did during the last year. The mix between the centenary trees and the man made walls give us extradiornary feelings. I love this place. In this moment some repair works are going on but it don't impact the visit. The areas are properly barricated.

Nice view. Very nice view. Have to able to climb up steep stairs. But view is beautiful. Can be dangerous if you don't walk behind the ropes at the edge of the temple. Recommended only for kids age above 12. There was a sleeping buddha stone wall at the back but not too visible if you don't look closely enough. Stairs is one way up and one way down.
Amazing. Currently under reconstruction, it is an amazing place to visit, and was once a great place, of which you can still see the remnants of how great it was.Stunning.

Overgrown trees and colors are lovely. But there's another temple about 2 hours out of town called Bang Malea that's bigger, more overgrown, far less touristed and has guides. And Banteay Srei is on the way, a recommended half day trip instead. Plus there's limited entry fees for them.
All the best temple. I go to Siem reap for a trip everything in okay1villa hotel is good and driver mr yen he is really good. he very take care us around a trip everywhere in Siem reap.
Lara Croft tomb raider. My favorite of all temples. The place gives a different vibe compared to other temples. There are trees growing on top of the rocks. The temple is pretty big too.
Great. I never heard of this place. A lot of aha moments. Truly fascinating. I recommend this to every one.

The jungle fights back. A once great temple complex which the jungle is re-invading. Some restoration work currently going on at the eastern end, but we believe they will leave much of it in its current state. Very atmospheric.

Stunning. Absolutely beautiful, and a vast site to take in. We visited this one twice, first by tuk tuk around 1pm and the second around 11am by bicycle. The trees weaving around the temple are like nothing else I've seen.Be aware that huge Chinese tours seem to be ever present, we visited the whole site over 4 days both morning and afternoon and they were always around. They can be very pushy and inconsiderate. The locals especially at this temple will be in attendance trying to sell souvenirs or getting their children to, which can be a little upsetting.

A must see atraction. If you were in Angkor Wat you will be able to see this wonderful interesting place without paying extra Charge. The trees here climbing the stones are worth of an extra fotoshot.
Thumbs Up. Lots and lots of old and huge trees to take pictures next to. Also known as the Tomb Raider temple - due to the movie shooting. Must visit
A Must-See!. This is a must-see stop for Angkor visit. Yes, there are plenty of tourists (dislike), but do it anyway - you won't regret it because it's stunning (like)!

worth the effort. It was a life long dream to see the temples and they didn't disappoint at all.- I strongly recommend getting there by 7am (with a big bottle of water and a hat!)- as by 9 the place is crowded with badly behaved Chinese tour groups (they are the new "ugly" tourists- touching everything in museums and the temples- being extremely loud, shoving and rude- (please know this is not a racist comment just a fact, every single group encountered was like this- a Chinese friend found them horrid too)- The other thing is other 'ugly' tourist doing selfies everywhere in the temples- deliver me from Kim Kardashian want to be's -would they do this in a traditional church? yeah maybe the clueless people wouldDon't let this ruin the idea of going- forewarned is the best way to avoid them- Angkor is a wonder of the world.

Jungle Tree Temple. I loved this temple. It's a little far out so expect a little drive, but worth it. It's the one with the dinosaur pic and the "tomb raider" one. Please keep in mind that it has no bathroom and plan accordingly. That fact definitely caught me unaware!

Trees Temple. You will love the trees that surround the Angkor. The trees are so beautiful and sleek and tall. It must be few hundred or thousand years old trees.
Highly recommended to visit though we are tired of walking in and out of this temple as it was a long walk.

Worth the visit. This is the site where Tomb Raider was filmed. It is not a very large temple unlike Angkor Wat and restoration is still ongoing. It's absolutely perfect for visiting as its main sights are not affected by the works. It can be pretty crowded in the late morning so my advice is to check it out immediately after sunrise at Angkor Wat before breakfast so as to skip the crowds.

Amazing tomb raider temple but will be busy. This was a wonderful temple to see and the one I was most excited about, I love how you can see nature taking over the ruins. On the downside it was very busy which meant it was difficult to get photos without people in them and you sometimes had to wait to get a chance to have your photo taken at key areas. Best try and go during lunchtime or early to avoid the crowds.
Siem Riep, Cambodia. Cambodia one of my favorite countries.Rich on culture, and very gentle people.I like visit the temples.And come back for sure.

A must see. This temple is a must see. Since it is left more in it's overgrown condition compared to other sites, it is very popular. So expect lots of people. It is just so very breath taking it is a must see.

Don't miss is. It was awesome and we almost forgot about seeing this temple and these massive tree veins that are crushing the temple walls. It's a bit more haphazard walking around this place than Angkor Wat. I think it's the second best for sure and a place you should go and see. A lot of fighting for pictures with massive tourist groups - be prepared to be a bit ballsy to get a good pic :)

Trees!. This is my favourite. The walk to the temple is surrounded by trees, so if the wether is hot, then you are protected from the sun. Along the way, the music from the band of landmine victims echoes through the path, making the walk more memorable and serene.There are a lot of reconstruction happening around the area. A wooden ramp has also been constructed to direct the path for tourists. Rails has also been erected to prevent the tourists from entering certain ruins.All in all, this place has the most magnificent trees I have ever seen. The temple ruins are also quite photogenic.
de place u must visit!. it is a very unique temple especially the Root of Banyan Tree that can see in this temple. it is a dynamic interaction especially for the natural lover.
Beautiful place. This is a must see temple. This amazing temple in the jungle is a great place to visit in the morning. highly recommend

Unique . Amazing to see full grown trees growing on the temples. The only bad thing about this place is, it is crawling with tourist, because it's not only popular for the trees on temples, but for the movie Tomb Raider. - Overall, a sightseeing experiencing.

WOW!! Better than Ankor Wat. We visited Ankor in the morning and thought it was great. Then visited ta Prohm and were bowled over!! Even better than Ankor in our opinion. The way the trees grow out of the walls, less touristy than Ankor and overall more intimate and visually stunning

Been tampered with too much.. Ta Prohm temple has undergone a conservation project which has completely changed some of the temple. Doesn't have the "lost in the jungle" feel. Many rocks just put into big piles, messy. But still interesting.

Another spectacular temple. Each of the temples / wats at Angkor Wat are individually very special with wide range of excellent carvings. Wat built around 1100 and being restored with the assistance of several countries providing funds and expertise teaching the Cambodian people the techniques
Tomb raider temple!. Make sure your camera has panoramic setting so you can take good pics of the trees growing out of the walls.
outstanding. get a guide and do the less travelled route, its well worth it if you want to be more than a click and shoot photos tourist

Stunning. You may feel 'ruined out' in siem Reap but make sure you get this sight under your belt! We met a Japanese man with a 100 year old camera there, he had 16 pictures for his camera for his total trip and Ta Prohm was one of them. That may share with you how impressive the sight is!Please do not be disrespectful of the people selling items on the entrance, just be polite if you are not interested. They are trying to make a living. If you want to buy, you must haggle!! The item is never sold without a profit and you will help avoid local inflation - be responsible

My absolute favorite place in Angkor Wat Siem Reap area.. Ta Prohm is the iconic photo stop most recognizable on media and I can see why. Usually I don't want to go to popular, tourist places, but this is worth the time and visit just to feel the age of the place and historical incidents that led to it's demise. The trees and jungle have swallowed up acres and acres of stone buildings and towns. It is an experience I will not soon forget.
Just like in Tomb Raider!!. Great spot for pictures. Feels just like being in the middle of the jungle. Loved it. Pity all the tree roots are ruining the ruins.

Jungle temple. Lovely walk through the forest to Ta Prohm. Lots of picture opportunities of the temple and trees. Ta Prohm was the last temple we visited in the morning before taking a lunch break - we were lucky to have a clear blue skied day and it wasn't too hot cause of the shade from the forest and the trees

Crazy Landscape. Scenery is amazing! Visit soon as restorations are taking place and much of the "hidden jungle" feel of the place will be taken away in years to come as the vegetation is ruining the temple (sadly)
Fabulous Temple. The ruins are awesome, but the trees that grow over the temple are a sight to behold... If you like history or just exploring, this is something to visit

The trees are funky. I suppose people go here to see the way nature has attempted to reclaim the stone edifices. Yes, the trees that have grown over and into the temple are very interesting. But not much else here.
Incredible. The site was wonderful with ruin and nature. Big tree and roots on top is special thing to see. We were enjoying our visit very much on the early morning.

Hate selfies.... too many ignorants taking selfies making it difficult to see, let alone take our own pictures... other than that it very impressive structure...if you lucky enough to see through crowds forest of selfie sticks...

Mesmerizing example of how nature and ancient ruins coexists. I never appreciated the beauty of the grounds where Tomb Raider was filmed until I was actually standing in the middle of these ancient ruins - We arrived at around 6am, way ahead of the flood of normal tourist influx, and it was the perfect time to explore this magnificent ruins complex. There was barely anyone there, and when you close your eyes you can hear the sounds of birds chirping and flapping through the rainforest canopy. The entire ruins gave such a tranquil feel, and the ages stone surfaces of the ruins columns spoke of hundreds of years of wisdom and historical past - it was so amazing to be in such a mesmerizing place. The mere fact that the trees managed to grown themselves through the building blocks of the ancient temple and coexist with it is just beyond amazement. A must visit if you ever plan to explore Siem Reap - you will love it!
Nature meet castle. Cool, nice temple. Amazing trees have been growing in to the temple. A place you should visit when you go to Angkor Wat!

Great site lots of tourists. All the sites around Angkor are amazing. This site was pretty crowded but it was still fantastic. It was under construction when we were there but still I found it really interesting. Well worth the stop.

AMAZING!!!. We made the mistake of beginning our day at Angkor Wat for sunrise and the crowds of thousands. Ta Parohm turned out to be the experience we were REALLY in search of. Ancient temple ruins partially reclaimed by nature, with active archaeological research and some restoration work. Start your day here!
The Best. This is the most interesting temple in the complex as it gives an insight into what they all looked like before restoration.
Love this Temple the most. Among all hundreds of ancient temples in Siem Reap, I love this one the most. With hundred-year-old tree on the roof of the temples
Temples - more temples. When we finally arrived at Ta Prohm I think our group were just all templed out. There is only so much you can take in a single visit.

Surreal beauty.. This area of Angkor Wat is incredible, and because we went early in the morning before the mass tours descended on it had a surreal atmospheric feel about it. Almost felt as if we had just discovered it. It's as if the trees growing through the masonry are meant to be there, and it would certainly loose something if they were removed.A wonderful place.
Awesome. Fascinating to see nature conquer man-made structuresThis was my favorite of all templesFantastic photo possibilities
the nature and historical wonder. Amazing temple with nature, that is my favourite in Angkor. We like to stay at the temple as whole day but time did not allow us to do that.
A must see. like no other temples in Siemreap, this amazing temple brings you back to 12 or 13 century or you can imagine as you were in an adventure of Indiana Jones

Amazing templo of the giant trees. The templo is really unbelievable. It´s a mixt of stones like being devored by the giant trees. Recommend visit it around noon as the shadown of the trees can protect from the sun.
Incredible. This is my third visit to Ta Prohm and each one is as exciting as the first. The integration of man and nature is a must see.

a shady walk in. loved the natural shade. i simply love to see the interweaved beauty of nature and architect. it is easy to walk with good natural shade. it can get quite crowded so be prepared. the beauty makes it all worthwhile. this is the 4th or 5th temple i visited in a day. with 2 children. it is quite an amount of walking but to see the beauty in front of us makes it all worthwhile.....

Really let itself go in recent years. Don't know where to start with this one. Trees growing through walls, moss everywhere, broken bricks all over the shop and most of it doesn't even have a roof. It's as if someone has just completely neglected the place for hundreds of years.No wifi either.
Awesome!. Amazing, don't miss it. Go early in the morning as there are less visitors then. Wonderful experience and great for photos.
