The Indiana Jones experience. The only words I understood by the Japanese-speaking tour guide in one of the groups enjoying this temple when we visited were `Angelina Jolie' and `Tomb Raider.' You must have this Indiana Jones experience.

Awesome. Saw the amazing Sunset and also the distanced Angkor Wat from this place. They are up on the hill, it took about half an hour for us to reach the top. Remenber to be there at about 1645 or else, you might be climbing up a dark hill and will reach the top seeing nothing.

Atmospheric Temple. We visited the temple before dawn and watched the sunrise. We were the only people at the temple at sunrise. The way the jungle has encroached into the temple with the trees growing over and through the walls is amazing. Useful to see a plan of the temple before entering so one gets an ideas of the overall layout. Another must see site.
Spectacular!. Probably the most photogenic of them all. Can be a bit crowded at times but well worth the visit. The trees growing through the walls are an awesome site

Raiders of the lost ark revisited. A must see in Siam Reap. It is where raiders of the lost ark was shot. Incredible photo opportunities. Massive trees engulfing the temple is a sight to behold.Requires a $20 day pass.

Magical and amazing. By far my favourite Temple in Cambodia- it felt untouched and mystical. The surroundings were beautiful and there were lots of nooks and crannies which you can go into to explore further.

Tomb raider territory!. Beautiful temple ,made more famous of course with Tomb raider and Lara Croft filmed here. Temple itself is set in the jungle and some amazing roots of huge trees intertwine with the walls of the temple and buildings. This one is now just starting to be restored. There are some unusual photo opportunities here ... if you can wait until the tourist groups move on.

Fantastic. For those of you who have seen Tomb Raider (I haven't) this is your temple to visit. For those of you that haven't it is a great temple, very different due to all the trees growing up through the temple.They are doing a lot of restoration work on the central part of the temple at the moment and you can't access it but there is still lots to see.

very impressive. The Ta Prohm temple is certainly one of the most impressive temples in the Angkor temple complex. To see how the trees reach a huge extent, clasping her roots the decaying remains of walls and stick together while growing up in the sky and the underlying ruin shadow donate simply breathtaking. And if you are lucky enough to be at an early hour here, if no other tourists have penetrated this far, and can listen to the sounds of the surrounding forest, you get the feeling like being with himself and the world pure. This happened to me at least.I will definitely come back again and also visit the other remote temple ruins.
Go here.. Watching nature slowly reclaim the workings of man put my short time on this planet into perspective. If you can hit during an ebb in the crowds it is magical.
How to judge a monument?. This place is ancient, magic and beautiful. .how come you guys ask for a review of this temple ? Makes no sense

Disappointing while so much renovating is taking place. Ta Prohm is somewhere I have been wanting to visit for many years. Sadly it was a bit of a let down.First of all, the number of visitors. I strongly recommend going either at 5pm or before 9am. Otherwise it is impossible to enjoy this fascinating temple ruin as there are just so few pathways open due to the renovation and repair works being carried out given the huge number of visitors.Secondly a lot of the trees that were growing on and around the temple have been cut down unfortunately, no doubt because they threatened to bring down much of the temple structure. Those that remain in most cases have barriers or fence around them so you can't get too closr., and it's not good for photography either.As a result it has lost much of the feeling of being lost in the jungle. There are two other temples you should visit nearby which also still have strangler fig trees growing on and around them though and which have far fewer visitors - Ta Som and Preah Khan.This temple is still well worth visiting - but be prepared for large crowds.
Fantastic - But Go Early!. An amazing site to see......but if you don't want to see it along with masses of tour group - then go really early - with some peace calm and change to enjoy...

Go Early for Sunrise. Went at sunrise , was the only person there, as soon as the sun was up , people began arriving - lots of restoration happening at the moment which detracts a little bit. Go early as this temple is very popular (tomb Raider temple) and is very crowded early

Indiana Jones eat your heart out!. This is an absolute must-see! The huge trees climbing over the temple walls with roots getting everywhere are simply amazing - as with other Angkor sites try to avoid the crowds by going at lunchtime otherwise you will wait a long time to get the pictures you want!

Our favorite temple.... We got to Ta Prohm at 8:30am - slightly before the bus loads of tourists.It's a fairly big temple. The towering trees, crumbling stones and moss add to the atmosphere of the temple. Almost felt like how the temple was discovered decades ago. Lots of hidden alleys and walkways to wonder around...Definitely our favorite temple among the Angkor ruins.Recommended: Do go early to enjoy temple without crowds.
Amazing Tree.. I am shock with the tree roots...... how would that be so giant. Don't miss tomb raider filming location. Be carefull, it is easy to get lost here.

The trees a amazing. Here you will also see the before and after of the restoration done by the India government. We hired the tuk tuk that picked us up from the airport , If you are comfortable walking then he will take you to Angor Wat , Angor Tom ( Bayon Temple ) , Ta Prom and Banteay Srei all in one day , so you can complete them in a day pass ( $20 per day ) and the next day you can do Beng Mealea the next day . The tuk tuk rental for the first day was $39 and I think it is $ 40 to visit Beng Mealea . The price list for tuk tuk will be in the room or the font desk can provide it., if you are solo you have the option to take the mini bus etc .. check with the front desk.The name if my driver was Toluah and his number is 0886644479. I stayed close to Pub Street
tomb raider temple. just amazing..seeing is believing so guys you need to see those temples strangled with the tendrils of the trees...just wow wow

Eerily amazing.. A must see part of the Angkor complex----the amazing tree roots wrapping themselves around the stonework is a sight not to be missed---you felt as if you had been transported to fantasy land!

Atmospheric but try to avoid crowds. We got here early , there is a lot of restaurantion work going on here including a big crane. Don't let that put you off. Keep going and you will get to the tomb raider bit.
It is as good as the hype and no photos can grasp the strangeness of the place
Excellent
Amazing. This sight was everything we expected from pictures and television shows. We left early so we could get there before the crowd and glad we did because they were right behind us!

A must !. This is a stunning temple in the way that nature is claiming its own back. It is probably one of, if not the most striking of all the temples and has to be on the hit list. Of course, everyone will look for the Tombraider shots and there are plenty of them.

too crowded. it was beautiful but again, too crowded mid-afternoon. maybe always this way? but gorgeous! I have been dreaming about being there for 30 years. it was as beautiful as expected but unable to get spiritual feel of environs due to crowds

Historic and biological wonders. This is my second time visiting the temple, and it is as grand as the first time I saw it. so majestic trees growing out of the ruins provide a juxtaposition of historical grandeur and biological wonder.

Amazing site. Amazing site to visit, it is fantastic. However, unfortunately not recommended for people with mobility difficulties. The site is vast and one has to go from one place to another to appreciate it all and there are plenty do steep steps to climb.

Nature nestles art. Ta Prohm brings out the oohs and aahes the most among all the Angkor era structures that abound near the city of Siem Reap. The majestic trees slowly taking over the ancient structures, the greenery, the relative isolation and ongoing conservation efforts to control Nature from completely gobbling up the temples all make for fascinating photographs and memories.

Temple from "Tomb Raider". Known as the temple from the movie "Tomb Raider", this is one of those amazing places where nature meets history in a stunning way. Every way you turn there is a great picture. There are several large trees that have taken over the temple and the roots are like thick syrup poured on pancakes. We could have easily spent 2 hours exploring, but it does get very crowded.
Do not miss it !. One of the highlighted part of our trip. Spend at least 2 hours and experience the temple with its tale, simply a different feeling of Asia
The romantic temple.. Too many visitors, yet it shows you how nature can improve old beautiful structures. Do not try to photograph the first tree you see, they are plenty around.

Another great cambodian site. In the greater ankor wat complex. Very cool like something out of an Indiana Jones movie or maybe lara croft. Can be taken in with others in very affordable day trip from siem reap

Fairytale-esque. Recently I saw that this temple was named one of the most fairytale-like places in the world (TripAdvisor). And it is so correct! This was very surreal to see the trees actually living within the stone. Apparently this was the set for Tomb Raider; and it's so believable! We felt like explorers ourselves!

One of the best. Definitely one of the best temples in the Angkor complex. Your best bet is to arrive early between 6-8am to be there when the crowds are thinner. I'd recommend walking the perimeter first as there will be very few people doing the same, and you'll feel like you have the temple all to yourself. The massive trees are an awesome sight, and the few reconstructions that have been completed fit in nicely.
A beautiful site. The encroachment of the surrounding vegetation onto this temple is extraordinary. The carvings and architecture are beautiful and enhanced by the tendrils of tree roots.

Nature showing its strength. Although quite small compared to Angkor Wat, this shows the power of nature. With 300+yr old teak trees, enveloping walls and structures like an octopus and destroying them like it was nothing. The Indian government is providing some reconstruction of the site, which interferes with some photographic shots, but is necessary to preserve what nature has destroyed. The engineering used around the 9 th century is absolutely amazing as well as the detail in the carvings. Since it is much smaller, the crowds are also obvious and difficult sometimes to obtain clear photos as each tour leader jockeys for the best spot for photos and eventual tips. This was my favourite Wat to visit.

Very nice, very busy. We biked there from Ankor Wat, which was a nice ride stopping at a few other temples along the way. Ta Prohm is really cool with the whole Tomb Raider vibe. We had heard before hand and while we were that the early afternoon is the time to go to get less tourists. I heard several guides say while we were there that there are more people in the morning and late afternoon. That said, it was still quite busy with people clamouring over each other trying to get a photo with the roots growing over the temple. Don't miss this place but be prepared for a cultural experience.

Nature taking its land back. At Prohm has out Siem Reap back on the map thanks to the tomb raider film. The famous view of the tree growing through the temple is well worth the visit - but this temple has so much more than that. The area is such an inspiration and with the Cambodian history as we know it, the Cambodians need a helping hand - the more visitors that are able to go and enjoy this unique country, the better for the people - who are amazingly beautifully inside and out. Depending on the time of year will determine how busy the temples, but being surrounded by these wonderful and inspiring people will hopefully provide a inner peace to help you deal with the crowds.

Great hotel!. We made hotel reservations at another hotel in Siem Reap for three nights, but disliked the small room we had. We requested a larger room, but was told all the rooms were the same size. The next morning, we looked for another hotel and found Ta Prohm Hotel. We loved this hotel(!). The room was quite large with a king bed, large closet to hang clothes, as well as, ample shelving for folded garments. There was a sitting area in front of the balcony, and a desk, as well as, free wifi in the room. The bathroom had two showers and a tub and breakfast was included in the rate.Ta Prohm Hotel is located near Siem Reap's restaurants, Pub Street, and the many stores/shops. Our windows faced the Night Market which was beautiful lit up at night. The hotel staff were very courteous and attentive to details. We could not have been more pleased with this hotel. Our thanks to all the staff at Ta Prohm for a great visit to Siem Reap!

Possibly my favourite. I found I enjoyed the temples for differing reasons and this was no exception. There was something in the way it has been left as 1 with nature that I found very appealing. It has a very different feel to the other temples and try to take a moment to sit and take it in away from the crowds.

My favourite in Siem Reap!! Must go. After visiting so many temples in Angkor Wat complex, this one impressed me the most!!! It's not as crowdy as Angkor wat or Byron, and there are plenty of shades in this temple which makes it very comfortable to visit during super hot days. There is no need to mention the spectacular trees growing among the blocks. When I visited this place, I felt like I was in a maze, making this place even more interesting. Usually in other temples there are signs guiding you where you can go, but in this temple there is no sign and what comes up in front of you is quite random. I don't know how to describe it. Sorry! But it is definitely fun to visit and worthy to spare sometime to visit this place. They were still rebuilding or recovering this temple and there were messy stones waiting to be put on to the structure. You can sort of imagine what it was like when it was first discovered.

Following the tracks of Indiana Jones and Tomb Raider. Jungle temple; good adventure; unfortunately a bit full with tourists while I was there; still a good experience!! Would go there again (and I usually don't do that)

The busiest temple on the tour. This is the temple everyone told me I should see - and I guess they are probably right. It is however a total tourist trap and understandably very busy. There is a lot of renovation work taking place and I have to say that the 'before' pictures seemed much more evocative than the 'afters'. Also they have created roped, decked areas for the most famous 'Lara Croft' type vistas which felt very fake and in retrospect I was not happy with the pictures taken there. That said I do think it's a 'must see' and very scenic. Have a good camera so that you can edit out the man-made walkways and capture some of the wider angles of the real ruins.

Ta Prohm, Siem Reap, Cambodia. What a wonderful opportunity to share the history of this country. Restoration works being undertaken will ensure many years of viewing to come. Nothing like this in Australia.

Tree Temple!. Amazing place where the trees are growing in between the temple structures. a must visit place for anyone visiting Cambodia. end of the trip to this place you will have a element of doubt is the temple structure holding the trees or the vice versa

Magnificent!. It is said that this site was left in its natural state to give visitors to it an idea of what it was like when they first discovered it. Indeed how amazing it must have been! It is a pity though that with the presence of so many visitors and the resultant noise generated, the distraction from the people posing for photos (yours truly is as guilty - who can resist!) etc, we forget to stand back from the crowd and absorb the wonder of it all. I think It would be good to visit when there are less visitors. The silence would definitely add to the mystery and magnificence.

Visit at the End of the Day. Crowds are much lighter and you can linger longer and take photos without people in them. Give yourself about two hours between about 3:00 to 5:00 PM. The setting is romantic, somewhat eerie, much smaller than Angkor Wat, but we enjoyed it more.

Fascinating place, a must see for all visitors. This place is the one that everyone sees on postcards with huge Banyan trees growing all over the buildings. It is very interesting and fascinating and you are not likely to see anything like it anywhere else I don't think.

Absolutely stunning!!. Do not miss this temple off your list even if you're a bit templed out. Well worth the effort after sunrise at Angkor Wat. Get ahead of the mass of tours and enjoy it in peace and quiet. Highly recommended.
A must see! (Tomb raider temple). Ta Prohm is simply beautiful - the trees that have become a part of the buddhist temple are simply amazing.Wish we'd gone here for the sunrise instead of Angkor Wat!

Nice one. . Definitely together with the bayon my favorite temple belonging to angkor wat. As mentioned more than once the huge and old trees and the way they are incorporated into the ruins structure is just mind blowing.

Busy but worth it. Very crowded because of the recent movies, but worth seeing. I went back for a second time because I felt like I rushed through the first time. Going back wasn't really necessary but I did get some less crowded photo shots.

Excellant but... Its a super place to visit, and the temples and the trees are amazing. Being a famous landmark from the movies, there are no doubt heard of tourists that come of the bus loads, which for me killed the uniqueness of the place. They should seriously consider days when mass groups are banned so families and other travellers can enjoy the visits, without being shoved and listening to loud talking people but should be visited if an Sieam Reap.

Very Nice!. A must visit. Never seen anything like this before :) Nice to take pictures here but a lot of tourist at this place. so you better have good skills to take good pictures with just you and the scene! hehe

Favourite. My favorite temple for sure. Quieter than AngkorWe did our tour with a man called Dyna. We had a great laugh with him, whilst learning lots we wouldn't through a guide book. I know he can be contacted via Soks Orphanage (can be found on facebook)- which I would highly recommend visiting or volunteering at!
Awesome Hotel. It is builted in the Bayon style largely in the late 12th and early 13th centuries and originally called Rajavihara. Love this Place a lot

Tree Temple. This should really be called Tree temple. Various opportunity for you to click pictures of tall overgrown trees growing all over the temple. This is the Lara Croft temple too...but many parts are off limit due to renovation work. Still worth a visit.
Great Site to see. This entire area is a tourist mecca so expect to be crowded by busses on busses of tourists, but its a really cool temple definitely worth a visit.

Mystic and magic!. We came here by taxi...well was really worth!the time is left in the past...the jungle seems to eat the temple...am i in a indiana jones movie!?the best temple in Cambodia!i did some pics that will last forever...get lost inside it!magic

The temple Angelina Jolie made famous. It's a bit of a walk from the parking lot, but the shade of the trees keep it cool. The shade from the trees makes this a cooler place compared to the other temples. There are lots of nooks and cranny to explore, and take pictures in. Many of the tree roots encroaching the structures are hands-off, but you have a platform where you can have your pictures taken.Tip: After sunrise at Angkor Wat, don't go inside yet, skip it and head to Angkor Thom (Bayon, Baphuon, Ta Prohm) to avoid the crowd. They will eventually catch up with you at around 9:00 AM, but then you will be off to see other places by then.
maybe the best temple!. very jungle like temple with great atmosphere . just a pity for all the busloads of tourists when we visited
"The tomb raider temple". This temple is famous for being in tomb raider. It has amazing trees that are 200-600years old climbing up all around it and over it. One of my top 3 temples
Ta prohm. This was an amazing sight. We thoroughly enjoyed the sights & this sight was up there on the list. It's quite uncanny to see trees growing all over the remains. Excellent

That Tree!. One of the most visited spot in Siem Reap, therefore expect a lot of tourists from all over the globe. They say it is as it is everyday! =) Never leave Siem Reap without visiting this place. Words can't explain how we felt when we were here...just pure awe! Got to walk where Jolie had. =)

Nature vs Man. A great temple that has met it's match with nature. A beautifully constructed temple has been unprotected from nature and the result is incredible. Unimaginable intertwining tree roots permeate throughout the temple, what a sight!

Something else. How nature, the forest and people have impacted this wonderful structure. Watching how the trees have embraced the structure, in some case destroyed it and other cases it's supporting it. Just amazing!

Amazing - nature overtaking stones. Ta Phrom, or the Jungle temple is another must see in Angkor. Why? Because nature has taken over. Trees grow over and through walls. Eerie and magical at same time. The film Tomb Raider was shot here, with Angelina Jolie. The trees also provide much needed shade.

Truly a Jewel in the Jungle. Built deep within the forest of Angkor City, Ta Prohm is a magical jewel as mesmerizing as ruby and as deep as sapphire! It doesn't just feels like I was on set of Indiana Jones or Tomb Raider, it's like I'm starring on my very own scenes! Each and every boulder and rock was placed perfectly by time to finish up with a ruin which is nit really ruined!

A must see!. I visited this Temple in November. They are doing some restoration of this temple so there are some areas that you can not access. I had hired a private guide for my time in Siem Reap and my guide knew just the right places for me to get pictures. This is a lovely temple and like most temples in the area, it can get crowded. The pictures you take here will turn out amazing.For Ankgor and to access all the temples you must purchase a ticket for three days that they check at every temple and punch it daily. The ticket has your picture on it. I do not recall the cost since my guide took care of everything for me. The temples are accessible by Tuk Tuk, bikes and cars. The location to buy your ticket is located just before entering into the area with all of the temples.
Must see in Cambodia. Along with Bayon and Angkor Wat, the three must-see temples in Siem Reap...fans of Tomb Raider will appreciate this place even more
Jungle Temple. Love all the temples I've visited but this one is really unique where the trees are growing through the ruins. Sooo beautiful!
Spectacular. My favourite temple from all Angkor area. Trees growing everywhere in and around the temples and ruins. Huge size. Tons to see and walk through.
Magical!. This temple is magical! You can see bufferflies fly around, giant trees grow out of temple, and birds are chirping. It was built for the queen, Indratevy, known as Cambodia's Cleopatra!
Gorgeous setting. Lovely to see, beautiful setting in the very welcome shade. Just as interesting as Angkor wat in my view.

Very Impressive. Just beautiful! Roots that intertwine with the stone walls, pillars and carvings are not an everyday sight to see. I'm glad I was able to see these temple ruins. It was one of my favorite ruins in Siem Reap.There were loads of people wanting to take photographs of the those trees that queues were very long. You should bring a bottle of water and a fan as it gets very stuffy there with all the other tourists or you could go there earlier to avoid the crowds and wear light-colored clothes.I went there in July and it rained in the afternoons- walked to one of the ruins soaking wet but still had fun. Go there before the rainy season.

The best temple. This is the best temple to see. It is left in slow decaying state with conservation being to keep it altogether. Going through the temple gives you the biggest feeling of adventure relative to some of the the others.
Cambodia, interesting place. Had a nice time except for one "glitch" that happenned. "KHMER EMPIRE" also known as LG JEWELRY defrauded us. They sold fake jewelries.

Tomb Raider Temple!. This temple is the one you see at Tomb Raider Movie, is very impressive and beautiful. It has been much as in the same condition it was found, leaving the big trees growing out of the ruins and that´s what make it very popular.

Stunning and relatively quick to see. This temple was stunning and was easy to get in and out of with young kids traveling and still keeping their interest and energy high. I am really glad we visited this place. There are 39 temples in Siem Reap. I think this one is a must see.

The 'tomb raider' temple. An amazing, atmospheric temple. Would highly recommend visiting at dawn when there are no crowds, so that you can fully appreciate this temple that has been engulfed by the jungle.
Cool Temple with Tree Power. Cool temple to visit with trees showing their power over the years. A must see in the temple circuit. You will not be disappointed.

Ta Phrom sent me back in time. Ta Prohm was amazing!!! This was one of the only temples that they decide not to conserve to give a taste of how it looks originally - and you can really feel the difference, esp after exploring Angkor Wat. The big strange trees was really something, I wish I had gone earlier in the morning when it was not crowded.
Wow. Great part of the full picture - so picturesque - loved the story . Once again very polite behaviour by all tourists

A captivating temple. Ta Phrom is another Khmer temple that you must visit when go to Angkor. You will be amazed and baffled how such gigantic roots of trees grew within this temple. Compare to other temples, it doesn't have that much buddhas in it but it's really the massive trees that makes this simple temple interesting. We went here as early as we can but time doesn't make any difference at all, people are always flowing in and out even if it is raining. When you visit Angkor, you have a lot of options to choose as a mode of transportation. First, there is Toktok (considered to be their cab/taxi) which is quite expensive for the whole day trip around the Angkor yet convenient, rent is per person which is US$15. Since we are just 2 when we visit Angkor and didn't much have time, we chose toktok to visit the place. Another advantage of hiring a toktok, is you can use it not just for visiting the Angkor but also moving around the city like looking for restaurant, bank etc. Second, if you knew how to bike, there are bicycles you can rent for a dollar with a map that will guide you in exploring the whole Angkor. However, the latter option is tiring and time consuming though I think it's fun. Last option you may have is renting a motorcycle if you know how to ride one, you just need to ask your hotel receptionist and they can refer you where to rent some motorbike. Not sure with the price but it goes around $3 to $5.
I loved this place. it was riden by the trees for many years, and a kind of mistery envolves your trip over there. the lakes surrounding and the beautiful sunset, at the top you can see the magic...

Magnificent trees (Lord of the Rings). The roots of the trees were just sooooo huge and so were the trees. It gives u an awesome feeling yet belittling how small humans as u will reflect in this mysterious beautiful location. It allowed me to "feel" as if I'm with Merry n Pippin together with Treebeard in The Lord of the Rings. The surroundings also gives a harmonious serene feeling of living among huge God made trees within temple grounds. The whole experience was just Awe-ficient!

Seen 4 - this was the best one!. Of course you have to see the main Angkor Wat, but then follow the suggestions to the best ones if you are in a hurry. We explored the big area by Motorcycle and Ta Promh is THE one with the trees grown over the buildings. Wonderful, interesting, impressive - absolutely worth riding 700km on dirt roads on one motorcycle (two people) all the way up from PhnomPenh. Go, go, definitely go! But of course, leave it the way it is, don't touch or take anything from there besides your impressions. Yet, a geocache exists there in case you are into geocaching!

The best of all the temples. We didn't spend long in Siem Reap (two days), but the highlight was this amazing temple. The atmosphere (especially if you wander away from the "main" bits so you're on your own) is incredible, and the way the trees have grown through the ruins provides a surreal experience for your senses. Although it was busy, it wasn't nearly as busy as Angkor Wat or Angkor Thom, and it's so much more beautiful and interesting.Unfortunately they're "restoring" the temple to how they think it looked originally, which I think will detract from its charm significantly. See it soon if you can.

Fantastic - loved it - Tomb raider eat your heart out!. Was fascinated by it all - the massive trees that have overgrown it - the fact that it was undiscovered in the jungle for hundreds of years - the construction - the beauty and awe of the place!Lots of restoration gong on - lots of damage due to jungle etc - so a lot of woodwork and supports etc. But - still amazing! Lust loved it - the imaginative adventure side of my senses was on full alert! Some great photo shots. Lots of people so be aware and accepting of that. Take water and time.

Hairs on the back of your Neck Feeling. One of the most awesome places I have visited. As you walk up the path towards Angkor Wat, you can feel the hairs on the back of your neck stick up, a thousand years old! Ta Prohm is magical, yes the "jungle" is taking over and the temple is being destroyed, but it is somehow wonderful! Of course this is also that famous scene with Angelina Jolie from the Tomb Raider film.A must see if you visit Siem Reap. There is a lot of restoration taking place, (at least when we visited), but the jungle and tropics will always win.

Must be seen.. Must be seen.One of the many temples around Angkor Wat in Siam Reap is Ta Prohm, my favorite temple.It's there the ernorme trees growing through the ruins (the world's most photographed tree) Use a few hours there, great atmosphere.A good way to experience the temples in Siam Reap is to go out there with a guide on the first day, choose a few temples, the area is so large that it is confusing. The day after can you go out there on your own, rent a bike and explore the area. An amazing experience.

Out of this world.. Ta Prohm is beautiful, delicate, fragile and awe inspiring. Her beauty lies in every tree, mangled root, flower, butterfly, and leaves. These living organisms have melded with this ancient temple to create an ethereal place of light and shade.You cannot take a bad photo here even if you tried.

Beautiful and mystic. The huge tree roots reclaiming the temple ruins. I took my grandchildren one afternoon and we painted the ruins and the huge roots engulfing the stones. It was a great experience.

Beautiful Temple with an Indian connection. Located among huge trees, Ta Phrom is a beautiful temple. Sadly these very trees proved its nemesis wrecking the temple. Yet it makes a beautiful combination to visit Ta Phrom. Also it cools down the temperature significantly making the visit more comfortable.The Angelina Jolie starrer Tomb Raider was shot here. Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) is working with the Angkor authorities to restore this beautiful temple. So a proud moment to visit this
Man vs Nature!. This place has a really interesting feel to it. Although the temple has been restored, huge tree roots have overgrown the stonework kind of melting into it. Fascinating!

Good but too crowded. We were there late morning but it was many people. But still worth to have a look. My suggestion is try to avoid getting too close from those big tour groups. They can spoil your mood quickly.
Color of the past. I could stay here for hours and still be inspired by what nature and human created. It is too charming.

Rivals Angkor Wat. The overgrown walls of this temple makes this a must see, There are many photogenic sections and it is no wonder that filming Tomb Raider has been filmed here. If visiting Angkor Wat this must also be included.

Brilliant but Claustrophobic. Fascinating temple, highlighted by the strangler figs that engulf the ruins, featured in the Tomb Raider film of course. As a result of its film connections, it is one of the most visited and due to the small size becomes very crowded and claustrophobic once the large tour groups arrive. It then becomes very difficult to navigate and take reasonable photographs.The temple is also undergoing extensive conservation and reconstruction with scaffolding prominent over parts of the complex. Still worth the effort of visiting.
My favourite.. This was my favourite of all the temples in the area. The trees and plants gave the temple a different feel and made it cooler and I think more interesting.

Unreal!. The jungle temple is just gobesmacking! Loved the ruins and in particular the threes growing atop the the ruins. Felt like a true explorer amid the ruins where one can breathe and feel the glorious past of the Khmer culture
very good. Very evocative and like all the Temples here you get a real sense of presence when you walk through them no matter what time of the day or night

Amazing. The temples around Siem Reap are all amazing but Ta Prohm is very special. For years nature was winning its tussle with man made edifices and the trees had invaded the 12th century structure. The roots growing everywhere - on, out of, over and around the walls make for a great sight. Now man is winning the struggle to reclaim the temple.As an Indian it made me proud that the Archaeological Survey of India was involved in reclaiming the structures and restoring them. The temple attracts huge crowds and is definitely one of the highlights of our Cambodian holiday.

tomb raider.. love it. This is the classic Tomb Raider temple in the jungle with full grown trees growing out of the ruins. Each of the temples you visit offers something different but this was special. Love it

By far my favorite temple. I hate to say it, but I was templed out at Angkor Wat. This one, however, I could stay for hours.. come early and beat the crowd. I was able to take some gorgeous pictures before it was mobbed and my pics were invaded by other tourists..

Awe inspiring. As others have noted, the temple is awe inspiring. Massive trees with tortuous roots growing out of it and on it. While it is not as intact as Angkor Wat (and it does not have nearly as many intricacies like the bas-reliefs) this almost makes it more charming. It was also a location of filming for tomb raider (and the concomitant crowds) so there's that too. Certainly a must after seeing sunrise at Angkor Wat.

Visit to Ta Phrom. All the temples are great but fairly good levels of fitness needed. My husband was using a stick following a hip operation earlier in the year but he managed ok although found it tiring. Weather hot so make sure you have plenty of water and cool clothing

A Must See when in Siem Reap. Who would have thought that tree roots could be so impressive but the way they have grown through the temple buildings is just amazing.The true test here is getting a photo without people in it.

Intresting and well kept temple. Wel it where worth while to visit this well kept temple that still sort of orignal for a visit. They did have made Indiana Jones movie here...amazing the tree that grow undisturber in the ruin.All the temple's are in the same region and with one photo card that they issue you with you can visit them with, or without a guide...
Ta Prohm. I marveledat the architure and the ruins. Disliked how the termites awe attacking all the foundation and feeling sad for the future generation.

The most impressive. I found this area to be much more impressive than Angkor Wat. You can really feel the history of the area when you see how the tree roots have taken over the temples. It's such a privilege to have been there and feel how the nature and man have evolved over the time. It's amazing how old the trees are and then to know that it is (in some cases) the reason for some of the ruins around.

One word... WOW. My girlfriend and I had only 3 days in Siem Reap. Personally this was enough for us as we certainly made the most of every day.Firstly, barter a price with a Tuk Tuk. Depending on how many temples/sites you wish to visit, they will offer you a price. Usually it can range between $5-$20USD. We did Ta Prohm & a couple 'less touristy' ones others for $15. Usually the hotel will help!!The Tuk Tuk will drive you there, wait, then drive onto the next one, wait, then drive you back. Personal chauffeur! Fancy! REMEMBER, you have to buy a 1 or 2/3 day pass to visit every temple. The ticket office is en route, be sure to remind your TukTuk. The 3 day pass is the same price as the 2 day. I think 40USD, little pricey for a traveller like myself, but worth every penny in Siem Reap. So... Ta Prohm! Personally this was my favourite of all the temples. Like any of the temples in SR, you'll be extremely lucky to visit at a time when it is dead. Early mornings or late afternoons are pretty much guaranteed to be quieter for ANY temple. If your unlucky then it will be packed full of Korean bus tours with people trying to take the 'perfect selfie' with a selfie stick or taking someone's eye out with their IPad and not even enjoying why they are there in the first place! So this is the iconic 'Tomb Raider' temple. You will need approx 2-3hrs here to really see it all and bask in the truly wonderful surroundings. If you want a speedy visit, you could cram it in 1hr. What I loved is that it is all completely unspoilt, yes they've carried out a couple restorations (minor) but the whole place is in ruins. A HUGE contrast to every other temple! It's what makes it so amazing! Trees are growing over Stone everywhere you look. Cheeky left and right turns will get you lost for ages until you randomly discover an ancient room with incredible Buddhist markings. To think this is a thousand years old makes you appreciate the capability of the human hands! Remember to take a camera (pretty obvious), you certainly aren't short of photo opp's. Some people may wish to get a tour guide, if you do ensure you grab a guy in a Beige/Brown shirt, they should have a name tag and an official badge on their shoulder. They'll be able to tell you more about the temple and it's history. However if like me and my girlfriend you wish to take your time and really make the most of it all, just wonder freely on your own.I hope you enjoy your trip here as much as I did. Read my other reviews for other temples. Thanks.
Tomb Raider. Initially was keen on visiting this temple due to the hype from the movie tomb raider however I was amazed by the huge trees that have grown and merged with the temple. Simply amazing!

impressive sight because trees growing in and on the ruins. A special temple because trees growing in and on the ruins. I hope they have control, and that the buildings not collapses due weight...It is an impressive sight, and a temple I recommend visiting when in Siem Reap
Another amazing place. Very impressive. Lots of very steep stairs. Worth the climb though. Earlier the better for visits as the crowds are large.
Indiana Jones!. The site is probably as close to Indiana as it ever gets. Ruins in the middle of the jungle... cool!

Amazing mix of temple and nature. This was the first of the temples in this area that we visited on our recent trip. Some restoration work had already been done and this is continuing, but the temple has been overtaken by nature with tree roots twinning themselves around the buildings. This mix of the man made and the natural is actually really rather nice and the conservation efforts are towards the trees as well as the buildings. I understand that one of the Tomb Raider films was partially shot here, which might explain some of the odd poses we observed from one party of visitors.You need to get yourself a ticket for admission to the Angkor temple complex and there are various options available depending on how many days you are likely to be visiting. We had a pass valid for 3 days over one week for US$40 each.

Stunning!. One of the best archaeological sites I`ve seen. It is located approximately one kilometre east of Angkor Thom and on the southern edge of the East Baray. Those massive roots of huge trees, intricate carvings, and statues gave me an exact definition of what truly a world heritage is.
Atmospheric.... Go early to avoid the crowds and take your camera, fabulous photo opportunities. Hire a tuk tuk for the day and you can do several temples in a day.

Getting itself together. The restoration that started 5 years ago was in danger of removing all charm from this 'Tomb Raider' temple. But with a few more walls up, and more access to the inner parts of the temple, the work has paid off. Great way to end your trip to the temple complex.

"Simply Awesome". You need to take more time to enjoy the sights. Taking numerous photos mechanically when you're too in a hurry to jump from one site to the next deprives you from getting the "feel" of this ancient ruins.

It is so amazing!!. I watched from the photos before I went there.At first I thought it is just small temple which just has tree cover to be a highlight.
But when I visited that place.It was so wonderful.Charming which feel like spiritual of itself.It is big area where you need to spend about 1-2 hours there.
Shouldn't miss!!

Amazing place, even despite the Lara Croft fans. The power of nature demonstrated by the jungle's reclaiming of the Ta Prohm complex is sobering. The reclamation/restoration being undertaken is well on the way to making this gem shine once more.

Brilliant place!. The most amazing temple in Angkor Wat complex. A lot of brilliant buildings connections with trees. It all looks incredible. A lot of blind alleys, it looks like a gigant maze. Must see!

A spectacle to behold deep in Angkor Archaeological Park. Ta Prohm is truly one of the most captivating archaeological sites one may witness in this lifetime. I traipsed through the forest in 100+ degree Fahrenheit humid heat with a baby strapped to my back to tour Ta Prohm. I must admit, it was worth it. I'd do it again. The tree roots affixes to the ancient wat (temple) are captivating. The enchantment of the surrounding area is palpable. If you head to Angkor, be certain not to skip Ta Prohm. You won't regret it!

Must see. In my opinion it was better than the main temple, as it has a more quiet feel to it. If you get a good driver he will take you to the ones that you want to see. Just driving around the site is awesome seeing all the building work there.Just be aware it's quite expensive trip for Cambodia.

Dawn viewing. We made an early trip, seeing the sunrise on the way. This made the whole place even more atmospheric and we practically had it to ourselves. Seeing the tree roots taking over and realising this was how many of the temples were found makes the whole Ankhor Watt complex more impressive! My tip, go early

True to its reputation from the Tomb Raider movie ... and more. First avoid the tourist crowd and visit this site early in the morning or late in the afternoon. We came at 4pm and had the place almost to ourselves. Second, take your time and explore every nook and corner. It is amazing to see how nature reclaim its space, roots overcoming tons of rock & boulder. My regret is that we did not read up on its history. Next time.

Worth a visit. It is wonderful to see how nature can soon reclaim the land. It is busy with tourists so difficult to photograph without capturing fellow travellers. I am sure fans of 'Tomb Raider' will find it of particular interest

Ta Prohm.. lost again.... I first came to Ta Prom over five years ago,and at that time was so awe struck by the temples' enchantment that it left an indelible imprint in my minds eye.. so much so, that i felt a compulsion to return again.. Afterwards I wrote a review about it,which is no doubt buried long since,amongst thousands on this site!Yesterday I finally realised my ambition and returned to that place of moss and tangled vines.. however much restoration has happened to service both the preservation and facilitation of the millions of visitors that flood through like a torrent daily! wooden boardwalks direct and control this tide of humanity, all hell bent on seeing this ancient relic.. that is all understandable for the future safety of the archeological ruins, but i must say, that by the end of my day there, i was forever grateful to have experienced this lost world,just prior to the overwhelming but inevitable tourism tsunami!

tree grows in Ta Prom. Magical junction of botany and old stones. This place is stunning; you will also see what probably destroyed a lot of the old temples -- tree roots squeezing in between the rocks.

My favorite!. This is the Tom Rider and is my favorite. I took the 3 days visit so I saw many temples but none compared with Ta Prohm. Take more time to explore it and plan to go very early in the morning because usually tourists follow a schedule and go there after visiting Angkor Thom. You will not regret insisting with your tuk-tuk driver to the the other way around. In my first visit it was so crowded that I had to get in line to take pictures but when I come back for the second visit it was around 8 am and there were very few tourists... I could enjoy it much more!

Incredibly special . Ta Prohm was our favorite temple in Angkor Wat, and that's saying something. There was just an air of mystery and magic with the trees growing out of the temples. There is a lot to wander into and around at Ta Prohm. It didn't feel crowded. We explored at our hearts content. It was very peaceful - the perfect way to end a day of visiting the temples. As a bonus, all of the trees also shield you from the sun!

My favourite. This temple is really special- the interaction of nature and structure is interesting and adds a sense of mystery-also the mosses are such vivid green which was a delight for my dry yellow australian bush eyes.

One of my favorite temples in Siem Reap. Where the ruins of an ancient temple meet the jungle. We could have spent all day at this temple, exploring and just taking in the mysterious beauty of it all. The old, tall tree growing right out of a wall with its roots stretching 10 feet to the ground below was one of the most beautiful and strange things that I have seen in my life so far.

Triumphant trees & ragged ruins. It's a close call between here and Bayon for me. Although Bayon edges it in my book, the almost mythical Ta Prohm is a great place to explore. Small in comparison to Angkor Wat, Bayon and the like, there are a surpising number of maze-like corridors that'll keep you busy whilst enjoying the shady respite from the scorching sun. A very popular temple, expect crowds and queues for photo opportunities in front of the famous tree roots. There are also quite a few 'salesmen' on the dusty track towards the entrance so expect to be bombarded with sales pitches en route.

Visit at dawn. We persuaded our tour guide to visit this temple at dawn instead of at sunset - what a great decision!! We arrived at the temple in pitch darkness with the sounds of the jungle all around us - there were no other people there as most head off to Anghkor Wat.Slowly as the sky lightened the temple eerily emerged from the gloom in all its splendour. Having the place to ourselves was magical and we spent a wonderful couple of hours climbing through the buildings marvelling at the way the jungle is slowly trying to reclaim the ruins. We took numerous pictures that will be a wonderful reminder of how special this visit was.

Favourite ruin in Siem Reap. I have been to Siem Reap twice and hands down this is my favourite ruin to see. The trees add another dimension to the experience and with all the shade it is not too hot.Definitely well worth adding to you Angkor tour. Don't be put off by the crowds, take your time and take it all in.

Best of them all. If you like to see the ruins and how nature took back, come here. Some restoration works are being done but mostly left untouched. Try asking the locals for some secret spots- we found one and the view was so good we sat there for 15 minutes.

Trees and Temples!!. This is one important and must visit temple in the Angkor Wat complex not only because this is where Angelina Jolie starrer Tomb raider was shot but also because of the fact that one can see the constant fight of survival of Trees and Temples with each other. The tress are huge in this complex and one of the biggest I have ever seen Breadth or Height. The temples off course bear the brunt of such massive trees resting on them. It’s amazing to see how the roots of some of the trees have crawled over the temples and crushed them under their weight. This makes the temple different from the rest in the Angkor Wat complex and I am sure this will definitely be on your list, if it is not then please make sure you do visit them.

Definitely number 1!. I've said in a previous review that Angkor Wat was disappointing. As much as I was disappointed there I was thrilled and enchanted in Ta Prohm!I do not want to parrot - I believe that everything has been said already.I didn't expect such a magical seductiveness in that fabulous place. Of all places I've been in this country the absolute number one is this stunning place that bewitched me completely.

Shadier temple area for time slots around midday!. During my visit, most of the temples/structures were being reconstructed. However, the other areas were great! The majestic trees that towered over the ancient buildings brings in enough shades even if you visit the place midday. In addition to that, it seemed much cooler inside the temples.Overall, a very good destination especially if you're a fan of the Tomb Raider.
Wild and Misterious. A pure beauty of nature taking over the civilization. Very mysterious if you visit it early in the morning

My Top 1. Among the 3 main temples that I've visited (angkor wat and Bayon being the others), this is my fav. It is really beautiful, it is more than just trees growing over the temple building. A must visit if you're in Siem Reap

"Impressive". This is one of the places I was looking forward to as this place has always been linked to Tomb Raider.When we got here, the huge trees were very much noticeable, rising very high and the big roots clinging to the ruins. It's very hard to take a very decent photo though as many people always pass by. It's better to go here early morning or aroung lunch time. Air is very humid as trees are blocking the air. Other than that, this place looks mysterious and very impressive and nothing that I have ever seen before.

Nature and Man combined.. The way the trees have overtaken this gorgeous temple has added something so special. It's such a peaceful place with a lovely energy. Something not to miss on the temple tour.

Most stunning feature is the massive silk cotton trees!. The temple itself is not very well preserved as the temples of Bantaey Srey or Angkor, having been destroyed partly by the constant wars between the Khmers and the neighbouring kingdoms and partly by the erosion caused by time and by the forest taking over. Nevertheless, it is still a stunning temple, set inside the forest and it's most stunning feature is without a doubt the gigantic silk-cotton trees growing out of the ruins! A must see in Angkor!
beautiful temple. Statue face was amazing. Or guide explain to us the origin of this temple and the story was amazing. Beautiful moment and a lot of pictures.
Nature Domination. What a beautiful place!! When trees come over the temple. Very touching moment when you step into the building. Anyway, this was a place that Tomb Raider had been film.

Eerie. With huge fig trees wrapping themselves over buildings like giant octopuses, this is a fascinating place. The focus is on the trees rather than on the carvings and bas-reliefs but you get plenty of the latter in the other temples.

more than just the "tomb raider" temple. There is so much more to this temple than the overgrown banyan tree. I recommend going early in the day to avoid crowds and appreciate the raw beauty. Ignore unofficial tour guides looking to make money.
Amazing temple. The fact that it was built so long ago and survived the horrors of the Pol Pot years and still stands in its glory to be preserved for ever more.

A step back in time. Absolutely breathtaking architecture. If you're in Siem Reap you must take a trip to Ta Prohm. Of all the temples we visited (and that was a lot), this was in my top 3. Gorgeous tree roots trickle down the temple walls and engulf the well kept wonder. With well keeping however comes maintenance. While we were there we encountered some scaffolding holding certain walls and trees in place but this was done with such care I barely noticed the metal structures. I highly recommend you check out Ta Prohm in the morning to avoid the crowds. Majority of tours commence at Ankor Wat and do not reach Ta Prohm until late afternoon so by going here in the morning you will have the whole place to yourself. Another bonus of visiting in the morning is all the merchants are at Ankor Wat. Happy adventuring!

Simply the most beautiful of all. Most beautiful temple I have ever seen. Movies have been filmed there clearly because it is so beautiful that it looks fake. Loved it. Go really really early just after sun rise to avoid groups of tourists and enjoy the light of the morning and the silence of the nature.

The forest temple. It is also famous for being the location where the famous movie Tomb Raider was shot.with the huge trees, with their huge roots growing all over the temple. It has some sort of a mystic feel to it. This is much smaller than the Angkor Wat, so it seems a lot more crowded, and you have to look for that mystic feel beyond the crowd!

Experience The Power Of Nature. My fourth stop of the day, and unique in many respects. Largely unrestored, Ta Prohm is an example of how nature inexorably reclaims even grand structures built of stone. A tumble of stone, with massive trees overpowering walls, leaves you with the experience of seeming to have discovered an ancient ruin in the Cambodian jungle. Found that this temple resonated most in terms of connecting with the past.Explore the full ruin by entering the main gate and exiting through the back gate (have your driver meet you there) - listen to the trilling of the cicadas and the hoots of the myna birds. Since the structure is unrestored and offers random paths, the presence of other tourists is less apparent. Make this a mandatory stop.
Impressive. Huge trees growing on and into temple walls provide a unique viewing experience. In some ways more impressive than the sprawling Angkhor Wat
Relief from the heat. This is one of the coolest temples to visit. So many trees surrounding ang growing on the temple. I felt like I was on the set of tomb raider. We really enjoyed this temple.

Spectacular. This place took our breath away, and was by far our favourite place in the Angkor complex. Make sure you make time to wander around the ruins and get really under the skin of this beautiful place

Untouched!. Angkor Wat gets most of the attention, but Ta Prohm is worth the time to see in contract to Angkor, since there has not been the restoration that has been done with Angkor. We went in the early morning when most tourists are at Angkor Wat, so we had the sense that there were fewer people at Ta Prohm. Mix it up a little. There are many, many people but most of them were quite thoughtful of other travelers. Wear sturdy walking shoes, and for those who are older, a walking stick isn't a bad idea.

Awe inspiring. Amazing temple over run by trees, a lot larger and busier than the Tomb Raider films show, so it is hard to get a unique solo photo. Touring around the outer edges as opposed to through the middle gives you a longer visit and less people.

Feel the Power of the Nature. You will never regret about your trip here. Aside from the structures built before 13th century, you also feel the power of the nature! Look how the trees grow on the wall and roof the temple. You would admire the power of the nature and creatures...

Tomb Raider Temple. Outside of Angor wat this was the busiest temple we visited by far. It was really cool to see the trees growing through the mostly well preserved structures.This temple had a lot of merchants and people trying to sell stuff as you walked in and out but like the rest of the area they were polite when you said no and they did not stalk you around the temple.This is a very easy temple to navigate through and still gives you the 'Jungle' feel however if you are more adventurous and willing to travel further out Beng Mealea is a much better experience. There are no crowds and you actually get to feel like you just found it yourself as you crawl through the small doorways over rubble and trees. It is not restored at all but it still has very large buildings that remain intact and again makes you feel like you are the first person to ever find it.

The Tomb Raider Temple!. Like right out of a movie (pun intended)! The ways that the tress have grown over and around the temples is impressive and exploring the Ta Prohm temple was a highlight of our visit to Angkor Wat.

The battle with nature plays out here . . .. as gigantic tree roots slowly take over the Temple of Ta Prohm. Really an other-worldly experience that I would love to repeat. We were there as part of a Nat Geo trip around the world several years ago in February and I am finally getting to review highlights--this temple of one of them. Truly amazing.
Amazing. This is one of the many temples you can walk around. They are all it has Trees growing out of the temples

A true wonder. We have visited Ta Prohm twice over the last couple of years. Of all the temples in Cambodia, this one seems to be a favourite with many travellers. It may have something to do with the film, Tomb Raider, but there's no denying the beauty and wonder of an ancient temple being claimed by nature...it's truly a grand sight.

Unique jungle temple (Ta Prohm Temple). My most favorite temple. Unlike other temples at Angkor, Ta Prohm has been left as it was found, preserved as an example of what a tropical forest will do to an architectural monument when the protective hands of humans are withdrawn. You will feel like you were backward a thousand years ago when visiting this temple! Never get bored with this one.

How Nature destroys--real evidence in Ta Prohm. We really have to humble ourselves before those great trees and their roots, these can move mountains of stones. Its sad to see carvings being ruined and being left in a heap. Any chances of further restoration?
very crowded but beautiful. loved the trees growing out of 'the tomb raider' temple. Wonderful stone carving and atmosphere. However it was at times too crowded to appreciate it fully

Tomb Raider Temple. Wow, again, another amazing site in Siem Reap and highly recommended, friends and I had a great day here and thought it was well worth visiting. After many hundreds of temples across Asia this is one of the ones not to miss I would say!
Amazing. It was amazing, it was almost ruined temple but still it is standing with silk route trees on top. Wonder of the nature to see with man made buildings.
stunning!. Those majestic 900 year old trees are beyond words... you'll need to bring a wide angle lens to capture it all!
Magical!. I loved this place. The strangler figs are eerie but magnificent. we spent ages here, walking amongst the ruins.
FANTASTIC. the trees are grown so unique that you will never find something similar elsewhere. a place you must visit

Amazed. A very old temple with unique overgrown roots surrounding the temple complex. Many sites are undergoing restoration process at the moment. Don't for get to ask your guide the popular Tomb Raider tree is

This has to be on your list of places to see in the world - you see but you can't believe it's real!. Siem Reap is incredible but this is unbelievable. Everyone should see it! Pictures don't do it justice, a spectacular testament to a place of such history. The people are wonderful - listen and learn and it will enrich your experience. Everyone is happy and we were too.

Outstanding. Different from other places with beautiful giant trees and roots and parts of the temple. You can simple tell its long history by the size of those trees. I went there during a long weekend and there were so many people. That was the only problem. Difficult to walk around with those crowds.

Amazing!. The walk to the ruins through the tunnel / canopy of trees, with traditional Kumar music playing in the background, and sunlight streaking though the leaves was SURREAL! Then you get to the ruins. There just aren't words to describe how overwhelmingly amazing it is. For me it was trip of a lifetime and I am so grateful and thankful I was able to experience this true wonder.

IF YOU ONLY VISIT ONE TEMPLE - MAKE IT THIS ONE!. We walked in the west side and right through to the east side. The feel of this temple is unique. The trees growing through the structures - the tall trees, the bird sound, the cool shade - the amazing sites you will see will last a lifetime

Breath taking. A must see
Absolutely mind boggling how these trees wrap themselves around these temples
Make sure you have good foot wear on as health and safety is none existent !!

nature-temples 1-0. very cool trees taking over the old temple grounds. Unfortunately a lot of other people thought so too. Try to avoid going in at the same time as big groups. But definitely worth going no matter what.

Everyone's opportunity to pretend to be in Tomb Raider. One can easily see why this is almost everyone's favourite temple near Siem Reap (well there is also Bayon and Angkor Wat vying for that crown, but they are all so different). This was our last temple visited during our 2.5 day stay in Siem Reap and what a way to finish off our temples! it doesn't disappoint and in many cases the railings can be avoided in your photos. Our 5yo boy went nuts with the spare camera. This temple was a tad cooler than the other more open temples due to the trees so is a good place to visit in the oppressive heat of August (when we went). Here and there are steps to clambour over but not a problem.

just amazing!. I could have come early in the morning to visit this ruins. It gets very crowded in then afternoon, so you really have to wait long time to get your shots. It gets very noisy as well. If I have to come back again, I will surely visit this first in the morning where you can soak in few hours and wander. This ruins is one of my fave.

Ancient ruins. Walking over the ruins of such an ancient site was pretty phenominal. It is a lost temple, where stranger figs and kapok trees have entwined themselves around the ruins. The roots of the trees are hugging the old structure with an almost loving embrace. There were so many tourists there, but you still got the feeling of intimacy, and reflection on a past era. Very impressive.
Ta Prohm. Amazing place, the most recognized from pictures and postcards. Definitely a must-see in this part of Asia.

Yes. It is the temple from Tomb Raider!. The most photogenic and oldest of temples around. A long one km walk in the jungles takes you into a unique construction form of the temple. The temple is stacked inside out rather on top of each other. Five walls and you are inside the main complex. Very familiar place for the Tomb Raider fans. A lot of photo ops available. The trees are inside, outside, under and over the temple. Restoration work was in progress in the affected areas. A local guide can easily explain the history of the temple. Suggest you spend about two hours including the 2 kms walk.

Spectacular. Impressive place, amazing sensation to walk through the ruins and imagine eyes wide open the life between the walls. A must do for all traveleres to Cambodia, the full site offers breath taking sights.

Definitely on the must see list.. My wife and I came here as a part of our own tour that we did of the Angkor Wat Archeological Park. This temple was my wife's favourite. This was also the temple that Tomb Raider was filmed at. It's not hard to see why, it's beautiful. Lots of trees growing from the temples and more within the grounds that have character. It wouldn't be hard to get lost in this temple, we struggled to find our way back. There are plenty of paths that lead to others. This temple should definitely be on your must see list.

Outstanding of all the temples our local guide was an old security official and not a regular guide and he showed us all. Being caught behind Japanese tourists en masse stopped when told to stop and take photos holding everyone up behind them !!!
Great atmosphere. I thought this temple would be interesting but I couldn't believe how fascinating you will keep snapping the photo,s

Breath-taking!. This was the 3rd temple we visited the day we went to Angkor Wat. Gosh, what a place the 'octopus' trees as the tour-guide put it amongthe temple took our breathe away. It is just so moving even justthinking back how many people in the village co-existed around this temple.Apparently, it was a tribute to the King's love for his mother, very movingindeed esp the chamber that gave a thumping echo whenever you hityour chest! I definitely left my stress behind, as I hit my chest so hard Ihad a big cough! I should return....one day!

Really Amazing. Try to go in the afternoon when there are less tour groups. It's really neat when its raining and overcast- more spooky. If it is crowded, just wait a few minutes for the waves of people to pass. The sides have less people too. No bathrooms on the West entrance end. East end entrance has bathrooms but more vendors. In the shade or on a cloudy day, Check your photos as you go since the exposure meters in most cameras tend to over expose the shot. They are set for flesh tones and the dark moss, rock, and vines tend to fake the camera into trying to constantly lighten the scene.

absolutely the most beautifull temple from Cambodia. This temple is stunning , cannot discribe it in words. You have to see it with your own eyes.its a pitty there are so many tourists but who can blame them . Tourists always want to go where no other tourist going but that is impossible ofcourse!!!

Ta Prohm temple. This temple was chosen by archaeologists to be kept as found, with trees and roots growing atop the walls. Popularized by the movie Tomb Raiders. Photos of these trees are common in tourist campaigns about the temples of Siemens Reap.
Temple with trees & roots growing all over. The forest setting and the trees and roots growing over the temple give it the special tag it has, and makes the place al the more photogenic!
Trees and Temples. It's basically called the temple in the jungle. The trees that grow in the temple give the visitors a relaxing and refreshing despite the hot weather afternoon in November.

CROWDED. It sounds like Disneyland inside - the din of people shouting, yelling, big groups, etc. all gets to be a bit too much. Try to visit during off hours (maybe closer to lunch time) so you can get decent pictures w/o mobs.

Excellent!. Such an amazing atmosphere here in the ruins. The trees are amazing and the restoration efforts aim to preserve the trees and the temple. Worth going when the crowds are light. If you enjoy this you will totally love Beng Mealea as well!
Definitely Worth It. Make sure you go in the morning to avoid the crowds. This place is a must see as there are few places like it in the world

Feel like Indiana Jones!. By the time we reached Ta Prohm, my travelling companion was - in his words "All templed out"This site is unlike any other and definitely has a special magic of it's own which was not lost.... even on him.You feel like you've stumbled onto the set of an Indiana Jones movie and the set is the star.We loved the way that nature and history have intertwined so beautifully, and the way in which building apertures frame the views, often framed within a frame, within a frame within a frame like a visual sleight of hand. Don't miss it if you are in this part of the world. Fascinating!
Stunning. Well worth a visit, particularly if you are a Tomb Raider fan! The trees are worth a visit on their own.

Breathtaking. This was THE highlight for me if the Angkor Wat complex. Watching nature reclaim her jungle with larger then life trees in a beautifully built stone temple is simple breathtaking. It seems like something out of Indiana Jones or more appropriately Tomb Raider. If you're limited on time, make this one of the top visits on your list because there isn't anything else out there like this.
Another must-see in Siem Reap. It was first time I see ancient temples ruined by trees - loved the mythical atmosphere and hearing the history of this place. This place also looks great in pictures.
Probably the best.. With all the amazing temples it's difficult to choose a favourite but this is one of the temples that really ticks all boxes..go and see it!

One of our favourites. This was one of our two favourite temples. Defineitely worth the effort. A bit difficult if you have mobility issues (as my husband does) but if you have your own guide $35 for approx 6 hrs and your own driver also $35, they will be able to get much closer to the temples for you. Recommended
So special. It is an amazing site I only wished I had time to ditch taking pictures every 5 minutes and just sit quietly to take it all in. I will come back!
Better than Angkor Wat. Magical quality with overgrown ruins, carvings. Not as congested as Angkor Wat (though AW needs to be seen by any traveler to the area)

okay. We temple-hopped so sometimes I don't remember the name of the temples where we went. But I remembered this one as the one where Lara Croft was filmed? It was a bit disappointing... Or maybe the built up was too much?? Anyway, a tree within the temples is still something to see
must do on day one, but not worth day 2. Main angkor temple is best. This one is decent, you should do it on day one, if possible, but not worth coming back for this next day.

Lovely photo opportunities. Undoubtedly when you visit Siem Reap, you will first get to Angkor Wat, but you should definitely see Ta Prohm. Only then will you really understand how so many of the temples were 'lost' in the forest for so many years. Amazing to see the trees growing through the stonework. And this is a great picturesque place.

Beautiful!. Everywhere you go in Siem Reap has its own special beauty to it…this place is no exception. It reminded me of being in a tomb raider movie! Definitely hire a tuk tuk driver to take you around for the day. It's a gorgeous stop..you won't regret it. :)

This is Cambodia, so temper your expectations!. Given the history lesson and current situation that our local Cambodian guide who was actually an english school teacher but moon lighted as a guide to supplement his income, gave us, we felt most fortunate to be able to have seen it at all. It just sounded like the Vietnamese were going to be milking Cambodian tourist sites as much as they could as long as there was this political vacuum and chaos in Cambodian politics! Very well touted and very photogenic and picturesque! It's almost impossible to catch a photo of it without being photo-bombed by the 100s of other tourists there!

Wake up early to enjoy peaceful atmosphere. We visited Ta Prohm around 6:30am and had the temple to ourselves. It was hard to wake up early but it's worth it as the atmosphere is peaceful and serene.The spung tree looks like an octopus covering the temple.Definitely a must in your itinerary!

Jungle Temple. Loved this site - the way the forest/jungle has taken over the ruins. magnificent trees and root systems add to the appeal of this "Tomb Raider" temple - the site of filming for that movie. Renovations under way meant that part of the temple was not accessible, but this didn't detract from the experience.

Very old temple a little run down, but still amazing. A very old temple, but looks special because of the interaction with the trees. Nice photo opportunity if you like those kind of pictures, and not many people. When you go to the temple area, start early in the morning then take a break around noon when it gets really hot, and the go back until the sun goes down, around 6 pm.

Just fabulous!. Ta Prohm is a marvelous place to discover, in the middle of the forest, with a kind of mystical message: the roots are absolutely not damaging the temples. It's more like they would like to protect them. When you visit Ta Prohm, you feel so small in this environment…Now it has to be said that Siem Reap in general has a lot of magnificent heritage culture to offer with, out off Angkor Palace, less known place as Prek Toal, Kompong Pluk or vat Athvea and vat Preah Inkosei

An exceptional place of natural beauty. The one place in Cambodia that you must absolutely visit. Hire a tuk tuk driver for the day and go from temple to temple. Ta Prohm is an absolute must. The jungle has, quite literally, won. The massive trees have powered their way through the ruins, and it really is a majestic place. Its seriously hot and humid in the summer, so take lots of water and sunblock - you'll need it! We hired a guide for the day who was good, but we couldn't quite understand all his English - which certainly made for an interesting day if nothing else! A really first class day trip, and certainly one of the highlights of my summer!

Wonderful at dawn light. We were there by 5.30 am. Alone. Beautiful light. Quiet. And wow is the sight of this ruined temple with giant tree roots curling round the great stone walls magical. We have done all the Egyptian sights, and this one is completely different.

A truly fascinating site. This is a fantastic site to ramble around and through. The lack of restoration is a large part of the charm and the lack of restraints that ruin visits to interesting sites in more westernised countries caused by the 'health and safety' nuts, is refreshing. Going there is an adventure for children and adults alike but you do have to be nimble enough to climb and crawl up and over large stone blocks some of which are a bit wobbly. The way nature is reclaiming this temple is wonderful.I have ticked December 2013 as the date visited as this is the earliest your site allows - I was there in 2007 but still have very clear memories of a fantastic visit to this incredible site.

Enchanting. We visited in the early afternoon and the atmosphere created by magical lighting and the avenue of trees was stunning. Unfortunately the crowds and other 'pushy' visitors made it difficult to take too many reasonable photographs. Would have liked to have stayed for about three hours but was on a guided tour.
Best in Siem Reap. The best temple of the Angkor Wat temples. It is featured in Tomb Raider. It has a very mythical feel to it.

Wonder of the world. It was hot but we were so excited to come to the site. November and all, anyway... You have to come to see for yourself. Be ready, mosquitos and the heat. Better come early or a bit late. Expecting to be crowded or many people all year round :)

Jungle Ruins!. Ta Prohm is part of the Angkor Wat complex. IT IS AWESOME!!! I highly recommend a stop here, if you are in Asia! You probably want to take two+ days to take it all in. I went in 1997 for a 'day trip' and only got to see three of the sites. Well worth your time. I've heard from friends who recently went there that the supportig tourist structure is a lot better now than '97. Don't think; GO!!

a truly remarkable site - make sure and visit in addition to Angkor Wat. Also known as the "jungle temple," this is the one that really captures the imagination. The trees growing over and in the temple walls look like candles that have melted over the walls. It is breathtaking. It would probably be best to try and visit early in the morning as the crowds were almost unbearable in the early afternoon.

Get lost. Much of my memory of Cambodia is dreamlike. The flying foxes swoop in the night sky. The ruins at the many temples are being pulled back into the earth by twisting trees and miniature life forms. We had a wonderful day crawling over the ruins and taking photos. When we went, there was little food or water available but luckily we were prepared. There were several musicians there and we bought their CDs to help us remember the sense of place.

Family trip to Ta Prohm. We thoroughly enjoyed exploring this beautiful temple. Think Tomb Raider. Some of the carvings on the walls of the temples looked like a dinosaur - intriguing. Lots of people at this temple. Highly recommend including this in your trip to Siem Reap.

Tombraider Temple. That's what it is fondly called by the locals!The site used in the movie, has the locals rhapsodizing about Angelina Jolie or Lara Croft standing at the famed site.Definitely a good place to visit.
Channelling Lara Croft. If you wanna feel like a tomb raider - this is the place! The trees growing through the temples are just spectacular!

One of my favourites. Famous for being in the tomb raider movie, go early as its popularity and small size means it gets packed. After 2.5 days of temples this was one of my favourites for its uniqueness and the way it blends into the surroundings with the trees now forming part of the structure. The heat and humidity along with the crowds can be quite stifling here therefore bring plenty of water and pace yourself.

Best of the temples for me. We were advised to go to this temple after 4pm by our trusty tuk tuk driver, Mr Cobra, which was great advice as there weren't so many people. After a little while we came across a local guy and asked him where tomb raider was shot. He then not only showed us this but lots of other hidden things to see and experience. So just loved it. Hope you can find him if you visit!

Incredible. My favourite of all the temples. The trees twisted in to the ancient ruins leaves you questioning exactly how it happened - everyone has a different theory. The uniqueness of this temple is what makes it my favourite, and the walk there is really fun.

Amazing place of Siem Reap. This is a fantastic place of Siem Reap, called Ta Prom, the tress are naturally growing and massive.
