I really enjoyed it here.The local guides will be proudly mentioning Angelina Jolie and her statue scene, but these amazing tress and structures are really attracting us. It is a place that you will want to go and see again, For me, I absolutely cherished my moment there and already decided that I will com visit here again, Fantastic place for photographer and whenever I bought a better camera, I miss this place, truly.

Not to be Missed. Whilst in Cambodia we visited the Circus twice. Once was just not enough. It is a "no animal" circus", just humans, doing amazing things. It is held in a tent-like building, with plenty of electric fans and hand-held fans are distributed as well. Remember Cambodia is a hot 35dg. I don't know how the performers were able to perform as well as they did for about 2 hours. The performance overall is a story which is easy to follow even when you are entranced by the acrobats the performers get up to. Fortunately also there is a kiosk out side which does a roaring trade in ice-cream and very cold drinks.

Once in a lifetime...have to see!. All of the temples are simply amazing -- the craftsmanship of Ta Prohm is impossible to describe. You will want to spend several hours here exploring the entire area.

A photographer's delight. Ta Prohm is a most go place in the Angkor Complex. This temple is left in much of the same condition as it was found. Huge trees grow out of the ruins of the structure. Its also worth taking out sometime to explore its corridors.
Yes amazing place. Hot and steps but so worth climbing up. Faces are great and leave you wonder how they did all this so long ago.
Gorgeous!. Apart from the supporting frames and the timber rail and walkway (not there in 2004), this site is a must see and famous for the tree roots growing out of the temple.

As expected. This is a smaller temple but it is impressive because the trees have engulfed the stones and have become integral to the structure, so that now it is impossible to separate them without causing further damage.

my favorite temple. i recommend you all to go to this temple first, early in the morning. I did and I could actually see the temple and get great pictures, without tourists everywhere. I loved it! Not like in the tomb raider movie, but better!

Stunning but crowded. I am so happy to have visited this temple. It was really astounding to see the work that must have gone into building an unforgettable site. Really worth it though I would have liked to find a moment when there were fewer yelling people.
Wow. Seeing those trees! It was amazing to say the least. Unfortunately there were so many other tourists, so you can hardly get a picture with no one else in it ;)

Weird tree roots shape this temple. Known as the Tomb Raider temple this is a demonstration of the true power of nature as it seems to be being slowly reclaimed. That makes it all the more special.. I had heard they had cut down some trees, but fear not they are there in all their glory. There is space here for the visitors, time to make an offering and receive a blessing, time to sit and look and think and discuss. It's shadier and a little cooler than some of the others.Try to find the dinosaur tile if you can

Get here early. This is such an interesting site showing how powerful Mother Nature is. The sheer number of tourists here later in the morning impacted on the experience here more than any of the other temples I visited. Very difficult to get a photo without tourists in it who just seem to be wanting a pic with the tree roots then head off. Having said that I recommend you get there early in the morning before the large crowds arrive to really take in this site.
Another great temple. Again the history and carvings of the stone work telling a story of war and peace, celebration and beliefs.
Great atmosphere. Very great with the nature atmosphere of tree and roots on the roof of gallery and sound of the bird which made the temple as special one.
Lara Croft Temple. Crowded because it really is special. The walk to the temple complex is long. People tend to not be polite about giving you a chance to take pictures.

Great Temple a definite must... I would recommend this to anyone. Get there early, to avoid the madding crowds. Great feel about the temple, slightly moody in a good way.A definite must to if in Siem ReapEnjoy

Other wordly. The trees have grown thru and around and in some cases support the temple ruins. Just plain beautiful. First trip was in a downpour, so we went back the next day. Go at lunch time, not so many tourists :-)

Most interesting of the temples. This is the temple in which Angelina Jolie filmed Tomb Raider - it is very beautiful with the trees that have taken over the temple. However, for this very reason, it is extremely conjested, even in the low season but still worth the visit.

By far my favourite.. Managed to get here just before the big crowds. Just the walk down to the temple was lovely with a band of mine field amputees playing local music. Temple just amazing, the trees reclaiming the area was unreal. Their canopies making Ta Prohm a lot cooler place to linger and photograph. By far a favourite and highlight of my trip.

Mysterious, not to be missed. This is the famous tomb raider temple, dark and mysterious with the roots and trunks of huge trees growing on the temple. Try to visit early in the morning when there are very few tourists and you will have a better experience. The trees seem to have a symbiotic relationship with the temple and appear to be in perfect harmony.

Nice tree roots. The trees is super huge and amazing. The roots of the huge tree impress us. We saw some monkeys.Take note that there is two entrance west and east in Ta Prohm, we went wrong the direction when heading to our Tuk Tuk which waiting us in the different entrance.

Where the sacred meets the nature!. It is not an exxageration to say that this temple is one of the most beautiful places I have ever visited in life. Don't miss it!The angkor complex has a lot of temples, including angkor wat, the biggest one. But Ta Prohm is the one where you can see the nature growing deeper-seated among the constructions - you get the real idea of how long ago this place was abandoned....amazing!

WOW!. It was an incredible view seeing such huge tree on top of Ta Prohm temple.The root of the tree looks like a giant octopus ready to take down the temple.Great sight that you wouldn't want to miss.
Another gem in Siem Reap. This temple is fighting a battle against nature, but the Archaeological Survey of India is trying its best to save it. Be careful of the falling tree branches
Very Crowded. A word of advice, go early. Throngs of group tours arrive at mid-day. It becomes unbearable. But, it's a must-see in Siem Reap. It's gorgeous and feels alive.

Typically known as the Tomb Raider Temple. It is one of the most amazing temples. The massive roots of the trees intertwining with the temple's ancient stone is really not an everyday sight. The views are breathtaking. There are many tours there, so do be patient and wait for your turn for them to empty the place in order to get a great shot.

Number 2 on the temple list. For most people I imagine that Angkor Wat is the first Temple they want to see. However Ta Prohm should be the second for everyone.This temple has the iconic trees that are slowly reclaiming the temple that make for such great photos.I am not a temple liking person at all. In fact, for me the quicker the temple tour the better. However, this one is an exception so make the time to visit.

amazing place. Without a doubt this is the most amazing place with the trees growing out and around the buildings. Tremendous atmosphere and well worth a visit. Just watch your footing as there is a lot of fallen masonry and the uneven pathways.

Kids loved this one.. Visited here after Angkor Wat and the kids loved the adventurous nature of this temple. The overgrown trees and roots make for some superb photos. The trees also provide shade relief from the sun. A must visit.

What a great place!. This was my favorite of the places we visited from Siem Reap, simply because it has absolutely tons of atmosphere. Yes, it is overrun with visitors, many of whom are not actually looking at what is in front of them but posing for endless daft photos of each other which makes taking a good shot quite a challenge - but achievable with a little patience waiting for each group to move on. When I was there our guide told us it was actually relatively quiet as well !!
Must see. A beautiful temple that combines aged architecture with infiltrative nature. Don't miss if travelling to Cambodia
Jungle meets temple. Fascinating temple made more atmospheric by the fact that the jungle is gradually engulfing this once amazing structure. Pity about the crowds though.

Arrive just after sunrise!. We got to ta prohm just after the sunrise at Angkor, we literally had the place to ourselves!The ruins were magical as if you could imagine many fairy tales had been inspired by this site, You can't miss this one if your in the area, it's a must! So lucky to have seen this
Amazing nature. Loved those huge tree branches, a must go when ur in siem reap, as u can see not one but many big tree branches spreading all over the temples.

So mysterious and solemn.... What a piece of work. Made famous thanks to Angelina Jolie's "Tomb Raider" movie, this place by itself is simply curious and alluring.The way the trees of the jungle merges and co-exists with the ruins of Ta Prohm make it all the more amazing and intriguing.The humongous trees are a sight to behold themselves, and the sight of their roots curling under, through and over the ruins create a magical sight. Definitely worth seeing, and not just because it's the "Tomb Raider" Temple.
The "Daddy" of the temples. Indiana Jones???This place is awe inspiring and hard to believe.Magnificent and a must seeCan spend 1.5 hours here easy.

Most favorite of the temples. By far this was our most favorite temple. It is not vast in size like Angkor Wat, but it is unique. With Large tree roots covering walls and stairs, you really see the power of Mother Nature when she is left alone.

Stunning Ruins Made Famous by Tomb Raider. This site is a fantastic mould of ruins and nature. Ancient trees have grown on top of the ruins. Many a fantastic photo to be had here. This is definitely not a site to miss when visiting the Angkor area.
Trees and temples. Angkor was the best sacrified place I have ever seen in my life. I don't have to recommend it. Ta Prohm is famous because of old trees whch carpeted the temple walls.
a sight to behold. Lovely spot that is less crowded than Ankor Wat.Well worth the visit.Some ruins have trees growing out of them.Much smaller site than Ankor Wat.

our favourite temple. We found the interaction of nature and building absolutely amazing, visiting at he end of the day is a magic time as less tourists, the parrots are all flying and the light gives the whole scene a special feeling

The combination of temples and nature is amazing. This was by far my favourite temple, though all are very impressive this was amazing from a completely different stand point showing how nature can take over an area even as grand as this one if it is allowed to. The trees growing through and over the temple is amazing and is something you don't experience as the other temples. A must see even if you feel you have exhausted yourself in terms of temples, this one is something completely different!
Better than Angkor Wat. Just amazing and love that you can crawl around the entire temple! Just try to go in the morning before it's too hot and too many tour buses show up
The most impressive. The result of the struggle between the trees and the stones has no winner, this is just gorgeous and so impressive

A must. . This is, besides Ankor wat, one of the most beautiful temples in the area. Take your time to walk, and get lost through its many spots. I would recommend to go early in the morning to avoid crowds.
Ruin with nature. One of my favorite among other temples. I love the temple so much ezpecially the tree which grow on top of the roof of the temple. Quiet time during the visit at late afternoon.

so good. Feel like the Indiana Jones surrounded by history which still seems alive and evolving around you. I wish I'd arrived earlier to see the ruins before all the tourists arrived - because there are A LOT of tourists. You can easily spend a long time wandering here. Make sure you're dressed conservatively, or have something to cover yourself with - I don't think this was specified for these ruins but other ruins in the Angkor Wat area definitely enforce covering shoulders and legs.

My favorite temple!. Outside of the Angkor Wat temple, Ta Prohm was my favorite. It is a great photo taking location. You really get a feel for how old the complex is with the large overgrown trees. Lots of passage ways and areas to explore. I had a guide which was very helpful navigating the temple grounds. I would strongly recommend touring this location when visiting the area.

my favorite!. Imagine exploring through a jungle and you come across ancient ruins covered in jungle shrubbery and trees- that is what it was like to walk around this site. The temple has been left largely the same as when it was found, giving it this mysterious atmosphere and the feeling that you are the only one who knows about it. Built in the 12th century also under King Jayavarman VII, the temple has a number of large trees growing out of it, with the roots of the trees devouring the walls of the ancient temple. So stunning!

Your chance to be Lara Croft. I got lost and kept going in rounds on this one. You may need a guide on this as there are dead ends everywhere. The sight of nature complementing/overpowering the complex structure is stunning.
Very unique temple. Have you ever seen the trees growing from the stone? This temple so unique because there are many trees and old keep overgrown the temple.

Tomb Raider!. I preferred this among the most famous temples that we visited in Angkor. It was quieter than Angkor Wat in terms of tourist movement, and less warm. The place was so beautiful and awesome that it sort of commands you to stay silent and just enjoy the sights. The lofty trees growing on the walls creeping their way into the structures; the remnants of the once beautiful and gem studded walls vandalized by humans for loot; the serene atmosphere conducive for meditation; all these add to the awesome experience that can only be felt after seeing the temple in actuality and walking through the ruined yet restored paths reticent of a once mighty empire. Make sure to visit this temple when you go to Siem Reap!
Get a guide. Avoid the crowds, especially the Chinese who seem not to be able to comply with local rules please see our review of the Bayon Temple as explanation
Indiana Jones!. Loved this temple. We got here at lunchtime to avoid the queues which I'd recommend. Incredible setting as the trees take over the temple.
Great for photos. Big trees growing out of the temple ruins make for some great photos.Well worth seeing, although it was very crowded when we were there.

My favorite temple here. Really impressed with Ta Phrom, by far my most favorite temple at the angkor wat complex. Be patient with it, there are a huge stream of tourists pouring through but its worth spending as much time there as you can, just to find every nook and cranny!Its so cool to see how nature has taken over the site and the roots look like candle wax dripped over the stones. Pictures don' really do it justice in my opinion, you've really got to see it. The restoration work carried out is really sensitive. You can see pictorial evidence of before and afters and I think they've done a great job. Enjoy!

Better than Angkor Wat. Loved it. After visiting Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, Ta Prohm is much more tranquille and beautiful. Nature has conquered civilisation here. Beautiful photo opportunities and the sounds of the surrounding jungle. Absolutely worth the visit.
Fantastic!. Wonderful, nature vs man-made structure, the magnificent tree structures are awesome, what more can I say...

Interesting to see the old tree embedded into the temple, but not a must see.. If you only get to see Angkor Wat, that should suffice, it's an incredible temple that still stands today, all the others you see afterwards will all look the same. There is one $20 all day fee to see all of the temples, you can see as many are your heart's content, but I would have been good with just seeing Angkor, that's why I came to Cambodia anyways.
Tomb raiders. Frankly, we couldn't care less about TR, but this is an amazing sight. Gives a real sense of what the jungle can do
Better than the photos. Photos of this temple are all over the internet. They do not do it justice. Easy to walk through. Helps to have a guide to point out so many things I'd otherwise have missed.
Unbelievable. To see what nature can do to a 1300 century temple is just amazing. Not to be missed in Seim Reap. See how these magnificent trees have taken over.

Tomb Raider. Beautiful temple, the trees have over grown round the temple walls making this temple very unique, it is where some of the scenes in the film Tomb Raider were filmed, great to walk around and explore, on of the highlights of the Angkor Wat visit! Dont miss this one out!!
Amazing temple. It was fantastic to see this temple. I was really enjoyable especially in the middle of the day, it seems quieter than usual. It makes feeling to be at ruin and nature.

Magic. For many years the temples of Ankor Wat and the surrounds lay hidden in the jungle, reclaimed by nature. While many of the temples have now been fully restored, Ta Prohm, also known as the jungle temple is still wrapped in the massive roots and dangling vines of giant fig trees that creates a real sense of mystery and adventure

Most impressive temple. From our POV this was the most impressive temple in whole Ankhor... Tomb Raider, Angelina, ... whatever... This place is really magic and due to symbiosis of Flora and temple absolutely amazing.Nice anecdote: When we left the area by bicylce, the tire of my gf exploded (really!)... Before we started accepting a long walk back to SR, there was a garage (ran mainly by a lady not speaking a single word english) that offered repair. The tube was exchanged and the outer tire (which was totally ripped) has been sewed(!) by the lady and fortified with the old tube!We paid 8USD (incl. 2 beers during waiting time)... Absolutely unimaginable in a similar situation in Europe...

Good for history and architecture buffs, a photographer's heaven.... Good for history and architecture buffs, a photographer's heaven...Highly recommended...Good to have a guide here.and this is the place where they filmed part of Tomb Raider

tree prohm. for a long time left unrestored as a display of how the trees had overrun the temples.ta prohm should not be missed and the sooner the better as it is undergoing restoration too.a lovely temple for photo lovers and ruin lovers, better than bayon in my opinion for the atmosphere and interplay of colors of the temple and the trees and the green moss.go in the early morning and u will love it.

The Tomb Raider Temple. Wife was in charge of choosing which temples we visited on our temple tour day and we were both really glad she chose this one. It was really fascinating to see such a good example of how the jungle claimed the city. Easy to dodge tour groups and get some great pictures. Really worthwhile visiting.

My favourite temple of them all. Magical. Buy your ticket from the one and only main ticket office on the temple complex. $20 for one day, or $40 for 3 days, of $60 for a week. The tickets will have your photo on them so are non transferable. Negotiate with a tuk tuk driver outside your hotel to be yours for the day. $20-25 is the norm, and buy him a couple of bottles of water during the day. You will pay him at the end and he will wait at every temple for you.I live in Cambodia and have visited most of the temples several times now. Ta Prohm (Tomb Raider Temple) is my favourite of them all.The trees growing up through the temple just make this place magical, and very different to the other temples. It does not matter where you point your camera you will get some stunning photos.

Forget the films. If you possibly can, get here very early before the crowds and you will be rewarded by a fascinating ruin of a temple, with lots of nooks and crannies, which is really enchanting with all the trees and their roots intertwined in the structure. However once the crowds arrive it loses some of its magic, and although still interesting and worthy of a visit it does not have the same impact.
Mysterious. A rather mysterious place with the magnificent trees intertwining with the temple. But awesome to behold.

Temple vs. Trees. This is where they shot scenes from the movie Tomb Raider.... It was refreshing to see moss greens and towering trees after the many gray temples we went to beforehand. The temple is in the midst of restoration, which gives it a distinct chaotic charm.
awesome. This temple is one of my favorites that we have seen in Asia. The trees growing throughout are magnificent. This is where the movie "tomb raider" was filmed. Great photo opps

Magical. Definitely a must visit. You'll love Ta Prohm. We even looked for the tree where Angelina Jolie stopped in the movie Tomb Raider. ^_^ It just feels magical being able to see these beautiful temples.

Temple in the Trees. This temple is the only 1 completely unrestored from its inception. Its also the scene of the Lara Croft Movie. The roots of the trees are quite unbelievable here and add to the glamour of the temples. If anything the trees are the attraction here but the temple is also great to wander around. Amazing photos and memories from this place! Enjoy!

tomb raider temple. One of the most beautiful temple in angkorwat.Ta Prohm is especially serene and beautiful in the early morning when we had gone. also one of the most crowded, full of hordes of tourists from different countries thanks to its increasing popularity.
Tomb raider temple was top of my list. Mossy and cool, this temple is divine. you can feel the centuries of history here! This is a beautiful temple, and high on the list. Make sure you get here.

Very crowded, but worth the trip. Of course a must see amongst the temples. The jungle has become one with the temples . The giant trees are consoler and destroyer at the same time. It is a shame though to see so many tourist paying so much money for the entrance fee and not much of it is given to the local people. They live in extreme poverty while the private company and the government puts the 40$ for 3 days tickets into their own pocket. Shame on the government, shame on the business owner.

Favorite temple by far. Coolest temple for sure (and this is including all the small and big loop temples and the Roluos group). Seeing how nature has changed and taken over this temple is pretty remarkable. Going in the late afternoon will offer the best lighting, in my opinion.

The Tomb Raider Temple. Ta Prohm, more commonly known as the temple from the Tomb Raider film, is one of the more popular temples in the Angkor Wat area but is a must see. There has been some construction to make it more tourist friendly but it does not take too much away from the experience. Try to avoid peak times (your guide may be able to advise on this if you have one) as large groups can take up a lot of the complex, especially in the main photo spots.

Amazing amazing. Definitely made me want to watch Tomb Raider again! What a beautiful temple at one with nature. The trees have grown into the walls and most of the temple is at its original form so not restored like the others in the Angkor area. This temple, is a must see! Go around lunch time when the big tourist groups break for lunch!

Stunning. Whatever you do, make sure you visit this temple complex. If you can manage it without hoards of tourists they you'll be doing well as it's very popular. The buildings and temples are stunning.

What an adventure. You should come here as soon as possible in the early morning if you don't wish to visit the temple with overwhelm crowded people. This was the most excited and desired temple which I wanted to visit however due to the overwhelming crowded people in the afternoon, it make me feel disappointed despite that you will need to squeeze in between the crowded sea of people and it was hard for taking pictures.
Fantastic. Must visit. UNESCO World Heritage sight, need one say more! This temple is more 'rustic' than many of the others so one can imagine the state it was in when discovered decades ago.

charming temple. It is better if possible to visit Angkor wat early morning, so you'll be able to enjoy the quietness, the beautiful nature...afterward you have so so many buses fo tourist, thousands of people shouting, walking around....So many marvelous temples to visit, to discover the statues of Apsaras,

Mesmerising. I really enjoyed Ta Prohm - for me it was the best of all the temples. Even my kids (who weren't particularly happy about slogging through 'boring' temples in the heat), enjoyed this one the most. It is almost like fairyland and quite mysterious. You can almost imagine the apsara dancers twinkling through the corridors and the whole place has a calming feel to it with secret nooks and crannies.Our Tuk Tuk driver dropped us off at one side and we walked through the place from one side to the other where our driver was waiting for us again. That was a smart thing to do and saved the hassle of slugging back through the heat. On our trip with 3 girls (aged 9,8 and 7 yrs old) we visited Bayon, Ta Prohm and Angkor Wat. These were all different temples with their own style and gave us a good feel of the place. We also carted round the place on a Tuk Tuk but didn't get out everywhere. Just enough for us adults to satisfy our temple thirst and enough for the children to digest.

This place are totally awesome!. Centuries old tree stands still with the temple reminded me about the co-exist of creation and destruction. But then, they are renovating it and somehow taken away this special feeling...

Ta Prohm awesome. Ta Prohm is my favorite temple . It is not all manmade. The over Grown roots embracing the ruined temple is really Natures way of Enchancing The beauty of the Temple . I love the look of antiquity that makes it one of the seven wonder of the world together with the whole concept of the Anchor Wat Temples . This temple is blessed with Designs made in heaven

Tomb Raider temple. The temple also known as the Tomb Raider Temple is spectacular. Centuries of abandonment have left this temple fighting with nature. The strangler figs have grown all around this temple. And the lichen and moss add a green hint to this impressive temple that is part of the Angkor Complex. There is a lot of renovation going on at this time. I believe Unesco is renovating at least two of the buildings. Also, it is very slippery when wet. There are lots of planks and rocks to climb over and stairs that become very slippery when wet. It is Cambodia so it rains a lot. Make sure you bring old shoes. Mine were destroyed by the lava mud.

Amazing root structures. The temple known by the large roots cover its ancient temples. Spend time walking around to find the perfect picture. Also, pay a guard a small fee and they will take you to hidden treasures.
makes you feel like Indiana Jones. this has to be one of the best experiences in Angkok. Go early before sun rise beat the crowd and see it in the mist.

Ta Prohm. I think was one of my favorite temples. This was built for the Kings mother as a summer retreat for her. This is where Angelina Jolie was filmed & it is so fascinating to see these incredible roots overgrown over Al the structures... Amazingly beautiful...

Left as found. The ruinous temple monastery of Ta Prohm is the one site I’ve really been looking forward to, and it doesn’t disappoint. It is at once obvious from the partially collapsing buildings that this temple hasn’t been restored. Left by the then custodians Ecole Francaise d’Extrême Orient largely as it was found. The undergrowth has been cleared, but in order to preserve the remaining buildings the large silk cotton and fig trees have been left in situ. In many areas huge sections lay in ruins, the fallen blocks lie covered in thick green moss.

WOW!!!. I have always dreamed of visting this temple and what a site!! We were so lucky that at some places there were almost no people as we were visting the area during low season. The overgrown trees engulfing the ruins were mindboggling and definately worth seeing. Enjoyed every moment.
yes it's tomb raider temple. A little less crowded than Angkor, beautiful temple however under a fair bit of restoration, but well worth the trip
Extraordinary. As with all the temples in Cambodia this place is jaw dropping. How did they do it, this massive out pouring of building architecture and art. Gob smacked hardly covers it

The best of all by far. Ta Prohm temple was by far the best of all we've seen in 3 days when visiting Cambodia. When exploring it thoroughly one can enjoy some of its sections alone and not only enjoy the silence, but get very nice pics as well.

Beautiful scenery!. The scenery is stunning with all the roots of the trees between the Temples. I can't understand how after all these years, the Temple is still standing. Great for pictures. The movie Tomb Raider was filmed here. I recommend to watch the movie before visiting, it enhances the experience.
Fantastic place. Loved this temple, the way the trees grown from and through the temple is amazing. For me this was the best of all the temples we visited
Amazing. What is there to say? How incredible. My favourite Cambodian temple. So atmospheric. Do not miss it!!
My Favorite. Loved this Tomb Raider Temple! It feels a bit like a maze and surprises you at every corner. Less crowded. Def my fav!

amazing. This temple is an extraordinary example of nature taking over. The temple was absolutely amazing. The spung trees that were growing everywhere were absolutely breathtaking. This is also where Tomb Raider was filmed.
Beavers Tour 2014. Well worth the visit. Truly remarkable! Just be ready for the trinket sellers on the way in and out.

Tomb Raider temple. Now there are wooden viewing platforms and the vines have been removed so it's not quite as "thrilling" as in the movie but a must see before the huge banyan trees are cut down as they are getting too big and will damage the ruins.

The Tomb Raider Temple. Better known for being the location for the movie Tomb Raiders, this beautiful ruin is made mysterious and magnificient by the huge number of large roots of the silk cotton trees. A must visit .
Beautiful but way too crowded. Way too crowded around the 11h (even though it's low season). Afterwards, I heard there is less people early in the morning or late afternoon.

Strong Trees. This is where the tomb raider is starred. The roots of the trees are amazing, growing through the roof of the temple. We manage to find a smiling buddha growing in between the roots. Do your search!

Spectacular. We visited Ta Prohm as part of an Intrepid tour through Cambodia. We visited Ta Prohm directly after Angkor Wat at sunrise, so we were just 1 of 2 tour groups in the place. I definitely recommend it as a place to visit early, as it gave the place a tranquil feel, and it was wonderful to get photos unobstructed by other tourists.
Amazing. This temple is so interesting with the trees growing through the temples. You will not find anything else like it in the world and it is well worth a visit. You will be amazed!

You can't miss this temple!. The temple is where they filmed the movie "Tomb Raider" starring Angelina Jolie. The trees grow all over the temples, including on top, and squeeze through some of the stones. It's an amazing mix of nature and architecture, and it's still stunning to see how the two live in harmony.

Nature creating its own carving. This is one of the few temples that has minimal restoration and one can see magnificence of nature taking over the temple complex. The giant root trees have added more beauty to the structure and is the major highlight of this temple.Turn on: Massive trees, Clean, Mother nature at bestTurn off: Missing proper signage easy to get lost.

The trees are spectacular and the shade is nice.. We didn't have a guide but if you follow one of the other tour groups, you'll make sure to hit all of the best spots to view the roots, pulling down the temples. This temple was shady and a bit cooler, so it was a nice break from the heat of the day.

Massive trees and roots. The site is overwhelming. No matter how massive the roots are, visitors are still drawn to the stone structures, the way they were designed and constructed, along with the art work on stones.In one corner, there is a wooden platform for picture taking. Almost everyone wants a photo taken under the tree and its roots.
The quiet feel with a nature. Very much like the noise of the bird and ruin looks amazingLove to stay here in the night time if possible

Ta-mazing!. After visiting some of the other temple that have been restored you will find this temple to be a breath of fresh air. What makes this site so fascinating is the fact that nature has reinvented Ta Prohm. The mixture of jungle with stone in my opinion is more beautiful than any of the restored temples. There are plenty of photo opportunities. If you have time try and find the stegosaur carved into sandstone on your own. Make it a game whoever finds it first wins. There are plenty of creepy areas that are dark and crumbled so have fun exploring all of the hidden corners.

tomb rader!. The giant ancient tree that grew inside and over the temple it was amazing! Walking through the temple and getting lost was just amazing. Lots of things to do, the people were very friendly the kids were all smiles.
Jungle. Part of the Temple complex as seen in Bayon. Here the tree roots choke the buildings, and gave me the feeling that I must keep moving or they might grab my leg.

Amazing. I have been there in Oct 2014 and was absolutely breath-taking, I would have loved to have the temple to myself to explore but unfortunately there were hundreds of people visiting the same time as me, so it was constant standing in queues inside the templeIt is also very confusing to find your way through the temple as the tuc-tuc drops you at the eastern side (or western side, can’t remember) and wait for you on the other side, so you have to make your way through the ruins on you own with no visible signageBut it is fantastic to see how nature is slowly reclaiming the areaThe spot that was used in the Lara Croft movie is virtually impossible to get close to, every tourist visiting wants a photo of them-self at that spot, so it was quite a wait before you could get close enough to take a picThis was the temple that I was really looking forward to see and it was absolutely worth the stampede to see itThis is in my view one of the must see temples

The tomb raider temple. That's what it is more famously called ;thanks to Lara Croft! It's amazing,uncanny, unsettling and much more. One has to see it to believe that nature and architecture can be so engaged to each other. The giant sponge trees which are 200- 350 years old ( I was told) growing out of the ears and eyes of doe eyed Apsaras and meditating monks are an unearthly sight. Being an Indian I am immensely proud of the extraordinary conservation work undertaken by the Archaeological Survey of India. They surely have understood that nature will prevail over man and so it is wise to adjust rather than protest!

Make this temple priority!. With a three day pass, I managed to see most of the temples and this without a doubt the most wonderful. Peaceful, sweet air and thick green moss decorating the walls. The temple is falling down fast, pushed aside by massive trees. There is something really phenomenal about this place. If you're limited to a one day pass, make sure you leave time for this temple.

Cambodian treasure. Great food, interesting nightlife, inexpensive massages. The seafood is of very high quality. Try the local fish, prepared in local style, as god as what Bangkok has to offer. Do try the coconut water, some can be nectar-like

Much more than just the Tomb Raider temple!. Ta Prohm was our joint favourite temple of the entire trip, the other being Bayon.Whereas Bayon, and to some extent Angkor, are examples of well preserved, still standing and active temples, Ta Prohm is a vision of what it looks like when nature takes over. The trees sprouting through roofs are the most iconic sight but the sheer range of wildlife is something you don't often hear about - I found a massive millipede, spiders beyond counting and tiny frogs all lurking in the cracks & crevices. Sadly they have needed to fend off the more well known (Tomb Raider) parts otherwise I'm sure the trees would be a mangled mess of graffiti by now! You can still get decent photos though and the boarding actually helps guide you through the ruin.This is definitely one of the best temples still standing in the Angkor region & definitely recommended. Try to time your trip in the morning or just before sunset to avoid the hordes of tourists and to get the best light for pictures.
Temple set in jungle covered in trees. This is the Tomb Raider (Laura Croft) temple which you can see set in trees which are growing out of it. One of many must do temples in the general Angkor area

See it before the destroy it. My second visit and it already looks different. They have fixed some of the doorways and paths, not the worst change but they have started removing the trees. This is what makes it so famous. Sadly, some of the trees have died and when they die they no longer keep the bricks in the temples together. This has led them to plan to destroy some of the healthy trees. This is going to cause damage to the temple and even the guides are against it. Hopefully they will change their minds.

Fat chance finding Lara Croft's tree - do like me instead.... ... and just pick ANY one of the magnificent trees growing over a nice archway and stop wasting time... There're MANY! After my friend and I posed at this spot we chose (see my pic), swarms of hapless tourists fought to shoot at the same spot... We ran before we got stampede on!My favourite spot was one of the collapsed and rebuilt corridors near the West Gate of Ta Prohm. Reading the signage and looking at what was rebuilt... I couldn't help going, "Oh WOW!"Note: Ta Prohm (like many part of Angkor) is not wheelchair friendly and you need to be reasonably agile to walk through all the ruins. Do not bring little children too. Also be careful when touching random trees - spotted a worm approximately 12cm long... (-__-)

Interesting trees! :). At this temple where scenes from Lara Croft:Tomb Raider with Angelina Jolie were filmed, you'll see trees with giant roots hanging down from top of the walls and trees growing on top of the roofs! One thing in particular that attracted my attention was a giant hollow tree kind of straddling a stone wall underneath and the wall itself was bent-shaped likely due to the weight of the tree above, and looking from some distance, it actually seemed like the tree was crushing the wall! People also seem to make it a point to come here due to the movie fame, I guess, as the place was fairly packed, and also one good thing is you can exit from the back unlike at Preah Khan where you have to walk back the way you came in. I was greeted by tons of kids selling drinks back there who weren't that many at other temples.Ta Prohm was the fifth stop on my Angkor circuit tour starting at Angkor Wat, then Angkor Thom (Bayon & Baphuon), then Preah Khan, then Ta Keo, then Ta Prohm, then Banteay Kdei and Sras Srang reservoir, then Prasat Kravan, and finally Phnom Bakheng the temple on a mountain. If you're coming by minibus from Poipet and meet the tour operator named Vara when you get off in Siem Reap, I highly recommend his services - honest, timely pickups and no hidden charges except some small tip to the driver at day's end after the tour.Also, one important advice is to have your admission ticket you obtained at the main entrance (before Angkor Wat) with you at all times during the tour since they check for it at each subsequent stop (not just at Angkor Wat).

Most amazing temple ruins in the world!. This was by far the most amazing temple ruins I've ever visited. The manner in which old trees are intertwined with the temple buildings, and the way they have now become one, each with the other, is jaw-droppingly awesome! The beauty of this temple complex has a mystical magical quality to it!
Unbelievable. The most stunning of all the temples if you like architecture and trees. Make sure you leave lots of time to explore this place.

The best in the Angkor region. Forget the crowds at Angkor Wat and head out here first thing in the morning These magnificent ruins are slowly being reclaimed form the jungle. Come early to make the best of the jungle light and miss the crowds. The Cambodians via international benefactors are slowly restoring all the Angkor temples and preventing further deterioration where possible while trying to retain the current ambiance of the place. A one day All Angkor Pass is available for US$20 on park entry.

The temple with 'snake' root tree. Wooow…! In this temple is the site for the movie 'tomb raider' and one eerie of the transformer. many large tree still standing on this temple. This is the main attraction of this temple. This temple is not too hot because many tree to shade the site. You can visit anytime, The site is large and you may need to carry few bottles of water when you visit this temple.

Beautiful. We managed to reach this temple fairly early in the morning so we managed to avoid the crowds. It is best to go with a guide-ours took us in through the opposite gate to everyone else so for a time we were more or less alone there.
Angkor Wat Temples are Stunning. Unbelievably breathtaking- the temples of Angkor Wat are Stunning! Beautiful Intricate Amazing! Must see!
The trees!. Loved this temple, stunning architecture, carvings and trees - a must see. We were lucky to go late in the day and get the place almost to ourselves.
Interesting but exaggerated. Long tree roots was really exciting. It distroy the ruins and provide you an amazing shot. If u are in Siem Reap,you should visit. Exciting but not terrific.

Our Favorite!. You can't miss this one and don't rush thru it. It is amazing and so beautiful. There are many photo opps and very incredible to know that this was buried for some time. We could have gone back for a 2nd visit, but too much to see ;) Enjoy!

magic place. Probably the second most famous Temple after Angkor Wat, Ta Phrom, a must see place, where you can see how great and powerful is nature. Jungles has taken over and conquered an amazing Temple build by an incredible civilization. A hot spot for all kinds of photographers, true the place is magical, very picturesque. Of course Tomb Raider movie also made it a must-see place for plenty of tourists, who are obsessed to see places from the movie. Make sure you won`t be in a hurry to walk around and "feel the place".
Nothing short of amazing!. This was one of my favorites. The temple and the setting are amazing. Even Hollywood can't spoil this one. Must see!
My favourite temple. The rubber trees have taken parts of this temple back, it's really amazing place made famous by the Laura Croft movie.
Ravaged by nature. One of the most beautiful temples yet to be restored and ravaged by nature.....man made beauty but nature knows its power - some to make good and some to destroy the good

Felt Like Lara Croft! - Fabulous Temple - with it's own treasure. This was a absolute must - as I wanted to get my Lara Croft on - and find a nearby geocache ... which we found - so felt like real life tomb raiders. The Temple is steadily being preserved and cleaned up and rebuilt bit by bit - and I love how that nature has taken over - and should continue to do so. Seems a shame to de-moss the stone though - as that adds to the mystique - my favourite Temple of the day out of Baynon and Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm.
Amazing!. Definitely worth a visit - the trees growing on the sandstone temples has to be seen at least once - so that you can wonder in awe as to what it looked like when it was first discovered!

Wonderful example of human versus nature. This was my favourite of the temples we saw in the Angkor region (the small circuit, some of the Grand Circuit, and the Roluos group), so we went twice. Our family loved the way the jungle is claiming the temples for itself. There are many little areas to explore, and even though there were a number of people there (even now in low season), there were places we could find to ourselves. Near the entry, the trees growing through the walls are popular sites for photography, and are roped off, but further in there are possibilities to find other spots like this without the hordes. A really lovely atmosphere, full of character. We were there mid-afternoon on our first visit, and returned at 4.30 until 5.30 on the final day of our pass to experience it again with better light as the sun sank lower. There were less people there at that time of day and it was even more magical with the longer shadows and sun setting behind the trees and ruins.
Loved it. We did angkor wat at sunrise but when we go back in a few days I think we'll do this place nice and early again, avoids the crowds and it's like a maze! My fav of everything so far!!
A must see!. This place is amazing. I think it should be part of the world's wonders. Pictures don't do justice. Do not miss this place!
Magical. An enchanting place. Everyone comes here because it is the 'tombraider' temple but that doesn't detract from how enchanting it is.

Ta Prom. Again, a different experience from the two other nearby temples of Angkor wat and Angkor Thom in that the remains are an amalgam of the temple and the steady incursion of nature over three or four centuries leaving many buildings in the clasp of huge trees. The site of the film Temple of Doom?
My favourite!. I absolutely loved this temple! Set amidst jungle and vines, it extends on and on like some kind of maze and it has such amazing atmosphere. It is both spooky and majestic.
Most beautiful temple. I spent 1-2 hours in most temples and 3+ in Ta Prohm. This temple is just amazing. I couldn't explore it enough
Romantic place to visit.. Please visit this temple. It's so beautiful with many tree roots hanging down from the top of the roofs.

This is the one not to miss!. You may feel "templed out" after your stay in Siem Reap but this is the one temple you MUST visit on your Cambodian holiday. This spectacular place will have you in raptures as it is probably what you came to see when you chose Siem Reap on your itinerary. Think moss-covered ancient relics, tomb-raider style jungle, shadows, vines, ancient carvings…. it is like an enchanted lost paradise hidden deep in the jungle. No wonder serval Hollywood movies have used this amazing place as a set. Make sure you have a local guide to show you the highlights and do respect the local dress rules (covered shoulders and shorts below the knee).

Spectacular. Ta Prohm is the Angkor Temple that you see in all the pictures/movies with the trees growing up and around and through the temple buildings . It is just amazing and takes you to another world.
trees are taking over. A magnificent view how trees have been taken over a building. It will take you back in time. Worth while tt spend your time
Worth the stop. Although you find a lot of people there at this temple it is still worth the stop. Keep walking around and you will find corners of the temple with out anyone else.
Very Cool!. This temple has character ... known as the "jungle temple", the disruptive effects of nature are incredible. Nice change up from other temple ruins.

Ta Prohm. This temple is also known as "Jungle Temple" for the trees or "Tomb Raider Temple" as Angelina Jolie did the movie at this site. You can see many giant trees with their roots covering parts of the buildings

Mind blowing. Amazing & awesome temple ,which has been taken over by the jungle. Trees roots all over the place engulfing the temple.It was the 2nd stop after Angkorwat temple & was too crowded during early part of the day. We had tough time getting pictures with temple ruins with sea of people around us. Everyone wanting to get pictures at the same time.Our our tuk tuk driver told us after Angelina Jolie's visit, this temple is attracting a lot of visitors. It would be good idea to visit this place later in the day.Siem Reap is all about temples so worth buying a 3 day pass . This temple was included in the Big Tour as per our hotel package .A must for this visit is good walking climbing shoes , cap, sunglasses, lot of water and suntan lotion.Worth reading about history of this monument before visiting.

Awe inspiring.. Fantastic visit to probably the most photogenic area in Siem Reap. The trees growing out of the structures really make Ta Prohm what it is.Photograph opportunities at the turn of every corner a real must if in Siem Reap.

My favorite. Many of the temples start to blend together after a day of touring. Don't get me wrong, they are all truly spectacular. Ta Prohm and Bayon by far were of the more interesting variety to me with the large trees growing in, on and around the ancient ruins.
Amazing. This temple is absolutely beautiful! If you visit Angkor Wat you must come and see Ta Prohm! It was much quieter than the other temples when we visited, and was definitely my favourite.

Nature vs humans. This is a small temple complex in ruins. It is a war zone! You are witnessing an ongoing battle between the trees and the temple structures....and the trees are winning! It is a wonderful sight as you wander through the temple rubbles, seeing those huge tree trunks at work! This is a must see. Highly recommended.
Absolutely stunning. Beautiful, beautiful place! Wonderful to see how nature and human-built structures just intertwine. It's definitely a must-see on your trip!

My favorite temple. Even though it's mostly in ruins, it was much more interesting than the others with its many corridors, courtyards, winding paths and a surrounding forest. Huge tree roots are growing over the walls making you feel like you're in Middle Earth. The walk in to it is through the forest, very peaceful. I'm a birdwatcher and enjoyed seeing the Alexandrine Parrokeets, Rose-breasted Parrokeets and Coppersmith Barbets in the trees above the temple grounds.

Tomb raider temple. If you've seen the Angelina Jolie movie Tomb Raider, you should definitely visit this temple. You will feel like you were in the movie. The place was not huge but it was definitely worth visiting.

Ancient architecture meets 600 year old trees. To keep it short: one of the most remarkable places I have ever had the pleasure of visiting. The way nature has taken hold of Ta Prohm is a sight to behold, and leaves a magical ambience in this ancient and very special place. No visit to Siem Reap is complete without a half day at Ta Prohm.

Ancient beauty. I can only rate excellent for all of the temples and get all seem to have there own vibe and character, for me Ta Prohm was peaceful and showed nature slowly taking back the ruins. Great spot to sit and reflect, as well as take 1000 photos.

Fantastic trees growing out of temple walls. This is the tomb raider temple. Busier than most temples as everyone tries to get that perfect tree photograph. Take your time and relax, the crowds come in waves and if you walk a little way from the main trees, then you will get a sense of peace and quiet.

Amazing!. For me, definitely one of the must-see temples because of the number of huge 400-500 year-old-trees that have grown over some of the structures.There are wooden platforms built in front of most of the trees which are a good place for photo-taking - I suppose, this is to protect the tourists and also the structures.This temple is also still being currently restored, so there are a lot of large stones lying around. When we were there (September 2014), there was also an area that we couldn't access because a restoration team was currently doing work.
Interesting. Again, we visited as part of the whole Angkor Wat package - were not disappointed, All of these temples are so amazing to see and marvel at the construction so many years ago. Stunning!

The tree and the temple. From the outside it seems like usual temple, but after you enter the main area temple. You will be stun by the combination of big tree and the temple surrounding. But this temple is too packed so you can feel it started to crowded in short time, but it is worth seeing. Unfortunately when I came, there is some restoration work is on going there so I can't explore more.

Stunning. Seeing this temple complex was amazing this is where they film Lara Croft film Tomb Raiders and i would highly recommend this when you to the area. The trees growing over and through the temple really adds to the aging of the site, amazing
Beautiful. We enjoyed visiting Ta Prohm. The combination of the trees and ruins is very dramatic and beautiful. It's pretty small, though, so it can get crowded. Great photos.

In the top three places to see. A decent place in Angkor Wat - the others being Bayon and Preah Khan. IF YOU HAVE LIMITED TIME (or don't want to spend $40 on a two-day pass), just visit these three and maybe Angkor Wat itself if time permits. This is the Tomb Raider temple - and the trees are cool - but TOO many tourists all trying to get photos and platforms taking away from the photo – you can see a great temple with trees wrapped around it at Preah Khan. If it is rainy, keep you pass in your wallet – or bring an ID card holder with a strap to put around your neck – every temple you need to show your pass.

Stunning blend of man made + nature...my favorite temple. Ta Prohm is quite famous (probably the 2nd or 3rd most famous temple) and it deserves the fame. The trees are literally grow in, from and around the beautiful limestone and sandstone that was used to build and decorate the temple. It is one of the temples that appears to have the least reconstruction (or at least you can see much less concrete)...between that and the massive trees spreading their roots throughout the temple, the pictures were absolutely stunning. I highly recommend viewing all the temples with a local guide that knows and can explain the history and the differences between all the temples...it will be a worthwhile investment.

Overgrown by the jungle. You will find this historical masterpiece on the eastern side of the Angkor Park. The long roads who leads to the temple are impressive. When you see the outer walls you will be shocked by the great structure and the nice inscriptions of the temple. Be here on time before the big busses with tourists arrive, because by then its gonna be very crowded. The temple itself is beautiful with trees that are grown over the some parts of the temple. Of course you will find the famous views from Tomb Raider here, but the whole temple has more to offer. Impressive viewpoints from the inside where the sunlight reflects. Maybe you have no idea of the size of the temple when you arrive, but its really big. You will need some time to visit the whole temple (1,5 hour) because it's really complex.Highlights:- Hidden corners- Trees entwined among ruins- Atmosphere

Keyword: Tomb Raider. We find this place just by the keyword: Tomb Raider & Angelina Jolie.Maybe the difference of this temple with the other is the roots and the fact that this is the notorious place that features in the movie. The temple is quite big, and its still under a major restoration process. However the gigantic trees and roots were quite a sight. There's so many of them so it took us some time to identify which tree that were used for the movie. Apparently the answer is easy, just follow the crowd.
Jungle Temple. Super nice, to see it it is a must, into my opinion one of the nicest temple I have ever seen in my life.

They're not all the same....... It can be hard to pick which temple you should spend more time in in the Khmer Park area as there are so many things to see.Personally, I think they're all great so I suggest a bit of research to thin the list if you prefer the main sites and a guide so the significance can be appreciated.

One of the Must See!. All the while I thought The temple where the roots of the tree engulfing the temple structure was Angkor Wat...well it's not, its in Ta Prohm. This is one of the major Temples in Siem Reap. Worth the visit.
A must visit in Siem Reap. Visited the Ta Prohm in the morning and found very few people around - pleasing. Definitely an interesting temple to visit.

Serenity. Walking around the temple gives you a calm experience. Some parts of the temple are still in restoration progress. Watch out the area where Tomb Rider scenes are, you don't want to miss that.
Amazing!. Truly a beautiful temple, awe-inspiring and great for photos also! I would put it in the top 3 temples in Siem Reap, out of the 11 I saw.

Must see - Tomb Raider location. This temple which was a the location of Tomb Raider filming is a must see. The parasitic trees 'eating up' the temples are something else to behold. Just when you think it's all in the movies nature rises up to surprise you! Ta Prohm is a good temple to explore even when the day warms up as it's encased in jungle.

Temple of Trees. I took a lot of great pictures at Ta Prohm, and they are not the ones you have. Sorry, but it is true. I allowed myself be guided by one of the unofficial guides who really knew where to get good pictures off the beaten path. At first I ignored him, as one has to do, but he was tenacious and proved to have a good knowledge of where to get the best shots. While he clammed up in the presence of the real tan-shirt guides, the blue-shirt security did not stop him, so I concluded that he was sharing his fee with them and they were letting him go off the official path. I gave him $5, but like I said, I got the pictures that you missed.That said, the temple itself is a lovely crumbling mass of stone and trees. Yes, the trees are all over several walls, and you have to stand in line to get a picture of the iconic tree wrapped around the stone structure (from the movie), and it is roped off. Look close for a carved face watching from between tree roots, and look up for raft bee hives.

Most atmospheric of the Anghor temples....... We have just returned from a Mercury Direct tour of the temple complex at Anghor Wat. We visited the Bayon, Anghor Wat and Ta Phrom sites and our view was that the Ta Phrom site was by far the most atmospheric. This is probably due to the invasion of the complex by various 'jungle' growths such as trees and their roots, creepers etc. The other sites are larger and more spectacular but the serenity of the Ta Phrom site seems special. Now about to revisit the 'tomb raider' film to see it from a different perspective!

The Trees!!!. Temples with tree on it, not just one but a lot.Trees growing from ground, attaching to the buildings and still stay strong. The roots has merged with the buildings.It's not unusual in Asia but to have so many of this within such small area is really amazing.

Awesome. This temple is still very much in ruins and that's what appealed to me most. There were huge trees growing in the temple and on the temple and thorough the temple. It was like history in front of you. I don't know if there are plans to restore this temple. But I hope there aren't. It's amazing because of the state it is in.

Just Beautiful!. I would agree that this is the best among all temples in Siem Reap. We went here last and is amazing during sunset. The roots from the trees were astonishing trying to wrap itself on the walls with those carvings. We went here on a weekday so it was less crowded and it appears that most tourists planned their itinerary to visit this place last so it tends to get really crowded by 5PM. We were lucky because we came in early so we had moments that we got a square of the temple to ourselves. Really got some great photographs from this place.
The best temple at angkor. The best one, a temple in ruins with trees growing on top of it. Would have been a five if it wasn't for the hordes of tourists and restricted areas.

Spoilt by inconsiderate tourist!. I was really looking forward to this temple and we went to this one last. Place is small and narrow walkways and it's filled with inconsiderate tourist speaking shouting yelling loudly! Each of them in a big group taking pictures individual leaving a big built up of people waiting.The temple itself is beautiful, the trees growing out from it is simply amazing and magnificent. I really wanted to stay longer to take it all in but unfortunately the magic is lost amongst the crowd.

Amazing site - but watch the crowds. This is a very close second to Angkor Wat - but only second, I feel, because we ran smack-bang into the massive tourist crowd. I suspect if it wasn't for that, I'd rate it as highly as Angkor Wat. So, a MUST: only visit EARLY MORNING or LATE AFTERNOON for one of the more spiritual places on the plenty.

A wonderful mix of nature and human building. Undoubtedly my favourite part of Angkor Wat complex was Ta Promh. When Angkor Wat is shown in pictures these tend to be the most common thing you see. Fig trees hug walls and buildings with their enormous roots. Wonderful and unique.

Best temple of them all!. Obviously seen on Tomb Raider, this temple despite being a little cliché is simple amazing. If you go early (after sunrise but before the crowds are finished at Angkor Wat), you cant help but be swept up into the magic of the place - where trees have silently taken over in places that seem to defy logic. The best photos we had of Cambodia where here and its something you just wont see other places.

Stunning!. This temple is real Indiana Jones material. Once covered with jungle it is dotted with tree roots growing through the stone walls of the temples. This temple has a quiet, peacefulness about it and the carved reliefs are beautiful.
The trees are amazing. The trees are are incredible and look like they are escaping over the walls. Amazing atmosphere. Go early to avoid the crowds
My favourite of the temples. This place was amazing. The way the trees have grown around the structures was incredible to see. Well worth the stop!

Mystical but rundown. Ta Prohm is a must-visit during your trip to Siem Reap. Trees literally grow out of the temple walls and roofs, giving the temple more of a 'jungle atmosphere', as compared to the normal 'ancient boring temple ruins' type of feel. However, like many other temples in Siem Reap, Ta Prohm looks like it is in need of major restoration.

Incredible Place to Visit in Siem Reap. Part of your temple tours in Siem Reap must include Ta Prohm. This is the temple with the huge tree growing down the side of it and the location for the Angelina Jolie film "Tomb Raider". Really spectacular. Don't miss it.

The best temple in Angkor. It was my second time in Angkor, but unfortunately I have discovered Ta Prohm only for the first time. And it is definitely worth going there only to see this place. So, if you have limited time - Ta Prohm is the place to go in Angkor!

Unique Temple!. It's my No. 1 favorite temple!
There's a major restoration at the temple. Simply amazed with the giant, famous tree's root is curling around the temple just like it's part of the temple's structure. It's really beautiful and stunning.
Despite the warm weather, it's actually very cooling in the temple due to the tall trees surrounding the temple.

tree-temple combos galore!. Ta Phrom is also known as the Tomb Raider site and showcases the most number of trees-in-temple combos. Good for photo ops! But they made pathways and platforms through the major tree-temple combos. For me, this strips the place of that "old temple charm". Too bad.

a fun walk - very busy. Everyone really wants to see the "tomb raider" temple and it shows. It is impressive and the trees growing around the temple. It's almost a little too touristy. They have built up platforms to pose for photos by the larger trees and people line up to have their photo taken. Worth the trip.

Ta Prohm - one of the best!. Visiting the Ta Prohm is a must see when you visit the Temples of Angkor Wat and was one of the best. Seeing all the trees growing among the Temple was an amazing example of how nature can come back.

Breath taking scenery. Those huge trees are incredible! I have never seen anything like that before! How the tree slowly taking over the temple is beyond word! Sadly to see many areas in this temple already collapsed!

Go Before The Crowds. If you're willing to get up before the sun, this is the temple you would want to visit. We got up at 5:30 am and there were only about 8-10 other people in the temple with us. WELL WORTH IT!. We got to take pictures without hundreds of people swarming in the background. :)
Interesting Temple. The structure of the tree branch covering the temple is so nice to see. Is considered the best small temple that we've seen besides Ang Kor Wat.

Nature is taking back what belongs to it. Visiting this temple made us realize how powerful nature is and that everything belongs to it. It was magical to see all those old parts of buildings "eaten" by tree. This one though was most difficult to get around with many uneven steps and since it was raining it was very slippery.
Just amazing.... An amazing temple, with the huge tree roots engulfing the temple. A wonder of nature and human architecture combined.
WOW. It is huge temple, too many tourist unable to capture nice photos. Be careful with walkway, bring umbrella if you go in raining season.

Tomb Raider. It bucketed with rain the first time I went there. Planned a whole half day the second time to get better photos. Get there really early to avoid bus loads of tourists wanting to see the tomb raider tree. My second favourite temple
THE best. I thought this was THE best temple, better than Angkor Wat. We went early just after sun rise and no one was there. Perfect for photos.

A Hidden Gem. Ta Prohm is often missed by many tours, but is unique in that it has been left mainly in its natural state to show what most of Angkor looked like when it was discovered in the 19th century. it is especially notable for the ancient trees intertwined among the ruins, which have inspired many to report glowingly on this temple.

Dreamt of seeing but thought it to be more dramatic. Great to see it in person but thought there would be more trees. As it was, there is only about 8 trees actually imbedded amongst the ruins. Still, you cannot miss this site if you are in Siem Reap.

I LOVE THIS PLACE SO MUCH!. I have been visiting this place. it is very beautiful and wonderful for anyone who comes here. My message to anyone who comes to every temple in the country should be obstinate in all the local people who force you to buy the goods they sell. I see a lot of people, especially from western countries, many buy stuff from them had.tips I can give is to avoid them,1 do not stare at them2 do not produce any words particularly "How much is it" to their3 continue your journey carefullyI know many people from western countries have a good heart. However, here you have to be strict to those who force you to buy their goods

Picturesque. Ta Prohm is a must see if you plan to visit the Angkor Wat Complex. Overgrown with trees, this picturesque temple is like none other. The majority of the temple has been left untouched, with ruins spread across the site. With plenty of areas to take breathtaking photos, make sure you have the camera on standby.

Unique Ta Prohm. Ta Prohm is unique because most of the temple has been left as it was found. A jungle grows in and around this beautiful temple. Well worth the visit along with Angkor Wat and my favorite, Angkor Thom. Plan visiting these temples early am to mid afternoon, 4-6 hours is plenty of time to take in all the sites. Bring water as there is no place to buy it. My daughter and I were on a tour that we booked through Exotissimo, who I would highly recommend for any tour of Asia. We had an English speaking guide who was very knowledgable about the temples.
Best of all the temples. Favourite in all Angkor. Real cool vibe. Loved the combination of temple ruins and nature woven together.

Like being in a movie set.. Ta Prohm is the ideal place where you can take photos with fantastic views. The area is very large and very highly crowded at any time. The heat here is exhausting perhaps because being surrounded by all this stone by a sense of suffocation. This site is different from all the other temples a bit 'similar to each other, the particular fact here are the big trees and roots that climb above the buildings making the scenario similar to that of an adventure film. Too bad for the presence of many tourists ...

Don't miss this one.. After seeing a few other temples I did wonder about another. Don't miss this one as it is quite different.
The trees growing out of the walls and the enormous roots was something else. I am so glad the trees were left here despite the destruction they caused. The restoration also shows how part of it was.

Excellent. After Angkor and Bayon, this is another fantastic temple. Partially hide form the big roots of the trees, nice colours, nice atmosphere. Probably you will alreday know that here is were a scene of the Tomb Rider movie was shoot, this is why they call it also Tomb Raider Temple.

reminds me of lara croft. I love our tour guide more when we arrived at Ta Prohm. Our tour guide Tep Nat (you can contact him at tep_nat_2007@yahoo.com) knows the good spots for picture taking. Send my regards to him from the Philippines. The trees looked as interesting as the temples. They are incredibly tall. Even the roots look fascinating.It's really better to go with a tour guide so you'll know more about the story behind the temples. The tour guides are lisenced and can speak English and other languages. The service of our groups' tour guide was $30 for the whole day.
Magnificent. A hidden temple in the forest. Get ready to be amazed at the overgrown huge trees which became part of the temple. Definitely a must see!

Extraordinary Sight. It was such an extraordinary sight seeing huge trees and its roots tower the ancient walls of the temple. This was where Indiana Jones & Lara Croft was filmed. Make sure this temple is in your list when visiting Siem Reap

Best very early in the morning!. We asked a tuk tuk driver to take us there very early in the morning, so we arrived at 05:30am. Nobody else there beside some dogs.Wonderful experience, felt as Tomb Raider could step right out of one of these doors.

Tomb Raiding Angkor complex. The visit to Angkor was driven by a must see desire of Angkor Wat, and whilst it lived up to my expectations I actually found Ta Prohm far more enchanting and captured my imagination. It also served as backdrop to the tomb raider movie hence the title of this piece. The beauty of this place against the main attraction of Angkor Wat is that it still reflects a balance between order and chaos, nature consumed and released in part this amazing temple and the roots of mighty trees offer a glimpse of how even these large monoliths, arranged in symmetrical order can be controlled and reordered by the unstoppable forces of nature. To give this temple and the others in the complex the time they deserve and for you the visitor to comprehend the splendour and majesty of a hugely creative and advanced peoples you need to spend at least 3 days IMHO

Astonishing temple. This temple, unlike any other you will see in Cambodia, has been maintained in the current condition of apparent neglect so that it is left in its 'natural state' (like how it was discovered in the 19th century). The trees, silk-cotton and strangler figs, intertwined among the ruins contribute to the atmosphere - serene, peaceful, awe-inspiring and mysterious.The layout is a little complex - just walk along, admiring the trees and the structures they are growing on and you will come across many hidden corners with opportunities you explore. Great photo-ops all around. The place will seem a little crowded as several tourists visit it due to its uniqueness, but it isn't crowded like Angkor. Do not miss!
Peace. Seeing the trees grow out of the temples was unbelievable. Loved the shadiness of the trees and the breeze that blew through the hallways of so olden days.

Favourite temple for atmosphere. Spent ages here just wandering around taking in the awesome beauty of the trees and temple entwined. Make sure you check out the tour bus schedules so that you can plan your visit at a quiet time. It makes all the difference. It was pouring with rain during our first visit, which added to the eeriness of the experience. Loved it so much went back again, this time in the sunshine.

Like another world. This temple is more famously know as the 'tomb raider temple' and so can be scoffed at by people who have not been there as a bit gimmicky but I was blown away. This was by far my favorite temple in the whole region and I only wish I had allowed myself far more time to explore. Seeing is really believing, this feels like another world. A long forgotten one. And even if busy with tourists there plenty of places to explore that will make you feel like you have the whole place to yourself. I can't stress enough how amazing the trees are here and the sense of timelessness they give, slowly creeping over the ruins, bit by bit claiming back the temple to the forest. I would recommend everyone who goes to the Siam Reap region takes time to visit this magical and amazing place.

Jungle ruins. If like us you like the ideas of giant jungle trees growing amongst and breaking through temple roofs and walls, this is the place to go. A little busy so try to plan your visit when others might not be there
Very interesting temple.. Must see when in Siem Reap. Easy to access and present in all Angkor tours. The downside is that it is always crowded but it definetly worths the visit.

Magic Place. Ta Prohm is one of my favorite temples in Siem Reap. It is truly mystical if you visit it early in the morning (best just during sunrise), which is also good to avoid the crowds. It is truly interesting how the plants and trees are growing within the temple which gives you some of the best pictures of your holiday. Enjoy!
Visually exciting temple.. This is a great place to get away from the bulk of Angkor tourists and soak up some amazing sights of nature enveloping mans past.
Fascinating. The way the trees intertwine with the temples is amazing, this place was definitely one of my favourite temples.

Look for dinosaur carving!. Many will go here to explore the ruins but let me give another major attraction of these temple. Looks for the dinosaur carving at main entrance of the temple. It hidden at the side of the door but keep looking. Not all the guide or I believe none of them show this carving. I came to know about this carving after watch history channel. Keep explore!
Filled with mystery. Temple can be a little'seen one seen them all' Not Ta Prohm, definitely a must do, has a real air of history and mystery

Got lost!. The temple was really amazing! But the signs were not visible ang confusing. We didn't get a guide so the signs would have been helpful. We ended up separated to each other and got lost. Hehehehe!

My number 1 temple. You must visit Ta Prohm sometime. It has been left somewhat untouched so the jungle still has it's hold. The massive roots and trees engulfing the ruins make this a magical place. You truly fee like Indiana Jones as you walk the grounds. Do not miss it!

Temple fest. A beautiful experience. Do go see the Angelina Jolie tree as it's there and it's amazing. Take your time to mooch around as there is so much more to see there. And buy a CD from the local band playing - they are all land mine survivors and the money goes to hep all landmine victims
My favourite. This is my favourite temple among all those i have seen ! So beautiful !! Go there early to avoid the crowds !!!!

My favourite of them all!. You couldn't help but be impressed by this temple, in places held together by enormous, ancient trees that have been growing through it for centuries. Some of the buildings are being supported by metal structures as removing the tress is not an option. It's where "Indiana Jones" was filmed and is just the most wonderful temple to visit. Definitely the top on my list. A photographers delight!
Another MUST SEE. Ta Prohm, aka Tomb Raider Temple is another stunning must see!Come early to slip the crowd and linger while you admire how nature has taken hold of this beautiful temple!

Magical! Amazing!. This was by far our favorite temple at the Angkot Wat temple complex. Breathtakingly beautiful, and there are so many nooks and crannies to explore. You don't want to miss this one!

My favourite temple in Siem Reap !. Loved the semi-restored look of the temple. Irony of this temple is that while it was destroyed by the jungles and trees - the same trees now act as the pillars for some of its structures, with tree roots intertwined with the stone bricks of the temple walls holding them tight.This can be a place for some peaceful time with oneself. Govt of India is helping partial restoration of this temple - but this temple will largely be kept unrestored intentionally - so as to give visitors a feel of Angkor temples as discovered by early European explorers. Definitely one of the top 3 Angkor / Siem Reap attractions.

The nature temple. It's so amazing to see how the trees grew in the temple. There are different locations to admire it. This temples has not been fully reconstructed and it makes you think how it really looks like in the past.

Temple Town. This Temple was interesting as you could walk through it rather than up or around it. Laura wasn't there but I checked the movie and she clearly was there before us. Just get a Tuk Tuk driver to tour the Temples. It's the cheapest and easiest way as you go at your own pace.

The Tomb Raider. The trees crawling though the structures gives it an excellent character not found in the other temples. The authorities are planning to cut down the trees in hope of preserving the structures... Anybody with knowledge of the character of the trees can comment whether the trees should be cut down. There are softwood as well as hardwood trees in the vicinity.
Beautiful. Beautiful place. Photos galore. Green. Bit hot going through temple. Friendly happy guides. Easy access. Amazing Temple and surrounds.

Ta Prohm is more than just a Tomb Raider flick. The place is simply stunning to the eyes with the bulging roots of the old tree eating up the golden aged temples is such a treat. Before we have this trip we did watch couple of rounds of the Tomb Raider movie and instill the scenery in our memory to savour it when we get there.
