Going around Ta Prohm is such a wonderful experience since it has wooden platforms to make it easier to roam around the temples. You might be bombarded of the extra friendly locals in the place and tour you around and get pictures of you in return for a tip not less than 5USD. Better get ready for the bills.To see more of the place, check:http://jlordalmighty.blogspot.sg/2012/11/besides-relic-and-temple-into-shades-of.html#.VAf51fmSzw4
Another must see. Spectacular structures. Huge tree with their roots exposed. Really, just like in the movies. Just as the other main attraction, crowded, but worth the visit of a lifetime
Ta Prohm. This is where everybody goes.Still, it is really one of the best of Angkor's many temples and you have to see it, not that you will have much choice as it is on all the standard routes.

Ta Prohm Temple, Lost City in the Forest. This was a former Royal Buddhist monestary, now over grown with roots and branches. It was untouched for 700 years. In 2004 the government of India started the restoration process. This was the venue for the "Laura Croft" film. The unusual tree with the huge roots over the temple is called the Spong tree. We saw mahogany trees, vital to early dwellers for fruit, wood and fuel.

Wonderful. I enjoyed this temple very much. Get there early. There are lots of areas for your to see and I was able to tour at my own pace. Wear comfortable shoes and clothing. Take water. The site is very impressive. You can purchase inexpensive souvenirs there, as well. Take a guide book along to assist you. The intricate carvings are amazing.

Temples in Siem Reap. Second to Angkor Wat,this temple gave me feeling of visiting a genuine temple. It looked soo old and touching the inner heart. Marvellous rock carvings,amaging trees over temples,their roots hugging the temple,etc. A must visit place while you are in Cambodia.

Dark Souls revisited. If you like playing video games, the Angkor temples are a great place to visit. Inspiration for many a game (and movie) setting, Ta Prohm was a specific inspiration for Dark Souls. The nature-running wild aesthetic is truly beautiful!

See History being overtaken by nature. The Ta Prohm is one of the several temples in the vicinity. This one is an example of tussle between nature trying to take over its territory and humans doing the restoration work, The trees have taken over the whole temple complex but the good thing is that the restoration work is mainly around those trees which cover a lot of the complex. best is to be there early morning (as most people go to Ankor Wat first). there are hidden caves and underground chambers which are usually hidden from the view but you can explore them if look carefully around. A must visit.,
Nice temple. One of the temples that was beautifully made and crafted. The whole experience of being here was very peaceful and definitely worth a visit.
Unique. The uniqueness of this temple makes it very worth a visit. The trees through the temples make it a great place to explore. Easily my favourite temple in the complex.

Stunning. After a few days in Phnom Penh this was a leafy cultural paradise. We hired a Tuk Tuk for the day (€13) to do a few of the temples. I recommend you get them to start at the furthest point then work back to Angkor Wat as most people do it the other way around and it therefore gets crowded.
amazing. It felt like this temple was in the process of falling apart. The way the trees were engulfing the stone of the walls was amazing to see.

Atmospheric at dawn. We got there at 0530. First on site. Moving and spectacular. Best without the crowds and all stalls were still closed.
This temple site was our best experience of all temples visited.

The Most Beautiful Abandon Place. In the ancient time, Most of the temples in Siem Reap filled up with many big tree all over the building but only Taprom is very beautiful temple with big tree cover. This temple is very nice don miss when u visit Siem Reap

Unusual and Beautiful Place. I visited Ta Prohm on my daily trip to Angkor Wat (Seam Reap Airport) on August 2014.The tour guide that I hired recommended for the time I have visit three temples - Ta Prohm was one of them. Here not only the Cambodian history and lore come to play but also a very beautiful and unusual intertwining of the ancient temple and nature is on display. There are other places where a mighty forest grows through the ruins. But nowhere have I seen o much fantasy delivered by jungles. Sure there are a lot of tourists, sometimes place could be crowdie, you can see people preoccupied with picture taking. Hard not to follow. Hard not to have discoveries at every turn.Angkor Wat temples are very different - like islands of Hawaii - the same chain, but boy, how different they are!I would strongly recommend for the first time to come with a good local guide. Ask many questions - about the place, abut Hinduism, about Buddhism, about Cambodia, modern and ancient. And then you can keep coping on your own.Gennady
Prepare For Another World. Fantastic. A must see. Take your time. Be prepared to do a lot of walking and feel hot. It's like your own Indiana Jones adventure.

Busy, busy, busy. Its the Tomb Raider temple all right, and with that popularity comes crowds. This is a gorgeous temple, hands down, but the crowds make the visit a little difficult. Crowds aside, this temple is totally worth visiting. When you imagine the overgrown, quintessential temple, this is it. Go in knowing that it might be stressful and that there will probably be someone in every photo you take.
Best to see before anything changes. They are currently working on the reconstruction, so it will be different than the old crumbling ruins as it was left there for hundreds of years.

Amazing place and wonderful tree. If you like historical and natural do not miss this place.This is very big temple and very impressive place. This place is one of my favorite.I really like the tree in there it's look so amazing and how wonderful they can growing. I want to spend my time in this place again when i back to Siem Reap
Must see. You have to see it, along with Bayon/Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat. Unless you speak Cambodian, get a tour guide. Ponloue Hip was excellent.

Amazing. A lovely place to visit nice an early in the morning while it is quiet. We went for around 6am which was perfect while it was not to hot to walk around. I would recommend taking a fully charged camera as there are so many amazing sights to take photos of.

Archaeological exploration at its best. If you're a fan of ancient architecture and mysterious structures, you've come to the right place. The temple is in a state of semi-reclamation meaning they left lots of Banyan trees and vines growing as they did when the place was discovered in the jungles in the 1920's. The walls are full of carvings, you can spend an entire exploring and taking it all in but of course there are so many temples to get to. Bring out your inner Indiana Jones at this site.

Still life in the flesh. Yes, this was used for Tomb Raider. However, it's better viewed as a still life experience, pondering on the impermanence of our lives and how nature (and the world) overtakes the places mankind builds to last. As a temple, it is reasonable. As an expression of the power of nature (in particular, trees) is is phenomenal.

My favourite. Absolutely gorgeous and well worth taking the time to go here. Again you can feel the history as you gaze around listening to your guide explain the temple but if you are very lucky, like we were, you can find a quiet little spot and just soak up the peaceful feeling.....I just loved the fabulous trees. This temple seemed to grab me the most. So lucky to have seen this place.
Those Amazing Trees. I was amazed at how the roots of trees had grown through and around the ruins of the temple. After the temples were abandoned, the trees continued to grow and take over.

Early morning delight. Beat the rush, while everyone is trying to capture the sunrise at Angkor Wat, head over here and enjoy the sun filtering through the jungle onto this 12th century temple. The marvel of Spung tree roots intertwined with amazing sandstone architecture will delight your eyes. Loved it!

Loved it!. This was the 3rd temple my friend and I visited in one day. We nearly killed ourselves doing it but it was great. Ta Prohm is an active archaeological site with restoration work currently in progress which I thought was most interesting about it. There were great signs showing before and after pictures of restored areas. I really felt like I was discovering something there. It's also known as the Tree Temple and when you go there you'll see why. Such a cool place!

Great temple. This is a great temple it was fun to find the snake, crocodile and waterfall in the tree roots which were connected to old trees which are now part of the temple. Our guide showed us where tomb raider film was shoot but really so much more to see. Was worth having a guide as learn more.

Pictures don't give it justice. This temple is perfect for those of us who think "Tour This Way" signs are for losers with fanny packs. Plenty of opportunities to explore areas relativly untouched by tourists, and a Saturday in August still gave me the opportunity for shots of main areas without other tourists in it.

Just excellent.. There are a lot of temples to choose from in the area and this is one of the must see. The way the jungle has slowly started to reclaim the temple is incredible, the blending of man made and nature is almost harmonious.

Incredible trees. Besides all the hype of being in Tomb Raider, Ta Prohm is an incredible sight. The massive trees growing out of it is something like I have never seen before. It was fun to walk around and explore the temple's grounds, which is also unlike many of the other Angkor temples. It was really different and definitely a must-see.

Beautiful. This is my husbands favourite of all the temples we visited. The jungle has reclaimed this land with beautiful ornate buildings being engulfed by tall trees and their butress routes. Yes it was used in Tomb Raider but there is so much more to be appreciated here.

Great to see. It was great to see the massive tree tearing the stone apart but it was a little disappointing. It is a small temple in relation the Bayan Temple and a lot of it was closed off. There's not really anything else to see there. You take your iconic picture of this temple and the tree and walk around it. It takes about 10 minutes to see it and that includes the walking. Still worth it!
Lots of huge trees at this place!. This temple is very well known as one of the Tomb Raider movies was filmed here. If you like to take photos, you can find many great photo spots at this temple.

Nothing but extraodrinary. The "Tomb Raider-temple" is something spectacular. The huge trees growing on top of and inside the stone buildings/walls. Probably one of the coolest temple ruins in the world. Lots of small paths and corridors to 'get lost in'. Still a lot to rebuild but they've come a long way.

The 'root' of every travellers visit.... what everyone comes to see...the roots. Beautiful, amazing, eerie, and just mind boggling. At the end of the visit we remember trhe roots more than the temples...and that amazing, easy to miss sculpture of a womans face with roots growing around it..so beautiful.

Great experience but busy... busy.... busy.... Get visiting before it gets too busy. It was fantastic to get a chance to get a photo at this site with the huge trees taking over the temple site..... but it wasnt easy and there were a lot of people around the site which made it difficult. but worth it!
The heart of Cambodia. it's a best place with old sculpture of the King in the past.​ The temple was a bit far from Angkor Wat Temple and it's have a big area of this temple.

WOW. This has to be my highlight. It is just such an awesome place. The trees growing through the temples is like they are reclaiming their area back. I would loved to have been there at sunrise or on dusk I think it would be an even more magical place. Down side is to have to share this beautiful serene area with so many people talking. I strongly advise a visit here you won't be disappointed.

Excellent Restoration. Going into the Ta Prohm, visitors see before and after photos of the restored sections. And I concluded that this is MAJOR work. When one sees the whole Ta Prohm, the restoration is not visible and the restored parts don't seem to stand out from the originals. Only some scaffoldings and planks of wood tell visitors restoration is still ongoing. Other than the main temple of the Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm is to me the temple that should not be missed. It is massive in space, and unique in design. Plus the added "significance" that Angelina Jolie was all over Ta Prohm in Tomb Raider.Angelina Jolie aside, I rate Tomb Raider a perfect spot for visitors and students of history. And photography enthusiasts like me.

Amazing. Words can not describe this place it is breath taking and you got to give it time and not rush through the place. I would like visitors to not scream and shout as much as too many did during our visit. If you have difficulties with walking and "half climbing" it can be difficult to see it all.

Very cool, but I preferred Beng Melea. Ta Prohm was the best temple in central Angkor that gave you that "overtaken by the jungle" feel. As you can tell from the pictures, huge trees have grown out of these stones.However, we had seen Beng Melea prior to Ta Prohm and found it much MUCH cooler. Keep in mind, you really need a guide for Beng Melea, and it's more adventurous (you should be physically able to climb over rocks), but I found that a much better experience.

My favourite temple in Angkor. Just stunning. So many photos opps, the way the trees just grow everywhere was amazing. I spent over an hour here on my own exploring the temple and finding every little nook and cranny.

Very unique. The movie, The Tomb Raider made this temple more famous, this is the building with the in/out growing trees, this temple has been left in much the same condition in which it was found, and surrounded by the jungle gives you a really unique place to be. The site can get quite busy. A must visit!

my favourite temple. Ta Prohm as you will no doubt discover is the 'Tomb Raider temple, it has underground some restoration but is renowned for the trees which have grown through and entwined with the buildings, it is very impressive and makes for some fantastic pictures, I would recommend seeing it earlier in the day as it gets very busy and large tour groups can hog the more impressive picture spots.

Not because of Tomb Raider!!. It's an eerie place, the trees have taken the temples back! every nook and cranny has a plant or tree root growing in it, spiders and giant ants roam the floor and if you can wait for a couple of minutes, you can always get a shot of the amazing natural architecture without another living soul in there. not sure if the same can be said in high season tho.

Great mix of man vs nature. Seems to be the consensus that the trees may well have to go soon in order to preserve the buildings so get in quick. At the moment their intertwining is a magical balance. One of few sites here where colour pics look best

Nature and Man collide!. True example of when nature takes over the manmade marvel it becomes just marvelous. Really difficult to imagine them apart when you see full fledged trees on rooftop. One of the best temples in the area being restored very well.

Very green, beautiful, unique temple.. If you're somebody who loves nature..like myself, you'd love this place..not to mention the fact that you have the opportunity to fascinate yourself being in a Tomb Raider movie!! I personally loved the gigantic trees growing on the temple..there're several "tree-on-temple" spots here that you can witness.The only things that i was disappointed about are..a big part of the area was closed for construction and there's way too many people here. I'd recommend Banteay Kdei too..it is similar to Ta Phrom, except, fewer people and a little smaller.Suggestion - Do not take too much time at one area, the temple is bigger than u think.

1/4 collapsed. Overgrown tree roots. Marvellous ruins!. A real piece of history! One of the highlights but also the most crowded temple among the lot.Negligible climbing to be done on this one and that may be the reason it is the most busy.

My favourite!. For me this was the most interesting and beautiful temple I've seen in Siem Reap.
Ta Prohm is also known from the film Tomb Raider with Angelina Jolie. It's kind of a jungle temple as there are many trees which grow there. I'd recommend to visit it in low season as the nature is even more beautiful during this time.

Loved it!. The temple is great, I went there twice at difference times. During the day I liked the sunlight in the temple better for picture taking, but there were many people. In the morning there were less people, but the temple walls appeared cold and so the beauty of the temple cannot really be seen on the pictures.

Ta Phrom, Amazing........ Ta Phrom is a really great ancient temple to explore. Although there are many to choose from in this area, this one is smaller and very interesting. You are allowed to wander without supervision and when exploring you'll feel like you're a part of "Lara Croft, Tomb Raider" because this is the place. You'll find intricate carvings, trees growing from the blocks of stone and mossy block that really let you know this place is ancient. Sometimes the smaller sites are more memorable, this is one of them.
This temple is amazing!. I loved this temple because jungle and temple are interlinked, with huge roots of the trees growing through the stone, it is so different from the others.

How did that monster tree get here?. Temple in a walled area, overgrown by gigantic trees, very good for some funky pictures. Try to be there early in the morning (ie skip Angkor Wat and come back later) as otherwise you will be queueing for the cool shots. And don't forget the bug spray!

The best!!. This is my favourite temple in Angkor, when i visited i felt like Indiana Jones!!In this temple you can see the best exemple how jungle retake place of the space!Amazing the tree that grow up over the wall

Most memorable. Most popular and memorable temple in the circuit, thanks to the Tomb Raider movie. It is good to see restoration work being carried out now on this site before the temple gets completely taken over by stangler figs. Parts of the temple have been cordoned off for this. Dramatic photo ops here with strangler figs taking over some of the structure. Best to come very early in the morning to avoid the crowds.

Temple with beautiful ovegrown trees. Recommend to visit earlier during the day if you're spending more days in Siem Reap. Otherwise, I would recommend to priority to visit Angkor Wat & Bayon first. Most of the beautiful site for pictures are set up with wooden planks & wooden railings for picture taking that doesn't look good on pictures.. Washroom located only outside the temple, out of the main gate
Breathtaking Temple @ Siem Reap. Trees growing within temple; PLEASE do not cut the trees away (as planned). I love how the jungle reclaimed the temple. Definitely worth a visit while in Siem Reap.

Great place for kids. Great place to visit with the kids! It was extremely crowded at times though and I would suggest trying to go at lunch time (even though its hot!) as it seemed a little less crowded when a lot of the groups were at lunch.

Tomb Raider Temple. One will have THE MOST AUTHENTIC experience of the temple adventure here! The giant trees we see in the Tomb Raider movie are here. Make sure you coordinate with your tuktuk driver on where he will be waiting for you because we got lost twice while looking for our tuktuk driver. They have north, south, east and west exits so make sure you tell your driver where you want him to wait.

A great part of the Angkor circuit. Went here as part of our Angkor Wat sunrise tour. It was awesome with the trees growing out of the side of the temple and would definitely recommend stopping despite the heat and humidity.

Breathtaking ruins. My favourite of all the temples. Lacking the grandeur of Angkor Wat, but with the added attraction of witnessing nature and architecture intertwine. Truly awe-inspiring - and not just for Angelina Jolie fans! :)

nice. beautiful temple but not much to see. most of it is almost in ruins as the trees overgrow in the temple ground itself. but it has a special touch to it and its where lara croft was taken so u can visit it. but the time i visited it was under restoration so i couldnt explore much.

Love the trees. This temple is famous thanks to a certain movie which was filmed here but the true reason why it is famous is because of the wonderfully wild trees which roots are holding together some of the murals and whose roots snake and grow mercilessly across the temple. Truly magical and definitely worth visiting.

Nature and ancient building. The nature is hugging one of the ancient building, looks so ancient and beautiful. Also you can appreciate a tiny sculpture of a dinosaur, you have to see it. I hope you have a good tour guide and show it to you.

Don't miss. Go in the early morning as it does get busy and very hot and humid. It is beautiful and atmospheric.Cambodia still carries a lot of sadness. Almost everyone we met had a disturbing story to tell and would then hold out their hands for money. Even a monk we spoke to asked for money so he could continue his education. It is hard for us to have any idea what life must have been like for these people - it seems the whole area carries the heavy weight of what has gone before, not too surprising. On our way to this temple their where young policemen trying to sell us their hats and their badges, children, beggars with horrible scars women offering their services, everywhere you go someone is trying to sell or beg.I agree with everything the other reviewers have said about the incredible temples, but on the whole we found Cambodia a hard place to be - especially as we had arrived from Bhutan the difference is like day and night.
Great!. This temple it´s so great! It´s incredible to see the trees on the top of the buildings. There is a lot of people and you can get lost inside. The pictures in this place are fantastic!
Over rated. The similar temple Preah Khan is in better condition and prettier than Ta Prohm (made famous by Angelina Joline's Tomb Raider film).

Is nature taking over or is it just a love affair ?. Built by king Jayavarman VII in the mid 12th century and early 13th century is famous bacause of the movie " The tomb raider". The temple is located in the east of Angkor Thom. it is an impressive temple complex where hundred of years old giant trees are growing, spreading their branches over and through the ruin. On certain spots roots are lifting up, pushing the stone wall away. Being in Ta Prohm is just like being in the jungle.

Like being Indiana Jones. Apart from the occasional bust of coach tourist, this temple is a great example of the balance between restoration and leaving something that gives you an idea how time can affect a monument. I love the way the jungle has taken over the place but the temple has been a partially restored to give an idea of romantic archeology from a bygone era. Great

Amazing!. Really stunning - the way the trees are intertwined into the buildings is truly amazing. I loved this temple - it's definitely a 'must see' in my book.I visited on my 3-day 'Angkor Wat' pass, which was well worth the US$40, and, apart from Angkor Wat itself, I think this was my favourite.
Beutiful. Amazing! Large old ruin, perfect picture opportunity! Beautiful architecture and history. A must see when visiting all the temples.

Take out your camera. This is a fantastic temple, with all those trees growing on top of the walls, the roots growing in all directions. You will recognize some corners from movies. Take out your camera and shoot as much as you can. Obviously, getting here in the morning hours would be best to avoid the crowd.

My favourite temple by far. Get to this temple as soon as you can as because it is quite narrow, you will get swamped by large tour groups. We had a super tight time schedule and did the four main temples in 5 hours. Helped we had an air conditioned taxi to take us around. This was my favourite temple because of the sheer size of the trees. My friend felt it was sad that the trees were slowly destroying the temples but I loved the metaphor as the power of nature. Check it out.

Power of nature. A stunning place that has been minimally restored which only adds to the beauty of the site. The encroaching jungle and moss covering the temples all adds to the landscape, placing you in an area time has forgotten about. It is nice that all the moss and growth has not been completely removed like that from some of the other temples as helps you to gain a perspective on what it may have looked like once re-discovered.This is a stunning place to take photos and the carvings on the temples are still quite clear. It is annoying to hear the locals refer to it as the Angelina Jolie temple (from tomb raider) as it should just be known as Ta Prohm and not require any Hollywood stamp on it. A must see.

Feel like Lara Croft. Of course, everyone goes to Ta Prohm first 'cause it's famous because of the movie. But it's an amazing temple in real life; the way the trees grow over the temples is beyond fascinating. Don't forget to take your camera over here.

As amazing as you think it'll be!. First a confession: yes, I too initially solely wanted to come to Cambodia because of the cool temples... As seen in Lara Croft:Tomb Raider. I'm not ashamed to admit it. The magic of this place it that you really do get to walk on and around almost all if the structures. For a British person (where it's health and safety gone mad) this was wonderfully liberating! It's great to see a temple which really feels like an abandoned ruin. The only thing which marred the trip somewhat was the giant coach load of tourists making a lot of noise when we were there. Really bloody annoying! It was very difficult to get a picture of any of the structures without a random stranger in shot holding up their fingers ✌! Definitely worth going to, even if you feel a bit 'templed out' as here you're admiring the power of nature as much as the temple itself.

Best temple in the area. Out of the three main temples in the Angkor Wat area this was my favourite. It feels like a maze walking around and over all the tree roots, and minimal restoration has allowed the forest to run free and coexist with the splendour of human construction.

My favourite Temple. Ta PhromThis is my favourite temple, in ruins enveloped by incredible tree formations, it's a photographers paradise. Even on a swelteringly hot day there are many cool shady spots to rest. The stone carvings are not as intricate as Angkor Wat, but the trees(natures architecture) are just as impressive.TIP: go late afternoon when most tourists are gone. The setting sun casts long shadows that really makes photos look great. I was a bit disappointed we were not informed that much of the site was out of bounds due to restoration. But still worth $20 Cheers Phil

Couldn't get enough of this one!. Visiting the Ta Prohm temple is like stepping back in time. It is humbling looking at the giant roots of the trees covering the temples. A little care is needed while navigating the temple because of the large blocks of stones lying about, but it adds to the feeling of adventure!Near the entrance was a write up about the history of the temple's excavation and it made me really thrilled and proud to learn that the Archeological Survey of India was deeply involved in the excavation project.
Indiana Jones like STUNNING!!!. This place is incredible! Thankfully still despite all the visitors is like a lost city.DO NOT MISS THIS PLACE
Every view is a photo op.. I didn't like the hordes of tourists. I would recommend getting there early when all the tour groups are recovering from sunrise viewings of Angkor Wat.

Gorgeous tree-covered ruins. There's a little walk to this temple (and out again), but the forest enclosure acts as a little sanctuary for this temple; it's got a mystical atmosphere. We were here in the early afternoon, and there were a lot of big tour groups that made it noisy and busy, but the temple itself was beautiful. If I could do it again, I'd try to go at a particularly quiet time to really be able to enjoy it. Be careful not to get too distracted on your route through - it's easy to get lost (although maybe that's not too bad for a while, eh?)!
my favourite. wow!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Trees intertwined with temple bricks all through,,,it was my favourit as i just loved evrey angle...the pics dont do it justice...def worth an hour or two!

Amazing Huge trees !!!. This has to be a MUST see. Seeing how the jungle has blended with the temple is incredible and shows natures power. Even though they are rebuilding it there is still a lot of the original buildings to enjoy along with the nature surrounding it. You can also hear parrots and can see them. MUST see ;-)

Wonder of nature. When set my sight of the area, didn't see anything great. But once you stepped into the temple, is a totally different sight. Appreciated our tour guide who knew the place in and out, you have to see yourself to experience the wonder of the nature.
really great!. Fantastic temple in the jungle, I liked it better than Angkor Wat. Incredible trees growing directly out of stone ruins.

Testiment to History. Loved seeing the difference between the restored temples and this temple still affected by time and nature. The juxtaposition is an awakening to society that without care our past will be forgotten.

A must see!. We were on a tour and found this to be one of the best temples visited. So beautiful with all the tree roots intertwined to form a roof over the temple walls. Very different and well worth a visit!
Interesting place. Has old trees. Lots of old buildings. Another good place to see while visiting. Can be a little busy at times.

Pure beauty!. It is amazing! Seeing the huge trees take back the temple is beautiful. I would strongly suggest going early in the morning as there are very few visitors here then. All the tuk-tuk drivers seem to follow set routes and therefore this would be around dinner time depending on how long it takes you to journey around Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. As we had already been we didn't go around Angkor Thom again and went straight to Ta Prohm. There were about 12 other people there so there were plenty of areas when it was just us, something which would never happen at Angkor Wat. This isolation from other tourists certainly added to the magic that surrounds this place. A must visit for anyone!
Those trees!. Loved this temple because it brings man made and nature together. How the temple supports the weight of those massive trees is beyond me.

Nature takes over. Recommended to visit, as one of the more famous temples not only for starring in the movie tomb raider but for the display how the threes grow on top of the temple. Even though the trees are damaging the temple they have been left alone. Very nice temple to visit and should not be missed.
Go Early in the Morning. If you go very early in the morning (we were there by 6:30 am) you will have the entire site to yourself. Incredible to see the jungle & an ancient ciivlization entwined
Interesting site. Loved seeing the ruins and how the trees have engulfed siem co the buildings. Not so nice having to refuse the approaches of the sellers lining the approach to the temple.
Tomb Raider. Absolutely breathtaking! This is a great temple to hit in the middle of the day because it's cooler with all the plants and trees. Don't rush through it - it's mesmerizing.

Tomb Raider. The locals refer to Ta Prohm as the tomb raider temple as this is where the movie with Angelina Jolie was filmed.The French explorers found this place in the 19th century and restoration works were carried out during the French colonial period. They intentionally left the trees in this manner to reflect what the explorers would have found. For me, I found it was a very beautiful example of how nature gradually took over a structure which humans abandoned, not ruining it but instead adding to its grandeur. The architecture of this temple is also rather different from Angkor Wat's, with more towers and large faces carved onto the towers - generally a very different aesthetic, built by a different king etc. Don't feel like Angkor Wat is the only temple you need to visit. This temple will give you a vastly different experience.

Nature always wins. Nature has taken over this as all other temples. Teaches us to take more care of our temples. In their pride each King tried to build bigger temples abandoning the old ones. Humbling experience.

Not Just Lara Croft. Even locally the interplay between the Kapok Trees and Temple over the ages seems to make Ta Prohm everyone's favourite. We did not suffer overcrowding or too much press of tourism and had plenty of opportunity to appreciate this entirely unique place

Tomb raider temple. Unbelievable sight of the Spung trees and roots growing through this temple made famous by Tomb Raider. Very calm atmosphere in the jungle setting. Easy to walk around. We visited with the one day tour by Cambodia cycling. There were excellent!

Mesmerising. This is quieter than Bayan or Angkor Wat but my favourite. Its a very quiet and special place to be with the most interesting ruins and trees that have grown within the temple. And yes, it also has the famous door as filmed for 'Tomb Raider'.A good tip is to go after watching the sunrise at Angkor by Tuk Tuk. This way you miss the larger tours so you should only share your experience with a handful of other people and spend most of the time with it all to yourself. Another general tip for the temples, buy a book and read the history, take a standard cheap Tuk Tuk and don't bother with the guide. The guides are great but also feel like they need to tell you everything about the temples as you view them. The temples are all so special you just want to look and let you mind picture the past and wonder at their majesty and mystery. This is very hard to do when you are being spoken to all of the time. This is also the cheapest and most authentic way to visit.

All so Magical. I've been wanting to see this place with my own eyes, with my own bare feet, and feel the mystical forest around it, for years! All this time I can already imagine how amazing it would feel, but surely, when I'm here.. everything here feels so magical, I find myself in a constant smile, everything I touch and see here, beyond everything I've ever imagined about this place...walking around here, sulking myself in the atmosphere here, I'm living in a dream!I recommend to visit this temple in the afternoon around 3-4 pm, although sometimes in rainy season, you'll got yourself in the middle of the rain here. But for me, being caught in the rain here for about 20 minutes, so I had to take shelter to one of the temple's window here, and watch the whole temple got pour down by soft rain, sure is magical....

The best in Angkor. This is my favorite temple in Angkor. Arrive before 7:30 AM and you will have it to yourself. At around 8:15, truck loads of Chinese/Korean tourists arrive. Hard to have the same atmosphere with crowds.

Words are redundant!. There actually isn't much to add to what others are saying......it's an amazing temple. It is partially ruined by nature but one can still see and admire it in this context of wild nature. We believe its a true must.

Amazing ruins. While there were a lot of tourists (arrived around 11 a.m.), the beauty is no less decreased. An amazing spots to see that really feels like a different world. Definitely a must see and will motivate you to see Lara Croft again
very good. I like the weird trees there. It's place in tranquility and allow poeple to find inner peace and the beauty of Angkor.
Unique and unmissable. The tree temple/Tomb Raider temple. Beautiful and a defining part of Siem Reap! The ruins are captivating.

Famous for the movie and the ancient trees. How the trees cover the temple and are causing the architecture to crumble is very interesting. It is famous from the movie, but be aware that is small and can get very crowded. Still a definite "must see" in Cambodia.

A Lara Croft experience. This was an amazing site and it is unfortunate that it is known for the Tomb Raider site as it deserves better. It was hidden in the undergrowth for so long that trees have grown up through the buildings. The carving are interesting and a guid helps to understand the place better. Do not miss a visit.

Very Atmospheric. Despite the enormous numbers of tourists that were there when we visited, this place is very atmospheric and there are a few quiet places where you can sit and ponder. I enjoyed it more than Angkor Wat, though that temple is magnificent in a different way.

Other-worldly look makes for a magical visit. Much has been written about how this temple differs from most of the other restored temples in the Siem Reap district. Somehow, it didn't really prepare me for the feeling of standing in and amongst its structure. Erected in the late-12th century, largely forgotten to history and consumed by the surrounding jungle until its rediscovery, large parts of it are now badly ruined. But the combination of the ruins and the jungle make this one of the most unique temples in the world, and brings with it a feeling of having visited something truly special. In fact, its probably safe to say that the more the jungle appears to have grown through or around a wall or doorway, the more intriguing it looks. We were largely the only visitors at the time, and the sound of the trees and the breeze brought a sense of peace and tranquility.Arriving at the east gate of the outer wall, it's a trek of several hundred metres to the main compound. The trail is broad but can be a little flooded if its just rained, so be careful where you tread. We also encountered more young children just outside the main temple compound selling drinks and little trinkets than at any other major temple we visited.
Spectacular. Nature has taken over this magical place. So amazingly beautiful. Wished we went there early to enjoy this mystical place because of the hoards of koreans tourists being rude and loud.

Enchanting. It was drizzling when we got here and rather than spoil the experience, it enhanced the feeling of being lost in a temple in the middle of the forest. It's amazing how Ta Prohm somehow manages to stand amidst the forces of nature around (and within) it.

Amazing to see. Ta Prohm is quite different from the other temples because of the way the trees have taken over and enveloped the walls. It is, of course, known for the movie Tomb Raiders with Angelina Jolie. It is, of course, in much more of a jungle like setting than Ankor Wat which also makes it cooler on a hot day. They are attempting to restore much of it now that it is being rescued from the jungle, but it will take a long time before one sees any dramatic changes. Do make it a must when visiting the temples as it is one well worth seeing..

Jungle Temple. Angkor Wat is the centerpiece and the vastness of it deservedly makes it soTa Prohm however is as they call it the Jungle Temple - very little restoration work and the forest has grown into the temple - it was a highlight to see it!

Tomb Raider- cool. Ta Prohm was an awesome temple- and the way the trees grow through and over the brickwork make it a unique site! definitely worth visiting- we hired cycles for the day and went from Siem Reap to Angkor Wat to Angkor Thom to Ta Prohm and then back to Siem Reap- a great way to get around and I'd recommend doing it this way!
Brilliant. Wonderful place to visit. Better of going in the morning before all the buses arrive. The trees were fantastic to look at.
AMAZING!!!. the trees growing through the walls are just simply outstanding! You will be amazed how on earth that could happen. Truly, you can't outdone mother nature,... NEVER!

Glorious through and through. Go to Ta Prohm! Just do it. Get lost in it's maze of paths and passages. See how nature is taking over the temple complex.By far my favourite attraction in Siem Reap; it's just beautiful.
temples temples temples. after visiting numerous temples, you feel templed out. but this one is great. the trees grow into the stone and its an amazing sight! a must see

'Jungle' temple. This temple is really popular due to the 'jungle' that's apparently taken it over. I was told by more than one person that, yes it's genuine jungle, but it's pretty stage managed. (You need to go to somewhere like Beng Mealea to see a genuine jungle temple). It is a beautiful temple and the encroaching vegetation helps you imagine what they may have looked like hundreds of years ago before there were quite so many tourists! Try and get away from the crowds of bus tours by avoiding the central section of the temple and going around the inside edges instead. Most annoying was the sheer number of people trying to sell you stuff on the walk into the temple. No other temple had anything like the numbers, nor were they anything like as pushy as they were here.

Astonishing place with many tourists.. Best in Siem Reap in my opinion. Walking through the doors, touching the history, feeling the foreign culture here was definitely the experience of a lifetime. But I think it might be better if there are less tourists, maybe in low season. Anyway, top recommend.

Blend of Nature and Human Creativity. Its a small structure compared to other places of Ankorwat circuit, but most beautiful and the nature's beauty is amazing.. The tree trunk which surrounds the structure like the snake is worth observing. It has added glamour because of Angelina Jolie's Tomb rider movie :)
Breathtaking. This temple is purely breathtaking, loved every minute of wandering through this temple. We obtained a one day pass to the temples and found that this was adequate.

Must see. Definitely one of the top temples to see in Siem Reap. Highly recommend getting a guide or going on a guided cycle tour through Grasshopper Adventure (as I did) best way to explore all the temples!
A magic Place. Ta Prohm is a temple wher the jungle has taken over. There are big trees and roots everywhere even if some have been removed to avoid accidents.

The Best Scenery. I love the scenery in this ancient place of Siem Reap area. It green with lot of trees every where you look especially Ta Prohm. Take your time and respect the place and enjoy the Tample and the surrounding. The strange tree was amazed us and beautiful to looked at. We have a private guide so it interesting to hear about this tree and why they let it grows over this ancient building like that.We spent 2 hours here and it so well worth every minute we spent here. So please do visit if you have an opportunity to do so because you will be amaze with what nature do to the environment.

Amazing place to visit. We visited a bunch of temples today. This one was our favourite. The trees in the ruins make it more interesting. It was raining but this was not a problem. There are a few classic photo ops but you might have to be patient to take one without other people in it. We used an ipad app called interactive Ankor wat guide and it was quite good (we did not have a guide)

the marvelous beauty of ancient temple. CC ( 2014.07.26 ) Marvelous.. !! This temple's atmosphere was very strange with moss green. I and my son visited there for trip to there, we were surprised. Strange mood, color was very impressive to us. The ancient temple with strange tree was very marvelous and beautiful. Don't miss there.

Best temple to visit. We spent over 2 hours at this temple alone. There are so many photo opportunities. It's a bit remote so get a tuk tuk. Also watch out for the scammers who pretend to be tour guides.

Stunning. The Indian Government have a team of restoration experts at Ta Prohm helping the Cambodians to restore it. No doubt it will take many years but at ach stage it will just add more quality to this temple area.

Beautiful. If you've hired the tuk tuk driver to see Angkor Wat, then this is just on your ring of thing to see. Don't skip it. To see how nature is reclaiming this ancient city is simply amazing. The trees are glorious to behold.Oh, and tomb raider or something like that was filmed here. Whatevs.It's an amazing place don't skip it.

Possibly the most unique temples for us. We went Ta Prohm because of Tomb Raider. We weren't disappointed. The place was very very special in terms of architecture and also the little things around. There were a lot of huge trees growing on top of the structures, which make some of the best scenes for photography. The place was big too so be prepared to spend a lot of times here. There were quite a lot of reconstruction works going on thou, but nothing too serious that would prevent the sight-seeing.

Amaizing - go in the low season. We went here after Angkor Wat and several other temples. This was completly different because you see the power of the nature. Simply amaizing! I give 5• because we were here in the low season and could walk around relative alone.

Abolutely amazing!. Nothing to dislike about this place. Best and most unique of all the temples. Definitely not for physically challenged people and not for wheelchairs. Ground is uneven and there are large crowds (even though it is not the peak season for tourists at this time of the year).
good temple. Ta prohm temple it is very nice temple in siem reap angkor .it have big tree in side the timple . it have a lot caving on the wall and in side . it is very good temple

My favourite temple. I have been wanting to visit this temple for years and it was absolutely magical. It felt like we were in a movie set and definitely lived up to it's reputation. Our kids loved climbing over all the ruins and tree roots and we took some amazing family photos!

Impressive. This is one of the most impressive temples in the Angkor complex. The intriguing aspect is the way the spung trees and strangler fig trees have grown around the temple. The crowds have increased since being featured in Lara Croft Tomb Raider. It is worth going early to avoid the crowds.
Lara Croft. Amazing view of the ruins. You will feel you are back in time and all those movie scenes will come to life with you as the main star.

Best temple I've visited. Amazing seeing what nature does to stone structures such as this temple.
Its been reconstructered and restored to a level which makes it safe and easier to perceive than a pile of rubble however at the same time it hasn't been modified.
Very peaceful place and certainly the one temple you should see alongside Ankor-Wat.
Tomb Raider Doesn't Do It Justice. Unbelievably beautiful temple. Get there (very) early to avoid crowds and get the best light for pic's.

One of our Siem Reap highlights. Crumbling magnificence, aerial roots wrapped tentacle-like around the temples and trees growing through the roof tops. Mysterious and magical, this is the complex that must not be missed.

Wanna be literally under a tree?. I love sitting under the tree.. Yes literally under the tree's roots. Never in a million years would I ever thought I would have gotten the chance to say that. :) beautiful place. :) must go with a camera.

Very good but don't go during the height of the tourist day.. This was again an amazing experience on our tour of Asia but I will be honest, one of the most crowded places. So much so that we left and came back and went when there was no one about at the end of the day and again the next morning. Lovely place and truly magi cal for young people but get there when you won't be pushed from behind by camera toting mad tourists

Awesome!. This is a visually stunning temple site, presenting many exceptional examples of gigantic trees entwining magnificent ruins with their roots. It's a magical effect. It's so popular that the density of visitors is a challenge - courtesy and patience will greatly help.
Too crowded. Too many Korean tourist buses. No atmosphere.Prah Khan was much nicer! We walked through the forest and enjoyed the private atmosphere!

Jungle Temple. Ta Prohm gives insights into what a big project it is to restore the temples. It has the coolest pictures - tree on top of temple - where do you get to see that? It was a wonderful visit.

Amazing. This was my favourite. The challenge is appreciating the beauty when there are hoards of tourists- there are certain tour groups from a couple of countries that ruin it for everyone by being loud and rude. Most people take the photo to avoid being in the moment and really appreciating what they are seeing. A total waste in my opinion. Because you can climb and explore on your own I encourage you to do so- find a quiet space away from the crowd.

This is my favorite Wat of all Angkor Wat Temples. Known for a movie shot here. This is my favorite wat. Beautiful scenes with trees growing in the midst of the Wat. Be sure and know which entrance you began it. There are three exits and you will never find your tuk-tuk if you leave the wrong exit. This Wat is fairly large and is somewhat easy to get turned around in. This is a must see Wat.
Gorgeous. Favorite temple in Siem Reap! :) The trees intertwined with the temples were just majestic! :) Although it was a bit hot and humid, as most of Cambodia really is.

Come here for sunrise... at around 6am. Might be that you are the only one at the temple. You can take some good pictures and have a nice atmosphere with the forest and the trees.
All in all very impressive temple. You should definitely come here.

Templo impresionante- Impressive temple. Uno de los templos que más nos impresionó en Ankor Wat. Id con suficiente tiempo porque ahí hicimos muchas fotos. Hay arboles en medio de las paredes de los templos, es único. Nos hizo sentir en El libro de la Selva ;)It was one of the most impressive temples in Ankor Wat. Go with enough time because you will want to take pictures in every corner ;)There are trees on the walls of the temples and made us feel like in The jungle book.

This is the Tomb Raider temple!. Absolutely loved the architecture here and especially the intertwined banyan trees! Most of the temple was under restoration but I really loved it! Very green, very mystic!

Trees and serenity. Also, known as one of the famous locations for the Lara Croft Tomb Raider film, this temple is shrouded with greenery and quiet. Large trees drape their roots over the ruins, and it give a beautiful effect of symbiosis between trees and the huge manmade structures. It really seemed more like a temple to the trees as nature takes its place among the stones.

Spectacularly Stunning. This is a simply spectacular place. It lies between the Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. It was originally a Buddhist monastery built around the late 12th early 13th centuries. Now, its simply a stunning place. The mixture of nature and stone is surreal, to be able to be in the middle of that is a once in a lifetime opportunity. The Tomb Raider movie has given this place a sense of glamour, but even without that, its a must see. Too see temples completely taken over and covered by tress will take you centuries back and will give you a sense of how all this must have seen to the first archaeologists on the scene. There is only one ticket for the entire Archaeological Park, so don' lose it, you can use that ticket for all the sites.

The Best of All of Angkor. This Temple is perhaps one of the best in all of Angkor Wat with some of the best photos you will take next to Angkor Wat Proper. Go here first for some great morning shots!
nice temple. temple was nice. but too touristy and crowded.come during none summer months.it gets very hot and many flies all over.

No crowds. Beautiful scenery.. I loved this temple even though it is more damaged than the other larger temples in Siem Reap. There were no crowds while we were visiting and the area is just beautiful.
Ta Prohm - Must See. pictures don't do justice. Must see in person. Bring bugspray. Seeing this place was like being in a movie set.

Indiana Jones Would Feel Right at Home.. Ta Prohm is the epitome of "power of the jungle" because it's swallowed by trees! This temple is mostly a reminder of how the temples looked when Europeans discovered them. The movie Tomb Raider shed light on this temple. Even if you only have one day to explore temples, this is a MUST SEE.
Trees!!. I loved Ta Prohm. We went when there was no one there. It was an amazing experience. Each corner was a wonderful new adventure.

Must see. We had to bribe our way in at 5:10 (it closes at 5:30) because a police guard wanted to go home early. It was funny, and we had the place to ourself and took very nice photos. It is an amazing place. Must see

Great place but overly crowded. The "Tomb Raider" place as they called it. Being here and seeing all the places where the movie was made was amazing. Tons of restoration work are in place, while the danger of the trees and the temple itself coming down sooner or later is surely increasing with the amount of crowd it attracts everyday. Restoration works must continue on but with the major crowd going in and out, it might be a long and hard process.
Jungle, temple, trees. A mixture of nature and culture. The big tress of the tropical jungle having conquered the remains of an ancient khmer temple. Unforgettable!
Most interesting. To me, this was the most interesting temple in the complex. The trees growing in the middle of the buildings were amazing.

Incredible. The famous Tomb Raider temple certainly did not disappoint. Just an incredible setting in the jungle with kepock trees growing all over the temple. Made for some amazing photos. Try to get there early to beat the hoards of tourists.
SIMPLY ONE OF THE BEST. We went twice but in both ocassion was crowed.Fusion between nature and the temple itself!Still it is worth to visit!

Not just Tomb Raider famous. If you are a film buff you will know that this temple became famous due to the Tomb Radier film, however this place can well and truly hold it's own for being famous. The temple is so photogenic with platforms for you to try and get a better vantage point. This entwined temple and trees are fabulous, be sure to look at the details that might be obscure.

Probably The Easiest Temple To Visit. an excerpt from my blog The Mediocre Wanderer: " Part 2 began with another short ride, through bumpy roads, to a temple featured in the Angelina Jolie hit, Tomb Raider. Unlike most of the temples we had visited earlier, this temple was pretty much left as it was originally found, with only the addition of walkways and structural support.Upon arriving at it's gates, expect mini restaurants, sanitary facilities and lots and lots of aggressive, English speaking vendors/street urchins who can't see to take "Ot teh!" (No in Khmer) as an answer. As high as the other temples were, Ta Phrom is flat in comparison. The unique feature of the place however, are the spung trees that have sprouted in, around and ON the place.  As with nearly all the other temples bas reliefs and apsara (goddesses) carvings decorate the walls and columns of this temple. The place is a bit muddy in the inside, with most parts of the flooring, covered in wooden walkways. I must say, the huge roots of the strangler trees as well as the awesome spung tree, have given so much character to this place.After going around the inside of Ta Phrom, be prepared for another 5 minute power walk. I think it took me 10 minutes, as, once again, I was carrying our exhausted child, MAX. Poor Phil was still suffering from the stress of Baphuon, compounded by his recently fractured and dislocated arm. At the end of the pathway, we were once again reunited with our tuktuk."
Ta Prohm - ruined granduer. Very impressive, especially the rebuilt section - rebuilt by the Indian Govt. The huge tree roots are destroying the structure but are impressive despite that - unique.

Truly phenomenal. Seeing is believing. I can't really say more than that. We created a bespoke package through Journeys Within and did everything by ac car with a driver and guide. It was well worth the extra cost. Ta Prohm is everything you've seen in the movies and postcards...and so much more. Don't miss it

Must see!. You need at least 3 days for the main temple places and this is one of them. Have comfy shoes and your camera ready. This is the temple you see in all the brochures with the big tree roots overgrowing the ruins.
Visit early. One of the most exciting temples I have ever visited. Despite being over one thousand years old, this temple is still in great condition and the carvings still tell the stories.

You are an adventurer. You have seen pictures but standing amongst the unification of man being overcome by nature again is incredible. There are feelings of childhood Jungle Book memories flipped with Indiana Jones and Tomb Raider. A definite visit.

Beautifully Serene. Find a nice quiet corner of this beautiful temple for yourself and just sit and listen to the birds and look as you try and imagine how many years it must have taken for the trees to have grown into the temple itself like they have!

Tomb Raider temple. Perhaps what made Cambodian temples famous all around the world – don’t tell me you don’t remember Angelina Jolie chased by stone demons were one of the best scenes you ever remember from your teenage days... Temple wise, what makes Ta Prohm stands out will be the huge trees growing on the temple complex. The roots of the trees growing are so massive and deep rooted, it’s a part of the temple structure now. The temple is undergoing restoration (joint India – Cambodian restoration project), so some parts of the temple were blocked out from public access. But you will still get to see a great part of the temple. Prepare to spend at least an hour in this temple and it’s worth the time. PS: if you are travelling alone and want selfie – do yourself a favor and get a selfie stick! The best 5$ you ever spend for photography. Tip : Before you go and visit the temples, take a trip to Angkor National Museum and spend 2-3 hours there to explore and find out more about the temples and who build them and when. Museum entry is 15$ and don’t forget to get the audio commentary in English, its worth the additional 3$ you spend. To enter inside the Angkor temple complex (which consist of the hundreds of big and small temples) you need to buy a pass. It’s USD 20$ for 1 days and USD 40$ for 3 days. If you have time and keen on exploring the temples, I would recommend to take the 3 days pass and you could take your own time to see the place and explore it on your own terms. Climate wise, July to Nov is Cambodian rainy season – so its low season you get cheaper accommodation etc. Downside it rains some time the whole day. Dec to June is summer time and when sun is out, its scorching hot! April is the hottest time of the month.

My favorite!!!!!. For me it's one of the more famous temples in Cambodia. The surrounding tree roots snake along and down the ancient walls, poking up and around fallen stones and lay sprawled out in all their glory. It feels almost like a Lord of the Rings out of this world type of experience - an ancient city that has surrendered to the surrounding jungle. I felt in complete ore of this place and was under it's spell, simply breath taking. It was magically mystical and I found myself imagining Cambodians years ago walking the same grounds. You will not regret seeing this!

3rd best temple on the short circuit tour. This temple shows what the other restored temples looked like before restoration. It is very photogenic and even has a platform to stand on for good shots. Search for the hidden Buddha face behind the tree.
This is an amazing place. If you want to see the jungle invading the stone structures and feel how it must feel to live in this climate, I strongly recommend this temple.

Amazing. The first day we visited here it was raining so didnt get a chance to look around properly.We returned 2 days later in the early morning (best time to visit i think} and took in the whole experience.Walk around the periphery and climb to the top for stunning views.You must go round the back to view the reclining Buddha on the back wall its amazing.Then walk alomg the tracks through the trees towards the elephant wall to complete the experience.Lots of steep stairs again.Very spiritual
huge. amazing to see how the tree has grown up there. We enjoyed clicking there considering ourselves posing as Angelina Jolie
Love the trees. Not only being the place where Tomb Raider was filmed, I love the way nature has weaved it's way through the stone work.
fantastic, surreal. my husbands favourite and worht going to see, so many camera opportunities and a highlight. would try and go no on a weekend

Awesome, but falling apart. I first visited here in January 2008 in the midst of their latest restoration. It was enchanting. Since then, the trees are taking their toll and much of the temple is now under scaffolding and restoration. It's still a cool place to visit.

Overgrown temple providing powerful images. Entered via West gate and exited via South. Our guide explained history, carvings and layout. Interesting how locals left the temple and let the trees grow (he explained that folk considered the temple bad luck). Could have used some better information boards as you can walk past some key carvings/areas without noticing.
Walking in a dream. Well it's not hard to see why Tomb Raider was shot here. It really does live up to and exceed expectations...a really awe inspiring place!

Great atmosphere. Love this temple complex. Worth heading into the middle to explore all the partially collapsed tunnels and hidden courtyards. The famous trees are popular and busy, but there is lots more to explore.

impressive display of nature survival. I had the first hand experience of seeing what happened when nature decides to take over a man made temple that has been deserted for decades. The trees literally engulfed the temple. Some trees are seen as providing shelter for the temple, but some trees are seen as slowly destroying the temple with its strong roots. Its a work of art by man and nature.
Getting even better. One of the "Big 3".Visited again and great to see new board walks and new areas have been opened in the last 6 months.A must see of the complex

Great Pictures. fantastic place for photos.
many good places to explore and walk around.
had the time of my life here running around with family and friends.
adventure for sure!
Girlie trip. Travelled back with my teenage daughter. Our last trip was 5 years ago and she was overwhelmed by this sight. We managed to avoid the large groups and take some stunning photos.

Magical!. Ta Prohm was one of the last stops in our one-day Angkor Wat circuit, so we got there just as the sun was starting to descend into the treetops. The effect, then, was very stunning! It's as if time stood frozen inside its dark, musty halls. And those huge tree roots, eating up all the rubble, were very breathtaking! I would suggest to visit Ta Prohm at around late afternoon, just like we did, for that full magical effect!

Fantastic place and location. It's everything you expected it would be. Located amongst lush rain forest this temple is a must see . Go early to avoid the crowds. Be warned... It can be very hot and humid.

Our favourite temple. This temple is excellent to go and visit. You can spend quite some time looking around the different nooks and crannies of this temple. The broken concrete and upturned roots of some huge trees make getting around the temple a little tricky, but try to explore different parts, go where nobody else is to get some great photos. A photographers paradise.

Very Very Unique!. This temple unlike others has not been spared by nature and you can see the temple truly being eaten up by trees!Relatively crowded. Our guide helped us move around through paths that were better to avoid the crowds. The restoration work done by Indian agency ASI is simply fantastic and there are pictures showing the "Before - After" comparison. \Must Visit!

Fantastic ruins. I honestly believe that these ruins are more impressive than Angkor Wat! Be sure to go early in the morning to beat the crazy crowds, and the stifling afternoon heat. My parents and I woke up early at 5:00 so we could be there at 6:00 and it was so worth it! Exploring the ruins was fascinating and actually really exciting. This was such a cool experience, and I'd highly recommend it to anyone in Siem Reap.

My Favourite Temple!. WOW! This is by far my most favourite temple in Angkor Archaeological Park. It is huge, intricate and has a magical feel to it. I can see why they chose it to film the movie Tomb Raider. We spent 1.5 hours here but I think I could have even stayed longer. Take your time to walk around and then try and find a quiet place to sit down and take in its beauty. The broken down parts of the temple, the green moss covering a lot of the temple and the huge trees with their great intertwining vines really add to the awe and greatness of this place. I would go back!
Jungle building. Where jungle meets structure. Amazing ancients building being eaten up an (sometimes) destroyed by nature. It's a great juxtapositions of nature and architecture.

Serene, magnificent jungle-conquers-thetemples kind of feeling. visit this place in the morning where thee were still few tourists around. i love seeing this place in the morning while feeling the cold chills of the windy breeze.

Younger Child Enjoyed This Temple. Our 11 year old enjoyed Ta Prohm because he could take fascinating pictures of the trees growing over the temple. He also liked it because Tomb Raider was filmed at this temple.

Iconic tomb raider set. Thank you restoration project! After restoration, Ta Phrom would be more appreciated. Seeing those large trees with roots crawling from the temples is stunning. The iconic Tomb Raider set where Angelina Jolie actually stood was overly crowded with people! She is that famous that up to this date, the movie was really influential gathering hundreds of tourists daily. You're fortunate if your guide knows how to move away from the buzzing crowd in order to appreciate this temple. Although this temple is currently undergoing some restoration, it's worth a visit! This is a must see temple in Siem Reap. Never miss this!

A must visit....its worth it,....!!!!. This temple has the unique thing that trees of white stem grows from inside the stones of the temple. This temple is rebuilt by Cambodian and Indian Govt. So its amusing as there are sign boards in hindi too. Plus the way this temple was built is so confusing that if u r going there for the first time, it is impossible to find the way out. u cannot come to know wat way is east or west. plus they have maintained it so well. ofcourse in all these places, u have to walk a lot but at the same time, its worth it....

Very crowded. The first time I went in the afternoon and would recommend it as in the morning it's rammed with coach loads of Chinese/Japanese tourists and you don't really get a feel for the place. Beware that there are many street sellers lurking at either gate who go in for the hard sell method.

Amazing and so glad they let it grow a bit wild!. Was looking very forward to this temple. Although the major photo op sites in the complex were set on platforms and surrounded by ropes, there were plently of places to see where the roots had overtaken the buildings. Pretty neat little maze of wonders. Although the Tomb Raider movies hyped up the place, it is still amazing despite the heightened expectations! I would take off one star just because the ropes ruining my precious photo ops.

Extremely unique!. Yup, this is the famous Tomb Raider Temple. Our guide brought us in from the back side which was a good walk. There was nobody back there and you get to see the back entrance which was pretty cool! This place is obviously super unique and known for its HUGE trees growing on the temple. We came here after Ankgor Wat so it was pretty crowded. There was basically a line to get pictures with the trees in certain spots. I can imagine it would be less crowded early in the morning. The trees are the superstars at this temple and how they are growing is amazing! It’s very, very unique and a must see. We spent less than an hour here. We had seen so many temples by this point, and we came here to see the unique tree growth. This is definitely one of the 4-5 must see temples in Siem Riep.

look around you. "Angelinas tree" is mobbed with tourists. Move to your right around a corner and there is another very similar and No One in front of it! The whole place is like that, step a few steps away from the crowd and your alone with it all.

A top rated sight for a reason.. A well preserved piece of Cambodian history with amazing detailing of stone structures. As with all the temples and palaces even with crowds still plenty of space to explore.

Eerie but Beautiful. So happy to see this temple. Ta Prohm looks way better in real life vs Tomb Raider! Props to the different organizations supporting the restoration of this beautiful place. This place shouldn't be skipped by any tourist visiting Siem Reap.
Incredible site. We went to most of the famous sites in Siem Reap. Ta Prohm is a must visit place. It is peaceful and really amazing looking at those trees growing out from the temple.

Ta prohm. Ta prohm it is far from siem reap town about 13 km .
it is good temple in sie reap angkor . htis temple have big tree in side ta prohm have a lot of the people go to see it.
Worth the visit. Crowded, hot, got mixed up with the 3 different entrances . . . but the trees and temple itself were worth the stop.
My favourite!. My favorite temple! Take your time and don't rush this one...also please don't be silly and climb on the old stones as conservation efforts are already huge!
Tomb Raider. Amazing temple ruins, but more importantly, the restoration work is simply stunning , a must see, and of course the scene setting of the Hollywood action movie Tomb Raider.
Favourite temple. My second trip to seim reap and taking a friend this is on everyone's list of must does for the right reason.

Reconstructed site with before and after pictures. The site is worth a visit to walk into the jungle for a 12 century temple. What is fascinating is to see the restoration that has been done and to see the trees grow among the ruins

its ok but much like the others. Once again a busy place but to be honest whilst there were some interesting aspects we started to feel jaded after the previous two temples being Ankor Wat and Ankor Thom and we felt that temple overload creep up on us. Maybe the trick might be to space the visits out over more than two days but sadly this one was just ok. The usual hawkers await outside to greet you but no more persistent than elsewhere in the world.It is a much smaller one than the two previously mentioned so the crowds can be more noticeable even though I didn't really find that detracted noticeably from the overall experience, we just got tired of ruins and so changed our itinerary on the spot to see more interesting things. the guide was good and was a wealth of information so no reflection on him.
very nice temple. Ta prohm it is very nice temple .Ta prohm have big in side it . it is far from Siem reap town about 13km. Ta prohm have a lot of caving on the wall and in side

Amazing temple. Beautiful temple complex of stone that is now intertwined with the massive roots of some amazing trees. Stone and wood have become one and it is out of this world. Something to be experienced. Take your time when you are there and enjoy.

The wonder of nature. This is the temple where many "sponge trees" were grown. The wood is too soft for furnitures etc yet it is amazingly strong that it's root could grow between the stones and create magnificent "octopuses"! There are many parts of this temple that is still closed for restoration and according to the tour guide, it would take about 3 yrs to be completed. Many sponge trees had grown so tall that it needs to be chopped down to prevent it from falling on the temples.
good temple. Ta prohm very good temple and big tree . Ta prohm good caving on the wall . ta prohm have a lot of caving .

Awesome Temple aka The Angelina Jolie Temple. This place is a must see! It's got great scenery. It's known as the Angelina Jolie Temple because parts of Tomb Raider was filmed there. This temple dates all the way to 612 A.D. It's very close to see the trees overlapping pieces of the temple. Only downside is that, it is heavily populated with tourists, as are most of the temples in Angkor Wat. It's definitely a must see, if you are in Siem Reap.
A must. Visited here later in the afternoon . No crowds, if fact we practically had the place to ourselves. Truly amazing. If I could give 6 stars I would
Tomb Rder temple. I love Ta pronh temple, it is very beautiful and green because it is the raining season. There are many big trees growing on the rock.I love it.
a must. it takes a whole day to do this one properly. beautiful and many separate temples. We did this after two other temples and were to exhausted to see the half

Ta prohm. You would feel transported back to a different time upon your visit here. Marveled at how the ancient people of Cambodia was able to do this artwork. Very large area to explore. There was a time we felt lost because the other gate to exit was far and very few people visited because it was early afternoon and very hot. We tried to pack everything in a single day. We got only limited time and one day pass at the temples. I suggest visiting the temples on different days to explore everything
"Tomb Raider" temple. Until Angelina Jolie is forgotten this will be known as the "Tomb Raider" temple but she has done a lot for Cambodian kids and indirectly for the temple.
Tomb Raider Temple. Magical temple with tree roots growing all through the ruins! Such a great contrast to the symmetry and size of Angkor Wat
Great!. It is really old but nice building with a lot of trees. Especially, these trees have grown for years then they stick into the walls. You can get many different experience here.
great temple. Love the faces and enjoyed the art work done my the ancient people of Cambodia. Amazing time we had there.

Great Picture. I took many picture of this temple as all the statue is look fantastic that we never see it before in the European country. I would recommend it to my friend to visit here again in December 2014.

A Work of Art. The trees have grown over the temple in a way that is beautifully artistic. My favourite Angkor temple. I was here in low season, still very busy so I imagine it would be hectic in peak season. Bring water, hat and sunscreen. Gets very hot.

Monster Trees and Lara Croft's Tomb Raider. Siem Reap is a historical and cultural mecca for the travelers who are curious of the past. After the great temple of Angkor Wat and the Temple of the Face.i.e. Bayon Temple, the third temple in our travel itinerary is the Ta Prohm. Our guide who was trained as a tour guide pronounced it Tap Room so I was surprised with the spelling which is so local in origin..Ta Prohm. It was a very fascinating temple since one will marvel at the monstrous trees hugging whole walls of the ruins in many parts of the compound. Not just one but rather a good number of huge monstrous trees with roots encroaching in the walls of the ruins. Interestingly, we even found one giant tree precariously in a very dangerously stilted position requiring very tall steel bars to stop it from falling and with it toppling down an entire wall. Although smaller in scale and magnitude the Ta Prohm seems to be quite popular among the film goers. It is the scene for the film Lara Croft's Tomb Raider and you will be transported into the land beyond time, the unknown tribes of generations past and of the mysteries that cannot be unraveled. As one explores the various chambers, hallways and balustrades, Ta Prohm Temple will make you wonder how the monstrous trees have found a home in the ruins and have lasted through many centuries.

Or Tomb Raider!. Very cool place, the kids thought it was very cool since they have seen the movie of Tomb Raider. The temple has been mostly destroyed by the giant tree roots - that date back over 300 years. However there are recently been a restoration project going on and they have restored one of the sections. The overgrown tree roots are the higlights, intertwined with the walls and giving a surreal and fairytale feel - as if you have stepped back into time. Nice place and fun for the kids!
Majestical! The best one in Angkor . This temple is absolutely amazing! It's shady and has so much beauty. Heaps of trees such a lovely feel! Would visit over and over again!
Lara Croft. Its a must! I love the huge cotton-silk tree… and try to find the hidden buddha in this temple! Good luck!!

Breathtaking. Literally and figuratively. Even though it's a straight walk from one end of the temple to another, you can easily get lost in its maze-like structure. No wonder this was chosen as a site for the filming of Tomb Raider -- the entire temple was just constructed beautifully. Of all the Angkor temples, this is where you can see a synergy of the ancient world with nature. The ambiance is peaceful and worth the admission fee of the whole complex alone.

My favorite. While all the others are photographing sunrise, get yourself to Ta Prohm for your first light pictures. So many angles, so many images. The decisions about restoration or keeping the trees in place are difficult. It really looks like a movie set.

Tomb Raider. I like this site best with the old tree roots working its way around the ancient building. Lots of interesting aspects for photography so take time to walk about and look out for detail stone carvings. Also take extra care when climbing steps and leave the flip flops behind and opt for a good pair of trainers.

Mystical magical wonderful. Probably one of the more famous temples in Cambodia due to 'tomb raider' film and it's easy to see why it was used for a location shoot. Again, I simply felt like I was in my own movie as I walked through this temple. The surrounding tree roots snake along and down the aincident walls, poking up and around fallen stones and lay sprawled out in all their glory. It feels almost like a Lord of the Rings out of this world type of experience - an ancient city that has surrendered to the surrounding jungle. I felt in complete ore of this place and was under it's spell, simply breath taking. It was magically mystical and i found myself imagining Cambodians years ago walking the same grounds. You will not regret seeing this!

tracking lara croft's trail.
