A trip to Siem reap is not complete without doing the ancient temples, that is what my friends who have been there would often tell me.As a matter of fact the ultimate goal of our travel is precisely to tread the temples of the ancient gods and goddesses of Cambodia. On our 2nd day after arrival, we started our encounter with Ta Prohm temple, hoping to trace the trail that Lara Croft of The Tomb Raiders once tookTa Prohm did not disappoint us! This temple was breathtaking! Though restoration was going on, it did not distract us from admiring and in awe of the history of these structures as explained by our local guide.Walking thru the temple, trying to figure out how it was built several centuries back with tools so unlike the modern hi tech implements in use today,made me truly appreciative of the high degree of civilization in this part of the globe! The architecture and the artistry of this temple is truly fantastic!The roots of giant trees enfolding the structures was indeed the ideal setting for an adventure movie such as Lara Croft! I would love to retrace the trail taken by Lara on my next visit because i felt i haven't had enough of it!

One of the great jungle vs temple experiences. Hard to imagine what it would have looked like before they started unravelling it from the jungle but it must have been a mess. Even now it still have that just about to be devoured by the jungle feel. We visited in July when there we hardly any crowds so got to enjoy it on occasion by ourselves.

Beautiful and just a bit sad. Lovely temple complex with the tree roots intermingling with the temple but also sad when you see the parts that have collapsed because these very same roots have weakened the structure. There is one section that has been cordoned off because a Tomb Raider movie was shot there. Wish it wasn't since most people who were visiting didn't even know about the movie.

Like Ancient Ruined Temples should be. The eerie feeling one gets when wandering through this temple and the ancient trees are that still wrapped around it is a true bucket list moment. While the Angeline Jolie Tomb Raider temple has been seen by millions on the big screen... In person it is breath taking.
just great. this site is spectacular - you have to see it to believe it. I couldnt have imagined something so breathtaking. We are so glad we hired a guide who explained everything to us
A Must See. Fans of Laura Croft and Indiana Jones should not miss this temple.It is being restored, but the remains of the jungle growth remain to add to the interest.

Ta Prohm with teens and a great guide-shade too!. Ta Prohm is the temple with the large tree roots everywhere and it is very small compared to Angkor Wat or Angkor Thom. Beautiful but crowded. I would love to return when there were fewer tourists. Nice walk into the temple and lots of shade from the Cambodian sun.

A must see temple before you die. I visited Ta Prohm with my guide by entered to the temple from the jungle - great trekking! You can see many trees with hundred years old growing every where on the temple. Wonderful temple! After getting advice, I visited it at noon time to take away from many tourists.
Great!. As in other temples in the Angkor Wat area it has a lot of visitors.One needs to go early morning to beat the crowds.
Amazing. Truly amazing place. Really well worth the trip to Siem Reap and to visit. Pictures from the internet and from book do not do its justice.

wicked wicked jungle is massive!. Awsome.just a heads up,tours come through thick and there can virtually be lines to take a picture next to the huge roots,I say see Angkor wat sunrise,then go to ta prohm to avoid crowds.
Looks like a fairytale. amazing temple, to see the way nature is trying to reassert itself is unbelievable! one of the smaller sites so quicker to get through
Excellent. As a photographer, I loved being here to get the photos. As it was the low (Hot) season, we didn't have as many tourists as I had when trying to photograph in January 2014.
Awe inspiring. Loved it, barely any tourists at this time of year. Kids loved it due to the whole Tomb Raider movie. Able to take fantastic photos as well.
Tom raider. Obviously this site is famous also from the movie. However it is simply stunning with the trees snaking their way through the ruins.
Preferred this to Angkor Wat. The old ruins with trees growing out of the remains is very picturesque and spectacular. Far less crowds too.
Magical. The trees, the history the magic of a palace of bygone days. Fascinating and less crowded in the morning than some of the other temples

Tomb rider 200. Hey Angelina Jolie, not only u can play movie in this place, but i can do it.hahaha.i love u ta phrom.i love the temple,tree when She hanged. Every place was amazedddddddddd....i am next tomb rider....hahaha
lets get templed!!. one of the many sights to be seen, I have wanted to go here since seeing it on tv years ago and it did not disappoint,,,

Ta Prohm. Beautiful again see my review for Bayon as we used same guide. same applies. once again I would highly recommend mrs Muth Phalin , pronounced Pauline Vido tours hired her on our behalf both her and her driver Savie were superb we used them for three and a half days doing all temples and lake village.
mystical jungle temple. Amazing architecture among the tree roots of the jungle. Loads to explore, though can be quite crowded as very popular.
amazing. This place is amazing seeing how the roots of trees blend into the sandstone. This is where Tomb Raider is filmed so got to visit. A very interesting place and popular place to go.
amazing. Amazing to see in real life. Photos dont do it justice. Would love to go back and visit again one day

Trees and Temples Galore!. If you want to see where Lara Croft (Angeline Jolie) shot her movie Tomb Raider, head to Ta Prohm, famously known as the Ta Prohm temple now. Watch roots and branches of trees combine with the structures of the temples, sometimes damaging them! The trees themselves are marvels of nature, with large trunks and amazingly long branches where you would find huge bee hives too! A must-visit in Siem Reap.

Simply unbelievable!. Looking at the trees growing big and strong around and above the temple is simply unbelievable. One has to pay attention and you could find Status between the roots of the trees.

Mind blowing. We visited this early in the morning, 6.00am and it was really worth the early start. No one else around except us and our guide. This is the most amazing sight I have seen. The trees have taken over and at every turn your mouth drops open even more by the sights that you see.

Only thing that takes away is the crowd. All the ancient trees growing up through the even more ancient ruins are just amazing. Unfortunately, with all the people coming to admire, it can be hard to get a decent picture at some points during the day, so if possible try to get to Ta Prohm early, perhaps after seeing the sunrise at Angkor Wat.

My own 'Tomb Raiders Experince". Quite often , when out and about in Siem Reap, locals would ask if you have been or are going to Ta Prohm, then they would so proudly explain of the Angelina Jolie movie " Lara Croft: Tomb Raider".What sights to behold, trees with hollows shaped like hearts, Roots of trees 100s of years old over growing temples and it all seems and gives you the feeling , this is just how it should be.Goddess's and idols hidden in many nooks and cranny's, a magical experience, adult fairy land , so many natural resting and hiding places .

Very cool. This is a great temple close to the town and other temples. Different from some others in that there is a lot of tree growth on and around the buildings. Another similar (even better) yet farther away destination js Beng Mealea.

Tomb Raider. Lovingly referred to the Tomb Raider temple as this is where some of the filming was done, my wife and I loved walking around this beautiful temple. The trees are huge and they have clearly embedded themselves into the ruins. Tourists love having their pictures taken here and thus, worth visiting. Please note, there is repair work being done but this doesn't prevent you from going as the main tourist parts are unaffected.

Avoid the Chinese tourists. This was an incredible place, it shows you how these ancient structures where slowly swallowed and destroyed by the jungles. They are in the process of rebuilding the place which is fascinating in itself. The down side the obnoxious Chinese tourists urinating on the structures, screaming at each other and totally disrespecting the site and the people around them. Just have to pick the right time to avoid the large Chinese tour groups.

Amazing Ta Prohm. It was a very beautiful sight to behold. Man's work intertwined with nature. The site was amazingly spectacular with the old civilization's structures being reclaimed by nature. Yet, nature has maintained the overall edifice though it may have been damaged. One can still visualize how the old world look at that time. Also, in the various edifices, one can see what the old civilization had in terms of their beliefs. A dragon, for example can be seen in one of the sculpted column at entrance area. It's just so beautiful, that if you are an avid paleontologist, it can take you a lot of time to enjoy the area.

Amazing restoration. This is a really serene area once inside the grounds. It has a beautifull walk up a tree lined pathway to the Temple which is in the throws of restoration and pictures of before and after are amazing. The tree roots covering the Temple are quite interesting.The temple is next to an orphanage so as you leave you will be approached by very young children selling souvenirs. They can be very clingy to say the least in this particular area.

Incredible structure that lives up to expectations. Large partly restored temple. Very grand with lots of carvings to see. Great views of jungle. It was very steamy when we went. Be sure to bring plenty of water. Also if you want to be able to see it all then wear appropriate clothes. No short shorts or strappy tops. Must have sleeves.
Tomb Raider. Even though the site is over run with vegetation in parts this adds to the character. A little imagination and you can see the splendour that it once was.
Fascinating. The design, the engineering, the skill and the beautiful results remain as a testament to a great civilization.
Gorgeous Photo Ops. This temple is where you can get some great photo ops, and it's a lot less busy than Angkor Wat. Beautiful, relaxing and inspiring.

The love of nature and man-made architecture. This def is one of my fav temple in Cambodia. It got such a mystery combined with nature, all the big huge trees and roots all over the temple. This reminds of me the snakes encircling it. Simply mystical. Not sure if this temple was Tomb Raider but it sure looks good to jump around and have an adventure there. Love this temple!

Really awesome!. We did all the temples close to Siem Reap and this was definitely one of the best. The places where some of the trees are growing out of ruins are amazing. A must do on your temple trip

Unbelievable. This def is one of my fav temple in Cambodia. It got such a mystery combined with nature, all the big huge trees and roots all over the temple. This reminds of me the animation of Hayao Miyazaki, Castle in the Sky. Must see!
Tomb Raider Temple. Very busy on the down side, but great place with the Tomb Raider Tree and lots of funky photo opportunities

Enjoyable, but there are better. To give 3 stars seems harsh given the fact that this is one of the most sensational wonders in the world, but given the attention that Ta Prohm gets as a result of Tomb Raider it seems slightly unfair given that this was my least favourite of the temples. It's beautiful, intricate and it's so nice to see the trees growing out of the monuments, but compared to Angkor Wat, Thom or Bauphon it was slightly underwhelming.

Don't Miss This One!. This was our favourite, make sure you have heaps of memory and battery on your camera. Suggest you go early to avoid the rush of people and it is much cooler then too. You will get some amazing photos - we loved it here!
Sheesh. What is to say that hasn't been said? A humble wordsmith such as myself couldn't begin to do it justice. Go visit, thats all.

Most spectacular temple visit!. If Angkor Wat is the largest Hindu relics in Indo-China, Ta Prohm is the most beautiful temple relics blended with nature. We walked from the west entrance as no car is allowed to drive through. After more than half a kilometer, we came to the temple complex. We saw huge trees with roots "hugging" the walls among the ruins. These trees might be centuries old. Very scenic for photography; no wonder it as chosen as the filming ground of "Tomb Raiders"!

Sounds of the jungle. We loved visiting at first light as the bird song was amazing in this special and sacred place. We highly encourage an early dawn arrival. The jungle setting is spectacular and you will find privacy hard to obtain at Angkor Wat.

Amazing Trees. I guess everyone knows already that this is the Tomb Raider temple. But apart from that, I was amazed by the enormous trees here. The roots are all over. They look magical. Try visiting this place earlier than 11am. We went there at that time and there were a lot of tourists already.
Amazing ! Wonderful trip to a breathtaking place.. Unfortunately you'll have to choose between low season ( rainy) or crowded season. Don't bother. Just go !

Let Your Imagination ON. The ruins of Ta Prohm will bring your liar mind flashback to the victory of Cambodia reign. Imagine your self as one of the mighty king, powerfull, charismatic and loved by all people.

Heart of Angkor. This was my favorite part of the Angkor Archaeological Park. Going after it rains makes everything seem more magical the way nature has overtaken the temple. The only thing that would make this visit EXCELLENT would be to go after they finish reconstruction.

Cool but small. Go early, here just after sunrise, had the whole place to ourselves and was great to explore without the crowds.
As we were so early, we did encounter stray dogs and while outwardly they did appear aggressive they were not but we did lose a breakfast box!

Aka Tomb Raider. Tomb Raider tomb was good too see. Very unique and worth the visit. Many passages and can easily get lost! (You can get lost in any of the tombs really!). Spend some time walking through and seeing what this tomb has to offer. Its amazing how to think they built this so many years ago!

A mystery Roots. Located Right side Out of Angkor Thom Complex venue; A forest green tree shade cover it all these little temple; A bit confusing way in and out ; There 's an area that some stone collapse; and theres area fully underconstruction of Anastilosis process; The enormous tree roots cover all the temple corridor and rooftop ; Good for selfie picture!!

Holy Jolie it is!. What I liked about this place is the hitching of the nature and the ruins. Located inside a forest and surrounded by huge trees, Ta Prohm is more than just being the setting of Angelina Jolie's Tomb Raider but is truly charming in its own way.

Bewitching!!!. Ta Prohm is serene and stunning. The growth of the jungle over the walls is bewitchingly beautiful.However you can get lost here because of its complicated and confusing system of passage ways since the place is under reconstruction and preservation. Best to have a tour guide who knows the inticacies of the passages and of course the history of the place. It's far enjoyable if someone leads the way with side tracks of history because you will have to appreciate the place more instead of memorizing the passages in the fear that you may get lost. And of course, tour guide will show you multitudes of beautiful spots to take pictures here.And yes, there is a lone carving that looks like a dinosuar, thanks to our tour guide we get to see it and take a picture of it. Ancient khmers might have seen one??? So they were able to mimic it by carving it in the temple's wall?? I don't know. But i saw the carvings and that amazes me.Visit www.tourguideinsiemreap.comIf ever you are interested to have a tour guide when visiting Siem Reap's many great temples. Sun Same is great.I love siem reap!

The Root of the Problem. I'll refrain from a comparative rating of the various Khmer monuments. If they're good enough for UNESCO, they're good enough for me.Ta Prohm differs from other key monuments, in that restorers retained some vegetable matter. The ficus was the great, inexorable, mortal enemy of all Khmer monuments. All temple robbers combined-- from foreign looters to Andre Mal, only come in second. The fig roots got everywhere, and then grew to force apart stones and comvert architecture into ruins. Here, you get to see some of this in action. In addition to mature trees growing out of the temple, there are some interesting and insidious opportunistic roots running along the bases of the temple. Scenic as all get-out, for the poetically inclined, or tree-huggers.

tHE MYSTERIOUS TEMPLE.. True Indiana Jones / Tomb Raider experience. Massive jungle roots support crumbling and exotic temple walls. Best photo shoot along with sunrise and sunset at massive Angkor Wat with guide Lek Krong from www.cambodian driver.com!

Tomb Raider!!!. This temple is absolutely beautiful and apparently the writers of Tomb Raider thought so too. This is the site where Tomb Raider, the one with Angelina Jolie, was shot at. This temple is unique as it seems that part of nature has taken it over. The huge trees on these temples makes it a must see. My favorite temple in Cambodia! A must see.
Dinasaurs??? Really. Yes. There is a spot there that has a Dinasaur carved into the stone. Amazing place. Amazing thing to see. I saw it and it does look like a Dinasaur. Hoax or not

This temple can be confusing - recommend taking a guide. Like my title says, this temple has lots of twists and turns. The really great shots that you want are somewhere at the back of the temple, or tucked away somewhere inside. If you enjoy the challenge of finding those sweet spots on your own, have at it! We were short on time and so hired a guide who was great in making sure we hit all the great spots for pictures.This temple is what many of the locals call the "tomb raider" or "Angeline Jolie" temple, since this is where part of Tombraider was filmed.

Awesome. You must see Ta Prohm, it is awesome. The huge trees growing over the buildings are awesome and wherever you look there are huge tree roots going in and out of the walls. Through each doorway there is something different to see.In one corner we saw a carving of a dinosaur which gave us a surprise. Ta Prohm is definitely worth the visit. I would go back to Cambodia just to see the temples again!

WOW. Words or even photographs cannot do justice to how breathtakingly mind blowing this beautiful place is. Humungous and ginourmous jungle trees overgrow and dominate the ancient temple ruins. Just beautiful and awe inspiring. Because of the nature influence this was one of my favourite temples.

An incredible experience. This place is amazing the way the jungle vegetation had taken it over. You may well have seem this temple in the movies. So glad we included this spot in our 2 day tour of the many temples in this part of Cambodia
keep walking - right to the back. another great site to explore - it seems as thought you have seen everything - and then you keep finding more and more nooks and crannies!
nature and mankind. another must see temple!trees growing on it, huge trees!interesting to see what nature does to architecture made by man.
Amazing. Ta Prohm feels like time travel, or travel to an alien land. We were blown away by the size of the trees and how they have taken over the temple

Witness the Wonders of Mother Nature. This temple is a unique experience on its own, as you admire how the forces of Mother Nature can create, "destroy" and influence the environment. It is probably not as "exciting" as Angkor Wat or Bayon Temple, but definitely one of the iconic ones to visit if you have limited time in Siem Reap and want to visit just a few of the key ones.

Unique. A very unique attraction where tree roots grow on temple buildings. One can get lost in the narrow corridors , much like a maze. There were many parts which were being restored. Wear comfortable walking shoes. Do not carry unnecessary things as one needs to walk and climb up some steps. Keep your tickets well. Tickets for the temple visits ( Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm , and Bayon etc many other smaller temples )can be purchased for 1 day , for US 20 dollars , and for 3 days , it costs US 40 . There are no ticket for a 2 day pass.
Tomb Raider temple. Very exciting temple to visit especially if you saw the Angelina Jolie Tomb Raider movie. It shows the power of nature overtaking the constructions of man!

Best temple. This is my favorite temple from all the ones we visited. Ta Prohm is a MUST because it does not only looks amazing, but you can feel very peaceful around there. Also, if you do the small tour with the tuk tuk driver which will cost you around $15, be prepared to walk and sweat a lot!

Just Missing Angelina .... This is a smaller site, and perhaps that is why it was not crowded. One can walk through some of the hallways (a cool respite), and even run across a monk that will perform a blessing. The most interesting things are the trees that have grown over some of the temple entrances - just amazing to see. There has been less restoration work done at this location, so it gives one a view of what the other sites were like before some of the restoration efforts began.

Worth it!. Very touristy, so go during odd hours, but overall a must-see at Angkor Wat! This is where Angelina Jolie filmed Tomb Raider, and you can tell. It retains that adventurous feeling, even though it's obviously a tourist trap.

Is it a temple or jungle?. Of all the Angkors we visited, this is the most popular and the most photographed, from one tree that grows out of the ruins to another. It reminds us of our childhood fairy tale, massive trees reaching out to the skies and enveloping the concrete, the wonders of an ancient civilization. Flabbergasted when you see them.

Temple. What I like about this temple is that you don't need to climb really steep stairs because I have my sister with me and most of the temples she had a hard time climbing. This temple has beautiful trees and no steeps stairs.

Awesome. Of all the many temples in Siem Reap Ta Prohm must be included to visit. An amazing place. We were up at 4.20am to catch the sunrise at Angkor wot, then onto Ta Prohm and Bayon before it got too hot. It takes about 20 minutes by Tuk tuk to get to the area, we then lined up with all the other tourists to buy a one day ticket (you can buy a 3 day if you want to spend a lot of time exploring the many temples) The ticket cost us $20USD each - they only accept cash and it helps to have roughly the correct amount. They actually take a photo of you and put it on the ticket so no one else can use it! There are many food stalls and coffee vendors in the area so you can grab a bite to eat. We found 3 temples were enough to explore.
The best of the temples. Probably the one you MUST see above the others even though it's smaller. It somehow feels different to the others.

Awesome place. Loved walking around the ruins and saw how the huge trees and roots simply outgrow the monuments. Really feels tiny among the huge trees like Jack and the bean stalk. Also saw the place where Lara Croft The Tomb Raider was filmed.

The best!. Really loved this place - it's so beautifulPhotos don't do it justice Spent ages exploring itThe trees are trying to destroy the buildings - so glad that restoration works are being sympathetic to its history and charm

Gorgeous smaller temple in nature. This temple has gone through a great deal of destruction over the hundreds of years since its as first built through many wars and the toll nature has taken on it. There are huge, stunning trees throughout the temple with root systems that rise above the ground and into some of the rocks.

Trees and temples. Once again amazing how the roots of the trees came up through the temples it was like you were on another planet.This was my husbands favourite place it did not disappoint A lot of walking but gosh worth every step

A Fantastic Temple in the Jungle. We find this an interesting temple. You take a short walk through the jungle to get to this temple. The structures are still pretty well preserved though huge trees with big roots are growing all over the structures. Very beautiful and interesting. Spending 1 to 2 hours to explore this unique jungle temple would be worth your while.

Good one to get up close to. and walk through, but be aware there is quite a bit of construction and restoration taking place. A few bits are blocked off as you walk around.By doing this as part of a dawn start (for Angkor Wat in our case), we made it most of the way through before the workers got into gear. That made it quieter and less busy.Tried to figure out some angles where Tomb Raider was shot, gave up after a few minutes and just took in the pretty staggering construction, - and the ravages of nature.Shame these are all built by people enslaved and dedicated to a dead guy and a bunch of fake gods.

One of my Favorite Temples. Go there very early to avoid the crowd. I like it when it's after the rain or rainy season. The growth of the moss gives it this green effect that is very picturesque. Been there 3 times, always see something that I missed on prior visits. I wonder how the conservation is keeping the trees from causing further deteriorations. The beauty of this temple is the juxtaposition of man made vs the power of nature. There are still piles and piles of stones around given the preservation of this temple has been happening over 20 years. Wear ankle supported shoes. Go off the path a little ;-). Also, may sounds cruel, but I don't recommend buying any trinkets and books from the children at the entrance on 2 fronts: young children shouldn't be hawking and those books may be infringing on copyrights. Feel blessed to be able to see it again and again.
Best one!. Best temple for us in the Angkor complex. Make sure you wear good shoes and maybe bring a raincoat. We did not need a guide, as the sites are impressive enough on their own.

TombRaider. More derelict and a little more photographic than the Bayon complex, this dilapidated temple complex is a must see. Incredibly popular, so get there early to beat the heat and the crowds. A camera here is a must!
Must Go. Came here around 8:30AM, not much ppl yet, but it was really humid already. The roots of this tree is just amazing. Must visit.
Climate but short. Nice climate, great trees but nothing more. Its good to see but short. Its inside the jungle so prepare for mosquitoes.

Very nice view temple. Ta Promh Temple is one of the most picturesque tree temple in the Angkor complex.Originally named Rajavihara, Ta Promh was commissioned 1186AD by king Jayavaman VII and was dedicated to his mother in honor of Prajnaparamita in the Buddhism...

Lara Croft!. Probably the best thing in the Angkor temples tour. Situated at nearly the end, this temple is worth visiting! It's just magnificent on how those trees grow on the temple infrastructure. A definite must for those visiting Angkor Wat. Remember to inform your driver about this temple!
WOW!. I'm not much of a temple fan to be frank, but Ta Prohm blew my mind really! Beautiful little Shrines and Temples covered and overgrown by giant trees, pretty exciting!
Mystic atmosphere. Go there in the early morning. We felt like being the first human beings discovering the mystic place.

Very atmospheric. You can see how this place was used for a film set. Mother Nature has taken hold and makes for an impressive sight. Get here early to avoid the group tours who make it difficult, if not impossible to get many good photos.

Amazing!!. This was the best of all the temples we went to over two days. We hired a tuk tuk guide who took use to 5 temples each day (we could have gone to more but it was too hot). It cost us $20USD per day for two people and was well worth it. He also kept cold water in the tuk tuk for us which was awesome as it was over 35 degrees! The fee to enter into the Angkot Wat Archaeological park was $40USD each for 3 days.
Surreal. Love Tomb raider ?You're in the movie...you are Lara croft! This may be cheap for the culture vulture but it's fun...get over it!

Temple so nice, we went there twice :). While it is Angor Wat that gets all the name and attention, you are likely to see more photographs from Ta Prohm from anyone who visits Siem Reap.The huge tree trucks in the middle of equally large and impressive temple ruins is quite a sight to behold. Plan to spend some time here to walk thru it at a leisurely pace and take it all in.

What a sight!. Temples which reflect the changing religious beliefs of the kings, 2 branches of Hinduism, one of Buddhism all changing with the ruler! The giant banyan trees are just stunning with them lording over the main temples. Proud of the work India is doing in restoring this complex

Where jungles claim back its soil. It was the most immerse temple visit we had out of the whole trip to Siem Reap. Tomb Raider was shot here with Angeline Jolie and when you get there you realize why. Tree roots literally try to smother ruins and temple towers and walls like giant pythons.There are a lot of places to explore and there are many corners hidden from tourist eye.Best place to visit in Angok Wat for educational and photography purpose. Make sure to bring wide angle lens with you.

Favourite Temple. I loved the amazing trees and overgrown roots and atmosphere of this temple. It was very green, beautiful and ancient. The restoration work is impressive, but I am thankful that they have left the trees as they are integral to the experience here.

Under Renovation. Was the best temple by far. No wonder that is where they chose to film Tombraider. Unfortunately, it is suffering from extreme disrepair. They are in the middle of a huge renovation project which spoils a lot of picture opportunities, but it will be worth a trip back she it is completely finished.
Unforgettable. Wow. That's all I can say about this temple. The unique construction and restoration to include the massive trees, is a once in a lifetime sight.
Tomb Raiding Ta Prohm. Likes: To channel the Lara Croft in you, many magnificent old trees entwined with stone temple structures.

Magical. This is a spectacularly beautiful place. Words simply can't do it justice. Like all of the main temples, come early to avoid the other tourists and also to see Ta Prohm in the morning light. Plus, the heat is less and you can get better photographs without a bunch of other people in them!

My favorite temple in Cambodia. I was fortunate to e able to spend ten days in Siem Reap. This gave me the opportunity to visit places more than once if I had the inclination to do so. I ended up visiting Ta Prohm three times. I went one late afternoon, it was nice but a few too many tourists. The last two times I went back was around 7:30 in the morning, which was awesome as there were only 2 or 3 other people there.Ta Prohm is just impressive with large trees and their roots coming directly out of the buildings. Very peaceful and mystical place. Not to be missed if you are visiting Angkor. Go visit in the early morning, you won't regret it!

Breath taking. Wow! You wouldn't want to miss this place when in the Angkor Park. Amazing! The "selfish" trees are all over the temples with their huge roots. Great photo-op. This place will surely transport you to the Khmer era.
Wow, just wow.. Spent a whole day here and filled my camera with photos. an experience I will never forget. If only I visited during a colder month!! Get in early before the storm of tourists!!

Astonishing. Extraordinary .Thrilling .. Some people like the impressive expanse of Angkor Wat, others admire the intricate carvings of Elephant Terraces, some want to find their inner peace in Bayon... Personally, of all the temples that I have been to in the Siem Reap area, the one that I love the most is Tomb Raider at Ta Prohm....Ta Prohm is as seductive as Lara Croft. Built in AD 1186 by King Jayavarman VII, the temple was dedicated to his mother. The trees growing out of the ruins are perhaps the most distinctive feature of Ta Prohm.....When in late nineteenth century temple was discovered by French, they decided not to conduct a full-scale restoration of the temple. The decision was made due to the fact that giant trees, such as ficus and silk tree, were so merged with ancient walls that eventually they became whole. Thats why we can see this unique Cambodia monument in the state it was discovered by the researchers. I felt magic here....

Where nature and human-built structures intertwine to create beauty. As the title suggests, this temple is 'as found', and contains many ruins in the site. Trees can be seen growing above, through, and in between these structures, to create a creepy/awe-inspiring look. This is a standout temple, along with Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, and one cannot afford to miss exploring the superb sights it has to offer.

Fantastic. This is the one with the tree roots. Absolutely astonishing place. Try to get there early to avoid the queues. This is Toruist Central and being a realtively small site it does get quite crowded: lots of folks queuing up to have their photo taken in front of the interesting bits
Ta Prohm. beautiful! went there just shortly before lunchtime and it was not too crowded. lots of shade and beautiful photo opportunities.

Don't miss it. We got here while raining and was an amazing experience. everyone was taking shelter inside the temple while we walked around the massive roots of the trees both keeping the temple together while destroying it.
better than Angkor Wat. this temple is smaller and more intimate. You can walk around it and really appreciate the extend of the work that it took to build. The trees and their roots are amazing.
Very nice!!!. Great scenery. I took a lot of pictures. This place is as enchanting as I imagined it to be. A must visit in Siem Reap.

Favourite temple!. Wonderful temple, beautiful and so picturesque. Amazing to see how nature is wrapping itself around the temple!Where they shot the tomb raider movies for a good reason... its amazing

Worth a visit. Like a lot of the Park temples, this temple is beautiful and fascinating. After all the Lara Croft Tomb Raider temples hype, we had to visit Ta Prohm and we weren't disappointed. We visited during April which is very dry - would love to return here during the wet season.

The BEST. This temple really floated our boat. Amazing atmosphere with the trees so a part of the buildings. We timed it well (guide) and so had the temple to share with very few. Amazing photography opportunities. Way better than Angkor Wat!

Straight out of a movie!. Very cool temple, which has been partially overgrown by the jungle. Looks like a scene from a movie! I actually enjoyed Ta Prohm more than some of the other larger temples. It is relatively small and you can explore at your own pace.

Quaint temple. This tree encroached Angkor temple takes you back to tomb raider.
The enormous Spung trees juxtaposes nature's power to human
Creativity.
The dilapidated crumbling temple is being restored with help of Govt of India, and already showing noticeable change.
A must visit ,very different from other temples.

Really worth Seeing. Go early and avoid the heat as much as you can. Was fantastic to walk around and see. Truly a magnificent site and so happy with the work going on to preserve these monuments. Worth a visit and take your time.

Must-See when in Angkor Wat. My husband, and a friend and I saw Ta Prom during a recent visit, which was our first trip to Cambodia. Thus we did all the things and visited the place you feel you have to go see for sure. Ta Prom had been made famous by the movie Tomb Raider and thus we really wanted to go there. Our guide Mr Mike was great and full of information. We took the usual photographs at the overgrown temple sites, where huge roots of jungle trees grow over old ruins of temples... it's fun and the trees help fight the heat, that's for sure. :)

Angkor Wat Temples. What an amazing historic Temple! I was sadden that my camera's battery went dead and still today I regret not having any pictures from this Temple. The beauty of this Temple was stunning. I was told by my guide that this is where the movie "Raiders of the Lost Ark" was filmed.

Surreal!. Must Visit! Make sure you know to ask for this temple, because it's a little far from the main Angkor Bayon Temple which everyone visits. You'll feel like in a movie set as soon as you walk in. It is breathtaking and interesting with a good guide to get you through it. Otherwise, you'll miss many details that make it all the more special.

Man V/s nature. We all saw Tomb Raider and said wooah what place is this and that primarily becomes the reason to visit Ta Prohm. But whatever the reason it sure is worth a visit. Ta phrom manages to amaze you to another level. Its like man took nature for granted, nature decided to take over, and now live together at Ta Prohm. You'll be thinking of what happened here and how. Its intriguing, spooky, mysterious and marvellous.

Visit Ta Prohm in a day with other temple sites. Ta Prohm is yet another lovely temple ruin that is worth a visit if you're doing the Angkor Temples.This temple site is a part of the "small tour circuit" so you can easily hire a Tuk Tuk and visit this in a day with various other temple sites. We visited Angkor Thom, Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm then Phnom Bakeng for sunset.

Lara Croft feel. For fans of sci fi Tom Raider or just wanted to explore angkor archeological park this temple is a must visit. Walked from East to West exploring the ruins from the sides to avoid overcrowding tourist in the main hallway. The amazing trees that grows around the temple and the hidden smiling carving is the highlight, extremely beautiful work large temple area you will need longer time to explore

When nature eats up the temple ruins.. Super breathtaking temple. With lots of intertwined roots covering most of the temple roofs, entrances and pathways. Very cool temple indeed. Too bad when I arrived in the temple it started to rain very hard which made it hard for me take good pictures of this stunning temple.

brilliant.... Visited Ta Prohm on a recent trip to Siam Reap..I had seen pictures but was blown away to see it in reality.To see the tree roots creeping down through the stonework is truly amazing.Allow time to just wander around this place.A definite must see.!!!!
Tomb Raider temple was my favourite!. The trees growing in, on and around the temples look amazing and make fantastic photographs. Go early morning to avoid droves of tourist groups.

Renovation and beauties. enjoy your time in the temple and understand how the renovation have succeded in rebuilding walls at the entrance. It must be say that the Tom Raider movie made this temple the most famous and if you go there you will understand why by yourself

wow. This is one you cant miss..when you see the roots of the trees growing trough and over the walls, the trees on top of temples...its like you are in national geographic tv. Also look at the bee nests in top of the huge trees... Build by people, nature took over and now people are taking it back. Good they show us what nature can do with this historical place.

A must See. So, my wife and I visited this temple at sunrise. Our tuk tuk driver thought we were crazy going here to a jungle temple where we wouldn't see the sunrise but we wanted to have it to ourselves. Perfect choice!! We had this temple all to ourselves for about an hour where we explored with no one around. It was amazing. The tree's growing in the temple are an amazing site to see. Loved this temple and I would suggest (especially if you are doing multiple days) to do this temple at sunrise before it gets busy.

The 'Tomb Raider" Temple. Very cool temple looking at the various tree and root development over the temple. However so many people here going for the perfect picture under the tree, that you might have to wait ages. Best temple to start with after sunrise.
Fascinating trees. Really amazing how these trees practically engulfed the temples over the years. Felt like I was in a sci-fi movie. Also a HUGE temple for exploring

Good restoration. Construction was in full swing when we visited but it didn't alter the experience too much and it is heartening to see there is a concerted effort to conserve and restore these amazing pieces of history. Less crowded than Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat, too.

Worth the trip. A little different to the other temples.. Less classically beautiful than other temples, but with the silk-cotton trees growing on the monument, it is uniquely stunning. Get your Lara Croft on! Wide angle lenses are a good idea if you are there for the photography as it is a little less spacious than, say, Angkor Wat.

Tomb Raider or not - dont miss!. The walk through the green canopy of trees to the ruins - awesome! Mindblowing to see how nature has taken over the place - again, a must-see if you are in Siem Reap! This was infact my personal favourite of the lot!

Mysterious temple with trees. One of those temples which is a must visit. Cool atmosphere and mysterious surroundings due to the trees sprouting through the ruins of the temples.
Can get very crowded in the afternoons.
very wide place. A so beautiful place where the nature and the temple are really embedded. a very romantic visit that you can plan at any time during the day because a lot of trees are Inside.

Trees Are As Spectacular as the Temple . This temple (aka The Tomb Raider Template, as it was in the movie) is really interesting as the trees have taken over. To me it was the way the trees have engulfed portions of the temple is what made it really interesting! There is a "predefined" path through the temple, but we crossed the rope and explored a little on our own - amazing!Great photos! I suggest going East to West as the temple is laid out that way and you will walk directly into the center.

Ethereal. A visit to Ta Phrom is an out-of-the-world experience and humbling that our ancestors in the 12th century could construct such a marvel. Modern constructions pale in the light of such monuments especially considering the technology we have today which should allow us to construct things of beauty. We should learn from the civilizations of yesteryear!
Be prepared for crowds. This is the most popular monument compared to the rest in the Ang Kor Archeological Park. Worth a visit but be prepared for the crowd.

my favorite!! Tomb raider temple.. Bring long pants and sleeves or you won't be key up the temple stairs! Bring water. Guide or book will enhance experience. I preferred my book. Diy. Biking hard- rent a tuktuk or motorbike ($10-12.) See at least a few different temples because they all are a bit different! Best: Angkor wat, ta Prohm (tomb raider temple), bakheng (views great, temple boring), ta kao (ziggurat style!), elephant terrace, banterey kdei (walk to end to see huge fig tree!).

interesting architecture. One of the many beautiful wats with great architecture and carvings that will cetainly amaze you! it's interlacing giant tree's which have become part of the structures has added much more beauty to the place.this is one wat not to miss provides good photos spots for memories!

A real gem in Siem Reap!. I was just here yesterday early in the morning. It's not at all like Angkor where it's just loaded with people. This place you can actually take pictures with just you and the trees growing out of the temple walls. Fantastic feeling in this place. Not overly large, felt great being here.
Nice and Big Temple. this is the 2th big tempe after angkor wat this is different with angkor temple this temple want to tell us how people living and many army

Let's join the Tomb Raider !!. Because of Tomb raider , because of Angelina Jolie , We must visit this place. to See, to feel the great empire and the temples. You will love here , here is an amazing !!

Great but a shame that they're 'fixing' it!. I've visited Ta Prohm 5 times over 9 years along with the other temples. It's still an amazing site, with the forest merged with the stonework, but the authorities have started a repair program and the forest is being cut away. Sadly I think this is robbing the temple of it's unique feel. See it before it's too late!

Best temple on the complex. Although Angkor Wat is the one everyone talks about this temple was probably the most enjoyable for me. Mainly because it's quite a lot different to all the other temples. Definitely worth a visit.
Out of this world. Centuries' old temples interlaced with gigantic trees, definitely out of this world. Ongoing restoration brings you back down to earth, though.
Put this place on your "bucket list". Will take your breath away...come with lots of room on your camera! Go in early AM to avoid crowds and the heat (start between 7-8 am)
Raiders of the lost ark. Be prepared to be amazed by this temple. Not as grand as ankor wat but with bags of character.a fabulous place for photography.

Would have been 5 stars if I didn't visit Beng Mealea. People come here for the "Tomb Raider" scenes of tree roots hugging ancient walls, but unfortunately a lot of the temple has been restored, and many of the cool-looking tree branches have been framed up by manmade wooden scaffolding to facilitate touristic photo opportunities. The more authentic photos and vibe are to be found at Beng Mealea more than 1 hour away.

Angkor - Ta Prohm - One of the highlights of the Angkor complex. You see the photographs before you visit Angkor and everyone wants to visit the trees growing through the walls. At Ta Prohm you come face to face with the reality and I have to say the pictures do not do this justice. You have to see first hand the way these huge live trees have embraced the man made structures and just engulfed them in their root systems. The temple itself is pretty run down and one of the less spectacular temples but the trees make so much difference. Over centuries they have grown into huge living organisms and the way this has included the structures is just mind blowing. It truly is a wondrous sight and one that no one should miss. Spend some time just wandering around the outside walls too and you'll see more and more examples of how a root has just wrapped itself around a wall or through a doorway and pushed on into life. One of the most impressive mixes of man and nature I have seen. Great also to see the plans for restoration which will hopefully embrace the trees and bring this temple back to life, although life currently runs right through its heart.

Very beautiful. This is the beautiful temple where Tomb Raider was shot. A number of towers and walls of the temple have large trees growing on it, which only add to the exotic look of the temple. In terms of sheer beauty i would call this one of the most scenic temple in Siem Reap.

Amazing Site. Angkor Wat is fascinating, but this was by far our favourite temple. The roots of the trees over the walls and the general ambience made it an extraordinary experience. If you are at Angkor dont miss this.

Nature at its best. Ta Prohm is really a mind blowing experience: just to see how nature managed to interact with man made structures is worth every penny of your visit. Trees mingle with stone from the temple remnants and the combination creates a unique sight that I don't think people should miss. I highly recommend it.
Our favorite temple. For us this is the most amazing temple due to the giant fig trees growing where ever they choose, creates an amazing photo.

The tree temple. I found it to be the most beautiful of all temple complexes in Siem Reap. Ancient trees surround the place and their roots, like a spider's web, entwine the temple in places. Made famous by Angelina Jolie's rippling stunts in Tom Raider, this is a serene beautiful place one should not skip.

Our favorite Temple in the Angkor Archaeological park.. Better know as the Tomb Raider Temple, it was fun to wander through it. We even got lost and had the help of a guard to find our way back to the entrance.

Better than expected. To start with, this temple is much more in ruins than Angkor Wat and Bayon. It has been repaired and made tourist friendly by the Indian Government (a super proud moment for me), and is considered as one of the three must-visit temples in the entire Angkor Wat complex (besides Angkor Wat and Bayon). I would agree to that also. The age of the temple clearly shows in the ruined state it is, it also has a reasonable long walk till the main temple, but a lot to see inside it.. There are trees inside which are clearly more than 1000 years old and it is a sight to how huge they are, and deeply rooted in the temple..

Great Atmosphere. This is an excellent example of a temple where Nature is still the dominant factor in survival. The huge tree roots growing through the temple walls create an eerie atmosphere. A must see in Siem Reap!

,Absolutely amazing. This was my absolute favourite temple. The trees wrapped around the temple buildings are something i have never seen in my life. This is a popular temple to visit though and was very busy in parts. Everyone wanting to have their photo take at the Tomb. Raider spot, makes it a bit of a squash!There are quieter parts though and having a guide really helps, not sure you would get much out of the temple visits without one, as they really do know their stuff and we learnt so much from them during our one day tour.
Tomb Raider Temple :). Very nice Temple. Must visit. Unique architecture. Simply loved it. Don't forget to take your camera for Tomb Raider pics..Highly recommended.
Not to be missed. Many great buildings in the angor wat site - make sure you visit Ta Prohm and spend enough time there.
Best Temple. By far the best temple and so beautiful to photograph, an oasis from the relentless heat. An absolute divine place

My favorite temple in Siem Reap. This is a really cool place which gives a sense of how much the jungle takes over a place when left unchecked. If you go in the early morning you'll have the ruins to yourself.

How the forest hid the temples. While at Angkor you will hear how these temples were hidden in the forests and may be some will wonder how this can be so. A visit to Ta Prohm will show you how trees have over time grown from within the temple walls, their large roots draped over walls, doors and roofs hiding the temple from sight. You need to see this to believe it. Ta Prohm is under restoration but let this not stop you from visiting the temple to see how nature started to take back these temples. A must see on your visit to Siem Reap

must see Angkor temple!. this is the tomb raider temple! awesome to see a temple that has been retaken by the forest again. after seeing angkor wat that is well preserved, it was great to see a temple that was left to the elements.

Giant Trees Growing Out of Rocks. Well, this is made popular by Angelina Jolie in the Tomb Raider movie, but it's also an interesting temple structure, where giant towering trees grow on top of the rock structures. Great for taking photos with you and the giant trees.

Magical. Ta Prohm is one of the temples that is actively being preserved and conserved, in association with India. It was great to see rubbish bins on the approach. It's instantly recognisable and has a great feel, with the encroaching jungle. Well worth a visit.
Worth a visit. We visited this temple as part of a half day tour which incorporated 2 other temples.Def worth a visit.Best to go in the morning to beat the crowds and before it gets too hot.

Anti-climax. Ta Prohm was one of the last temples that I visited and it was disappointing for that reason. It lacked any distinctive features - not the largest nor the best carvings. Even the much touted trees are nothing when compared to Koh Ker or Sambir Prei Kuk.
Go early and beat the crowds. This place will not be nearly as cool when crowded where a place like Bayon or Angkor Wat is more sufferable when crowded.
Beautiful temple. It's such a very romantic and beautiful temple among all. Highly recommended to do the sunrise here that is quiet and romantic.
Great. Luv the temples & the people, kids are cute. Hot, hot,hot, plan your visit for the morning . Have good walking shoes & allow 1 - 2 hours, depending on your love of temples
Tomb Raider filmed here.. This is a must see, since there are so many trees amongst the tomb. They left these growing, but they destroy the buildings. This is the one they let nature go. Very good!!
Fabulous. This is an absolute must see in the Angkor Wat complex! Straight out of an Indiana Jones movie!! The place is such a wonderful and beautiful site. You simply cannot miss it.

Really cool!. Ta Prohm, or The Tomb Raider Temple, is a really beautiful temple left as natural as possible. Some areas are being restored which is really good but it is not compromising the natural environment that has taken over this temple. Large trees embrace the ruins and remains of this 13th century structure and leaves a fantastic impression of the connection between nature and architecture.Remember that this is a Buddhist temple, so there are things to consider, like women wearing shirts with sleeves, so it covers the body. Absolutely worth a visit!

Jungle vs man. This is a beautiful temple made famous by the Tomb Raider movie. So famous in fact that in places, there is a bit of a squeeze with the number of tourists trying to get the "tomb raider tree/temple" perfect photo. We did go in the middle of the day so it might be a lot quieter in the early morning or late afternoon. A must see for sure but don't expect it to be as isolated as when Lara popped in!

Number ONE!!!. This temple is my number 1 of all Angkor temples. It is located on the small round. I even cannot describe it.. but it is amazing. Although there are always many people, you can always get some great shots without people. It is impressive and breathtaking.Some drivers let you visit this temple only when driving a small round. Our driver did not have any issue to stop there and on a small and on the big round!We had an awesome driver/guide, which I recommend to all of you:http://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/Attraction_Review-g297390-d6522493-Reviews-Angkor_Guide_Sam_Day_Tour-Siem_Reap_Siem_Reap_Province.html

Back to nature. This part of Angkor is probably the best part of the complex. Nature has taken over most of the ruins giving the surroundings a spooky but interesting atmosphere. Very easy to lose your bearings inside, but don't worry, you will eventually pop out somewhere.

Tomb Raider and Indiana Jones. if you watch this two movie and you wanna see the real scene real life, then you should go to this places before its vanish from the earth. it is conserve, yet still everything is moving from time to time. i love the huge big trees at ta prohm. something you won't get from other country
The trees take over. This was our favorite temple with trees strangeling the temples themselves and growing out the top, very beautiful and made for some awesome photos

Wow. We were lucky and nearly had no people. Make sure you are there early. Yes, it's famous due to Tomb Raider, but there is obviously a reason why the move was produced there. It's really impressive. What I liked most was the "before and after renovation" documentation you can experience there. They are still renovating it. Could about 90 minutes, more if there are tons of people. You need to walk about 10 minutes from the parking place to the temple

Roots, roots, roots. Go early and avoid the crowds. Once the crowds come, it's awful and you can't get a decent photo without strangers in it.It isn't good for any sunrise shots, but I went early anyway at sunrise and waited for light.
Very Unique. Natures work at its finest! This place is very unique to look at. The tree roots made for great pictures.

Amazing!. I loved how nature has over time exerted its influence over this temple and to reclaim it for its own, so much we went twice. This place can get super-crowded so definitely recommend you plan to visit first thing in the morning, ideally before 8am, when everyone else is finishing up at angkor wat or are still at breakfast. This will ensure you have the time but more so the space to explore all of it and enjoy the atmosphere.

BREATHTAKING !!!. My wife & I were just in AWE of this temple !!! To see the kapok trees intermingling with the structure the way they are is truly a sight to behold. we quickly discovered that april (we were there the second week of the month) is the hottest month of the entire year here. You will need plenty of water. We hired a private driver and newer van (with great a/c) through our hotel, and the driver had cool scented wash cloths plus ice cold water waiting for us. It was well worth the $150.( this included our guide) US dollars for the day that we spent. The surface can be quite uneven and very hard on the ankles so wear comfortable shoes with good support .Beat your chest in the corner of a room and hear an echo . Very very cool . You can really feel all the history here. Don't miss it !!!
Interesting!. Famously known for the film Tomb Raider, it's great to be able to visit there personally. Could be pretty hot!

Great Temple. Tree roots and ancient stone work entwined. Make sure this one is on your tour itinerary. Site of the Tomb Raider movie, spectacular combination of ancient stone work and incredible Fig and Banyan tree roots. Get a 3 day pass and book and tour guide and a car to get the best value out of the visit.
Best temple. Great temple, don't miss it. The roots overgrowing everything aqre just too iconic to miss. Other temples start all looking alike, but this one is awesome.
my favorite. my absolute favorite temples there, it is super interesting and lots to look around and walk around..definitely visit there and plan for at least 1-2 hrs just being there.
astonishing. Step inside and stand by a corner. Take a deep breath, beat your chest and you will hear the whole room echoing your sounds.isn't it enough?

Really unique tranquil temple. Set in rural surroundings with lots of greenery, Ta Prohm has gone under reconstruction in some places. The reconstructions are not noticeable as they have tried to make it as realistic for the time period as possible. There are lots of helpful Khmer people around too who will help you out and point you in the direction of useful things. They will expect a tip though beware, and if you don't they will ask!

Awesome must see temple. This place are totally awesome! Centuries old tree stands still with the temple reminded me about the co-exist of creation and destruction. But then they are renovating it and somehow taken away this special feeling...
Be Lara Croft. A great place to re create the film :) and really feel like Lara Croft!Amazing to see all the trees growing on the temples :) and an amazing experience all in all.
Truly a Must See. I have seen a kapok tree roots all through out the temple. the century old tree stands still. It is really nice to be with this place feeling like an action star- Tomb Raider.

Crowded. Pretty cool temple. I loved seeing the interaction with nature and history. But they have renovated it and taken away some of the special/hidden feel. Although I appreciate they preserved it for future generations. However, it was way too crowded. I think we got there just as 10 tour buses unloaded. We were waiting in line all the time because people wanted to take a picture in the exact spot Angelina Jolie stood (or something, I can't remember the movie). They blocked the way and were very annoying. But the temple itself is awesome.

should be #1. I find this temple ruin a much better visit than angkor wat. Looking at the trees that have grown above, around, and through the temple is a sight to behold. Also, going inside the temple makes it so surreal that I agree why this became the inspiration for the movie Tomb Raider. I disregard all the reviews complaining about too many people, and too many touts. If that's the basis for not enjoying the visit, then do not visit to begin with. I believe the significance of the place goes beyond its reconstruction and commercialization. That said, the crowd in this place is much better controlled than those at Angkor Wat and Phnom Backeng.

laracrofting. It's quite a big temple, we went in April, which meant that we were dripping with sweat. The temple and the trees there was just mesmerizing. once you walked into the temple it was just like you were standing in a movie set or something. This is one of my favorite temples in Siem Reap.

Wonderful experience. We'd seen pictures of the kapok tree roots slithering across the ruins before, but seeing them in real life is quite an experience. You get the feeling of time standing still for centuries. It's awesome, disquieting and amazing that people with so little equipment could make buildings of such extraordinary complexity.

Impressive run-down Temple. The temple was under re-construction when I visited on May 2014. The trees that seem to be stepping over the temple are unique sight. However, the awe factor is not as great as compare to Bayon Temple

A fascinating place. For something really different combining art, architecture and nature, this is it ! Striking buildings taken over by nature then largely rescued and partly restored give the impression of a magical place. Probably best to go late afternoon when it's less crowded - live out your T0mb-Raider fantasies.
Rugged. Third temple of our visit, I loved the photos I was able to take at this beautiful temple, taken over by the forest. A must see!

Magic. There is something in me that wishes all the temples were like this. Some of the others are just over restored. What is pastiche and what is a restoration? For me this hits the right balance. There is room to move around and look at the temple but there is still a sense discovery.Not sure what it will be like when the big car parl being build outside is finished so go now and enjoy.

Must See. Traveling With Baby and Toddler. It was spectacular. Get a guide before hand through your hotel because there is so many things to know about this area. We were traveling with our 8 month year old and 3 1/2 year old toddler. It is a lot cooler here then in Angkor Wat. So If it is a hot day see Angkor Wat first then go here. The trees provide a lot of shade. It's a large area to cover so I would bring your baby carrier and child carrier if your children cannot walk far. Plus, its hot so my child got tired quicker.

A jungle master piece. We were lucky enough to have a guide who has grown up in Siemens Reap so when we visited Ta Prohm (Tomb Raider temple) we were able to explore away from all the tourists in spots he explored as a 3 year old. I love that the Cambodians have decided to keep this temple as a preservation temple and not a reconstruction. The growth of the jungle over the walls and platforms is magical. You feel like you're in another world when exploring this temple

amazing jungle temple. one of the most photographed temples in Angkor, Ta Prohm is famous for its overgrown trees and air of desolation and abandonment. But thats not why the tourist hordes ares queuing up to take photos - that is solely because Angelina Jolie filmed 'Tomb raider' here. However its easy to avoid them and wander around the other parts of the temple complex and get beautiful photos...One other tip - for even more jungle-fied ruins, try Bang Mealea temple about 45 mins drive away. It is basically empty of tourists and stunning too...

This should be # 1...but to each, each their own!. First off, the entire place is amazing and nothing short of spectacular. Someone needs to get kicked off the 7 wonders of the world list and add this place!!! Think about how hot it is in Cambodia all year and then having to build that huge temple. Poor Brazilians and their one statue built over a view to die for and ocean breezes. Are you listening UNESCO?Filmed tomb raider here but it's the type of trees that have overgrown this temple. It was purposefully not restored and it's like being in another time. Great when sun is setting due to trees casting odd light and shadows. Great for pictures.
My favorite. This temple is really impressive. The nature has covered the ruins with huge trees which gives it a very special atmosphere. The kids loved it.

fantastic place - amazing guide. Loved this temple, really atmospheric and mesmerizing. Must mention Viantours here who we booked our day trip to Angkor Watt, Ta Prohm and Angkor Thom with (they also did all our transfers for our whole holiday around Vietnam and Cambodia). Best company we have ever dealth with, efficient, knowledgeable and we had a fantastic day with them visiting the temples.

Ta Prohm. This temple is being reconstructed. We saw men chiseling stone by hand, so it is no surprise that is taking years to put together parts of it. I was so impressed by their work. As for the Banyan tress, also very very impressed.
Trees on Top of Temples. Here trees are more amazing than the temples,extremely beautiful site of huge trees grown on temple walls..
Hot Hot Hot!!!. Bring an umbrella and loads of water. The sun is intense but the viewing is amazing! We paid for a guide and tuk-tuk, definitely worth it.

I felt so small. We were pretty tired by the time we got here which was a shame as it was amazing. To look up at those tall trees literally grown on top of an ancient temple.. it really gets you feeling how old it is. The little buddha face peeking out from roots growing down into the ground is easy to miss but worth looking out for.

Overrated. Thanks to Tomb Raider this marvellous temple has been sanitised and is crowded with people. Worth seeing as part of the circuit but if you want to see a real jungle temple, make the trip to Beng Mealea or Preah Khan

Early morning trip. We left our hotel at 5.30am and arrived at the temple just at dawn was breaking. There was nobody else there, the birds were singing a dawn chorus and created a very atmospheric sound. After 45 minutes another couple arrived and it felt that they were invading our temple. It was definitely worth getting up early to visit this temple in the cool of the day and without the hordes of other tourists. We thereafter returned to our Hotel for breakfast.

Magical!. really beautiful a lots to explore in this temple, too many tour groups was a negative. I would recommend going early in the morning or later in the afternoon. seems that most tours come here around 10-2pm

Wonderful in the morning light. The Temple is located within Angkor Thom, great walking around it - very hot mid April hence I would suggest starting very early (6am) and going till lunch-time if your traveling at that time of year. We were at Ta Prohm around 7am and it was very empty only saw other tourists for the first time around 8am, would suggest getting a guide to understand the site and didn't see anyone to hire at the temple. Ta Prohm was amazing in the early morning light.

Not the best temple in Angkor, worth visiting for its tomb raider history!. This was an average temple but for those tree trunks and roots penetrating into the temple construction. Although, cabbies in Cambodia are very excited to take you to the 'Lara Croft' temple!

Loved Ta Prohm!!. Brilliant, loved the feel of this place, it had a magic feel about it. The trees growing through the temple were magnificent, this may not be forever as our guide said the trees will be cut down to protect the temple. Glad we got to see it before this happens.

So much anticipation, so disappointed. Heard a lot about this "Tomb Raider" site but it was disappointing to say the least. While the root is still there, the tree was totally bald. Probably because it was the dry and hot season.

Jungle sounds. Photos don't quite prepare you for the amazing sounds you hear as you wander these ruins. There is a constant high pitched whistle from insects and exotic bird noises to accompany you on your visit. The Tomb Raider connection means that it gets crowded here, especially around the famous tree clad doorway. Further into the temple you can easily find a quiet corner to yourself. Roots weave their way all over this structure. Everything is at ground level, for some it might be difficult clambering over the piles of rubble everywhere.

My favorite of the temples. This place was amazing. The trees that have grown through the temple walls are breathtaking! There are so many temples to see and this one really has the best photo opportunities. It is simply amazing to see. It is best to go really early in the morning to avoid the heat and the large crowds so you can get great pictures as well as enjoy the scenery without hoards of tourists.

hungry jungle. this temple has been left untouched with amazing views of trees and temple as one. Famous for being a back drop in the movie lara croft tomb raider. this is a stunning place well worth a visit.
Mysterious Temple. It's a special temple with mysterious temperament. Many visitor take a lot of picture here, some people bring some picture which in print on the website before they come here.

Beautiful place but too many people. Its a must visit place as the temple was in Lara Croft the Tomb Raider. It would have been a better experience if there wasnt too many people trying but since it is one of the most prominent temple other than Angkor Wat, you have to tolerate it and be ahead of groups to snap good pictures without having to que.

Travel back in time. Once you enter the complex, you will feel as if you were transported back in time. Huge Banyan trees surround the complex, twisting the walls and foundations a few inches at a time, but the duration spanned centuries already. The ruins were very interesting, and one temple even gives an echo as you thump your chest with your fist. Not to be missed on your trip to Angkor Complex.

Tough Layout. What we thought was an intentionally unrestored state of Ta Prohm was actually being restored while we were there. The restoration, coupled with the size and complexity of its layout, made orientation a little difficult; but, we knew traveling throughout the park meant a lot of walking.Everyone around was hunting for the majestic tree (from Tomb Raider) and it was not what images pictured it to be. Nevertheless, it is cool to see... and I'm glad for the restoration so that those in the future can get a better idea of the original state.If you have a driver, the best is probably to ask to be dropped off at the E gopura and then picked up at the W gopura.
Special place must see. You need a good guide to see the little nooks that have great things to see.Though you can't miss some of the big things especially the famous trees growing amongst the ruins
Very nice. one of the temples you "must" go and in the tourist circuit. I would recommend take a tour, it is more efficient unless you have plenty of time to do it at your own leisure

Another highlight amongst the many temples of the area.. A great guide to pick up about the Angkor Wat area in general - even if some of the tourist information is out of date - is Angkor by Dawn Rooney. It actually has pretty much all the sites of the temples clumped together bite size chunks that would allow you to see basically all the sites in a ten day period. But most of us won't ever get ten days at Siem Reap so have to cherry pick. The main temple is a no-brainer but other highlights include Bayon Temple and this, Ta Prohm.The attraction here is of course the chance to see in real life the sorts of shots you've seen online and in books of the way nature has moved into the temples and the huge trees that have become entwined with the temple. My words will never be able to describe this as well as a brace of photos so do yourself a favour and check out some of the traveller shots here.You will want to put this entrancing temple complex on your must do list.

A must-visit temple when in Siem Reap. When in Siem Reap, there are sooo many temples you can visit so it's good to select a few in advance. I think this one's easily part of the top 5 temples to visit in Siem Reap. Bonus: It's the famous spot where Tomb Raider was shot.A lot of great scenic shots - the huge majestic trees for example added to the uniqueness and charm of the place. I also loved how some areas were not crowded and I could just enjoy a part of the ruins/temple to myself for a moment. There were a few parts that were under construction though, which was shame.Since the area was surrounded by all the trees, it was always nice and shaded especially since it was 35 degrees when I visited! There may be several pushy vendors at the entrance of the temples who will try to sell you things. Just be ready to say no with a smile if needed, and you'll be fine.It's about a 10-minute tuktuk ride from Angkor Wat, and a 30-minute tuktuk ride from the city center.

Natural special effects. Very famous place where were the movie Tomb Raider (Angelina Joly) took place.Magic huge temple and monastery of the XII° century.The temple is completly eaten and devastated by the trees and vegetation. Romantic, wild, amazing place.

A must see!. Stunning place! Although there were construction and renovation works, the place is still amazing! The jungle conquers everything around, even you can hear lots of birds, it is just like I imagine that the jungle sounds like!

Fantastic. This was the first temple we visited during our stay in Cambodia. Due to Khmer New Year on the 14-16th of April the roads around other Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom were extremely busy and it took us nearly an hour by Tuk-Tuk from Siem Reap. Outside the entrance I almost got annoyed by the sales people trying to sell me things and even though I did say no they tried to shove things in my face and block my way in. Finally inside there was not a problem as guards at the gate only let people with entrance passes in.The temple itself is amazing, a lot to walk around and look at and to explore. It is one of the jungle temples that has been restored fairly much and the work they have done is fantastic. The before and after pictures paints really shows how much work has gone into restoring this ancient monument. You feel really small, standing there looking at the giant trees growing out of the building. This is a real must see. Just remember that it is dry, hot and dusty. We opted for a 3 day pass and did 2 temples a day on two different days and stayed for about 2 hours at each temple. That way we didn't get what they called "templed out". We enjoyed the city, landscape, temples and culture and enjoyed it fully. Don't forget to bring plenty of water and protection against the sun.
One of the top places to visit. We really liked this area of the Angkor Wat complex. There are probably four must-see places. Put this in that category and on your list.

Under construction. We visited in April and there was a lot of construction going on. I had been there 5 years earlier and unfortunately all the old beauty and charm seems to be lost. Hopefully when they are finished they will do it justice.
A Maze[ing] Temple Layout. I was stunned by the beauty of the trees and the maze-like structures layout.. This was my absolute favorite temple at Angkor!

A-ma-zing!!. It's hard to describe how it is, it's simply magical and mystical. All the trees that had grown over and into the stone give it quite a spooky flair as well. Would be interesting to see it in the darkness :D

Fabulous Construction. In the whole immense Angkor Wat complex, we paid much our love on this travel site. We got to know this place via a film and honestly we were so amazed when seeing it by our own eyes and touching on its 1000-years-old stand stone. All details of this temple were carved very sophisticatedly and probably taking so much time. it's so deserved to visit and highly recommended

Awesome temples. We did a day trip to the temples with a guide and driver in a tuk tuk.
We had an amazing day. these temples are amazing to see.

Nature at its Strongest. This Temple reminds us all how Nature really controls the World we live in. The many parts of the Temple that are almost completely taken over by the tress are amazing to see. Like Bayon the temple is not massive and can easily be seen in a hour or two. Sometimes felt I was not sure which route to take although there are makers advising on this. There are also Guys in Police uniforms to help but they also sell small touristy goods so not sure what their exact role is !On entering the temple look out for the large trees with several Bee / Hornet nests. We entered one side of the temple and exited at the other end. On our way out we were greeted by several small children selling their goods of carvings, pictures etc. Again one of the must see temples.

Temple with tree growing on it.. This temple is different from the rest of the temple we went. It's unique because huge trees grows on the temple itself. apparently Tomb raider, the movie was shot here. I'm not suprise since its just beautiful here.

Tombraider in real life: Nature overpowering human structures. Ta Prohm is the best temple in the Angkor group of temples! Mangnicient crumbling structures slowly getting strangled by humungous trees! The trees rise from everywhere - the growing through walls on ceilings like a monstrous entity claiming their right to rule.Morning time is the best time to visit this place as the crowds are less and you can survive the stiffling heat. Visited in April so was hot and really humid. But the temple simply takes your breath away. Wonderful place for lots of unknown corners and beautiful photography shots This is the video shoot location for Lara-Croft's Tomb raider movie.Do not miss this at any costs. This one is being restored slowly- the Cambodian and Indian restoration team working jointly are making a valient attempt to restore some glory to this absolute beauty

This is a WOW. This temple is otherworldly. The trees snake inside the temples and all along the ground, making them look like creatures from another planet. No wonder Tomb Raider was filmed here. A must see in Siem Reap.

The Jungle Reclaims the Temple. Beauty - ancient temple, nature taking over, amazing old trees. So lovely and breathtaking. Right now they are doing a lot of renovation, so you won't feel as tucked away in nature as possible, but still very much worth a visit

The one with trees encroaching ruins. This is the temple you mightve noticed online where huge hundreds of years old trees are growing out of the ruins of temples of Angkor Wat. The sights are extraordinary and quite scary for people with imagination. Lovely, a must visit.

Simply Stunning Site. Jungle-enveloped Ta Prohm is one of the most atmospheric of all temples in Angkor and sister site of Preah Khan. Once home to 2,740 monks, Ta Prohm looks much as it did in the early 1850's when this crumbling site was "rediscovered".
