Good Complex !!!. Very well maintained. Good to see the rebuilt done in such a good way for the ruined temple. worth spending time here
Must do in Cambodia. This is the temple of movies from Tomb Raider to Jungle Book, and rightly so, because the place is magical

Tomb Raider. If you have seen the movie Tomb Raider you have seen this temple. It was my favorite temple in Siem Reap. The trees and the stone combine to make a super unique temple unlike anything you have ever seen.

The most spectacular of all. In my opinion this is the best of all the temples. This one is famed for being the site of filming for Tomb Raider, but this is not what makes it special. As you'll see in the thousands of photos, it's the huge trees consuming large portions of the temple and tearing it slowly apart that really create the truly epic site of nature reclaiming this structure. It's much smaller than Angkor Wat and therefore can be much more crowded. My advice is stay clear of tour groups and take your time for them to pass to properly enjoy it. Coming here during sunrise while everybody crowds Angkor Wat would probably work well.

Ta Prohm :). ..this temple still amazes me up to now...the ruins are still untouched but there are areas already restored in it's original form...I love the to see how the roots cover and grow on top of blocks of sandstone temple..
Amazing sight. To walk into this temple & see the ancient ruins with trees growing, on top of & through buildings is simply awesome, nature's attempt to reclaim and a must see.

Favorite temple in Angkor!. This temple made me feel like Laura Croft haha it was all these hallways and pathways between huge trees and vine covered stone walls... it was really cool! I recommend at least 2 hours there. And go early while all the tourists are at Angkor Wat!!

Worth visiting.. This temple is now under reconstruction,and India is helping it. There is no drinking water facility. Walk only in the arrow direction shown there.Or else,you will reach opposite end from where you have to pay two dollars to reach your parked vehicle.

Go at dawn!. This is the temple where Laura Croft, Tomb Raider was filmed. It is largely unexcavated, and the tree roots have invaded in many areas, adding to the mystery of the place. It may not be the most exciting architecturally, but it is well worth a visit. We went at dawn. The light was incredible, and there were very few people there. It was also cooler that time of day. Loved it!

Small temple taken over by nature. This temple was one of my favorite between the temple complex around Siem Reap (Bayon, Angkor Wat, etc). Ta Prohm is a small temple ruin with some huge trees standing on the wall.If you like this temple, you would love Beng Mealea which is located 40km east of Siem Reap! (it was by far our favorite)

Icon Temple. Ta Prohm temple for me was one of the best.Though in total ruin its a great place to get off the paths and just explore. Once inside its like stepping back in time and also feels like a film set.It was constructed by JayavarmanVII around 1186 and was a very important monastery.This temple seemed to have a very eerie but fascinating feel to it. Its best to visit this place in early morning as it tends to be quieter and better for taking pictures.If you are in Siem Reap this temple is a must

Nature in its supreme presentation. To Prohn is so far my favourite temple in Cambodia. I t shows how the nature is majestic and impressive. The trees are the queens of the place, just very impressive. Breathtaking, peaceful...worth`s the visit.

Like stepping into a film set!. Another amazing place, surprised that the authorities allow visitors to clamber all over these temples. I think in time they are going to get worn away with the thousands of visitors clambering over the stones every day. having said that it was fairly quiet whilst we were there!
Nature takes over. Fascinating place to visit. Watch how nature has taken over this ancient man made site to spectacular fashion. You can wander round for hours and get lost in the wonder

Great. Awesome temple and it was cool to see all of the old trees. The temple was being repaired as of 2/14 so that may take away from it a little and it can get really crowded, but its totally worth it.

Rumble in the Jungle. Ta Prohm is quite possibly Cambodia’s best temple. Despite being in the same area as Angkor Wat and Bayon, Ta Prohm holds its own against its more famous cousins. It was built in 1186 and was listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1992. Interestingly, the idea for the video game franchise Tomb Raider was taken from the images here of Ta Prohm.I wanted to arrive at Ta Prohm fairly early to avoid most of the crowds. By Tuktuk from downtown Siem Reap, it took about 15 minutes. When I arrived at Ta Prohm, sure enough the crowds were fairly manageable and I was able to get my Angkor Pass inspected and then able to head in to the temple. There is a long dirt road from the car park into the actual temple, and you can hear the aggressive screeching of the crickets and cicadas in the jungle either side of you, which all adds to the atmosphere of the place.Not long after you enter the temple proper, you can see the famous overgrown trees that have captured the temple ruins. For the tourists, this is a major photo opportunity. Crowds of tourists can always be seen posing in front of these overgrown tree roots, but I found it more interesting to look at the details on the ruins themselves. The closer you look, the more you will discover, especially if you have done a bit of research beforehand.Disturbingly, I did notice a few huge hornets nests high above Ta Prohm, especially in the inner courtyard areas. I did not see any hornets (only ants) but it was still a little disconcerting to see their nests above me as I was exploring. In Sri Lanka at Sigiriya, there are also hornets nests nearby and we were told to keep quiet to avoid provoking them. Here at Ta Prohm, no such warnings exist.Overgrown roots and hanging vines are what makes Ta Prohm so special, and so different from many of the other temples in the Angkor region. Of course, you have Beng Mealea and Preah Khan that are jungle ruins, but Ta Prohm is the best out of the three. It has been left in much the same condition as it was found, unlike most of the other temples here, which have had extensive restoration work. I did notice that some restoration at Ta Prohm was underway, as a joint effort between Cambodia and India.

Just the best place in Angkor !. The walk to the first temple is so worth it, and as you enter you will see a part of the building overgrown by tree that is is so often photographed and recognisable as the 'image' of Ta Phrom, yet the best is yet to come, keep walking thought the maze rooms, ruins and roots of the huge trees that shadow this ancient building and you will be seeing the most wonderful combination of nature claiming back the buildings. A must see at Angkor Complex.

Beautiful. Ta Prohm, the Jungle Temple, was one of my favourite temples. A bit disappointing that there was construction work happening when I visited, but they're working to restore parts of the temples which is great. I loved the trees literally growing through the temples. Very beautiful, definitely visit this temple.
So beautiful and fun. The trees makes this place magical and fun to photograph. Temple pictures ends up looking very similiar after seeing them. This one sticks out.
Amazing!. This is the best are for me in the whole angkor complex. It is like being in a jungle with temples. The trees are humongous. The structures are amazing! Do not miss this site!

The most visually engaging of any temple we saw at Angkor. I loved the way the carnage of rubble and huge trees disorientates you. So many picture opportunities, which are completely unique! You would regret not making time for Ta Prohm.

Very mystical, trees growing on and over temple. A must see when visiting the Angkor Wat temples. One only gets a small idea what it must have been like when the temples were discovered in the 19th century. There are still some trees that have grown on and over the temple. It does get, of course, very crowded with hordes of tourists, but it's still worth seeing. And if you are a bit patient and seek the odd location one can get some incredible shots.
One of the 3 temples you can not miss. This temple speaks for itself, it is one of the main 3 in Siem Reap, you can not miss out on seeing it.
Surreal trees add mystique. This is such a surreal temple. The trees growing out of the temples are truly amazing. The roots are huge and look like giant serpents. This is an unmissable temple.

Incredible Jungle Temple. Our guide took us to visit Ta Prohm during a quiet period of the day to avoid the big crowds. This temple is well known as it was featured in the movie 'Tomb Raiders' starring Angelina Jolie. It has a jungle atmosphere as it is only partially cleared of overgrowth with massive fig trees growing from the towers and corridors of the temple so there is plenty of opportunities to get good 'tree-in-temple' photos which is a feature of this temple.

Used to love it. Again, lots of restorarion works underway. I am not sure if people want to see a restored temple, which cost lots of money, and after a while, you get tired of hearing the same story - the Sri Rama epic, the Hindu and the Buddha teachings, the Apsara dancers, the list goes on. It is an attraction itself to see how nature and lack of care caused the temple walls to crumble. In my personal view, the money is best used to give compulsory education and basic food to the kids.

An absolute must - Dissapointed not to see Lara. Whilst under severe renovation, this is must if you do not plan to visit all/many temples. Both our kids loved it . With two kids, 8&11 we only did 2/3 temples each visit, plus it's very hot, living in Singapore, I thought it would be fine - much hotter
Amazing. World heritage and nature monument in one.For me the most impressing temple after Angkor Wat as the highlight.
Trees .... We went here because tomb raider shoot here.and its a long walk,many stones are cramped but they are into construction nowadays.but you still see the beauty of the place.

Incredible. Our tour guide took us to the temple around 10:30, and there weren't lots of people crowding around. The temple is where they filmed the movie "Tomb Raider" starring Angelina Jolie. The trees grow all over the temples, including on top, and squeeze through some of the stones. This temple is an amazing mix of nature and architecture, and it's still stunning to see how the two live in harmony. You can't miss this temple.

Best Of The Bunch In Angkor. My 5th visit to Ta Prohm. It is a most remarkable spot. Tomb Raider vibe when the place isn't jammed with tourists. Remarkable carvings and lots of dark places to scramble around in. A more personal experience than the more famous Angkor Wat. Kids selling postcards in the parking lot are a minor hassle. If I was only allowed to see one temple this would be it.I strongly advise anybody visiting Ta Prohm to get here as early as possible. I went at 5:30 this morning and had the place to myself for an hour. Temps are cool and no package tourists to fight your way through. They generally will not show up till around 9 AM.

Very interesting. Our guide collected us from our hotel at 05:30 so that we could visit this temple before the huge crowds (which other reviewers complain about). It is a stunning place. It is particularly interesting specifically because the jungle is taking over again. There are so many trees which are growing through the ruins - it is very haunting, especially as the sun rises. You are advised to follow our lead and go before the crowds (and of course before the heat).

Another must see ruins, although Benteay Melea is a good alternative. Most people visit this section of Angkor Wat Park, and thus can be overwhelmed with tourists. In saying that if you pick a good guide for a day trip he can usually arrange visits to most of the popular temples on the "quiet-ish" times, including this one. It is a remarkable site, seeing the strangling figs reclaiming the ruins (but Benteay Melea is also just as good, quieter but much further outside of town - a good 1/2 day trip is needed plus additional entrance fees....but worthwhile).A definite must do / place to visit whilst in the Angkor Wat Park.

Fantastic a step back in Time. From the moment you walk in the gates you follow a dirt path to the Temple, And instantly are met with an ancient tree engulfed in the ruins. The whole temple can take a few hours to walk around properly and go early around 6-7 am While Angkor Wat is being invaded by tourists I was the 2nd person at the site for the first 40 minutes so I had the opportunity to get some great photos.

Excellent. Rode here on bicycle as part of the 30k Temple circuit. All the Temples were amazing.Surprised that you could go anywhere you wanted including clambering over the ruins - health and safety would have a fit in New Zealand looking at all the loose stone!!
Temple in Jungle Setting. Fantastic evocative the Kapok trees covers this Temple complex. Don't miss the Hall of Dancers photograph opportunities abound on every corner.

Good Temple. Upon entering the gate, you need to walk about 300 meters before reaching the temple. There are blind musicians along the way, children selling key chains and souvenir items. As compared to other temples, most of the Ta Prohm temples are with large trees. The trees are so hard that they can displace the ruins. We took a lot of pictures in this area. It is worth a visit.
great. Another great temple. Some of the temples in Angkor have really steep steps so be careful. They all are very good and worth a visit.

Tomb Raiders. Our teenage kids really enjoyed this temple, once I told them it was the location for tomb raider and it's where Lara Croft lived. It's an amazing temple, slowly being reclaimed by the jungle. Our tuk tuk driver, Mr Mean, was brilliant. He dropped us off at one gate and picked us from the other.

big trees and big roots. Incredible big trees are around this place. Some buildings are covered by very big roots. Sure, you will enjoy those trees and ruins which have to remind yourself that there are many places waiting your visit.

Fabulous atmosphere. The feeling created by the overgrown nature of the place and the intertwining fo the intricately hewn temple and snake-like roots of the trees is quite as special as its reputation would have it. I hope they don't do too much more restoration, but just try to keep it stable.
Natural destruction. Trees within the temples, temples within the trees. Whichever it is, make sure you go. I hope the currently ongoing renovations do it justice.

Favorite temple. This was my absolute favorite temple of those we visited. Though an important site historically, what I really enjoyed was walking through the jungle and seeing how nature has intertwined with the temple. Very peaceful, despite the other tourists.

The Temple of Trees. We were given the best tour by an older gentleman Prohm (named after temple) after I had asked if I could take his photo. He was justing sitting there talking to another older man. Prohm showed us the best spots to take photos and explained the history of this temple. The trees are amazing with their roots growing over the temple rocks. A must see temple if like us you have limited time.
marvelous. the trees intertwined with the ruins make it really unique and one of my favorite places. The further you visit the more interesting it becomes.

Better then Tomb Raider!!. This historic and scenic site was breathtaking. It felt like an endless maze with tree root's ingrown everywhere. The locals told me there was no public access for two months when they were filming Tomb Raider however when you look at the movie there were very few scenes actually filmed in Ta Prohm. A lot of the scenes were built on set in Hollywood. You can get to Ta Prohm from your hotel (usually all located on the hotel strip) via a tuk tuk. I stayed at Lotus Blanc. Not sure how much tuk tuk would have cost. My cousin and I hired a driver with an english tour guide via the hotel. We called around for private tour guides to compare prices and the hotel does offer competitive pricing so we just booked via the hotel. The price of an English translator was US$30 and the car rental US$35. This does not include the admission pass which is US$40 and tip for the driver and translator. Also you may want to make sure you have US$1 bills on you as there are a lot of kids wandering the streets trying to sell tourists post cards, bracelets, etc. They are really too cute to turn away. $1 can go along way for them.

Angkor trip Feb14. Reason for visit is to see the white trees growing over the walls, the roots covering the ruins. Locals call them 'holy trees' (eavesdrop from the many local guides there). Reminds me of the 'White Tree' in LOTR: Return of the King but many times larger & sturdier!

Another do no miss Temple. Another incredible site and so lucky to have seen it. Amazing restoration work ( ongoing) and original buildings basically held up by trees that have rooted and grown over the centuries

A dinosaur?. Wow, this was a real 'jungle takes over' moment. The roots of trees wound around the temple, some looked like an elephants trunk, others a snake, what is for certain is that this temple has been swallowed / strangled by the jungle. The carvings included some more unusual ones such as two women pounding rice and a dinosaur. Yes that's right. Not sure what species, (my guide did not know either), and of course there is s the Angelina Tomb Raider tree where everyone stopped for a pose.

Words don't do it justice. Angkor and its surrounding temples are beyond words...such beauty and life within ruins. The most disappointing thing about visiting the temples is the hordes of tourists. Get there as early as possible. Tourists, especially tired tourists are horribly grumpy and seem to forget that we are guests of another nation... if i find people being disrespectful, or idiots, i'll pull them up on it. You should too. ; )

Interesting and more authentic - with Stegosaurus!. An interesting more authentic temple as some of the ruins are left as they were. One often overlooked aspect is that among the reliefs of monkeys, buffalo, pigs, etc... is a relief of what appears to be a Stegosaurus! Of course as it is said that dinosaurs were not known about until the 1800s, how did these people several hundreds of years ago know the Stegosaurus ever existed, unless they perhaps saw one? This is being debated amongst creationists and evolutionists, some who think the relief is just a hedgehog in front of a bush. It is located is towards the front gate and you can ask the guides where the "dinosaur" is.

Incredible nature over man. I came here one year later after my first visit, and I was not disappointed again. The temple shows the terrific strength of nature over the work of man throughout the centuries. Muscular root prevailing over carefully laid structures, so many excellent photo opportunities. The time of the day was reasonable too, I was there by 9.30am, not too many people yet, unfortunately it sees hords of tourists, but with careful planning, you can still enjoy your visit early in the morning. There is a lot of restoration work in progress, be careful. Wear good trekking shoes, it's easy to twist your ankles on all those fallen stones.

Amazing temple taken over by the jungle!. It's a beautiful, shady temple with trees growing out and over the walls. Much restoration has gone on so the statues and carvings can be accessed and viewed. The shady canopy and smaller size lets you get around quickly and all he Buddha faces are amazing. This place should definitely be on your to-see list! Our guide even met Angelina Jolie when the were filming Tomb Raider there.
The Indiana Jones temple. An absolutely must do - simply the best temple at Angkor Wat. The mix of trees and temples gives the best photo opps imaginable
This is where Tomb Raider took a few scenes. One of the must see other than Bayon Temple and Angkor Wat. The tree blending with the archeology site/temple is awesome.

Tomb Raider!. some portions of Angie's film were shot here... it was indeed an unforgettable experience exploring this jungle temple... huge trees with their monstrous roots embrace the entire temple area... wooden path are provided for visitors to get inside and out of the intricate temple... when you go there, you should never miss the peeping prisoner of the trees... :)

Somewhat Less Than Expected. Maybe we should have visited this temple first. Instead we spent Day 1 touring some truly magnificent temple grounds in the Siem Reap area, thinking we were saving the best for last. With all the hype about Angelina Jolie filming Tomb Raider here, expectations were high. Then, after seeing Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat, this didn't compare.We were more blown away by the astonishing trees growing here, that have trunks twenty times the size of human girth and tower 100 feet into the air. Trees are so gargantuan that the expanding root systems dislodge a 20 ton section of wall like it's made of Legos.The temple itself is in varying states of crumbling and restoration. The restoration effort has included cutting away some of the towering flora that had swallowed the structure for hundreds of years. Piles of fallen stone blocks clutter the grounds everywhere, as do visible steel and wood support beams where renovation is going on. It's a mess, so tread very carefully.You can get a bit of an idea what the temple looked like in its glory, in a few small sections where a restoration team from India worked for three years. Otherwise it looks like a pile of rubble with trees growing through the walls.Ta Phrom is in use as a temple again and, in a few areas, headless Buddhas are posed for the faithful. Both men and women are expected to wear respectful clothing (no bare shoulders, midriff, cleavage, short shorts or dresses) but, unlike the other temples, I didn't see any enforcement here.Don't go between 11-3. Though the area is heavily shaded, the heat is incredibly intense, even in early April.You'll be absolutely barraged at the entrance with a throng of locals hawking scarves, T-shirts, postcards, cold drinks, etc. They don't accept no for an answer, so be prepared. I thought one woman was going to finally grab my husband's leg when our tuk tuk was pulling away. Admission is $20 per day to experience ALL temples in the area (or $40 for a 3-day pass.) You can't possibly see them all in a day, so get the multi-pass. You can't buy a partially used pass from another tourist because yours is personalized with a photo ID at purchase.I'd recommend seeing this temple first and building your experience from there.
Like walking in a dream. This is the quintessential Angkor Wat site. Trees growing out of the buildings, you can see just how the jungle took over. Well worth the visit
Eerie temple. Beautiful temple from Tomb Raiders covered in trees and roots. Breathtakinly eerie! It was my favorite temple. Not too many steps to climb.

Easily the best temple. This was easiest the best temple at Angkor. We got there just after sunrise with very few other tourists. It had a magical feel to it and loved that it had been taken over by the trees and nature in parts. I could have spent most of the day there!

A tad disappointing. Ah, please don't hate me, but I am disappointed by this temple. I was blown away by Angkor Wat and Bayon but this one, was a let down a little bit. Yes, I was impressed and in awe by how nature intertwined with the temple. But perhaps with all the construction going on, it got in the way of experiencing this temple at its very best.
Unreal. Go early before the crowds. Even if you haven't seen the film ( as we haven't) you can use your own imagination to be an explorer too. I felt very emotional through the visit
La Croft temple. You get to see the famous tree that Angelina Jolie was filmed at. But there are some restoration works going on. But still got to see the most impt part of the temple

Atmospheric, yes, but somewhat less impressive - Ta Prohm. Ta Prohm is the temple - besides the association with Tomb Raider - where nature and human monuments are locked in a struggle, making for an atmospheric scene. The size of those trees are simply stupendous! The roots are muscular in appearance, splitting apart the carefully-laid stones of the Khmers centuries ago.It was crowded though, and the monument itself is somewhat ordinary, compared to the Preah Khan, which for me is much more interesting and still with those destructive trees.

"the wonderful temple in Siem Reap town". i have to visit this temple at last weekend. it is very nice temple with the jungle around of this .also by the way into Ta Prohm temple i can see most of forest. i will to visit again with my family and the other friends. thank.

The tree temple offers cool photo opportunities. Ta Prohm is nicknamed the tree temple because of the enormous trees that have grown upon its wall with thick roots climbing down. When I went, it was undergoing renovations, but still have several cool photo spots.

A must see!. This temple is a must see and we saw it during our "larger circle" tour of the temples in Angkor. The temple has some very interesting and awesome carvings and shouldn't be missed on the tour!

the best temple of angkor. For me this temple was the highlight of Angkor. It offers something different from most due the way nature has taken it over again and when you are working your way round the temples I think this one really stands out!

This is amazing, just see how nature always wins. This temple was lost and buried in the jungle for hundreds of years before being found relatively recently, which is very evident when you see the huge trees which have grown both over and through it during the centuries, all of which makes for a truly awesome sight. This temple is also very popular with visitors, partly because of its sheer beauty and partly because of its use in the Lara Croft: Tomb Raider film.When you see this temple and the massive trees that have, and still are growing through it, you really do start to understand the power that nature has to take control of man made objects.This really is a 'must see' if you are visiting Siem Reap.

Mesmerizing!. The sight of those trees were breath-taking! Walking around having to look at it caused me to wonder in great amazement. If you're thinking that it's such trees and rubbles, think again! You'll be surprisingly blown away!
the tomb raider one. A part of the Tomb Raider movie was filmed here. Very cool place with all the roots. When I was there, some construction was going on. So a small part was closed.

Tangled tree roots. We went to Ta Prohm by tuk-tuk. Very little restoration has been done here, but they do seem to be doing a little. Worth visiting to see the tree roots intertwined with the temple.

Get there early. Make the effort to get up early. Walking around the Temple when the coach loads of Tourists are still in bed is worth it.. Walking around watching the Sun rise is an great experience..

In love with this temple!. We came here yesterday while doing a day trip out around a few choice temples (we only had a one day pass) and fell in love with Ta Prohm! The way the trees are entwined with the temples is fascinating and in someways eerie. It truly gives the impression of a lost temple in the jungle - despite its restorations and all the tourists! It's incredible to see and probably my favourite of all the ones I got chance to visit! A must see!

Invasion of the jungle. Ta Prohm, one of the Big Three outside Siem Reap, has the added feature of the invasion of the jungle, and especially giant fig trees, into the structure of the buildings. For that reason alone, it is worth visiting, so that one can compare the way in which nature can take invade, over the centuries, if mankind does not interrupt its progress.

Mysterious Ruins and Tangled Roots. Ta Prohm is my favorite temple, it's the site of Angkor's most memorable imagery. I love exploring the mysterious ruins and tangled roots of Ta Prohm, the setting of Tomb Raider film.

Impressive with or without the movie connection. Obviously, this temple is most famous because it was included in the movie, but even without that connection, it is one of the most interesting to wander through as you can see how nature has gradually reclaimed it's hold on things when left unchecked for some time. You can probably spend more time in this temple and find more interesting things to see, than most of the others
Quite a Site. You'll be amazed to see the roots of the Banyon trees intertwined with the temples. I've never seen anything like it!

Wow!. We visited the Angkor complex mainly to see Angkor Wat, but I fell in love with Ta Prohm. It gives you better insight as to what it must have been like to stumble upon a lost temple, although even this temple has obviously been cleared for traffic. The tree roots intertwined with temple remains could be both eery & beautiful at the same time. I thoroughly enjoyed visiting this temple and will hold the memories of it dear.

Serendipity. I think I prefer Ta Prohm most of all the places I visited at Ang Kor Wat. Just amazing. You have to see it for yourself to appreciate this amazing history. But crowds are a big let down though. Good luck!

Very good attraction. Every temple is being preserved by the Cambodian govt. and UNESCO. The temples are one of the World Heritage sights which are visited by millions of people from around the world.
"Tomb Raider" filming site. This temple is a must on your trip to Angkor. Great carvings. I recommend a guide to see all of the temples.

Beautiful and atmospheric!. We visited this amazing temple in February 2014, and it ended up being my favourite temple in Siem Reap. We went early, arriving just after 6am, and this is definitely the best time to go, as there were only about 10 other people there. Having this temple mostly to yourself is just amazing. I was stunned by the beauty of the trees and their roots growing over stone fences and through buildings. I loved the fact that although some renovation of buildings is going on, most of the temple is being left as it was found. This adds so much atmosphere to it, and gives you an idea of what it would've been like when first discovered in this state. Came across a lovely Buddhist lady, who tied a red bracelet on me, and said a prayer for good luck while she was doing it - even though you give a small donation, I found the experience very uplifting. You can get your tuk-tuk driver to wait for you, but frankly, there are so many waiting when you come out that you won't have trouble getting one! Go as early as you can and beat the crowds, I think the essence of these places is to try and have them to yourself as much as possible, so you can experience the atmosphere and sacredness of them as much as you can.

beautiful but veeeery crowded. If you are so lucky to get there with less crowd i guess the experience must be unique, probably late afternoon is recommended. The temple is very nice but the "main role" is for the trees and roots incorporating temples!
Our favorite temple stop!. Love the beautiful scenery and nature, here! Our most pleasant temple tour of the trip. The beautiful trees growing over the architecture was so wonderful to photograph.

One of my favorite places in the world. Ta Prohm is one of the most spiritual places I've ever been. In addition to it being GORGEOUS, it has a wonderful energy and begs you to explore. Although I probably shouldn't reveal this here... the best time to go is right after sunrise when most people are at Angkor Wat or eating breakfast. Later in the day it's overrun by busloads of tourists. Yes it's on everyone's list... so go there before they do.

Back in Time. We went twice to crawl through these ruins. Amazing pictures! Get there early to avoid the heat and crowds. Also, make sure you know where your tuk tuk driver will meet you. There are 3 side gates!

Beautiful, atmospheric and busy!. It's on everybody's list and rightly so. If you arrive as a tour bus is disgorging, let them go ahead. It's possible to enjoy it with a minimum of groups pushing past you.

Almost eerie - certainly magical!. One of our Siem Reap highlights. Crumbling magnificence, aerial roots wrapped tentacle-like around the temples and trees growing through the roof tops. Mysterious and magical, this is ne complex that must not be missed.

Fascinating. Ta Prohm has been almost untouched so the jungle has eat some of the ruins, so it's Incredible to see the big trees in the middle of the ruins. Is such a Magical pleas that you fell is almost unreal.

Incredible.. Now all of Angkor Wat is stunning, a real must see in your lifetime, however, for me, Ta Prohm was the pinnacle of the ancient ruins. Infamous by Tomb Raider, but so breath-taking in real life, you just have to stand and marvel at the ruins and of course by the wonder of nature, and those tree roots claiming back the ancient structure. Go, admire and stand in awe of not just Ta Prohm but all of the beauty of Angkor Wat.

nature fights back. this one fully merits the hype and it is good to see the present day craftsmen restoring large parts of this amazing monument. It will take many decades to finish this if that is the intention of the authorities. would it be better to leave it as it is?

My favorite ever. This where Angkor is getting it's poetry. You will see there nature flirting with man's creation. A pure magical moment, especially if your are going at sunrise, you will be avoiding the crowd and this peace of art for yourself for an hour or so... Fascinated

The great nature growing. evin this temple a bit ruin under restoration but rally nice with the tree that growing up on the top of temple.I like the tree that growing up on top of the temple and best time to visit early in the morning.

Better than the movie :). This temple shows how Angkor Wat area was found and this temple was deliberately kept in the same state as it was found.This temple is shown in Angelina Jolie Movie - the Lara Croft.All those big fig trees some how give a very romantic appeal to the temple. Though we keep calling this as a temple, there nothing here which shows the object of faith. A must visit and extremely difficult to capture the grandeur in camera lens.
Magnificent!. Absolutely fabulous temple overtaken by nature.Go early in the morning or late in the afternoon to avoid the crowds.
Another magnificent temple. Strolling through the temple grounds made me feel like I was in a fantasy movie, a different world....it's truly amazing and something absolutely special!
Awsome. You have to visit this Temple it is awesome. The trees growing through the temple make it unique. For some reason this place people seem to forget about after visiting other places

lives up to its photos. This smaller complex is well-known for the trees that are anchored in its ruins and tower over the stone. I had thought that early morning would be a quiet time, as most tourists would be watching the sunrise over Angkor Wat, but I was wrong. This is where we found the worst crowds of the whole trip. Common advice is to visit here in the afternoon because of the shade, but it appears everyone thought morning would be less crowded. Nevertheless, totally worth it. The whole place is an artistic piece of nature's and man's work.

Top temple in Siem Reap. If you have to choose between Ankhor Wat and Ta Prohm, go for Ta Prohm. Why? It is smaller, has many fewer visitors and a more relaxed 'I'm just discovering this myself' feel about it. It is less developed for tourists, so no shops or touts that I can recall. Here you will see the iconic tree roots growing around walls of the temple and holding them together. Sure, you don't get the large pool of water in front of the temple here, but there's something quietly magical and intimate about Ta Prohm. Enjoy.
Tomb Raider. The ever presence of the jungle waiting to reclaim the temple back, minimal restoration with roots and creepers hugging and swaddling this temple. Great atmosphere
My favorite. Breathtakingly beautiful. We enjoyed Ta Prohm on our 2nd day in Angkor and it was the last stop on our short tour. What a great way to end an awesome day!

India helping with the conservation. The temple is famous for the trees that have grown over the temples and walls. Huhe trees have crept over most of the walls and temoles here. The buddist temple is being conserved with joint effort of archeological survey if India.
The best Temple in Angkor Wat. With its crumbling ruins with large trees growing through it, it is by far the most interesting temple in Angkor Wat.

Tomb Raider? Who cares, it's worth a look.. This temple isn't so big but is a worth a visit (if you can squeeze past the crowds). It looks a little more homely, if that could be said of any of these temples, since it's smaller and has the long tree routes making look like an ancient home. There are a few really good photo opportunities.

epic. Certainly not the largest of temples around Siem, but what it lacks in size it makes up for in elegance and majesty. The trees that embrace parts of the temple are incredible and the design itself is magnificent.

I was in the movie. Among the main temples I visited, Ta Prohm was my favourite..because it was a jungle temple and you will really feel you are in a scene in Tomb Raider. I just love ancient ruins...
Tomb Raider. Most "wild" of the Wats - amazing to see nature's role in taking over man's creations. Definitely worth seeing!

A temple left virtually as found. Knowing that this temple was the set for the movie "Tomb Raider" wasn't a big concern of mine at all and this temple is one of my favourites purely for the beauty of the place. It has been left virtually as it was found and there is jungle growing amongst it and rubble everywhere. Although in many circumstances this would lower the quality of the place it doesn't in this instance and only makes it more beautiful and more magical to walk through - another great temple to capture amazing photos!

A Must Visit Temple (next to Bayon Temple). If you're fond of the movie Tomb Raider, then you would definitely love this place where they shot the film. To me, this rank the second of all the temples in Siem Reap.

Rumble in the jungle. Man builds.. nature taking over.. Sad to see years of manual labor to complete literally in ruins, stone vs nature.. Every nook and cranny nature finds it's way, mega roots in doorways, rooftop etc.. Creepy !!! Tomb raider was filmed on location here, very appropriate, giant trees certainly raided the tomb

Lara Croft from the rafters. I wasn't that bothered that it was the site of a major film - the site is just amazing on its own. The massive tree roots are now so much a part of the temple that the temple would collapse without them, I think.Again, too many people. It was hard to move around the temple as there were queues waiting to shuffle down the corridors, and very hard to get any good photos with several hundred heads in the way. Get there early or late for a more relaxed visit.

Very different temple. The temple has certainly become famous thanks to Lara Croft: Tomb Raider and is one of the must-visit temples in Siem Reap. Its a small temple and you don't need much time to have a look around. The temple of course, is a great example to show how long the Angkor temples have been ignored such that nature has taken over it with trees growing along several walls of the temple. The large trunks and roots stretch around and alongside temple walls giving the temple an eerie look and feel. There are a few key points in the temple that make for great photographs, but otherwise there isn't much to do here. Make sure you do stop here as this temple really completes the Angkor Thom experience.

Site of the tomb raider shoot. Home of the banyan trees. Also the site of the Lara Croft Tomb Raider shoot. In here, trees are valued because once you decide to remove them, you have to destroy an entire area because their roots are scattered around.
Best temple of them all. Fabulous temple with the forest growing through. Shows you how long it's been there. If you only visit 2 temples - Angkor Watt & TaProhm are the 2. A spectacular site !
Lovely. Expected a bit more jungle from the descriptions, but the trees in the towers and growing from the stones are still very impressive.

Amazing walls seem to be held up by trees. This is the place you imagine when you see movies like Tomb Raiders. The trees growing over and into the stones are unbelievable. There are many spots for amazing pictures, but others have the same idea, so go early and be prepared to be patient. The feeling here is mysterious and otherworldly. It is definitely different from the other and grander monuments nearby and well worth seeing.
Best of All. Of the three sites visited - Angor Wat, Bayon and Ta Prohm - Ta Prohm was our favorite. Go early in the morning to avoid the crowds. Roots, rubble and ruins.
Ta prohm temple. Ta prohm is the 2nd biggest temple & has a lot of history, it's under going reconstruction at the moment due to decaying aged stone..
fantastic. Unbelevable temple! Probably the best and prietiest in the world! I love all Angkor Vat, but in my opinion this terrific temple is best of the best.

Tomb Raiders we were not.... ...but we enjoyed the visit. The atmosphere of the temple was amazing. Seeing nature take over the place was spectacular. The root systems of the trees invading all the nooks and crannies of the stone and clinging on to the stonework. Initially, was worried that it would be too commercialised but once you enter the temple and walk round the compound and see what the trees have done it is quite inspiring. The mix of the man made temple structure and the trees gives the whole place a magical feel.

Stand out temple. A little different from the other temples in the Angkor Wat complex, probably the most well known as this is where Tomb Raider was shot.As with most of the other temples, there were renovation projects underway when we visited, but don't let that deter you!The most interesting aspect were the trees that have grown in, on or around the temple itself - showing it has weathered through time and nature.We visited early in the morning, around 7-8am when there were significantly less people around and could grab a few great photo opportunities without the odd, weirdly dressed tourist in the background.

Perfect blending of nature and worship. This amazing place takes you back in time and is a testament that nature and worship could and should go together.
A place that leaves you speechless.

Time your visit. This was probably my favourite temple because of the quintessential 'strangler figs all over the walls' photos together with a wonderful feel.We felt so lucky as we almost had the complex to ourselves, well not exactly, but no other people in our photos probably because we visited, by accident, at lunch time (12.30pm to 1pm) and I daresay the hoards of tourist bus tourists must have been stopped for lunch.At every turn there's an even better picture than the one before.Exquisite!!

Awnsome threes. It pays the visit when you see that amazing temple covered with the roots´ threes... It´s really incredible and it looks like you are back in time. Those weird and awnsome threes took over the temple´s walls and roofs.

Restoration Transformed this place. The overgrown trees taking over the temple are quite a sight. I found the most amazing part was seeing the before/after pictures from the restoration. The amount of work that went into this restoration seems crazy. There were some areas still in disarray - it was like seeing the puzzle before they put it back together.

A temple lost in time.. The famed temple from Tomb Raider movie, Ta Prohm feels is a place lost in time. The jungle has taken over the once mighty temple. You see trees growing in and around several structures. You do not come by something like this easily. All in all great to visit.P.S: Reach early.Visited Jan'11

Yes, It's The "Tomb Raider" Temple... And Much More!. There are many Kapok trees about the temple to have your picture taken with, so don't get bogged down waiting in line with the masses for a single, specific shot and place. We found a few wonderful tree photo-ops off to the sides, away from the main pathway. My girlfriend loved this temple, but I'd place it behind Angkor Wat and the Bayon Temple at Angkor Thom.

By far the BEST!. This place its amazon, the tries growing from within the buildings are an amazing thing to look at, I'd say IMPOSSIBLE. I recommend to walk around and climb a few rocks! even though its not 100% permitted. Its worthwhile.
Fantastic. This is certainly mind blowing, absolutely fabulous.Our guide suggested an early (5.30 am) start and it was worth it. We were the first people there apart from the security (2) people.

What You expect to see. Going to Ankgor Wat I expected not to see perfectly econstructed temples but something like this. A feeling of a lost temple in the jungle. And this is it. It gets crowded tho because every one wants to see a 'tom rider' temple. So come in the morning to get more spiritual feeling.

Lots of scaffolds. Unfortunately this site is undergoing a lot of restoration and I was a bit disappointed in it. Long term it would be a must see. This is the temple with trees growing in it and where the movie" Tomb raider" was filmed.

Magical. I felt this to be best of the three temples we visited, it was so atmospheric. The trees have grown into and around the walls, and it has the most amazing feel to the place. A real must see if you are visiting Cambodia.

Another magnificent temple that you must see. Ta Prohm is another magnificent temple in Seam Reap, a beautiful place. Visiting this temple makes you feel as a explorer of a lost city. Much has been written about it...Jayavarman VII built this temple to honor his mother. This is a wonderful temple for pictures.
Astonishing!. An ancient temple overtaken by nature. Kapok trees have overwhelmed the structure, but it retains much intricacy and romance.

Cool. Facinated to see the temple in which part of tomb raider was shot at. Would love to see how the temple would look like before the huge trees took over but at the same time the trees gave the temple an ancient and mystical atmosphere.

Don't miss this experience. This is unique - tree roots sitting on top of ancient structures. Its only a matter of time before the sheer numbers visiting means that tourists will not be permitted to clamber all over the monuments ; so get there soon as the restoration work makes no difference to your enjoyment.

Look at them trees grow. It can get really crowded from time to time, just have a little patience. The government need to seriously build a better public facilities for such a great sight. Saw a girl went into the jungle for toilet break, OMG.

A true wonder of the world, but essential to be there before the crowds. Easy to visit, as always to be there early in the morning before the crowds is the best. Great restoration in progress. This was the cultural moment of my life.......

Wow - unmissable. I had to keep pinching myself that I was really seeing this. The trees interweaving through the buildings are unbelievable. I'd seen it in films, but nothing beats seeing it in real life. The noise of the parrots and other birds only enhances the atmosphereThe downside is that it is very crowded - someone steps in front of your camera every time you take a photo.Unmissable

Best Temple In Siem Reap. One word, amazing! The blend of old temples with nature is impressive. Had a police man become my guide and he was very friendly and energetic. He showed me stuff I would have missed. They expect payment but this is typical in Cambodia as they don't get paid much.

Breath-takingly good. Came here with family and a tour guide. Just a great mysterious temple with of course the famous Tomb Raider history. Just amazing photo ops with the huge trees everywhere. Highly recommended!

Tomb Raider. Very interesting due to the march of nature,tree roots slowly finding there way through the walls of the temple.
As usual,very busy,I think for photos,afternoon is a better time,take alook up though at some of the trees,& you will also see several bees nests attached to the branches.

Really Romantic & Mysterious if you can avoid the Crowds. Forget the films and just absorb the atmosphere.If you possibly can, get here very early before the crowds and you will be rewarded by a fascinating ruin of a temple, with lots of nooks and crannies, which is really enchanting with all the trees and their roots intertwined in the structure. However once the crowds arrive it loses some of its magic, and although still interesting and worthy of a visit it does not have the same impact.It is not one of the most interesting structures as a temple, but it is the combination of the romantic ruins and the effects of nature on it which provide the allure. If visiting the temples complex this one must be on the list.
Jungle tree takeover. The huge trees growing over and around the temple and walls are really amazing and worth many photos. Best light for the iconic photo is in the afternoon.

Go visit the place earlier. The time i went to this place is afternoon and packed with groups of tourists. Would suggest to go earlier. As most of you know this is the temple where tomb raider shooting takes place.

Amazing!. Fascinating visit . We went at dawn and it was so atmospheric. Tomb Raider was filmed here so you ladies can pretend you are Angelique Jolie lol. The combination of stone and trees is so unique. Each brought 63 kilometres by elephants. Tis is the only temple where they have left the trees. You do need to be sure footed as its uneven terrain and slabs but an amazing and unforgettable experience

Memorable. One of the most memorable temples we visited. Yes it can be a bit crowded at times, but don't let that spoil your visit. This is a beautiful temple, where the man-made meets mother nature. Definitely go and visit this very individual temple!
Out of the world.. We knew that Angelina Jolie's movie with the title " Tomb raider... was shot here but were not prepared for the sheer mystery of giant roots of trees almost covering a temple ...

Beautiful, but be ready for crowds!. One of my favorite temples we saw, absolutely stunning! Tons of tour groups going through… They tend to bottleneck in one area and take over.. If you give it a second, eventually they will move on and you can get a moment to see the amazing root systems and temple.
amazing temple. "Tomb rider" temple really lives up to its reputation. One of the most amazing temples with massive roots of the trees growing from temple's ancient ruins.Although too crowdy.
Incredible experience. one of our favorite because untouched ! you feel the strength of nature and have a feeling of how the people who discovered this temple must have felt when they first saw it.

My Favorite Temple!. Typically known as the Tomb Raider Temple. It is one of the most amazing temples. The massive roots of the trees intertwining with the temple's ancient stone is really not an everyday sight. The views are breathtaking. There are many tours there, so do be patient and wait for your turn for them to empty the place in order to get a great shot.
To many people. it's a very exiting temple, but the number of tourist is more than enough to spoil the experience. We have been here before - all alone - fantastic!
Wow. Visiting this place made me feel like I'm in ancient times. Gave me a relaxing and an extraordinary experience with my family.

Requires quite some walking. The place is very good. Angelina Jolie seems to have made it quite famous. Most locals will point out the way if you ask them about 'Tomb Raider' temple. Places are in quite some ruins,

One of the most misterious constructions. This is one place why ANkor Wat is known for. Trees growing with their massive roots on the top of the edifications. This is where Thomb Rider was set- one more reason for its popularity. Expect the visit to be a crowded one. You will probably walk in line through its narrow pathways inside this monastery. It is under restaurations as tree roost end up eroding the constructions. You will find the celestial dancers (apsaras) sculped in the walls.

Another amazing temple in Siem Reap, number 1 or 2 for us!. Ta Prohm is an incredible temple, and this is a must see. Quickly you will notice that the name of the temple might as well be AngelinaJolieTombRaider temple, as the guides keep saying this every time they refer to ta Prohm.This temple is breathtaking. The combination of the trees with the ruins make it a magical place, and it is delightful to walk around. If you manage to get it at a quieter time, it is even better.Can not miss it.

A favorite temple visit. The massive tree roots intertwined with the ancient stones is quite a sight. Yes, this is the one featured in 'Lara Croft'. The temple itself is also worth the visit, not just the trees :) Naturally you are never the only visitor but with a good dose of patience it is possible to get some good photos. Just sit and wait, or 'get in line'.

Favorite of the temples. My partner and I visited 3-4 temples in the day and this was by far a favorite for both of us! It had wow factor, but is being restored at the moment - besides that you can still walk through much of it and get some great shots.

Amazing Ta Prohm. Ta Prohm was one of the best sights to see in Siem Reap. My girl friend and I visited last February and it was everything I imagined. The temple itself was great but even more amazing was the roots. It was worth the trip. Visiting in the morning is better as the place started getting crowded towards the afternoon.
wonderful. Despite having seen pictures, I was impressed by this temple - quite surreal, no wonder the film makers were taken by it.

Favorite Temple of the ones we visited. Leaving ruins in half-claimed jungle state to show tourists what happens when nature takes over was incredible. The trees were amazing as were the ruins. Knowing that a Hollywood film (Laura Croft's Tomb Raider) was filmed there was an added fun thing to know.

The one with the trees. Ta Prohm, after Angkor Wat, is probably the temple most people think of when they conjure up images of Angkor. The Banyan trees growing throughout the temple give an overpowering impression of the power of Mother Nature. Man can build, but she'll take it back eventually.

Spectacular tree temple. But... horrible with the crowds that now come through here. Be especially weary of groups of mainland Chinese travellers... I was here 10 years ago and the crowdedness has exploded. Angkor needs to find a way to manage the no doubt increasing groups in future.

Stunning! The jungle takes back. If i absolutely had to pick one from all the temple ruins i visited in Cambodia; Ta Prohm would be it! Built in the Bayon style largely in the late 12th and early 13th centuries and originally called Rajavihara; it is imposing and completely in the grasp of the trees that hold it together. The jungle has taken over such that the monument is pretty much held by the trees.After the fall of the Khmer Empire in the 17th century, the temple of Ta Prohm was abandoned and neglected for centuries. When the effort to conserve and restore the temples of Angkor began in the early 21st century, it was decided that Ta Prohm would be left largely as it had been found. The ruins are being conserved in partnership with the ASI. MUST visit this one.

Rocks and Roots. The temple is one of the many of Angkor. It is the only one where the nature invade the monument. The effect of roots embracing the stones is fantastic. Surely that the temple is also very interesting. Do not miss

Well worth the visit.. A struggle between restoration and losing its main attraction of the amazing trees growing out of the temple. Seems to be succeeding for the time being. Make believe you are Lara Croft. Great photo opportunities.
Back in time experience. Most interesting thing about the site is how the jungle has overgrown the monuments. There is an odd symbiotic nature to how the ruins and the trees entwine.

The right balance between restoration and nature taking its toll. The temple has been engulfed by the fiscus trees of the forest, the roots have disrupted the foundations and topples a lot of the structure. The restoration has been careful to maintain the wildness, and restoring it just enough so that the whole structure will be preserved for ever. Please don't refer to it as the 'Tomb Raider temple'. That's like calling the Notre dame cathedral the the "Hunchback's church".

Angelina jolie wannabe. Everyone excited to be here because of tomb raider movie. so many Angelina jolie wannabe. too crowded with people and some tourist took long time to take picture at certain spot.
Raiders of the lost ark. Ruins are only partly restored and the atmosphere is great. It makes you wonder how people built the temple without modern machinery

Magical, Must-do. You must visit Ta-Prohm! It was my favourite temple of the lot. Called Ta Prohm, it has both Buddhist and Hindu heritage, but it is best known for its stunning trees that have outgrown the temple. The fig trees that have grown around the temple give the place a special feel, where you see nature's interaction with civilisations over the centuries. Poetic and beautiful, it's a must-do! :D
Magic. No wonder that this place has been used for shooting movies. The buildings and ruins partially being overtaken by the jungle is just awesome. Try to avoid the biggest tourist crowds.
One of the more interesting temples. I loved the trees growing in and out of everything. It wasn't nearly as crowded as the other temples, either.

My favourite temple ... loads of atmosphere. About one kilometre east of Angkor Thom. so can easily be visited on the same day.It was originally a Buddhist monastery and university. Unlike most Angkor temples, Ta Prohm has been left much like it was when it was found (though currently some restoration is underway which spoils some of the better views!): the combination of trees growing out of the ruins and the jungle behind make it one of Angkor's most popular temples.Again no visible presence of security personnel keeping unruly visitors from climbing over the barrier ropes and up the trees, slowly ruining the place for future generations.

What I Expected. Not surprised with the amount of people. This is one of the big ones for most people to see. A shame that a lot of the big trees were cut. Preferred some of the farther away temples more so won't likely come back. Can understand the need for all the pathways but it took away from the experience.
Tomb Raider templte. This was my favourite temple, because nature had started claiming back the space. Everywhere, you see lovely tall trees growing over the old structure.

Gorgeous Blend of Man and Nature. Ta Prohm is absolutely stunning. The way the trees and temple have grown together is awe-inspiring. Be aware that during the day this temple, like many others, will have a ton of people so you may have to be patient get the pictures you want. The temple may look small from the front but it goes one forever once you enter - it is kind of a maze so make sure you know which lot you are meeting your driver at because there are two entrances/exits and it is easy to get turned around once inside. This temple is truly unique compared to others in the area due to the impressive and beautiful melding of nature and man mad structure. Allow yourself time to wander and take pictures. The areas made famous by the Tomb Raider movie are beautiful for pictures but may have multiple people waiting to take pictures so be patient.
Pink Lady temple. Despite being over one thousand years old, this temple is still in great condition and the carvings still tell the stories.
Unique - Just Unique. One of the most exciting temples I have ever visited. Fantastic setting. Go early in the morning and soak in the very special atmosphere

Visit early. We visited ta prohm right after viewing sunrise over Angkor Wat. There were very few tourists there. By the time we were leaving around 10am, there were lines and lines of tourists entering. Get there early!! Also- try to use the bathroom beforehand. There are "eastern" style bathrooms there (a hole in the floor). Easy enough for men but ladies, trust me- you don't want to use this!
Beautiful. Beautiful temple - the trees in the temples make for good photos - one of the essential temples to visit!

Wonderful attraction. A must see on your list.. Excellent temple ruin.... The trees are mind boggling.... A bit strenuous to walk around but worth the effort....
Do carry water and hats...

Amazing. This is the most amazing sight- Angkor Wat is huge and wonderful but this Temple is magic! There is a feeling there that time has stood still and the forest and trees truly are trying to claw back!
Nature vs Man. Incredible temple where nature has really taken over man. It had such a wow factor. Loved it and it's a must see.

Best of all ! Top attraction in Ankor Wat!!. This is unique compared to rest of Anlot Wat temple. Unlike most Angkor Wat temples, Ta Prohm has been left in much the same condition in which it was found. The ruins and the trees that grow from the ruins give that unique experience. This place is truly spectacular and very photogenic as well. Take extra care when walking on the wooden walkways. Must visit place if you are in Ankot Wat!
tomb raider. eerie temple in the process of being reclaimed by the jungle - scenes of tomb raider were shot here and you do feel a bit like an adventurous treasure hunter
Temple overtaken by the jungle. Massive trees and roots have overgrown the ruins of this temple, which is also called the Angelina Jolie temple because Tomb Raider was filmed here

A must!. This temple was amazing,there were massive trees growing all through he temple walls and roofs,definitely has the tomb raider feel to it. Lots of hawkers and children selling wooden flute,bracelets or brass ornaments. Can be hard to say no so they follow you down the road,on the plus side they are selling things really cheap.
My favourite amongst all the temples. Unlike the other temples in the area, this one still have much of the vegetation preserved. Gives the feel of a ruins in the forest. Quite unique!
sunrise. it really is worthwhile to get up before dawn to watch the sun rise over the Kings Pool. Very atmospheric and peaceful.

Come as early as possible! !. You should come here as soon as possible in the early morning if you don't wish to visit the temple with overwhelm crowded people. This was the most excited and desired temple which I wanted to visit however due to the overwhelming crowded people in the afternoon, it make me feel disappointed despite that you will need to squeeze in between the crowded sea of people and it was hard for taking pictures. Nevertheless, it is still one of the most interesting temple for exploring on the trails of tomb raider and those gigantic trees that covered some of these temple areas.

Amazing!. The only temples left to the devices of the jungle. It is however constantly under restoration works so it does somewhat take away from its natural beauty. Necessary evil though so one would just have to take it with a grain of salt. The trees really are breathtaking!

Another must do. They took one tree down due to the endanger of the structure but the other 3 remained. This was one of the shooting scene of Tom raider. My main visiting purpose was because of the tree roots, I went at 9/10 am however was already flooded with tourists... Should've gone much earlier!

Restoration work. Ta Prohm is in the middle of an extensive restoration programme. Some parts of the complex are presently out of bounds, other areas have been sensitively restored. This means that it may not look as you had expected it to, but nevertheless, it is an outstandingly interesting temple.

Great, but overcrowded. This site has several trees growing on the ruins and it is majestic to say the least. Unfortunately the site has a lot of small rooms to go through. This in itself is not a problem, but doing it with thousands of other tourist makes it a problem. Don't expect to be able to shoot a picture without people on it if you come after 10 am. There is some restoration work going on at the site, but don't let this stop you.

One of the 4 main temples in the Angkor Wat complex. I think this was the one where they filmed 'Tomb Raider', with the huge roots of the jungle trees curling over the stonework. There is some renovation work being undertaken by Indian archaeologists, but this does not detract from the experience

Restoration work, throngs of tourists, but the trees.... When i visited Ta Prohm, I didn't really feel its magic. It was too crowded, too noisy, and too touristy. The tree featured in Tomb Raider was unarguably amazing but when you're actually there, it's next to impossible to "get lost" in the atmosphere of an abandoned temple. There was also restoration work going on when we visited.The saving grace of this temple, apart from its beautiful trees, some of which are, by the way, in danger of being cut, is how you can still sneak to the side where you can actually be alone and where you can sit on fallen blocks and gaze at the marvel that is nature reclaiming what was once hers.If you want to feel the odd beauty of ruins, I recommend Beng Mealea (significantly less toursity especially in the afternoon). Koh Ker, though rather far, offers peace and some beautiful photo opportunities, minus the tourist crowds.
Tomb Raider Temple. Never miss this one! Very popular because of the movie Tomb Raider. This temple is very crowded but visitors gave way - they line up so one can take good pictures. Worth a visit.
Amazing and breathtaking. This is one of the best sights in Angkor; it's quite awesome to see giant trees uprooting almost every ancient ruins and you'll be amazed by its historical facts.

Genuine fun. Should a temple be fun? I've been in China 6 years and not really had that feeling before but here (and a few others on the tour) once you get past the entrance and get going in and out of doorways and corridor's that have been lost to jungle you do get a little bit of big kid in you come out.Agree with the last reviewer too, it's spooky but in a good way!
Spooky. This temple has a spooky feel to it - very desolate and forlorn. Alas it is also very crowded and it is hard to get a photo with hoards of visitors on it! Worth a visit.

love the tree roots and temples. I really like the contrast and the harmony of the tree roots and temples and now they are so intertwined that when they do restoration work they need to account for the tree roots staying in place for structural reasons.if you come inn the afternoon be prepared to wait for photos with the tree roots/temples even though there are many of them all the tourists wants these photos.
See it before it disappears. Ta Phrom is a picturesque temple that is slowly being swallowed by the trees. Nice and cool place with some shade to shelter in during the searing afternoon heat.
Loved it - nature taking back over. Loved the way that the tress were growing over the magnificent temple ruins. Simply stunning. You need to clamber. Having a guide is helpful

"The Tomb Raider temple" is disappointing. If you ask a Tuc Tuc driver for the "Tomb Raider" temple, this is where they'll take you. Ta Prohm was the temple that featured most heavily in the movie. Arguably the trees are the star of this temple, and a particular tree that's prominent in the film has become the main attraction. Admittedly I was there in February during a busy period, but it was stupidly busy. I'm not kidding, I actually queued in a 20 strong queue to have my photo taken with the tree which has a little rope across it. Also, unfortunately a lot of restoration work was happening, and there's nothing like diggers, scaffolding and 2000 people with bum-bags to shatter the fantasy that you're an lone intrepid adventurer on a quest to find hidden treasure. I'm afraid it really isn't that great. Nor is it the only place where trees have grown over the temples. I'd actually say somewhere like Preah Khan has a bigger and better tree that doesn't require fighting hoards of tourists to get a shot with it. This was the temple I was most excited about and the most disappointed by. There are smaller temples that you can visit early in the morning and have to yourself if you're looking for the explorer experience. If you're looking for a theme park experience, this is it. Whilst Tomb Raider helped the local economy, it has sadly helped trash this temple. But I shouldn't complain too much, I was one of the idiot tourists trashing it! You won't bear more than an hour here.

Magical place!. Even though this is one of the smallest 'popular' sites in Angkor Wat, it is still as amazing as the others. Be sure to get here early, because after mid day there are a lot of people and not much shade in the heat!
Jungle temple. Not as busy as expected, great experience. Amazing how the jungle is conquering the temples...! Spend 1.5 hours here

a bit crowded but impressive. I definitely wanted to see this part as it provides an interesting insight to the problems of destruction faced by trees rooting in the temple buildings. Lots of people seem to like this contrast as well, with the consequences that they all feel like taking pictures with them in front of what one would love to photograph without them.

My Favorite Spot in Angkor. Ta Prohm is my absolute favorite of the spots in Angkor I've visited so far. In contrast other temples this one is largely unrestored as far as I can tell, which results in a special atmosphere. The mix between the temple parts and the vegetation - especially the trees that embrace temple rocks - is just amazing. The place was more crowded than Angkor Wat or the Bayon temple when I visited it, so it is probably a good idea to come soon or late in the afternoon as some walkways are narrow. But most importantly allow yourself plenty of time, because this place is awesome.
Great temple with hidden surprises. I loved this temple, the trees were beautiful and there were some great photo opportunities. I would love to return and see it all again.

Beautiful !. I love the place. The sun was out when I was there. It is such an amazing experience, great place, lots of history. It worths every seconds to be there. Some tips that you should go there early to beat the crowds. Packs of tourists from 9am onwards !

See this at dawn. Go.
This is a truly magical place. The travel guides can't do it justice. There is nowhere quite like it anywhere else.

Exactly what you were imagining. A delicate balance between man and nature the tree roots are demolishing the temple but add so much to its asthetic. Tough to work out how they should preserve this temple without removing the trees which give it a unique character.

Add This To Your Bucket List. If you've ever watched the first "Tombraider" with Angelina Jolie it is worth knowing that some of the ruins in the movie were filmed at Ta Prohm. This was the third and final temple my group visited after Angkor Wat and Bayon. I found the layout to be much more simple than the previous two although it covers a good amount of area. The trees growing over and through the temple are pretty incredible. At certain areas trees are physically supported.#1 No part of Ta Prohm is an active temple so you can wear whatever you want, even if it's shorts with a sleeveless shirt. #2 There are lots of food vendors right outside the entrance to the temple and I highly recommend fresh pineapple on a stick. #3 It is very easy to get around the temple although there is a bottleneck of tourists trying to take photos of the same iconic locations. #4 It is pretty easy to view the temple within an hour or two.

Once you've seen Angkor Wat, head over to Ta Prohm for a different experience. Undoubtedly when you visit Siem Reap, you will first get to Angkor Wat, but you should definitely see Ta Prohm. Only then will you really understand how so many of the temples were 'lost' in the forest for so many years. The authorities have decided to leave some of the trees growing into the stonework here, so that one can see the enormous power of nature to undo man's handiwork. OK, they are restoring this temple and quite a lot has been put back together again, but amazing to see the trees growing through the stonework. And this is a great picturesque place. Lovely photo opportunities!

Breathtaking!. Having read about the temples it was just so amazing to actually be there. Do some research before you go or hire a Cambodian guide. Our guide told us many interesting stories and described the carvings all over the temple. Just incredible.
Natural State. Ta Prohm is a fascinating ruin with the complexities of the interlaces vines and fig trees forming an interesting contrast with other Bayon style ruins

Just Plain Cool. Not much to say other than it's one of the more impressive temples in the Angkor Complex. Sunrise here was one of the more memorable experiences of my life. Get dropped off well ahead of time with a headlamp and just explore and make your way to the West side and watch the sun rise.

Forget the film and have your own experience. I loved the 'face' tower above the gate, the room which created a boom when I hit my chest, the tumbled rocks and upright trees. It became a bit of a maze until we found a quiet space and sat to meditate amongst the ancient spirits of the place.
Wonderful!!!. They're all magical, and all must be done. Take a guide or a detailed guide book of all areas, because then you'll learn more about them.

A must on your sightseeing list. Fabulous, extensive ruins in which you can immerse yourself and which give a hint of what early explorers would have found. There is little more to add that you cannot find in one of numerous guidebooks.

Awesome...My favorite!. My favorite temple and a must see. Built in 1186 and served the empires administrative center for the 102 hospitals. Europeans found this temple in the 19th century and today still looks as it did when it was found. Huge trees growing up through the temple provide a breathtaking view. The massive roots ruined many passageways and courtyards but it’s amazing to see how the jungle has taken over. Ta Prohm temple was in the movie “Tomb Raider” starring Angelina Jolie.

Jungle temple "pearl". I am certainly happy that I saw Angkor Wat, but it seemed relatively "sterile" compared to the other 14 temples I visited in the Angkor Archaeological Park -- all vegetation has been removed and it was crowded with visitors. On the other hand, I really enjoyed Ta Prohm Temple. This is likely the most famous of Angkor's jungle temples -- seemingly in the python-like grip of strangler fig trees and site of the filming of Angelina Jolie's Tomb Raiders film. Our guide was Nu Tat. He speaks English very well, is well educated, and his commentaries are interesting and meaningful. Another of Tat's good qualities is that he doesn't follow the conventional itinerary so his clients tend to see the temples at less-visited times. Tat can be reached at nutarth@yahoo.com
Beautiful. Took a tuk tuk from siem reap. Really enjoyed it. A must see if you're in the area. Small compared to angkor wat but more breath taking.
Were nature and men embrace.... Beautiful location. The trees (spung) "eating" the temple gives it a new dimension. Amazing small temple in the middle of the forest.

Trees vs. Temple. Ta Prohm has become famous as being the setting for the first Tomb Raider film. But hype aside, it does deliver the interesting junctions of restoration and destruction, where trees had overpowered the temples.Many have described it as amazing, and I must add to these testaments.It is still best to read up before visiting: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ta_Prohm, read or not, it is still visually stunning.The trees are incredibly huge, and the canopies provide ample shade. that said, this is a really nice temple to spend some time. We went before lunch time and though we wanted to spend moments of silence, it was nearly impossible because of the flock of tourists in the area. I've noticed though that some of the children here were quite bored, for them it would be just stone and trees anyway, and lots of walking get them tired. I guess if you tell them that this was an Ancient Kingdom, which it really is, may be it will get some of their attention.Bring water. Nice hiking shoes and cool clothes. I can't stress water enough.
sooo cool. Just like in the movies, only better. Let your imagination go wild in this temple, left overgrown by huge trees. The shapes of the roots are as amazing as the temples.

Amazing archeological find. No matter how long you have to spend, Ta Prohm is a must see Temple Complex in the Siem Reap area. Trees were left in place rather than excavated from the site and it makes for a wondrous experience to see the roots growing through the stones. Some of the best pictures you will find will be in Ta Prohm!

AMAZING. By far my favourite temple. The trees growing out of where ever they please is just breathtaking, Ta Prohm is a must see if you are going to the temples. *Tip* go the opposite way to the tour groups, you will get the greatest pictures. :)

Get there early!. Great Temple! Family visit: 2 adults/2 late teenagers. We went on a private tour (via Beyond Unique Tours: see my review of them), but you can easily visit this yourself by hiring a TukTuk driver from your hotel or in town. Went early and bought our tickets at 07.45am at the Official Ticket Office which was already busy! US$20 per person for a one-day, all-temple visit, or US$40 for a 3-day ticket. You have your photo taken for a personal ticket, so that you cannot re-sell it ... and each temple door-staff ask to see it. This was a great start to our day. You can buy water and fruit at the stalls OUTSIDE the temple walls. An 800-metre walk up a sandy path to arrive at a great temple... where the tree roots really do intertwine with the temple building. Very eery & quiet. And yes, you do see the infamous "Tomb Raider' door, but it is roped off now, so you can only stand on a wooden platform in front of it. Well worth a visit and do go with a guide who can tell you the history ... particularly about the old 'Library' which is the first building on the right as you approach the temple. I had a foot-cast & walking stick, but still managed to get around. We all loved this!

It's all about the trees!. When you see the tree roots growing over the walls and inner structures of Ta Prohm, you can understand how these temples were lost to the jungle for centuries. Unfortunately these same trees are causing immense damage to the temple, which was very apparent after a 2 year break from visiting. They have started stabilising the temple for safety, and I'm guessing some of the trees will be removed. But I'm sure that the authorities realise that these trees are the big draw card here.
