It does get very busy, but have always found it easy enough to photograph without getting crowds in the shots. There are some huge tree roots on the boundary walls, which make a great background when taking portrait shots of people standing amongst the roots.

Fusion of man and nature. What an amazing sight - there are about 10 trees in the park that have grown on/in/around the temple structure and are amazing to see. Some great photos if you use black and white setting. My second favourite temple site after bayon.

Trees overgrowing temples. Fantastic 50/50 mix of culture and overgrowth by huge trees.The Archaeological Survey of India is doing a fantastic job restoring the place. There was a lot of rebuilding activity when we were there. Don't miss the middle part of the temple with the most spectacular tree root.
Beautiful! My favorite temple. How they kept the beautiful temple, and how personal it is. You don't get tourist in all your pictures
Unique temple. Roots and roots everywhere. So many corners and alleyways, you could easily get lost inside the temple.Every corner is tourist attraction spot to take photos!

Amazing temple. Our tour guide took us into side entrance, not the main entrance. He said that said entrance will lead us to filming location of Tomb Raider, and it was fantastic...we passed through a small forest, many old ruins and cross small river. You won't found it if pass through main visitor gate. I wonder how old is the temple with those old tree on it. According to the old story, one of the temple (little one in the middle) can cure illness by patting our chest until you hear echo. The echo can only came from your chest, if you clap or even shout aloud...you won't hear the echo...amazing. Beautiful and amazing temple.

THE TOMB RAIDER TEMPLE. this is a bit remote in location and partially claimed by nature and hence its appeal , the trees and the buildings integrate together to give some of the most spectacular views in ANGKOR
Must see. great place to visit while in Siem reap, tomb Raiders was filmed here. great for pics and a lot of walking while you are in there
Fantastic temple. 5+ experience. Like being a kid again, Environment like an Indiano Jones or Lord of the Ring Movie. A must see if visiting Angkor Wat
nice, unique, but too crowdy. Fantasy in the huge forest. The place were left and the tree has grown up on the top of the big architect thing. nice

Cool. A great example of nature verses culture. Nature 1 Culture 0
Smallish temple after AW, no disrespect intended, but atmospheric and beautiful.
Ta Prohm. Just amazing! The sight of the giant tree enveloping the temple wall gives you insight into how the jungle can just reclaim these monumental structures

Great temple - lots of people!. It was crazy busy here!
The roots growing through the structures give it a great feeling.
It's hard but you can get most of your pictures without other people if you are patient and persistent enough.

Too many tourists. This is another very impressive attraction however much overshadowed due to crowds of tourists!
Could not even see most of it due to people taking photos in front of every single root!

Nice experience. You have to go there early in the morning or late afternoon to enjoy ghetting lost without seeing to many (chinese) tourists.
Too bad the temple is being renovated.

Beautiful but try not to get the cranes in your photos!. Ta Prohm is undergoing a huge restoration project and it's an amazing job. The temple is amazingly beautiful with the banyan trees all around, but sadly the cranes don't really add to the ambiance! Still, nothing can detract from the beauty of the place. Take your time to wander around and you can find areas where you will be alone to photograph or simply just enjoy your surroundings.

Tomb raider.... This temple is very well known as one of the Tomb Raider movies was filmed here. Lots of huge trees at this place! If you like to take photos, you can find many great photo spots at this temple.

Our Favourite of all the Temples. We like this the most, of the 5 temples we visited. Some areas were busy as it was Chinese New Year, but have a look around, there are some areas you can access that most people do not go to.

Out of this world. This is a perfect place to be to have a view and sense of nature wonderful capability, especially if you could visit the place very early in the morning. Try to find a spot and sit crossed-legs, relax your shoulder and breath slowly, inhale & exhale, shut your eyes and be mindful of your breathing and the surrounding spiritual air and sounds of nature. You will be surprised how you would feel after only 15 minutes... again toilets facilities are lacking and perhaps, the dirt road from the parking area to the temple should be tiled and sitting places provided along the road...

Wonderful at sunrise. Amazing experience walking to the temple in the dark and seeing the shadows of the buildings as the sun came up whilst listening to sound of the distant drums and wildlife awakening.

serenity. This place is timeless, we were fortunate enough to get here early and virtually had the place to our selves. Ta Prom will take yr breath away it is just about one of the most amazing experiences in Cambodia. This place leaves you with a sense of awe

Early morning, was best. We went to Ta Prohm at about 6.30 am , it was perfect, only a couple of people there, the sounds of the birds dawn Chorus was wonderful. You will visit this temple on your trip to Siem Reap, try and do it without a thousand fellow tourists, go early.
beautiful. Very active temple for tourists and locals. Try to go in the am before all the buses get there if you are truly interested in the structures.

My Favorite Temple in Angkor Area. lots of trees and roots covering the ancient stones of this temple and left unchanged how the folks, rediscovering this temple hundert years ago must have felt. lots of alking and evey minute a new discovery. clearly my favorite!

Marvellous place. Amazing place, with the temple overgrown by massive trees. Parts are in course of restoration; I admire the people who are busy with this giant work and it is also worth to restore this beautiful historical place

Jungle ruins, just like the movies. A lot of the temples in Cambodia are in various states of disrepair due to their age but Ta Prohm is unique. The restoration is trying to maintain the current state of the ruins, not repair it. And that state is surreal. The jungle has taken over, with trees rising out of the middle of the temple and giant roots everywhere. It's a mystical place.

Nature wins!. Its super impressive seeing the massive ancient trees devouring this temple. Much of it has been reconstructed (and work is ongoing) as nature has completely won over this tribute to the Khmer Kings mother. Again, I suggest going early if you want to explore and not get rushed though the grounds as a herd of tourists noisily tramples though for their photo-op ( man they were infuriating!!!).Definitely impressive and worth a visit.

See it now!. Wear your walking shoes and try to go opposite the crowds. This is a popular one because of the Laura Croft movie. The trees make this a very dramatic spot with roots growing around the temple. We did it as part of the bicycle trip and it was fantastic. Not to be missed, and know none of the tour busses miss this one.
Must see. This is a very special site, different and refreshing, after seeing lots of temples. The site was a little crowded, but we came at peak season.
My favourite temple. This temple was stunning withh all the trees and roots growing around the walls and structure. Just amazing

Raiding the Tomb. After all the other visits to temples in Siem Reap, we had a visit here which was so fun. We had seen the perfection of Angkor Wat, the beauty of Banteay Srei, but this was this felt like a real-life exploration of a forgotten time. We were there at dusk which created this eerie- cicada filled atmosphere of adventure. If a tiger or naked savage had jumped out at any time, I would not have been surprised. The photo opportunities of posing with a tree were endless, and while they sometimes had a line- everyone had their politeness to grant everyone a chance. This is a can't miss!

A must see. My second favourite site. They have been doing a great job Restoring this site as it was neglected after the fall of the Khmer Empire. As I always say, look but don't touch. Its has some great photo opportunities

The best temple in Angkor! . I guess we got lucky or because it was early in the morning, but there was barely any people when we visited. Which left us getting lost in the ruins of this beautiful temple complex. The fallen stones and the giant cotton trees made for a surreal atmosphere. Around every corner it would seem is another giant tree sitting on a wall. Go there first in the day before it gets busy. You won't regret it.

Crowded but worth it. Yes, Ta Prohm gets crowded, and I suspect it is always crowded no matter the time of day. Yes, it is popular due to the movie as evidenced by the bus loads of tour groups and individuals on tuk tuks and bicycles. But despite the crowds and popularity, Ta Prohm still holds wonder and mystery. The growth of trees across the temple only confirms the power of nature and adds mystery and charm to the area.

Popular for the Tomb Raider tree. The movie made this temple complex popular for good reason. This site has silk cotton trees overgrowing the walls and becoming one with the complex walls. You'll need to stand in line to take your picture at the Tomb Raider tree but people are courteous.
A tree could be so huge !. Open eye experience for me to see a few of the gigantic trees inside the Temple. A bit crowded though with all the different tours.

The Power of Nature. Great place to visit and be awed by the power of nature! How the roots grow and the trees stay intact for such a long long time engulfing the buildings and become part of the civilization!?! Love the place and certainly a must visit at Siem Reap

Great way to sense the impact of the jungle... This particular temple lets you see the impact the jungle has on the temples. Beautiful and rustic. Forget the Angelina Jolie stuff, look at the natural beauty.

This was equally sensational place to visit.. There are just so many temples here like this one, you really need 3 days to tour the entire site. Go early morning and rest in the late afternoon, before enjoying a relaxing evening at one of many great restaurants in Siem Reap.

The tree temple. Its amazing to see roots of huge ,tall fig trees growing out of ancient stone structures and at times supporting these structures. It is interesting to see how these stone structures were built by mere placement of stones.
Amazing!. Amazing cultural and historical experience. Would advise to get there early so not too crowded and not too hot.

Fantastic setting for a movie. And at least two famous flicks, Temple of Doom and Tomb Raider, were shot here to take advNtage of the huge trees grown on and through the ruins with massive roots twined in fantastical patterns across the stonework. Go at dawn or dusk if you can to take advantage of the warm, soft light that time of day.

Lara Croft was here !. Fabulous temple in the jungle.Used for filming the Tomb Raider movie and you can see why. This is a truly atmospheric experience and probably the most exciting of the temples to visit.

Tomb Raider. Our guide was mainly interested in taking tourist snaps of people at this temple while talking about Angelina Jolie! Fab temple - definitely worth a visit but again, would recommend knowlegeable private guide and go early. Absolutely heaving by 9am and quite small spaces, so a bit of a crush. Loses some of its magic!

An amazing attempt of nature to reclaim territory. Best known I guess for the filming of Lara Croft - Tomb Raider with Angelina Jolie, this Wat is truly astounding with huge trees and their roots destroying much of the temple. There is a currently a joint venture between India and Cambodia to restore this magnificent structure but I hope they do not go too far as the reclamation by nature is the major attraction in my opinion. A must see along with Angkor Wat.
Great but less interesting than Bayon or Angkor Wat. Still amazing scenery but a little more generic. I'll call it a must do as part of a day in the park but make sure you do the others.

Inspiring. This was the first temple we visited and it has been kept in a state of slow decay. The delicate beauty of the temples and the savagery of the vegetation were awe-inspiring. It gave us a sense of the Herculean task the archeologists have undertaken to recover the rest of the complex.

Growth of the trees into the temple structure is unbelievable and amazing. The temple structure was affected by the Fig trees (roots) provides a great spectacle and also challenge to the conservation of this temple complex.Great experience
lovely but busy. Although it is lovely there are so many other tourists there it can be a bit overwhelming. Def check it out when everyone is out at lunchtime :)

An amazing expression of Nature claiming its own. Photogenic with a great atmosphere with the magnificent trees growing out of the ruins and the jungle surroundings. We felt left in awe as we imagined stumbling across something like this on a jungle trek. Parts of it have been restored to give you a glimpse of this Mahayana Buddhist monastery and university as it would have been in the 12th century. Jayavarman VII made one of the main images to honour his mother, which is the personification of wisdom; the other to honour his father which is the personification of compassion. The energy is still present.

An impressive site. A beautiful temple trying to and not succeeding to fight the trees which have through centuries grown through the temple and now reign supreme. The roots of huge trees have completely enveloped parts of the temple. Trees have very strange colour bark almost pale silver. It is a sight that is magnificent to photograph. I loved it

Wonderful. What more can be said - the other reviews say it all. It is a definite must see. While getting crowded, there has been an effort to secure the ruins from more wear and tear without hindering the sights.

lots of tourists but just try and zone into the place - try and go anti clockwise if possible. i loved loved loved the combination of nature's growth through the beautiful hand makings of man, what is a little sad is that in order to try and save the temples - some of the marvelous and age ole trees need to be cut down - that upset me - but I can understand the reasons behind it, it's just such a pity becase that is what makes ta prohm so very special....

Incredible Place but A Long Walk to/from Site. Ta Prohm is fascinating - the old,huge ,overgrown trees, and other ruins. Place can be crowded though specially with tour groups. It's a long walk to/from the site. It's a good thing it was not raining otherwise it would be a muddy walk.

A Beautiful and Enigmatic Ruin. The most beautiful of the ruins around Siem Reap. Here nature interacts with the ruins. I have been to Siem Reap and visited the famous ruins around it three times, Ta Phrom is my favorite.
EXCELLENT VISIT. Excellent visit. very attractive ancient history. Suggestion : visit to be done at the end of the day to avoid to many people.

Incredible!. This entire place feels like a movie set. It's amazing seeing the way nature has has reclaimed this place. Things inside the main temple area can get very crowded with tour groups. We stayed here until near sunset, and things really cleared out.

Worth a trip. Even with Laura Craft, this is an amazing place. If you want to see the jungle invading the stone structures and feel how it must feel to live in this climate, I strongly recommend this temple.
Untouch ruins. The ruins is just the way it was found. Trees growing in, around and over the temple. The site is just one little temple.

After Bayon and Angkor Wat, this is a must-see. This temple has trees growing all over the place, with their roots swirling around the blocks and seemingly extending everywhere! The place is under construction and is in bad nick still, although the before and after renovation pics show just how far it has come. It was thronged with tourists though, so it was hard to get good photos and take your time to take it all in.

The very best!!. We left the very best for our last day in Siem Reap. We started early in the morning with a visit to Ta Prohm the temple that has been demolished by giant fig and silk cotton trees. These trees are still at work reducing the temple to rubble although renovation work has started. Build by Jayavarman VII for his mother in the late 12th century, hundreds of people now visit the ruins every day. The best place for photo opportunities. Together with the Angkor Wat Palace, THE place to see when you are in Siem Reap!

A long walk in but A nice walk to the ruin.. Give to the music players along the way if you can..they are all disabled and earn their living this way instead of begging....ps...everyone takes pictures at the famed overgrown ruin with straggler tree, but there are so many large trees to select from, both here and at other ruin sights.

Jungle temple. Aside from the usual associations with the Tomb Raider movie, this temple is pretty amazing! Seeing these massive trees that have taken root on temple roofs and then grown over centuries is impressive. Many photo opportunities, and also awesome for using the panoramic capability on my phone camera (S4). Loved it!

Ta Prohm. One if many temples, to check out. Try and get here early as many people here after about 11.00amAmazing trees built into the buildings. Lots of restoration work going on at the time.The trees are almost as fascinating as the temple.
A place so spooky, its unbelievable. Every temple is great and every temple is worth visiting. A definite place off my bucket list! From Angkor Wat to Bayon to Ta Prohm, the journey was amazing.
Favorite Angkor temple. My favorite temple of Angkor. Such a nice atmosphere in the Jungle with the sound of birds and the smell of nature.
Finally!. For those who've seen the Jolie movie must see this one. However, like most of the temples in Ankor Wat, this one is under maintenance. The trees are amazing, by the way.

Under intensive renovation. and sadly there was scaffolding everywhere plus due to its fame it was rammed full of people. This made it very difficult to see anything really and photos weren't great.I much prefered Ta Som which is also a temple where the nature has taken a hold but is not over run by tour groups.

Wow. Beautiful and wonderful. Try to go in the earlier morning. When busy, especially with noisy tour groups, some of the atmosphere is lost, but still, there is always a corridor or 2 you can get lost in and feel alone.
Fascinating. More shady areas. Stone work stunning amazing these were built 9/10th centuries. Guided tour is more meaningful

6 to 13 Century Cambodian Temples. I recommend Sophea as tour guide for his experience and knowlodge about this temple. The temple and sorrounding areas are beautifully and I recommended to visit this place.

Checked-off an item on my bucket list. Definitely one of the wonders of the world, and nature. Some 600-years old trees grew up on top of the walls, their roots looked like melted candles. It was very crowded though, and sometimes it was hard to take a picture without other tourists in it. It was worth the trouble, though.
Best temple in Siem Reap. I just loved it here where the trees have become an integral part of the buildings. Get there early before the large tour groups arrive. We were there well before 8am

Spectacular! Nature always has the upper hand.. This was one of the temples we saw during a three day flying visit to Siem Reap.The temple has been reclaimed by nature in a spectacular way and hole place really looks quite surreal. The various buildings are been restored and soon it will get closer to what it looked originally.A must see place and worth going with a local guide who will always get to you to the interesting places to see and well worth the extra cost involved.The one day pass costing 20USD covers all main temples in the area.Don't miss it even if you have only one day of sightseeing.

A Must See. Apart from Ankor Wat this has to be a must see. Seeing how the jungle has blended with the temple is incredible and shows natures power. Even though they are rebuilding it there is still a lot of the original buildings to enjoy along with the nature surrounding it.

The jungle reclaims! . A little bit crowded, but the crowd seems to disappear as you wade through the temple ground. Just a lovely place to explore because you can hide from the sun! The giant trees poking out beneath the ruins is... Without words to describe! You have to see for yourself! We explored this as a part of our bigger circuit of Angkor temples.

It's one of the best ting i have ever seen. Its one of the best temple complex i have ever seen. We went round 3.30 pm and came out of the place round 6 pm. But let me tell u one thing you may spent hrs but its not enough.

Under restoration but totally worth it. We went during the afternoon just after the height of the sun at its fullest and the views were still amazing and made for wonderful photos. The trees really have a way of creating enough shade but letting enough sun that it doesn't matter what time of day you go. Loved it. People say to wear these super heavy clunky shoes- you don't need them.

What Atmosphere!. You can really feel that you are in the jungle when visiting this temple. The number of people visiting with you detracts a little from the spectacle but the size of the trees encroaching on the ruin take your breath away. I feel that it is a good idea to show the condition of this building as opposed to other temples as it gives a real feeling of what happens if the wilderness is allowed to encroach on a structure. One of my favourite temples in the Angkor complex

Top of the list. A bit crowded but not enough to detract from this fantastic place. Words are hard to find to describe it. Left untouched since it's"discovery" it only needs Indiana Jones to complete the fantasy. If you can only go to one attraction this should be it.

Tree took over- Must see. You just can not beat the nature. The trees took over the temples lock stock and barrel. It is lovely to see. It clearly shows how long these temples were hidden from public view.
Keep this in your radar during Angkore visit.
A Favourite. Although the crowds were big, it was still an amazing experience. The majesty of the trees sprouting and engulfing the ruins. Breathtaking

My favourite temple in Angkor Wat!. I visited quite a few temples in Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm is definitely my favourite one! With its amazing combination of trees growing out of the ruins and the jungle surroundings ... just magical!

Loved this temple.... The banyan and other trees growing over the temple walls is incredible. One of my favorite temples. Go early to avoid all the tour buses and hordes of people...we always got there by 7:30 - 8am.

The seclusion where you can truly find yourself.. This temple is what you imagine, trees growing over ancient structures piercing light and a sense of tranquillity. The problem with Ta Prohm is by 8.30 the whole ambience is destroyed by bus loads of Eastern European and Asian Tour groups. If you want a great experience get to Ta Prohm at about 6.00am and ask to go to the Western gate the back door gives you an extra half hour of peace and quite.
Stunning - especially at 5am. We followed the (good) advice given to us and got up at 5am to be here ahead of the crowds as the sun rose.It was absolutely worth the effort - quite breathtaking!

The classic tree-torn temple. Many of my photos of this temple have people in them - which I normally avoid. The point on this visit was to show how massive the tree roots are and how they dwarf us mere mortals. This temple is small, but complex (our guide was quite concerned about losing us). I could have stayed for a few hours, but as usual, the tour group had to move on. Give this temple 2 hours or so if you are a keen photographer - the textures and patterns alone will keep you mesmerised. Wear sensible shoes and watch your step - everything here is out of plumb!

Temples. So many temples around Angkor Wat near the city of Siem Reap but this one is a bit different .Not only was it the location for the movie Tomb Raider but over the centuries the trees have embedded themselves in the remains of the walls. Yes many temples here but this one to me was just so different and interesting

Hauntingly beautiful. We avoided the crowds as much as we could, entering from the South gate and taking our own directions.This is the temple I really wanted to see, as the images I have seen are so spiritual. Some parts of the rebuild may have diminished this slightly. If you sit still and imagine the buildings as they were before the jungle invaded them, then sitting for centuries slowly becoming part of the landscape, it is eerie. We loved Ta Prohm and took some great pics.

Most interesting of all temple sites. Ta Prohm was the most interesting and amazing of all the temples in the Angkor Wat area. It is spectacular in not what it was built as but in what it has become. The jungle has taken over this place with such finality that the huge trees and their roots now appear to be parts of the structure in keeping it still standing. I am sure if any attempt is made to remove the roots the structure will collapse.It was amusing to see that the temple is hyped more with the tourist groups by their guides because of the Tomb Raider filming here on Angelina Jolie. The crowds were the thickest at the spot where she was supposed to have been filmed in action. In that packed area I could hear guides in at least three languages including Japanese explaining the site to the groups. I did not understand a word they said but I did hear Angelina Jolie mentioned at least four times with great emphasis. It almost sounded like that this ancient temple was dedicated to her than any of the gods the Khmer worshiped.There is a lot of restoration work going on at the site and care must be taken not to lose your footing and injure yourself inside the temple structure.

Absolutely Amazing!. It's quite a sight to see how the roots of the Champak tree have symmetrically wrapped themselves around temple structures. Quite an unusual structure, there is nothing like this anywhere in the world, I think.
Exciting!. Again, climbed and admired the architecture and details of the buildings, visible even though covered in hundreds of years of moss and growth.
big and tall trees. we went here because tomb raider shoot here.and its a long walk,many stones are crampled but they are into construction nowadays.but you still see the beauty of the place.

See the harmony between human architecture and nature.. This is a small temple. So long time, there is no trace of human. and so this temple became nature things from human things. many parts of temple are collapsed. collapsed parts are replaced to big trees. Visit earlier. small temple but so many traveller(sepcially group traveller).
The Giant Trees!. This is also one of the temples you have to visit. Unlike the other temples you will find giant trees and roots entangled with the ruins. It is absolutely an amazing site.

A must see. We entered from the back and were confronted with huge tour group crowds and a restoration which pretty much looked like a 'Disney re-build' (i think this restoration seems to miss the point of Ta Prohm). Away from this, Ta Prohm lived up to expectations with huge trees consuming the temple ruins ..... a definite must see!

Impressive takeover by nature. This temple is impressive because of how it blends into with nature right now. It is so calm and peaceful there. Giant trees now hold some of the walls of the temple with their roots. This place is very harmonious and has a certain balance.
Under repair. Beautiful temple (from Tomb raider) but under repair at the time of visit so could see more scaffold than anything else.

Wow!!. When you have seen a few temples around Angkor you can become 'templed out', at this point you need to re-inspire your sight seeing with this marvel of nature meeting the ancient world. What a place, unlike anywhere I have ever been before. A must see

Travelling through time. Ta Prohm was excellent really, but we were unlucky to visit at the time when some restoration was going on so some areas were not open for visiting.As everywhere, expect a lot of people around.Try to avoid the crowd by visiting early in the morning. Of all the temples of Angkor, Ta Prohm is the easiest to imagine covered by jungle…and in another time.Good spot for geocaching lovers 
Beautiful. Amazing place, had a guide which I thought was great as I clearly understood what each temple was for
Ta Prohm the BEST temple. Love the trees growing through the temples, less restoration and it looks amazing, some work being done to restore it so not all of it is open (January 2014)

Really enjoyed it. I actually enjoyed Ta Prohm more than any other temple. Yes, there were people everywhere and at times it was a bit crowded, but the entire area has that mystical feel about it.The ancient trees growing in, on and around the temple are just fantastic. There is also a team of specialists slowly restoring the temple by hand - it's painfully slow but you can see real progress and the place is starting to come alive even more.Even though Angor Wat is impressive and is a must see, I actually enjoyed Ta Prohm the most (it just feels more intimate). If you have no time to visit any of the temples in Siem Reap, then just see this one (otherwise this temple and Angor Wat will suffice if you have a bit more time).Love Cambodia, it's people and Siem Reap.

Amazing, each temple is different. Atmospheric, if you can ignore the crowds, we were there in peak season. The temple is falling down with beautiful trees and roots pushing their way through the structure. Occasional artists selling their wares, but not hassling. Definitely worth a visit. We visited just three temples, this one Ta phnom and angkor Wat and they are all so different it was definitely with a visit to these three. Not 5 stars because there were arrows trying to guide the large crowds in a particular direction but they were very confusing and their was quite a bit of scaffolding and covering over sections. I am probably being a bit mean!

Indiana Jones Temple. I was there at 12:30pm. It was hot and crowded. Had to wait in long lines to get pictures. I really enjoyed watching how the roots off the tree grew. They are actually holding the temple together. makes for good pictures. Be prepared to walk. Loved the temple. Must see.

Recommended it. The temple is decades old and the place holds some great historical importance. The visit to the temple was on the advice of one of my close friend. I was here in this city for business purposes and in evenings I really need to have some fun by spending my time with friends on the streets or by visiting historical and recreational places. We used to have dinners outside and I rarely had something to eat in the hotel. The hotel was quite close to the famous places so I did not have to worry for spending my extra time after getting free from business related activities. One Sunday I had an opportunity to visit this place in the afternoon. I would say that we must visit places considering varieties. We usually go to beaches, theatres and amusing parks and avoid going to historical places. I recommend going to places like this one.

An exilirating tour of temples and more temples. Spend a whole day here at Angkor Thom, the ancient city of the Khmer Empire near Siem Reap that is marked by the Bayon and Ta Prohm Temples, among other structures. Learn a bit or two about conservation and how the temples and other structures are being restored as you go along the way. You need a full day here.

Spectacular trees. Ta Phrom lies a little aside the Angkor Wat. It's another relic from the 12th to 13th century Khmer empire. Spectucular are the fig trees withn there roots all tangled up in the ruins. Very photogenic.

Nice place, but very crowded. It's a nice place, and one of the must-see's in Angkor Wat but it can be to crowded there, so make sure to go early in the morning, or maybe late in the afternoon, maybe just before closing time.

Just magical. Honestly, this temple and surrounding temples were the absolute highlight of our trip. They were the reason we travelled over the border to Cambodia in the first place and we were not let down. It still blows my mind how this kind of attention to detail and craftsmanship and architecture was possible given the technology available to the builders at the time.

My idea of an Indiana Jones Temple. Having always been a big tree fan I was really looking forward to my visit to Ta Prohm, I was not disappointed. The whole complex is stunning and the trees lived up to my expectations. I noticed a few other people have commented on the crowds as I went on Christmas Day the only others there were Cambodians. Apart from Angkor Wat this area really has to be visited when in the area. Wow.
Prettiest of all the temples. This was our favourite of all the temples, the only thing we didn't like was the large amount of tourists, might be quieter during wet season.

Proof of Ancient aliens. This temple is famous for the roots growing to huge size and swallowing walls. BUT, the most amazing thing in this 800 year old temple is a bas-relief of a dinosaur, extinct for 8000 years. HOW? Worth finding!!!
Overrun but worth it.. Overrun with tourists. Definitely one of the popular temples thanks to Lara Croft (one of the resons we were there!). But would definitely recommed seeing anyway.
DINOSAUR CARVING - DONT MISS. THERE IS A STEGOSAUR CARVING !its not easy to find by yourself, search the location on google to find it ! or hire a guide
Eaten by the Jungle. This is the temple where the roots of the trees are just "melting" with the walls and temples of this beautiful temple. A kind of Indiana Jones feeling once you're there!

the most particular I ever saw, a „must” to see. Ta Prohm Tempel is situated a bit far approximately 1 km from Angkor Tempel, but really worthy to see!! but advice; you must be carefully.The best thing is that this temple complex is still in the same condition in which it was found: So nice picture shooting or filming and atmospheric combination of trees and their roots growing out of the ruins and the jungle around have made this temple one of Angkor's most popular temples to visit; It was built as a Buddhist Mahayana monastery-university.

An amazing place. very special. I loved Ta Prohm more than any other of the Angkor wat Temples. It has a very spiritual feel to it. The best time to see it in my view, is very early 6 am.. After that it loses it ethereal feel. Also the chatter of large tour groups is distracting for mind and photography.

Ta Prohm. The stuff that movies (and fairytales) are made of! There was a lot of reconstruction / renovation going on but walkways were put up to make getting around easy enough. Unfortunately there were two busloads of extremely loud and inconsiderate tourists around at the same time. Maybe it's just me but the lack of any kind of respect and consideration at what is really a rather holy site just annoyed me.

was worth it. Ta Prohm was on the bucket list of things to see in the world and it was worth it. Exactly as I expected...It is complete enough to get a general sense of the place, but with the addition of the big figs it becomes very special...do yourself a favour, go see it.

Beautiful and interesting. This is a must-see temple. It was definitely our favorite because of the amazing trees. We went around 10am, and there were quite a few people there. If you are spending more than one day, it might be nice to get there around 8am, and beat the sunrise viewers from Angkor Wat.

Iconic tree root photo shoots. Amazing place, spooky with the iconic tree roots strangling the walls and carvings but although sad that the trees are damaging these amazing temples there is a peace and calm within these walls. You can easily imagine Indiana Jones running thru this temple chased by some crazed Indians with poisonous darts flying everywhere, ok great imagination but I Would so love for CGI. To be used to recreate these places as they once were in their full glory and colour, they must have been awesome to those approaching in a flat landscape and with so much colour and splendour, they were obviously amazing feats of craftsmanship, so many stone masons and supporting builders, no mechanical help, an army of people to feed the workers, amazing!!!!. I also love the countryside around these temples, Cambodia is a very lovely place. I would suggest that you buy your. 3 day pass the day before you plan to visit and avoid the 2 hrs or more lost at the ticket office, they are valid for 7 days and you can use them for any 3 days in that period. As with all the temples be careful, there is little evidence of repairs or restoration, there are steep steps and crumbling walls that at some time will fall, just be aware but for sure we'll worth the visit.

Amazing Roots. There was a lot of restoration work going on and some of the walkways were dangerous but the sight of the enormous tree roots clinging to the rocks far overshadowed any reservations we had about health and safety. Watch out for the Korean tourists who take ages photographing each other in front of the ruins!

Amazing. Best temple in angkor. There is so much places for great pictures and amazing the way the trees are growing through and around the temple. Some great restoration work has been done here also.

The best temple. Absolutely wonderful place. We did not experience crowding as others have, even though we went over our Christmas vacation. We saw Ta Prohm iin the afternoon and that may be the best time to see it as we had no problem with crowds.The area is indeed spooky, and as others have said, the temple and its semi-restoration make you feel as if you had stepped back in time. Hire a guide from your hotel to understand the temple better.

Stunning Temple. Just a beautiful temple - the one covered in tree roots seen in all of the photos of the Cambodian temples - a must visit. There was some restoration work going on whilst we were there so part of the temple was closed off but there was still plenty to discover and enjoy. The surrounding trees were spectacular too.

Loved the temple, worst crowds in Angkor. Second time visiting Ta Prohm, both visits were in mid-January. The first, about 5 years ago, was no where near as crowded as this trip. The temple is amazing, mostly in ruins but with beautiful banyon trees which have taken over the temple with their roots. This trip, the number of tour groups made it nearly impossible to appreciate the temple or the banyon trees. I would give it a third go, but definitely not during the high tourist season.

My favourite. I loved the way the enormous yes were part of the structure. It allows us to see just how old the whole place is. It was very busy and a lot of renovation work continues on the temple but a great place to visit.

Fantastic temple. Ta Prohm is an beautiful set temple. We went were straight after the sunrise and we had the temple nearly to yourself. The ruins with all the trees growing out gives you a mystic feeling. Best time to visit is early in the morning when it is not s overcrowded.

Always worth a visit.. Brilliant, we have been three times now and it is amazing. Make sure you have a good guide who has a good understanding of your language because there is so much to learn about this place

The most amazing of Angkor Temples. Still under restoration, that's the temple where you get the real feeling of archeologists back in 1800s when they found the temples abandoned and forgotten in the middle of the forest. You feel like an Indiana Jones!It's just amazing to see nature claiming back it's space, with giant (and I mean it... GIANT) trees growing on mold covered structures, many of them still untouched by restoration... only by 500 years of nature action!If you're into photography 3pm-5pm is a great time for lighting.

Fantastic. Great photo opportunities. I recommend purchasing a book from one of the many hawkers to enable you to read a little about the history plus it will enable you label your photos when you get home.
amazing. an amazing site, it goes on and on, think tomb raider, wonderful photo opportunities, a visit to the archaeological park is not complete without a visit to Ta Prohm

Wonderful, a bit spooky and my favourite temple. This temple is 6 kms east of Bayon Temple. It has loads of massive trees roots growing from the ruins. Built in the 12th Century, it is a must see along with Angkor Wat and Bayon Temple, all Unesco sites. Your ticket is good for all sites.You need to hire a tuk tuk or a bicycle to get to see them all. You can buy a ticket which is good for all sites the day before your visit and it is valid from 5pm the day before the ticket is issued for, so you can go watch the sunset and get your bearings the evening before.
Fascinating!. Loved the "ruins" of this temple. It's like you have travelled back in time. The trees and roots growing out from everywhere were just surreal.

Awe inspiring. What a magical spot!Ta Prohm is so much more than the famous pictures of the twisting trees wrapping the ancient stones. It is much larger than expected and you are basically free to clamber and explore the site at will. For the best experience I highly recommend going very early in the morning. I arrived around 6:30 a.m., a good 2 hours before the mass of tour buses and tuktuks so the place was nearly deserted, a huge bonus! Bring good shoes and your camera and plan to spend a couple of hours to really soak in the atmosphere.

jungle temples. this is the Indiana Jones temple you have always wished to see... beautiful. Even with crowds you can find a quiet corner. The touts are annoying here too - and they hunt you down. However it is worth a visit and a donation to the Khmer band of mine victims outside. Inspired location and reliefs.

I felt like Angelina Jolie ;-). mind blowing to see those trees eating away temples built long long time ago. If you are going to travel to Siem Reap please do yourself a favour and stay at least 3 nights.

Definite Must See!. This site is a definite must see when in the Siem Reap area! We went in the afternoon and stayed until closing. The afternoon sun provides the perfect light for enchanting photos of these temple ruins. Don't just stay in the main sections with all the other tourists, but venture out to the sides of the ruins for a more intimate and quiet experience as well. Take your time and enjoy it. The fee was included in our 3 day pass to all the Angkor sites.

Enjoy. We loved this temple and the old trees coming out of it. It really did blow us away. Having a guide really does help, as he knew how to avoid most of the masses, great photo spots and lots and lots of information about the temples, what we were looking at etc

Stand Back and relax. This is a stunning temple, another of those bucket list moments, but relax enjoy the spectacle, stand back and look at the beauty of man and nature. Everyone is going for the photos and appear not to be seeing the place. Loved every minute but explore the less busy parts and you will love the experience. Watch the photographers, don't be one, I waited patiently while one cameraman lined up the perfect photo, he took at least 12 shots and held up everyone. I stood back and got some great shots. Cokes water and coffee always seemed to be $1!!! Not 3 that someone else mentioned.

Under reclaim from giant trees. Temple in itself is very big and a major portion is being reconstructed by assembling different pieces together. Giant faces of Indian gods and Buddha line the temple. The English speaking guide was really good during the circuit tour.

neat (but less to see than I expected). This was my husband's favorite (a Tomb Raider fan) temples but I expected there to be more to the complex and it was really rather small. This can be a good thing because there is a lot to see if you try to do it all in a day. Expect this to be a fairly quick stop!

good place. I was surprised to know that this temple has been conserved by Cambodia Government in collaboration with the Archaeological Survey of India. The place has a good charm of its own. However, it was terribly scorching and sunny. Do remember to take your hats and sunglasses in all temples, not only Ta Phrom, but also Angkor Wat and Bayon.
Most amazing temple. Simply stunning, we didnt want to leave and spend the whole afternoon wandering around this breathtaking place.

Pretty good. Ta Prohm is quite nice but at the time we visited was undergoing reconstruction works, the work done and being done made me realise how much things had been restored and replaced in the national park, it was something I had not considered up until that point. This temple is obviously worth seeing and that famous tree is great to see in person. Tomb Raider was filmed here, but Mortal Kombat was filmed at Angkor Wat, and we all know which film is better (the one without Angelina Jolie in it obviously).

Another must see temple. Interesting to see how nature has overgrown the temple ruins. Lots of interesting photo ops. Ask your guide to take you through the forest (about 15 minutes walk) so that you can see the entrance gate with the 4 faces. And use insect repellent if it's late afternoon. This temple has become popular thanks to the tomb raider movie but even inspite of that was always worth a visit

Ta Prohm is owned by Vietnamese businessman!. Did you know that this amazing site was sold off to a vietnamese businessman by the Cambodian political leadership? When you pay the $20 to see Ankgor Wat, you are giving it to a private business based in Vietnam. This really shocked me. The entire Ankgor Wat complex is amazing and worth seeing. It is ridiculously expensive though--for example a can of coke costs $3 US! Don't eat at the restaurants in this area unless you have money to burn!
is nice. ones of the best places to go, i recomend it its, nice,. but its fare away in tuk tuk, spend no m,ore than 10 dolars in it, what its insane

Still love the place but degrading fast. When I visited Ta Prohm in the hectic years, when mine clearance was a big concern here - I fell in love with those majestic trees. Now two decades have barely passed and the location lost all or most of it's glorious beauty. Hordes of sightseers and your usual suspects of mass tourists flock the spot. Had my fair share before and do not complain - too bad that they didn't preserve the authenticity in style. Still giving it the max rating, but won't return here.

Should be on your bucket list. Awesome. Incredible. Suggest you do sunrise at Angkor Wat, then head directly to Ta Prohm. That way you will beat the hordes that descend on Ta Prohm later in the day. Also suggest you have a guide. If the guide is a good one, they will impart a great deal od knowledge to you. Ta Prohm is a testament to how nature reclaims that which was once its own. So wonderful to walk around the ruins. Not wheelchair accessible. Must purchase ticket before going to Ta Prohm.

My favourite. This temple is the jungle temple with the iconic trees growing over the structure. superb. When we were there there was some restoration work happening which limited photo opportunities at the most famous spot but I still got the shot. Don't miss this temple?

A bit overrated now. The "TombRaiderAngelinaJolie" temple is a bit overcrowded and thus overrated now in my opinion. If you are looking for remote and newly discovered temples, it is better to travel a bit further out of the Siem Reap area.

Trees. This temple was being rennovated but even with all the scaffolding around parts of it, it was amazing. There are these giant trees almost comparable to California Redwoods in size but with root structures so big a Hobbit could live in them. There are areas around the main temple where the stones that once were walls and maybe buildings are piles of rubble, but this adds to the ancient mystique of the site. Great photo ops everywhere because of the massive trees whose roots intertwine around the stone walls and rock piles surround and infiltrate the temple.

More than "Tomb Raiders". This is my favored temple ruin in all of Angkor. That the trees are left to overgrow the ruins is wonderful. Angelina had good taste to use this temple for the movie. Highly recommended.

well worth a visit. Nice because it was quite different from Angkor Wat and Bayon. Lovely shaded spot which was very welcome with the heat and very interesting with the trees growing out of the ruins.

Ta Prohm - Tomb Raider and awesome century old trees. Went there to see the super famous and super old tree shown in some of the scenes in Tomb Raider. Still lucky to have seen some parts of Ta Prohm even if they were renovating in Oct. 2012. When I came back last June 2013, they closed most parts of Ta Prohm, there was nothing much to see. I'm pretty sure it will be great once the renovation is done. Just a bit worried since they cut sooo many trees :(

WOW! Get there before the buses.. This is the most magical of all the temples, why, because they left it (sorta) how they found it. The archeologist have spent a lot of effort maintaining the buildings how it was rediscovered in 1800s. As far as I am concerned, that was the most brilliant idea ever. There are a ton of tourist there, so get there early. Plus it gets so hot during the day that its much nicer to relax at the pool in the afternoon. I recommend going around sunrise. Its really twisty in there, like a maze, with wonders at every turn. I recommend a guide to learn more about the history and what the different friezes mean. They are also doing a lot of work on the temple now, which is interesting also. The best temple in the entire park.

Simply stunning. This is the most bizarre temple as some sections has been left (sort of) untouched so it is posible to see how the jungle is slowly devouring the temple. For best experience is better to enter from the South gate to avoid the crowds an early in the morning, if time allows it.
A great place for history. This whole area was great to explore, I should have downloaded an audio guide - lots of history and interesting aspects to learn about.

A temple which preserves its natural surroundings. Brilliant! Ta Prohm is a temple which is still undergoing restoration. What makes it unique is that it keeps its main buildings and temples with trees growing in it, around it, surrounding it. You can see really old trees with huge roots around the temple buildings. There are many great spots where you can take beautiful pictures with the natural trees growing in Ta Prohm temple. Definitely worth a visit.

Very unusual temple. Although many of the temples are amazing, this was my favorite. The way the trees have become a part of the temple makes it unique. Iet is a fun place to visit...it feels like a maze but with a surprise at every corner. It is also feels less hot here because of the way the trees have grown.

Simply Stunning. This was our standout temple - but get there before 8am......really stunning, with the temple overgrown with amazing large trees....you can imagine how difficuly it was to find these temples originally...our favorite, but better when quiet

Ta Prohm is worth a visit. Great site and not as many tour buses if you pick your time. Its large so allow plenty of time and take water. Don't believe the kids - they don't need the $1 for school- education is free in Cambodia. It doesn't mean you don't buy - just not for that reason. And remember that $1 for you probably isn't much if you're bargaining but to the locals it can be a lot so think about that if you are negotiating. Winning isn't all.

Like it was found. The real attraction of this temple is not that it was in Tomb Raider but that it is currently the least restored temple (of the major groups anyway). It is the closest visually to what it would have been when it was rediscovered by the Portuguese.The symbiosis of the trees and the buildings is amazing and aesthetically spectacular. A must see, if you only have a day the Bayon Temple inside Angkor Thom, Ta Phrom outside of Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat give the best tastes of the temples. Bantay Srei aka the lady temple is also worth a visit such a different and distinctive style.
Bring on the repairs.. Got a bit confused at the start but then followed the enormous crowd. Loved the huge trees growing though the temple. Great to imagine how old it is.

A must see.. I had luck to visit the temple when there was not too much crowds. The temple itself is amazing and provides a few small nooks where most big tour groups don't squeeze into. Great photos can be taken at almost any corner.Certainly a great temple to visit.

Fantastic trees, try early in the morning. The famous "temple with the trees" is big and very, very popular. It was the most crowded when I visited.If you like photography or hate crowds, go early in the morning around 7. The trees will look fantastic with the soft light and you will be able to stroll around with very few people. It really adds to the atmosphere, even more than other Angkor temples. It's also good in the afternoon around 4:30.If you just leave the courtyards with the famous trees, you will see fewer people and you might enjoy some fine carvings above the doors. Be very careful if you feel like scrambling around masonry as it is loose and may fall.

Tomb Raider is a Favorite. This is obviously one of the most popular temples due to the more natural/jungle/exotic look. There are a few others like this (Beng Melea, for example) but it is a conveniently located, and fun, temple to visit. Be sure not to miss it.

awesome !!!!!!!!. Must see ! Ta Prohm is different from Angor Wat, the omi present smiling faces must have been an amazing sight in its day. This temple with its maze of corridors and towers with the Lokeshwara faces on every side of every tower lends it that mystic charm!
The Jungle or Tomb Raider temple. Really worth a visit just because its so different to the other temples. Good photo opportunities but being a small complex it can get very crowded.
Our top of the temples. Overgrown, under reconstruction and with a jungle feel to it. We enjoyed this temple the best of the 'big 3 - Ta Prohm, Bayon and Angkor'.

Amazing. Ta Prohm was amazing, you can see where the movie industry gets its' ideas from and why it was used for the Tomb Raider movies. The size of the trees growing on the ruins is something, in many cases they hold the temple together.

More than expected. With all the advertisements describing this as the "Tomb Raider Temple," I was expecting a let-down. It wasn't. In several places, there are trees growing on top/on the roof of the temple and it really gives you a sense of history and the cycle of life. Whatever humans build, nature can still find a way to overcome it. The fact that the temple is in the process of being reconstructed emphasizes how elaborate the stones are, and the significance of the Khmer Empire in creating structures like this in the 13th Century. The only drawback is that there are so many tourists, and many are loud and don't obey the rules about where they are allowed to go. It was annoying, disruptive, and disrespectful. Nevertheless, nature overcomes and this is still a beautiful site.
.. Our group went very early. Best time to visit and escape the crowds, so you can have time to roam around and take plenty of pictures
Must see!. The entire Angkor Wat complex is amazing - and Ta Prohm is NOT to be missed! Go early to avoid the crowds.

Romantic. Hollywood knows their locations. This temple definitely has class. it is romantic, grandious, mythical and now famous.Visit it in the afternoon, shortly before sunset. The sones come alive and the scensery is incredibly beautiful.

Do get a guided tour. The trees that grow on and around the ruin have fused with the architecture and as such can't be removed. Quite possibly the highlight of the temple complex in the Siem Reap area.
Crowded but nice. The Lara Croft temple is full of tourist but worth the visit. You pass Ta Prohm on the way to the Baphuon temple.

This was our favorite temple.. It probably did not hurt that this was the first temple we visited so we did have a bit of a WOW. The overgrowth by the trees and the roots becoming essentially part of the temple really gives this temple a different feeling from the others we visited. It is still being renovated. Does not have the scale of Angkor Wat which we visited at the end of the day.
Spectacular. Nuff Said really. Go see it, you would have seen anything like it before. Crowds are always there but its so cool they dont annoy so much...

Awe Inspiring!. My husband and I visited here last month and were simply awestruck as to how truly amazing this place is. It is a real testimony of nature vs man made monuments. Out of all the temples we have visited on our trip to the Angkor Complex (each one having something special and wonderful to offer), this one has to be the most atmospheric. We took the route through the jungle to get there and spent a few hours exploring. With having so many trees growing through the building, it is in need of restoration; so it was pleasing to see that the works are underway. It did mean that we could not access all areas, but I would rather have that than have such a beautiful place be destroyed.It is a really popular place to visit, especially following the Tomb Raider film, but despite the crowds, the visit is totally worth it. It is a huge complex in which there are so many wonderful things to see, such as beautiful carvings which have survived the wilds of the jungle and wars, unbelievably huge roots growing in different areas of the temple.

Amazing Ta Prohm temple. Ta Prohm is an amazing place to visit, a location used in the Tomb Raider film to full atmospheric effect. The trees growing throughout the temple take your breath away, I have never seen anything like this before. The temple was abandoned and neglected in the 17th Century when the Khmer Empire collapsed, and it is in virtually the same condition as it was found.A must do place to visit.
Loved it. Had a lot of fun exploring Ta Prohm - along with a stack of other tourists! Recommend walking around it a few times as you spot different details each time.
Fantastic. This was more beautiful then Angkor Wat, this is the place with the tree roots and huge trees covering temples.

Temple and Treetops. This is the famous temple seen it the movie the Tomb Raider. You will see very beautiful vegetation and ruins. We enjoyed this temple very much and bought a beautiful watercolor painting while we were there.

Unique and fascinating. Ta Prohm,I can say was so much more fascinating than Angkor! I was spellbound by how the trees have invaded the temple walls. I wish I had rather come here first than going to Angor first, because by the time I went here it was afternoon,hence very very crowded and hot! What I also liked is that on the way to the temple there was a group of handicapped locals who were playes local music,it was really beautiful , what I really appriciated was the fact that they did not beg for money, and were rahter making money by entertaining tourists.

Under Major Restoration but still memorable!. The Tomb Raider Temple!! I visited here before in 2007 and Ta Prohm was completely un-restored. Now it is undergoing a major restoration and has cranes, walkways, platforms and ropes to keep you constrained in some areas. Still worth a visit but get there before the crowds so it is a peaceful visit. Go straight from an Angkor Wat sunrise might be best...we did and just as we were leaving all the noisy buses of Koreans and Chinese were arriving...Peace Gone! Enjoy this wonderful Temple...it's still one of my favourite.

Amazingly atmospheric. The most atmospheric of the main temples in Angkor to my mind (and therefore my favourite). Still lots of people but somehow they seem better dispersed in the nooks and crannies and you can still find spots where you're totally alone. Definitely not to be missed

Ta Prohm. Ta Prohm - Mystical, Magical Adventure where Tomb Raider was Shot. This ruin is the stuff dreams imagine and awe takes hold. Part of the Angkor Wat, Siem Reap Archaeological Park. This is only one of many ruins to see in the ancient city...entry fees paid at the park entrance are valid for all the ruins. Spend at least a week if you truly want to see EVERYTHING - it's worth the visit! Ta Prohm is a bit off the beaten track, so plan to spend additional time driving to this site.

Nature and history. This temple needs to be visited, but it was probably my least favorite. There is a lot of work going on to stabilize the temple and the trees and although necessary, this really takes away from the beauty and magic of the palace.
Impressive. Trees growing triugh tepmle were mind blowing, so huge and so beautiful - I just couldn't stop taking pictures of them

Amazing!. Ta Prohm was amazing, we went right after sunrise as most people are at Ankor wat at that time. It was perfect. It was quiet enough to take pictures uninterrupted.
It was much smaller then I thought it would be.

Cicadas were deafening. We visited this fascinating site in the evening so there were not too many people around. The cicadas were deafening and it was very humid but it was a beautiful place to visit at that time of the day. The site has been left very much as discovered with huge trees growing out of some of the temple buildings, some of which have collapsed as a result. apparently Tomb Raider and one of the Indiana Jones films used this location for some scenes - you can see why. Stunning.

Memorable temple. This was temple number 6 for us and to be truthful altho I keep a journal and write up all informaioin some of them have gotten muddled up -however this one you cannot easily forget.the ruins are being held together by nature- yes this is the one that was featured in the film. This temple was built for the Mother of the king- most of them were built for a particular family member as that helped with attaining greater merit to becoming nearer enlightenment for Buddhist Kings at that time.Our guide told us that the walls would have originally held gemstones, gold plate,pearls and rubies etc- wow must have looked totally dazzling. The times of plundering and looting when the area became less used took away all that wealth. Again this temple housed people- at one point the monks and students maintained the building, they used to live there and clean the building.It was built in 1186 with the intention of it being a scholarly place- a school for the Royal Family aswell as for students- ie a sort of university.The dwelling places that were there originally have sadly all crumbled a long time ago.This temple was a big temple to be used by the people- unlike Angkot Wat which was only for the king and his retinue to use- for the god king ceremonies.After walking around you can leave and use the various stalls outside for some relief- fruit, delicious Cambodian coffee, snacks and meals- we had fish amok,aubergine curry and morning glory- exceptionally tasty- and no after effects! The stalls close at 5.30. You will also see lots of tiny children selling postcards, fridge magnets etc.they are so sweet and petite- they should be at school but often their fathers have no work and so the family cannot afford to send them to school so I did not feel bad giving them the odd dollar.
beau-tree-ful. Stunning temples whos beauty lies in its destruction by mother nature. Take pics from Lara Croft temple, and at the many, many massive tree roots. Picturesque, not to be missed!

Yeah, Tomb Raider movie scene!... Really cool! Look for hidden statue faces in between wicked tree roots. Tomb Raider movie site can get crowded, pick and spot and wait. Take a guide for hidden meanings,
Great. If your aré in seam reap you must see this. Will taje 1 TO 2 horas justo TO see This temple......is Battery if you have a tourist guide

Amazing site and great atmosphere. We went to Ta Prohm as part of our day in the Angkor Wat Park and were not disappointed. The kids loved this temple the most, because it had so much atmosphere and so many nooks and crannies to explore. It was even fun when we all got separated and had to find each other. Definitely for them the Tomb Raider element kicked in here, but even so they loved the combination of jungle and temple intertwining. I would have liked to go here earlier or later in the day though to see the light changing through the walls and windows so thinking we may need to go back for another trip.

Wow, what a sight!. Ta Prohm was certainly a sight not to be missed. We simply included it in a day trip we already had booked did and it was great. The trees and ruins are just phenomenal. Definitely worth a visit.

Our favourite temple. What a stunning and unique place. The temple complex met all our expectations. It was amazing to see the tree roots entwined with the bricks and the buildings still standing after all these years. we went with Backyard travel and their tour guide organised a small treasure hunt throughout the complex which was greatly enjoyed by both adults and children alike! This was definitely our favourite atmospheric temple. You have to see it to experience it , with or without the crowds!

Fave Temple . Of all the temples in Siem Reap this one was our favorite. The integration of the trees is just so cool. I'd recommend arriving before 8am to beat the crowds and buses that seem to flow all day. Arriving early will also help you get some better pics. They were doing renovations on part of the temple but this was not a problem as there was still lots to see.

Temple and Jungle. Experience the magical feel of a temple fused over time with jungle surroundings as you step into this complex...... not really...unless you go very early as others suggested, expect to be shoulder to shoulder with hordes of people during peak season/time. Its fame and unique surrounding means it is one of the place all tours will bring people to, the narrow walkway and temple structure ensure that you will always be with the crowd. Resist the urge to queue for picture taking at the most popular location as there are many parts of the temple where the tree grows into the temple, enjoy the visit, take some photos, walk right to the end and enjoy the perimeter of the temple. You will find many opportunity to capture a unique perspective of this temple

Worth visiting, but too touristy.... The temple is as stunning as it looks in the movie/postcard, but just a bit too touristy… Would be good if you go there really early in the morning, since most of the tour group go to Ta Prohm around 11ish after their visit to Angkor Thom

Our favorite temple!. It really is like being in another world! Despite the buildup around it, being the "Tomb Raider" temple, it really IS the best of the ones there! Bring a picnic lunch and stay for awhile!

Exceeded Expectations. This is what I had always imagined in my mind as the perfect temple experience. The merging of nature with the ruins of the temple are strikingly beautiful and speak volumes about man and nature. I wish I could have spent days there just to see the contrast of light and dark and the textures and colors of the ancient architecture and glory of the jungle becoming one. A wonderful experience, the only thing that would have made it better would have been less people. It is amazing how disrespectful some visitors were to the point that they would actually litter the area and disrespect the sacred aspects of such an ancient and venerable place.

Too Prettified. Cambodian conservators may have gone overboard in restoring the Ta Prohm complex. While the site provides a good glimpse of what the area was like when constructed, some of the sense of grandeur that comes from signs of aging is missing.

What man and Nature can do!. I am so grateful that the archeologists decided to leave the jungle in place, because in this way one can see what man can make and what nature over time takes back from man when left in peace. Ta Prohm was constructed in the end of the 12th century and was a buddhist Monastery. Today much of the monastery is in ruins, but you can see how the huge Kapok trees have been growing, slowly taking back the nature. Some restaurations are being made, but in principle they are never going to fully restore the temple, maybe because a lot of visitors wants to see this place because of the filming of "Tomb Raider" in the ruins? I liked the place very much, and recommend a visit to all who are interested in history.

Fantastic temple complex. The place itself was incredible but the experience was tarnished by fellow tourists who insisted on posing for ages in front of the temples. It was literally impossible to capture the beauty and history of the place without someone posing as if they were on a catwalk. Nothing wrong with having your photo taken here but honestly,this was more like a fashion show. Granted, we probably came at one of the busiest times, so you may have better luck. Phenomenal place though.

This Temple is a must.. Even if you decide on skipping some of the other temples do not skip this one. It took my breath away to see the most amazing integration of man made structures and nature. this place has the most amazing tree's that you will ever see in the world. The Temple itself was mostly closed off due to restoration works however its still amazing. From the many temples we visited by far this is my favorite.

Tomb Raider Temple. It was number one on my itinerary for I wanted to see and experience the temple where the entire Tomb Raider was shot and that is also the reason why many of the tourists actually head to this temple. The temple no doubt like many other temples around is not without the jungle dominance and is beautiful and an absolute delight for camera. The tour guide we took was really enthusiastic and informative about the place and showed around the place very efficiently. The temple is actually haunting with the clinging roots and overgrowing jungle from each corner of the temple complex. Ta prohm has a very unique ambiance and without the hustle and bustle of the touring crowd the place can actually be a little eerie. Depending upon the climate, it is better to get proper precaution in clothing and having a comfortable shoe comes as a necessity around the place as there is a lot of walk and climb.

Beautiful and Tumbled. You don't have to be Miley Cyrus to be on top of a destroyed stone wall! You've got it all right here!!! An amazing place with a tree growing right through the roof, with all the roots clutching the walls. The place of 'Lira Kroft: Tomb Raiders' and with traditional music in the background. There a tourists, but not a single photo we took had a tourist (except us) inside.

Busy but beautiful.... I got here 05.35 (in the dark) by 06.15 a dozen or more tourists were here. It is busy and the wooden walkways do not always assist the photos, but with patience it is possible. Some works were in progress but none to mar the images. Ensure you have a 10-16mm lens or much will pass you by.. Enjoy the beauty.

Enjoyed. Really enjoyed this temple, although it was quite busy with tourists. There is a fair bit of climbing over large stones fallen from the temple. For me this means sneakers or sturdy shoes is a must.

Where Tomb Raider was filmed. Amazing trees weaving through fallen temple and rocks...look for the hidden face in a rock! It's a must see temple...was good enough for the filming of Tomb Raider with Angelina Jolie! Great photos! Good to see some re-construction and conservation going on there too.

Early Important. This Wat is one that is really a "ground Level" one. By this i mean that when taking photos, the amount of people there really impacts your ability to capture your memories. We went to this Wat first and then did others as last time we could barely get photos without tour groups or stray people wandering into the shot. Brilliant place. yes there are major restorations happening at present, which again makes it all the more important to get there early

My family's favorite temple. My husband and daughter loved the jungle aspect of this temple. It has a total "wow" factor. Go there early if you are going during the peak season to avoid the large group tours that are often noisy, loud and pushy

Mystical temple entwined by tree roots. The entwinement of some of the temple makes this one very special. You feel as if you are one of the first to visit it (in reality, you are one of many thousand).We would recommend that this is the last temple on your itinerary as it will leave you with a really good feeling.

We LOVED this temple. After exploring a few in the region this one to use definitely had the most atmosphere. If you only have time to do one temple this is he one I would recommend. It is wild and dramatic - an excellent easy walk from one side of it through to the other.

Must See Angkor Temple. Ta Prohm is one of the "must see" sites in the Angkor complex. Referred to many locals as "Tomb Raider" after the Angelina Jolie movie was filmed on the site. Unlike other temples in the area, Ta Prohm has been left largely as it was found after the jungle encroached and took it over. Wooden walkways have been added to aid in navigation.Walking through the temple ruins is best done after seeing some of the other Angkor temples which have been restored and cleared. In contrast Ta Prohm retains its giant fig trees growing out , over and through the buildings along with stones and rubble. You want to believe that the temple is largely untouched (although some restoration has occurred). It's awe inspiring, beautiful and (if the crowds are thin) a little creepy as you navigate the passages.Tip: Schedule your visit to other temples in the mornings and Ta Prohm during the hottest part of the day. Shade is ample and the site remains relatively cool throughout the day.
Beautiful Temple. Magnificent temple, photographs do not justify the beauty of the temples. Very popular temple, was busy early afternoon with large tourist groups.
A must-see place negar Siem Reap. No matter if you have already visited Angkor Wat or even Bayon, Ta Prohm actually deserves to be talen into account.

Tomb Raider temple busy but impressive. The famous "tomb raider" temple is currently undergoing an extensive restoration so some of the most interesting sites are a bit difficult to access. Seems a bit sanitized with plenty of wooden walkways, though this makes the temple easy to navigate. This one gets very busy so save it for either early or later in the day. We visited around 8am and it was mostly empty. We stayed around an hour, plenty of good photo ops even with the ongoing works.
In the process of renovated. An interesting building that is in a very bad state of repair, although it looks as though renovations have started. Incredibly ancient and worth a visit

The Bestest. I guess it is because it features so often in all the literature from even when I was a small boy.With the figs growing into the ruins it still evokes the feeling of something lost and reclaimed.Oh and did I mention Tomb Raider featured it heavily. I think the temple upstaged the star....
must, must see. dont miss out on this trip, amazing, got to see it to believe it, photo's just dont do it justice!! could have spent the whole day but we only had limited time...

Magnificent Temple. Yet another magnificent temple that harmonised with the nature. The beauty of the temple is unbelievable. Don't rush through the walking, take some time to sit down and enjoy the serenity.
WOW. All the temples were much more that I expected. They certainly did not disappoint. Looking back we could have stayed longer and visited even more temples - we never got tired of looking at them!

The Jungle Temple is Amazing. We visited Ta Prohm last in our two day visit having gone to Angkor Tom, Angkor Wat and a couple of other temples. This is the temple that most people remember when they picture Siem Reap, with the trees growing over the walls and buildings of the temple. Quite large and many areas to explore.
Most Unusual!. This is probably something you will never see again in your life. Birds drop seeds and these trees grow and took over the buildings and roots grow down and over the temples.
Amazing but too crowded. Tomb Raider temple. Must see. Amazing but too crowded. Try to go there very early. Nice to take pictures.

Jungle Temple. This was an incredible experience! You really did feel as if the jungle could consume you at any moment! The tree roots and sheer size of them are totally unbelievable. Do not miss this temple!
Dont miss this temple. This is the temple where you get the full effect of the jungle having claimed the temple complex.Some restoration work underway but doesn't impact on the experience

Divine energy. I know this place got famous after Tomb Raider was shot here, but when i got there, 90% of people were too busy trying to take pics with the trees clinging to the walls and sides of the temples, and not focusing on the actual temples.Yes the trees are magnificent, the atmosphere had the most wonderful energy out of all the other temples i've visited due to nature's vibe indeed. It was awesome! But i just feel like people sometimes forget contemplate the temple itself.

Amazing as long as you are alone. Visited this temple at sunrise, with almost no other tourists.Went in the front of the temple a few hours later: it was crowded and I believe the visit would not be as magic with the crowds.

Amazing ancient ruins. This temple is unique and the jungle is trying to reclaim the area. There are amazing photo opportunities throughout the complex. This is where "Tomb Raider" with Lara Croft, played by Angelina Jolie was filmed. Best to visit early in the morning prior to all the tourists and souvenier sellers. Absolutely breathtakingly beautiful.
Part no 3 on the temple tour. The least excavated temple of the three famous temples near Siem Reap. This is were the trees "flows" over the wall and temples. Fine views.

Siem Reap Dec 2013. Accfess to Ta Prohm was somewhat tedious but once we reached it was like magic. The Indian Government working with the Cambodian Angkor organisation is trying to do its best but restoration work did not allow us to see too many areas.
Awesome. seeing how the jungle has tried to reclaim the place is incredible, but not as incredible as the people who built these amazing places
The best temple in the region. Unique temple where trees are trying to reclaim the area! Plenty of photo opportunities all over the temple complex

Ta Prohm rocks!. I only went on the "small" temple tour (not the "big" one) because for me this was more than enough.
Ta Prohm was definitely my favorite, mainly due to all the vegetation, with Ankor Wat in second place.
