Interesting Temple. Every temple in Siem Reap area is unique and has its own charm. The special thing about this temple is the giant tree roots which emerges from the temple ruin which is like a candy for a photography avid.

Best time to visit is early in the morning. Ta Prohm is one of the most popular temples in the complex. Often your exprience is shared with hundreds of other visitors. If you want to enjoy this beauty personally and quietly, I would recommend going directly there after your sunrise view of Angkor Wat. At that time of the morning, it's still and empty, leaving you to enjoy it all to yourself (and take photos with no bombers!)

One of the best, especially at 5am. Do yourself a huge favour and visit this place early in the morning, taking a flashlight to enhance the experience. It's like discovering the temples all over again... just you, the jungle, animals and ancient ambiance like no other place on earth.Then the mecca of tourists arrive at around 7.30am and it's just like herding sheep through a shed

Tomb Raider location. This temple was the location for Laura Croff- Tomb Raider. Surpringsly the movie was coming on HBO when I got back to the hotel. It was fun to see the same place I had just visited earlier in the day, in the movie. Seeing the trees growing on top of the temples was impressive.

Jungle Temple and beautiful architects. After the movie Tomb Raider, this temple is a must for tourist. So no reason not to do this. However, what most people miss is to go into details of the Kala face, and the small relief of the animal inside the temple. The guide can help locate all this interesting relief. The musicians playing Khmer music are making the temple sacred with their music. please support them small donation.

Perfect spot for Tree/temple sights. Lots of spots to walk round to get the photos that you want. The trees have been propped up by scaffold in some places due to the instability of some parts of the temple . Beautiful place to see

Ta Prohm. Made World famous in numerous movies, most notably the "Indiana Jones" franchisee movies.Most of the temple is in ruins and a few are being restored with the help of the "Archaeological Survey of India".The giant trees are to be seen to be believed and there is a huge rush to be photographed with the trees.

Nature wins. Its a sight to see all those silvery bark trees creeping through the temple monuments. Best visited during lunch time when there is less crowd - quiet moments in that environment is an awesome experience

Jungle's Revenge. The trees have literally destroyed much of this temple but it has been restored enough to give you an idea of what it was once like. The roots of the trees look like octopus arms in places. Tomb Raider shot some scenes here when they filmed. Worth the extra effort to find for sure.

Temple site. Yeah this temple is famouse but not because of the fim tomb raider. This temple was there before Hollywood was born and I am sure it will be there when nobody speaks about Hollywood anymore. Great to see the temple in the jungle. Go check it out its worth it but be sure that a lot of people are around you :-)!

Under construction and crazy busy plan ahead!. The Tomb Raider part of Angkor as it's most famously known is a knockout and one of the main reasons why people head to the archaeological park. A few hints for December 2013 - the east gate is quieter than the west gate (one closer Angkor Thom) - unfortunately there is A LOT of construction going on and renovations including scaffolding to large sections of temples and trees. There is even a crane erected to aid with restoration efforts. I do think it changes the feeling of Ta Prohm and to be honest I left a little disappointed. It was still amazing but perhaps prepare yourself that there will be restorations going on I'd say for a few months ahead. Plan your trip to avoid the busy periods if that is at all possible. A lot of tours seem to head anticlockwise around the small loop from Angkor Wat to Ta Prohm so perhaps you could head straight there in the morning.... What a fantastic place. Unfortunately the hordes of tourists and restoration efforts take away a bit of the magic. Still worth the effort!

Temple of Trees. Very much promoted due to Tomb Raider being filmed here, hence expect many crowds. Temple ground is undergoing several restoration works hence take care while moving around.Located within Angkor Thom, best ways to get there include renting a bicycle, or a full/half day car booking which costs around USD25. I used driver Sophean (+855 92 986 353) who spoke good English and told of tales and history of Cambodia. Entrace is included in the Angkor Heritage Pass - USD20 for one day and USD40 for up to 3days. I recommend the 3day pass as it is not possible to visit all in a single day. Hire a guide if you must for more elaborate understanding of the temples but I went temple hopping alone. Tour groups and large crowd in this temple makes it difficult to take nice photos - my driver recommended to visit this temple first before the rest for best pictures and less crowd. Normal itineraries usually include this as one of the midday or afternoon stopovers.Ta Prohm is mostly in ruins and trees overgrow the temple grounds but this adds an amazing feature to photos. Dress code recommended for temple visit include light sleeved tops, knee length pants at least and comfy shoes.

Top temple attraction in Siem Reap. Went with group and a guide. This temple is one of the top, if not the top, attraction in Siem Reap. The trees and roots over temple are a sight to see. It is also where Tomb Raider was shot. Do bring some water as there is some walking in humid/hot weather. Do not miss this one when in Cambodia.
Another great temple. Part of the temple complex, don't miss it. Make sure you take plenty of water as the temples are large and there is a certain amount of climbing and walking.

Extraordinary- if you only get to one temple, this is it.. IMHO, this temple is magical. go early in the morning so that you have it to yourself. We went right after the sunrise in Angkor Wat( which was disappointing.) But this temple was not. The trees grow into the bricks and on top of walls. Not to be missed.

Tomb Raider!. Part of the movie was shot here. The jungle ate the temple up. It is mostly in ruins and reconstruction is ongoing. The banyan like trees have roots like we have never seen before. They are incredibly long, huge and have wrapped themselves around the stone structures in an eerie, yet beautiful way!

Trees are more exciting than the temple itself. We only visited 3 temples on our trip to Siem Reap, of these, Ta Prohm's condition was the least appealing (the temple is undergoing restoration and hopefully will have more to offer once completed). The pathway to the temple reminded me of the walkway to Chateau Chenonceau in Loire Valley, but then everything else is centuries apart. The temple is more of an attraction for the trees and for the fact that the movie tomb raider was shot here. The trees are other worldly. The barks are huge, at least 5-6 feet in diameter, but our guide explained that they're hollow. There were many types of unique branches around the complex at which people stopped for a photo-op.The only interesting tower in the complex was the echo tower, where apparently the king beat his body (which then resonated in the tower) in an effort to cast away evil spirits before his prayers/meditation.

Gigantic roots over temple structures. A great walk across the temple grounds from West to East as the Tut tut leaves us on one end as we walked across to meet us on the other end. A very pleasant walk across a beautiful river, beautiful temple ruins with great shots of roots reclaiming back their grounds. Part of the tut tut tour

NATURE—AT HER MOST AMAZING!. There are at least 3 reasons, why you should visit this temple: 1) To approach this temple you will walk through a tropical rainforest. The jungle is close to other temple areas, but here you feel you are in the heart of the jungle. 2) So far there has been little restoration to this temple. In this more natural state you can sense its 800 years of history. In its dark corridors there is a strong feeling of mystery. (For this reason this temple became famous in 2000 when the movie, TOMB RAIDERS with Anjelina Jolie was filmed here.) (3) The overpowering sight of tree roots consuming the temple. The roots appear to crawl from room to room.
WOW place. It has ancient trees and their roots are everywhere, it is of course a must visit place while there, you feel like you are in a movie set

One of our favorite temples. It is amazing to see the tree's that grow around the temple walls and now currently are the only thing holding up some of these walls. It is a nice change of pace from the other temples here. It is a must see!

Unique. I love the trees that are growing from the ruins. It truly is an amazing site and a beautiful temple. This was my first temple I went to in the morning so there was hardly anyone around which was nice. One word of caution, there are soooo many children trying to sell you items here so just beware. Also be cautious if you're going to buy a CD from the musical group affected by the mines because their CDs only have one song on them even though they show they have 11 songs on them.... although I saw the funny side in this when I got home and played the CD.

You MUST visit this temple!!!!!! . The forest and the temple intertwined as one. I was taken away by the beauty. Went in the afternoon, beautiful light at 4-5pm. A lot less tourist during that time too. A must when u are in Siem Reap!

A must visit. The temple is kept as it. It has huge trees surrounding the entire temple. The movie tomb raider was shot here in 2000. What a site can't describe it in words. Worth a visit. It would've great if you went early morning as it is very hot during the day. A lot of walking so do wear shoes if possible.
wow. Make sure you get a good Tuk Tuk driver who will meet you at diff points as its a very long walk.Please be aware you will be asked at diff points around the temples to buy books cards etc

Probably our favorite temple, as it has been left untouched.. This is a peaceful temple, a little less touristy. There is an amazing silk-cotton tree growing through the temple, which is holding it together. Quite an extraordinary sight. It is a calm place to walk an feel in touch with nature.

Amazing - go early. This was an amazing experience. This is the ‘Tomb Raider’ temple and while it is crowded in as it gets later in the day do not miss it. Getting there early makes a big difference – do it right after sunrise at Angkor Wat and you’ll be rewarded. The temple is undergoing some renovation, but it's a long way from done. So it's crumbling in some places which makes it a visually stunning temple.There are a lot of corridors to follow – including some that are accessible if you scramble over some of the fallen blocks. There are ‘hidden’ inner sections of the temple that you will not see if you stick to the paths that everyone else is following. Walk around the whole temple – it’s worth it. With the trees growing throughout and on top of the temple and the massive blocks scattered throughout the temple it's a beautiful example of the temples. Hire a guide and driver to take you through the temples. There are nuances you will miss if you do not have someone to tell you the stories and the details. It's inexpensive and incredibly worthwhile.

Tomb Raider Temple. One of the most photogenic temple, unfortunately also one of the most crowded and cramped. Go early or very late if you want pictures with no people in it. Wide angle lens highly recommended.
Don't miss it. Get there early...maybe while everyone is going to capture Angkor Wat sunrise you can go to Ta Prohm instead and get great photos without the masses

Temple with huge trees growing on top of them. It is one of the most iconic temple out of all the temples. There are huge trees growing out of the building and it looks so amazing. Great for photoshoot. We went there directly after sunrise at Angkorwat and manage to take some good photos of the sun rays shining into the temple.

Most Unusual. The temple is very interesting because of how much is still preserved but also because of the way the tree roots have grown all around the structure. This gives you an eerry feeling but great photos and experience. You also get to see the area which was used for some shots in the Laura Croft movie.

Eerie - Nature's Revenge. The image of trees sprouting out from temple walls is iconic but you have to see it for yourself to have a sense of how awesome and powerful nature is, no matter what we build, nature can ultimately take it back.

Tree temple... It is amazing to see trees as old as 300 yrs linking themselves on the temple without breaking the temple.
Good things that restoration being done there

Lives up to its reputation. Yes its is busy - no matter what time of day, late afternoon is the best time, however there are still quiet spaces. It captures the power of the jungle and you cannot fail to be impressed.
Atmospheric. Just loved it. So peaceful and overgrown.could have spent much more time there. lots of restoration work happening.

This is why I came here!!. The magnifcence of the structure and the visual effect of the roots growing into the block structure was all that I thought it would be. An exciting adventure with new sights at every turn.
My favorite. The officals want to clean off the trees but the tourists and visitors want to keep them. I say...keep it.

Maze of Wonder. A 'MUST' when you go visit Angkor Wat. I highly recommend that you get a private guide who can ferry you around all the temples at the right times of days to avoid the heat and crowds.

spooky and fab. visit at dawn to be really spooked. spooky and fab. visit at dawn to be really spooked. in a very 'natural' state, as it was overcome by the forest, and still has trees mangled around it.

Must-see in Siem Reap. Easily one of the coolest temples you can see in SE Asia. Seeing trees grow through, and on top of, an ancient temple is just fascinating. Definitely go. My only complaint was the crowds - it was nigh impossible to get a picture without someone in the way. You might want to go during lunchtime or the high heat of mid-day when others seek shade. If this keeps up, they will need to start limiting how many people can visit at once... I listed "fee for this attraction - yes" due to the $20 (for a one-day pass) charge for ANY temple in Angkor Archaeological Park.

Kingdom of the Trees. Ta Phrom has been taken over by fig, banyan and kapok trees -- and therein lies its distinctive character.This temple is virtually untouched by archaeologists -- except for some clearing to make a path for visitors and some propping up here and there to prevent collapse. As a result one can experience the wonder and amazement mid-nineteenth century explorers must have experienced when they first set eyes on the jungle-clad temples scattered all over this area.

Awesome. This is an unique temple where trees were grow on the stone, you feel that you are Lara Croft while you're visiting this place. An amazing temple and don't miss it, a worth going.Best place for shooting as well.

Main reason to come to Siem Reap. If there were no other attractions in the park I'd still come. Ta Prohm is a historical site where the trees take your breath away. These trees can give you nightmares if you envision them in your garden surrounding your private house. My first visit, pre Tomb Raider time, gave me more freedom to take photos as there were fewer tourists and no renovation going on.I will have flashbacks whenever I eat a fig.

One of the best Temples for how nature has taken over. Great temple for all Fans of Ms Angela Jolie of Tomb Raider fame. Lot easier to get appround now they have built wooden steps and walkways, before you could break your kneck climbing over the slipperly stones.Bigger groups of hawkes that I remember and if your not with an official tour group they can get quite agressive in their sale pitch, as it they howned you both in and out of the temple.

Smaller but interesting. Pretty amazing that this temple dates from the 12th century - what engineering capabilities! The temple is mainly in ruins now, helped along by the Strangler Fig trees that give it such atmosphere. This temple was used in a "Tomb Raider" movie and I can see why! Since it is a smaller complex than Angkor Wat or Angkor Thom, it does feel more crowded. But, on the good side, the number of trees provides shade and coolness - a welcome change!

Yes, nature is the boss. This is probably, the most crowded temple on Angkor, mostly because of the Tomb Raider film. The Tuk Tuk drivers actually call it the "Tomb Raider Temple".If you can deal with the crowds, it will be a very pleasant visit. The view of the trees crushing the temple and taking back the space that was once jungle, is just awesome. Very impressive. Since it's a shady place, it's also a good spot to take a break from the heat.
Spectacular historic site. Trees devouring ruins really provide unique visuals. Mind-boggling what they could accomplish in the 12th century!

Crowded but nice and shady. There were so many people it was hard to enjoy this temple complex. Seeing the tress growing in so many directions from the temple walls is very interesting and does look just like the photos. It is worth seeing and I'm glad we waited until the heat of the day since it was a bit cooler here than some of the more exposed temple areas.

Fantastic. Of all the temples we visited in Siem Reap, I think Ta Prohm was the most impressive -- and that is saying loads!It's absolutely amazing to see how the jungle is slowly but surely reclaiming this crumbling ruin. Some parts almost look like they can't be real, with impossibly large vines twisting around and through crumbling bricks. It is honestly one of the most fascinating places I've been to on this planet. Its somewhat eerie and timeless beauty have to be experienced firsthand; if you come to Siem Reap you really must visit this temple, and be sure to schedule plenty of time to explore the grounds thoroughly -- don't just stay on the main pathway. You won't be disappointed; it is truly a one of a kind experience.

man vs nature. an amazing man-vs-nature structure. a must visit temple in the angkor complex..... you will see here a war between the huge trees and the ruins of the temples. this amazing site relives the memory of tomb raider (angelina jolie).... a must see.
WOW!. Laura Croft didn't do this place justice. Magical and mystical. There are so many temples in Siem Reap, but Ta Prohm is a must see. Get there early and avoid the crowds (and the heat).

Must do. Amazing must do but at 10am was extremely crowded which took the gloss off a little. Everyone lines up for a quick photo and moves on. But we were extremely thrilled to find the small "dinosaur" carving we had read about and that was definitely a highlight for the kids. Pleasant walk in past land mine bands and people selling various things.

Amazingly Mystic. On our visit to Siam Reap, we found Ta Phrom, quite a distance away from Angkor Thom, we relaxed on a nice tuk tuk ride to Ta Phrom.Ta Phrom was beauty re-defined. The entrance to the ancient temple was pristine with huge trees surrounding the area, with small ponds on both sides of the small temple.The Temple itself was small, but it was beautiful, aesthetic ruins at its very best. Huge trees has grown from inside the temple, over moss covered red stones. The giant, tentacles of shoots of the trees wrapped around the temple stones like an octopus. The sights was amazing and would be a painter’s delight and a photographers dream !  Would highly recommend this place to anyone visiting Siam Reap.

Trees, trees and more trees!. I saw the trees and it made me happy. Seriously, the trees in Ta Prohm are worth visiting. The trees are so large, they are crashing the temples. They are so alive,. I felt like Treebeard would show up. :)There are areas where reconstruction are being done but that should not make you stop to visit this wonderful place.

Wonderful historic site. This is a must see for anyone visiting Siem Reap. The temples although old and ruined look alive and part of nature with ancient trees growing literally through the remains of the temples. Quite breathtaking and definitely one for the bucket list.We were lucky to go on the day of the Siem Reap 1/2 marathon when there were very few tourists. Our friends went the following day and found the place heaving with bus loads of tourists. My recommendation? Read the reviews and find the best time to visit, probably means getting up early and enjoy the place to yourselves.

Beautiful place. I wonder if they knew that all their hard work would end up being ruined by nature hundreds of years later, and make it even more beautiful... Lots of beautiful carvings, giant stones making beautiful temples, stones toppled over each other, and amazing trees and roots growing wherever they wish! Beautiful in pictures and in movies, even more amazing in person. A quick turn inside a building or around a tree would get you lost into a more secluded area without tourists. I would definitely come back in the future!

Very atmospheric if you can go when there's no one else there!. The ultimate ruin of a temple, with the famous tree roots entwined around the stones. Go with a guide who knows the back route in, the angles to take the best photos, and the way round it to avoid the tour groups

Big Tree on the Temple.. I arrived there in the first day. than i take inside around 200 or 300 m i saw the big tree than i have wondering, why can the big tree on the temple?? so wonderful and very very beautiful that i never see before. This temple so nice. The area of this place at small circle tour if you ride a tuk tuk you will spend maybe 30min from town or 10 from Angkor Wat.
Simply stunning. The tree roots alone are spellbinding. Be sure to have a guide who can tell you the history and stories of the Wat. This is not to be missed

the "Tomb Raider"-temple is a must see. This is one of my favorite temples: the giant trees overgrowing the walls and buildings give it a unique atmosphere.
Tip: Go during lunch hour when the tour groups are at the restaurants or near sunset for an extra eerie feeling...

Favorite temple of the region!. Truly spectacular! Known as the "Tomb Raider" temple as part of the movie was filmed there (yep, we're going to watch that again now that we've visited). It's the combination of the Spung and Banyan trees and toppled rocks that make this temple truly "other worldly". It FEELS like a movie set and fascinating that it's survived since the 13th century. NOT TO BE MISSED!

This is the one with the movie star. Another of the "Big Three" temples of the Angkor Archeological Park, this is the one famous because Angelia Jolie filmed Tomb Raider here. Justifiably, it is horribly crowded, and it can be very hard to get decent photos, even in "quiet" periods. It is certainly beautiful, and with the trees growing through the walls it still looks very wild. Definitely worth a visit.
Wow - just like movies. A mystical place with the overgrown tree trunks...really something to see. Next to Angkor wat...a must see
Absolutely Amazing. Surreal, entwined with nature, this is a must visit place at Angkor Wat. You are transported into a different world and altogether another era.

Simply stunning. We arrived late afternoon just before sunset - where most of the other temples have undergone significant restoration, this place has simply been overtaken by nature... It's eerily captivating and the size of the trees and roots wrapping around the Wat will leave you speechless

Nothing like it!. Arrived here first thing in the morning as everyone else seemed to be heading to Ankor Wat.This place has an amazing atmosphere especially as we were the only ones on site.The tree roots wrapped around the ancient buildings look eery and strange.You really have to visit to take it all in.A must do on your trip to Cambodia

Tangling Trees and Stones. In 1431, Angkor was captured by Siam, and Khmer people moved the capital to Phnom Penh. Since then, the abandoned city of Angkor has been swallowed up by the forest. For hundreds of years, giant trees has grew and covered up the temples, together witnessed the decline of the Angkor civilization.In Ta Prohm temple, until today still maintain almost the condition when it was first discovered after covered up by giant trees for years. The state of tangling trees and stones showing the immense power of nature.1431年吴哥王朝被暹逻攻陷而迁都金边，被遗弃的吴哥城从此被森林所吞噬，百年巨树在庙宇的空隙间盘根错节生长，树根深入建筑的石缝并向四方扩散，巨大的树根紧紧抓住破庙，见证了吴哥文明的衰亡败落。塔普伦寺(Ta Prohm)在修复过程中特意保留了最初被发现时的倾屹状态，古庙里木石交缠，生死与共的画面，显示出大自然的无比威力。

Impressive!. Although this temple is still being re-claimed by the jungle, it was an impressive place. It was interesting to learn that Lara Croft: Tomb Raider was filmed there. Wait till later in the day to visit since morning brought throngs of tourists.

Don't leave this temple till last. They say that Tomb Raider was filmed here and the tree roots are amazing growing out of the temple ruins. This was our 3rd temple of the day and we were beginning to wilt in the heat so don't go in the middle of the day or leave it till last.
Did not meet Lara Croft. Evidently the location for tomb raider. Wonderfully atmospheric visit at dawn with the trees being amazing the way they grow in and around the stones
Best of all. Could be the setting of an Indiana Jones movie. Very unique mix of religion, nature and architecture. All at their best. Do not miss it

really impressive trees temple. The most exciting is the hug root of the tree place on the temple create the best art scene. The hundreds of trees that grew in this temple, slowly destroying bits of it, are magnificent. It's so natural place like a hidden city that we just recover by our adventure. the best time of the life. the best place of Siem Reap if you enjoy nature.

Nature reclaims what man created. In my opinion the best of the main temples. The huge trees growing, surrounding and even strangling the buildings show you how nature reclaims man's creations if we don't take care of our works and become the real protagonists of the well-known landscape. Must not be missed at all costs.
Must see. Ta Prohm is simply awesome we had a wonderful time and took some beautiful pictures. This is a major reason to visit Cambodia.
Ta Prohm. Here's where they shot the film with Angelina Jolie.It is amazing how the trees are around the temples!!!!

Partially Restored, Some Jungle Left, Lots of Tourists. Ta Prohm is one of the most popular tourist temples meaning it is also one of the busiest. We avoided some of the crowds by biking the circuit backwards. Some of the temple has been restored, however, there are still numerous places where the massive trees growing over the walls have been left. This adds a definite authentic aesthetic that few of the other temples are able to replicate. If doing a single day tour and selecting which temples to visit and which to skip, make sure this one goes in the "visit" list, you won't be disappointed!

Tomb Raider!. This Temple is one another must see temple in Siem ReapTree roots holding the the temple structure together. It seems like this can only be found only in Siem Reap.Not a very large temple but lots of nice photo taking areas here.

Just like a film set!. We visited this after Bayon and it was a little less crowded, which gave us a better opportunity to appreciate the special feeling this place has. Seeing the tree roots growing over the ruins is quite a sight. Tip:- see this place before visiting Angkor Wat itself other wise it will pale by comparison and you might be disappointed.

Nice temple easy to tour. Famous as the temple seen in the Tomb Raider movie. Nice and shady. Great for an afternoon tour. Not crowded. Easy walk. Great carvings and relief work. Interesting trees and their coexistence with the ancient temple site.
Better Than The Movie!. You know what it will look like, but it is even more amazing than you expect it to be! Incredible to see in person and not to be missed.

Avoid the crowds. A nice experience to walk around, just make sure you avoid the crowds and inform what times are best (for example, first thing in the morning)In the beginning of november, restoration works were going on. It however only covers part of the temple and you will still have a good experience. Furthermore, you'll notice many structures are supported with cables.It is possible to take pictures with several of the massive destructive trees with you just on the picture.If other people are around making pictures, just be friendly and ask to switch turns when making pictures! It does give you a 'lara croft' feeling, if you like that make sure to also visit Beng Mealea 40 km east of the main group of temples.
Incredible. Its almost unbelievable the way the trees grow up with the remaining buildings. A must see in Siem Reap.
Woaw!!. You have seen the pictures and probably have expectations… they will be blown away! To Prohm is a MUST, the most amazing temple in Siem Reap neighborhood...

Example of The World After Human Race. This is an example of what the world will become if human race was to disappear from Earth. Mother nature will take back what belong to her.It makes me wonder whether the roots are destroying or protecting the structures.It made me spent time to find the Tomb Raider movie from the DVD collection and watch it again!Anyway, it was an amazing place to be.

Tomb Raider. Incredible temple, one of our favorites. Several large trees growing through. Must see. It is a small temple and therefore was a bit more crowded due to it's popularity. Well worth the mild crowd in the rainy season.

Loved it !!. Sooo cooooool! Century year old trees growing around this temple ruin, with giant tree roots struggling parts of the crumbling walls ! I loved it so much I visited this temple twice.. If your into exploring take your head torch and clamber around inside... Beware of the bats though ! And the ghosts..na.. just kidding // but you never know ;)

Come in the early morning for the mists and quiet before the crowds!. We visited at about 8am in July 2013 for the mists and the quiet before the crowds. Highly recommend this time to visit! The primeval quality of the tree roots taking over the temple can be luminously felt at that time. Photography is easier without the crowds. A wondrous temple, not to be missed along with Angkor Wat and Bayon.

atmospheric jungle temple. as seen in tomb raider. lacks the sheer scale of Angkor wat but is a superior experience. if you like this place and have the time, try and visit Beng Mealea which is much more recently discovered and much less touristed.

My favourite temple. so picturesque with tree roots entangled eith the structure. You coukd wear your camera out on this one temple. Lots if restoration going on but so much to see that doesn't spoil it and good to see it happening.

Hidden temple. Never seen such hugh trees, roots overlapping hiding growing in the temple and protecting the temples yet not ruining them. It's an amazing sight , natures world. Now i know what's it like to walk in a real jungle.. Another crowded place for photo session , under the roots, in between them.

Totally awesome!!!. This is definitely every visitor's of Siem Reap must see. The centuries old trees that grew over the temple are just breath taking. Unfortunately, these beautiful giant tress were also the cause of some of the destruction. This was the site where they filmed the movie Transformers. Amazing photo opportunities for camera aficionados.

Blend of history, culture and nature. Huge old trees invading the temple, making this temple stand out among the others. Allocate some time to wander around this temple as the route of visiting is not as straightforward as others

Breathtaking. I'm not quite sure what is more beautiful the trees or the temple, but either way it is a must see! The billion vendors outside are a bit annoying but once you're inside it's really all about the amazingness in front of you.

The one to see. If you have time for just one temple, see this one. The trees growing into the building is just amazing. We went towards the end of the day, but there is always a crowd at this one. Wander outside the buildings a bit to get a scale of how big the trees really are compared to the temples. One of my favorites!

the real thing. Much better than Angkor Wat - glad I saw that before coming here or I would have been disappointed. Nature taking over the structure and people clearly fighting the trees for control. A bit tiresome how many people are trying to get money from you, but some good artists in between.

Awesome sight!. It was very impressive and I particularly liked how the jungle is reclaiming the temple with the huge trees and roots growing over it. I was not expecting the restoration work that was going on there, nor was I expecting the masses of people trying to sell you things. If you just keep your head down and don't make eye contact with the sellers, you can enjoy the temple without feeling hassled! Well worth going. Really a highlight on Siem Reap temple trail!

atmospheric. this place is immense, and it's hard to get a good idea on just one visit. So many little passageways and galleries to get lost in. most tourists seem to head just to the "tomb raider tree" to get their photos. There are certainly a lot of groups but perhaps less crowded earlier in the day.

Wow. Whilst re-construction work was going on in Ta Prohm, what created the wow factor was the huge tree trunk and its large sinking roots going down into the temple grounds. It was impressive. Have never seen anything like this before.
Scene of Lara Croft Movie. This is the only temple where the jungle has not been fully cleared. It is amazing to see the trees growing out of the sandstone and competing for space.

Spectacular temple. This is where nature and human structure mixing as an impressive complex. Very old trees and ancient temple bring a completely opposite atmosphere to modern life. Come and back the the past of Cambodian culture. A must do for photography lovers.
One of our favorites. Recovered from the jungle. Amazing place recovered from the jungle. Lots of great pictures of trees invading the temple. Don't skip it!!

A Time Capsule. I went there in April 2013, it was stunning, take your breath away, these huge trees were allowed to grow to these gigantic sizes as these temples were neglected for centuries. What we were seeing was a real time capsule, the place people had forgotten and rediscovered for us to see and understand the ancient culture. These trees are a type of fig, that grows to gargantuan size with roots that penetrate through crevasses, between rock blocks that was made by the temple architect, in search of water in this arid land.Now these roots of these trees are forming as a natures own sculpture, showing us the beauty of infinite power that is inherent in plants. Just enjoyed the visit, an unforgettable day in my life. This is the morning visit along with Bayon Temple and the Angkor Wat in the afternoon.Take a hat and umbrella it is hot during day time.

Cambodia's favourite film set. Hoping I've remembered the name right - this is the overgrown temple made famous by Tomb Raider. In fact, say "Tomb Raider" and the tuk-tuk drivers know exactly where to take you. It is being 'improved' at present, with heavy machinery at work, but you can still queue up to have your photo taken at the roots of that enormous tree, splitting the stones apart. And there is plenty more to see - it is a fair-sized complex. The main drawback, possibly, is its popularity; we visited before the season really started, and were already in a milling crowd. A must-see, but be prepared!

Great. There is not much to say. If you go to Cambodia, you have to see the Angkor Wat complex. Just because its something unbelievably impressive created by our own species a thousand years ago. Ta Prohm is definitely my favorite.. the fig trees overtaking the temple are just so picturesque.. one con is that it is just soooo crowded

Nice "Light" jungle temple. This is fun! A temple in the midst of the junge with al lot of trees nad branches wrapped around pillars, doors and so on. We had slight rainfall as we visited the temple which was quite fun and added some "spice" to the scenery. Its a must when in Angkor!

Make sure you get there before 9 am. The tour buses swarm this place after 9 in the morning. And its so small, you will not get a single picture without a crowd in it. Arrive early and really enjoy the unique peacefulness of this location. It's a lovely spot and one of our favourite of all the temples. Bayon is pretty spectacular, too.

Astonishing. One of the temples that I'm dying to see. We went there in November 5 and left the hotel at 5am to catch the sunrise. It is incredible how it was built many years ago. Due to its popularity, a little patience is needed because the place is a little crowded and we had to line up just get our photos taken. Too bad my camera did not cooperate so I was unable to capture many pictures as I wanted to. This place is truly worth a visit.

Great early morning visit. One of the "must-visit" temples at Angkor. It gets very busy with tour groups later in the day, but I was there early morning (c. 06.30) and there was hardly a soul around - magical.

One of My Top 2 Temple Visits. This place exudes atmosphere, jungle and history. I loved it. Hard pressed to decide if this was my favorite or Bayon. Too bad our visit was cut a little short by a thunderstorm.

my fav temple. We went at 7am. We were the first people there. Worth getting up early. I read on another person blog to not go to Angkor Wat for sunrise, as its crowded - go to this one instead - SO worth it!!!

Worth it. A lot of restoration going on so easy to see the before and after. Huge strangler figs have surrounded the remnants of the buildings. Each Wat has it's own character. I found this one impressive.
Wonderful. Yes, I agree with other reviewers that Ta Prohm is awesome, but I felt a little disappointed that one of the walls has been cleared of trees and rebuilt since our last visit.

Probably the best temple in Angkor area. I really love this place. Went there one early morning after the sunrise trip to one of the other temples. It was not that many people and the sun was still rising and made a lot of nice shadows and beaming lights through the openings/pillars etc. It made the place very mysterious. The kids (9 and 11) was very tired after the sunrise thing and the youngest complained on the way to Ta Prohm temple. When we got inside it wasn´t that bad anymore. I think he eventually enjoyed it a lot and when he watch Tomb Raider in the future he will be glad that he went there. If you go to Siem Riep this is one of the places you must see.

Stunning example of nature. Very crowded. It worth it to see the giant trees push themselves through these temple buildings. Quite awe inspiring! If doing Angkor one would be disappointed not to see this site.

Ta Prohm - The "Tomb Raider Temple"...…. Ta Prohm is one of the temple which is a must to visit............. the architecture of the buildings are extremely outstanding and bound by massive roots of huge trees.. Its definately a best place to take beautiful pictures....................
Awesome. It's beautiful one of my higlighted temple if my visit in Siem Reap. Highly recommed to have sunrise here... so romantic place.

High on your list for a three day visit.. A truly enigmatic, inspiring temple with the kapok and fig roots growing through the stones of the temple. Work with a guide and go when there are the lowest number of tourists, as this can turn into a cacophany of tourism which can ruin the experience of this haunting temple.There are a large number of temples in the Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, and outlying areas as well. Don't feel you have to see them all. Three full days of touring are important to do this world-class venue justice but these are the Don't Miss sites, in this order of priority: Angkor Wat, of course, the stellar, Number One site; Bayon; Terrace of the Elephants and Terrace of the Leper King; Ta Prohm; Bandrey Srei; Preah Kahn; Pre Rup; Neak Prean.Give yourself time to visit your three favorites a second time within your three day itinerary. Many are so overwhelming in their interest, architecture, and artistry that you must see them at least twice to begin to appreciate them. We had to see the Churning of the River of Milk at Angkor Wat three times, as it was so artistically stunning, and is comparable to the greatest carvings anywhere in the World.

Ta Prohm ....... great!. Ta Prohm is amazing with the huge trees intertwined with the ruins. Don't miss this temple no matter what you do. They are doing a lot of restoration work at present ......but if they don't the trees will destroy the temple completely.

very atmospheric, good luck with the crowds. it is by far one of the best and most atmospheric temples at angkor. but the problem is that too many visitors and now, since restauration is taking place, one path to walk on. imagine 2 busses of tourists in front of you stopping to take their pictures each at a time. i was lucky it was relatively calm when i was there but it doesn't mean that it is always like that. one of the best temples to spend 2 or 3 hrs depending on the mood of the place when you are there. you can start on foot at ta phrom, continue to banteay kdei ad end up at sra srang where there are many restaurants to chhose from.

Amazing and must visit!. This and the grand Angkor Wat were definitely my favourites, can't be missed! Try to go early, maybe do the sunrise at Angkor Wat and then to Ta Prom, that way you get a bit of space to your self!

Amazing Temple. This is another amazing ancient landmark. The huge trees that has grown in the roof of the ancient temple is breath taking. You can not imagine big trees growing on roofs and yet this very old monument is still standing.

A must see. Ta Prohm was the very first Angkor temple we chose to visit and one of the very best. The restoration work which has been completed has been done to an exceptional standard. The ruins are amazing and it's fascinating to see how huge trees have grown and become intertwined with huge walls. A fantastic place to explore and not to be missed

Majestic. This is a must see. We went very early in the morning before all the tour buses came. This temple would have absolutely beautiful when built. Currently work is being done to restore it as so much damage has been from the trees. Loved it. Only saw the eastern side!

Tomb raider temple :). The place is very good. Angelina Jolie seems to have made it quite famous. Most locals will point out the way if you ask them about 'Tomb Raider' temple. Places are in quite some ruins, Requires quite some walking

A Must See. Very interesting temple complex partly taken in by the Jungle. I can see why Tomb Raider was filmed here. Decent amount of tourist, but not as crowded as Angkor Wat.This actually was one of my favorites in Siem Reap because of the surreal beauty of the place. Lot of hidden areas for wonderful pictures so have fun and explore.
Loved it!. What an awesome temple! If you get to see only one or two while you are in Siem Reap - make Ta Phrom one of them!

Crowded but fabulous site to visit. There are so many visitors but it's alright in the beginning of the high season(the last week of Oct) I don't even want to imagine how this place will be when it's winter and Christmas vacations.This site offers lots of places to take good photos to wow your friends back home but the thing is, you have to wait and wait to get your pictures without others in them.
Tomb Raider. Creepy tree roots growing all over the amazing temples at Ta Prohm. Part of the Angkor Wat complex and definitely worth the trip.
My favourite. Lush and green amongst the rubble. An inspiring and amazing visit. quite crowded, but very worth it. Give 1-2 hours. Dress modestly

Absolutely stunning. This was our favorite of the various sites near Angkor Wat (Bayon was a close second). The combination of the structures and the trees growing out of them really made the entire area incredibly beautiful. And the pictures are just amazing. It was certainly a bit on the crowded side, but we were still able to find some areas that were less visited. Absolutely amazing.

Amazing temples. Just slow down and take your time enjoying the temples. Just hire a Remork driver for the day - tell him what temples you want to see and listen to his suggestions - like how long it will take you at each one - they will drop you off at one gate and pick you up at the opposite gate.
One of the most beautiful temple!. I adore this place! Very beautiful and cinematographic landscape. Highly recommended! Try to reach this temple early morning and avoid hundreds of tourist.

Unbelievable!. It's incredible how these ancient ruins survived and entwined themselves within the surrounding jungle. You'll never be able to take enough pictures. This was our favourite temple during our visit, one not to be missed.

Amazing!. We were lucky to have a tour guide on our visit to Ta Prohm, who explained the history and it was clear to see that this temple was lost for many hundred of years....the trees have destroyed this temple and there is some restoration work going to revive some of the parts.

Crowded. Try late afternoon for less crowds but the lighting for photos is not that good. If you have the time, suggest going twice, in opposite directions. In addition, you can walk around outside of the main complex. Lot of opportunities for interesting photos without crowds in the background.
Stunning. This temple left me speechless, so beautiful. Make time and don't rush, beautiful, almost like a painting. Very surreal.
Speechless!. One of the most amazing temple I´ve ever been. It´s impressive how nature made its way through man´s creation. It´s like to be in a movie (actually I was told Tom Rider was filmed there)

Just loved this place- The Banyans rule ok. The challenge to preserve this archaeological site is huge. Mother Nature and the buildings are one. The Banyan trees and root systems are so interwoven with the buildings that one is holding the other up. Strangely enough they complement one another. I am sure the purists would want the trees removed, but I am not sure they can be and I think this site will lose something. Enjoy this for what it is...
Amazing!. The jungle has literally taken over the temple. What was amazing was this one three that had to be propped up, coz if it fell, it would take down part of the temple walls.

Romantic. The most visually engaging of any temple we saw at Angkor.
I loved the way the carnage of rubble and huge trees disorientates you.
So many picture opportunities, which are completely unique!
You would regret not making time for Ta Prohm.

Awe and wonder. A marvel of architecture and religious expression. To see the tree roots imprison the walls is to wonder at the unstopable strength and encroachment of nature. A wonderful stop for an hour or two. Don't miss it!
Under heavy restoration work. Still awesome to roam the quiet little areas (especially before the tour group hordes arrived) with tree roots invading the temple

Ancient trees vs man-made temples. If you are time poor, then there are 4 temples not to be missed in Siem Reap.. Bayon, Angkot Wat, Banteay Srei and this one, Ta Prohm.. all quite different, but ALL well worth seeing. Ta Prohm is where part of Indiana Jones was filmed.. but more importantly, lets people witness the dynamic interaction between man made art and nature... temple walls where ancient trees have grown and split massive stones. To actually stand beside trees that are hundreds of years old, and see where their strangulating roots have "taken over" the inside of the main entrance pavilion of the temple, is spectacular. I recommend that you take an English speaking guide with you to explain the history of various temples.. its very cheap, and is worth the few dollars it will cost.

A little too crowded. I personally loved this temple and our guide was excellent as he took us around this temple on a less tourist-ridden route. Of course we couldn't avoid them forever and taking pictures with some of the temple landmarks (that famous tree root) was very trying. Because of the smaller spaces; it can get very crowded.

Another must-see. Walking through Ta Prohm is like wandering through a maze. It's easy to come to a dead end but that is half the fun of the temple. The size of the trees that surround the temple are incredible and the strangler figs overtaking some of the ruins are fascinating. Make sure this temple is on your list of "must sees".

One of the more interesting temples. This temple is one of the more interesting ones. With a maze-like rabbit warren of walkways and corridors and the trees growing out from the stones are the highlight. Amazing!

My personal favourite. This temple is my favourite with the ruins and trees transporting you to some lost world. The banyan trees growing over the stones create a special atmosphere. Definitely a not to miss amongst the Angkhor complex!
amazing. didnt realise there were so many other temples here glad we got around to see them, each has something special to see, the carvings are quite spectactular

Unreal trees growing out of temples. Ta Prohm is one of my favourite sites at Angkor Wat. The Cotton Silk Trees that have naturally destroyed the original temple, have also made the site more unique that anything else I have ever seen. Not to be missed.

Beautiful. Loved this temple! !! Especially with the trees growing through it!! Although you spend most of your time waiting for tourist to get out of the way...one pic is fine but going as a family and taking 20 pics infront of each sight one by one is selfish and ruins the experience... this was not just one family eather..

Ta Phrom - The Tomb Raider Temple. Apparently the biggest claim to its fame seems to be the fact that Lara Croft frequented this place while raiding the tomb. It is currently in the process of being restored by the co-operation of the Government of India. After having seen the Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom temples, this did not come close in terms of architectural beauty. But this has some really fascinating and old trees, with barks as wide as 10 meters in diameter.

pure magic. No wonder that this place has been used for shooting movies. The buildings and ruins partially being overtaken by the jungle is just awesome. Try to avoid the biggest tourist crowds. We were lucky because we visited the temple during a heavy down pour.
Overgrown wonder. Last temple on our tour but so atmospheric it was worth the wait. Would have been easy to get lost without our excellent guide. Glad we were there when it was quiet
Trees rule this temple. Ta Prohm is the temple famous for the trees literally taking down the walls. It is haunting to see, and very beautiful.
Quieter than the biggies, but amazing. Great temple that draws less crowds than the big ones, so you're free to explore at leisure. Worth a trip. Loved it.

the beauiful one. A photographers delight! Little pockets of maiden hair fern, strangler figs creeping over the ancient strcutures, collapsed doorways, beautiful cool dark corners with shards of light reaching into them.Was by far my favourite of the 6 temples we visited.Take some time to sit in the shade and enjoy the peace.

So atmospheric. If you're reading this, you're surely already in / about to go to Siem Reap. So, rather than say: "go" (which is obvious) the only thing I'd suggest is that you go early. This is the place to go to first thing - for sunrise. There isn't a particularly spectacular sun-strike moment on the temples, but there is a wonderful serenity to the temple and seeing it (without lots of other tourists) emerging from the jungle is amazing.

Our favourite temple. A joint favourite (together with the Bayon). Two reasons: 1) the place is beautiful – moss covered ruins that are being reclaimed by jungle. Just loved those huge tree roots which had taken hold of the temples like giant prehistoric beasts; 2) there weren’t many people here when we visited (around 8.30am), and a lot of the time we had parts of this complex completely to ourselves, even the famous ‘Tomb Raider shot’ tree roots. We felt like we were discovering the place. Very atmospheric. Fantastic!

Shame that it's been cleared - but still good. I really wish that I had seen this place when it was overrun with trees - I guess that Beng Melea is the place to go to now. Still this is a fantastic place - we went first thing in the morning - around 5am and we were pretty much alone in there.

Incredible. I cant imagine how they build ed this palace a thousand years ago , it was incredible.
Find Apsara who hiding in a tree roots and dinosaur painting on the wall ... it's amazing !!

Magical. I saw it at dusk in a light rain which only added to the dramatic atmosphere. Beautiful, mysterious and exotic. Try to go when tourist volume is light as I did for a more personal experience.
Favorite Temple. A step back in time, to see the giant trees that have broken through the walls, roof, and foundation of this temple left me in awe.

Mysterious Ta Prohm. This is a must-see temple. The roots crawling all over the place tell the story of the jungle---and provide wonderul photo pops. Wooden walkways and stairs make it safe to clamber over most of the structure.

The Tomb Raider. Also called the Jungle Temple but better know for the Angelina Jolie movie shot here...this temple is currently totally in ruins but is being restored in a collaborative initiative with the Govt of India....must see
Great place for who loves adventure. Beautiful and attractive for adventuring. This is the place that has been appeared in a famous Hollywood movie!
amazing. A very interesting and well maintained temple. Don't miss this one if you only chose a few to visit!
Fantastic. Go late in the day when the temple isn't so busy. It is incredible so don't miss this one out. Trees growing out of buildings and reconstructions just blow you away.
Majestic in size, almost unbelievable!. Dedicated to the King Jayavarman VII’s mother, this temple is popular for the tree roots being the foundation of the current structure of the temple.
Favorite temple. Fairly well restored. Effects of jungle growth on these temples well demonstrated. Ongoing restoration project active. Tomb raider air!

Unleash your inner Lara croft!. Very mystical amazing place overgrown with trees, although busy when we went, people queuing for photos but there are still afew quiet corners if you look. The setting for many films including tomb raider, raiders of the lost ark. Well worth the visit.

Breath Taking!. Of all the temples in the Ankor Vat complex, this one is most breathtaking because of the way the structures have been engulfed by Nature - the trees around are monstrous! Being from metro cities, one completely overlooks the natural elements, and places like these make you realise how powerful natural forces can be.

Beautiful Temple, but child peddlers are annoying.. Okay, I do realize we are in Cambodia. However, running the gauntlet of peddlers is rather annoying. Unfortunately, the kids are the most persistent with selling magnets and flutes.The temple is gorgeous. It is absolutely amazing to see with the trees growing. They are working really hard to preserve the temple, and with the amount of renovation being done. Controlling and minimizing the damage from the trees will be an ongoing challenge, but I look forward to someday revisiting this temple to see it restored.

Enchantment of Ta Prohm. It is amazing when you walk through the ruins of Ta Prohm how much it feels like you are in some enchanting story and can almost visualise how things may have been back in the day. An amazing experience.

Mystical Ta Prohm Temple. This was THE temple. Majestic trees entwined in old stone. Wonderful and magical. There's plenty of opportunity to find a quiet place for contemplation. Sitting alone in these places is special

Jungle temple. My third favourite behind Angkor thom and Angkor wat. major restoration underway but trees are being left in place. Busiest temple visited and sections are currently locked off for renovation. It was the only temple that was less spectacular than I expected due to Hollywood previews but still enjoyed it as it is different from others

Beautiful. This temple is in our top 3 favourites for photo shots. The trees taking over complete with the remaining visible carvings are beautiful. I think they're restoring some of this temple so the trees are often supported with heavy cables or the walls with wooden frames but there are still some great photos to be had!We did visit early afternoon and the crowds weren't as bad as Bayon earlier around 11am so I think the tour groups were on their lunch breaks though there was a bit of a queue to have the photo of the infamous strangler tree!

Nature meets architecture. What an amazing situation where trees grow up into a temple and then become part of the temple. THis was a truly spectacular day. PS: I had to go and watch tomb raider after visiting this temple as it features :)

Unique. Ta Prohm is the temple you see in movies and photos with the kapok trees forcing the stones apart and embracing them at the same time. The tuk tuk driver, usually organised by your hotel/guesthouse at your request will wait for you as you go temple hopping. It is worthwhile to read up about the various temples beforehand or buy the guidebook so you can fully appreciate the intricacies of the relief carvings and . The architecture is fascinating! The temple is well worth the visit as it is not over-crowded and it is well maintained in it's "taken over by the jungle" state.

Jungle Temple aka Tomb Raider Temple. Ta Prohm is probably best known as the Tomb Raider temple, even though other temples were used in that film. We ended up here a little later than we had hoped, which resulted in our arrival after many tour groups, nevertheless it was really quite something to see so much destruction of a temple by trees alone! The temple is currently undergoing restoration works by UNESCO, halting Nature's progress at retaking the land.

A must visit temple. This has temple has been severely invaded by the wild, making it one of the most interesting temples in Angkor. The temples merged with the trees gave it a very exotic look, making it more enjoyable than some of the other much restored temples. However, everybody else seemed to be aware of this too, and we found this to be the most crowded of all temples in Angkor.
Stop in your tracks. The best of all the temples where Tomb Raider was filmed so these Buddhist temples have huge ficus trees growing out of the crumbled buildings.
Amazing!!. Best Temple we visited, go early in the morning, less crowds and cooler. Reminded me of scenes from Tomb Raider.

Very impressive. This was as interesting as expected. It helped us greatly that we had a private guide. The information he passed on was a bonus as I don't think we would have understood the history in such detail without him.
Favourite temple!. You can see why tomb raider is filmed here with All the sprawling trees and roots everywhere. This place is so much fun to explore!

Lucky Timing. We went to this temple straight after the Angkor Wat sunrise & breakfast. Just perfect timing! Only a few our groups there - we couldnt believe our luck knowing this to be one of the most popular temples. As a result the atmosphere was awesome - all you hope for when seeing an ancient temple. We didnt have a guide and struggled to find the 'iconic' strangler tree but asked another group so all good. There is a lot of work going on on site but it didnt impact our experience at all. Well worth visiting and great to say you have been there - its the one everybody asks about when you get home.

Start your day early and visit before anyone else gets here.. Early morning this is very atmospheric, our guide got us there before anyone else, and it was brilliant, no waiting for people to leave the photograph you want to take, the trees growing into the walls are incredible, it is just a fab place.
The Best of the best. The old Ta Prohm is much better - before the viewing/photo stands and ropes BUT the place still has the magic and power of Mother Nature vs Man. Rocks!

Out of this world. What an amazing place. This is where ancient civilisation clashes with ancient nature. Some of the trees are so huge and their roots need to be seen to be believed. Having spent some time at Ta Prohm, I would love to be able to show the current ruins to the guys that built it. They could never have envisaged the clash with nature that has occurred. These ruins are quite large and there is a fair amount of walking involved, however well worth it! One of my friends did slip while we were exploring so please take care while you walk around. This temple of one of the must see sites at Angkor!

Ta Prohm is a Must!. Ta Prohm was my favourite archaeological site in this region. The way the trees are taking over the ruins just goes to show how mother earth can reclaim the land! This is where certain scenes of Tomb Raider (Lara Croft) was filmed and there are wows around every corner.

You'll love this temple. This temple has been super overgrown by the jungle. I think it's the one in Tomb Raider....can't remember, but it's very impressive. I took a zillion photos here, couldn't seem to take a bad one. I could have spent hours ferreting amongst its nooks and crannies. We went early to this site, 7.30 to ensure we missed the crowds which inundate the place mid morning and then overrun it in the arvo.
Jungle temple. Fascinating to see how the jungle is taking over this temple. Trees growing on top of parts of the temple, roots coming between huge rocks and moving them. Iconic photos.

This is the temple with the giant tree eating roots. This site has been left to a large extent as it was found. Removing the tree roots would result in structures tumbling down. We were fortunate to be on a Gate 1 tour. They engaged Hoy Pheakdey as our local guide and we would certainly recommend his services. We also read the novel Temple of a 1000 Faces by John Shors prior to going which helps understand the context. Plan to reread now that we are home. Some great photos here.

make sure you buy things in securely place. This is the second interesting temple I have been visit. I still can feel the mystique things around. the atmosphere, I do not have any complain about it. But for the selling boys and girls outside, if you wanna help them by buy their things, make sure you buy in a securely place. Otherwise they will come around you like an ants and want you to buy their things even you have already buy from one boy. They will not stop chasing you from temple to parking tuktuk, until you buy it. Just make sure, you but in a very safe place which none of other merchant notice.

Nature and temples. The huge trees hugging the temples are a sight to behold. Also known as the tomb raider temple. You need to have a nice pair of shoes to go around, There are areas being restored when we visited, but you can still take a good photos around the area, most specially under the roots of the giant trees!

Love how Mother Nature Stars at this site!. Ta Prohm was the highlight for me in the Angkor Archaeological Park. The massive trees growing around the structures are magical. I really hope they don't overdo the renovations (were significant works in progress when we visited) as the ruins provide a greater sense of time and majesty.

Nature Versus Man. Deliberately left unrestored by the French, this temple shows how the jungle and nature can ravage a man made building given enough time. Fortunately some restoration is now being conducted but there are a number of photo opportunities around the site where giant trees are growing on and within and destroying parts of the temple.It is a fair walk to the temple from the main car park and it's popularity (as the 'Tomb Raider' temple) means that it can get very crowded. It is justifiably one of the main temple draws in the Angkor Archeological Park along with Angkor Wat and Bayon.

Better than Angkor Wat. Even more beautiful and photogenic than Angkor Wat. The giant tree roots and beautiful architecture make this a photographer's paradise. There are helpful onsite guides. Don't miss this if you come to Siem Reap!

Ta Prohm is nice but it's a bit run down. It's a shame how the trees are damaging the temples and it also made it look so nice. Even without the tree itself, Ta Prohm is a bit more run down than Bayon and Angkor Wat. It's a smaller temple complex but it's quite unique with the trees blending into the temples.I would save this last just cause the other 2 worth more of your time.

Left to nature.. The really interesting aspect of this temple when comapred to any other in the area is the fact it has been left as it was found, to a certain extent. The trees that grow on and around the ruin have fused with teh architecture and as such can't be removed.Quite possibly the highlight of the temple complex in the Siem Reap area.Do get a guided tour, private if possible, the cost is only around $30!
well worth the visit. very interesting place lots to see if you can manage to avoid the mass of tourists that descend on this one , and you will definately need to have good walking shoes

THIS COMPLEX MUST BE HIGH ON YOUR BUCKET LIST. We were only home from Cambodia for less than 24 hours when Tomb Raider was on a local TV station. We had heard all about Lara Croft from our tour guide when we visited Ta Prohm several days before. When we watched our recording we were thrilled to see 'Lara' exactly where we had stood for our photos.To say that this temple is magical is an understatement - it was one of the best temples we had visited in the previous four weeks. To see the way the Silk Cotton trees and the Strangler Figs had grown over, through and in the temple complex was wonderful and the area is a photographer's delight. Although the Cambodians, with help from other countries, are repairing this ancient temple the character is guaranteed not to be lost.This whole area is a must for your Bucket List.
Wonderfull. Wonderfull to see how the trees try to take over the temple. Knowing the scenes of the movie makes it even more special to walk in this temple.

Awesome. Ta Prohm is amazing - the enormous Banyan tree roots look like giant pythons crushing the ruins. I did not have a guide and really didn't need one. The site is barely conserved - and it's quite a hike from the car/bus park to the temple complex itself so you feel like you've been swept back in time. Lots of photo ops (which also means lots of mugging tourists who seem more interested in photos than the amazing carvings). But.... go EARLY. Outside the gates are hoardes of souvenir sellers. Can be hotter than blazes by mid-day. This is a must see Siem Reap temple.

One of the best!. Ta Prohm is the iconic Tomb Raider temple, and as such it's very busy, even in the rainy season. Come in the rainy season for the best experience, but wear tevas or other grippy outdoor sandals. Although it rained during our visit to Ta Prohm, we found that the hoards of tour groups avoided the flooded and muddy areas--which left a lot for us to explore alone! I really felt like Lara Croft exploring the undiscovered ruins at Ta Prohm.

The Tomb Raider Temple. A girl I met at the hostel asked me if I'd visited the Tomb Raider Temple and I immediately knew she meant this one. Very little restoration has gone on here and that means you're getting as close to discovering an ancient civilization a la Indiana Jones, as you can get. There's also no real thought gone into health and safety on this site. There's a walk way that's been boarded over so you don't have to walk in the mud but you can "off road" and go climbing over the debris if you like. The most interesting feature is the gargantuan tree roots which have all but taken over some of the buildings. Really interesting for its raw nature and also not as big as some of the other temples so you can see if before you start to tire of seeing yet another apsara! A warning though. Most tourists enter through the East Gate. Outside the ceremonial West gate are lots of really pesky kids trying to sell you bracelets and cold drinks. Ignore their cuteness, steel your heartstrings and run!

Everything you imagine. We love Ta Prohm. Even with the scaffolding and restoration world it's still a magical place. This was our second visit in 4 years, so we didn't hire a guide. No worries, a local worker named Prohm who has been on site for 11 years took us around and showed us all the good photo spots. He showed us the echo tower and pointed out the holes that used to hold diamonds in the main tower. He even showed us the dinosaur carving and the tree that looked like an elephant. Get there early to avoid the crowds. We arrived at 7:30 and there were only a handful of people on site.

Tomb Raider experience. Was in awe of this place and the way the forest has taken over. It was everything I expected and more.On advice we arrived at 6am and were the only ones there... felt like we were explorers al la Indiana Jones and the ambiance was amazing as our photos can vouch.To be able to walk through the ruins and touch history and then to witness how much restorative work has been done to allow us this trip through time was a humbling experience.Two hours later as we were leaving the crowds started arriving so do yourself a favour and get there early.

I felt amazing energy, not just another temple. My favourite in the Angkor Archeological Park, Ta Prohm was constructed in late 12th century and like most others was abandoned at some stage, The jungle took over and massive tree roots from parasite trees have invaded the building. This is the temple used in Indiana Jones and Tomb Raider movies and is worthy of at least an hour's visit to explore the ruins and labyrinth of passages.It is being restored in some sections but I they seem to be leaving the massive root systems in place. To me this was not just "another temple" and felt a surge of energy, climbing over the ruined sectionsDon't miss this one - to me it is head and shoulders over other temples

Hauntingly beautiful. ta phrom makes you feel as if you stepped into a portal to the past. You feel like you are a visitor to a place that holds many secrets. It is hauntingly beautiful. It heightens your sense of awe and wonder.

You haven't seen Cambodia if you miss this place !. One of the most interesting sites of the world. A early morning walk through is the best way to see it before the crowds get there. We were the first there at sun rise and though the light wasn't the best for photos, our pictures don't have any tourists blocking the remarkable views.

Amazing!. A must if you are visiting Angkor Wat. The temple has been left to the jungle so trees are growing out of the walls. Massive fig trees make this place stunning and very cool. You just have to visit and yes pretend you are in Tomb Raider!

Just like the photos!. Simply remarkable. Well worth a a visit. We only visited three major temples, Angkor Wat, Bayon and Ta Prohm. I had read many reviews that suggested that if you had limited time, or indeed did not want to suffer temple overload, then these were the three to visit. We loved them. All quite different to each other and all well worth seeing.

Not to be missed. Of all the temple sites including Angkor Wat this is the one you would not want to miss out on.We were absolutely fascinated by Ta Prohm as it is the one you always see photos of with the trees growing out of the ruins as the jungle reclaims the area.After viewing this awesome spectacle we found all the other temples/ruins a bit of an anti-climax.

Well Worth A Visit. I visited the Angkor temples in 2008. This was one of the 3 main temples I wanted to see the first day of my visit. This year I decided to revisit some of the temples and this one was on the list. It is currently undergoing some renovations which is kind of ironic as this is the one group of temples that is largely remained untouched. It is definitely worth the visit but will be better to see probably in 2014 or later. Really good for a lot of pictures. Enjoy!

unique site. Nature overtakes civilisations...you can see and feel how nature takes over ...the powerful trees are amazing...the site is undergoing some significant reconstructions ..but nevertheless you can enjoythe site...

The best of Siem Reap. For me this was the highlight of a long weekends temple running in and around Siem Reap. Whilst most of the temples are awe inspiring and fascinating Ta Prohm has something special. I don't know if its the Lara Croft factor or the way the jungle seems to be claiming the area back but there is a mystique that makes this place very special. Get there early and take your time. There are a few hidden gems that must be sought out.
Loved my visit to Ta Prohm. Just don't miss visiting this excellent Site .Wonder of the World,take enough time to appreciate this site.Start early to see this site
enchanting place.... I like the century old tree that grow in the old temple, it's like walking in a different world- i love the feeling of silence that give me inner peace.

A tremendous labyrinth. Don't be shy and push your self to an experience discovering some of the hideways of this temple, but never dare to miss the main attractions here, where you can see how nature is claiming back what it's hers. Is not the top temple but is on third position after Bayon and Angkor Wat

Amazing. Make sure you get in and under the simple stunning trees/jungle of Ta Prom.This really is site that you simply cant miss. After strolling around and photographing every thing possible be sure to grab a cold drink from the locals selling either a water, beer and soft drink at the entrance to the temples.A visit you wont be sorry that you did!!
Tomb Raider. This place is like another world, the trees are amazing,loved loved it!! No one trying to sell you stuff out the front either.
tree roots. As wonderful as I anticipated. A bit eerie. An example of nature reclaiming what man built. Great photo opportunities.

Likely my favorite. You cannot miss it.. Along with Bayon, my favorite temple site. I think the intertwined banyon trees give Ta Prohm the edge as it accents the ancient aspect of the temple so well. Wonderful photo ops around every corner. Truly a jungle feel, almost like you were discovering it yourself. This is one that cannot be missed. Even the rubble is photogenic.
Loved Ta Prohm..... Ta Prohm, "Tomb Raider" temple was the best. Loved all the trees and the natural ruins. Great location for awesome photos.

Its all abt tomb rider and the tree. I'm speechless,I love all the spots here especially those giant trees with their unhidden root hugging the ruin.I just wish my eyes cud take pictures. Come and witness it by urself.its not only just tomb rider's spot,it a state of beauty,the home of prajnapramita (jayavarman vii's mother)

Amazing! Lara Croft Tomb Raider. The huge trees are amazing and to see that tomb raider made this site famous. I can see why !Id recommend comfortable shoes, sun protection and comfy clothes caution slippery paths so no crocs !
Unusual Temple. My second favourite temple near Siem Reap. The tree formations are something else. If you are going to the area then include this temple on your itinerary.

Breathtaking !. No words can be found to describe such a site !!!This is the site I love the best in Angkor !!!Just go there and see how nature worked on these rocks ....!!!!has to be seen to be believed !!!But every one knows this......!

AeJay aka Angelina Jolie. It's jungle and ruins combined... I love it... I feel like I was part of the Tomb Raider movie... i like the feeling of being able to be in a place i used to just watch and read about... it's amazing... it would be nice if you come here prepared... read about it in advance so you'll appreciate the beauty of the temple more... don't forget to bring a bottled water also especially if you come here during summer time... it can really be so warm...

Home of the Angelina tree!. A really interesting site to visit, especially with the overgrown trees. It's also a great example of a site which is not fully redeveloped, therefore, showing the ravage of time and nature. Not recommended for people who are unstable of foot but really interesting to see the site of the Tomb Raider.
Best Temple. This is the best temple to visit. While Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom are large and beautiful, this temple captures the awesome power of nature but also has beautiful restored parts.

Best temple to visit with your children. It's an incredible sight to see in person, with huge tree roots seemingly strangling the temple walls. A great place to bring the kids, as they will enjoy the easy walk through the temple complex. A truly impressive place to visit.

Great temple, worth seeing. This is another temple you must see. It's gorgeous walking through, but probably try get this one early in the morning so there aren't as many tourists there! It will enhance the experience.

Tomb Raider temple. Absolutely worth a visit, and worth having a guide with you or reading up about it in advance of your visit to really appreciate it. This temple is difficult to avoid crowds at, but a little patience may dissipate the crowds a bit and give you some quiet time here.

Huge trees. I feel lucky to be able to go and actually visit the temples with amazing characteristic. Each temple have its own character. The trees growing inside the temples are great. Afraid that these big trees hugging the structures would eventually damage the area and other generations will not be see them in the future.

Ta Prohm: The Jungle Temple. go to this link to read on my review... http://neillangit.com/2013/09/01/ta-prohm/One common observation about the multitude of tourists I saw when touring Siem Reap in Cambodia is that 98% of all of them regardless of their race are very young. They are the able-bodied, in shape and high spirited types of mortals. Well I guess possessing these attributes would be an advantage to any tourist who would explore the wondrous sights in Siem Reap.This is especially true when I and my sister went to the magical temple called Ta Prohm. After being dropped by our hired driver at the eastern gate who told us that he will be waiting at the western side of the complex, I knew that exploring The Jungle Temple would require a considerable amount of strength.Upon entering the gate and a 15-minute walk of a dirt road penetrating though the Cambodian jungle, we witnessed our first glimpse of a breathtaking out of this world sight.
