Just when we thought we’d seen the best along came Ta Phrom and it blew us away!It seemed like the gigantic unrelenting jungle trees married themselves to the stone buildings by hugging and caressing them which results to bizarre breathtaking form.It gives you the feeling that after being left to nature for hundreds of years, the jungle decided to take over the temple and make its presence felt by outgrowing the numerous parts of the temple complex with very huge stems, branches and roots gripping and embracing the walls.Words definitely do not do justice for Ta Phrom.
Greamt Temple. Every Temple complex in Siem Reap is brilliant ..!! It is only a photographer's imagination, and battery, memory card.There are so many pictures to capture..!!

Surreal and beautiful. This temple looks ordinary from outside but this hides a world where man and nature have struggled over the centuries and nature - in the form of fully grown trees draped over temple walls - has surely held its own! the fact that many areas still look tumbledown just adds to the bizarre but wonderful atmosphere. Stunning!

amazing combination of nature and ancient temple. it's too worthwhile to visit this temple! i feel lucky to capture the scenes of the temple with the big trees, as the temple will eventually collapse if the old trees die off.The reconstruction site is a bit obstructing the view though it is necessary for conservation.

temple with a huge tree. This is a fantastic temple to visit but you did need to get there early to avoid the crowds. just stunning to see this temple and all the tree roots, it is amazing, that the temple is still there.This' where they film Tomb Raider. One simple advice that remember to bring good camera and big memory card with you.One of the best attraction at Angkor, certainly recommended this.
very exotic. Very old temple with massive old trees and roots developing in the temple walls. Dont leave Angkor without vising it ...
Large trees with mystical roots and stems. Ta Phrom Temple was built by King Jayavarman 7 dedicated to her mother. The interesting point is it is covered by huge trees with mystical roots and stems.

Magnificent. It's like stepping 1200 years back in time. Just as I arrived at the site a powerful Thunderstorm hit and the place began to flood. It was beautiful. The sounds of the singing bugs in chorus with the frogs was beautiful. If it's rainy season bring a cheap waterproof parka!

The most memorable moment of my life. What can I say.... This is one of the all time best experiences of my life.We made a treck to this site on our last day in Siem.The heavens opened and we were in the middle of the most spectacular tropical storm. We persevered none the less in anticipation of seeing this great temple.We arrived and due to the storm were only with a handfull of other people.The atmosphere of this place was spectacular. Of course the lack of other tourists and the stillness after the storm all helped.My advise to everyone is you must go here if you get the chance. It's absolutely amazing!
Weird, overgrown temple but that's the attraction. This is eerie and massive and alien. Definitely see this temple even if you're not into Tomb Raider or Angeline Jolie.

Nature Climbing on Friendly Monuments. The famous pictures of Angkor are to be seen at Ta Prohm. Tomb Raider was filmed here. The large sponge trees with their roots all over the monuments intertwined and going all over inside and outside is a sight to watch from all angles. You need to go there quickly before they mow the trees down.

Best temple of Angkor Wat. Every temple in Angkor Wat as its reason to be loved... this one is definitely for the amazing interaction between the temples and the trees who take over the scene. Incredible photo opportunities so if there is a temple not to be missed...this is it!There were some refurbishment works going on when we visited it on the 12th September 2013 but nothing major that it will affect your visit - just have to choose more carefully some of the angles for that perfect photo :)

Feels Like 'Lara Croft'. Was here last year. This place is incredibly stunning! Maybe when you arrived at the entrance it looks ordinary, but after you go through the path and get further inside the temple you'd feel the glorious back in time when the empire of Angkor existed. Few buildings were being renovated and looks artificial, but the trees, uh uh it roots are swallowing each temple's wall every corner. It's beautiful and amazing! Have you seen Tomb Rider? Yes that's exactly the view you could see. I feel like Lara Croft looking for a treasure here :)Unbelievable! Great adventure!
Unbelievable. We went at 0600 hrs before sun got up and before any crowds. Truly wonderful visit and the best of all around.

one of the most popular temples in Angkor Wat. huge trees grow from the walls of the temple, many visitors, not so many sculptures or pictures on the wall left, the focus is on the structure cohabiting between trees and artificial temples. reparations under construction
Highlight of our time in Angkor. This temple is amazing. The trees are growing on, in and around the ancient structure. Amazing photo ops. If you are a photographer this is a must shoot.

Great vibe, not overly grand. Number three on my "must see" temple list.
If you're short on time in Siem Reap, this is the temple that feels most "forgotten". If you have more time in Siem Reap though, there are some great temples a few hours out of town that totally kick butt.

Best Temple in the area. We went twice.. It's tough to write reviews about some of these. Of all the temples int he area, this was our favorite. With just the right balance of restored vs. re-taken by nature, it makes for some of the most iconic images of the area. The spung trees and strangler figs growing in and around this temple are a sight that photos just don't do justice.
wow. you will never see anything like this in the worlf ; this ancient sitehas not stopped the growth of these enormous treesA great photographic spot

Trees and the temple ruins. The growth of trees and the combination of the temple ruins are a thing to appreciate in this area. Also, because of the foilage, this place is cooler to roam around even at noontime compared to the bigger temples.

"Lara Croft" temple. One of my 3 must see temples. It is cool to see how the trees and temple walls merge into one. There is a bit of renovating going on but still plenty to see if you are patient. Most people go in a clockwise direction. Try going in an anticlockwise direction if it is busy.

Jungle fever,dark corridors and the magic of Ta Prohm. This is a massive sprawling monastic complex which only has been partially cleared of the encroaching jungle. It has been left intentionally unrestored,cosidering the amount of massive fig and silk-cotton trees growing from the towers and corridors offering a 'jungle atmosphere' and some of the best "tree in temple" photo opportunities at Angkor Its popularity has necessitated the construction of wooden walkways and as such Ta Prohm is an exceptional visit-must to explore its dark corridors and open plazas. magic place,my favourite.

Mother Nature takes over. The question that my guide asked me was which came first, the temple or the trees? Ta Prohm was made famous by the Lara Croft and the Two Brothers (Deux Freres) movies but nothing prepares you for the first sight of the trees within the temple complex. The tress are obviously centuries old and yet they have been integrated amongst the ruins as though a brilliant temple architect planted them when the sandstone block were laid so that the tress would grown within the blocks. A favorite amongst the tourists simply for its Kodak moments.

The Trees Were Awesome. This temple was my favorite. It was so unique in that the archeologists tried to do minimal restoration to preserve that feeling of having discovered a temple that had been hidden in the jungle for centuries. And as a lover of nature, I found it awesome how the roots of the trees could penetrate through the large heavy rocks and take over this man-made temple. The producers of the Lara Croft series made a good choice for the location of their films.
Amazing experience!. This is a very unique view. Giant roots of trees cover the ruins and you can't see it anywhere else. When we're arrived here, it's quite hot but the experience here is priceless!

Fantastic. This is probably my favourite. Although different from Angkor Wat as it has not been restored as much it is so lovely with moss, grass and trees everywhere. It is fun to explore with lots of different passage ways, paths to follow and avoid the crowds. Amazing to see - don't miss this one.

A bit different. Ta Prohm is quite different to many of the temples you will visit, because they have made the decision to allow the jungle to rule. It is quite hot and very humid but then most are, particularly in September (wet season). The kids love seeing how the roots of the trees cover the ruins and of course the connection with Tomb Raider is always I big hit.

Awesome roots. When I think of this place, I think of the picture I took of a face lurking out between the roots of those giant trees...It's a bit creepy but at the same time fascinating. And if you're a big fan of the Tomb Raider movies, go check out the place. Made me feel like a tiny ant standing next to those gigantic roots.

I felt like Lara Croft!. It's amazing to see all those huge trees that seem to be trying to engulf this temple, maybe even the trees are in awe of this beautiful creation that's why they're trying to hug it. I'm just a bit disappointed that some construction work is going on during the time of my visit that's why some areas of the temple are off limit to visitors.

Amazed by the trees.. Other than the heat which was a mood killer, the place itself was amazing. We might've gone at a wrong time because big part of it was under repair. So it was a little disappointing that we couldn't go inside the temple. But the surrounding itself was great.
Great Jungle Temple. A smaller temple to walk around and marvel at the jungle invading the temple. Hopefully the Indian/Cambodian conservation can continue past next year, when it's planned to stop.

Absolutely fascinating. The most atmospheric temple in the Angkor area, where nature plays a big winning role.The temple was swallowed by the jungle and has come to life again due to some incredible and clever restoration work, that has left the right balance between the work of man and the power of nature.Many corridors and towers allow each one to build his one exploration path, making the visit a memorable one.The real downside is represented by hords of tourists that fill any available good spot for photos !But still, it is a not to be missed attraction, without which a visit to the Angkor area would be inadeguate.
Great place to visit. Eventually you see so many temples and they all are wonderful with their own uniqueness and are all wonderful to see. You nearly wear out the camera.

Magical. We went there on our honeymoon and I can tell you all that it was magmagical! The history, the meaning, the force of nature... I highly recommend it. Better to go with a guide so you don't miss a detail!!
incredible. Just Loved, number 1 temple with incredible sight and seeings and utterly amazing experience within the truly authentic angkor wat temple complexes, dont really loose it whatsoever
Wonderfull. Nature at its wonderful form nature gets its own way to grow anywhere or everywhere same thing happened in TaProhm .must see to know the reality of nature

Splendor in the jungle. What can be said about Ta Prohm that hasn't already been mentioned? This is such a magnificent site that defies a simple description on TA. Ta Prohm is a huge complex of mystery and intrigue. The place seems to be overrun by huge trees centuries old. Their gigantic roots creep into holes large and small until the site is literally one with nature. The site is immaculately maintained. I really liked the wooden walkways that allowed you to explore the entire length of Ta Prohm. I would have liked to spend more time there. It is a place well worth learning about and discovering ancient engineering ingenuity and artistic masterpieces.

They're taking over (not just the trees!). Ta Prohm lived up to our every expectation in terms of scenery, etc. Unfortunately the place was not only being taken over by the gigantic trees but also hoards full of tourists- as shame really as this kind of took away some of its charm. We went there around 11am and the place was pretty busy. Try to avoid the other tourists if you can to fullly absorb this magical place.

The Jungle Temple. Ta Prohm isstuff of which nightmares are made - all those overhanging trees provide a gloomy atmosphere for an active mind. When researching, I was surprised to find Ta Prohm is the modern name for this temple - it was originally called Rajavihara. This was its name in Khmer - រាជវិហារ. The temple is to the east of Angkor Thom and you enter from the west and leave from the east. Building on Ta Prohm began in 1186 AD. Originally known as Rajavihara (Monastery of the King), it was built by Jayavarman VII who dedicated it to his mother. Constructed originally as a Buddhist monastery, it was enormously wealthy in its time with control over 3000 villages, thousands of support staff and vast stores of jewels and gold. Unlike the other wats at Angkor, this one has been left the way was it was found - overgrown with trees, their roots taking hold and the temple reverting to nature - an overgrown jungle with hanging branches and leaves the master here. When my driver dropped me at Ta Prohm, I walked under a canopy of trees along the path and heard music. A group of disabled landmine musicians were seated on the ground playing instruments. These men are victims of the landmines that were laid by the Khmer Rouge. They do not play, they wait for money to be given, then they play. The best time to visit this temple is in the middle of the day as the leaves form a canopy shading you from the hot sun. There is a sense of timeless beauty surrounding this eerie place, no doubt due to the quiet and the fact that it is a ruin in the middle of a jungle. The only sound was the sound of the birds swooping around the trees. You need to watch were you're walking, there are so many massive stones, rocks and bits of building paraphernalia lying in assorted fashion as though they have been laid there artistically. Among the ruins I saw balustrades with carving at the top and bottom. There was a large Banyan tree in the foreground. To give you some idea of the place, you just need to look at all the foliage, now imagine it is an endless sea all around you - everywhere you turn and when you crane your neck up to look at the sky - all you see is miles and miles of tree and leaves. It is like being in another world seeing these giant trees taking over and growing out of the temple. Banyan, kapok and strangler figs spread and twist their roots over and under and around, their knobby roots looking like deformed snakes taking over everything it their wake.
Trees do take over. Must see if you are visiting Angkor Wat. The trees covering the temples are truely amazing and offer some terrific photo opportunities.
Amazing site for pictures. A must for those love good pictures. The tree structures are amazing. You might get bombarded with adorable children selling souvenirs on the way in/out though.
The power of a tree trumps what was built by man. Tree roots that grow right through a demolished temple. Loved it so much. Wish they had some way for disabled access. Very spiritual.

My Favorite. All of Angkor Wat is amazing however, this one is in the Jungle and is very interesting because of the trees growing over and around it. Reconstruction is going on, but this doesn't detract from the experience. This was probably my favorite temple, we had some fantastic pictures here. The setting here was amazing.

Ancient ruins in most peaceful setting. As mentioned in other reviews, the temples in Cambodia are similar and yet very different . Over four days trying to rate my favorite, I must say this one is the most inspiring. The huge trees and roots overtaking the structure create an ambiance not easily reproduced. Try to wander off away from the throngs of tour groups....our guide led us off track and through some tucked away courtyards. The grounds leading tot the temple are equally a pleasure as is the music played by the monks resonating through the trees.
Amazing structure. Highly recommend visiting this smaller temple in the afternoon when the crowds have thinned. Loved the trees entwining themselves over the ruins.

Lost In Time. Avoid coming here late in the morning,otherwise you'll be assaulted by intrusive,shouting and pushy tourists in group.-tours of at least 20 people each.The best time to enjoy this wonder is from 5:30 to 6 am.

The Tomb Raider Temple. Each temple, while similar, is different. This one is very interesting as much as anything because of the trees growing over and around it. You can gets lots of fantastic photos. Reconstruction is going on, but this doesn't detract from the experience.
Magnificent Structures. The beauty of wild trees enveloping the all powerful structure is in itself an awe inspiring and exciting scene to relish...

Brilliant jungle adventure. We went with our boys aged 3 and 5 and they thought it was the best place ever. Set in the jungle it had heaps of atmosphere and b/c there were lots of tumbled down bits they were able to climb over huge stone blocks, follow through passage ways etc etc. And anyone with kids knows happy kids means happy outing. They fell over numerous times but got straight back up again as it was so much fun. Having said that the adults loved it too!It can be a bit slippery so think of your shoe choice. Whilst the carving wasn't nearly as impressive as Angkor Wat for example we enjoyed it far more b/c of the atmosphere and shade the jungle provided.We went mid afternoon and there were other people but certainly not a lot. Plenty of opportunity to get away from others. Preah Khan was also great with even less people.Fee covered by Archaeological Park ticket.

Get there early fro best pictures. This is a fantastic temple to visit but you did need to get there early to avoid the crowds. Unfortunately I got there about 9 which was Ok but the coach tours were gathering. It is incredible to see the trees growing through the ruins. Need good walking shoes and hat as gets very hot. I went with a guide and air con car which if you can afford is worth it. My guide was brilliant, great knowledge not just parroting a guide book.
Ta Prohm. the temple with the tree or the tree with temple, the natural and man made temple is become one. Huge tree are standing on the roof of temple with huge root.

Gigantic roots enveloping "tomb raider" temples. Amazing structure with magnanimous roots that enveloped / surrounded the temples. There were a few irritating tourists for they were inconsiderate in taking group photos, staying in one place for such a long time. Plenty of photo bummers.

Breath taking. The trees here was unbelievably huge, massive and whatever u want to call it. However, the party involved need to suggest this place to tourist as not the "Tomb rider" film place but suggest it as a temple that has its own uniques and characteristics.

"Tomb Raider" Tree and the famous root tree. thanks to both the Tomb Raider movie and other Angkor Wat guide books - there are 2 photos shots in this park that you have to get a picture of. do not leave this park without the 2 photo shots.

My favourit temple with the trees all over. This is a must see, specially after seeing Tomb Raider. But compared to Angkor Wat, it was so different and special with the nature taking over this temple. I loved that it was not totally restored, so you could see how much work it really was to find it and make it accessible for tourists.

temple with big tree. really amazed seeing big trees growing within the temples. however, most of the areas were under repair when we went there. this temple appeared in Tomb Raider film,starring Angelina Jolie.

Tough competition with Bayon Temple. This place is in it's own right just as spectacularly awesome as Bayon Temple. The jungle has more or less eaten this temple and, as long as the restoration work has not cleared the temple from the jungle vines and trees, it remains one of the most photogenic temples I've ever witnessed.

Definitely a must see. Our guide brought us there immediately after our sunrise tour at 6.45am. It was a wise choice cos we practically had the whole place to ourselves. We took lots of beautiful pictures with only us n the temple/trees/roots as background. The air was fresh n cool, the walk was pleasant, n we saw lots of parrots flying around too.

Playbg Indiana Jones. It's really like the Indiana Jones movie that I remembered. Apart from the tourists. This is not one of the best preserved temples, but the vegetation growing on it really makes it unique and very fascinating. It also has great carvings still in very good shape
AMAZING. Words really can't describe how wonderful this place is. The tress growing through the structures is mind-blowing

Love the pic with the big tree... Very ancient temple with tree grew within it. They said the Tomb Raider movie filmed here. Rent the tuk tuk to get there or u can hire a tour guide to accompany you. We didnt as we bring ipad together to read about it

Tree & roots temple!. It all about tree roots, quite a long walk through this temple from west to east gat, but we found we were continually stopping to marvel at the enormous trees pushing through the ruins. Very much an Indiana Jones atmosphere to this one!its breath-taking to be there to witness the amazing tree roots for yourself!

Amazing Temple. Seeing the trees growing throughout the temple is like nothing I've ever seen in person. Probably one of the most unique temples in Angkor Wat. Was pretty crowded, but certainly worth a visit.

Don't mess with mother nature. You can keep a good tree down. This site is amazing, the way the trees have grown around and up through structures has to be seen to be believed.
Feels more of a tourist trap, lots of children and vendors selling bits and pieces as you exit.

Huge trees by Ta Prohm Temple. I think this is a very unique temple (aside from the experience of being in the temple where Tomb raider movie was shot) it is such an experience seeing such huge trees that almost destroyed the hundreds of years old temple. The trees somehow compliments the temple which gave it such extrinsic look. amazing! The best temple I have been at Cambodia.

Sunset!!. Great sunset!! The sun set at around 630pm; but it's a steep walk up the hill, then you have to walk to the top of the temple. So, if you don't want to rush, get there early and take your time. Also, if you want a good vantage point of the sunset getting there early is recommended, as it fills up quickly with other tourists. Overall, well worth the sunset and views over the landscape!!

Its all about the trees. Ankor is a very large city, and within there are dozens of temples. And Tha Phrom is one of them. You will just need one ticket to explore the whole Ankor vacinity. As you go along, may probably have seen so many temples and they are almost the same ( though a bit diference in character or built design), however this one. Tha Phrom strikes out, its all about the trees. Fascinating, the trees seem to grow on top of the temples, hugh roots gripping on them. They must have grown over 100s of years. How is that possible?. Logically the explanation was that when Angkor was discovered, these parts of the city was at level ground with these large trees on them. Then only the temples was dug out, leaving the trees as it is. One of the best attraction at Angkor, certainly recommended this.
A must in Siem Reap. Aside from Angkor and Bayon, this small Ta Prohm shouldn't be missed from your itinerary. Amazing experience.

Ta Prohm. Must visit, less crowded and archaeologically intense site, restoration is going but its good to see how nature reclaims its right, Best time to visit is during cool season, you can not bare the heat otherwise.

Out of the world. A must see temple for the amazing huge trees that grow all around the temple. Wonder how theruins are still intact!!! The combination of the temple and the trees makes it just perfect. Currently restoration work is going on inside the temple.

magnificent 'tree-in-temples'. Ta Prohm is arguably one of the famous temples in Angkor Park and it was further popularized by the Tomb Raider movie. I'm really amazed with the way tree roots hug and crawl on the temple ruins! its absolutely a 'Man vs Nature' wonder. These massive roots enhanced the beauty of the temple ruins. Mind-boggling if you ask me. How the heck did this happen? :) Its easier to go around Ta Prohm than Bayon and Angkor Wat...maybe because Im not really fond of stairs and climbing. TIP: Taking photos is difficult as there are many tourists lining up so what i did was find another spot (there are plenty of picturesque spots here dont worry) without that much people and take photos there. After that, I went back to the famous spot and taa-daa! people moved on to their next destination so its all mine. its just a matter of timing. Because most have tour guides that take them systematically around Ta Prohm, you just have to be ahead of their "route" :)
beautiful. We didn't request a guide but we got one anyway... turns out that was fine he was very friendly and took us to the best photo op places
Iconic. This is the ruin with the fabulous trees that appeared in the Tomb Raiders movies. They are amazing and this is an easy walk. It is under reconstruction.

Most popular. This is the most popular of all the temples rivaling Angkor Wat and Bayon. After Tomb Raider, things are never the same here! The trees growing into the walls are awesome but to get a good shot without crowds of people, its best to go very early in the mornings or really late before 5 pm. Parts of the temple is now under renovation. A sprawling monastic complex it should not be missed.

nice place but too many constructions. like it in the movie, it is an amazing place. I am just wonder would it be better to visit here early in the morning...The trees here looks stunning but there are too many frames and fences...it is good for the relics but not good for pictures...

awesome. just stunning to see this temple and all the tree roots, it is amazing, that the temple is still there.
and yes there is a lot of people, some are not very friendly!!
it is a most , when you are in Siem Reap.

Tomb Raider!. You should definitely go here! And make sure you go here IMMEDIATELY (or after a quick bite) after the Angkor Wat sunrise, the Lonely Planet guide hit the money with this suggestion as the groups usually go in a clockwise direction, if you go counter-clockwise, you're pretty much alone in one of the most beautiful temples, this means no one in your way for your photographs!
Magical and enchanting. An absolute must see when you visit Siem Reap. A wonderful ruin, where nature has been allowed to run rampant and your imagination can run riot.

Breathtaking. Quite possibly one of the best temples you can see while in Siem Reap. While there have been some restorations attempted, many places are still left to nature and the elements, and this gives it an unearthly feel, unlike anything you will ever experience. And forget the fact that this is touted as "The Tomb Raider Temple" as the move used about for different location for a the one temple shown in the movie.

Gorgeous & Mysterious. Although Angkor Wat is the more popular monument, akin to an overachieving older sibling, I knew I would fall in love with Ta Prohm, the younger sibling bearing striking features with an air of romance brought about by her inherent balance of majesty and decay.http://9inchtales.com/ta-prohm
Tomb Raider trees!. The trees are awesome. It was a bit busy so I had to wait to photograph the trees without people in the shot. It didn't take long and was worth the wait.

Truly a special temple.... Ta Prohm may have been my favourite temple out of all we visited. It felt like we were in a tree house in the middle of Cambodia. The trees enveloped the temple. It was absolutely magical. Make sure to include Ta Prohm in your visit.
Tomb Raider!. Super cool temple ruins--we did this one separately after Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. You do get a bit of temple fatigue, so it was nice to break them up.

You must visit here. The whole Angkor complex is to die for , but this temple with all the trees inside the temple is something else . try to visit late in the afternoon when the heat is more tolerable.

too many people at once. It was very busy and a bit hard to get around with so many people in one space. it is one of the smaller temples, but it appears to be one of the most popular. Everyone wants to see the Tomb Raider temple.
gorgeous and so amazing. what will you say about this amazing place ? it is so impressing and beautiful. a must do in Cambodia !

Nature reigns. Mighty Kapok trees tower over the temple stones. Follow the path in the book "Ancient Angkor" (best price $5) p138. Go inside the temple, pass the rubble to a landing, great photo op in between a giant tree's man-high roots. Before taking the front exit, turn left and admire often missed out path. Back track to front exit or you you'll end up encircling the temple square once again.
Temple. Having your own Tuk Tuk means you can choose how long you stay, this is worth a visit but a quick one

Unbelievable that it is real. When you arrive you can't believe that this is natural and not a film set. You can totally understand why the chose this for Lara Croft. It is an unworldly sight that if you visit Ankor Wat then you must visit here. Arrive early before the crowds arrive to see it at its best.

Natural Temple. This was by far my favorite temple when we visited Angkor Wat and the surrounding temples. The beauty of the trees growing over, around and through the temple walls was incredible! We also really enjoyed taking photos throughout this temple complex and because of the leaves providing shade, but still allowing some light in, the lighting was the best in this place! While I probably will never return to this spot, I will definitely recommend it to anyone planning to visit Cambodia.

Nature's Temple. Ta Prohm, located about one km east of Angkor Thom, it is one of the most visited temple in the Angkor Archaeological Park area and also one of the most photographed sites. So unique is this temple site that it was also used for shooting of the famous film “Tomb Raider”. Ta Prohm was constructed during the late 12th and early 13th century by the Buddhist King Jayavarman VII not only as a temple but as a Buddhist monastery as well as a university in honour of his family. After the fall of the Khmer empire, this temple was forgotten and left in total neglect for centuries until it was rediscovered much later and subsequently made a Unesco Heritage Site in 1992.  It gives you the feeling that after being left to nature for hundreds of years, the jungle had decided to take over the temple and make its presence felt by outgrowing the numerous parts of the temple complex with very huge stems, branches and roots gripping and embracing the walls. Strangely the gigantic roots, instead of uprooting the buildings, have in fact grown in such a manner as though to lend support and stabilize further the building structure. Most of the gigantic roots have grown so big and flushed so well with the buildings that they become a surprisingly photogenic combination. There are so many locations around the temple complex where you can see these tree roots hugging and caressing the building structures and they are really amazing. In some areas and walkways, wooden platforms have been built for the safety of tourists and it can be observed that as far as possible where it does not pose any danger, the original state of the whole temple have been deliberately left unaltered and untouched by archaeologists and restoration teams and so as they say, in the ruins of Ta Prohm lies its magnificence.This unanimous decision to preserve the natural state of the temple as it was discovered is in recognition and appreciation of the natural wonder and beauty of the dense jungle, the uniqueness of Ta Prohm Temple and also the immense tourist potential. Today Ta Prohm is one of the most visited sites in the whole of Cambodia.

Forget Tomb Raider - this is simply amazing. Yes you can get your picture taken where Angelina Jolie filmed.But this temple is far more than that and by wandering around a little you can avoid many of the other tourists that flock to this must see wonder.

Trees, Trees everywhere.. Definitely a scene from Tomb Raider. Just when you think you've taken your photo in the famous temple in the tree, you turn the corner and there's another one. Make sure you camera battery is fully charged. So many photos to take. Be aware that there are sometimes queues to have your photo taken in the more 'famous' trees. We were very lucky but we missed all the large groups!

Hungry Jungle. this is the place to see nature take over what man has built and show that mother earth is still the BOSS!!! the way the roots of those huge trees eating up those temples is quite unlike anything... beautiful

Extraordinary ... Magic..... Fantastic temple as it has only partially be restored and still "sleeps in the forest". Gigantic trees have married themselves with the stone buildings, the result is breathtaking. The entire structure exudes a magical atmosphere ... But it is in the short Angkor circuit, so crowded. Try to visit it very early or as late as possible in the day.Definitely one of our favorites (and we've seen most of them....)

The perfect ruins... Famously known as the tomb raider temple, this is the place where you will get a feeling that you are in ruins. Trees grow out of the temple walls which makes the temple beautiful and picturesque. If you are lucky, just go to this temple after a short drizzle. It will look more green and the pics would come out good.This site is renovated and maintained by my country, India, which made me proud when visiting this site.

TOMB RAIDER!. When we went to Ta Prohm, it was still being renovated. Unfortunately so much of the beauty has disappeared and does not look like the booklets but there is still so much to see. Be sure to bring sturdy shoes and lots of water!

Most beautiful Temple. A must see!. This is the most beautiful Temple in Siem Reap. it is worth getting up early and getting to the temple between 7 and 8 in the morning when the rest of the tourist busses have not arrived as yet. Do not leave this off the list... it is a must see .. known as the "jungle temple" as it has been left with all the trees growing through the temple! Gorgeous.

Go See It Now. Our guide highlighted the fact that Ta Prom changes constantly because the jungle trees are unrelenting and powerful enough to destroy the heavy stone temple buildings. The managememt technique is to cut back leaning trees before they topple over and take out large sections of the temple. It is true that this can spoil some views but this Temple is very large with many, many, beautiful and spectacular photo opportunities. The bigger problem is the rapid growth in the number of tourists in the temple rich Siem Reap region. The Cambodian economy is benifiting from the boom, but it remains to be seen how well the authorities can manage these beautiful and unique sights - so go now. Important hint: do not rely on a guide book! An accredited local guide can really add to your appreciation of these unique sights. It is money well spent for multiple reasons.
Busy but beautiful!. Well worth a visit but be prepared for busloads of tourists! I enjoyed seeing this famous attraction but preferred the more off the beaten track temples!

Best of the Angkor Wat temples. Our family including our two sons (ages 10,13) visited Ta Prohm, Angkor Thom, and Angkor Wat on our trip to Cambodia. Our favorite: Ta Prohm. The trees growing around and sometimes through the temple really added to the overall effect. It had a real Indian Jones feel to it. (Of course, it's also the site of the movie Lara Croft Tomb Raider.)Go early in the morning to avoid the big crowds and the hot temperatures.If you'd like to see photos or get ideas about other kid-friendly things to do in Cambodia, check out our travel blog at www.aroundtheworldin72days.com
Wheelchair accessibility. Apart from the fame offered from the Tomb Raider movie, this is an average temple (according to my able-bodied companion) that is definitely not wheelchair accessible.

Natural Beauty. This my 2nd favorite temple. The natural surrounding does gives it the magnificent feel of the entire temple experience. It is currently undergoing refurbishment and it will take some time to get finish. We were amazed with the giant tree trunks that grew around the temple. It was as if the trees are supporting the temple from collapsing.We were amazed by the simplicity of this temple as compared to the rest. Angkor is a place to experience on its own. I will truly recommend for all travelers to visit it. Amazing Architecture

The Temple of the trees. This temple is most impressive due to the enormity and unusual growth of the trees in and around it.. This is a photographers dream and if you are able to time it correctly, either very early am or at lunchtime, the crowds should not be quite so horrendous. I really loved this Temple ..it was beautiful

Disappointed by the restoration of this temple. I visited Ta Prohm temple 4 years ago and was so impressed by the temple and the trees that had taken over and was really looking forward to seeing this place again. However, I was so disappointed by the restoration which has removed several of the trees that had made this temple so special. Also, since this temple was used in making of some movie, the crowds have so overwhelmed the area, it is not the temple I would revisit again. The restoration has ruined the Ta Prohm.

Beautiful temple overgrown by trees. I really liked visiting Ta Prohm temple. It is definitely my favorite temple. It is amazing to see how the temple is overgrown by trees. It gives you a clear understanding that the temple was hidden by the trees and not easy visible to the people. You can easily visit this temple in the afternoon as the trees provide enough shaded. In the afternoon you can also take nice pictures as the sunlight provides a nice glow on the trees and temple.

Angelina Jolie's- Tomb Raider site. Ta Prohm is a amazing site lots of history and if you cant tell is an old site from the stones and you can just looks at the trees.When visiting go early in the morning we were their early around 8am the place was particularly empty so we go to take lots of photos and our guide could stop and explain along the way.It gets really busy, packed and super hot around midday so go early and start you Angkor park visit in Ta Prohm.Another thing is before entering the Angkor park you need to get you photo's taken for your admission pass best to get their early. Buses filled with people were arriving by the time when got ours we were lucky to miss the long lines (they are efficient so the lines will move fast)

Despite the thronging crowds, you can find your own roots entwining with the temple. If following the main circuit, Ta Prohm will be one of the last spots, giving it a large advantage of your final impression of the Angkor temples if you are only spending one day here.It is certainly a great final temple, but due to the fame through Tomb Raider, the crowds do really build up, particularly around the 'Kodak moment' spots! The way the roots entangle themselves around the stone walls is amazing and gives a real impression of how this would have looked discovering it for the first time.Despite the huge crowds, we did manage to find a spot just as spectacular, which we had to ourselves. Just after the most famous Lara Croft spot, through the doorway towards the exit, turn sharply left and straight ahead there is a great spot where you can climb the fallen stones to get a good vantage point (see attached photograph).
Amazing heritage. The whole complex is a unique experience for people who love history and archeological heritage! Go early in morning for good pictures.

Amazing trees!!!. The temple will not be that interesting without the roots it the huge trees trying to cover the parts of the structure...Every tree has a very unique formation and photographers loves it... So do I.

Definitely not to be missed!. be prepared to open your eyes to the amazing trees growing atop the ancient temple and still growing... one had to be there to truly comprehend the feeling of standing on this historical ground... part of the temple has crumbled down but we are glad that they are restoring it to their best to it's glorious time...

Wonderful old trees in the temples. This is the famous temples with the trees growing through and over and around the temples. We could not imagine how old some of these trees are as they are huge. Really loved this complex and I don't think we saw it all so will be coming back. Yes, it does get busy as everyone was to see the trees and take photos but be patient and everyone gets a turn. Loved it...

This temple is one of the very best. To see how the trees grow on top of the stone walls is really something to behold, and warrants going to see in person. If you are in the region, ensure you don't miss Ta Prohm.
Unique. Amazin that would be the word to describe this place, i can understand why tomb raider was film in this place its a unique and different to anything i have seen ever...
Really amazing place. Amazing to see such a place and understand how much effort has gone into restoring it just to where it is now, nevermind where it needs to be. So much to do!

The constructions kinda block the view. This temple as I was told was used in the movie "Tomb Raider" starring Angelina Jolie. It's really beautiful from the outside. You'll love nature even more because of all the trees surrounding the temple. However, when you get inside, you won't see much with all the constructions going on. I believe they would want to restore the temple. But I think there's no need for that. The temple is beautiful as it is.

great history. like angkor wat this is a place everyone should see, incredible place, is starting to fall apart so im glad we saw it when we did. The best way to see all the temples is use the taxi service, it is so much better.

Most beautiful and eerie place. I was most curious to see this place as it was featured in movies and I must say, the movies dont do this place justice! This is a beautiful place where nature has won over man! most of the temple buried under the creepy roots of gigantic trees is a sight you wont forget! This was the highlight of my trip to Cambodia!

Seen in Laura Croft movie..... Now you can too! Super, SUPER cool temple that has been overgrown in trees that are hundreds of years old. It's an amazing example of nature reclaiming the land. According to our guide, the initial thought at conservation was that these trees should be cut down. But when that happened, the buildings began to crumble withe the death of the supporting root system. Truly a site to behold. You MUST go early or late, because in the afternoon it becomes overcome with visitors who love to take lots of photos!
A favourite. We loved this temple with the trees still growing through the ruins - has real character and atmosphere.
Temple with trees. To see the way the trees grow out of this temple in many locations was great to see. Some great structures are also in this temple. Not to be missed.

Stunning. ooops just realised this is the Tomb Raider one...thought it was a different one. Anyway this is very different to any of the others as it literally has tress growing out of it. It’s amazing how the structure stays together when there are such big trees growing through the gaps in between the stones…..well worth a visit and very interesting to see something slightly different

all thanks to my tuk tuk driver. came here with a tuk tuk since i couldn't ride a bicycle. but he was more than happy to drag me to this quieter temple. this was part of the route for all the major temples, which eventually, still not to be missed. each temple seemed to have a story to tell. if only i had more time!

Like Temple Run. This was my favourite temple of all the temples I visited! I liked how it looks so much like Temple Run. Trees splitting temple rocks, pile of stones covered in green moss, butterflies flying around. It was simply beautiful.

Tomb Raider. Yes, this is where parts of Tomb Raider was filmed. Truly amazing seeing the giant banyan trees growing over, around, and through the temple complex stones. Can be very crowded, go early, and go with a private tour guide. Easier to get around and you don't have to be rushed.
Famous Tomb Raider Temple. The temple is almost completely collapsed, but still an amazing sight to see as most of the rumble of the remaining temple pieces is covered by big jungle trees!

Enjoyed it and haven't even seen Tomb Raider!. Loved the 'Jungle Temple'. Well worth a visit. A very original temple. It is a shame that the same roots are damaging the temple but very very much worth a visit. Lots of tourists so get there early.

Excellent ruins!. This temple is the best among others. It has a strong ancient spirit along with its ruins! The walls, trees ruins is amazing, but the sight was ruined by the renovation construction everywhere.
Tomr raider 2 temple. A very different temple with all those huge trees coming out of the stone.There is still a lot of reconstruction work to do but it was a ery pleasant temple too.

The most famous. I guess this was probably the most famous of the temples because of its' use in the filming of Tomb Raider but for me, not the most exciting. What was amazing about this temple was the Silk-Cotton trees growing from within the brickwork. Just incredible, have seen nothing like it. Sadly, they will demolish the building work in time

Truly a wonder; ruined by crowds and reconstruction. This temple is truly a wonder, and such natural beauty with the trees and roots cog rowing around it. However, you are lucky to actually get a look at these let alone take a decent picture. With large tour crowds crowding it like it is going away in 5 minutes and taking the time to take a picture or 2 of every tourist in their group at every turn it is definitely ruined. Had a hard time appreciating it for its history and beauty with the loud crowds and construction distractions. If you can get in their without many people it would truly be a site.

What a site. Ta Prohm would have to be my favourite site out of all the temples in the area. Yes this is where Tomb Raider was filmed, but apart from that, this is a pretty amazing site. While some of the temples are being preserved, I do hope that they leave it as it is, as the trees and the moss over most of the site actually enhances the temple complex as a whole. Yes you will get the chance to have a photo in front of the tree from tomb raider, but be quick, as there will be hundreds of other people wanting to do the same thing.

Stunningly beautiful.. Personally, I would put Ta Prohm and Bayon top on my list of must-visit places at Siem Reap. Ta Prohm is a natural wonder. To see beauty in a temple in ruins is an unconventional experience. Ta Prohm is stunning in this regard.
Yes, yes, the one associated with Tomb Raider. This temple ruin is excellent because of the trees that grow on the stones. They change color dependent on the weather.

Totally feeling like a Tomb Raider!. What separates this temple from the rest is that this feels like a long lost temple that you've stumbled upon in the forest. With trees tangling upon the stones, one cannot help not feeling like Indiana Jones or Lara Croft.

Tomb Raider temple. Temple largely in ruins that was made popular by Angelina Jolie in Tomb Raider. Actually, it was the root complex of the invasive giant ficus that is the star attraction of the temple - which is a shame really. I would recommend the temple for visitors with senior citizens given the shaded walks, the numerous seating areas, and the smallish size of the temple proper

Visit early to avoid the hordes. After tomb raider now more likely to be referred to as the angelina Joliet temple but that's not a reason to miss seeing this. Really interesting but be prepared for the hordes of largely Korean tourists wanting to pose as her in front of some of the temples/ roots. Interesting debate at present regarding the preservation of the temple vs the keeping the trees.
What a sight!. Ta Prohm and the ruins are fantastic. The stairs were a challenge along with the humidity and heat, but something not to miss.
Awesome structure of the temple and trees. Do not go there without a camera... The trees grown awesomely in the temple. Nice place for photography.

amazing temple!. This was my favorite temple that I visited in Siem Reap. The temple is gorgeous and it feels so untouched (aside from some of the restoration efforts going on to save the temple from crumbling from the tree roots). I feel like I could have spent all day at just this temple. Unfortunately we were there during the rainy season and we got rained out halfway through our tour! I would definitely recommend this temple. Beware of all the people selling goods outside the temple and children tugging on your arm begging for money. Once you're in the temple you won't have anybody bugging you.
The best bit. Just when we thought we'd seen the best along came TP and blew us away. The friendly guard showed us the best views for great photos.
Stunning. Plan at least one hour, but three is better. Prepare to take hundreds of photos because at every turn, there's more beauty. Walk and walk, don't stop when everyone else does.
Worth a long walk and visit. Travel with a guide to learn more about this temple. Wear appropriate clothing to all temples and bring water!

Words Do Not Do It Justice. Another must see temple at Angkor. We were concerned about the crowds but low season has its benefits! Our guide made the tour for us.....he took us in the back way through jungle tracks without a tourist in sight then came out the front when we were finished. We loved all the temples..they are so different even in their colours, let alone design. My main advice would be to get a good guide, do not get a tuk tuk here (too far from Siem Reap and way too dangerous. My sister ended up in hospital when their tuk tuk was forced off the road last year), and go as early as you can to beat the heat, crowds and afternoon storms.

Stunning - go at lunchtime to avoid the crowds. A beautiful temple where your visit can be made even better if you watch the Tomb Raider scenes it is in beforehand. Before we visited, we were concerned about how busy it would be as the entrances were always solid with coaches, mini buses and tuk tuks. However, our guide took us at lunchtime and we had the temple almost to ourselves. Amazing atmosphere and amazing picture opportunities!!
welcome to TombRaiders.... gigantic roots overgrown...like in the movie starred by Angeline Jolie...majestic scene,spectacular trees...ruined temples...historical realms...

Won't be disappointed. Our tour guide took us to Ta Prohm "Tomb Raider Temple" straight after sunrise at Angkor Wat which was perfect timing as it was pretty much deserted. This one was eerie with all of the trees growing through the structures but ended up being the favourite for most of us. Again I would recommend a tour guide if you are doing any of the temples to get the most out of them. If you had limited time do Ta Prohm, Bayon and Angkor Wat.

Beautiful temple ruins. We visited Ta Prohm early in the morning and it was a great time to go as there were barely anybody there which allowed us to explore the temple ruins in our own time (and peacefully I might add!)
Not to be missed. Right out of an Indiana Jones Movie. Great pictures of the roots from the trees trying to reclaim this old temple. One of the top 3 temples to see n Siam Reap.

Interesting temple with many trees. This is another interesting temple but very very very crowded. We followed the whole crowd from the entrance to the exit, pretty easy to walk without getting lost. Trees grew in an unusual way. some had no branches, some growing out of the ruins. Then it became funny when u see people queueing to take photos with the trees but we did the same anyway!! Definitely worth a visit.

A must see. After all the photos I'd seen, i was not disappointed. Our guide very cleverly took us to the left hand side entrance avaoiding the large groups of visitors. Took some great photos. Despite the hords of fellow travellers it was a very peaceful place. Worth seeing.

Ta Prohm Temple. This my absolute favorite in Cammbodia. Plenty of photo opportunities. Not a big temple but much to see here. A lot of the temple is covered in bright green moss making it look even more beautiful. The trees growing amongst parts of the structure looks fantastic....a must see.....

Beautiful, ancient and amazing!. Have you seen trees growing out of buildings in such a way that stumps you? This is also part of the Angkor archelogical park and you can't miss this. Inspires people to sing, dance and paint and draw..
Right out of a movie set. Extremely interesting sight; every section was a little different from the next. This temple looked the most ethreal.

Surreal. This temple has been more or less left as they found it. The trees roots growing all over the temples give it an eerie feel almost surreal. Of course everyone will recognize it from the Tomb Raider films. Definitely a must see.
don't miss it out!. Without any doubt the best spot of the Angkor complex. It was awesome to see the trees with the roots over the the buildings, really outstanding and unforgetable place

Awesome. Ta Prohm is lovely, and you cannot come to Siem Reap without seeng it. The jungle is beginning to reclaim the Temple so there are a lot of trees growing over walkways and doorways. Good photo opportunities, but you may have to wait a while for your chance, as a lot of package groups come through and they are so focused on getting their own shots. Still, if you have patience it's not such a big deal. Come early, around 7.00am, to avoid the largest groups. Yes they have been doing restoration work which can be noisy and unsightly but it must be done. You will be surprised as how long it can take you to walk through Ta Prohm but take your time so you don't miss any of it, and make sure your camera is well charged! If you arrive by tuk tuk, it is best to enter at one entrance and have your driver meet you at the other entrance, as the complex is so long.

Most interesting temple in the area. Great, interesting views of the forest mingled with the temple. It was the kind of image we expected on this trip (not surprising, since this temple was used in some movies).

beautiful. The jungle growing over the ruins is so spectacular.Be sure and buy a book or two at one of the hotels that details the park and all the sites and explains what the history is.I had a guide but I must say it's hit and miss understanding everything and missing things in translation.If you know ahead of time what you want to see, you can read up on it and that way know what you are seeing as you're seeing it. I, on the other hand, didn't do my homework and am doing it the wrong way: seeing and then reading about it after the fact.
Tomb Raider experience. As you enter the place, you just WOW....I found a ruin city in the jungle. Massive trees roots strangling the towers. Love this place!

Nature takes over.... This is an amazing temple! Left for years and years, the jungle has claimed it as it's own again. The trees come up out of the temple as if by magic and are awesome to see! Just goes to show what happens when nature takes over.
Well worth the visit. We went during the build up which made it slightly uncomfortable travelling weather but all of the temples were amazing and well worth a good look around
Roots. Fantastic setting for Photographs. Take the time to enjoy it..give yourself 1 1/2 to 2 hours. Watch the movie Tomb Raider after a visit. Take black and white photos too.
The trip was fascinating. The trip was fascinating as the carvings of each head had different expressions, it was a large temple and had stood the degregation of time.

Ta Prohm. Another great place to visit. We went by private taxi from Siem Reap for a good price. We ended up with a local guide indirectly but it was quite helpful in the end. Worth the visit, fascinating place.

ta prohm the jungle temple. how is that possible??? century old trees growing intertwined with old ruins from the temple??? that is the mystery and magic of ta prohm!!!! it is good to know that the government of india is supporting some restauration projects to preserve this gem!

Amazing. I have seen over the years so many photos of this temple in Cambodia. I never could have believed that it is this amazing. It is no wonder that film makers want to make movies with this background. So many amazing scenes.

Beautiful but is being restored. It is amazing how this temple has been overtaken by the jungle. It is badly damaged and is also incredibly popular with tourists. Spend lots of time exploring as there is a lot to see even with it being quite small. But its just beautiful to just sit and admire how the trees are connected with the ruins. There are two entrances . East and west gate. You will be dropped off by your tuk tuk driver and he will meet you on the other side. So don't walk back to the entrance where you walked in from.
Don't miss this temple.. Amazing trees and stone work. You can get some terrific photographs. A large temple with some restoration work being done.

A Jungle Temple - everything you imagined. One of the Big Three - don't miss it. the photo opportunities are amazing. Get there at the time of day to avoid the tourist hordes - mid afternoon seems to work.

And the jungle wins this one!. Exactly as you imagine from seeing this temple in "Tomb Raider." The spung tree and the rest of the jungle have taken over and become embedded in the temple. The restorers cannot remove the tree without damaging the temple, and so it remains. Very cool sight! However, our views and enjoyment were somewhat marred by scaffolding and noise related to ongoing restoration work. It was also very crowded with large tour groups, making it difficult to move around. Great photo ops, though. And if you can, rent a bike to ride to this temple and then ride through the jungle to Ta Nei, a little-visited temple that you may have all to yourself.

Amazing place - a must see. At point it felt like being part of the Tomb Rider, at some points very crowded and it was a low season, but taking everything into account an amazing place to visit and I think one of the main ones on the temple complex.

Tomb Raider!!. Yup, for those of you that used to go gaga over Angeline Jollie in Tomb Raider, this is where it all started. It truly is a magnificent sight to see the human-made structure got sucked back into the Nature bit by bit. Highly recommended!

Misterious and impressive.. Great temple, when you arrived it seems really small but it is impressive, the jungle has grown inside it and it gives it a sense of mistery. Here is where Tom Raider's movie was shot but being at the place is a totally different experience.

An amazing temple!. A beautiful Indian temple that survived centuries of wars and religions yet never lost its spiritual force.
I suggest a $20 guide to get the historical and architectural details of this magical kingdom.

From the movies.... Our guide kept referring to this temple as the "Tomb Raider" temple. It is the one with the huge trees growing on it. It really is quite impressive. Great photo opportunities and there were not very many people there. This has not been as restored as some of the other temples, but they are working on it.

Stunning!. This was our favourite temple, without a doubt. The way in which the trees are reclaiming the temple is both eerie and beautiful. As our guide said, the trees are taking back the land, religion versus nature and nature is winning. I only wish that some of the large tour groups would respect the fact that you are in a temple and cut the fooling around and loud noisemaking - it seemed so out of place.

Fingers of the banyan tree. The fingers of the banyan trees abound in this temple. Although not as massive as some of the other temples of Angkor, this temple is the one that is closest to my heart. It affords the viewer the opportunity to enjoy the buildings and their significance to the area. However, it also provides the perspective of nature's ability to re-claim it's rightful place. Although, the tour guides are wonderful, this temple is best enjoyed when the tuck tuck driver drops you off and you enjoy a few hours on your own or with a friend. It is a much better experience when you take the time to enjoy the moment there.

The best in Angkor wat. It is absolutely the best there that I think human could not duplicate it as the temple has combined with the nature already. Bricks And trees just mix together naturally. U would feel a sense of history there.
The best place ever seen. Wonderful place with a powerful energy and picturesque views))) Never forget these huge trees sprouting straight from the ruins of buildings - unforgettable impressions!

Great temple tree grow up!. It is amazing temple with a tree grow up very nice view. It was good, we found in the Hollywood movies don't believe but now really great to see in my eye. The temple was good designed by Khmer empire but some of building broken but it is good and amazing.
our favourite site. beautiful, lots of fantastic views for taking photos. very easy to get away from the other visitors. short walk to the site from where the tuck tucks drop you off.

Atmospheric contrast to Angkor Wat. A place with real atmosphere. Some restoration has been done, but much of the site still has trees embedded in the structures. This contrast is fascinating to see and you can appreciate just how much work is involved in getting what amounts to a 3D jigsaw puzzle finished to show what the buildings were like originally. We went without a guide, taking a tuk tuk from our hotel there and back. It cost USD10 and the driver waited over an hour for us at the site. He even provided us with ice cold water and refresher towels at no cost. A generous tip was give and thoroughly deserved. Suggest you go early as it gets crowded and the middle of the day can be unpleasantly hot and humid. Crowds not only hinder access through the narrow passages, but get in the way of photo opportunities.

I think it's just that I'm not a fan.. July 2013, most of the place is actually undergoing renovation. It's not pleasing to look at it while there are lots of scaffoldings and other structure supports that are holding the place together. I'm curious as to how it would actually look like without those scaffoldings.

when nature takes its course.... This place is just beautiful... If you love nature then this is the place for you. It's located in the middle of the jungle hence the large trees growing around and through the temples. There's one area where rocks are just scattered around the trees, a good spot to just sit and spend some time enjoying the view (did this on a Sunday afternoon) :)*Visited this temple twice. It was crawling with tourists on a Saturday afternoon and practically empty on a Sunday afternoon. :)
The best!. The most atmospheric! Would have liked to spend more time there. Go early or late in the day as the light at this time adds further to,the atmosphere!

Amazing place. this is where Angelina Jolie's 'Lara Croft-Tomb Raider' was shot. Ensure you spend at least 1.5 to 2 hours here to do justice to the place, the arcitecture, the carvings on the wall and most importantkly get a good English speaking guide who can explain everything and the History to you to make the trip memorable, that is, provided you like history.

Tomb Raider!. If your traveling to Siem Reap to visit the temples, Ta Prohm is a must on your list of places to see. This is the temple used in the 1996 movie tomb raider. Much of the temple grounds have been taken back over by the surrounding jungles; the trees growing 20-some feet (7m) up on rock structures is truly amazing.This temple is easy on all visitors; there are not steep stairs or long climbs required. Although much of this temple has collapsed, there is still plenty to see worth your visit!Remember to bring water for drinking, sun block and bug spray.

Spectacular. Great photography opportunities. Have visited more than once and it is still full of surprises. Best time to visit is in the low season and not as many tourists crowding the prominent spots for photos.

The most mysterious of all the Angkor structures. This is probably the most interesting because it is the intriguing. I is under re construction but it is still beautiful. This is best know as the "Tomb Raider" site which starred Angelina Jolie. The fig trees which are growing on a round and through the temple make it a relaxing site to visit. Also because it is only a one level site, the trees supply a much needed shade from the hot sun. This site should be one of the must visit locations.

Nature is amazing!. Everyone who goes to the Angkor complex seems to have this temple on their list. Of course, it's most often referred to as the Jungle Temple or the Angelina Jolie temple. I was fascinated by how nature had taken over this structure. It was very interesting to see the state in which these temples were discovered by the French explorer back in the 1800s though it's sad to see the place continue to go to ruin. We had our picture taken at the Angelina Jolie tree which was silly but almost seemed necessary! We visited in July and early in the morning. Crowds were not a problem at all.
Beautiful. Beautiful temple, didn't realise how big it was and some of us actually missed some of the main parts which was a shame

Loved it!. Be prepared to hike back into the site and then climb around rocks, etc, once inside. Wear good shoes and carry a backpack to keep your hands free. A few vendors along the route but nothing too bothersome. Many great photo ops here.
Ruin!. Ta Phom is the archaeological park because there are many big trees that cover on the castle.I love it likes this but I dislike the construction!
Nature vs man-made. Another must-see here - humongous trees swallowing up an amazing temple. My favourite temple along with Angkor Wat

Hollywood Temple In Siem Reap. Ta Prohm !This sprawling temple was built in 12th by king Jayavaraman VIITa phrom was dedicated to his mother this temple also originally constructed as a buddhist monastery and was enormously wealthy in its time, boasting of control over 3000 villages, thousands of support staff and vast stores of jewels and gold.of the monastic complex styleTa Prohm is a superior example example and should be included in almost any temple itineraryAnd especially this temple was selected by famous American movieOf Hollywood of Tom rider I would high recommended this temple to all people and the best time at afternoon

Very unique experience. I think that anyone who visits Siem Reap should go to visit Taprohm temple. The archtechture and environment of these ancient ruins are spectacular. You will definitely enjoy your experience here. It feels as if you are in a long lost city.

Tomb Raider Temple.. The tuk tuk drivers know this place as tomb raider or Angelina Jolie temple. Historically, the temple might not have as much a significant as Bayon or Angkor wat. This temple has impressive large trees that grow out of the temple walls and infrastructure.

Erratic power of nature.!. Rajavihara (assumed to be the original name for Ta Prohm) was built around 12th century.. Thats approximately 900 years ago.! This place would probably make you feel like you are on a time machine on the way back to olden days. Unlike most Angkorian temples, Ta Prohm has been left in much the same condition in which it was found. The roots of trees running through the temple walls is really unique. Just tells you how nothing stays above nature.P.S: Be it be noon, sunrise or sunset. Good to be visited at anytime of the day. Even the hottest noon wont bother you as this place is covered with lush greenery.!
Hire a guide. Love exploring the ancient ruins of Cambodia and Ta Prohm doesn't disappoint. Take your time lots to explore

come from east gate early morning. there is a construction site. but this place is my number two favorite spot. not easy to get clear shots. bring your tripod for slow speed motions if another tourist passing by

Nature & Temple combined. This is another must see when visiting Siem Reap. Quite amazing to see huge tree roots snaking through, over and underneath an ancient stone temple. You can see why it was chosen as a location for the tomb raider film. Starting with a dawn rise we managed to visit Angkor Wat, Bayon and this temple by 3pm as they are all in close proximity to each other.

Wooooow!. It is amazing to see how nature has taken over this buildings. Unlike most Angkorian temples, Ta Prohm has been left in much the same condition in which it was found: the photogenic and atmospheric combination of trees growing out of the ruins and the jungle surroundings have made it one of Angkor's most popular temples with visitors.

Great to visit during the hottest part of the day. My husband and I are travelling with our 19 month old daughter - our visit to Ta Prohm was a fantastic experience and we have some incredible photos from it. Just note that:- There is some restoration work in progress at the moment, and the scaffolding may be prominent in some of the 'iconic' photos. - Visitors can go almost anywhere, however there is a lot of 'uncleared stone' at this site in particular, some areas may be slippery in the wet season or unsafe - our toddler was able to roam comfortably in some grassy areas but she was carried in a backpack for most places (as you might expect). - There is limited information on site, and I do think that for the price ($60USD per person for a 7 day pass) that some information should be provided to 'unlock' the story behind this ancient place. We had a great reference book, and others have hired personal guides - either or both of these options are helpful to get value from the visit.- Tuk Tuk was the best transport for us - gave us flexibility to go anywhere and anytime. Most tuk tuks have a legal maximum of 3 passengers.- It's highly likely that you will be approached by children selling wares at each site. We were given advice to avoid purchasing from these children because it encourages their continued exploitation. It's hard to say no to these kids, so an alternative way to support them is to give a gift (e.g. a pencil, notepad, wrapped candy) rather than money. We got a 7 day pass, and spent early mornings (5am - 10am) and late afternoons (3pm - 6.30pm) at the temples. This site offers a lot of good shade and can be done at almost any time of the day for that reason.

Tomb Raider!. Our guide continued to refer to this temple as Tomb Raider - sorry never seen the movie! The incredible fig trees growing around and through this temple makes it unique, an incredible sight. It's great to see the restoration work being done at the temples by so many different countries.

Go at lunchtime. This was our favourite park. Our guide told us to have early lunch so we arrived at 1230 and the hords we leaving .. And we were the only ones arriving. We go in there and only saw perhaps 10 Other people ... AMAZING!! So no one to stand in our photos ... Then at 130 pm there were hords again coming in so we left .. Because I think especially the big tour buses have set times for lunch around noon. The photo ops were fantastic here

Where history and nature collide. This was one of my most favorite travel locations in the world. The ancient temple has been partly reclaimed by nature with giant trees growing from the roofs of the temple buildings. I'm so thankful I was able to squeeze this visit in; i would have been devastated to have missed it!

This is a must see!. This was my favourite temple and def the most popular. It is so Mysterious, I can imagine a scene with wizards and magical creatures. I love how the jungle is living and thriving alongside the man made temple. The trees are impacting on the temple & causing displacement , but the trees also appear as if they are holding up the temple. To me it's beautiful, as if the trees belong there.

Highlight of tour. Not because of temple run game or tomb raider film. But the spung trees and design was fascinating for such a small temple. The king created this for his mother....nice resting grounds :)

Incredibly Amazing. This was one of my favorites. Smaller than some of the other temples but interesting to navigate through the small nooks and crannies in rooms with less light. The temple over run by giant tree roots is amazing to see first hand. It is now under restoration and there is much evidence of the ongoing work. This was the site of the movie "The Tomb Raider!"

Lara Croft. This was my favourite place. Went just after sunrise at Sra Srang. (sp.) ordered a ice cold coconut water across the entrance and ate my packed breakfast at one of the tables. Was much quieter first thing, so don't linger too long over breakfast. Take your water in with you as it is a little walk down a path before you reach the temple.As we were leaving (early morning) the tour groups arrived and the moment there is lost. Try to avoid the crowds, it really is just that little bit more special.

You feel you are Tom Raider. Ta Prohm has been almost untouched so the jungle has eat some of the ruins, so it's Incredible to see the big trees in the middle of the ruins. Is such a Magical pleas that you fell is almost unreal.

A' la Angelina and a lot more.. As I agree with some of the reviews here, the crowd can just get bigger in and around Ta Prohm. Just try to walk past the first and second tree roots and find that the crowds thin at the other "roots". Initially, I wanted to visit the temples because I wanted to try and meditate among these structures. But my plan to go with a group just kind of set that aside. So, if you would insist on being among the structures with at least a few crowds, try going there perhaps around 5 in the evening. Don't forget to hire your own tuktuk driver and a guide.

It can get very crowded here. It can get very crowded here. I don't know when the best time of day to go is, but if you don't like crowds go to Beng Mealea instead. It has many of the same characteristics but is MUCH less busy.

Crowded Temple but beautiful. It is beautiful to see the huge tree roots blending with the temple. I took some amazing pictures here, you should go to the end of the temple where is a huge root and it's less crowded because everyone stops at the first and second root to take pictures, just keep walking and you will see the other huge root with less tourists. It is a lovely temple. It is crowded with tourists and Very Hot, so be prepared.

Must see. This is a must see temple. There were a lot of parts to just explore around and we went back and explored around while our tour guide waited. He had taken us to all the main sights in the temple but we just wanted to search around. I felt like I was actually in different video games I had played years ago.

Taking photograph of Ta Phrom. Our main objective to visit Ta Phrom is to try taking some 'unique' pictures of the temple. So the key is to shoot during golden hours and crowd avoidance. We visited the site twice, first in the afternoon around 3.30 PM until 5.30 PM where the crowd has dispersed and you have the temple for your own. Of course, you have to hire your own transport (tuk-tuk) and not part of the group tour. The sinister fig tree root, devatas bas-relief and meditating chambers are some of the awesome subject. But with a lot of scaffolding and fence surrounding the temple to protects the ruin, taking clear shot is proven to be challenging, but rewarding. The next day we visited the temple again in the morning around 7.15 AM when only handful of people around. The natural light is not as we expected so we'd rather focus in the macro portraiture type. The crowd start pouring around 8.30 AM. So based on our personal experience, it's much better to take photos in the afternoon.

mesmerizing. a little bit scary, but completely mesmerizing nevertheless! you cannot give this a miss. there will a line to queue up for is you want to take a picture infront of the famous tree roots you often see when googling about Ta Phrom. There are signs, saying it is dangerous to stay too close to certain structures for fear that the structures might collapse. However, it is just beautiful! it is as if, nature has become vindictive and has now reclaimed back her land, reclaimed back what was once hers.

Very misterious but need cleaning. I like the trees soorrounding the ruines, but I dislike very much the lack of maintance and the mold and mildew that is damaging the carvings and the temples, they make too much $$$ money and they don't care about preserving it. Many areas are abandoned.
Yet another winner. Like all of the ruins in this area the scale and skill of construction and workmanship has to be seen to be believed.

very heavily visited site. When you see the trees that appear to have grown out of the stones at this temple it is an amazing sight. The temple is being renovated and although the temple itself is not as impressive as some of the others it is the way that nature has forced its way onto this temple that makes it so amazing.

So crowded but nice. Very crowded with travellers. A nice spot to see big trees grow with the temple. Temple gates are east & west, so make sure you go to the right exit to get your transport, cause the entrance is so similar that walking towards the other end is very far.

Remote, quiet. This is around 7 kilometers from Angkor Wat. it is unusual. I did not have a guide and a temple attendant took me around (N.B> elderly Buddhists often take on care of temples as a pious task)

Ruins in the Jungle. Ta Prohm was one of my favorite places to visit in Siem Reap. There were very few other tourists at the time we visited this site. So it really just added to the ambiance of ruins in the jungle. It was amazing.

My favourite Temple. We were lucky to travel in July, Temperatures were good and not too many tourists, other friends reported both may be extreme, but we were delighted to find the opposite. This temple is fascinating and some great photo ops with the colours and shapes of these ruins in the jungle.

So disappointing with all the scaffolding. After visiting here for past 2 years without the scaffolding, it was really disappointing to visit with the central passage and heaps more of the temple blocked off with scaffolding and reconstruction.
