And the crowds were unbearable? Do NOT visit mid morning!
the harmony between man and nature. Evidence of the cultural work of an ancient community recovered from the clutches of Mother Nature. A place for reflection and learning about the value of history.
Ta Phrom. The massive huge trees is quite beauty but it ruins the temple. Even in its destruction, we can still the intricate details of writng on the walls.

was awesome!!! would recommend.. v good experience the wat surrounded by trees it was awesome to see how pretty it was. would recommend. there were a few kids trying to sell you things along the way but other than that was pretty and good trip. worth the money for the temple pass.
The jungle temple. Very awesome experience to visit this jungle temple that become famous as used for the film of Angelina Jolie's Tomb Raider :-)
Nature growing within the walls. Recognised this temple primarily because of the movie Tomb Raider. But when i saw the huge trees and its roots growing around and over the walls, amazing! Must-visit!

Indiana Jones meets Tomb Raider. This tree riddled site is exactly how much of the Ankor complex would,ve looked , when first visited by Europeans. The jungle has reclaimed much and gives a very authentic feel to this amazing site. A photographers dream come true, get there fisrt up to beat the crowds and you will be well rewarded.Incredible!!!!

Tombraiding @Ta Prohm. It first caught my attention when Angelina Jolie played Lara Croft in Tombraider. It was one of the reasons I wanted to see Cambodia - to see the jungle temple of Ta Prohm. Walking through the entrance gates of Ta Prohm, I couldnt help but notice the beautiful terra cotta colored earth. I was thinking how many generations of people have religiously walked that earth - Buddhists, Hindu, Khmer royalty, and spiritually evolved beings. Soon enough, I was awestruck by the ancient and giant forest of Spung Trees - most older than any human being alive, by many times over. These trees over bear witness to Khmer life and history. I am in the midst of an ancient civilization that has managed to keep its old world charm for a thousand years.Seeing the overgrown trees on temple rocks made me think - nature is powerful. We try so much to change the natural environment to suit us, but then in the end, our efforts remain only for as long as nature lets it. The beauty of Ta Prohm is that the trees have reclaimed the temple lands as it once was - their own. This is the power of nature. It is silent, patient, and seemingly passive. But it endures.
Trees growing on top of temples. This is a must see temple. How the trees have managed to grow in too of the temple is unbelievable as is the restoration project being done here.

Jungle Temple is a must. My favourite temple at Angkor. Do not leave without seeing it. Being there was truly sensational, I could not wait to see this temple and I was not disappointed.Agree with other reviews photo opps were amazing.
This was our favourite temple. Everyone has to go to Angkor but it is also good to see other monuments and this was a good choice. Take a picnic and spend the day there

Must do. Out of all the temples visited, this would be the best. Easier accessible, though would be impossible for wheel chair bound people. Incredible atmosphere, so peaceful, and of course, the sheer history of the place. It outshines Angkor Wat for me.

Tombraider setting. My favourite in the Angkor complex.
A must see place of reclaiming jungle wonder.
Ideal place for some amazing photos.
Highly recommended. Really enjoyed this and would say it was our favorite. This is where they filmed Raiders of the Lost Ark. Lots of tree trunks, vines and roots growing around the ruins.

MUST SEE. It is one of 3 must-see temples in Cambodia - Bayon, Ankor Wat and Ta Prohm. It's not a huge temple, requiring maybe a 30 minute walk about the grounds. This place is overgrown by trees over the stone.
Keep yourself hydrated and protected from the sun, an umbrella can be useful too!

Busy busy, blank your mind to enjoy the beauty. With the number of other visitors with you, it's important to just block it all out and pretend! I could see people getting frustrated when they couldn't take the 'perfect' shot, but hey, what can you do? I liked the lane way walk to and from the temple site with the accompaniment of music played by amputee groups. The KR tried to crush this music like the people, and so it's important to appreciate that it all lives on. ADVICE: bring an umbrella for the sun.

Photographers Paradise. This is an amazing place. I love big and interesting trees and seeing them growing up and through old stone temples is something else. I was in Siem Reap for 2 days and went both days I liked it that much. I was lucky the second day as there weren't a lot of people so managed to get quite a few shots with no people in them. In some places I was the only person there for minutes at a time which by other peoples posts is quite rare. If you can handle the heat and humidity just get a tuk tuk for the day $15 USD. Take water but you can always buy out there which helps the locals out. A $1 tip goes a long way here so spread it round.This place is a must visit.

Beautiful... Beautiful..... It's a beautiful, wonderful, amazing place... i love the way those trees grows above the stone temple. It's amazing. Sadly there's a restoration happening there and they cut some of the trees. I really hope they can preserve the temple without chopping those trees.Overall this place is just fantastic. my 2nd favorite at the location....

Magnificent blend of stone and trees.. Ta Prohm is a like a giant rendition of a bonsai sculpture. The trees that grew out from the cracks now seem to envelope and eat the remaining parts of the temple.

Impressive. I've visited the temple a bit circumspect because I generally do not like place that became famous in action movies. Yet, I truly loved the temple: the way stone and wood mix together in a temple making you wonder who built it: nature or humans is unique and touchy. I had the feeling the temple is small, but it is much bigger then the first impression it creates. We spent there 2 hours without realizing it.The only thing I did not like were the large numbers of children selling things instead of attending school.

This place is overgrown by trees over the stone. This place is overgrown by trees over the stone. You can see the unrestored bits and compare them to the restored parts. You can still find a quiet spot to reflect here about the magnificent history of the Khmer.

Lost in Ancient Times. I heard that Tomb Raider had Ta Prohm as one of its shoot location and somehow I feel like Lara Croft exploring the place. Being in these ruins felt as if I am transported to a time when history took place and where the trees were the only silent witnesses to the years. It was as breathtaking, as it is beautiful.

'Tomb Raider' in real life!. We found this the most evocative & authentic of all the temples in Angkor as the archaeological restoration done during the colonial period has left it very much part of the jungle with giant kapok trees spreading over the buildings & walls.Ta Prohm was originally a Buddhist monastery & is full of small stone meditation rooms. Amazing opportunities for taking photos if there are not too many tourists in the way!

Behold!!!!. That was my first thought after seting foot on this temple. Get ready to get asked a thousand times if you need a guide a monkey a snake purse or whatever they can sell you. But be nice and decline politely as this people is in serious economical problems. But dont let anything ruin your visit.Beware of extreme heat, sunblock a hat or an umbrella as our fellow asian travelers do. And plenty of water.Visited february 2012

My favorite Angkor temple. Strangling firs upending temples. The only disappointment is the the temples are crumbling, and I think they were looted and left to rot for too long before international organizations tried to revive them.

Better in person. Very crowded but, fantastic. Just amazing to see in person and hard to get you head around. We walked through and got many photo opps. At the end we didn't go back though since it was too crowded, we actually walked around the side and didn't see one person, it was magical and an excellent choice.

Spund Trees in Ta Prohm. Its like something from the Tomb Raiders movies.. Huge trees growing through walls and out of temples. One of my favourite temples in Angkor. Well worth and aul gach. (a look)
awesome. Huge and beautiful - lots of nooks and crannies to discover. The only negative is the large tour groups - but there are so many avenues to explore that for the most part you can avoid them.
Where is Angelina Jollie when you need her.. Tomb Raiders film location is real and quite astounding. How mother nature reclaims the planet if left alone is spectacularly witnessed here.

Even more awesome than Angkor Wat. I'm not too sure about that, but certainly just as beautiful. It's worth the cost to hire a private guide and car. Make sure you have plenty of dollar bills to buy postcards and trinkets from the children. Carry a small towel because you are going to perspire a lot. Make sure you see this temple.

Stunning. I absolutely loved this temple! I would list it as my favourite among all the temples I visited in the archaeological park. The trees growing on the temple walls and roof were beautiful, and there were wooden platforms to walk on and take photographs. It's not a huge temple, requiring maybe a 30 minute walk about the grounds. Many places to just stand and admire the view, so feel free to linger.
Tomb Raider set. Very atmospheric and like an earthquake has just struck. They're doing amazing work to put it all back together, and the best thing is the fact they've left the trees.

ancient strangler trees. Great temple with many ancient strangler trees, which eat up the original tree and have complex roots. The sight is amazing. Ta Prohm is also called the Jungle Temple, with lots of greens. Only thing is, beware of little kids at the entrance asking you to buy souvenirs. They DON'T stop until you buy something or leave with a tuk tuk.

This place is a must. Tree roots have taken over and you are allowed to wander at will between the ruins and in the areas that have been restored. Of the three temples this was my number one. Bayon came second and Ankor Wat third - but a wonderful third.

Lara Croft was here - so was I!. Lovely structures around especially the giant tree roots. Some even shines off like metallic colour and the others a bit gold-like. Excellent choice for the movie "Tomb Raider". Thumbs up for the movie AND Ta Prom!

Beauty in ruins!. The ruins of Ta Prohm, with huge trees branching out of its ancient walls, make for a photographer's delight! Although restoration work is slow, & a lot of areas need improvement, it is definitely a nice place to visit on your own. You don't need a guide if u buy a book on Ancient Angkor or get yourself a map of Angkor from your hotel. Then you'd know which all places to go. Your tuktuk driver can also double up as your guide, for no extra charge!
Beautiful. Untouched natural beauty merged with ancient megastructure. Some renovation works going on. It's beautiful, atmospheric and picturesque. One of my favourite temple.

back again to the past. Visit this place in 2000 and then 2005, and now again in 2013 and there had been big changes. More commercial but also more to see at this site. easier to walk around now, but also more people here, so in all good and bad things but still my favorite

Heavily visited but worth it. Though we were there during off-season, and during the lunch hour (suppose to be the least visited time), this place was still packed with tourists. It's is highly photogenic! But over-run with people as well.

Lara Croft Tomb Raiders filmed here. Much smaller to get around than the bigger temples, but the overgrowth by the trees is very atmospheric. Lots of photographic opportunities and there is a cafe and vendors in close proximity.

Closer to the original discovery. Gives you the first experience of how these temples were in their original state! A big favourite of mine in the Angkor complex.
Keep yourself hydrated and protected from the sun, an umbrella can be useful too!

Into the Jungle. This a great temple, it is impresive how does the Jungle got inside the temples and even with this the rocks has handle the pressure. Incredible photos can be taken in here with the light in the morning or late afternoon, even raining.Tip: Get early to Ta Prohm and then jump to Angkor Wat, this way you won't find many tourist and you'll be ready by noon to go for lunch.

Capturing in every way. This was by far the best temple, very well known for "Indiana Jones". Numerous buildings with trees covering them or literally through them. You need a guide to get the full value. This is a photographers delight. The temple pass which covers all the temples is valid for 2 individual days so you can go back at less crowded times. Just loved this temple

This place is remarkable. This place is remarkable, a must see for sure! The Jungle has begun to reclaim its space and has overgrown this ancient temple; trees have grown around, up and through parts of the structure. Absolutely Amazing, I could have took pictures for weeks.

What can one say. It has probably all been said, but this is a must see temple. There are the standard photo shots, but try some from the back near the exit looking back to the temple. We were there about 8am and it was not crowded at all.

Unforgettable experience!. Visited on my own (other family members hot and "templed-out"). Despite being quite busy I found myself alone regularly in the most amazing spaces. If you wander off the beaten track a bit - round the outside wall away from the tour guides - you can almost imagine you have just stumbled across the place. There was quite a lot of restoration going on when I visited, and scaffolding spoiled some views. Overall though, an unforgettable experience.

Ta Prohm Temple. One of the oldest Buddhist temples at Siem Reap, Cambodia. Very important thing is Indians should proud of this, that the Excavation here is taken place in presence of Indian Archeologist. The sign board here are painted with English as a first language and Hindi as a second language. All the ruins of this temple are buried in giant trees and the sculptures are beyond imaginations.

Under construction. This is the 3rd time I'd been here.The first time was the most magical experience, it was still 'untouched' looking.The second time, there were a few ropes and boardwalks to protect the site.This time, there was a massive crane and the area near the best picture shot was mostly closed off.. It made a good picture very difficult.I can understand and appreciate why they do this, hopefully it won't be on going.. It ruins the magic, but it's still beautiful!
My impression is trees on temple. This is an amazing sight. You must see this temple. Did the trees grow on the temples? How did the trees grow so big and strong on top of the temples?
hundreds of very rude picture takers. everyone wants the same photos at this temple, so you will not have a great picture if you don't have patience or go at a very popular time.

Going back in time. You kinda feel like an explorer coming upon a lost temple when you visit this place. Just mesmerizing and awe-inspiring seeing the trees reach up to the sky like that. And make sure you go to the echo chamber and send your wishes and thanks up to the gods!
Dont go in May,its very hot season. Good and exciting place..come in oct or nov..the weather more good..everything is valuable for pocket..

Top spot. This temple complex is close by Angkor Wat and should definitely be included on your visit. This site has a more intimate feel than some of the other temples and was returning to the jungle before it was rediscovered.

adventure place. The most exciting is the hug root of the tree place on the temple create the best art scene. It's so natural place like a hidden city that we just recover by our adventure. the best time of the life. the best place of siem reap if you enjoy nature.
Impressive trees temple. This temple was impressive. The hundreds of trees that grew in this temple, slowly destroying bits of it, are magnificent. My favorite temple in siem reap.

Another great place. These ruins have four almost identical gates. It is quite extensive and we loved having a good look around. When we had finished I wanted to walk around the outside and my partner wanted to walk back through the temple. I thought I was waiting at the right gate but it took half an hour for us to find each other-I should have gone to the next gate!

Temples within Nature. Siem Reap, Cambodia will not run out of cultural experience. This was the 3rd temple we visited and it can be at par with Bayon Temple. It was a different experience coz the temples are separated by trees. It was also being one with nature while exploring the history of Ta Prohm Temple. I guess 1 day will not really be enough to explore all the temples.

Second time around.... Second time around my favourite of the temples, a little different this time with the restoration and the few trees that have fallen. It is impressive to see what a fantastic job they have done with the resoration after 7 years, for such a tedious job they are doing amazing work. :-)

Fantastic ruins and being encroached by the tree growth. Get there early - before midday - as all the tour groups head out there in the afternoons. A small site which can become overcrowded, Amazing ruins with tree growth in amongst the stone work

Big Tree!. Before I visit the temple, I just know about the Tomb Raider, and this is the place where the film was shot. Once there, I was attracted by the big trees and their overgrown roots covering the building. It seems like they are inter-dependent. :)

all the temples in and around Siem Reap are gorgeous. I love walking around, not too many people in May and it was so quiet and peaceful. Our guide and driver were awesome, knowlegeable and kind. Highly recommen Siem Reap for a holiday

Tree roots of Jungle. It is amazing that who is supporting who? the tree is supporting the building or the other way round!! You will see the different kind of trees with different kind of roots, like twine or massive straight. Some places are under restoration and closed for visitors. But tree grew of building and another one was spread in courtyard where just beautiful. Some movies have their shooting done here in past and lots of photo opportunity for your own collection. The ruins are still in very good shape. I even saw a big spider web and a big spider between 2 trees.

This temple was amazing. The must see Tomb Raider site gives you a pretty good idea how closely invasive the trees were at other sites, and how much work is required to restore them. It is more shady that the Bayon experience but has a real appeal just because it is so unusual

Trees and stone. angelina jolie would love the action role in this place. how spooky and old and again, mysterious is this temple. in the jungle and discovered and trees and trunks and old fixtures now restored. the whole temple scene is an experience to witness and to smell and take in the atmosphere and appreciate what these people lived like

Magical. Really beautiful site with crumbling temples and overgrown tree roots. Try to go early because by late morning the tour groups arrive and the place will be overrun by tourists trying to snap their portaits in front of the trees. Even with the crowds, this place is pretty special. A must visit on any tour of the Angkor park.
The best temple by far!. My fiancé and I were the first to visit this temple early in the morning. By far the most interesting and amazing temple there!

Amazing but Beware the Angkor Police!!. This temple was amazing, so beautiful!! You can just wander around it and marvel at what time and nature has done to this structure. I thought I was so lucky to have an Angkor Police tour guide, maybe he was just bored and wanted to chat up a tourist? NOPE. I wanted to walk to the east gate to look at something, he brought me THROUGH THE WOODS and demanded I give him $5USD for showing me around, to help "pay for his english lessons". Unreal. I paid it because it was weird and I wasn't super comfortable. Just watch out for super friendly Angkor Police. Otherwise, it was great.
Awesome Temple. This is the Awesome Temple, The Jungle is brilliant that how can stand on just a small building / temple?

Enjoy the beautiful temple. At the time of our visit, a big part of the temple is under construction, even we can't enter from the main entrance since it is closed for renovation, and the most famous point of taking pictures by the tourist is under construction as well. There are some big trees being cut too to preserve the temple. But you can still enjoy the beautiful temple, especially since the time Angkor was discovered again, Ta Prohm was made to be kept in the way it was found, this is why we can still see the big tress growing around even on top of the temple, sometimes it looks like some part of the temple are being entwined by trees like an octopus or snake, or even an elephant trunk. It's like the temple is supporting the trees, but the trees are supporting the temple as well. It's really is a different experience.Sadly we saw some people who don’t respect the temples or understand things, they climb on top of some temples which has been restricted with rope and warnings for no climbing, not only they put them self in danger but they also show no respect. Please respect the temples and the grounds.

Don't miss this one!. I actually felt like I was discovering this place for the first time. Go at 6am while everyone else is at Angkor Wat or Angkor Thom. You'll have the whole place to roam, without worrying about anyone getting in your photos.

But overrun with tourists. I thought Angkor Wat was overrun with tourists until I visited Ta Prohm, which on a busy Saturday was bursting at the seams with tourist groups. If there is a good thing about tourist groups it's that they move through quickly!

Great ruins. Saw these ruins in a few weeks ago. Fantastic ruins, and I can now see how spectacular they were in Tomb Raider. It is great to see that some repair work is being done, the trees will ultimately destroy a great percentage of it if something is not done. Well worth seeing.

Amazing Overgrown Wat. Trees engulf every inch of this Wat. It is incredible to see how the massive trees have taken over. I definitely recommend making this a stop. This Wat doesn't take very long to get through. Lots of great photo ops here!

Awesome!!!. Loved the fact its less commercialised than Angkor Wat. Its still being restored so heaps you still get to see in its raw state. Trees growing entwined with the man made structures etc. Bricks and pieces of the temple still lay in ruins, unlike angkor wot which is totally restored, has "shops" selling souvenirs etc. You won't find any of that here!!

Temple with a difference. Obviously this temple is famous for being used in the sets of box office movies. But put all that aside and you will see an amazing temple that is now partially supported by these enormous trees and their root system. If you have limited time and can only fit in a few temples, then this should be one of them. Visit either as early in the day as possible or later in the afternoon, as this temple is just about as popular as Angkor Wat itself. We spent a fair bit of time in this temple climbing over stone pathways and metal ramps, it truly is soul inspiring.

A bit of movie magic. For all the action or adventure movies you have seen, you will find Ta Prohm very familiar. Besides Tomb Raider which Angelina Jolie made this part of Cambodia even more so famous, going through the ruins and grounds gives you a sense of adventure like Indiana Jones could have experienced (without the traps, danger and movie action of course). Do not miss out this on your day trip to Siem Reap.

My favourite place in Angkor. This is really the one to see! It's breathtaking - try to go early in the am bc it gets packed and its hard to get pics without people in the background. One of the most impressive things about the Angkor parks is how clean the bathrooms were - I was seriously shocked and impressed!

A Jewel of the South East. Ta Prohm is a bit farther than Angkor Wat but had less groups of visitors and was worth the extra 15 minutes in tuk-tuk. Angelina Joli shot a movie there, among the old temples and the huge tree roots that make this holy place a jewel.

do not miss. if your going to go home with a life time memory, go to see ta prohm.you can imagine the jungle engulfing the temples from what's left of the trees growing out of this temple, they films do not do it justice, I wish I knew what it is about these temples here at Angkor, I can spend hours n hours wandering around trying to work out how they built them how they managed to get the carvings done so neatly, and all done in this heat n along time ago. yrs if you see a nutter in the corner deep in thought its probably me, dreaming ime back in the day, working out how they managed to construct such a spectacular array of temples, I am impressed.

Wow! Straight out of Indiana Jones. This is one of the "overgrown" temples. It is well worth a visit, but be prepared for the crowds. There are many places where the huge tree roots are squeezing the walls and buildings of this temple. Loved it!

Is it real?. When exploring Ta Prohm, you expect to turn a corner and fid that it is just a film set and there's nothing behind the incredible exteriors. But no, it's real and awe inspiring and a must-see on your Angkor visit.

Ta Prohm. Just like the pictures one sees, huge Strangler Fig Trees growing out of the ruins. Many parts just a jumble of rocks. Think if the trees died the whole complex would just collapse, they really anchor the huge stones. we were lucky in that our guide was allowed to drive us very close to the Temple as it was so hot.

Awesome..Lara Croft here we come. This was my favourite temple and def the most popular. It is so Mysterious, I can imagine a scene with wizards and magical creatures. I love how the jungle is living and thriving alongside the man made temple. The trees are impacting on the temple & causing displacement , but the trees also appear as if they are holding up the temple. To me it's beautiful, as if the trees belong there. This is a must see!

SO BEAUTIFUL I CRIED. This was the best finale could have had for my stay in Siem Riep. We were picked up at 5.50 by our Tuk Tuk driver and we were at the temple by 6am to be the ONLY two people there. Words caznnot describe how truly magestic this place is.
Temples you want to see. One of the must see temples when you visit Siem Reap.This is one of the temples with roots overgrowing everything. A treat for your eyes.

Magic. Incredibly powerful place!Ta Prohm was one of the most powerful places that I saw. The force of nature at its finest. Producing one of the coolest looking places. Locked in the middle of the jungle is this temple struggling to survive being crushed buy the growth of giant trees that sag, and puddle as if they where made out of taffy. Must see temple when visiting Angkor.

A really interesting Wat. I was impressed by the huge tree roots growing over some of the buildings and the obvious work going on to conserve the temple including trying to preserve the trees as an example of what was there when the temples were discovered in the jungle.
make sure you take your camera!. Tomb Raider was filmed here - the trees growing out of the temple structure are truly amazing. I hope they don't ruin it by trying to over-preserve it.

Stunning!. You just have to walk through all the doors and the hallways... I don't even want to believe it was built by human without innovative technology.The temple is beautiful and worth to see. The strangest part is the dinosour sculpture on the wall, mysterious!!!

WOW!. Its a different world and not just ruins! I was particularly happy to see the way the place has been restored - and was proud it has been done by Indian archaelogists. Dont miss the deserted and still-in-ruins chambers behind the reconstructed passage.
Beautiful. I loved that in September the temple is covered in moss. This should be the 2nd temple you see in Siem Reap.

pretty. I liked this temple because it had something different to the others. The tree roots entwined between the stone really set it off from the other temples. This was definitely one of my favourites,

Not like 20 years ago but still impressive!. The most favorite tempel of many people. Sadly it was "cleaned" some years ago but the main roots can't be removed because archeologists say Ta Prom would collapse if they would remove ALL trees with their gigantic roots. Very popular so don't think you will have it alone.....

The best!. I LOVE this temple! It is just unbelievably cool and beautiful! A reminder of the skill of ancient builders against the effects nature and time...A truly beautiful temple that one MUST see!

Good to understand. Ta Prohm like Preah Khan are cool to see because different from others where were made works to get better and consequently cleaning from vegetation, they choose these two sites to leave exactly the way the french found it more than 100 years ago.Therefore the atmosphere is quite exotic and feel like and adventurer or for those that watched Indiana Jones or Tomb Raider like such protagonists.

More to be discovered.. It is undenyable that the place gives a feeling of sacred ritual. Yes it is Hindi from that time. History can be found in every bricks and stone. Mostly stone so to speak. The culture by then last to make you feel the difference from the present time. It is hot there anyway so i suggest to go there early and you will have time to enjoy other places in the same day such as Bayon(the reservoir) and other castles remaining nearby. For souvenior such as t-shirts or bracelet can be bought from the local with bargainable price. Enjoy:)
beautiful. we liked it all... but way too hot. arrive as early as you can to really enjoy the sights. we could not see it all. too many beggers and tuk tuk drivers.
Stunning. This temple had been maintained as is because of the stunning views of all these trees and roots growing in the cracks and lifting the stones. This was truly remarkable.

Leave it alone. This temple is famous due to the movie Tomb Raider with Angelina Jolie. They're re-structuring the famous front area of the temple but I wish they'd just leave it alone and leave it the way it was.
Explore. Really this ruin the most, as you could really get in there and do some really good photos without there always being someone in the way. There is shade, though still a long walk.
The Temple of root. Here you can see big roots on top of the temple. unfortunately these roots are damaging the temples. some of them were already cut. this temple is undergoing reconstruction

Breathtaking! Mysterious!. Perhaps one of the most amazing experiences we had (me and my wife) was to have gone to Cambodia. The country is very special, mainly if you know a little of its glorious past history and also his infamous recent history. Of the many wonders we saw in our stay in the country, no doubt visit the temples of Angkor in Siem Reap, was the best of all things. We depart from the capital Phnom Pehn to the north and the 6 or 7 hours we stayed and the surreal road ( no more than 300 km) made us feel what was coming. Siem Reap is the nearest town to the Angkor complex with its numerous temples, and the starting point for every visitor in the region. This is where tourists staying and attending markets and restaurants. Among all the temples in Angkor, which dazzled us most, was Ta Prohm. It is simply spectacular. Built between the late twelfth and early thirteenth century by Jayavarman VII, one of major kings of ancient Khmer kingdom, whose capital was then the city of Angkor itself, is approximately 6 km far from the city center and can be reached by tuk-tuk or even bicycle. You must purchase a ticket which entitles nearly throughout the complex, at the park entrance, which is 3 km from Siem Reap. This amazing temple of Ta Prohm is unique, mainly because it has been kept pretty much the way it was found, many centuries after it was abandoned in the jungle, by the integration of nature with which was built by man.. The landscape reminds us of the cartoon, where plants and huge trees have life and seem to embrace the ancient stone buildings. Bas-reliefs depicting religious motifs, "talking" about the life of Buddha and showing various types of animals, are present everywhere. The mysterious air of the place, which was the scene of the first Laura Croft’s movie, Tomb Raider, starring Angelina Jolie, is present even in the representation of an animal for millions of years fickle, the stegosaurus, which appears on some stone carvings . How it got there, no one knows, but scientists have proven that these figures were not placed there later. They are original. We stayed at the temple for a few hours, but the desire was never to leave.

Highlight of Angkor Wat. This temple is just fantastic to take it easy and wander around. It's the place with least reconstruction and thus all the trees grow around and from the structures. Simply breathtaking

So fascinating. This temple was used in the Tomb Raider movie and is so fascinating and interesting. The roots of the trees are huge and have grown over and around and down over many parts of the temple. One of the most interesting temples I've seen. Many places to get wonderful pictures and many interesting parts to the temple. Lots of children selling trinkets at this one, more than the others we were at. Very scenic walk into the temple and lots of information about it once you walk out of the temple to get to the area that you depart from.

The highlight Angkor complex. Whatever you do dont miss out on this temple, dont get a guide just wander around at your leisure, but much better to go latet in the day as the sun is setting and get some great shots!!

The Best part of Angkor Wat. Ta Prohm (tomb raider temple) is the one with all the vines and trees growing amongst it. It makes for some amazing structures and you can get some great pics as well.Its best to head there straight after sunrise if you can and you will miss the crowds. we got there at 7am after sunrise and there were two other people in the whole complexe. Even the guards hadn't all come out yet. There is some renovation going on and a crane with construction equipment so that ruins a few sections. Although when you see the evidence of past renovations you will understand how necessary the renovations are.
Ta Prohm-Rider. I cant belive i was at this temple where Tomb Rider was having one of their scene shot at! this temple has walls, unlike the outer temples you shall passed along..
trees growing out of temple. unusual to walk around then back into tuk tuk for next temple. Worth seeing because different to the other temples due to the trees merging with the stones.

Better than Angkor Wat in my opinion. I was quite excited to see Ta Prohm because it has a much more atmospheric appearances, still being slightly overgrown by jungle. By and large, that is exactly how it worked out for me. Whereas many of the other Angkor monuments are scrubbed clean, Ta Prohm still looks a little more romantic and adventurous because of the massive trees still overgrowing the structure. That is probably why it has featured in so many feature films, including providing the backdrop for many films, including Angelina Jolie's "Tomb Raider". The trees also help provide shade from the punishing Cambodian heat.In many ways the temples are like children: they are all beautiful in their own way. But I will admit that Ta Prohm is really my favourite.

Featured in the movie "Tomb Raider". The massive trees growing among the ruins are a sight to behold. We went in the afternoon when it was not too crowded. With our ticket for 3 days to visit the temples, we had plenty of time to have a leisurely walk in the temples. Our private tour guide was very good in showing us the highlights of the temple. We also had a separate driver with an air-conditioned Toyota Camry, who provided us with cold bottled water and cold towels (in sealed packets).

Totally surreal. This temple is amazing. The trees growing through the walls add to its unique charm and around every turn there is another incredible sight.Can really see why it was chosen for Tomb Raider.

My favourite temple - trees as a piece of art. Minus all the tourists, this is an amazing temple which I think can be serene after tourists have left. The ancient trees with their roots hang over and under and around walls and roofs, makes this temple probably more beautiful now than it was when it was being used? Trees as a work of art. If you can avoid it - dont come in April. It is not an understatement to say it is extremely hot and humid

Doors to your heart.. Basically you'll find alot of doors, it's doors after doors after doors, then there's an altar in the middle and same time you will feel you're surround with good energy even it's May and it's dry season.

Beautiful but crawling with tourists. Ta Prohm is really quite a sight but my experience was hampered by the hordes of tourists that came in by mid morning. Unlike Angkor Wat that is rather spacious, Ta Prohm is made up of narrow corridors and walkways, so you have to elbow your way through crowds. It was hard to get a good shot as there always people in your frame! Another gripe is the persistent vendors selling trinkets and souvenir items the minute you walk towards the temple. They're also waiting for you as soon as you step outside! That said, Ta Prohm is actually a magnificent site and quite breathtaking. Perhaps the best time to visit is at the break of dawn,as most tourists start their visit at Angkor Wat during sunrise.
Good ruins. Not as impressive as Angkor Wat but worth a visit as it is very different, very long walks to each temple, tuk tuk is advisable or tour bus.

Thomb Rider. remember Angelina Jolie in thomb rider?should come, see, touch and feel the tree, the temple and amazed by how God works through the nature...i really love the place and can sit, relax for hours...
Impressive!. Ask your guide about the hidden dinosaur! We had Dat (pronounced Date). He was very good. Our hotel set it up, he's part of the certified guides group there.

Definitely my favourite of all the Angkor temples. The place looked enchanted. It was so mesmerizing. Looking it the massive trees growing right smack on the temple walls makes you think of the history that has happened as this temple was being eaten alive by the jungle. I liked it even more than the great Angkor Wat. Photos cannot justify the amazing things you can see here.

Jungle and Temples. I love how the jungle mixed with the temples. It shows uniqueness and beauty to the ruins. This is where the Tomb Raider movie was filmed. Also, the reason why I'm very eager and excited to see this place.

Tomb raider. This is an unmissable photo opportunity all those pictures you've seen of the tree growing out of the temple...well this one is the best. Walk all the way through to the end even if its unbearably hot as it was for us or you'll miss this great Kodak moment!

Awesome. We went here in april. It was so cool. It seems so understated walking up and into it but there are so many little and big treasures. The trees taking over the temples was very cool. Also the restoration that is and was going on there is great. They are doing a fantastic job. Well worth seeing.

Fascinating. Well worthwhile visiting this tree temple. It was amazing to see how the roots have embedded themselves in the temple such that they now seem integral to each other. Some restoration is going on but it doesn't detract from the visit at all.
Jungle temple. Ta Prohm is a beautiful temple, bound by massive roots of huge trees. Tomb Raider were filmed there.
Fantastic site. Another fantastic example of amazing architectural achievement. I found this place as amazing as al the others in the area...great trip.

Wowza!. This is a smaller temple complex than that found and Angkor Wat, but it is just as lovely. One of the things that I found wonderful was that there are trees draped over the stone walls and various masonry. The roots just hold tightly to the stone and some go on for many meters. If you are visiting temples, make sure that this, along with Bayon and Angkor Wat are on your list. Go early in the morning to avoid the heat.

Pretty good. I reckon this is the best temple after Angkor Wat. Well worth visiting but it's easy to get lost as the exits are not well sign posted. The trees and thick vines growing throughout the emple a amazing!

Best ruin in Angkor. This was the most interesting of all of the ruins. It's the famous one with the trees growing out of the remaining buildings. If you come to Siem Reap, this is THE ruin you should not miss.

Ta Phrom and Beng Melea. Wow, every temple that I visited was different and beautiful in their own way. I went later in the afternoon and managed to avoid most of the crowds at Ta Phrom. It was great to be able to walk around so much of a site where in a lot of other countries you would only be able to view from afar, here you could walk through the temple and really get lost in the forest. By comparison Ta Phrom is in better condition and easier to get to than Beng Melea but if you have the time to make the trip (1.5 hours by car) it is also worth going to see. Even more over-grown and you literally climb over the tumbled down walls and through the ruins. In some areas it is hard to distinguish a path but you can feel like Indiana Jones or Lara Croft and explore almost every inch (at your own risk) and find your own way around. A boardwalk and some questionable stairs have been set up to assist you in your adventure and of course there is the obligatory guy selling souvenirs but all in all you feel very alone when browsing this site. Beng Melea is not part of the Angkor Park so it does cost an additional US$5. There are some great restaurants across from the entrance and water available to buy which is a must!

Gigantic Root of Trees overwhelmed the Temple. Beautiful gigantic Root of Trees overwhelmed the Temple over hundreds of years , will take you to a different world . Create mystery and story . Angeline Jolly movies was inspired by the uniqueness and the beauty of this temple.

Enchanting temple with an ancient feel. Having heard about the hordes of tourists to Ta Phrom daily, we planned our trip out to have the place basically to ourselves. The best time to visit Ta Phrom is between 6.30am-8.30am early in the morning with barely any crowd. We started out journey from the hotel at 6am and arrived at Ta Phrom at 6.30am. At that time there was only about 10 people around and we got to explore the temple in peace in the beautiful morning sun reflected in the gigantic trees. No queues whatsoever and we took the most beautiful pictures with the serene surroundings! Recommended to visit early in the morning to fully enjoy the splendors of the temple. The crowd starts coming in around 8am.

A Must See! Trees hundreds of years old!. This is one of the pretties temples of all. Reason being, the trees that have grown onto the temples form a beautiful site for excellent photos. It's almost unbelievable how huge these roots are and how it has held some parts of the temple together. This is where many scenes for the move Tomb Raider was filmed as well. Heaps of shaded areas to rest as well.

Overcrowded with tour groups. We visited Ta Prohm at around 11am and there were at least 4-5 tour groups there (or at least it felt that way)! The trees were huge and magnificent but the atmosphere was ruined because it was really noisy and the place was overcrowded.When I thought we could finally escape from the hoardes of tourists, we were blocked from exiting the temple by at least 4-5 locals trying to sell a group of european tourists postcards/books/musical instruments! Would recommend visiting this place during lunchtime to avoid the crowd.

Nature vs Man - winner is nature - see it while you can. There is no doubt that this is a dramatic temple to view. There is clearly a conflict between preservation and the drama of nature reclaiming its land. The current state of Ta Prohm gives an insight into the clearance and subsequent renovation that has been done in Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, those sites have been restored and stabilised to a point where over the years to come we should see an improvement in their condition; at Ta Promh the small annual take over by the jungle is managed / reversed but the major strangulation by the trees and particularly their root systems is allowed to continue. There is no half measure in this situation, either remove the trees and try to restore the temple or allow the trees to, in the end, erase the temple. What is not clear today is what the authorities are trying to do, obviously they are using this as a tourist attraction to show the tree damage but at the same time there are small areas of the site that, judging by the quantity of scaffolding being deployed, are equally clearly having the structure fully restored. Contrary to some reports there was insufficient scaffolding around to limit photography (March 2013), there were also some places where it was evident that a bit of scaffolding might be a good thing in keeping structures intact!I am sure the Health & Safety police will be attacking this site in the near future - get there before they do and enjoy it as much as I did.

A find, a real find.... This is a place to see as it is unlikely that anything of this stature and importance, where trees live in a symbiotic relationship with nature, will ever be found. Thank God no enterprising archeologist ever decided to cut the trees, as Ta Prohm Temple is possibly the most intesting temple in Siam Reap. Go early, take your time, and enjoy this wonder...
trees from temples. this is an amazing temple with huge trees growing all around it. we were told that this was where "tomb raider" was filmed. it is certainly worth seeing.
Tomb Raider Temple is the Best!. The atmosphere created by the trees growing over the walls makes this so special! We really enjoyed this temple even more than Angkor Wat.
Tomb Raider temple. Lots of interesting structures here- trees have grown through and around these buildings. Lots of tourists here; be patient and you can get photos without others in the background

Not blown away. I visited this temple at 06.00AM as suggested by other reviewers to avoid he crowds as most people are at Angkor wat for sunrise.Yes there are a lot of trees growing through the ruins but what spoiled it for me was the amount of building work,scaffolding and wooden boardwalks throughout the temple.I also visited Preah khan and thought it was much better,Ithink Ta prohm gets more attention due to the tomb raider link.

My favorite. What i liked most about Ta Prohm is the fact that it has this feel of being a forgotten, lost temple. It's not *exactly* forgotten, in fact it's one of the main tourist attractions in Siem Reap, but still, with the its huge trees with roots wrapping around and growing over the ruins, it looked as if nature was slowly devouring the temple. Very peaceful, very quiet vibe. Made me very thoughtful. I liked it best of all the temples I visited. :)
Gorgeous. A definite must see for temples. It was awesome to get to explore around and the trees growing out of the rocks are beautiful

picture perfect. the place was so picturesque. from the towering trees with huge roots to the ruins of various structures. the different figures in the structures were still visible even after thousands of years. the tour in this site also entails long walk :)
Must go. Tomb raider was filmed here for the entrance, and when you see it you know why.. A place where you can see the power of nature, and be overwhelmed at how it grows.
The "Tomb raider" temple. Even without the hordes of visitors, this would not my favorite temple in Ankor. With them of course...

My favorite in Angkor National Park. Ta Prohm (or, as it is sometimes know, Tomb Raider Temple after the Angelina Jolie movie filmed there) is like nothing else I have ever seen. The incredibly beautiful temple has grown into the surrounding jungle so it appears to be part of the natural landscape. Like its neighbors in Angkor National Park, Bayon and Angkor Wat, the intricate carvings are strikingly well preserved given that these buildings languished in the heat for many decades. As a note, I visited with a private guide, which I would recommend if you want to learn about the temple's history as well the meaning of the carvings and statuary.

It does not get hotter than Siem Reap. But when it comes to heat, Ta Prohm was the hottest place i've ever been in my life. The air was still and the bodies were quietly moving through the temple and it was so beautiful and so hot that nobody really talked. I think our family photo was taken right before we all melted onto the floor. The guides always have water and cold towels which truly saved us all from spontaneously combusting.

Truly Amazing!. I love this place showing several trees that have overtaken the temple. Have a tour guide lead the way for you to bring you to the best spots to take your pictures then do the exploring later.
Very interesting. Fantastic and very interesting and amazing how things were built those many years ago and how they have stood up with time.

Don't Miss. Many people go to Sien Reap to see Angkor Wat which is of course a must, but several of the other temples are also a must including Ta Prohm. We arranged our for a private driver and tour guide prior to arriving in Siem Reap and they set us up with a three day temple pass and recommended a number of temples to visit including this one. We were very pleased with all the choices they made for us and clearly their local knowledge was valuable in finding the most diversified and best temples.

My Fave Temple. This is my favorite because aside from this is where Tomb Raider was shooted, I love watching those trees on top of the temple. I hope the place will be perfectly renovated and will still remain as mystical as it is.

the temple where Tomb Rider was shoot. It is the third temple I visited after Angkor and Bayon. I like the scenery in the temple. It is full of gigantic tress aged thousand years. You can pose as much as you like and don't forget to mimic some pose of Lara Croft as seen in the movie Tomb Rider
Best temple in Siem Reap. Absolutely breathtaking views of gigantic trees grown over temple ruins. This was by far my most enjoyable temple visit in Siem Reap (even more than Angkor Wat and Bayon).
everybody wants the Lara Croft pose. Huge roots just want to envelope the temples and it was mesmerizing. However, the temple just couldnt hold a large crowd.

Simply amazing.... Famous as the jungle temple in "Tomb Raider"; Ta Prohm has a mystical air of antiquity with the huge trees growing from the ruins. With all the renovations that appear to be ongoing removing the massive trees would be a mistake...it is what makes Ta Prohm unique. For photographs, try to go early or late to take advantage of the light and to avoid the crowds.
Ancient Tree. They were having restoration works when I visited.Overall was fantastic despite the crowd, it's hard to get one on one pictures with the ancient trees and their roots.
Fabulous!. Though renovations are in progress, which takes away from photo opportunities, one should not miss this temple and see the power of nature.
Under rebuild. It's under rebuild and they just keep the famous scene for photographing. It's well below expectation.

The tree is the best part. We did Ta Prohm as part of our trip around Angkor Wat and it wasn't as interesting as some of the other temples but the tree growing out through the building was impressive. there was a lot of construction/rennovation taking place and it killed the atmosphere.
Fantastic. Simply the best temple of them all. Go early in the morning and its empty, you really do feel like a tomb raider. I can't rate this one highly enough

My favourite of the Ankor temples. This place is a must. Tree roots have taken over and you are allowed to wander at will between the ruins and in the areas that have been restored. Of the three temples this was my number one. Bayon came second and Ankor Wat third - but a wonderful third. Get the day pass for $20 and do Ankor Wat for sunrise, return to your hotel for a shower and breakfast and return in the afternoon to do the others.

Tree-mendous!. One of the other most famous temples in Siem Reap, this inner-circuit temple is truly worth a visit. The way the tree has overtaken the ruins is fascinating to see - as are the ruins themselves.

My favorite temple. I think that anyone who visits Siem Reap should go to visit Taprohm temple. The archtechture and environment of these ancient ruins are spectacular. You will definitely enjoy your experience here. It feels as if you are in a long lost city. Very unique experience. Our tuk tuk driver and guide Sam explained to us the great history of this temple and of the people who once lived here. Dont miss this site!

Tomb raider temple. Really interesting, great history, tress that grow and support the temple very strange, but much more run down than Angkor wat. So expect some climbing/navigating steps etc. as with all the temples and tourist hot spots, locals hassling to get you to buy souvenirs is quite intimidating and seems harsh saying no.

Best Ruin to go & see. I think this was the best ruin to see - the trees growing out really make it & so parts are falling down & adding an air of mystery & there are passages all over. You can get lost but easily come out again

Magical Ta Prohm. The trees' sheer height and their enormous tangly roots forcing their way gracefully into the different parts of this interesting temple is quite surreal. Despite the heat and humidity, I could well imagine different scenarios occurring in this mysterious and magical looking structure. The experience--magical!

Must see for all Tomb Raider Fans!. Aming place to visit with all the intertwining trees with all the temple buildings. This is the site of alot of the temple shots from the Tomb raider series of movies... with Angelina Jolie. It si kind of sad to know that this area will not last for much longer due to the damage being done by the trees but it is a must see when here in Angkor Wat. And BRing your Movie camera! Lots of crowds in the afternoons so woudl suggest you try for a morning visit.
The best. the whole Angkor complex is to die for , but this temple with all the trees inside the temple is something else . try to visit late in the afternoon when the heat is more tolerable .
wow. All the trees tangled around the temple really give it some atmosphere. Go early or late to get the best light for pictures, and its less crowded!

Add this amazing place to your must-visit list!. beautiful and amazing place which you should visit when you are coming to Cambodia! The place is simply awesome! :) wonder human + mother nature creation

The best temple. If you only saw one temple, this should be it. A myriad of interesting shapes covered in tree roots and jungle. Famous from Tomb Raider too, make sure to ask your guide if he "met" Lara Croft. They all did !

Photo Opportunities.. Beware the guy who says, "You can get a great photo from this angle." He will then take you on a whirlwind tour of Ta Prohm and then ask for $20... Take your time and get as much out of it as you can and don't get caught up by 'friendly locals' who are not guides...

Unique. Certainly up there amongst the "must see" temples of the area. The trees growing through the stonework are quite incredible. Our guide (Mr Sim) took us in by a totally deserted side entrance and, for the first few minutes, we had the place almost to ourselves. Our guide didn't hesitate in telling several groups of visitors (adults old enough to know better) to get off the walls they were climbing all over - as they tried to compose "interesting" photographs of each other. I've never been able to understand the "look at me standing in front of......" mentality. Still, pity the poor folks back home who'll have to endure viewing their holiday snaps in due course......

Wow!. We sat quietly in a corner while our kids drew the temple... An amazing experience if you can just sit down and think, rather than rush through temple after temple... If only have time for one, then chose Ta Prohm

I was Lara Croft for a Day!. The first temple I visited in a series of temple visits lined up for the day. Definitely, one of my favorites among the temples at Angkor Wat complex and probably, the best 'tree-in-temple' photo opportunities. I really felt I was Lara Croft, climbing and hopping from one temple to another, in this very huge and sprawling complex. offering a jungle atmosphere with its massive fig and silk-cotton trees growing from the towers and corridors.One word to describe the experience: Awesome!!!
nice big trees. nice place need to go by tuk tuk and have lots of big big big treess... not sure which one is the tomb rider tree.. still under renovation so beware of your heads ppl...

Ta Prohm. Ta Prohm was one of the temples I wanted to see the most.We came there were early in the morning, to escape the big crowds.The temple area is really beautiful! The old trees covering the huge stone bricks is simply amazing and always worth a picture!The problem at the moment is, that there are serious reparations going on.....of course they must be done and are important, but the workers take over almost the entire place and it disturbs the few a lot. As well they are very noisy.Let's hope that in a few month or years, when everything is repaired or reconstructed this place will get its silent hidden beauty back.

A beautiful sanctuary. I loved this temple as it was different to the others I had seen. The trees weaves in around the stone was amazing. They are doing a lot of work to it which can be inconvenient but necessary.

Superb Experience. Really amazing place. Amazing to see such a place and understand how much effort has gone into restoring it just to where it is now, nevermind where it needs to be. So much to do!The guide we had took us a less busy route and this really made the experience - such a beautiful place with such a history and the photos of the restoration add a real feel to it!Take a look and make sure you take some time!
One of the Best. One of the best temples I visited, has many opportunities for picture taking with lots of nooks and crannies to fulfill your DSLR desires and creativity.
Great photo opps. This is one of the three temples to visit. Very interesting to see the place of nature over time.This is great place for photos if it is not too crowded.

Wow! This place blew me away.. I was told by a friend this was the place not to miss and they were right. This temple is held together by trees that act like sticky tape. It is just incredible and one of the best places I have ever been.

Amazing magical place on earth. Amazing... The architecture is mindblowing, based on astronomical alignments and sacred geometry, very magical place. No doubt about it one of the wanders of the world. Its very intresting to note that Angkor wat itself is one of the biggest religious monuments in the world. There are many other amazing temples that you have to visit if your here, some are prymids very simuler to the prymids in south america. I was told by a very intresting Wize man that the pine cone towers represent the pineal gland ( crown chakra) and that the heads with four faces represent enlightened consciousness seeing into the spiritual dimensions. And these designs bring down divine energy into the meditation chambers directly beneath them. Even if you are not a believer still very intresting stuff. Its also intresting to note that most of these temples were Hindu, but have now been claimed as Buddhist temples. Would have been so amazing while they were in use, the architectures muat have been genius. Really amazing.

Work in progress. Beautiful nature meets civilisation as you walk in...then you're hit by the sight of cranes and all sorts of building site equipment! Ta Phrom is in the process of more restoration work and unfortunately we visited in the middle of it. Can't be helped, the work needs done and you still see plenty of nature taking over, however the tree that appears to be on lots of the guide books is right in the spot where lots of the work is taking place. Don't be disheartened, there are lots of other areas that you can visit within Ta Phrom of a similar ilk.

My favourite. We only had time to do this, Angkhor and Bayon and while they were all fascinating, I just love the way nature has taken over here at Ta Prohm. I strongly recommend a good guide to give it meaning, otherwise it could end up being a hot slog around a lot of temples.
Amazing view. Must go attraction in Angkor wat. Very special with nature ( roots of trees ) merging with architecture. Very impressive!!
Really Neat. Lots of cool pictures to be had here. Be aware that most of the really neat scenery will have barriers in the pictures (wooden posts with ropes to keep people away from certain areas).

Popular and beautiful with trees overgrown. A lot of tourists come here as it is part of one of the smaller tours that tour companies offer and it's close to Angkor Wat. We were here around 9:30 and you can follow the people in a steady pace, not much space inside to just stand around. When we were done a bus with Chinese arrived. Overall I would rate Preah Khan higher and it's a similar wide set up, with a long hall way to walk through. It's nicer to see from the outside anyway as there are some cool trees overgrowing, however the tree in the middle at the end of the inside of the court gets so much attention that it's impossible to take photos without anybody else in it. I imagine it might be nicer first thing at 6 am or something. We didn't take a guide as our guide book explained the different stages of building these temples, the why and the what and the different stories that are depicted in the different temples, so that was enough for us. I could see those poor chinese standing in the heat of 35 C degrees in long trousers, shoes with socks listening to their animated tour guide...

Release the Indiana Jones & Lara Croft Within. This temple is among my favorites, if not the favorite one. I did it early in the morning, right after the sunrise at Angkor Wat, and there was almost no tourist around. This was just perfect to just take the best pictures I wanted. What makes Ta Prohm so successful is definitely to see these big jungle trees taking over the stone and literally growing on top of the temple's walls. Some trees and roots are impressively huge. Some sections of the temple have mostly collapsed, the reason being, the Buddhist temples were built with weaker foundations than the Hindu ones. They also had less materials available, most of the stones around were already used for the Angkor Wat temple. Some of these sections are being refurbished, but it won't take anything from the whole experience. No wonder a few scenes from the 2001 movie Tomb Raider with Angelina Jolie was recorded in this very temple. It offers a truly unique atmosphere, and some pictures will definitely make you look like an adventurous movie hero!
My favorite.. This Temple is from far my favorite, Those old tree just make me feel like the deep forest. All temple are beautiful but this one have a special thing.

Wow!. Ta Prohm is very beautiful and going in the late afternoon or early morning is best as you will be able to get some decent photos without the throngs of tourists there. Its certainly a must see on the temple circut.
Amazing. The temple itself is extraordinary with its beautiful carvings. But to see it being taken over by the jungle is equally extraordinary.

Ta Prohm temple complex. The temples in this complex have been untouched and the jungle has grown over the ruins. It is beautiful but eerie to walk amidst the ruins, you feel so far removed from everything.
Top 3 Temples. This is similar to Preah Khan with the trees engulfing the temple itself. This was also used in a scene in the Tomb Raider movie.

lovely ruins and huge trees. WOW...i said that when i saw the huge trees around the area and on the ruins. Well, i love trees in all its form (With leaves, without leaves, small and big:-)) Personally, i think the trees made the ruins more attractive. I had lots of pictures with trees more than the ruins. Its really something...but again, there are stories to tell in all these ruins...so read before u visit the place so u can appreciate it better. But im telling you now, its never a waste of your time and effort...With all these temple visits, we connect; not just to nature but to people, we talk to them. Also to the local children. We even brought food for the children. We have anticipated this. We read about children asking for 'tips' in USD for simply following tourists. So,we thought of giving them something else as a gift...My colleague was doing an ART installation during this trip so at times we meet curious children...we spend time teaching them some paper art works...simple ones just to 'quench their thirst'. We were actually very happy to see them grasping ideas very fast...As teachers, we were touched and hope they get good education they deserve. We feel that doing these is better than giving them money. Just in case, u feel like doing the same thing, be ready with ur materials for art work. Believe me it feels REALLY good...
Tomb Raider Temple. A must visit even if only to see where Tomb Raider was filmed.The power of nature in destroying the temple with tree roots is amazing

"Tomb raider temple". This temple was definitely one of the busier ones but was definitely well worth a visit. The trees' sheer size is pretty amazing let alone the beautiful construction of the temple. This was one of my favourites of the temples in Agkor Wat.
Wonderful Experience. Another amazing temple where they filmed parts of Tomb Rader, but the architecture and tree roots growing over and throuhg the ruins are just unreal.
Forest versus Temple. Ta Prohm is famous for the large hollow trees and huge roots. Fascinating to see how the trees have taken over parts of the temple.

12th century monastery and university overgrown by trees. Ta Prohm was left largely as it was rediscovered in the early 21st century. Archaeological Survey of India is currently restoring more of the temple in the back of the complex one brick at a time, a very costly endeavour.This is the temple where you can see the huge silk-cotton trees and their roots slowly devouring this 12th century monastery and university, offering great photo opportunities and leaving you in awe of nature's power. Must see visit, but be mindful that the trees are quite brittle, so no sitting or touching.

Of trees and temple. Famous because of movie scenes, unique because of the large trees and roots. Surely, it was a temple in a jungle, by rocks and roots. Unlike the other temples before, there were rumbles and inaccessible paths. It looked most original and less reworked (restoration was going on). We had to queue to take photo at the popular landmarks but note around you that there are many other equally interesting landmarks that are less touristy- we even walked to parts with only us being there in the same temple.Free admission as long as you have the entrance to Angkor pass. Quite a walk in from where the 'tuk ruk' dropped us.For photos, visit blog.

Nature takes on Temple. How did they find this temple in the jungle? Great find. Unique formations of trees entwined with the temple. Great photo ops but be patient. No washrooms that I remember. There are usually food stalls along the roads.

My favorite site. The tree roots, the patina and creative architecture make this my favorite place in the complex. Pace yourself and take your time to really look and enjoy. Do not rush...relish this place and this experience.

Wow!. A beautiful site which we visited at 5 a.m. in the morning to miss the crowds and heat.
The roots of the trees which wrap around the buildings are amazing.

Best "Indiana Jones" experience. One of the best temple to see in Angkor, especially if you are an Indiana Jones fan, I liked to listen the sounds from the jungle...
Coming around noon is not a bad option because it seems to be less crowded at that time.
Just Another Temple. After a few temples in Angkor Wat, you start to get temple fatigue. It's true for me anyway. I like temples but there are just so many.

Magic place - and too crowded. I was so excited about this temple in advance. And it definitely was a great temple - worth the visit. Unfortunately it is one of the most popular ones (because of this movie with Angelina Jolie...), so it is veeeery crowded. I went there with a group and a local guide - and that was not the greatest way to visit this temple, because we I felt that we were rushed throuh the temple - together with all the other groups.A tip if you travel by your own: be there very early or very late to avoid too many other tourists.

The real Lara croft temple. Best time to visit is after rainy season. Water will be in the ponds and the rocks will be covered with green Algiers. However, the stone formation is in the tight grip of the big trees. An amazing combination between wood and rocks.
Amazing!. You too can feel like Lara Croft - Tomb Raider exploring this fabulous temple. The trees growing in this structure have to be seen in person to be fully appreciated.

Extensive, shaded, amazing - crowded!. This one has too many crowds but should not be missed. It's a pretty extensive temple, I enjoyed wandering through but maybe research a time to go when there are fewer tour groups.
Fig trees. Loved the natural feel to this place and the trees holding the stones together, we went very early morning and it was cool and more quiet
loved it. just like the photos show, an amazing temple covered with tree roots..not to be missed. If you only have time to visit a couple of temples, make sure you do this one.
Tomb Raider Temple. Watch the movie with the children first and they'll love going around Ta Prohm pointing out all the places that they think that the action happened. Very crowded though.

Temple of mystery. Known by some as the "Tomb Raider Temple," this is one of the great world's wonders! Many of the ruins have been left untouched, and this temple has been overtaken by many giant trees, with roots spiraling around the ancient stone structure. This temple was featured in the first "Tomb Raider" film, and it also has a carving of what some believe to be a stegosaurus. I think they feature this one on the Ancient Aliens TV show too.
Stunning. Visit Ta Prohm right after the sunrises to be there by yourself and feel spiritual/magical inspiration. The sounds and sights are truly unparalleled.

Excellent place in morning. It is cold fresh air within sunrise, we are visit Ta Prohm temple during early morning with my kid. Excellent the bird song and sun light run through the tree made dance shadow. great experience for my son and I with this place.
great. the sesation of knowing that people were actually living there hundreds of years ago. Being in the tomb raider movie scene.

Jungle temple. I loved the jungle feel of this temple. Left partially unrestored, massive fig and silk-cotton trees grow from the towers and corridors giving some of the best ‘tree-in-temple’ photo shots at Angkor.

one of my favourite Angkor temples. This temple has been left more or less as it was found, with trees growing on top or through portions of it. The trees and the sense of ruin impart a lot of character to the temple.

One of the must- see temples. If you've seen Tomb Raider, you might be exhilarated to see the famous roots in a temple or the temples in a root live! It was under massive construction during our visit so much so that it was a a challenge to get a shot without obvious construction fences. Nevertheless, it was picturesque and intriguing how concrete and nature meshed as one. Sometimes, we just really want to see the things we see on tv in person to give us that certain feeling of surreality and amazement.
wow of that trees !. at moment u just can tell who is first the tree or the temple . the place gives a feeling of that u r back on time ! thats awesome

THE temple to visit!. If I had to rank my favourite temples, Ta Prohm would be tied for first with Bayon (with Angkor Wat a close third).The tumbled stones lay where they fell in many places, with powerful, gargantuan trees spilling over the crumbling walls. The trees are really what make this place so magical, as this is the only temple (of many temples in the Angkor temple complex) where nature has rivaled human settlement. This temple can also be recognized from its cameo in the movie "Tomb Raider", and lives up to what is seen in the movie. This temple is absolutely beautiful AND (bonus!), the trees provide refuge from the merciless sun. Trust me, this is a HUGE perk in a place where the temperature is frequently in the 39-40 degrees Celsius and the sun adds its 2 cents.Enjoy!(This temple is on the short circuit, fyi)

Nature vs Man - Amazing. Just outstanding and worth going back for 2nd visit as the temple has so many corridors, passages, courtyards, we missed so much on our first visit that we went back. Loved the fact that the jungle is trying to take over. Renovations are taking place which is fascinating that pieces of stone work are being pieced together to reunite after years of lying on the ground in piles of rubble. Lots of shade from the enormous trees. Great photo opportunities for all. We did feel a bit like Lara Croft walking about. Just loved it and how amazing that other countries and organisations are taking the time and expense to renovate these Temples for future generations.

One of our favourites. Ta Prohm and Ta Nei were two of our favourites. Ta Prohm being more restored than Ta Nei but both with the amazing trees and tree roots growing within and through the temple. Just such incredible architecture and detail in the temples. Go early to beat the crowds.

Awesome power of nature. Saw this first, Angkor Thom next and Angkor Wat last. Nice progression. At Ta Prohm it was very interesting to see how effective Mother is in reclaiming her world. Gave us an understanding of the enormous challenges to restoring these architectural masterpieces.

Amazing - just the best. This was without a doubt the highlight of our trip. We went at daybreak, no crowds, very atmospheric, just fantastic. Go early as you can to enjoy this unbelievable temple complex
Awesome. Loved all the temples ! Would like to get more pictures, but hard with so many tourists around :( Maybe next time I head back to Siem Reap......

Impressive temple. This temple is just breathtaking specially because you can not imagine how nature fits so perfect with the architecture. Looking at those huge 800-year-old trees growing on the temples is just amazing. This temple was my favorite from all

Exceeds expectations, atmospheric. After a long day of same-same temples, Ta Prohm felt like another world. Although the construction can be a bit distracting, there is enough going on to allow for ample photo-ops despite the popularity of the site. Nice canopy of trees allows for much-appreciated shade in the middle of the day
Surreal. These are ruins, not as much a temple. But the foliage wrpped around man made structures are a lasting image that stays with you for a long time!

It is going to be great when renovation is finished. It looses a bit of charm with the ongoing renovation and metal ramps going around, but still some beautiful courtyards and passages with just a few tourists passing by

Beautiful Place!. Ta Prohm was built in the mid 12th early 13th Centuries and is east of Angkor Thom. Its a stunning place with massive fig and silk cotton trees growing from the towers and corridors and spreading their gigantic roots over, under and in between the stone pillars of the complex. This temple was one of King Jayavarmans first major temple projects and was dedicated to his mother. Ta Phrom was originally a Buddhist monastery and there was a sandscript inscription on stone (this is now in the Conservation d' Angkor). This stone tells about the size and function of Ta Prohm. Ta Prohm was very wealthy in its time having control of over 3140 villages, 79,365 staff to maintain the complex, including 18 High Priests, 2,740 officials, 2,202 assistants and 615 dancers.Property that belonged to the temple was a set of golden dishes weighing over 500 kilograms, 35 diamonds, 40,620 pearls, 4,540 precious stones, 512 silk beds and huge stores of jewels and gold.  Some of the temple is impassable and some areas are accessible only by small narrow passageways. There are many lovely spots to just sit outside and just wonder at this amazing place. An absolute must to visit Ta Prohm and explore for a couple of hours.I could go on and on about our 8 hours of touring around a few of the main temples, multiply everything I have said by 100. It was a brilliant, amazing, fascinating day. I don't think I could pick a favorite place, they were all so different. I'm just so glad I have been there to see all of this, as surely one day only certain areas will be open to the public to protect this wonderful place.

One of the best temples. My family, including a 10- and 12-year old absolutely loved visiting the temples in Siem Reap, and this was one of our favourites. A beautiful place, having evolved over time to include the surrounding jungle. We will definitely visit again.

Terrific. Amazing place. this is where Angelina Jolie's 'Lara Croft-Tomb Raider' was shot.Ensure you spend at least 1.5 to 2 hours here to do justice to the place, the arcitecture, the carvings on the wall and most importantkly get a good English speaking guide who can explain everything and the History to you to make the trip memorable, that is, provided you like history.

Go early!. Do it in the morning to avoid hordes of tourists. We went there around 7am and finished by the time when crowds arrived. Leave yourself 1-1,5 hours to visit the grounds.Although the roots attracting the most tourists and this is no accident please recognise what more this temple can offer....

Highlight of tour. This was the last of 6 temples visited on the Outlying Adventure Tour with Beyond Unique Escapes - and the best. Known as the Lara Croft temple made famous by the Tomb Raider film. Very atmospheric you can see where the trees had taken over the site with their roots burying into the temple and its walls crushing many of them. It was built in the Bayon style in the late 12th and early 13th centuries by the Khmer King Jayavarman VII as a Buddhist monastery and university. It has been left in much the same way in which it was found and some parts are very collapsed.
