It makes you appreciate how other temples have been restored but still you find it a privilage to see the site in its present condition. Great visit a must see.
Go Early. The best rout for this Wat is 5:am Angkor Wat for sunrise. Atfter sunrise head to Ta Prohm. It will be packed later.
A temple lost to nature. Arguably the most intriguing temple in the Angkor Wat archaeological area, Ta Prohm features ancient temple walls crushed and intertwined by the growth of massive trees.
Nature entwined with architecture. Can see why Tomb Raider II was filmed here - very cool temple that allows nature to be a part of the structure. A must do on any visit to Angkor park.

tomb raider location (as everyone will tell you). this is a great sight in its own right despite the cinematic association. Its something to see the roots overspilling the walls of the temple and looking as though they are literally walking through it. It also gives a sense of the sheer scale of the archaeological challenge of restoring these temples. just be prepared to be inundated with young children begging before you go in: more so than the other temples for some reason

The most interesting temple. Also known as Angelina Jolie Temple. It was an amazing temple. Loved it. I totally recommend others to visit. A bit disappointed as big constructions were going on. We thought the tree butt crack is funny. Go look for yourself.

favourite. this is a must,even if you feel templed out please make time for this, it is amazing. look for the'bottom' the hidden face and try to buy something off the begging children keen to seel their wares for pennies, it is their only source of income and you will be amazed by their salesmanship and their extensives language, french, english, german at least even at the age of 6
Temple overgrown with roots!. Unbelievable, in the jungle! What an amazing Temple, highly recommended, so wonderful to experience this!

You do not feel the nature taking the temples. The temple is being reconstructed. However, the charm of it was the nature around it. There are three famous trees were all tourist take a picture under. There is noise, working men, noisy and unpolite tourists and hawkers selling items. To forget.

Quite amazing. We came here before lunch with our guide. The 'Spung' tree roots growing down over the ruins are incredible. Our guide took us on a route different to the bus load of tourists that were there so we could get our photos without a lot of people in them. (Big advantage having a guide). We only had to wait a very short time for our photos in the two very popular spots. He also knew where to find the stone face peering out through a hole in a tree root. Like most temples early morning would be good time here but you can't visit every temple at that time.
my favorite place in Siem Reap. this was an amazing place, and my favourite spot on a day of temple viewingguide was helpful, and fun to watch Tombraider DVD afterwards too...

Ta Prohm. Going early in the morning, just after dawn, was an excellent time to see this, as next to no one else was around, so I was free to wander at my will and take many unobstructed photos, the whole area is fascinating, with the ancient trees growing out of an ancient temple. One of my top sites on my trip!

My favorite Cambodian temple - just amazing. So, when I first thought of Ta Prohm - I thought - OK, this is where they filmed the Lara Croft movie. When I see it up close and personal -- it is so much more amazing than that. We arrived early in the morning - around 7am - so the sunlight was just starting to come through the fig tree branches. The carvings, the ruins, the towers, makes you realize how truly beautiful this temple must have been when first built. Now, with the fig tree roots curling around doorways and pushing huge stone slabs out of the walls, it's a testiment to mother nature's enduring tenacity to reclaim her territory. It was beautiful, somewhat eerie and so peaceful. With the grays and beige stones - the only color that splashed across the scene was when a monk, with his dark skin and orange robes would walk through a door way, as they did hundreds of years earlier. I loved this area and hope many others come to enjoy it as well.
Treess. Its all about treessssss... Old Tree, Old Temple... Nice place... Attached with a tourist guide will be better

stunning place. after 2 days of visiting divergent temples, this one is especially impressing not be size but for its trees, last hour before sunset worked well for us as also most visitors depart for the traditional sunset spots
Awesome. The trip was fascinating as the carvings of each head had different expressions, it was a large temple and had stood the degregation of time.

Nature conquers all - Magnificent. If one were to be reminded about the awesome power of nature, Ta Prohm is the place to experience. A magnificent structure was totally overpowered by the myriad of trees which didn't care two hoots about man's creation. Lost for hundreds of years, Ta Prohm is a fantastic ruin. It makes one wonder how the trees made a home among and on stones - it is sight to be seen to be believed. Trees growing out of every nook and cranny, anywhere they could find space and if they couldn't find space, they created it.The temples are a mandatory visit when you are in Siem Reap. Photograps of Ta Prohm can tell only half the story. A world Heritage site, Ta Prohm was faithfully shown in the movie Lara Croft - Tomb Raider. See it.

The jungle took over. It's no surprise that Tomb Raider was filmed here, it looks like Disney created everything to use as a set, it is not only interesting but, beautiful. In some ways, this was more interesting than Angkor Wat.

Nature's artistic might!. While the rest of Siem Reap is about the artistic might of the people of the day, Ta Prohm is a reminder of the fact that nature is mightier than man! Gigantic silk-cotton trees whose roots embrace the structures in a vice like grip that has caused the structure to crumble at many places. This place was a forgotten complex as it was totally engulfed by the jungle. It was left that way to give everyone a glimpse of what Angkor and all the temples were like, when they were discovered by the French.The temple was started by Jayavarman and enhanced by Indravarman in the 12th century. This temple was then made famous by the Tomb raider scenes.

Impressive ruins. Reconstruction deliberately left some of the impressive tree roots twisting through the ruins. Photos cannot do it justice. Somewhat long waits to get in some of the best photo shots.

Where the roots of trees is an expression of artistry and age.. Ta Prohm is an exquisite art form and landscape where roots of trees sticking in stones is a wonderful work of nature in art form. I have my own picture here. Cambodia is not Cambodia without this natural wonder.
Tomb Raider. We watched Tomb Raider the night before visiting Ta Prohm which made the trip all the more interesting.

Must See. An amazing experience. Easy to see why Ta Prohm was the site of Tomb Raider.... Recommend organising a guide and tuk tuk to really relax enjoy the temples...our hotel organised this for us, and was inexpensive and meant we didn't miss anything.

highlight of our holiday. This is the 'ruin' you see in the pictures. Spectacular! The fig, banyan and kapok trees spread their gigantic roots over, under and between the stones. Untouched except to stave off further deterioration. Worth the flight across the Pacific!
Truly amazing. As these temples have been left to naure, many of them seem to be held together and/or supported by roots of trees. Great spot for photographs and once again, interesting history.

How Nature Reclaims its Own. People may leave their mark(s) on natural settings, or on materials taken from such settings, but nature eventually works to reclaim it. Thjis is the uniqueness of Ta Prohm Temple, where the botanical activity of growing roots and tree trunks gradually brings down to ruins the grandiose structures that people build. To see that this is occurring and the results, before your very eyes, is to recognize that nothing people do seems to really be permanent. Perhaps this is what should be expected in a tropical area with a wet season. Ta Prohm is a must-see temple, for this very reason.

Magical!. Ta Prohm is absolutely magical, such an amazing place. We did visit all the temples in Siem Reap including Angkor Wat - you can't miss seeing these incredible sites if you are in Cambodia - I would even suggest to Bangkok or Vietnam holiday makers to make the trip into Cambodia - its really a special place and one that will stay with you forever!

Very interesting. We visited TP on the first morning of our two day tour of the temples. We had an english speaking guide and tuk tuk both days - excellent and cheap (total £30 a day with tips)Without a guide we would have struggled - the heat and walking/climbing are a challenge to older travellers. We got great photos and memories but if we did it again we would take all 3 days and mix in other less demanding sightseeing
Beautiful. Amazing at sunrise - just amazing. Our group got there early and the result was some awesome photographs and fewer crowds. Hauntingly beautiful. A must see.
Magical setting. Best to go in the morning, to this temple and in fact any of the temples before the busloads of tourists get there. Be there by sunrise

Restoration intrudes on beauty. I cannot find words to describe how the vicious battle between nature and human civilization is so well-captured in Ta Prohm. It is amazing how the jungle has taken back what man has taken from the jungle-- but the feeling of awe and amazement is short-lived. Smack in the middle of the complex is modern civilization's intrusive attempt to restore Ta Prohm.As with all the past few reviews, a few tips--1) Club this with a trip to Banteay Kdei next door. Have your Angkor pass available for inspection.2) The ruins are smaller and... Ruined. Do talk to your hotel staff and find out the best time to go.3) If going at a later part of the day do have a torch in hand, there are some dark passageways. For someone as uncoordinated as I am, the torch helped... and since we did a good job with tip number 2 (above) there were several instances when we didn't have a crowd to follow.Parents traveling with thrill-seeking tots will love this place. If you're doing the small or grand circuit and leaving this for last, do make sure you have enough power in your camera... This place is crammed with photoopportunities.
Excellent. I think it was one of teh best temples I visited. It's smal, comparing to Angkor wat but i loved it. I think that's why they choose to do the Tomb Rider there.

The most magnificent of the temples. Seeing the trees growing through the temple structures is like looking at the postcards you see in travel brochures. This is definitely the coolest of the temples in the complex.
Amazing. Overcrowded but nothing can erase the feeling you get at this place: the respect and awe we owe to nature, the glory of past times and the bond with power of those magnificent trees.

Fascinating. This rivalled Angkor Wat as our favourite place across the huge area of the temples campus. The way the trees have weaved themselves into the ancient buildings and made themselves part of the relic is just fascinating. I found it hard to leave, it so engaged my imagination. We went in the early evening and the light, together with the absence of tour groups, added to the mystery of the place. Not to be missed.

Mystical and enchanting (referred to as the tomb raider temple). The fee for this temple is included in your purchased ANGKOR PASS. This is probably my 2nd favorite temple (my favorite is Beng Mealea). Please take 2-3 hours to explore this wonderful temple. The temple is undergoing major restorations now. There are many trees that have attached to tmeple walls and free-standing trees that make this a mystical setting. The temple is enormous and be sure to take plenty of pics. Enjoy this turly remarkable temple.

Enchanting, despite the hordes of tourists. I thought Angkor Wat was overrun with tourists until I visited Ta Prohm, which on a busy Saturday was bursting at the seams with tourist groups. If there is a good thing about tourist groups it's that they move through quickly, but you're in real trouble if you end up at any of the Lara Croft/Tomb Raider tree sites when a group rolls up and starts an endless parade of photos. My suggestion is to let them move through and then hope you have a quiet 5 minutes before the next one comes in. And, in some areas of the site you won't see any tourist groups at all, and those moments can be truly magical. For photographers I would also recommend visiting Ta Prohm immediately after sunrise, when you might have the chance to get some eerie shots with the light streaming in at an angle and with a slight mist in the air.

My favorite temple ever. Thanks to my Cambodian colleague (Sophary Pich) for giving recommendation to include Ta Prohm on the top of our visit list. We've gotten a lot interesting photo session with beautiful green scenery as background. Better to visit Ta Prohm early in the morning since there are still few visitors arrive here. A "tomb raider" corner is still becoming a point of interest as always.

Love this place. Our favorite temple during our visit. This was also where they filmed Tomb Raider. We just loved that it was still "a mess", giving it a wild and adventurous feel. We did not have a tour guide, just walked around and climbed up all the rocks and bricks and trees and enjoyed the scenery ourselves.

Djungle Temple. This is the most exciting temple in the Setting of jungle. Trees growing out from some of the walls. Amazing to see.While exploring make sure you climb on some higher parts or walls of the inner temple to catch a scenic picture without People.leave your tablet at home and take Pictures with a normal camera instead. Otherwise you will miss to experience the beauty there.

Great fun temple. Get there early to avoid the crowds. Stopped off at TA Prohm this afternoon after seeing many other temples and this one stands out purely because of the many banyan trees draped over the temple ruins. It's very Tomb Raider and this draws the hordes of Chinese / Korean tourists. It can get a bit busy in the main areas as everyone wants to take that magical picture. Try and get there early if you can to enjoy it without the thousands of other tourists.

You feel like you are in Tomb Raider. It was astonishing how the jungle takes over what humans create when it is left abandoned to nature. Ta Prohm was interesting because they left much of the area in the state that it was when it was rediscovered. The huge trees seemed to swallow the structure. Definitely worth the visit.
Amazing. A must see ! The prototype for Angkor Wat temple, very interesting skills used in the carvings. A quiet, calm site compared to some of the others.

Very nice but falling apart - Must go!. You have to walk about 10 mins to the temple from the point that the Tuk tuk drop you off. You will walk through a path with trees surrounding you. It's really close to the nature. This temple is almost falling apart as huge trees are growing through the temple. But it was a very nice sight. Restoration work is already going on, certain parts of the temple are closed off. But it is still so pretty for us to spend a good 2hours here.

Stunning. It's been many years since Lara Croft was filmed here and made it famous. This means that it's been many years where those famous trees have had time to work the place into more ruin. But you'll feel the mysticism and awe regardless.Break off from the crowd a bit and have a look about. You won't be disappointed. Take a lot of pictures and when you walk out again be firm with the kids. There are a lot of them and it can be saddening but again, say no firmly but politely and don't give them hope that you'll be back.

Worth visiting. Loved seeing the Ta Prohm. In fact returned a few days later to enjoy it again. The ancient trees have grown up, through and around the temples. It was fascinating. Movies have been made there and that is understandable.

Get down with the jungle. Feeling a little adventurous? Feeling like Lara Croft? Well, it's because this site was in Tomb Raider! This jungle temple is just that- reclaimed by the jungle. The trees just climb through the site and make you feel like you've stepped back in time. This site was just as amazing to me as Angkor Wat was. Don't miss it or you'll be disappointed.
Very Beautiful. This was my favourite of the temples as it was just so beautiful. smaller than the others but the mossy rocks were divine

Do it as early as possible to avoid the tourists. Try and get there as soon after breakfast as possible to avoid the hords of tourists. Try and get deep into the temple not just the normal walk ways. take pleanty of water it still gets hot and humid.

"Tomb Raider" temple. This was the last temple on our day at the Angkor complex and the only one that still has the tree roots wrapped around the temple features. It is also in the most disrepair - but this just adds to its splendor in my opinion. Our guide was quick to point out that this was the on-location site for the Angelina Jolie film "Lara Croft - Tomb Raider."
Lara Croft wasn't there :( But worth going anyway!. Well worth the trip. A unique and fantastic site with some incredible views. A must-see visit when in Siem Reap.

Restoration work being carried out. This is a great temple, lots of trees so some escape from the heat.There is also a lot of restoration work happening and the entire centre courtyard is roped off. I heard that they were cutting down some of the strangler figs, hope they dont go too far and spoil the whole feel of the place.Well know because of the tomb raider movie, my daughter liked that, also the buddha in the tree, would have missed that if not for a kind policeman.
jungle gem. This is an atmospheric temple with the ruins and encroaching jungle. Beautiful photo opportunities too

Awesome...Amazing. Again awesome and amazing infact I think this is my favourtie temple so much to see there and to see the trees growing around the temples, There is alot of rennovation ongoing there but still worth going. The same pass goes for all one day $20 or three day pass $40. Everyone too wants their photograph taken there due to tomb raider being filmed there

Different because of the trees. This temple is not in the best condition but what makes it special is the tree roots and foliage covering lots of buildings - quite spooky!! Well worthe a visit because it is different
Interesting. Lots of photo oppotunities. Quite a lot of climbing and steps. If not fit then you will be by end of visit. Beware of the wild monkeys, don't have anybfood in you bags.

Currently under construction. You can still seem the famous tree growing on top of the temple, but the rest of the site is currently under major construction. About a 10 minute walk to reach it from the road.

Fantastic. You must go in the late afternoon...allows you to avoid the major crowds...enjoy the warm, soft rays of the late afternoon sun...beautiful pictures...visit at a more leisurely pace...wonderful visit

One of the 4 must see temples. This is one of the temples near Angkor Wat made famous for its amazing trees growing through the temple. Also well known for its part in the movie 'Tomb raider' with Angelina Jolie. The only thing that spoils it is the hundreds of tourists! But that can't be helped except to have a guide to take you to the temples at the best times. We did 3 of the smaller temples before seeing Ta Prohm and we were virtually the only ones there. our Guide (Angkor Family Guides) also took us through the forests to enter the temples from paths no one else used so the only busy temple was this one. The are great photo opportunities here but you must have patience as there are so many people and not all of them have 'photo courtesy'! A must-see along with Angkor Wat, Bayon temple and Banterey Srey.

Our highlight of the area. Exquisite temple, you can experience the atmosphere of this place more readily than the huge Angkor Wat. The warmth of the red sandstone and the ornate carvings made this our favourite.
Fascinating ruins. Though much to be restored, the most fascinating thing for me was the tussle between tree and man made stone. Who will win? Time will tell..

Another beautiful temple. This temple was made famous by Lara Croft and tomb raider. It was my favourite of the 3 we visited due to the way the tree roots have invaded the walls of the temple and added to its beauty

Beautiful but bonkers with tours. You know how Disney or Universal have special hours for park visitors who stay in on-site properties? Well you can't do that here and it's too bad. It is wall-to-wall tourists. The site is absolutely incredible though. Walk around the perimeter, you can actually get some peace and quiet to soak it in.

Temple inside trees. Stunning. Luckily the authorities decided to keep overgrown trees as discovered. South wing has been funded & restored from a heap of stones by Indian archeologists. Tomp Raider movie gave popularity to this temple for those who dint know history..:)

Ta Prohm is not to be missed.. This lightly restores temple (mostly for safety sake it seemed to me) put me into a world of a 1,000 years ago when about one million people lived in Angkor complex and surrounding temple areas. It was as close to original as it can get considering the long years of abandonment. It was more than a sight to see; it was as much an experience inside me as outside me. Please go if you are ever at Siem Reap.

Tomb Raider. This is the temple to go to if you want to see the Tomb Raider shots. The overgrown trees are amazing.The only drawback was that we went during the peak time so there was ALOT of people constantly getting into our shots. We had to constantly wait for the groups to leave an area before we could take shots.Try to go here early in the morning or late in the afternoon to avoid the people.

Temple with huge tree roots. Really lovely temple, more sheltered then some others with some amazing trees and huge roots, if you go early morning you will miss bus loads of Chinese tourists who seem to be really loud.

WOW...This Temple. It is amazing that this temple built in the jungle and the very big tree grow on top of the temple. We feel we are back 1000 years ago. Don't miss this temple. There are a lot of temple to visit.

Must DO!. Of all the temples I liked the Ta Prohm the most.
It looks nearly the way it did before it was re-discoverd. Sadly some bridges and stuff had to be built inside the temple.
But it is really the most mysterious temple in Ankor.
I would recommend a visit in the morning, because it is very full in the afternoon.
Better than expected. We all know this is where Lara Croft was filmed, but it was much more than we expected. It's quite extensive and really shows the power of nature v man. Not to be missed.

Mind your step. If Western culture was applied to this place it would never open! The fact that is over run by nature is great and a joy to experience however so many of the walls, doors etc etc look like they are about to fall on you due to the dsiturbance of movement over the years.Its popularity is due to TOMB RAIDER and unfortunately brings in the crowds adding to the need to watch out
Not much to see. So there are trees and roots coming out of the walls and they cut some parts because some of them fell during a storm. There's a lot of people because it's a popular temple.
Wonderful historical site. It was a wonderful experience to see this amazing historical site and to just "wonder" at how on earth did they achieve such an engineering feat.
Again with the hoards of visitors!. Great temple overrun with far too many visitors, they may want to cap the number of visitors but money first attitudes run the show.
My partner's favorite temple. Due to the trees & vines growing in the remains this was my partner's favorite temple that we visited. It does give it a mysterious quality.

Mystical and surreal. This is a must must visit. Not only coz you've seen Angelina Jolie prance about around it, but it truly is out of this world. When I went, I was lucky to let the tourist hordes pass till I entered. There was pin drop silence save for the birds and the movement of the trees. It was magical. One moment was spectacular when the guide with me, pointed out a Buddha peering thru a tree. It was eerie as it was surreal. This is top of my temple lists in Angkor Wat. Don't miss it.

Ta Phrom temple at dawn. Highly recommended. We arrived early to watch the dawn over this temple. It's a very atmospheric place, and very different from Angkor Wat, as Ta Phrom is in the forest, and has been abandoned for centuries, to be reclaimed by nature. Huge trees with massive roots envelope several walls and towers. There were very few people compared to Angkor Wat, which made a huge difference to the peace and quiet, and allowed for photos of the place without hordes of tourists all wanting their friends to snap them in front of this or that. Apparently one of the Lara Croft movies was filmed partly there.

Incredible. The main Angkor Wat temple complex gets all the glory, but Ta Prohm is a unique gem that needs to be experienced in person. I read a quote that said "Ta Prohm looks like it was left to be swallowed by the jungle." It's true. You will not regret visiting Ta Prohm.

Sunrise in Ta prohm temple. We went there early in the morning. Only a few people were there and we took breathtaking photos. Our guide named Khiev Ratanak from travel Cambodia, except the history of every monument new to tell us where to stand to take photos. He was our director of photography as we named him! The place was so quiet and peaceful, quite abandoned though, since huge trees had already embrassed the limestones of the Temple . No description can give you the atmosphere! So you must go there

Ta Prohm. When visiting Cambodia and you get an excellent tour guide, like we did, he convinced that we would enjoy Ta Prohm..... yes, we did, and it is a sight to see!!! It is very interesting and will make your jaw drop!!!

Best of the lot. Definitely the jewel in the crown of Angkor Temples for me although since I first visited in 2005 it has been ruined by coach loads of tourists who overrun this otherwise peaceful spot. I am not sure about the restoration that has gone on either as I think it has spoiled its natural character. The trees growing around the walls are an awesome sight. This is one temple not to be missed but I wish it was as quiet and peaceful as it was back in 2005!

Atmospheric, you'll feel like Indiana Jones. The way this temple has been preserved in a semi original C19th state is simply incredible. Quite unlike anything I had experienced before. Get there early for the best light and the least crowds.

Amazing Trees. The trees run wild encroaching into, on top of, and within the temples were simply awesome. The large tree roots snaking into the buildings were everywhere. Good site to visit. Just did not like the many constructions/renovations going on.

Amazing--but!. Truly amazing and unique...but impossible to enjoy give the swarms of tour buses descending on ths popular temple. My advice is to go either before 7a or after 4p to appreciate and admire the melding of natural and man made beauty of this special temple.

T HE FAMOUS TREE ROOT TEMPLE. This temple is also a must to see ,especially if time is limited.The tree roots have taken over several areas,which make interesting atmospheric photos,especially with jungle surroundings.Part of Angkor ticket price.

Amazing - but really crowded!. This is a must see - to see huge trees growing out of a spendid temple is truely amazing - but the crowds are annoying. This temple is much smaller than Angkor Wat and Bayon, so, unlike those, it does feel crowded (at least in high season - I was there just after Chinese New Year, in the morning).

My favorite!. Skip Angkor Wat in the morning and go to Ta Prohm instead to avoid the swarms of tourists in the afternoon. It is typically hazy early morning that there is no great light for photos. For Ta Prohm, a large number of visitors really does ruin the experience because the space is more intimate than Ankor Wat. Angkor Wat is much better closer to sunset.
Our favorite!. This was our absolute favorite of all the temples around Angkor Wat. Get there for best photo ops and cooler temps. Don't miss this stop
beautiful. the most beautiful temple of them all. loved it. could stay there for hours. many visitors, very crowded.

Enchanting.... Ta Prohm is a must see if you are visiting Siem Reap.In my opinion, it is the most impressive of all the temples in Siem Reap - even better than Angkor Wat. Makes us think of what would be left on Earth if our species are wiped out.Nature 1 Humans 0.Amazing!

Buck the trend and visit at dawn - you won't regret it!. We spent three days at Angkor exploring the temples and even though we were there in low season the crowds (coupled with the heat) during the day can be a bit overwhelming at any of the temples. Ta Prohm was a temple we were both keen to visit, and we decided to buck the trend of only visiting Angkor Wat at dawn and head here instead. Our tuk tuk driver picked us up at 5.15am and drove us out to the temple.We got there while it was still dark and walking through the jungle towards Ta Prohm was one of the most incredible experiences of our two months in SE Asia. When we arrived at the temple it was just starting to lighten up and it was the most incredible experience to be there without another soul in sight - although we did get a bit of a fright when a load of bats came flying out of one of the doorways straight at us!We spent at least 40 minutes wandering around before we saw another group of people arrive, and by then we'd explored most of the temple.If you get chance, I would highly recommend heading to Ta Prohm at dawn - we did Angkor Wat at sunrise as well but it didn't compare for us.

Indiana Jones like experience. Of course, everyone has seen images of this temple, which seems "lost" in the jungle. In reality it is pretty much crowded and is currently being restored, so it might loose part of its mysterious looks. However it is still worth the visit, especially with kids who will love the Indiana Jones feel of it...

Must see. Alot of restoration going on when we visited. You can see the battle to preserve the site with the trees as they grow. There is a face between tree roots within the site, make sure to see this. Tomb Raider was filmed here so there may be long lines to get your photo taken at the spot were it was filmed.

Tomb raider. I so love this temple! The highlight of this temple is the sight of overgrown trees intertwined with the walls..when in the area,don't forget to take a photo of the tree where Angelina Jolie shot for tomb raider. It's not difficult to find,just follow the other tourists as they would definitely lead you there!

You feel you are in the set of a movie. Amazing temples, not to be missed if you don't have many time, this is one of the must see.amazing conservation from unesco . You feel like Lara croft or Indiana jones is going to come out from there.

Definitely worth a visit.. This temple was a particular favourite. Very cool to see as the trees are growing over the walls. Going around the ruins seemed like going through some adventure. It is a good idea to have a guided tour which will take you to a small number of the best ones

Incredible!. This temple was incredible. Seeing the trees overgrowing the walls was spectacular. The two downsides to this temple was the crowds were immense and very inconsiderate. I had so many photos ruined by people not paying attention. The second is the ferocity of the begging of the local children. I had one girl attempt to tie a bracelet onto my wrist after I had declined buying it and then began yelling at me because I didn't want it. She was about 8 years old. If you can let that roll off your back it is definitely a place that needs to be visited!

A temple with mystic tree root formations, made extra popular by Tomb Raider. The most significant detail in this temple are the trees, which grow from and on top of the walls. The place is made extra popular by the Tomb Raider movie, and the amount of tourists trying to take photos in the same spot where Angelina Jolie was shot can be quite noticeable,
Magic!. This place is unmissable. The power of nature is humbling seeing enormous trees growing through these ancient structures. This is a photographers delight, with such a site!
Part of the amazing tour. Again a wonderful place. You cannot believe these place existed, unknown for so many years and the detail in their design is unreal.

Photogenic...the best of the Temples.. For those of us who love to take photos...Ta Prohm stands out. Probably the reason a number of movies have used it in the past. Another temple not to be missed and no wear near as busy but has the same feeling of the Jungle slowly consuming it is "Banteay Kdei" temple.
Fantastic. It is amazing to see how the jungle tries to reclaim these grounds. A fantastic photo opportunity awaits!

Another great temple to see. Of course Ta Prohm is now more popularly known as the place where one of the Tomb Raider scenes was filmed; but Hollywood movies aside, seeing Ta Prohm was a humbling experience for me. Huge trees growing out of ruined temples were like allegories to me, showing that nature would always win against man/man-made structures. I really like the jungle-like feel of the temple. The downside (again), is the place is teeming with too many tourists... but hey, it's not really a bad thing, because they came for the same reason as i did: to see the amazing temples of Siem Reap.

feels mystical and exciting. a exotic sit, feels mystical and exciting,you feel liek you have you indian jones hat on, however the down fall is the large crowds do distract from the felling and prevent being able to really stop and enjoy this interesting place.

A Siem Reap Favorite. Of all the places, Bayon, Ta Prohm and Angkor Wat are probably the three most famous and well known temples. I spent three days exploring all of Angkor Wat, and this was perhaps one of the more "peaceful" busy sites. An oxymoron, but was definitely less hectic here than Bayon or Ankgor Wat.

Nature 1, Temple 0. Like with most temples in Angkor, there is a mystery, gracefulness and bitter-sweetness about the place. Such majesty fallen and taken over by nature. You stand there in the middle of the courtyard surrounded by immense trees and wonder why humans strive to build and build for greatness, then it lays fallen and forgotten, that only nature surrounds it. Its beautiful, this place, and really makes you think about your own place on this planet. DO NOT MISS THIS PLACE.

Fantastic but again too many tourists. Fantastic place to visit. Unfortunately too many tourists who go all over the places and ruins. There are also renovations going on that spoil considerably the atmosphere of the place

The Tomb Raider Temple. Ta Prohm, the temple that co-starred in the movie "Tomb Raider" along with Angelina Jolie still gives the appearance of being swallowed by the jungle, though the ruin has been stabilized to make it safe for tourists, though there appear to be motion detectors attached to many of the gateways that tourists pass through. The strangler fig and silk-cotton trees that soar over the temple and straddle the walls of the ruins complete the picture.

Awesome. Seeing the way the trees have melded into the stones was amazing. Totally inspiring place. Some renovation by Indian Ministry of Culture ongoing so watch for the crane ruining a great picture! A must visit place in Angkok Wat.
Beautiful temple. Nothing I can say that can explain the feeling of walking through this temple. The fact that it is covered with the jungle trees is awesome. I was awed.

If you are Indian, be proud!. I had no clue about this place except for the fact that its the 'Lara Croft, the tomb raider' temple. To my surprise everything there was in Hindi and i got to know that the Indian Archaeological survey built it from grounds up and it was all funded by India. The temple was all in ruins when IAS went there. The temple is famous for it giant trees and a part of it is still in ruins making you feel a part of the tomb raider movie!

Most incredible of the incredible temples. This temple reduced me to tears it was so beautiful and atmospheric, easily my favourite. I think this temple is the least contrived of any of them. It is slowly being reclaimed by the land. Unlike the other reviewers here our first vist (we went twice) was almost deserted. We walked the whole left hand side not seeing another person which made the whole experience that much more incredible. So in order to do that I would recommend go early. While everyone is watching the sunrise over Angkor Watt. When you get there move past the first big tree fast, there are a million other amazing photo opportunities. Don't get stuck in a group waiting for this first one. And enjoy it :)
Very nice but crowded. The natural beauty overtaking the temple was very fascinating. I just wished that there weren't so many Lara Croft fans who was there for sensational reasons.

In Nature's Grasp. This is pretty much the way the French found the temple. There are massive trees growing out from the walls, so large and spectacular that the Temple can not be refurbed... we were in awe of the beauty, the angles for great photography... we actually enjoyed this site more than Angkor Wat itself.

Crowded. Although many seem to prefer it, this was my least favorite of the temples visited. Very crowded, even late in the day when others seems to thin out. Because of selective removal of vegetation the place had sort of an artificial feel to it, sort of a Cambodian Disney experience.
Beautiful but way too crowded. Would have been my favorite temple if it weren't so overcrowded!! It is beautiful but hard to move around. :( A must see, regardless.

Pop over to Preah Khan instead. Ta Prohm's great, but a little overcrowded, and suffers from Lara Croft Syndrome - if you really want a semi-destroyed temple, overgrown by trees, head over to the infinitely more interesting Preah Khan. If you're taking 2-3 days over Angkor, see them both, but while Ta Prohm's got its beauty, it's not necessarily the priority it can be made out to be.

Arrive early, proofed planks detract from the temple. Since this temple is so popular, they have put down wooden walking planks to help people navigate the terrain. While I understand the purpose, it's really to bad as it takes away from the natural feel. We arrived early and by 8:30, it was already packed with people so if you want photos with people, get their early.
Tomb Raider. The location of the movie, but was still in restoration when we visited the place. Lots of construction in the area.

Overwhelmed by vegetation. The impact of the vegetation on the works of man is extraordinary. the sight of apparently sensitive restoration work is reassuring. The wounded soldiers with limbs lost to land mines is moving

Amazing. Don't miss this one. The photographs you see just can't give you the feel of this temple with massive trees roots spread over so many walls. To see some rooms filled with walls of rock that had tumbled down added to the feel of this temple. We went in the afternoon. It didn't seem too crowded. We did have to wait 3 or 4 different times to get the photo we wanted, but we were able to climb where we wanted to be and get some fabulous photos. Loved it.
Beautiful. My favorite temple. So interesting to see how the trees are taking over the temples. When we went it was pretty busy, try to make it to the temple and take pics!
Wonderful. Ta Prohm is under reconstruction currently (Feb. '13) and on approach it appears that most of the ruins are cordoned off. Keep going as this is not the case! It's incredible.

Go early!. The most magical of all Angkor temples... those huge tree roots are really there.A simple tip: paths in Ta Prohm are narrow, so sharing them (and the views) with hordes of other tourists spoils the experience. To avoid that, GO EARLY. Be there before 7 am. Enter through the east gate and walk across. The weather is slightly chilly, there's wonderful morning light... and almost nobody else. The big tours come much later, you are alone to the extent that one of us got completely lost inside the temple.Lonely morning at Ta Prohm is better than crowded sunrise at Angkor Wat.
The most atmospheric temple. This is the temple famous as a movie location. That aside, it is wonderfully atmospheric and less restored than Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom.

Lovely huge trees inside the ruins. This was another fantastic temple which has large trees growing inside and adds to the romantic feel of it. It was quite busy when we went and getting a picture of the trees without any other tourists in it was nigh on impossible but we managed it after a lot of patience!

An absolute must-see. I was incredibly excited to visit Ta Prohm whilst in Cambodia, and it definitely did not disappoint! To see nature slowly reclaiming the temple... Photographs simply do not do this wondrous place justice. Ta Prohm will take your breath away.Unfortunately, it was incredibly busy whilst I was there, and of course you get the usual hordes of boisterous tourists that seem to care nothing for others. As such it was a bit of a battle simply moving through the temple, though certainly worth the trouble! Absolutely don't even think about missing out on the beauty of Ta Prohm.
Favorite !. This was my favorite temple out of the ones we visited (angkor wat and bayon temple). I like how the nature if now mixed with the history. Very impressive !!!

Look dad, Temple Run!!!!. For anybody who has a kid who is an avid player of Temple Run - this is one of the places for them :-) Had a great couple of hours walking round the temple, in aw off mother nature trying to claim back what is hers. Photographs do not come close to actually seeing how the trees and their root system have become intertwined throughout this whole complex.Let your kids watch Tomb Raider before you go and then get them to spot the sections of the temple used in the movie. I did that after the trip, but would have been good to add it as another piece of entertainment for inquisitive minds.

Eerily beautiful overgrown Khmer temple. Another must see if you are in Cambodia. It gives one a tiny taste of what it must have been like to come upon the Angkor complex when it was overgrown. It is a tremendous task to balance restoration with leaving the trees and roots as they are growing.

great temple to visit - though it gets hot later in the day. This is one of my favourites at Angor Wat site. also knon as the tomb raider temple, because some scene with Anjelina Jolie was shot here. I took my friend there in Feb (I have already been) and it was so hot and I just wish the area where that scene was shot was better signposted. The temple itself is amazing, I loved it regardless, but my friend who is not into temples was just so hot and bored after already a whole day of temples.

My favorite temple. We visited a lot of temples, and Ta Prohm was my favorite. It has a magical quality and is interesting to watch the workers continue to unearth the temple and put the pieces back together. The trees are awesome.
Crazy circus!. This site is originally amazing but you could hardly see it because of all the people and being pushed about is not a nice way of seeing it!
Awesome adventure and so beautiful. even though lots of visitors were there at the same time...there was plenty of room to roam around and discover

Unique jungle temple. Amazing temple in the jungle which outstripped my expectations. In some ways it is a shame that it was used as a film set (Lara Croft) as I would have been just as happy not having my fellow visitors constantly referring to Angelina Jolie, but the place is a must see.

Beautiful and Serene!. Ta Prohm was a different experience from other temples. One can spend hours looking at the trees and their roots inter-wining the structures. The temples is all of small alleys and this place has more shade than others hence the walk around this ruin is not stressful. We liked this place and came back again the next day. We visited during the lunch times to avoid the tours and crowd.

My favorite. This was definitely one of our favorite temples in the whole siem reap area. The temples are made of stones which are really cooling so inside you'll be chilled although it's probably 80 degrees outside. The scenery is spectacular, you get to do a bit of climbing it you want, it's huge and it's close to all the other temples and downtown Siem Reap.
Fascinating. If you have seen Lara Croft then you have seen this Temple but it is absolutely fascinating that so many of these trees grew on top of the Temple - just awesome

Excellent. Really enjoyed this and would say it was our favourite. This is where they filmed Raiders of the Lost Ark. Lots of tree trunks, vines and roots growing around the ruins. Highly recommended. Go with a guide.

That Temple!. The must see Tomb Raider site gives you a pretty good idea how closely invasive the trees were at other sites, and how much work is required to restore them. It is more shady that the Bayon experience but has a real appeal just because it is so unusual
stunning. the best of the attractions in my view.. though ankor wat is the end all and be all... A beautiful and screne attraction which is stunning and mesmerising.

Interface with Forest make this special place. This site has not been restoresd as much as the others and this makes it special because the trees are growing out of the ruins making for some great photos. Best seen at dawn when you also get the parrots and parakeets in the trees.

Explore at your own pace. We arrived at Ta Prohm after lunch and surprisingly it wasn't too busy. I loved it here because we were able to explore off the track as almost nothing is off limits in terms of wondering around the broken temples and through doors, getting lost. We had a tour guide with a large group but decided to venture off on our own & I'm glad we did, as we were able to get some great photos and see places where no other tourists were. Loved it!

Atmospheric. Ta Prohm is by far the most atmospheric of the Angkor temples and the one with the most amazing photo opportunities.We were lucky to be able to visit twice. Our first visit was during late afternoon when the crowds were thinning out, but unfortunately my camera battery expired the moment we entered so our guide agreed to a return trip two days later while our Angkor pass was still valid. Ta Prohm is relatively small but full of enticing nooks and crannies. As previously mentioned the famous photo opportunities attract a queue of people who seem to take an absolute age posing themselves in front of the famous tree roots. Patience is certainly needed.

Civilisation giving way to nature.. Such a beautiful temple site. The fact that the strangler figs are taking over actually adds to the beauty and mystique of this place. We went on a private 2 day tour with our own locally hired guide and driver. When the temple was busy, we tucked ourselves away and had lunch in a little isolated, crumbling corner and waited for the bus tours to disappear (which they did pretty quickly!), and then we wandered around at leisure, taking lots of pictures that didn't have a soul in them. Our pics look like we had the place to ourselves entirely. This and Bayon are, in my opinion, the best, most atmospheric temples on the complex.

Get there early. If you have time, definitely get to Ta Prohm early, about 6-6.30am is probably a good time as you have some time to reflect on the tranquility of the walk up to the temple as well as well as avoiding the crowds. This temple is known by most people as the 'Tomb Raider' temple and you will be blown away by all the beautiful curling and winding tree roots which envelop the temple structure. Getting there early means you will be able to enjoy the serenity and beauty of the temple without busloads of tourists getting in your way. As you walk up the path to Ta Prohm from the main entrance you will hear beautiful traditional Khmer music, the music is played by landmine victims who play music and sell their CDs in order to support their families (feel free to give some dollars/riels as it is very much appreciated) and adds beautifully to the atmosphere of this temple. Take some time to enjoy the atmosphere. Also take a look at the work of one of the artists at Ta Prohm although his artwork looks similar to the ones at the markets, you can watch him paint at the site and he is very friendly and explains a bit about his work to you.Ta Prohm is more than just the 'Tomb Raider' temple, it is well worth several hours of your time exploring the nooks and crannies of this beautiful temple
lovely. Wonderful those roots are so massive and make look this temple so impressive I love it, A most do, DO NOT MISS IT!!!!!...

One of my favorite places .... Being a bit of a photo nut, I had researched this location and looked forward to the visit. The experience exceeded the expecations. You don't see the sky too often in this part of the world, but this morning it was there. With a blue sky and this scenery, a poor photo was impossible. Angkor park is a world class destination - and of the half dozen sites we visited, Ta Prohm truly is the best imo. The power of nature exposes how a city can be lost in a jungle over time. Photo Hint; The only way to get a picture of a doorway without somebody posing in it is by standing in queue with the posers - and then disallowing any posing until you get your shots, then allow the next in line - it works. Its a short little hike to the site and hard to say how long to plan for - I could have spent a couple hours but in reality the site is very small. Tomb raider and all that - this place is a winner.
WOW!. Also called the jungle temple, if you like enjoy photography you will love this place. Take care when walking very rocky

Great to see early morning. We've been just before sunrise to see Ta Prohm just because there were some clouds on the sky. It was simply amaizing. When we arrived was a bit dark and there were just about three people entering the temple. We could enjoy a quiet morning, listening to birds and seeing the first sun shades. Curently the temple is going through some restaurations but this was not an impediment to enjoy the visit.Ta Prohm is different than the others in Angkor Thom as nature tried to regain the land and you can see from quite a lot of trees growing through the ruins of the temple. It is quite spectacular the view. One of my favourites for sure and a must see among the temples in Siem Reap.If you like this you could as well go to Beng Mealea.

Beautiful Temple with Gigantic Trees. I really like this place... Amazing view of gigantic trees grows on top of the temple. Great spot for photography lover.If you're traveling in group, make sure to keep close to each other. Or you might find the trouble finding your group member, like we did :))
Amazing Temple Ruin Overgrowth. Century old tree growing on a like wise centuries old temple ruins. Picture perfect for all those tomb raider buffs. A Unesco world heritage site.

Fun to explore. It was really interesting to see how the trees have grown through the temple. Our tour guide told us the history of the temple and it is fascinating - especially the area with the big holes that are meant for huge diamonds! They were doing some restoration in the back of the temple which was kind of cool to watch as well. NOTE: Get a tour guide. They speak great English (and other languages are available). Ours was $25/day = WELL worth it!

At Prohm. It's amazing how the structure has survived with the trees growing through it. It's best to do TaProhm early in the morning before the crowds get there. We got some great shots without other tourists in the picture....

Must see. It's worth seeing, not so much for the temple itself but more for how nature has reclaimed its place. The pile of loose stones all coded and numbered for the conservation of the temple gives you a better sense of the work involved. According to our guide, this has become a "busy and noisy" temple because it's so popular and that's unfortunately true. Unlike the large spacious Angkor Wat, there's much less space between the ruins and trees to enjoy it. But still worth the visit.
fabulous. get a guide to show you around. Ta Prohm is beautiful and well worth a visit as part of a tour around the temple sites.

under contruction. Visited this temple after lunch and it wasn't as crowded as we expected. It was very overrun with trees and we had a great time exploring. Only shame was that it was under construction and a large section was closed off when we were there. Other than that though - amazing.

better than Angkor Wat Temple. dislikes - crowds and people letting their children run amok and climbing everywhere. Likes - seeing how nature reclaims man made stuctures and restoration work that is tying to get a balance of preserving the temple while respecting natures intrusion.
Totally stunned.... Nothing much to say... One of the must see temple in Siem Reap. You can see here how nature and man-made art mingles with each other.

Awesome trees versus temples. We arrived early enough to get a good look through this complex. It has not been restored as much as the bigger places, which I found rather good. I did not have a guide, just the book 'ancient Angkor', which really tells you enough. I did the 'tour' in reverse, however.

Tomb Raider filmed here. This is where they film the Tomb Raiders. Big trees growing from the roof of the temple with roots coming down the sides and into the ground. Amazing what nature can do to a building if left alone for 500 years. Very photogenic. Really like visiting a lost temple in the middle of the jungle. It is smallish compare to the other temples like Angkor Wat and Bayon Temple. So there is less tourist especially in the morning.

Best of all the temples around Angkor Wat. We thought this was the most beautiful and memorable temple among others. Not as busy or big, but it felt more serene and real. They should provide small motorized vehicle to ferry elderly into the compound though rather than making them walk the long stretch.

All within the small tour. Again if you are visiting Angkor Wat then this temple isnt too far and is part of what is commonly known as the small tour. You can see the trees growing and holding up the structure, which is what makes this place unusual. Be aware that there are lots of Chinese tourist who seem to want to pose at every opportunity, so it can be busy and difficult to get a photo without someones face ruining your shot.

Machinery everywhere. The site is very photogenic but there is so much reconstruction machinery on site left unused that it is now becoming part of the landscape, destroying the appeal. Still one of the top 3 to see. Too bad about the lack of care in the reconstruction.

Eerily magical. We went here toward the end of the afternoon and it was not as busy as the other temples. We were able to take several photos with no people in them at all. The cicadas and parrots are the noisiest I have heard and it adds to the mysterious ambience. Do not miss this one! Our guide, Niem Sokhem was the best and so was our driver, Dalat (I hope that's correct) booked through angkorguideservices.com. We were dismayed to see tourists from various countries, walk beyond the yellow tape, and sitting on delicate trunks to have a smoke (which is forbidden). Their guides seemed nonchalant but ours did speak up.
Amazing. In my opinion this was the best place we visited, it was like something from another world, a fabulous temple being engulfed by huge tree roots, you have to see it to believe it.

It is real!!!. Well worth a visit. These temples are in ruin but are amazing to see. The trees are literally growing over the walls of the temples. It was made famous by Tomb Raider. And is great to see in real life. Plenty of brilliant photo opportunites.
Watch out for the small monkies!
Amazing Temple. Like stepping in to a fairytale or a movie set. Such an amazing place with the trees growing through and over the temple walls. A must see and a highlight of our trip to Cambodia.

Feeling conflicted about the conservation that has been done here. I was in Siem Reap 2.5 years ago and Ta Prohm was one of my favourite temples along with Angkor Wat and Beng Meleae.This time however the Ta Prohm that greeted me is so different from the one that I remembered. It was previously one of the most mysterious and magnificient (really magnificient) places I have been to despite being in ruins back then.The Ta Prohm now has been partly rebuilt- and it is great that there is a certain structure to the place and it is safer to visit the place now. It is also obvious that quite a bit of effort have been put in place to save as many of the trees that make the place special. At the same time however, the atmosphere of the place has been "altered" and the temple now feels very comparatively more commercial.
renovation. so dissapointing to see that this temple was in renovation!When you see what they prepare here you can just be afraid about the future....

Nature Chooses Its Own Path Here!. All the trees growing on top of the roofs of the temple, growing half on one side of a wall and half on the other. Parts of the temple broken due to these trees. Really quite amazing! Definitely a sight to see here.
Raiders of the lost Ark. This is how I though the other temples would look. Try to go early in the morning before the crowds to really explore.

The Tomb Raider temple. yes yes... thats what the local guides & drivers call this temple thanks to lara croft & they even show the spots where the scenes from the movies were shot. Even though the temple is overrun with tourists, it is still worth seeing. This is the temple where the trees have not been cleared & they present the best photo ops

stunning atmosphere. this temple is magic! Trees and roots has grown taking place all over! I felt like an Indiana Jones discovering the place symbol of the decline of Khmer empire. It was astonishing to see how after temples were abandoned they were overwhelmed by jungle. The soundtrack during this visit was the sound of the cicadas, magnifique!. Don't miss!! Simply magnificent! Don't forget to wear comfortable shoes and bring your camera
Magical Ta Phrom. One of my favourites. The gigantic trees growing over the temple gives this a magical feeling. Tomb Raider stuff - loved it.

Brilliant.... Ta Prohm is the temple that is being overtaken by the trees.. so very photogenic with massive roots squeezing the life out of the temple... Set in the jungle so a nice walk up to it. Have some dollars ready for the land-mine victims playing music...
Epic!. Dedicated to the King Jayavarman VII’s mother, this temple is popular for the tree roots being the foundation of the current structure of the temple. Majestic in size, almost unbelievable!

Must Go But So Crowded. I was really looking forward to this temple but it was over crowded with tourist groups. The authorities are also doing conservation works so many areas are off access and with built up ramps everywhere, Ta Prohm lost the "missing civilisation" feel and tranquility.

Tomb raider here we come.. We got here early before the crowds - it is a little further out than the other temples so we had a wonderful time wondering around admiring the place. It is more damaged and in greater disrepair than the other temples due to the damage from the trees that overgrow the walls - but that is what gives it its mystical feel...

Second best temple after Ankor!. This is the tomb raider temple with enormous trees winding their sinuous roots throughout the structure. If you only had a day, this would be the place to visit after Ankor Wat.

Magnificent. Of course, every guide will tell you of The Tomb Raider and of Angelina Jollie when you go there. Clearly the place is awesome and unsurpassed anywhere in the world for its tale of the genius of the bright spiritual Khmer people around the 12th century. But, an authority has to manage the massive pedestrian thumping it gets from tourists, for its preservation.
Over-rated. Too many tourists.Too many touts.It would be so so so beautiful without all the media attention.I blame Lara Croft!

Last but not least for me. The so called jungle temple is a great example of how nature reclaims its own if given the chance. The enormous trees intruding on it with roots invading both vertical and horizontal weaknesses would destroy the temple if given time, so much so that one tree is propped up with a metal pole to stop it toppling over and taking a large piece of temple with it.While not the largest of the three generally visited sites, to me it was the most attractive, spoiled only by the restoration work being carried out but which is essential longer term.If visiting Siem Reap, add this to your bucket list.

Gorgeous. This temple had a very different feel than the others, and is practically a must-see! It was under construction in March 2012 when we visited, but most of it was still easy to see. You just had to frame your shots to avoid the construction material.There were more bugs at this temple than the others -- probably due to location. It was also very hot since there was no breeze.We felt safe here -- but a bit rushed. There is really one main way they diverted people through this one so there was a group behind you the whole time.

Go early at 7am to really appreciate this wonderful place. The temple is partly being renovated so seeing the big tree with the overgrown roots can be a bunfight unless you get there by 7.30am latest to get some space on your own to take it all in.This was one of my favourite temples as it just was not as busy (at 7.30am) unlike Angkor Wat with all the coachloads of tourists!!

Tomb Raider Temple. When you imagine a "jungle temple" with giant tree roots growing through temple walls, this is the temple to see. It was featured in a dramatic scene in the original "Lara Croft Tomb Raider" movie, so it draws a crowd. It is currently undergoing extensive renovation, so access is limited in some areas. Ta Prohm was built by Jayavarman VII, the "buider king" as a tribute to his mother. This Buddhist temple was originally a monastery and housed enormous amounts of jewels and gold. This is another "must see" temple when touring the Angkor complex, with great photo opportunities.

A temple getting a dramatic overhaul. I visited the site January 2013 and my fellow travelers were a bit disappointed at all the construction equipment there. I found it fascinating as it was a wonderful glimpse into the choices being made to halt the deterioration yet retain the charm of some of the trees which though they played a part in the destruction added a beauty to the site. I found myself just as intrigued in the work going on as I was with the temple. Even with all the construction equipment (mostly in the first courtyard) the site was almost overwhelming it's beauty. We only spent one afternoon there but like most temples, we could have easily spent a week just exploring the various bas reliefs and nooks and crannies of the temple. I hope to see it after they have completed the restoration as like the other sites I am curious as to the final result and where the line is finally drawn.
GORGEOUS. I really loved this temple. It was much nicer than Angkor Wat in my opinion. Really beautiful! Take the small path to North Gate.

A Tomb Raider Experience. The thing that echoes through the crowd when you go to this Temple is that a number of important scenes were shot here for the Hollywood movie, Tomb Raider with Angelina Jolie as Lara Croft. Of course, I lined up to have my picture taken in that area. However, this is not the only thing that makes this place special.The place alone is spectacular. The old trees with their roots embracing a number of structures in the temple are simply majestic. Along with the ruins (that are currently being restored) this place gives you an ethereal feel to it. Make sure that you do not spend a lot of time having your pictures taken only at the tomb raider site as there are a lot of other areas that are equally beautiful and worth exploring.

Under Construction (Jan '13). We were really looking forward to visiting this temple and were dissappointed to find it under heavy preservation construcytion. We still really liked this temple but it would have been even more wonderful without the horrid equipment everywhere. If you are running out of time (like we were), you may want to skip this one until you can confirm the preservation construction is complete.
Spectacular temple. Spectacular temple and the trees that have intertwined themselves in the ruins are a sight to be seen. Unfortunately some restoration in progress but still well worth it.

How Amazing Is THIS???. I know, I know. It has been in the movies and Angelina Jolie already discovered the area. BUT..even though I am from L.A. and have seen it all from "the business" side, I guess I assumed alot of the pictures we all see to be 'Hollywood'. Well, this is far, far from Hollywood and is absolutely amazing - and more impressive and grand than any movie set. It is magical, really. How nature can take over and 'wrap' itself around manmade structures to take back it's space. Beautiful. Magical. Eerie. Mystical. Fascinating. You must be patient when visiting. There are way too many rude tourists. Some trying to pose as Lara Croft - and pay no attention to the damage they are doing to the trees and delicate surfaces they are invading. Nonetheless - go with the knowledge you must be patient and grab that perfect moment to make the space your own - and marvel at the wonder. It is truly magnificent. Early or late in the day is your best bet.

Other Worldly and Ethereal temple. One of the omst beautiful places I have ever seen, the giant trees and air of desolation amid the temple is mind blowing and so atmospheric. One tip - avoid the crowds lining up for a photo where Angelina Jolie posed in Tomb Raider and explore a little further for lots of brilliant photo ops and magnificent ruins and roots...

tomb raider temple. unique temple with big tree surrounding it. as beautiful as you see it in film,it makes you wonder how these big trees can grow inside,up the temple without collapse it ( some section really collapse and can not enter ) but the temple and tree makes a very good artistic form

Jungle vs. temple. One of the highlights of the Angkor circuit (although it is hard to choose which is the best), this is one where you will see many immense trees having taken root over the ruins. Magnificent.
Very Scenic. This is one of the more scenic temples you can visit at Angkor. Picture yourself in a Lara Croft or Indiana Jones movie, entering the ancient temple overrun by the jungle.

Nature wins here!. Another of the Angkor Complex treasures, although this time with a difference. I am sure it would be a lovely Temple all on its own right. However, nature has attempted to reclaim the area and what has been left behind is amazing.Actually, I expect all of the Temples of the area had the same experience as Ta Prohm but the difference is they have not cleared out nature in this Temple. This allows you to see the Temple something like how it was discovered. Mind you there are lots of tourists so chose your visiting time well.It is a very unusual scene and one which you have to see with your own eyes to really take in.
Fascinating. The trees make this a unique and fascinating temple. Not very big so easy to see in a short time but worth every minute.

Good, but overrated, and way too many people.. Everyone comes here because its the tomb raider temple, but there are other spots in Angkor Wat that are just as good. Come at lunch to escape the crowds.

Overgrown and gorgeous. Apparently when the French colonists "found" Angkor Wat and the surrounding temples, they decided to leave one of them in its romantic, overgrown jungly state. Ta Prohm.This temple is the one in your fantasies, the one simulated in video games and movies and fashion shoots etc etc . I doubt there is anything like it anywhere else.See it soon, as the trees threaten to topple it and if not them, it will be the busloads of tourists allowed to swarm over and through it.(As with all temples in the area, try to visit before or after the heat of the day)
Magical. Loved seeing the tree roots that have grown down over the temple - it really givs you an appreciaion of how long the temple has been there.

Tomb raider. Apparently this si where the film was set, and it loooks stunning when deserted. We were lucky to get there just after sunrise, amazing light and birdsong and only one other couple apart from us. The trees and roots growing through the temples are amazing.

Busy and a building site. You will recognise the iconic images of tree roots growing over the temples here, (from the tomb raider movies) and they are amazing to see but currently the whole area is one big building site with scaffolding and workers everywhere, it definitely detracted from the atmosphere. It was also very busy when we were there due to a few Korean tour groups passing through so it felt a bit like Disney land, although I've heard that we were unlucky and at other times it can be more peaceful.

How do those trees live in those ruins!!. This is pretty ridiculous. Not only do you see a partially reclaimed to the jungle temple but you also gget to see these crazy giant trees that actually live atop the ruins. It's just mind boggling to see up close.

Better than Angkor Wat. My girlfriend and I went to see this temple twice as we enjoyed it so much the first time round. in our opinion it was more spectacular than Angkor Wat due to the intertwined trees and the feel that you are walking around a living/breathing temple.It was much more crowded the second time we went but I guess that was due to the set times the organised tours have. We went around 4pm the first time and there were half the tourists there compared to the second time when we went at about 11am.A definite must see if you are visiting the Angkor temples.

Bayon-early am. incredible. We hired a car at six and at 6.25 discovered that we only shared thois amazing site with one other person. Truly incredible experience and a dream come true for us, It was a highlight of Siem Reap.

The Ancient Jungle Temple!. Wow! Did I just step on to the set of an Indiana Jones Movie? This place is remarkable, a must see for sure! The Jungle has begun to reclaim its space and has overgrown this ancient temple; trees have grown around, up and through parts of the structure. Absolutely Amazing, I could have took pictures for weeks.

Must see. Had a fantastic day with our friend\guide Heang Song (on facebook) who showed us around for a day in 3 different complexes, this was the most exiting and I would realy recomend it to all. Amazing to see the trees growing into the walls. I recomend to have a guide to get all the history as well. Contact Heang Song on facebook and he will give you a day you never will forgett!!

Get here early!. If you want amazing photos, get here early before the crowds and the stupid things that many tourists do. Ta Prohm is very special with all the interesting shots of ruins and vegetation. However, many tourists engage in irresponsible behavior and are walking and climbing in places they shouldn't. If this site is to remain for eternity, tourists need to think more smartly and act more responsibly or the site will, at some point, be ruined and necessarily, closed.

A real highlight! Dont miss!. We were always going to Vietnam for a couple of weeks in January and doing north and south and the middle. We only went to Cambodia as an afterthought and we are so glad we did. Siem Reap was great, nightlife was fun and buzzy and the people very friendly. Angkor Wat was stunning but the hidden gem is Ta Prohm, the "Tomb Raider" temple.Dont miss it! Indiana Jones and Tomb Raider rolled into one!The pictures we got were amazing (even n a cheap camera!)Go early in the morning to miss all the tourist groups and get the best pictures!!

Should be closed until it is restored.. Ta Prohm is overrun with visitors in the midst of all the restoration work going on. And these are the irresponsible tourists who only care about posing on the most precarious stones and boulders kept aside for retoration and clicking away useless pictures. This is a major problem.Seeing the grandeur and the intricacy of Ta Prohm sculpture, it probably rivals Angkor Wat in beauty and sheer size. However, it is in very precarious condition. I am really shocked that the authorities are allowing visitors to trample all over this treasure making the restoration so much more difficult. Like most major archeological sites around the world that are closed completely for restoration (the Acropolis, some of the Egyptian Sphinx, some of the Italian museums), this Temple needs to be shut down for a few years. In the meanwhile, all thos busloads of irresponsible tourists need to be banned from visiting here.

"Tomb Raider" Temple Does Not Disappoint. Walking through the tree-limb entwined temple ruins, I half expected Angelina Jolie aka Lara Croft, to come swinging through. This temple was left as it was found in the mid-1800's and though its a tourist hot-spot, there's much to marvel at. I loved the way tree roots became part of the building itself. Very unusual.

My favourite Angkor temple. As a photographer you'll want to visit this temple 2 or 3 times during your stay. The way the light trickles into the various areas in this temple is really nice. While the Tomb raider tree is the focus, there are plenty of nooks within this temple.

So evocative. The wonderful, tree-wrapped temple of Ta Prohm is best visited at lunchtime. Yes, it's hot, but all the big groups will have gone for lunch and you stand a good chance of getting some really excellent and deserted pictures.
My favourite. This is the most beautiful of all in my opinion and shouldnt be missed! unfortunately some restoration in progress but still well worth it.

my childrens' favourite temple. the children ( 11 and 13) liked this temple the best. it was amazing to see the trees enhancing/ destroying the temple and debating the ethics of cutting the trees down. lots of photo opportunities and lots of hawkers here too.

Amazing Place. It is truly incredible - a jungle growing through a temple. You keep being amazed time after time with the size of the trees growing through the temple. So much construction though - you wonder how long tourists will actually be allowed to keep going through this place as the rocks keep falling and the construction workers trying frantically to repair and restore. Ta Prohm is definately worth the visit though.

Nice but under refurbishment. Ta Prohm is fantastic. Unfortunately the 'Tomb Raider' temple is having a fair bit of work done to it (jan 13). There are cranes and scaffolding in a number of places. You'll have to use your imagination as to what used to be

Timing is important. We visited early afternoon and certainly managed to miss the coachloads of visitors. With a little patience I managed to get photos without other people on. Certainly worth the visit - great atmosphere.

Temple in the jungle. We arrive at the temple full of expectations, we have seen hundreds of pictures, we know what to expect ... But when you walk in the front door was simply amazed at the spectacle that nature offers us. Never as in this case, the forest seems to want to take your own space and stone structures seem deformars to trace the roots of the trees. As it enters the temple are discovering new symbiosis between trees and sculptures.
Excellent. Visit this temple even if does not have the size of Angkor Wat the carvings are amazing. It has a lot of photo oportunities.

The Best. Only Preah Khan, perhaps, evokes the same atmosphere as Ta Prohm. Despite its over-exposure it is a magical place. It is all those tree-roots, see, forcing the rocks apart and burrowing into the foundations.... a canvas emblazoned with the battle between Man and Nature.

OUR FAVOURITE!. This is not to be missed if you are visiting the temples. It is stunning. We spent around 4 hours here, and I didnt want to leave. There is loads to see and explore. Perfect photograph opportunities. We went after lunch and left just after sunset and found it a good time to go. It is quite shaded so does not get too hot!

Pick a right time to go!. We went to this temple twice. The first time at about mid day and the second time early in the morning. Made famous by the Tomb Raider movie, this was probably the most crowded temple we'd visited in Siem Reap and there was just no way to take a nice picture without some else's head or arm in it. With the advise of our guide, we attempted to visit the temple a second time early in the morning, and this turned out to be a fantastic experience. The crowd only started coming in as we were about to leave.With many big trees growing in the compound of the temple, the sight is simply spectacular. While some trees helped hold up the structured of the temple, others were destroying it. Many parts of this temples are in ruins and there is ongoing conservation efforts at the moment. I'll definitely want to be back again in a couple of years time to look at the restored temple! It is worth catching it in its current original state before all restorations are completed.
Wow!!!. one of the favorites. The magnificent face carving seems to rule the place. the gentle wall carvings tell a story- you better have a local guide to show it to you!

It would be magical if.... ...if you could experience it without the busloads of other tourists and the archaeologists that make it look like a construction site. It;s certainly worthy work reconstructing parts of the temple - a major puzzle given the piles of stone blocks everywhere. Still impressive to see the trees growing out of everything - sometimes holding it together or destroying it?

Beautiful temple, must see in Siem Reap. Unlike the pristine Angkor Wat, this temple complex is still enveloped by trees and their giant roots. Its eerie ancient appeal made it the location for "Tomb Raider" which the locals are very proud of. Still improving do to continued rebuilding of the complex.
A favorite temple. We saved this for last, it is beautiful, but very popular and was the most crowded of the temples we visited.
the koreans get in the way of every photo!. fascinating experience if you can avoid the busloads of Koreans and chinese who destroy the ambience and your photos !

Not to be missed.. Currently there a conservations works ongoing at the most famous corner. If you add tons of tourists, it can be difficult to enjoy so plan the visit carefully. Nevertheless, it delivers what the pictures were promising you!
