Also part of Angkor Wat, don't miss it. Also a must see. If you get a decent tuk-tuk driver, they will already have this site and many others built in to their standard package. Just be sure to do a little research before hand to be sure he doesn't leave anything out.

Atmospheric. a bit of reconstruction going on but if you arrive early (9-10am) there will be a lot less people. There seems to be more mystical atmosphere here and the jungle has become part of the stonework which you don't see at Angkor Wat

Very interesting but under construction. While we were there there were many men with hard hats on trying to rebuild the temple as many of it had fallen down. The only bits of the temple still standing were the bits kept up by trees. Very interesting though.
Wonderland. You can't miss this temple, it was just amazing. I felt like I was 12 years old, pretending to be an explorer. AS Indiana Jones as it gets. Absolutely wonderful.

Amazing. I call it the temple with the most famous tree in the world.
The jungle, the nature, the air, the ruines.. Once in a lifetime experience, this is my favorite temple in Agkor. Dont miss it

Ta Prohm - Tomb raiders. Saw Ta Prohm on 3rd day of 3 day temple pass $40. What a wonderful site. The temple in the jungle - were I believe tomb raiders was filmed. Taking a camera here is a must - well worth visiting.
amazing. it's the most amazing temple because of the trees roots all around. Go there late in the afternoon or the atmosphere will be distrubed by touristic groups.

Cool. After spending a few days walking around temples, it was nice to see one that was quite a bit different from some of the other ones. Trees and roots winding their way up and through the temple made it a wondeful and unusual sight.It was quite busy there and there was some construction work going on to try and repair and keep the temple from completely falling apart, but it was well worth the visit.Enjoy it

Not to be missed. Never realized that a building can be so charming even when it is crumbling down! Timing of the visit can be very crucial - most people suggest visiting early morning before the crowds arrive. However if you arrive too early there is not much sunlight, since the dense vegetation makes it very dark. For a serious photographer, even half a day will not be sufficient here!

Ta Prohm. It is a tragedy that some time in the future the whole temple will be swallowed by the roots of the trees growing all over. People go to the place to photograph the roots rather than the bas-reliefs. We were told that some religious groups insist that nature take its course and allow the whole place be allowed to decay.

Fantastic. This is an amazing place. The tree roots winding there way through the temple is a sight to be seen. This is the place that Tomb Rider was filmed and you can definitely see why the director chose this location. It is very atmospheric.

Wonderful sunrise temple. We were virtually alone to enjoy the serenity of this great Wat, and it is definitely worth getting up early to experience. We want to re-watch the Lara Croft movie to pick out the Tomb Raider scenes . The majestic curving of the trees that almost swallow the surrounding temple rminds you of the power of mother nature reclaiming the land.

Jungles encased Temple. Beautiful and quiet in the early morning sun. Recommend going early morning (7am) or late afternoon to other tour groups. Very peaceful seeing nature (giant kapok trees) swallowing this temple, in the jungle. So many photo opportunties your camera battery will go flat. Definately get a guide to tour you around the best bits of this vast site, and explain the carvings etc. (Un-escorted tourists can get lost, and miss bits).

COOLEST PLACE ON EARTH!. I felt like Indiana Jones wandering through the tunnels and over the rubble piles (that you're technically not supposed to climb) while in Ta Prohm. You'll recognize it from movies but it's a wonderful place to lose yourself in - don't get LOST.... just lose yourself. It's hauntingly mysterious.
Amazing. Harry Potter. amazing. camera is a must. Never felt like I was in a story book more than this. Spend some time and just be in awe.

Seam Reap Adventure. The temples are worth seeing, specially those who love history and adventure. I would not however recomend taking children below the age of 12 since it will make your life specially difficult. Walking through all these temples is also not recomended for those who are physically challenged due to a disability or simply through age. Go while your young and capable of walking, climbing and sweating your heart out.
favourite. good to see what the jungle had done to area that wasnt lived in and the rebuilding efforts are incredibly. get there early though
Great but getting touristy. This is one of the great temples to visit, amazing structures and features, size and colour. Like most temples get in early or at lunch time when the numbers are down.

Most amazing place I have ever been to. My husband and I specifically planned a trip to Thailand and Cambodia based and the desire to go to Angkor Wat. While all of the temples were amazing Ta Prohm blows them all out of the water

Beautiful but too crowded. Sounds like everybody goes there because of Tomb Raider. Really??? Can't believe it... As a result, the temple is over crowded. Get to other temples that are just as nice (and maybe even more picturesque), such as Beng Mealea and Preak Khan, and you'll admire giant trees intertwined among antique walls and statues, all on your own!

Like being in Indiana Jones!!. The temple at Ta Prohm is amazing - the roots of the tree's growing over the temples is a facinating site!They are doing alot of work on restoring Ta Prohm but it doesnt spoil the visit as there is loads of parts to explore where there is no sign of any construction going on... You can spend well over an hour here so give yourself lots of time to explore :-)

Lara Croft Temple. One of the things we realized when we got the Siam Reap is that there are more than a 100 (?) temples. You have to pick which ones you want to visit. Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom are must dos. If you have to pick one more dont miss Ta Prhom. What i liked about the temple is the trees that are intervowen into the temple. There is a lot of restoration work going on so that can be dissapointing. However i was told that once this is cleaned up most of the old trees may be removed to make the temple structure stronger. What a pity...so dont miss it.. the trees may not be around for too long !
Under renovation. And too much movie hype.. It's an incredibly beautiful temple in it's own right. I was annoyed by all of the crowds focused on "where Angelina ran out", etc.

Out of this world. The place looks straight out of a mythological book.....It is mysterious and divine...we couldnt stop staring at the trees and how they enveloped pretty much everything - the rocks, the walls, more tress....It is a must visit....
Sunset spot. Good spot for sunset get there early hawkers get tiring but enjoy the sense of history. Will be crowded so get up to top for best view.
Good place to visit. You can see how the nature power to conquer the human construction by time. It is amazing place. It is a different place from other temples.
Tomb Raider Temple. While there are many temples to see I would make sure to add this one to the list. This temple had some ridiculously large ficus trees growing throughout.

Amazing. The crowd was horrendous with everyone wanting to play the Tomb Raider bit! The restoration work added to the din but it was interesting to examine the restored part to witness the glory of the original temples. The trees gave it a wild (and creepy) look.

Fascinating to see in person, and even better with a knowledgeable guide. I've seen it in movies and read enough reviews to make me feel pretty comfortable with what I was about to encounter. I was still surprised at how large it is and how beautiful and peaceful the environment is, even though there were others milling around the temple at the same time that I was. The stegosaurus was easy to find (although, seeing it live, I don't think it was really meant to be a stegosaurus). More interesting, to me, was the way some temple walls were designed (with xmas tree-like cutouts) to ensure structural integrity and all of the holes present that I was told once contained jewels. Perhaps I either misunderstood or just fell for it, but was told that Ta Phrom was considered among the elite of temples of the time and was adorned with jewelry that has since been removed. I haven't tried to verify if this is true, but it sounded good at the time. I had previously seen videos on how people put holes in stone blocks to move them into place, but this temple has many more holes than other, similar temples so the explanation I heard at the temple sounded plausible.
Must-see. Although there is a lot of renovation going on atm, this is still an amazing experience of nature reclaiming the temples
Genius of the ancient Khmers. Ta Prohm has so many vast tree root systems that it seems a wonder that the temples still exist. This is a Buddhist temple dedicated to the mother of King Jayavarman VII

Cool temple. Such a cool temple! Its amazing how nature has taken over, with the trees intertwining between the temple. The beauty of this temple is that it has had minimal restoration and you feel as though you are discovering this temple after thousands of years of it being abandoned.
Not like it was. last visited in Jan 2005. Too many access restrictions in Dec 2012 - Wood walkways have ruined the charm. Preah Khan is more like it was.

My favourite. The atmosphere here was amazing. I loved that we were in among the trees which meant it was a bit cooler. It is not very big and can be visited relatively quickly but it was magical to meander through the buildings with the trees growing all around the stones. A must visit.

anotheer mind blowing site. Bayon style but showing how the temples were being absorbed back into the tropical rain forest. Still being restored, just hope they don't go too far and destroy the magic of the place.

Its all you hope it to be and more. with all the amazing trees crawling up everywhere this is THE place in the Angkor complex. well worth arriving early in the morning to avoid crowds and walking around, exploring the trees and temple buildings and taking in the atmosphere. a must.

Construction noise spoiled it a bit, still really cool. This is the temple where the trees are fused to the temple as a testament to how long it was undiscovered. The 'Tomb Raider' tree is among the construction and the rubble is extensive. I hope they do a good job with the restoration.

Personally for me this is the best temple!. Since I was a kid I loved Indiana Jones movies and videogames such as Uncharted where you are a world explorer seeing ruins or looking for treasures. This temple is exactly like this - it just feels like you are in a movie. Personally I recommend starting early in the morning at this temple to avoid the crowds. Most people start the morning at Angkor Wat, so if you come to Ta Prohm in the morning you will have a chance to have a much more peaceful visit.

Seeing it in person is a must. I knew I wanted to see the famous site of Angelina Jolies's movie and it did not disappoint. I spent much time enjoying the details. Ask someone to show you the miniature Buddha face in the tree roots. Like the roots created a fram around a carving. Though the trees have wreaked havoc, it is an awe inspiring sight to see. Don't move through too fast, even though crowded

Trees on the Temple. The trees on the temple are unique, and seem as part of the same structure. The temple structure and the natural environment have fused to become one spectacular site. A must visit site.

Astounding temple, left shrouded in jungle.. Visited nov 2009. Not only did this temple briefly feature in Tomb Raider, but it offers a fascinating glimpse into how the Khmer temples were all rediscovered, hidden in jungles, crumbling and decaying. They took the decision to leave Ta Prohm as it was found, half hidden by jungle, trees destroying and at the same time holding together the temple.Tree roots slither across the ancient ruins like immense snakes that seem to writhe just out of the corner of your eyes.The trees cast a peaceful green shade over the old ruins, while carved decorations have gathered lichen over the centuries.The complex is extensively ruined and many passageways come to a sudden halt, blocked by rubble. At the time I visited you could climb, crawl and explore to your hearts content, not sure whether that is still the case now however.

Magical, despite the hype. This famous temple was my kids' favorite. They had heard about the trees taking over the temple, and seen images on google. But the real thing, despite the massive restoration going on there, was compelling. Definitely worth a visit. As temple visits go, this one can be done fairly quickly. The walk within the temple compound is very pretty. Musicians were playing traditional instruments on one side. Lots of children selling clothes, magnets, etc. Definitely a tourist trap, but worth going anyway.

Unbelievable and well worth the trek to get there. I preferred this temple to the main Angkor Wat temple, it was amazing to see the huge tree roots wrapped around the stone walls. Even more amazing to think that the stone walls are still standing after all this time. Watch your head and ankles as you walk around ! It is very popular because of the "Tomb Raider" fame but the crowds seem to flow through the ruins efficiently. Lots of good photo spots.

A Magical Temple - Our Favourite!. The Tomb Raider temple was the one site that we visited where you could really get lost in nooks and crannies, giving you a feeling of what it might have been like all those hundreds of years ago.The tree roots are impressive as is the initial architecture itself.At our time of visiting (Early December 2012) there was a lot of scaffolding and renovations going on which killed the ambience slightly, but for us it still felt magical - We loved it!

The Indiana Jones Temple. Get up before 6 and arrive before the tour groups arrive, you wont regret it. Still possible to crawl over the old stones and make great pictures like you discovered it yourself.

Impressed but the pile of rubble. When I first entered the site, I didn't know that this was the place where they shot Angelina Jolie's movie Tomb Raider - I knew it was somewhere around in Angor - but I was genuinely impressed the site. The temples are fantastic, the trees are awesome. The only thing you can say is: wawwwooo.The second thing the surprised me is the state the temples are in. Pretty degraded. Piles of stone and rubble everywhere. I thing that India (the country) is sponsoring the reconstruction, and I can tell you, there is a lot of work to be done, and it's really worth while.Hope that they do honor and justice to the site.

Loved the trees growing out of the remains. I so appreciated the way this temple was restored leaving many of the trees in place that have taken over parts of the temple. we spent a lot of time here and appreciated the unique feel of this place. don't miss it!

Amazing!. I really loved this place, it is beyond any wonder I ever imagine. How the trees grew up out of the building? The combination of human and nature power made the site so special. It is a harmonious construction to me rather than a ruin or devastating. Definitely worth a visit!

Deep roots are not reached by frost. The amazing temple surrounded by deep giant roots. It just remarkable! I wonder how it's possibly happen in the past. Did they plant it into each temple for the worship? And the point is how come the plant can grow on the stone? Huh..
The "Tomb Raider" temple. Covered in massive fig tree growth, very cool. See my Angkor Wat review for more. Try to avoid midday so you can avoid the crowds and the worst heat.

Walk in the jungle. Amazing. The temple was busy but there were still plenty of places you could wonder off and pretend to be Indiana Jones.
Well worth the visit.
Giant Tree Roots. Affectionately know by the locals as "Tomb Raider" because of the movie, you'll be amazed the huge trees with roots that dwarfs even a giant.

A must visit. The temple is surrounded by sapong trees which made this place so mysterious outstanding.
Don't miss the Tomb raider's scene.
overcrouded. To many People here. This is now a Mass Tourism side. Don't go if you are looking for the nice quite unique experience, you will be disappointed.

Waw, but restauration works in progress. In my opinion, one of the top places in Angkor. The trees growing over the walls are amazing. But as in Angkor Wat, restauration works are in progress, and it might spoil your pictures. But of course, nobody comes to Angkor only for the pictures... Well, I do since its the second time we visit Angkor...
My favorite Temple. Great place for photos and to visit in the afternoon. There are lots of trees to protect you from the strong sun. Bring bug spray.

Worth the visit!. The temple is in the middle of Angkor National Park, within the jungle and the jungle has been reclaiming the temple since it was abandoned.There's lots of great photo opportunities, however this temple is busier some of the others, primarily due to it being the "Tomb Raider" temple, where one of the scenes was shot.There was some restorations ongoing when we were there in November 2012 and it appears they'll be ongoing for some time but didn't take away from the mystery/history of the ruins!A fee is charged for entry to the Angkor Park, one day for $20 and $40 for 3 days!

Lovely!. This temple wasn't offered as a "must see" by our tuk tuk driver who is used to driving tourists around the temple track, but we definitely would recommend visiting here, it's stunning and we actually enjoyed exploring the broken ruins more than Angkor!

Land of the Tomb Raiders. It's just amazing to see mother nature at work among the ruins of man's endeavors.The huge roots of trees growing over the ruins of the temples here gives you the feeling as if you're taken back in time. Ever wonder why part of the film "Tomb Raiders" was filmed here?

One of the highlights. Definitely best to go and see for sunrise. Whilst everyone else is off at Angkor Wat we had Ta Prohm pretty much to us and 5 other couples. The light breaking through the trees and the ruins along with the birds and animals out in the early morning before all the tourists scare them away makes for a very special experience. Be sure to have a guide to explain everything to you - it is well worth the money.

A mix of human-made and natural wonder.. I love this temple because of its condition of apparent neglect. It is not fully cleared and fully restored as with other Angkor temples. Ta Prohm maintains its romantic, ruined atmosphere amidst the tall trees which intertwine with the temple's structure. However, there are some restorations on-going to prevent an absolute decline of temple. A main restoration project is being done at the Hall of Dancers east of the temple --- just a fair warning so you wouldn't be surprised with the presence of cranes, heavy machinery, and frames at the eastern part of Ta Prohm. The traditional tour route of the temple is by going from west to east of the temple. That's great if you want to start with Ta Prohm early in the day and then go around the Big Circuit counterclockwise for the rest of the day and then stopping by Phnom Bakheng for the sunset --- a day's tour idea for you there. (Note: If you plan on doing this, have your driver leave you at the west side of Ta Prohm and make your driver wait for you at the east side of Ta Prohm.)Another route goes from east to west of the temple. Since the temple is oriented east, it's like entering through the real entryway of Ta Prohm. If you don't have much time to visit (less than 1 hour), follow the tour route as laid out. If you have about 1-2 hours or more for your visit, explore the temple where only a handful of tourist goes, i.e. stray away from the tour route. It's really a great experience as you see a more quiet and more abandoned part of the temple.In Ta Prohm, do not miss taking great pictures of scenery protected from the sun by a canopy of tall trees. Sometimes, rays of sunlight would escape from this canopy and put a tower or part of a temple under a spotlight. Also, make your imagination run wild when trying to view the roots which tangle up with the structures. They sometimes make funny human anatomies. Have fun with them!Ta Prohm is definitely not to be missed because of its unique feature of apparent neglect. It's one of the top Angkor Archaeological Park sites you must visit other than Angkor Wat, Bayon, and Banteay Srei.

Love the tree roots tangled in the stone. It's probably a shame that everyone knows this as the one used in Tomb Raider, as the temple itself is spectacular. Tree roots wind through the stone, if they remove the roots the stone collapses so they are part of one another now.

Atmoshpere Galore. We LOVED this temple - after exploring a few in the region this one to use definitely had the most atmosphere. If you only have time to do one temple this is he one I would recommend.It is wild and dramatic - an excellent easy walk from one side of it through to the other.

Massive trees. This place is overgrown by trees over the stone. Currently being restored but still worth a visit. You can see the unrestored bits and compare them to the restored parts. You can still find a quiet spot to reflect here about the magnificent history of the Khmer.

Awesome. You have to see Angkor temples for yourself - words cant explain. Consider going in a quieter season as it can get really busy. We went with 'Go Asia Travel' - having an english speaking tour guide and airconditioned car was a win.

Don't miss this!. This was my favorite temple - I got there at 5:30AM ahead of the crowds and i had it to myself - see my youtube channel at http://www.youtube.com/my_videos?feature=mhee this is mystical and divine - make sure you visit early before the masses of people come - its worth getting up early to see this. I loved the trees growing out of the temples. And you will too.

Very beautiful. Lara Croft was here.. You kan make reservation true a travelagency but better is to do it with Tsoi. He speaks English, has a car for 4 passengers, airco and cool water. His phonenumber: 01/7976308. You can also "rent"him for other trips. I used him as a private driver for 12 days (1.200 km). He's not expensive and reliable.

Absolutely amazing except for the crowds.. This was easily my favorite temple. I even felt Ike going back to take a look at it again. This is widely known as the tomb raider temple and attracts people by the droves. I think this was probably the second most crowded because there is so much to photograph and it is a very large complex making it easy to miss parts of it. There are a few places that really attract people to take pictures and you will need to wait in line for your turn. This is a definite must see even if you only have one day

This stands out unique!. Again, the stone work looked stunning. But more amazing was the fact that for 100s of years these temples were lying inside thick forest unknown to the world and enormous trees have engulfed all these temples!
The temple with the big roots. I was very impressed by the size of the roots and knowing that the film Tomb raider with Angelina Joli was recorded there.

The Jungle's Power. Probably the most interesting temple because one directly sees the power of the jungle with the ficus trees. This temple is the classic tourist photo and, of course, made more famous thanks to "Tomb Raider". We loved the "untidiness"!

Wonderful place with a lot of people.. It is just as you expected it to be, except for the crowds. Don't even dream to get that picture of you alone, if you get lucky you will get it with a couple dozens of Chinese tourists. However, the place is amazing.
Temples with Trees growing out of them. This place is unbelievable and is well known from the movie "Tomb Raider." The scenery is jaw-dropping and a must see.

would be real great if not so crowded. there're only few sites at the complex where you can see how the jungle embraces and swallows up the ancient walls, just a few places can give the sense of a mirracle, jumping into the picture, you know. Ta Prohm could be that place, if not for crowds that seem to be there around the clock. So I guess 7 30 in the morning would be the best time may be.. but then again, there's Preah Knan - the best morning spot, nothing could beat that one.

Awesomeness!. This was the first temple we saw in Siem Reap. I wanted to see it due to the filming of Tomb Raider there, but what we saw and experienced was so much more. The 500 year old trees growing over the tops of the temple were truly incredible! Loved this place!
Magical. This was certainly teh high light of our visit to Siem Reap.. I truely enjoyed the mystifying experience...

A ruddy marvel. I say again - these folks were sensationally clever, ingenious, resourceful and incredibly determined.
A mere thousand years ago and still in this condition. Surrounded by incredibly fertile Tropical Rainforest. Staggering.
Our favourite temple we visited, even when we were temples out!. A must see even in the heat. Take water with you and enjoy the sights. Beware of the crowds and just o with the flow
tomb raider temple. loved this place- even with loads of tourists milling around and scaffolding every where while some renovation work was ongoing

a real jungle experience. It is everything the guide books tell you, i.e. covered in vines and trees growing out of the temples. Try and go when the tour buses are not there otherwise you get lots of (disrespectful) people shouting and taking photos. Lareg heads at the North Gate are worth seeing.

awesome. Just as awesome os seen in Tomb Raider. With it's status quo maintainance, seing the temples as they were found makes one feel like an explorer oneself. A temple to excite the children's imaginary, and stunn the grown-ups.
Possibly overrated. 12 years ago it was covered in trees and quiet. Now it is cleaned up and crowded. Still an enigmatic place, but if you are short of time, don't prioritise it.

a must see travel experience!. this was the second temple in my tour itinerary, and again i was lucky enough to avoid the crowd and heat of the sun. i was overwhelmed by the fusion of nature and man made structures that took hundreds of years to develop. again i want to stress the importance of getting a guide, the angkor experience will be totally incomplete if you dont know the history of the khmer people, plus the guide will highlight the most interesting parts of the temples so your time will be maximized.

Should not be missed!. Wander around the outside and see the massive trees spanning the walls, then head inside for more amazing photo opportunities if you can get a clear shot through the crowds. Still really worth while!!

One of the best of the smaller temples. You can't fail to love this combination of ancient architecture and art and jungle. Now being heavily restored but still with those famous giant trees growing out of the stones in many places.
amazing temple. By far our favorite... so integrated to nature. Beautiful, and a great spot for pictures! Have been there twice, and still the same amazement
Very cool!. A must-see temple in Angkor... shame it was very crowded at the time we arrived there (around 3pm)...
Amazing-Jungle Temple. Its mind boggling to see what trees can do and how they live with their roots climbing all over this ancient temple! Still being reconstructed but another must visit..
Great for pictures!. Good temple for pictures. Lots of trees- nice and shady. Go early or late to avoid crowds that will be at Angkor Wat.

Trees!. This is where you will most closely see how the temples looked when they were first revealed to westerners. The trees growing on the structures are amazing and you will really get a feel of stepping into an ancient world.

The Trees are Winning !!!. When we were here there was major renovation work going on so plenty of scaffolding and machinery operators which did ruin the mood for me. I can see the beauty however so it will be good to come back in a few years when the scaffolding has been removed. Still very beautiful and the trees are definitely winning the battle to take over the ruins.

Very impressive but too many large tour groups. I am not sure i have seen bigger crowds at an attraction than at this temple except Disney land! The temple is very beautiful and the trees over growing the temple make for some amazing views. The Japanese tour groups are so large that if you try to get past them it is near impossible so you often have to stand and listen to the tour in Japanese before you can move on. There is currently some building work going on here which also alters the experience somewhat.

2nd visit!. Still love this temple! Unique blend and coexistence with nature! But this time there was more construction-renovation so taking pictures require much patience as tourists take their turns at choice spots.

Stunning. The fig trees are truelly amazing, sadly it is packed with tourists, especially near the area where Angelina Jolie filmed Tomb Raider, but still worth fighting through the crowds to have a look. Other trees on the outside with hardly any tourists is also just as impressive.
Beautiful, but crowded. Not sure what the ideal time to see Ta Prohm would be, but I'd recommend going then! We loved it but felt rushed due to all the crowds.

Favourite !. Best temple in the area. Absolutely beautiful but of course there are big crowds. It's lovely to just wander around and I love how the trees are growing amongst the temple walls. If you only go to one temple , go here!
Tomb raider style. Find the special entrance, Buddha face hidden in the tree, well done to the Japanese, Swiss and Indians for supporting the maintenance efforts.

Big tree on top of temple.. Is a short walk into it. You be surprised to see a very big tree with roots covering the temple beneath it. Nature is so great. It took so many years to make it happened. Tomb Raider was filmed here. Certain parts of temples are upgrading so not much too see inside.
Amazing. As much as Angkor Wat is considered a wonder, for me this temple where the jungle has started to grow over these ancient ruins, is beautiful beyond words.
Get there early!. This site gets very busy with hoards of tour groups. We recommend arriving as early as possible, or taking advice about the best time to visit.

Nature always wins. When you see the trees that appear to have grown out of the stones at this temple it is an amazing sight. The temple is being renovated and although the temple itself is not as impressive as some of the others it is the way that nature has forced its way onto this temple that makes it so amazing. A very heavily visited site. Go first thing in the morning (at sunrise if possible) or last thing at the end of the day for fewer tourists.

One of a kind within the main temples. Don't miss this. Angkor Wat ranked number one with me but this placed an admirable second. If you get there very early (i.e 6am) this is the most atmospheric place in the temple complex. Some of the ruined temples up the back of the complex will make you think you're the first explorer on the ground there. The trees growing from the temples are gigantic and really helps to harness the age of these places when you consider how long the rainforest took to grow within them. Unmissable, go after sunrise at Angkor Wat for one of the mornings of a lifetime.
worth the visit. Another of the fantastic temples in the area.Every one one is worth the visit.The workmanship and masonry work of the workmen is just sensational

Sometimes Mother Nature Wins. You may have seen the pics before: An eerie setting....an ancient temple made of stone blocks, crumbling, in ruins; covered by moss; taken over by twisted, giant serpentine roots, of the tropical rainforest.That is Ta Prohm, another one of the many Hindu/Buddhist temples around Seam Reap, Cambodia.A tale of the age-old conflict between human spirit and Mother Nature. The difference being, for once, the grand old lady wins. And, for once, we are glad modern humans didn't remove the trees to "restore" the temple. That would have removed the escence, the beauty, of Ta Prohm as it is now. Not that it is physically possible, anyway. If they try to remove all the roots, the temple would probably disintegrate and fall down flat. Advice to visitors: wear good walking shoes. Need to have good stamina. It will be hot and humid, so wear light clothing and bring a lot water to drink Maybe no need for a hat, since the canopy of the rainforest mostly shields out the sun. Be careful if bringing children. Most of all, ensure bring along a good camera. The pics are worth keeping a lifetime.

Tomb Raider. We had to visit this temple because of all the hype with the movie! Plenty of photo opportunities with the famous tree and the enormous roots. In fact the whole temple is surrounded by absolutely gigantic trees and the biggest and longest roots seen anywhere. No sign of Angelina but still visually stunning!

Spectacular. Great trees tower over the temple ruins, their roots holding them in a deadly strangle while lichen and creepers tangle with the reliefs on the walls. Left to the clutches of nature and a living jungle, Ta Phrom makes a spectacular sight. Today, it is more popularly known as the Tomb Raider temple -- a name that had stuck after it became the location for the film Lara Croft: Tomb Raider. Ta Phrom is a must visit.

tomb raider here I come.... Just want to channel your inner Lara Croft, this willl definately get you in the mood!!
Amazed that you are still able to climb all over the temple and in the tree...do it quick before OHS & preservation goes mad in SE Asia!!
Temple highlight. The best temple which we saw late in the day when the light was superb. Real Indiana jones experience

Where the trees meet the rocks. Interesting architecture, loved the way the trees intertwined with the temple structure. Several parts were cordoned off as some of the rocks had collapsed, so be careful when walking through the temple passageways. It was surprisingly comfortably cool in the shaded areas. Pleasant relief from the hot sun! :)

Restoration ruins the mystery at present. It is of course famous, the trees have taken back their territory and they look beautiful doing it around the crumbling stones. Unfortunately there is reconstruction and restoration work going on at present and so it was loud, crowded and lots of areas were cut off. Plan your timing, go before 7am if you can (before construction crews get there) and I am sure the mystery will return. I still loved it, but my guide took me to some not so popular areas of the temple and so I got to experience the wonder...

tree-huggers paradise. so you want to see what happens to a temple overwhelmed by 300-year old trees? Dramatic, photographic, and I'm glad they just left one of these temples to the elements and Mother Nature.
Wow!!!. We went here at 6am which was such a good thing to do before the coach tours go! It also wasn't too hot or crowded. It was AMAZING!!! where Tomb Raider was filmed.

My favourite temple. We are able to see the way the huge trees have re-taken over this temple, reminding us that even the greatest achievements of man are nothing compared to the force of nature. I could spend hours in this temple just soaking up the atmosphere.

Oh dear. Our third visit and our most disappointing. It hasn't withstood the onslaught of so many tourists clambering over it and is not a patch on how it was in just 2009/10. Now with areas fenced off, cranes etc etc it isn't the same any more.

A must. An excellent introduction to the magnificent collection of temples in Siem Reap, offering a historical perspective of how the jungle overtook tyhe structures. Just as others have suggested, get there early before the buses. a car and guide and a 7 am pick up from Happy angkor wat tours worked for us.
Lost. Wonderful place. Go early or late to avoid the crowds. Must for photographers. Good place to work on your HDR.

If you feel like a tomb raider. Immerse yourself in a wonderful historic site. Congratulation to the Kingdom Of Cambodia government for its effort to restore the site and restore it to the past glory.

The original 'Jungle Temple' familar to all Tomb Raider fans!. Possibly the most 'picturesque' of the early temples in the region, dating back to the 12th/13th Century, left largely as it was found & now overgerown with jungle vines & trees.
Perfect. This was my personal favourite, you can explore most areas and find secluded spots for good photo opportunities. There's a lt of construction going on, but this doesn't spoil the experience.

Tomb Raider - amazing!. Although by far the most crowded and touristy temple, this one cannot be missed. With the huge trees breaking away at the temple, it is beautiful and great for photos. Just be patient as there will be swarms of Chinese tourists coming off buses. I suggest going as early in the day as possible and talking to your tuk tuk driver about the best times.
Best typical Angkor Experience. love the place, try to go before or after tourist buses for best photographs and time to explore the temple.

The trees make it unique. On its own, the temple looks like any other in the massive Angkor Wat complex. However, the way the trees from the surrounding forest have invaded and grown into the temple make it stand out. A trip to this temple is not just a history lesson, but also a botanical lesson about the different kinds of trees and their uses in Cambodian life.Some parts of the temple have already collapsed or are on the verge of collapse, thanks to the roots of the trees. Thankfully, some parts have been reinforced, and reinforcements are ongoing to ensure minimal damage to the temple. Do expect to do some navigating around some parts of the temple which have crumbled a little.
More than tomb raider. Wonderful overgrown temple leaves so much to the imagination. We had a wonderful guide who just brought this temple to life for us.

Cranes and lots of tourists make this less fun than 5 years ago. When I saw this temple in 2007 it really captured the feeling from the Tomb Raider movie - the trees growing on top of the forgotten temple. Now it feels completely different, with cranes, walkways and lots of people. There's no real sense of 'discovering' anything.The trees are still amazing, growing on top of the temple, and the temple is worth a visit, but see Beng Mealea to capture that feeling of discovering something special.

Very cool!. Just fun place to see. Love the interaction between nature and man made, nature is winning. Cool because of the movie being filmed there but really much more important for cultural, religious reasons. I hope the restoration does not ruin the feeling of nature reclaiming the site.

Wonderful temple and nature. A place you MUST visit!. Ta Prohm is among the largest of the monuments in the Angkor complex, the in scrimption gives an idea of the size of the temple. The complex included 260 statues of gods, 39 towers with pinnacles and 566 groups of residences. Ta Prohm comprises a series of long low buildings standing on one level, which are enclosed by rectangular laterite wall. The center of the monument is reached by a series of towers connected with passages.Some areas of the temple are impassable and others are accessible only by narrow dark passages. It is recommended to follow the plan with a route and landmarks indicted or to stay with a guide to avoid getting lost.
Temple area taken by jungle. Mysterious abandoned looking place, makes your imagination fly. Many in our group said that this was even more impressive thank Angkor Wat, and I have to agree.

favorite temple, trees wrapped around ruins. To image this temple, think of the movie, Tomb Raider. There are many trees that are wrapped around the ruins. I liked this temple the best, the trees were massive and felt so alive.

a magical visit. Ta Prohm is a series of dark galleries and pillars held hostage under the iron clasp of gigantic roots. The walls are decorated with carvings of sensuous celestial nymphs with smaller roots crawling across them like a rash.

My favorite temple in all of Cambodia. This place totally blew my mind. ok I did have fantasies about pretending I was Angelia Jolie in tomb raider in that one famous door/arch opening with the tree trunk all around it but foolishly I thought that was all there was.I was not prepared for how large and immense is whole place was. I was also not prepared for just how larger than life these trees going growing thru and all around the temple is hard to describe.I recommend you just come and see for yourself.
Under renovation. There are many portions under restoration. But the protruding trees and their gigantic roots are a sight to see.
Amazing tree roots.. Temple is overrun by very large and old trees. Like web of roots.I took few nice photos there. But some spot had queues to take pictures. So need little extra time and patient.

Exquisite temple ruins. This is the probably the most famous temple after the main area of Angkor Wat itself, with tree roots covering many of the temple ruins. Our guide made sure we didn't miss any of the best camera shots, he was an expert and greatly enhanced our visit, much recommended to get the best out of your visit.

Adventure inspiration. This temple oozes inspiration for the adventurous mind. Undergoing huge restoration work, its hard to know if the intertwined tree roots are holding up the temple or damaging the ruins further (i suspect the latter in most areas). This is a true mine field of beautiful ruins to spend your time wandering through and dreaming of what it must of been like a 1,000 years ago. Hope you enjoy it as much as i did!
Magical!. This is one of the best site we visited. I loved it!!! I was impress with every tree I saw that took over the temple.

Impressive tree on temple. We really liked this temple. The overgrowing trees were spectacular.Many spots to take pictures. The temple is being restored carefully by Indie government and Cambodian government. You can climb different parts of the temple. Visit it

Under renovation. There are sections of the temple filled with construction equipment, scaffolding and workers but still an interesting visit. Try and visit when the tour bus crowds are not there if you can. Great to see the trees trying to reclaim the ruins and the holes in the inner walls that used to have gems to reflect the light.
Power of nature. The way the trees are reclaiming the temple is unbelievable and stunning at the same time. It has a different feel than the other temples, more raw, I think.

Beautiful. Another beautiful Angkor temple that was set in the middle of the jungle and was taken over by the forest to give it a very special touch to it.
Amazing carvings here to.
As for Angkor Wat a good local guide is recommended to fully appreciate.

Trees growing on Temples. The trees growing over, on and in the temple is beautiful. The temple was used in the movies (Lara Croft Tomb Raider for one). The strength and resolve of the trees to survive is inspiring.

The Heritage Trees Are The Stars!. Ta Prohm was made famous with Lara Croft movie where Angelina Jolie placed the jasmine flowers at the giant heritage tree that nearly gobbled up the wall of the architecture with its roots. Tourists poured in from all around the world after the movie was published. There was not just one tree but many and they all exuded different styles that merged the ancient temple with natural prowess of the life form. The scene was breathtaking undoubtedly. There was even a small dinosaur engraved on a sandstone wall near the back exit of Ta Prohm! It made one wonders the era when this temple was constructed. Glad to see that the Indian government was joining effort with Cambodian government to restore the ruins in this temple. It would be a massive restoration effort to preserve the architecture without uprooting the heritage trees. Really love the scenes here!

Just what I expected, and more.. Ta Prohm was the temple I was most looking forward to, and it did'nt dissappoint. The tree growth, the ruins, the rebuilding all terrific to explore. Ta Prohm was the most hectic for beggars and peddlers, although they stayed outside the temple in the parking lot only.

Magic Trees. Loved the way the strangler figs wrap their roots around the ruins, sometimes holding the stones together, sometimes breaking them apart, allowing a door here and a façade there to peep out.
Tomb Raider. The amazing tree roots entwined with the stones. The restoration of parts is very sensitive and true to the original. Wonderful atmosphere.

A favourite. Ta Prohm is one of the few temples in Angor where the enormous Silk-cotton trees are still allowed to grow, giving the temple a more authentic feel with made stronger with collapsed corridors and rubble lying around. It was also the temple used in one of the Tomb Raider movies. Overall, Ta Prohm was one of my favourite temples when visiting Siem Reap. Also try to find the smiling figure looking out from under one of the roots without a guide

wow those giant trees! like the Baobabs in the Little Prince!. it is amazing how those trees conquered it all! we were in November and it was hot whether, but we suffered it the most walking around this temple, maybe because of the humidity of the vegetation? if you really want to appreciate it you should star fresh from there in a second visit to Angkor temples!

Tomb Raider!. Wow! what an old place this is! Great photography here and lots to see inside and outside of the buildings that are still standing. Expect to be in here for an hour or so but definitely memorable to see architecture of times gone by and get a glimpse of where Angelina Jolie was :):)
Our favorite. This is definitely the most amazing, so beautiful with the jungle and the forest on the top, every one has to see this temple,do not miss it, you will regret for ever!!!

The best Temple by far. If you only go to one temple go here. It's so genuine and authentic. The trees intertwined with the temple are amazing! After you go here the others will seem average. You can really explore and climb around. It's great!

The jungle temple. One of the most striking temples in Angkor. This time around, the construction was a little off putting, but I always enjoy the combination of natural forces and man made splendor. The jungle seems to be overtaking the grounds in a controlled and beautiful manner as many of the giant trees are growing right out of the walls and embracing them.
special place. This Wat is still surrounded by very special trees, this gives the Ta Prohm a special atmosphere. The Ta Prohm is part off the small route.

Absolutely amazing sights. Dawn chorus is a must to listen to here as well.. Our guide got us to Ta Prohm before anyone else in the morning although we did have to leave Siem Reap at half five! The benefit though was that there were no crowds and pictures taken invariably had no added people. As an extra bonus as we started the tour, the dawn chorus started which was something else to listen to. The area is undergoing some restoration which does slightly restrict the photography but this is essential work that will in years to come, enhance the experience.Some of the root systems are just huge and often gives the impression of unreality. But, this IS real and a must to see.

A temple engulfed buy the forest. Ta Prohm has a different architectural style from Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, both of which featured a central "mountain". The logical thing to do is to visit the other two temples in the complex first. Ta Prohm is flat. Much of it isn't in too great a shape although there is quite a lot of reconstruction under way. One feature that captures everybody's imagination are the amazing sets of massive tree roots that have engulfed much of the structures. These are truly amazing. The jungle is taking over. Wear good walking shoes, take a bottle of water (it can be very hot) and maybe take a light rain jacket too (it can rain too). The limited reconstruction is described on some information boards. They have a long way to go and maybe it is just fine as it is. A visit to the Angkor National Museum in Siem Reap will prepare you for your visits to the temples.

Magical. Certainly a great temple to see. Unlike the other temples the most striking thing here is seeing nature reclaim its turf. It is a must see but the only consideration to keep in mind is that it can get crowded because everyone tends to follow the same path to view the temple and tours get in the way. Based on that it is ideal to see it very early in the morning which has the added advantage of the light; or even at noon (is surrounded by the jungle so the sun is manageable). Endless opportunities to get great pictures of the trees and since it is rather small, if it is not too crowded you can explore it in depth.

A tree + a temple = fantastic viewing. Visited this area of temples etc and this was by far the one I loved the most. There is something about those big roots wrapped around the buildings! It's an interesting site and you will get some great photographs. Loved my visit here, well worth the trip.

Gorgeous temple with surreal atmosphere!. This temple should be seen early morning. There is no sunrise here but the atmosphere in the morning is magical and you can get some beautiful pictures before all the tourist groups hit it. And believe me, this temple can get really crowded because of the Tomb Raider fame and also because it is very small. This one has the maximum of the strangler trees. It is a beautiful temple. Feels almost unreal, like you are walking in a dream or something.
The jungle temple. Another fascinating piece of antiquity which is most notable for the way in which the natural environment has reclaimed the site.

Certainly Memorable..... The giant old trees adds character to the temple. Just amazed seeing this trees still living in this age. This is seeing nature at its best...
Had an early lunch so we can visit this place during lunch time and less crowd.
This you have to se. For me this is the temple you have to visit.Here you can se the firht between nature and the temple.It give great vieuws

one of my favorite temples. I thought this temple had a lot of character and shouldn't be
missed. The tree roots are amazing and I can see why several movies have been filmed there.

Unique experience. Very powerful trees!! it's a must go spot. You can never find something similar to this elsewhere. It's very beautiful, and unique. It's more about the trees then the temple, although it's a bit too crowded with tourists.

Film favourite. Although being restored when we visited in March 2012 the site does not dissapoint and its quite clear as to why it has been a movie set. Appeared almost engulfed by the jungle in part yest plenty to see and experience.
Tree vs. Temple. Ta Prohm is one of the temples that you can see tree vs. stone playing out with the tree winning. Active reconstrucion going on with this temple but still worth the visit.

Tomb Raider!. One of the must see temple after Angkor Wat. Your trip is incomplete if you disregard this place. It is living up the the Tomb Raider hype. Seeing how the trees conquering the old temple is a sight to behold.

Forget the time. We now understand why it's among the must-see temples. The giant trees growing from and over the rubble are astonishing. It's like being transported to another world. It's a pity that some areas had to be roped off to regulate the crowd. We would have wanted to visit it a less crowded time but that's difficult considering its popularity
the best. We got struck by the beauty of this temple, we spent hours looking at it in admiration . try to get there in the late afternoon as it might be darker but it is definitely less crowded.

Ahh Ta Prohm, where nature puts you in place. Ta Prohm was the location where Tomb Raider was filmed, but when I was there, I saw something more than the Tomb Raider. I saw how magnificent nature can be, with the trees' roots snaking all around the temple. Some roots were so strong that the tiles came off. These tress are usually 200 years old, and you will marvel at their survivability. Now, who says plants aren't smart?Verdict: Must visit!

worth a visit. As part of a one-day trip to the 3 main temples it was very good. I would not want more than One day!It was also very hot - the trip cost 62$ for my wife and I including a car/driver and guide.

worth a look. As part of a one-day trip to the 3 main temples it was very good. I would not want more than One day!It was also very hot - the trip cost 62$ for my wife and I including a car/driver and guide.
Best of all, in my opinion. Still rugged and barely carved out of the surrounding jungle, the best of the Khmer temples, I think.
Awesome but.... the crane and building work took the shine off a little. Still, once in a lifetime experience that I wouldn't have missed.

Ancient Temples Ta Prohm. You must see these beautiful temples in Ta Prohm. You will be astonished in those temples as if the trees are protecting and holding them to avoid collapse. One of the most visited site in Siem Reap because of its natural beauty and the chilling effect of the environment (you'll have goosebumps). So what are you waiting for go and visit this nice place Ta Prohm Temples.

Best temple. This is the best temple you can visit in the Ankor area. Reason is not its fame due to Tomb raider ind Indiana Jones, but that it is not rebuild in a way like most of the other are.And, best thing, you can climb nearly anywhere you like if you are up for So you have the chance to leave the tourist trail and find your own spots, where you can enjoy the temple in a quite atmosphere, or take pictures without any other people in the way.And if you really need something to smile about, take a few minutes to watch the tourists queuing up for a picture in front of the famous trees on a podium. A must if you are visitng Ankor

Very crowded but worth a visit. Because you have to stick to certain walkways, it can get very crowded here. I don't know when the best time of day to go is, but if you don't like crowds go to Beng Mealea instead. It has many of the same characteristics but is MUCH less busy.
Impressive. It was under construction the last time I went, but still very beautiful and I love the big huge trees they have there.

You may remember this from Tomb Raider. This temple is overgrown with big trees which have worked their way into the rocks and broken up many of the walls and towers. On my first visit (many years ago) we got there during lunch so had the place all to our self making plenty of photo ops. On my most recent visit the temple was much more crowded and there is a lot of construction equipment around as they are working on restoration. This is still a fantastic temple to see and a must visit while in Siem Reap.You may also remember this one from the Tomb Raider movie.

Temple in the jungle. Probably our favorite - get your tuk tuk driver to drop you off at the west gate and then pick you up at east gate. Lengthy walk to temple but you are entertained by a musical band of amputees = donations optional - some great photo opportunities - much of temple is overgrown by trees- lengthy walk out and it can get very hot -ake a drink

perfect wedding beetween construction and nature. This temple is very nice because they let it more or less the way it was when they found it. Enourmous trees are growing everywere and give to the place a magical atmosphere.

Wow!. We visited about 6.30 am and it was amazing to have this wonderful temple almost to ourselves. It is a really different atmosphere to the other temples due to the spooky trees taking over. We loved it.

Are they aliens?. A short walk through the trees observing amazing butterflies takes you to an awesome temple complex, straight out of an adventure movie set. Giant trees grow on top of it and though it. Their thick tentacles crushing the walls. I felt that if time could be speeded up you would actually see the roots move. It gets quite crowded and thus hot and stuffy so go early.

The trees are out of this world. Angkor in general is beautiful but Ta Prohm was my favourite temple! We had a great time with my kids & husband not only discovering the temple but having fun and playing with the trees and the tree roots!The one watch out is that Cambodia is just opening to the world and they still don't know how to preserve this world wonder... basically you can walk, jump, or touch everything and wIth the number of tourist coming every year this place will lose its magic and will be eroded.Reminds me of Machuppichu in the 90's when you were allowed to touch everything but now is all protected to preserve this place for future generations

Nature vs culture. A beautiful site with nature climbing over the walls of the temple. Easily a 1 1/2 hour visit. Seemed like less tourists than Angkor Wat. Don't worry about trying to get the 'tourist shot' set photo on the platforms, amazing photos can be ahad around every corner.
Amazing. if you're walking alone... i'm sure you'll feel like wakling into an haunted house. some part of the temple will be very dark.

Simply Incredible. It is indeed difficult to describe the indescribable feeling one gets while visiting this fascinating temple. It will pull you in with its powerful mysterious climate and atmosphere. The power struggle and strange symbiosis at the same time between the jungle and the former glory of the temple. This place should not be missed. Even if you have no time to read about Ta Prohm interesting history and its golden age - just come and look! You will be tempted to take countless pictures. The sights of this temple remain in your memory for ever.
Stunning! Must see. A marvel of man and testament to a King's ego. Just a shame there were too many of us pesky tourists.

"tombraider" temple. All the tour guides and guide books refer to this temple as the "tombraider" temple. I have never seen the movie, but the force of the jungle is pretty amazing. Definitely worth a look, but not too much time is needed here. We went early in the morning, so there was less crowds.

You must make time to visit. An immpressive temple amazing photography opportunites especially if you go different times of the day. However as with all the other temples if you visit between 12.15 - 13.45 it is much quieter

Amazingly beautiful!! Just like in Tomb Raider!!!. This was by far our group's favorite temple. It was absolutely beautiful and the rain just made the whole experience even more memorable. Expect to take A LOT of pictures here. The only negative was part of the temple was undergoing some renovation so the construction site was not so pretty to see.

The trees are the stars. The trees are the main attraction in this fantastic place. As with other recent reveiwers the renovations happening at the moment detract slightly from the experience but it is one not to miss. It was a little busier than some of the other temples but this is the place that you will get your most spectacular photos.

Beautiful place. It's not the temple that takes your breath away here, but the forces of nature! The trees growing inside and around the temples are massive and so majestic you just can't take your eyes off of them. It can get pretty full here, so make sure you don't enter when there is a travel group arriving. ;-)
The Big Tree on the Temple. This temple I used to see on the picture only and now I see the real temple with the big tree on top of the temple roof. Very amazing to visit this fantastic temple.
power of nature. i like how they are letting the trees grow the way they are growing - even if it means that some structures will be destroyed. this is a display of how powerful nature is

If only they had left it. This is still a really atmospheric temple, but recent restoration work and the introduction of wooden walkways and safety ropes detract a little from the 'wild' temple I remember. I am sure it's necessary to preserve it, but it was so much better before

Would have been perfect without the renovation scaffolding.... My joint-favourite Angkor temple because of the magnificent sight of Man and nature twisted together in (dis)harmony. Too bad there are some major renovation works going on. But still worth a visit to see the huge roots and trunks encircling the ancient temples.

Tomb Raider temple. When we 1st arrived, our tour guide have told us what temple we will be visiting since we have limited time so we could only visit 3 temples and this temple is one of them. first reason, because tomb raider we filmed here and second because this temple were built in a tree. well not actually in a tree but after the temple been built there are trees grow on top of this temple. Every temple here have their own uniqueness and been built by different ruler. Understand from our guide, this temple built especially for mother.

It just roots.... but a pretty one!. Comparing to others templates in Angkor Watt temple complex, i like this temple the most. A bit cooling here & peacefully as It's surrounded by many tress. But during our visit, major re-construction on-going so to we need to wait in line just to snap our photos at this super famous roots!

Eerily beautiful. We visited this site expecting to see throngs of people but it was actually pretty quiet. It was kind of eery looking at the faces in the stone and even more eery when my camera's 'smile feature' recognized the faces smiling back at me!! Quite amazing!

Trees. That was the most interesting thing was to photograph ancient banyon trees growing into the ruins. I would strongly suggest you go early to beat the crowds and the heat. Get back to the peace and quiet of your hotel pool for an afternoon rest. I found tuk tuk drivers want lots of money to take you to the sights. They should have a better Transfer system.
It didn't disappoint. Ta Prohm was my reason for visiting Cambodia and it didn't disappoint. I loved the huge tree roots intertwined among the temple walls. Don't miss it.

my favorite from Angkor Wat. this temple is just great, to see how the nature grows amount it! how the trees combine with the walls! Woooooooooooooow... it's also the temple where Angelina Jolie filmed Tomb Raider, this makes it even more attractive for tourists :))

Ta Prohm. I had no idea there was so much at this site. I had seen pictures of the one tree that climbs down the walls, but there is so much more at this site after seeing that first tree. It just seems to go on forever. Wonderful place, but very crowded with tour groups.

One of the most beautiful temple on the planet!. Charming, interesting, stunning & amazing temple. Temple with the tree root on the side, great mixed & match between nature & man made. One of the must temple in Angkor Thom, you can't miss!
Mysterious and incredible. This temple has a very different feel from Angkor wat. You will be missing a lot if you don't visit this temple. Bring lots of water and mosquito repellant!

Ta Prohn. This old temple is in the process of being restored. But the giant tree roots that are holding the structure together are very impressive. The site was used in making the movie Tomb Raider and you have probably seen pictures of it before. After parking the car it is about 1/4 mile to the site. The peddlers are a pain the in the parking lot. A word to the wise, do not buy anything at these places. In Siem Reap is every kind of trinket you could possible ask for. If you give one of these people money you will be mobbed. Keep your hands away from your wallet.

Wondrous. Like Angkor Wat, TP is a beautiful location that should be on everyone's bucket list. My words cannot do it justice. I suggest you research the temples and try to find a way to go there. You will not be disappointed. It may very well change your life.
Ta Prohm is awesome. Like - Tree branches blend with temples - man made and natural combination. Dislike - the weather is too hot
Amazing, beautiful, great photo taking opportunities. My favorite temple/ruin of them all. They are in the middle of restoring it, but the construction didn't take away from the beauty of the ruins.
Jungle palace. Great place with unique atmosphere, unfortunately, there is huge renovation work going on so it is disturbing to enjoy in full. Should come back in 2 years or so...

elevation. if only i can fly, if only i can climb the highest vantage point on this ta prohm temple, i can considered my self adventure is complete and i can die in peace. u2 on tomb rider movie sings elevation, and it is the same experience you can enjoy here. the scenery, the detail and the ruin of the temple will elevate your soul. some parts of the temple is being restored at the moment and might bother your trip for short period, but it wont affect the beauty of this temple. its like every single shot you took is nice!

work in progress. its a joint conservation effort with India and its a very cool place..really gives a sense of being in the back of beyond..the many years of neglect give the place an aura..no wonder angelina jolie loves the place!!haha if thats ever a reason to visit a place..but seriously its good!!
Lush, tropical setting. A very attractive temple, lush tropical setting. Go early or late to miss the crowds and avoid the hottest part of the day.
The tombraider temple. Fantastic, with all the ancient trees growing through the newly restored areas of the mighty temple.

Mystical. Ta Prohm seems to be from and of another world. I have visited here over a period of years and, once you break away from the crowds (as you near the entrance to the actual structures, head off to the right side) it is like like entering wonderland.Every place you look provides another unusual view - your camera will get quite a workout.

Seeing is believing. To believe what Ta Prohm has to offer, you have to be there. One of the best temples in the Angkor Wat complex, Ta Prohm is a must visit. As an Indian, the site was more than special to me. The restoration work of the temple is being conducted by Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) and I feel, they are doing a great job. If you are photo lovers, then, this is a must visit place. The location is exotic and has got various points where you can get beautiful angles. As a solo traveler, I was deeply touched thinking about the structures in it's erstwhile glory and imagining how such temples must have been built. Siem Reap is one of the safest cities I have ever been to. This adds to the beauty of this place. But when you visit Siem Reap, make sure that you have at least 3 full days at your disposal. If not, you will come back feeling cheated.

Lara Croft Territory. This was brilliant. We loved climbing, walking and discovering the wonders of these temples/structures that have been invaded by the huge and powerful vegetation. I felt like a kid again. You could not possibly travel to Cambodia and not visit this site.

Magical. If there was one word to describe it, it's magical. It truly is. It makes you feel like fairies are going to appear in a few minutes. The gnarled roots around the structure was really beautiful. There's nothing I can compare it to. It was even better than how it looked in the film.
Overgrown wonder. I loved the overgrown nature of this site. It's not a huge place, and is easy to wonder around and find a quiet spot away from the crowds. Highly photogenic!
Paradise for explorers. We would recommend people to visit during the green or rainy season, less people and more nature! Just pack a waterproof camera and some rain gear!
Trees growing from the Towers. Loved this temple. Jungle overgrowth with the massive fig and silk cotton trees grow from the towers and corridors
My Favourite of the Temples. Our guide took us here last and he knew what he was doing. I found this the most atmospheric and fascinating of the temples in Siem Reap. LOVED IT:)

Recovered from the jungle. Ta Prohm is one of the Angkor temples in which you can see how this has been recovered from the jungle. Popularised by Anjelina Jolie, this is an excellent temple to visit. She has done much to improve the economy of Siem Reap.The Achealogical Survey of India has done a good job in preserving the trees as well while restoring the temple. Very popular with the tourists and is usually crowded
Incredible site.. Thre banyon trees are amazing and surreal. Not repaired at all, so you can see what it looked like when it was found.
superb!!. - I am very very amazed by the beautiful and humongous tree roots and the trees itself. - Visit the whole place, not only the site of the "tomb raider" tree. It really worth it!!

Fantastic temple. We had a wonderful time here, although we arrived just before lunch and it was incredibly warm! Lovely security officer took a photo of our group of 4 so we have lovely memories of this particular temple! Highly recommended.
Amazing. Of all the Temples I visited this was my favourite most atmospheric with amazing trees roots growing out of structures.

Spoiled a bit by the restoration work. Still well work a visit but the restoration work, which is necessary, spoils some of the views of trees growing out of the stonework for which the temple is most noted.

Favorite. We loved the adventure of this site. All the temples at Angkor are over the top. Beautiful, thought provoking, interesting and the like, but Ta Prohm really had me going. The clash of nature mixed with human architecture really was fantastic. Our guide got us there at just the right time, 2.5 hours before sunset. The crowds were minimal and the photos fantastic. We had the place almost to ourselves for about an hour, then the crowds started to show as the sun started to dip. But too close to sunset and the trees start to swallow the good light. So it is not so good at sunset itself and the mosquitos started biting as well, so we began to leave. It was a perfect time spent and highly recommend. Do not miss it if you are in the area.
Treeeeemendous temple. Well you just have to see it. The mixture of nature and ancient endeavors is magical. More than just a film set. Much more.
the jungle fights back. A photographer's paradise. The colour and the temple/jungle relationship really kick's the imagination into gear.
Best temple to see. Real 'lost city' feel about the place. In my opinion the most memorable temple in the region. Its an easy walk compared to others, and shaded by the rain forest.

eaten by the jungle. Ta Prohm is the temple complex that is famous because it is overgrown by mature trees. (and there is of course the Angelina Jolie tree from Tomb rider)The complex is in the middle of the jungle and is ideal to visit at the middle of the day when all the other attractions are in full sun and too warm.The atmosphere is dreamy and it is amazing to think about how long it would have taken the trees to grow that big.Some trees are currently being cut down because they risk to destabilise the temple complex.

A must-see, but you need to be fit. Ta Prohm and the associated sites are one of those "top 10 must-see before you die" places. However, the climate is very hot and humid, and and good deal fo walking and climbing is needed to really appreciate the sites... so do this while you are younger and reasonably fit. Also, adapt to the climate - do your sight-seeing very early in the morning, then head back to your hotel and take it easy for the rest of the day. Use the evenings to explore around town.

A must-see!. Obviously, this is where Tomb Raider was shot. Definitely a must-see aside from the Angkor Wat! Don't forget to visit this when you visit Siem Reap. When we went here, it was currently under construction in preparation for the peak-season. But it was still worth the walk and sweat for hours. Just wear comfortable shoes for walking and enjoy the rest. It's amazing how the trees grew that huge and slowly eating the temples, just a perfect example of man vs nature. See it for yourself!
Breath taking beauty. An amazing temple you can only truly appreciate when you are standing on the roots looking up..make this a priority in your agenda along with bay on..

Wat another Wat. Truly amazing place. The trees have managed to usurp the temple and have become an attraction in its own right. The access to the place is easy although if it rains be prepared to walk through a quagmire. You enter one way and exit another straight into the hands of the hawkers. The buildings are built to the same design as all the others in Angkor Wat. There are hundreds of these places in Siem Reap so you are spoilt for choice. You could spend a few weeks looking at them. Having said all that, it is a worthwhile see.

Incredible is the only word for this place!. Ta Prohm lived up to its reputation as the most amazing of all the Angkor temples. The fact that it has been left somewhat overgrown with enormous root-trees is what adds to the mystical charm of the place. Photographers could spend all day here, as there are so many potential subjects. This is a good place to take a guide, as Ta Prohm is labyrinthine in nature and there are so many places that could be missed without a guide - such as the echo room and also the "peeking" girl.Biggest drawback to Ta Prohm is its popularity. At times, there are swarms of people crowding into the same places. Photography can be frustrating as many people are waiting to get the same shot. One suggestion is to enter on the "back" side of the temple and go through in reverse. This seemed to make the visit a bit better when we went.

Just like the movies. This place looks like a movie set, and no surprise it has been used as one in Tomb Raider. If you wanted to design a jungle over-run ruined temple, this is what you would design.
A must see temple ruins. The only downside are the crickets!

Trees galore at Ta Prohm. I loved the trees in Ta Prohm. They are just amazing, and are definitely a wonder in themselves. That was the best part of this temple. And there is a famous door which has tree roots all around it in front of which you MUST take a photo of yourself.be careful of the touts who try to sell you books on the temples. They tell you the book is for 1USD but when you get hooked and give them 1USD they very vociferously start to demand another 10USD!! Bargain for the book and a good price for it USD 6 or 7 for one piece.

Awesome! the Temple that time forgot. no wonder they used it for some of the scenes in Tomb raider, a beautiful aura about it!!The beautiful way nature has entwined itself around solid rock, eerie passageways and rocky outcrops, excellent photo opportunities, stunning place

MY VERY FAVORITE!. I felt like Tomb Raider, or Indiana Jones, the whole place is brilliant, and I loved being able to get off of the beaten path and explore a little more whilst climbing all over everything and really experiencing the entire beauty of the place... although some stuff has changed since last here (Oct 2011) they are really working at refurbing it and building it all back up. Either way it is a MUST SEE!!

Fantastic temple and restoration. The huge spung trees that grow throughout this temple add to the display and also decay of the stones in the temple.We've all seen the typical tourist shots in front of the roots of the tree growing over the temple and yes, we did this too... who are we to buck tradition.To think that this was built in the late 12th century is overwhelming, how did they get the stones there, let alone build the areas and carry out all the carvings?Great to see restoration work being carried out, however I fear that it will not be able to keep up with the decay being caused by weather and the vegetation. Looking forward to a revisit in a few years to see how it is all going.
i know it's sad but this is where they shot Tomb Raider. loved all the HUGE trees, twisting and turning everywhere. it was a bit of a maze and i kept getting lost, as per usual.
Tomb Raider. Amazing loved this Temple with all the trees growning thru it, its under restoration posibbly 1/2 way and would love to go back when its finished, It was all we imagined and more
Destroyer. Now i know why i see people sweeping the temple floors all the time. A small seed unattended can uproot the temple ... great site
awe. awe inspiring. brilliant. Did this one early in the morning to avoid the tourist crowds it was great. Some parts are closed for now though.

Magnificent Ta Prohm. For those visiting Siem Reap this place should not be missed. It's an architectural marvel. The best time to go there is early in the morning or late in the afternoon when the weather is not too punishing. The place is a respite from the crowd in the city proper. You could just sit down there for hours and marvel at those great structures. Fabulous!
Beyond belief!. Part of the Angkor complex. The site has been pretty much left to nature, with the huge tree roots taking over, returning the area to the jungle.

Tourist will trample you!. Go first thing! No one ever goes first thing before Angkor Wat! They always start at Angkor Wat and move in a similar pattern! Go first thing in the morning before the tourist over run you! It's amazing! You have to close your eyes and imagine you're Indian Jones! So fun!

Better than Angkor Wat.. Absolutely beautiful! Its smaller and more interesting than Angkor Wat in my opinion. Its was really awe inspiring. If you are limited for time, make sure you make time for this one, it was my favourite thing in Angkor.

Jungle temple. One of the most popular temples with visitors. Mainly as Bayon style. It was modelled on the king's mother. Also well known as Tomb Raider temple. The cross between gorgeous nature and artful architecture makes Ta Prohm one very unique temple to visit. It was actually not only a temple but a monastery also.
The Tree Temple. Made famous in the Lara Croft movie a must visit and a phenomenal battle between nature and civilisation!
Tomb Raider. Loved this place, hasnt been rebuilt, has been left as it was found. Just as I imagined it should be.

Special tour. Really amazed by the trees that have grown on this temple. Was very busy and could easily get lost by the many walk ways. A guide by the name of Ben took me through some small alley ways for some beautiful pictures. Very interesting place and more interesting was that Ben makes $25/mth working 12 hour days. he is the lone income for a family of 5. How much do we take things for granted?

Particularly impressed.. Among the temples of Angkor Wat, we was particularly impressed. Roots of large street clinging to the ruins of a stone like a snake. And put my self in the ruins, I feel the smallness of man. I think everyone is surpised at the appearance, such as the tree swallow, landscapes, trees swallow the temple and statue of Buddha.

Jungle taking over. This jungle is taking over this beautiful temple, with giant trees, plants and moss growing all over it. This was by far one of our favourite temples in Siem Reap, and I preferred it to Angkor Wat. A stunning place to wander around for hours at a time.
