Get here early!. The importance of arriving early cannot be understated as by 7:30am the temple is overrun by tourists. My girlfriend and I went to see the sunrise at Srah Srang but it was cloudy and the hawkers at that particular spot ruin any chance to enjoy the moment. We decided instead to head to Ta Prohm around 6:15am. Best decision we could have made. For the first three-quarters of an hour we only saw four other tourists and essentially had the place to ourselves. The atmosphere was palpable, with an eerie silence amongst the ruins mixing with an orchestra of sounds from the encroaching jungle. Visually it was even more impressive with vast silver roots entangling themselves around ornately engraved stonework. As you explore the labyrinth of doorways and courtyards you can lose yourself in the experience and, for a moment, it feels as if you have discovered these ancient ruins. Arrive after 7:30am though and it will feel more like a theme park.

singular. This was our favorite site, with the possible exception of Angkor Wat itself. Leaving some of the forest incursion into the ruins makes for an amazing atmosphere, and maybe met our expectations/imaginings.

Nature and architecture merging - a marvel. You will never have enough valuable information unless you prepare your homework by yourself before you travel, and you keep guiding your guide. Relying on your guide alone, you will have the impression that since its "rediscovery", the temple was meant to be the future location of the "Tomb Raiders" movie! This is one of those places of "must go" where you have to be well prepared in advance.

Just Amazing. This was my favourite of the many temples in the area. It is very atmospheric and unlike the other temples has been left to be swallowed by the jungle. I went early in the morning and it wasn't crowded at all so I had a good chance to explore the temple without being swamped by tourists. However, after spending around an hour there it really started to get crowded and I was glad I went early. It was interesting to see how the strangler figs and kapok trees have entwined themselves around the ruins, bursting through walls yet protecting them at the same time. The temple is undergoing some repair work and reconstruction but there is still so much to explore. It truly is a 'lost temple.'

Over the top!. This is an absolute must-see and is quite different from the other ruins around Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom - the jungle is pristine and closed around the ruin site and makes the experience and photo ops absolutely stunning.
tourist mad. overun by pushy tourist after the kodak moment ala tomb raider. but a must see. i loved the little band of musicians outside the temple

Crowded & under construction, but compelling. A favorite stop on everyone's visit to Angkor, including Angelina Jolie's - this is the scene you remember from Tomb Raider.There's a bustle of construction activity going on as well, so this is not a peaceful ruin. I'm certain that whatever spirits still linger here have a headache.But I'd still say it's a can't-miss site. The giant roots wrapped around the ruins, though certainly not left in their wild state, are simply marvelous & just plain fun.Like all the other sites around Siem Reap, you're besieged at entry & exit by kids who want to sell you postcards, guidebooks, bracelets, etc. You can probably get the cheapest deals from them, but they should be in school, so save it for a shop in town.

Love this place.... Ta Prohm became famous because of Tomb Raider, but even without the said movie, I truly believe that this place would still be one of best temples to visit when in Siem Reap. I love the fact that nature did take its course when we see the very large roots of those majestic trees on top of the temples. A bit of a downside, the temple was undergoing restoration when we came to visit.

The number one. We visited all the temples in Siem Reap and I have to say that Ta Prohm is the most impressive one. It is difficult to explain why. Some would say it is because Tomb Raider was in there and this is why it feels special. But in fact there is a good reason why the film was made in this one. It has an aura, and you can feel it. You can feel how the dungle tries to overrun human creations....My recommendation, take enough time to explore this one.
So amazing. We got the best pictures here! Make sure and check out the echo chamber where you beat your chest 3, 5 or 7 times - incredible sounding and powerful!

Amazing, worth a visit. Silk Cotton Tree silk floss tree, is the tree roots can penetrate the hair to achieve even destroy the stone structure of the odd tree. In fact, other temple also scattered trees silk floss tree, but Tabu Long does more trees faster to catch up with stones. Tree landmark tree is quite shocking, visitors are scrambling photo. Other tree slightly smaller scale, the power is not small. Lap stroll over to see really fatigued, of course, because the old roots in fact not much aesthetic. Tabu Long Temple is still worth a visit, architectural features, tree and stone of misfortune always is quite eye-catching.
a must visit within Angkor for the pictures. The jungle temple site, made famous where Angelina Jolie filmed tomb raider. Incredible pictures by the contrast of trees and stone

Excellent. Sorry, made a mistake in my previous review as I mixed up places.Start early with this place to avoid the crowd and take less waiting time for photo opps. It was even more exciting since we started our trip with this site.

Nature reclaiming its own. This is the most enthralling site we visited. This ancient monastery is slowly being embraced/strangled by a gigantic complex of cave forming roots, emanating from the aged stately trees within the site.

Restoration on going during my visit. I was amazed by the mesmerizing beauty of nature. The temple was in the jungle and walking through the jungle track and enjoying the tranquillity is such a nice experience. However, the big scale restoration in the temple during end of September 2012 spoilt the visit a little.....

Impressive. One of the main temples on the tours organized by the hotels and guesthouses. It is definitely worth seeing and you should have your camera ready because it is very photogenic and atmospheric.

Roots Roots Roots.................at dusk. After a big dose of Bas reliefs at Angkor our trip to Ta Prohm at dusk was a totally amazing experience. There was no carving which caught my attention at this flat Khmer temple. However this was a totally new ball game with the giant roots of trees everywhere .One tree was even growing on top of the building with its roots keeping the structure together. The fading light added to the eerie atmosphere. This trip gave us a peek into what the other Temples must have been like before restoration workAs the Archaeological survey of India is involved in the restoration work at this site one sees a lot signs in Hindi.
Beautiful. The best temple that I visited on my tour. So picturesque and tranquil. Visited in the middle of the day and was still cool with lots of trees
great. Ta Prohm is the most photogenic plac i've ever visited. I used about 10 gigs of space on this temple alone.
Our favorite temple. My boys (pre-teen and teens) liked this temple the best. It was featured in Tomb Radar, so it peeked their interest. On a temple tour, don't miss this one!
Under construction. This place was so crowded! the trees growing out of the temple were interesting. I haven't seen tomb raider yet, but I will watch it to reminisce!

Ta Prohm. There are boardwalks to guide you around, which is good in a way, but it loses some of its charm as ruins and makes it look more touristy. The trees are still really impressive and you can still walk around off the boardwalks.

Tomb Raider!. It was also very nice to take pictures around the huge roots growing out of the temple, its just that they are still looking to restore them and there are many places that have huge cranes and backhoes hanging around

Amazing. Of all the temples, we found this one the most enchanting with the trees almost trying to reclaim it. The rebuilding work at present does take away that mystic feel, but it is a necessity and they are doing a very good job of it. This is the muddiest of temple locations we come across keeping in mind it was the wet season. Easy to move around, but don't wear your favorite shoes! You will also need to run the gauntlet of people selling the wears inside the actual temple gates which is a bit well, not disrespectful, but you loose that ambience a bit until you get past them. That aside, a must visit!

The best of all the temples. Construction work is going on however it did not take anything away from this amazing temple. There was just an aura about this place and we were glad that we had decided to not miss this temple. It was easy to walk around and not overcrowded . Multiple photo opportunities.

jungle temple. it was nicer back in 2005 when it was stilll much more overgrown and less touristgroups! but still very facinating, peaceful (once the touristgroups are gone) and amazing how nature waits it's turn!

One of my favourite temples. I think it's the Lara Croft thing - this temple is cool.I went recently (for the only time this trip, second time overall) and just loved it. I think I spent about 2 hours going through the entire place and just soaking in the crazy atmosphere with the crumbled walls and tree roots snaking over the bricks.Avoid the tourist route at all costs. It will drive you mental. Go in the north gate (serene in the dry season, quite a fun challenge in the wet season!) to avoid the crowds. After sunrise it's great and there are not that many people around. It gets busy around 8.30, and at 9 the buses arrive.In the main Angkor area - second only to Angkor Wat.
Excellent temple, but lots of tourists. I would recommend this temple for the ambience, but check with your guide to make sure you miss the hordes of tourists! Very atmospheric.

The highlight. Ta Prohm was the highlight of the temples I went to. The way the trees are growing on and through the temple is amazing. I arrived there at about 9am and it wasn't too busy. A couple of tour groups were there but it wasn't too bad.

Magnificent. It was amazing to see this structure still standing with trees growing out of the stones. The trees formed some magnificent views. The carvings on the walls telling a story was amazing. It is great to see that this awsome place and efforts being done to preserve the history and the ruins of this ancient city. We booked a private tour and were able to see many of the temples in Siem Reap and the guide was able to answer the many questions we had while touring through the temples. The temples in Siem Reap is a must see attraction.

A MUST!. We took a tuk tuk to the site and started to make our own way around. A little man non English speaking 'adopted' us and showed us around ... good photo opportunities etc. Took pics of my husband and I. We gave him dollars and we were all pleased. Ta Prohm should be a 'must visit'. It is a magical place.
amazing location. a must see! you'll be amazed on how strong the structure is! imagine a ery huge tree growing though the pieces of stones! am glad efforts are being done to preserve it!

Seems a bit commercial. Lots of construction going on which takes away from things a bit but still spectacular. Also I found the Tomb Raider references tiring. Still, it's beautiful and exotic with the trees growing on everything.
Amazing what nature can do!. This place has been completely taken by nature. The trees have grown into the temple forming some amazing views. The views are fantastic!

Skip the organized tours and book your own. To have the most fun, book a driver and tour through the Ponheary Ly Foundation and allow for spontaneity. My daughter saw boats outside the gates to Ta Prohm and we decided to take a short cruise spur of the moment. 2 hours later we had seen 3 additional temple ruins including a corner fortification temple most tourists never see, learned about the defenses of the ancient city, enjoyed a relaxing boat ride, and had a great time. Thank you Dara (of the 7 Candles Guesthouse and the Ponheary Ly Foundation) for a wonderful tour!

Not Overratted. All of the temples in the Angkor Wat complex are amazing, but Ta Prohm I vote Ta Prohm as the most unique and amazing. There are several passageways you can walk in (sometimes with a few bats up top!) and the tree roots wrap the temple so it looks like artwork. As of September they are doing some restoration on the main part of the temple but it does not take away from the experience.

Look for Lara Croft. This is real unique place to visit. Huge Spung trees are erected on the walls 3-4 meters high. If you enjoy ebout those trees and their occupation, I can recommend you to visit Preah Khan as well

Tomb Raiders Temple!. The juxtaposition of the ancient temples with the ingrowth of the forest amazing! Need time to get good photos as the tours are thick and fast and a picture without other tourists takes some time to achieve. Good photo opportunities around the tomb raider tree but need to be patient as many tourists vying for the photo. There are numerous other good spots to photograph the tree invasion so search around.

all good. as I said in an earlier review ... if you make the effort to get to Siem Reap I reckon the 3 day pass is not enough to take it all in..... perhaps for the younger person it is .. but few hours a day was enough for me .... made it more enjoyable and gave you time to breathe between temples .... this Ta Prom is not an all day affair ... but it is interesting despite that ... like all the ruins .... brilliant for taking the perfect photo .....

Favourite by far!. I could have spend all day at Ta Prohm! It is genuinely a spectacular and beautiful place to behold. Crumbling ruins in the midst of lush jungle, with trees growing amongst the stone. It really was a magical experience. Would visit again in a heartbeat.

Best temple in the area close to Angkor Wat. Very classic Khmer temple in the Angkor Wat Area. A beautiful and moving site where the exuberant jungle nature takes over abandoned ancient civilization temple. Only surpassed by Beng Mealea if you like Jungle Temples.

tomb raiders location!!. i have never visited such an atmospheric site before with its growing kapock trees mingling with the temple brickwork. it was so spooky but most enjoyable - will never forget this experience

Power of Nature!. The enormity of growth of trees over the building is unbelievable.
Over period of time,it shows how insignificant man is against nature.
Fantastic. The first temple we visited at 06:00 there were hardly any tourists. We took fabulous pictures. What a introduction to the temples.

the tomb raider temple. this is the temple made famous for the English movie- the tomb raiders - starring Angelina jollie.some people know this temple by this movie name only.this is a originally Hindu temple ,mostly with lord Shiva.but nothing is there now.this temple is very fascinating ,with towering trees on top of it,roots going around the stones to the ground which in turn creates amazing shapes.these shapes are big hit with the tourists.at present this temple is under restoration by the ASI INDIA, who are doing a commendable job. full restoration may take further years.
Tomb Raiding. The Lara Croft a.k.a Angelina Jolie factor is not the only draw. The temple and its surroundings are simply worth the venture - intriguing, mysterious and magical.

Very crowded but nice sight. Ta Phrom is one of the most crowded temples in Siem Reap. It has the interesting huge trees that clipped the structures but aside from that you'll be annoyed on how crowded it is. They shouldn't have put the platforms in front if the interesting locations, it just destroy its genuine and authentic feel of the place.

Stunning!. This temple, was - BY FAR - the most beautiful one of the bunch we've seen in Angkor.Ta Prohm has an almost magical appeal to it and the old ruins, covered by the outgrown trees is a sight that needs to be seen to believe.While the temple is usually packed with tourists looking for the exact GPS place where "Tomb Raider" was shot, you can still enjoy its tranquility - simply head away from the crowds and enjoy charm of this beautiful temple.1 hour should cover the visit to the temple nicely.
Fantastic. A great place to visit, loved it. Don't miss going here, so worth the visit! Have some wonderful photos that I will treasure for ever.
Ta Prohm Temple. A must see for everyone. We enjoyed seeing the most awsome sights of the trees and how they grow on the temple

The most impressive of Angkor temples. Ta Prohm is a lesson of humbleness and respect for the mother nature. The remains of Khmer civilisation have been slowly, through centuries taken over by giant strangler fig trees. It's worth being patient and explore the area bit by bit. If you're lucky you might even find yourself being all alone among the ruins late in the afternoon when crowds of tourist head towards Siam Reap. Unforgettable experience...

A real treat. An excellent and atmospheric visit. Really spectacular sights. Quite busy but once you get in to the depths of this temple the amount of people seem to disperse.We had a fantastic guide who was very informative and took us to some great places within the temple.Who played there as a child before it became a tourist attraction and was also on sight and used as a guide when they filmed tomb raider there.A must see!

Another hstorical place. Pictures and pictures shld b taken in this historical places. I was so engrossed with the explanation that the tour guide did for us. Too bad it was a rainy season, i woudl like to visit again.

One of the majestic ruins.. Having visited Ta Prohm 5 years ago I could see the visible changes done by the tree roots in such a short time. Extensive restoration is underway and possibly just in time. Although the tree roots add to the modern day charm I wonder just how majestic the complex would have been in its heyday.Like many ruins in this area there is virtually no wheelchair access and if you are slightly infirm or unsteady on your feet excercise great caution,
Brilliant. get your 3 day pass and see as many temples as you can!!Just try to avoid the other tourists!So many crazy big trees everywhere around the place overgrowing everything!!

Foundation and roots. Ta Prohm is an amazing temple, with much to see in a variety of spaces, inside and out. Trees are interwoven with the stone of the temple. The guide said that if the trees died the buildings would collapse.

Not only for Tomb Raider fans.... Simply stunning! This temple is probably best known for its short feature in Tomb Raider movie, however, visiting it is worth absolutely every minute you spend there. The enormous trees coming out of temple's foundations make this my favorite temple in the whole complex. Exploring rooms filled with pieces of rocks make for an unforgettable experience. Please be aware that they close the temple and usher everyone out around 5 p.m, so make enough time for your visit.

wonderful and very atmospheric. brilliant - as before in my other reviews, visit in morning, take lots of water and small notes for trinkets - travel by tuk tuk - find out one at the temple behind the Steung siemreap hotel - he's called Rae - fabulous guy!

Our favorite Angkor temple. This temple is completely different from all others. The trees and their roots all over the ruins, esentialy destroying them, give it mystical feel. It feels like you are in the movie. Tomb Raider was filmed here but the place reminded us also Spanish movie Pan's Labyrinth.
Excellent!. Do visit the Lara Croft/Tomb Raider tree, near the central Sanctuary. And watch out for the iconic tree! Must go!

Un-restored temple with its special charm. This is my favorite template out of the 7 that I saw. The crazy looking trees growing around the building structures were really interesting, and the sense of chaos as a result of the fallen structures made this temple special.
Gorgeous. My favourite temple site. The way the trees hold up the temple and vice versa makes thiss temple so special. In more of a jungle setting there is so much atmosphere at this temple

must see. timber board-walks have been errected to help save the temple but the trees are still growing and slowly but shorly taking their toll - have visited this temple many times and each time there is less temple and more rubble - see it while you can......

Where the Power of Trees is humbling. Beautiful and still relatively unspoiled and intact. Lots of tourists, especially since its the "tomb raider" temple. But forget all that and appreciate the beauty of nature commingling and eventually strangling these incredible structures.

Trees in the temple.. A must-see in our oppinion. Try to walk away from the groups of tourists when possible, do it in a different direction. Wonderful corners are hidden for those who will wander inside.

Pick your time!. This is an unforgettable place. Preferably watch "Tomb Raider" before you come. There were quite a lot of people when we visited with our own guide, but if you just wait a little, the crowds move on and you can get good photos.
My experience with Seam Reap. Awesome and great. No words tom mention. Every individual who loves to learn about history and culture should come and visit this site.

My Favorite Temple Complex. Not much to say about this that others have not, except this was my favorite complex because of it's nature setting. Go really early to be the tourists. I actually went twice because the first time was so busy.

Ta Prohm. Among the temples in Cambodia Angkor Wat, Bayon & Ta Prohm are the major one, area wise Ta Prohm is the smallest among these three, but it has a totally different appearance than the other two. The ruined temples and the huge trees grown over to that makes you think and respect the history and glory of Cambodia. One of the best photo spots in Siem Reap

Improvement works on going. It was on improvement works, some spots were sealed off. We couldnt get close for pictures. Plus it was raining really-really heavily during our visit. It totally ruined the whole experience for us.

Reminds you of Tomb Raider!. Actually Ta Prom does not do just that, it does much more tha reminding you of Tomb Raider! Did you say Angelina Jolie? Not really!It reminds you that nature is more powerful than history. Ta Prohm are the 8th Century temples which have been gorged by those Silk Cotton trees. Some of those trees are as tall as 100 feet and there roots diameter ranges in meters. An amazing site to be at!

Trees over the Temples. Lara Croft had shots here. According to Khmer belief, the trees over the temples are nature's answer to human's indiscriminate abuse of his environment. I had goosebumps seeing proud trees with trunks and roots bigger than and mightier than the temples.

wow. Amongst the various sites I visited at Siem Reap, I suspect Ta Phrom will remain etched in memory the longest. Neither the largest nor possessed of the highest towers, Ta Phrom's endearing memory will be of the huge tree roots hugging and slowly crushing the temple ruins in a super slow motion dance of death
amazing view. u can see something different, a hug root of trees which date back to thousand of years,, you would this place and you can take a nice photo there

A true Wonder. Ta Prohm is in my top 3 favorite temple sites in Siem Reap. In my opinion Angkor Wat, Bayon Temple and Ta Prohm should be on the must do list of any tourist..especially if you have very limited time. The magnitude of the beauty is indescribable as is the wonderment of the trees growing out of rock. It is truly a world wonder.

Breathtaking!. Ta Phrom is beautiful because is the temple with a "maze" feel to it, you feel like you are in some kind of Indiana Jones type of experience. The roots from the trees and the green moss over the grey stones are breathtaking! The temple is even more beautiful when it rains. There are extensive work being done to the temple, but we hope that we will not loose that "jungle" feel to it.
Love it!!!. The history that brought this temple into what it was, made my nerve wrecking... Thanks to our guide, who patiently share to us, how the temple came to be....

Nice - but nothing amazing. People say the trees growing over the structure is "wow" but if you've seen something like that before this wouldnt really be much of a wow factor. Lots of restoration happening - but worth a visit to see where "tomb raider" was partly shot. That's a pic worth taking. Plus there's this little structure you stand in and thump your chest - and the louder the sound bounces of the walls the more luckier you're supposed to be. Mine was like a bomb going off - wonder when my luck will strike! ;p (But again, lot of touting by kids outside to get you to buy stuff...)

Unnecesarily under restoration. This beautiful temple with so much of damage, trees encroaching walls and Tomb Raider fame is, in our humble opinion, unnecessarily under restoration. It is nice to resotre it, but need to keep the old look, which i feel missing from some restoration.

Definite YES for your 'Bucket List'. Nothing short of magic! First, head to Cambodia, second, visit the Ta Prohm Temple. This is exactly what we've just done & all I can say is, you'll stand there, look around and go 'Wow, Wow, Wow". All this BEFORE you even enter the Temple.It is absolutely unbelievable and such a picture (I took dozens) with the masses of silk & cotton tree roots intertwining and branching out and around the Temple. Fantastic photo shoot opportunities. I can certainly understand why Hollywood was interested in using it for their film Tomb Raider. Would love to go back one day.

Temple under trees. You might seen this temple complex in the film TombRaider, with Angelina Jolie. Nevertheless, this is the most 'adventurous' temple of the Angkor vicinity, with piles of scattered rocks, and remains overgrown by gigantic tree trunks. There are parts under construction, but this did not bother our visit and is only promising for the future.
Ta Prohm. This is the temple were was shooted Tomb Raider, and is one of the most amazing things I have ever seen. The trees with the constructions formed a surreal place.

Different!. While Bayon Temple impressed us with the man made architecture, Ta Prohm gives another perspective. It demonstrates the great power of nature. This mix of a unique architecture and trees which are literally swollowing the temple is something not to miss!
Temple + Jungle. I love how the trees seem to eat up the ruins. Seeing it is surreal. It seems impossible but it's not.

LIke the temple in the Tomb raiders. This is a unique temple that is almost devoured by the roots of a gigantic tree, a unique picture out of the movie the tomb raider. A sight you must experience. Plenty of photo ops.
Good to visit!. Love how these temples have been discovered and restored by various parties. Truly a remarkable experience.

a 'must see' in Angkor. Not the biggest but for sure 1 of the best temples to visit. Just explore the hudge area. Climb and walk for hours in this beautiful comple. Massive tree roots on massive walls. You can walk everywere you want. Do it on your own and not with a guide for more fun. For children this must be a heaven to explore.

Tomb Raider for an hour or so. Experience the wonders of nature, engulfing a man-made structure - large trees of several decades old spreading their roots over the temples. It was a sight to see this, with some of the trees I found glimmer like gold-is yellow. Amazing! I felt like Angelina Jolie in Tomb Raider, even for an hour.

ALmost too good to be truth. Reconstruction/conservation work is still being done, and it has been chosen not to remove all trees. This makes a visit to the Temple a definite MUST for anybody visiting.nature never seazes to amaze!

Loved it!. The busiest of the temples we went to as you are restricted to where you can walk due to work being carried out but still a awesome sight with the massives trees growing out of everywhere and make sure you go to the exterior walls and get the perspective from there as it is totally different.

Truly a Unique Temple. If you want to see a unique temple surrounded by big trees, you must go to Ta Phrom. The roots of the big trees among the temples were so beautiful and giving magical effect. It was indeed an antique temple. However, some point of interests in this temple had been being restored. It was not a good news for photographer, since some part of this temple had been covered by plastic.

The amalgamation of Man's Creation and Nature is so incredible. LOVED IT HERE! Just thinking about the history of these ruins and how awesome the power of nature is left me in awe. The stunning craftsmanship leaves you amazed and the sheer size of the trees that grow over the walls leaves one feeling very small indeed.
Worth going to! DO IT or Regret it!

Awesome! Great architecture really interesting. This was my favourite temple as the most aesthetically pleasing. If at Angkor you must see this! Along with the Tomb Raider links the way the trees grow around the ruins is intricate, interesting and e sures this one stands out from the others

Please Visit!. Of all the temples we visited, I love this one the most! The trees that grow on top of the temple and the roots encircling the wall of the temple are very magnificent. Picture opportunities are plenty, it's like you want to stop every 5 steps to snap a picture :) Please visit, you won't be disappointed.

The place!!. This was our favourite along with Angkor Wat. The photos you will take here will be plentiful and fabulous. A must see on your trip. A pity that its owned by a South Korean and the royalties go back to him.

Set of a famous "Hollywood movie". Part of the spiel of the tour guides and the biggest reason for its popularity (in my opinion) is because it was one of the scenes for one of Angelina Jolie's Tomb Raider movies. Amazing, strange tree roots taking over the temples. I hope they preserve it carefully, taking into consideration that these trees are part of the charm.
The most "romatic" temple of Angkor. What a worderful decision, when the archeoloists decided to leave temples and trees in a single suggestive hug...

Take a number, wait your turn, then take a photo and leave. Hordes of other tourists and touts.
It's pretty much ruined, sorry to say. The place might need some traffic lights installed in the near future.
Like the rest of Angkor Wat it's pretty much ruined. I think the best thing we can do is give it back to the jungle...
Amazing. This was the place which impressed me the most, due to its setting. Doesn't make Angkor Thom or Angkor Wat less fascinating.

Good one to take kids to!. Travelling with 4 and 6 year olds can make temple visits difficult but they both really enjoyed Ta Prohm. It's compact and lush and interesting. It is currently under renovation so some sections were blocked off but it's a must see if you are there. Very special.

Glad we bought the 3 day pass. On our third day of looking at the temples we did wonder if it was worth the trip, but we we were not disappointed. Had a wonderful driver who made the trip all the more enjoyable. Was very hot and humid. Make sure you take plenty of water. Not as crowded as the other temples.

Temple and Trees. The combination of the temple with the trees is amazing. Plan to spend 1-2 hours walking on it. Enjoy the details and the combination of the architecture and the trees. It is a beautiful place.

Tomb Raider. maybe it was the anticipation, maybe it was the crowds, maybe it was the third day of temples, but this didn't give me the "wow" factor I thought that it would. That is not to say it (as is all of the Angkor area) is truly spectacular. Lots of it are under renovation and there are the key photo-spots where everyone stands next to the big tree and far more souvenir touts than necessary. However, buy a CD from one of the cripple musician groups to help support their project. (i say cripple because that it how they refer to themselves - they're victims of landmine explosions and have missing limbs)

love it. You'll understand why Lara Croft loved this temple. It too is my most favorite. The ambiance is eerie yet very romantic. It rained right before we headed into the temple grounds. The transformation was amazing. The grounds seem to come alive with all the trees and moss at their brightest greens. The only annoying thing here was trying to avoid the very insistent vendors at the entrance. Still, definitely one of Cambodia's finest treasures and should not be missed.

or more popularly known now as ..the "Lara Croft" Temple. If you watched the movie, then you will know what this temple is famous for. Yes! it is the tree!! The trees here grow in such peculiar way that it is actually beautiful..no, i m not on medic....What i mean is the trees actually grow intertwined with the temple building and nobody knows why it happens that way.. Ok ok, they say it is the birds that had deposited the seed on top of the roof and somehow the tree roots downwards to the soil....but hey, those are some really big roots!!This is the temple you definitely do not want to miss. Try to be early or you will risk having some chinese tourist in all your photos. haha.

We visited twice!. We visited Angkor for a second day just to be again at Ta Prohm! The atmosphere, the jungle, the ruins are something so amazing! It is better to visit this place early in the morning because after 11 it is full of people.

this is the most beautiful temple of all ~. i love this temple more far more than others i've seen. Its really awesome. The beautiful roots making their way up the stone pillars or temple for support and cool surrounding of the jungle is totally a blown off. A defintely must visit in SR!!!

A great Ruin. Although badly ruined and resconstruction is on going albeit very slowly due to the extensive damage but this is by far the best temple amongts all that I have seen in Siem Reap. It may not have been as famous as Angkor Wat and have not been recognised as the Seven Wonders of the World, but everything here is so inspiring!

Better than the movie!. The "Tomb Raider Temple" as they will tell you, was amazing. No wonder they decided to film a movie there. Our tuk tuk driver for the week was great and told us to go early and it paid off, only a few other people there the whole time!
Superb. Exceeded expectation, with the aid of a professional guide sourced through our hotel, a fascinating experience.
brilliant photos. we did all the temples,with a multi ticket and saved money,you can have tickets for 1 day to 2 weeks
A must see. One of the best sights in the region -- natures trees meets mankinds buildings - a photographers dream I am sure!

Must love Trees. The prominent aesthetic of this temple is the huge trees and its roots, like the weight of history and its toll on the lives of the Cambodians. We all know what the locals have gone through. That's why every time I see a temple weighed down by the huge & heavy roots in Angkor, I am reminded of its gloomy past.
Very unusual . . . . . .in a good way. By the time we visited this site we were a little templed out but it's worth seeing, really great lush surrounds and the history is fascinating
Best temple but really crowded. Make sure you plan your visit here to avoid the crowds and tour buses. An amazing spirit to this place!

My absolute favourite temple. Go.....less crowded than the main temples and much more mysterious/compelling. Lots of great photo opportunities. Please donate to the musicians on the road to the temple, they have retrained following loss of limbs due to the landmines. GO GO GO!!!!

Restoration Works. There was a lot of restoration activities taking place and hence a number of sites within the ruins were inaccessible to tourists. This is quite understandable but it left tourists feeling slightly short changed. The children trying to sell postcards as well as others selling books are quite a nuisance and should be regulated. They come on you like flies to food and would not take a "no" answer. This was quite irritating to an otherwise nice morning tour of the ruins.
Wonderful!. This fascinating temple has trees taking over many sections of it, which creates a 'Temple of Doom' atmosphere & character to the place.

Beyond expectation. This part of the temple makes me stand at amazement how nature and history grows together, it was simply beyond expectation. You need to experience it yourself to get what I mean. Its really unique, especially with the big tree growing on the temple. The dark alley adds the magical feeling. Amazing!

Natural Beauty. This temple is amazing..it has been only minimally restored though there appears to be some major construction happening off to the side of the main temple. The temple was left to the ruins of nature and it is simply gorgeous to see. The trees have grown up, around and through the walls and doors of the temple and moss and lichens are covering the stones making it all look so organic. It's a photographer's dream...don't miss it.

Unreclaimed. This is one tuildingsemple in Angkor complex which has been deliberately left in the state it was found. The result is that there are huge strangler fig tree roots encompassing many of the walls of the buildings. It is a very unique and fascinating site
Amazing. Its incredible to see trees growing over and thru the temple makes for some fantastic shots. i think it was one of our favourite temples and definately want to go back.
great nature. the trees and roots are amazing and unique - go there at 6 am before the crowds descent, well worth it in the hazy early am light

Extraordinary. Another "must" visit temple when you are traveling in Siem Reap. Wow, this place is simply magnificent! The way the trees' roots creep all over the temple walls make the whole place look extremely mysterious and magical. It's amazing how the trees can evolved to such extend and make the place extraordinary. Our tour guide managed to bring us visit the place at the right timing when the crowd is at the minimum. As we were about to leave, huge crowd starts pouring in and gladly, we managed to make our escaped.

Still Amazing. We visited Ta Prohm 11 years ago and it was simple mind blowing. Since we have returned it's still great to see that there has not been much change except some restoration taking place, but overall a MUST. Ta Prohm is one of my favourite temples. Can be a bit noisy with all the Mainlanders!!!
Surreal. Amazing and at times overwhelming with the history and creations. Imagining the people and efforts is incredible.

Just as stunning in real life. Judging by the other reviews we were very lucky as there were not too many tourists and I can see how the experience could be spoilt by having a lot of people around. We went at around lunchtime after having gone around The Bayon and The Baphuon, plus a few small temples, and although there were other tourists we had plenty of opportunities to take good photos. This place has to be seen to be believed, it almost looks like a film set. It's so weird the way the tree roots have grown over the buildings. If you don't have time to visit everything at Angkor, make sure you don't miss this one!

ginormous trees. cannot believe these trees have just grown from cracks and evolved into the beautiful giant trees dwarfing the temple. explaining the wonder does not do it justice. you really have to visit as the photos don't even do it justice.

Amazing Temple - Tombraider was shot here!. This temple makes your trip to Angkor Vat worth every penny! You see huge trees over buildings with their huge roots all over the place. The place might give you the creeps, but you feel a great presence of some supreme force in the temple.. Must see!

Ta Prohm. Loved the history and the local knowledge from our guide. Very well worth it!! We visited the temple sites with our guide who explained everything - his kindness (such as carrying umbrellas for us and having a never-ending supply of cold drinking water!) was appreciated. The temples were amazing - and we were almost overwhelmed by their age - especially since they were build hundreds of years before Australia was even discovered!

Nearly destroyed by time and nature.. Better known by some now as the "Tomb Raider" temple. Here you can see what the jungle is capable of. Many parts of the building have been knocked down by trees and creepers. Restoration work is going on. This area is being restored with the help of the Indian Govt.
Unbelievable. Have never seen anything like it ,these strange kapok trees that cover the ruins.they seem to be alive.Loved it
Better then photos!. It was my favorite temple of all time. The trees are fascinating...even after Angkor Wat, you'll be amazed.

Breath Taking. Would not miss it if I were travelling there even for a 2nd or 3rd time. Ta Prohm is beautiful and a Cambodian experience not to be pass by. Make sure you have a guide (we spent $25 of the tuk tuk and guide for the day) The history is interesting and without a guide I would think you would miss out on learning how truely amazing Ta Prohm is.

oh those gigantic trees take your breath away.. This really is an amazing site. Ancient gigantic trees growing atop the temples. So much to see. On my second visit to Cambodia, this was one of the sites in the ancient kingdom I really wanted to go back to. Gives you a feeling of being back in time. Lots of tourists, tour groups and local guides tour the site, each and every day. Both times, went in August and it was very crowded despite it being a low season. Definitely a highlight of my trip!

Lara Croft feeling pure. OK the headline is cheesy and one should not reduce this beautiful place to a Hollywood blockbuster. But once again, Ta Prohm delivered exactly what I had hoped for and more. It is a mythical place, where you can really feel the history of the place and you can almost hear the hustle and bustle of centuries agao.

Tomb raider. A must see, forest claiming back the land, by eating it up with roots. Its good to see the progress made and be sure to see the before and after photographs Best go really early to avoid the bus loads and the heat.

Another gem. This temple was built in the 12th and 13th centuries. The trees grow over the temple and that is both good (magnificent) and bad (not good for the temple's survivability). Even though you are standing there surrounded by the majestic decaying temple, it is hard to imagine people living and working there but occasionally you seem to hear the temple's voice and the place comes alive.

Exceeding expectations. Nature and man-made creations fused in unforgettable magnificence. Make sure you find some quiet areas to experience the sound of birds, sunlight and silence on the stones and trees, to recapture just a little of the early explorer Mouhot's amazement. Even amidst the tourist groups clambering over the famous spots, you can see stunning pictures. Of all the temples you will visit, make this your last spot for those unforgettable memories.
the best one of them all. You need to see this one as early as possible in the AM.....it will be empty! You will feel as though you are back time.

Wild Roots. This is a must see to realize how inventive tree roots can be. The designs & the "natural" photo ops that exist within the grounds of this area are amazing. The temple itself is amazing but what the trees have done almost takes center stage.

good photo opportunities... very old trees around the areas, some are very eerie..this the sight we've been looking for after we watched the movie lara croft..there are areas though that are restricted to tourists as it is very dangerous, the roots of the trees are growing on the temple that is on a brink of collapse. nevertheless, its a good photo opportunities.

Still 5 stars even if we couldn't find Angelina. Our first temple visit and my joint personal favourite still (along with the Bayon). With trees everywhere curling roots and branches around the ruins, long dark passageways and stone carvings on piles on the floor as well as on the still standing walls, it's easy to imagine yourself as Indiana Jones. Probably the one the kids loved too: generally they groan at temples but this one is as fascinating to a child as to an adult

Tomb raider temple !!. Look the little buddha head that the root did not cover. I disliked the crowd but liked the history of the place. It is interesting how the place was excavated and stuff. A must see.

More interesting than Angkor Wat. Angkor Wat may be a big area, but the design and structures there, in my opinion, are actually not as interesting as what you can see at Ta Prohm. The way the trees grow on and around the temple structures is very cool.

Very interesting place. I quite like this place, especially the giant tree growing above the ancient castle. And if you know more about it you'll think it's amazing how this place were build with it's interesting history.
Ah Tomb Raider. The temple with the roots from all the trees holding the temple together but also destroying it at the same time, a must see.
Awesome trees. It is amazing to see the tree hugging the building, live. The feeling you get in the midst of all the ancient structures is very uplifting.
Thanks, Tomb Raider. Those big trees with the huge roots leave me spell bound. I can almost imagine the archeologists finding the ruins in the jungle.
Fascinating place to visit. You have to climb over things a bit but this is great to see and amazing for photo shots. Interesting place to visit as part of tour of Angkor
Great!. Must see when you got to Ankor Wat! Trees are all around the ruins of the temple. Beautiful! You can see some of it in the Angelina Joli movie Tomb Raider.

Go now!. This is the one of the famous temples - the one with the roots/vines growing all over it. Unfortunately, the roots are actually ripping the place apart and for that reason they are being removed. This is of course good to preserve the site, but it also sterilizes the feel of it. Usually visited with Bayon, Angkor Tom, and Ankor Wat.

This is the one!!. Tomb Raider. This is such a beautiful temple. Its incredible how the jungle took it over.My best advice is be there at sunrise, its so still and beautiful. The sounds of the birds and monkeys which you will not hear later in the day. We had the place to ourselves both mornings we visited it. Truel amazing.

Awesome!. All of the temples at Angkor are amazing! To think that these structures were built 900 years ago and are still standing is breathtaking! What is our generation going to leave on the world? People come from miles to see this because it is classed as an unofficial wonder of the world. It is a must see just like the other temples. The architecture and detail is like something you will never see in this day and age. An absolute must visit. You only need 30 mins to walk around it and then move on to the next one. Go early in the morning to avoid the congestion and the midday sun. It gets very hot walking around the complex. This was our favourite temple. A little out the way from Angkor Wat and the Bayon and am absolute must see. Tomb Raider (rider to the cambodians) was filmed here. The way the trees intertwine with the building is beautiful, although it has ultimately destroyed the original temple. It's different to the other temples as there is a jungle feel.
Ta Prohm. This is fantastic - Amazing - beautiful - and bizarre with all the trees amidst the ruins. Loved it.
Spectacular. The way the roots of the trees seem to hold up the ruins is amazing. Make sure you have a guide on all the ruins tours, if you dont you'll miss out on so much.

Tomb Raider. Amazing to see how the jungle can overgrow a temple, but can still see a lot of the structure still standing. Some repairs and re-construction is ongoing, so funny to see a giant crane to do what was done originally without machines...

Lost in time. A must see! Ta Prohm was left how the archeologists discovered it - consumed by the jungle. It gives you a good idea how all of the temples looked before they were rehabilitated. Seeing the giant tree roots curving around the temple stones is equally as interesting as the temple itself.

impressive temple. Everything here breathes history and religion. It is fascinating to see the changes made to the temple when the kingdom changed hands... Hire a guide or you will lose most of the historical content

Well worth it!. Definitely worth going, although some of it is roped off due to restoration. Some amazing photo ops, but LOTS of people! Just be patient and move away from the walkways to discover some interesting areas!

Travelling with an Infant - Arrived early for best Photos.. We travelled with a 15 month old. We had her in a back pack. We bought the 3 day pass, enabling us to use the ticket on any day within the week (from purchase). Cost $US40 each.In the 3 days we visited:Day 1: Angkor Wat and Banyon Temple (4 hours total from the point we left the Hotel to the point we returned)Day 2: Preah Kahn and Ta Prohm (4 hours total from the point we left the Hotel to the point we returned)Day 3: Banteay Srei, Butterfly Museum and Landmine Museum. (5 hours total from the point we left the Hotel to the point we returned)We hired a car to take us (Day 1 = $30, Day 2 = $30, Day 3 = $40)We arrived at around 7:00am and got some really great photos. The light was perfect and there were not too many tourists.If I was doing it again I would have left the hotel every day at 6:30 to avoid the heat and tourists.

Ta Pohm held up by trees. This was one of our highlights in the Angkor Park. We were absolutely amazed by the trees growing around and through the temple and it was probably one of my highlights. This is a must visit temple in the park.

THE temple in angkor. hard to describe in words, you just have to see it for yourself. I would go there early in the morning and experience the atmosphere while the jungle awakes. you have to buy a ticket (daily to multiple days) to enter the historical site of angkor wat, with which you can see all the temples. close to the elephant terrace there are some restaurants where you can have lunch.

Gorgeous and romantic. The trees are what you come for here- unless you're a tomb-raider fan, and then it's all about the door she comes out of in the movie. This is one of the few temples that still have the figs pouring over the walls. You feel like you were the ones who "discovered" the temples in the jungle in the 18th-century. Well worth a visit!
what are they doing???. the construction that was taking place, should have given notice and close the place for the duration, or divert away from the construction area.
Vishnu Temple. Gave us an Idea of the Hindu influence in far off Cambodia and the kings that ruled Ta Prohm, Leart about the Lord Vishnu being the main deity

I was looking forward to this temple from the day one of my visit. Ta Prohm was ringing in my ears right from the moment I landed in Siem Reap, as this was the temple which appeared prominently in the movie "Tomb Raiders". Ta Prohm was the first temple in my 2nd days itinerary and it was a perfect blending of nature and a temple. The huge roots of trees that hold the temple in a giant grip is a unique site. It is advised for those who are very keen to study the carvings very closely, to carry a head light as inside the temple may be bit dark to see. This is must visit temple

Temple in the jungle. It was raining when we were at Ta Prohm but this just added to the character of this crumbling ruin being swallowed up by the jungle. The atmosphere was slightly dented by the noise of a chain saw, tree felling is probably inevitable here. Wear sensible shoes as you need to scramble over fallen stones and uneven paths.

the jungle temple. wonderful temple in the Angkor Archeological Park. A paradise for photographer, roots, carvings, trees, everywhere. The only problem is that usually is very crowded. Anyway a must, you cannot loose it.

Jungle Temple... We did this temple as part of a full day with guide. Having a personal guide with transportation is absolutely worth the money. They know so much about these places that you would otherwise have to acquire before you visit. This temple is particular nice due to the trees that have taken over. In the end Nature always wins.!!

One of the best temples at Angkor. The so called "tomb raider" temple (not that I've seen it). It's unique amongst the temples in the area because of the giant trees seemingly growing out of the walls. It's hard to get a good photo because there are lots of people there. It's not as overgrown as I thought it would be, but it's still great.

Amazing. Lovely place to see, because you can see parts where nature has taken over vs parts restored to their former glory. Unfortunately, given the restoration efforts, some parts of the temple are out of bounds.
Great jungle temple.. Ta Prohm is a wonderful temple, it is flat, so it is good for elderly visitors. With all the trees, it is shady.
Look at everything`. Loved this temple. Don't just go straight to the 'Tomb Raider' tree, this temple is amazing make sure you have a really good look around.

Most unique temple inside Angkor. This is the temple where they film the Tomb Raider and the most amazing sight is the huge tree overgrown on the top of the temple. However, we noticed that some of the temple structure begin to crumble. If you wish to see this amazing site, don't wait any longer.

Overrated. I went around 11 AM. Perhaps it was a poor decision on my behalf.
The temple and the strangler figs were amazing, but the hordes of tour groups everywhere took away from the experience. It's something that you should see, but try to go early to avoid the crowds.

The best from the Angkor park. just magnificent as good as it gets. this is the temple used in the tomb raider movie and made famous for the trees growing on top of the temple.
Ask your guide to take you from the north gate no one knows about it except guide and locals, there is no tourist there and is the most beautiful of all.

Fantastic!. Really an amazing temple! You can see what the combination of human work and nature can make! We have to enjoy such a place as long as it exists, as the trees will ultimately destroy the temples.
Don't miss it if you have the chance!

Amazingly beautiful temple. My girlfriend and I visited the temple early (about 6 am) and had the temple to ourselves. We saved it for the last day and were glad that we did. it was amazing. The tree growth alone would had made the area beautiful, but with the overgrowth going around the ruins and through the paths it was breathtaking. Very different from most of the other temples that you will see. I can't imagine anyone missing this temple if they are coming to this area.

Love the trees. I loved this Wat, again there is a long walk in to it in the heat. There is lots of work being done here at the time of our visit. We were both expecting the trees themselves to be much bigger than they were after seeing the Raider film. But then we come from Tasmania where trees are truly huge in the south west. We did manage to get quite a few shots without other tourists featured in them which is a huge bonus.

By far the best one for photo fanatics. This was my highlight. Stunningly huge trees that have overgrown the temple walls and structures creating a photographic setting beyond Hollywood standards! Best to go at lunch time or sunset to avoid tourist groups stepping into your shots
great for photos. visited first and entered through rear gate, had 1 hour with few people around. Was our drivers idea but a good one.
Magic. My favourite temple by far. Truly awe inspiring to see nature and man made construction come together in such harmony.

Words cannot describe it. Apart from being the famous temple in Tomb Raider, it is a must-see. Relaxing under the giant trees is a great experience and strolling leisurely through the temple is much recommended

Eerily spooky but oh so beautiful. We made it here at 6.30 am and had the whole place to ourselves. The sun beamed through the trees as it rose and emphasised the roots growing mysteriously over those ruined temples. My children enjoyed this temple the most, and I can understand why.
My Favourite. It is a shady area, with amazing root systems, every moment is a Kodak moment

Giant trees and roots. Angelina Jolie's Lara Croft and the tomb Raiders actually made this place famous. It was simply amazing to see the huge trees sitting right on top of the ruins and their giant roots traveling in all directions towards the soil..slithering like giant snakes..

Keep it secret !!!. the loveliest of all temples. To enjoy to a max, get there at 6 am. There will be a few visitors, but only a few. Later in the day, this place becomes a circus... But don't tell everyone !

Be Lara Croft or Indiana Jones for a day at Ta Prohm. Channel your inner Lara Croft and allot an hour of tomb-raiding at the picturesque Ta Prohm temple. This is a cluster of temples located about 10 Kms from the centre of Siem Reap. Restoration and rebuilding efforts are underway, so expect a lot of dust and hammering. Until you get there, it's quite hard to imagine just how enormous these tree roots are, until you stand next to them. The humongous trees that have rooted into the temples, will make you look like the Incredible Shrinking Man/ Woman in your pictures. These are the tree-in- temple photos you can do show-and-tell with back home, while regaling your friends with stories of trekking through the jungles of Cambodia. Helpful tips: 1) Slather on mosquito repellent before you visit this site. I noticed there were more mosquitoes here, compared to the other temples I visited. Best to be safe than sorry. (2) From Ta Prohm, head out to the other remote temples like Banteay Srei (a half hour away by tuktuk) and Pre-rup. I was able to visit all 3 sites in a little over 4 hours, and grab a late lunch back in Siem Reap city proper. 3) Get there by 7:30am to get ahead of the bus tours. Because of the Tomb Raider movie, it's a popular destination and you don't want to be queuing to get your photos taken by the roots.

Photogenic, atmospheric, you'll love it.. Make sure you have your camera and maybe a bit of cash as there are artists at work and you can purchase their paintings. Allow plenty of time to explore. If you want to enjoy a similar temple with fewer people then walk 1 kilometre through the lush green forest to the Temple of the Butterflies, Ta Nei.

Ta Prohm, the jungle temple!. If you are an ancient temple buff, you should not miss Ta Prohm. Most of Asian tourists do not like to spend more than one day visiting temples. but however, they should not miss Ta Prohm. The tour itinerary can be packed with Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. Yes, the schedule is a bit rushing but at least they can see the wonderful temple. this temple is built in Bayon style largely in the late 12 and early 13 centuries. the temple originally called Rajavihara.
Great. Walking through this temple makes you feel like Indiana Jones. The jungle trees have grown on the temple in many different places, making this an excellent place to see.

A Must See !!!. Absolutely wonderful experience visiting this site. Ta Prohm was the second temple we visited, arriving around mid-morning. A perfect time really as the crowds as yet hadn't arrived in full so we had the luxury of taking our time exploring the site and captured quite a few photos of just the structures and the invading trees without groups of fellow tourists in the shots. Ta Prohm really lived up to our expectations. It is and was as we had imagined from the various books and magazines we had seen. Seeing it for real was simply unbelievable. The hard thing for the future will be how to preserve it in it's current state - yes, we want to see the trees and roots protruding from the walls and roof, but how do you stop the further deteriation of the structures? Something surely for the Indian Archaeology team to consider as they set about their proposed restoration project. Perhaps it is a case of go see it now before it current status is lost or remodelled too much by the hand of man.

Wow!. Loved this temple! You walk through the jungle to reach it and when you are there can really understand why it has been included in movies. It brought out the little boy in my husband who crawled through little doorways and over the huge tree roots. Fabulous.

Loved the trees!. This is a stunning site. So many trees and roots growing all around and through the structures. Crowded this time of year and a line to get pics taken at the tomb raider. Take water as it is hot and humid. An amazing place!

my personal favourite. This temple is the only one almost entirely strangled by trees - almost as if the trees built it themselves. Impressive, gotta see for yourself to understand the feel of the place, I'm afraid pictures don't do it justice.
My favourite. Just awesome how the trees have overgrown this complex. I loved it. We took great pictures. I just felt very sorry for all the small kids trying to sell junk....

The Tomb Raider. I read in the guidebook that this is where they filmed the Tomb Raider. Tomb Raider or not, the place holds a certain charm with its massive ruins, not to mention the giant trees extending its roots on the temple roofs.

Truly a great wonder to see.. This temple and Bayon, just may be the coolest to check out. It and the Bayon temple were used in the Tomb Raider movie. Only thing, if you do not like the heat and humidity, then you may want to visit during the cooler months. Worth seeing, even if Angelina Jolie is not there when you visit.
A la Indiana Jones. A great place to explore and the jungle has just taken over. Kids loved the variety and the little bit of climbing

enchanting place. Giants trees that look like they are thousand of years old cling to temples giving them a romantic look. If you could look pass the construction going on, it would seem like you've wandered into the jungle and stumbled upon it. Funny thing is, they've even built a platform in front of the tree so that you can stand there and have your picture taken with it. Tourists here are very courteous and each would wait their turn in front of the tree. There's no line but people just have the decency to wait till the first one is finished before they step unto the platform. A truly enchanting place... once you get pass the ongoing construction and the tourists.
Ta Prohm. The trees around this are amazing! Have to see to appreciate.
Beautiful temple. A must see!. Beautiful temple. A must see when in Cambodia. This was the temple that was used as the movie set for Tomb Raider!

Best temple of the whole complex. Lot's of people know this temple from Tomb Raider but I'd never seen it so didn't know what they were on about. As soon as I started looking around this temple I was awe-stuck at the way the trees and roots have inter-twined with it. I like the idea of the nature fighting against the man-made imposition. It's a very cool spectical with loads of photo ops.
Enchanting. The old trees play a huge role in making this temple more enchanting than it already is. The roots and trunks are massive and they wrap gracefully around the ruins. Definitely a must-see!
Impressive. Trees growing over temples. something you don't see in my places around the world, if in any.
greatness of nature. the other angkor sites tell you how great was the architecture, but in ta prohm the nature shows you who is the boss

Trees growing out of Temples. They say it is the best site to see trees growing out of Temples and they are right! It is a good place to see the raw state (fallen down ) and the restored (but not perfect). They are doing a wonderful job in what they are restoring. Very enjoyable.
The best after Ankgor. Unbelievably beautiful with all the trees. The trees just make the temple look so msytical. cannot miss this!! Make sure your battery does not run out of juice here!
Tomb Raider relived!. It is obvious why the filmcrew choose spots from this temple for their movie.Truly incredible to see the force of the tree roots upon the manmade buildings....amazing!
The trees!. You cannot imagine this before you see it, the trees growing out of the temple - simply amazing.
Mystical and almost magical. Love the mystery surrounding the giant tree roots enveloping the temple ruins. See it before it completely engulfs what's left of the temples.

Ancient temple in the embrace of the tree roots. Ta Prohm has been largely left to the clutches of the living jungle. The trees growing out of the ruins are perhaps the most distinctive feature of Ta Prohm. Amazing.

The must see temple. If you dont get to see any other temples in Cambodia, this is the one that you must see. This is also were part of the Tomb Raider move was filmed. Instead of clearing out all of the trees like they have with the rest of the temples they have left this one in a sate of ruin. It is amazing to walk around and see how the trees have grown into the stones. Leave the beaten track and explore other parts of the temple but be careful as some of it is unstable (and there are also bugs).

The one to see. This is the one people come to the temple complex of Angkor to see. The ruins with the tree roots intertwined is amazing. The place was undergoing some repair and maintenance during our visit but it didn't detract from the experience. A guided kept referring to the Lara Croft movie to describe the various areas which seems to be part of the marketing push for Ta Prohm..

Magical. Our favourite.. We loved this temple - it was certainly the kids favourite - as it hasn't been sanitised for mass tourism - you can clamber around the crumbling ruins covered in tree roots and really pretend you're Indiana Jones discovering this temple for the first time! Magical!
Breathtaking scene. I really like the old old trees on top of concrete structures with its roots creeping all over. The restoration work is ongoing so some areas are not accessible.
An over-used phrase, but this really is 'Must Try'. Go first thing, like 5.30-6.30am. Almost unbelievable

The Most Beautiful Temple. This is my favourite temple and not just because it is wh.ere 'Toom Raider' was filmed... The way the forest has taken over the ruins is so beautiful. If you enjoy photography you will love this. You just have to be very patient to ensure you get your shots without people in them. This can take a while. Unfortunately there is also quite a bit of scaffolding here for restoration work, but still wonderful
very special temple. I can feel how much strong the power of nature... amazing! and donate to the people who participate in the war and lost there limbs , they are playing beautiful music for you
Amazing!!. Another great temple with the added attraction of large trees and their trunks growing over and amongst the temple. Wonderful to photograph
cheese tree ?. the Fromager (cheese tree) are so amazing mixed with the temple. very nice. and now they put wooden path and spot the best angle already..

Tomb Raider and Tourists. This was one of my favourite temples in Siem Reap. I loved that Tomb Raider was filmed here and I loved seeing all the overgrown trees wrapped around the temple. There are a lot of tourists here now and if you can take a guide to show you the best parts.
simply wow!. Embracing huge trees and dancing apsaras on the temple walls everything creates a serene and beautiful ambiance.
By far my favourite!. This definitely my personal favourite, together with Angkor Thom.. The was the jungle has taken over the temple in the 1000 years is fascinating!

Lara Croft eat your heart out !. Great place to visit - beware of the multitude of 'sellers' at the gates. It is truly amazing to see what time has done to this amazing temple and what man has done to try and claim it back.
Our favorite temple. It's so exotic and interesting. The trees intertwined are just amazing! Absolutely must do! Kids love it the best of all temples

My favorite of all the ruins. This is the "Tomb Raider" temple. I never saw the movie, but this ended up being my favorite of the ruins in Angkor, the way nature has taken over and worked its way into the architecture is quite stunning!
Nice Temple. This temple very old and if you take inside for visit you will see the big tree on the temple. very lovely and nice view.

Mystical Jungle temple. This was my favorite temple in Angkor. It really comes to life with the temple ruins being strangled by the trees seeing mother nature do her best. Part of Lara Croft movie was filmed here. Such an enchanting place.

Loved It More Than Angkor Wat & Angkor Thom. The trees disrupting the structure is the best part of this beautiful temple. Definitely the most striking in my opinion. It's 5 km from Angkor so we were thankful for our tuk tuk at this point. I didn't spend too long here because there were too many people and the sun had become really hot. Everyone queues for a picture in front of the tree over the structure, so be prepared for that. Be careful on rainy days as the mud walkway to the temple is extremely slippery.
Most amazing temple. Just surreal... Like stepping back in time... Aka tomb raider temple... Seriously feel like Indiana Jones or Lara Croft minus the sexy shorts.....must see!,
Go early. We went here very early and were the only ones in the park, so cool. This was the most amazing temple of the Angkor wat park. Go see it by yourself gives you an amazing feeling...
Not a cliche!. Stunning to see how the balsa and banyan trees have wreaked havoc with the structures. Again a guide is great to get the full experience

Fantastic. I loved this one, the trees growing through the walls are just amazing. Again lots of walking and steps. Would suggest go with a guide as there is so much to learn and without a guide you would have no idea.
A glimpse of jungle. This was one of the highlights of the trip, ruins surrounded with trees growing around them, very unusual and quite an adventure to explore, highly recommended

My Favorite. This was my favourite of the temples we visited. It is an spectacular place with the trees still growing through the ruins .. Take a guided tour.. It is worth the money for the expert commentary and to make sure you don't miss anything

The Trees of Wonder. To be able to see how these beautiful trees grow and protect the landscape is just unbelievable.
Along the way, musicians played some traditional cambodia songs the made the whole experience very enchanting.

better than I imagined!. We had all seen pictures of Ta Prohm but it was really great to see in person. So amazing how the trees have grown for years on top of the temple and how they have allowed it to remain that way. Really cool.

A part of our 4 day trip to Siem Reap a wonderful sight. We organised our trip to Siem Reap by reading other reader's contributors guides / reviews. We found our tour guide through trip advisor Sophana Yous. He organised our 4 days in Siem Reap and Ta Prohm was part of the tour. Not to be missed when walking around the huge complex of Angkor ( which has more than 1 temple)
just like the movie. Amazing place to visit, even if you've seen it on the tv before

Most unique temple site. All of Angkor is absolutely amazing and all it's cracked up to be and more. Ta prohm is unique because the jungle and trees have infiltrated the temple ruins so it is something out of an Indiana jones movie. I've been to Tikal and Borobudur and Angkor temples blow them away.

1 hour is enough. Tomb raider temple. Your guide/driver might tell you all about Angelina Jolie. It is not a good option if it is raining since most parts are open but it is interesting to see the nature confiscating the temple-the land that was taken from her.
trees, roots and stones. in my opinion better than Angkor Wat. More "real."
Even better than you imagine. Amazing tree roots all over the temple give amazing photos and experience for people

An amazing place, despite persistent touts. This is my second favorite place after Bayon temple. Be prepared for very persistent touts who will try to engage in some emotional blackmail to make you buy something from them.

Interesting -the tomb raider temple!. I've never seen Tomb Raider but this doesn't spoil your enjoyment! I found this one of the busiest temples - but it's worth the visit for the incredible site of the trees bursting through the stone
A must see. This temple was left in a relatively "undisturbed" state with large trees tand roots taking over. Very cool.

amazed. am really proud india is contributing to the restoration of this temple ,this was the first temple we visited and was pleased with my decision to do siem reap ,history and architecture lovers this is the place to visit ....

Tomb Rider Re-Visited. Of course, one would think of Lara Croft here, but at the same time, the site remains very authentic and impressive.
Renovations are on in the central part of the temple (columns with apsaras). Go there quite early so that you may avoid the hordes of package tours tourists and their flashes all over the place.

Cool!. A very native environment! The jungle has over run this temple and the conservationists have elected to leave the old trees that have engulfed the temple. Some are braced as they do a lot of damage when they fall. This temple has for the most part not been reconstructed (yet) though as with almost all of the temples, there is some work underway. Get your Tomb Raider fix in here, this is quite a unique place in the world!
My favorite. Where nature meets ruins...absolutely lovely and a visible reminder that time always keeps on...
Favourite. This was my favorite temple to visit. The trees were amazing and I think I took one too many photos of them growing over the temple grounds! Just so unique and spectacular. Must See.

Yes, it was from Tomb Raider. If Tomb Raider brought you here, be thankful. It was easily my favorite, but not because I saw it in a movie. Of the Wats and Temples near Siem Reap, this one was my favorite. You could feel the life that this place once housed. The location and the encroaching jungle make for a magical experience you should not miss.
The most attractive of the Temples. This place is magical - the trees growing inside of the temple are stunning. Definitely worth a stop when travelling round the temples of Angkor.

Temple from 'Tomb Raider'. Amazing to see how the jungle can overgrow a temple, but can still see a lot of the structure still standing. Some repairs/re-construction is ongoing, so funny to see a giant crane to do what was done originally without machines. For a different view, walk through the temple inside and back on the outside of the temple to
Tomb Raiders Temple. my favorite among the Angkor Temples. if I should visit only One temple -this would be it.

Temple trees keep you cool on a sunny day. My friends and I visited Ta Phrom after lunch, which was still a hot part of the day. We almost didn't feel the heat because of the trees that surround the area. Near the entrance, you will be greeted by music played by the war victims. Giving a small donation to the group is optional but giving a little amount will be of great help to them. Our tour guide told us of the different magnificent trees that make up Ta Prohm. Of course, when we saw the famous 'Tomb Raider' tree, we just have to take a picture with it. There are other interesting information about the temple in Ta Prohm. Having a guide to tell and show you about these things is very helpful.

Beautiful but way too many tourists. I'd been a few years ago at the same time, rainy season, and the place wasn't busy but this time tons of tour groups which killed the whole experience. Pick your times carefully. If you want the old TaProhm experience go to Beng Mealea. Much bigger and much more of an adventure
Tomb Raider eat your heart out. Ta Prohm was an amazing site with the majestic jungle still maintaining pride of place weaving its way through the temple landscape.
Nice experience. It really caught my attention how the roots from the trees embraces the temples as it really protecting it.

See it now before Indians "restore"/rebuilt it!. The unreconstructed "tree temple" is famous for its dazzling decay. Unfortunately, an Indian group has begun to aggressively "restore" (i.e., rebuild) the tree temple. Even if some of the sprawling trees are left intact, the power of this place is its mix of nature, rubble, and ruin. Couldn't this one temple be left in its glorious deterioration?
Even better than Angkor Wat.. This temple is one of the best. It is not as well maintained in areas and much of the temple is in piles, but this is it's appeal.

tomb raider spectacular. we were dropped off by our tuk tuk driver at west gate and indtructed to meet at east gate when finished. easier said than done as it was like a maze after exiting 3times at wrong gate we finally found the right way. As there is no wind only blistering heat it is advisable to take a hat with you. 40 degrees when we were there

Tomb Raider?. Ta Prohm is one of the favourite temples within the Angkor Archaeological Park. The temples and setting are just wonderful but especially the centuries old giant trees give Ta Prohm a special atmosphere. Very picturesque!
Nature took its course. It is unbelievable, all this ruins covered with giant trees, just the roots are amazing, we had such a nice time, great weather, lots of stairs, but enjoyed each minute of it

Fun temple, get here early before the crowds. An excellent place for photos. The trees here are really stunning, and while tomb raider may be a bit of an exaggeration, it's not that far-fetched. This was my favorite temple after Bayan, but be sure to get here early in the morning.
Overrated. Ta Prohm is highly overrated. It looks more at a constuction site.Sure it looks nice where it's overgrown by the trees but most of it is destoyed.
Garden Temple. Lovely view. An ancient temple framed by huge old trees.

Don't miss it. Even when full of tourists, an intriguing place that's a must see. Our guide continually referred to it as the "Lara Croft Tomb Raider" temple, which was funny to us, as neither of us had ever seen that movie. We rented it that night, and can say it doesn't do the real site justice!
The land of Tomb Raider. I like the old trees and the ruins of Ta Prohm. Its much better in actual than in the movie.
Amazing. Loved looking at how this great structure has combined with nature. So many tourists though it's hard to get good photographs.
Avoid the organized tour like plague. GO late PM. This is TombRaider. Meaning it is a stop for masses to go to. Don't get trap in their visit

Epic battle of man vs nature. Amongst the various sites I visited at Siem Reap, I suspect Ta Phrom will remain etched in memory the longest. Neither the largest nor possessed of the highest towers, Ta Phrom's endearing memory will be of the huge tree roots hugging and slowly crushing the temple ruins in a super slow motion dance of death. The sights are a reminder that in the end, nature will be all that remains.
