There are quite a few popular locations where tourists will line up to take pictures of the roots, but don't miss out taking pictures of yourself in the trunk of a huge tree and another through a “dragon's eye” tree root. Get your guide to explain the parasitic fig trees eating away at some huge trees and visit the Third Enclosure Gallery, which has an amazing before and after picture of the restoration. Restoration works are still in progress and it was bewildering to see the sheer numbers of stone blocks to sieve through. Many stone reliefs are in good condition and are beautiful. There is also an unusual relief of what appears to be a prehistoric creature that you shouldn't miss. All this makes Ta Phrom a must see site in Angkor. Spend about 2-3 hours there.

Tomb Raider Temple. Those trees that have grown on the temple WOW!Spend at least 2hrs here to really admire this place beware of the kids selling stuff on the way in they say they are poor but they have so much stock hidden just off the trail ready for the next tourist this is the same for all temples
Butterfly Interaction. Just relax when they come near you... They like to perch and will stay long for pictures.
Wow!!. This was my favourite temple - could have spent hours here. Would definitely visit again if we came back to Cambodia to really soak up the atmosphere.
What a temple!. Fantastic sights with the trees growing all over the temple!Straight from an Indiana Jones set!

Ta Prohm - Popularly known as the root temple. This is the most popular temple with tourist and is located on the Eastern side of the main Angkor complex. This temple was built by king Jayavarman the VIIth. This is called the Brahma temple and also known as a Buddhist monastery. The uniqueness of the roots of trees hundreds of years old supporting the ruins of the temple is the special feature of this place. A classic example of nature supporting man made structure and vice versa. A sight seen nowhere else in the world. This explains the reason why this is the most popular place with tourists and for photography.

one of the best place at the small circuit. here is the best example of what the other temples may looked like when they were discovered by the archaeologist a hundred years ago,although there's much restoration activity on some area during our visit, they left the big trees with big roots, the other fallen roofs, columns and walls as they were,and you can see additional bracing on some old structures and some wooden walk ways, so to preserve the aesthetics of the place
Best temple in siam reap. Great photography chances but there are too many tourist over there.
Tomb Raider. Great place. Great photos. Loved it. Recommend seeing it in the cooler part of the morning.
Monster trees.. Check out the monster trees and feel like Angelina Jolie.

Lara Croft Temple of Doom. This is the one that we all want to see and believe me it doesn't disappoint. The trees though are cut on a regular basis, as if left to grow they topple and could do more damage!

Magical temple surrounded by trees, vines, and fallen rocks. A definite stop on your tour to Siem Reap. A good place to visit early in the morning or near the end of the day. Try to get there before all of the tourists, If you are in the area 2 mornings, try to make one morning here, and one at Angkor Wat.
Astonishing. Dont miss this wonderful sight! A gift to mankind :)

A gem of a temple. The temple is left in a stranglehold of trees. It has been untouched by archaeologists and is in a sad state of disrepair. Much of the structure has been taken over and damaged by Strangler Figs. Because of its natural state, it is possible to imagine the wonder of the early explorers as they stumble upon this temple. It is especially beautiful in the early mornings. Take your time to walk through the passages into the central courtyard and enjoy the silence and stillness. A gem of a temple.

amazing. one of the larger and MUST SEE temples, dedicated to the king's father. beat the crowds by going there at dawn(great photo ops if its a clear day- sunrays trickling/leaking in from the tropical foliage makes it surreal)

Overcrowded, but brilliant scenery!. This temple was amazing. A lot of it is in ruins, but the giant trees that have grown and moulded over the site since it has been built make you realise how small you are in the big scheme of things. It was very crowded, but if you stop following the crowd, you can find your own pathways and enjoy it in the silence of the nature around you. One of my favourite temples, definitely worth the stop.

Ruins lost in time. Think Ta Prohm when you think ruins lost in jungles. Consumed by trees and nature. It's really beautiful, just like I imagined it to be after watching Lara Croft: Tomb Raider (2001) There was that tree that was on the ruin. Except unlike the movie this place was visibly well visited with tourist dotting the place like ants. But if you come here during the low season or if you are lucky and there wasn't a huge bus tour coming through I can imagine this place to be magical. When we was here there are some restoration work going on so some construction equipment was lying around. Inside the temple ground there are some towers that had a really cool echo effect when you thump your chest =)

Tomb Raider!!. This is where they filmed it. But that aside, this is a very atmospheric temple, loads of tree roots, fantastic Angkor architecture and workmanship, and well worth the visit. However, most tourists come here so it can get crowded.
Amazing. This is one of the most beautiful temples. Presently being restored.

Beautiful temple. Great temple. We visited in late May and things were starting to get greener and it wasn't as busy as in the hot season. They were doing quite a lot of restoration work when we visited but was still beautiful.
Similar to Bayon. The true forest temple with lots of picture opportunities

Excellent combination between nature and monument,,,. I have been visited many ancient temple in Siem reap Cambodia such as Angkor Wat, Bayon, Bantaey Srei, but my favorite temple is still Ta Prohm temple,,,

A big surprise. Funnily enough, we had been anticipating Angkor Wat being the big draw card of our trip. We were blown away when we visited Ta Prohm - it is secretive, mysterious, shady, and just so peaceful: silent in fact. For me, it was more moving than Angkor Wat (which I loved visiting) and it was very easy to sit and reflect at each turn . You coudl almost hear the ghosts. It was magnificent. Having said all this ( and because I cant find a spot to sing its praises), Beng Mealea was the real highlight of all the temples for us - it isnt included on the Angkor Wat ticket and is a fair bit further away but if you get the chance, go there. Now that is a treasure.

This is my favourite of all the Angkor sites .... Think Tomb Raider and you will get an idea of what will await you. Ruins covered by large trees growin all of it ... Amazing photo opportunities. Love it, love it, love it!!

It's beautiful & feminine, must visit!. As a second temple to visit in Angkor complex, I think Angkor Wat is a masculine temple & Ta Prom is feminine.The giant old root trees that grows in between the rocks of the temple is its uniqueness. Then the trees grow on top of the temple. Only in Ta Prom!Everyone wants to take pics where the Tomb Raider movie was taken. Must visit!
Huge root on top of the centuries old structures.. Amazing and very memorable. However, there are areas with scaffoldings since the place is under restoration.
In-tree-gued with the tree!. Quite intrigued with walking through the temple that has the tree that cascades through the building!

An awe inspiring temple but over-run with busloads of tourists. This is my second visit to Siem Reap - I guess I should be thankful on my first visit I got to enjoy this temple. This time I tried 3 different times to walk through but the hords of tour buses was very off-putting. Not only that but these bus groups are not polite. I tried to enjoy my time there but was constantly bumped and even shoved a couple times as the tour groups forced there way past me and some others. At that point I gave up and left - I did try to visit again - but each time I saw buses unloading --- reminded me of the lines at Disney World-- scary!I want to remind everyone that these temples are a treasure and everyone should get to enjoy them and please be polite to others that are there.
A bit crowded, but the trees are amazing. The crowds are around the Tomb Raider tree, but they are all impressive.

Trees over grown and my favorite place in Angkor.. This temple was the home of film Tom Raider took place. But I didn't know when the film took so I think before restoration. I visited all the places in Siem Reap and this temple was on the list of my favorite. If you visit I recommend to visit in late afternoon will more less people probably most people move to the place for sunset view.

Like dream.... For me, this place was more impressive than Angkor Wat ( which I loved) - it was more mystical and quiet and a bit more out of the way. The light is amazing, it has a sense of deep spirituality and the sense of nature and structure connecting over time is realy moving.
another piece of magnificent work. the blend of trees with old walls makes it unique, looks as if the walls grew out of trees or vice versahttp://immaculateviews.wordpress.com/
Amazing Ruins. It's not everyday you see trees growing on walls...take advantage when your here and see something truly unique and awe-inspiring

Cool temple, and great guide. This is one of the coolest temples, also known as tomb raider-temple. Lots of stones around Angkor Wat, but with a great guide you get the best stories. I reccomend Mr.Heang. (www.cambodiaroadtrip.com) His English is great and knowledge endless:) Great guy.
fascinating. Beautiful ancient temple with soft detailing,carvings and the nature(trees)= fascinating!

Our #2 Temple. Second only to Beng Melea, our group of four loved this temple. It features some of the beautiful apsaras you will see in other temples and has absolutely stunning overgrowth of trees in the temple. A very unique setting, and while it is a shame that the trees are damaging the structure, their overgrowth is what made the temple one of our favorites. Just gorgeous.

amazing. this is imo one of the more amazing temples in the angkor wat complex. if you have limited time do angkor wat AND THIS ONE!!!the jungle reclaiming the temple and the sounds of birds chirping in the background lend a unique mystical feeling about this place, which you dont even get with angkor wat!!!
Complex. From the begining these stone architectures were built in considering the effects of a tuff plants.

Channeling Tomb Raider. This is where nature goes wild. Imagine big roots eating those similarly massive temples and you get the idea that these trees are also ancient. There are areas that are cordoned from the public to avoid untoward incidences.

Excellent. Know as the 'tomb raider' temple had to be my favourite due to its tranquil setting and the way the figs had taken over the structure. The artwork in here is impressive. For the most detailed carvings and therefore most impressive make the trip out to Banteay Srei!
Amazing trees!. So very cool how they have grown out of and around all the temples. Also neat to see the before and after of the restoration.

Tomb Raider - Lara Croft. Great place to see...big roots....imagining myself that Im angelina jolie as Lara croft....
Although I am not certain how long they can keep the place as the big roots are somehow breaking the place apart....
don't miss seeing this place.....rain or shine dont make sure you come and visit
Great Experience. Amazing interaction between the ancient architecture and Mother Nature with the beautiful trees growing amongst the ruins. Another photographers' dream.

Beautiful Decay. The temple is famously covered with giant tree roots. These roots have crumbled some portions of the site, but in some ways that only makes it more beautiful. Due to the number of blocked passageways, this site can sometimes feel like a maze. It's probably best to enter with a guide the first time you visit so you are sure to see everything. I have been here several times and I still get turned around once I'm inside. Restoration efforts are underway, but hopefully the giant tree roots will remain.

Beautiful ... and the temple with the stegosaurus carving. After two full days of temple-visiting, we were all templed out, but a friend strongly recommended we see Banteay Srei for the beautiful carvings. However, on the way to Banteay Srei, our tuktuk driver recommended we go see Ta Prohm as well. We initially wanted to give it a pass, but he said we really should see it. We gave in to him (mostly because after tuktuk-ing us around for 2 solid days, we had grown very fond of him) ... and boy, were we glad we listened to him!Ta Prohm really is quite beautiful, with huge silk-cotton trees hugging the stones and standing in silent sentience over the ruins. Really, really breath-taking. Many people will have guides with them, but there are also tourist guards within the inner portions of the temple who will happily tell you stories of the temple or offer to show you around. I'm sure this impromptu "guide service" might come as a bit of a pressure to those of you who might not want to be harassed in such a manner, but I really didn't mind. Our "guide" showed us the more popular sights (all this fascination about Angelina Jolie and a specific tree), the best angles to take pictures from, and even pointed out to us the relief of a stegosaurus-like animal which I had made it my personal mission to find on this trip! All in all, for a 1-hour tour, we tipped him USD5, which he seemed more than happy with. Do give Ta Phrom a visit. It really is beautiful, even against the beauty of the other temples (temple-fatigue can set in, I know) and unlike the other temples of Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, this one is mostly in the shade as it is surrounded by huuuuuuuuuge silk-cotton and strangler fig trees. Oh, and souvenirs are always being pushed in your face at all the temples in Siem Reap, but in the inner courtyard of Ta Prohm are some youths who sell original brush paintings. Very, very beautiful, and I had intended to get a few pieces on my way out of the temple, only I forgot. It's something I still regret!

Coolest temple in the complex. Easily the most interesting temple in Angkor park, this temple is known for its massive trees that have taken over the ruins. Roots that reach past the ceiling and wind their way all over the stone ruins make for great photographs and interesting explorations.Be sure to wander off the standard travel path here, as there are many cool sights in the insides of the temples and behind the paths, on the back sides of the complex.
MY FAVOURITE. This place was awe inspiring, loved the ruins mingled with trees absolutely beautiful

The Tree Temple. This temple is very famous for “Tomb Raider I,” and everyone flocks here to take pictures in a particular spot that is shown in the movie. You won't miss it because there's always a line. I call it the tree temple because it is one of a handful that the government left in its natural state when the colonists first discovered it. The tree trunks and roots that envelop the walls, doors, windows, and stray stones are amazing. You really feel like you're in another world. Ask your driver to recommend the best time to visit since this is a popular temple.

250 year old trees growing from the ruins. The delicate balance between nature and preservation is most evident at this temple. While fascinating to see the large trees and roots growing on the temple ruins, you know that the trees will ultimately destroy the temple.

Enchanting!. Ta Prohm is the site where Tomb Raider was filmed. Its a mix of haunting ruins, astounding temple structures, and massive trees with giant roots intertwined through the buildings. It has a peaceful and mysterious atmosphere. It feels like an adventure making your way through the various rooms and corridors. Photography enthusiasts are wont to go crazy with their Nikons and Canons. Visit the place after lunch so the heat will be bearable and there wont be as many tourists "blocking your shots" of the picturesque temple grounds. Hunt for the "stone face peeking through the roots" made famous by lonely planet.
Looks like many adventure movies.Just go see it.. It's a great temple to see how the jungle reclaims the ruins. It was really amazing looking at all the trees that have been left in place.

Like being in the movies!. This site truly made me feel like I was in an Indiana Jones movie. The roots of the trees overgrowing the structures was mind boggling. Careful though...easy to get lost in there.

Wow!!. There were quite a few renovations/repairs going on while we were here- but exploring this temple was still one of the highlights of our trip. Sure sure, this is where they filmed Tomb Raider (and every child peddling postcards outside will tell you if you forget)- but we honestly didn't know this until we pulled up. This temple is unique in that the trees are literally growing out of the rooftops. It's beautiful seeing how the jungle is reclaiming the area- though sad to see the ancient temple falling to ruin. Just go- you won't be disappointed

must see. This is where you'll see the "Tomb-Raider tree." I suggest going early to avoid the bus loads of tourists. Be wary of ambulant vendors who will coerce you into buying scarves, cambodian art and cold drinks =)

loved it - lived up to my expectations and more. loved Ta Prohm, didn't like not many signs, we started along a track and did not know where we were going so turned back. Other temples have small signs pointing to what is along tracks. Hated tour groups who get to set of stairs and then just stop and look - noone can pass

the trees were so unsual. i loved the trees here the temples were all overgrown by trees and they were such a beautiful and amazing site. it just shows how long these temples have been there when you look up and see how big the trees are.unfortunately when we got there, there was a flood of asia tour groups so we found it had to really see it for what its worth since you were fighting through the crowds just to be able to see. just bad timing i guess. make sure when u visit you go later in the afternoon when its quieter or early in the morning when its cooler.if you ride your bike there like we did it a good 13 km from town or from angkor wat it was 8.5 km so a bit of a hike and in that sun so bring PLENTY of water!
Well yeah, it's huge. So?. I visited Ta Prohm after I visited Angkor Wat and Bayon. It's a huge place with ancient ruins. But I can't say it impressed me.

Lara Croft site. Ta Prohm is very very nice but also very very crowded.Trees were allowed to grow among the ruins and it gives the place a magic aura that is somehow crushed by the hordes of tourists (given that it was used for the Lara Croft movie). No matter what, with a bit of patience and timing, its a quite enjoyable site. Lots of details and perfect pictures to be taken.
Surreal. The incredible power and relentlessness of nature. This place must be seen to be believed. Very surreal and inspiring.

BEST temple by far!!. The Ta Prohm temple was so much cooler than Angkor Wat in my opinion! Overrun by trees and the location of the Tomb Raider film, this temple was such a magical place. I could've spent all day there. DO NOT MISS THIS ONE!!
Best of the best. It was so good, we had to go back another day to do it all over again...

Beautiful. This is a must visit. It is amazing to see how massive trees growing on a structure. The beauty of this place is unparalleled when it comes to temples. Definitely a must see on a visit to Siem Reap.
senstational. the vines and tree roots are astounding. Get there early in the morning to avoid the heat of the afternoon and the crowds. All the temples in the Angkor area just defy belief.
a must see. a beautiful temple that you must visit while visiting Angkor Wat.

Nature has added to this ancient marvel. The way the jungle has invaded the buildings here is stunning. The way the trees have spread through the buildings have added to this place in an amazing way.
Don't miss this if at Angkor.
amazing. A must see, you wont regret it. Historically important , stunning scenery, a real wonder
Impressive. Impressive jungle. Make sure to check out the chest-thump-echoing altar.

Best known for trees growing out of the ruins. one of most photograghed site. Ta Prohm is most famous for trees growing out of the ruins and these photogenic feature made Ta Prohm one of most popular temple in Angkor. There are two main types of trees; the silk-cotton tree, and Ceiba pentandra. Ta Prohm is also known for movie Tomb Raider. You will surely want to spend hours here.

Our Favourite. We visited ta Phrom just after sunrise and found only one other small group of tourists here. I realize that it is not realistic to expect to be the only person at a historical site of such value but this was a truly special moment - we felt like we had the entire temple just for ourselves

Interesting trees. This temple has a different atmosphere than the others and is worth the visit. It was very crowded, which is to be expected as it seems to be one of the more popular temples. I would try to get there early, especially before the tour groups.

Forget that awful movie. Don't let bad memories of Tomb Raider keep you from visiting. This is the temple that they chose to keep in its "original" shape; in other words, only enough of the jungle has been pruned back to allow access and protect the temple. Because of that dreadful movie Ta Prohm tends to be a bit crowded, so this is a good temple to put first on your morning list. Even with crowds, though, it's quite dramatic.

Amazing jungle temple. This is a can't miss. If you go, I recommend getting there early before the crowds, like 6:30am early. But it's worth it to have time to tour at your own pace with out lots of tour groups around.
must see!. every temple is different and this is one of the more popular ones that the guides will recommend you seeing...i think all of them are a must see!
Stunning. To us easily the best we visited. Interesting and fascinating to explore.
Best site in Siem Reap. Enchanting area with great atmosphere, especially late in the day as the crowds thin. Dramatic contrasting shapes of the ruins and the massive trees.

Cool looking but too many tourists. I like the fact that this temple has the trees growing out of it and it is still over grown and looks somewhat more adventurous than some of the others.. unfortunately I must have gone at the same point that buses full of tourists did. It made it very difficult to enjoy the coolness of the temple.
Old world charm. We loved this temple more than all the others. We loved the fact that you can still see how nature took over pocession of this temple though the structure stayed standing

Probably the best temple in Angkor Historical Site. It was amazing. The combination of the growing trees, their branches and roots and the concrete of the temple formed an unique beautiful construction: it's simply incredible to see how nature takes its own course if things are left behind.I cannot imagine how Ta Prohm was before, without all the trees around it, beneath it, surrounding it. All I can say is that I don't think the temple would be so special without them.Even if it doesn't has so many carvings and details as Angkor Wat or Banteay Srei, it was my favourite temple on the site.
Tomb Raider Trek. Oh My! The 1km trek we took beside the temple is marvelous. The ancient Strangler Vines are immense. Truly a breathtaking visit.
Fantastic. also a must see when going to the temples around ankor wat i liked the way the trees are and how there root system is all over the place proberly my favorite temple :-)
"The Jungle Temple". Loved the trees and the stones. It was at the end of the day for me, so I wish I had come earlier in the day.
Beautiful coloured stone. Just go, get a guide and take your time. Different colours show at different times of the day shadow and light, ancient stone a photographers dream
Tomb Raider Temple. This is the temple with all of the incredible tree roots growing over the walls. It's even better in real life. AMAZING!!!

Man vs. Nature. A huge banyan tree grows right out the top of a courtyard wall at Ta Prohm, and its trunk been left in its natural state as an exhibit of this dramatic clash between man and nature. Come early to beat the crowds.
Great trees. This temple is in fairly bad shape, but it is because of the huge trees growing in and around the stone work, so it's still beautiful!
The Tomb Raider Temple!. Fantastic photo opportunities for any budding Lara Crofts or Indiana Joneses! Amasing ruins entwined by tree roots - wow!

Breathtaking!. Don't miss this temple. The trees overtaking the structures are just mind blowing and amazing to see. Try and go when there are less crowds and it's a completely different feel. Love it!!

Amazing Atmosphere in The Late Afternoon Light. With our guide,we approached Ta Prohm at 3.30pm through the jungle off a pathway that is usually flooded for 6 months of the year. To get to the side entrance of the temple we had to clamber down several steep embankments which our guide said in a bygone era, were the moats to the temple. There were some local young children at the bottom of a moat who sang us on our way, cute!And once you're inside the walls of the temple, it truly is an amazing sight to behold. The late afternoon light just highlighted architecture you would miss in the middle of the day. We explored until we got asked to leave at closing time.We also visited Angkor Wat and Beng Mealea, but Ta Prohm was my favourite.
my favorite temple of Angkor. I visited it several times and the best one was very early in the morning. Though small, the place has such magic I could stay there for hours!

another fascinating place. This is a smaller temple where enormous trees have taken over and wreaked havoc. It is this that is the most interesting feature. Glad to see that restoration work is being done as otherwise, eventually the place will be nothing but rubble

Crumbling Beauty. Its beautiful in its decay especially how the trees have grown into the walls of the temple. There's a lot of restoration work being carried out so that will get in the way of your pic taking.

Gorgeous Temple. First one walks a few meters to come to the temple between huge and ancient trees.The temple itself is just so amazing! I had to sit there for many hours looking and talking to the guide about all the history. I visited every corner of this temple that I could. What a marvelous combination of nature and man. Loved it.

Wow!. I'd seen photos, but nothing can really prepare you for the sight of those tree roots taking over the temple. Go late in the afternoon when the light is golden. It makes the experience truly memorable.
The Temple with the giant tree roots. This place was a good place for great photo op. Here we got to see the roots of the trees that was all over the wall.
Loved the trees!. Liked the way you can see how the trees have grown around the walls. But tourists who all want their photo in front of each tree are so annoying especially big groups.
Ta Prohm. Inspiring to see the renovation and contribution between governments.

Fine when not overrun by crowds. Of Lara Croft-Tomb Raider fame, this temple has trees and vines growing out of the ruins. It is one of the most popular of the temples and thus tends to be (read: is) overrun by loud and noisy tour groups. We went twice: the first time when it wasn't too crowded, and the second time, when it was very crowded. If you are free-lancing, go early in the morning or late in the afternoon to avoid the crowds... otherwise, it can be an unpleasant experience trying to make your way through the crowds.
Temple + Giant tree roots. My favorite temple of Angkor Wat where the nature has ruled the temple with its tree roots making a great iconic photos.
Mysterious. All the temples have their own personality so visit as many as possible! This one had lots of trees growing out the buildings which was cool looking
Second visit, still love it. I came back for a second visit and am still amazed by this place. If you don't visit Ta Phrom, you've not visited Siem Reap.
Great temple for photos. The overgrown temple showing huge trees growing from its ruins gave great oportunities for photos.

Most impressive temple of Angkor area. The Tomb Raider temple was the temple we liked most during the tour we maid in the Angkor area. The atmosphere at this overgrown, half destroyed temple was great and it is nice to explore the temple yourself.

Exceeded expectations. Tis is my favourite temple and should not be missed. It's is truly forgotten, trees ancient ones growing out of the temples. A wonderful place to spend a couple of hours. Easy t access with a motorickshaw

Lara Croft Tomb Raider Tree. Home to the famous Lara Croft tree. Ta Phrom is equally stunning. This temple is currently being restored. If you only want to see the Lara Croft tree, start from the exit.
Visit my blog to see photos of Ta Phrom: http://erickcamba.blogspot.com/

The power of nature. The interest in this one is the appreciation of the victory of vegetation over stone. It doesn't take too long to walk round but you will be treated to some bizarre sights of the trees recapturing the buildings.

Temple with the Natures art. Ta Prohm is like a temple of art come from the collaboration of human and nature. They have beautiful alleys, carving, together with the root winding thru their wall, windows, and sometimes even breakdown the part of the temple. Weird..., this all create a romantic atmosphere to the temple
The Movie Star. It's small, compared to the other Wats but it hits the spot. See it before the Fig tree roots destroy it

FANTASTIC!!!!. I actually enjoyed this temple the most. Left my mountain bike outside with the ticket checker and in I went. 2 hours later I came ouyt absolutely elated!!!!! I thought it was a wonderful place to isit!!!!!
You just have to see it!. No pictures can do justice to this. You have to experience it for yourself. Just wander amongst everything and take it in as best you can. Less a visit,more an experience!
A highlight of our temple tours. Wow! The way that the trees have grown throughout this temple is amazing. Must be seen to be believed! Definitely worth the visit.

Well worth a visit. This temple is definitely worth a visit to anyone visiting Siem Reap. It was fascinating to see the way the trees had swallowed up parts of the temple. We had a guide which made it all the more interesting.
Worth the visit. THe entire site was just magnificent. Well worth the heat

Stunning. We saw this after Angkor Wat and it is just as impressive - photos in books don't do it justice. Our tour guide steered us away from big groups and knew all the best photo spots - you can pretend to be Indiana Jones here :)

Most beautiful temple. Not the biggest (Angkor Wat) nor the oldest (Bantrey Srei) but easily our favourite and most beautiful
Take a guide if you can to get the most out of the experience.
Amazing. This was our favorite temple to visit. The mixture of stone and trees made it one of a kind. April is HOT in Siem Reap. Take LOTS of water,
The trees!. Loved Ta Prohm. The trees, sadly, are ruining the temples, but they look so cool.

Interesting. Buildings and trees to see what has become a cut tree will fall like Johnny buildings, ancillary buildings, trees and kill Johnny and ... In fact, I leave gatateum're just letting the trees that are rare even know why for sure enjoy the scenic skydive, Form a large tree stretches toward the sky from the ruins is a masterpiece, but exactly where it is said is like the ruins of the "Castle in the Sky" well. The feeling is proof that the ruins had been buried in the woods for a long time that you get drunk in the woods even any great ruins in this way, the forces of nature. Turning off the trees, because tree roots from entering the interior of the ruins, is likely also causes the breakdown of the ruins. I felt the power of nature do not get tired even though many hours.

An incredible merging of nature and stone. I really felt like I had stepped into a time bubble here, walking around this place with the trees taking over some of the stonework. It helped that our guide managed to steer us away from and around the main tour groups so that for some bits it was just us and an eerie silence with only the occassional shout of a tour group in the distance.
Unique and Must See!. Surreal experience, definite must see of all the temples! Great Photo opportunities.

Arrive Early. After watching the sunrise at Angkor Wat on our guides advice we visited Ta Prohm before the crowds arrived. Well worth a visit. Arrive early so you can some fantastic photo's without other tourists in them

The pix don't begin to show it all. The kapok trees growing through the temple grounds are stunning. Got my own great pix to show to friends. :)
Just be aware that the paths are unsteady and might be a problem for those with walking difficulties.

Trees!. Imagine if the trees from the Lord of the Rings decided to lay around some temples and ruins in Angkor. It defies nature the way the trees are on top of the ruins. If you only have one day to visit Angkor, this is a must!
Loved this place. Loved how the trees took back their land. Great picture opps. Try go at lunch time when the tours are at lunch, gives you a better chance for tourist free photos
The one in all the photos!. This is the temple that's overgrown with roots. It's absolutely fascinating and a bit of a maze - I lost my partner for about half an hour in there! Well worth seeing.

A favourite. We liked this place the most of all temple areas. Perhaps it's the greenery and trees, perhaps it's the ruinous piles of rocks, but with plenty of walkable and explorable area around. It's very photogenic. Shame about the hordes who insist on standing individually one by one in front of the Lara Croft tomb, making it impossible to photograph without people. There are plenty of other photogenic spots however. Take your time.

Save this one for last!. We did Angkor Wat and Bayon on the first day. One the second day we took a tuk-tuk to Bantheay Srei and another smaller temple on the way back. Then our driver took us to Ta Prohm. This was the one we had been waiting for! If we has seen this one first, therest, including Angkor Wat, would have been a let-down. This one is spectacular! Enough said.

Return visit.. The juxtaposition of ancient buildings and encroaching jungle is an artistic wonderland. Of course you must have a photo in the "famous places" but look around and see the many fascinating examples of man-made objects and nature intertwining.
Worth seeing. Try and see as much as you can with a good guide that will take you to the best areas if your time is limited.
Amazing!. I was so fascinated with all the big trees especially the huuuge looong roots going up & down of the ruins!
Really amazing. One of the must see sites. Thinking about the centuries during which the trees grew gives you the chills.

Must see!. This is the best temple for photos. Make sure you take charge your camera batteries because you'll be amazed by the trees growing over the temple.
I liked Ta Prohm much better than Angkor Wat and it's less touristy.
Watch out for the kids selling you stuff outside.

From Two Perspectives. More than man's magnificent talent and capacity to endure in order to achieve his/her goal, there is Mother Nature who bides her time, never tiring, until she can reclaim what is rightfully hers. While the temples inspire, nature keeps us in line and on track; another source of inspiration anyway.
World Heritage area. As with the rest of the Angkor complex, Ta Prohm is a wonderful experience for anyone visiting Cambodia.

Ta Promh & Bantaey Shrey. So Ta Promh is a must see, but so is Bantaey Shrey temple. I don't see it on TA. A lot of ppl skip it because it's a little far 34kms from Siem Reap. So ppl that read this, do visit Banta Shrey, it's beautiful. And of course visit Ta Promh too :-)
Raiders's Tomb. With trees still overtaking and growing through the ruins, shows what it must have been like when the French rediscovered it

One of the best temples. This temple is a must see, it's got a different atmosphere than the main Angkor Wat temple. Massive trees sticking out from the ruins. Watch out for the kids asking you to buy stuff at the end! Tip, when you get asked to 'buy' a book for $1 it means it's $1 for a look and $5 to buy it!

Otherworldly. This is the temple where trees have "had their way" with the galleries of stone wending their ways under a green canopy. A lengthy approach to the temple creates anticipation for seeing this often photographed site. The ancient and crumbling stone passageways create a mood of history and mystery, drawing you deeper and deeper into the temple. Trees sprouting atop the building and immense roots snaking their way through openings add to the mood.
Amazing. Hire a guide and go early so you have the place to yourself. Do not miss this temple complex.
Amazing. Fantastic temple that is well worth the visit, everyone should go

Come and see for yourself. If you are reading this you are probably thinking of visiting, all i can say is come and have a look, stay at the Golden Mango in Siem Reap and hire a tuk tuk and driver for a day cost $15. Nothing I can write can tell you how amzing this place is
The Movie Temple. Famous for Tomb Raider this temple deserves much more praise. Incredible tree roots show their muscle as they reclaim their territory.

So incredible. Absolutely magical. Another one of my favorites. There was some restoration work being done so a portion of the site was blocked... but still so worth it to see. Nothing compares or can describe this experience.

Top five temple, sprawling, huge and beautiful. There are lots of tourists but oddly enough most of them take the same path and miss most of the fun of exploring 90% of the site. Take the time to wander and you will be rewarded with stunning views and secret treasures. In most places of the temple I was alone, despite there being hundreds of other people there.
Third best site in Angkor!. Such an atmospheric, charming, wonderful place! So many stunning nooks and crannies to explore and fall madly in love with.

A must see!. Great site to visit but very crowded with tourists. Head out to Beng Melea for a true "lost temple" jungle feel with all of the amazing trees that you see at Ta Prohm and the tomb raider feel.
Brilliant. Another must do & get the best Enlish speaking guide you can get.

Made Famous by the Trees that twist throughout the stones. The temple of Ta Prohm is the perfect lost in the jungle experience. Unlike most of the other monuments and temples at Angkor, this has only been minimally cleared of its undergrowth, fig trees and creepers. It is regarded as one of the most enchanting temples. Ta Prohm was built in 1186, it was built to house the divine queen mother. The outer enclosure are still obscure by foliage but reach well beyond the temples heart. Ta Prohm literally translates to the Royal Monastery and that is what it functioned as, home to 18 Abbots and 2740 monks. Vegetation has matured and caused untold destruction to the buildings but that's what gives this place its charm and gracefulness.

amazing. but too many people. the great thing about these temples is the lost in time atmosphere... here it is lost in mass tourism. got stuck between two groups of korean travelers (about 100 in each group who look at nothing and only want to have their picture taken. quite rude too.)
Tombraider. The earth takes back what mankind has built.The strangler trees are enchanting.
Tomb raider yeah. Felt like a real adventurer in some parts of it. The jungle trees taking over the ruins gives one such a feeling of a lost empire.
See the tree roots. Here are the 'Lara Croft' tree roots!! Amazing how they've grown on, around and through the temple

Beautiful. Beautiful site and a really unique experience. Some parts were completely deserted.... and then came the Asian tour groups. Such a shame that these groups completely ruin these sites. Visit at quiet times if you can. Would return like a shot. Loved it.
Photographers Dream!. Make sure that your camera battery is fully charged and you've got an extra memory card . Tomb raider film set!

Magical. This temple area is really special. I loved it! We were kinda lucky, there was not that many people the day we went there. Its such a magical place, in the middle of the jugel. The trees growing on the temple ruins. They actually did some reconstruction work when I was there, so I am not sure how much they have done since then (desember) but I am not quite sure what I think about reconstruction. Some of the magic with this place is the ruins and the tree growing wild, so I hope they dont reconstruct to of much. BUT on the other hand, it is so good that they take good care of it!
Perfect for photos. The overgrown trees gave the temple a very natural touch. One can sit for hours admiring the beauty of the location.
Where trees grow out of the buildings!. This was really the coolest of all the temples because of the trees - they have taken over parts of the buildings and create a unique environment!
Beware of Tomb Raiders. Anyone that has seen the movie Tomb Raiders will recognize Ta Prohm. It's really awesome to see the way the temple is being swollowed up by the jungle.
Unique temple among the famous wats. This was easily my favorite temple to visit. The giant trees and crumbling walls definitely made me feel as if I was on my own archeological adventure.
Wonderful!. I just love this temple because it showed nature and ancient history entwined in one. Beautiful.
it is a good looking temple with the root of the tree.. I like this temple with the root of tree cover the all the form of temple. i like reconstruction the new entrant.
See What Nature Can Do. Fascinating to see what the trees and their roots have done to this temple.
trees alive. Fun to see the trees all grown up around the temple, but not much else to see compared to the other temples,
Excellent. This attraction can be quite busy but it is still well worth the visit! Unbelievably beautiful and great pictures can be taken all over!
beautiful but too crowded. Had to walk quite a distance, and there were long queues to take pictures on the platform!

Back entrance is less crowded. Approach down a long tree-lined avenue and avoid many of the crowds. Extra points if you find the stone carved Bhudda face cradled by the tree roots! We're on a year-long RTW trip, and there's more about this at www.changesinlongitude.com

A Must See!. The movie "Tomb raider" starring Angelina Jolie was shot here. You'll be awed to see parts of the temples have intertwined with giant roots of trees, sort of married together,and meant to stay & lived happily ever after. Pretty incredible sights, you must visit this temple.

My favourite temple. What you will find at this temple is what I often associate with the whole temple complex. The huge gum trees growing over the breaking walls. Amazing. Be prepared for crowds. Seems there's always a stranger in any picture you take. Can't avoid it!

Nature at work. Imagine the winds blowing leaving deposits of soil and seed pods on top of these architectural ruins. Small plants taking root and sprouting small plants. Over time these plants are nourished from the seasonal rains and the minerals found in the sandstone.As the trees grow their roots clinging to the stones, reach towards the ground longing for water and soil in order to thrive. A beautiful presentation of nature.
great treeroots covered temple. it wasn't as good as i had hoped, and overly crowded however its still worth a visit
Temple with Big Trunk n Tree. One of interesting sighseeing, Ta Prohm temples with lots of Big Trunks of tree like they grow up on with the stones of these temples, u hv to see it!

As others have said, just like in the movies. Seeing a part of a tree growing almost from the temple walls shows you the amount of years these temple has been hiding in the deep forest.
Second must amazing temple in Angkor Wat in my opinion after Bayon.

cool temple. My Lonely Planet book described Ta Prohm as “cloaked in dappled shadow, its crumbling towers and walls locked in the slow, muscular embrace of vast root systems”. That was pretty accurate! It was hard to believe some of the trees were real, as they were so massive and the roots hardened like stone.For more info and photos, check out my blog post at http://growninsouthernground.wordpress.com/2012/03/22/siem-reap-day-1-angkor-wat-angkor-thom-ta-prohm-apsara-dance-performance/.

Not As Good As I Thought. So I thought this would be the one deep in the jungle, dark and overgrown but other than a handful of invasive trees it was not much more so than the others. Lonely Planet painted an exaggerated picture of it.

Awesome. Awesome place, take a spare battery and memory card for your camera as you will need it! Tomb Raider locations aside, the place is amazing in every corner or direction you look. If you enjoy this, get out to boeng mealea (about 1.5hrs out of town) to see a really cool temple that has not been rebuilt or completely cleared as yet.
Ta Prohm. Trees growing over ruins! Just like the movies. Fabulous restoration efforts. Must see along with Angkor Wat.

Crawling Trees. The roots of the trees snaked around the buildings and almost looked like it was holding it together. They are still reconstructing many of the sites from crumbled stones. It looks like a giant puzzle that will take many years to rebuild. Definitely worth a visit.
The Jungle Temple. The huge tree branches which had grown throughout the stones of the temple was a reminder of the power of nature.
Awesome. Good to see restoration work going on to try and preserve these ancient temples. Huge fig trees growing through and over some parts of the temple. Magnificient sights to see.
Amazing. The trees overgrowing the structures is an amazing site. A must when visiting Siem Reap, part of the package cost of the Angkor Wat temple.
As Seen in Tomb Raider. Very cool site that brought flashes of the movie. Loved the trees growing out of the ruins and the 'just discovered' feeling of the site.
Loved The Way The Jungle Has Been Left On The Site. More Work Being Done To The Site Still To Many Visitors.Euro Money Being Spent On the Site.Not By the Outside Interests Reaping The $25 Fee

Breathtaking but crowded. Ta Phrom was beautiful but like Angkor Wat very crowded (our guide told is it is now unofficially just called the "tomb raider temple"). If you have to chose I would go to Preah Khan instead, it is just as beautiful, maybe more, it's larger and has way fewer people.
Our favourite. All the roots coming out of the stonework. Get there early, which applies to most sites, like by 8 a.m.

Mystery and enchantment. The temple is magnificent and the gigantic trees whose roots embrace the buildings create an atmosphere of indescribable mystery and enchantment. Part of the movie Tomb Raider was filmed there. It was impossible not to imagine that Indiana Jones would appear at any time! The place was overcrowded, so it was impossible to take good pictures what was a pity!! It is a must-see!!

Temple of the Trees. This place is amazing, one of the temples that really stood out for me (this one and the Being Melea). The trees are really determined and it's amazing to see the structure being swallowed by the trees!
Amazing place. Truly amazing temple being destroyed by the trees! Very popular and well worth a visit.

Best of all. Trees growing out of the temple. Used in Tomb Raider.Get there very early, we left the hotel at 06:30.Read up about the legends firstPhotos are unbelievable the restauration work is impressive.

No superlative is good enough. We bought a three day ticket for all the Angkor sites ($40) and this one, along with the Bayon in Angkor Thom, rank as the absolute must-sees of the whole group. Ta Prohm is the one featured in "Tomb Raider", with fully mature trees swallowing up the temple walls - and excellent is just not a good enough ranking for it. The day we visited Angkor Thom and Ta Prom is definitely one of our top ten travel experiences ever.

The great romantic one!. Well, this is it folks, the most well known temple of them all, that embodies all that is considered "ancient", long forgotten and history preserved. A must see site for all, who r interested in culture at all.
Trees are beautiful. Did you watch Tomb Raider , and liked the places where Angie did all her tricks. Then you have come to the right place. Ancient and intriguing !
AmAzIng!. This is another must see temple if you make the trek to Cambodia! Your pictures will be amazing, and you will be amazed at the trees growing through this temple. This is an amazing place!
Great temple complex. I like this temple a lot because you can explore all around and inside the temple. However, because of the renovation, you are unable to access some parts of the temple.

Amazing. What mother nature has done here is amazing. There are plenty of photo ops, in fact I took way too many tree root photos. The downside is the number of people swarming over this attraction because it is a must see. Suggest going early or late to avoid the crowds.

Temple in the forest. This one is cut right out of the middle of the jungle. Incredible how it's almost merged with the trees that grow out of it. Also unexpected-- you are walking along in the forest and boom there it is. Gives you a sense of being one with nature and back in time. Less touristed so you will get it, if not to yourself, at least with only a few others. Surreal experience.
super. great and so fresh and relaxing place.we were really surprise by this incredible site.

surreal beauty amidst the woods. famed by "The Tomb Raider" Angelina Jolie, this ruin site is exceptional amongst others as the jungle temple attraction. Unless seen by oneself no one can believe the destructive nature of the tropical forest. whatever is left of the temple premises is being restored by a handshake program of the Cambodian government and the Archaeological Survey of India.

Totally magical place.. I first went to Ta Prohm at around mid day, it was really full of other tourists and so noisy that I decided I just had to return another time when it was less busy. So I organized for a tuk tuk to pick me up at 6am just to take me to Ta Prohm. At that time of morning it was the most magical experience. It was for me the most awe inspiring temple. I rate it as the highlight of my trip to Cambodia and I will return to visit Ta Prohm again.

What a building (and not only because Angelina was here). Angkor Wat is the top, but Ta Prohm may not be missed in your tour along the temples in the surroundings of Siem Reap. It's the place where part of Tombraider was filmed. You can get yourself photografed under the tree where Angelina Jolie once stood (if you manage to work your way through the crazy bunch of tourists from all over the world, but especialy Japan...).

Loved it. This " jungle temple" is in the process of being restored. Not only can you marvel at the giant trees that have taken over this temple but , if you can spare the time you can watch workmen trying to put the puzzle pieces back together again.
Mystical. What may have been 'just another temple' made more mysterious and awe inspiring by the overgrowth of trees. Photographers dream.

Loved the trees!. I had always wanted to visit the beautiful ruins & ancient trees from pictures. I was definitely not disapointed! I was ooh-ing and wow-ing as I walked around in amazement at how humongous the trees were and how it wraps itself around the stones spanning hundreds of years.Do go. U will not be disapointed. This is where Tomb Raider was shot. U wouldn't wanna miss this. If u have just one day to visit the temples, make sure Ta Phrom is on the list. Tip: If u're doing solo traveling, do catch one of the official tour guides and ask them to take your photos. They will be in uniform so its easy to identify them. They would know which are the best angles to choose and will direct u where to stand to get the best shots. TIP them for their kindness, even if u didn't use them as a guide. I had mine taking me all over the place enthusiastically so I was happy. :)

Amazing trees. This is an amazing place. It is where they filmed the Tomb Raiders films with Angelina Jolie. The trees are just amazing the way the roots go all around the building. It was my favourite temple around Angkor.

Still enveloped in jungle. The temple is still covered with the roots of massive fig and cotton trees which spill over the walls like liquid. Sometimes the walls are being held together by the roots and sometimes the roots have wrought huge damage. Almost surreal sight and absolutely top of the list to see.

The temple with the trees!. I think this was the place with the trees growing through the ruins. Again, absolutely amazing and in my opinion the most impressive of all the sights, all the carvings and faces were still in such good condition

Incredible. Absolutely stunning, I think it is my favourite in Angkor. The trees growing over the ruins are just beautiful. And there are lots of nooks and crannies to explore that are quiet and tour group free.
Another stunning temple. Make sure you visit it on the circut around Angkor

How did the trees grow??. If the trees took decades or centuries to grow to that height, you will be amazed that how well the temple can hold. Fortunately restoration efforts are in place to preserve the place for visiting. Visit it before it ever collaspe.

Also good site for birdwatching. One of my favorite temples in Siem Reap. It's a given that the sight of the strangling fig trees and silk-cotton trees weaving their gigantic roots among the temple blocks can be mesmerizing (those are the most photographed as well, I'm sure). But I am also a birdwatcher, and Ta Prohm is where I've found joy discovering that a nearby tree from where I sat one hot afternoon was full of Red-Breasted Parakeets, quietly walking along the tree's branches. There were at least a dozen of them in the single tree, not easily visible among the thick foliage. (Good thing I had my binoculars with me!). I also had fun watching the noisy Alexandrine Parakeets that seemed to favor the taller trees with green berries.

The Temple of Living Trees. Perhaps the most photogenic temple ruin in the entire world, Ta Phrom was used during the filming of the movie, "Tomb Raider." The temple is unique in that the decision was made to continue to let nature interact with the temple in rather startling ways. Altho there is currently an effort being made to stabilize and restore this national treasure, you will still be able to see amazing scenes of ancient trees enveloping and growing out of an over this even more ancient edifice. A definite highlight of our trip the through the temples of the Angkor Wat region.
Nice. For some reason, I liked this place the most. It is in a very ruinous stage. Restoration activities are in progress.

Wonderful experience. Ta Prohm is currently under a lot of construction but definitely worth the trek! My son might have liked the construction cranes and workers more than the ruins themselves. I have mixed emotions about the rebuliding of the ruins since we went to see ruins, but the sections that were rebuilt are simply gorgeous!

Go early to enjoy the atmosphere without the crowds. I was worried I might be disappointed - after all, Ta Prohm has had such media and celebrity coverage. But it was truly stunning. Go as early in the day as possible - it is wonderful enjoying the temple without the crowds.

Jungle overtaking temple!. A wonderful site, despite its popularity. [Ever notice that really great places are often over-run with tourists? Funny, that!] A very atmospheric place, with several trees apparently overtaking the jungle temple. Lots of photogenic spots, despite the crowds. make sure you include it, even on a short day trip.

Rustic & Beautiful. Try to make time to visit Ta Prohm during your time exploring Angkor Wat. Ta Prohm has been left essentially untouched so you can see nature at work, repossessing the land. Trees are growing over & through the stone work and it makes for amazing photos. Apparently Tomb Raider was filmed here.
gorgeous, original. Intriguing mix of the temples and the trees that have overgrown them. One of the most crowded places in angkor complex, over run with tours while we were there.

The temple in the forest. I loved it walking through the debris and big roots of the trees. Too bad pillars and other rulers have destroyed some of the beautiful architecture of the temple. Looks like the roots are now taking over as well...
Indiana Jones relived. This is a very photogenic site, where the temple was overgrown with banyan tress. This gives the site a feeling of Indiana Jones wandering about the Temple of Doom.

Plant invaders. This is the site that seems the closest to Sci-Fi with huge, ancient, towering fig trees with serpentine root systems that seem to have been poured over the buildings on this site. When it comes to the crunch nauture wins out. Amazing and unmissable.
Amazing!. Incredible place. Nature always prevails, and it is evident here. Awe inspiring. Our wonderful guide made it even better.

Atmospheric. We went early in the morning and saw the site in peace.
Breathtaking.
Very much like ruins, felt like it was authentic. Liked the trees with exposed roots. This is where tomberator was partially filmed. This place felt the most like an archaeological site
Gorgeous!. Very picturesque sight. Really different from Angkor. Don't miss this!
Our favourite temple. This temple was so great walking though- amazing architecture mixed with natures delights.

Worth a visit. Ta Prohm is great even if you are not a Angelina Jolie fan ! A little crowded unless you go very early in the morning before the tourist buses arrive. Once the groups come the entrance doorways and all the interesting spots are blocked by people posing and holding up traffic on the wooden walkways.

Unique Temple with Trees Growing Through. We loved this temple, known to most as the "Tomb Raider" temple because the movie was filmed here. For many, this is their favorite in all of Siem Reap and I cannot say I am surprised. We loved our experience here and it is certainly very unique and easy to reach. Our guide, Thy from Cambodian Trails, made sure we got here at a time that we avoided crowds and took us around the best parts not known to others guides. He also gave us excellent insight into the origins of the various parts of the temple. We were thrilled with the experience.

Beautiful Site. Go Early Early!...Was at temple at 6am...Quite magical..Only 2 others present...Watch the rising sun over the temple grounds...Take time to read up and about it and discover the secrets of the Temple...Tip your Tuk Tuk Man!

Loved this area with giant fig trees strangling the ruins. With our expert local guide we were guided through Ta Prohm, had special things pointed out to us like the small stone head trapped between roots, that I don't think I'd have found on my own. I just loved the way nature had overtaken the ancient buildings.
almost walking in a movie in ancient times!. It did gave me a bit of Tomb Raider feeling. Special atmosphere, cool on the heat of day!
Great. This is oldest temple in angkor wat compalex that you should visit
"Tomb raider" temple. Man versus nature - jungle overtaking the temples. Impressive!
Temple vs Nature. Brilliant! This is a rare and unique opportunity to see such wonderful history in competition with the forces of nature. I didn't know trees get this big!
Beautiful!. Don't miss this temple. The architecture and the trees growing down over it, make it an incredible experience. Just amazing.

Wonderful experience. One word about this temple...actually two. Visit it. You climb over, under, and through it. Do not try to climb the trees or walk on the walls, just take a lot of pictures of them. Everywhere you turn there is a picture to be taken. a very enjoyable couple of hours. During my ten days in the Siem Reap area, I visited about two dozen temples and this one was in the top 3 or 4. Not in the best condition, but the atmosphere was so 'Tomb Raider'.

the tomb raider temple. also know as the tomb raider temple because this was where some parts of the movie were shot by angelina jolie. what sets this temple apart from the others are the strangler fig trees that are slowly taking over the ruins. sadly the trees that made this temple the most popular will also be the cause of the temple's destruction because they're slowly destroying the foundation. not much to see here in terms of wall carvings but the trees are exquisite and a must-see.
temple under the roots. I liked this best. some views are known from movie scenes

Be like Lara Croft!. Dodge the crowds and go at lunch time because a lot of people go to this place! They've had some areas cordoned off and some areas being rehabilitated when we went last January 2012.

excellent. With Bayon, the best. This temple, although falling down, has the best preserved stonework, and with the trees growing out of its walls, this is, I suppose, the classic anglor experience. Unmissable
Trees. They were working on this when we visited but still good to see and an easy cycle from the main temples
Loved it. Travelled with a 10 year old and 15 year old. They loved this temple. Well worth the visit.

Excellent first stop to avoid the crowds, and to enjoy the cool and quiet of the morning.. Try to hit this temple as early as possible. If you go right after seeing sunrise over Angkor Wat you will have an before the first tour buses arrive. Great photos, silence to ponder the majesty of the ruins and cool, quiet mornings reward the early risers who venture here.

Ta Prohm Giant Roots and Trees. Ta Prohm temple was built by King Jayavarman VII in the end of 12th century, it is best because it jungle around and inside of temple. The giant roots are the most attraction thing that make this temple full of visitors. The amazing thing is the way of the big trees grow on the temple.
Trees!. These amazing trees growing right up through the temples create powerful images. Well worth a visit!
the trees at this Ta Prohm is amazing. The former hero king 7 was build this temple and dedicate to his mother as I know from the story
Lara Croft. fantastic place to go to you will spend hours walking over fallen masonary and in and out of complexes. they are doing a lot of restorative work there at the moment.

My favourite of all the temples - don't miss this one!. Incredible, breathtaking and just simply jaw dropping beauty. Ta Prohm temple was my favourite of all, and much quieter in comparison to temples such as Angkor Wat and Bayon.
The tree roots are incredible, and the carvings in the stones are fascinating to look at in close detail. Make sure you don't miss this temple.

Eerily stunning. A beautiful temple being overun by the trees, it's fantastic the way they have become part of the building! Look out for the funny tree branch that looks like a naked person trying to scale a fence!
this temple was the best. the way the banyan trees came through the temples making it a picturesque place and took many a pic there

Building Site . . .. Would be stunning but unfortunately for me, the timing of my visit seemed to coincide with major reconstruction and the crowd got filtered to a very small area. Saying this there was still lots to be seen and many photo opportunities are available.

The trees temple. seeing the trees growing limbs thru the temple and over its walls and roofs is an experience not to be missed, awe inspiring and a beauty of our world, the cambodian people must be proud.Thank you for the fact that they kept the trees as they have grown in the temple itself as it really is god's work.

A true Wonder. Ta Prohm is in my top 3 favorite temple sites in Siem Reap. In my opinion Angkor Wat, Bayon Temple and Ta Prohm should be on the must do list of any tourist..especially if you have very limited time. The magnitude of the beauty is indescribable as is the wonderment of the trees growing out of rock. It is truly a world wonder.

Never seen nature so determined to take what humans made. Amazing temple. The trees are so interwoven throughout the temple, it is amazing that it was found and so much has been restored. The carvings, especially the hindu carvings are beautiful We took our Christmas 2012 shot here with the family. Be careful, this is in the jungle. Wear plenty of bug spray and watch were you step. Saw a scorpion on the side of the footpath. Not good for disabled people or elderly people who are unsteady. Lots of thresholds and uneven steps.
The trees. This is the one you cannot miss.When the trees take over your town you know its time to move out.Just 1 of the best sites I have ever seen.
where they made tomb raider. it is beautiful the jungle is swollowing the ruins
Amazing !. I loved this temple, it is stunning and the way the trees have grown around the structure is just spectacular. A must see if you are in the area

Looks like Raiders of the Lost Arc. All the Wats in the Angkor complex are jaw droppers, but this one was my favorite. It has been only partially reclaimed from the jungle and really demonstrates how mother nature can eventually overpower even the most massive manmade structures.
Liked this one best. Overgrown with the trees it really seemed spectacular. The best for me.

Possibly my favourite temple. It is hard to describe the meeting of the architecture of nature and of man on this site. Twisted tree roots travelling within and around the temple structure, and hints of the civilisation within. Well worth a good bit of time!

Destroyd by Too Much Donation. Used to be 'Tomb Raiders" awesome.. now a bunch of stones all numbered for some day rconstruction..Would have been better if Angelina Jolie had donated a school (film school and studio even) then the 'repair' money
I like it - best temple. In the jungle, really nature based the temple, with tree, you can feel how was the life between these 39 towers.

Tree-covered ruins. There are hundreds of temples in the areas and the ways the trees intertwine with the ruins is about the only thing that makes this one stand out. Still, that's pretty cool to see.
Tomb Raider Rocks. The grown of the jungle is still present - this site was jaw dropping, shot up about 200 pics!!

Feels like Tomb Raider indeed!. I enjoyed walking through the ruins of this Bayon style temple. Ta Prohm is simply photogenic, beautiful and atmospheric. The combination of trees growing out of the ruins and the jungle surroundings have made it a very popular visit for tourists. A must visit!

When Nature and Might collide. Some preservation work hindered the complete fun, but overall the site was tremendously magnificent. There were spots in which you could just admire the wonder work of nature, seeing tree roots breaking and slipping through stones.
TREES WERE INCREDIBLE. This is the really famous temple complex with the incredible trees intertwined amongst the ruins. Photos are incredible. I really enjoyed my visit to Ta Prohm.

Get lost, and discover beauty all over. The only thing I can say about this place is to take the path less walked - break away from the crowd, and you will see plenty of things in less crowded settings. The walkways will naturally take you to the main photo ops, but you should really try to get off it to really enjoy the place.You can't avoid the crowd, since this is a major attraction, but you can step away from the most maddening parts of the temple - just get off the wooden walkway and wander.
Take lots of extra photo cards - you will need them.. Well worth the visit - there is a surprise around every corner. Be sure to take a good guide to learn all you can about this amazing place.

Don't miss this one.. Temple in the jungle.....or jungle in the temple! Great foto-ops here.Unlike Angkor Thom and Angkor there are few stairs to climb. thecrocodile tree will certainly get your attention.
The temple set of Tomb Raider. Great architecture and to see the Banyon trees growing up over the ruins is spectacular.
Fabulous. Hot and dusty. Wear trainers to climb around. Get the kids to watch Tomb Raider before you go, it will mean so much more to them.

Lovely especially when the weather is gloomy and grey. Ta Phrom is so spectacular that I have to sit for a moments to absorb its wonder. You have to see it to believe it. No wonder this place is chosen by Hollywood to feature a lost city... It is!
Awe struck!. this is like a jungle temple with trees 400 to 500 years old growing out of the walls, etc. This was my favorite temple and I would come back just to see this one again!

Liked more than Angkor Wat. We went here straight after seeing the sunrise at Angkor Wat and enjoyed the quiet at that early hour. Also enjoyed the fact that it had been left almost in the state in which it was discovered with trees taking over and almost becoming part of the stone work. We did as suggested and walked through from the east gate through to the west gate.
Super awsome!. This place was in the middle of the jungle and it was super awsome. Recommend it alot...

Wow! Overgrown jungle among the ruins. I really wanted to see this particular temple, as it seems so much like the surrounding jungle is trying hard to reclaim ownership of the ruins there. However, I didn't expect it to be so gorgeous! I loved it!While this temple has been partially restored, the enormous tree roots growing over, through and around the buildings makes this a unique place to visit. The balance between the restoration and leaving it in it's natural degraded state definitely makes it unique among the temples around Angkor.Unfortunately, there are always a lot of tourists roaming around this site. Be patient, wait for the larger groups to leave and you get better photo opportunities, plus the chance to explore and enjoy the ancient feel of the place on your own (until the next group arrives).Be sure to wear comfortable walking shoes and take plenty of drinking water.
Stunning. Just my most favourite temple complex of them all. Again get here early and avoid the peak heat of the day. Have yourself the afternoon by the pool at your hotel... double win...
A must on your to do list. This site has not been cleared totally of jungle and massive fig and silk cotton trees grow through the ruins.

closest thing to discovering a lost civilization buried in the jungle. Yes, there are LOTS of tourists. But it's still not too hard to find a secluded spot by yourself and immerse yourself in the ruins of an ancient temple overtaken by nature's vines and trees (and what trees!), while listening to birdcalls for a soundtrack.

Different from the others, and not to be missed. Put it up there with Angkor Wat and Bayon. The balance between the restoration and leaving it in it's natural degraded state makes it unique among the highly trafficked temples of Angkor.

Nice but crowded. One on the most popular temples since the movie Tomb Raider (or parts of it) was recorded here. The temple is not in very good condition and restoration work is in progress at the time we where there. It's surrounded by jungle and big trees with huge roots growing over the temple walls. This is one of the temples you don't wanna miss. Expect busloads with other tourists to share it with you. It's a small temple so it really gets crowded. Get here early (or late in the afternoon).

where nature keep his right. Absolutely amazing
By far our favorite temple, do not miss that one.
Nature here recover part of the temple it seems like in a film, architecture and nature , amazing
crazy crowds. Visit early to avoid the crowds...during the day too crowded, always crowded, but an amazing place

The "Raiders of the Lost Ark" Temple. A lot of people skip this one but I would recommend it strongly. The way that the trees have taken over the temples which were lost to jungles until the French discovered it a couple of hundred years back is absolutely amazing. Great place to go during the day. I would not like to be lost here in the dark ! Has an air of mystery like all the other temple sites in Siem Reap.

My favorite. Watch the sunrise at Angkor Wat and then come straight here in the morning and wander through the ruins. The morning light is definitely the best, and because its not usually the first stop for tours, you'll be one of the only people there.
One of the place you should see before you die. The trees grow inside and on top of the temple really amazed me. Kudos for the massive restoration works which currently on going when I was there.
Pure Tomb Raider. I think this was our favourite temple of Angkor. We were blown away by it - huge tree trucks growing through the ruins. A must see.

This is where Tomb Raider movie was film. Very interesting to see such a huge trees rooted over a building. Beautiful man made stone wall sculpture every where. The green swap looked scary, fascinating, and alluring. Keep you guessing what you're going to find inside the place.
Lara Croft moment. It is just as you will expect it to be. The way the trees grow within the buildings are amazing.
Unbelievable. This temple has been left more or less as it was found, with an overgrowth of jungle and portions tumbled down. Sections will be familiar to those who have seen the film "Tomb Raider".

Wonderful ruin, one of the few not fully restored. Although this site gets a lot of attention for being the filming site for Tomb Raider, this ruin deserves more credit than that. The ruin has been partially restored, but they have allowed the jungle to remain, several trees that have grown over the site remain. It's is a great way to imagine what kind of disrepair the sites had fallen into since their glory days. Go, then imagine Angkor Wat with a few of those monster jungle trees taking over the place.
TOMB RAIDER!!. Very cool feel of nature empowering remnants of ancient civilization.

A place not to be miss to visit - the film shot of Tomb Rider. Hey, everyone hears about the history of film shot on Tomb Rider, most tourists queuing for photos taking here. It's an old temple with many tree roots which were few hundreds years old and grown between the sand rock where you can view gigantic roots (most). Impressive place to see by yourself. Should visit.
This is a must see, don't miss it. this site is special with all the large overgrown trees and roots in the ruins. Less tourist and great picture taking. This was our favorite site.

Secret to Seeing Ta Prohm. This is my fourth trip to Cambodia and to the temples of Angkor. This January we were there over the Chinese New Year and the crowds were the worst that we had ever seen. I would love to see Cambodia stop the use of big buses and large tour group. The buses are too big for the roads and some of the magic is lost when they barrel past you. Large tours who travel in large groups of 30 people + make it very hard to see and appreciate the temples. Splitting the tour group up into smaller groups to see the temples would make it more enjoyable for every-one, even the tour groups. Ta Prohm has always been one of my favorites. You can still see traces of the Jungle swallowing up the temples with the twisted fig trees growing right inside and up the temple walls. There is a secret to seeing Ta Prohm the way that it can truly be appreciated though and I almost hate to tell you how. While the mass of tourist are scrambling to Angkor Wat to see the sunrise - do the same but go to Ta Prohm instead. You will arrive in the dark so don't forget to take your flashlight . Once inside the temple just sit there is silence and watch and listen to the jungle wake up. It is amazing. When there is enough light go and explore. This January when we were in Ta Prohm we passed only one other couple and that was after an hour of having the temple all to ourselves. It was magical!

Spiritual. I loved Ta Prohm most of all. We were early enough to beat the crowds initially, but we spent so long here that the crowds caught up to us. Just so gorgeous here. Also very interesting to see the restoration work going on. Take some time to sit and soak up the vibe of the place.

Old Trees and Older Temples - Cool. We visited Ta Prohm soon after lunch and it was not so crowded. There were some quiet cool corners where people could take rest, read and imagine the ancient times. Old trees were everywhere and they were growing between and above their older neighbours, temples. There were some funny trees with big holes at their bottom which was large enough to hide a person.There were some restoration ongoing but the work did not affect our visit.
Eery temple. Ancient ruins overun by nature, as featured in Tomb Raider. Best to see in evening light.

For us "best movie of 2012". If you forget your camera or mobile and instead of "clicking" you stop to just look carefully and passionately, you'll realize that in very very slow motion you are watching just in front of you the eternal fight between man and Nature.

iconic for a reason. I felt, and still feel, that I needed to see this site. It's very different from most of the other temples and I greatly enjoyed it. I was a bit disappointed, only because I was expecting to see 50 different examples of massive trees, rooting themselves through the ancient stones, and there are really only a handful. This was sad for the photographer in me, who wanted to try and get some unique shots of this well known site, but the small number of trees, compared with the Large number of tourists trying to take pictures of/with them, didn't leave me very inspired. All that being said, it's still an amazing place to go, my expectations were just a bit too high.

Tremendous atmosphere despite the crowds. We visited Ta Prohm in the afternoon which was abit of a mistake as it was heaving with visitors but nevertheless it bacame my favourite temple for its jungle atmosphere. Giant trees and their roots literally grow out of the tumbledown walls and there are pockets of tranquillity even on a busy day. Very pleasant tree lined walk, too as you exit the temple

Tomb Raideresque. Parts of the Temple was under restoration, so there were a lot of board planks and green nets all over. The inner temple was somewhat intact and we had fun watching a couple of groups take of their footwear trying to climb a tree trunk ala Angelina Jolie. LOL.

The jungle reclaiming the temple.. We chose to see this temple first before viewing the others - from reclaiming jungle to Khmer ingenuity.This is the most atmospheric of the temples with huge tree roots, piles of rubble and narrow corridors blocked by huge stones.We were approached by a "guide" who looked the image of the hermit monk engraved on many of the reliefs. He led us through narrow doorways, thin spaces and over tree roots to find the perfect "picture opprtunity" without a word of English and only by using sign language.
