The Tmple of the Old Capital. Beautiful and contrasting architecture to Angkor Wat. This magnificent temple whilst still in reasonable repair bears the scars and predation of its surrender to the jungle but it is still a formidable sight and is undergoing a lengthy programme of repair.
Busy busy busy!. Its amazing but busy in mid mornings, might be better ay dawn when everyone else is out side angkot wat!

Can be busy but worth it. A very popular place partly because of Tombraider! They have put a couple of platforms which are constantly full of Korean tourists having their picture taken by the tree roots so it does feel very touristy but seeing nature intertwined with the temple makes it a place not to miss, try and find a time where it could be quieter if you can.

Amazing temple. Really liked this temple, plenty of photography opportunities with the huge trees growing amongst the temple walls. The day we visited there was a huge crane and a lot of restoration work is going on, where they were working was cordoned off but there was still plenty to see and it is definitely worthwhile including this temple in your itinerary. Again best to go late afternoon when there are not so many people around.
Must see. Still in its 'natural state' as discovered by the French in the 19th century. Trees are intertwined throughout the structure and give it the most amazing atmosphere.
Ta Prohm. Very interesting site. The trees growing through the stone are other worldly. It is in the process of being restored, but there's still plenty to see and marvel at.

Not our favorite. We had 3 full days to explore the temples. If we had a chance to go back, we would likely skip Ta Prohm and spend a day visiting the sites that are further out. That being said, It had interesting parts to it, and will likely not disappoint. It was more crowded than the others. The giant tree is a good photo op.

Amazing temple overgrown with trees. This temple isn't in as good a condition as some of the others (such as Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom), but that's what gives it a lot of it's charm. In deciding not to remove all the trees that had overgrown this temple, restorers allow us to imagine what it must have been like to rediscover these temples in the jungle after so many years. The carvings and structures that remain are beautiful and the whole complex has an aura of mystery about it.Another nice thing at Ta Prohm is that they have an area where they show you some of the restoration work that's been done and continues to be done so that you get a sense of how the temples are being painstakingly put back together. Finally, our kids loved exploring this temple and climbing along various tree roots and rocks that were accessible to the public. And if you like this temple, make the effort to go to Beng Mealea - similar to Ta Prohm but even bigger and less overrun with with tourists (which, of course, is the only problem/negative of Ta Prohm).
Our favorite. Whith its trees on the walls. We feel like indiana jones. Manage to visite when there are not too many groups !

The Jungle Temple. Photos don't do justice to the serpentine limbs of trees taking hold of the temple. The only down-side was the number tourists. We made the mistake of going in the day. Stick to early mornings where you avoid the crowds to truly enjoy the beauty of Ta Prohm

Banyan Trees!. Ta Prohm seems somewhat mystical because of the Banyan trees that are destroying the temple while simultaneously adding to its beauty. We walked all around the temple looking for one specific tree, which was unfortunately somewhat hidden by scaffolding. Oh well. There is a famous tree that was in the movie Tomb Raider with Angelina Jolie. Now I have to go back and look for that scene!If you like Banyan trees, visit the backside of Banteay Kdei and Preah Khan.
in the roots of stones. Amazing place, surely more magical if less crowded. You can feel the strenght of nature

Visually stunning - despite the crowds. Famed for its role in Tomb Raiders, but nevertheless a fascinating site - 'preserved' in its overgrown state, rather than 'restored' to ancient monument status (reflecting UNESCO's current policy). Stunningly photogenic, despite the crowds, especially the famed tree trunks growing in and around the ruins - and holding them together in many cases. But wear comfortable shoes!
amazing. this is one of the most symbolic temple of angkor wat and cambodia. it was really impressive and wonderful character for our pictures. you definitely have to visit it

Compulsory!. Has to be seen even on the briefest of trips to the temple area. The famous creeping root systems are slowly being removed as they destroy the stonework but the peace and shade this temple offers even in the middle of the day is a great relief for sore-footed tourists.For a far more dramatic tumble-down temple experience you should try to make a pre-dawn drive the 1.5 hours to Beng Malea though.
Photographers paradise. What an extroidanary place. A photographers dream. Could walk around this place for hours
amazing. get there super early to avoid crowds - we were the second couples at 630am
Nice small temple. Must see cos its in all the movies and pictures but it's really small and you can finish all in under an hour. Go early

Very Crowded. Ta Prohm is amazing and definitely one of the more atmospheric temples in the Angkor complex. However, it was so crowded one could hardly move and had to stand in line to take pictures - definitely not what one is looking for and totally spoiled the impact. Go early or between noon and 2pm to experience this wonderful place.

Work in progress. I was a bit concerned about the current restoration work being done but all for nothing. The work that is being done doesn't impede the overall experience at all. Still a very eerie place to be with the trees taking over in places.
Well Preserved. A must see at Angkor. Ta Prohm, and the nearby Ta Som are great for a half day temple viewing.

wonderful - our pick!. we nearly left the kids at the hotel but the guide urged us to coax them out and we are so pleased we did - we went at 4pm - cooler - crowds gone - we could have spent hours there. this is the jungle temple - a photographers dream including amateurs like us - with every step it just got better, evocative, magically.Inspired to leave it this way - huge trees and their roots are growing over the temples -m as they trees destroy them they are restored but the jungle is allowed once again to reclaim them. Ta prohm - a must!!

Tomb Raiders filmset. Liked this Temple the best as it has so much character mainly provided by the figs that have laid their roots over and around this temple. Discovered overgrown and brough back to stunning life.

Go early if you want to avoid the crowds!. I had to visit this area twice. The first time I went it was bombarded with tourists and it was difficult to get photo's without tourists in them. The second time I went was at 7am and there were few tourists there but they did start to show up around 8am-9am when the tour groups arrived. Go as early as you can to avoid the crowds.
Simply amazing!. I don't have words for it. Go in the yellow morning light when the sunlight plays between the big trees and the ruins. It is a symbiosis between mans creation and natures forces.
Mystic!. I liked this place very much... it's telling you a story when listening carefully! It's just amazing to walk and see... even though it's under construction these days.
The root. Ruin temple with the root rooted for years. Unbelievable

Overcrowded and has lost its true meaning as everyone calls it the "Tomb Raider" temple. There are more beautiful temples and views than Ta Prohm. The outcropping roots are beautiful but marred by the overcrowding of too many tourists at the same time. Was surprised there are platforms showing sites where the temple was featured in the movie for that "picture perfect" moment but beware of the flogs of people waiting to have their picture taken there. It was a beautiful temple but visited by mass tourists for the wrong reasons

My Dream Comes True. I had been dreaming to go to Ta Prohm long ago. Had seen a lot of pictures. Again, due to flood, I was told i can't visit it. So dissappointed, thinking that I had come all the way, purposely, & most importantly to see this. At last, I made it. We made it. The tuk tuk driver took me there. I had to wear rain coat to explore the place. I don't mind at all. I am impressed. I am energised.

There's more to Ta Prohm than those amazing trees. The tentacles of the massive trees are responsible for making Ta Prohm such a distinctive temple site, and most photographers have to endure the bus loads of tourists who descend upon the site in waves like invading ants after about 8AM. I have found that the best way to truly enjoy all my favourite ruins (and Angkor Wat is NOT one of these) is to go at dawn, before 6AM. This is clearly not everyone's idea of what they think they want to do on their vacation, but for those who want to experience the serenity and beauty of Ta Prohm and other ruins like Bayon and Preah Khan) this is the only way to go. Not only do you have a much better chance of taking great photos without the stress of inconsiderate tourists, you actually get to imagine yourself as the explorer who discovers the ruins for the first time. It's priceless.
My favourite temple. The jungle temple is a must see- absolutely stunning
Great atmosphere. This is one of the "must-see" items on the Angkor Park list - don't mist it.

A real maze - try to beat the crowds to make the most of it. Ta Prohm is magnificent but because the central site of the temple - the bit people actually come to explore - is relatively small, and the volume of people attempting to cram into it is very great - above all because of the famous unrestored state of the temple where trees and rock co-exist - the effect is not for the claustrophobic. Make no mistake, it is still WELL worth a visit; the temple is undeniably beautiful and has a labyrinthine quality that adds to the sense of adventure. But at peak times it also adds to the sense that you and many other busloads of tourists are all doing your Christmas shopping in Oxford Street at the same time. It is, perhaps, just a bit too much and the closure of the centre of the site, whilst adding to its maze-like quality, also serves to increase the crush. We didn't feel the same at any other Angkor temple.2 tips to avoid this:- Try to got to Ta Prohm early in the morning. We didn't, but next time this will be a top priority. Having the temple more or less to yourself would be an astonishing experience.- Explore all of the nooks and crannies. If you have the 'Ancient Angkor' book follow the author's tip of doubling back on yourself in the site to Ta Prohm's less explored Southern Tower and Library where you just might get a bit if space to contemplate the temple without getting in the way of someone's shot.

More impressive than Angkor Wat. It is the most amazing place. When we went to Angkor Wat, we thought that nothing could impress us more, but then, we went to Ta Prohm.It was abandoned many centuries ago, and the jungle just "absorbed" it. The temples are covered by trees and roots, and became just one. It is really hard to describe, the beautiful temple, the noices of the jungle, the parrots flying abobe your head.

The best Among All The Temples. Personally, I prefer Ta Prohm not just because this was the temple where Tomb raider was shot but because it has lots of trees and not just ordinary trees but huge trees. Its a combination of the temples plus nature.

most beautiful temple there. from all the temple sites we have visited , this was the most impressive one. it's in the middle of the jungle and there are all these tree's growing from the ruins of this temple...a very nice scenerie there... will put some pictures up soon

Atmosphere +++++. This temple complex is the best in Ankor Wat.Most of it not restored, with trees growing right out of the temples.Could spend the entire day here, busy at times but not like the other restored sites like Ankow Thom or Ankor Wat.Best time to go is rainy season when fewer tourists around but muddy. Amazing place will go back for sure again.
As nature left it. Great temple to see as nature has left its mark, ignore the touristy photo ops.

Go in the early morning or late afternoon to avoid the crowds-amazing atmosphere & great photo opportunities;)! must see. This temple is part of the Angkor Wat complex, a short distance by tuk tuk from the main Angkor Wat, Bayon & other temples. We went in the late afternoon(around 3 PM) & it was fairly empty. Words cannot really describe how beautiful the whole complex is--huge trees interwined within the temples, lots & lots of moss covered temples & bricks that have fallen from the temples scattered everywhere. Since it was quiet, largely devoid of tourists at that time, we took our own time just wandering around & taking pictures. Here are a few tips;1. Try to go in the early morning or late afternoon when the tourists are at Angkor2. Carry hats & water- there really are no restaurants nearby, no place to buy water.3. Be wearing a sturdy pair of shoes- while most of the temples are fairly easy to climb through, rocks are piled in places & could be difficult to climb in sandals & open shoes.4. Be sure to see the famous "Lara Croft" tree first- that is the most popular photo opp & a large group could mean a long time waiting!

lives up to expectations. Brilliant - juts like Indiana Jones/ Tomb raider and all that. Kids allowed to clamber about a bit so they loved that. Quite busy but we were there peak season, didnt spoil the experience. A must see temple
The Pick of Angkor?. The Tomb Raider affiliations aside, this is a must if at Angkor - it is just an eerie but engaging place where the buildings are in contest with the surroundings
Brilliant. Easily the most photogenic site in the complex, and very much worth the visit.

Tomb Raider site. This is location where Tomb Raider was filmed and a guide will point out the spot where Angelina fell into the underworld. Full of trees growing out of the temples and roots stretching everywhere. Truly an amazing place to visit!

Stunning. This was my favourite of the temples - wild and surreal and unlike anything I had ever imagined. Be careful though, as the crowds can be quite overwhelming, and there are many touts about, including very young children. I would say please be respectful of this temple - when we were there, many tourists were climbing over the fenced off areas and even moving the signage to get the perfect photo! I was so frustrated to see this behaviour, remembering that it was built as a place of worship, and I think it is only a matter of time before someone falls and gets hurt or damages the building.

Your chance to feel like Lara Croft!. This is the temple where parts of Tomb Raider were filmed. More restorations are currently being undertaken, but there are plenty of areas to explore.The place is a photographers dream with giant tree roots growing through the ruins. We came twice to catch the different light in both the early morning and at dusk. One temple I consider a must see... and there are plenty to choose from!
The Lara Croft Temple. Didn't see Lara Croft but still worth a visit! It was fascinating the way the trees have grown around the temple buildings. Too many tourists but well worth a visit.
Tomb Raider. If you ever watched Tomb Raider, you will love this place as it gives a nostalgic feeling of being on the set!

The best of the lot. This is the Tomb Raider temple and the one that is commonly mistaken for Angkor Wat in various books. Angkor Wat doesn't have trees growing from it, this place has. In a state of disrepair which adds to the atmosphere of the place. Would be 5 stars but has essential maintenance at the front of the temple

Another Temple Jem. Huge trees growing out of it and much in a very damaged state but facinating. One is permitted to go where one wants, some places may even be dangerous as huge stones could fall but we risked it hopeing there would not be an earthquake!

So much character. Ta Prohm is an astounding looking place. As the tree takes over, it is gradually choking the temple beneath it, creating a surreal vision. This was my favourite place I visited in Siem Reap.

Best temple in all of Cambodia. Take your time, don't hurry it. Sit down for a while and take in the marvelous ruins. Walk through the labyrinth-like hallways, get lost in the ancient corridors. Skip the photo-ops, but take pictures. This is one temple you'll definitely remember from your Cambodia trip.

The 'Tomb Raider' temple setting. Walls, carvings gradually being swallowed by massive tree roots. Intricate carvings and stunning architecture.
Somewhat shaded during the hottest part of the day.
Tombraider magic. Trees weaving around the fallen temples. Beautiful bas reliefs. Very special

This one if nothing else. Just unbelievable. If you have to chose between Angkor Wat itself and Ta Prohm, do Ta Prohm! Nature at its most amazing.I was on a crutch following knee surgery but managed it without too much difficulty. There are no facilities at this site although there are the usual food stalls and kitch sellers outside the gates.A 3-day pass for any/all of Angkor Wat costs USD40. Worth it. You can come and go as you please for a duration of a week from date of purchase and/or 3 visits.

Simply Awesome. We visited the Ta Prohm first thing in the morning, and there were very few tourists at that time. It's just an amazing place with the trees and roots taking over the structures. Do yourself a favor and go...

Toll by mother nature. How can mother nature be so cruel? Yet it has been. The tall gigantic trees which have grown into a monstrous form on these temples is a sight. Unfortunately, this has been a cause for the ruins in this area along side many other reasons. Though scary but have a very picturesque angle to this entire area.

Incredible. Ta Prohm is one of the better known Angor sites, even if you dont know the name. Its the one made famous by Tomb Raider with the trees growing over the ruins. Surrounded by trees, it is a real labyrinth and we spent most of and afternoon getting lost and exploring. The place was being extensively restored and the work being done is amazing, you can see this in the before and after photos dotted around. Because of the restoration there were big areas we couldn't see but that didnt stop it being one of the highlights of Cambodia. We were in Siem Reap for 3 days and visited Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm. It was an unforgettable experience and a place I would encourage everybody to visit.

Awe inspiring. The Ta Prohm temple has to be seen. I haven't ever seen anything like this before except in "Tomb Raider" (the movie was shot there!). The gigantic trees that seem to have erupted all over the temple defying the laws of gravity is quite amazing. The entire family (big and small) enjoyed visiting this temple and clicked many photos with all the different kind of tree formations.
Memorable and fascinating. Make sure to see the rebuilt part next to the still collapsed buildings.
MUST SEE!. Trees have overtaken the temple, and mother nature tries to reclaim its land. There's beauty in these massive trees with its roots choking the concrete temples. What a sight to behold.

Magical!!. It feels like you have walked onto a movie set when you enter Ta Prohm; trees grow out of ruined wall and mosses cover many of the carvings adding to the magical, mystical feel of the temple. Absolutely stunning!

Incredible sight. This temple is one of the very best. To see how the trees grow on top of the stone walls is really something to behold, and warrants going to see in person. If you are in the region, ensure you don't miss Ta Prohm.

Very cool. If you came to Siem Reap to get that indiana jones/tomb raider feeling, this temple is one of the many places to definitely visit :)
Very cool aura to the place, historic and majestic.
Awesome photo-op :)
The trees clinging to the structures make you feel small and insignificant (not in a bad way)

Small and crowded, but worth it.. Try to visit this must see location during an off time to avoid the crowds and improve your shots at getting great photos of the key areas where the trees grow through parts of this temple.

Eerie but amazing. Had to see this temple as it is famously known as the Lara Croft/Tomb Raider temple. It's amazing how nature has taken over the temple with giant tree roots/trunks that 'drape' over the walls. Looks like an invasion by giant octopuses in some sci-fi movie. I found it rather eerie and fascinating at the same time. Not my favourite temple but still a must see.There are 2 famous tour routes: red and white. The white route can be done in a day and includes 3 temples: Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom (with huge Buddha faces) and Ta Prohm (Tomb Raider temple). The red route requires 2 days and covers more temples. After a day and a bit, we were all templed out especially after visiting Angkor Wat for its sunrise and sunset. If you are short of time, just do the white route. Even though we bought a 3 day pass, we decided to spend the third day in Siem Reap town instead. Note that despite the red and white routes being clearly marked on the hotel map, we found it very confusing when we were at the temple sites as the so-called red or white routes are not clearly marked. So glad we hired a guide - Mr. Poy Pines (he can be contacted directly: duokbuffoon@yahoo.com) to show us around. He was excellent - patient with my boys, humourous and knowledgeable.Temple passes: 1 day pass costs US$20, 3 days pass costs US$40 valid for any 3 days in a week. An unflattering photo of you is taken when you pay up and the picture will appear on your ticket which you have to carry with you througout the 3 days and there are checkpoints at each temple. Children under 12 go free but you need to bring their passports as proof of age which is a pain. I prefer to leave them at the hotel safe but any saving is a saving especially if you visit the whole area more than once. If you purchase tickets after 4:45 p.m., it is dated the following day but you still get to visit the temples for free for the rest of current day (temple shuts at about 6 p.m.).

Amazing trees grown into the temple!. Cool to see where some shots from Tomb Raider were filmed. If you like Ta Prohm, you should pay the extra $ & go out to Beng Melea - another temple buried in the jungle but was more interesting to me & fewer tourists.

Nature is gobbling the temple!. I had seen pictures and films, but nothing prepares you for the famous tree eating the temple. It is just....out of this world. Needs to be seen to be believed. Amazing.

Standing still. The trees have overtaken slowly and steadily this forgotten place and have merged with the walls of the Wat creating incredible symbiosis. One of the smallest temples but the forms and shapes catch your attention and you simply can't let go...even more incredible is to meet a monk stralling around in its orange robe. Maybe one of the best known images largely due to the Tomb Rider movie
The trees seem almost human !. Don't stand on the same spot for more than a hundred years or the trees will get you ! Not so much remains of the temple but some great photo opportunites.
Haunting and beautiful. Seeing the trees growing into the temples with their intertwining roots in the walls is just amazing.

Trees are the most amazing part!. When we approached this temple tomb raider was on my mind. This is one of the most spectacular temples not so much the buildings but what mother nature had done to it. The tree roots a literally covering the temples giving it a antient and adventurous feel. The place is super crowded so be ready to wait to get that perfect shot.
amazing. same as the rest - everyone should see to experience the size and strength of the jungke, the discovery of it all - wow

Like stepping back in time. This temple is really cool - you can almost imagine what it must have felt like to come across these temples in the jungle, before modern times. It's crowded but so worth it! You can find quiet spots if you look.

Go early. This temple does not disappoint, but as it is so famous, do go early to avoid the crowds of rude and obnoxious tour groups. Get there early and take your time taking in as much as you can, I know they are trying to repair it, but with all he tourist traffic I have a feeling it is an uphill battle!

My favorite. And that is saying a lot, cuz I liked them all. You'd think you'd get bored, but no way, they are all different and each has something special about it. This one though, with the trees encroaching on the walls and holding up parts of the temple is stunning. The trees are huge, the roots are huge, the temple blocks are huge, and the way they come together is mesmerizing. Loved this one!

Feel like Lara Croft in this "cool" temple. Another excellent temple to photograph but it is best to go early or in the evening to capture the best light. This is definitely larger than the Bayon temple and we almost got lost wandering around the place (we ended up walking in a circle) while trying to find the other exit. The huge trees encircling parts of the temple create both shade and an aura of ancient ruins being engulfed by the jungle - quite an interesting feeling. It is quite easy to understand why Tomb Raider was filmed here.

Templed out?. There is something quite special about this place. I personally have found each temple different and interesting but this does beat them all. Around every corner you feel you are about to make a new discovery ... Perhaps it's my alta ego Lara croft
Ta Prohm - Jungle Temple. No wonder this is straight out of a movie (Tomb Raider), this gem in the jungle is a must see.

Unique atmosphere. Ta Prohm was left as unrestored as possible to give a sense of how the whole site appeared to the French archaeologists who first explored the site. Although necessary work is now being done it really has a unique atmosphere, with enormous and beautiful trees overwhelming some of the buildings. It is both eerie and beautiful.

Good but small and overcrowded. Even though this is super cool (Lara Croft: Tomb Raider) it is very small so it get's wuite crowded. But a visit to Siem Reap without going to Ta Prohm would make no sense. Don't miss!

Nice tree covered temple. I like my trip to this area. Very nice scene of the temple, covered by trees. This place was abandoned for some times before.The good thing was i got in to this area from the other side of the entrance, so it was a different entrance than the common entrance for tourists. It was nice, we have to walk through the jungle until we reach this famous temple.One of my favorite place...

Wonderful ruin. Though this temple is very much 'commercialised' and full with tourists at every hour, it did not disappoint me. Explored every possible room/corner that I could get to and it's indeed really impressive. One can't imagine how maginificent it would have been if the nature did not stake a claim on it. If you are going without a tour guide, try to 'hitchhike' on the big tour's guide as he could lead you to the only apsara face that wasn't 'covered' up by tree root in one of the room. Nothing magnificent but just something worth seeing.
Tomb Raider excited our family. While I've never seen the movie (my daughters have), you felt a if you were on a movie set. Just beautiful.

One of the most interesting temples. This is the temple which was left as it was found - with trees growing throug walls. The temple is not big and ruined and many parts, but the image is really beautiful. There are a lot of spots for photo making.
You cannot deny the spendour. You cannot deny this place should be amazing but ruined by walkways and huge crowds.
A must see. And not only because of its inclusion in Lara Croft: Tomb Raider. This is a beautiful and compelling site.

Nature is so amazing!. Ta Prohm seems very different to Angkor Wat and Angkor Tom. Visited the three temples in one day. Quite a long day, but very worth it. The three temples are very different from each other. I didn't take a guided tour and at times wish I had. Then again, at other times, I am glad I didn't. Many tourist were walking around with guide books and pointing things out. Others were just walking through without paying much attention to anything. There is a lot of information regarding temples. If you don't read the guide book, it might be a good idea to get a guide.

Captivating trees growing on ruins. Ta Prohm was used as a location in the movie Tomb Raider. Unlike nearby temples, several areas were left intact as ruins which make it fascinating to explore. Trees that grow on top of the ruins are so captivating!
Excellent. Good to see the temple where the movie Lara Croft -Tomb Raider was supposed to have been shot!
Amazing Fig and Cotton Silk Trees!!. My girls marvel at how trees can grow in this way...Nature is one amazing force
Liked this a lot. Do not miss this. 5-stars for the ruins. It's a bit of a walk but worth it.

Famous even before the tomb raider movie. Ta Prohm is going through some restoration. Some parts are closed off to the public. Still, It is probably the second most popular destination after Angkor Wat within the park when I was here in November of 2011. I think it might have to do with the trees growing over the temple more than the Tomb Raider movie. Atleast I hope so. The place can get crowded. If you have time, you can wait it out because bus tours go in and out. They don't stay there long. There is plenty to see. If you want it all to yourself, go early in the morning as the big tours go to Angkor Wat first or during lunch time. Walking the perimeter of the temple is another good idea as it is less traveled and you will see trees over the temple. From the previous review, there aren't stairs going up to any temple like Angkor Wat or Baphuon. They have added wooden paths mainly for you safety. People have been getting hurt walking over the large stones. There are some stairs but nothing that will make you think twice about coming back. Ta Prohm is in the jungle with standing water. Mosquito repellant would help alot. My guide told me that they are starting to cut some of the trees that are ruining the temples. That's part of the attraction but they are more concerned about the temples and I have to agree. Eventually trees die not only from man but nature as well. There are carpenter ants that chew through the wood. Also during flood season, some trees usually go down. Temperature went up to 100 degrees in November with crazy humidity. This place has plenty of shade.  You will also hear a loud pitch noise at the temple. It's Cicadas. It can get pretty loud. They are really hard to see ( see pic of the tree bark)I didn't post the most popular photos as there are plenty here. These are to show what it looks like with the restoration going on. It's not as bad as it looks since the place is pretty big. So go enjoy yourself as I did. If you like Ta Prohm, I highly recommend Beng Melea which is out of the way but worth the 1 hour and 20 minute tuk tuk ride. I also recommend. Ta Som and Bantey Kdei as they are not as large or popular but still within the park. And it's right next to Ta Prohm

Ta Prohm - Nature v. Man. This temple visit was spectacular. Just to see what nature accomplished made us continually ask 'how' as we wandered thru the temple. How long did it take the trees to grow? How did the trees actually get to where they are and how were they able to grow in the way we saw them? We loved getting up close and personal. No dislikes at all.
Magical. Be sure to pay a visit to this temple if you want to see some of the longest living being in the planet: the silk-cotton trees that grew out of the ruins.

Feel history. You really can image how it was hundreds of years ago. This temple was forgotten for a long time and coverd with trees. Some trees are still attached to the temple and hold it in a firm grip.

So very crowded. This is the famed "Lara Croft" temple, with huge trees overwhelming the temple. Unfortunately it is the most crowded temple in Angkor Thom, and you will have to wait for hours just to get a picture without tourist.Best time to visit (in my opinion) is at sunrise, but then you will have to skip Angkor Wat's sunrise or come another day.
Power of nature. Amazed by the power of nature. A different experience fr the other temples in Angkor area. Not to be missed.

Chaotic but beautiful. It was atonishing to see how the stone structures held together for so many centuries. May not be suitable for people who have trouble climbing as some of the most beautiful places were behind fallen walls. Really amazing to see the tree roots take over the place. Highly recommended.

Power of Nature. Amazing how nature and man made temples come together. You literally feel like Lara Croft exploring these amazing temples. The visualization of the trees devouring the temples are absolutely amazing. One of my highlights.
My favorite temple by far. This was amazing. Smaller than angkor watt and for us more interesting. This is where tomb raider was filmed. We loved it.

Temple and Nature intertwined. Absolutely stunning to walk around snapping photos and admiring the way the trees have grown onthe temple grounds. I couldn't help wondering and imagining what it must have been like when it was built.

Site for the movie Tomb Raider. This temple has been left largely in its original condition to show how these temples once looked. The tree roots are slowly expanding and parting the stones from which the temples were constructed and destroying the temple.
Fantastic. A must see! I feel like that all the Temples of Angkor a must see. I spent 2 days exploring the temples and I didn't even make a dent. It is a truly aw inspiring place.

My favorite. At the third day we repeated Ta Prohm. Together with Bayon and Beng Mealea (70Km from Siem Reap) this was my favorite temple. In this case for the amazing sculptures that the roots of the trees created around. And don't miss the dinousaur carved in one of the walls !
A must see. An old temple taken over by trees..really strange and fascinating
As the rest, a must.. It's so incredible. You will go there on guided tour. Enjoy.
Steep stairs. Quite a steep climb requiring me to descend from the steep stairs using my hands. Not for the faint-hearted or weak legs.
Tomb-Raider, but better.. Those trees growing out of the temple lost in the jungle - all that romance, adventure & mystery is here.

You can't take a bad photo here. My photos are amazing--and I didn't take a sophisticated camera with me. It's just that it's almost impossible to take a bad photo at Ta Prohm--the stone/tree combinations are just amazing.

Man vs. Nature!. The epic battle of man's ability to build vs. nature's ability to reclaim... the interplay of stone carvings with dense jungle and spooky structure strangling trees here is absolutely immense! A must see....

Possibly the best temple to see.. To see how nature entwined around the temples was amazing.
Sometimes there are many tourists off buses, but just take it easy wait a minute as these people go, then you have time to take great photos.

Amazing temple with huge overgrown roots..... During a itineraries proposal by my Siem Reap tour guide, Mr. Sowanna Yun of Cambodiaguide.com, I noticed daily visits of temples...which I thought my family may get bored (it's our 1st visit to Cambodia). However, after the 1st day, you can actually distinguish individual temple with unique characteristics. So it's was entertaining after all (we bought a 3 days temple pass) . And Ta Phrom promises to be 1 you will remember for a long time. The overgrown roots masking the temple ruins really amaze you and lots of pic opportunity, as usual. Just remember to bring along a good-sized memory card in your camera ^__^

The jungle overgrowth makes it unique from the other temples. Loved this temple but it was super crowded when I went through it mid afternoon. At this point it was one of the last temples we had to see in the whole Angkor wat complex and we were pretty templed out as they all looked the same. However, I was impressed with it because it was unique. The way the jungle has reclaimed it was interesting and the trees growing ontop of the temple was awesome. Shame there were so many tourists there when I was trying to go through. Sorta spoiled it a bit but I think that was my fault more than the temples so I gave it 5 stars.
Great atmosphere. The place is magic but under renovation. Nevertheless good pictures to take for Photographers
Trees on the statue. the amazing part was the trees roots grow up on top of the building which I never see this before. mysterious!
Just here because you saw it on Tomb Raider?. It is worth it to see all the trees take over the natural structure, but the influx of tourists kind of killed the allure for us.

atmospheric. This was definitely my favourite of all the sites within the Angkor Archaeological Park. We arrived early in the morning and so not many other people there and it was very atmospheric atmosphere.

under construction. it was interesting to see actual repair and renovation under way. beware as there are 2 entrances/exits, we got confused and missed our tour bus back to Siem Reap; we had to hire a tuk tuk at $8, which was actually rather fun!
Lovely ancient site in Cambodia. We would recommend this in addition to the obvious Bayon, and Angkor Wat.
adventure. This temple was really nice....more savage I would say...very different from the others.

my favourite. this is really nice, in fact i prefer this to Angkor wat. Its is smaller and more intimate. More detailed and better for picture taking! If you need to get souvenirs, get it there ( other than the old market area) because the children really work hard for it and they do give you a good price if you bargain hard enough. Really, they just want to make a living, if the price is reasonable enough, they wont try to make a killing. Afterall, they are out in the open unlike those in the comfortable stalls at Old market area. So be nice, do your shopping in ANg kor area. They are in fact ,cheaper than you think.Hard bargains : Magnets 3 for $1 , scarves $1.50-$3, postcards 10 for $1.Bring ALOT of cash, small USD notes. NOone takes cards there, even restaurants. Only hotels do that.
Super trees. This temple is covered with acient trees. Just like the movie - Tomb Raider. Great time by all. Go early or you will have lots of tourists in your photos.

No wonder why they shot the Tombraider movie here. Just come in the afternoon an hour or two before sunset, pretty much every picture is going to be a keeper, the whole place just oozes atmosphere, the candid mix of vegetation and heaps of ruinous rubble simply sparks the imagination to a degree, that the comparatively sterile places like Bayan and Angkor Thom just can't match. A place of dreamers and poets, highly recommended!

mesmerizing!. the temples, being restored as an India-Cambodia collaboration initiative are simply mesmerizing.. the old huge monster trees add a lot of character and magic to the place. Must visit in Angkor!
A early morning must see. Go early in the morning, about 7 am. This is a serene place, not one to see with crowds of tourists.
My favorite temple in Cambodia. It is being restored......it is amazing to see the jungle and trees growing around it.
A nice rustic temples surrounded by "creepers" trees. I love this place! Once you see the trees trying to engulf the temples you will understand why this place is so amazing.

Ruins + Jungle. While Angkor Wat is more famous, it attracts way too many tourists and gets overcrowded. Ta Prohm is yet to be fully cleared from the jungle that's entwined itself around it, so it provides for an amazing, unique feel to the place.

My favorite. This temple is just amazingly beautiful, the trees mixed with the temples makes this temple unusual.Again as I mentioned for other temple, there is many people and I would avoid 9.30am to 12am as all the groups are there.I found this temple interesting as you can see in details how the stones are strong and fragile at the same time, nothing to stick them to each other so some parts are destroyed by the time next to an impressive walls or towers, this contrast is amazing.

In the end, nature takes it all back!. The Ta Prohm temple is by far smaller than most of the well-known sites around Angkor Wat, but the way the roots of the trees overgrow the crumbling walls is really spectacular. Something you don't come to see quite often. Worth a visit for sure.

Amazing temple with tree roots growing through it. As seen on Tomb Raider film !. This is a must to see with the tree roots which grow among the beautiful temple. They filmed some of the tomb raider film here. Stunning to see !!
Nice. Wonderful sight seeing experience! The ancient architecture is a delight to behold. Fortunately, it is being re-structured to bring back the original glory. Good work ASI.

Amazing visit. As part of our tour we visited Ta Prohm. It was incredible hot and humid when we visited but coming to the site you forget the weather. The Temple was totally overgrown by the jungle and banyon trees when found and as you climb around the rocks and walking path, you become incredibly amazed to see how the trees and huge roots were completely "eating up" the structures. You can see how the workmen are trying to hack away these enormous trees to free the Temple.It was one of the highlights to see and definitely worth the trip.
Unique and stunning. I can see why the location was used to film Tomb Raider; it's so unique...no special effects needed

A moviestar.... Made famous by the Tomb Raider movie, Ta Prom gives you an idea of how the temples must have looked when the first explorators "discovered" the site again in late 19th/early 20th century. It is one of the main temple on the "short circuit route" (along with Angkor Wat and the Angkor Thom complex) and is worth the visit. However, note that if you have time to visit smaller, lesser known temples, you are likely to see similar ones (Ta Som) with less tourists
One of my most favorite places in Angkor. Be wrapped in time by giant trees and Apsara's smiles over and under ruins of the temple

a must see. the classic Angkor photo opportunity is Ta Prohm, but be prepared for the barage of souvenir sellers you will encounter at the entrance. the walkways are very good, but sad to see so many tourists of one particular nationality ignoring the "do not climb" signs and climbing all over the tree roots.

You have to forget the wooden walkways.... Three years after our first visit, we visited this weekend. Conservation work was definitely needed, but the wooden walkways that now line the complex are a little clinical, compared to the clambering needed a few years ago. The new roped fence around the Temple of Doom doorway doesn't exactly help photographers either... Having said that, the conservation work is a must, the tree formations are still stunning, and you must visit Ta Prohm while you are there!

Tomb Raider Temple!. If memory serves me correct, this is the temple where they filmed a scene for the Tomb Raider movie. It was sweeeet! It looked like something made for a Disney set, but it was completely authentic. My favorite place in all of Angkor... I spent about 3 hours there. I wrote about it in my blog... http://blakesworld211.blogspot.com/ if anyone wants to see some pictures or read about. It's a little bit further than the other sites, but its worth it... I highly recommend!
Epic film spot. Amazing temple complex swallowd by the jungle.A lot of trees havent been removed. You sure will rember the movie that was shoot here...

Very atmospheric. Lovely temple which everyone knows as the "Tomb Raider" Temple. The encroachment of the trees has really made it quite a magical place and photo opportunities abound. the one downside is the huge crane and mass of green netting that surrounds the construction work going on at the site. Interestingly it was about the only temple in Cambodia where I actually saw some monks, there having been a solitary one at Angkor Wat!. Well worth a couple of hours of anyones time just to wander through and take things at your own pace.

Awesome. I'm no Angelina Jolie or Indiana Jones but it felt like I could have been! It's so atmospheric and crumbling and fabulous. A must see as it's in stark contrast to Angkor Wat which is well restored.

The best!. A must-see! This is the temple where Tomb Raider was filmed, and has all the trees growing through the temple. One of the large trees fell only 3 days before we visited which was quite sad to see. But a beautiful temple. One of my favourites.

The welknown TREES. What almost everybody knows from pictures and TV, can be seen in reel. The nature that takes back what human stole hundreds of years ago- The huge trees that grow on top of the ruins makes you feel very ...LITTLE and humble towards nature. Like all other places near Wat Angkor, to crowdy
WOW. absolutely WOW! another of our favourite temples. Truely amazing.
tomb raider. yes, you will recognise some of the locations from the film but the reality is better than hollywood.

Lara Croft. I was Indiana Jones, I was Lara Croft, I was a little bug wondering around the giant roots of the trees... The temple looked as though it was baring it's own magic. A must see in Siem Reap...

A quiet morning in the temple. We entered at dawn, via the west end, which frustrated my brother but our guide proved to have made a wise choice. We were virtually alone and the lighting effects were just as good. Delightfully peaceful and only one larger group but note that there ar extensive building works at the east end and as we left at 7:15 am the work was getting under way for the day and promised to be noisy.
Poignant. More than anywhere else I saw during the tour of sites, Ta Prohm shows the impermanence of empires. Ta Prohm is a beautiful site engulfed by the roots of giant trees. All glory fades.

the most romantic temples of Cambodia.. the most romantic temples of Cambodia. See the roots of trees embrace the foundations of this temple is just incredible. This is all due respect to see nature take over the monuments of the past.
Go there before 4pm. The light is missing.
Angelina Jolie. No just about her but the roots have taken over the temple and it is a ridiculously beautiful sight!

Hidden Buddhas and Angelina. Made famous by the Tomb Raider movie this has to be one of the highlight Wat's if not the Wat to see. Get your picture taken where Lara Croft stood but keep your eye out for the face of a Buddha hidden in the roots of a tree growing around the temple. You know this Temple is old, the trees did not grow overnight. 300 years old and growing. Due to flooding we had to walk to get to Ta Prohm. Well worth it.
Ta Prom. One of the most atmospheric places ever. Vines, culture and a jungle feel all in one.

A must see!. This is the most photographed and well known of all the temples and now we know why!The trees invading the temple is sight to see.Alot of the structures are in ruins but alot of it being restored.Don't miss this!
Trees on temple. You will have the feeing to be Indiana Jones in this temple
Lara Croft was here. We visited this on our 3rd day and it is worth the trip. Wonderful works of the Gods and nature. Don't forget to pose with the large tree. :)

Outstanding. This place has been deliberately left overgrown ith the various trees and roots that have reclaimed the place as the jungle does!A fascinating place. I got a bit fed up with the hawkers who can be difficult to get rid of.
The one with the roots. This is probably my favourite as it shows how close the jungle has come to taking over

Perfect for photos. You will get some great shots here, with the roots and trees growing straight out of the walls and other structures, this is seriously a photographers dream. Best visited late in the afternoon - the tourists usually frequent this around lunch time. Nothing beats exploring this on your own, when it really feels like you are the first person to find it :)

Most impressive!!!. Must SEE!!! Lara Croft ...Tombraider was filmed here.Nature is really taking over here with those immense trees and the constant typical sound on the background of some insects which makes it very exciting almost spooky....
Roots of Nature. Absolutely amazing to see how nature takes its space back from buildings! The renovation work going on spoils it a tiny bit though, but the place is still really magical.

Tomb Raider!. This site shows just how much restauration and effort has been done on other sites, it is very instructive to see the workers and architects work. Beside, the amazing trees growing on the temple are just amazing.

my favorite!. There are so many temples throughout the Angkor complex but this one was my favorite! I really enjoyed how the jungle is trying to take over this temple, the tree roots creep up and over the temple walls at multiple places here and it's so picturesque. The temple is also big enough that we didn't feel crowded by other tourists here. The area is a little more tree covered than some of the others so it was a good choice for us for visiting during the heat of the day.Ta Prohm is easily one of the top 3 temples you have to see so make it a priority when visiting!
Felt like in Tomb Raider. The aged trees are really a sight! You will feel like in the set of Tomb Raider. Don't miss the drum room.

Tomb Raider!!. Amazing jungle setting,tree roots have grown over & through walls.I was shown the "echo chamber" by a security guard.When you clap you hands nothing but when you hit your chest with the flat of your hand you hear a wonderful drum like sound.
Top 3 temples in my list. Ta Prohm rocks. Men built it but nature wanted it back. It´s crazy to see those enormous trees tangling themselves with the walls.

It's big, it's got a lot of trees and it blew my mind!. Most people probavly know Ta Promh from the Tomb Raider movie, which shows some interesting points but fails to convey the real awesome power and mystery of this temple. Be warned it will flood in heavy rain, so check with locals before venturing out there without a guide.

Superb - tumbledown charm. We had a superb guide called Bunleat and he took us through this temple. People know this temple from Lara Croft and you can see why it made an amazing film set. It is incredibly atmospheric. The overgrown strangler figs and piles of stones definitely provide a sense of 'tumbledown charm' but it is the sound of the cicadas that also heightens the atmosphere of the place. We thoroughly enjoyed it - the number of couples taking silly 'lara croft-esque' pictures next to the waterfall strangler fig was a bit cheezy but everyone was very good natured and seemed to be totally enjoying the temple. It always amazes me the number of people who walk on areas that are clearly off limits with no thought to the damage they may cause to this historic site - or the fact that they may slip and damage themselves! This is a general irritation but this site is great and will be even better in a few years when restoration work is complete.

Jungle vs. Man. Ta Prohm is a complex of temples where excavators have left the trees and roots growing as when they found them meaning some amazing sites of giant roots growing up and through buildings giving a unique and wonderful site!

A symbiosis of architecture and nature. The wonderful thing about Ta Prohm is the way the massive trees and roots have become an integral part of the architecture, and the beauty of the buildings is enhanced as they are embraced by nature, even in its destructiveness.
Straight out of Indiana Jones. One of the best sights to see before it has been fully rescued from the jungle. A great experience. A marriage of man and nature at it's best.
A must see. Really must see when you go to Cambodia. Just like Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom and the only temples, you will be amazed.

Awesome. The growing trees through the ruin give this temple an amazing atmosphere and a great place for taking photos, the light in the afternoon in the temple areas provides great opportunities for amazing photos.

Not just for Angelina Jolie fans. This location is literally straight from the movies. Though it gives an eerie atmosphere at the start, the perfect merging of the trees and the temples sort of made it really romantic and amazing.

Not quite as wild as expected...but amazing!. When you hear that Ta Prohm was found in the jungle and remains pretty much as discovered, that's not strictly true - as otherwise, visiting it would be all but impossible! However, the mighty Spung trees are still in place, and their almost snake-like roots have this temple in a tight embrace. Again, there are quiet corners where the crowds don't go, and you can lose yourself in the wonder of this place. Visit early or late in the day - most tour parties hit this one in the middle of the day as it is one of the more shady spots, so if you want to see it when it is quieter, avoid midday.
An Indiana Jones experience. Atmospheric. Eerily beautiful. Mesmerizing play of light between the dark corridors and the greenery outside. Easy to get lost in the vast complex.

Captured by the Jungle. While you will see many of Angko Tom and Angkor Wat's resplendent facades, releifs and other carvings in neat, surviving or restored beauty, Ta Prohm shows the beauty and the power of nature which has taken back this temple form it's builders and worshippers.The sprawling roots of the buttress trees show power, strenght and the enduring healing of nature. It is something to see, and wonder how the early Colonial explorers felt when they chanced upon the complex in the early 1900's.A definite 'must see'' on your trip. Do not miss out, it is breathtakingly powerful to see the belnd of nature and man's art combined.

Bucket list must visit!. Nature vs man - nature will win. This place puts you right where the ancient folks want you - in the middle of it all! The narrow passages and massive trees and vines make this place magical.

My favorite!. This is amazing - you may recognize parts of it from the "Tomb Raider" movie. But be careful. I fell against some rocks and cut my finger very badly. It probably needed stitches but I wasn't brave enough to visit a doctor! On the upside, our trip to a Cambodian pharmacy was a surprising bonus.This temple is very crowded and pathways are quite narrow, so get here early and be patient. This is not to be missed!

Lara Croft and I hung out at Ta Prohm. Amazing! The large trees and roots intertwined with ancient stone walls are unbelievable. Although there is a great deal of preservation work going on, you are still able to move through the temple site and see all of the great views.This is a must see on your trip to Siem Reap.

better than watching the movie. I just watched Tomb Raider again after visiting Ta Prohm. Wow. I had forgotten how bad it was. Most of the Cambodia scenes from the movie feature Ta Prohm.Of the temples we visited, only Beng Mealea was more otherworldly. Strangler figs and kapok trees are clinging to the temple ruins everywhere. You can visibly see how the jungle was slowly swallowing up the signs of the Angkor civilization, until Angkor Wat was rediscovered.A must-see.
smaller than you thought. still under reconstruction, unbelievable how can man rebuild the place, trees makes the impression
a must-see place in Siem Reap. This is one of the historical and legendary place in Siem Reap. So amazing!
Beautiful ruins. In less good shape than some of the others, it was staggeringly beautiful with massive tree roots I ther twined among the ruins making it appear to have arisen from middle earth.

Very Tomb Raider. While there are a lot of visitors to this temple, we were still able to explore the interior down some less traveled halls and find some pretty amazing and pristine sights (incluse of an actual live cobra in a pile of rocks).
OMG. this is an awesome place, the tree roots wrap around the stone buildings like a snake. restoration is ongoing but this doesn't affect taking some fabulous photos

A good companion to any Angkor Wat visit. Pros: -Amazing piece of history and well preserved ruins. Very cool watching the architects/archeologists reconstruct ruins-Tour guides are very knowledgeable and politeCons:-Not fault of site, but very hot - come prepared to sweat!
Very pretty. A bit over-rated by Angelina Jolie's film - The Tomb Raider???

Nature's Raw Power. My first view of Ta Prohm was filled with awe and wonder. The intertwine tree roots which has become very much the identity of Ta Prohm provided the uniqueness to this ancient ruins. Known also as the Tomb Raider temple (thanks to the portrayal of this temple the the Lara Croft - The Tomb Raider movie), Ta Prohm is one of the most popular attraction here other than the Angkor Wat.For those who had watched the movie, a visit to this site will certainly be more rewarding as there are more than what was portrayed in the movie. Although certain segment of the temple is closed to visitors due to its unstable condition, there are still many areas to be explored. The intertwine tree roots are clear examples of how old this temple is, and how the temple is being reclaimed by the jungle after years of neglect. The strength of these roots are visible as huge stone blocks at various portions of the temple have been literary lifted out of position by these roots. While the tree roots are giving the temple its unique features, these roots are also said to be the main problem which contribute to the condition of the temple. However, preservation works at various sites of the temple have been carried out to save the temple from collapsing. Despite this, the intertwine tree roots were very much untouched and continue to show the uniqueness of this place.To those intending to visit, do ensure that you come lightly dressed, with comfortable shoes as there will be a lot of walking and climbing. Also ensure you have ample drinking water.Other than that, there is nothing much to prepare for except perhaps to prepare yourself to be blown away by the sheer magnitude of this structure.

Atmosphere. Ta Prohm was built at the same time as the massive Angkor Thom complex, and by the same ruler. Like Angkor Thom, with the decline of the Khmer civilization it was abandoned and eventually overgrown by jungle. Unlike Angkor Thom though, there has been very minimal clearing of the jungle here for tourists, making it a unique experience.Everyone's seen the pictures of massive trees growing over walls and doorways. In reality the temple is much larger than the pictures suggest; but still fairly small. There is some restoration work going on, but it's minimal. There are jumbled mounds of moss covered building blocks everywhere you look, making it difficult to picture just what this place looked like when it was in its prime. But boy do they give it atmosphere!Wooden walkways are a recent addition, making it easier to traverse the ruins, and several areas have been roped off and viewing platforms erected. While this helps preserve the temple, several prime photography spots are now off limits. Someone else mentioned the queue for the tree covered entrance photo: well we had a giggle and joined it anyway.A great little temple. Crowds weren't too bad when we were there. If you're not templed out after Angkor Wat & Angkor Thom this is a must do.

Amazing Views of Ruins and Ingrown Trees. Of course your tour guide would specifically point out the spot where they shot the scene in Tomb Raider. Not too sure about this as I didn't watch the movie, but that's what i overheard from a tour guide, who was truly very proud of this =)There are many great photo ops here, with many ingrown big trees, which are left in their natural state. And the temple is very much in ruined state, but with lots of ongoing heavy restoration work. It does feel like in the middle of the jungle, which makes this one of the very few special ones here in Siem Reap. Somehow it also feels like you are walking in a maze, every turn you can see an amazing ingrown tree on the ruins. Definitely worth a visit, even if you're pressed for time, after Angkor Wat and Bayon.
When trees replace stones. ... you can stop and stare. Awesome place, impressive pictures!

Stunning. Its touted as the temple in tomb raider, but in reality its so much more. The same period as Bayon and newer than Angkor Wat, the forest seems to have completely invaded the structure that needs to be seen to be believed. Again a Must-Do
temple visit. We did not get to this one but our friends did and in their opinion it was the best. Each to his own!
Huge trees. One thing that is so amazing on some temples are the huge trees whose roots and branches are already growing in the temples.
Amazing Roots!. its breath-taking to be there to witness the amazing tree roots for yourself!

Jungle tangle... and great photos. Look for the hidden Apsara dancer as you go round. This is a tangle of jungle trees growing out of s tangled structure, wonderful and mystic carvings and a feel of how it might have been when the Ankor temples were first uncovered
Unusual - in a good way. Unusual in a good way, felt like I was in an Indiana Jones movie scene. Had a very mystical feeling about it.
some of the coolest sights you'll ever see. the way the jungle took over the temple is something you just have to see to believe
The trees are majestic. What an amazing temple, the trees and there roots make it a magical place, no wonder it is so photographed, as with all sites take your camera

Don't miss this one!. Spectacular and magnificent!We liked this temple the best out of all in the area, just stunning. We were lucky that we had the place virtually to ourselves, it was late in the day, spitting with rain and thundering! The atmosphere was straight out of 'Tomb Raider'.The trees growing out of the walls and canopy of leaves made it really special for great photos and exploring.A must to do but try to avoid the crowds (very early or very late in the day is best.)

I loved the mystic.... This is my favourite as it had character, was mysterious and I enjoyed seeing the nature and beauty of the trees engrained in the temple. NB: there was much debate amongst the locals to cut down the trees however they decided to preserve nature.No need to have a guide take you around as it speaks for itself.Definitely worth a visit!

Covered in walkways and tourists. It's a good temple but it's a pity that it's gotten so much publicity. You can't move for tourists asking you to get out of their photo (the queue for the doorway with the tree growing above it is hilarious). Plus there are now wooden walkways marring a lot of it.I had a much better time at nearby Prea Khan. A similar style but mostly unreconstructed with big blocks lying around in the courtyards. Fewer visitors and I even found a quiet courtyard with a doorway tree just like the one at Ta Prohm.

A must visit. As others hv mentioned best visited when there are minimal crowds ,try to go early in the morning , an amazing place where massive ,i mean really massive trees are entwined within the temple structure !!!!!

One in the top 3.... I won't say what a lot of other already told : just the best advise I could think about :DON'T GO WHEN IT IS TOO CROWDED as the charm will vanish...It will be difficult, but try to be in the first to get inside, so get up early (maybe 6.30 - 7 AM).

An extraordinary world out there.... At first, I was so curious about this place because I saw it in the movie, Tomb Raider. Then a friend of mine worked in Phnom Penh and went to this place. She highly recommended me to come and visit this place in my lifetime. And so when I got the opportunity to visit, I made sure to go Ta Prohm.True enough, I was in awe all the time that I was there. I couldn't believe that it would be possible for trees to grow on top of the temples and the structures there. I find them creepy, yet fascinating and interesting. I wonder what it looked like before it was almost forgotten and the time when it was rediscovered and after the reconstruction. It is like you are in another world out there, and the civilization that existed during that time could be as modern as it is now today (with different and rich culture, of course).It sure is a MUST see and visit place.
Arguably the best temple. Amazing imagery, although there is some re-construction going on at the moment. Arguably better than Ankor Wat.

Favorite Temple. Of all the Angkor Wat temples, this was clearly my favorite. The scenery is spectacular, you get to do a bit of climbing it you want, it's huge and it's close to all the other temples and downtown Siem Reap. For those of you who have limited time to see all the temples (perish the thought), make sure you check this one out!

So much more than Tomb Raider.... What a magnificent experience. While the ocmplete oposite of Angkor Wat that celerates human engineering and faith, Ta Prohm celebrates natures determinedness and beauty. Don't go to Angkor without visiting Ta Prohm!

The so called " jungle temple". Here you can see enormous tree growing side by side with the walls of the temple. Some roots of the trees seems just like giant snakes. This temple is beautiful and because of that a must see in Siem Reap.

Rustic and nostalgic experience. Ta Prohm is one of the 12 main temples in Siem Reap apart from the Angkor Wat. Unlike the Angkor Wat, this one can be viewed at any time of the day. The temples are made of stones which are really cooling so inside you'll be chilled although it's probably 80 degrees outside. Make sure you buy a crate of mineral water (costs only about 50cents at the markets) and take it with you. Just leave them in the tuk tuk while you go inside the temples. There is a lot of construction going on at the point of visit so watch your step and head. Most of the roots are overgrowing on the temples and it looks somewhat being crushed. This' apparently is also where the famous Tomb Raider scene was shot. There are 2 time options to enter Angkor Wat to view it at its best: AM or PM. Shortly before sunrise or shortly before sunset. We chose the former option. The sun which slowly rises over the temple domes is definitely a sight worth seeing. There is a moot or a lake in front of the Angkor which reflects the temple beautifully at any angle and this is where visitors usually flock to enjoy the picturesque view. Some others would prefer to have climbed to the top of the main temple to view. It really depends on your preference really. Note that there are 12 temples in this area. They're not all near to each other. From Angkor Wat, you'll need to get on your tuk tuk and ride on to another area where the famous Faces temple "Angkor Thom" and Tomb-raider temple "Ta Phrom". The others you may find interesting to go to are: BANTEAY SREY (citadel of women), Grand Circuit Temples: Preah Khan (End of 12 century), Neak Pean and Ta Som.
Hear and feel the sound of the forest. Have a break at this shady temple by the middle of the day and stay for a while; hear the sound and feel the surrounding forest!

What a stunning place!!!. Ta Prohm was arguably of more interest to us than Angkor Wat itself as it is just so stunning with the trees growing on top and around. I cant recommend this place enough. Its age is shown by the size of the trees growing on top of its roof. Love this place!!!One thing though, if you plan on eating around here, dont do it at Ta Prohm as we found the prices for some reason were way way higher for food than outside Angkor Wat itself, maybe because its more out of the way. Bring lots of water!

This is the Tomb Raider Temple, great landscape, great temple to visit! Do not miss it!. Despite some reviews that say it is not worth to go, I disagree. The jungle is still there and it is a great place, they had better not cut down any of the trees, and if they are painting stuff gold they had better stop otherwise people will not return.If things have changed so much in the six months since we have been there I would be really surprised. This place is really cool with tree roots coming over walls and in door ways, this is a really spectacular and cool temple. Not because of the movie, it is because of layout and the trees that are running around and through the temples, it is really cool.I did not get enough pictures of this temple and now I regret it.Do not miss this temple!Fees are paid with your Angkor pass. You have to buy one in order to gain access to the temple sites.

lower than expectation. Maybe read so many positive reviews before going, it is some kind of under expectation.It took us some time to find the most famous one, almost near the east gate. It seems more beautiful and mysterious in picture than in fact. However, it is still one of the best in Cambodia along with Angkor Wat and Bayon Temple.

Very dissappointing. Read so much about this place and couldnt wait to see it for real, however, Lonely Planet has got it right again.Too manicured and has lost the feeling the jungle is swallowing it up. Even some of the roots have been painted gold for the tourists.Talking of tourists, place was choking with Japanese coach parties, all with follow me flags and loudhailers and this was low season!!.Such a shame as it could have been an amazing place to visit.
The best. Ta Prohm is for me the #1 temple to visit it is real nice seenery and it looks like it is eaten by mother nature. I did 3 days of temple sightseeing but thing one was the best!

Must Visit Temple. - Ta Prohm was the last temple for the day and i was getting tired to seeing one temple from another. But Ta Prohm was so worth it. For me this temple had so much character. With the roots of the trees snaking through the temple, just shows how mother nature is taking over what was once hers. So beautiful. This is by far is my favorite temple.

Tomb Raider!. After years of just seeing these in Tomb Raider and on countless travel shows and channels, I finally got to see the very temple ruins famed for growing old with gigantic trees!The place was amazing and one-of-a-kindGoing around the ruins seemed like going through some adventure-like maze while at the same time, enjoyable because of its spectacular viewGoing around feels like being immersed in an ancient city housed in a forestIt really made my dayTruly, this is one of the treasures of Angkor City, Cambodia

Favorite?. This was definitely one of our favorite temples in the whole siem reap area. This is known as the "tomb raider" temple as it was used in the movies. Very cool to see as the trees are growing over the walls. They have preserved parts but are restoring parts as well so go soon.

More exciting than Angkor Wat. This is an interesting temple to visit because it has been partly taken over by the Spong trees making it one of the most photographed temples. It is being gradually restored and some places are roped off because they are too dangerous to allow the public to enter, however there are plenty of areas to explore and it is quite maze-like and therefore exciting for both adults and children alike.

Lots of atmosphere!. A good contrast to both Angkor Wat and the Bayon. Quite a long walk through this temple, but we found we were continually stopping to marvel at the enormous trees pushing through the ruins. Very much an Indiana Jones atmosphere to this one!

Massive trees intertwining the temples!. This temple was a particular favourite - because of the trees; massive majestic trees that intertwined the temples - one really wonders how the structure manages to hold up under the weight of those giant trees! It's something that you really need to be there to appreciate, the combination of the sheer size of the trees and the deliberate un-restored temple really makes you feel like you're adventuring through an unexplored temple!

One of the most fascinating temples in Angkor. If you are looking for a bit of adventure on your sightseeing trip, you will definitely like Ta Prohm. The temple has been largely overgrown by the jungle, which makes it a really fascinating place with huge trees growing out of temple walls. It makes excellent foto opportunities and is also great for climbing a bit through the temple.Not to be missed also if you liked the movie Tomb Raider as part of it was shot at Ta Prohm.
angkor vat. best his temple ttemple constructed by rajendra varman indian i also contributed my service to this temple thanks to indian government

Beautiful jungle temple. Very famous temple because Tomb Raider was done here. But still very beautiful temple in the jungle. Here you really see the power of trees, they are all over the temple. We visited the temple at dawn and it was a very good time for the visit. Not many tourists there and it was nice to experience the morning in the jungle.

A must visit temple. The best way to get to know about the temple is by visiting it. Without putting yourself in the middle of the ancient temple, you will never know the "feeling" of the ancient "tree on bricks". The temple has a large coverage of 1000 x 600 m, built 36 years after the great Angkor Wat, by King Jayavarman VII for his mother. History claimed that there were more than 12,000 people reside within the outermost enclosure. We can reach the temple by heading east from Angkor Thom towards Sras Srang. The temple is around 2 km away from the gate of Angkor Thom. By car, around 10 minutes away from Bayon.As the temple was abandoned for hundreds of years, forest had once reclaimed the area until, well, all of us come and make it a world heritage site :-p There are several trees overgrown the temple's structure. The root of the trees somehow found their way through the bricks and reached the ground. The temple was badly damaged, with only a few routes open for visitors. The temple was under heavy restoration work as well.My advice, you can enter the temple through east gate (or gopura) as the route is less crowded. There are several "outstanding" sites for photo taking, each with special platform built for the purpose. Keep in mind that there is a massive crowd in the temple. We have to queue in many places in order to take a nice picture with the "tree on the temple". Please visit my blog for more information and photos at:http://bettyandlingshing.blogspot.com/2010/12/preah-khan-and-ta-prohm.html

In one word - Ethereal!. quite easily - the most magnificently built temple of all not only in angkor complex, but among all I have seen in my heritage trips completed till date - the eerie and yet peaceful aura of the jungle temple is unparalleled and it's breathtaking beauty will be a treat especially for photography connoisseurs..

My favourite of all temples in Siem Reap. I loved this temple and is my favourite out of all of those we visited. I love the way the jungle has taken over (although some may not like this). There are some huge trees which are growing in and amongst the temple ruins and in some parts feels like a maze. We visited twice and the second day we found a whole part we had missed. There of course is the 'famous' tree growing from the temple which many come to have their photo taken at, but there are many trees growing that make excellent snaps. There is some restoration work going on at part of the temple so a small section is closed off, but a very small section. This is a must see for Siem Reap.

“Tentacles of the Octopus”. Here, the jungle has taken over despite the restoration efforts. The crumbling walls and towers are locked in grip of old strangler vine, the roots of which twist and turn like snakes. The trees are like massive tentacles of the octopus, taking over the temples and reducing it to rubble. I really loved this temple and there were many tourists here, taking pictures with tree stranglers. This is one of my favourite Temple.It is easy to understand why this temple was chosen to film the "Tomb Rider"

Stunning. The temple on its own is not the best in Angkor and the trees, if they were standing in a forest, would be less than remarkable. But together this place is pretty amazing. 400 year old giant trees growing on the roof of a 900 year old temple, with the massive roots somehow managing to grow from the ground below, makes this an amazing sight. There's less mythology behind this place, but it's definitely a great sight.

old jungle town of Ta Prohm. Ta Prohm is a big sprawling temple complex in the middle of the jungle, and with the jungle literally in its middle. Like at Preah Khan (but more breath-takingly so), massive trunks and roots have grown through walls and reduced entire sections of temple to rubble. It was built in honour of the king's mum and in its heyday was used to store precious gems, pearls and gold dishes apparently weighing over 500 kilos. We took our time exploring the various towers and galleries and pretending to be Lara Croft (scenes from Tombraider were filmed here), lots of fun.

I love the trees!. This temple complex is surrounded by trees that are more than a hundred years old. It is such a refreshing site than the other temple complex of Angkor as the shade given of by the tall trees are not just pleasant to the eyes, they can be of great help when you feel the heat of the midday sun from the other temples. If I am a movie director I would definitely love my first film to be shot in Ta Prohm. Until now I can vividly picture Ta Prohm in my head.

Great Time with big tree and excellent tour Guide Mr Kol Chhen. Siem Reap has rocketed from a dusty crossroads to a full-fledged tourist town in just a few short years, and the changes make it truly unique--a place where you can get just about any luxury you're craving but where you don't have to look very hard to find the "real" Cambodia.Lots of travelers are uncomfortable with the level of poverty and worn down by everyone trying to make a dollar from tourism. I lived in Siem Reap for a year and a half and I guarantee that most of the people are warm and helpful, but if you're concerned about the few who will take advantage of you, the best defense is to be prepared. It's worth the little bit of time and money it costs to book a reputable tour guide in advance in order to ensure that your vacation goes smoothly. When friends or family would visit, I always suggested they reserve a spot with someone like Kol Chhen (www.cambodianangkortour.com--he's knowledgeable, reliable, and possibly the friendliest person in all of Cambodia), rather than relying on the shady alternatives that skulk around local guesthouses. A good tour guide like Chhen will make sure that your trip to Siem Reap and the nearby temples is really worth it.

Straight out of an adventure film, I half.... Straight out of an adventure film, I half expected a massive boulder to come rumbling down after us!Trees just growing seemingly out of the ruins. Mental but amazing.If the hordes try to sell you a guide book don't use the 'i've already got one' excuse, because they seem to think you could do with ten. If you need one it's only going to cost you a dollar though.
Awesome temple and massive trees. This temple is just amazing. It's the one famous for the tomb raider film. The tree roots are so huge it's amazing and it is a fascinating site to see.

Wow my favorite temple. Ta Prohm is seriously my favorite temple in the complex because its hidden in a jungle like setting with trees that kind of eat but try to go early to avoid the huge amounts of tourists.

shaded. Ta Prohm is pleasant to visit because the place is still well shaded by trees. The temple is smaller than seen in Tomb Raider. The presence of tourist controllers is more prevalent here than any other temple, perhaps because of its semi-cleared state. The vegetation encroaching the complex is preserved to represent the state when the complex was found and the trees protect some of the structures.
Root Stone. Great Art

Good picture opportunities, Can be crowded. Visited Ta Prohm (or the Tomb Raider temple as many refer to it as) again in August this year. The previous time was March 2007 and it was so packed with people that one hardly had enough time to snap a photo without having someone walk past. Compared to March, August has relatively fewer tourists. However, as we were told by our guide, this being one of the must see temples, it can still be crowded.We were supposed to arrive at the temple before 9 am but because of a very long breakfast and because we went to another nearby temple first, it was already 10am. We were told that bus loads of tourists, especially tours from the East would converge at this temple at around 10am. Apparently, our guide more or less knew the tour itinery. We passed by the entrance and true enough, the entire road leading to the entrance was jam packed with tour buses and all. So, we left and came back in the evening, which was a good idea as it was relatively empty.Compared to last year, there are one or two places cordoned off (which makes it difficult, photography wise) but you still get a good feel of the place. There are platforms erected here and there to make walking easier but at the same time, this also makes it less authentic. This is where Preah Khan, another temple with overgrown trees and less visited, has a plus point.Nevertheless, it is still a must see.

The very atmospheric temple. Ta Prohm is probably the most atmospheric and funnest temple in the entire Angkor temple group. I had fully experienced the power of nature at Ta Prohm, seeing all these gigantic trees engulfing the buildings. There were a lot of narrow corridors; so be careful and watch your head when you are walking around, I could get up close with the apsaras on the walls as most of them were behind piles ofrocks. I just needed to climb over the piles and took some amazing closeups. This is a must-see spot for tourists; which means come early to avoid the tourist groups.
